column2: To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer has waited to see it some one would not propose a solution (and a ready solution) for the railroad tunnel overcrowding, caused by three separate lines of railroads converging into the tunnel and Grand Central Station.
MONTE CARLO, Feb. 27. -- The chess masters this morning began the fifteenth round of the international tournament, the pairing being as follows:

The letter of Mayor Low, urging the Legislature to amend the charter so as to lodge the power of reorganizing the City Government in the hands of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, independent of the Board of Aldermen, must have been written very reluctantly, and with a full realization of the risk of its misinterpretation.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- Senator Cocks's Automobile bill was amended almost out of recognition in the Senate to-day despite the vehement protests of its author, who declared that the effect of the proposed amendments would be to make the bill absolutely worthless.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If adding my voice will help in accomplishing the desired result, I wish to add it most decidedly in regard to the giving of transfer by the Metropolitan Street Railway Company at One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Madison Avenue, seconding a letter on the same subject which I read in your issue this morning.

Defective insulation is believed to have started a fire in one of the lodge rooms on the fourth floor of the Grand Opera House building, at Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, while the great theatre was crowded from pit to dome at the performance of "In Old Kentucky" last evening. Some of the smoke crept into the gallery just as a fireman stationed in the building summoned the engines.

Col. Michael J. Dady declared yesterday afternoon that there was no truth in the reports current to the effect that for the sake of harmony all around in the Republican Party in Kings County he intended to resign as Elections Commissioner, as well as from the local Republican Executive Committee.

TACOMA, Wash., Feb. 27. -- President Roosevelt to-day appointed Clarence Ide, now United States Marshal for Washington, to be Collector of Customs for Puget Sound in spite of the fact that United States Senator Foster of Washington has strenuously opposed Ide. The new Collector, however, had the earnest recommendation of the Department of Justice that he be retained in the Government service on account of his unimpeachable record for the last five years.

The inquiry into a stock transaction between Bert Reiss, the young Brooklyn lawyer who brought charges against Sheriff Guden, and the Hamilton Trust Company of that borough, instituted by District Attorney Clarke and inspired, as alleged, by political enemies of Reiss, ended yesterday in the dismissal of the proceedings by Magistrate Tighe in the Butler Street Police Court, after a brief examination.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is generally admitted that engineering in this country has reached a very high standard. Nevertheless, I have yet to come in contact with any of these professional gentlemen who Have been able to make a thirteen-inch shell go through a six-inch hole, and this is the principle on which they are now figuring in regard to the Brooklyn Bridge.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 27. -- In fighting a bill in the Legislature to force the Baltimore and Potomac Railroad Company, a branch of the Pennsylvania, to abate the smoke nuisance of an open cut between the long tunnels under this city, the railroad officials and other employes have made startling admissions of the dangers from gas existing in the tunnels.

According to the verdict of the Coroner's jury, delivered after an inquest that lasted nearly all day yesterday, James McAuliffe, the Glennon witness, "came to his death on the 16th day of February, 1902, in Roosevelt Hospital, from a fracture at the base of the skull, a hemorrhage, and a lacerated brain, caused by violence at the hands of some person or persons unknown to the jury."

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Dr. Morrison, the Peking correspondent of The Times, says it is announced that the agreement between China and Germany, by which Germany acquires a mining monopoly throughout five zones of the Province of Shan-Tung, is on the eve of being concluded, no other Government having protested against this violation of the policy pf the "open door."

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Feb. 27. -- The preliminary bouts in the amateur boxing and wrestling championships were contested at the Penn Athletic Club, under the auspices of the A.A.U. before a very small crowd to-night. Summaries:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report in this morning's TIMES of the slight disturbance at Grant's tomb yesterday morning is incorrect in several particulars; there was no indiscriminate snowballing by the boys of the Horace Mann School; the boys were not warned by a policeman.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There are several things which the Committee of Fifty can do to investigate and alleviate the bridge crush, viz.:

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The settlement intensified the tightness of money, and borrowers were entirely dependent on the Bank of England, to which institution the indebtedness is estimated at u7,000,000 to u8,000,000. Discounts sympathized with the demand for money. Business on the Stock Exchange was mostly stagnant, and the attendance was poor. Gilt-edged securities were steady.

To The Editor of The New York Times: It seems that constant repetition is necessary to impress the public mind with the need of reform. Iteration of the postal abuse may, therefore, be justified. The primal and paramount use of the mall is for the carrying of letters. This use far transcends all other uses in importance.

Most of the stocks prominent in yesterday's trading in the outside market were strong and ended the day substantially above the closing prices of Wednesday. Considerable interest continued to be shown in the Copper Stocks, several of which were more than usually active. In this group, as well as in other parts of the list, there was evidence of an increase in public interest in the market.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 27. -- A special train carrying the Florodora theatrical company from Norfolk, Va., to Wilmington, Del., on the New York, Philadelphia and Norfolk Railroad was wrecked to-day at Eastville, Va., and several members of the company were seriously injured.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 28 -- The great gorges in the Allegheny River are broken and the ice is sweeping down on this city. The first break occurred at Montrose about 3:30 o'clock this morning, and an hour later the gorge near Sandy Creek broke, with a roar like that of heavy artillery, and began to move slowly down the river.

Yale and Short Hills played a tie game of hockey last night in the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, Columbus Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. The score was 4 goals each, but the finish was of a decidedly sensational character, for the whistle had scarcely sounded to close the game, when Stoddard, one of the Yale forwards, shot a goal on a forward pass.

On Thursday and Friday, Feb. 20 and 21, Stan. V. Henkels sold in Philadelphia a choice collection of autograph letters and historical documents gathered by William R. Weeks of New York and Henry S. Cushing of Philadelphia. Perhaps the most interesting item was Gen. Robert E. Lee's farewell address to his army, a document signed by him April 10, 1865, at the headquarters of the Army of Northern Virginia.

Miss Jekyll's name on the title page of any book concerning the kind of home that includes a garden is a guarantee that the reader will gain both information and delight. In the present case her aim has been merely to provide an amateur's handbook, "a simple guide to those who whish to grow lilies in English gardens."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I commend your editorial of this morning on "The Nation's Shame." There is no use denying that delay in the matter of reciprocity is being used as a club to force Cuba to demand annexation as her only salvation from positive industrial ruin. Thus our Nation is put into the despicable position of one who, having, from honorable motives, whipped a bully, has now turned bully.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: With interest and amusement Ihave read your advice to the aspirant to poethood whose appeal neverthless, appealed ultimately to the Dr. Jekyll side of my nature and left me wondering compassionately whether any of your Hydish suggestions would be followed.

Below will be found for the first time in print what is believed to be John G. Whittier's earliest poetical production. In 1823, then sixteen year's old, he visited some friends in Newburypbrt, Mass., and while there wrote in an album fifteen lines, which are said to be the first of his productions in verse of which there is any definite record.

One of the most successful art sales of recent days was concluded last night, when the remainder of the collection of watercolors, oil paintings, and a few bronzes belonging to Boussod, Valadon Co. went under the auctioneer's hammer at Mendelssohn Hall for prices reaching the total of $155,867.50.

CANON RAWNSLEY, in his "Ruskin and the English Lakes," has added one more, and in many ways the best, volume to his series of books upon some of the literary aspects of the Lake Country. His intimate knowledge of Ruskin, both from long association and from common interests as regards the foundation and support of cottage industries, makes him approach certain phases of his subject with unusual sympathy.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Feb. 28 -- The Delaware River and Pequest Creek overflowed their banks this afternoon, and Pequest Creek flooded the village on the north side and the big river is flowing along West Street. The silk mills are flooded, and so is the electric light works, and the city is in darkness to-night.

During the week that ends to-day the French people have been "delivering themselves," to employ an appropriate Gallicism, to the centennial celebration of Victor Hugo, who would have been a hundred years old if he, had lived till last Wednesday. Apart from critical consideration, the celebrationis a cheering fact.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- A somewhat unusual literary tone was imparted to the Founder's Day ceremonies of the University of Pennsylvania, held here a week ago, by the brief speeches made by Dr. Horace Howard Furness in presenting to Provost Harrison the various candidates for honorary degrees.
The following-named officers are assigned to regiments as indicated:

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY RE VIEW OF BOOKS of Feb. 15 I noticed an extract from an article in the current International Monthly by Mr. Hamiltion Wright Mabie on the "Poetry of the South." I have since read the whole article in which he says: "Southern poets have not received adequate attention at the hands of students and critics of American litrature."

When in the year 1838 the name of Henry Schomberg Kerr was entered in the list of the collegiates of Winchester, the note was made that the lad was a descendant of the Duke of Schomberg. History tells us that Friedrich von Schomberg was one of the Prince of Orange's leading Generals, and that the Duke was killed at the battle of the Boyne.

HOUSE building is a subject in which an increasingly large number of people take the keenest interest. There is no investment so personal and delightful, and often there is none so profitable as the house one lives in.

We print in another column a letter from a French gentleman who seems to disapprove something said on this page last week in regard "to French Life." It would be an amusing letter if it were not so pathetic. Here is an educated Frenchman laboring under the delusion that he understands the English language and the people who speak it, and basing on his assumed knowledge an incoherent but obviously sincere denunciation of the latter.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 -- If plans now on foot are brought to a successful termination extensive explorations will soon be made by the Harvard Semitic depatment in the fields of Egypt, Babylonia, Assyria, and Palestine. Prof. Tp; Lyon, Curator of the Harvard Semitic Musen is very anxious for such explorations to commence, and has already made a plea for money to commence the work.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- The Erie Railroad Company has granted an increase of wages to the conductors, trainmen, and switchmen on the entire line, to take effect March 1. The advance is the result of conference in New York between the Erie officials and the Boards of Adjustment of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen and Order of Railroad Conductors.

JOHN HOWARD BRYANT, the last of five brothers, died during the past month on an Illunois farm, where he had lived for seventy years. He was the youngest and favorite brother of the first born of the family, William Cullen Bryant, whom he survived for twenty-three years.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- The terms of the lease of the Union Traction Company to the new company represented by John M. Mack were announced to-day. As stated yesterday, the company is to be capitalized at $30,000,000 in 600,000 shares, with a par value of $50. The company is to be known as the Consolidated Traction Company.

The Rockwell brothers of the Erasmus Hall High School captured three of the four senior skating championships of the Long Island Interscholastic Association last night at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn. O. Minton of Poly. Prep. took the odd event. Each race was hotly contested, and as each school represented had a large delegation of rooters present, considerable enthusiasm was expended during the evening.

If District Attorney William Travers Jerome, aided by Capt. Goddard and a host of private detectives, can close them, there will not be a saloon open to-morrow. Mr. Jerome declared yesterday, during the trial of a man for violating the excise law, that he would from now on enforce the law, although he thought it a bad law.

Liability insurance men who are now in conference in this city are devoting most of their discussion to that part of the manual which has to do with hazards involved in the insurance of teams and elevators. A recommendation for an increased rate for these two classes of casualty insurance is expected.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Considerable apprehension exists in this village this evening of a threatened flood and ice gorge in the Delaware River on account of the heavy rains the last twenty-four hours, and people residing near the shores of the stream have prepared for the expected flood by moving their portable property to higher ground.

ABOUT a thousand men and women, presumably admirers of French literature, and particularly of the works of Victor Hugo, gathered last Wednesday afternoon in the auditorium of the Horace Mann School in order fittingly to commemorate the centenary of the birth of the great French poet and romancist.

John M. Wisker, the engineer on the Harlem train which ran into the Danbury Express in the Park Avenue tunnel of the New York Central Railroad on Jan. 8, when seventeen persons were killed, was found responsible for the disaster by the Grand Jury yesterday. He was indicted on two counts for manslaughter.

Following is a statement of books which have sold best in regular book and department stores in New York, Philadelphia, Boston, Cincinnati, Chicago, St. Louis, Baltimore, and San Francisco between Jan. 30, 1901, and Feb. 27 of this year. The statement is based on reports received from the regular correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in those cities, personal inquiries having been made for the information sent to us.

The week end does not present many attractions. Southern California and Florida have taken many of the fashionable people away, and the continuance of very bad weather here is strengthening the resolution of others to get away.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23. -- This city is practicalyy in a state of siege. Unlicensed assemblages of students have occurred here in the past week. On Feb. 21 the students of the Technical College lighted a bonfire in the street and with much ceremony burned the latest obnoxious decrees of the Minister of Education.

Florence Burns, paler than usual, appeared again yesterday at the examination in her case, which was resumed before Justice Mayer in the Court of Special Sessions. Detective McGovern of the Church Street Station, Dr. Sweeney, the physician called to the Glen Island Hotel to attend Brooks, and Joseph Cribbens, the office boy employed by the firm of Brooks Wells, were the witnesses heard.

Considerable activity was shown in certain parts of the list in the outside market yesterday, but in most cases the transactions resulted in only small net changes in prices. Several issues which recently have been prominent supplied very little business, and the only part of the group which was unusually active were the Copper shares.
The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: You say "The Inference is essentially false to the facts, but logical from the books referred to."

We have already pointed out that the extortion of exclusive mining concessions by Germany in the Shan-Tung Peninsula is quite as much opposed to the spirit of the principle of maintaining the integrity of China as are the proceedings of "Russia in Manchuria. It seems that they are equally infringements of the treaty rights of other Powers.
BOSTON, Feb. 28 -- The eighth and last lecture of M. Hugues Le Roux at Sanders Theatre this afternoon was given on " Tendencies of the Modern Romancers."

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The propagandists of the Whitman-Saved-Oregon Myth all adopt the "Flathead Deputation" to St. Louis as the cornerston of the Oregon missions. Spalding, Gray, Eells, Barrows, Craighead, Nixon, Mrs. Dye, and Mowry all represent Whitman's mission funded on four Amerinds of the Upper Columbia deputed by their tribe to St. Louis to 1832 to ask for the Bible.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 28 -- The local market to-day continued to circle around the G. Bs. Brewing issues. They were by all odds the feature of trading. The income bonds seem to come into special favor and were bought more vigorously than firsts or the common stock. Both the last named, however, were also in good demand and moved upward aggressively.

Animated efforts were made to give the market a smart setback yesterday, but forced recessions were of little consequence. The total of the day's transactions was barely above 400,000 shares. Important interests figured in no conspicuous way; the market seemed wholly given over to the seesawing performances of the littler room traders of the Stock Exchange, and most of the members of that group are always professionally bearish.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Two books of travel as absorbingly interesting in their way as Nansen's "Farthest North" are likely to get into print within the next year. The first is Pritchard's "Through Patagonia," for which the author himself has supplied, to illustrate his narrative of personal adventure, nearly four hundred illustrations, including pencil sketches, water color drawings, and photographs.

Assistant District Attorney Osborne spent the last day of the fifth week of Albert T. Patrick's trial on the charge of murdering Millionaire William Marsh Rice in corroborating the details of Valet Charles F. Jones's sworn statements that he murdered Rice at Patrick's instigation.

Not long ago we published some lightminded remarks in answer to a young gentleman, desiring to become a poet. It appears from a communication printed in last week's issue that these remarks were misunderstood. The letter to which we now refer with some sense of humiliation described our remarks as caustic, but then went forward to give some serious advive as to how to be a poet.

LONDON, March 1. -- Following the precedent of Earl Roberts, who announced Gen. Cronje's surrender on the anniversary of the battle of Majuba Hill, which was fought on Feb. 27, 1881, Lord Kitchener apparently selected the same anniversary to achieve a big success by a combined movement, lasting two days, against the Boer forces in the vicinity of the Harrismith and Van Reenen line of blockhouses.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 -- Lingo was the only winning favorite to-day. The Stewards have reinstated the steeplechase jockeys J. Gormley and H. Hayes, and the horses W.H. Dixon and Bristol. Weather clear, track fast. Summary:

THE absurd overestimate which was placed on Mr. Kidd's "Social Evolution," though it has been severly chastened by the criticism which has intervened between that and the present book, no doubt persists sufficiently to secure for his second importent venture, which now comes to hand a wide measure of interst which it will fully justify if not by the fruitfulness of its main conception by what is incidental thereunto.

The Municipal Art Society, having been deputed by the Fine Arts Federation to represent it in securing action under the law of 1900, authorizing an annual expediture of $50,000 by the city in works of art for beautifying public buildings, grounds, and parks, its committee, of which Spencer Trask is Chairman, has filed with the Board of Estimate and Apportionment the following recommendations and requests for such appropriation for the current year:

"The most fascinating search which ever yet allured the seeker after forgotten history" -- what is that? According to the writer of this volume, who speaks with the authority of an assistant in the Department of Egyptian and Assyrian Antiquities in the British Museum, it is the study of the problems of Mycenaean archaeology.

-- A private letter received in this city from a young Irishman who has earned a commission by two years of active service in South Africa gives a picture not less instructive than interesting of the Boer as seen by such a man as he. "At the sort of fighting going on at present," says this very competent observer, "the Boer is the best soldier in the world -- bar none.

MICHAEL ROSS, MINISTER," by Annie E. Holdsworth, author of "The Gods Arrive," c., will be published early in the Spring by Dodd, Mead Co. It is a story of English village life, the minister being the central figure a study of Irish life and manners, called "At the Back of Beyond," by Jane Barlow, author of "Irish Idylls," c.

It was said at his residence yesterday that Archbishop Corrigan has, by confining himself strictly to his room, so far recovered from the effects of his recent fall as to expect to be able to go out this afternoon and to he the celebrant of the solemn pontifical mass of thanksgiving at the cathedral on Monday morning next at 10 o'clock.

Because of the inability of the court officers to get a woman prisoner out of a cell, the business of the Flatbush Police Court, Brooklyn, had to be suspended for nearly an hour yesterday morning. The woman had been arrested for intoxication. New combination locks were placed on the doors of the cells in the court yesterday morning.

Business on the Stock Exchange was yesterday further restricted by the storm, which not only delayed the work of repair which has been going steadily on since the storm of a week ago, but also created fresh interruptions, particularly in the South, few wires being working even to Philadelphia or Washington.

The fourth annual dinner of the Twenty-seventh Assembly District Republican Club, held last night in the gymnasium of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, attracted an attendance far beyond the expectations of those who had charge of the affair and who had desired to make it the biggest Republican gathering of the late Winter season.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 28 -- The suit of minority bondholders of the United States Flour Milling Company to prevent the foreclosure of the $15,000,000 on its properties, was continued to-day before Vice Chancellor Pitney.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 28 -- The storm which swept over the Southeastern Gulf States yesterday and last night has apparently passed north and out to sea, Charleston feeling its force at 4 o'clock this morning, when the wind there registered forty three miles an hour. The heavy rains have raised the water to flood height in the Chattahoochee, Alabama, Ocmulgee, and Savannah Rivers, and much damage is reported in Georgia and Alabama.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 28 -- As has been already intimated. Prince Henry will not be able to extend his visit to Ottawa, but a hearty reception will be given him when he visits the Canadian side of Niagara Falls next Wednesday. A detail of the three branches of the service, required to do honor to the German royal visitor, will be drawn from the town of St. Catherine's.
Transactions in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange for the month of February were the smallest in any month since August last.

The Board of Estimate held a prolonged session yesterday and laid many plans for public improvements. Mayor Low presided and Controller Grout protested several, times when it was proposed to increase the expenditures over the amounts allowed for the city departments for 1902, made by the Board of Estimate presided over by Mayor Van Wyck.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To the list of those on whom the freedom of the city has been conferred, which your correspondent, "Manhattan," sends you, I would add the name of Baron de Stuben. The original document conferring this honor on the Baron. I have in my possession.

Guy L. Briggs, with a handicap of 10, won the opening games last night in the annual hand tennis tournament of the New York Athletic Club. He defeated G. Orvis, whose allowance was 18, in two straight sets, the scores being 25 to 23 and 25 to 20.

Two of the headings in the rapid transit subway, between Thirty-fourth and Forty-first Streets, under Park Avenue, met each other yesterday morning at 8 o'clock, and now there is a continuous passage, eight by twenty-two feet in dimension under the west side of the avenue.

Preliminary arrangements were consummated yesterday for the consolidation of the Staten Island Electric Railroad Company, the New York and Staten Island Electric Company, and the New Jersey and Staten Island Ferry Company. These three companies were placed in the hands of John Greenough as receiver by Justice Dickey in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, as a means of avoiding legal complications in the reorganization.

MRS. WHARTON'S equipment as a writer of fiction is of an order which insures a certain distinction of taste and style and a certain remoteness from the major passions and interests of life. She has a power of analysis which has been reinforced by thorough training; she is attracted by complex or subtle motives, and she is impelled by these qualities to choose her words with fastidious care.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 28 -- New York exchange was 20 cents discount to-day. Time and call loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent. Trading in local stocks was quite as featureless as the New York market. Prices apparently were firm for most of the leaders, but the business was so dull and of so purely a professional character that it was somewhat difficult to determine the actual trend of the market.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Prof. E.G. Bourne characterizes Mr. Ripley Hitchcock's article on Marcus Whitman (published some time ago in your columns) as "the only scholarly and critical review of Mowry's Marcus Whitman' that appeared in the public press of the United States during the first six months after the publication of that deceptive work."

Pirates and restaurants have always had a strong attraction for Mr. Frank R. Stockton as subjects of historical, critical, and psychological study. Years ago -- before he had begun to be famous -- he and I were associated in the editorship of a weekly family newspaper, and in addition to our office association, we nearly always went together to luncheon.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- After a long consultation with Attorney General Davies this afternoon Gov. Odell decided not to make public his decision in the ease of Sheriff Guden of Kings County until next week. It was announced that the delay in the decision was due to the fact that the Attorney General was desirous of looking up further the precedents with regard to the removal of officials by the Governor.

"The Hound of the Baskervilles." When Dr. A Conan Doyle first wrote the preface to his new Sherlock Holmes story, "The Hound of the Baskervilles," he intended to affix the following note, which led his friends to believe that Mr. Robinson had aided in creating the plot and other imaginary details:
Frederick D. Tappen, President of the Gallatin National Bank of this city, and whose home was at 49 East Sixty-eighth Street, died yesterday after a brief illness at Lakewood, N.J.

The Senate could not possibly have done less than it did yesterday in censuring both the Senators from South Carolina. To have purged them of their contempt on any easier terms would have been to invite a repetition of the offense. It would have shown that the Senate as a body had no higher sense of its own dignity than the two members who had violated that dignity.

When the British ship Ems arrived here yesterday her Captain reported a mutiny that delayed her in the West Indies for more than a month and resulted in the trial and incarceration of three of her sailors. A British gunboat, the Buzzard, had to come to her assistance, and the three mutineers one of them a Swede and the others Englishmen, are now awaiting a hearing before an Admiralty Court on Turk's Island.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senators McLaurin and Tillman of South Carolina today were severely censured by the United States Senate for the sensational personal encounter between the two Senators on the floor of the Senate last Saturday during the consideration of the Philippine Tariff bill.

BAYONNE, N.J., Feb. 28 -- Attempts to erect a railroad bridge over the Bayonne Speedway near Sixtieth Street, the connecting link of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's New York Bay Railroad line to the mammoth new freight terminal on New York Bay, are blocked by the Mayor and Common Council of the City of Bayonne.

Volume V. of Mr. Michael L. Rodkinson's translation of the Babylonian Talmud is kown as the tract "Baba Bathra," or the "Last Gate." Sometimes one wonders whether the early Jews were essentially a litigious people. In this particular section of the Talmud may be found all the rules and regulations concerning houses, yards, fields, with minute instructions relating to the disposal of property.

Mr. HAY brought to the always difficult and delicate task of eulogy, in his address on Thursday, some rare and happy qualifications, with the result that the address is a substantial contribution not merely to the general knowledge of Mr. McKINLEY, but to the understanding of the time in Which, he lived and did his work.

The revival of interest in the life and works of Fenelon, begun some years ago by Janet in his biography, ("Fenelon in the Grands Ecrivains Series," 1892,) and Crousie in "Fenelon and Bossuet," (1891,) still continues. THE SATURDAY REVIEW had occasion some months ago to review a new life of the Archbishop by Sanders, and now there has appeared a still more recent work on the same subject.

ONE has the feeling of assisting at a discovery when he rises from a persual of this biography of this great naturalist, whom Dr. Packard justly calls the founder of biological evolution. Every one knows something of Lamarck, but it is safe to say that few are acquainted with the facts of his personal life or the breadth and depth of his knowledge and generalizations in both practical and philosophical biology.

The storm yesterday afternoon which swept over the city was one of the most disagreeable of the season. The wind reached a speed of sixty-eight miles an hour and blew the rain that came flown almost in sheets into the faces of pedestrians and beneath their umbrellas so that these rain protecters were useless absolutely.

The annual report of the Delaware and Hudson Company for the year ended Dec. 31, 1901, which was made public yesterday, makes a very good showing, the earnings being equal to 9.03 per cent, on the stock. If the amounts charged for betterments, , against operating expenses were counted in, the earnings would be about 17 per cent.

MONTE CARLO, Feb, 28 -- The chess master this morning engaged in the sixteenth round of this international tournament. Round 19 of the Berger tables guided the pairing, and the players faced each other in the following order:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Prince Henry's visit to the National capital had a fitting culmination to-night in an official dinner given at the German Embassy and later in a tremendous outburst of popular enthusiasm from the German residents of Washington, as the imperial visitor was about to start on his Southern and Western tour.

The most interesting gossip about the theatres yesterday concerned a promise that J.E. Dodson and Annie Irish are to star next season. There was an absence of definite information as to who is to stand sponsor for the venture, but it is thought to be probable.

TELLURIDE, Col., Feb. 28 -- Two snow slides on Smuggler Mountain to-day wrecked the Liberty Bell Mine buildings, carrying them into the gulch, 2,000 feet below, and burying more than 100 men, more than half of whom, it is believed, are now dead. The first slide came down at 7:30 o'clock, burying the mine houses and between sixty and seventy men.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Mayor Low to-day called up Gov. Odell over the long-distance telephone and asked him to withhold judgment upon the bills introduced by Senator Siranahan granting extraordinary powers to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in reorganizing the various, boards, consolidating offices, and determining the salaries to De paid employes of the City Government of New York.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- At an extraordinary meeting to-day of the shareholders of the new Panama Canal Company President Bo read a message from the Consul General of Colombia in this city setting forth that the company would not be allowed to transfer its concession to another nation without first, with the assent of Colombia, modifying the stipulations of Articles 21 and 22 of the agreement.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 1 -- Prof. William S. Gorman of this place was seriously injured last night during a game of basket ball between two teams composed largely of New York business men in the Young Men's Christian Association gymnasium. In attempting a pass he slipped and fell backward, striking his head with great force on the floor.

PRINCE HENRY'S overtures to Carl Schurz at the gala opera Tuesday, when he invited the former revolutionary Germans to sit by him in his box, have called attention to the fact that Carl Schurz would not have been able to enjoy the friendship of Prince Henry had he not fled from Germany over fifty years ago.

Remarkably interesting side lights on commercial conditions in China, and particularly with reference to the payment by China of the indemnity due to foreign nations, are thrown by Clarence W. Wrightson of the firm of Fearon, Daniel Co. of Shanghai and New York. Mr. Wrightson has just arrived in this city from Shanghai and soon goes to London.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1 -- The two-year-old race furnished all the sensations of to-day's sport. While the horses were at the post, Ed. Corrigan concluded his negotiations, for buying the colt, with Hiram J. Scoggan, Frank Rice's owner. The colt ran a great race in spite of poor racing luck, and was a strong favorite in the betting.

There is no property in the world likely to be more permanently of value to its possessors in this generation than anthracite coal property; its area is well known, and at last it may be said that its value is acknowledged. The shipments for 1901 are put at 53,657,601 gross tons, as against 45,107,484 tons in 1900.
Prince Henry of Prussia sailed for New York Feb. 15.

Cheerfully innocent as to the ways of the press agent, "Long Jim" Reynolds, head of the Brooklyn Central Office, and about a dozen of his detectives lay in wait last night to capture a mysterious, blackhearted villain who had threatened the life of a local actress.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- There is wide diversity in the predictions made as to the effect on canal legislation of the announcement made by Colombia to the Panama Canal Company. Those thoroughly committed to the Nicaragua route say now that it is quite out of the range of possibilities that the Panama route should be chosen.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- Union Traction and Philadelphia Company monopolized the trading in the Philadelphia market. A vigorous demand set in for the latter at the opening and continued without interruption until the close, the price touching the highest for many months, advancing from 48 7/8 to par, $50, at which figure it returns 6 per cent.

NO agitation to legalize the opening of saloons on Sundays can have practical results as long as legislators stubbornly refuse to liberalize the laws. Their prejudice against the use of any alcoholic beverages is based on the misapprehension that alcohol will undermine the health even of temperate drinkers.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Weather Bureau has issued the following summary of crop conditions for the month of February:

William C. Pruden of Brooklyn and Elsa E. Stein-Rothenstein, who said she lived at 113 Hudson Street, Hoboken, were married in Jersey City on Friday night by Justice Charles A. Roe. They were unaccompanied, and Daniel T. Smith and Robert H. Trippe, friends of the Justice, acted as witnesses.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The University Settlement Society of New York will offer a strong protest to the final passage of the bill introduced by Senator Marshall amending the labor law in such a way that women over twenty-one years of age are not restricted at all in the hours they may work in factories.

LONDON, March 1 -- There is danger that London is going to get another batch of ill-advised statues, as, in view of the coronation, the old plan to decorate Blackfriars Bridge with effiges of royalty has been revived. Equestrian statues of King Edward and Queen Alexandra, of Prince George of Wales and his Princess, are contemplated, as well as groups representing the monarchs of history.

NEWARK, N.J., March 1. -- The judges completed their work of awarding the prizes in the first annual bench show of the New Jersey Kennel Association yesterday. The silver cup given by Mrs. M. S. French for the best dog on exhibition was awarded to Darnell Kitty of the Ashton Kennels, which took first and second prizes in the open class of the Prince Charles spaniels, the second prize going to Ashton Autocrat.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one of the survivors of the Park Avenue Hotel fire I would like to testify that I heard the housekeeper told twice that all the windows of the court rooms were closed before any idea of real danger to the hotel was entertained. A short time afterward heard the crash of the falling skylight and immediately there was a cry of fire.

The Henrietta, Frank J. Gould's new steam yacht, is to be launched early next month. It is now being constructed at the works of the Gas Engine and Power Company and Charles L. Seabury Co., (Cons.) at Morris Heights, on the Harlem River, where a number of other large yachts are also nearing completion.

The sub-committee of the Public Education Association, which makes the decoration of schools a specialty, gave an exhibition of the work it is doing yesterday by inviting public inspection of Public School. No. 7, which is at Hester and Chrystie Streets. In other schools of the city the scheme of educating the finer feelings of scholars by the ocular suggestion of paintings and portraits has been tried with appreciable result.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- The newspaper La Patrie has now received full confirmation of the horrible fate of the scientific mission sent out by this journal in 1900 to explore the small and savage islands in the vicinity of Borneo and New Guinea.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 1 -- The past week in Baltimore has been hopelessly dull. A few spasmodic attempts at gayety were made, but society is still so fagged out with its exertions during the season that so far it seems inclined to take its Lenten enjoyments mentally rather than physically. On Monday night there were several small theatre parties to see "Ben Hur" at the Academy of Music, with suppers afterward.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 1 -- The rental of three additional cottages for the season of 1902 was announced to-day. They include the William C. Rives brick villa in Red Cross Avenue, to Amedee D. Moran of New York; the Bishop Potter cottage, in Rhode Island Avenue, to Goold H. Redmond, and Lispenard Stewart's residence, known as White Lodge, in Bellevue Avenue, to James B. Haggin of New York.

Plans for the installation of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler as President of Columbia University have been completed, and all those who were asked to speak have consented to do so. The programme will include a speech by W.C. Schermerhorn. Chairman of the Board of Trustees, who will present the charter and keys of the university.

Telegraph and telephone systems have not yet recovered from the damage done by last week's storm. The work of repair, which has been pushed with all possible rapidity, was set back again considerably by the rainstorm of Friday. The floods in New York State, particularly in the Mohawk Valley, have seriously hindered the work of the linemen.

LONDON, March 1 -- With the month-turn the tightness of money is diminishing. Upward of L5,000,000 changed hands to-day, including the Treasury bill operations and dividend payments. Discounts were easier, in anticipation of a spell of cheaper money. Kafirs were the only active section on the Stock Exchange.
VERPLANCK BIRNEY, the artist, made a suggestion the other day which may give some woman just the idea for making money that she is looking for.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 1 -- Burglars wrecked the Post Office at Pelham Manor, near this place, early this morning in a futile attempt to secure $2,000 in cash and stamps from the safe, by the use of dynamite. They fled immediately after the explosion, which roused the neighborhood and brought the police running to the building.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 1 -- Ten persons were more or less seriously injured by the collapse of one of the buildings occupied by the Cleveland Baking Company, at 17 Central Avenue, to-day, and three others in the place at the time are reported missing.

In the tournament of the Custom House Bowling League yesterday evening the team of the Eleventh Division carried off the honors, winning three games and losing none. The Fifth Division won two and lost one. Isaacs, Vought Co. won one and lost two, and W.H. Steiner Co. lost three games.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1. -- Manager Frothingham of the Harvard baseball nine announced the schedule of this Spring's games. There is a total of twenty-seven games, three more than last year, of which sixteen will be played in Cambridge. The chief feature of the schedule is the game with Princeton, which college Was not played last year.

MARCH has a gift peculiarly its own that will, rejoice the hearts of dwellers in the north temperate zone. When March rules the year, the Vernal Equinox occurs, the astronomical Spring begins, the gates of the charming season open for the procession of the flowers, and the incoming of vernal delights.

MRS. REBECCA SALOME FOSTER, who met such a tragic death in the Park Avenue Hotel fire, began the missionary work in the criminal courts of this city which won her the name of the "Tombs Angel" nearly twenty years ago, shortly after the death of her husband, Gen. John A. Foster.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Despite the opposition of the Bill Posters' Union and other organizations to the bill introduced by Assemblyman Landon, providing for a tax upon advertising signs, there is a disposition on the part of the Assembly Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment to take some step which will act as a deterrent upon the flaring advertisements which so frequently mar the landscape in the country and offend the aesthetic sense in the cities.

The bell in the old church at East Ogunquit is clanging this morning. There will be a wedding in the church this noon. Old "Sleepy" Williams will be the bridegroom, Miss Lottle Davis the bride. They should have been married forty years ago, when Williams was a robust, bright-eyed young man, and Miss Lottle was so pretty and graceful and gracious

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 1 -- Fishkill Creek, which passes through the heart of the village of Matteawan, Dutchess County, is out of its banks and has done about $40,000 worth of damage. The electric light and power plant of the Citizens Railroad Light and Power Company is completely submerged to a depth of six feet.

Vagaries of Actors. If the vagaries of actors could be printed they might fill a large volume. But some of the more pronounced characteristics of the people of the stage suggest themselves naturally to one, who, while in entire sympathy with the difficulties of the calling, its disappointments, and its hardships, is convinced that the actor is not altogether blameless in the results.

Photography is so close to the people as a quick and cheap means to get a likeness, and is used so much to furnish the illustrated press with substitutes for drawings, that we regard it as a machine-made handicraft into which art does not enter. At most we commend a photograph for its sharp lines, and in general we imagine that, in this form of reproduction of nature, realism cannot further go.

An heiress of George Drummond, Earl of Perth, news of whose leath was received yesterday from England, lives in Brooklyn in the person of Miss Mary Drummond, a telephone operator in the Cortlandt Central office, Manhattan. Miss Drummond is a great-granddaughter of the Earl. Her inheritance, however, is said to be problematical.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Hearing the gypsy strains of "Manru," I was forcibly reminded of the negro songs of Hampton, where I had just been studying the work of the great Normal and Agricultural Institute. Without musical resemblance, the one expression is as gen- uinely racial and inevitable as the other, and the duty of preserving both records of primitive peoples equally obligatory.

IT is credibly reported that Archbishop Corrigan's acceptance of the invitation to the banquet in honor of Prince Henry gave offense to a portion of his priesthood. They did not perceive any justification for an agreement, on the part of so conspicuous a prelate of the Church, to do this honor to a notoriously Protestant Prince.

IT WAS a pity that something of really artistic importance could not be done in arranging the operatic performance in honor of Prince Henry. It might have been interesting to the royal visitor to study the position of honor which German musical art occupies in this country, and it a star performance of a German work could have been given it might have been instructive as well as interesting.

William Marconi, the young inventor, who in December startled the world by announcing that he had succeeded in transmitting prearranged signals by means of the wireless telegraph across the Atlantic, arrived at New York on the American liner Philadelphia yesterday morning. He made another statement in regard to results achieved on the way over by the wireless system, little less remarkable than the achievement he announced from Newfoundland in the Winter.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment will at the next meeting take up the question of acquiring sites for the Carnegie Libraries to be established under the deed of gift of Andrew Carnegie, through which he gave to the City of New York the sum of $5,200,000 for the establishment of sixtyfive public libraries in all the boroughs.

BERLIN, March 1 -- The first, quick impression of wonder over Prince Henry of Prussia's reception in the United States has passed, but fresh incidents of the Prince's experiences continue to entertain the public. The newspapers here handle the dispatches from the United States as though they were installments of a serial romance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Evidently those of us who have been railing at the distinguished gentlemen who are responsible for the Park Avenue tunnel must this morning take off our hats and offer apologies for the unjust and unkind remarks which have been hurled at the management of the New York Central Railroad Company.

BOSTON, March 1 -- Money rates, bank clearances, balances, and foreign exchange rates are reported to-day as below: Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 10 to 15 cents discount; call loans, 3 to 3 1/2 per cent.; time money, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Clearing House exchanges, $23,123,051; balances, $2,357,253.

NOW that the question of reduction of internal revenue taxes is being discussed, a few extracts taken from the recently issued report of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue may Drove interesting. This document covers a period beginning July 1, 1900, and ending June 30, 1901.

SYDNEY, Jan. 28 -- It is very doubtful if the Federal Prime Minister, Edmund Barton, will long retain office. He has been invited to attend the coronation ceremony in London, and it is understood that should there be no previous change of Ministry he will resign the Premiership before returning to Australia, in order to assume the office of Federal Chief Justice or Federal High Commissioner.

FOR two months and a half now the spacious drillroom floor of the Thirteenth Resident Armory, Brooklyn, has been turned, theoretically, into a coastwise battle ground. In two of the corners and at the opposite end from these a four-inch rapid-firing piece, a mortar, and an eight-inch disappearing gun have represented forts on points of land.

The Director of Fine Arts at the Chicago World's Fair, the Pan-American Exposition, and the Louisiana Purchase Exposition of 1903 was entertained at luncheon yesterday in the National Arts Club, some thirty artists and men interested in the arts being present. Charles R. Lamb was host.

PATERSON, N.J., March 1 -- The flood caused by the sudden rising of the Passaic River yesterday is the greatest ever known. The river to-night is fully twelve feet above high-water mark, or more than a foot above the high point of the freshet of 1882. Four bridges were closed to traffic this afternoon, as the water completely covered the paths.

Wall Street's security market, narrow and uninteresting, has during the week past confined itself generally to movements in specialties, making especially conspicuous some of the lower-priced railway issues. There have been drives in variety at the market made by the bear contingent, rather better organized and more aggressive than since it had to take punishment around New Year's.

In a less degree, but still to substantial purpose, the faculty possessed by the Russians of consorting with Asiatics and eventually assimilating them provides the Slav Empire with a weapon against its Anglo-Saxon rival. Russian rule is not humane, or just, or honest. The British is. But, for all that, the natives of Asia prefer the former.

THERE has lately been made in Europe one of the most remarkable discoveries in the history of cartography, and one which must hereafter be referred to in all works pretending to give in detailed form the story of the New World. This discovery is nothing less than the unearthing in an obscure corner of a nobleman's library of the first maps known to have been made containing the name America.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 1 -- A tele- gram from San Francisco says: "Capt. George A. Detchemendy, Twenty-second Infantry, claims to have been more instrumental in capturing Aguinaldo than any one else. Before he left Manila he wrote to the War Department demanding as a reward a commission as Brigadier General, and tendering his resignation as the alternative.

Harvard won the right to meet Yale in the series of three games for the intercollegiate hockey championship by defeating Princeton in an intercollegiate match at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening by a score of 6 to 3. Harvard played one of the fastest and cleanest college hockey matches seen here this year.

If Senators Hanna and Foraker of Ohio ever had a real fight in their State, as was announcel when the factions bearing their names strove with each other for the control of the Legislature in January, there was no sign of animosity between the two principals at last night's dinner of the Ohio Society in the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE second annual dinner of the brethren of the "Amen Corner" of the Fifth Avenue Hotel will take place at the hostelry on the night of Friday, April 4. Senator Thomas C. Platt will be the guest of honor.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 1 -- Lakewood's enjoyment of Winter pleasures was very brief indeed. Moonlight sleigh rides, snow races, and trotting races on the ice were being planned when a warm rain came down and ended it all. The cutters and sleighs have been put away until some other time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Feb. 23 appears a communication from Congressman Underwood of Alabama, under the caption, "How the Tariff Pinches Our Foreign Trade." It seems to be a resume of a speech made in the House of Representatives the preceding Monday.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 1 -- The session of the Students Volunteer Movement to-day had a large attendance. Samuel B. Capen. LL. D.. of Boston, delivered an address on the necessity of making the financial plans of the church commensurate with the magnitude of the task of the world's evangelization.

Policy playing came to a standstill last night in this city, Brooklyn, and Jersey City, for the first time since the game was inaugurated, and thousands of policy shops were compelled to suspend business. By one of the most successful raids ever planned the headquarters of the policy dealers, where the official lists are printed every day, was broken into and the form and press seized.

Dr. Sweeney, who attended Walter S. Brooks when he was found dying in the Glen Island Hotel, continued to tell what he knew of the tragedy when the hearing in the case of Florence Burns, who is accused of slaying the young man, was resumed yesterday in Special Sessions Court before Justice Mayer.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 1 -- The reception to Prince Henry in this city was most cordial. Thousands of people crowded the passageway leading to the Union Station, which overlooks the tracks, and thousands more were scattered along the tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad for some distance on either side of the station.

The late snow, it is said, was not the deepest ever known here -- one that fell about March 8, 1888, being sixten inches deep. But this cold spell has been a record-breaker and, in fact, the entire Winter may be classed almost as the only on of its kind. Since the fires were first started in the Fall they have harly been allowed to die out.

ONLY a short time ago there was unveiled in the small Russian town of Gelahuga, under military honors, a monument to the remarkable woman, Nadescha Duroff, who served in the Russian Army during half a century, and finally died in 1866, at the age of eighty-three, a Rittmeister in the Russian cavalry, and decorated with the cross of the Order of St. George.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 1 -- Railroad officials roughly estimate that the losses by floods in Maryland and West Virginia in the destruction of bridges and the washing out of tracks and roadbeds will exceed $1,000,000. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company's losses are very heavy. Between Martinsburg and Cumberland traffic is suspended, with four to five feet of water on the tracks.

Nickel Plate issues have been among the recent market leaders as a result of buying by brokers recognized as representative of Vanderbilt interests. To explain the activity and strength Wall Street learns from what may be regarded as authoritative sources that the much-discussed readjustment of Nickel Plate stocks, involving the retirement of the first preferred, is shortly to be carried through.

WITH the steady increase in the price of diamonds and the assurance on all sides that the advance will continue for some few years at least, come reports from all over the world of explorations and examinations looking to the discovery of a diamond field that will be a fitting successor to the De Beers Consolidated Mining Company's lands in South Africa.
SOUVENIR makers have done well by the visit of Prince Henry. Considering how recently his visit was decided upon, they have turned out a goodly quantity of mementos of different kinds.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 1 -- Frederick Mead of New York was again on the witness stand in the Greenwich Probate Court to-day to explain why he had charged the estate of Solomon Mead, of which he was executor for three years, the sum of $83,000 for services, office rent, clerk hire, and incidentals.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- The worst flood along the Schuylkill River in years is being experienced now. It began last night, and from the source of the river to its mouth great damage has been done. It was an anxious night for the residents along the river.

TERE is a recommendation for the woman of business. A man who has recently arrived from Chile says the railroad companies there prefer women for conductors "because they do not steal as badly as the men!"

The second Empire play of the present season will be presented at that theatre to-morrow evening. It is a comedy in four acts by Ludwig Fulda, who wrote "The Lost Paradise," and it is entitled "The Twin Sister." The play in its original German form was produced at the Irving Place Theatre last season.

MILAN has been busily occupied with operatic novelities. No less than three works have been given for the first time at the various lyric theatres of the city. The first of these was "La Fata in Prigione," both libretto and music being from the pen of R.A. Thomas, a wealthy German merchant residing in Milan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent, "Hudson River," in this day's TIMES makes a good suggestion, that the passenger traffic of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad "be ordered back to the original river route" and go to the old Thirtieth Street station.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Harry Boakes, the racquet professional of the Chicago Athletic Association, succeeded in breaking even with Champion George Standing of New York, by winning the second match of the series to-day by a score of three games to one. The first match played at the Chicago Athletic Association courts on Thursday was captured by the visiting expert, who, after a brilliant display, took three games out of four.

THE recent list fight in the United States Senate, precipitated by Senator Tillman of South Carolina, is one of the most disgraceful episodes that ever took place in the upper branch of Congress. The dastardly attack of Preston S. Brooks, also of South Carolina, upon Senator Charles Sumner of Massachusetts does not afford a parallel.

The past week has seen some rather unexpected developments in the money market and a fairly considerable drain upon bank resources in several unexpected ways. The banks, for instance, lost to the Sub-Treasury during the week no less a sum than $3,585,000 -- a loss greater by a million dollars than in any week thus far this year.

WHEN Col. Beard died a few years since he left a delightful home at Poughkeepsie to be used for aged men of culture and refinement who have been unable in their days of labor to save a competency for themselves. It is known as the Pringle Home, is luxuriously fitted up, and an ideal place for those who are privileged to enjoy its homelike surrounding's.

The New York Equal Suffrage League held a public meeting last night at Mendelssohn Hall. Forty-first Street, near Broadway at which a number of foreign delegates to the recent National convention at Washington spoke. The meeting was well attended. The speakers were Miss Vida Goldstein of Australia, who dwelt on it.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The Direct Nominations act, introduced in the Senate this week by Senator Marshall, is understood to be inspired by the Brookfield faction of the Republican organization of New York City. It has also been indorsed by the Young Men's Republican Club and the Democratic Club, both of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Considerable important business was disposed of by the Senate to-day. What is known as the Omnibus Claims bill and the measure providing for the irrigation of public lands were passed. The conference report on the Philippine Tariff bill was agreed to and the Shipping bill was made the unfinished business.

LONDON, March 1. -- It is rumored that instead of continuing the practice of the late Queen Victoria of offering annually three 100-guinea cups for the competition of the principal yacht clubs of the kingdom. King Edward intends to offer only one cup to the Royal Yacht Squadron.

Capt. Edward L. Munson, Assistant Surgeon, is detailed as a member of the Board of Medical Officers appointed Feb. 2, for the examination of candidates for admission to the Medical Corps, vice Capt. Frederick P. Reynolds, Assistant Surgeon, who is relieved.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The cordiality of the relations between the United States and Germany is shown eloquently by the commerce between the two countries dur- ing the last few years. These figures show that the commerce of the United States with Germany exceeds that with any other country of the world except the United Kingdom.

Superintendent Stewart of the Bureau of Buildings yesterday decided that every precaution must be taken to enforce the safety provisions of the Building Code in the case of skyscrapers and large buildings how in course of construction, or projected. The Superintedent takes this action now because of recent distastrous fires in so-called fireproof structures.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Language is a factor in the evolution of the race, and an instrument which works for ethical progress. If, as Max Mueller has pointed out, the endowment of intelligible speech is "the Rubicon which separates man from the brutes," intelligent American people should strive to evidence the degree of their elevation by correctness of expression and conscientious use of their language.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 1 -- No flood has occurred in Dutchess County for half a century equal to the one which swept through the valley of the Wappinger's Creek and the Fishkill on Friday night and Saturday morning, doing damage amounting to many thousands of dollars.

A DINNER gown recently worn by Mrs. Elisha Dyer, Jr., was of black net heavily spangled. The lower half of the skirt was simply laden with glittering masses of jet, but from six inches or so above the knees the jet grew less and less heavy, until only delicate spirals of jet formed whorls about the waist line.

CINCINNATI, March 1 -- Prince Henry of Prussia traversed the States of Maryland, Pennsylvania, and Ohio to-day, and to-night his special train is speeding through Kentucky into Tennessee, with the battlefields around Chattanooga as its final Southern goal. He stopped for formal receptions at Altoona, Pittsburg, Columbus, and Cincinnati, reaching the latter place at 8:45 P.M., but the welcome extended to him was not limited to those places.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Considering the enormous population of the central section of Manhattan north of Central Park, is it not a pitiful reflection on the intelligence of that part of the municipality to note the meek resignation, the helplessness, and the apparent indiffer- ence to the elemental conveniences -- or lack thereof -- shown by Harlemites toward the existing administration of local affairs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent contribution of $25,000 to the poor of our city by James R. Keene, who wanted it distributed immediately, and who so admirably expressed his views on the question of practical charity, deserves the highest commendation. His act and his words should open a general public discussion on the question of charity.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since your "Man in the Street" asked the public to assist him in his Sunday story-telling I have recognized many old friends in his columns. Some of these veterans have made their reappearance more or less disguised, but I have found great pleasure, nevertheless, in renewing their acquaintance. And what memories they recall!

THE gowns worn at the gala performance at the Opera House on Tuesday evening in honor of Prince Henry were not more handsome, nor were the jewels seen more gorgeous than those in evidence on many previous evenings. By actual count there were no larger number of tiaras and crowns worn than at several earlier performances.

LENOX, March 1 -- It is quite a novelty to many New Yorkers to visit this almost inaccessible hilltop in midwinter. The highways are drifted even more than usual this Winter, and those who go out sleigh-riding are liable to either get stuck in the drifts or have the novelty of having their sleighs overturned.
The following leter having reference to the proposal to supply the Borough of Brooklyn with water to be obtained from Suffolk County was received at THE NEW YORK TIMES office a few days ago:

C.B. Marshall and Irvine Orton, representing respectively Columbia University and the University of Pennsylvania, made the race of the evening last night in the Twelfth Regiment Armory, Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street. The men met in the scratch intercollegiate half-mile run, which was one of the features in the intercollegiate games given under the auspices of the Columbia Track Association.

The West has been for twenty years or more insisting that some legislation should be inaugurated by Congress looking to the reclamation of the arid west. The great difficulty has been that Senators and Reprepresentatives from the Eastern, Middle, and the humid States of the West have not understood the irrigation question.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Richard T. Greener, United States commercial agent at Vladivostock, Siberia, has submitted a report on agriculture and farm machinery in Eastern Siberia, which in part is as follows:

An act has been passed by the Senate and House of Representatives, and is now awaiting the approval of President Roosevelt, which is of importance in National banking quarters. The charters of a large number of National banks expire this year and next, and it is the obect of this bill to enable such banks to extend their corporate existence for a period of twenty years.

Reading stock, which for a lone time sold for the assessment paid on the old Philadelphia and Reading, and frequently for less, and which only a year ago was quoted down in the twenties, has lately been one of the lights of the stock market, active and strong, making records around 60.

The events of the last week were exciting and quite out of the ordinary. The visit of Prince Henry was a very bright spot in the negative dullness of Lent. Now that he has gone away for a few days, the town has settled to its routine of musicales, of sewing classes and those nondescript entertainments known as Lenten Amusement Clubs.
Whether New York shall be wet or dry to-day, in the matter of the sale and purchase of malt and spirituous liquors, will depend upon the judgment of the Captains of police precincts.

LONDON, March 1 -- A bit of good news from South Africa which came late Friday served to strengthen prices somewhat and to increase business, but really the dullness which occupied all the rest of the week was decidedly monotonous.

A concert for the bennefit of the George Junior Republic will be given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Tues- day evening, March 11. The George Junior Republic, which was founded in 1895 by William R. George, and located at Freeville, N.Y., is devoted to the care and education of the wayward young who otherwise would be sent to reformatories.

In an action brought by Samuel Samuels to recover $25,000 damages from William Horwitz for the loss of his two-year-old child, who, he alleged, was killed through Mr. Horwitz's negligence, a jury in the Supreme Court returned a verdict for $200, and Justice Dugro held that the verdict was adequate.

CONSTANTINOPLE, March 1 -- Miss Ellen M. Stone, the American missionary, until recently held captive by brigands, arrived here to-day from Saloncia and proceeded to the United States Legation. Miss Stone and Mme. Tsilka, her companion, are in excellent health.

So far as the general character and volume of its business is concerned, the week has developed little that calls for comment. This business, however, has been noteworthy in at least one particular, namely, the large number of transactions preliminary to the erection of new office and mercantile structures.

At the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday the customary two performances of opera took place. In the afternoon the matinee lovers were invited to consider the error of the bride whose curiosity led her to ask a fatal question, and so to lose a husband. In the other Wagner's "Lohengrin" was performed.
SOME interesting figures are given in the annual report of the State Board of Tax Commissioners recently submitted to the Legislature.

TELLURIDE, Col., March 1 -- Fourteen dead, as many injured, and a score or more missing, are the results, so far as known, of the series of snowslides which occurred yesterday in the vicinity of the Liberty Bell Mine on Smuggler Mountain, three and a half miles north of Telluride. The roads betwen here and the Liberty Bell are almost impassable, and details of the accidents are hard to obtain.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Consul General Holloway reports from St. Petersburg, Jan. 31, 1902:

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- The terms on which the Union Traction Company is to be leased to John M. Mack and his associates were made public to-day. On Monday the Board of Directors of the Traction Company will meet, and the following resolutions will be passed:

Fresh details of the wreck of the No. 6 furnished by the aeronaut himself will be of interest. M. Santos-Dumont says that shortly after sailing off he found that the balloon was letting out gas, owing to the defective working of the valves. Instability of the vessel was the result. The silk cylinder getting out of shape and losing its rigidity, the rudder ceased to act properly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among the many things for which people pay money, and which are intended to procure a profit for the receiver of the money, some are substantial enough and others are what the mathematicians might call imaginary, having in themselves no material existence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Wednesday your correspondent "Manhattan" makes a statement in relation to the granting of "the freedom of the city" to Lafayette which appears to me to be a little "off color." Correcting a previous statement of THE TIMES, he says:

The preliminary report of the British Government upon the mineral production of British Columbia for the past year estimates the tonnage of ore mined from the lode mines at nearly 872,000 tons, equal to an increase of 317,000 tons over the preceding twelve months, or rather more than 37 per cent., while the gross value of the mineral production is stated at $20,714,000, in contrast with $16,345,000, or an increase of about 25 per cent.

INTERNATIONAL athletic contests have become so numerous lately that they have almost ceased to be a novelty. Their interest, however, has not diminished, and if one looks at the yacht racing rivalry between England and America for an ex- ample, it would seem as though popular enthusiasm increased with each new con- test.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 1 -- "The entire population seems to be on wheels," said a prominent New Yorker yesterday, as he watched the long line of rolling chairs moving up and down the Boardwalk, "and I believe it is one of the most enjoyable diversions, I know of."

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The River and Harbor bill was completed to-day, and the items made public. Unusual interest attaches to the measure this year, as last year passed without a River and Harbor bill. The total carried by the measure completed to-day is $60,700,000. Of this total $24,000,000 is in cash and $36,700,000 is in continuing contracts available July 1, 1903.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Washington's Birthday I read in THE TIMES Mr. Hall's letter, also on the following day one from Mrs. Roger A. Pryor on Jamestown, about which comparatively few people are interested or know anything, and yet it was the cradle of the founders of Anglo-Saxon America.

ONE incident of the launching of the Meteor which seems to have escaped the chroniclers of that international ceremony was not lost by the girl friends of the graceful central figure of the function, and their involuntary exclamations illustrated how old superstitions linger.

The plan of taking the lands of the friars in the Philippines by the exercise of the right of eminent domain has much to recommend it. The acquisition of the lands is a matter of high expediency, and though the need of acquiring them and the purposes to which they are to be devoted are not such as have been recognized in this country, the policy is within the spirit of our law.

THEY talk in United States Treasury circles of coining a 2 1/2-cent piece. There are many who favor the coinage of such a piece of money, and there are many who think it would be useless. Collectors of coins are strenuously advocating such a plan, but theoretical students of the money question say the United States has too many coins already.

Bridge Commissioner Lindenthal admitted yesterday that one detail of his plan for the relief of the Brooklyn Bridge congestion, which he will make public to-morrow, contemplated the purchase of the block on which the Staats-Zeitung Building stands, and also the triangular plot just north of the bridge.

BERLIN, March 1 -- In the course of a discussion of sugar taxation in the Reichstag to-day, during which some of the members spoke of the prejudicial effect of the cartel system on consumption, the Imperial Secretary of the Treasury, Dr. von Thiel- mann, remarked that as he had not been notified officially that the international agreement had been signed at Brussels, he was not in a position to enter into details.

It became known in Brooklyn yesterday that Street Cleaning Commissioner Woodbury had brought to light in that borough a surprising expenditure of the city's money for the work of removing snow from the streets. The Commissioner recently received information to the effect that money was being wastefully spent in connection with the removal of snow.

The State of Kansas employs at present 11,028 public school teachers, the average age of whom is but twenty-one years. In the three Counties of Logan, Rock, and Shawnee the average age of the teachers is only nineteen years.

Senator Benjamin R. Tillman of South Carolina was a caller on Senator Platt at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. The talk lasted over an hour. One of the principal topics of conversation was the proposed visit of President Roosevelt to the Charleston Exposition.
"Baggage must be trucked and not rolled, and in unloading it from a truck a pad must be used."

Nervous prostration and suggestion by a shoplifter, who is one of the characters in the play, "The Girl and the Judge," combined to make Mrs. Frederick L.C. Keating, wife of a lawyer at 38 Park Row, who resides at 222 Central Park South, loot Sixth Avenue department stores yesterday and get herself arrested on the charge of shoplifting.

Upon the occasion of his retirement from the position of Assistant General Traffic Manager of the Southern Pacific Railroad Company. Edwin Hawley has been made the recipient of a valuable testimonial from the officiats and employes under Mr. Hawley's jurisdiction. It is in the form of a punch bowl, with ladle, platter, and cups, all of special design and of solid silver.

The statement of District Attorney JEROME relative to the outrageous miscarriage of justice in the case of the tunnel accident, which is elsewhere printed, will be read with even more amazement than was the announcement that WISKER had been indicted for manslaughter and the case against the managers of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad for maintaining a public nuisance dismissed.

PITTSBURG, March 1 -- At midnight the indications are that the flood has done its worst. The Monongahela marks at the Smithfield Street Bridge showed at that time 31.9, a fall of nearly a Herr's Island registered 35.5, a fall of three-tenths of a foot since 6 P.M. At Davis Island Dam the Ohio stood stationary at 30.1 feet.

Flags flew at half mast over many banks in Wall Street yesterday as a tribute to the memory of Frederick D. Tappen. Business went on as usual at the Gallatin National Bank. It was stated by one of the officers of the institution that Mr. Tappen's death had come so unexpectedly that it was impossible to call a meeting of the Board of Directors to be held yeterday.

Is a goose an animal or is it merely an obstruction, or is it neither, when it stays out on a railroad track? This question has just been decided by the court of Tennessee, and the conclusion reached is that a goose is an animal only until it strays out on a railroad track. After that, if it gets in the way of a train it is to be considered not even as an obstruction.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- The damage done in this village and along the Delaware River west of here by high water and heavy ice is the greatest in years. The water rose rapidly in the river last evening, and at 2 o'clock this morning the heavy ice gorge between Narrowsburg and Callicoon, gave way.

THERE is much good-natured rivalry among the division engineers along the Rapid Transit Subway, and Mr. Value, who is in charge of the work above One Hundred and Fourth Street, is now exulting over Mr. Carr, who has the part from the City Hall to Forty-first Street, because the underground headings in Central Park met each other before those under Park Avenue came together.

Because of the gold shipments made during the week and the continued strength of sterling exchange there have been few topics in Wall Street in the last few days of as much general interest as the foreign exchange situation. Discussing this situation, a leading exchange authority says:

NEW HAVEN, March 1 -- An important addition to the pitching staff of Yale's baseball nine was announced to-day in H. P. Olcott, the football player. Olcott played at centre on Yale's champion 1901 team and left guard last year, and was for two years an All-American choice. He is tall and heavy, and has a fast delivery.

The Charity Organization Society has received from one of its patrons, who desires that his name be withheld, a valuable collection of antique and mediaeval cameos and intaglios to be sold privately for the benefit of the Charity Organization Society and the Provident Relief Fund.

HAVERFORD, Penn., March 1 -- Haverford 32, Rutgers 32, was the score to-night at the finish of the fourth annual gymnastic contest between the two colleges. This is the first meeting of the series to be held at Haverford, and is also the first contest ever held in Haverford's fine new gymnasium.
