The fine weather of yesterday served to bring out a large number of shotgun experts, and the shooting at the Crescent Athletic Club's Bay Ridge traps therefore was very lively. There were 3,385 targets demolished, while only six events were contested. "Harry" Kirkover, "Jack" Fanning, and Skelly shot as guests of the club in the regular events, and contested in the open scratch shoot for the Brigham Cup.

The open swimming races of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club were held last night in the natatorium of the club. The Knickerbocker swimmers won two of the three events contested, J.A. Ruddy finishing first in the 200-foot scratch race, and J. Lawrence leading in the 100-yard handicap. The novice race at 100 feet was won by H.K. Terlune, a swimmer of the Pawnee Athletic Club.
A decision of interest to importers was rendered yesterday by the Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers, in an appeal taken by Eisenbach Brothers Co.
Music and wit were the keynotes of a dinner given last night at the Lotos Club in honor of Maurice Grau, manager of the Metropolitan Opera House.

MONTE CARLO, March 1 -- This was another off-day in the international chess masters' tournament, and only drawn games and games that were left unfinished in previous rounds were ordered by the committee to be concluded or replayed, respectively. When an adjournment took place, at 1 o'clock, the following results had been recorded.

There can really be no cause for such hysteria as Wall Street seems to indulge in, no matter where the Northern Securities Company may land. It would be to write the history of the whole affair, to go over the facts on which arguments pro and con are based, or will be based, and this is not necessary.

The train schedule at the Grand Central Station was demoralized completely yesterday. Trains that should have been in Saturday night were not in last night, and all trains from beyond Albany were anywhere from five to thirty hours late.
Capt. Norton F. Goddard, President of the Anti-Policy Society, said yesterday when speaking of the raids on Saturday night, that "policy in the City of New York not only could, but would be stopped."

The record of liquor selling yesterday, which we publish this morning, may, we suppose, be taken as fresh evidence that the excise law is what District Attorney JEROME has frequently declared it to be, "unenforcible." It will be interesting to learn from him his view as to the reasons.

President CANTOR, at the Arts Club on Saturday, had a pitiful tale to tell of the obstacles he is obliged to meet and may not be able to overcome in securing an appropriation of $40,000 for decent street signs in the Borough of Manhattan.

After the severe cold of the past month the comparatively mild weather of yesterday was welcomed by the cross-country runners, who found the going, though wet and muddy, much easier than when the ground was covered with snow and ice. A half dozen runs in all were held, three in the Bronx, two in Brooklyn, and one in Long Island City, and over a hundred runners competed in all.

PASSAIC, N.J., March 2. -- The flood today has not subsided in the Wallington section of the city, which is under water. The water seems to be slowly rising. Great damage is being done not only to houses and stores, but to the mills in that section. The entire city is in darkness owing to the flood reaching the fires under the electric light company's boilers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have noted with the keenest interest the special telegrams from Washington, published in THE TIMES, in relation to the Tillman-McLaurin episode. The general condemnation of these gentlemen in the press of the South has been especially striking.
BRUSSELS, March 2. -- L'Etoile Belge publishes the text of the sugar convention by articles.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 2. -- The flood here continued to rise from midnight until 9 this evening, when it reached a point 32 feet above low water mark. The water now covers a portion of this city and suburbs two miles long by a mile wide, and almost a thousand families are homeless. At Kingston, Edwardsville, Plymouth, Dorranceton, Luzerne, Pittstoii, Wyoming, and smaller places 1,500 families have been compelled to leave their homes.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- The semifinals and finals in the boxing and wrestling championships of the Amateur Athletic Union were decided last night. Four of the seven boxing championships went to New York men, William Rodenbach of the New York West Side Athletic Club winning the 158-pound class honors without even a contest.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 2. -- The worst floods in the history of the State have inundated Western North Carolina since Thursday. Wires are down and all traffic suspended.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- At a meeting of the Columbia Yacht Club of Chicago, held at its clubhouse yesterday, the Lipton Cup Committee reported the receipt of a letter from Sir Thomas Lipton, together with a deed of gift for the cup.

ROME, Feb. 20. -- To-day began the jubilee or twenty-firth year of the pontificate of Leo XIII., but the celebrations were merely a prelude to the great functions which will take place on March 3. At noon the Pope received deputations of those concerned in organizing the different pilgrimages which will be made on the occasion of the jubilee.

BOSTON, March 2. -- George Fred Williams to-day made public a spirited defense of Senator Tillman. In it, after praising the Senator and deprecating the sweeping condemnation visited upon him, he says:

Differences which have arisen between the Bread Bakers' and Cake Bakers' Unions of Manhattan, and have given rise to much bitterness of feeling among the members of the respective organizations, were aired at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union. There are two local unions of bread bakers and one union of cake bakers in Manhattan, and all three belong to the Journeymen Bakers' International Union.

For nearly two hours last evening in the rain over 100 boys and youths fought, in the vicinity of Ninth Avenue and Fiftythird Street, with stones, sticks, paving bricks, and anything they could lay hands on. Windows were shattered, doors scarred, and passers-by got off luckily if they only had their hats smashed.

At a meeting of the Society of Arts Gen. Sir G.W.A. Higginson being in the chair, Mr. E.H. Stuart Bruce read a paper on the "Use of Balloons in War." He began by giving a short historical account of their employment in war, which he pointed out had been the stimulus to their practical invention.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 2. -- The storms and floods have caused the wrecking of the steel and granite viaduct across the ravine in which runs Rawley's Brook at the dividing line between this city and Hastings. A trolley car laden with persons had a narrow escape from plunging down with the viaduct forty-odd feet to the bottom of the ravine.

There were deep gloom and sorrow yesterday among the members of the Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church, Tompkins Avenue and McDonough Street, Brooklyn, when it became known to them that there was practically no hope that they would ever see again alive their pastor, the Rev. Dr. Robert R. Meredith, who is reported to be dying in Mexico.
One of the most prized relics of the civil war in possession of the State of Colorado is the inkstand used at Appomattox, Va., on April 9, 1865, on the occasion of Lee's surrender to Grant.

The first of the informal century cycle runs of the New York State Division of the Century Road Club of America will be held on the first Sunday in April, and this will inaugurate the formal opening of the century riding season. Ten gold medals are now on exhibition at the residence of P. A. Dyer, 270 Bridge Street, Brooklyn.
After an exceptionally rough voyage the Cunard steamship Umbria, from Liverpool, arrived yesterday none the worse for the bad weather encountered.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 2. -- Unless the situation changes materially this week, the Democratic managers are completely beaten in their carefully laid plans to make the State more solidly Democratic through the medium of the "gerrymander," and an election bill that will more effectually disfranchis the negro voters than the present law.

Dr. Louis Albert Banks spoke by way of a prelude to his sermon yesterday in the Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, One Hundred and fourth Street, on "The Appeal for Justice for the Policemen of New York City." He spoke in part an follows:

PATERSON, N.J., March 2. -- This city, so recently swept by fire, is now overwhelmed by flood. Three weeks ago the greater part of its business section was burned out and to-day the quarter occupied by the houses of the poorer class is inundated. Hundreds of families have been made homeless by the overflow of the Passaic River and the country for miles around the city is under water.
Louis Kron, Consulting Engineer of Public Buildings, states that the steel of the Seventy-first Regiment Armory which still stands is a menace to public safety and must come down.

Six representative railroad systems made public their January statements of earnings on Saturday. These were St. Paul, Louisville and Nashville, Canadian Pacific, Wabash, Big Four, and Chesapeake and Ohio; and the showing made by them is at once gratifying and significant.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 2. -- With the arrest in New York of Clinton Huffman, who is accused of forgery, the Pinkertons and Detective O'Brien of this city believe that they have secured a man with many aliases. His arrest was made on information from Lima, Ohio, where it is alleged that he forged the name of T.J. Mullen for $1,000, secured the money from the Ohio National Bank, and decamped.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 2. -- Fully 15,000 people greeted Prince Henry, who arrived here at 11:03 o'clock. Mayor Bookwaiter extended to Prince Henry a cordial welcome, addressing him as follows:

The unsuccess which has attended the efforts to popularize the metric system in Great Britain and the United States continues to be for its advocates a perennial source of surprise and regret. Its advantages have been explained so often and so fully that nothing remains to be said in favor of it; but the fact remains that it does not interest either the English or the American Nation.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., March 2. -- Telegraph and telephone communication was restored to-day for the first time since Thursday with the towns along the Southern Railway which were cut off by the recent heavy rains. Several stations on the French Broad River were carried away and the track washed out.

FOREIGN MEASURES AGAINST THE YOUNG TURKS. -- The Constantinople press is jubilant over the measures taken by France regulating the Young Turks congress within the republic. The special organ of the Porte, with an unpronounceable name, declares that the refugees "pollute by their presence the soil of the country on which they set their foot, and base and vile they will remain in this world and in the next."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 2. -- High water is playing havoc all the way up the Valley of the Genesee River. The river and all its tributaries are raging torrents, and crowds standing on the bridges and banks watch the wreckage come down stream. Horses, cows, sheep, whole sections of fences, outbuildings, logs, walls of houses, and one dead body passed over the falls.

PARIS, March 2. -- The fetes in commemoration of the centenary of Victor Hugo's birth ended to-day with the ceremony of handing over to the City of Paris, to serve as a Victor Hugo museum, the house in the Place des Vosges in which Hugo for some time lived. The weather was superb.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 2. -- Prince Henry of Prussia spent fifteen minutes in Nashville this afternoon, arriving over the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Road at 2:30 o'clock and departing over the Louisville and Nashville Road for Louisville fifteen minutes later. About ten thousand men, women, and children crowded the Union Station and yards for a sight of the royal visitor, and accorded a most cordial reception to him.
On two occasions last night the tenants of the Emerson apartment house, One Huntired and Sixteenth Street and Lenox Avenue, were thrown into a panic by a visit from a dog.

BERLIN, March 2. -- Although the reception of Prince Henry in the United States made an excellent impression on the Boerse during the last week, it did not influence values, the disposition being to await practical results therefrom. After the revival of speculation of the last few weeks, the impression gains ground that this matter has been overdone: consequently there is a tendency to take profits.

LOUISVILLE, March 2. -- Prince Henry reached Louisville at 7:45 o'clock to-night. heard an address of welcome, received an album and an engrossed address, acknowledged with repeated salutes the cheers of several thousand persons, and at 8 o'clock started for Indianapolis. The time of the Prince here was cut short at least a third by a slight accident, which prevented him from leaving his car as soon as the train stopped.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 2. -- Yesterday afternoon the French Club presented Octave Feuillet's "La Fee," ("The Fairy.") All students of French were invited, and members were allowed to bring two guests each. The club restricts its membership to the classes in junior and senior French.

The first Sunday of March, generally considered the opening of Spring by athletes, found the Harlem River oarsmen rather unprepared for its coming, and though the attendance at the boathouses yesterday afternoon was much larger than has been the case for some weeks past, the cold and rainy weather kept most of the men indoors and only the enthusiasts who row even when the ice is in the river were seen upon the water.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- The Schuylkill River is again within its banks and close to its normal condition to-night. The work of cleaning up was begun during last night, and to-day the railroads which skirt the shores of the river resumed operation. The first train out of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's city station, at Twentyfourth and Chestnut Streets, left at 7:30 o'clock this morning for the West.

It is very gratifying to every citizen who knows what the name of HORGAN SLATTERY implies that the Mayor should have delivered himself yesterday, at the meeting of the Armory Board, with such vigor and directness, about the municipal employment of that firm. The plain fact is that the name is a trade mark of municipal disrepute and jobbery.

The railroads are gradually and slowly recovering from the effects of the floods of the last few days, which were the most serious since the great floods of 1862, according to the statements of the various railroad officials.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company made public yesterday its annual report for the year ending Dec. 31. 1901. The report, so far as the finances of the company are concerned, is divided into two parts, the one for lines east and the other for lines west of Pittsburg.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- In a decision rendered in the United States Supreme Court to-day it was held that the ordinance enacted by the City Government of Detroit, Mich., arbitrarily reducing street car fares to 3 cents was irregular and without binding effect.

PATERSON, N.J., March 3 -- The waters of the Passaic are falling and gradually the streets are appearing. The city seemed stunned to-day. There was not the activity and the bustle which followed, the fire. Few of the mills turned a wheel.

At any time prior to the opening of the present session of the Legislature the prediction that the Republicans of New York would decline to renominate Gov. BENJAMIN B. ODELL would have appeared to be destitute of supporting probability. If the failure of Gov. ODELL to secure a renomination has now come within the range of discussion and probability the change must be due to the acts or omissions of the Governor himself.

BERLIN, March 3 -- The United States Navy Department has ordered a complete outfit for two stations of the wireless telegraph system of Slaby Arco from the Allgemeine Eectricitaets Gesellschaft of Berlin for the purpose of experimenting against the Marconi system.

Though dull, yesterday's market was strong -- a continuation of the recent record. Commission house transactions represented a small proportion of the 360,000 shares which made up the day's total business. The smaller professional traders of the Street, still bearish, were able to cause no declines worthy of note, due to some extent, perhaps, to the fact that such traders are already heavily short.

The report of City Superintendent of Schools MAXWELL is a document that should be read with care by all engaged or interested in the development of our schools. It gives an admirably clear and succinct account of the changes in the system produced by the amended charter and the problems that await solution under the new provisions."

PASSAIC, N.J., March 3 -- Six lives are known to have been lost in the flood last night. The old Outwater Bridge, connecting Passaic with Outwater's Lane; in Bergen County, went down, carrying with it six men whose identity is unknown. The men were standing on the bridge watching the water, when the structure parted in the middle.
The petition just forwarded to Congress by the Secretary of the Navy from citizens of the Island of Guam is a singular and interesting document in several ways.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

The property 139 Broadway Has been leased by the Washington Life Insurance Company to the Liberty National Bank, through Brokers John N. Golding and E. A. Cruikshank Co., the former representing the bank. Under the terms of the lease, which covers a term of about forty years, the insurance company will erect on the lot a two-story building for occupancy solely by the bank, and to be specially constructed with this end in view.

The many guests in the Marlborough Hotel, Broadway and Thirty-sixth Street, were alarmed early last evening by a report that there was a fire in the building. The alarm increased when partial darkness resulted from repairs to the dynamo which were going on in the cellar.
Van Houten Sherwood have been appointed Jersey City agents of the National Assurance Company of Ireland.

Interest in the outside market yesterday centred principally in the copper stocks and nearly all the issues in this group were more active than usual. Elsewhere in the list the transactions were somewhat below the average of recent days, and in few cases was the trading of a character to draw special attention.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Trains on all steam railroads leading into this city are running regardless of schedules, and street car traffic is completely at a standstill as a result of the freshet in the Hudson River. The water was 18.25 feet above the low-water mark this afternoon, and is now receding.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 3 -- The great flood, which began to recede this morning, leaves in its wake damage to the amount of about $5,000,000 in the northeastern part of the State and has swept to death about a score of persons in the same territory. This list may grow as small towns, now isolated, are heard from.

The stockholders of the New Jersey and New England Telegraph Company held their annual meeting at the Hotel Washington, in Jersey City, yesterday. George W.E. Atkins was elected President and member of the Board of Directors. The following Directors were also elected: J.B. Bertholf, Thomas F. Clark, T.T. Eckert, Jr., W.C. Humstone, J.W. Schmuls, and C.S. Shivler.

Joseph Mayer, once Albert T. Patrick's office boy, was the chief witness against his former employer yesterday at the beginning of the sixth week of Patrick's trial for the murder of William Marsh Rice. Mayer has never testified in the case before. He was subpoenaed by the prosecution at the preliminary hearing, but was not called.

ALBANY, March 3 -- When Senators Platt and Depew were about to get aboard the train which left the Grand Central Station for Albany to-day at 1 o'clock Col. Abraham Gruber, who had counted the cars attached to the train and discovered that there were just thirteen, prophesied that those who took the train would be lucky if they ever reached their destination.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 3 -- The New York Republicans in the Legislature have christened Mayor Low's bill to give the Board of Estimate and Apportionment the power to reclassify places in the city service and fix salaries, "The Ripper Bill." Chairman Otto Kelsey of the Assembly Cities Committee, who refused last week to introduce the bill until he had been further enlightened about it, said to-night that he would not stand sponsor for the measure.

BERLIN, March 3 -- Emperor William today received Prof. Kuno Francke of Harvard University. His Majesty questioned the professor on the subject, of the Germanic Museum at Harvard, in which the Emperor showed the liveliest interest.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 3 -- Not since 1865 has this city experienced such a flood as came last night, and the water has increased all day. Streets that were flooded last night are now buried. The water bubbles through the pavements and makes its way unobstructed into stores on both sides.

MANILA, March 3 -- Twenty-five members of the Constabulary of Moron, ten miles from Manila, encountered eighty well-armed insurgents to-day. The former, after expending all their ammunition, fled. Eleven of the constabulary are unaccounted for, and it is believed they were either killed or captured.

Before Judge McMahon in Part I. of General Sessions yesterday morning the March Grand Jury was sworn in. Judge McMahon read from the Criminal Code the rights and duties of the jurymen, but made no specific reference to any case that might be brought before the March jury.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- All interest centred upon three stocks in the Philadelphia market to-day -- namely: Union Traction, Philadelphia Company, and Consolidated Lake Superior, the latter displaying greater strength than anything in the list, the common rising 1 and the preferred 1L. points, but Union Traction supplanted all others in point of activity.

Many matters of local rowing interest were discussed and decided last night at the annual meeting of the Harlem Regatta Association, which was held at the Pabst, West. One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street. All of the leading clubs were represented, the delegates being E.J. Keene, New York Athletic Club; C.M. De La Vergne and Fred Vilmar.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Commissioners of the District of Columbia are making a strenuous effort to secure an amendment to the Constitution through which a change would be made in the date of the inauguration of the President. They have received favorable replies from the Governors of thirty States to letters asking them to serve on a National committee, which will urge Congress to adopt the proposed Constitutional amendment this session.

LONDON, March 3 -- A telegram from Queenstown received here at 7:35 P.M. says that, while many inquiries have been made regarding the non-arrival of the Cunard liner Etruria (from New York, for Queenstown and Liverpool, Feb. 22,) which at that time was about sixty hours overdue, no anxiety was manifested as to her safety.

There seems, to lie a general movement toward Southern California. A number of parties are being formed, and the long journey under the present conditions does not daunt travelers in the last. Mr. and Mrs. Louis Lorillard are going there in a few days. Mr. and Mrs. James A. Burden, Jr., have been there for the past two weeks, and several parties left last week.

Superintendent Ferez M. Stewart of the Bureau of Buildings has formed a plan for the establishment of a Bureau of Public Safety in his department, in which fifty Inspectors are to be employed to examine hotels, theatres, department stores, and other places where large crowds of people assemble, the Superintendent will ask the Board of Estimate for an appropriation of $50,000 a year for this purpose.

BERLIN, March 3 -- In the Reichstag today Herr Hasse, (Liberal,) referring to the visit of Prince Henry to the United States, said he was glad to see that it had frustrated the designs of Great Britain against a German-American understanding, but that the German element in the United States was a power which would not and should not build up a state within a state.

ALBANY, March 3 -- There was a second conference to-day between members of the State Board of Charities and the Committee of Five appointed by the Republican legislative conference. The members of the State Board presented alternative propositions to those embraced in the tentative bill put forward by the Commitee of Five.

LONDON, March 4 -- In a dispatch from Pretoria, dated yesterday, Lord Kitchener sends details of the disaster to the escort of the convoy of empty wagons southwest of Klerksdorp. The British casualties, in killed, wounded, and men made prisoners, totaled 632. In addition, the Boers captured two guns.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 3 -- H.B. Kenwick of New York has sub-rented the Leroy King cottage, in Bellevue Avenue, which Dr. Austin Flint, Jr., of New York had previously leased for the coming Summer. Dr. Flint will occupy the Paran Stevens cottage, in Berkeley Avenue, which he recently purchased and which he is remodeling and extensively improving.

LONDON, March 4 -- Dr. Morrison, the Peking correspondent of The Times, says that evidently the British-Japanese agreement, by giving a respite to China, has greatly strengthened the confidence with which the Chinese Government can treat foreign questions. Knowing that an extension of Germany's rights in Shan-Tung is disapproved by Great Britain, Japan, and the United States, the Chinese Government is stiffening its back against granting such an extension.

Bridge Commissioner Lindenthal yesterday gave out the details of a plan to provide adequate facilities for interborough passenger traffic between Manhattan and Brooklyn. Among the features of the plan is one providing for the erection of a sixteen-story office building for the use of all city departments on the site of the StaatsZeitung Building.

John H. Wisker pleaded "not guilty" to manslaughter in the second degree yesterday before Judge McMahon, in Part I, of General Sessions. The February Grand Jury returned the indictment against him. He was the engineer of the White Plains local train which crashed into the rear of the New Rochelle train in the New York Central tunnel on Jan. 8, when many were killed and many others wounded.
Contract Surgeon Robert L. Richards will report in person to the Commanding General, Department of California, for transportation to the Philippine Islands.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Senate to-day began consideration of the ship subsidy bill, a measure to provide for ocean mail, service between the United States and foreign ports, and for the common defense, and to promote commerce and encourage deep sea fisheries. Mr. Frye, (Maine,) Chairman of the Committed on Commerce, made the opening statements in support of the bill.
PROCTOR'S NEWARK -- "The Beaux and Belles. Octette" is the feature.

BOSTON, March 3 -- The money situation still continues surprisingly easy, and, despite the expressed fears in some quarters of hardening rates in the future, there are as yet no signs in sight of any change. Money rates, bank clearances, balances, and foreign exchange rates are reported today as below: Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent.

ROME, March 3 -- The principal ceremony in connection with the jubilee in honor of the twenty-fourth anniversary of the Pope's coronation -- the holding of the "Papal Chapel" -- took place in the Basilica of St. Peter's this morning with extraordinary pomp. The Pontiff was present, and there was an assemblage estimated to number fully 50,000 persons.

The storm of the past week is probably not unprecedented, but being more destructive over a much wider area than any storm of recent years, and operating to delay or suspend intercommunication along many important lines of travel, it stands alone in the recollection of the present generation as characterized by the maximum of destructiveness.

LONDON, March 4 -- A Blue Book, containing dispatches and reports regarding the Remount Department in South Africa, which was issued last night, is considered the strongest indictment of its own incapacity yet issued by the War Office, and as going far to explain to the public the reasons why the war in South Africa has been so unduly protracted.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- A glare of red fire that could be seen for miles, the blaze of hundreds of torches, the sparkle of myriads of electric lights, and the cheers of thousands of people made up the first display of Chicago's hospitality to Prince Henry of Prussia upon his arrival this evening.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 3 -- Prince Henry stopped in St. Louis nearly four hours this morning, and during that time he was kept busy following out the programme prepared for his entertainment by the local committee. From the time he entered the Union Station until his departure for Chicago he received a continuous ovation.

The annual meeting of the Road Drivers' Association of New York was held at the Rossmore Hotel last evening. There was a large number of members present, and the meeting was a spirited one from the beginning to the end.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday refused absolutely to talk on the excise question and the administration of the law in regard to Sunday closing. It was, however, learned that with the aid of Police Commissioner Partridge and the Society for the Prevention of Crime, headed by Dr. Parkhurst, a great amount of evidence has been obtained to be used when it has been agreed that the proper time for action has come.

We are sorry to say that the plan of bridge relief to which Commissioner LINBENTHAL committed himself in his communication to the public on Monday, and in his address before the Brooklyn Committee of Fifty on Monday evening, will be a disappointment to most of those who take the trouble to examine it critically.

Thomas P. Costigan, Clerk of the Eighth District Municipal Court and formerly prominent in municipal politics, died last evening at his home, 415 West Thirty-fourth Street. Death resulted from Bright's disease.

ALBANY, March 4. -- There apepars to be no indication of a truce between the Governor and those who oppose his policy with regard to the judiciary. To-day Senator Elsberg introduced a bill which is understood to represent the views of the members of the bar in New York County who do not approve of the Governor's attempt to secure the power of designation of Supreme Court Judges.

NORFOLK, Va., March 4. -- A mob of 5,000 strike sympathizers to-day thronged the Norfolk streets on which runs the main line of the Norfolk Railway and Light Company, and defied the efforts of the police to keep order. From noon until after dark, when the cars were housed in the barns, the rioters had things their own way in the city.

Corporation Counsel Hives received late yesterday afternoon a telegram announcing a decision of the Court of Appeals in favor of the city. The saving to the taxpayers will amount to hundreds of thousands of dollars, and the Corporation Counsel said that it was one of the most important decisions in the city's interests rendered in some time.

Several important facts were brought out yesterday at the inquest before Coroner Goldenkranz into the Park Avenue Hotel fire of Feb. 22, which resulted in the loss of twenty-one lives. The most important testimony on each phase, of the subject was given by the firemen themselves, including Chief Crokeer.

LONDON, March 4. -- The money conditions were somewhat easier to-day and the supplies were larger. Discounts were quiet. Stagnation and irregularity of business prevailed at the Stock Exchange. The tendency in some directions was to recover. First-class securities were easier. Home rails were inclined to slip back.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Gov. Odell to-day received a telegram from Gen. Tracy informing him that he had been retained us counsel for Sheriff Guden and asking that the Guden case be reopened. The Governor replied that he would not reopen the case.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- A musicale was given in the East Room of the White House this evening, at which 300 guests, mostly personal friends of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, were entertained. The artists of the evening were Mrs. Leila Livingston Morse, soprano, and Mr. Heinrich Meyer, baritone, with Miss Hauser and Isidore Luckstone at the piano.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- Delegates from eight of the leading motor vehicle organizations of the East and the West at the Coliseum to-day, completed the formation of a National body to be called the American Automobile Association. The organization will be governed by a Board of Directors, composed of the President, First Vice President, and Treasurer, ex-officio, with the seven other Directors.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., March 4. -- It was a race with death and death won. One of the Jersey Central's fastest engines with a passenger coach attached left here at 10:45 o'clock last night for New York. The train was chartered by Robert Sternbach, and it carried a messenger, who was sent to summon his brother, Sidney Sternbach, of 27 East Seventy-sevsuta Street, to the dying bed of his mother, Mrs. L. Sternbach.

The Hamburg-American liner Beutschland, on board of which Prince Henry will sail for Germany next Tuesday afternoon, arrived in port after a tempestuous passage yesterday morning. In spite of the rough weather encountered the steamship crossed the Sandy Hook Bar only six hours and thirteen minutes behind her record passage for the westward voyage, her time being five days twenty-two hours and thirty-six minutes.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Assemblyman McKeown of Kings County to-day introduced two bills which were drawn up by Corporation Counsel George L. Rives at the suggestion of Controller Grout. The bills relate to the offices of the Sheriff, County Clerk, and Register in Kings County. At the last session of the Legislature there was a bill passed making these three offices salaried instead of fee offices.

Tuesday is rather an off day in society -- at least during Lent. There were the usual small entertainments. To-day, there will be the Knickerbocker Bowling Club, and the opera at night. Among the more notable affairs of yesterday were a card party at Mrs. J. Muhlenberg Bailey's, in the afternoon, and the reception given by Miss Leary.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., March 4. -- The strength of the boycott sentiment against the street railway company, whose trainmen are now in the seventh week of their strike for recognition of organized labor, is indicated by the action of eighty pupils at Seeleyville, on the suburban line, who took their books and left school because two teachers rode oil the cars.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Mayor Low's bill granting to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment increased powers with regard to the pay and appointment of city employes, was amended to-day as a result of a conference held between Gov. Odell, Chairman Robert C. Morris of the Republican County Committee, and Assistant Corporation Counsel Whitman.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Assemblyman Fowler has introduced a bill which provides that before an electric railway can be extended, the consent of the Railroad Commission must be secured. At present there is no restriction upon an elevated road have in a franchise in a city extending its line as far into the country as it may desire.

ALBANY, N. Y., March 4. -- The memory of the late President, William McKinley, was appropriately honored by the Legislature of the State to-night. The exercises were held in the Assembly chamber, and were presided over by Gov. Odell.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Not much importance attaches, in the minds of Senators, to the decision of the sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals to report that it finds the Panama Canal Company unable to give clear title to its Colombian properties. No-other report was expected from this sub-committee; in fact, the general belief is that the committee was made up with the distinct purpose that it should find against the Panama route.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Kearsarge, Alabama, Massachusetts, and Indiana sailed March 3 from Cienfuesos for Colon.

The will of Louis C. Behman of the Hyde Behman Amusement Company, whose death occurred on Thursday last, was filed for probate yesterday in the office of the Surrogate of Kings County. The estate consists for the most part of Mr. Behman's theatrical properties and rights in the theatres controlled by the Hyde Behman Company.

A correspondent renewed, in Monday's TIMES, the suggestion we made editorially some weeks ago, that a commission like that which has been proposing a plan for the embellishment of Washington should be employed to render a like service for New York. In either case, the brilliant success of the scheme for the National capital made the suggestion obvious; we may add that it made almost equally obvious the proper personnel of the commission.
Assistant District Attorney Osborne win rest the State's case against Albert T. Patrick, charged with murdering Millionaire William Marsh Rice, to-day.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 4. -- The market encountered several adverse rumors from the General Assembly to-day, which threw the sentiment into semi-confusion. The favorable report of the six tickets for a quarter bill when the friends of the United Railways anticipated its curly defeat, and the introduction of an unexpected bill to reduce the price of gas from $1.10 to 90 cents, caused uneasiness among the holders of the securities concerned.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 4. -- A number of millmen, members of the Southern Hosiery Yarn Spinners' Association, met here to-day informally to discuss the hosiery yarn market. About 245,000 spindles were represented.

Justice Clarke, in a decision handed down in the Supreme Court yesterday, held that by the provision of the Constitution of the State and by the statutes of the State, betting and gaming on race horses is forbidden "no less on race tracks than in poolrooms, though the penalty therefor prescribed is different for a violation in one place than in the other."

NEW ORLEANS, March 4. -- A series of mishaps occurred in the hurdle race to-day. Carlovingian bolted over the outside fence at the third jump, broke his leg, and was shot. Torreon tripped over a dog as he rounded the far turn and fell. J. Weber, who had the mount, broke a collar bone. Robert Morrison fell at the fourth jump, but escaped serious injury. Intrusive and Van Hoorebeke were the winning favorites.

WILWAUKEE, Wis., March 4. -- Milwaukee was host to Prince Henry of Prussiafur six hours this evening and gave him a reception that was highly enthusiastic and an entertainment that was unique. His special train came at 4 o'clock and at 10 o'clock was away again on the Long run to Niagara and New England.

"You women! What are you?" says one of the peasant characters in Tolstoi's "Die Macht der Finsterniss," played last night at Conried's Irving Place Theatre for the first time in America. "We men work and learn things in the world. We become artisans, shopkeepers, soldiers. But you are a herd of silly beasts driven here and there in your ignorance by instincts you don't understand."
ALBION, N. Y., March 4. -- At the charter election to-day the Democrats elected Judge Ramsdale as Trustee, and all other candidates but one.

The Senate enters this week on the final discussion of the Ship Subsidy bill at the moment that the announcement is made in London that the practical consolidation of Atlantic lines is about completed.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- The Chicago which Prince Henry of Prussia saw last night by the glare of many lights was presented to him to-day by the clearer light of the sun. The welcome which he received last night was repeated and emphasized, and he had further opportunity to enjoy his expressed desire to meet American citizens at close range.

The will of Charles Broadway Rouss was filed for probate yesterday in the office of the Surrogate, where it had been left for safekeeping on March 21, 1898. The will, which was executed on March 17, 1898, was turned over to Surrogate's Clerk Washburn, and yesterday he broke the seal, and the will was officially filed.

BERLIN, March 4. -- Emperor William, instead of being displeased with the cablegram from Miss Alice Roosevelt concerning the launching of the Meteor because of its familiar tone, as some of the English newspapers assert, was, on the contrary, very much pleased with it. A member of the Cabinet relates that, after an audience with the Emperor on Feb. 26, he was about to retire when the Kaiser said:

Mayor Low sent a message to the Board of Aldermen yesterday, in which he made a statement of the city's financial condition and dealt with many of the questions that are before the present municipal administration.

Dr. Lyman Abbott, previous to his departure for an extended vacation abroad, was the guest of honor at a dinner of the Aldine Association, given in its clubrooms. 111 Fifth Avenue, last night. To do honor to Dr. Abbott, in addition to the hundred or more members of the association, there was present a notable gathering of clergymen and laymen.

The Board of Aldermen held a stormy session yesterday. One member made an appeal to President Fornes to restore order and prevent "Tillmanism" on the floor of the board. Aldermen Downing and Stewart denounced each other. The first named shook his fists in the air and called his fellow-member" a despicable spirit," adding "He is no gentleman, and I denounce him for what he has done."

BOSTON, Mass., March 4. -- Rates all around are unchanged, and money still appeal's to be in abundant supply. Sterling exchange is inclined to work easier. Money rates, bank clearances, balances, and foreign exchange rates are reported to-day as below: Clearing House rate, 21/2 per cent. New York funds, 13 1/2 and 15 cents discount.
LIVERPOOL, March 4. -- The Etruria will possibly reach the Azores to-night or tomorrow morning.

It is not to be expected that the residents of the West End will have the sympathy of anybody but themselves in their grievances against the Commissioner of Street Cleaning. Certainly they will not have when the facts are understood. The same annoyance that Dr. WOODBURY finds Col. WARING found in his day.

--Whatever other New Yorkers may think of the Grand Jury's determination to hold the engineer, WISKER, responsible for the collision in the New York Central tunnel, and to let the railway officials off without even a reprimand, the chances are that the Coroners received the decision with a composure that concealed a good deal of satisfaction.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Republican leaders in the House are tremendously worried over the Cuban question. They are just beginning to realize what was pointed out by Senators Proctor, Gallinger, and Platt in interviews published in THE NEW YORK TIMES weeks ago, that the beet sugar men are damaging the cause of protection, undermining the tariff, and imperiling the Republican Party.

It is reported from Washington that President ROOSEVELT has warned Mr. RIDGELY, the Controller of the Currency, that he must abate his activity in the factional struggle in Illinois over the election of a United States Senator in the place of Mr. MASON, and that one of his nominees for Internal Revenue Collector has declined the place because the condition was imposed that he must not take part in the same contest.
E. S. Willard has sold for Mitchell A. C. Levy to G.B. Bounce 11 and 13 East Thirty-second Street, 50 by 100. It is understood that a twelve-story apartment hotel will be erected on the site.

Passengers struggling to board an elevated railroad train at the Rector Street station shortly after 5 P. M. yesterday saw an old man in the thickest part of the throng, who was getting more than his share of jostling, suddenly grow purple in the face, throw up his hands, and sink to the platform.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Senator Platt to-day expressed the opinion that Gov. Odell would be renominated. He said there was no one else in sight. The Senator made this remark to one of his trusted lieutenants in the Senate.

ALBANY, March 5. -- State Superintendent of Elections John McCullagh in his annual report, transmitted to the Legislature to-day, says that the most flagrant violations of the law at the primary election of 1901 were in the Second, Seventh, and Thirty-second Assembly Districts in New York County.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5. -- With the exception of the extreme southeastern section of the State the entire Commonwealth of Pennsylvania to-night is in the grasp of the heaviest snowstorm of the Winter. Railroad travel is practically tied up in many places, and the indications for to-morrow are not encouraging.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were small, and for the most part prices showed a downward tendency. Few or no net gains of any consequence resulted from the day's trading, and while the losses were in few cases not at all large, the falling off in prices was more marked than on any recent day.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Gen. Hughes to-day told the Senate Committee on the Philippines that the Filipino forces would have been of but little assistance if it had been necessary to capture Manila from the Spaniards by assault.

BERLIN, March 5. -- Relief is felt here that the journey of Prince Henry through the United States is now drawing to a close without any untoward incident, for, notwithstanding Emperor William's entire confidence as to the safety of the Prince, others in authority have had misgivings that some Polish fanatic in Chicago, wrought up over the conflicts and national feeling in Polish Prussia, might attempt something violent.

Senator PLATT to-day expressed the opinion that Gov. ODELL would be renominated. He said there was no one else in sight. The Senator made this remark to one of his trusted lieutenants in the Senate. -- Albany dispatch to THE TIMES of yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Clark Baker, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Baker, to Henry Greenway Kemp took place to-day at noon at the home of the bride's parents, 1,891 H Street, in the presence of a small company of relatives and close personal friends, and was followed by a breakfast, at which 100 additional guests were present, including the young friends of the bride and bridegroom.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 5. -- The victories of Cambaceres and Duke of York II., two 30 to 1 shots, were among the features of the racing at Oakland to-day. Bozeman and Frawley, who have not figured conspicuously this season, had mounts on them. Cambaceres won by four lengths from Golden Light, who did not get away well.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The beet sugar men continue to profess confidence that they will be strong enough to-morrow night in the conference of Republican members of the House to defeat the Ways and Means Committee's Cuban tariff concession project.

The conferences which have been going on for the last ten days between representatives of the American Tin Plate Company and a delegation of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers, headed by President Theodore T. Shaffer, resulted in an agreement being reached yesterday. The conferences were held in the offices of the American Tin Plate Company, 24 State Street, and lasted until late last evening.

LONDON, March 6. -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times calls attention to a new book by Prof. Ernst Halle, called "Volks und See-wirthschaft." It contains, says the correspondent, an unblushing statement of Germany's intention to absorb Holland, first economically and then politically.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5. -- There was a slight falling off in prices in most of the local list to-day. Exceptions were Pennsylvania Railroad and Consolidated Lake Superior. Most of the day the market centred in the Readings, the whole group declining with the heaviness in Wall Street. Union Traction was lower, on a resumption of liquidation, but met support at 39 1/2, at which price it closed.

PRINCETON, N.J, March 5. -- The management of the university gymnastic team has just about completed the plans for an Easter trip, the extent of which is much greater than any heretofore attempted. It is expected to leave here at the beginning of Easter vacation and tour the New England States for a week and a half, giving exhibitions at Providence, Springfield, Worcester, Bangor, Portland, and St. John's N.F.

Mr. JEROME evidently has not yet acquired that thickness and toughness of skin which conduce so much to the comfort of the incumbent of an office so conspicuous as his. He seems to consider that his fellow-citizens have lost confidence in him since election. We think we can assure him that they have the same regard and respect for him which induced them to elect him at the top of the Fusion ticket.

NEWARK, N.J., March 5. -- There is a serious shortage in the supply of beef and mutton and other meats here owing to washouts on the railroads between Buffalo and Scranton. Cars shipped here from the West have been stalled along the line since Saturday and few of the local beef men have received consignments since that day.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 5. -- There was a sudden adjournment of the courts here to-day in consequence of the discovery of a case of smallpox in the jail. The case is a serious one, and it appears to be certain that the man must have contracted the disease while confined in the prison.

HELENA, Mont., March 5. -- The thriving town of Twin Bridges, Madison County, was nearly destroyed by an incendiary fire which was started at 4 o'clock this morning on West Main Street. The flames spread from one business place to another, as the town is without proper fire protection. The citizens finally rallied and managed to check the progress of the flames. The loss was about $15,000, with little insurance.

In spite of the inclement weather last evening almost every seat in Carnegie Hall was filled at the meeting called under the auspices of the Armstrong Association in the interest of the Hampton Institute of Virginia and the Tuskegee Institute of Alabama. These institutions are similar in character and have for their object the education of colored children, especially along industrial lines, and both are supported largely by voluntary contributions from the Northern States.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 5. -- Prince Henry of Prussia traveled from Chicago to Niagara Falls to-day, crossed the Canadian frontier for a brief stay, and was welcomed officially by the Dominion, and to-night resumed his journey to Boston over the New York Central Railroad. His longest stop in almost thirty hours of continuous traveling was at Niagara Falls, which he saw bridged with ice.

DETROIT, Mich., March 5. -- The schedule for the coming season of the American Baseball League was adopted to-day at the first day's session of the delegates. When the subject of expansion of the American League or a change in the circuit was mentioned to President Ban Johnson, he said:

LONDON, March 5. -- The indications today pointed to easier money. The market was paying off loans to the Bank of England, supplies were more plentiful, and discounts were sympathetically easier. Business on the Stock Exchange began quiet, with prices fairly steady. The money indications favored high-class securities.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 5. -- Fully 20,000 people crowded the train shed and station of the New York Central and additional thousands lined the tracks for blocks east and west when at 8:25 the arrival of Prince Henry's special train at the city line was announced by the firing of a bomb at the end of the train house.

There was a conference yesterday in the office of the District Attorney between Mr. Jerome and Superintendent McClintock of the Society for the Suppression of Crime. The proposed wholesale raid of disreputable Raines law hotels was discussed. The District Attorney and Superintendent McClintock refused to say what decision they had reached.

BOSTON, Mass., March 5. -- Money was marked up at the Clearing House to 3 per cent, for a few loans, and there, was a lessened inclination among the banks and outside lenders to let out money at currently quoted rates. Sterling exchange still holds firm. New York funds, 3 cents discount and par. Call loans, 3 1/2 to 4 per cent. Time money, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

BOSTON, March 5. -- With Prince Henry almost knocking at the door the people of Boston to-night viewed a howling north-east, snowstorm with anything but equanimity, for should the Prince's train be delayed for even an hour in its arrival here a most elaborate programme for the entertainment of the royal visitor will be seriously disarranged.

NEW ORLEANS, March 5. -- Falella, Bill Nixon, and Felix Bard were the winning favorites to-day. In a breakaway before the first race, Anna Handspring bolted through the inside fence, cutting her shoulder badly. She was then withdrawn. Bill Nixon scored very easily in the Premier Stakes, worth $1,120 to the winner.
The prosecution's case against Albert T. Patrick, charged with murdering millionaire William Marsh Rice, was rested by Assistant District Attorney Osborne yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, March 5. -- The new State Charities, bill was introduced in the Senate and Assembly to-day. The only material change which the enactment of the bill will make in the existing system will be to transfer the supervision of the finances of State institutions from the Controller's office to a new official, who is to be known as "Fiscal Agent," and who is to receive a salary of $4,000 a year.

ALBANY, March 5. -- When Senator Platt came to Albany the question on the lips of all of the Republican politicians was, Is Odell to have a renomination? This question was answered by Senator Platt, who informed one of his lieutenants in the Senate that Odell would be renominated. The phrase which the Senator is said to have used in connection with his prediction of Odell's renomination was, "There is no one else in sight."

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- It is understood the Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals will meet Monday to take final action on the question of the route of the proposed Isthmian Canal. There is no doubt as to what the action of the committee will be. Four members of the committee want the canal built on the Panama route, provided the President can secure good title to the Panama Company's properties and sufficient concessions from Colombia.

For five hours yesterday evening a balky horse blocked the traffic about the corner of the Imperial Hotel, at Thirty-second Street and Broadway, and finally, when he did conclude to move on, he was unable to budge, because his feet had frozen to the pavement. They were pried loose with a crowbar.

In yesterday's stock market the declines of Tuesday were recovered and net gains scored -- worry over gold export engagements having intelligently waned. The sober sense of Wall Street concludes to accept the conservative views of bankers that money market conditions are not threatened in preference to the dreary predictions of explosive speculators short of stocks.

Henry Fink, President of the Norfolk and Western Railway since 1896, and identified with it for a much longer time, has resigned from the Presidency to become Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors. He says that the reason for the change is his age, and his intention of withdrawing from business gradually.

John Peirce, who has the contract for the stone work of the Hall of Records, at Centre and Chambers Streets, will before the end of the week have in place one of the monster granite pillars which will form part of the facade of the structure. There will be thirty-two pillars, eight of twenty tons of 2,200 pounds each, eight of twenty-eight tons, eight of thirty-two tons, and eight of forty tons.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., March 5. -- The coal barge Cardenas, Capt. Raymond and crew of four, arrived in port this morning in tow of the tug Cuba, after being adrift for twenty-nine days, encountering five stiff gales and surviving every peril, to be picked up at 3 o'clock last Monday afternoon by the same tug from which she parted company one month before.

Exactly what was to be expected is what has happened. The Mayor has found himself compelled, to appeal to the Legislature to restrict the powers of the Board of Aldermen and to prevent that body from meddling with and marring the municipal administration. This was the Mayor's clear duty.

Perhaps we ought to be reassured and satisfied by the statement of Count VON BUELOW that the aims of Germany in China are not at all territorial, but strictly commercial. We observe that some journals accept this assurance as covering the whole question. We wish we could, But the context of the speech indicates that that is not quite the correct view.
LONDON, March 5. -- Lord Avebury (Sir John Lubbock) presided to-night at the banquet here of the Associated Chambers of Commerce of the United Kingdom.

ALBANY, March 5. -- Encouraged by the apparent strong sentiment in the Assembly in favor of the Dooling bill to permit amateur boxing. Assemblyman Manee to-day put in a bill to take care of the professionals. Mr. Manee's bill provides for the licensing of incorporated boxing clubs and for the supervision of exhibitions by a State Commissioner.
Once more, after a short respite, the city is blanketed in snow and slush, due to a storm that was a gale, a snow blizzard, a torrent of sleet, and a deluge of rain all in one.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 5. -- The heaviest snow of the season fell yesterday afternoon and last night in the eastern, southeastern, and central portions of the State, the fall reaching four to ten inches.

Senate Document No. 171 contains "correspondence relating to the Philippine customs tariff." On Page 248 is a letter from the "International Paper Company, per T.W. SPICER, Manager Export News Division." It is addressed to the Hon. R.L. EDWARDS, Chief Bureau Insular Affairs, and was written a year ago.

The second evening of the last week of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which was last evening, was devoted, to the third performance of "La Fille du Regiment." and the fourth of "Cavalleria Rusticana." The former was made delightful by the presence of Mme. Sembrieh as Marie, while in the latter Mme.

The old Jaffray store, at the northeast corner of Broadway and Leonard Street, has been sold, through William A. White Sons, to Louis N. Jones, for about $650,000. The buyer gives in part payment other property valued at $350,000, the exact location of which could not be learned yesterday. Mr. Jones, who is a builder, will erect on the Broadway and Leonard Street corner a store-and-loft structure.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25 cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
HAVANA, March 5. -- Gen. Wood says that the statement made by the beet sugar interests that the Cuban sugar crop of this year has been bought up by the sugar combination is without foundation.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Senator Clark of Montana has been brought suddenly to the front in politics, not only by the discovery that he is extremely likely to be the manager of the Congressional campaign this Fall, but by the fact that he has been suggested as the next Democratic candidate for President.

Indians Canadian trappers, Adirondack camps, and a man giving an imitation of duck shooting from decoys were among the attractive features last night at the Sportsmen's Show, which was opened during the day in Madison Square Garden. The exhibit will continue for two weeks, and besides the regular exhibits of the sportsmen's craft, there will be, beginning today, daily competitions in fly casting, canoe races, rifle and revolver shooting.

Controller Grout is making an investigation of the Horgan Slattery contracts. He has up to the present time examined carefully into the contract which the Tammany architects obtained through the efforts of Mayor Van Wyek to complete the new Hall of Records. Corporation Counsel Rives has decided that this contract is binding on the city.

William J. Bryan was the guest of honor at a smoker of the New York Press Club last night, and made a short speech, in which he contrasted his experiences as a candidate for the Presidency and his present work as editor of The Commoner. He referred to New York as "the centre of money and perhaps of some other things."

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The suggestion that the Ship Subsidy bill may fail to pass the House this session does not accord with the expectation of persons assumed to be well informed as to the legislative programme. Nor does it accord with the expectations of the promoters of the measure, who say they have no doubt the bill will be acceptable to the House.

ALBANY, March 6. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee to-day presented its report on the question of suppressing anarchism. The report calls attention to the fact that immigration laws have allowed an undesirable class of persons to come into this country, who misunderstand Its institutions and know nothing about its form of government. The report continues:

Gov. ODELL is to be congratulated on the fact that he has succeeded in devising a series of changes in his bill relating to the State Charities which make it, on the whole, acceptable to the members of the commission and meet practically all the objections to the original bill.

"As an American citizen," said Henry J. Duveen of Duveen Brothers yesterday, speaking of the purchase by his firm of the Fames A. Garland collection of Chinese porcelains which was loaned to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1895, "I should have liked to have seen the Garland collection remain in America.

TRENTON. N.J., March 6. -- Ex-Mayor Frank A Magowan was arrested here at noon to-day as a fugitive from justice, and was locked up at the Central Police Sta tion, pending the arrival of extradition papers to take him to Philadelphia, where he is indicted for obtaining money under false pretenses. The amount involved is about $14,OOO.

The monthly meeting of the Baptist Social Union took place at Delmonico's last night, about 100 members being present. Frank Moss, the principal speaker of the evening, was introduced by George Leask, the presiding officer. Mr. Moss stated that it would be a mistake to encourage indiscriminate criticism of the present municipal administration.

LIVERPOOL, March 7. -- Fifty-three of the passengers and crew of the Waesland arrived at Liverpool on board the Harmonides at 3:33 o'clock this morning. They were received by the agents of the American Line here, and were quartered at various hotels.

In point of entertainment Thursday is about the gavest day of the Lenten week. Yesterday there were the sewing classes, notably that of the Post-Graduate Hospital, which met at Mrs. Ludlow's; the Thursday Evening Club, which had a meeting at the residence of Mrs. William Jay Schleffelin, and the Junior Thursday Evening Club met at the home of Mrs. B.S. Church.

ALBANY, March 6. -- Gov. Odell said tonight that the Stranahan Excise bill, introduced at the request of the Excise Department, was dead, and that there would be no excise legislation of any character at this session of the Legislature. This means that the Bennet bills, relating to local option and the Raines law hotel in New York, are also to be interred.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Gen. Hughes to-day gave further testimony before the Senate Philippine Commission. Senator Patterson resumed the questioning which yesterday led to a sharp colloquy in the committee room between the witness and himsell. He again inquired as to the motive of Gen. Otis in requiring the withdrawal of Aguinaldo's troops from Manila to the line designated by Gen. Merritt.

MANILA. March 6. -- A court-martial has been ordered to try Major Littleton W. T. Waller and Lieut. John H.A. Day of the Marine Corps on March 17 next, on the charge of executing natives of the Island of Samar without trial.

PITTSBURG, March 6. -- The second day of the bench show of the Duquesne Kennel Club was one of great interest to the many dog fanciers in attendance. The signal victory of the day was achieved by T. E. Orr of Pittsburgh in capturing the Duquesne stakes in the collie class. This is the largest cash premium of the show, and had twenty-six competitors.

DETROIT, March 6. -- The American Baseball League owners at their last session this afternoon adopted the changes in the playing rules recommended by the Buffalo conference of last month, with the exception of the foul strike rule, which will be played in the American League the same as it was last year.

By the time our royal visitor has finished his American tout and started for home he will be ready to lock his stateroom door with Instruction that he is not to be called for a week. He is having an experience in the American habit of "hustle" which is not only new to him, but distinctly antithetical to the German temperament.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 6. -- The thirteenth annual open handicap games of Princeton University will be held here on April 19. The programme will consist of 100, 200, and 440 yard dashes, half-mile, one-mile, and two-mile runs, hurdles, pole vault, shot put, hammer throw, running high jump, and running broad jump.
The Indianapolis Board of Fire Underwriters has elected these officers to serve during the coming year: President -- F.H. Gregory; Vice President -- F.F. McCree; Secretary -- J.J. Reilly.

Under a ten-year lease the New York Realty Corporation will erect a four-story building, covering the two lots, 50 by 100, on the west side of Fifth Avenue, 50 feet south of Forty-fifth Street. Who the prospective tenants of the property are could not be learned yesterday, but it is said that the concern is one now doing business further south on Fifth Avenue.
MONTE CARLO, March 6. -- The nineteenth round of the international chessmasters' tournament was played to-day according to Round 4 of the Berger schedule, the players being paired as follows:

Sunday liquor selling In New York will be the subject of Increased interest next Tuesday. On that day the several excise bills offered in the State Senate and Assembly will be called before the Assembly Committee on Excise and the Senate Committee on Taxation for a hearing, and there will be a meeting of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, headed by Dr. Parkhurst.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Mrs. L.E. Leiter was hostess at a dinner party this evening in honor of the English guests now visiting in Washington, Lord Grey, the guest of Mr. and Mrs. George Westinghouse, and brother-in-law of the Governor General of Canada: Mr. and Mrs. Moreton Frewen, guests of the British Ambassador and Lady Pauncefote, and Mrs. Moncrief of Liverpool.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6. -- Clarence Mackay and Lawrence Waterbury of the New York Tennis and Racquet Club defeated Barclay H. Warburton and Edgar G. Scott of the Philadelphia Racquet Club in four straight games in the second round of the amateur double championship series played here to-day.

Hoboken had a novel policy case yesterday. Two detectives arrested the alleged proprietor and one of them then received plays, after which he placed the players under arrest. Several days ago Edward W. Martin, who owns the house 60 Second Street, informed Detective Sergeant Julius Nelson that he had reason to believe that John Eysel, to whom he rented the ground floor for a barber's shop, was also running a policy shop in the place.

BOSTON, Mass., March 6. -- The money market is showing a slightly firmer tone, and lenders are now very generally marking up rates, particularly on call loans, and borrowers are now in some cases paying as high as 4 per cent. Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds. 8 and 10 cents discount.

ALBANY, March 6. -- All arrangements for the reception of Prince Henry of Prussia on his arrival here to-morrow have been completed by the committees representing the Senate and Assembly and the municipal authorities. The Prince's train will arrive about 8 o'clock, and he will be greeted at the station by Gov. Odell, Adjt. Gen. Henry, and the Senate and Assembly committees.

ALBANY, March 6. -- A large delegation from New York appeared before the Assembly Cities Committee to-day to argue in favor of the passage of the Three-Platoon Police bill introduced by Mr. Uhlmann. Police Commissioner Partridge and the city authorities of New York are opposing the passage of the bill.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 6. -- The date for the fencing match between three men of the Washington Fencers' Club and three of the Naval Cadet Fencers has been set for Friday night, March 21. The match will take place at the clubrooms of the former team in Washington.

Every sportsmen's exhibit, including the Ojibway Indians and the Canadian furtrappers, had more spectators looking at them last night, and incidentally more questions asked on a hundred and one topics, than had ever before been the case on the second night of the Sportsmen's Show.

BERLIN, March 6. -- The question for the moment of first importance in Germany is the attitude of the Government to the International Sugar Convention, which was signed at Brussels yesterday. The cablegrams describing Prince Henry's tour in the United States occupy, for the first time since his arrival in New York, a subordinate place in public attention.

PHILADELPHIA. Penn., March 6. -- The schedule of the University of Pennsylvania Baseball team was given out to-night, and with it came the official announcement that Pennsylvania and Yale will resume baseball relations after a break of nine years. The Blue will play the Red and Blue here on Saturday, May 3.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the communication from Charles J. Bates, printed in the Sunday edition of THE TIMES, there is a misstatement regarding the railroad experience of Mr. W.C. Brown, recently appointed Third Vice President of the New York Central Railroad, and given charge of the operation of that system.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In 1876 the young State which has hail the inglorious honor of furnishing the party of Seymour and Tilden with a candidate for the Presidency and the triumphant organizer of its crushing defeats in two successive contests startled the country and THE TIMES with a bold declaration, unequivocal and aggressive, in favor of the immediate resumption of specie payments and honest money.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- A notable speech was made In the Senate to-day by Mr. Hanna of Ohio, on the pending Shipping bill, which he discussed from the standpoint of an American business man. His arguments were carefully arranged; he was always forceful and earnest, and at times became eloquent.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6. -- There was a marked improvement in the Philadelphia stock market to-day, with a wider range of trading than for many days past. Pennsylvania Railroad touched 76 during the afternoon, and this acted as a mild stimulant to all the steam roads, Lehigh Valley advancing 3/8 and Reading common 1/8.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 6. -- In honor of the visit of Prince Henry of Prussia to the United States Military Academy tomorrow, and owing to the uncertain condition of the weather, three programmes have been arranged. The one most likely to be carried out folows:

LONDON, March 7. -- The production by George Alexander at the St. James's Theatre last evening of Stephen Phillips's "Paolo and Francesca" was notable, part from the growing fame of the author and the ambitious character of the play, which is the first he has written, because of the uncommonly distinguished first-night audience present.

Acting upon, the recommendations in a long report dealing with the measure now before Congress known as "A bill to maintain the legal-tender silver dollar at a parity with gold and to increase the subsidiary silver coinage, weights, and measures on Jan. 13, 1902," the Chamber of Commerce yesterday indorsed that bill.

LONDON, March 6. -- Money was in brisk demand to-day and discounts were steady. Business on the Stock Exchange was quietly cheerful. Operators were indisposed to engage in fresh commitments, in view of the holiday on Saturday and the eve of the settlement. The only feature was the strength of Americans and Kafirs.

William H. Mullen, twelve years of age, who lives at 201 Hester Street, entered the Criminal Courts Building yesterday morning crunching a piece of paper in his hand. He went to the District Attorney's office and demanded to be admitted to the man whom he described as "dat feller Jerome, who's honest."
The following transfers made by the President Jan. 18, 1902. are announced by the Secretary of War:

PITTSBURG, March 6. -- Public interest in James K. Hackett's stage production of "The Crisis," by Winston Churchill, founded on his novel of the same name, was evidenced by the immense audience at the first performance at the Alvin Theatre tonight. In placing "The Crisis" on the stage Mr. Hackett has evidently subjugated his interest as a star to his position as a producer.

Dr. Alpheus Freeman, alumnus of the Presbyterian Hospital, and said to have a large private practice, was ordered to pay his wife, Josephine Freeman, $25 a week by Magistrate Pool in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday. The woman was gray-haired, and appeared to be very delicate. Her appearance, she said, was caused by Dr. Freeman's abuse, and not age.

Lewis Nixon returned to New York last evening after a trip to Florida. One of the first announcements he made on his arrival at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was that a Democratic State headquarters would soon be opened in New York City.

ALBANY, March 6. -- Gov. Oclell to-day announced that at the close of the session of the Legislature he would make a trip to California with his family. He will be gone from six weeks to two months. During his absence Lieut. Gov. Woodruff will be the Acting Governor. Gov. Odell will return in time to permit of Lieut. Gov. Woodruff sailing for London to attend the coronation ceremony.

ALBANY, March 6. -- Assistant Corporation Counsel Whitman will have a conference with Mayor Low in New York Saturday, and expects to learn from the Mayor at that time the terms of the proposals of the New York Central Railroad Company with regard to legislation for the remedy of conditions in the Park Avenue tunnel.
LOUISVILLE. Ky., March 6. -- There are nineteen horses on the list of eligibles for the Kentucky Derby of 1902, and fifteen for the Kentucky Oaks. The Derby entries are as follows:

Frederick B. House of counsel for Albert T. Patrick, now on trial charged with the murder of William Marsh Rice, outlined yesterday to the jury the defense the accused lawyer expects to make to disprove the accusation of Valet Jones that he conspired to gain possession of Rice's millions by forgery and then induced Jones to hasten the octogenarian's end with chloroform.
It is interesting to know that the Fall campaign for Congress is to be waged in behalf of the Democratic Party under the guidance of our ancient and seasoned friend, Senator CLARK of Montana.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a reader of THE TIMES for more than a score of years, a strong approver of its general view of things, I beg leave to say that its utterances on the subject of psychical research with reference to the society bearing that name evince less accurate Information than usually underlies the editorial columns.

BOSTON, March 6. -- Prince Henry of Prussia was the guest of Boston to-day. His welcome to the city was stately and cordial. Gov. Winthrop Murray Crane and Mayor P.A. Collins. acting for State and city, extended the official courtesies. When Prince Henry ceremoniously had returned their calls he went to Cambridge to deliver to the Germanic Museum of Harvard University the gifts of his brother.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Chairman Payne of the Ways and Means Committee to-day gave out the following authorized statement in connection with the discussion over Cuban reciprocity:

NEW ORLEANS, March 6. -- Egyptian Prince was the only beaten favorite to-day. Little Elkin was run up to $1,200, an advance of $700 over the entered selling price, and sold to H.T. Griffin. Weather clear, track fast. Summary:

MARKET MOVEMENT. Nearly 600,000 shares were traded in on the Stock Exchange yesterday, an increase of 50 per cent, in transactions beyond what lately has been the daily average: and coincidentally the market throughout was strong. Many stocks scored substantial gains, some of the advances being sensational.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I consider this statement from your issue of yesterday quite unfair, not to say libelous, concerning Pompeii, as contrasted with the streets of New York: Unless they are content to stay in their hotels in the evening or to hire guides such as are employed in Pompeii, their experience is likely to be disagreeable, for there is absolutely no means of getting about without guidance.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Thanks to the beet sugar people, the story was circulated through the country this morning that the President had "thrown up his hands" and announced his willingness to accept, in lieu of tariff concessions to the Cubans, relief by rebate according to some such plan as that supported by Representative Tawney.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The third conference of Reublieans members of the House to consider the question of Cuban tariff concessions was held to-night. After remaining in session from 8:15 until 11:15 the conference adjourned until next Tuesday night, no action having been taken. Representative Mahon, (Penn.) offered a resolution postponing the entire matter until the next session of Congress, but nothing was done with it.

The efforts of those who persist in trying to force the use of the metric system upon the people of this country have been very properly and very emphatically rebuked by a committee of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, consisting of COLEMAN SELLERS, COLEMAN SELLERS, Jr., GEORGE M. BOND, JOHN E. SWEET, and CHARLES T. PORTER-names which will command great respect among those who are familiar with the best American work in exact mechanics.

There was posted last night in the twenty-six barns, stables, and power houses of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company throughout Manhattan a notice from President Vreeland to all employes announcing the establishment of a pension system for the superannuated employes of the concern.

-- Though an immense amount of sanitary work has bean done in Manila since the American occupation began and the condition of the city is steadily improving, no such remarkable results as have been achieved in Havana are yet reported from the Filipino capital. In December last Manila had 250,000 inhabitants, of whom 186,619 were natives, 51,567 Chinese, and 11,814 "Americans and others."
