BALTIMORE, Md., March 6. -- The feature of to-day's market was the abrupt halt in the realizing sales, the consequent reversal in the general trend, and the good strides toward recovery made by several of the leading issues. International Trust held first place, having advanced 1 1/4 points above yesterday's closing.

ALBANY, March 6. -- Assemblyman Allen, who represents the district of Republican National Committeeman Gibbs in the Assembly, and Assemblyman Fitzgerald, who is one of the Tammany leaders, had a rather lively interchange of words to-day in the room of the Assembly Cities Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The Spanish Treaty Claims Commission to-day handed clown a decision against the claimants for deaths and injuries received by officers and seamen in the wreck of the battleship Maine, in Havana Harbor.

CLARKSBURG, West Va., March 6. -- A mortgage for $75,000,000, given by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, was admitted for record in the office of the County Clerk here to-day. It was in favor of the Union Trust Company of New York.

Controller Grout gave out a statement yesterday showing the operations of the offices of Kings County since Jan. 1, 1902. Under the law which was passed by the Legislature last year, the Register, County Clerk, and Sheriff of Kings County were to receive stated salaries, and all fees collected were to be turned into the city treasury.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., March 6. -- F.L. St. John's new schooner yacht is nearly completed at the Jacob yard. The inside joiner work and fittings are about completed, and with a few outside fittings the boat will be in condition to launch about March 25.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: The discussion of relief plans for the New York end of the Brooklyn Bridge have brought out many new ideas, but most of them require long time and the expenditure of much money, while the relief is needed at once. I make no new suggestions, but simply concrete suggestions already made, viz.:

CHICAGO, March 6. -- All the Western Traffic Bureaus were put out of existence by the executive officers of the various roads at their meeting in this city to-day. The conclusion was reached to discontinue all the committees, including the Kansas City committee, of which the Northwestern was not a member, and thus avoid the necessity of each road giving individual notice of withdrawal.

LONDON, March 7. -- Another dispatch urging the Powers to withdraw the Tien-Tsin provisional government and to permit the Viceroy of Pe-chi-Li to take charge of the civil government of the native city is sent by Dr. Morrison, the Peking correspondent of The Times.
In a letter which Swinburne wrote to the Secretary of the Omar Khayyam Club in 1897 he said:

ALBANY, March 7. -- Assemblyman Wainwright said to-day that he had been handed the bill which Mr. Bedell introduced as a part of the plan to bring about a change in the conditions with regard to the Park Avenue tunnel, with a request that he introduce it and that he had refused to stand sponsor for it, believing the powers it conferred were altogether too sweeping.
BALTIMORE, Md., March 7. -- Rudolph H. Crouvatt, aged twenty-seven, a bridegroom of four days, committed suicide some time last night by shooting himself in a room in a hotel in this city.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7. -- Dr. S. Weir Mitchell, who seems to have turned to literary pursuits with an enthusiasm which increases with his years, has written another story, of the long-short order, which is booked for early appearance in Lippincott's Magazine under the title of " New Samaria."

At the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday Controller Grout showed the large amounts of money which were being paid put in fees in the condemnation of lands for public purposes. The Controller has frequently made the claim that the fee system should be done away with and all mutters pertaining to the condemnation and acquirement of land for public purposes be done by the Law Department of the city.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 7. -- United States District Judge Emory Speer estreated to-day the bonds of Benjamin D. Greene and John F. Gaynor, charged with implication in the conspiracy of Oberlin M. Carter against the United States. Bench warrants were at once issued for their arrest. William T. and Edward H. Gaynor were in court and were arraigned on the new indictment recently found against them and the others.
Army. The following transfers, made by President Roosevelt, are announced by the Secretary of War:

The appetite for the marvelous and startling in natural history, (as every where else,) which makes newspaper readers roll wild tales of monstrosities as sweet morsels under their tongues, and keeps wormeaten " chestnuts " in circulation long after their falsity has been exposed, comes nearer being gratified by the truth in the story of past ages than anywhere else.

Wall Street is giving attention to an address delivered by Vice President Frank Dickerson of the American Tin Plate Company upon the subject of corporation development. Mr. Dickerson takes the position that there is scarcely a limit to such development provided sane policies are pursued; and among what he considers the necessities is open accounting between corporation Trustees and their shareholders and the public.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 7. -- According to the police, young Mrs. William Klump of Lowell, who died a few hours after swallowing what she supposed was a "Flag Salt" headache powder sent to her through the mail, was the victim of a cold-blooded murder. Her husband was arrested to-day, after the investigation of Sheriff Chapman and the village officers.

There was something peculiarly appropriate in the tribute paid by the Aldine Association -- largely an association of publishers -- to Dr. Lyman Abbott, the presiding genius of The Outlook. And it was characteristic of Dr. Abbott that he should desire that the speeches on such an occasion should be directed to the subject of "The City and the Citizen."

Northwest -- A twenty-point rise in any stock in a single week is noteworthy, butwhen it occurs, as it did last week, in a high-priced security such as Northwest, it is especially noteworthy. There does not seem to be any news to explain the advance -- to the highest price on record -- other than the fact that the stock is rapidly being taken out of the market for investment purposes.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S " for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
Money on call, 2 1/2@3 per cent. Time money, 3 1/2 per cent, for thirty days, 4 per cent, for sixty to ninety days, 4@4 1/2 per cent. for four months, 4 1/4@4 1/2 Per cent. for five to six months.

Three matches were decided in the Metropolitan bowling championship tournament last night, the Fidelia bowlers of Manhattan winning three games from the Prosperity team of Brooklyn on the New York alleys, the Metropolitans winning three games from the Lotus team, both of Manhattan, on the White Elephant alleys, and the Belvideres of Manhattan winning two of three games with the Manhattans of Brooklyn on the Elephant Club alleys.

Such a work as Dr. Fairlie's "Municipal Administration" ought to appeal to a wide audience among the forty millions of people of the United States who now find themselves enabled through perfection in transportation facilities and distribution of products to live within the precincts of cities, and who find about them many serious administrative problems for solution.

The English railway return for the last half of 1901 now available are not lacking in interesting features. There are few points at which either the properties themselves or the results obtained offer proper comparison with United States roads, but in spite of this fact many attempts have been made to institute such comparisons, and to draw conclusions therefrom.

The merits of the three-platoon police system and the two-platoon system were discussed last evening at a public Hearing before the Police Committee of the Board of Aldermen. Chairman Holler asked if there was any person who desired to speak in favor of the two-platoon system, and no one responded.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- In an article by Mrs. Creighton, in Longman's Magazine, I noitice that the historian John R. Green was accustomed to seek relaxation in reading novels.

In reviewing the developments in the money market for the past week two significant facts stand out conspicuously: one, that notwithstanding the ex- portation of approximately $5,000,000 in gold, money rates at this centre have held easy and have in no sense reflected any disturbance; the other that the foreign banks certainly are in no immediate need of gold and could not have pressed for the recent shipments.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Nothing is known here, either at the State Department or the British Embassy, about the report that the Hon. Alfred Lyttelton is to succeed Lord Pauncefote. The latter does not expect to be recalled immediately, and has laid his plans for staying here throughout the Summer at least.

First of the Library Institutes. Library Institutes are a comparatively new form of library activity, and they are entirely new, so far as New York State is concerned. The State Library Association at its annual meeting at Lake Placid last September decided to extend its work through these institutes, and as a result eight will he held during April next.
ALBANY, March 7. -- Gov. Odell removed Sheriff Charles S. Guden of Kings County this afternoon. At the same time he announced the appointment of Col. Norman S. Dike as Guden's successor.

The New York Saturday review of Books: The paragraph in your issue of March 1 relating to "Whittler's Earliest Poem" closes with the remark that Whittler's " Address to the Rustle Bard," which was published in 1828, among Robert Dinsmoor's " Incidental Poems," was long believed to be his first poem to appear in a book.
ROME, March 7. -- Capt. Casati, the African explorer, is dead.

This little book is the reproduction of a work both famous and fascinating, that dates back 250 years, "The Elements of Architecture by the curious Pensil of the Ever Memorable Sir Henry Wotton, Knight," published in 1631 among the author's works, with a sketch of his life by Izaak Walton, his attached friend and fellow-fisherman.

-- Rarely, if ever has anything in this column created in so many minds such fervent joy as seems to have resulted from the recent reference, in the course of a eulogy upon the Weather Bureau, to "people who call a moon 'wet' or 'dry,' according to the inclination of the earth's shadow on that satellite."

ABOUT 4,300 new books are published in the United States every year, and the total number of copies issued and sold is perhaps 10,000,000; but the intellectual food of the mass of the people is, after all, not books so much as newspapers and periodicals.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In view of the numerous requests forwarded to me desiring to know if such a person as the Rani of Jhansi ever existed as I have depicted her, it is possible you will be interested in learning the sources of my information in that respect.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The Secretary of War and Mrs. Root entertained at dinner this evening the British Ambassador and Lady Pauncefote, the Italian Ambassador and Signora Mayor des Planches, Senator and Mrs. Elkins, Senator and Mrs. Wetmore, Senator Hanna, Mr. and Mrs. George B. McClellan, Mr. and Mrs. Olmsted, Mr. and Mrs. Boardman, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wadsworth, Mrs. William Sheffield Cowles, Mrs. Richard H. Townsend, Miss Patten, Representative Hitt, and Representative Gillett.

LIVERPOOL, March 7. -- When the British steamer Harmonides, which was in collision with and sank the Red Star Line steamer Waesland last night, about forty miles southwest of Holyhead, arrived here early this morning, her decks were crowded with half-clad passengers of the Waesland, whose pale and haggard faces told the story of their trying experience.
That such a treasure as the Garland col-lection of Oriental porcelains should leave America was a grievous thought, but it is not to leave America.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 7. -- A number of prominent theatrical men held a secret meeting in Cleveland last night to form an effective combine which would result in the betterment of the managers' interests and save them $500,000 a year.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Those good people who hold that the func- tions of our public libraries are strictly educational will doubtless be gratified at the proposed exclusion from their shelves of those purely recreative works of fiction styled with varying degrees of justice "light novels" or "trash."

The security market has had a good week. A variety of tests subjected quotations to pressure, including the taking of some millions of sold for export. But investment sentiment was not affected. Bearish contingents among the professional speculators of the Stock Exchange raided prices without inducing any outside following whatsoever, and toward the end of the week an extended short interest showed nervousness.

Not many illusions in literary matters have been dispelled with quite so much force as the one to which Mr. John Cotton Dana devotes himself in the article reprinted elsewhere in this issue from The World's Work. In the past few years the notion has been quite common that all the world was reading popular novels.

When Payne Whitney, son of William C. Whitney, married Miss Helen Hay on Feb. 6, it was announced that among the presents which the couple would receive was a mansion, yet to be erected in this city, the donor being Col. Oliver H. Payne, the bridegroom's uncle.

Though not much activity developed in yesterday's market, it was strong throughout. Commission house transactions were again conspicuously a feature, commission house advices were still pointing out the market's maintained strength, as a reflection of healthful business conditions throughout the country.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church is to meet in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, early in May, and will continue in session during a large part of that month. There will be two principal features of the meeting. One is the presentation of the report of the Creed Revision Committee and the other the celebration of the centennial anniversary of the Board of Home Missions.

NOT the least interesting aspect of the hypothesis of evolution which took defi- nite shape through the rea- soning of Darwin and Wallace about half a century ago is the attitude toward it, and especially toward certain logical deductions from it, assumed by various men of science.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Please register my protest with that of "Justice," "Taxpayer," and all the rest of those who protest against the tenement house law.

A pretty discussion has been started by an attempt on the part of the amiable Springfield Republican to explain why so little poetry is published in these days. The Chronicle of Brookline, Mass., comments on the utterance of The Republican and takes a slightly different stand, and no doubt other papers, which have the time and the inclination to consider matters of literature, will also have something to say.

A POLITICAL biography of more than usual significance, soon to be published by McClure, Phillips Co., is "Reminiscences of Sixty Years in Public Affairs," by George S. Boutwell. As Grant's Secretary of the Treasury, as Governor of Massachusetts, and as his State's representative in both houses of Congress, Gov. Boulwell has had a considerable share in making history.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Permit me to state that I have been a reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS since its first issue. The information I have received therefrom, in all branches of literature, has been of great value and is highly appreciated.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The press dispatch from Manila to the effect that Major Littleton W.T. Waller and Lieut. John H. A. Day of the Marine Corps had been ordered before a court-martial for killing Samar natives without trial has been confirmed by a message from Rear Admiral Rodgers, commanding the Asiatic Station.

" Better Roads " was the text of nearly all the speeches made last night at the third annual dinner of the Automobile Club of America, held in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria. The roads of the city and the State were considered in all their bearings, and were condemned unanimously as being insufficient in mileage and quality and far behind the highways of, Massachusetts and other New England States.
George Blair, Superintendent of the Outdoor Relief Department of the Board of Charities, was yesterday summarily removed by Commissioner Homer Folks. Mr. Blair will contest his removal in the courts.

The old German students, assembled at Arion Hall last night to honor the Prince with a regular German " Commers," were just about to break into a rollicking song when a message came to the presiding officer that the Prince would arrive in a few minutes.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were diversified, but in few stocks was the total unusually large. New interest was shown in Northern Securities, and in several other issues as well was business livelier than usual. Prices were irregular. A number of net advances appeared in the list, but in about as many cases final quotations showed net losses.

BORN eight years before the death of George II., and living far into the Presidency of Andrew Jackson, Philip Freneau was one of the strongest martial and political influences of the formative period of the United States as a constitutional government and a political power.
One has but to open the cover of Mr. McCarthy's dainty romance, "If I Were King," to be held fast by the melody and fervor of some of the author's lines.

Mr. Poultnoy Blgelow, who, as everybody is aware, knew the Kaiser and his brother Henry when at Bonn in their schooldays, gives in The Outlook an interesting account of the training of the German Prince as a sailor:
Thomas Whitlock, one of the ultra-conservative students of current American business conditions, writes in The London Economist:

When James Huncker, "Helomaniacs," the author of " Melomaniacs," the satire on music, was recently asked if he had in view the elucidation of any problem when he made his curious medley of men, women, musicians, poets, singers, painters, crazy philosophers, and fashionable melomaniacs, he said " No."

It seems strange that the European country which not only has comparatively little to do with us, but which has alone almost officially announced its desire to have less, should choose this time to raise the rank of its representative at the capital of the United States. There seems to be a certain inconsistency in the behavior of Count GOLUCHOWSKI, Foreign Minister of Austria-Hungary and official sponsor for the proposal to boycott the United States.

FORTUNATE is the novelist who has been able so thor- oughly to annex an even rel- atively small portion of his native land as to have recreated the old and half-forgotten Kingdom of Wessex, and in novel after novel to people it with a race, born, it is true, in his imagination only, but more real to us than its actual inhabitants.

LONDON, March 7. -- Money was very firm to-day, supplies were much curtailed, and there was an active demand, partly in connection with clearing goods from the Custom Houses in anticipation of budget proposals, and partly for repayments to the Bank of England, the indebtedness to which reached u8,000,000 recently.

At the banquet tendered to Prince HENRY by the City of Boston ex-Secretary RICHARD OLNEY indicated in a few words the high significance and interna- tional utility of the Prince's visit -- for certainly we are permitted to believe that what Mr. OLNEY calls this embassy from the German Emperor mingles in some proportion the useful with the agreeable.

A wearied editor, trying vainly to explain to a philanthropic correspondent that he really could not give up half his paper to an exposition of that correspondent's epoch-making project, exclaimed in despair: "How necessary it is to know something about newspapers in order to write for them."

Praise could hardly be higher than to say of this work that it gives a more modern and more intimate interpretation of Scott's romances than has been hitherto generally available. Still the praise is deserved, and the person who reads his Scott with "Scotland Historic and Romantic" within easy reach is sure to gain in historical knowledge without losing any of the old romantic fascinations.

"In this book I endeavor to present with whatever skill of penmanship I may possess my father's impressions of Japan," writes Miss Dorothy Menpes in a little foreword to Mortimer Menpes's "record in colour" of that lovely flower land of the Far East. The artist, with his brush, and the writer with his words, together have succeeded in laying before us a series of fascinating pictures.

The junior Senator from this State knows many things. One of the few which he does not know appears to be yachting. In the Senate on Thursday he undertook to instruct Senator TILLMAN about it. Shifting his quid and hitching his trousers and shivering his timbers, he misinformed the Senator from South Carolina that the Meteor was "a sailing racing machine of the same type as beat the two Shamrocks."
Trade reports to the several commercial agencies are again most encouraging. Bradstreet's says:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 7. -- The Philadelphia stock market to-day was narrow and ragged. There was not enough activity to give a decided tone, and the list closed with gains and losses about equally distributed. The stocks in demand were Reading, Philadelphia Company, Electric Company of America, and Union Traction.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Miss Alice Roosevelt will not attend the coronation in England next June. No official announcement to this effect comes from the White House, but it may be accepted as a fact that the President's daughter will not accompany the American embassy. Why she has abandoned the trip is a matter for conjecture.

Wonderfully elaborate arrangements have been made for the floral decorations in honor of Prince Henry on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland, where he is to occupy Capt. Albers's private apartment and the quarters of the chief, third, and fourth officers, all on the bridge deck of the great racer.

The District Attorney has now engaged in an enterprise in which he will have the sincere sympathy of all good citizens, no matter what their opinions may be upon the propriety of the existing excise law, or even upon the practicability of a complete enforcement of it. That is the attempt to punish the offense of blackmail by the police under cover of the excise law.

Some years ago I had the privilege of spending a few weeks among the miners of silver in Colorado. I found that when the "prospector" went out to search for the precious metal there were certain appearances of the soil and vegetation which first arrested his attention. They were merely surface indications, but they told to his experienced eye that probably in that region he would find the metal for which he was seeking.

Constable's place as the first of the moderns and perhaps the last of the old masters is emphasized and explained in this fifth volume of the Artist's Library as it could not possibly have been forty years ago when Leslie wrote his fine and authoritative biography.

Secretary of the Treasury Leslie M. Shaw got his first glimpse of the Inside of Wall Street yesterday. He arrived in the city from Washington early in the morning, and went first to call on Assistant Treasurer Conrad N. Jordan at the Sub-Treasury. He was in conference with Mr. Jordan for a considerable time, and was then taken through the Sub-Treasury building by Deputy Assistant Treasurer Marlor.

NEW ORLEANS, March 7. -- Honda and Torrean were the winning favorites today, Lyne rode three winners. Jockey Hope, who rode Dr. Stephens in previous races, was suspended pending investigation. The starters in the handicap comprised most of the eligibles for the Crescent City Derby, but the race afforded little if any opportunity to determine their respective merits.

ALBANY, March 7. -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided that the indictment found against Police Captain John D. Herlihy of the Twelfth Precinct, New York City, for failing to suppress disorderly houses in his precinct, is a valid one, and he must stand trial. The court affirms a decision of the lower courts, overruling a demurrer to the indictment made by the counsel for the defendant.

Although designed to meet a popular need, the new book, "Words and Their Ways in English Speech," by Profs. Greenough and Kittredge is a learned work. Its value to the public at large will perhaps be increased by the fallowing criticisms:

Prince Henry returned to New York at 6 o'clock yesterday evening. He had been absent from New York nine days. During this time his special train was within the territory of thirteen States, and it covered a distance of 4,358 miles. From early morn- ing to late at night on every day of the trip Prince Henry had been treated to ova- tions and receptions, with few opportuni- ties to rest.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Representative John Wesley Gaines of Tennessee, better known as "two-chair Gaines," was one of the numerous statesmen who went to the Philippines in 1900 in order that they might equip themselves by personal observation to talk intelligently on the issues which the Spanish war brought to the front.

Henry Bischof, head of the banking house of Bischoff Co. at Tryon Row and Centre Street, died yesterday at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. Amanda Von Graberg, 536 West One Hundred and Fiftieth Street, in his seventy-fifth year. He had been failing in health for nearly six years, and had paid little attention to business for more than five years.

LONDON, March 7. -- An authorized epitome of the " Dictionary of National Biography " will shortly be presented, including a condensation of every article found in the great original edition and its supplement.
BOSTON, Mass., March 7. -- Money rates, bank clearances, and balances are reported to-day as below:

CHICAGO, March 7. -- The American Mo- tor League, which is to be patterned close- ly after the old League of American Wheelmen, was placed upon a firm basis here yesterday. A reorganization of the body formed in 1895 was perfected and officers elected. Edwin F. Brown of Chicago was chosen President.

Senor Jose Vicente Concha, the newly accredited Minister from Colombia to Washington, is in the city. It is his special mission in this country to demonstrate that Colombia is favorably disposed toward the construction of the Panama Canal and its control by the United States. He has received full powers and specific instructions from his Government.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In browsing to-day in my favorite book-haunt the name of H.W. Mable on the cover of an old Atlantic Monthly arrested my attention. In the same heap I found several other magazines purchasable at the price of a denied car ride, some of which contained poems of the most highly derived and satisfying nature; and in the way of analysis veritable pearls of critical expression and judgment.

ALBANY, March 7. -- Gov. Odell has been furnished with a copy of a bill, which is said to have been drawn by Congressman Montague Lessler, providing for the reimbursement of Lieut. Col. Clinton Smith of the Seventy-first Regiment, to the extent of $23,000 for money said to have been expended by him for counsel fees in defending himself against the charge of cowardice in the Santiago campaign.

BALTIMORE, March 7. -- The strength of the G.B.S. Brewing issues was the feature of to-day's trading. The income bonds and common stock were both in good demand and scored substantial fractional advances. The income bonds closed 3/8 higher, but the first 4s were 1/8 lower.

At the close of his speech for the Subsidy bill on March 3 it is reported that Mr. FRYE was asked by Mr. BACON of Georgia as to the condition of business in American shipyards, and whether it were true that "they were full of orders," and that to this Mr. FRYE replied, "It is not true."
This letter was yesterday read with interest by Health Commissioner Ernst J. Lederle:

Following are the returns of foreign com- merce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

ALBANY, March 7. -- Gov. Odell left Al- bany this afternoon for New York, on his way to Washington, where he will visit the President and take a few days' rest. He was reticent to-day as to the nature of the conference he would hold with the President.

Mayor Low was the guest of honor at the twelfth annual mounted games of Squadron A, which were held last night at the squadron's armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street. Major Gen. Roe served as referee of the games, and the judges were Col. N.B. Thurston, Major Oliver B. Bridgman, and Capt. Latham G. Reed.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, March 7. -- A broken rail on a curve caused a frightful wreck on the Southern Pacific Railroad near Maxon Station, twenty-five miles west of Sanderson, at 3 o'clock this morning. From the latest accounts received here fifteen people were killed outright and twenty-eight more or less injured.

Dr. Walker Curry, who attended Millionaire William Marsh Rice during his last illness, was cross-examined at length all of yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Osborne at the trial of Albert T. Patrick, charged with Rice's murder. The impression made on the spectators by Dr. Curry was that of a guileless old Southern gentleman of the ante-bellum school.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 7. -- In one of the most sensational racquet matches ever witnessed in this city Clar- ence Mackay and "Larry" Waterbury of the New York Tennis and Racquet Club were defeated to-day in the semi-final round for the double championship of America, by George H. Brooke and H.D. Scott of the local club, after seven most exciting games.

The most important event of to-day will be the breakfast followed by a musicale which Mrs. Ogden Mills will give Prince Henry. Besides this affair the most interesting news will be that of the various sailing's and departures for Europe. The Kronprinz Wilhelm will sail this morning, and there will be other ships for various points abroad, the passenger lists of which will contain many well-known New York names.
Details will be found in another column relative to the purchase of the plot, 70 by 100, on Fifth Avenue, between Seventy-eighth and Seventy-ninth Streets, by Col. Oliver H. Payne.

As a result of many conferences between the District Attorney, the Police Commissioner, agents for the Society for the prevention of Crime, and Fritz Lintinger, President of the New York County Liquor Dealers' Association, it is said that a decision has been reached as to the enforcement of the excise law.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 7. -- Attorney General Douglas has appealed to Congress in the Northern Securities case. With the backing of the Minnesota Legislature and of the Minnesota delegation in both Congressional branches at Washington, he hopes for an amendment to the judicial acts changing the anomalous position in which Minnesota is now placed.

In the international cable chess match to be played Friday and Saturday of this week between teams of this country and of Great Britain, the Brooklyn Chess Club has invited the following well-known players to represent America: H.N. Pillsbury, Philadelphia, Penn.; J.W. Showalter, Georgetown, Ky.; J.F. Barry, Boston, Mass.; A.B. Hodges, Staten Island, N.Y.; E. Hymes, New York City; H.C. Voigt, Philadelphia, Penn.; C.J. Newman, Philadelphia, Penn.; F.J. Marshall, S.W. Bampton, and C.S. Howell.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 8 -- The first automobile races ever run in the South took place this afternoon on the mile track of the Savannah Fair Association, and were witnessed by a crowd of nearly 2,000 persons. The greatest enthusiasm prevailed, and there was much interest in the events.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- George H. Brooke, the ex-football player, and H.D. Scott of the Philadelphia Racquet Club won the amateur racquet championship of America here to-day, defeating Newbold Etting and George McFadden, the local squash racquet champion, in four straight games.

Edwin F. Merwin, who was on Friday appointed by Charities Commissioner Homer Folks to be Superintendent of the Out-Door Relief Department, in place of George Blair, removed, entered upon his new duties yesterday, being coached by Deputy Superintendent William F. Walsh, whom long experience has made thoroughly conversant with the details of the work.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Interest in the approaching court-martial of Major Waller and Lieut. Day of the Marine Corps for murdering Filipinos is stronger here than in any other case in recent years except the Schley case. This is due chiefly to the prominence of Major Waller and the bearing of the case upon the succession to the command of the corps.

The theme of the new burlesque which William H. Post has written for production at the New York Winter Garden Thursday night deals with stock manipulations and promoting. It is in one act and three scenes.

ALBANY, March 8 -- The Princely Social Club has teen incorporated for recreative, social, and educational purposes, with head-quarters in New York City. The Directors are Harry Abraham, 84 Norfolk Street; Max Sussman, 86 Norfolk Street; Max Cohen, 243 East Eighth Street; Nathan Fishel, 210 Broome Street; Moe Liberman, 81 Henry Street; Barney Levy, 316 East Eighth Street; John Lichner, 135 Rivington Street, and Morris Abraham, 84 Norfolk Street, New York City.

Representatives from nearly twenty preparatory schools in New York and the vicinity competed yesterday in the indoor athletic games held at the Eighth Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, under the auspices of the Montclair High School Athletic Association. The greatest rivalry centred in the point competition for the silver cup.

BOSTON, March 8 -- The close of the week finds the money market in a slightly firmer position, but with no great apprehension in evidence regarding the immediate future. The feeling now is that the present conditions may continue for some little time, but that no pronounced marketing up of rates is to be expected.
David W. Temple, the first Democratic Mayor of the City of Rutland, Vt., ever had, was inaugurated last Thursday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 8 -- The engagements have been announced of two young ladies, sisters, who have been quite prominent socially -- Miss Juliana Rogers and Miss Virginia Clayton Rogers -- the former to Lawrence Wesley Lloyd of New York and the last mentioned to John T. Nevins, a lawyer, of this city.

A bill has been introduced in the Legislature of this State to provide a summary method of collecting claims of the City of New York for personal taxes for past years as well as in the future. It will, if it becomes law, change the methods of collectins such taxes. The measure has passed the Senate, and a hearing on it before the Assembly Committee on Cities will be had on Tuesday.

"No man win be a sailor," said Dr. Johnson, "who has contrivance enough to get himself into jail." Dr. Johnson was, however, a landsman, while many of the following expressions are the opinions of seafaring people. "He who trusts himself on the sea is either a fool, or he is poor, or he wants to die."

REAR ADMIRAL, EVANS, who has been in the public eye of late quite as much as he is ever in the public heart, was asked by one of the party with Prince Henry of Prussia what was the most marked instance of patriotic action that had ever come under his observation.

HERBERT KELCEY and a few friends were discussing repartee of the present and past generations tine other day. The Viscount Canning of "Her Lord and Master" insisted that our ancestors had quicker wits than the men of this commercial age. In order to substantiate this assertion Mr. Kelcey said he would repeat a few retorts made by famous men in the bygone days.

RECENT snowstorms have caused a season of strenuous life for wild birds and animals that have homes beyond the parks and garbage heaps of the cities. A Sullivan County farmer saved a flock of quail in the last hunting season by posting the wood lot where they were bred, and where they made their home.

Alfred Nobel, as far back as 1848, during a residence in France, produced the first nitro-glycerine powder that was then known. It was in Hamburg that he discovered by chance dynamite Guhr. Some of his powder had trickled out of a cask on to the damp soil and become spoiled by the infusorial earth.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- In previous letters to THE NEW YORK TIMES the new labor unions called "Les Jaunes" have been referred to. This departure in trade unionism has now become what the French call an "actualite." As stated at the time of their organization, Les Jaunes were organized about a year ago, at the time of the great coal strike at Montceau-les-Mines.

BAYONNE, N.J., March 8 -- Owing to summary eviction without notice, Bayonne's "Little Church Around the Corner," in West Forty-seventh Street, will dispense with the customary Sunday services. Possession of the premises has been secured by William D. Salter, who claims to have a deed of ownership, and a legal contest is likely to result.

As a grand finale to a long list of public entertainments in honor of Prince Henry of Prussia, came the banquet of the German Society of New York last evening. Incidentally, it was the largest dinner ever served in the Waldorf-Astoria, and in the Grand Ballroom, the two balconies and the Astor Gallery were seated more than 1,500 people.
A SALESMAN in one of the large Jew- elry stores on Broadway explained the other day why his and other , stores of the same class are still almost as crowded now as before the holidays.

BANGOR, Me., March 8 -- Charles E. Oak of Bangor, General Manager for the American Realty Company and timber land agent for the International Paper Company, expresses the belief that at the present rate of cutting the timber supply in Maine is , sufficient to meet all demands upon it for an indefinite period.

HERE is a secret. Not a member of the Health Board breathes it, but every woman who is vaccinated at the Board of Health stations must tell how old she is unless -- but then, of course, she wouldn't prevaricate anyway. Hut isn't it an unpaternal demand of the City Government?

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES is usually so well informed upon all subjects discussed in its editorial columns that I trust you will allow me to make a rather complete statement concerning the methods and objects of the Society for Psychical Research. You seem absolutely without any real information on the matter.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 8 -- It now looks as if Dr. J.N.J. Burnell of Greenwich will receive the estate of Jothan Tompkins, the miser, who died two years ago, leaving several wills, the last of which left the whole estate to Dr. Burnell, who had cared for the old man during the last years of his life without receiving any compensation.

OURAY, Col., March 8 -- The order has gone forth from every camp in the San Juan country that the Chinese must go and go quickly. Within the last three months a feeling has developed that the laxity regarding the enforcement of this decree should be corrected.

Mark Twain was the principal speaker at the Hotel Savoy last night at the dinner in celebration of the twentieth anniversary of the foundation of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence. He said at the outset of his remarks that it was a pleasure to watch a company of gentlemen "in that condition which is peculiar to gentlemen who have had their dinners."

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 8 -- The feature of the card was the Oakland Handicap, at a mile and a quarter, and worth $1,165 to the winner. Nitrate was a hot favorite in the betting. Ben Chance's support was confined to his statble and its friends. Egyptian Prince, light weighted and a long shot, made the early running, and yielded in the last quarter to the favorite.

THERE is a certain class of men in this city, the members of which number thousands, who, although they never served for any department of the National or State Governments, or worked for private or public corporations, are receiving pensions, with which they manage to eke out existence with the same regularity as those whose names are on the official dockets of the Pension Office at Washington.

Wanted an Aesthetic Police. What are the duties of a dramatic critic in case of aesthetic murder? The life of many a human being is worth, less to the world than the lire of a wholesome and amusing play; yet it would fare badly with any one who made way with even the worst of actors, whereas the actor may murder a good and beautiful part nightly and so scot free.

One of the most beautiful and notable afternoon entertainments was that given yesterday by Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Mills at their residence, 2 East Sixty-ninth Street, in honor of Prince Henry of Prussia. The affair consisted of a breakfast, to which only the Prince and his suite and a few intimate friends were asked.

At the Hotel Endicott, Columbus Avenue, Eighty-first and Eighty-second Streets, yesterday, a maid was cleaning a curtain in an unused dining room on the fourth floor on the north side of the building at 12:30 P.M., when the naphtha which she was using blazed up in some unexplained manner and set fire to the hangings.

An aged clergyman, a very religious man, once declared that the best thing which this world afforded was a good run, the next best was a bad run, the next best a day with the hounds on which you had no run. Many men who really love hunting will at once agree. And many who have not the taste for it will shrug their shoulders.

For a fortnight this community has had in it two men -- perhaps more -- who go about their business dreading that a certain thing will hoppen. Hoping, each one, that when it happens it will happen to another, and not to him. Grasping at the hope that the delay which grows from day to day means that the thing they fear is never to come.

The Bricklayers and Masons' International Union of America announced yesterday that it has entered Into an agreement with the rapid transit contractors of this city on behalf of the local unions of brick-layers by which a dispute over the concrete work in the tunnel which had lasted for nine months has been settled.

LONDON, March 8 -- The new army regulations proposed by the War Secretary, Mr. Brodrick, providing for increased pay and other reforms, which have created so much comment, appear to have been directly copied from the United States. Major Arthur Lee, member of Parliament for the Fareham Division of Hampshire and formerly British Military Attache at Washington, to-day said of the proposed change:

Mr. Nahan Franko will conduct the concert at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time this evening. It will also be the twenty-fifth anniversary of Mr. Franko's appearance as a violinist, and all the artists of the Maurice Grau Opera Company, as well as the members of the orchestra and of the general staff, will unite in presenting him with a handsome testimonial.

FORTUNATE is the man who having formulated a theory, (not necessarily novel) finds that after 30 years he still adheres to the same. Of course this implies that after the promulgation of his idea, he has still continued his observations. The subject of this article is concerning dreams.

The people of New York who take interest in the treasures of the Metropolitan Museum of Art were greatly interested in the report published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that the James A. Garland collection of Oriental porcelains had been purchased by J. Pierpont Morgan, and was to remain in the United States.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 8 -- It was semi-officially announced last night that a conference between Yale and Harvard athletic leaders was held at Springfield Thursday night for the purpose of discussing athletic meetings between the two universities for the coming season.

SILAS LARRABEE talked this morning in entertaining fashion about the senior Senator from South Carolina, the Hon. Benjamin Ryan Tillman. It was raining cats and dogs all the morning and Mr. Larrabee, along with a lot more Ogunquiters, watched the downpour through the windows of the "corner store."

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have taken and read your paper for some time and like it very much. As you seldom print anything in favor of the policemen, I was very much pleased to see an article in Monday's paper, quoted from the Rev. Dr. Banks's sermon on "The Appeal of Justice for the Policemen of New York City."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Corporation Tax bill has been twice withdrawn for amendment. It was so bad that even its friends were not willing to be responsible for it. It has been amended again, and reported to the Senate without a hearing. It is now Senate Bill No. 701.

Patrick Fay of 210 East Ninetieth Street, who is employed as a bartender in Patrick Keary's saloon at the southeast corner of Ninetieth Street and Third Avenue, was taken to Presbyterian Hospital in a dying condition last evening, as the result of a shooting and general free fight in the saloon.

Current dealing, aside from its remarkable volume, presents what is perhaps a still more striking feature in the fact that much of the buying is for immediate improvement, and in this particular the character of present activity is in marked contrast to that of last Spring. Speculative attention was then focused upon Longacre Square and Washington, and, to a greater or less extent, upon the entire Rapid Transit territory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is interesting to learn in your issue of this morning that Mr. J.H. Wells is able to derive amusement from the situation in the wrecking of the Seventy-first Regiment Armory. The fact that he knows the Superintendent of the Bureau of Buildings should give weight to his utterances, but I fancy the condition of adjacent property will speak more loudly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the editorial in your issue of the 5th inst. headed "Dr. Woodbury and the West Side" may influence certain persons who have not your facility for knowing the exact truth, in regard to the situation referred to in that editorial, and who do not know that the article failed to state all the facts of the situation, will you be good enough to publish this letter?

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Congress has just awakened to the fact that it has been completely outwitted and outmanoeuvred by the Administration and its friends in regard to the Permanent Census Bureau bill. That measure lay closer to the heart of the average Congressman than almost any other passed at this session, and its effect, so far as the object which the Congressmen wanted attained is concerned, has been completely nullified by an ingenious move.

BOSTON, Mass., March 8 -- The Amateur Athletic Union relay swimming championship was decided at the Sportsmen's Show to-night, and the Brookline Swimming Club team was the winner, with Knickerbooker Athletic Club of New York second, New York Athletic Club third, and Brookline Swimming Club second team fourth.
BERLIN, March 8 -- A Progressive newspaper that usually is not a particular admirer of the monarchy finds compliments for the way in which Admiral Prince Henry of Prussia has pleased the Americans.

John Wanamaker, who has been abroad since Nov. 23 last, is expected to return to this city by Easter. This is not certain, however, as Mr. Wanamaker did not fix any definite date for his home-coming. He is in Italy now. When he left Philadelphia he sailed for Paris and from there to India. After visiting the principal cities in that land he went to Italy.
The Charleston (S.C.) News and Courier prints the following letter from Senator Tillman:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Editorial comment in American papers upon the Hon. John Charlton's reciprocity resolution, recently introduced in the Canadian Parliament, betrays misunderstanding of the resolution. The purpose of the resolution is to provide a way by which the United States can continue to trade in Canadian markets without the present tariff restrictions being increased.

William Barclay Parsons, Chief Engineer if the Rapid Transit Commission, explained the other day why the underground trains in this city would not cause buildings along the line to be damaged as they have been damaged by the vibrations from the Central London Railway, known as "The Tube."

The Board of Managers of the Long Island State Hospitals has sent to Gov. Odell a reply to those passages in the memorandum of the Governor submitted in connection with the signing of the socalled Lunacy bill, which refers directly to the hospitals under the supervision of the board.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senator Patterson continued his questioning of Gen. Hughes in the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day, taking up the beginning of hostilities in, February, 1899. The witness repeated his previous, statement that the first shot had been fired by an American. Senator Patterson asked Gen. Hughes what he had meant when he said upon hearing, the firing at first, "The thing is on."

The Lenten season has certainly not been very penitential in character. Here it is almost mi-careme, and two of the most notable functions of the year are given. It is true that the visit of Prince Henry made this more or less imperative. The dejeuner of Mrs. Mills yesterday was a beautiful affair, and to-day there will be the dinner and musicale which Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt will give in the Prince's honor.

SO many supposedly or so-called fireproof buildings have been destroyed within the past three years, whose records for fire losses have been so unprecedented that the query has been raised in numbers of instances as to whether there is any such thing as a genuinely fireproof method of constructing the modern skeleton steel-frame buildings which are being erected so generally in the progressive cities of the United States.

The Russian Disturbances. The present demonstrations in Russian university towns must not be interpreted to mean that the new Minister of Education, Gen. Vannovsky, has shown himself to be as great an enemy of student liberty as his predecessor was.

AFTER all, unless an American has lived in Porto Rico and has studied at close range the present condition here, he but theorizes upon, second-hand information, or book knowledge, or possibly upon the superficial views of some careless observer, when he talks or writes glibly about the future of Porto Rico.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A short time since there was held in this city a meeting in memory of that great Irish patriot and martyr, Robert Emmet. The principal speaker on that occasion was the notorious Senator Tillman of South Carolina. For my part, I cannot understand why the committee in charge at that meeting gave Mr. Tillman the use of their platform.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of March 2 you publish a letter signed "Jersey," headed "The Indictment of Wisker." The contents of this letter from beginning to end meet with my most hearty approval, and should and will, I believe, add its weight to the sympathy that is felt by a large number of people for the unfortunate engineer, John M. Wisker.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 8 -- Society at Lakewood has been very gay this week. Such an amount of entertaining has never been crowded into any previous week this season. Besides the round of teas, luncheons, and dinners, the social features of the week include charity entertainments. Lenten lectures, and last, but not least, a ping pong tournament, which was held at the Lakewood Hotel.

WOODBINE, Iowa, March 8 -- Mrs. Hillis, mother of the Rev. Newell Dwight Hillis of Brooklyn, who last October was stricken with paralysis and was expected to die, is again in a critical condition. The physician in attendance reports her as being very feeble, her appetite and speech being gone, and has small hope of her recovery.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Without taking official action, the Maregette Club will not participate officially, and probably not by any representation, in the celebration of Illinois Day at the Charleston Exposition. This was decided at a meeting of several committees last night, and is an echo of the Lieut. Gov. Tillman episode, in which President Roosevelt was requested to withdraw his acceptance to present a sword to a South Carolina soldier.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, pianist and composer, took possession yesterday afternoon of all that part of New York interested in the divine art of music. His record was unprecedented, amazing, extraordinary. He played in opposition to himself, filled two great auditoriums, turned crowds of people away from both, and entertained 7,000 persons with music written or performed by him.

Did They Come from Boston: He was quite deaf, and his wife, possibly for the sake of domestic harmony in physical and mental shortcomings, had gone lame as to her sense of humor. So it happened that the audience at Weber and Fields's a few nights ago got two shows for one price of admission.

LONDON, March 8 -- King Edward and Queen Alexandra participated in a number of inspections and ceremonies at Plymouth to-day, including the distribution of China medals. Among the recipients was Admiral Sir. Edward Hobart Seymour, who commanded the first Pekin relief expedition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I respectfully ask space in your columns to reply to an editorial which appeared in to-day's TIMES under the head of "Commissioner Lindenthal's Plan." I refer to the following paragraph:

ON foundations built more than half a century ago a monument is now in course of erection near Ephrata, Lancaster County, Penn., to mark the burial place of 200 revolutionary soldiers who died at the Mount Zion cloister of the Seventh Day Bunkers after the battle of Brandywine.

The Hon. James H. Ross, Governor of the Yukon Territory, spent a little over an hour in this city on his way to Ottawa. The Governor has just come out from the Yukon country, and was in excellent health and spirits. He was accompanied by his brother and Arthur Hitchcock, M.L. A., Moosejaw, who are also on their way east.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 8 -- John P. Altgeld, former Governor of Illinois, was the guest of the Independent Club at a banquet given to-night. Ex-Gov. Altgeld spoke on the subject. "Shall the people own the monopolies ."

NEW HAVEN, March 8 -- Yale baseball leaders have aroused the university to the unpromising baseball outlook for the season, and as a result there is now unparalleled activity among the undergraduates in bringing out all of the available material that there is in college.

The Lords' Committee on Betting continued their interesting investigation yesterday, when welshing, tips, and street betting in the metropolis formed the subject of the evidence. Viscount Peel again presided.

PITTSBURG, March 8 -- The following are the estimates of the cost of improvements to be made by the United States Steel Corporation in Pittsburg, work on which has either started, or will be during the present year:

One of the most exciting and closely contested hockey games played in this Winter's series of the Amateur Hockey League was played at the St. Nicholas Rink last night between the Crescent Athletic Club and the New York Hockey Club teams. It resulted in a victory of 4 to 3 for the Crescent team.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 8 -- B.F. Keith, the New York manager, has secured an option on a site for a theatre in Pittsburgh B.F. Nash, his personal representative, who has been in the city seeking a location for the past fortnight or more, left to-day for New York with his mission completed.

Mayor Low made public a letter sent yesterday to Andrew D. Baird of Brooklyn in reference to proposed amendments to the tenement house law as affecting the Borough of Brooklyn. A movement was started by the builders to have the provisions of the tenement house law in reference to air space amended, and a bill was introduced in the Legislature by Assemblyman Ash.

LONDON, March 8 -- Charles Frohman is leveling himself to rehearsals of "The Girl from Maxim's," which opens at the Criterion Theatre March 22. This, and "Ben-Hur," which is in active preparation at the Drury Lane Theatre, promise to be the most interesting productions of a month that has been prolific of new plays.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The strained Cuban reciprocity situation is prolific of compromise plans. The Morris scheme, the Tawney project, and the other propositions which look to the avoidance of immediate action on the...

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 8 -- An epidemic of colds and rheumatism has been left on the trail of Prince Henry of Prussia on his tour through the West. Milwaukee has suffered most, probably because the large German population turned out more enthusiastically than at any city on the royal visitor's route.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 26 -- Within a few months, thanks to the humane sentiment of Americans, a most necessary reform probably will be well under way in Porto Rico. Cruelty to animals henceforth will be a crime. The last bill of the present legislative session, which will end on March 1, was introduced by Secretary Hartzell, and imposes severe penalties for maltreating dumb beasts.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Chairman Knapp of the Interstate Commerce Commission stated to-day that the proceedings to be instituted against railroad officials, as a sequel to their recent admissions of wholesale rate-cutting, would be civil actions in equity to enjoin the carriers from further violations of the law.

NEW HAVEN, March 8 -- This week promises to be the most interesting that Connecticut has seen since the present Constitution was adopted in 1818. After ten weeks of argument the Constitutional Convention that is now in session at Hartford has reached a vote on the question of representation in the General Assembly, arid Wednesday probably will see this problem settled.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Thomas B. Atkins, Secretary of the Maritime Canal Company, was examined at considerable length before the Senate Committee on Isthmian Canals to-day regarding the concessions made to that company. He said that the company had paid the Nicaraguan Government $25,000 for lands along the right of way, it having 50,000 acres in one grant.

We have already expressed the opinion that the municipality should pay no money to Messrs. HORGAN SLATTERY except at the end of a lawsuit; and that, if it must pay them any, it would be more respectable, and probably cheaper, to pay them damages for not being allowed to do architectural work for the city than commissions for doing it.

The Cunarder Lucania, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday, had some more interesting chats on the way over by means of the Marconi wireless telegraph system. This is the Lucania's first arrival at this port since Operator Hepworth had his midocean talk with the Kronprinz Wilhelm, on which occasion for two hours the Cunarder Campania, westward bound, tried to break in on the conversation.

The central idea of M. Hugues Le Roux, in his lecture on the "French Family of Yesterday and To-day," delivered at the Horace Mann School of Columbia University yesterday morning, was that this basis of French society, the family, is not at all known to the outer world and consequently is misjudged.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit me to say that my experiences of street cleaning and care are the same as those signed. I think, "G.A. W." in Thursday's TIMES? On that day the stacks of pails, cans, and boxes in front of nice dwelling houses on the upper west side had reached a formidable quantity.

THERE are few extant writings which throw much light upon the customs and manners of our forefathers of old New York two centuries ago, and the antithetical and contradictory statements contained in many of the pamphlets and chronicles handed down to us cast but vague shadows of truth.

The illness or TOLSTOI suggests that nations have to pass through the same troubles, although at different times, and points a parallel between certain phases of Russian thought to-day and events that took place in Western Europe 500 years ago.
Gen. Frederick Funston was the guest of honor at a dinner given last night at the Lotos Club, which proved to be one of the most successful ever given at the club.

Mr. J. PIERPONT MORGAN was already one of the chief benefactors of the Metropolitan Museum. But he has now made himself a still more conspicuous benefactor and shown himself a friend in need to the Museum by securing for it the permanent possession of the Garland Collection.

Charles Guden, elected Sheriff of Kings County last November, and who was removed by Gov. Odell on Friday, will, according to plans last night, surrender the office to Col. Norman S. Dike, his successor, to-morrow. Mr. Guden, it was understood, had decided to vacate his quarters in the county building in Brooklyn and seek redress in the courts.

ARTISTIC entrances to some of the finest houses in New York show remarkable instances of the modern development of art applied to industrial progress. The cheapening processes of manufacturing metal ornaments for interior and exterior decoratlons, and the art of working these up into elaborate and tasteful designs, have revolutionized architects methods of constructing public and private buildings in recent years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The "Man in the Street" adds another version to a joke which has already traveled widely for one so young. I refer to the paragraph in last Sunday's issue in which Joseph Jefferson, while driving from Buzzard's Bay to Onset, was (said to have been) asked by two bloomer-clad women:

EL PASO, Texas, March 8 -- The Southern Pacific relief train with the bodies of the dead and with those injured in the wreck at Maxon, arrived here to-night. The bodies were taken to a temporary morgue and the injured to hotels or hospitals.
CERTAIN achievements of the opera season which ended last night are shown by the following table:

THE revival of hand bookbinding among American woman may be said to have passed the fad stage. Since Miss Evelyn Nordhoff went over to study with Cobden-Sanderson seven years ago, and then came back and established her bindery, hundreds of American women have turned their attention in this direction.

"Corporal" Herman A. Braun, celebrated as the Federal soldier who, overlooking the natural prejudices of a prisoner for his captors, wrote a book to do justice to the Confederate management of Andersonville prison, will be buried in Cave Hill Cemetery this afternoon [Friday, Feb. 28.] That book cost him the friendship of many old comrades and almost lost him his position in the G.A.R.
NEWPORT, R.I., March 8 -- Charles F. Hoffman, Jr., of New York has rented for the coming Summer the Pendleton estate on the Cliffs, between the estates of H. McKay Twombley and Mrs. Ogden Goelet.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 8 -- The Manufacturers' Association of this city announced their decision not to increase wages above the rate previously set, namely, a fraction above 6 per cent., in letters to Secretary Whitehead of the Weavers' Association and Secretary Taylor of the Textile Council to-day.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., March 8 -- The crews of the sealing fleet, numbering about 3,000 men, went on strike this morning, demanding a higher price for the catch than is now paid. The present rate is $3 per hundredweight. The men demand $4.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 8 -- In the local market to-day there was unusual activity in Choctaw common, and Union Traction exhibited evidence of good buying, the stock advancing 1/2. Keeping pace with the rise in New York, Pennsylvania Railroad touched 76, and Reading common reflected increased demand, but Lehigh Navigation fell 1 1/8 points and closed at the bottom.

There was little life to yesterday's stock market, but what little there was resulted in keeping prices generally strong and in some instances advancing them. In the early part of the trading there was a disposition to await the bank statement, while immediately following its publication room traders and professionals endeavored to depress the entire list by offerings of short stock.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 8 -- The forty days period of the penitential season is being kept here by those prominent in social circles, and they appear to consider it a splendid respite from the incessant round of pleasures the Winter months bring. All thoroughly enjoy the walks beside old ocean, the chair rides, or sitting on the piers listening to the band concerts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter published in your issue of March 2 Mr. Paul Plimton takes exception to my recent statement that the La Fayette honored with the freedom of the city in 1824 was the son of the great Marquis, and makes long extracts from Hassard's "History of the United States," none of which, however, alludes to the bestowal of the distinction in question.

MONTE CARLO, March 8 -- The two remaining games, begun this morning, resulted as follows: Napier succumbed to Teichmann, and Janowski beat Tschigorin. The record of all the players up to date is appended:

BALTIMORE, Md., March 8 -- The Art Loan Exhibition at the Fifth Regiment Armory arranged under the auspices of the Municipal Art Society, of which Mr. W.W. Spence is President, has formed the principal subject of interest in Baltimore during the past week. The exhibition comprises a magnificent display of the chief art treasures of the city culled from private collections.

The recurrence of Washington's Birthday recalls some interesting points, and its observance by a dinner at the old Morris house was highly appropriate. This storied mansion will gradually drop the Jumel name and also its associations, while those of the Morris family will resume their importance.

TWO HUNDRED quarts of soup. 7,200 oysters, 500 chickens, 450 pounds of fish, 2,000 pounds of beef, 600 ducks, besides innumerable gallons of coffee and scores of freezers of ice cream, were needed to serve the guests at last night's dinner to Prince Henry. The banquet was the largest ever prepared in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Florence Burns, the young woman accused of the murder of Walter S. Brooks at the Glen Island Hotel on Feb. 14, was arraigned yesterday morning before Justice Mayer in the Court of Special Sessions for the continuance of the examination in her case, postponed a week ago. As early as 8 o'clock the corridors of the Criminal Court Building began to fill up with persons interested in the fate of Miss Burns.

ALBANY, March 8 -- On the train which left the Grand Central Station at 1 o'clock last Monday for Albany was Col. Abe Gruber. Tired out by the long delay at Hudson in consequence of the high water, Col. Gruber stretched himself out on the sofa in the compartment occupied by himself, Chairman Ten Eyck of the Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee, and District Leader Edward Healy, and went to sleep.

If there is one point in connection with the South African campaign regarding which enlightened opinion is practically unanimous, it is that our shooting leaves very much to be desired. The public has at last woke up to the importance of the subject, and now recognizes the value of possessing a large number of men among the civilian population accustomed to handle a rifle and use it with effect.

With the police hot upon his trail for forgery and a private detective standing outside of his room to see that he did not get away without paying his board bill, James "Webster, forty-seven years old, a traveling salesman of shirt waists, residing at 4 Rising Place, Rochester, N.Y., killed himself yesterday morning by swallowing carbolic acid, at the Herald Square Hotel.

To arrange for an international athletic carnival during the week of the coronation festivities in London is the purpose of W. A. Gavin and G.C. Lee, representatives of the National Sporting Club of London, who arrived on the steamship St. Paul yesterday.

As usual the athletes of Battery E carried off the lion's share of the honors at the indoor meeting of the Thirteenth Regiment Heavy Artillery of Brooklyn, held in the armory, Sumner and Jefferson Avenues, last night. Battery E not only won a majority of the events, but made a new record for the meeting.

Much interest has been aroused by Commissioner STEWART'S report of building operations projected in Greater New York for the year 1901, showing that the aggregate amount, for Manhattan and the Bronx, was $112,000,000, and that this is nearly double that of the previous year.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 8 -- It appears to-night that the river here will reach a stage of 40 to 41 feet on the present rise. This will do great damage to property in the low lands, and great alarm is felt among the farmers in the bottoms.

The trading in the outside market yesterday was relatively larger than that of the earlier days of the week. In several stocks which recently have not been active transactions were fairly brisk, and in some few stocks there was evidence of considerable interest. The course of prices presented the same irregular aspect which has marked the trading for some days past.

Columbia defeated Yale in the junior competition for the Morris Medals at fencing in the Fencers' Club rooms last night. Play in the final round between the colleges was exceedingly close, the score standing at four bouts each when in the deciding bout F.B. Clark, the Columbia Captain, defeated E. Calmer of Yale, making the final tally 5 to 4 for Columbia.

With the disposal of the National golf championship tournament for the women of the United States the National tournament programme is now complete and the Executive Committee has given indication of quick work by fixing the dates for the three events. The amateur championship, Which will be played on the Glenview links, near Chicago, will be held, at the suggestion of the Glenview officers, during the week of July 15.

President Louis F. Haffen of the Borough of the Bronx has received so many complaints from residents of that borough concerning the inconvenience and danger of overhead telegraph and telephone wires that he has decided to take action. Under Section 525 of the new charter the powers formerly vested in the Board of Electrical Control are transferred to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

We commend to Commissioner PARTRIDGE the consideration whether his duty to the policemen detailed for service at the New York terminal of the Brooklyn Bridge is not to encase them in some kind of armor sufficiently stiff and resistent to protect these unfortunate men from having their bones crushed and their viscera displaced by the pressure to which they are daily subjected.

ORANGE, N.J., March 9. -- Mr. Lock Wing, the Chinese Vice Consul at New York, who has been the guest here of Judge John B. Lander, occupied the pulpit in the St. Cloud Presbyterian Church this morning by invitation of the pastor, the Rev. Robert Gardner McGregor.

The need of better educational facilities in the South is recognized there as well as throughout the country. The South is doing much and preparing to do more, and the rest of the country is prepared to help. The "General Education Board" was formed systematically to direct aid to Southern education.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9. -- Decorators were busy all to-day arranging the interior of the Mayor's office and the Union League for the reception of Prince Henry, who will reach this city from New York about 10:30 o'clock to-morrow morning over the Pennsylvania Railroad. All the final details of the programme for the Prince's stay of five hours have been concluded and everything points to the proceedings being carried out without a hitch.

CINCINNATI, March 9. -- The lock-out of the brewery workmen of Cincinnati, Covington, and Newport, which has been in progress for a month, promises to end tomorrow. The main issue now is the Brewery Workmen's request that all the men be allowed to return without acting on the recognition of the engineers' contract, and that all parties to the controversy shall abide by the decision of the American Federation of Labor.
"The Religious Crisis in America" was the topic chosen for his sermon yesterday by Dr. Georse C. Lorimer, pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church. He said in part:

As Gov. ODELL appears to have an effective control over the Legislature it may be assumed that his bill, introduced in the Assembly by Mr. ALLDS of Chenango, providing for the appointment of a new State officer, the Fiscal Supervisor of State Charities, will be passed by that body.

NORFOLK, Va., March 9. -- From present indications the street car strike by no means is over. It is very probable that the strikers will not accept the terms of settlement named by the Arbitration Committee of the Chamber of Commerce last night, though both strikers and company agreed to accept the arbitration decision.

Under the auspices of the West Side, and Army Branches of the Young Men's Christian Association a patriotic meeting for young men was held yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Gen. O.O. Howard presided and Gen. Charles F. Roe of the National Guard and William Cary Sanger, Assistant Secretary of War, made speeches.

Would-be depressors of market values are not finding much consolation in the reports of railroad earnings being put out from time to time by the leading railroad systems of the country. Instead of predicted decreases -- and decreases would not be surprising in view of the phenomenal increases lately reported -- there have come, with only here and there an exception, steadily expanding earnings, increases piling upon increases.
Prince Henry's last Sunday of his trip to this country was spent in a way that appeared to give him as much enjoyment as any of his experiences in New York.

BERLIN, March 9. -- Some of the daily papers have begun summing up the results of Prince Henry's trip to the United States. Their tone is one of complete satisfaction. They declare the Prince's trip was never intended to have any specific political aim, but merely to bring about an improvement in the popular feeling in both countries.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 9. -- The train crew of the fast freight, eastbound, due here at 2 o'clock, had an unusual and unpleasant experience this morning between Trenton and this city. Two dead men were picked up, one of them having been killed by the train itself, and one being found by the trainmen beside the track.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Miss Alice Roosevelt, the daughter of the President, with, several friends and accompanied by a maid, left here to-night for a visit to Gen. and Mrs. Leonard Wood at Havana, going by rail to Florida. Mrs. Harriet Blaine Beale and Capt. Philip were of the party. Miss Roosevelt expects to return to Washington the latter part of the month.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Press, in a recent editorial supporting the forced and niggardly compromise offered on behalf of the beet-sugar interests to Cuba, says that the question is "whether an annual sum total of $100,000,000 is to reach American or Cuban pockets." I will not say, let them be fair upon the facts of the case presented.

In accordance with the wish of the German Emperor that his brother should be entertained at dinner by some representative American family during his visit to the United States, Prince Henry dined last night with Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr., who, when she was Miss Grace Wilson, met the Emperor abroad while on Mrs. Robert Goelet's yacht.
HORTA, Azores, March 9. -- The Cunard liner Etruria anchored here at 6 o'clock this evening. All on board are well.

Daniel F. Hays, a waiter, twenty-six years old, walked into the Grand Windsor Hotel, 9 Chatham Square, last Saturday night and engaged a room. The night clerk believing the rash on his face was produced by smallpox, informed the day clerk.

Although there was a good attendance of oarsmen at the boathouses of the various Harlem River rowing clubs yesterday, there were few crews out upon the water, for the damp and chilly air was altogether too suggestive of rheumatism.

THE FATES OF FUAD PASHA. -- The cable dispatches have already given some information concerning the arrest and deportation of Marshal Fuad Pasha in Constantinople, but in the light of the prominence of the victim -- as "the hero of Elena" his name was familiar a quarter of a century ago as one of the most brilliant Turkish officers in the Russo-Turkish war -- the methods taken to apprehend him are considered most extraordinary.

A recent statement of our to the effect that the term "German-American" is offensive "only as all such hyphenizations are offensive" has given one of our readers a chance to make what he doubtless thought was an extremely neat dig at -- we will not say ourselves, but at everybody who likes only one sort of Americanism, and that the American sort.

In the annual report of the Forest, Fish, and Game Commission there are some interesting facts as to the steady and not slow destruction of the forests of this State. In the Adirondack forest region, outside the holdings of the State, which cannot be cut, there are now about 700,000 acres that have not been lumbered, or from which a second cutting of spruce can now be obtained.

HARRODSBURG, Ky., March 9. -- Daniel Wilson, who lives in the edge of Washington County, twenty miles from here, had a thrilling battle with crows yesterday. The snow and sleet of the past four weeks have been very hard on the birds and they have become so famished that it was no unusual sight to see them perched on the backs of sheep and lambs, riding about and pecking into the flesh.

Col. John F. Gaynor, ex-Treasurer of the Democratic State Committee, who has been proclaimed by Justice Emory Speer of the United States Court at Savannah, Ga., a fugitive from justice, is believed by some of his friends to be in Canada.

WASHINGTON, D.C., March 9. -- Sunday brought something of a lull in the agitation over Cuban reciprocity, although the elements for and against concessions continued to prosecute their plans in anticipation of the struggle on Tuesday night, when the fourth conference of House Republicans will be held.

ALBANY, March 9. -- Senator N.N. Stranahan of the Oswego district, after the close of the session of the Legislature, which is expected to take place in the last days of March, will proceed to New York to enter upon the discharge of his duties as Collector of that port. He will take with him the best wishes of all his friends in the Legislature, with whom he has been a great favorite.
