BOSTON, Mass., March 9. -- Ten thousand men -- teamsters, freight clerks, freight handlers, and longshoremen -- will go on strike in the morning in sympathy with 100 freight handlers of the New Haven Railroad, who went out last night rather than handle "scab" freight. The movement is the direct outcome of the strike of the teamsters of the R.S. Brine Transportation Company.

MANILA, March 9. -- Capt. Howland, aide on the staff of Gen. Wheaton, who was sent to report on the state of affairs in Rizal Province after the recent outbreak of activity there, reports that the insurgents have now been dispersed, and that the soldiers and constabulary are closely pursuing them.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 9. -- There is now every reason to believe that the Legislature will not adjourn until March 28. It is understood that a resolution will be offered Monday evening in the Senate that the Legislature adjourn sine die on March 21, but that later the date will be changed to March 28.

The individual championship handball tournament of the Union Bat Club was continued on the courts of the clubhouse. West One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street and the Harlem River, yesterday afternoon. Fourteen matches were played. J. H. Kirk took the lead in the series, with 135 points.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Chairman Fowler of the House Committee on Banking and Currency, to-morrow will introduce an important financial measure framed by the Republican members of the committee after conferences extending through the last two months. It brings together into one financial measure a number of propositions which heretofore have been urged separately.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, March 9. -- The novelist William Dean Howells, after visiting his brother, J.A. Howells, the veteran Ohio editor, at Jefferson, this county, for a few days, has left for Pittsburg, from which place he will take a steamboat trip down the Ohio River. This is a journey he has been planning for a long time. His brother accompanied him.

Several important changes were made in the old rules, and a number of new rules were added to the code which will govern in the world's championship pool tourney commencing to-night at the Montauk Academy. Brooklyn, at a meeting of room keepers and patrons of the game yesterday in the Montauk's new academy hall.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 9. -- George White, a motorman in the employ of the Union Railway Company, has been laid off for saving the life of a boy. The boy was saved at great risk yesterday afternoon at Beechwood Avenue, in the western end of this city.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 9. -- Word has reached here that Cornelius Van Ness, the octogenarian millionaire of Port Jervis, formerly of New York, has been baptised in the River Jordan by the Rev. William K. Hall of Newburg, N.Y. Mr. and Mrs. Van Ness sailed on the steamer Celtic for a trip to the Orient his desire being to gratify an ambition of years to be baptised in the Jordan.

CLEVELAND, March 9. -- As an outcome of last week's meeting in this city, a burlesque show trust was formed by the representatives of the Empire Circuit Association of Burlesque Theatres and the Variety Managers' Association of America. The scheme is the result of several years of deliberation between the theatre managers and the managers of burlesque companies.

BERLIN, March 9. -- The Boerse showed a decidedly quieter tone during the past week, and the volume of transactions was considerably reduced. The New York market, together with the fall in Kafirs at London, caused a waiting attitude to he displayed here, with little disposition to invest.

We congratulate Senator CLAY of Georgia on having taken the post and done the work of leader of the Democratic Party in the Senate with energy and distinguished ability and in a courageous fashion to which the party has too long been unused.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Lieut. Gov. Woodruff said to-night that the understanding which he had of Sheriff Guden's action in resisting, the claim of Norman S. Dike to act as Sheriff, by virtue of his appointment by the Governor, was that Guden did not want to take any action which might militate against him in the legal proceedings which he will begin to establish his right to the office.

Before a gathering of 2,000 military men and pretty girls, all of whom by cheering and yelling lent an atmosphere of excitement, the athletic meet of the Twenty-second Regiment was held last night in its armory, at Sixty-seventh Street and Broadway. For the first time in many years Company A won the first trophy, scoring 47 points.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of this date you state editorially that the lintel de Logerot on Fifth Avenue, corner of Eighteenth Street, this city, has among other buildings been "swept away" to make room for modern business structures, thus clearly conveying the impression that the Hotel de Logerot exists no longer.

The Committee of Forestry of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation, which is composed of. Edmund P. Martin, Chairman; John H. Washburn, Edwin S. Marston, Peter F. Schofield, and Henry S. Harper, has sent a long statement to Gov. Odell and the members of the Legislature concerning pending amendments to the State Constitution as they relate to the State Forest Preserve.

Mr. Bauer's recent appearance with orchestra, when he played the Saint-Saens concerto in G minor in a manner unsurpassed by any other artist, naturally awakened a desire to hear him once more in recital, and the audience yesterday afternoon was a large one. It must be confessed that close attention to the recital left one with precisely the same impression as was gained from his first appearance here in this form of entertainment.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The fight between the House leaders and the sugar-beet representatives over the Cuban question may be settled to-morrow night, but there is no certainty that it will be settled even if a vote shall be taken on the pending bill. It is not simply a question as to which side can command the greater number of Republican votes.

LONDON, March 10 -- There was a brisk demand for money to-day and supplies were scarce at stiffer rates. Discounts were easy. Operators on the Stock Exchange were practically idle, except so far as concerned the arrangement of the mining account, the comparative smallness of which was in striking contrast with the volume of the recent settlement.
LONDON, March 11 -- Distinguishing features of the editorials in the London morning papers on the disaster to Lord Methuen's force are, first, the outburst of sympathy for Methuen, ...

ALBANY, March 10 -- In a letter to Chairman Bedell of the Assembly Committee on Railroads, Mayor Low makes known his position with regard to legislation to remedy existing conditions in the Park Avenue tunnel. The Mayor's letter was handed to Mr. Bedell to-night by Assistant Corporation Counsel Whitman. Briefly stated, the Mayor's position is as follows:

LONDON, March 11 -- It was announced yesterday that Lieut. Gen. Lord Methuen bad been wounded and captured by the Boers commanded by Gen. De la Rey. The Boers also captured four guns. Three British officers and 38 men were killed and 5 officers and 72 men were wounded. One officer and 200 men are missing.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The wife of Sol. Berliner, bon vivant and politician of New York City, now Consul at Teneriffe, has written a letter to a friend in this city in which she vigorously "roasts" the people among whom her husband's lot is cast, English as well as Spaniards. Mrs. Berliner was a Miss Ottenbergh, daughter of a well-to-do Washingtonian, and was married to Sir. Berliner last September.

The little Williams Gallery, 397 Fifth Avenue, has a collection of water colors ma oils which will he something of a surprise for those who have Known the work of T.F. Wainewright only from the small, delicately painted landscapes which have enjoyed a reasonable popularity in New fork and Hoston during the past three decades.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10 -- Lawyer James B. Dill addressed the Economic Department of Harvard University on "National Laws for Trusts" this afternoon.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Senator Elsberg tonight introduced a bill appropriating $60,000 to replace the property burned in the fire which destroyed the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

It is significant and encouraging that the Republican majority of the House Committee on Banking and Currency have agreed upon a very intelligent and effective bill for the completion of the establishment of the gold standard, for the final redemption of a large part of the outstanding legal-tender notes, and for increasing the elasticity of the bank issues and enabling the banks to respond more promptly and usefully to the needs of business.

Information was gathered yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Lord in the case of the death of James McAuliffe, the witness in the police trials who is said to have earned the enmity of certain men on the police force who were firm friends of Diamond, Bissert, and Glennon. Other policemen are under indictment, and McAuliffe was to have given additional testimony.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 10 -- Announcement is made to-night of the personnel of the working committees of the Yale and Harvard Committees of Conference on university athletics. The committees are: Harvard -- Prof. Ira N. Hollis, James J. Storrow, and W.E. Ladd; Yale -- Walter Camp, R.G. Gurnsey, and Charles Gould.

In yesterday's market for outside securities there were few developments of special interest. The irregular course of the Stock Exchange market was reflected by similar conditions on the curb. For the most part, however, net changes were fractional. The San Francisco Street Railway issues were among the most active in the list, and more attention was given to these stocks than to most others.

Expert medical testimony, presented by the defense, to show that William Marsh Rice died a natural death, occupied the day's session yesterday at the beginning of the seventh week of Albert T. Patrick's trial on the charge of instigating Charles F. Jones to chloroform his old employer.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

President Cantor of the Borough of Manhattan yesterday appointed the 110 members of the local School Boards, who are to serve without pay. Many of them appeared at the City Hall and were sworn in at noon. In the list there are forty women. Mayor Low was present, and congratulated the new officials on their appointment.

Earl Grey, President of the Central Public House Trust Association of England, upon the invitation of members of the City Club delivered at the clubhouse, in West Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon, an address upon the working of the new system for diminishing' the evils of the saloon.

The evidence of any reluctance on the part of high police officials to further the investigation now in progress into the circumstances attending the death of JAMES MCAULIFFE, the Glennon witness, may be attended with consequences far more serious than have resulted from any revelation of police iniquity since the present Metropolitan police force displaced that which under Mayor WOOD had become a municipal disgrace, or worse.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- For nearly two hours to-day Mr. Vest of Missouri addressed the Senate in opposition to the pending Ship Subsidy bill. No member of the body has been accorded more flatteringly close attention than he received. Despite his evident feebleness, he spoke with force and fire, and at times became brilliantly eloquent.

Prince Henry rose early yesterday morning, and after a light breakfast with his suite in his apartments at the WaldorfAstoria bade farewell to Manager Boldt, entered his carriage, and was driven quickly to the Twenty-third Street ferry, where he took a special boat at 7:50 o'clock for Jersey City.

The services of the steamship St.-Paul of the American Line in the war with Spain will be commemorated to-day on the vessel at the foot of Fulton Street, North River, by the unveiling at the foot of the staircase of the main companionway of a bronze tablet and a bronze plate, with appropriate exercises and addresses by distinguished persons.

After deliberating more than three hours yesterday the Coroner's jury empaneled to investigate the fire in the Park Avenue Hotel on the morning of Feb. 22, in which twenty-one persons lost their lives, brought in a verdict that the fire was caused by sparks from the burning Seventy-first Regiment Armory, across Park Avenue from the hotel, and that the hotel was not properly equipped for the safety of the guests.

ALBANY, March 10 -- To-day was marked by two important events in local financial circles. The Union Trust Company began its career and the Park Bank passed out of existence as a State bank of deposit and discount and became a branch of the trust company. The first depositor of the trust company was the Albany City Savings Institution and during the day deposits in the neighborhood of $400,000 were received.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The "bird cage" sign proposed for street purposes is a patented article, and therefore prohibited by the charter. Chapter XXIII., Title 3, Section 1,554, as it would be impossible to bring such a monstrosity within the provision of the law, which says, "There must be a fair and reasonable opportunity for competition."

Charges preferred against the Board of Managers of the Manhattan State Hospital by Gov. Odell have called forth a reply which was made public yesterday. It is signed by President Henry B. Howland, Secretary George E. Dodge. Henry H. Hoilister, John McAnerney, Eleonora Kinnicutt, Louisa Pierpont Satterlee, and Isaac N. Seligman.

BOSTON, March 10 -- After nearly six weeks of skirmishing the war between the organized teamsters, freight and express handlers of Boston, and the two railroad corporations, the New York, New Haven and Hartford and the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad, the latter locally known as the Boston and Albany, broke out to-day.

Lester Bennett, who has been employed as a special agent under State Superintendent of Elections McCullagh, and who is considered one of Mr. McCullagh's chief aides on the east side in preventing illegal registration and balloting, was shot and perhaps fatally wounded last night by Abe Kutner, the manager of the saloon at 11 Bleecker Street.

It would only be natural that in mid-Lent social matters should be dull, and also that there should be a reaction after the two days' festivities in honor of Prince Henry, especially when it is considered that many of the fashionables are at present in the South and West and others have gone to Europe.

The pool turnament for the world's championship was started last night in the new academy hall of the Montauk billiard rcoms, Brooklyn. Two games of 125 points each were played, H.P. Stofft of Cleveland defeating the "cowboy" expert, Charles Weston of "Wyoming in the first, 125 to 59. Grant Eby of this city beat Irving Long in the second game by a score of 125 to 93.

MONTREAL, Quebec, March 10 -- The Vanderbilt railway interests of the United States, who, through Dr. Seward Webb, are credited with having purchased the Canada Atlantic Railway system, have also secured an option on the Ottawa, Northern and Western Railway, and the Inter-Provincial Bridge, which spans the Ottawa River at the federal capital, and gives entrance to the new central station in that city.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 10 -- Fifty men reported to practice for the Princteton baseball team in the cage this afternoon. The greatest part of the time was spent in fast batting practice. A short drill in fielding followed, and the work closed with a brisk run around the cage. The battery candidates were given a little trying-out exercise, but were not allowed to use any speed.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Agricultural Department this afternoon issued the following crop report: Until the publicaton of the census figures of acreage, based on a farm-to-farm canvas, admit of the making of any necessary adjustments in the acreage figures of this department, no quantitative estimate of the amount of grain remaining in the hands of farmers on March 1 will be made by the statistician.

When a young volunteer Brigadier was captured in Virginia, forty years ago, with a squadron of cavalry, the President of the United States remarked that it was "too bad about those horses." He went on to explain that he could make any number of as good Brigadiers as the one in question, but he could not make horses.

There is now in progress in Boston a very serious strike of the freight handlers, sympathetic in character and growing out of a relatively unimportant disagreement originating with the teamsters employed by a local firm engaged in the freight-forwarding business. At the same time a great strike, which is expected to tie up all the cotton mills of Fall River, the outgrowth of a wages disagreement, is imminent.

The New York Clearing House Association yesterday held a meeting in honor of the memory of Frederick D. Tappen, the late President of the Gallatin National Bank. It was the first time in the history of the association that such a service had been held. A hundred Presidents and officers of banks, trust companies, and other financial institutions were present, and several of them delivered eulogies.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- As the market in Philadelphia did not participate in the earlier strength shown in Wall Street, it was but logical that it refused to yield when the sagging course followed in the monopolies. The arbitrage shares, however, felt the influence, but the local favorites held firm, and in the Choctaws there was a conspicuous show of strength with the preferred assuming the most prominence, rising over two points.

The bodies of two men, dressed in the uniforms of privates of the United States Army, were found by boatmen yesterday morning floating on a raft of driftwood off Sands Point Light, in Long Island Sound. One of the bodies has been identified as that of Thomas Corcoran, a private in Company D of the Eighty-first Coast Artillery, stationed at Fort Slocum.

LONDON, March 11 -- Referring to a dispatch to The Times from New York, giving a rumor that the object of Prince Henry's visit to America is to obtain the United States' permission for a German naval base in the Caribbean, the Vienna correspondent of The Times says the revelation of great political schemes on the Continent is almost invariably preceded by "a theoretic preparation of the world's opinion."

BOSTON, March 10 -- The Metropolitan Opera House company, under the direction of Mr. Grau. began to-night an engagement of two weeks at the Boston Theatre. The opera was Verdi's "Aida." Mr. Seppilli conducted. The cast was as follows; Aida, Emma Eames; Amneris, Louise Homer; a priestess, Miss Muilly; Radames, De Marchi; Ramfis, Journet; Amonasro, Scotti; the King, Muehlmaim; a messenger, Vanni.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Miss Edes entertained this evening in honor of Senator and Mrs. Depew. The guests to meet them were the Belgian Minister and Baroness Moncheur, the Attorney General and Mrs. Knox, Senator Kean, Mr. and Mrs. James Wadsworth, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wadsworth, Mme. Bonaparte, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Glover, the Hon. Maude Pauncefote, Miss Kean, Mrs. Perin, Mr. Hitt, Col. Morrell, John R. McLean, and T.B. Ferguson.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- For the third time a change has taken place in the Cabinet left by President McKinley to his successor, and this time the Secretary who goes is-one of those who went into office with the late President in March, 1897.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Another attempt was made to-day to change the effect of the law which Congress inadvertently passed regarding the new Census Bureau. This time it was in the form of a resolution introduced by Representatve Sims of Tennessee, who Saturday attempted to get the floor on a question of privilege for the purpose of revealing the alleged deception practiced in the House by Chairman Hopkins of the Census Committee.

News of the British losses in South Africa interfered with the strength of yesterday's New York stock market. This may seem illogical, but the same fact has been of record over and over again recently. What may disturb British sentiment is construed in Wall Street as of consequence on this side of the ocean as well, and Boer war developments are influences as acute as our own ups and downs in the Philippines.

Four persons were painfully injured, half a score or more were less seriously hurt by flying glass and escaping steam, and a numbered were badly frightened in a peculiar accident which happened to Madison Avenue car No. 1,927 at Madison Avenue and Forty-fourth Street yesterday about 5:30 o'clock P.M.
ALBANY, March 10 -- The annual report of the Superintendent of Insurance, Francis Hendricks, was submitted to the Legislature to-night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- Prince Henry of Prussia finished his American tour in this city to-day, and for the brief space of five hours was the guest of this municipality. His reception was most cordial, and his welcome heartfelt. From the moment when the special train bearing the imperial visitor steamed into the Pennsylvania Railroad Station the popular demonstration was hearty and spontaneous.

BERLIN, March 10 -- The dispute between Germany and Venezuela is nearing a settlement, but the terms of the settlement are as yet a Foreign Office secret. They are, however, satisfactory to Germany, and Venezuela has apparently yielded without Germany having made any direct threat or having had to do anything like sending an ultimatum.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 11 -- Capt. Archer of the University Gun Club team has issued a call for all candidates for the team to report for practice on Monday. During the first three weeks' practice shoots will be held once a week, after which the regular semi-weekly matches will be held on Stockton Field.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The work of the Reform Committee to secure excise legislation which would meet the needs of the situation in New York came to an unexpected ending here to-day. There was to have been a hearing to-day before the Assembly Committee on the bill drawn up by the Committee of Five and introduced by Mr. Newcomb.

PORTLAND, Me., March 11 -- Granville W. Leighton, teller of the National Traders' Bank of this city, is under arrest, a selfconfessed defaulter to the extent of $43,000. To-night the bank officials would make no statement further than that Leighton had made over to the institution all his real estate and other property, and that this, together with his bond, will make good the loss sustained by the bank.

There were many wordy contests at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday. The members called each other names and little public business was transacted. Tammany and Brooklyn Democrats were jubilant throughout the meeting because they claimed the Republican-Fusion majority had been disrupted on vital questions and that the friends of Mayor Low would not be able again to control the board.

LONDON, March 12 -- The Princess's Nose," a new play by Henry Arthur Jones, produced at the Duke of York's Theatre last evening, is not up to the mark of the author's best. He seems to have spent all his energy in devising a role, full of technical difficulties, for Irene Vanbrugh, whose return to the London stage after her long absence was received last evening with cheers.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 11 -- No little surprise was occasioned here to-day when at a meeting of the Kentucky Horse Breeders' Association Secretary Horace W. Wilson tendered his resignation to accept a similar position with the New Empire City track of New York. Wilson succeeded Edward A. Tipton here as Secretary in November, 1896.

FISHKILL LANDING, March 11 -- Charles H. O'Connor of New York, who travels for a Chicago publishing house, narrowly escaped being shot by mistake for a tramp last night. The section of the town surrounding Willow Street, on which are the homes of Walter Bell and R.F. Heaton, has lately been visited by tramps, who have terrorized women of the neighborhood.

ALBANY, March 11 -- President of the Borough of Manhattan, Jacob A. Cantor, and ex-Controller Bird S. Coler sat beside each other in the Senate Chamber to-day when the Senate Cities Committee was giving a hearing upon various bills, and were pointed out as the two most likely candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

Since the fire in the Park Avenue Hotel Inspectors of the Bureau of Buildings have visited nearly all the hotels in the city. In their reports they stated that some of the hotels were without the requisite fireescapes on certain parts of the building, and that inadequate precautions in this respect were lacking in others.

The general course of prices in the outside market yesterday showed no change from the conditions prevailing for some days past. For the most part, only small net changes resulted from the day's transactions, and the stocks which advanced were about as numerous as those which closed below Monday's prices.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Roosevelt to-day sent his first veto message to Congress. It was directed to the Senate, and the bill vetoed was one removing the charge of desertion from the naval record of John Glass. The message was as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- There was an abatement of yesterday's pressure on the Readings in the local market to-day. New York appeared as a buyer and the issue closed with but a slight loss. There was a revival of strength in Electric Company of America, stock that has been in seclusion for some time.

It is, of course, unprofitable and impertinent to speculate as to what may be the outcome of the suit against the Northern Securities Company undertaken by the Department of Justice. But we think that almost any layman, reading the argument of the Government and comparing it with the anti-trust law, must receive the impression that the case as stated comes within that law.

In deciding the anti-trust law of Illinois to be invalid the Supreme Court of the United States declares that a statute which permits farmers to form combinations to raise the price of agricultural products while a combination formed by manufacturers to raise or maintain the price of their products is made a crime conflicts with the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution, which says that all persons are entitled to equal protection of the laws.

Following the report from Washington that terms for a consolidation of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company and the Lanston Monotype Company had been agreed upon come denials of this transaction, and rumors of consolidation of interests between the Mergenthaler and others of the dozen companies in the field.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- The statement published in New York to the effect that Miss Susan B. Anthony, who is visiting at the home of her niece, Miss Lucy Anthony, in this city, is ill with pneumonia, is exaggerated. It was said at the house to-day that the venerable woman suffragist is somewhat indisposed, but that her illness is not at all serious.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Gov. Odell returned to Albany to-night. When asked about his visit to Washington. Gov. Odell said his trip was principally for recreation. He said he had talked with President Roosevelt about the reappointment of Capt. Joseph M. Dickey as Shipping Commissioner, and was assured by President Roosevelt that Capt. Dickey would be reappointed.

LONDON, March 12 -- Expressions of steadfastness have succeeded those of humiliation which were universally heard on the publication of the news of the disaster to Lord Methuen's column. There is little disposition to minimize the incident, but everywhere are heard and read declarations of a determination to maintain the tradition that blows serve to strengthen and stiffen British resolution.

Promoters of the scheme to widen Fifty-ninth Street from river to river to boulevard dimensions held their second meeting at the office of John D. Crimmins in that thoroughfare yesterday, and elected the following officers:

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Senator Clark's recent statement in THE NEW YORK TIMES that the Democrats were not unanimous for Cuban reciprocity and that he doubted whether a majority of them favored it received a certain measure of vindication to-day, when Representative John Thayer rose to a question or privilege in the House.

At the annual meeting of the American Ice Company, popularly known as the Ice Trust, held in Jersey City yesterday, Charles W. Morse, among others, was not re-elected a Director of the corporation. Mr. Morse was chiefly interested in formins this company, and was for two years its President.
BRUNSWICK, Ga., March 11 -- J. Pierpont Morgan and party arrived here this afternoon from New York and left immediately for Jekyl Island, where they will remain for several days.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 11 -- President of the Borough of Manhattan Jacob A. Cantor appeared before the Senate Committee on Cities to-day to urge the passage of the bill empowering the city to sell Blackwell's Island to the Government upon the stipulation that it should be used for a naval yard and a public park to which the citizens of New York should have free access.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- For several hours to-day the Senate had the Ship Subsidy bill under consideration. Mr. Mallory of Florida made an extended speech in opposition to the measure. His opposition was based chiefly on the ground that it would extend the favor of the United States Treasury to private individuals and corporations without a Just return for the expenditure.

BERLIN, March 11 -- In the Diet to-day the Foreign Secretary, Baron von Richthofen, after reading the answer of the British Government permitting the delivery of German charitable gifts to the Boers in the South African concentration camps, under the surveillance of the camp authorities, declared that the reply guaranteed a just distribution, and added:

BOSTON, March 11 -- The second day of the great strike of organized labor against the demands by railroad and steamship companies that merchandise delivered at freight depots by the R.S. Brine Transportation Company be not discriminated against witnesed large additions to the ranks of the strikers.

Charles Guden, who is defying the order of Gov. Odell removing him from the office of Sheriff of Kings County, stood at bay last night, the physical possession of the County Jail and of part of the suite of offices in the County Court House having been wrested from him during the day by Col. Norman S. Dike, the man appointed to succeed him, and nearly all his retainers having gone over to the enemy.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The Senate to-day by a vote of 27 to 12 passed Senator Brown's concurrent resolution proposing an amendment to the constitution relative to the Forest Preserve. The object of the proposed amendment is to permit of the cutting of timber in the Adirondacks and other forest lands of the State under a system of scientific forestry.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 11 -- The local market developed and held a rather firm tone to-day, despite the irregular record of Wall Street. Cotton Duck again figured prominently in the dealings and disclosed some qualities of unexpected firmness. The attempts to raid it down failed utterly. The common stock and income bonds both closed with a gain.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 11 -- Announcement of the appointment of new professors and other business transacted at a meeting of the Yale Corporation was made by the Secretary, the Rev. Anson Phelps Stokes, to-day.

Bridge Commissioner Lindenthal has planned a scheme by which he hopes to obtain from persons who use the Brooklyn Bridge during rush hours information which will show the currents of passenger traffic across the East River. This information is wanted to guide the department in planning the loading and unloading facilities at the Manhattan terminals of the three bridges -- the Brooklyn Bridge, the Williamsburg Bridge, and the Navy Yard Bridge.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The officials of the Department of Justice will make every effort to secure the extradition from Canada of, Gaynor and Greene, who are charged with complicity in the Savannah frauds, for which Capt. Oberlin M. Carter was sent to the penitentiary.

The Central Railroad of New Jersey yesterday published its annual report for the year ended on Dec. 31 last. The report is the most detailed ever published by the company. According to the figures given, the year was the most prosperous in the history of the company.

MONTE CARLO, March 11 -- The chess masters to-day engaged in the final round of the international tournament, and, as round seventeen of the Berger tables guided the pairing, the players were placed in the following order:

TRENTON, N.J., March 11 -- Charging fraud, four stockholders of the American Alkali Company to-day filed a bill in the United States Circuit Court here asking that the company be dissolved, and its affairs wound up.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The friends of the census clerks in Congress have not given up hope of securing some action which will nullify the effect of the President's order of Friday. A meeting of the House Census Committee was held this morning, at which the subject was discussed.

-- That long statement in regard to the State forests, prepared by the Forestry Committee of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation and sent by it to Gov. ODELL, expressed, in effect, the opinion that neither the Forestry Commission nor the Legislature was wise enough to be intrusted with any discretionary powers as to the treatment of the public woods.

LONDON, March 11 -- Money was in considerable demand to-day in connection with the settlement on the Stock Exchange, besides calls for various new issues of capital, and rates were firm. Discounts were steadier. Business on the Stock Exchange opened depressed. The topic of conversation was the capture of Gen. Methuen.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $6,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- In the House to-day, Mr. Burleson (Texas) called attention to the resolutions introduced by him a few days ago, calling on the Secretary of State for information as to whether he had declined to request the British Ambassador to furnish passports for Rev. Hiram W. Thomas and wife of Chicago, who were selected to distribute funds collected in Illinois for the relief of non-combatant prisoners in South Africa.
Mr. Plunket Greene, the popular Irish baritone, has returned to America, and yesterday afternoon he gave the first of two song recitals at Mendelssohn Hall. The programme was as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The first important speech which has been delivered in the House on the subject of Cuban reciprocity was made to-day by Representative William G. Brantley of Georgia. It was a striking speech, and the unusual compliment of silence and close attention was paid throughout by the House.

There was disappointment at the exhibition of the American Rose Society in the Berkeley Lyceum Building, West Fortyfourth Street, yesterday. The chief interest this year centred in the rose "The Helen Gould," and the teamsters in Boston going on strike at an inopportune time not a blossom of the flower was to be had for love or money.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Canal legislation made a decided advance to-day. The Davis bill was put on the order of third reading in the Senate, and the Weekes bill was advanced to third reading in the Assembly. The difference between the two bills is that the Weekes bill carries an appropriation of $5,500,000 for the Oswego feeder, while the Davis bill makes no provision for the Oswego route.

There is, we suppose, no doubt in any impartial mind that Lord KITCHENER'S proclamation of last Autumn, proclaiming the continued resistance of the Boers to be what "Mr. Dooley" calls a "nonunion war," was a very ill-advised performance. One of Lord ROSEBERY'S chief points against the Ministry was the issue of that proclamation, of the responsibility for which, however, he acquitted its ostensible author.

Prince Henry of Prussia, who arrived in this country Feb. 23 as the special representative of his brother, the German Emperor, at the naming of the latter's American-built yacht Meteor at Shooter Island, left for home yesterday afternoon on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 11 -- Cornell athletes representing the track, crew, basevall, and football met on common ground in the Cornell armory in a four-cornered basket ball carnival to-night, and the games drew a larger crowd and attracted more attention than any other contest held here this Winter.

The false statement that just previous to the outbreak of the Spanish war President McKINLEY suppressed and concealed from Congress dispatches from Madrid which might have averted hostilities has been stamped upon and destroyed in this country, but in England it still possesses vitality enough to do some mischief.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 11 -- Stephen J. Jesensky married the widow of Prof. Fogo at St. Paul's Cathedral, Nov. 16, and left his wife here while he visited Hungary. Mrs. Jesensky did not hear from him, and went to New York last week and made inquiries at the steamship office.

QUEBEC, Quebec, March 11 -- Col. John F. Gaynor of New York, whose bail of $40,000 was reported forfeited because of his disappearance from Savannah, where he was indicted on a charge of conspiracy to defraud the United States Government, is in town and registered publicly at the Chateau Fontenac.

There was a large outpouring of members of the Nineteenth Century Club at the regular meeting, held last evening at Sherry's. The feature of the evening was a discussion on "Should the Saloons be Opened on Sunday?" The first speaker was the Rev. Dr. W.S. Rainsford, who was introduced by Dr. E.R.L. Gould, the President of the club.

M.L. C. Ernst have sold the nine-story building at the northeast corner of Broadway and Howard Street, 60.10 by 97.8. The sellers declined yesterday to give any further details of the transaction. They acquired the property in trade about eight months ago, and have been holding it, according to reliable report, at about $600,000.

BOSTON, Mass., March 11 -- Money conditions are firm and appear to be gradually working toward higher rates. Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds, lOc; call loans, 3 1/2 to 4. Time money, 4 to 4 1/2. Clearing House exchanges, $23,835,720. Balances, $1,576,897. Prices of copper stocks were Inclined to sag.

LONDON, March 11 -- Delegates from a number of the British Chambers of Commerce visited the Foreign Secretary, Lord Lansdowne, at the Foreign Office, to-day, and presented a memorial relative to British trade with Cuba.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The Senate Finance Committee met this afternoon to consider the Charities bill. Majority Leader Allds, Minority Leader Palmer, and Chairman Rogers of the Judiciary Committee of the Assembly also were present. The meeting had been advertised as a public hearing, but no one appeared to either favor or oppose the bill.

There was a considerable increase in the transactions in the outside market yesterday. Several stocks were traded in to a much larger extent than they have been recently, and a number of issues were more or less active. As a whole the net changes were not important, although in Consolidated Refrigerating and one or two other issues substantial net gains were recorded.

Literary thefts of a peculiar character were suggested yesterday morning in the Yorkville Court, when Edward Kearney, thirty years of age, was arraigned before Magistrate Mayo charged with the larcency of rare books, autograph letters, and valuable manuscripts from the home of John D. Crimmins, 40 East Sixty-eighth Street.
LONDON, March 12 -- King Edward will fit out the Britannia for the coming yachting season.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- In a report to the State Department, dated Jan. 13, Rufus Fleming, United States Consul at Edinburgh, says:

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Cabinet rumor makers continue to busy themselves with Mr. Roosevelt's official family, predicting now the retirement of Secretary Wilson of the Agricultural Department and Attorney General Knox. The Attorney General is to go out, it is said, after the suit he has begun against the Northern Securities Company shall be decided.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Republican leaders have won in their first engagement with the beet sugar representatives, and apparently have demonstrated that a majority of the Republicans of the House favor the measure of relief for Cuba suggested by the Ways and Means Committee.

In view of the demonstrated utility of the pneumatic tube service in mail transmission it is much to be regretted that the business management of the system which proved so useful in its limited way in New York and other cities seems to have erected so serious a barrier to its further employment.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- General debate on the Post Office Appropriation bill continued in the House to-day, a number of topics being discussed. The proceedings were enlivened by a clash between Mr. Corliss of Michigan and Mr. Richardson of Alabama on the subject of the Pacific cable.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 12 -- The strength of the United Railways group was the feature of to-day's market. It was expected that the Legislature would take final action on the six tickets for a quarter bill and kill it. Some good buying developed in anticipation of that sequel, the Street being of the opinion that a good rise will follow the overthrow of the measure.

BOSTON, March 12 -- Money is steadily hardening, and rates on call loans locally were quite generally marked up to-day. Demand is quiet for call money, but time money is in fair demand. Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 10 and 15c. discount; call loans, 3 1/2 @ 4 per cent.; time money, 4 @ 4 1/2 per cent.

BOSTON, March 12 -- The Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees of the United Society of Christian Endeavor met here to-day and accepted invitations to hold the International Christian Endeavor Convention in Denver, Col., in July, 1903.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- President Furber of the Olympian Games Committee to-day received from Prof. Cox of the United States Weather Bureau a report that may determine the matter of a great yacht race off Chicago while the Olympian games are in progress.
ALBANY, March 12 -- "I think Mr. Dike ought to blow up his muscle."

ALBANY, N.Y., March 12 -- There was a hearing to-day before the Assembly Committee on Electricity. Gas, and Water Supply, upon the pending bill to repeal the Burr law, which gives to Suffolk County authority to control the supply of water within its borders. Timothy M. Griffing, attorney for the Board of Supervisors of Suffolk County: Col. William J. Youngs, and exAssemblyman Burr appeared in opposition to the repeal bill.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Senate Committee on Isthmian Canals has decided by a vote of 7 to 4 to report the Hepburn bill providing for the construction of an isthmian canal via the Nicaragua route.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained this evening at a musicale in the East Room, some 300 guests being invited for 10 o'clock. The artists of the occasion were the Misses Cornelia and Louise Dyas and Mrs. DyasStandish.
"Practical Politics" was the subject discussed after the second dinned of the Get-Together Club No. 2 on West Twenty-fifth Street last night.

The name Appleton Brown suggests landscapes in which the grass has taken on the freshest tints of Spring and orchards are in bloom. The country In its new dress for April and May seemed to appeal to him more profoundly than at other seasons, so that at the exhibitions his pictures announced their presence from afar by the boughs of fruit trees heavy with blossoms and by the meadows starred with the earlier flowers.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- After an illness of two weeks Miss Susan B. Anthony was able to sit up for the first time to-day. Miss Anthony is staying in this city at the home of her niece, Mrs. Helen M. James, 4716 Windsor Avenue, West Philadelphia. She came to this city in order to deliver a lecture before Bryn Mawr College, but on her arrival was obliged to take to her bed.

More than 1,000 would-be Inspectors who aspire to hold places in the Building Bureau have answered the question, When is an apartment house not a tenement house? In the last civil service examination. Since that time a complication has arisen, and now the problem is vexing the minds of even the astute examiners who "rate" papers written by aspirants for places.

President Greatsinger of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, Assistant Engineer McLean of the Department of Bridges, and some of the company's officials spent the afternoon yesterday in Mr. Greatsinger's office at 168 Montague Street, Brooklyn, around a large desk covered with blue prints of plans for the relief of traffic on the trolley cars running over the Brooklyn Bridge.

ALBANY, March 12 -- If we had direct nominations by primaries we might not have had Guden, or if we did have him, the responsibility would have been with the people instead of with the organization." This remark was made by Lieut. Gov. Woodruff at the hearing to-day before the Senate Judiciary Committee on the Marshall Direct Nominations bill.

Gen. Thomas T. Eckert, since 1893 President of the Western Union Telegraph Company and for many years one of the foremost figures in American telegraph companies, resigned yesterday his office as President and was immediately elected Chairman of the Board of Directors of the same company.
Total tax on their gross earnings paid by the railroads to the State of Minnesota for 1901, $1,658,764, as against $1,441,549 for the previous year.

Capt. Morton J. Henry is relieved from duty as assistant to the purchasing commissary in New York City and will proceed to Boston and relieve Capt. James A. Loean, Jr., of his duties as purchasing commissary in that city. Capt. Logan, upon being thus relieved, will proceed to Manila for duty in the subsistence department in that division.

Mr. Henry K. Hadley, instructor in music at St. Paul's School, Garden City, gave at Mendelssohn Hall yesterday afternoon a concert of his own compositions. Mr. Hadley, it will be recalled, won last Fall the Paderewski symphony prize, and had the honor of having the work performed by the Philharmonic Society under the active direction of Mr. Paur.

The Lenten amusements occupy the younger people, and there is little for the others, except dinners and luncheons, none of which are very elaborate. Yesterday afternoon there was the usual meeting of the Knickerbocker Bowling Club, and in the evening that of the Wednesday Amusement Club.

The American Tobacco Company issued its annual statement for the year ended Dec. 31, 1901, yesterday at the annual meeting, which was held in Jersey City. The most interesting figures in the report are the statements on the asset side of the general balance sheet, which show the amount of stock held in other companies.

Twenty per cent, reduction on Cuban sugar seems to be the nearest to a compliance with the President's view of "plain duty" that any faction of his party in Congress can be got to go. According to Gen. WOOD, that is too little to give the Cuban planter a real access to our markets.

It is calculated to surprise the thoughtful reader that the Massachusetts Legislature is now listening patiently at public hearings to arguments in favor of a bill legalizing the establishment and maintenance by men on strike of a system of picketing around the plants in which the strikes occur, to intercept all who may be suspected of a desire to take the places of the men voluntarily idle, and render other services to the unions.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Again to-day the Ship Subsidy bill occupied practically the entire time of the Senate. Mr. McCumber (N.D.) presented a carefully prepared argument, in which, as a representative of an agricultural State, he favored the bill on the ground of its protective features.

Before Judge Warren W. Foster in the Criminal Courts Building yesterday Paul Uriza, eighteen years old, pleaded guilty to having stolen a pearl pin from Tiffany Co. Sentence was suspended because the Prison Aid Society of New York had investigated his case and found that he was worthy of another chance.

The pool tournament for the world's professional championship was continued yesterday at the Montauk Billiard Academy in Brooklyn. Three games were contested during the day, the first in the afternoon between Weston and Long, won by the former. The night games were played by Clearwater and Walsh, the former winning by the score of 125 to 84.

MONTE CARLO, March 12 -- Six games from the semi-final and final rounds of the international chess masters tournament, which had ended in draws on Monday and yesterday, were replayed to-day in order to end the contest, which was begun on Feb. 3. The games were between Mason and Eisenberg, Wolf and Sehlechter, Napier and Marco, Popiel and Gunsberg, Maroczy and Tarrasch, and Scheve and Eisenberg.

Two matches were decided in the Metropolitan Championship Bowling League Tournament, and some remarkably high scores were made in each. In Manhattan the Metropolitan Bowlers won their third consecutive series of three straight games, and scored 1,016,954, and 1,022, an average of 997.
MANILA, March 12 -- The volunteers under Gen. Cailles have inflicted heavy punishment on a force of insurgents in Laguna Province. They killed fifteen of the enemy and captured thirty-one rifles.

LONDON, March 12 -- The brisk demand for money was maintained to-day, and there was no indication or an increase in the supply. The indebtedness to the Bank of England increases instead of diminishes. The firmness of the rates for money and the better supply of bills strengthened discounts.

Bessie Cruikshank, the thirteen-year-old girl of this city who surprised some of the crack fly casters last week in Madison Square Garden by her remarkable exhibition with her light pole and line, had the field or rather the canoe stream all to herself yesterday when the judges called for the contestants in the fly casting competition for girls.

CANTON, Ohio, March 12 -- On April 16, in Paris, is to be given the greatest theatrical benefit performance ever arranged in the French capital, according to advices received here. The proceeds are to go to the fund for a McKinley memorial at Canton.

Messrs. Blumenthal, Moss Feiner, lawyers, at 35 Nassau Street, yesterday instituted proceedings which they say they hope will result in checking alleged arbitrary and illegal acts on the part of District Attorney Jerome. They accuse the District Attorney of usurping powers not conferred upon him by the Constitution, or the laws.
Discussing the condition of the iron and metal trades The Iron Age will to-day say:

Mr. LINDENTHAL'S latest plan of shaping his official opinion as to what should be done by taking a popular vote designed to show what the people who use the bridge want done, and his request to the newspapers to print coupons which can be cut out, filled in, and deposited in convenient receptacles, from which they will be taken and tabulated, was doubtless not intended as a contribution to the gayety of nations.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- Daniel Frohman, who is in this city on a visit to E.H. Sothern, now playing here, was asked to-night by a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES as to his plans for the stock company. Mr. Frohman said:
At the annual meeting of the Continental Tobacco Company, held in Jersey City yesterday, the old Board of Directors was reelected.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There have been in your columns some comments by correspondents and otherwise upon the recent disabilities of the New York Central Railroad, caused by floods, at and below Albany, which I know are the results of mistakes in location or construction when the road was built.

The Red Star liner Westernland, from Philadelphia for Liverpool March 9, was sighted in longitude 67.06 and latitude 40.31 Tuesday by the Italian liner Sardegma with her low-pressure crank pin broken and making for this port. The disabled vessel refused assistance and said that she would proceed slowly for New York.

Mayor Low will have to decide in a few days the question whether the examiners and many other officials of the Commissioners of Accounts office shall be placed on the exempt list and therefore removable and appointable at the will of the heads of the bureau.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Mendelssohn Trio Club has been incorporated, with principal office in New York City, and particular objects "to cultivate and promote the art of music, harmony, and theory, render classical and other musical selections, , and to do and perform all acts and things pertaining to music.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The following cablegrams were made public here today:

Towels and sponges, after being saturated with chloroform, were burned yesterday by experts at the trial of Albert T. Patrick, accused of murdering William Marsh Rice, to prove the truth or falsity of Charles F. Jones's statements as to the way he disposed of the articles with which he killed his employer at Patrick's instigation.

The reports of a contemplated change in the head of the Police Department are positively denied. Commissioner Partridge yesterday declared unequivocally that he had no intention of resigning, and stated that no one had asked for his resignation.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "P S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall tie placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The overcrowding of the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge has been the fruitful subject of many plans, suggestions, and ideas, the majority of which, however, would require such a length of time and such large sums of money to carry out that they are really of little, if any, value.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Cities Committee this morning reported favorably to the Senate the Stranahan tenement house bill, advocated by Robert W. De Forest, Tenement House Commissioner. The amendments proposed involve no departure from the principles underlying the bill enacted last Winter, but make certain provisions of the act clearer.

LYNN, Mass., March 12 -- The Boston strike has caused such complications in this city, especially in the shoe trade, that the Board of Trade has deemed it necessary to take a hand. A canvass of the members has shown that the majority believe that a radical plan should be adopted to bring the R.S. Brine Company of Boston to terms.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Overtures have been made for compromise of the conflict over tariff concessions to Cuba, and there are evidences that the two elements will come together, probably on a proposition to have the 20 per cent, reciprocal reduction apply for one year from next December and covering one sugar crop.

Eschwege Cohn, importers of fancy goods and notions at 648 Broadway, are in financial difficulties. An involuntary petition in bankruptcy was filed against them yesterday by Hays Hershfield, attorneys for Alfred W. Schlesinger of Third Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, a creditor for $5,000, for money loaned for which he holds a note of the firm.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- There are a good many persons in Washington who believe the next House will be Democratic and the number who subscribe to this belief grows rapidly. Republicans as well as Democrats are among those who expect a political overturning in the House. There is no denying that the Republican leaders are dismayed at the outlook in the Congressional districts.

Oscar S. Straus, ex-United States Minister to Turkey, whose efforts had much to do with the payment of the indemnity claims against the Turkish Government for the losses incurred in 1895-96, yesterday received the following letter of thanks from Judson Smith of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions:

District Attorney Jerome yesterday questioned John Y. Fitzsimmons, the merchant who declares he saw Walter S. Brooks in the Glen Island Hotel on the night of Feb. 14. This is the first witness which has been examined personally in the Burns case by Mr. Jerome since the clay after the shooting.

Frank J. Batcheller of Boston, Chairman of the National Committee of the American Minute Men, yesterday issued a call for a meeting of the National committee, to be held in Boston May 21. The purpose is to perfect plans for thorough organization, and for an aggressive campaign throughout the United States for the election of members of Congress and other officials.

The plan for checking the liquor evil which was described by Earl GREY at the City Club on Monday afternoon is by no means a pure experiment in the United Kingdom. It applies on a larger scale a principle and method already tried with great success.

NEW ORLEANS, March 12 -- The Chicago Limited pulled into New Orleans over the Illinois Central this morning a veritable wreck and over an hour late. The train was in charge of Conductor O.C. Betz and had aboard 100 passengers. There, was hardly a whole window pane on any one of the cars and the passengers, as they disembarked, plainly showed the effects of a frightful experience.

John Daniell, the Broadway merchant, in his will, which was executed on Jan. 8, 1901, left to his grandson, William Sohier Daniell, $5,000 and all his horses, carriages, and equipment of his stable. In a codicil, executed a short time afterward, he left him an additional $5,000, but by a second codicil he cut him off completely from any participation in his estate.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 12 -- A sharp recovery in the Reading stocks served to impart a better feeling in the local market, and nearly at the leaders closed at the top. The news of the new $50,000,000 bond issue by the Pennsylvania Road and the announcement that they would be convertible into stock at $70 per share was followed by a slight hardening in the price of the stock.

Yesterday was given up to sewing classes and Lenten amusements. The threatening weather kept many from the Avenue, and the restaurants were not as well patronized as usual. There was a reception at the Maternity Hospital in the afternoon, on Stuyvesant Square; a meeting of the postgraduate class at Mrs. Hitchcock's, and one of the Bellevue Sewing Class at Miss Learv's.

ALBANY. N.Y., March 13. -- Mayor Low's bill to authorize the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to fix the salaries of all city employes came up in the Senate to-day and was advanced to third reading. Senator Grady said he did not care to object to the measure at this stage, but would have something to say upon it when it was considered on the order of third reading.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 13. -- The announcement that the coal operators will, before the end of the week, post notices, offering the anthracite miners a renewal of the concessions of last year has created a great deal of talk among the men of this district. It is as clear a definition of the operators stand as they need.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Representative Sulzer of New York, during the consideration of the Post Office Appropriation bill in the House to-day, made an eloquent plea in favor of a new Post Office in the City of New York. He said, in part:

The acephalous condition of the Demo- cratic Party in Congress has never been quite so strongly put in evidence as by the present condition of the attempt to give relief to Cuba. A situation more tempting to an opposition never was created. Here is the Republican Party openly divided against itself, and apparently in doubt whether the name of the party's leader is ROOSEVELT or OXNARD.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt received the Minister from Costa Rica and Mme. Cairo in the blue room of the White House this afternoon, the call being the first formal appearance of the Minister and wife since the return of the former from Mexico.

BOSTON, March 13. -- Through the united efforts of representatives of the great mercantile bodies of the city, seconded by the Chief Executives of city and State in conference with the recognized leaders of organized labor, the great strike of freight handlers and kindred trades represented in the allied freight transportation council was broken to-night.

MATAWAN, N.J., March 13. -- An exciting man hunt that lasted long into the night took place here to-day. The hunters were farmers living near the town and the hunted a big black negro who was seen at noon to-day in the act of setting fire to a barn on the property of William L. Roberts, a mile east of Matawan.
PHILADELPHIA, March 12. -- The following notice will be posted to-morrow in all the collieries through the anthracite coal region of Pennsylvania:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 13. -- The Democratic majority in the State Senate has declared war against the combine of independent Democrats and Republicans in the House led by Isaac L. Straus, the anti-organization Democrat from Baltimore. Gov. Smith and the regular Democratic managers, together with the Democratic members of the Senate, to-day, at a conference at the Executive Mansion, decided to fight Straus and the coalition until the end of the session.

Swept for a distance of seven block or nearly half a mile in the turbid waters of a city sewer from twenty to forty feet underground, and in inky darkness, through noxious gases and deadly vapors, and at last swept into the East River with the city's refuse without once having lost consciousness, was the experience yesterday afternoon of Edward Boyle, a wiry plumber's helper.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The decision of the Senate Committee on Inter-Oceanic Canals that the Chairman should make a favorable report on the Hepburn bill, locating the Isthmian canal on the Nicaragua route, created no surprise in the Senate, and when the report was presented this morning it attracted practically no attention.

The condition of the Shrievalty contest in Brooklyn seriously perplexes the people of Kings County baring business with the Sheriffs office. Especially are lawyers alarmed regarding real estate transactions. Last night Col. Norman S. Dike and Charles Guden, whom he displaced as Sheriff by order of the Governor, each occupied a portion of the quarters allotted to the chief officer of the county in the county building.

The evolution of the modern society drama, with a side light on the relations of authors, actors, and managers, is provided in a controversy that has reached white heat over the play, "Hearts Aflame." Mrs. Robert Haines, wife of the leading man of Mrs. Fiske's company, wrote the piece and a few weeks ago an announcement was made that Amelia Bingham would produce it shortly at the Bijou.

LONDON, March 14. -- The Madrid correspondent of The Daily Mail says that although it is asserted in official circles at the Spanish capital that Bellamy Storer, United States Minister to Spain, who has started for America on account of the failure of the negotiations for a treaty of friendship, will return in six months, the general impression is that Mr. Storer will not return to Spain.

ALBANY, March 13. -- Gov. Odell to-day authorised the extradition of Charles A. Cockran, wanted in Nashville, Tenn., on a charge of larceny. He is accused of having defrauded the Union Bank and Trust Company of that State through papers of the American Hardware Company, of which Cockran was President, discounted by the bank.

The passing of another of the few remaining landmarks in the lower part of the city is foreshadowed by the announcement made yesterday that the old United States Hotel on Fulton Street, between Pearl and Water Streets, has been sold. The property has been bought by a client of Broker C.E. Harrell, and it is said that a twelve-story building containing both offices and lofts will be built on the site.

A review of the private collection of Samuel Colman, N.A., makes one grieve that nobody has been inspired to buy it as a whole, in order that eventually it might find its way to some public museum. When Mr. Colman began to collect there were marvelous bargains to be had in San Francisco, and New York, and London and Paris.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 13. -- The principal development in the strike at the mills of the American Woolen Company in Olneyville and Manton to-day was the announcement from Plymouth, Mass., that the weavers of the company's mills there had struck, according to the plans of the strike leaders announced on Tuesday.

A series of Indian canoe races, tilting matches, Ojibway tribe dances, and log rolling by the Adirondack guides were the features of particular interest that kept one of the largest crowds seen at the Sportsmen's Show in good humor last night. Every available space in Madison Square Garden was utilized where a good view could be obtained of the island with its Indian tents and pens of wild animals.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 13. -- While the Legislature is fighting over bills for leasing oyster beds and a general planting law to prevent, as is claimed, the rapid depletion of the great oyster yield of the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries, a glut exists in the Baltimore market. Instead of a threatened famine in the bivalves, it would seem that the supply is as unexhaustible as ever.
LONDON, March 13. -- The requirements for the settlement increased the demand for money to-day. The supplies were slightly larger. Discounts were firmer.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 13. -- The an- nouncement of the engagement of Miss Katherine Rowland by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George P. Rowland of New York, to George Lauder, Jr., a Pittsburg millionaire, and nephew of Andrew Carnegie, has been announced, and now the romantic features of the engagement have leaked out.

ALBANY, March 13. -- Fire Commissioner Sturgis appeared before the Assembly Committee on Cities to-day to urge the passage of the bill intended to remove the existing limitation placed upon the amount of the life insurance fund of the Fire Department. Under existing law the fund cannot exceed $10.000.
It was announced last night that a suc- cessor to Brother Charles as President of Manhattan College will be chosen by the Board of Trustees at a meeting to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- William J. Bryan was here to-day, talking politics with Senators, Representatives, and newspaper men. He left the impression with many persons that he hopes to be the Democratic candidate for President in 1904, and that meanwhile he considers himself the leader of the National Democracy, entitled to outline its policies and supervise its campaigns.

Army. Major Gen. Samuel B.M. Young, United States Army, is relieved from the command of the Department of California to take effect March 15, 1902, when he will proceed to Washington and report to the Adjutant General of the Army for further instructions.

The application of Commissioner FOLKS of the Department of Public Charities for a sufficient appropriation, estimated at about $88,000, for the repairing and equipment of the buildings on Blackwell's Island lately vacated by the insane patients, and their conversion into hospitals to be devoted to the care of tuberculosis patients, merits respectful consideration from the Board of Esti- mate and Apportionment, and should receive the hearty support of the medical organizations of the city.

Mayor Low yesterday explained in detail the plan and scope of the proposed revision of the civil service classifications to be made if his bill, now pending in the Legislature becomes a law. He said there seemed to be a general misunderstanding on the part of the press and public of the real purpose of the bill in question.

Many revolver and pistol enthusiasts gathered last night in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club to witness the opening of the annual competition for the revolver and pistol championships of the United States held under the auspices of the United States Revolver Association. The contest last year was held in Madison Square Garden during the Sportsman's Show.

The 1902 directory of iron and steel works of the American Iron and Steel Association, compiled by Mr. JAMES M. SWANK, is a publication well worth examination even by those for whom, as a directory, it has no especial interest. It gives a better idea of the magnitude of our National development in these great industries than can be gained from any other source of which we have knowledge.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13. -- There was little activity in the local market to-day. The opening was generally higher, but there was little further improvement. The Readings were predominant, and their activity caused the rest of the group to be neglected. There has been persistent demand for the Readings here ever since the Jersey Central report was made.

John F. Cockerill, President of the Road Drivers' Association, has appointed standing committees to take charge of the various matters relating to road driving that will come up at the meetings of the association.

It would seem as if the New England labor leaders could have found a better and cheaper way of settling the issues of a very small and local question than by sympathetic strikes which are paralyzing the trade and industry of all New England, and cutting off, or diminishing, the earnings of certainly fifty thousand and perhaps a hundred thousand wage earners.

Prices in the outside market yesterday were irregrular, and transactions in most stocks were somewhat larger than they were on Wednesday. Several issues were in greater demand than they have been recently, with the result that substantial advances were recorded, but elsewhere in the list there were declines which offset thes gains.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Representative Pugsley of the Sixteenth New York District said to-day that he shared in the hope entertained by a good many Democratic members of Congress that his party will control the next House.

Dr. Austin Flint, called by the defense at the trial of Albert T. Patrick, charged with William M. Rice's murder, was the principal witness at yesterday's hearing of the case. The prosecution asserts that Dr. Flint's testimony supported materially their contention as to the cause of Rice's death.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The Senate to-day resumed consideration of the Ship Subsidy measure. Mr. Berry, (Ark.,) a member of the Commerce Committee, which reported the bill, made a vigorous argument in opposition to it. He charged that it would foster trusts and monopolies in the shipping industry.

BAYONNE, N.J., March 13. -- Congressman Allan L. McDermott's son Walter L. caused some consternation in the Bayonne District Court this morning by his denunciation of the lawyer, William D. Salter, of this city, formerly City Treasurer.

Henry R. Towne, President of the Yale Towns Manufacturing Company, extensive producers of fine builders' hardware, locks, and other specialties, yesterday responded to a request on behalf of THE NEW YORK TIMES for his views on the tariff as follows:

The suit brought by a minority of the stockholders of the United States Flour Milling Company to prevent a foreclosure sale under a $15,000,000 mortgage held by the Central Trust Company was again before Vice Chancellor Pitney at Jersey City yesterday on argument.

NEW ORLEANS, March 13. -- Andes was the only beaten favorite here to-day, and in this race Volma Clark, a strong second choice, won. Jockey Brazil has presented to the stewards evidence tending to exonerate him of any complicity in the steeplechase frauds, and the stewards have recommended his reinstatement by the Western Jockey Club.

It was very natural that the politicians in the House of Representatives, who had arranged for the transfer of their favorites from the Census Office to other places in the Government service, should attribute the failure of their little plan to treachery. That was the charge against the members of the conference committee, but it was unfounded.

Up-town Democrats to the number of about 400 gave a dinner last night in the Casino, at One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue, to Lewis Nixon, the leader of Tammany Hall. The dinner was under the auspices of the Speakers' Club of the Thirty-first Assem- bly District.

Controller Grout and President Cantor of the Borough of Manhattan are at odds over the Blackwell's Island bill now before the Legislature, by which the city officials are authorized to carry on negotiations with the United States Government for the leasing of the island for a naval station and public park.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An editorial in THE TIMES of Feb. 27, on "Vibration from Underground Traffic," ex- presses some fear, from the report of a committee of the British Board of Trade, that New York may experience trouble from a like vibration to that in the London underground railroad, upon the operation of the New York subway.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 13. -- The Illinois Railroad and Warehouse Commission contemplates at an early date a complete revision of the railroad rate schedule of the State. It has directed the Secretary to collect information on the subject, and he has prepared a letter to be sent to persons interested.

ALBANY, March.13. -- The substitute measure offered by Mayor Low for Assemblyman Bedell's bill to amend the railroad law so as to make provision for the condemnation proceedings necessary in connection with the change of motive power from steam to electricity in the Park Avenue tunnel is being more severely criticised than the original measure.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- United States Consul Kenneday, writing to the State Department from Para, Brazil, says: "Fire recently destroyed the establishment of Frank da Costa Co. in this city. This firm is one of the largest exporters of rubber and other commodities in the Amazon Valley, and there were forty-three tons of rubber in the building at the time, of which twenty-eight tons were totally destroyed and fifteen tons damaged.
WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Daniel T. Phillips, United States Consul at Cardiff, Wales, in a report on fuel oil, says:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

BOSTON, Mass., March 13. -- Money is still working firmer, while there is quite a general marking up of rates now under way. The Clearing House rate was lifted to 4 per cent., and time money is now hard to obtain at anything better than 4 1/2 per cent for six months. Demand is a trifle better. New York funds, 13 cents discount.
WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Consul Edward H. Ozmun, writing to the State Department from Stuttgart, says:

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The Cuban relief question is regarded as practically settled on the basis of what is called the Sibley compromise, limiting the operation of the Ways and Means Committee's bill to Dec. 1, 1903. There may be some modifications of the compromises, but it is expected the scheme will stand about as it does now.

NEW YORK, March 13. --The Inspector of the Third Lighthouse District gives notice that the experimental gas-lighted buoy placed at the entrance of Gedney (Cut) Channel. New York Lower Bay, near the Gedney Channel Whistling Buoy, has been extinguished and will be relighted as soon as the state of the sea permits.

The Committee on Subsidy of the Merchants' Association, consisting of Mr. G. L. DUVAL, and Mr. WILLIAM R. CORWINE, has published its correspondence with Senator FRYE in regard to certain passages in the Senate Ship Subsidy bill which make possible the payment of subsidies under that bill to ships built abroad.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From time to time I have read with in- terest your comments upon the different plans proposed to relieve the crush at the bridge. May I bring to your notice my idea for an immediate relief?

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the article which appeared in your issue of Tuesday last, dealing with the exoneration by the Civil Service Commission of Postmaster Roberts of Brooklyn from any willful violation of the civil service law and rules, it was stated that the charges on which the investigation was based were brought by the National Civil Service Reform League.

LONDON, March 14. -- The official announcement of the abandonment of the proposed visit of King Edward and Queen Alexandra to Ireland is quite unprecedented in form, and causes keen discussion, the general tone of which is distinctly adverse to the action of the Cabinet, which is interpreted as displaying petty spite and spleen.

Representative PUGSLEY of the Sixteenth District is one of the many Democrats who are now turning their graze to the future. Nobody who watches the political signs of the times can have failed to observe that a more hopeful spirit is stirring in the Democracy. Many members of the party have the courage to believe that a Democratic House of Representatives will be elected this Fall and a Democratic Governor in New York.

The most interesting figure in British politics at the present moment is the nobleman who has placed himself at the head of what may be -- but not by him -- called the Primrosebery League, and, after an absence of several years, has re-entered public life in a manner as impressive as it is puzzling.
The "Iphigenie auf Tauris" of Goethe was given yesterday afternoon and evening at the Irving Place Theatre for the first and last time this season.

ALBANY, March 14. -- The Court of Appeals this afternoon handed down four decisions, the effect of which is to declare unconstitutional the law which granted to the Appellate Division the right to name the Commissioner of Jurors in Kings County.

BOSTON, March 14. -- The freight handlers formerly employed by the New York, New Haven and Hartford and the Boston and Albany Roads, after a very animated meeting, voted not to return to work unless they were taken back in a body.

BOSTON, March 13. -- As very little effort was needed to bring the sale of Mr. George Cary Eggleston's "A Carolina Cavalier" up to 17,000 last year, there is very little doubt that the large advance orders already received for "Dorothy South," his coming book, will be followed by many more when once the story is published.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14. -- Choctaw was the leading issue in the local stock list and dominated the list throughout the forenoon, both the common and preferred advancing sharply on extraordinary trading.
