The buying seemed to be chiefly on orders from New York, and it is said that the issue will be listed in that city.

Mrs. Alice E. Stover, a woman of fortyfour years, shot her husband before daybreak yesterday morning in their apartment at 61 East One Hundred and Sixth Street. After she had killed him the woman set the breakfast table, then stepped out into the hall and knocked on the door of the adjoining flat.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Republican Senators were laughing yesterday among themselves over a remark made by some Western Democrat whose name it was impossible to learn. As the story ran, the Westerner found fault with the minority of the Senate on the ground that it was doing nothing that would be likely to help the Democrats win Congressional fights in the Fall elections.

It is at least satisfactory to have the report officially denied which set forth that King EDWARD'S constitutional advisers had dissuaded him from going to Ireland because certain Irish members of the House of Commons had yelled with delight at the announcement of a British defeat in South Africa.

NEWARK, N.J., March 14. -- Papers were filed here to-day incorporating live rubber shoe companies, each with the same amount of capital stock and with the same incorporators. The concerns are the International, German-American, FrancoAmerican, Anglo-American, and BelgianAmerican Rubber Shoe Companies.

ST. LOUIS, March 14. -- Architect Cass Gilbert of New York must again remodel the $250,000 festival hall, which is the decorative key to the great cascade garden feature of the World's Fair. Director of Works Taylor has instructed Mr. Gilbert that his plan for a square building is not in harmony with the $1,000,000 architectural and landscape treatment of art hill.
LONDON, March 34. -- The money conditions were practically unchanged to-day.
Commissioner Strassburger received yesterday depositions in reference to the personal taxes of D.O. Mills. The amount of the assessment was fixed tentatively at $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The conference committees of the two factions of House Republicans resumed consideration of the Cuban question to-day and were in session nearly all the afternoon. The Administration leaders were represented by Messrs. Payne, Dalzell, and Cannon, and the beet sugar people by Messrs. Metcalf, Taylor, Morris, Dick, and Fordney.

THE OPPONENTS" is a new novel by Harrison Robertson, author of "Red Blood and Blue," and "The Islander," to be published soon by Charles Scribner's Sons. The story deals with latter-day politics in Kentucky.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Senator Penrose of Pennsylvania gave notice to-day of his intention to offer as an addition to the House resolution providing for the election of United States Senators, an amendment providing for the election by a direct vote of the people of at least two Senators from each State and one additional Senator for every additional ratio of 500,000 people.

Col. Norman S. Dike, appointed Sheriff of Kings County by Gov. Odell, vice Charles Guden, removed, yesterday took possession of that portion of the Sheriff's office held by Mr. Guden and ejected the latter. There was no personal violence offered on either side.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- At the Cabinet meeting to-day Secretary Shaw brought up the subject of his proposed order discontinuing bond purchases and after returning to the Treasury Department he issued the following notice:

BOSTON, March 14. -- The money market is slowly but steadily hardening, even while the demand continues relatively light. The local Clearing House rate is now stiff at 3 per cent., and some banks will offer nothing better than 4 per cent. New call money is now loaning almost wholly at 4 per cent., and very little time is obtainable under 4 1/2 per cent., on all periods.
Bar silver was quoted in London at 24 7/8d per ounce and in New York at 54c per ounce. Mexican dollars at 43 1/4c.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 1. -- Correspondence giving details of the earthquake at Shemakha, Transcaucasia, has just arrived here.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Throughout the session of the Senate to-day the Ship Subsidy bill was under consideration. The measure was discussed by Mr. Foraker of Ohio, Mr. McLaurin of Mississippi, and Mr. Harris of Kansas. Mr. Foraker supported the bill, although he admitted that he would have preferred to build up the American merchant marine by the levying of discriminating duties.

The will of Mrs. Charlotte M. Goodridge, widow of Frederick Goodridge, dated July 8, 1899, was filed for probate in the office of the Surrogate yesterday. Under her will Mrs. Goodridge disposes of an estate worth several millions of dollars.

The annual contest by cable between America and Great Britain for chess supremacy began yesterday morning on eight boards, and will be continued to-day on ten boards. The American team played at the Assembly Rooms of the Academy of Music at Brooklyn, while the Britishers played their games at the Cafe Monico, London.

Apart from the announcement by Mr. Carnegie at the dinner on Thursday evening of the New York Library Club that he had made gifts during the same day to nearly forty libraries, (in itself an event sufficient to make the dinner notable,) further distinction belongs to that gathering because of the representative interests assembled at the guest table.

At the Church of the Transfiguration, better known as the "Little Church Around the Corner," twelve new windows are to be shown in the chapel on Easter Sunday morning. Four upper ones represent the "Nativity," "Christ Among the Doctors," "The Baptism of Christ," and "Christ in Gethsemane."

SALT LAKE, Utah, March 14. -- Articles of incorporation were filed with the Secretary of State to-day of the National Railroad Company of Mexico. The capitalization is placed at $65,350,000, and the object is stated to be to build and operate a railroad line from Laredo, Tex., to the City of Mexico.

Hero is a new pleasure for the growing hosts of amateur naturalists. Since Prof. Sargeant began bringing out his phoros work on the trees of North America something near a dozen handbooks have been published to aid the inexperienced in the beginnings of the study of forestry. Along with them came books describing and portraying the blooming plants of smaller size.

John W. Gates spent most of the afternoon yesterday in Justice Truax's part of the Supreme Court listening to the evidence in a suit brought against him by John I. Parks to recover his share of the millions that were made in the formation of the American Steel and Wire Company several years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- At the French Embassy this afternoon the Ambassador, M. Cambon, entertained at a large tea in honor of his friend and guest, M. Theobald Chartran, who came to Washington to paint the portraits of the wife and daughter of the President.

Holdridge Ward have leased for the Charles Frederick Hoffman estate, for a term of twenty-one years, the plot at the southwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Thirty-second Street, 100 by 100, upon which the lessees will erect a modern business structure. Nothing could be learned yesterday from the interested parties relative to the identity of the lessees.

George Shefield, alias "English Jack," a confidence man who once got $7,500 from Gen. Benjamin F. Butler, and whose picture is in the Rogues' Gallery, was arrested yesterday for the alleged swindling of E.P. Morton, a lawyer of Lawrence, Mass. He was held in $1,000 bail for examination Wednesday.

It is not written that Charles Reade or William Aytoun Thackeray seriously affected the fleecing of the lambs of their time, and yet the temptation to essay the impossible, to persuade foolish innocence to remain beyond the reach of unscrupulous avarice, is irresistible to many a living novelist, and Mr. Charles Clark Munn has yielded to it in his "Rockhaven."

LONDON, March 1. -- Lord Dufferin passed the greater part of his life in the diplo- matic service, but he began life as an author. His "Letters from High Lati- tudes" was the most notable book of travel of its year, and it was probably due to the late Dr. McCosh, then of Belfast, that the success of the book did not confirm its author in the resolution to devote himself to literature.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 14. -- The United Railways group was stronger. It now looks as though the company will succeed in its contest in the Legislature. The apparent wrangling of the Senate against some interests in the lower House has so complicated matters that it looks now as though it is utterly impossible to get the bill through even the House of Delegates, which house at one time seemed likely to pass it readily.

Elsewhere will be found an interesting article on the pay of authors. It gives some details certainly unfamiliar to the general reader. Most students of the history of literature in this country know that Washington Irving's works had immense popularity for many years and that they earned for their author a substantial amount.

MR. DOUGLAS SLADEN'S "In Sicily" is one of those rare books of travel sure to be interesting to a very large class of readers to those who have been to Sicily, to those who are going to Sicily, and perhaps more than all, to those unfortunates who may never hope to visit those fascinating shores otherwise than through the delightful expedient of reading all that Mr. Sladen has to say about them.

CHICAGO, March 14. -- Billed as a choice sack of potatoes, a young man has arrived in Chicago from Kansas City tied up in a sack. For three days and a half he had been confined in the sack, and during that time he had traveled close to 700 miles in a freight car. The sack which covered him was inclosed in an open fruit case.

The mansion of John A. Morris at Throgg's Neck was entered early Thursday morning and robbed of over $1,000 worth of silver, among which were many valuable heirlooms belonging to the Morris family. Mr. Morris and his family at present are in New Orleans, and the only occupants of the house were two servants, John Bodine and Andrew Ferrara.

At the time of the London World's Fair of 1851, if that was the fair at which the Koh-i-noor was publicly exhibited, an ingenious and amusing magazine story appeared about that famous stone. The story set forth how an ingenious thief, excited by the prospect of such a prize, went about to steal it.
THE curious title "What Is Shakespeare?" chosen by Mr. Sherman for his volume on the great Plays of Shakespeare, reminds one forcibly of the poet's own lines: "Who is Silvia, what is she?"

LIEUT. ELLICOTT, in his "Life of John Ancrum Winslow, Rear Admiral, United States Navy," has subordinated Admiral Winslow's childhood and early youth to his years of service during the Mexican and civil wars, and allows him as far as possible to tell his own story in letters to his wife and to foreign and American officials.

Two women, called by the defense, testified yesterday at the trial of Albert T. Patrick, charged with the murder of William Marsh Rice, that they had each on one occasion seen Patrick and Rice together in the letter's apartments. These witnesses were Alaria Scott, the colored woman who cleaned up Rice's apartments, and Mrs. Isabel Carpenter of Dunellen, N.J., the widow of Charles Carpenter, a close friend to Rice.
THE library of American books formed by William R. Weeks of New York, which at first was announced to be sold in New York, was sold successfully on March 5 and 6 by Stan. V. Henkels in Philadelphia.

Dr. R.H. Sayre won the pistol championship and W.E. Petty the revolver championship last night at the conclusion of the championship tournament under the auspices of the United States Revolver Association, held in the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. Sayre scored a total of 448, while Petty scored 439.
LONDON, March 14. -- Lady Methuen, wife of Lieut. Gen. Lord Methuen, is going to South Africa. She will sail to-morrow.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I think Mr. Moncure D. Conway is in error when, recently. In a letter to a New York paper, he writes regarding Frederick the Great's attitude toward the American colonies in the Revolution as follows:

ALBANY, March 14. -- The fate of canal legislation hangs in the balance. While the claim of the canal men that they have enough votes to pass the Davis bill in the Senate seems, to be justified, there is no certainty that the Senate would accept the Weekes bill, which carries $5,500,000 more than the Davis bill, and there is likewise doubt as to whether the Davis bill can be passes through the Assembly.
Shipments of 475,000 ounces of silver to Europe by to-day's steamer.

The purpose of the plan recommended to the United States Steel Corporation by its Finance Committee, as we understand it, is to increase the capacity of the corporation for profitable output while reducing the annual charges.
LONDON, March 14. -- Several prominent English publishers are considering a translation of Anatole France's forthcoming history of Joan of Are, which will soon be published in Paris in two volumes.

The boycott placed upon Limburger cheese by Dr. M.K. Allen, the Health Officer of Louisville, Ky., and described in THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday, was a surprise to many people in New York, but the indignant protests of the German citizens of that town were described as quite natural under the circumstances.

A jury before Justice Scott in the Supreme Court yesterday returned a verdict which will act merely as a stepping stone to further legal proceedings in the already long-drawn-out litigation over the ownership of what was once known as "Apthorp's Lane," running from the old Bloomingdale Road to Harlem Commons, now embraced in Central Park.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. Picard, the biographer of Whittler, who wrote last week to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS concerning Whittler's earliest verses, is in error when he infers that the poet's ode, which was sung at the dedication of the Haverhill Academy April 30, 1827, has never appeared in print.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Judicial Department, yesterday afternoon handed down a decision in favor of the four City Magistrates appointed by Mayor Van Wyck last Spring to serve in Brooklyn, in their fight to retain office against the Magistrates elected last Fall.

The exhibition of a remarkable collection of artistic bindings from the a teller of Charles Meunter of Paris that began at Charles Scribner's Sons on March 10 is unique in several respects. This is the first time that a notable exhibition has been held in this country in which the various units were all from the hand of a single foreign master.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Representative John J. Fitzgerald of Brooklyn made an effort to-day to get the pneumatic tube service between New York and Brooklyn, as well as in the other cities where it was formerly in use, restored. His attempt was made through the medium of an amendment to the Post Office Appropriation bill, but Chairman Loud of the Post Office Committee disposed of it with a point of order.

The Executive Committee of the Greater New York Democracy met last evening in the rooms of the Broadway Club, 1,115 Broadway, for the purpose of perfecting an organization. There were several protests against the decisions of the advisory committee in settling disputes over the leadership of Assembly district organizations.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The Senate in executive session to-day ratified without division the convention growing out of The Hague peace conference relating to the conduct of war on land and sea. The discussion turned entirely on the conduct of the war in the Philippines and related especially to Gen. Funston's capture of Aguinaldo.

The Brooklyn Bureau of Charities wishes to renew its appeal for $21 with which to pay the transportation of a Swede to his home in Sweden where he will be comfortably cared for. Eight dollars is still lacking to the amount needed.

Edith Wharton. Three years ago Mrs. Edith Wharton was practically unknown. Now she occupies an established place among the American writers of fiction. She is, moreover, one of the few American writers who are able to deal at first hand with the fashionable life of our larger cities.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 14. -- Charles Farrell, Secretary of the Indiana Bankers' Association, left for New York to-day to attend a meeting of bankers from all parts of the country which will be held to-morrow at the Waldorf-Astoria for the purposeof taking further steps to organize a National money order concern which is designed to take this business from the Government and the express companies to a large extent.

Yesterday was quite gay for Lent. There were the dramatic entertainment at the Waldorf-Astoria and the lecture on the land of gold given by Mrs. Hitchcock at the same place. Miss Ford gave a talk at the residence of Mrs. Charles Berryman, and in the evening Mrs. John Di Zerega's play, "The Mouse," was produced, with an amateur cast, and there was a meeting of the Ping Pong and Badminton Club at the Berkeley Lyceum.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Representative Burleson of Texas in the House to-day renewed the discussion of the case of the Rev. Hiram W. Thomas and wife, whose application to the State Department for a request to the British authorities for passports to enter the Boer lines in South Africa, for the purpose of distributing relief funds, was brought to the attention of the House by him a few days ago.

DELAREY seems to have offered the British, much the same sort of dilemma by releasing Lord METHUEN which KRUGER offered them by handing over JAMESON and his comrades to British justice, instead of punishing them themselves. That the Boers would have been entirely within their rights in putting all the raiders to death was beyond dispute.

Real estate men discussed their troubles and their joys last evening at the sixth annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of Brokers at the Hotel Savoy. About 150 members of that organization and their guests were present. Francis E. Ward, President of the Board of Brokers, presided.

SAID the dentist: "It is surprising howmany children have to be fitted out with false teeth. There is hardly a week that I do not provide artificial grinders for some unfortunate youngster. In most cases this premature toothlessness is the result of accidents. It really seems as though every time that a boy takes a tumble he manages to knock two or three of his front teeth down his throat.

The Bankers' Money Order Association held a meeting yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria. The object of the association, which was established some time ago, is to enable banks throughout the country to issue interchangeable money orders in competition with the United States Post Office.

The Shades of Sherlock Holmes. When Mr. Gillette devised and put in practice his celebrated theatric device of the dark curtain he might have hesitated bad he foreseen the terrible legacy he was bequeathing to the American public. Sherlock Holmes has long departed to other worlds, but his shades still haunt Broadway.

SEVERAL charming brown gowns have been noted of late. One was worn by Miss Caroline Drayton, daughter of J. Coleman Drayton, and a granddaughter of Mrs. Astor. It was a velvet carriage gown, golden brown in hue. The skirt swept the floor with its dip back, and was perfectly plain.

Residence in London on the part of Mr. Fernand Lungren has not made so great a change in his methods of work as the longer stay of Frederick Muhrman has effected in his; but there is a difference. The subjects he is now exhibiting at the Macbeth Gallery, 237 Fifth Avenue, move of course in an entirely different field.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The speech of the Hon. William G. Brantley of Georgia in the House of Representatives on Tuesday on the question of reciprocity with Cuba had a listening house, and it will have the wide attention of the country, as it makes its strong appeal that such reciprocity would be for the public good.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The Senate to-day agreed to take up the Ship Subsidy bill immediately after routine business on Monday, and that speeches on the bill be limited to fifteen minutes except in the case of the Senator from Maine, (Mr. Frye,) who was accorded thirty minutes.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 15 -- "The Parkhurst society will not lift a finger, will not turn a hand over, to-morrow to secure evidence of violations of the excise law in New York City. No action will be taken by the Parkhurst society until Police Commissioner Partridge makes a statement that the excise law will be enforced in New York."
MONTREAL, March 15 -- In the little town of Perth, in the Ottawa Valley, a few days ago, the death was announced of Miss Catharine Millar, known in the neighborhood round as "Kitty" Millar.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 15. -- Failure on the part of the steel works in Pennsylvania to deliver material is causing considerable delay in the progress of work on the Great Northern Steamship Company's two monster ships building at the yards of the Eastern Shipbuilding Company. Six months ago it was stated that the vessels would be ready for launching in August.

[Copyright. 1902.] LONDON, March 15 -- While it has been possible to find a few experienced observers inclined to regard the present state of the money market as "verging on the abnormal," yet the general opinion still is that there is no development of a sensational character to be expected, and that conditions will adjust themselves in due time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your timely editorial in to-day's issue on provision for consumptives dwells upon the necessity of greater accommodation in our immediate vicinity for the proper handling of this constantly increasing class of afflicted among the poor of our city, and gives a very clear statement of Commissioner Folks's most praiseworthy efforts in that direction on Blackwell's Island.

ALBANY, March 15. -- The State Civil Service Commission to-day refused to approve an amendment to the New York City civil service rules which would give to the New York City Civil Service Commission the power to cancel eligible lists. The commission for New York City requested that it be given this power.

A concert will be given by the Public Education Association and the City History Club in Carnogie Hall next Saturday evening. An elaborate programme is to be rendered by the choir of the Musical Art Society and an orchestra of eighty under the direction of Frank Damrosch. Anton Vail Rooy will be the special baritone.

For the first time since her arrest Florence Burns, the young woman accused of the murder of her sweetheart, Walter S. Brooks, in the Glen Island Hotel on the night of Feb. 14, yesterday faced the mother of the dead man, who took the witness stand on the resumption of the examination before Justice Mayer in the Court of Special Sessions.
The Boston Stock Exchange firm of Peters Sewell have views of their own on the question of whether success for the Northern Securities Company will be advantageous to brokers, writing:
There was a large crowd last night at the big armory of the Twenty-third Regiment, Bedford and Atlantic Avenues, Brooklyn, when the twentieth of the series of indoor athletic games were held.

EMANUEL, FRIEDLICH, a wealthy merchant of Rochester, N.Y., is dead at his temporary home at Pasadena, Cal. He was a sufferer from heart trouble. His wife, who was with him, will take the body to Rochester.

To the Editor of The New York Times: United States Senators were intended to represent the States as States. Egro, they must be chosen by the State Legislatures -- Q.E.D. What more can the mind of a logical man ask than this?

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Terence V. Powderly, Commissioner General of Immigration, is to go, and Prank P. Sargent, Grand Master of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen, is slated to succeed him. President Roosevelt has offered the position to Mr. Sargent, who has it under consideration.

ALBANY, March 15. -- Chairman Krum of the Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment and Chairman Morgan of the Assembly Committee have received during the past few days a number of letters from the representatives of corporations protesting against the passage of the Krum Corporation Tax bill.

The weekly Clearing House statement yesterday issued somewhat earlier than usual was an agreeable surprise to Wall Street in that it showed only a small decrease, in surplus reserves and a very substantial reduction in loans. The decrease in loans was no less than $14,372,000; the loss in surplus reserves was $845,525; specie decreased $5,338,000; legal tenders decreased $831,100, and deposits decreased $21,296,700.

The closing lecture of the series which M. Hugues Le Roux has been giving at Columbia University on the life of the French family took place yesterday morning, when he spoke on the "Crisis of Marriage." He said, in part:
British investors are still bowed down over the outlook for their "home rails." One London authority, discussing the disappointing results of operations during the last half year, says:

The buying of plots in business sections for reimprovement, the sales of several high-class dwellings of recent construction, and large dealing in those neighborhoods of recent speculative activity have combined to another week's business of unusual volume.

Lent has progressed with an earnestness of purpose and a steadfast grip which will not relax until the Easter chimes shall lave sounded. Every one is now determined to keep the holy season. This week and, next are the most solemn in the observance of the Church. To-day is Passion Sunday, and in a week comes Palm Sunday, and then Easter.

LONDON, March 15. -- The Bishop of London, the Right Rev. Arthur Ingram, to-morrow will preach a farewell sermon to the picturesque "Blue-Coat Boys," who after the Easter vacation will leave the ancient Christ's Hospital, in the heart of the city, and go to new quarters in the country, the opening of which King Edward is expected to attend.

Relatively little business was transacted in the outside market yesterday. For the most part the net changes resulting from the day's operations were on the side of advances, although in a few prominent issues selling pressure resulted in declines. National Bread, among the recently introduced stocks, was particularly prominent.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I have been reading your paper these last five years, and always found it true to its device which has become so familiar to almost every New Yorker. Being somewhat interested in the social and musical events of this city. I never neglect to read your criticisms, which always seem to be just and fair.

FEW pedestrians who pass by Grace Church and snatch a moment from the day's business to gaze into the pleasant open rectery yard have any idea that the large earthen jar standing out prominently to view near the Rev. Dr. Huntington's residence is an antique of the most interesting character.

The budgets of the Boruugh Presidents, containing the amounts required to administer the various departments and bureaus under their charge, have been completed and soon will be considered by the Board of Estimate. President Cantor of the Borough of Manhattan has arranged his departments so as to save $123.043 of the amount allowed by the Board of Estimate presided over by Mayor Van Wyek.

[Copyright. 1902.] LONDON, March 15. -- Gordon Craig's designs for the costumes in the Purcell Society's revivals of Handel's "Acis and Galatea" and Purcell's "Masque of Love" cause much pleasantry, all dresses being made of loose strips of tape and ribbon, and bearing as little likeness to any clothes ever worn on the face of this planet as the most advanced artist could desire.

MONTREAL, March 15 -- The results of last year's Canadian census show that the Dominion continues to be a man's country as distinguished from Great Britain, where women are in the majority. There were last year 2,751,473 males and 2,619,573 females, an excess of 131,900 males. Ten years ago the excess of males was 87,708, proving that the past decade has been one of masculine growth.

Dock Commissioner McDougall Hawkes, accompanied by a number of officials and others, made an inspection of the Staten Island water front yesterday. The visit was made so that the Commissioner might familiarize himself with the Staten Island shore and learn what improvement might be made by his department.

ALBANY, March 15. -- A religious census was taken this week. One of the census takers rang the bell at 5 Elk Street. This is the house which is familiarly known in Albany as the "House of Lords," from the fact that it is the dwelling place of Senators Ellsworth, Stranahan, Higgins, Krum, and Humphrey, the Republican leaders of the Senate.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 15. -- At a meeting of the Fall River Manufacturers' Association, held this afternoon, it was voted to increase wages in all Fall River mills 10 per cent, on next Monday morning.

LONDON, March 15 -- The rates for money and discounts were firm to-day. On the Stock Exchange business was very restricted and the movements were fractional. Operators say there will be no further activity until after Easter. Another small failure was announced. High-class securities were quiet.

PARIS, March 15. -- The flat racing season in France opened with the St. Cloud meeting to-day. Five American jockeys, J. Reiff, Rigby, Mclntyre, Buchanan, and M. Henry, rode. In six races they won two firsts, three seconds, and three thirds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer, for himself and at the solicitation of a number of other owners of the preferred shares of the United States Steel Corporation would appreciate a little space in the columns of THE TIMES for the presentation of their protest against what they esteem to be an essentially dishonest and unjust proposition.

An exhibition of prints by twenty or thirty photographers, calling themselves the Photo-Secession, and the photographs they show, pictorial photographs, develops the fact that they are rejected alike by the ordinary photographers from whom they secede and the makers of pictures, into whose order they fain would penetrate.

WASHINGTON, D.C., March 15. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at a small dinner party this evening, their guests later going with Mrs. Roosevelt to the closing performance of the French opera. The company included the German Ambassador, Senator and Mrs. Lodge, and Miss Carew.

In several plays now being presented here there are excellent illustrations of that well-worn phrase, "trifles make perfection, but perfection is no trifle." And in these so-called trifles the fact is demonstrated that success or failure is often dependent upon things which neither actor, dramatist, nor manager can see prior to the actual production of a play.

MONTREAL, Quebec, March 15. -- Eugene Gauthier. who is wanted in New York for the alleged murder of Maude Gentile last Thursday night, surrendered himself to-day at the Central Police Station. His mother lives here, and he was formerly in the tailoring business in this city, but failed, and has been in New York for the last six months.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Representative Crumpacker of Indiana, the leader of the movement to reduce the Congressional representation of the Southern States, was notified to-day that the Committee on Rules has decided to report a resolution for the investigation of the operation of the Southern election laws and the Southern representation in the House.

NEW HAVEN, March 15. -- Thursday afternoon the Constitutional Convention passed, in a final vote, the resolution amending the State Constitution so that the House shall hereafter consist of 168 members, one from each town, irrespective of population, and the Senate to consist of 60 members chosen from equally populated districts.

PARIS, March 15. -- M. D'Estournelles de Constant, the French diplomat, arrived in Paris this morning on his return from the United States. He referred most enthusiastically to his visit to America, and in an interview said:
ATLANTIC CITY, March 15. -- Every inbound train since last Monday morning has brought its quota of Easter guests. They came from all sections of the States, many being from New York.

The opposition to the financing scheme of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company is beginning to shape itself into active hostility. Parker C. Chandler, a lawyer of Boston, representing some Boston and New York stockholders in the Metropolitan Street Railway, is in the city and threatens to get out an injunction to prevent the majority interests carrying out their scheme.

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to your Washington dispatch in to-day's paper, the beet sugar men will win their fight, and the triumvirate of the Ways and Means Committee, who "did not want any concessions granted to the Cubans," will have their way.

THERE were several bottles of wine opened the other evening at the Manhattan Holel over the winning of a wager that proved the extent to which the building of the Rapid Transit subway impodes the service of the Fourth Avenue trotley line.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If Commissioner Lindenthal had rejected my proposition of widening the roadways of the, Brooklyn Bridge for technical or economical reasons he might have succeeded in sustaining his objections by plausible arguments, but merely pronouncing the plans to be "worse than useless" (as reported in The New York Tribune of March 11) is one of Mr. Lindenthal's characteristic criticisms which are sharp, but unfounded and meaningless.

ALBANY, March 15. -- The Court of Appeals yesterday handed down a decision declaring unconstitutional the law which grants the Appellate Division the right to appoint the Commissioner of Jurors of Kings County. Jacob Brenner was appointed Commissioner under this act, but William E. Melody, the incumbent, declined to surrender his office, holding that the new law was unconstitutional.
WHEN the quartet met 'round the restaurant table the three girls with fur boas began to pour consolatory phrases into the ears of the girl with the unprotected neck.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Rainsford has found a man -- and he looked respectable -- who damned the Church. Now, there are lots of other men who are doing the same all over the country. The sneak thief, as he passes the tall, dark building at night, and conscience whispers, "Thou shalt not steal," shakes his fist at the edifice and mutters, "Damn the Church."

Aside from the question of the advisability of subsidizing vessels engaged in the country's foreign trade, either from the political or economic standpoint, even a superficial study of the records shows that the course of American carrying trade between countries has come to make a very poor showing.

BOSTON, March 15 -- The freight handlers employed at the time of the strike on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad voted to-night to return to work Monday. The railroad company, it is understood, has agreed to reinstate 250 of the men on full time and 50 others on half time, taking back others as fast as there are vacancies.

A fire that started at 8:30 last night damaged to the extent of $50,000 the five-story building at 55 Warren Street, running through to Murray Street. It was occupied by Surpless, Dunn Co., hardware, at 55 Warren Street; A. L. Juska, Japanese goods, at 55 Murray Street, and, on the four upper floors, where the fire did most damage, by the New York Bag Company.

Following are the returns at foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

BANGOR, March 15. -- The first four-masted schooner ever built at this port is to be constructed this season in the yard of E. I. K. Stetson. She will carry 1,500 tons of coal. She will cost $50.000, and the shares have been taken up by New York, Boston, and Bangor men.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 15 -- The Mercantile Trust Company of this city and New York and Boston capitalists have completed the merger of all the street railways and light and power interests of Atlanta, Ga. The merger will become effective April 1. It provides for the organization of the Georgia Railway and Electric Company, which will have the following capitalization:

THE Chinese shops in the basement and under the staircases of Mott Street are building up an extensive trade in tea and tea things. There are a number of these shops, and the amount of trade they do cannot be measured by their appearance either outside or inside. The business is good, for there are always several clerks busily employed, although the room used as a shop is rarely over fifteen feet square.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 -- Bids for the Jeffries-Fitzsimmons fight were opened here to-night. "Billy" Delaney represented Jeffries. A number of local clubs submitted bids. The only outside club to put in a bid was the Century Club of Los Angeles. The bids, with the exception of the Los Angeles club, offered only a straight percentage of the gross receipts.

The Brooklyn league has taken the field against the vicious conditions, which it claims obtain in nearly all parts of that borough to a greater or less extent. The lengue declares that there are many disreputable resorts in Brooklyn, and that the law is being openly violated in the borough.

Four hundred and fifty "Friends of Ireland" sat down to the twenty-third annual dinner of that organization last night in Shanley's Roman Court, Forty-second Street and Broadway. Strings of shamrocks decorated the tables, and the Irish and American flags were intertwined on the menu cards.

NOW, who would believe it, but this is surely the way they do it in Philadelphia, for The North American says so, and even gives a picture of the lady sitting at the dining table with an apple speared by her fork, while with a table knife she is peeling it. Alas and alack-a-day! she does look such a backwoods lady.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 15 -- The whole market was very firm to-day. The general list was disposed to advance, the exceptions being rare. International Trust figured as a feature, not so much on account of the volume of sales but on account of the tightness with which the stock is held.

Mme. Emma Calve will give her first New York public concert at the Waldorf-Astoria to-morrow evening, being assisted by MM. Salignac and Gilibert of the Metropolitan Opera Company, by permission of Mr. Maurice Grau. The programme will be composed entirely of popular French songs, ranging from the "vieille chanson" of the thirteenth century to the present popular love songs and satires of Beranger, Juies Juoy, Deroulede, and Darcier.

Two political conferences have been held in the Democratic fold during the last two days. The first was on Friday, and Lewis Nixon, the new leader of Tammany Hall; State Chairman Frank Campbell, a follower of David B. Hill, and Senator Patrick H. McCarren, a representative of the Brooklyn Democracy, conferred.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a casual reader of your paper I read with surprise your remarks on the cheers of the Irish "rebels" in the House of Commons on the announcement of the recent defeat of Gen. Methuen by Delary.

According to a dispatch from Chicago, published yesterday, Gen. William Sooysmith said some startling things at a dinner of the Chicago Real Estate Board in regard to the corroding of steel in tall buildings. He was quoted as making the statement that many of Chicago's skyscrapers were in danger of falling down within a very few years, the steel in them having rusted until it was in a condition "nothing short of public outrage."

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Consul General Cole, at Dresden, reports that a recent law enacted by the Saxon Landtag (Parliament) prohibits the Chamber of Commerce and Export Association of Dresden and all similar business associations in Saxony from giving information of any character to the representatives of any foreign country.

LONDON, March 15. -- The report that Americans soon will have a London club equal in exclusiveness and prominence to any of the leading clubs in the United States is confirmed. An influential Anglo-American Committee was formed this week for the purpose of arranging all the details and getting the organization ready prior to the coronation of King Edward.

The Railroad Gazette of this week reports one of the speeches at the celebration of the Baldwin Locomotive Works which we commend to the attention of those who believe that prohibition is the best mode of securing relief from excessive drinking.

Seldom has a prisoner at the bar appeared to be more crushed by a sentence than was Franklin McIntyre, twenty-one years old, who was a prisoner in the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning on a charge of abandonment preferred by his bride of a month. The decision of Magistrate Mott was that he must go right home and tell his mother all about it.

NOW that the opera company has departed into the East, where Mr. Alvarez is regarded as a greater artist than Jean de Reszke, and only Mme. Sembrich occupies a position similar to that accorded by New York, the really musical people of New York are having a chance to listen to real music.

NOW practically completed are the buildings in which are to be contained the works of the British Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company at Manchester, England. This plant, when finished, will represent probably the largest outlay ever made outright for a manufacturing establishment.

LONDON, March 15 -- The day on Which the disaster to Methuen was made public I saw a well-dressed gentleman coming along Pall Mall, smiling. When suddenly his eye fell on the yellow bulletin of one of the evening papers, he stopped, brought his two well-gloved hands convulsively together, while an expression of dismay overspread his countenance; then, remembering himself, he resumed his smile and air of ease and passed on.

The ancient Romans had a wise proverb which presumably acquired in the estimation of the professional agitators of that day the character of a platitude, but which nevertheless embodied much wisdom. It was Respice finem, and has its modern analogues in such homely bits of proverbial philosophy as "Look before you leap,"

One of the reasons why Wall Street received yesterday's bank statement, showing a further decrease in surplus reserves, with such equanimity lies in the fact that the very large bond redemption purchases made by the Government yesterday and Friday do not show in the statement, and it is recognized that the banks, therefore, are much better off (certainly so to the extent of these purchases, which approximate $5,000,000) than the statement shows on its face.

The earliest known historical reference to insanity occurs in Egypt papyri of the fifteenth century B.C. In one of these, according to Mahaffy, music is spoken of as employed in the treatment of insanity and many formulae are given for the cure of diseases caused by an evil spirit dwelling within the body.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to my suggestion in THE TIMES on Feb. 27 in reference to improving the ferry service and connecting the boats with trolleys to Broadway as being the only practicable method by which the present congestion on the bridge can be overcome, I notice that Commissioner Lindenthal proposes to test the popularity of the plan through the press on Monday.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 15. -- The old fisherman who keeps the boathouse at the foot of the lake opened up for business on Monday, and Lakewood residents now feel sure that Spring is really here. The robins have come, and their arrival is added assurance that the vernal season is here. The days are as warm and sunny as in May, and most people have found outside wraps a burden.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES recently made mention of the coming "passing" of the old dry goods establishment of Lord Taylor, at the corner of Grand and Chrystle Streets, and the probable turning of the building there into a Hebrew theatre or dance hall.

Advancing quotations, some of them of a substantial nature, were quite generally the rule in the stock market yesterday. In the early dealings there was a manifest disposition on the part of the professional element to await the publication of the bank statement, which --so the popular prediction ran -- was completely to wipe out surplus reserves.
Pretty Lulu Glaser, who is now playing the star part in "Dolly Varden" at the Herald Square Theatre, tells of an incident that happened to her while playing in Boston.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of March 8 I read a paragraph on Page 9 reporting the organization of the General Board of Education. To-night I read your strong editorial, "Organized Aid to Southern Education." It has inspired me to write a message to your readers, through the columns of your valuable paper.

George Fox Tiffany beat Robert L. Redfield yesterday in the final round for the February cup on the golf links of the Westchester Golf Club. The match was eighteen holes, but at the end the result was a tie.

The subway is half finished. That is, it is half finished when the actual work of ligging and construction and blasting is considered; but it is more than half finished when the time and the incidental problems of the early period of the enterprise are taken into calculation. Unless the plans of the engineers miscarry, cars will be running over the road late in the Fall of 1903.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of the vigorous agitation attending the nightly crushes at the Manhattan end of the New York and Brooklyn Bridge I beg to add my suggestion thereto for the alleviation of the trouble that appears to be uppermost in the public mind at present.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial of to-day is, I venture to think, somewhat less than fair to the late John Altgeld. If he was "painted black," and indeed he was, so much the worse for the painters, for Altgeld, and for your community, because such a prepossession as society in this country cherished against him impaired the utilities of a man of singular force, sincerity, and courage.

Many engineers of worldwide reputation gathered in the Montauk Club of Brooklyn last night to do honor to Charles C. Martin, engineer of the Brooklyn Bridge, whose friends had bidden him to an elaborate dinner in celebration of his long public services.

George G. Stephenson, Jr., won the third match for the Brigham trophy at the weekly shoot of the Crescent Athletic Club, at Bay Ridge, yesterday afternoon, and this finally disposes of the prize. It was offered by H.M. Brigham two weeks ago for the best scratch score at fifty targets, and was won by the giver, who put it up again a week ago, and again won it.

IN recent years the world has heard a great deal of the wonderful progress that Japan has made since that Summer morning in 1853 when Perry's squadron sailed under the shadow of Fuji-Yama and heralded the awakening of the Land of the Rising Sun from her long isolation. Fifty years ago Japan was almost, a terra incognita; to-day she is recognized as being a force in international politics.

LONDON, March 15 -- The Archdeacon of London (the Ven. William M. Sinelair) attended a performance of "Arizona" this week at the Adelphi Theatre, and was so pleased with the American play that he sent the members of the company tickets for the services at St. Paul's Cathedral and an invitation to take ten at the Chapter House afterward.

Corporation Counsel Rives is preparing to organize the new legal bureau of the Tenement House Department. Frederick W. Steele was yesterday appointed an Assistant Corporation Counsel, at a salary of $2,500 a year, and will be assigned to the Bureau for the Collection of Penalties.

WILLIAM C. WHITNEY is continually making interesting additions of animals and birds to his great game preserve of 10,000 acres on October Mountain, situated about four miles from Lenox, Mass. One of his latest accessions is a "pheasant farm," where he has several hundred of the beautiful Engiish pheasants sometimes called Japanese green heads.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 15. -- Mayor Low of New York and Mrs. Low alighted from a train here shortly before noon today and were driven about town in company with a local real estate man. Their presence created much talk and many were congratulating the town upon the prospect of having another notable on its list of residents.

The returns of the Bureau of Statistics for the eight months ended with February, corrected to the 14th of March, for exports and imports, show a considerable falling off in the former and an increase in the latter. We present the figures in tabular form, as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Pension Commissioner Evans, an officer of this Republican Administration, was to-day defended by a Democratic Congressman from Republican attacks made on the floor of the House. The Democrat was Mr. Gaines of Tennessee, who made a speech answering some criticisms of the Pension Commissioner recently made by Mr. Sulloway of New Hampshire and Mr. Cannon of Illinois.

TRENTON, March 15. -- Legislation to prevent forest fires will be enacted at this session of the Legislature, after an agitation of many years. While the provisions of Senator Minch's bill now pending apply to the entire State, they more directly affect the forests of Southern and Western Jersey, and particularly Atlantic, Camden, Burlington, and Cape May Counties.

BOSTON, March 15 -- Money rates, bank clearances, and balances are reported today as below: Clearing House rate, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 20c discount; call loans, 4 to 4 1/2; time money, 4 to 4 1/2; Clearing House exchanges, $21,701,467; balances, $1,212,294. The stock market was quiet and irregular.
SILAS LARRABEE says the tariff issue is looming up, and he predicts it will be the great political question in the next Presidential campaign.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., March 15 -- Edward D. Bates, an old man noted for his many peculiar habits, was found dead in his bed to-day. Death was due to heart disease. Bates was about seventy-five years old, and, so far as known, had no relatives. It is believed that he left considerable money. He was last seen on Thursday evening, and it is thought he died soon after retiring that night.

Yale won the intercollegiate hockey championship by defeating Harvard by the score of 4 to 1 at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. It was the second game in the series of three for final honors, and a Yale won the first match the previous night this victory gives the New Haven lads first place.

LONDON, March 15 -- Although violend wind and rain spoiled all outside pageantry, King Edward's first Court reception within the transformed Buckingham Palace was all that could have been expected. There has been no such brilliant gathering in the old palace since 1842, and all the awkwardness and stiff formality of the old "drawing rooms" have been abolished.

HER maiden aunt had all day been sounding in her ears the praises of a certain modest young man, and her maiden heart had rebelled, because it is very hard on a girl to listen patiently to what others take for granted and she is very uncertain about.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 15. -- The strike of painters was settled to-day by a compromise agreement. The rate will be 40 cents an hour or $3.20 for an eight-hour day. The 1,800 strikers will return to work at once.

WHEN James A. Garland began collecting Oriental porcelains ninteen years ago his purpose was only to secure a few beautiful ornaments to decorate his home. Year by year his treasures increased in value and number, however, and he became enthused with acquisitive pose.
Army. Capt. John S. Fogg, Assistant Surgeon United States Volunteers, on account of physical disability, is honorably discharged from the service of the United States, to take effect March 25.

It is many years since the music lovers of New York have had the opportunity of hearing a programme of such great and varied beauty as that which has been chosen by Mr. Frank Damrosch for the concert to be given in Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening March 22. in the interests of the Public Education Association and the City History Club.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Senator Berry, representing the minority of the Senate Committee on Commerce, to-day presented the report in opposition to the pending Ship Subsidy bill. The minority deny the accuracy of both the predictions and the facts in the majority report. They urge that the bill is wrong in principle and declare that it will utterly fail in the accomplishment of its professed objects.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Going to New York late and returning early, I am not one of those who daily suffer inconvenience because of the crush at the bridge. I have been deeply interested in the subject, however, and have read everything that has appeared in THE TIMES.

In these days when the chorus of Republican politicians is raised against "disturbing the tariff," it is refreshing to hear a Republican who is not a politician, but is a business man of wide experience and high standing, declaring that he desires that "the tariff may soon be revised and reduced to a much lower basis."

WHEN James A. Garland began collecting Oriental porcelains ninteen years ago his purpose was only to secure a few beautiful ornaments to decorate his home. Year by year his treasures increased in value and number, however, and he became enthused with acquisitive pose.
Army. Capt. John S. Fogg, Assistant Surgeon United States Volunteers, on account of physical disability, is honorably discharged from the service of the United States, to take effect March 25.

Reports received from Scotland announce the successful launching of the steamship Columbia, which is said to be by far the finest vessel ever constructed for the New York-Glasgow service. The ceremonies took place at Meadow-side, Particle, Scotland, in the yards of D. W. Henderson, on Washington's Birthday, the naming of the steamship being accomplished by Lady Balfour of Burleigh.

The New York Winter Garden opened last night with a vaudeville performance interspersed with ballets, a so-called character creation, " The Dope Fiend," and a socalled comedietta, entitled "The Belle of Broadway."

It is quite plain that Mr. BRODRICK'S efforts to reform what is amiss in the organization of the British Army have been sincere. It is equally plain that they have come very far short of complete success. The "remount scandal " showed that a number of honest but inexpert British officers were appointed to take charge of the supply of horses to the army and that they were grievously outwitted and cheated.

Gov. Odell was assailed as a dictator and autocrat by Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy yesterday before Justice Gaynor, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, on the argument for an order compelling Col. Norman S. Dike to turn over to Charles Guden the books and papers of the office of Sheriff of Kings County, from which position Guden was removed by Gov. Odell, Col. Dike being appointed as his successor.

Three plays new to this city are to be produced this week. One of these, Martha Morton's comedy. "The Diplomat," has not yet had a production elsewhere. The other two seek a metropolitan indorsement after having been received with some favor elsewhere. Revivals of old melodramas and farce comedy enter into the hills elsewhere, while a number of popular attractions are still current.

Four games were played in the world's championship pool tourney yesterday at the Montauk Academy, Brooklyn, two in the afternoon and two in the evening. Walsh beat McCune and Keogh defeated Long in the afternoon, the last game being won by only five points. Clearwater and Stofft furnished a good contest in the first evening game, Clearwater winning.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15 -- At the close of their conference to-day the subcommittees representing Yale and Harvard announced that satisfactory progress had been made toward an athletic agreement for a term of years. The members stated, however, that no agreement was signed. An arrangement was made to meet in Cambridge, and possibly also again in this city before reporting to the larger committees representing the two universities.

The thirteenth annual open scholastic meet of the Barnard School was successfully held yesterday afternoon in the armory of the Eighth Regiment. The athletes from Dwight School figured in nearly every event, and easily won the point competition with a total of 2S, St. Paul's School finishing second with 13 points.

William Hildenbrand, chief engineer of the Roebling Sons' Company, which has the contract for the cable work on the new East River Bridge, made the following statement last evening concerning the problem of the congestion on the Brooklyn Bridge:

The annual charity ball of the Purim Association is to be held next Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House. Some very ingenious tableaus have been devised for the entertainment of those who attend. Among which will be a representation of the seasons.

BERLIN, March 15. -- The North German Lloyd and the Hamburg-American Steamship Companies have had so much expense in returning from the United States emigrants who have been excluded under the American immigration laws that they now have entered into an arrangement with the Prussian railway authorities under which the latter agree to refuse transportation to persons from Austria and Russia who fail to meet certain requirements.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Anent your editorial in to-day's TIMES on the willingness of Austria to at last concede to this country the "official" dignity to which it had long ago nationally risen, you may be right when you say that perhaps the reason is because its Minister, Dr. von Hengelmullar, recently found himself so woefully eclipsed by Dr. von Holleben.

Six cross-country runs were held over wet and muddy courses in the suburbs of the city yesterday, the most important being that of the Shamrock Harriers, held over the Jerome Avenue course from One Hundred and Seventy-fifth Street to the Mosholu Parkway and return, which had about a score of starters.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 16. -- Of all strange deaths recorded in this part of the country for many a day, the fate met by Oliver McVeigh, a builder, in Kentwood, La., yesterday morning, is strangest. McVeigh was at work on the new depot there. The Chicago Limited, southbound and running at a terrific speed, struck a cow just opposite the station.

Road drivers and horsemen from far and near, behind their favorite trotters and pacers, thronged the Harlem River Speedway from early morning until the rain began to fall yesterday afternoon, and furnished some excellent sport for the crowds of spectators that occupied the sidewalks.

It was not by any means a "dry" Sunday in Manhattan yesterday as far as the selling of liquor was concerned. The saloon keepers seemed to have confidence that they would not be molested by the police or by any of the detectives of the different societies instituted for reform which aim at the standard of a "dry" Sunday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 16. -- North Dakota and the Canadian Northwest has experienced the worst snowstorm in many years, and railroad traffic is practically paralyzed. The Northern Pacific and Great Northern Roads have not moved a wheel for nearly thirty-six hours in the blizzard-stricken districts and have abandoned all efforts to do so until the fury of the storm shall abate.

Alois Spinner, an inside salesman for Damon Peets, dealers in printers' materials at 44 Beekman Street, yesterday tried to shoot Dr. Samuel Landsman of 68 East Third Street, whom he holds responsible for the death on Dec. 10 last of his son Alois, who was eighteen months old.

ORANGE, N.J., March 10. -- Seven cases of smallpox in Orange and four in Bloom-field have developed among people who attended a "wake" held over the body of John William McKenna, who died two weeks ago to-day. One of the cases resulted fatally to-day and the death of another is expected to-morrow, as the patient has the disease in a very severe form.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 16. -- Alexander R. Peacock, the steel millionaire, of this city is the victim of a blackmailing plot. His wife and three children are now living at the Holland House, New York, as a result. He is also in New York with them for the present.

The irrepressible conflict between the Senate and the Assembly over the canal improvement bills will be the greatest war ever fought. The farmers of Chenango may watch the tide of battle roll this way and that, believing that it is the real thing. Good men who sincerely desire the preservation of the canal system may attend committee hearings and plead for compromise.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., March 16. -- The Bowery Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association of New York City has decided to lease a farm of nearly 100 acres in Middlesex County. It will send probationists to the country, where pure air is plentiful and where there is less temptation.

TRENTON, N.J., March 16. -- A movement is on foot among the labor organizations of New Jersey and the United States to give a substantial testimonial to J.P. McDonnell of Paterson, who has been active for many years as a labor leader and editor and who was instrumental in having passed many of the labor laws now on the statute books.

TRENTON, N.J., March 16. -- Bishop McFaul of the Diocese of Trenton, who inaugurated the movement for the federation of Catholic organizations, has received an official statement from Anthony Matre, Secretary of the National Federation, stating that the movement is growing rapidly, and will soon have a membership of upward of half a million.

A toper who will not reform is usually spoken of as his own worst enemy. The Democratic Party at the present moment, sick and weary of its six years of debauchery, is prayerfully trying to reform, and is not its own worst enemy. It has an enemy nevertheless. He lives in Nebraska when he is not roving about the country, and his name is BRYAN.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Lieut. Gen. Nelson A. Miles, according to a Washington paper, made a specific request to the War Department to be sent to the Philippines, and in connection therewith submitted a plan by which, in his opinion, the war could be brought to an end without further loss of life to either side.

The Clearing House weekly bank statement disappointed bear speculators. There was not the sensational shrinkage in the surplus reserves which they had so much predicted. Their money market squeeze is, therefore, a programme hardly scheduled for the present week. And short contracts put out freely are hardly likely to be covered forthwith at a profit -- certainly not because of loan market disturbance.

A plan for relieving, at least temporarily, the congestion of trolley traffic in the Manhattan terminal of the Brooklyn Bridge, is said to have been at last adopted by Commissioner Lindenthal and the officials of the Brooklyn Street Railroad companies. This plan comprehends the building of four additional loops for trolley cars in the Park Row terminal.

A suit has been begun against Lewis Nixon by Dr. Carl W. Volney, a chemist and a patentee of a brand of smokeless powder. Mr. Nixon on the application of Meyer J. Stein, counsel for Dr. Volney, has been ordered by Justice Miles Beach to appear in Special Term to-morrow, and undergo an examination relative to the disposition of about $4,000,000 of stock of the International Smokeless Powder and Dynamite Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It very seldom occurs, indeed, that your esteemed paper falls into error. Your issue of the 8th inst. contains an article entitled "The Austrian Embassy." You there comment upon the proposed elevation of the representative of Austria-Hungary at Washington, and throughout the article you speak of "Austria" and the "Austrian Minister."

More than 15,000 bales of jute were either totally or partially destroyed by a fire yesterday in the big storage house known as "No. 2." belonging to the American Manufacturing Company, in Greenpoint. Incidentally to the fire nearly a dozen firemen were more or less overcome by smoke, and some narrowly escaped suffocation.

John W. Foster, a publisher, of 642 East One Hundred and Fifty-seventh Street, who was taken from the Bellevue Hospital Insane Pavilion Saturday to be placed in a private sanitarium, became violent in his home yesterday, and after smashing some house furnishings, was taken back to Bellevue in a coach.

"The young King of Spain, is physically and mentally as fit to reign as any boy of his age, and I have no doubt he will be crowned on his sixteenth birthday," was the reply of Bellamy Storer, United States Minister to Spain, to a question as to the qualifications of Alfonso XIII. to administer the affairs of Spain.

The conclusion drawn by English railway men from the address of Lord STALBRIDGE at the recent annual meeting of the London and Northwestern Railway is that "the American invasion of the British railway field has begun in earnest." The term is ill-chosen. English railway management is being Americanized to some degree, but opportunity has not yet been offered for anything like an invasion of that country by American railroad men.

Although the skies were gray and threatening, the air was sufficiently mild yesterday to bring the Harlem River oarsmen out upon the water in greater numbers than on any previous Sunday during the season. Eights were out from the Dauntless, Harlem, and Atalanta Clubs; fours from the Metropolitan, Harlem, and Union Clubs; a triplet from the Metropolitan Club, and singles or doubles from almost every club on the river.

Hugh O'Neill, one of the best-known dry goods merchants in this country, died at his home in this city yesterday afternoon. For many months he had been in ill-health, but it was only a little over two months ago that his condition became such as to necessitate his actual retirement from the supervision of the large establishment at Sixth Avenue and Twentieth and Twenty-first Streets that bears his name.

-- In explaining to one of the London papers why he recently protested against the execution by the British military authorities of Boers whom he calls "criminals according to military law, no doubt," Mr. GEORGE MEREDITH makes use of a curious argument -- an argument that will not be at all relished either by the Boers or by their European and American friends.

BRADLEY BEACH, N.J., March 16. -- Mayor James A. Bradley of Asbury Park, who owns considerable property at this place, took steps yesterday to reverse the decision of the Election Board which, recently declared A.T. Rogers, Democrat, re-elected Mayor of this resort. In order to do this the board rejected forty-eight votes, claiming they were marked ballots.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 16. -- Conferences in this city last night and to-day of noted railroad lawyers and financiers interested in bids to be submitted to the Mayor and City Councils to-morrow for the Western Maryland Railroad indicate that an important deal is pending, in which the Gould, and probably the Vanderbilt, interests figure prominently.
LONDON, March 16. -- The War Office has received the following communication from Lord Kitchener:

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 16. -- The United Mine Workers' delegates from this end of the region will leave for the Shamokin convention to-morrow, confident that there will be no strike, and that they will return home, having put in motion a movement which will end in the operators granting a much-desired concession.

ALBANY, March 16. -- With final adjournment in sight, the Legislature still has a vast amount of work to perform. There are on the Senate calendar at present, either on the order of third reading or In general orders, fully 250 bills, and among them at least 12 important measures, which are likely to call forth argument.

LONDON, March 17. -- The flat race season had an excellent sendoff at Lincoln this afternoon. The weather was pleasant, and big crowds congregated to whet their appetites for to-morrow's great handicap. The American owners of horses were not represented to-day.

In the tournament of the New York InterClub Bowling League on the Century Wheelmen alleys last night, the home team won three games from the Caledonian Club team. The scheduled match between the Harlem Republican Club and the Knicker-bocker Athletic Club was postponed. In the Harlem Navy League, Pearce of the Nonpareil Rowing Club team equaled the high individual score of 248. The scores:

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- This was the last day of talk and conference over the Cuban reciprocity question. To-morrow the House Republicans will meet and vote in favor of relief for Cuba. The beet sugar men have fought to the end, and will go down with their colors flying. They know they are beaten, and frankly confess it, but that does not move them to give the slightest heed to compromise.

LONDON, March 17. -- Money was in fair demand to-day, and there was little prospect of relief. Over u7,000,000 is owing to the Bank of England. It was difficult to maintain discount rates, owing to Continental inquiry for bills.

ALBANY, March 17. -- Gov. Odell said tonight that he would appoint Georse T. Canfield. President or the State Charities Aid Association, a member of the Board of Visitation to the Manhattan State Hospital.

Much announcement being made of the fact that many prominent Wall Street men are enjoying Southern vacations, popular expectation was ready for a furthur narrowing of the stock market yesterday: and weakness would not have created much surprise. Yet the day's aggregate of transactions mounted above what have recently been average totals, and yet changes for the day were in large majority advances.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 17. -- The money investors of this city and Dutchess County, especially in the vicinity of Pine Plains, will be heavy losers by the collapse of the Bunnell Eno Investment Co. of Philadelphia. It is thought that the aggregate losses of Dutchess County people will be between $400,000 and $500,000.

BALTIMORE, March 17. -- The first definite step toward a sale of the holdings of the City of Baltimore in the Western Maryland Railroad was taken to-day, when bids were opened and read by a special committee appointed from among the members of the City Council for that purpose.

L.P. Ittel of Allegheny City, Penn., won the chief trophy yesterday in the concluding contest of the Zettler Rifle Club's tournament which has been held during the past ten days on the ranges of the Rifle Club at 159 West Twenty-third Street. Most of the competitors have been seen in previous shooting sontests at the Sportsmen's Show, but it was impossible to arrange this season to hold the Zettler tournament in Madison Square Garden.

BERLIN, March 17. -- The recent establishment of a line of steamships to run between between New York and the Orient has aroused considerable adverse comment in regard to the Hamburg-American Steam Packet Company. The newspapers which represent German industries complain that a German line is thus assisting American goods to compete with German goods in the Orient.

CHICAGO, March 17. -- The wrecking of a childhood romance is set forth in the divorce suit of Harold E. Thomas, a son of Gen. Samuel Thomas of New York, against his wife, the trial of which opened in Judge Bishop's court to-day.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 17. -- An invitation to the Weld Rowing Club of Harvard to send a crew to meet Cornell's junior crew on Lake Cayuga this Spring has been extended by Cornell's Rowing Committee. Prof. Durand said to-day the negotiations for the contest were now under way.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 17. -- The city administration is beginnings to think that the ecnduit, which the Illinois Telephone Company has for many months been constructing underneath the city street level, is not a harmless hole in which telephone and telegraph wires are to lie, but a traction subway through which in a few months street cars may go whizzing.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 17. -- Bourke Cockran spoke to-night in the Exposition Building to an audience of more than 5,000 people. His address on the topic "St. Patrick as the Original Founder of Popular Government," was a marshaling of historic facts in which the apostle of Ireland was presented in a new light.
WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The title of the subsidy bill passed by the Senate is:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 17. -- It is not often the Philadelphia market is dominated by a degree of apathy such as attended to-day's dealings. There was plenty of buying power, but no incentive to bring it out, except in the Readings, where a constant absorption by a house prominently associated with the direction of the property brought in an outside following.

Corporation Counsel Rives replied yesterday to the criticisms which have come from Albany in reference to the provisions of the bill offered by Mayor Low to change the motive power from steam to electricity in the Park Avenue tunnel of the New York Central Railroad Company.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Sprays of shamrock in honor of St. Patrick's Day graced the lapels of the coats of half the members when the House met to-day. Immediately after the approval of The Journal the House went into Committee of the Whole and commenced the consideration of the River and Harbor bill.

PLYMOUTH, March 17. -- The Hamburg-American liner Deutschland, from New York March 11, having on board Prince Henry of Prussia and his suite, passed the Seilly Islands at 8:30 o'clock this morning, and reached this port at 12:30 P.M. The Deutschland remained three-quarters of an hour in these waters, and then proceeded on her journey to Cherbourg and Hamburg.

ALBANY, March 17. -- "The Citizen" was the subject which gave ex-Senator David B. Hill an opportunity to deal with many questions of National importance at the dinner of the Albany Sons of St. Patrick, at the Ten Eyck to-night.

McVickar Co. have sold for Mrs. Fannie Musgrave of Washington, D.C., the four-story building 535 Fifth Avenue, 30 by 100. The property has been held at $250,000. It adjoins Delmonico's, at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, but the brokers in the deal say that the purchaser is not an adjoining owner.

By an overwhelming vote the Republican Club of the City of New York has placed itself on record as opposed to the sort of protection that is fighting Cuban reciprocity. A resolution indorsing President Roosevelt's plan for a reduction of duties on tobacco and sugar imported from the island was passed last night, after a spirited and almost riotous debate that lasted until a few minutes before midnight.

Keen, swift play, coupled with an ability to place the ball accurately, resulted in Edmund D. Evans (plus 12) defeating the scratch man, Frank L. Donohue, yesterday afternoon in the handicap hand tennis tournament in the New York Athletic Club gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Rumors of conflict of authority between the civil and military authorities in the Philippines find substantial confirmation in an order recently issued by Gen. Chaafee, the Division Commander at Manila, to the commanding officer of the Fifth Separate Brigade, operating in Iloilo.
CHERBOURG, March 17. -- The Deutschland arrived here at 6:35 P.M. from Plymouth.

CHATHAM, Mass., March 17. -- Seven brave life savers, practically the entire crew of the Monomoy station on the south end of Cape Cod, met death to-day at their posts of duty, and with them into the ticacherous sea which capsized the life-beat went five men from the stranded barge Wadena, whom they vainly tried to bring in safely to the shore.

ALBANY, March 17. -- The appeal in the case of Police Captain Thomas J. Diamond, who was convicted of a misdemeanor in falling to suppress an alleged disorderly house in his precinct in New York City, was argued before the Appellate Division, Third Department, this morning. Capt. Diamond has paid a fine of $1,000 and now asks for a new trial.

LONDON, March 18. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times describes a great demonstration in the Russian capital on Sunday. It was, he says, organized by two committees, one of students and the other of workmen. They previously sent notices to the army officers that a peaceful demonstration was intended, and requested that the officers order the troops not to fire or use cold steel.

Carriages, hansoms, victorias, and bupgies rolled up in front of the apartment house 100 West Sixty-first Street yesterday afternoon, and handsomely dressed women disappeared in to the second-floor flat. At 4:30 Capt. Kear of the West Sixty-eighth Street Station forced his way into the flat with four detectives and raided the place as an alleged poolroom.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 16. -- Student riots here to-day, in which over 10,000 people participated, kept a small army of police and cavalry busy throughout the day. Probably 100 arrests were made, but the repressive measures were not so strict as on the corresponding Sunday of 1901. While many persons were injured no fatalities were reported.

The fact that an exceptionally large number of cases of smallpox were reported yesterday and that the disease is, according to the testimony of physicians, more prevalent in New York City than at any previous time, with one exception, caused unusual interest to attach to the discussion of the disease at the meeting of the New York County Branch of the State Medical Association at the Academy of Medicine on West Forty-third Street last night.

At the moment when the friends of Bryn Mawr College are striving to complete the fund which would make Mr. ROCKEFELLER'S gift available for new buildings and equipments, a calamity has befallen the college in the burning of Denbigh Hall, one of its principal dormitories.

OMAHA, Neb., March 17. -- Suit was to-day filed against the Government to set aside the deed held by it to the land embraced within the military reservation of Fort Omaha. The plaintiffs in the suit are the original donators of the land, and the list includes more than a hundred names, all of well-known citizens of Omaha.

"It is easily possible," observes the cheerful OXNARD, "to develop the beet-sugar industry so that it may supply all the needs of the United States." These needs he estimates to be, "within a few years," 3,000,000 tons a year. At present they are 2,330,000 tons. Of this amount the native American beet contributes some 76,859 tons, or about onethirtieth.

ALBANY, March 17. -- Mayor Low's "Sweep" bill, as it is called, will probably come up in the Senate to-morrow.
