Friends of the city administration in the Legislature were informed to-night that Mayor Low was very anxious to have this bill put through, and strong efforts will be made to have it in the Mayor's hands early next week.

-- When Magistrate MAYO imposed a ten-dollar fine yesterday upon Mr. FREDERICK C. HAVEMEYER for running an automobile through Fifth Avenue at a speed not only dangerous to the public, but in violation of a city ordinance, the Magistrate very wisely took pains to ward off criticism from himself by announcing to the reckless youth that he had received the heaviest penalty provided by the law he had ignored.

There is in the Senate of the United States a considerable number of gentlemen who are past middle age, who are conservative in their mental and political tendencies, who are possessed of large estates and are interested in many enterprises, commercial and industrial. They would be greatly surprised and somewhat incensed to hear themselves described as Socialists.
ALBANY, March 17. -- The thirty-fifth annual report of the State Board of Charities, covering the work of the board for the year 1901, was transmitted to the Legislature last night.

The fly-casting competition at the Sportsmen's Show yesterday was done under the novelty of a forward obstacle. A large canvas sheeting was suspended over the stream, to conform to overhanging brush, a condition which the skillful flycaster frequently meets in his trout fishing.

As a result of the caving in of an embankment on Forty-sixth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning, two men lost their lives, and two others were seriously injured. The men were members of a sang of laborers who have been at work excavating in a lot at the point mentioned for several days.

Mrs. Almira C. Lawton, an artist, and Frank H. Lawton, a musician, occupied the entire day of Justice Levintritt in the Supreme Court yesterday in relating two sides to a remarkable story of domestic infelicity.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, March 17. -- The Venezuelan insurgents, commanded by Gen. Monagas, captured the port of Guanta (about 150 miles east at Caracas) on March 13. Six Custom House officers were wounded. A Dutch steamer arrived off Guanta shortly after the insurgents had taken possession of that place, and transferred to the revolutionists several bags of mail matter, the steamer's officers thinking they were dealing with the legal authorities.

Mrs. Ida C. Craddock, who was arrested on March 5 charged with violating Section 317 of the Penal Code, in using the malls improperly, came up for sentence before the Court of Special Sessions yesterday afternoon. Hugh O. Pentacost, who represented the defendant, handed to the court two letters from the Rev. Dr. W.S. Rainsford, with a plea for modification of sentence.

Morris Meyers, formerly a clerk in Albert T. Patrick's law office, and who is a witness to the will of William M. Rice and to the general assignments of all the latter's property to Patrick, which the prosecution contends are forged, was called to the stand yesterday at the trial of his former employer on the charge of murdering Rice.

Six miles north of Diamond Shoals Lightship, the splendid schooner yacht Endymion, of which George Lauder, Jr., a Pittsburg millionaire, and nephew of Andrew Carnegie, is owner, was sighted Sunday by the Cromwell liner Proteus from New Orleans, dismasted and flying signals of distress.

In discussing the conclusion of the freight handlers' strike in Boston, Senator MARK A. HANNA gave expression to some very creditable sentiments, which have the advantage of sounding extremely well without committing the speaker to anything in the least inconsistent with his interests or ambitions.

The arrest yesterday of Dr. Ottokar Porsch and his son, Joseph E. Porsch, President and Secretary-Treasurer of the Porsch Chemical Company of 19 Liberty Street, by Deputy United States Marshals Blake and McAvine, promises to expose a systematic scheme by which the Federal Government has been robbed of many thousands of dollars.

BOSTON, Mass., March 17. -- The money market, while still showing a deal of firmness, is causing less apprehension than a short time ago. Clearing House rate, 3 per cent. New York funds, 20, 15, and 10 cents discount; call loans, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.; time money, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Clearing House exchanges, $16,975,850; balances, $1,065,088.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Talk about the Hanna boom for President amuses nobody more than it does Mr. Hanna himself. Mr. Hanna does not expect to be President of the United States nor to be nominated for the Presidency by a Republican National Convention. Nobody intimates that a Presidential bee is buzzing in the Senator's bonnet.

Frowning skies and intervals of drizzling rain had not the least dampening effect on the enthusiasm of the many thousands of sons and daughters of Ireland who turned out yesterday to march to the tunes of the motherland or to cheer the verdant hosts hat went marching by in honor of St. Patrick, the patron saint of the Emerald Isle.

Few of our readers, we suppose, are ignorant of the name of the City History Club. But as few, we suppose also, are really familiar with the admirable work it is doing. Most of us admit that a lack of municipal patriotism has very much to do with our shortcomings in municipal government.

In spite of Augustus Thomas's modest disclaimer, in his speech last night after the third act of "Soldiers of Fortune" at the Savoy Theatre, there are strong and indisputable traces of his handiwork in the play. Passage after passage in the dialogue, and those among the most telling, were touched and pointed with the racy vernacular of his wit.

Helped by the strength of the Stock Exchange market outside securities yesterday showed a good deal of strength and considerable activity. In some cases the prices recorded were the best on record, and in others substantial net gains were made. Even the Copper stocks were only slightly affected by the decline in Amalgamated, and some of them actually ended the day higher than they were at the close of the market on Saturday.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 17. -- The will of Jerome Wheelock, inventor of the Wheelock engine, who was at first supposed to have died intestate, was found Sunday at his home and to-day filed in Probate Court. The estate is valued at from $500,000 to $600,000. The Worcester Safe Deposit and Trust Company is made trustee.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 18 -- The defeat of the six tickets for a quarter bill in the Legislature to-day, a fate which has been predicted, had the precise effect on the United Railways issues which has been persistently foreshadowed. The defeat did not happen until just a moment before the close of the Exchange, but even then, in almost a twinkling, it started the income bonds upward.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Representative Hepburn of Iowa to-day made his annual speech against the River and Harbor bill. Mr. Hepburn's speeches against this measure are always listened to with intense interest, and every Congressman is in his seat to hear them, although the House always votes him down.

In the tournament of the New York Interclub Bowling League on the Harlem Wheelmen alleys last night the home team won two of three games with the Century Wheelmen team, the scores being as follows: Harlem Wheelmen, first game, 866; second game, 844; third game, 810; Century Wheelmen, first game, 746; second game, 757; third game, 812.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Davis Canal bill, carrying an appropriation of $31,800,000, for the improvement of the Erie and Champlain Canals, passed the Senate today by a vote of 27 to 15. There was no debate, but on the roll call several Senators asked to be excused long enough to explain their reasons for voting against the bill.

The suggestions of ex-Secretary of the Treasury Gage with reference to the further development of the National banking system was the subject under discussion fit the meeting of the Academy of Political Science, held last night in Room 401 of the Library Building of Columbia University.

Important and unexpected transfers or Methodist Episcopal pastors in the metropolitan district will be made at the Spring sessions of the New York East and Newark Conferences, April 2. Some of the more conspicuous changes that will be made, according to present arrangements, follow:

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Weather Bureau has issued the following summary of climate and croos in Porto Rico during February, 1902: "Four consecutive weeks of hot dry weather have resulted in considerable damage to growing crops and in the paralysis of all farm work except the cutting and grinding of cane, for which the conditions have been ideal.
Second Lieut. Eugene R. West is assigned to the Eighteenth Battery. Field Artillery, and will join that battery at the Presidio of San Francisco.

Poultney Bigelow, the American traveler and writer, who for some years past has made his home in England, arrived at New York on the Atlantic Transport liner Minneapolis from London yesterday morning. It has been rumored that Mrs. Bigelow is about to sue him for a divorce, and it was to that affair the the first question put to Mr. Bigelow on the pier referred.

Down the North River, forced onward by wind and tide, came the wrecked steamship British Queen and four smaller craft, all ablaze. The New York shore was in danger. Toward this side of the river drifted the burning boats, and the Fire Department had one of the tasks of its history on its hands.

Yesterday's programme was filled with Lenten entertainments. The two principal affairs were the afternoon recital for the benefit of the Stony Wold Sanatorium and the lecture on Dawson given by Mrs. Rosewell Hitchcock. This afternoon there will be the regular meeting of the Wednesday Afternoon Bowling Club, otherwise the Knickerbocker, and a few sewing societies will also have meetings.

A blaze which, according to Asent Mason of the Phoenix Steamship Line's pier, at the foot of Seventh Street, Hoboken, started on the north side of the pier among a pile of wicker baskets, set fire to a pile of cotton bales. A few minutes later billows of flames swept along the pier and enveloped the British Queen, a liner of the Antwerp service berthed there.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

The New York Fire Insurance Exchange yesterday made a radical advance in fire Insurance rates on many classes of property in this city. Throughout most of the States of the Union, excepting only a few of the larger cities, similar advances have been made since the Waterbury and Paterson conflagrations, but it had been expected in many quarters that New York City would not be subjected to like action by the fire underwriters.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Senator Elsberg enlivened proceedings at the Capital to-day by inaugurating a fight against the autocracy of the Assembly Committee on Rules. Because that committee took off the Assembly calendar a bill of his, which had been advanced to third reading. Senator Elsberg declared that he would block all Assembly bills in the Senate.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Senator Krum's bill to amend the banking law relative to the securities in which deposits in savings banks may be invested, was passed by the Senate to-day. The bill called forth denunciation and gloomy prophecy from Senators Donnelly and Ahearn.
LONDON, March 18 -- The money conditions were practically unchanged to-day. Supplies were restricted.

M. Leopold Mabilleau, the Director of the Social Museum of Paris, explained the purpose of the institution with which he is connected to the League for Political Education, at 23 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday. He lectured in French, his lecture being afterward summarized in English by Prof. Adolphe Cohn of Columbia University.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Senator Raines's bill to amend the Raines excise law so as to do away with sham hotels, was passed by the Senate to-day. The bill had a narrow escape from defeat, as the vote was 26 to 18. The 26 votes necessary for the passage were secured only through Senator Fuller changing from the negative to the affirmative after Senator Raines had gone over to him and pleaded with him.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- In the early hours the stock market here was very dull, except for the Choctaws, but after the demand for the Readings sprang up in New York, a more cheerful tone was observable. Some stocks still sagged, however, Cambria Steel, Philadelphia Electric, and Consolidated Lake Superior all ending lower.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 18 -- Ex-President Grover Cleveland was sixty-five years old to-day.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., March 18 -- The most important convention of hard coal miners since that which resulted In the memorable strike of 1900, opened here to-day, and is likely to remain in session until Saturday. The three anthracite coal districts, known technically as Districts 1, 7, and 9, United Mine Workers of America, are represented by over 600 delegates, the majority of whom presented their credentials.

PARIS, March 18 -- American jockeys had twenty-two mounts in six races during the contests at Maisons Laffitte to-day, and were placed eleven times. B.J. Rigby got one first and one second place. J. Reiff and W.B. Buchanan got one first place each. Milton Henry got two second and two third places, and Archie Mclntyre obtained two second and one third places.

The ice carnival of Heffley School was held last night in the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn. Besides the ordinary skating contests and exhibitions it included the ordinary foot races and a potato race, an unlimited bicycle pursuit race, broom-ball, and hockey.

The only change of importance in the subsidy scheme contrived by Mr. FRYE and his advisers, as it passed the Senate, is an express prohibition of the subsidy to any foreign-built ship. Congress is not bound by this, of course, and can at any time reverse it. But it has the advantage that no foreign-built ship can get the subsidy without affirmative action by Congress.

Frederick Waite, thirty-three years old, of 165 East One Hundred and Sixth Street, a motorman of the Third Avenue surface road, received an electric shock yesterday from reversing his current lever on his car, and was taken unconscious to Flower Hospital.

John W. Gates occupied the witness stand most of the day yesterday before Justice Truax in the Supreme Court and testified in his own behalf in the suit brought against him by John H. Parks to compel him to render an accounting of the disposition of the $15,000,000 profits said to have been derived from the formation of the American Steel and Wire Company, a part of which Mr. Parks claimed was due to him.

LONDON, March 19 -- The debate last evening in the House of Commons, on the motion of the Liberal leader, Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman, for the appointment of a Select Committee to investigate the whole commercial history of the South African war, called out several acrimonious exchanges of remarks.

BOSTON, Mass., March 18 -- Money holds firm, but with light demand. Clearing House rate, 3 per cent. New York funds, 15c and 12 1/2c discount. Call loans, 4 to 4 1/2, per cent. Time money, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Exchanges, $24,000,645; balances, $1,034,856. The stock market was strong, at times buoyant, and trading was active.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- About 140 Republican members of the House met in tonight's conference -- the fifth gathering held to settle the Cuban reciprocity question. Among those present were Speaker Henderson, Chairman Payne of the Ways and Means Committee, and others who have figured prominently in the contest.

The municipal budget for 1902 will be about $100,000,000 or $2,000,000 more than the amount allowed by the Board of Estimate presided over by Mayor Van Wyck for the work of the departments and all other expenses connected with the City Government. Two of the must important departments submitted their budgets yesterday.

In the outside market yesterday transactions were larger than usual, and quotations as a whole were higher. In several prominent stocks substantial advances resulted from the day's trading, and many minor net gains appeared in the final figures. Colorado Fuel bonds showed a very large total and ended the day two points or more above Monday's closing price.

This community regards with interest end the utmost favor the plan of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to construct a tunnel under the North River, terminating in a spacious underground station for which land has been acquired between Thirty-second and Thirty-third Streets, west of Seventh Avenue.

Clearly enough the market is a waiting one -- but while it waits it isn't discouraging. Yesterday's total business ran somewhat beyond 600,000 shares, transactions being well distributed throughout the list. Most changes of as much as a whole point were advances. One fact emphasized day by day is that floating stocks -- stocks actually on sale -- are scarce.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 18 -- An indictment returned against the Louisville, and Nashviile Railroad by the Federal Grand Jury was made public to-day. It charges a violation of the inter-State commerce law, the offense consisting in the road charging less for the transportation of corn in carload lots than the inter-State commerce law prescribes.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day disclosed its plans for its crusade to prevent violations of the Sherman anti-trust law by railroads. The commission has seized upon the railroads' own great weapon, the injunction, and turned it against those corporations.

Four games were played in the pool championship tournament at the Montauk Billiard Academy, Brooklyn, yesterday. In the afternoon Weston and Long were the victors, defeating respectively Walsh and Stofft. In the evening Keogh defeated McCune in the first game, while the second game was between Clearwater and Eby.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The general immigration bill, prepared by Chairman Shattue of the Committee on Immigration and Naturalization, and accepted by that committee, was by him reported to the House to-day with the recommendation that it be passed. Mr. Shattue said of the bill:

-- Nobody could have watched the struggling and terrified crowd of people that was imprisoned Monday evening on the platform of the City Hall elevated station by a brief interruption of the train service without seeing that an appalling catastrophe was prevented only by the same marvelous luck which has saved so many of the Manhattan's trains, when derailed, from plunging into the street below.

A communication from Morgan Slattery, the Tammany architects, was read at the meeting of the Armory Board yesterday. The architects discussed in detail the plans and resolution passed by the old Armory Board referring to the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. They stated that they were willing at all times to alter and modify their plans, so as to conform with the appropriation of $450,000 but were instructed not to do so.

CUXHAVEN, March 18 -- The return of Admiral Prince Henry of Prussia to German soil, took place this afternoon amid all the pomp and circumstance with which the Emperor has seen fit to mark the successful ending of his brother's American mission.

David L. Short, who declares that, with Morris Meyers, he witnessed the execution of the purported will of William Marsh Rice which gives to Albert T. Patrick the bulk of the millionaire's property and money, followed Meyers on the witness stand yesterday at the trial of Patrick, who is charged with Rice's murder.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Senator Hoar's bill for the protection of the President was introduced in the Senate to-day, and will be passed to-morrow. It would have been passed to-day had it not been that Senator Money, who was out of town, desires to have a chance to speak against it.

At the conclusion of the day's session in the examination of Florence Burns, accused of the murder of Walter S. Brooks, which was resumed yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions. Justice Mayer requested the opposing counsel to present arguments at the hearing next Saturday upon certain points in the testimony of the detectives.

Park Commissioner WILCOX has arrived at an excellent, and what appears to be a generally acceptable settlement of a controversy that has made more stir than its apparent importance deserved, although it was really, in its way, of high importance. That is the choice of a site for the monument to Gen. SHERMAX.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday and transacted routine business. It was decided to name the present New York and Brooklyn Bridge the Brooklyn Bridge, the new East River Bridge the Williamsburg Bridge, Bridge No. 3 the Manhattan Bridge, and Bridge No. 4 the Blackwell's Island Bridge.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The State Board of Tax Commissioner gave a hearing today to corporations operating special franchises in New York City on objections which they have to the tentative valuations placed upon their franchises for the current year, under the Special Franchise Tax act. The board will not make public the tentative valuations until it has determined the final valuations.

After questioning five patrolmen and Detective Sergeants of the West Forty-seventh Street Station yesterday afternoon. District Attorney Jerome said again that he had discovered nothing which would point to a case of murder in the matter of the strange death of James McAuliffe on Feb. 16.

The agreement of Great Britain not to adopt a preferential tariff in favor of sugar, the produce of any of her colonies, was probably necessary to the success of the conference. It seems to be inconsistent with the report that reaches us from London that the British Ministry is inclined to recommend such a preferential tariff.

News was received by cable in this city yesterday that Mme. Sarah Bernhardt has begun rehearsals at her theatre in Paris of F. Marion Crawford's version of "Francesca da Rimini." Her present intention is to product this play at the earliest moment that adequate rehearsing of it will allow.
BAYONNE, N.J., March 18 -- After his arrest this morning Max C. Mayer made the following statement, in the presence of a court officer:

SALEM, N.J., March 18 -- Bishop Andrews this morning announced the following appointments, among many others, after the adjournment of the annual conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church for the Southern District of New Jersey:
ON BOARD THE DEUTSCHLAND, March 18, 3 P.M. -- As this steamer drew near to Cuxhaven Prince Henry received the correspondent of The Associated Press in his Royal Hignness's cabin. The Prince said:

The tunnel hearing which is to be held in the Mayor's office on Friday morning at 11 o'clock began to be actively discussed among people interested in, railroad and rapid transit matters yesterday, and the indications are that it will be well attended.

Max C. Mayer, who was for several years confidential manager of the extinct brokerage firm of R.L. Rathborne Co., and was later a member of the firm of Rathborne, Mayer Rathborne, was arrested yesterday morning in Bayonne. N.J., charged by the existing firm of Rathborne Son of 7 Wall Street with having embezzled over $100,000 of the funds of the original company.

Scores of pedestrians were put to flight yesterday, when a team of horses attached to a victoria galloped madly down Fifth Avenue from Ninetieth Street to Eighty-third Street. The carriage, after narrowly escaping several collisions, finally struck a truck and the coachman was thrown from the box.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., March 19 -- The indi- cations to-night point strongly to a strike declaration by the convention of anthracite coal miners in session here. It is said by some of the delegates, who represent the entire anthracite region, that the declaration may come as early as Friday of this week.

In his address before the librarians a few days ago Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE said some curious things about the influence of books through mere proximity, even when unread. He also expressed views about fiction which would scarcely bear the test of critical examination.

The rapid increase of population in Europe, with the exception of France, makes the question of the adaptation of Europeans to life in the tropics more important than ever. We see Germany and Italy, following the lead of Great Britain, looking about the world for colonies where their surplus population can found new homes.
BELLOWS FALLS, Vt., March 19 -- Edward Green, husband of Hetty Green, died at his home here to-day. He had been ill for a long time of a complication of diseases. He was eighty years old.

ALLENDALE, N.J., March 19 -- The O. H.P. Archer residence here was entered by burglars on Monday night, and the robbery was discovered on Tuesday morning, but the matter was kept quiet until to-day in the hope that the burglars would return with a couple of vans to take away what they left behind at the time of their first visit.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The chief social incident of to-day was the celebration of the annual feast of St. Joseph at the Home for Aged of the Little Sisters of the Poor, society always being largely represented at this annual dinner. This home is a charity under the special patronage of the French Embassy.

Novice skaters competed in the annual figure skating contest under the auspices of the National Amateur Skating Association at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. After eleven events had been decided, all of which were closely contested. William Valentine of New York City won the honors with 46 points.

BOSTON, March 19 -- The rates for money are still holding firm, but there is no present general inclination to mark them up. The situation as a whole is somewhat mixed, with opinion divided as to what is just ahead of the market. Money is still in good supply, but demand continues moderate, and is hardly likely to increase until after the first of the month.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Crumpacker resolution is looked upon by the Southern Democrats with mingled feelings. While they think it will give them a winning issue, they regret its introduction because of what they consider is certain to be its effect upon the relations between the North and South.
BERLIN, March 19 -- Prince Henry landed at Kiel at dusk and joined Princess Henry and their sons.
Still the market is one of specialties. Reiteration of this description gets to be trite. Yet how often has Wall Street known any other market? But once or twice in a decade.

It must be said that there was nothing handsome or magnanimous about such a measure of compliance with the recommendations of the President and the Secretary of War as the House has finally been induced to allow. The concession from the full force of the Dingley tariff is much less than that which has been put by experts in the subject as the "irreducible minimum" of what would enable Cuba to prosper.

SAX FRANCISCO, March 19 -- By a decision rendered to-day in the Supreme Court of California, the trust clause in the will of former United States Senator James G. Fair, so far as it pertains to the personal property of his estate, is declared invalid, and an order of distribution by Superior Judge James M. Troutt to the children, Charles L. Fair, Mrs. Theresa Oelrichs, and Mrs. Virginia Fair Vanderbilt, is affirmed.

There are artists who steal into notice because it is found that certain collectors, whose attention has been called their way by fellow-craftsmen or by critics, have been purchasing the works of the favored ones, whereupon other collectors rush in and the art dealers discover that it is safe to vent- ure.

The Texas and Pacific Railway Company, one of the lines composing the Gould system, yesterday published its annual report for the year ended Dec. 31, 1901. The report contains some unique features, among them an account of the operations of the railroad's hospital at Marshall, Tex., which handled 2,773 patients last year, out of which number 14 died.

OBERLIN, Ohio, March 19 -- Ex-President James H. Fairechild, for twenty-three years President of Oberlin College, died tonight, aged eighty-five years. He was connected with Oberlin College for sixty-eight years, and had served longer than any other college official in the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Senator Simmons of North Carolina believes the Democrats will elect a majority of the next House of Representatives, and that they will enter the next Presidential campaign with chances in favor of the election of their candidates. Asked why he entertained these expectations, Mr. Simmons said:

BOARD OF EDUCATION'S REFUSAL TO ISSUE A TEACHER'S LICENSE NOT REVIEWABLE BY THE COURTS -- The right of a teacher in the public schools of the Borough of Brooklyn to have a review by the courts of the Board of Education's refusal to grant a license enabling her to teach in a higher grade has been denied by the Second Appellate Division.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Gen. Otis continued his testimony before the Senate Philippine Committee to-day. Referring to his order of Sept. 8, 1898, directing the withdrawal of the insurgent troops outside the defenses of Manila, Gen. Otis said he did not give the insurgents actual permission to occury the blockhouses which Aguinaldo claimed had been given.

Col. John F. Hobbs, editor of The National Provisioner, to whom prominent meat shipping companies yesterday referred all inquirers about the German Government's new decree in regard to meats, declared last night that the decree practically barred American meats from Germany. The decree prohibits the use of borax and boracic acid to preserve meats.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For an American President to have his portrait painted by a foreigner is a gross injustice to the portrait painters of this country, as it implies what is entirely false, that there are no painters here equal to the task, and when the President chooses an inferior foreign painter it becomes a public outrage.

Two important facts were brought out in the testimony of John S. Kennedy, the banker and capitalist, before the United States Commission inquiring into the Northern Securities Company merger at the hearing yesterday. The first of these points was that the formation of a holding company was originally planned some years ago, primarily to retain in block the shares of certain large stockholders in the Great Northern Railroad.

Yesterday was typical of the season. It was a dreadful day, and it snowed, rained, and blew by turns, and sometimes it did all together. It was dull and decorous as a Wednesday in Passion week should be. It was the feast of St. Joseph, a day on which in the Roman Catholic Church, those who are to marry in Lent may obtain a dispensation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among measures pending in the Legislature and which will probably become laws there is an amendment of the lien law introduced by Mr. Harris Wilson, Original No. 85, which interests owners of real estate and institutions and individuals concerned in building and in loaning money on mortgage.

NEW ORLEANS, March 19 -- Kaffir, imp. Albula, and Andes were the winning favorites here to-day. Felix Bard clipped a half second off the track record in the second race. Weather clear; track fast. Summary:

Opposition to the scheme of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company's managers for the raising of new capital by the formation of a securities holding company which, has been developing for the last two weeks, resulted in the granting of a temporary injunction in the Supreme Court yesterday afternoon.
A very simple amendment will bring the Pennsylvania's tunnel bill into harmony with the spirit of the charter and the established policy of the city.

The southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, a plot 90 by 102.2, has been sold by Henry H. Cook to Jeremiah C. Lyons. Mr. Lyons has also bought from Mrs. Maria N. Benedict the plot 35 by 102.2 on the south side of Seventy-ninth Street, 175 feet east of Fifth Avenue, together with an abutting lot on the north side of Seventy-eighth Street, 185 feet east of Fifth Avenue.

There was a special meeting of the Young Men's Bible Class at the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church last night, and it being the first of the meetings to which the women were invited, there were many present to add a touch of color to the scene.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The resolution adopted by to-night's caucus of House Democrats was offered by Representative Randell of Texas and was as follows:

PRINCETON, March 19 -- Sir Henry Irving delivered the third Trask lecture here this afternoon before the entire student body and several hundrd visitors. The subject of his lecture was "The Bacon-Shakespeare Controversy." He took the Shakespearean side of the dispute and lectured in his robes as Doctor of Letters of Cambridge University.

Two fires occurred on the top floor of the Astor House within a few minutes of each other last night, but before there was any chance of the flames spreading firemen were on the scene and had them under control. The second fire caused considerable comment, and a number of the guests of the hotel expressed the opinion that it was suspicious.

Pedestrians in New York City yesterday had a hard time moving about. The wind blew a gale, and men and women in the streets were blown hither and thither. The velocity of the wind was highest at about 9 o'clock in the morning, when seventy-four miles an hour was registered at the Weather Bureau.

Lawrence Delmour and John F. Carroll will contest for the leadership of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District. Mr. Delmour was standing in the Court House yesterday near the revolving chair which is the headquarters of Senator Plunkitt.

Two women and a child were thrown headlong from the platform of a Columbus Avenue electric car yesterday afternoon as it shot around the curve at One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Manhattan Avenue at a rate of speed, which caused it to careen as though it were about to toppic over.

BOSTON, March 19 -- Some weeks ago the representative business men of Boston made a strong appeal to the Administration setting forth the need of action along the lines looking to the encouragement of trade with Canada. Their demand was for the negotiation of a mutually satisfactory treaty of commercial reciprocity.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 19 -- The University Track Athletic Association made public its schedule for this Spring this morning. The only new feature of this year's schedule is the dual meet with Amherst on May 10. The schedule is as follows:

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Mme. Paderewski, wife of Ignace Jan Paderewski, to-day announced that the famous pianist has in preparation a new opera. The music has nearly all been written, and he is now searching Polish writings for a fitting libretto. The opera, Mme. Paderewski says, will be distinctly Slavonic both in music and story.
LONDON, March 19 -- Money was in strong demand to-day, and the prospects of continued scarcity hardened discounts.

A board of officers is appointed to meet at the can of the President thereof at Fort Riley for the examination of such officers as may be ordered before it for examination to determine their fitness for promotion. Detail -- Major Alexander Rodgers, Major Paul Shilllocky, Capt. James B. Erwin, Capt. Granger Adams, First Lieut. Robert N. Winn, Capt. Peyton C. March, Recorder.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Chairman Payne of the Ways and Means Committee to-day introduced in the House the following bill, entitled "To provide for reciprocal trade relations with Cuba," as a result of the Republican conference decision last night:

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations to-day made public the definition of policy with reference to the House of Representatives in connection with the reciprocity treaties, which the committee has agreed upon. The practical effect of this agreement is to authorize the amendment of each of the reciprocity treaties by adding the provision that "this treaty shall not take effect until the same shall have been approved by the Congress."

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Democratic caucus to-night developed two facts -- that the Democratic leadership in the House is still irresolute and nerveless,' and that the advice of William J. Bryan is still potent on party policies.

Two men dead, an unidentified sailor, supposed to be a victim, three more sailors still missing from the crew of the steamship British Queen, seven persons more or less seriously injured, and a property loss conservatively estimated at $800,000 are the results of the disastrous fire on the Hoboken water front Tuesday night.
CAPE TOWN, March 20 -- A bulletin issued at midnight said that the Right Hon. Cecil Rhodes had taken nourishment; that he was slightly stronger, and that he was sleeping.

Those who pay attention to such matters are aware that no municipal institution was more completely Tammanyized under the late administration than the New York Aquarium. When the immigrant depot was removed from Castle Garden, everybody agreed that it was a happy thought to convert its site into a resort for pleasure and instruction, which should also come to have a high scientific value.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Senator Mor- gan, from the Committee on Isthmian Canals, to-day presented to the Senate the majority and minority reports on the question of the validity of the title of the new Panama Canal Company and its right to transfer the Panama Canal property to the United States for $40,000,000.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March. 19 -- A big deal in horseflesh was consummated here today when J.W. Schorr of Memphis and J.J. McCafferty of New York purchased of J.N. Camden the Hartland Stud, in Woodford County, comprising thirty-one head of yearling throughbreds, for $20 000. Sixteen are by Imported Esher, twelve by Handsome, and the rest by well-known stallions.

August Belmont, with the counsel of the Rapid Transit Subway Construction Company, is expected to appear to-morrow morning before Mayor Low in opposition to the Pennsylvania Railroad Tunnel bill at the hearing set for that measure. It is also considered likely that the Rapid Transit Commission may appear in opposition to this measure, the argument against it probably being made by Edward M. Shepard.

After the unusual activity of Tuesday, the outside market yesterday assumed a quieter aspect and in most issues trading was relatively small. The bonds of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company were again very largely dealt in, but elsewhere in the list the falling off in activity was marked.

In the tournament of the New York Inter-Club Bowling League on the New York Athletic Club Alleys last night, the home team won two of three matches from the West Side Republican Club. In the Metropolitan championship series the Metropolitan team won two of three games from the Manhattan five.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 19 -- A scandal was developed here to-day over the Brooklyn Magistrates bill. The bill appeared on the Senate files to-day, amended in several important particulars. The amendments had not been agreed to by the Senate, and Senator Stranahan denied that the Cities Committee was responsible for or had any knowledge of them.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The Assembly today passed a bill introduced by Mr. Keenan to amend the Greater New York charter so as to permit of the payment by installments of assessments for street improvements. The bill was opposed by Assemblymen Davis and Newcomb, but so successfully was defended by Assemblymen Keenan, Dooling, Grady, and Wainwright that Messrs, Davis and Newcomb finally abandoned their opposition, and the bill was passed without an objecting vote.
For the relief of F.E. Coyne. Postmaster of Chicago. The purpose of the measure is to relieve Postmaster Coyne from the loss of $74,610, the value of stamps stolen by burglars on Oct. 19, 1901.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Attorneys representing the Kansas City and Chicago Railroads and W.A. Day, representing the Federal Government, will hold a conference here to-morrow or Friday regarding certain phases of the proposed litigation to secure observance of the provisions of the Inter-State Commerce act.

Papers in the separation suit brought by Mrs. Nina Larre Smith Duryea against her husband, Chester Burnell Duryea, son of Gen. Hiram Duryea, who organised the Starch Trust were filed in the Supreme Court yesterday in connection with a motion made before Justice Gildersleeve by counsel for the plaintiff applying for the issuance of a commission to take the testimony of Mrs. Wetherspoon-Asser, a witness who is now living at Cairo, Egypt.
PATERSON, N.J., March 19 -- A boy was killed, his mother injured, and fifty or sixty persons narrowly escaped death in a trolley accident this evening.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The New York delegation in the House of Representatives received a severe jar to-day from Representative Burton of Ohio, Chairman of the Committee on Rivers and Harbors. After Mr. Burton got through with it, New Yorkers in the galleries were wondering how much attention the New York delegation pays to local measures, and to the interests of its constituents.
The Daily Saratogian (N.Y.) recently published an article, which said:

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 -- The local market to-night had a languid and heavy tone, declines being registered in Electric Storage Battery preferred, Consolidated Lake Superior, Pennsylvania Steel preferred, Warwick Iron and Steel, Philadelphia Company, Philadelphia Electric, Electric Company of America, Union Traction, Lehigh Valley, and the Readings.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., March 20. -- At today's session of the convention of Districts Nos. 1,7, and 9, United Mine Workers of America, several resolutions were adopted as the result of various alleged grievances which were announced in the convention by the different delegations, and were presented by the Committee on Resolutions.

NEW ORLEANS, March 20. -- Chorus Boy, Death, and Sam Lazarus were the winning favorites to-day. Death had the Flight Stakes at his mercy, leading from start to finish and winning very cleverly by a length. Weather clear; track fast. Summary:
Details will be found in another column relative to the purchase of the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-second Street by the New York Realty Corporation.

A Lenten quiet pervades society. The few entertainments which are on the tapis sire Lenten in character. Last evening saw the conclusion of nearly all the meetings of the different Lenten clubs, except the ones devoted to Ping Pong and Badminton. There are several of these which hold meetings this evening.

There was a meeting last night of the New York Academy of Medicine, 17 West Forty-third Street, where former paralytics walked about in perfect ease, miracles in the art of surgery. There was no talk of absent treatment or any other treatment which does not require the knife. After the doctors had exhibited the results of their surgical skill, they unanimously adopted the following resolutions, which were presented by Dr. J. D. Bryant:

BOSTON, Mass., March 20. -- Money continues firm; Clearing House rate, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 12 1/2, and 10 cents discount and par; call loans, 4@4 1/2; time money, 4 1/2@5; Clearing House exchanges, $21,684,980; balances, $2,200,677. The copper stocks were active and generally higher to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Ambassador Choate has transmitted to the State Department a copy of a circular sent to the United States Embassy by the Chief Secretary to the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland relative to a proposed rowing race for eight-oared shells at Cork in connection with the exhibition which will be held in that city in July.

LONDON, March 21. -- Arriving at Klerksdorp (Western Transvaal) after several weeks' trekking in the Eastern Transvaal, says a correspondent of The Times, one is struck by the different aspect of affairs in various centres of the military operations.

TACOMA, Washington, March 20. -- State Grain Inspector Wright has received news from Palouse grain district to the effect that 300,000 acres Fall sown wheat have been frozen in the region north of Snake River. The extent of the damage done by Winter freezes in this region was not known conclusively until this week, when Spring thaws demonstrated it.
A. -- Only the brave deserve the fair. B. -- No one else can live with them.

ALBANY, March 20. -- The Park Avenue tunnel bills were passed by the Assembly to-day. The first bill taken up was the Apgar bill, which fixes May 1, 1905, as the date on which the use of steam in the tunnel shall cease, but provides for extensions by the Railroad Commission upon reasonable grounds.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- It was the liveliest day the Philadelphia market has experienced for a month, and a wider range of securities was dealt in than for many weeks, but it was all at the expense of prices. Union Traction was an exception, with a fractional advance based on today's favorable action in councils on the subway ordinance.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Your thoughtful readers cannot but recognize that at this critical period in the history of the Democratic Party the support accorded by your paper to the Republican policy of imperialism is a very serious hindrance to the formation and union of a successful Democratic platform for the next election.

The New York Realty Corporation has bought from Stewart H. Chisholm the plot of five lots at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-second Street, 125 feet on the avenue by 100 feet on the street. This property is directly opposite the Vanderbilt mansions, adjoins the new Union Clubhouse, and with the possible exceptions of the corresponding corners at Thirty-seventh and Forty-fourth Streets is the most valuable parcel of unimproved realty on Fifth Avenue.

A protracted meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission was held at its offices, 320 Broadway, yesterday afternoon, at which it was determined that the counsel to the commission, Messrs. Edward M. Shepard and Albert B. Boardman, together with its President, Alexander E. Orr, shall appear this morning before Mayor Low at the hearing on the Pennsylvania Tunnel bill.

Assignments to regiments of officers recently promoted: Major Charles W. Taylor, to the Thirteenth Cavalry, vice Ellis, deceased: Capt. John B. Christian, to the Ninth Cavalry, Troop C, vice Taylor, promoted.

PARIS, March 20. -- M. Santos-Dumont, in an interview here to-night, appeared very enthusiastic concerning his approaching trip to the United States, whither he will go on his own initiative. M. Santos-Dumont said:

NEWPORT, R.I., March 20. -- An arrangement has been made between W.S. Wells and August Belmont which will give Mr. Wells the ownership of the entire square between Bellevue and Congress Hall Avenues on the east and west, and Ruggles ana Victoria Avenues on the south and north.

The final indoor games of the season of the Williamsburg Athletic Club were held in the clubhouse, Withers Street, Brooklyn, last night and resulted in T. Anderson winning the indoor championship of the club for the season with a total of 133 points. He received a gold medal. F. Birmingham, who was second with 83 points, received the silver medal, and N.J. Bickard, who was third with 64 points, received the bronze medal.

ALBANY, March 20. -- The bill sent to Albany by the Corporation Counsel with Mayor Low's approval, granting to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment of Greater New York the right to fix salaries, was passed in the Senate to-day by a vote of 34 to 15. The bill was severely attacked.

In the tournament of the New York Stock Exchange Bowling League last night the team of Clark, Dodge Co. won two games, Charles Head Co. won one game and lost one, and Cooper, Cramp Beadleston lost two games. The scheduled games in the Interclub League were postponed on account of the death of President Sullivan of the Catholic Club.
We do not think that the officials who support the bill granting special and perpetual privileges to the Pennsylvania Railroad state quite fairly the objections made to it.
A meeting of the stewards of The Jockey Club was held yesterday afternoon, August Belmont, J.H. Bradford, F.R. Hitchcock, H.K. Knapp, and F.K. Sturgis being present.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Mrs. Richardson Clover, wife of Commander Clover, now Naval Attache at the Court of St. James, sails Wednesday to join her husband in London after spending the Winter at their home, on New Hampshire Avenue. To-day she gave a luncheon to the hostesses who had entertained her in the last two months.

We should suppose the incident which enlivened yesterday's debate of the House of Commons would be read with some satisfaction by members of the Senate of the United States. Almost all our own traditions of parliamentary language and parliamentary usage, as well as the very adjective itself, were imported from England.
That the Democrats in Congress should hesitate to resort to extreme tactics in regard to the Republican policy toward the South is neither surprising nor blameworthy.
LONDON, March 20. -- Money and discount rates were firm to-day.
LONDON, March 21. -- The Times announces that recent excavations at Knossos, in Crete, have brought to light a further important room in the buried palace, (supposed to have been that of King Minos.)

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The printed report of the testimony of Secretary Root before the Senate Military Committee on the bill providing for a general staff was made public to-day. In his statement the Secretary said that the general staff of the army, as it is proposed to organize it under this bill, would be simply an advisory board and that its principal duty would be that of an advisory board.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- There is no doubt whatever that the South has had quite enough of Mr. Bryan's leadership. Whoever talks with Southern Democrats in Congress as to the future of the Democracy quickly discovers that when they speak for their section they disclose the prevalence there of a desire that the Democratic Party shall get back into the realm of practical politics, forgetting the follies and vagaries of the past six years.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Senator Aidrich, from the Committee on Finance, today presented to the Senate the report of that committee on the bill repealing the war revenue act, and thus made public for the first time the amendments to the bill suggested by the committee. There are many changes in the language of the bill, but except in one instance the intention of the House bill of repealing the entire act is respected.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Gen. Nelson A. Miles to-day told the Senate Committee on Military Affairs that, if the bill introduced by Senator Hawley at the instance of the War Department for the organization of a general staff for the army should become a law, he would decline to longer hold his commission.
LONDON, March 21. -- One of the liveliest scenes witnessed in the House of Commons since the palmiest days of the Irish Nationalists ended yesterday afternoon with the suspension of John Dillon.
More than 1,200 pictures have been submitted to the jury of the Society of American Artists, although only one of four can find place on the walls of the galleries.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 20. -- Grave charges against the Chinese Consul General here, Ho-Yow, and designed also to inculpate Minister Wu Ting-Fang, all under the seal of the Six Companies, are on file in the Foreign Office in Peking, said The Chronicle this morning. When interviewed in regard to the matter Ho-Yow said:

The Purim Association Charity Ball, in aid of the United Hebrew Charities, was held in the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The affair was in every respect a success, and about $15,000 was realized.

Very irritating is it, when one proposes to take again some favorite drive in the country through a particularly pleasing road, where the wayside trees constitute more than half the attraction of the scene, to find the best part of the route as bare of trees and shrubs as the back of that island on which Sindbad the Sailor was unwary enough to build a fire.

ALBANY, March 20. -- Canal legislation received what is generally believed to be a knock-out blow in the Assembly to-day. The Assembly voted against the proposition to amend the Weekes bill so as to make it conform to the Davis bill, and then defeated the bill. When the Assembly convened to-day the canal men had decided upon a plan of action.

We were not able at the time to justify the tone and manner of the Secretary of War's reprimand to an officer of Gen. MILES'S long experience and brilliant services, even for the indiscretion which the General had committed in publicly expressing opinions upon the proceedings of a naval court of inquiry.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Gen. Otis today resumed his testimony before the Senate Philippine Committee. Senator Patterson continued his questioning and referred to a letter dated Sept. 8, 1898, addressed by Gen. Otis to Aguinaldo as "the commanding General of the Philippine forces," in which he spoke of the sacrifices made by the revolutionary forces "in the interest of civil liberty."

The United States Life Insurance Company, of which Dr. John P. Munn has just been elected President, has decided to discontinue soliciting new business in the States of Georgia and Alabama, and an announcement to that effect has been issued by the company's Atlanta Manager, W.E. Hawkins.

With an overwhelming majority vote the stockholders of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, at a meeting held yesterday for this purpose, ratified the lease of the company's system to the Interurban Street Railway Company and authorized the issue of a $65,000,000 mortgage on the property of the company.

Fire, the origin of which could not be ascertained, started in the three-story annex of the piano factory of Hardman, Peck Co., 633 West Forty-eighth Street, shortly after 6 o'clock last night, and burned for quite a while before the flames were seen by some of the neighbors and the alarm given.
ALBANY, March 20. -- The Assembly Rules Committee to-night reported favorably the bill creating the office of Fiscal Supervisor of the Finances and the various State charitable institutions.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was brisker than on Wednesday, and there were several sharp advances in quotations. Colorado Fuel bonds again attracted much attention, and closed with a substantial net gain. Interest was also taken in the trading in Bay State Gas, which for many months has shown little or no life.

LONDON, March 21. -- The debate in the House of Commons yesterday, which reached the climax of interest when John Dillon, having called the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain "a damned liar," and, having been requested by the Speaker to withdraw, did so amid the boisterous cheers of some of his Irish associates, was one of the fiercest and angriest of the present session.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
It was an eventful night for the east side members of the Boys' Clubhouse at Tenth Street and Avenue A. last night.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Throughout to-day's session of the Senate the bill providing for the protection of the President was under discussion. Just before adjournment an agreement was reached to vote on the measure and pending amendments at 4 o'clock to-morrow. Three substitutes for the bill are pending, and will be pressed when the voting begins to-morrow.
W.F. Allen, President of the Manhattan Fire Alarm Company, made a reply yesterday to the statement of Fire Commissioner Sturgis as to his reasons for revoking the company's license. He said in part:

BANGOR, Me., March 20. -- Bangor suffered to-night the greatest disaster by flood since the city was inundated in the great freshet of 1846. Great damage has already been done, and vastly greater damage is threatened. Ever since last December, when the river closed, there have been fears of trouble this Spring when the ice began to move, and to a large extent these fears have been realized.

Mayor Low has removed Patrick H. Quinn, Deputy Commissioner of Street Cleaning in Brooklyn. The removal caused the circulation of rumors that there was trouble between Commissioner Woodbury and the Mayor. Major Woodbury smiled when seen yesterday and when asked about the rumors said:

BOSTON, March 20. -- Mrs. Julia B. French, a widow well known of late by reason of the extent of her litigations, was found dead this afternoon in the house on Newbury Street where she lived alone. There is every reason to believe that she died at least a week ago by falling down the elevator well.

TRENTON, N.J., March 20. -- The Senate this morning had two long discussions, one on the bill annexing North Plainfield, in Somerset County, to Plainfield, in Union County, and the other providing for a single-headed Street and Water Commission in Jersey City and Newark. Both bills have a referendum clause attached and both were passed.

LONDON, March 21. -- Ogden's, (Limited,) as the representatives of the American Tobacco Company, yesterday gave notice of their intention to give their entire net profits and u200,000 yearly for the next four years as a bonus to their customers.
BALTIMORE, Md., March 20. -- Money on call was 4@4 1/2 per cent. Complete transactions for the day, amounting to 5,898 shares of stock and $245,000 worth of bonds, were as follows:

The Consolidated Railway Lighting and Refrigerating Company held its annual meeting yesterday in Jersey City. Considerable interest attached to this meeting, as it was expected that it would settle the contest for control of the company, which has been going on for some time, through the efforts of F.C. Hollins, the broker and banker, to oust Isaac L. Rice from the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The Department of Agriculture will immediately prepare a list of articles imported into this country in which boracic and other acids are supposed to exist. This action is the first step taken by the Government looking to retaliation for the German prohibition on the importation of meats containing boracic acid.

In volume of business there is little Stock Exchange variation from day to day, and the continuing characteristic of the current market is liveliness in specialties and dullness in standard issues. Some of the kiting favorites are making exceptional records, and alert traders on the board are able to make quick and profitable turns by skipping around from pool to pool.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, March 20. -- The Venezuelan revolution, headed by Gen. Matos, seems to be taking form. Eight hundred revolutionists, under Gen. Penalozo, are besieging Carupano, (a seaport town in the State of Bermudez,) and the Revolutionists under Gen. Monagas have surrendered Barcelona, (the capital of the State of Bermudez.)

-- General regret will be created by the news from Manila that the counsel for Major WALLER, instead of promptly meeting the terrible charges on which that officer had been brought to trial, saw fit to delay the settlement of the case by raising a technical point -- the question of jurisdiction.
LONDON, March 21. -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Times says that the treaty revision negotiations, which were suspended on account of the illness of Sheng, have been resumed.

Frank Campbell, thirty years old, a produce dealer, who lived in the Glenwood Hotel, Williamsburg, was instantly killed last night in sight of many persons by an electric light wire, which had fallen at Berry and North Thirteenth Streets, while several men who went to his assistance nearly met with the same fate.
"The Kindred of the Wild: A Book of Animal Life," by Prof. Charles G.D. Roberts, is to be brought out in May by L.C. Pape Co. These publishers have now control of Prof. Roberts's entire works:

An exhibition of books, manuscripts, c., relating to the Germans in the United States was opened for public view by the New York Public Library at the Lenox Building, Fifth Avenue and Seventieth Street, on Monday, March 17. Ono of the most interesting items of the exhibition was the first German Bible printed in America, at Germantown. by Christopher Sauer, in 1743.

TLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 18 -- The sixth annual meeting of the Pennsylvania Library Club and New Jersey Library Association closed its sessions here on Saturday. The atendence was large, arid the meetings were marked by interesting discussions of topics in library work of pressing interest to all librarians.

Before the great spite strike, miscalled sympathetic, which for seven days paralyzed the commercial activities of New England, is forgotten in the more absorbing interest of later news, its lesson may be studied with advantage by organized labor. That it was a failure need occasion no surprise.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 21. -- Gov. Gen. Leonard Wood of Cuba passed through Savannah this afternoon en route to Washington, where he is to see President Roosevelt and Estrada Palma to-morrow. He said of Cuban affairs to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES to-day:

In a valedictory address at Newton Hall, London, the other evening, Mr. Frederic Harrison, who in spite of his more than three score and ten years, we are not yet ready to call venerable, made a very quiet and unostentatious withdrawal from public life and from active lead in the English Positivist Society.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- John P. Altgeld will have a monument built to his memory in Chicago. Admirers of the dead statesman have already taken up the plans. Even before committees have been formed contributions have come in.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The War Revenue Reduction bill passed the Senate to-day in an informal sort of fashion, without a division or a yea and nay vote. It has already passed the House and is about to become a law. It passed the Senate in an interval between the talk and the vote on the Bill for the Protection of the President.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 21. -- Now York exchange was quoted to-day at 5@100 premium. Time and call loans, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent, Local stocks were a little more irregular to-day. What looked like a profittaking movement in Biscuit common sent the price of that stock off to 50 1/2 but around that figure considerable buying took place.

ALBANY, March 21. -- There has been much mystery about the provision of the so-called Bedell Park Avenue Tunnel Condemnation bill, which permits any railroad company having a terminal in the City of New York, or any city of the first class, to secure rights and easements "under or over any waters, river, lands, streets, avenues, parkways, highways, or public places."

On March 10-12 Bangs Co. sold the first part of the library of the late Isaac Dayton of this city. The collection included the best editions of the standard authors, all finely bound and in remarkable condition. The character of the library is illustrated by Lot 817. a collection of Jesse's historical works, " Reign of the Stuarts," 1840; " Memoirs of the Court of England," 1843;

LONDON, March 12 -- They say Lord Dufferin was at work, just before his last illness, on a selection of poems and passages in famous poems relating to his ancestors and their historic dwellings. Byron, Browning, and Tennyson were all to be represented in the volume, which was to have been printed. in a limited edition for private circulation.

Never has the excellence of the format and the typographical excellence as well as the extreme cheapness of the Mosher books been more apparent than in this issue of the Vest Pocket Series, in three styles -- limp cloth, flexible leather, and Japan vellum.

LONDON, March 21. -- The demand for money continued strong to-day, and was enhanced by upward of u1,000,000 in calls falling due. Money is likely to be in keener request next week, in connection with the settlement, the holidays, and the month end. Discounts hardened to-day.

It was to be expected that Russia and France would take some notice of the Anglo-Japanese agreement. That agreement amounts to an undertaking to preserve the integrity of China and keep the door open to foreign trade on equal terms in all parts of the empire. It includes an agreement to resist the partition of the empire by force whenever, in the judgment of both contracting parties, that course may be necessary.

The arrest at an early hour yesterday of Edward J. Parley, an elevator attendant at the Astor House, has resulted in a confession explaining the recent mysterious fires in that hotel and in other places in the city where Farley either lived or was employed. There is declared to be good reason for believing that Farley started sixteen fires, one of them in Saratoga, and that he is a pyromaniac.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 21. -- The G.B. S. Brewing issues continue to hold the leadership in trading which they secured two days ago. The business outlook for the concern, reinforced by the persistent belief that the brewing interests all over the country will profit by Congressional action, continues to stimulate confident absorption ou the issues, the opinion being expressed that the whole group is destined to reach a much better level.
Two games were completed yesterday in the world's championship pool tournament now in progress in the Montauk Billiard Academy. Brooklyn.

While observance of Lent and especially Holy Week, has been growing in non-Iiturgical churches for several years, it has never been so marked as this season. Presbyterian. Congregational. Reformed, and other churches, with but few exceptions, have been holding series of Lenten lectures in the past month.

ALBANY, March 21. -- The bill introduced by Senator Mills proposing an amendment to Article VI. of the Constitution relating to Supreme Court Judicial Districts passed the Assembly to-day by a strict party vote. Minority Leader Palmer characterized the bill as "an attempt to Republicanize the Judiciary."

The rebellion in the three southern coast provinces of China is spreading with a rapidity that makes it a serious matter for the Viceroys and other officials immediately concerned. The desertion of considerable bodies of imperialist troops to the rebels is an incident characteristic of Chinese warfare.

Miles Amber's book reads as if he had known the persons who serve as his characters. Why he should have chosen that particular set of characters in order to lay before the world his question "Why does fate treat us so?" is not altogether clear. Every one of his characters is queer. There is nothing strange in the fact that such an extraordinary combination of personalities should inspire fate to inexplicable actions.

ALBANY, March 21. -- Lieut. Gov. Woodruff has decided to abandon the Brooklyn Magistrates' bill. It will be allowed to remain in the Senate Cities Committee. Lieut. Gov. Woodruffs explanation for the abandonment of the measure is that the bill would cause too many complications.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 21. -- Edward M. Shepard of New York spoke tonight before the Friday Evening Club of this city on "Politics in Municipal Affairs." He took the ground that two great parties were very needful in National affairs, and said that in municipal elections nineteen out of twenty voters divided along the prime lines.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 21. -- In the Philadelphia market stocks that were notably weak yesterday were somewhat remarkable for their strength to-day, Consolidated Lake Superior and Electric Storage Battery showing the greatest strength. The first named preferred, which sold at 71 last night, rallied with little effort to 73, and the common advanced to 22 3/8, both closing at these figures.

Business on the Stock Exchange is becoming well distributed. Yesterday's total of 635,000 shares was distributed over a list of 160 issues. The market was firm. Relatively few quotations changed as much as a whole point; yet there were some instances where advances of a sensational sort took place.
The annual report of the Providence Public Library for the year 1901, recently presented to the Trustees, shows a circulation of 120,604 as compared with 106,452 in 1900.

The Rosegger Society. That " A prophet is not without honor save in his own country " has failed to prove true in the case of Peter Rosegger, the novelist, poet, and story teller of the Styrian Alps, two of whose works in English version.

Col. Partridge, Commissioner of Police, yesterday summoned Inspector Adam Cross and the seven Captains of the First Inspection District to confer with him as to the best method to pursue in reducing the number of plain clothes men in their precincts. The Commissioner announced that conferences with all the Captains in every inspection district in the city would also be held.

" The Story of Old Saratoga " is by no means a local history in the accepted sense. Although the career of that place on the Hudson, prior and subsequent to the climax of Burgnyne's campaign is carefully dealt with in fact, legend, and tradition, yet Saratoga in the light of National history occupies the major portion of the book, and for this reason;

LONDON, March 22. -- The Saturday Review, continuing its anti-American campaign, to-day publishes a long communication from Alfred Stead, son of William T. Stead, the editor, picturing the alleged deplorable condition of Hawaii as a result of annexation to the United States.

The Ottawa Hockey Club seven defeated the Hockey Club of New York team in a spirited game of hockey at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink last night by a score of 4 to 3 The Canadians played hard, clean hockey during the entire contest, and won the game on its merits, although seemingly outplayed in the first half by the New York players, who succeeded in penetrating the Canadians' defense three times.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I have been reading what you have had to say on the subject of poets and poetry, and I have read also what some of your correspondents have said, and still I have my doubts about poets and poetry, and particularly those who put upon them the stamp of acceptation as poets and poetry -- the editors.

Second Lieutenants recently appointed are as signed to regiments as follows: George W. Biegier. Seventh Cavalry; Edgar Nicoffer, Twelfth Cavalry; Walter C. Short. Twenty-fifth Infancy; John D. Shuman, Twenty-eight Infantry; James W. Everlngton, Third intantry.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21. -- The fourth annual championship meeting of the intercollegiate association of amateur gymnasts of America was held in the Academy of Music to-night in the presence of a fashionable crowd. The best exhibitions were given by Yale, Princeton, Columbia, Haverford, and Pennsylvania men.

It cannot be denied that John Ruskin said a great many foolish things, but it must be admitted that he also projected into the world some wise thoughts. These were generally uttered when he was talking about books, art, or culture in general, for then he was on ground with which he was acquainted.

The current number of The Independent contains an interesting article by the Hon. JOHN CHARLTON, member of the Dominion Parliament and of the Joint High Commission appointed to consider the various points of difference between the Government of the Dominion and of the United States.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: A recent article on "Extra-Illustrated Books," and the letter it called out from John Anderson, Jr., in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of March 1 stirred pleasant memories of the days when I was a "Grangerite," (book butcher, some said, who afterward fell from their high estate of assumed grace.) I think, however, that both statements need some qualification.

George R. Read has sold for the Eagle Fire Company its building at the junction of Wall, Pearl, and Beaver Streets, a seven Story Structure on an irregular plot having frontages of 70.4 feet on Wall Street, 225 feet on Pearl Street, and 61.6 feet on Beaver Street. It is said that the buyer is an investor, who will make no changes in the property at least for the present.

ALBANY, March 21. -- Assemblyman Weekes's bill authorizing Police Commissioner Partridge to reinstate Policeman Edward O'Neill, the patrolman who was dismissed by Devery for disobedience of orders and general insubordination, was passed by the Assemebly to-day by a vote of 89 to 32.

After nine weeks devoted to obtaining a jury and to the taking of testimony, Prosecution and defense in the trial of Albert T. Patrick, charged with murdering William Marsh Rice, rested their respective cases at 12:15 o'clock yesterday. The case will go to the jury on Wednesday.

TONAWANDA, N.Y., March 21. -- J.B. Post, a farmer, thirty-five years old, living four miles south of this village, bound his wife, Amanda Post, to a stake in the bull pen of his stable this morning. She wore a red calico apron, which drove a confined bull to frenzy, and in its rage it attacked the woman and gored her to death.

In his amusing and often o-difying occupation of looking into the seeds of time to tell what grains will prosper, Mr. Wells has discovered that "the narrative form becomes more and more of a nuisance as the speculative inductions become sincerer," and has accordingly abandoned it "in favor of a texture of frank inquiries and arranged considerations.

Mr. Hornung has been an industrious writer of books for quite a good many years. He has often used Australia for the scene of his plots. He has recounted the doings of bushrangers and reveled in details more or less sanguinary. But he did not confine himself to highway robbery alone.

Commissioner J. Hampstead Dougherty of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, has adopted drastic measures to force companies having wires strung across the tops of tall buildings to transfer their conduits to underground ducts prepared for the purpose. A squad of employes of the department started out day before yesterday morning to cut down the wires in the district bounded by Battery Place, Canal Street, Broadway and Greenwich Street.

It is nine years since the world was on the qui vive to know the full story of one of the most remarkable journeys ever made. When "Pioneering in Tibet" appeared it became manifest that Miss Taylor was a better traveler than bookmaker, and the public in disappointment turned away and very nearly forgot the very fact of the journey.

"A Garden in the Suburbs" is a pleasant little book, treating of the possibilities of amateur gardening in England. It is necessarily somewhat narrow in scope, and will appeal chiefly to a limited circle -- those whose limited means and limited acreage cannot curb their ambitions and interest in horticulture.

BERLIN, March 21. -- Prince Henry of Prussia has sent a telegram to Secretary Jackson, as Charge d'Affaires here in the absence of Andrew D. White, the United States Ambassador, in which the Prince says:

One thing was made perfectly plain yesterday in the hearing before the Mayor regarding the plans of the Pennsylvania Railroad: that is, that there is no opposition to the general purpose of the company and no desire to impede or embarrass it, but only a very earnest desire that the permanent interests of the city shall be clearly and properly guarded.

Tudor Jenks. Tudor Jenks has made a success with his latest book, "The Talking Pony." It belongs, by the way, to one of the most profitable Kinds of literature a man can engage in at the present time -- literature for children. Parents have never been more watchful about the stories their children road, and they welcome a writer who can appeal to youngsters in the wholesome and humorous style characteristic of Tudor Jenks.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The House to-day passed the River and Harbor bill, which has been under consideration throughout the week. Although several minor amendments were adopted, not a single dollar was added to the measure, and, as passed, it carried exactly what it did when it came from the committee -- $60,688,267, including authorizations.

BOSTON, Mass., March 21. -- Money rates are hardening. Clearing House rate, 3 per cent. New York funds, par, 15, 7 1/2, and 10 cents discount. Call loans, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Time money, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Clearing House exchanges, $23,842,974 balances. $2,591,918. The stock market was entirely professional.
Mayor Low gave out a statement yesterday, which was headed, "The So-Called Sweep Bills." It is as follows:

Justice Gildersleeve, sitting in Special Term, Part I., of the Supreme Court, listened for five hours yesterday afternoon and evening to arguments of counsel representing those who oppose and those who support the lease of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company to the Interurban Street Railway Company.

Clerks from the law office of Lamb Guernsey had a lively time yesterday trying to find J. Pierpont Morgan and serve upon him a subpoena to appear before the commission which is taking evidence in the suit brought by Peter Power against the Northern Securities Company, and it was not until 0:15 o'clock last night that one of them finally succeeded.

LONDON, March 21 -- Oxford won the animal Oxford-Cambridge field sports today at the Queen's Club, her athletes capturing five of the nine events. Coe, an American boy attending Oxford, won both the shot-put and hammer-throwing events, He sails for home on the American liner St. Paul to-morrow.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I wish to reply to where Prof. Bourne, in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS says that Dr. Marcus Whitman and Secretary of War John C. Spencer could not have been schoolmates, as Spencer was graduated when Whitman was but four years old.

WASINGTON, March 21. -- The new Colombian Minister, Mr. Concha, has about completed the proposition his Government is to make to the United States in respect to the building of the Panama Canal. The protocol may be forwarded to the State Department to-morrow, but more likely it will not reach Secretary Hay until early next week.

Of course, the wives and families of policemen would prefer to have those public servants take their meals at home and stay at home of nights like other people. They are entitled, the wives and families, to a certain measure of sympathy. But they are not at all entitled to have their wishes consulted at the expense of the very public interests which policemen are appointed and paid to protect.

DUBLIN, March 21. -- At a meeting of the tobacco trade here to-day it was unanimously resolved that the Dublin Tobacconists' Association would have nothing to do with the Imperial Tobacco Company, and that the association would permit freedom of action with regard to the circular issued by Ogden's Limited.

The New York Times Saturday Reeicu of Books: The casual occurrence of the name "Cutty Hunk" in a review of a little book. "The Riddle of Life," by J.
