Wesley Johnston in your paper, recalls to me the fact that there is a real island of that name, on which 300 years ago this coming May 21 the first attempt at setilement by whitemen within the limits of New England was made.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 21 - The University baseball team had its first real out-door practice this afternoon on a grass diamond that has been marked out in a corner of the Varsity field until the regular diamond is in shape. A six-inning game was played between the first and second nines, the former winning by a score of 6 to 3.

IN a big octavo volume, paralleling in essay and controversial form the latter part of Prof. Goldwin Smith's purely historic presentation of the subject, Mr. Bernard Holland, an English student new to the rank of authorship, but a fully qualified recruit, as his matter and manner attest, gives us a strong, thoughtful, and well-sustained consideration of the trend of colonial policy, with a weak conclusion.

SARATOGA, N.Y., March 21. -- The confession of the Astor House elevator attendant, Edward J. Farley, that he committed incendiary acts at the Astor House. New York City, and that a fire occurred in the Grand Union Hotel, Saratoga Springs, while he was in the house, is not confirmed here, so far as the latter hotel is concerned.

Over certain topics in the literary field, as well as elsewhere, a perpetual ''storm-centre" is wont to hover. We think the clouds have moved from there sometimes, and that the sky is once more clear and tranquil; but it is not for long, for new forces soon arrive to conduct the surely recurring fray.

From The London Mail The viee of drug-taking which has taken so firm a hold on the lives of society men and women is developing to such an extent and in such curious directions that it threatens to become a serious and all-pervading evil.

On the floor of the Stock Exchange was posted yesterday an amended and revised constitution, which has been adopted by the Governing Committee for submission to the members. Under the rules, members of the Exchange have one week within which to file all objections, and if at the end of the week a majority has not filed objections, the constitution stands adopted.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 21. -- The Surrogate of Dutchess County has decided that a deed of gift is subject to the collateral inheritance tax where it is marie in contemplation of the death of the grantor and is not intended to take effect until or after his death. The decision is in connection with the death of Charles Miller, the late owner of the Phoenix Horseshoe Works of Poughkeepsie and Joliet, Ill.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The Countess Marguerite Cassini the adopted daughter of the Russian Ambassador, to-night gave a dinner of twenty covers, which was followed by a reception to nearly 100 additional guests. The feature of the entertainment was that each guest adopted a style of headdress of at least 100 years ago, while the costume in most cases was of the twentieth century.

A burglar who has not yet been Identified, but who save the name of James Wilson, was shot and killed by Samuel Hague, Jr.. at 41 Glenwood Avenue, Jersey City, shortly after 1 o'clock A.M. yesterday. The house is occupied by Jeremiah Vanderbeck, with whose family Hague boards. The house is equipped with a burglar alarm.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- At the Cabinet meeting to-day the publications relating to the statements made by Gen. Miles before the Senate Committee yesterday were brought up, but consideration of them was postponed until all the facts in the matter become known.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- It is by no means certain that the House will have a chance at the Crumpacker resolution, which virtually provides for inquiry whether the South, having restricted suffrage, is not overrepresented in the House. Strong Republican opposition to the resolution is developed. It is not held that the South should not have her representation in the House cut down, but objection is made to what is regarded as a mere agitation.

A special Census Bulletin by ARTHUR L. HUNT, summarizing the statistics of the gas industry of the United States, contains some interesting tables which throw an instructive side light upon the net results of the reorganization work of the past few years, which constitutes what is popularly known as "Gas Finance."

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Prof. Bourne's criticism is mainly based upon an error in Mr. Clarke's letter as to the name of the Secretary of War in 1843, the time of Whitman's visit to Washington. Mr. Clarke said that Whitman was introduced to President Tyler by "his friend and schoolmate, John C. Spencer, Secretary of War."

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: For many years I have been a member of the New York Library Club, and have been present at, I think, all of its public dinners. I desire to thank you for the generous notice given in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of March 15 of the event at the Aldine Club on March 13.

Alterations at Burus's Cottage. An important a alteration has been made in the range of building's at Alluway which have for nearly a century boon known as Burns's cottage. For some years a alteration and rearrangement at the poet's birthplace have been going on and the result has been very material changes on the interior as well as on one the exterior of the buildings, and in the outward aspect of their surroundings.

BOSTON, March 20. -- Miss Mary Devereux, the author of "Up and Down the Sands of Gold," has written another novel which Messrs. Little, Brown Co. will issue in the Autumn. She is spending the Winter in Boston, but her home is no longer in Marblehead, the scene of her first novel, but in Cleveland, Ohio.

ALBANY, March 21. -- The Canal bill was finally interred to-day, Gov. Odell speaking the last sad words over its grave. The Governor placed the responsibility for the death of the bill on members of the Brooklyn delegation who either voted against the amendment offered by Mr. Weekes to make his bill conform to the Davis bill or else staid out of the chamber and were not recorded.

MADAME DE MOTTEVILLE'S Memoirs in three large, wellprinted volumes, attractively bound in red buckram, with paper labels, having for their solo ornament the, arms of the subject of the memoir, impressed on their sides, will be found to contain a long and minutely written chronicle of the doings of Anne of Austria and her Court.

A Rossetti exhibition is being held in the Print Galleries of the New York Public Library, Lenox Building Firth Avenue and Seventieth Street. It consists chiefly of nearly 200 photographs of paintings and studies by the painter-poet Dante Gabriel Rossetti. Many of these pictures came from the collection of the artist's brother. William M. Rossetti, and bear his signature.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21. -- The Authors' Club, at a second meeting held at the Art Club a few nights ago, has decided to be known as the Franklin Gun Club. The close race between that title and the Franklin Head was decided by the influence of Dr. S. Weir Mitchell, the President.

IN a list of 500 books selected by the New York State Library as representing about 10 per cent. of those published in 1901, and intended as the best in the total, there are included seventy-three works of the biographical class.

Copyright. 1902 LONDON, March 21 -- Besides the memoirs of Stokoe, the naval surgeon who was with Napoleon at St. Helena, a translation of which from the French of Paul Fremeux by Edith Stokoe is announced by John Lane. the early publication is promised of the diaries of Count Balmain, the Russian Commissioner at St. Helena, translated and edited by Alder Andersen.

KRASZEWSKI'S name will probably to most readers, yet in a Iong introduction to the present volume, S.C. de Soissons its editor and translator says that in 1879 the Polish nation celebrated at Cracow the fiftieth anniversary of the literary debut of Joseph Kraszcwski, in solemn and imposing fashion; his body now resting in the Parthenon set aside by the Poles for their literary celebrities.

A suit growing out of the absorption of the Houston and Texas Central Railroad by Southern Pacific interests, and involving 4,000,000 acres of Texas oil lands, was begun before Justice Truax in the Supreme Court yesterday. The plaintiff in the suit is Cornelius Macardell, as owner of 900 shares of the Houston and Texas Central Railroad Company, and representing the interests of other stockholders of the road.

An examination was recently held in this city of applicants for the position of Tenement House Inspector. Some of the most important requirements of the law in regard to tenement houses relate to the area of openings for air and light with reference to the cubic content of the room which these openings serve.

Wrestlers to the number of threescore engasod last night in the preliminary bouts for the annual metropolitan championship of the Amateur Athletic Union. The tournament this year is held under the auspices of the New Polo Athletic Association, One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Park Avenue.

LONDON, March 22. -- The feeling among the London tobacconists, exemplified at a big meeting yesterday afternoon to consider the rival bonus schemes of the Imperial Tobacco Company and of Ogden's, (Limited,) was one of bitter opposition to the boycotting clause of the agreement proposed by the Imperial Company, which was described as arbitrary and unjust.

LONDON March 15. -- Mr. Andrew Lang wrote a long letter the other day to one of the daily newspapers to complain of the deterioration of the King's English. He pointed out that the use of the word "big" has increased to an alarming extent, and that people constantly use it as a synonym for older words with whelm it is not by any means synonymous.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 22 -- The telephone linemen's strike in this city is creating considerable trouble. Thursday night many of the local wires were cut. Yesterday non-union men were sent over from Mount Vernon to repair the lines. A crowd of about fifty men and boys set upon them, and they were badly beaten before they escaped.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Mayor Low's so-called "Sweep bill" was not reported by the Assembly Committee on Rules to-day. Consequently it will not go on the calendar for Monday night. The failure of the committee to report the bill led to the belief that it was to be killed. This was denied by the Republican members of the committee, who said that the bill probably would he reported out Tuesday.

It is practically certain that Mayor Low will return to the Legislature for a thorough revision the Kelsey bill providing that railroads may build tunnels through the city on perpetual leases obtained with the consent of the Board of Aldermen and the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A short time ago you published a letter written by me to you in reference to the violation of the railroad law of this State by the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, in that it neglected to give transfers at one of its most important points, One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Madison Avenue.
A.C. HART, editor of The Atlantic Highlands Journal, died yesterday morning at his home of appendicitis and peritonitis.

SOME Tennesseeans say that the New York sculptor George Julian Zolnay "made Sara Davis." Mr. Zolnay replies that "Sam Davis made him." Made him, that is, in the South. And indeed if it had not been for the young Southern hero Mr. Zolnay might not to-day bear the title of "Sculptor of the Confederacy," nor have made his famous "Winnie Davis" monument.
ALBANY, March 22 -- The Committee on Rules to-day reported the following bills:

CIRCUSES are such old institutions, and most circus attractions are so stereo-typed that one would think the managers could never get anything new for their bills in these late days. That this is not true is due to the fact that the managers spend about half their time thinking out new acts or novel elements for old ones.

Rat is for call money held firm throughout the week just past, but there was at no time anything approaching stringency, or even what may be called tightness. This was the more significant for the reason that a number of the leading banks called some large loans -- for such calling would ordinarily have been followed by higher rates.

In a graceful speech, pointed with keen humor and marked by the evidences of experience and serious striving, Annie Russell on Friday afternoon provided food for thought for the would-be actors who on that day were graduated from the American Academy of Dramatic Art at the Empire Theatre.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In these days of reform. 1 wonder greatly that I hear of nothing being done in the direction of stopping unnecessary street noises.

NEW ORLEANS, March 22 -- Love's Labor and Major Mansir were the winning favorites to-day. The feature of the card was the New Louisiana Handicap, at four miles, and worth $1,850 to the winner. Major Mansir was a strong favorite in the betting, the price being cut from 6 to 5 to even.

WITH the demolition of the United States Hotel, at Fulton, Water, and Pearl Streets, another of New York's famous landmarks will pass into history. That old marble pile, whose Pearl Street front is nearly hidden from view by the elevated railroad, is one of the city's most ancient hostelries, antedating the Astor House by several years.

Long, Walsh, and Clearwater were the winners in the world's championship pool tournament yesterday at the Montauk Billiard Academy, Brooklyn, All three games furnished interesting contests, and caused a shifting about in the standing of the players, Long and Walsh each moving up a place.

FEW people have an idea of the immense amount of mail received daily at the General Post Office for distribution in the lower business section of the city or of the thousands of letters sent out by large business firms, which must be received at the Post Office. The amount of first-class mail matter alone received by individual firms is stupendous.

Marie Dressler's Ups and Downs. "There is a well established superstition, I understand, that whatever you dream turns out to the contrary," remarked Marie Dressler. "For many years I was a firm believer in that theory, and consoled myself with it on many occasions.

Stock market changes -- changes in financial conditions -- are changes for the better. The security market having withstood attacks in variety begins to show stalwartness. This is not yet aggressive, but tokens of the consequence of it are in many ways disclosed. The current market commands and is entitled to respect for the way in which it has proved itself superior to influences calculated to damage any situation.

LONDON, March 22 -- The most noteworthy individual performance in the notable revival of "Caste" for Macklin's benefit was the vivacious, highspirited, tender-hearted, loyal Polly Eccles of Marie Tempest, who now has no equal in such roles on the English stage.

Palm Sunday is one of the most triumphant feasts in the Church calendar -- but it is a triumph not unmixed with sadness as the shadow of the cross waxes, and there is a distinct minor in the hosannas sung by choristers. From Palm Sunday to Easter, New York observes religiously the spirit of the Church.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The chief social incident of to-day and one of the most interesting happenings of the season was "the assault at arms" between the members of the Washington Fencers' Club and a picked team from the Naval Academy at Annapolis, the contest taking place at the new home of the club on Nineteenth Street.

"Du Bnrry" and the Critics. It is a matter of current gossip that of the critics who wrote about "Du Barry," all except one welcomed it with the utmost enthusiasm, and that that one was observed during the greater part of the performance to be asleep.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 22 -- S. Isett Woodbridge, a missionary in China from South Carolina and a son-in-law of the Rev. Dr. James Woodrow, writes an interesting letter from Chin-Kiang about the war-purged China.

After lying grounded and capsized for an hour or more on Randall's Island Point in the Harlem River last evening the big steel tugboat Transit, owned by the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, took fire and burned to the water's edge while hundreds of people gathered along the river front watched the ineffectual attempts that were made to save her.
Gov. Jordan of New Hampshire has appointed Thursday, April 17, as Fast Day in the Granite State.

AT THE corner of Frankfort Street and Park, Row, the site of the Pulltzer, Building there is a flagstone which measures eight inches in thickness. Eighteen years ago when the stone-was first put there, its depth measured twelve inches, and thereby hangs an interesting tale -- a few instances of the length of the lives of the thousand and one familiar objects of usefulness which we see daily.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In writing of the concert given in Carnegie Hall last evening by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, is not Mr. Henderson in error when he states that "the last evening concert of the twenty-first season of this orchestra in New York was given at Carnegie Hall last night" ?

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 22 -- Yale opened the baseball season at Tale Field to-day with Manhattan College of New York, and after a stubborn contest won out in the ninth inning. Manhattan started well, scoring a run in each of the first and second innings. Yale then braced up and held down the visitors for the remainder of the game.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The Assembly has passed and the Senate Judiciary Committee has reported favorably the concurrent resolution introduced by Assemblyman Adler proposing an amendment to Article XII., Section 1, of the Constitution. The proposed amendment is as follows:

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Benjamin J. Rosenthal, who has just returned from a trip to the East in the interests of the Olympian games, to be held in Chicago in 19O4, says that New York financiers are to take a substantial block of the stock of the International Olympian Games Association. Mr. Rosenthal expects that at least 10 per cent, of the stock will be disposed of in New York without difficulty.

That the French Line steamship La Bourgogne, which sank after collision with the Cromartyshire, in July, 1898, was properly equipped with lifeboats and other safety devices is the chief burden of the decision handed down by Judge Townsend of the United States District Court yesterday upon the petition of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique for a limitation of liability upon the loss of the vessel and its cargo.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- The three European Fellowships of Bryn Mawr College for 1902-03 have been conferred. Each of these fellowships is of a value of $500, and is given to enable some student to pursue her studies for one year in the English or Continental universities. They are awarded for excellence of work and for promise in scholarly lines, and are the greatest honor Bryn Mawr confers, except the degree of Ph. D.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 22 -- A lively fight between the Eastern and Western roads for the Summer passenger traffic of the resorts is promised. The Eastern lines have been losing business to the Western roads for the last three Summers and are preparing to retaliate.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 22 -- The marriage of Miss Florence Washington Nelson, daughter of Commander I. Thomas Nelson, United States Navy, to Ensign Walter B. Tardy took place here to-night in the Naval Chapel.
J. EDWARD WELD, the artist and a member of the Harvard Club, loves a good story, even if it happens to be at his own expense, as the following that he tells certainly is:

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A dispatch received hero from Atlantic City, N.J., announces the death there at midnight of pericarditis of Dr. W.W. Johnston of this city. The deceased was one of the bestknown physicians of Washington, and was called into consultation in most of the cases of illness of well-known public men for years past.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 22 -- Secretary and Treasurer W.B. Wilson of the United Mine Workers of America returned to National headquarters here to-day from the East, where he attended two conventions of miners. Mr. Wilson discussed the situation in the coal fields of Virginia and West Virginia, and gave out the statement that in all probability a strike involving 35,000 miners will be called in those States within a short time.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- New York exchange was 10 cents premium; time and call loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent. Lake Street Elevated held the centre of the stage on the local Stock Exchange to-day, the trading in that stock aggregating over 7,000 shares. The price at one time stood at 13 7/8, a gain of about a point from last night, but practically all of this was lost before the close.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I ask your . . . dulgence for a few more words regarding the proposed mortgage tax measure that appears to have been temporarily defeated in the Senate, and to have been opposed in the Assembly for reasons not altogether creditable.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 22 -- Society at Lakewood intends to devote itself to penance during Easter week, and there will be no entertaining or functions of any sort. Lakewood will be crowded with visitors next week, but they are coming here to rest. Just now this resort is a paradise for tired city workers.

DISCUSSION of the "color line" issue in the General Federation of Women's Clubs is coming to a focus. At the biennial convention in Los Angeles, in May, some action in the matter must be taken, and the discussion and its results are sure to be interesting to women generally. There arc some who counsel delay and urge that the whole question lie over for another two years.

AFTER a period of seventeen years, in which the Lyceum Theatre, in Fourth Avenue, has been a factor in theatricals in this city, and indirectly in those not only of every city in the United States, but also of London, is now but a memory. Its history closed last night, when Annie Russell spoke the last word from its stage.

The Ottawa Hockey Club was beaten at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink by the New York Athletic Club last night, the score being 6 to 3. The Canadians did not show as good form as they did in their opening game with the Hockey Club of New York, ana were defeated rather handily by the local players, who at the start of the contest played as if they expected defeat.

Through the efforts of the National Civic Federation a strike in the paper trade which was to have started last night and might have seriously hampered nearly every newspaper in the East was averted. The strike would have affected ultimately about 50,000 men employed in twenty or thirty paper mills.

CLEVELAND, Ohio. March 22 -- A meeting of the National Baseball League will be held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, New York, Tuesday evening, April 1, to arrange a schedule for the coming season and to discuss other business matters.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The superiority of the American bricklayer as compared with his British rival is interestingly shown in a report recently sent by United States Consul McFarland from Notting ham, England. The Consul quotes an article recently published in a Nottingham paper.

THAT Richard Harding Davis himself was the original of Van Bibber, as well as the creator of that interesting literary personage, is an article of faith at Lehigh University, where the then budding author took a full course in athletics and amateur theatricals from 1883 to 1885, and incidentally attended a few lectures.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The case of Gen. Miles is proving one of the most embarrassing to the President of all that have come before him. For the first time the President finds himself opposed in a course which he desires to take by the advice of the persons in whose counsels he places the greatest reliance.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Reginald De Koven has been a Washingtonian only about two years, but he has already proved himself a public-spirited citizen by taking a leading part in various movements for the improvement of musical conditions here. Two plans which he is now engineering are for a symphony orchestra and a concert hall.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 22 -- In accordance with the mandate of the United States Supreme Court. W.T. Nugent of this city was committed to jail indefinitely by Judge Evans in the Federal Court to-day on account of his failure to pay $14,000 to the creditors of his father, the late F.B. Nugent, formerly a dry goods merchant of this city, who failed several years ago.

AT a recent afternoon function Mrs. Richard Irvin wore a gown of fine net spangled in stripes and flowers over white chiffon and silk. The stripes were three inches wide: one set was formed of single lines of tiny jet spangles twice their own width horizontally from each other, but meeting in the vertical lines.

After five weeks' imprisonment in the Tombs, on the charge of murdering Walter S. Brooks, in the Glen Island Hotel, on the night of Feb. 14, Florence Burns was last night discharged from custody by Justice Mayer, in the Court of Special Sessions. Justice Mayer has henrd the evidence since the beginning of the preliminary examination a month ago.
Fred E. Saward, editor of The Coal Trade Journal, speaking of the use of anthracite coal in Germany yesterday, had this to say:

Mr. Joseph Linden Smith, whose pictures of the remains of Egyptian architecture on the Nile were much admired when shown in New York, has been to Japan picturing scenes in Nippon on the same scale and with equal cleverness. They are shown in the Art Gallery of the Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, where they will remain till April 5 inclusive.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 22 -- Secret negotiations have been in progress in New York City all week to form a combine of several of the largest hardware houses in the United States, including the Simmons Hardware Company or St. Louis, the biggest of its kind in the country.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

NEW HAVEN, March 22 -- So unexpectedly successful were the experiments undertaken last Summer in this State in the scientific raising of leaf tobacco by the Connecticut Agricultural Station, under the auspices of the National Government that this coming season, which is about to begin, will see much fuller and wider experiment.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 22 -- A gigantic proposition, second only to that of the retimbering of the vast tracts in the Northwest laid waste by the lumberman's axe and numerous fires, is that of saving the impoverished cattle ranges in Nebraska, Wyoming, Colorado, Utah, Montana, Idaho, and the Dakotas, which the railroads penetrating those States have undertaken.

LONDON, March 22 -- Money was in fair demand to-day, and there was less pressure, as is frequently the case on Saturday. Discounts were firm, there being no special Continental demand. The Stock Exchange operators were mostly at the Oxford-Cambridge boat race, and those who were doing business were generally occupied with the preliminaries for Monday's general carry-over.

Messrs. Talbot J. Taylor Co., with which Stock Exchange firm Mr. James R. Keene makes his Wall Street headquarters, issue a circular letter reviewing the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's progress and its prospects. They say:

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is an equestrian statue of Gen. Ulysses S. Grant in Brooklyn, and there is soon to be erected in this borough a similar statue of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman. I hope the citizens of New York are not unmindful of the fact that there was another great General of the Union forces who did much toward bringing the war to a successful conclusion.

The rapid shrinkage which has lately been in progress in grain deliveries at Western primary markets, and particularly at the chief point, Chicago, where for the late month wheat, corn, oats, barley, and rye figured for only 7,755,000 bushels, against two and one-half times the volume a year ago, has again directed attention to the progress railroad earnings have made while the grain movement has been an adverse influence.
Mr. Charles J. Dyer will give a concert tomorrow afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria. He will be assisted by Miss Ternina of the Opera, Mrs. Morris Black, and Mr. Randegger. The programme:

There seems to be some misunderstanding about the significance of the movement in the House of Representatives for the appointment of a special committee to investigate the suffrage laws of the several States and related questions. Opponents of the movement denounce it as an attempt to revive sectional feeling and to enforce negro suffrage upon the Southern States.

Mrs. John Fox, Jr., has brought suit for $150,000 damages for the alienation of her husband's affections against her father-in-law, John Fox, the millionaire iron manufacturer and President of the Democratic Club. She declares that her husband jumped out of a window and deserted her on the evening of March 14. and accuses her father-in-law of sending him money to a large amount to aid him in his escape from her.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 21 -- Baltimore society has been very much interested in Mrs. Patrick Campbell, who has been playing here at Ford's Grand Opera House during the past week. Not only have numerous box parties to see tier been arranged, with a supper afterward, at which she joined the guests, but several entertainments especially in her honor have been given at their homes by members of the smart set.

Francis Lynde Stetson, counsel for J. Pierpont Morgan, yesterday made the following statement in reference to the circumstances attending the service of a subpoena on the latter in the suit of Peter Power against the Northern Pacific Railroad Company:

The last concert of the Boston Orchestra in this city for the present season took place yesterday. By an inadvertence the final entertainment of the evenings series, which was given on Thursday night, was mentioned as the last of the twenty-first season of the orchestra here. It is indeed, the twenty-first season of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, but not in New york.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., March 22 -- Difference of opinion on matters pertaining to the wage scale prevented a final adjournment to-day of the convention of Districts No. 1, 7, and 9, United Mine Workers. After being in session for three hours this morning the convention adjourned to meet Monday, and many of the delegates assert that a conclusion will not be reached that day.

BERLIN, March 22 -- The yacht which Emperor William has named Alice Roosevelt is beautifully decorated in the modern, impressionistic style which his Majesty disapproved of in his recent art utterances. Nevertheless, the Emperor was greatly pleased with the decorations when he saw the yacht at Kiel this week.
BALTIMORE, Md., March 22 -- A number of changes will be made April 1 in the organization of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am very desirous of enlisting the sympathy of the American public in my peace mission to this country, and I feel I can do so better through the press than even by public meetings, so I venture to solicit a little space in your journal for this purpose.

From The Baltimore American. Extensive manufacturing works are to be crected in this city by the Rice Polishing Machine Company of America, recently incorporated in this city with a capital of 5100,000. The company has secured control of all the existing patents of improved devices for polishing rice, including a number invented by Oliver R. "Welch of Baltimore.

LONDON, March 22 -- With the exception of "The Girl from Maxim's," (first presented here at the Criterion Theatre Thursday last,) no new productions marked the theatrical week, though several changes occur to-night. In spite of its popularity in America, "The Girl from Maxim's " has utterly failed to be appreciated in London.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reading an editorial on Bryan in THE TIMES a day or two ago I noticed that you assumed that he would be the obstacle in the way of Democratic success in 1904 because he would not be willing to abandon the principles of the Kansas City platform at the bidding of the men who knifed the ticket in 1896.

WHITEHOUSE, N.J., March 22 -- The little village of Peapack, up among the hills of Somerset County, seems to have a monopoly in the wonder line. The great caverns discovered there are still remembered by hundreds of people, who went to see them, but another part of the town has suddenly sprung into prominence by the discovery of what seems to be a big underground river.

OCCASION has frequently been taken to comment in this place on the bad sinking of opera singers. Certainly most of them ought to stay as far away from the concert platform as possible. The stormy applause of the Sunday night concert audiences means nothing.
Ex-Controller Andrew H. Green, known as the father of the Greater New York charter, complains that much harm is resulting from some of the amendments enacted last year.

Among the educational associations of this city is one which devotes its energy to teaching to children and young men and women the city's history. The work has been carried on for only five years, and even now its effect is beginning to be seen plainly all over town, from the lower east side to the wealthier up-town localities.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The House to-day entered upon the consideration of the contested election case of Moss vs. Rhea from the Third Kentucky District. In this case the Committee on Elections divided on party lines, the majority sustaining the view that Mr. Moss had been elected, and the minority that Mr. Rhea, the Democrat, was entitled to retain his seat.

LONDON, March 22 -- The most significant, indeed, the only definite charge which the most hostile members of the Opposition bring against the Ministry is that the Government is withholding bad news from the seat of war and that the censorship habitually suppresses the facts concerning the dark side of things in South Africa.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The growing interest of the United States in the trade of Asiatic Russia and the countries tributary thereto lends especial interest to a statement received by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics from a report of the Belgian Commercial Agent at Vladivostock, recently published in the Bulletin Commercial, (Brussels.)

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 22 -- It is announced here to-day that Yale and Harvard have agreed upon the terms for the annual boat race to be held in New London on Thursday. June 26. with William Meikleham as referee. There will be three races as usual. A four-mile race between the Varsity eight-oared, a two-mile race between the four-oared, and a two-mile race between the freshman crews.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the rusting of iron and steel work in buildings is a subject which periodically comes before the public, in view of its importance, it might be well to place before your readers some facts bearng on this matter, which recent newspaper reports from Chicago briefly touched upon.

The course of the outside market yesterday was somewhat irregular, but the changes that appeared on the side of advances were more numerous than those which appeared among the declines. The principal losses among the active issues were in American Can and Colorado Fuel bonds, both of which have been following a very irregular course.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 22 -- "Snap courses " are in disfavor at Harvard. An investigation concerning the college's elective system, which has just been completed by Paul Henry Hanus, Professor of Classical Philology, and one of the most prominent educationalists in the country, shows this.

The decision and opinion of Justice GAYNOR in favor of GUDEN, recently removed from the office of Sheriff of Kings County by the Governor, which we give in full in another column, raises a very important issue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In connection with the discussion of the New York Central tunnel, while plans for electrical equipment are being considered, the following plan for doing away with the steam might be tried: Turn the steam from the exhaust of the cylinders into the water in the tender, thus condensing the steam.

The publication by the Western Union Telegraph Company of its estimated results, showing improvement for the March quarter and nine months of the fiscal year, draws attention to the anomalous position held by the company's stock on the local security market.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Elliot H. Goodwin, Secretary of the Civil Service Reform Association, declares in an interview in to-day's issue of your valued journal, that no self-respecting veteran should favor the Ellsworth bill, and takes pains to say that positions of veterans are silecures which this bill makes permanent.

WHAT I have may be good enough," said the old collector, " but that which I have not is what I hanker after. Pray do not misunderstand me. I do not long for the impossible. There are the limits which money imposes. There are not many who can pay a hundred thousand dollars for a picture.

SHE was relating her wonderful experiences in New York to a circle of admiring, and, it Is to be feared, a little bit envious friends. And they really had cause to be envious, for had she not spent three whole weeks visiting her city cousin and reveling in the joys to be found nowhere as in New York?

From The Rochester Democrat. A news item states that the people of Fall River, Mass., have succeeded so well in protecting the wild gray squirrels in their neighborhood that the animals wander into the streets of the city and accept food from friendly hands. Probably such cases are rare.

When Sir Thomas Lipton first came to America in an effort to "lift the cup," and the Erin was anchored within the three-mile limit, flying the British ensign from the stern and a flag adorned with shamrocks at the mainmast, the Irish knight was elected an honorary member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick.

The upward movement in prices which has been in evidence in the stock market now for some days was continued yesterday, with the result that at the close of the day net advances appeared in not a few important stocks. Indeed, up to the time of the publication of the bank statement practically every stock on the the list showed an advance.

A sentence out of the will of the late LEONARD LEWISOHN, which we printed yesterday, must have attracted the notice of many readers. It ran: "Having during my life given largely of my means to deserving charities, I make no charitable bequests, leaving it to my children to make such gifts, out of the estates which they may receive under the will, as they may deem proper."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 22 -- The expected rush to the shore has set in, and the hotels are filled to their limit. Not a single room can be had at the big beach front houses until after Easter. A matter of comment is the great number of young men here. Heretofore the fair sex predominated numerically, but this year there are nearly as many men as girls.

The American railroad companies were even greater sinners than our own in differentiating rates some years ago, remarks The London Statist discussing "home rall" sorrows They used to "pool " their favor of large customers, and to make a great difference in the rates for what were called " long hauls " and "short hauls."

In what appears to be an effort to discredit the system, the British Government has arranged to employ the Marconi equipment of some of its ships in an attempt to intercept private messages, with a view to proving whether MARCONI has really perfected his syntonic system to an extent which makes his aerograms inviolable.

The upward movement in prices which has been in evidence in the stock market now for some days was continued yesterday, with the result that at the close of the day net advances appeared in not a few important stocks. Indeed, up to the time of the publication of the bank statement practically every stock on the the list showed an advance.

A sentence out of the will of the late LEONARD LEWISOHN, which we printed yesterday, must have attracted the notice of many readers. It ran: "Having during my life given largely of my means to deserving charities, I make no charitable bequests, leaving it to my children to make such gifts, out of the estates which they may receive under the will, as they may deem proper."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 22 -- The expected rush to the shore has set in, and the hotels are filled to their limit. Not a single room can be had at the big beach front houses until after Easter. A matter of comment is the great number of young men here. Heretofore the fair sex predominated numerically, but this year there are nearly as many men as girls.

The American railroad companies were even greater sinners than our own in differentiating rates some years ago, remarks The London Statist discussing "home rall" sorrows They used to "pool " their favor of large customers, and to make a great difference in the rates for what were called " long hauls " and "short hauls."

In what appears to be an effort to discredit the system, the British Government has arranged to employ the Marconi equipment of some of its ships in an attempt to intercept private messages, with a view to proving whether MARCONI has really perfected his syntonic system to an extent which makes his aerograms inviolable.

Justice Greenbaum, in the Supreme Court, has issued an attachment against the property of George W. Lessels of 337 1/2 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, ex-Treasurer of the Jennie Clarkson Home for Children at Katonah, N.Y., and at one time a stock broker. Lessels, it is said, cannot be found, and bonds and securities of the home worth $15,000 are missing from the box in the safe deposit vaults of the Market and Fulton National Bank.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While no one questions the desirability of a uniform metric standard, the arbitrary character or the bill now before Congress for enforced vise of decimally proportioned weights and measures would seem to justify a critical inquiry into its merits and demerits.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, March 22 -- Paderewski caused a lot of trouble to the yardmen of the Rock Island road at this place when he came from Chicago to Davenport in his private car to give a concert. He insisted that the car be turned around for the return trip, as he could not sleep except with his head toward the engine.

LONDON, March 22 -- Continental Europe is full of religious excitement, and the recent pronouncement of the Vatican against the so-called Christian Democracy of Italy, which assumes to work for the social and religious betterment of the country, is regarded as another proof of the reactionary influence and intolerance of Cardinal Rampolla.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 22 -- Princeton easily defeated Rutgers here this afternoon in the opening game of the baseball season by a score of 25 to 1. Only seven innings were played. The Tigers won by their heavy and consistent batting and by excellent fielding work. Score:

THERE is no time or the year holding so much, of interest and pleasure to the nature lover as the Spring season. To the bird lover this is particularly true, for after the barrenness of Winter, when but few birds are to be met with, and the woods are sombre and silent, the northern migration of the birds is looked forward to with delightful anticipation.

A conference was held yesterday between Mayor Low and the members of the Municipal Civil Service Commission with the State Civil Service Commission over the proposed reorganization of the clerical force of the city departments. The talk was held at the Hardware Club, and lasted from 10:30 o'clock until 2 in the afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just read on Page 7 of to-day's TIMES the item headed "Why the Blind Do Not Smoke." I am a Boston man, or was until recently, and one of the most familiar figures in the business section of Boston is an old blind man who goes from store to store selling brooms and brushes.

When one considers that more than a fourth of the city's new railroad is to consist of an elevated structure, it seems strange that the official name of the whole line is the Rapid Transit Subway. Five and a quarter miles of track will not be in a subway at all, but will be laid on a raised steel trestle constructed just like the Manhattan Elevated Roads in Ninth, Sixth, Third, and Second Avenues.

It has afforded grounds for surprise to many thoughtful people that crimes perpetrated in rural communities are so frequently characterized by peculiar and exceptional brutality. Those committed in cities are largely of the kind inspired by sordid motives or are the result of ungovernable passion, and exhaust themselves in commonplace robbery or murder.

GROWING plants in the dark for commerce is becoming a vast Winter industry, while as a subject of scientific investigation the "blanching" process is productive of some very remarkable experiments at the New York Botanical Garden. In commerce rhubarb forcing forms the typical illustration.

ZANESVILLE, Ohio, March 22 -- R.F. Rogers of New York, representing the bondholders, was the only bidder for the Terminal Railroad in this city to-day, and it was knocked down to him for $92,000. This insures the continuance of the present management, which is closely affiliated with the Columbus, Sandusky and Hocking.
Alexander E. Orr, President of the Rapid Transit Commission, yesterday made public the following letter, which he received from ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial upon the Grand Army of he Republic THE NEW YORK TIMES of his date says, among other things: There is very good reason to believe that one-half the persons now in receipt of pensions from the Government have no title to its bounty."

LONDON, March 22 -- The tone of the stock market has been fairly steady all the week. In spite of a very limited volume of business American rails have been improving and presented a strong front, while there was quite an appreciable revival in South Africans toward the close, the illness of Cecil Rhodes having ceased to be a disturbing factor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The claim that important financial interests are the large holders of stocks is well founded; so is the fact that the same interests are not moving heaven and earth to get out of them at any price, fearing some catastrophe in the near future in the shape of a general market breakdown.

PUTNEY, England, March 22 -- The Cambridge crew to-day fulfilled the expectations of the prophets and won the fiftyninth boat race with Oxford as they liked. At no time throughout the race did Oxford in the slightest degree flatter the hopes of the supporters of the Dark Blue. Any possible chance which the Oxonians might have had was shattered by the result of the toss, giving the Light Blues (Cambridge) all the advantage of station.

As bearing upon the question of the improving basis of railroad security values, no feature of recent railroad progress is more conspicuous than the development of local resources, no feature more closely allied to the appreciation which has taken place than the shifting dependency of earnings from special to general influences.

Palm Sunday was commemorated last night by the Lambs Club members with a performance of Clay M. Greene's sacred drama "Nazareth," presented at the Garrick Theatre by a carefully selected cast of twenty-four persons.

BRUSSELS, March 23. -- The Liberals and Socialists, including many members of the Chamber of Deputies, held a big parade here this afternoon. The paraders halted in front of the City Hall and sent in a deputation to the Burgomaster, bearing a petition for universal suffrage and proportional representation.

Spring burst suddenly on the town yesterday, and the unanimous agreement after a lovely day was that the Winter weather was finally ended. From early morning the "feel" of Spring was in the air and when night fell more people had been in the streets and parks than on any single Sunday in five months.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., March 23. -- At an Executive Committee meeting of the National Loom Fixers' Union held in this city to-day the principal business transacted was to vote to authorize the Loom Fixers' Union of Lowell to use its own discretion in the matter of striking.

OTTAWA, March 23. -- The Dominion budget was presented on Monday last, St. Patrick's Day. The Hon. W.S. Fielding, the Finance Minister, had another story of prosperity to tell. The one discouraging note in the annual financial statement of the Canadian Government was the census figures, which were said to be disappointing.

A large congregation was present yesterday afternoon at the twenty-fifth regular service of the Actors Church Alliance, held at the Manhattan Theatre. The meeting was presided over by the Rev. Thomas R. Slicer. Addresses were made by Augustus Thomas, the playwright, and the Rev. Sydney Herbert Cox, pastor of Bethany Congregational Church.

The bill sent to Albany by the Mayor giving the Board of Estimate and Apportionment the power to fix salaries for the budget which must be prepared this Spring is a legitimate measure, which the Senate has passed and which the Assembly should pass also without question.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., March 23. -- From an official source it was learned to-day that to-morrow an effort will be made for an adjournment of the joint convention of Districts Nos. 1, 7, and 9, United Mine Workers of America, without committing the delegates to a strike declaration.

The arrival of Gen. LEONARD WOOD at Washington, and the iteration of his complete conviction that the concession of 20 per cent, on the exports of sugar and tobacco from Cuba to our ports is insufficient, will again raise the question in the mind of the President and in the minds of the party leaders of increasing this concession to the level of real justice.

BRUSSELS, March 24. -- The Petit Bleu. referring to the arrival at Pretoria of Messrs. Schalk-Burger and Reitz and Commandants Meyer and Krogh, says it believes that Mr. Schalk-Burger's move is in response to fresh British overtures for peace, made out of gratitude for the release of Lord Methuen, and predicts that these overtures will lead to no result unless Boer independence is conceded.
The United States soldiers who are to take part in the military tournament to be held in Madison Square Garden this week arrived here last evening after a nine hours' journey from Washington.

A slight fire in the Constance apartment house at 60 St. Nicholas Avenue, on the corner of One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, at noon yesterday created intense excitement among the many tenants in the big building, and was followed by a hurried scramble on the fire escapes and the elevators.

Mrs. John Vranken was arrested last night and taken to the Tenderloin Police Station, charged with having created a disturbance in Young's Restaurant, at Sixth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street. The arrest revealed the romance of a runaway match, in which figured Capt. John Vranken of the Eighth Artillery, Belgian Army, and Mrs. Vranken, who belongs to a prominent and wealthy family of Amsterdam, Holland.

Several scores of sweatshop workmen barely escaped from a burning building in which they were employed, at 86 Walker Street, yesterday afternoon. The fire started shortly after 2 o'clock, and had done damage estimated at $7,000 by Deputy Chief Ahearn, before it was finally under control, three-quarters of an hour later.

LONDON, March 24. -- The War Office states that it has as yet received no official news confirming the dispatch from Pretoria in regard to the movements of Mr. Schalk-Burger and his party. It is taken for granted here that the move of the burgher leaders can have only one meaning, and that another attempt is being made to negotiate peace.

LONDON, March 12. -- A few belated afterthoughts may not be amiss about the careful and interesting production of Stephen Phillips's "Paolo and Francesca" by George Alexander at the fashionable St. James's Theatre, a house so closely associated under his management with fashion in dress and deportment and the doings of high society that a few ribald persons are fond of calling it "the parlor maids' theatre."

Gov. Odell is reported to have said that the Krum Corporation Tax bill as it now stands is fair and should give satisfaction. There have been many conflicting reports as to the effect of the bill, and Lawson Purdy, Secretary of the New York Tax Reform Association, having been asked what the bill actually provides, said:

LOWELL, Mass., March 23. -- Lowell is threatened with one of the largest strikes in its history as a result of the communication sent to the Textile Union by the mill agents in reply to the official demand of that body for an advance in wages for the textile operatives of the city.

RED BANK, N.J., March 23. -- The stables of the Monmouth Hunt Club, between Eatontown and Oceanport, were burned to the ground this morning, and sixteen horses lost their lives in the burning structure. Among the horses destroyed were ten valuable hunters owned by Peter Fenelon Collier, the New York publisher.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 23. -- There has been and is now a very strong feeling in North Carolina against the manufacture and sale of liquor. In a number of counties there is absolute prohibition of the traffic in liquor. In the year 1881 the liquor question was submitted to a vote of the people, and there was a majority of 117,000 for manufacture and sale.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 23. -- Opponents of Lieut. Gov. Tillman in his candidacy for Governor are delighted to-night at the sensation promised for to-morrow, by which it is expected that the Lieutenant Governor will suffer in the public estimation.

LONDON, March 24. -- Reviewing Japanese press opinion regarding the Franco-Russian declaration, the Tokio correspondent of The Times says one leading journal considers that the French-Russian alliance has been weakened for European purposes by its extension to regions where the interests of the allies are not always identical.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 23. -- The unknown steamer reported afire yesterday by the crew of the Oregon Inlet Life-Saving Station, in North Carolina, was identified to-day as the oil steamer Major Barrett, bound from Sabine Pass, Texas, to New York, though her home port was Philadelphia. It is believed some passing vessel rescued the crew of the fire-stricken ship, though no definite information to this effect has been received here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of March 17, under the heading "Topics of the Times," you refer in terms of slight commendation, if not of disapproval, to Congressman J.F. Lacey's bill to protect the game birds and animals of Alaska.

One of the best comedy programmes of the season is announced for Keith's Theatre this week, with a liberal sprinkling of European novelties. "The Girl with the Auburn Hair" will be the leading feature, in her brilliant scenic specialty, which is acknowledged one of the greatest acts in vaudeville.

As yesterday was the first warm and bright Sunday of the present year, it proved the actual opening day of the local rowing season, and all day long the waters of the Harlem River were dotted with racing and pleasure craft, both large and small, while the clubhouse balconies and floats were thronged with the members and guests of the various clubs.

Thirty-five men employed by Canavan Brothers, the Building Department wreckers and contractors, worked all day yesterday propping and bracing still further the three Park Avenue houses, between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets, which were damaged by the caving in of the rapid transit subway excavation forty-seven feet below street level.

The Hotel Astor, the construction of which has just been commenced on Long Acre Square, will occupy the entire block from Forty-fourth to Forty-fifth Street, extending 162 feet down each street, and will be one of the handsomest structures in Manhattan. William C. Muschenheim is to be the proprietor.

HANOVER, Penn., March 23. -- The suit brought by the Rev. Jacob Kurtz of Waynesborough against the Rev. Jacob Aldinger of York for $25,000 for slander has been withdrawn, as the rules of the German Baptist Church forbid lawsuits on the part of its members. The Rev. Mr. Aldinger declared that the Rev. Mr. Kurtz did not possess the holy spirit.

-- It is really a pity that a man who has seen so much of the world -- and profited so much thereby -- as has M. HUGUES LE ROUX should have wasted his own time and that of the Princeton students by exploiting a new before them the ancient idea that money is in this country an object more madly pursued and more ardently loved than it is in other countries.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Frederick W. Hossfeld, the United States Consul at Trieste, in a report to the State Department makes some suggestions as to methods of increasing the sales of American coal in Austria.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Oleomargarine bill will receive the greater share of the attention of the Senate through this present week, but if there should be a time when no one is prepared to speak on it, Senator Proctor, who will have charge of it, will give way to the Chinese Exclusion bill, which is in the hands of Senator Penrose.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 23. -- At the home of Mrs. Charles A. Strong, daughter of John D. Rockefeller, with whom he is staying, it was said to-day that the report that Mr. Rockefeller was on the verge of LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 23 collapse, or was a physical wreck, was untrue. According to the report, Mr. Rockefeller's hair and mustache had fallen out, and his appearance denoted a general breakdown in his health.

The Brewery Workers' Union was finally declared suspended by President Eugene A. Johnson at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union, which was uproarious all the way through, and finally broke up in disorder. There are now two factions in the body, one holding that the union, was legally suspended, and the other that the suspension was illegal, and that the brewery workers were still affiliated with the body.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 23. -- J.C. Jaudon has wired to New York offering a guarantee purse of $25,000, or 70 per cent, of the gross gate receipts to have the twenty-round glove contest between Jeffries and Fuzsnumons on May 13 held on the grounds of the South Carolina Inter-State and West Indian Exposition here, if the offer is accepted an arena with a capacity of 20,000 will be erected.

For more than a decade there has been agitation on the part of the owners of riding academies south of Central Park and of their customers for admission to the Park for equestrians on Fifty-ninth Street between the two corners to which entrance was originally restricted.

BERLIN, March 23. -- During the past week the stagnation on the Boerse grew more pronounced, no department showed any life, and transactions continued to shrink in volume. The professionals attempted to realize, but outsiders were conspicuously holding aloof. Domestic loans have held their own fairly well, and some large investors have been buying in all the departments.

ALBANY, March 23. -- The Legislature of 1902 will adjourn sine die on Thursday. There remains but very little more to do that is not already known. An attempt will doubtless be made to pass the $30,800,000 Canal Appropriation bill now in the Assembly Committee on Rules. This is the Davis bill, which passed the Assembly after a hard debate.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 23. -- Major Micah Jenkins, after all, will receive a handsome sword from South Carolinians, and moreover it will be presented to him through the President of the United States. Major Jenkina refused to accept the sword that was in the hands of Lieut. Gov. Tillman because of that individual's insult to the President.

Commissioner of Immigration Fitchie announced yesterday that he had been informed by President Roosevelt that he was soon to be superseded as Commissioner of Immigration at the Port of New York. The President did not disclose the identity of Mr. Fitchie's successor, and it was said in immigration circles that he had not as yet decided the matter.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 14th inst. there appeared another wail from the ladies of the land against the present customs laws. This time it comes from "Porkopolis."

The powerlessness of the United States Steel Corporation fully to carry out its declared policy of holding iron prices steady against the efforts of producers outside that organization to establish a "boom" market and run prices up to the limit, is indicated by the fact that the Pittsburg users of pig iron are now importing quite largely.

Mrs. Howard Crosby Butler contributes to the March number of The Princeton University Bulletin a brief description of sculptured monuments found by the American Archaeological Expedition to Syria in 1899 and 1900, with illustrations from the photograph. They appear to have been carved in place.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "One little word" in the article I wrote for your paper regarding the proposed Marine Hospital at Savannah so utterly changed the whole drift of my letter that it may be well to call attention to the matter.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., March 24 -- The United Mine Workers' Convention to-day adopted a resolution declaring for a strike, to take effect on a date to be fixed by the district Executive Boards, provided a final effort at reconciliation with the operators through the medium of the National Civic Federation proves unavailing.

The Continental newspapers continue to exhibit ignorance of American affairs and traditions, in their comments upon the rival alliances in the Far East. Perhaps the most striking of these exhitions is that made by the Independance Belge, in suggesting that "probably Germany and the United States will constitute a third group of 'allies.' "
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Cuban delegation on Economic Affairs, through Mr. de Abad, its secretary, has issued an open letter directed to the members of Congress. The letter says:
John J. Kavanagh has sold for Klein Jackson, for about $95,000, the six-story apartment house 44 East Seventy-ninth Street, southeast corner of Madison Avenue, 21 by 80.

LONDON, March 25 -- The Daily Chronicle says an armistice has been arranged pending the duration of Acting President Schalk-Burger's mission to Mr. Steyn and Gen. De Wet, and that offensive operations against De Wet, De la Rey, and Botha will be suspended, these three Generals having agreed honorably to observe the armistice and to refrain from operations until the return of the envoys to the Boer lines.

A rumor was in circulation yesterday which, owing to the secrecy on the part of the police of the Charles Street Station, could not be verified, that Mrs. Michael Murray, the wife of a policeman attached to that station, had yesterday attempted to redeem a gold chain which was the property of Mrs. Kate Voelpel, who was mysteriously murdered a month ago.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Consternation was caused among traffic officials here to-day when they were informed that the Inter-State Commerce Commission would make another investigation of alleged violations of the Inter-State Commerce Act, and that hearing would be commenced in the United States Court room on April 1.

In the tournament of the New York Interclub Bowling League last night the Century Wheelmen bowlers won two of three games from the local five. The Roseville Athletic Association team of Newark won three straight games from the Belvidere bowlers in the metropolitan championship series.

Amid the cheers of the thousands of spectators and the tunes of the martial music played by the military bands, the sixth annual military and athletic tournament, commonly known as the Military Show, was opened last night at the Madison Square Garden. The crowd filled the amphitheatre to overflowing, and it was in every way an appreciative and demonstrative gathering.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday announced that he would not, present the cast of Florence Burns, to the Grand Jury unless evidence in addition to that presented before Justice Mayer should be found against the young woman: discharged in Special Sessions, where she had a hearing on the charge of having killed Walter Brooks in the Glen Island Hotel.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Assembly Committee on Rules to-night again amended the Tenement House Commission bill, this time making some concessions to the Tenement House Commissioner. In the bill, as it will go on the calendar to-morrow, the 4 by 12 airshaft, which was the principal point contended for by the Brooklyn building interests, will remain in the bill.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- After the conclusion of the District business in the House to-day, debate upon the contested election case of Moss vs. Rhea, from the Third Kentucky District, was resumed. Mr. Bowie, (Ala.,) a member of the committee which reported the case, argued in favor of sustaining the contention of the minority, that Mr. Rhea was entitled to retain his seat.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Representative Pugsley of the Sixteenth New York District has received a large number of letters from various parts of the country, indorsing his views set forth in THE NEW YORK TIMES as to the position the Democratic Party should take with reference to the political questions of to-day.

George Shauer, forty-three years old, an ironworker employed on the new East River bridge, met death yesterday afternoon by falling from the centre span of the foot-bridge, 108 feet, into the river, and was drowned in sight of hundreds of people on ferryboats and other craft who were unable to rescue him.

-- It wasn't quite nice of Mr. W.G. VAN NAME, whose letter we published yesterday, criticising our recent remarks about the Lacey bill to protect Alaskan game, to charge us with suggesting that "it is a matter of no consequence whether the game is exterminated or not, so long as the law is to forbid people from enjoying the pleasure of killing it."

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 24 -- Something akin to the busy days of last Spring was suggested by the sprightly character of the market in Philadelphia to-day. The whole list shared in the betterment, but the event of the day was a 6 1/2 -point rise in Electric Storage common and 5 in the preferred, both touching the highest figures since last Summer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the suggestion to place the statue of Gen. Sherman at the Fifth Avenue entrance to Central Park, it is not clearly stated whether the "circular plot" mentioned is the one within the Park boarders or the one in front of the Plaza Hotel.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was active, and in most stocks resulted in some improvement in prices. In fact, the several issues most conspicuous for their activity were notably strong, and ended the day at the top prices with considerable net gains. Even in the Fuel bonds, which early in the day showed a decided downward tendency, the afternoon trading brought about a sharp recovery.
HAVANA, March 24 -- The trials before the Audiencia Court of the cases arising from the embezzlement of Cuban postal funds have resulted in the following sentences:

NEW ORLEANS, March 24 -- The Kansas City, Watkins and Gulf Railroad was sold at receiver's sale to-day for the sum of $1,000,000 to the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of Trenton, N.J. The road is in operation between Alexandria. La., and Charles Lake. The sale took place on Lake Charles.

No action was taken yesterday to put in force the decision of Justice Gaynor in the Kings County Shrievalty case, and there was practically no change in the situation during the day. Contrary to expectations, Justice Gaynor did not sign the order necessary to make his decision of force, and Col. Norman S. Dike was not disturbed in the possession of the Sheriff's office and the County Jail.
Bar silver was quoted in London at 24 7/8 d per ounce and in New York at 54 7/8 c per ounce. Mexican dollars at 43 1/4 c.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Senator Cullen of Brooklyn has made himself remarkable at this session by not introducing a single bill. "My notion," he said to-night, "is that there are too many bills introduced and too many laws passed. I have introduced but five bills in seven years, and three of these became laws."
THE HAGUE, March 24 -- Acting President Schalk-Burger's arrival at Pretoria was a complete surprise to Boer circles here.
PARIS, March 24 -- The Chamber of Deputies to-day, by a vote of 469 to 32, adopted a bill providing a credit of 300,000f, to defray the expenses of President Loubet's visit to Russia.

At the meeting yesterday of the North Jersey Street Railway Company a very important announcement was made. This company controls a large part of the trolley system of Northern New Jersey. Its President, Mr. E.F.C. YOUNG, said:...

Lawyer Robert M. Moore, of counsel for Albert T. Patrick, on trial charged with the murder of William Marsh Rice, devoted yesterday's session of the trial to an exhaustive review of the evidence taken during the nine weeks previous, and to a lengthy summing up of the case for the defense.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Plans are on foot for the combination of some of the leading color engraving concerns of the country. The American Three-Color Company and the National Colortype Company of Chicago and a New York firm have taken the initiative in the scheme, and a meeting will be held in New York the latter part of the week.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- For the fourth time during the past few years the United States Supreme Court to-day rendered an opinion affecting the estate of the late Thomas Blythe of California. Upon his death his daughter. Florence Blythe Hinckiey, came into possession of the property, and other relatives have since sought to destroy her title.

It was all on account of the telephone. If the long-distance wires between Baltimore and New York had not been overworked, Lucie Milner, the ingenue of Mrs. Patrick Campbell's company, might still be secure in her precious woman's secret. But no one could be expected to go on paying large tolls indefinitely without arousing some curiosity, and least of all in a theatrical company.

Local politicians in several districts yesterday were eagerly engaged in discussing the features of the Weeks bill, known as Assembly bill No. 898, and great interest was manifested in the effect it would have on the primaries this year should it become a law. So quietly had this measure progressed in the Legislature that it was not until Sunday of this week that it began to attract attention here.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 24 -- In a head-on collision between freight trains at 7:10 o'clock this morning on the Pittsburg, Youngstown and Ashtabula Division of the Pittsburg, Fort Wuyne and Chicago Road, four men were killed and three injured. The dead are:

NEWARK. N.J., March 24 -- Miss Lillian Wilson, aboui fifty years of age, shot and killed Robert Stewart Hutchinson, about thirty-five years old, this afternoon, and then drank two ounces of carbolic acid. She died while being taken to St. Barnaba's Hospital in an ambulance.

District Attorney Jerome and Police Commissioner Partridge, working in thorough harmony, have developed a plan for the regulation and the reorganization of the Police Department on a basis different from any that hitherto has been tried.

ALBANY, March 24 -- A motion was made to-day before the Court of Appeals to place on the calendar and advance the appeal in the case of Anton J. Dittmar against Count Bont de Castellane, Anna Gould, Countess de Castellane, defendants, and George Gould, Edwin Gould, Howard Gould, and Helen M. Gould as trustees under the last will and testament of Jay Gould.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Gen. Miles's testimony before the Senate Committee on Military Affairs, as it will appear in the official records, was made public to-night. His alleged threat to resign if the pending General Staff bill is passed does not appear, and the following colloquy at the close of the hearing explains it:
It being Holy Week, there is, as a matter of fact, practically nothing, doing socially, and with the exception of a few dinners and fewer Lenten lectures, the six days will be almost a blank.
LONDON, March 24 -- The scarcity of money stiffened rates to-day, and borrowers were entirely dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts were firm.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- With the consent of the defendants, Judge Grosscup, in the Federal court to-day, issued the temporary restraining order asked for by the Inter-State Commerce Commission against six railways entering Chicago. The order holds good until June 1, or until further orders from the court.

In Margaret Rhodes, whom Edward Fiezer, alias Edward Stillman, married under the latter name in this city in December, 1899, he met a woman destined to check his propensity for getting married. After several months of detective work on her own account, which led to many heartrending scenes, the young woman faced him in the First Criminal Court in Newark yesterday and accused him of having married three women besides herself.
The action which the Mayor has taken in regard to the proposed improvement by the Pennsylvania Railroad is surprising, puzzling, and needlessly risky for the interests of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The French Ambassador, M. Cambon, entertained at dinner this evening. His guests were the friends originally invited for March 14, that dinner party having been deferred to the present date by reason of the Ambassador being invited to the White House.

Major George R. Smith and Capt. George E. Pickett, Paymasters, are relieved from duty at New York City, to take effect at such time as will enable them to take transport from San Francisco on or about May 1, 1902, for the Philippine Islands.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- About 150 guests were present to-night at the biennial banquet of the Virginia Democratic Association, held in the banquet room of the Metropolitan Hotel. They included Democrats of National prominence and most of the political leaders and Democratic members of Congress from the Old Dominion.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Assembly Committee on Rules to-night reported a bill to amend the rapid transit law. The bill reported to-night is intended to protect the powers of the Rapid Transit Commission and to supplant the Pennsylvania Tunnel bill.

We note with interest the account given by The Tribune of the efforts of the Democratic Congressmen to relieve themselves of the burden and nuisance of Mr. BRYAN'S leadership. According to this account, it is the old-time leaders in the Senate who are most restive under the continuance of Mr. BRYAN'S influence.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 24 -- Assemblyman Weekes's bill to amend the primary election law is attracting a good deal of attention from the politicians, in view of the understanding that it is the one bill of all the primary bills introduced which is to be put through.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Major Richard Sylvester, Chief of Police, has received through the German Ambassador, Dr. von Holleben, a gift from Prince Henry of Prussia, in recognition of attentions extended to him by the Police Department during his visits to Washington. The gift is a silver cigarette holder, studded with miniature diamonds.

We learn from Albany that the amendments proposed by the Committee on Rules of the Assembly go much beyond what has been published in the press dispatches. They purpose to allow the continuation of the worst features of the old rookeries, which we all thought had been abolished forever.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Major Richard Sylvester, Chief of Police, has received through the German Ambassador, Dr. von Holleben, a gift from Prince Henry of Prussia, in recognition of attentions extended to him by the Police Department during his visits to Washington. The gift is a silver cigarette holder, studded with miniature diamonds.

We learn from Albany that the amendments proposed by the Committee on Rules of the Assembly go much beyond what has been published in the press dispatches. They purpose to allow the continuation of the worst features of the old rookeries, which we all thought had been abolished forever.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Washington Jockey Club will inaugurate its annual Spring meeting at the Bennings race track to-morrow. Many of the well-known stables throughout the country are represented. Following are the entries:

The bill providing the annual appro- priation for the Military Academy was announced to come up yesterday before the House Military Committee. The bill is of unusual importance this year, for the reason that no adequate legislative provision has yet been made for the enlargement of the Academy's "plant," to conform to the authorized enlargement in the number of cadets.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- That Ambassador White's tenure of office is drawing to a close is now a certainty, in spite of statements to the contrary. He will resign the German Embassy within about two months. Dr. White has himself made this statement to a friend.

In weather which was almost Summer-like the baseball season of 1902 was begun yesterday afternoon on Manhattan Field. Twelve of the twenty-three players who are under contract to the New York Baseball Club reported for practice and were greeted by Secretary-Treasurer Knowles and Manager Horace Fogel.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A conference was held at the White House this afternoon between the President and seven of the Republican members of the House of Representatives who have been foremost in opposing the plan of Cuban reciprocity urged by the Ways and Means Committee and understood to have the support of the Administration.

LONDON, March 26 -- The Constantinople correspondent of The Times says that Germany is manifesting eagerness in regard to the proposed unification of the Turkish debt. The German Ambassador tells the Sultan that, considering the immense advantages of the unification offer, the Porte is ill-advised in wasting time by bargaining over terms.

Yale and Harvard graduate teams played a tie game of hockey at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening, finishing even with three goals for each team. The game was the last exhibition of hockey that will be seen in the rink this season, for the skating year will come to a close on Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Weather conditions here to-day could not have been more favorable for the opening of the Bennings Spring race meeting, while the attendance was the largest ever seen at the track. About forty books were on hand eager to lay odds, and the speculators kept them busy throughout the afternoon.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Compromise Judiciary bill, advocated by Gov. Odell, and introduced by Senator Brackett, was passed by the Senate this evening, there being a party division on the roll call, the vote being 30 to 14.
