The bill will go to the Assembly, and it is expected that it will be passed there to-morrow morning, and will be in the Governor's hands to-morrow afternoon.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Senator Marshall to-day suffered the most crushing defeat of the session on his bill to amend the labor law so as to permit women over twenty-one years of age to work in factories at night. The bill in its original form raised the number of hours women might work in a day, but this provision was stricken out.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Another conference was held at the White House to-night on the subject of Cuban reciprocity, and was participated in by the President and the House leaders, including Chairman Payne and Messrs. Daizell and Long of Kansas of the Ways and Means Committee, and Mr. Cannon, the Chairman of the Republican caucus.

The North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse sailed for Europe yesterday morning with every cabin taken. The departure of the great ship, carrying as she did so many prominent people, was the occasion of the most demonstrative scene witnessed so far this year on the pier of an outgoing steamship.

LONDON, March 26 -- The Times summarizes the conclusions reached by Jonathan Hutchinson, M.D., F.R.S., consulting surgeon to the London Hospital, who has been studying the local diffusion of leprosy in South Africa. Dr. Hutchinson visited the two large leper asylums in that part of the world, and also studied the domestic conditions of victims in many districts.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- A renewal of the demand for Union Traction, suggestive of the buying which culminated just before the merger plans were announced, was the feature of the local market. The activity was stimulated by purchases for inside interests, and the price again crossed 40, at which point some holders were ready to take profits.

-- A mysterious organization which for mysterious reasons calls itself "The American Society of Freedom" devoted several hours of its more or less valuable time Sunday night to hearing the Rev. Dr. H.D. VON BROEKHUIZEN rehearse his familiar calumnies against the British soldiers in South Africa.
LONDON, March 25 -- King Edward's cutter Britannia and Emperor William's new schooner Meteor will both race off the Isle of Wight during the Cowes regatta.

District Attorney Jerome and his assistant, Mr. Sandford, took an active part in the closing flay of the trial of Policemen Burke and Reid of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station before Commissioner Partridge at Headquarters yesterday on charges of attempted bribery and neglect of duty. At the close Col. Partridge announced that he would reserve his decision.

Second Lieut. William C. Fitzpatrick, Seventh Infantry, will report to Col. Charles A. Coolidge, President of the Examining Board convened at Vancouver Barracks for instructions relating to his examination to determine his fitness for promotion.

Officials of the rapid transit subway were kept busy yesterday with their work of remedying the Park Avenue cave-in, and the residents of Murray Hill were equally well occupied in their efforts to cast discredit on everybody connected with the subway. The officials determined upon a solution of the difficulties incident upon the cave-in, and the residents held a meeting at which speeches and resolutions of a bitter character were applauded vociferously.
LONDON, March 26 -- The Chief Secretary for Ireland, George Wyndham, introduced the Irish Land bill in the House of Commons yesterday.

Some of the plans of the promoters of the New York City Interborough Railway Company, which was incorporated at Albany on Monday, with a capital of $400,000, were learned yesterday. Thomas J. Brady, head of the Building Department, said:
It is announced that Elsie Leslie has been asked to play Ophelia in William Gillett's presentation of "Hamlet" next season.

For the first time in the history of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States collegians contested with representatives of outside athletic associations last night in the annual National gymnastic championship contests which were decided in the spacious gymnasium of the new Polo Athletic Association, at One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Park Avenue.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Senate to-day passed Senator Stranahan's bill to amend the rapid transit law so as to give the Rapid Transit Commission jurisdiction over the proposed Pennsylvania tunnel. The vote on the bill was 33 yeas to 11 nays. The bill was advanced out of its order on an emergency message from the Governor.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., March 25 -- The Common Council, after an all-night session, this morning awarded a contract to the Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company to supply this city with pure water to be obtained from a power canal to be constructed from the Niagara River to this city.
LONDON, March 26 -- The Duveens have bought the Gerleos collection of Limoges enamels at Madrid for 1,300,000 pesetas, ($285,000.)

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The beet-sugar men rallied their forces again to-day and, under the guise of a compromise, tried to get the Ways and Means leaders to assent to one of their old propositions -- the scheme for taking off the differential protection on refined sugar. This scheme was brought up by Mr. Morris of Minneapolis in the Republican conference on the Cuban reciprocity question.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 25 -- Judge John F. Philips, in the United States District Court, here, to-day, issued a temporary restraining order against eight Chicago-Kansas City and Kansas City-St. Louis railroads, on the application of Judge W.A. Day counsel for the Inter-State Commerce Commission, who asked that the roads be enjoined from deviating from published schedules.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Secretary Root this afternoon made public an order to Gen. Wood, directing him to turn over the government of Cuba to its people on May 20 next. The order requires the Cuban Government to assume all treaty obligations, and directs Gen. Wood to continue an artillery force of 800 men, to avoid leaving the island entirely defenseless, until the Cuban Government shall have opportunity to organize its own force.

The second night of the Military Show at Madison Square Garden drew even a larger crowd than on the opening night. Mayor Low, escorted by the Ninth Regiment, N.G.W.Y., supplemented by regulars and officers of the Forty-eighth Highlanders, Canadian Militia, arrived early in the evening, and was heartily cheered by the spectators.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The House to-day, by a vote of 137 to 127, unseated Mr. Rhea of Kentucky, a Democrat, and seated in his place J. McKenzie Moss, who was formerly a Democrat, but who, according to his brief, is in accord with the Republican Party on the dominant issues. The Republican majority in the House is 43.

BALTIMORE, March 25 -- The jump of 2 1/4 points in Light and Power preferred to-day revived the belief that either some deal is on between Consolidated Gas and the Electric Company, or else that the Susquehanna Company of which Light and Power will be the selling agent if the plans are consummated, is nearing a stage in its affairs which promises success in the end.

KANSAS CITY, March 25 -- Celebrated wing shots who will participate in the Grand American Handicap in this city next week are beginning to arrive. The 437 entries already received insure a purse of $10,925 for the Grand American Handicap. This will be divided among sixty-three men. The three high men will receive $1,500, of which the first man will receive $600, the second $500, and the third $400.

A raid in which a large number of alleged bettors were captured and five prisoners taken away in a patrol wagon attracted a crowd in front of 117 Nassau Street yesterday afternoon that completely filled up that narrow thoroughfare. The raid was made by Anthony Comstock, assisted by five officers from the Oak Street Station, on Rooms 28 and 29, on the fourth floor of that building.

LONDON, March 23 -- The monetary conditions were practically unchanged to-day. Business on the Stock Exchange was quiet, and there was an indisposition to operate, in view of the approach of the Easter holidays. Prices were firm, owing to the hopeful outlook for peace in South Africa.

The announcement by the Mayor that he was in communication with the Governor from Saturday evening last in regard to the Pennsylvania Railroad improvement matter, and that the course adopted by the Mayor was in accordance with the views of the Governor, is naturally reassuring.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS " for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $2,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President-elect Thomas Estrada Palma of Cuba left here at midnight for his New York home, where he will remain until the last of April, when he will leave New York for Santiago province, in which he will spend a few days, going thnce to Havana to be inaugurated May 20.
ALBANY, March 25 -- The following statement of the result of this year's legislation was issued to-day by the Republican leaders:

There were a few informal dinners last evening, and a few meetings of sewing classes during the afternoon. Of social incidents there were none. The Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse went out with a number of people. To-day will be another blank socially. There will be no meeting of the Knickerbocker Bowling Club, neither will the Wednesday Amusement Club assemble in the evening.

The meeting of the Committee on Conciliation of the Civic Federation to consider the labor troubles in the anthracite coal fields will begin to-day in the Mission Building, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, at 10:30 A.M. Senator Hanna, who will preside, arrived here last evening from Washington by the Congressional limited, and went to the Waldorf-Astoria, accompanied by Ralph M. Easley, Secretary of the Civic Federation, who met him at the train.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A sharp attack on the pending Oleomargarine bill was made in the Senate to-day by Mr. Money of Mississippi. He denounced the measure as "unconstitutional, immoral, dishonest, and unjust." He said it was a proposition to tax out of existence one industry for the benefit of another, and was "protection gone mad."
The fifth evening concert of the Kneisel Quartet of Boston took place last night at Mendelssohn Hall. The programme was as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senate Bill No. 1,145, introduced by Mr. Krum "To amend the tax law in relation to the payment of State fees and taxes by corporations," is reported to have passed the Senate yesterday. The bill appears to us to be objectionable on the grounds of justice and expediency.

, March 25 -- The advocates of Canal legislation made their final stand hero to-day, but gave up the fight after a conference with Gov. Odell, when he announced that he was unable to aid them to get a vote on the Davis bill. The canal delegation, which came hero from New York, flooded the capital with circulars attacking the Committee on Rules for refusing to report out the Davis bill.

AMSTERDAM, March 25 -- Abraham Fischer, one of the Boer delegates, in an interview to-day grave a variety of reasons why the Boers in the field should be in a mood to continue the war rather than accept terms less advantageous than those previously demanded. He quoted the latest report from Mr. Steyn, under date of Feb. 13, which said:

Otto G. Mayer Co., shipping and commission merchants' at 44 to 48 Cedar Street, one of the oldest houses in their line of business, who have been in liquidation for some months past, will not be able, it is said, to pay in full, and their affairs are to be settled up in the bankruptcy court.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- The management of the Rock Island Road practically has determined to spend in the neighborhood of $2,000,000 to build ten new trains for the Chicago-California service through El Paso. The new trains will be delivered to the Southern Pacific at El Paso, and from there on Southern Pacific engineers and Southern Pacific crews will operate them.

Officials of the Evansville and Terre Haute Railroad Company who had declined on Monday to discuss the reports about mismanagement of the affairs of the railroad were persuaded yesterday to make the following statement, which was given out by W.F. Carlton, President of the Board of Directors:

We have great sympathy with Col. WATTERSON in the effort which he pursued at the dinner of the Virginia Democratic Association in Washington on Tuesday evening to provide the Democratic Party with a rational and patriotic and winning issue. So are the hundreds of thousands of voters who are earnestly endeavoring to be Democrats, but who find themselves baffled by the management of the party and forced to vote the Republican ticket at National elections.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 23 -- Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock of New York has rented of Mrs. Sallie Hargous Elliot the latter's cottage on Belleville Avenue for the coming Summer. Mrs. Hitchcock has occupied for the past several Summers the Chanler villa on the Cliffs, which Winthrop Chanler has remodeled and is now occupying.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Gov. Odell said this evening that he was considering a plan for expediting a final decision in the DikeGuden controversy over the office of Sheriff of Kings County. The Governor said he had in mind the calling of a special session of the Appellate Division to sit in Brooklyn for the purpose of passing upon the case.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Mayor Low's socalled "sweep" bill passed the Assembly to-day by a vote of 93 to 49. An amendment to protect veteran soldiers from the provisions of the act was defeated by a vote of 84 to 49. The measure was debated at some length. It was opposed by two Republicans, Mr. Allen of the Ninth District of New York and Mr. Blackwell of Brooklyn.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 25 -- In a suit for the possession of forty acres of accretion land lying south of the Missouri River in Kansas City, Kan., valued at $200,000, S.K. Howe, an old fisherman, secured a verdict in the District Court last night against the Armour Packing Company and the Chicago Great Western Railway Company.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- The jury appointed to select a design for the proposed Soldiers and Sailors' Monument to be erected in Logan Square to-day reported to the Monument Committee of Councils that the first prize should be awarded to Lord Hewlett of New York. The committee approved the selection, and will report to Councils, recommending that the firm be employed as architects to supervise the erection of the monument.

As after to-day and to-morrow the Stock Exchange takes a holiday till Monday, traders on the board regard a narrow market as natural. In yesterday's course of prices there was the exhibit, recently the rule, of specialties active and moving while standard stocks lagged.

BOSTON, Mass., March 25 -- Money rates, bank clearances, and balances reported to-day as follows: Clearing House rate, 3 per cent. New York funds par. Call loan, 4 to 5 per cent. Time money, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Clearing House exchanges, $24,509,776; balances, $1,779,277. The stock market was uninteresting.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 25 -- The report of Patrick W. Cullinan, State Commissioner of Excise, has been transmitted to the Legislature. The transactions for the year ended Sept. 30, 1901, show the total amount collected to be $12,467,674. Of this amount the State's share was $4,198,377,09, and the cities' and towns' share was $8,126,669,05.
CHICAGO, March 25 -- H. Clay Read of Big Springs, Texas, a mining man, has laid the needs of the Texas town before Mayor Harrison in the following letter:...

The latest accident resulting from the furious driving of an automobile occurred in New Jersey. The peccant machine and driver were those of Mr. GEORGE J. GOULD, though Mr. GOULD was not himself present. The general recklessness with which the machines are driven has inculcated in most people the dread of them expressed the other day by Magistrate CRANE.

It is evident from the conference between the President and the opponents in the House of the concession to Cuba that Mr. ROOSEVELT is going very carefully over the ground to see if some agreement cannot be reached which will substantially meet the tremendous responsibility resting on the Government of the United States.

With new scenic and electrical effects, Proctor's Fifty-eighth Street house is both worse and better than was to have been expected. That it is interlarded with vaudeville turns, and ends in a blaze of electric lights and fireworks, may be regarded as neither here nor there. It should be judged, if at all, by the acting.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Indications multiply that the leading Democrats of the South are determined to break away from the policies on which the party has met defeat and insist on a progressive and upto-date policy. A number of the Southern Democrats in the Senate, men of unquestioned party regularity, have clearly indicated this purpose in private conversation.

WILKESBARRE, March 25 -- Mayor Francis Marion Nichols, who for twelve years has been chief magistrate of this city and goes out of office on April 1, gave out his farewell address to the citizens this evening. He said:

Lawyer Albert T. Patrick, for the past nine weeks on trial, charged with the murder of Millionaire William Marsh Rice, on Sept. 23, 1900, was found guilty late yesterday afternoon by the jury after less than two hours, deliberation -- the record lime in this county for arriving at a verdict in a criminal case of this importance.

Five men alleged to have conducted a counterfeiting plant at Corona, L.I., which was the marvel of all who saw it because of the completeness of its equipment, were arraigned before Commissioner Benedict in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday morning and were held in $5,000 bail each for examination next Monday.

At Jasper Oval yesterday the Manhattan College baseball team defeated the Yale University nine by a score of 5 to 3, and by doing so evened up for the victory of the Sons of Eli over the New York boys at New Haven last Saturday, when the Manhattan team was beaten 3 to 2.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- The field of operations in the local market was wider to-day, and prices were generally better, but in no stock was there large trading. An exception to the general trend was Asphalt. Nearly $100,000 par value of the American 5s were sold, opening at 30 1/4 getting down to 29 and closing at 30.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 26 -- Princeton won the eighth annual debate against Harvard to-night in Sanders Theatre on the question. "Resolved, That Mayor Low should strictly enforce the excise laws in New York City." The decision of the judges was unanimous, and they were out only two minutes.

The Colorado and Southern has been bought by a syndicate composed of Edwin Hawley and his friends. This announcement, made yesterday, accounts for the recent rise in the common stock of the road, which went up from somewhere near 12 to 28.
Much interest attaches to the result of the popular vote to be taken in Chicago on the 1st of April on certain questions of public policy, including the following:

LONDON, March 20 -- Money was much wanted to-day for settlement payments, though the pressure did not equal expectations. The uncertainty of the monetary outlook limited the discount business. Rates were easier, owing to the strength of the Continental rates of exchange.

It may assist Gov. ODELL in determining what may be his duty toward any bill passed by the Legislature subversive of the esential provisions of the Tenement House act of last year, if he will give thoughtful consideration to a few simple propositions which may be stated in few words.

Mayor Low, Borough President Cantor, and Jacob H. Schiff spoke last night at the dedication exercises of the Lucas A. Steinam School of Metal Working, at 225 East Ninth Street, which has been erected for the Hebrew Technical Institute by Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Steinam in memory of their son, Lucas.
Joel Tuttle has been appointed Des Moines agent of the Travelers' Insurance Company of Hartford.

--It was bad enough when a New York policeman arrested and carried off to an ordinary police station like an ordinary, lawbreaker the bearer of a name no less than "Havemeyer," doing it, too, with no better excuse than the trivial fact that Mr. HAVEMEYER had found it convenient to run his automobile through the city streets at a speed forbidden by a municipal ordinance.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The political suggestions made by Senator Clay of Georgia, in the interview reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of to-day, seem to interest a good many persons in Washington. Members of Congress from the South are interested especially in Mr. Clay's talk about the opportunity for usefulness that, according to his philosophy, now confronts the Southern Democrats.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Throughout to-day's session of the Senate the Oleomargarine bill was under discussion. Mr. Hansbrough of North Dakota concluded his speech begun yesterday in support of the measure, maintaining that the oleo industry had been outlawed by the Legislatures of many States, and that it ought to be compelled by Congress to take off its mask and place its product on the market for what it really was.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- General debate on the Military Appropriation bill was concluded to-day and consideration of the bill under the five-minute rule begun. The provision limiting the longevity pay for retired army officers to the sum allowed and paid at the date of retirement went out on a point of order.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The Assembly today passed the Krum bill to amend the tax law in relation to the payment of State fees and taxes by corporations. The bill was vigorously attacked by Assemblyman Fitzgerald, who charged that it was a measure designed to exempt the Metropolitan Street Railway Company and the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company from a large amount of the taxes which they at present pay to the State.
LONDON, March 26 -- The House of Commons, after a brief session to-day adjourned until April 7 for the Easter holidays.

De Wolf Hopper, Shepherd of the Lambs Club, announced last night that the publicity and misunderstanding that have arisen over the performance of "Nazareth" last Sunday evening precipitated matters regarding the building of a new clubhouse for the organization.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- The final steps in the formation of the National Millers' Federation, representing a total capital of $400,000,000 and an annual flour output of 100,000,000 barrels, were taken at a meeting held here to-day. The federation is the National organization of the various State associations, and in addition it will include the National Millers' Association and the National Winter Wheat Millers' Association.
There is the suggestion of a big Easter garden party up town, where all the smartest gowns sold by French modistes to smart New Yorkers are on exhibition in one of the large shops.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The first speech made at this session on the Schley case was made to-day by Representative Breazeale of Louisiana. He criticised the Naval Affairs Committee for suppressing the numerous resolutions offered in Congress in behalf of Admiral Schley, and he also criticised the President's decision on Admiral Schley's appeal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to call attention to the latest effort at Albany to degrade the judiciary of the State. By the bill introduced in the Senate yesterday, reported at once, and evidently to be hurried through in the confusion of the closing hours of the session, the very worst of the series of the acts offered since Jan. 1 is presented for passage.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- In a long report to the State Department on "The Manufacture and Technical Uses of Alcohol in Germany," Frank H. Mason, United States Consul General in Berlin, after referring to the alcohol exposition recently held in Berlin, says:

Trading in the outside market yesterday was fairly active, but prices were irregular. In several issues there were further sharp advances in quotations, but in many parts of the list a reactionary tendency appeared. Business in Colorado Fuel bonds was more than usually heavy, and was accompanied by a sharp advance.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The Stranahan bill, amending the rapid transit law so as to permit the Rapid Transit Board to have control of the franchise for the building of the proposed Pennsylvania Railroad tunnel, passed the Assembly to-day by a vote of 96 to 39. The measure passed the Senate yesterday. The bill called forth some harsh criticism from the Democratic side and protests from three Republican members, Messrs, Newcomb, Allen, and Bennet.

The Board of Estimate met yesterday afternoon and Considered the budgets of several of the city departments. The first estimate considered was that of Commissioner J. Hampden Dousherty of the Department of Water, Gas and Electricity. Commissioner Dougherty asked for an increase of $164,955 over the amount allowed by the former Board of Estimate, which was $4,341,741.90.

BOSTON, March 26 -- While rates for money are holding firm there is as yet no general disposition to mark them up still higher, although this may come during the next few days. The banks are still supplying all requisite needs quite freely, and the best opinion still holds to the belief that no serious "squeeze" is ahead.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- On the parapet encircling the dome of the Capitol, 375 feet above the level of the street, there appeared at 12:50 o'clock to-day two police officers. Immediately after them a young man, somewhat flushed and out of breath from his long climb, emerged, and then turned to give a helping hand to a young woman, still rosier and still more breathless.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the article in to-day's issue headed "Heavy Broadway Blasting," Division Engineer Value defends Messrs. Farrell, Hopper Co. for the manner in whish they perform their work.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The Sheehan Democracy has requested a hearing upon the Weekes Primary Election bill, which is now before the Governor. The Governor has decided to grant the hearing. It will be held either on April 6 or 7.

The Conciliation Committee of the National Civic Federation heard the miners side of the trouble in the anthracite coal district yesterday forenoon in the Mission Building, 281 Fourth Avenue, this being the first regular meeting of the committee. The conference will be resumed this forenoon and will be attended by all the principal operators or their representatives, as well as by the representatives of the United Mine Workers.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "P.S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3.000.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The Senate to-day passed the Finch bill to make a preferred jury list of citizens in New York City who fail to register. It is understood that the Governor favors the measure and that it will receive his signature.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The report of the House Committee on the Chinese Exclusion bill was filed to-day by Representative Perkins of New York, who drafted it. The report says in part:

MARCONI'S system renders possible the realization of the prediction that the time would come when daily newspapers would be published on the ocean liners. There would seem to be no good reason now why the steamers equipped with Marconi apparatus should not issue printed news bulletins recording happenings of importance on both sides of the ocean, together with items relative to the day's run and such announcements as are of interest to passengers.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 20 -- Manager Ed Barrow of the Toronto baseball team, has received a letter from an official of the New York Baseball Club offering him the managership of that team in the National League. Barrow is under contract with Toronto for this season, but it is un- derstood that if he can secure his release he will accept the New York offer.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Ways and Means Committee is getting ready to do something with the Cuban relief question. It is understood that just as soon as Mr. Grosvenor gets back to Washington the committee will be called together and asked to order a favorable report on the Payne bill, giving the Cubans 20 per cent. off the tariff rates for a year and ten months.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 26 -- The second, day of the trial of Mrs. May Fenton Haines, who is accused of the murder of her two-year-old stepdaughter Gwendolyn, attracted such a large audience that the court officers had difficulty in forcing a way for the accused to her seat. Mrs. Haines was accompanied by her mother, her husband, and her two-year-old son, and she again brought her six-months-old baby into the courtroom.

Expecting to witness the novelty of seeing J. Pierppnt Morgan on the witness stand, a large audience gathered in the Circuit Court room pf the Post Office Building yesterday for the hearing in the case of Peter Power against the Northern Securities Company, the object of the suit being to dissolve the merger of the Northern Pacific and Great Northern Railroads.

Mr. RHODES was a typical "Captain of Industry." He was so typical as to illustrate the confusion which was said to have overcome some of Prince HENRY'S traveling companions between a "captain" and a "chevalier" of that excellent quality. That is to say, he was a man of great energy, of large conceptions, and of little scruple.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 26 -- Copies of the complaint in the case of the State of Washington against the Northern Securities Company have been served upon the officers of the Great Northern and Northern Pacific, and mailed east to the officers of the Securities Company.
Nothing could be more exemplary or of better augury for the future of Cuba than the fate of the three postal thieves who have been fairly tried and justly condemned by a Cuban tribunal.

Pease Elliman have sold for the Crocker estate, to Royal Phelps Carroll, the five-story American basement dwelling, 11 East Forty-ninth Street, 22 by 100.5, one of the row erected by Charles Buck on part of the old Columbia College block.

From present indications the work of excavating the foundation for the new Astor Hotel in Long Acre Square, between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets on Broadway, may be retarded some months because of the presence of a three-story building on the ground where the excavations are to be made.

LONDON, March 27 -- Commenting on the "absurd speculations and conjectures" regarding the Boer leaders' mission that are being published in the French capital, the Paris correspondent of The Times says that those who produce them are as ignorant as the public for whom they are written.

In one of the roughest and hardest-fought games of the season and before a crowd of hockey enthusiasts which literally packed the Clermont Avenue Ice Skating Rink to the doors last night, the hockey team of the Crescent Athletic Club won the championship of the Amateur, Hockey League from the New York Athletic Club by the decisive score of 5 to 1.

LONDON, March 27 -- Commenting on the "absurd speculations and conjectures" regarding the Boer leaders' mission that are being published in the French capital, the Paris correspondent of The Times says that those who produce them are as ignorant as the public for whom they are written.

Whether well-considered and intelligently executed measures of public sanitation "pay" in cities is a question which would seem to be answered very specifically in the case of Havana. Under the military administration of Cuba such changes have been introduced in the municipal sanitation of Havana as were deemed practicable, in view of local habits and the improbability of anything like intelligent co-operation on the part of the Spanish population.
Contract Surgeon Louis A. Spaeth, now at Fort Sheridan, is relieved from further duty in the Division of the Philippines, and will proceed to Jersey City for annulment of the contract.

BOSTON, March 26 -- There has been introduced in the State Legislature by the Bank Commissioners a bill which provides that ten or more persons, one-half of them residents pf the city or town where the bank is to be located, may become a banking corporation. Among the provisions of the measure are these:

The announcement that two British, or at least "Colonial," officers have been shot in South Africa, by direction of Lord KITCHENER, after trial by court-martial, is of high importance. There is no doubt that the execution of the Boer commander, SCHEEPERS, affected very unfavorably foreign observers who are by no means prone to put the worst construction upon British official actions in South Africa.

ALBANY, March 27. -- Under an emergency message from Gov. Odell, the Senate this morning concurred in the amendments made to the New York Tenement House bill by the Assembly, and passed the measure. Previous to the final action amendments to the bill were offered by Senators Audett, Wagner, and Hennessy.

LONDON, March 28. -- Much comment, says the Tokio correspondent of The Times, has been caused by the omission of any mention of Korea in the second part of the Franco-Russian declaration. From this it is inferred that Russia is left to deal single-handed with the Korean problem.

Justices Hinsdale, Wyatt, and Mayor, Justice Hinsdale presiding, listened yesterday in Special Sessions to testimony that may mean the reconsideration of the cases of several young men who are now serving sentences in the penitentiary for stealing copper wire from the New York Telephone Company.

BOSTON, March 27. -- Money holds firm, Clearing House rate, 3 per cent. New York funds par. Call loans, 4 to 5. Time money, 4 to 5. Exchanges, $19,554,549; balances, $1,610,127. An active demand for African and Continental Zinc, which lifted the former from 10 1/4 to 13 and the latter to 4 1/2, was the noteworthy feature of to-day's stock trading.
WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Following is a statement made by Niels Gron regarding the Christmas statement:

BALTIMORE, Md., March 27. -- The local market to-day was virtually flat there being nothing in the semblance of a feature except the slight lift in Light and Power preferred. It is said the Susquehanna Company will buy this preferred stock at 50, and will pay the United Railways $1,250,000 for its $2,000,000 holdings of common stock.

Major Gen. Henry C. Corbin, Adjutant General of the United States Army, was the reviewing officer last night at the military show in the Madison Square Garden. In the reviewing box with him were Gen. Byrd S. Spencer, Col. George R. Dyer, Jr., Lieut. Cornelius Vanderbilt, and Lieut. Col. Johnson of the Twelfth Regiment.

UTICA, N.Y., March 27. -- That an inventor has no redress against the Federal Government in patent infringement cases was decided to-day by Judge Coxe in a suit brought by the International Postals Supply Company of New York against Postmaster Bruce of Syracuse and the American Postal Machine Company.

ALBANY, March 27. -- Promptly following the adjournment of the Legislature to-day, Gov. Odell expressed himself as greatly pleased with the results achieved in the course of the session of 1902. The Governor said that while much meritorious legislation had been accomplished, he regarded the abolishment of the direct State tax, except that tax required by law for canal purposes, as the principal achievement.

Lawyer Albert T. Patrick, convicted on Thursday of the murder of William Marsh Rice, had lost none of his air of confidence and seemed not to be unduly downcast at his conviction when seen yesterday in the counsel room of the Tombs.

The Century Realty Company has sold, through Louis J. Du Mahaut, 11 and 13 East Thirty-second Street, a plot 50 by 98.9, to Campbell Clement, builders, who will erect thereon a twelve-story apartment hotel. The operation, including the cost of the building, will involve about $600,000.

The Stock Exchange adjourned yesterday without having been under the depressing influence of the much-predicted "flurry in money." Indeed, in Wall Street the day was without exceptional incident of any sort. Transactions fell below half a million shares, and stocks that fluctuated as much as a whole point made a very short list, being, however, chiefly advances.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 27. -- The prosecution in the trial of Mrs. May Fenton Haines, charged with the murder of her two-year-old stepdaughter, Gwendolyn, closed its case to-day, and the defense began calling witnesses. Counsel for the prisoner entered a general denial of the charges against Mrs. Haines, and added that he would prove that the defendant loved the child as though it were her own.
LONDON, March 27. -- Moderate relief in the money market is anticipated on Saturday, with considerable Government disbursements. Discounts to-day were steady.
LONDON, March 28. -- A. memorial service in honor of Cecil Rhodes will be held in St Paul's Cathedral on April 10.

The tournament of the Fire Insurance Bowling League was concluded last night, the Norwich Union team winning first place with sixteen games won and three lost. The Hanover team is second and the Federal third. Martin of the Home Fire Insurance Company wins first individual prize with an average of 187.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The State Department denied emphatically to-day that Capt. Christmas acted for this Government in the negotiations for file purchase of the Danish West Indies, and denied also that he was recognized in any way by the State Department as the representative of the Danish Government.
Col. William F. Spurgin is relieved from recruiting duty at Omaha, Neb., to take effect March 31, when he will proceed to join his regiment.

WASHINGTON, D.C., March 27. -- Jockey Wonderly's riding was the only feature of a tame afternoon's racing at Bennings to-day. Of five mounts he rode three winners and two placed horses. The talent picked only two first horses, Water Alone and Bastile, the latter being odds-on. Weather clear. Track fast.

The significance of the provisions of the Krum corporation tax measure, which is now in the hands of the Governor, according to an analysis made yesterday by a lawyer who was connected for many years with the State Controller's office, and who is a recognized authority in corporation tax measures, is as follows:

The engagement is announced of Miss Beatrice de Trobriand Post, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Post, (Marie C. de Trobriand,) and Duncan W. Candler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Flamen Ball Candler, (M. Lillian Welch.) Miss Post is the elder sister of Miss Edith Church Post, whose engagement to Goelet Gallatin has just been announced.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 27. -- The engagement was announced at St. Augustine to-day of Miss Estelle Willoughby, daughter of Hugh L. Willoughby of Newport, to Clayton Dixon, son of H.P. Dixon of Philadelphia and a representative of an old Quaker family. Mr. Dixon is a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania.

Telegraphic advices from London are to the effect that the leading ironmasters of England are in negotiation with the ironmasters of the Continent looking to the formation of "a gigantic combination to maintain prices, in view of the American demand for pig iron." In the existing circumstances the organizers of the trust to make American buyers of foreign material "pay through the nose" express themselves as confi- dent of success.

The absence of the bonds of the Colorado Fuel Company, which yesterday were transferred to the Stock Exchange, considerably decreased the transactions in the market for outside securities. No other issue approached the activity which had been shown by these bonds, and even in other parts of the list there was a falling off from the totals shown early in the week.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment considered the budget for the Charities. Correction, and Health Departments at the session held yesterday. Commissioner Homer Folks asked for nearly $500,000 more than was allowed for the work of the Charities Department by the old Board of Estimate.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and " R S " for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27. -- Extensive dealings in Reading common gave the local market a cheerful tone to-day. The steam roads advanced, and Union Traction sold up to 41, the highest since December, 1899. Philadelphia Traction, Philadelphia Company, Electric Company of America, Consolidated Lake Superior common, and Electric Storage Battery were higher.

ST. LOUIS, March 27. -- Emil A. Meysenburg, capitalist and politician and an ex-member of the City Council, has been convicted on a charge of acception a bribe, and sentenced to three years in the penitentiary at Jefferson City. The jury in the first of the bribery cases to, go to trial retired at 6 o'clock, and at 6:55 returned a verdict.

At the second night's sale of modern paintings belonging to Prinz Brothers, held last night at James P. Silo's Fifth Avenue Art Galleries, sixty-five paintings brought $27,120, making a total for the entire sale of 129 paintings of $45,375.

While a crowded car of the Third Avenue surface trolley line in the Borough of the Bronx was proceeding south at 3:30 o'oclock yesterday afternoon the passengers noticed a well-dressed man with a Van Dyke beard staring rather rudely at another man who sat opposite and whose face was covered with little lumps.

That the session of the Legislature which came to an end yesterday was the shortest on record is a fact which the majority of the voters of the State will doubtless impute to the Legislature for righteousness.

Two witnesses were recalled for examination in the Peter Power suit against the Northern Securities Company yesterday, and, after hearing their testimony, the commission took an adjournment to an unnamed date. John S. Kennedy was on the stand for a few moments, and then Col. W. B. Clough, Fourth Vice President of the Northern Securities Company, was asked several questions, one of which he refused to answer.
VIENNA, March 27. -- Miss Ellen M. Stone, the American missionary, passed through Vienna to-night on her way to London.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The Controller of the Currency to-day mailed to all the National banks throughout the country a duplicate set of blanks tor reports, with a circular letter requesting them to preserve the blanks for use in forwarding their reports immediately upon notice through the press that a call for a report had been made by the Controller, without awaiting the receipt of the usual notice and blanks by mail.

TRENTON, N.J., March 27. -- It was 10:30 o'clock to-night when the Legislature carried out its programme of adjourning sine die, although the resolution providing for final adjournment fixed the time for 3 o'clock this afternoon.

ALBANY, March 27. -- In the Senate today the Adler bill, to allow the opening of butcher shops on Sunday morning up to 10 o'clock in the Summer months, was defeated. Senator Ellsworth, the Republican leader of the Senate, led the opposition to the measure. Senator Ellsworth had the assistance of Senator Grady, the minority leader, in his opposition.

The special message which the President has sent to Congress in regard to Cuba is for the most part, we will not say perfunctory, but concerned with matters as to which there is no difference of opinion, and with which Congress will doubtless deal promptly in accordance with his suggestions.

Any one having a jail-new or second hand -- which he is anxious to dispose of may hear of something to his advantage by communicating with one Charles Guden, by grace of Justice Gaynor Sheriff of Kings County. Mr. Guden is looking for a jail; he needs one in his business. Just now he is losing sleep nights worrying over the possibility of somebody committing a prisoner to his care.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The President this afternoon sent to Congress a message recommending provision for diplomatic and consular representation in Cuba. The message was read in the Senate and referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations. The text follows:

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 27. -- A meeting of the official board of the Methodist Episcopal Church was held here yesterday to take steps to retains the pastor, the Rev. Jesse L. Hurlbut, and avoid a factional fight over his resignation.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The House to-day without a dissenting vote decided to investigate the charges made by Capt. Walter Christmas that, while promoting the sale of the Danish West Indies to this country, he had made corrupt contracts to the extent of $500,000 with members of Congress and other persons.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- It was thought to-day that the report was premature that Representative Babcock had foresworn allegiance to Oxnard, and joined tlie ranks of those gentlemen of the Ways and Means Committee who desire that the Payne Cuban Relief bill shall not be contaminated by an amendment abolishing the differential on refined sugar.

NEW HAVEN, March 28 -- More baseball grounds are a great need at Yale Field just at present, and steps will be taken in the near future to secure them. The university and freshman diamonds are entirely inadequate to meet the demand which will be made by the class teams this Spring, and as soon as the ground is in the right condition two new fields will be laid out.

Prof. Hamilton has made another contribution to American philosophy in his new book, "The Moral Law," an ethical text book on the theory and practice of duty. This certainly stamps him as an independent and original thinker, even more than his former treatises. His first book, "The Human Mind," introduced marked advances in epistemology.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Sundry Civil Appropriation bill, the most important of the Government supply measures, was completed to-day by the House Committee on Appropriations. The bill appropriates $49,316,395, being $12,463,042 less than the regular and supplemental estimates, and $12,579,512 less than the appropriations for the current fiscal year.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Gov. Odell spent today in going over the Supply and Appropriation bills. The Governor has the privilege of striking from these bills any items of which he disapproves without invalidating the bills. He said to-night that he would exercise his privilege in a number of instances.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- In a report on import trade in Greece, United States Consul Daniel E. McGinley, at Athens, controverts allegations made in an article published by the German press, which he says was full of mis-statements. The report says:

The New York Times Saturday Revieve of Books: Editorially you ask to-day, "Who reads a real book now?" and quote Ruskin's dictum that the English public of his day was incapable of understanding any thoughtful writing by reason of its "insanity of avarice."

The back of tie scarab was nearly always cut in the form of a beetle, hence the name, from the Greek word signifying beetle. They were mode of pottery or engraved on stone, such as hematite, carnelian, or other agate forms, lapis lazuli, serpentine steatite. The scarab was used as an amulet, and from the first they seem to have had a mysteriously sacred character.

RICHMOND, March 28 -- After being un- der consideration for more than ten months, the suffrage question, so far as the Democratic Conference is concerned, was settled to-day. This body adopted what is known as the Glass plan, with numerous amendments. The vote on the article as amended was 46 to 17.

PROF. HERBERT ALLEN GILES of Cambridge University, England, has been lecturing this month at Columbia University on "Chinese Life and Literature." The course or lectures was intended to be the initiatory step toward the establishment at Columbia of the Chinese department, made possible by the recent gifts reputed to have been made by Gen. Horace W. Carpenter.

It is appropriate that there should come from the University of Montana a plea for the poet and the poetry of science. In a recent issue of The Independent Prof. E.E. Slosson of that institution of learning and letters makes this plea, using as an example of what the modern spirit has produced in that line the verse of M. Sully-Prudhomme, who last year received the Nobel Prize for the greatest work in pure literature.

Throughout New York yesterday Good Friday was generally observed. The Stock Exchange and other Exchanges were closed, but banks and banking houses were open, the day not being a legal holiday in this State. Many large business houses were, however, closed throughout the day.

Equipped with foil, mask, and buskin, the fencers of the college teams began their annual tournament for the intercollegiate championship last night in the gymnasium of the New York Athletic Club. The teams represented the United States Naval Academy of Annapolis, the winners of the title last year; West Point, Yale, Harvard, Columbia, Cornell, and the University of Pennsylvania.

Those who best know Balzac would find the choice of his best the most difficult, and few of them would envy Mr. Alexander Jessup the task which he has accomplished in his little volume, "The Best of Balzac." It is a pretty book, with a portrait in photogravure, and a title page with an ornamental border in sepia, and the editor has succeeded in making seven selections showing as many phases of the author's genius.

Mr. Bunford Samuel's "Index to American Portraits," so he informs us, is a selection made by him of a general nature in manuscript, "covering portraits of all nations." As one of the Librarians of the Library Company of Philadelphia Mr. Samuel understands what are the wants of those frequenting libraries.

WASHINGTON, D.C., March 28 -- Rain to-day had no effect on the betting faction at Bennings, though it materially decreased the assemblage in the stand. Notwithstanding the heavy condition of the track, the favorites captured five of the races, Elizabeth Moan, Blue Delft, Justice, Charley Moore, and All Saints winning.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 28 -- About 300 operatives of Globe Yarn Mills Nos., 1 and 2 are out on strike. These mills are owned by the New England Cotton Yarn Company, which did not enter into die recent agreement among the local mills to advance wages 10 per cent. The operatives demand the increase.

THE man who first published "Les Miserables" in Brussels in 1862 and enriched himself thereby is still alive. His name is Albert Lacroix, and he was one of the famous publishers of French booksat the time of the Second Empire.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- First Lieut. John H. Lewis, Fifth Cavalry, is relieved from further duty in the Department of California and will report by letter to the Commanding General, Department of Colorado, for assignment to duty.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Not much importance is attached to the favorable report of the Senate Committee on Rules on the amendment to the rules proposed by Senator Hoar at the close of the Tillman-McLaurin episode. Mr. Hoar's amendment provided that the following should be added to the rules:

LONDON, March 29 -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Daily News says that the news has been received from Kutais, Transcaucasia, that three Russian nobles. Prince Kipinadse, Prince Valerian, and Prince Zulukidse, were executed on March 3 for the murder of over one hundred persons.

Policeman Dierkes, who is attached to the West Twentieth Street Station, was passing the furniture store of Gerard Kilp, 147 Eighth Avenue, about 9 o'clock last evenins when he noticed that there was a fire at the rear of the salesroom. He at once notified Mr. Kilp, who lives on the second floor, above the store.

The second day's hearing in the case of Mrs. Michael J. Murray, the wife of a policeman, in whose possession was found a pawn ticket for a gold chain belonging to murdered Mrs. Kate Voelpel, was held yesterday before Magistrate Deuel, in the Jefferson Market Police Court. Although many policemen were examined, the case was not finished.

The death of Mr. Peter W. Clayden, which removes from English journalism one of its most honorable representatives, suggests the consideration of a subject of great practical interest to all writers for the press. At the time of his death Mr. Clayden was in his seventy-fifth year.

MANY dusty, pigeonholed documents have come to light in the revival of interest in Colonial and Revolutionary history that began, some years ago. Many monographs have appeared, and re-edited books long out of print have come from the press.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- Investigation by the Audit Company of New York into the affairs of the National and the American Asphalt Companies has resulted in bitter disappointment for the holders of the trust's securities. Net earnings of the Asphalt. Trust for the years 1900 and 1901, it is found, amounted to only $698,176.18, and this was made on an authorized capitalization of $58,000,000, divided as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Democratic Congressional Committee met tonight and elected Representative James M. Griggs of Georgia Chairman. He was placed in nomination by Senator Carmack of Tennessee. Representative Thayer of Massachusetts nominated Representative W.S. Cowherd of Missouri, but after forty minutes' talk Mr. Cowherd's name was withdrawn and Mr. Griggs was elected unanimously.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 28 -- The most eventful campaign in Arkansas Democratic annals since 1874 closed to-night, and to-morrow each of the seventy-five counties will hold a primary election to determine its choice for United States Senator and State and county officers. Senator James K. Jones, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and exGov. James P. Clarke.

Lawyer Albert T. Patrick, convicted Wednesday of the murder of Millionaire William Marsh Rice, announced in the Tombs yesterday his engagement to marry Mrs. Addie M. Francis, in whose house he lived up to the time of his arrest.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- H. Clay Evans, Commissioner of Pensions, has tendered his resignation to the President. The following letter, together with an appended statement, was made public at the White House to-night:

The schedules of Frederik W. Harrison, formerly a livery stable keeper at 830 Seventh Avenue, were filed yesterday in the Clerk's office of the United States District Court. His liabilities are $34,937, and he has nominal assets of $19,863, including an equity of $50 in two gold watches, two gold chains, a gold cigar cutter, and a diamond ring, all pawned for $125.

Following is a statement of books which have sold best in regular book and department stores in New York. Philadelphia, Boston, Cincinnati, Chicago, Baltimore, and San Francisco between Feb. 22 and March 25 of this year. The statement is based on reports received from the regular correspondents or THE NEW YORK TIMES in those cities, personal inquiries having been made for the information sent to us.

The representatives of the coal-carrying companies who accepted the invitation of the Conciliation Committee of the Civic Federation to attend the conference on Thursday and give their side of the troubles in the anthracite districts were emphatic yesterday in saying that this did not mean official recognition of the union.

EDINBURGH, March 26, 1535 -- It is said on good authority that a chronicler, not of the Court, has obtained a full record of certain errant pastimes of his Majesty James V. of Scotland. The King's penchant for going about his kingdom in the guise of a private citizen has long been known.

The personality of actors always has an interest for theatregoing people. Though published separately, Miss Hamm's volume may be said in a sense to belong to the series of which the first volume, "American Authors and Their Homes," was published last Autumn, and the second, "Authors of Our Day in Their Homes," has just appeared, these volumes on the homes of authors being reprints from THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A correspondence appearing in your issue of March 23, appertaining to the bill before Congress having in view the extension to our weights and measures of the metric (decimal) system, has struck me as rather peculiar on account of the argument and reasoning contained therein.

This little book, which is beautifully made, is the first of a series of "Handbooks for the Clergy" to be edited by Mr. Robinson, who is the author of the initiatory volume. We cannot but hope that the succeeding numbers will better the instruction of the first, which is of a thinness that is deplorable.

Dr. Walter G. Douglas and Florian Tobias will play the deciding game in the first-class division of the handicap 14.2 billiard tournament at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club to-night. The winner of this game will then meet C.M. Folsom and Dr. Bullard, the winners of the second and third class respectively in a series of games for the championship prize of the tournament in which the present handicaps will govern.

PETER ROSEGGER, the Austrian novelist, has added a new volume to the group entitled "The Forest School-master" and "The God-Seekers," which were published by G.P. Putnam's Sons, translated into English by Miss Frances Skinner.

RECEIPTS FOR DEBTS -- Louis G. Osthelmer, when sued in the Supreme Court by John H. Evers and another on a judgment for $263.11, which they secured against him in 1885, pleaded payment, and showed a receipt, dated March 2, 1894, by one of the plaintiffs for $75, "in full of all claims to date."

The directness of these chapters in the way of personal address begets in us an impression that we have here a record of spoken utterance, but certainly not a series of sermons addressed to one and the same congregation, and that so well groomed as the congregation to which Mr. Slicer habitually ministers.
The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Here's from my heart, because you have -- even if it be late -- called attention to Richard Jefferies.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 28 -- The crowd at the Court House this morning was greater than on any preceding day of the trial of Mrs. Mabel Fenton Haines for the alleged murder of her two-year-old step-daughter, Gwendolyn.

As amended for final passage, the bill changing the New Jersey law relative to the conversion of preferred stock into bonds is free from the objections which were recognized in the measure as originally drawn. Instead of permitting so important a step to be taken on the two-thirds vote, per capita, of those present at a stockholders' meeting, the law as enacted requires the assent of two-thirds in interest of each class of stock.

LONDON, March 28 -- A "Prayer for Peace" was the only novel feature of the observance of Good Friday in England. The Bishops of London, Rochester, and St. Albans issued special appeals to their dioceses to unite in praying that to both British and Boers be granted the temper of peacemakers, pointing out that similar prayers were being offered in the Dutch churches of Pretoria.

Most of the persons who are most likely to be interested in this admirable series of studies in American Colonial architect- ure might be supposed by this time to be aware of it. But it would be a rash as- sumption. Certainly all those who are professionally interested as designers are so. It is for them, primarily, that the work has been undertaken.

Secretary of the Treasury Leslie M. Shaw was a visitor to Ellis Island yesterday. The Secretary was accompanied by Mrs. Shaw and Assistant Custodian of the New York Sub-Treasury Thomas F. Lawlor, Mr. Shaw went through all of the departments of the Bureau of Immigration, being shown around by Commissioner Fitchie and Assistant Commissioner McSweeney.

Col. Thompson of the Internal Revenue Service with four Government agents, assisted by four policemen, raided an illicit distillery in an abandoned carpenter shop at 441 Pleasant Avenue, near One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, yesterday afternoon. They captured 75 gallons of whisky ready for market, a plant worth $5,000, with a capacity of 300 gallons a day, and Banny Stevack, twenty-two years old, who says he had only worked in the place three days.

MACINACK ISLAND, Mich. -- William Davenport Hulbert, who for years has known and understood the birds and beasts and fishes or this country as few men have ever known and understood any birds or beasts or fishes, has written a delightful series of personal sketches of his friends. They include biographies of the beaver, the trout, the lynx, the porcupine, the loon, and the deer.

Justices in Special Sessions yesterday lis tened to further evidence in the story which developed Thursday in their court as to the working of the system of the New York Telephone Company in paying rewards for the arrest and conviction of persons caught stealing copper wire from the company.

LONDON, March 19 -- The Oxford English dictionary is now half finished, but it is understood that the remaining five volumes will issue from the presses more quickly than the five already in the hands of subscribers. This will be an authoritative and monumental work.

NEW ORLEANS, March 28 -- Nothing like the flood which is now holding sway in Central Mississippi and Northwestern Louisiana can be recalled by the oldest inhabitants. Now heavy ruins are falling in the southern part of Mississippi, and the streams are all over their banks. The tie-up of the railroads is almost complete.
TRENTON, N.J., March 28 -- Gov. Murphy to-day signed the United States Steel Corporation Bond bill, which was passed by both houses of the Legislature yesterday.

PRETORIA, March 28 -- About 1,500 Boers, under De la Rey, Liebenborg, Kemp, and Wolmarans, were within the area of Lord Kitchener's latest movement, but, though surprised toy the rapidity displayed by the British troops, gaps in the British lines enabled most of the burghers to escape.

The Chinese Minister has established a reputation in this country for not talking in public without saying something. His occasional addresses are always worth attention. On Thursday evening he made one in Springfield, Mass., which was by no means an exception to his rule.

We have from time to time of late made some comments on the essentials of the constitution of a poet. We have endeavored to point out that, while poets were born and not made, there was nevertheless a good deal to be learned. We have also striven to convey the impression that, no matter how hard one might study the art of poesy, he would not necessarily be a poet.
CINCINNATI, March 28 -- The Brewers' Exchange of this city to-day telegraphed President Gompers of the American Federation of Labor, at Chicago, as follows:

A Sudden Head of Water Starts the Jam and in the Sight of Many Spectators, including Stewart Edward White, the Author, Jimmy Powers, and His Men Are Swept Away -- "Goad-Bye, Boys," Called Jimmy, and Flung His Hat in the Face of Death.

According to the statement of Benjamin Steinhardt of the firm of Howe Hummel, who acted as counsel for Mrs. Marion Faversham in the divorce suit she brought against he husband, Mr. Faversham was allowed to choose his own co-respondent from a number of women against whom the plaintiff in the suit said that she had evidence sufficient to name them as co-respondents.
"John Rodinski," called the Clerk in the Gates Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, and a meek-looking man, with bushy hair, was led forward before Mag- istrate Kramer by a policeman.

LONDON, March 28 -- The London house of Messrs. Harper is about to begin the Publication of a notable series tracing international commerce of the present day and supplying accurate information of the trade resources and needs of the principal countries.

In the language of the sporting fraternity, "the town is wide open," except, it is said, in those districts controlled by the Police Captains of the Leonard Street and East Twenty-second Street Stations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Noticing an article in a recent issue of THE TIMES concerning the lessening desire of the blind to the smoking habit, I take the liberty of offering my contribution to this subject, and give the benefit of sixteen years' experience, and if one in my condition can use such ail expression, also my observations.

Various reports are sent out from Washington in regard to the resignation of Mr. EVANS, the Commissioner of Pensions. The most definite is that his resignation has been placed in the hands of the President. One less specific is that it will be accepted when a diplomatic post "of importance is found for him."

After five days of searching for a missing employe of the Riverside Bank, at Fifty-seventh Street and Eighth Avenue, the Diroetors of the bank met yesterday afternoon and authorized the issuance of the following statement, which was given out by Warner Van Norden, a Director:

The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations has reached a very wise conclusion. It is to report at an early date, either favorably or adversely, the reciprocity treaties negotiated with so much trouble by the State Department last year. Several considerations have led to this decision.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Referring to your Issue of March 22, I beg to call your attention to Victor Hugo's preface to "Les Miserables." This was evidently taken from one of the older translations, which is apt to be a little misleading.

The Real Bluebeard Ernest Alfred Vizetelly, who is believed to be the author of "The Lover's Progress" recently published anonymously by Brentano's, has almost completed a new book, which Chatto Windus of London are to publish.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 28 -- Coach Courtney began work with his crews to-day by holding two practices on the inlet. This programme will be continued throughout the Easter recess. It is expected that the crews will be able to row on Lake Cayuga before the end of the present week. Today the Varsity eight went out in the following order:

BOSTON, March 27 -- The question as to whether or not there is any demand for such books as the new fine edition of Raleigh's story of the last fight of the Revenge seems answered by the exhaustion of the edition. Mr. Lowell's "Democracy," which, unlike most books of its species, has been sold in, the shops, has been bought with eagerness very encouraging to the venture.

New York has at least one show during the season to which we all have learned to look forward with expectancy. The twenty-fourth annual exhibition of the Society of America has in fact a rather more festive appearance than usual, owing to the presence of pictures by men of note whose work is rarely seen in the regular annual collections.

Baseball and track athletics will have full sway at the Adelphi Academy of Brooklyn for the next two months. The schedule of events has been completed by the athletic association. The season will open on April 5, and will continue until the Long Island interscholastic championships on May 31.
That is a curious announcement which sets forth that a publishing concern, with ample capital, is about to be established in Atlanta for the express purpose of "encouraging Southern literature."

IN 1825 the Marquis Rone d'Arsenson, a great-grand-nephew, published the "Journal et Memoirs du Marquis d'Argenson," the latter being, according to Sainic Beuve, one of the most prominent and justly esteemed names among the politicians and men of the eighteenth century, who were closely identified with matters of public interest.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Gov. Odell to-day announced the dates upon which he will give hearings upon bills over which there is controversy. The two bills before the Governor over which there promises to be the most contention are the Weekes Primary Election bill and the Krum Corporation bill.

FORMING, as it does, a readily perceptible climax in every department of human endeavor, the dawn of the twentieth century is a station on the road of time when a query may be addressed to the past and evoke no uncertain answer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In pursuance of the Governor's policy to entirely exempt the rural counties from their proper share of State taxation, bills have been urged for passage in this and the last Legislature placing additional taxation upon corporations, nearly all of which are located in this city.

IN the Summer of 1859 held some correspondence with Sir Edward Bulwer Lytton, not yet come to his Earldom, and in looking over my letters of that period I find the following from him, one of a dozen or more which passed between us in the course of some literary negotiations.

This little collection of sketches is far from anything like sympathy with "art for art's sake." To the serious student of art they have little enough to offer, and hardly more to the student of history, but they provide in an attractive form for the devout Roman Catholic readers for whom, obviously, they were written, much that is beautiful in legend and story concerning certain favorite saints.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Rev. Dr. H.D. van Broekhuizen, whose address at Columbus Hall is quoted in THE TIMES this morning, made several remarks which I believe he can hardly substantiate.

It is needless to say that if the Democratic leader in the House of Representatives had had in his possession the clear and remarkably convincing statement of Capt. CHRISTMAS'S counsel which was published in our columns yesterday morning he would not have insisted, as he did, upon instant investigation.

Pitcher Roy Evans and Infielder James, Delahanty reported to Manager Horace Fogel of the New York baseball team at the Polo Grounds late yesterday afternoon. Rain prevented the team from taking outdoor practice yesterday, but the players got two good hours of work in the morning. The weather was raw and chilly, still the practice was gone through with conscientiously.

The new $50,000 steam lighter Santos, built for Arbuckle Brothers, at the Townsend-Downey Shipyards on Shooter Island, and which was warped to the same pier as is the Kaiser's schooner yacht Meteor, was partially destroyed by fire early yesterday morning. The Meteor was on the opposite side of the pier and fortunately was berthed some distance away from the Santos.

Continued trade improvement is the tenor of the reports to the several commercial agencies of the country, telling of the general business situation. With here and there an exception. Easter trade has been phenomenally active, it being a recorded fact that the general distribution of merchandise exceeds that of any previous season.

On April 9-12 Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge will sell in London the fine library of the late Lieut. Col. Edward George Hibbert, formerly of the Grenadier Guards. Though a small collection, (it comprises 914 lots.) it is easily one of the most important libraries that have ever come upon the market.

To the great majority of those who have read the opening sentences of Mary Johnston's new novel, "Audrey," there remains only a general impression of satisfaction, tinged with admiration for the artist who has painted such a vivid picture in words.

It would be dificult to imagine a dirtier crime than that which on Thursday, and again yesterday, was plausibly charged in the Court of Special Sessions. The offense was tempting boys to steal, in order that policemen and their confederates might get the rewards promised in case of conviction.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A report which is said to have leaked out from the Senate Committee on Military Affairs says that the 600 or so brevet nominations for the promotion of officers who served in the Spanish war may fail of confirmation by the Senate. The committee, at its meetins yesterday, took up these nominations, and after some discussion laid them aside for a week without action.

Residents, of Brooklyn were much interested yesterday to learn that more than half the lepers found in New York State after a two years' hunt by the United States Leprosy Commission are at large in their borough. This information is contained in the report of the commission, just rendered.

LONDON, March 29 -- Dr. Morrison, the Peking correspondent of The Times, says the Manchurian negotiations continue. M. Lessar (the Russian Minister to China) is conciliatory, and Prince Ching (President of the Chinese Foreign Office) is reasonable. All the main conditions have been agreed upon, and the early signature of the convention is expected.

LONDON, March 22 --The Daily News has done a bold thing. Several changes have been made in it since the accession of its latest editor, but the most remarkable of them all is the complete exclusion of all betting and turf news from its columns.

NOW and then is to be seen in the streets of Philadelphia a genial looking man, short of stature, with white hair and mustache, a quick step, and the kindest of eyes, to whom his acquaintances of younger years instinctively take off their hats, and from whom the ragged urchins of the curb ask pennies with an air that bespeaks their surety of success.

" Frederique" is a new departure in French fiction. Of all men a Frenchman is the last man, and of all Frenchmen, Marcel Prevost is the last Frenchman, to whom we should attribute the ideals of feminine conduct, and the prophecy of the feminine future enunciated in his remarkable book. Not that Mr. Prevost has not written other remarkable books.

APRIL, the fourth month in the year, presents many attractions for those who follow with unwavering interest the ever-changing movements of the heavenly bodies. The scene of beauty has, however, shifted to the early morning hours, if one would see the planets in their glory. So that it takes an early riser to glean from the heavens the really choice bits, unless a telescope is at hand.

WRITES the woman from Bermuda: "Yon are envying me all the enjoyment I am having surrounded by Easter lilles, I suppose, but I wish there was not a lily on the island. Through one of the windows of my room at the hotel I discovered when I first arrived that when the wind was right the most delicious fragrance from a big bed of lilies blew in.

Nominally, Towser belonged to his master; actually, he owned the regiment. He joined with his master, but from that day be ceased to be a private personage and became the regimental dog. When the "fall in" sounded Towser took his place at the head of the regiment, wet or fine, in daylight or darkness, he was always there.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- It developed to-day that the $8,000 necklace stolen from a Pullman car running between Charleston, S.C., and Jacksonville, Pla., on March 7, belonged to Mrs. Harriet S. Blaine Beale, daughter of the late Secretary of State James G. Blaine. Mrs. Beale was en route to Cuba, accompanying Miss Alice Roosevelt, the President's daughter.

CHICAGO, March 29. -- The Attorney General of the United States will be called upon to determine whether clubwomen can make discriminations on race, color, or previous condition of servitude. A committee of Chicago clubwomen was appointed to-day to ask Attorney General Knox about the constitutionality of what the General Federation proposes to do at Los Angeles.
District Attorney Jerome, asked yesterday about his visit to the Tenderloin Friday night, remarked that he had simply gone there for his health and to get some exercise.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is Mr. W.H. Haworth an Atheist? Today it seems to be generally conceded by Hebrews and Christians alike that it is better for a man to have either of the above faiths or to believe in any of their numerous creeds or sects, than for him to be without faith.

Park Avenue property owners, aroused over the recent explosion and cave-in along the line of the subway excavation in front of their residences, voiced, through a committee of their selection, an indignant protest at the meeting of the Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday.

Numerous complaints have been heard of late in regard to the poor care that is given the Harlem River Speedway by the employes of the Park Department. There are many holes and ruts in the roadbed, while on several occasions during the past week it was impossible to drive on account of the dust, which could have been laid with sprinkling carts.

COMPOSERS of music in the dawn of the twentieth century are experimenting. Musical history is making to-day just as surely as it was in 1700. Operatic composers are experimenting along lines indicated by Wagner, and instrumental composers also have taken certain hints from him.

A test of the money market, and an excellent indication of its inherent strength, came on Thursday last when the demands of Stock Exchange operators for loanable funds had to be made and met. Inasmuch as these call loans carried over until Monday the fear was expressed in some quarters that there might be a "flurry" that, in fact, it scarecly seemed possible that higher than the legal rate would not obtain.
LONDON, March 29 -- Abstaining from eating meat-during Lent is quite going out of fashion in London. This, apparently, is due more to the high price of fish than to a decline in religious feeling.

Women who belong to Soroses or "Daughters" of various sorts or any other organization peculiar to their sex may be surprised to learn that the Mormons claim the credit for having originated the idea of the woman's club. As far as authentic records are concerned, the first union of women was perfected with twenty-two members on March 17, 1842, in Nauvoo, III., then a thriving city of 30,000, now but a village.

THERE has recently been published in this city an important book bearing the striking title "Regeneration," by Prof. Morgan of Bryn Mawr College. The title might suggest that the subject matter is theological or sociological, but in reality the book is an exhaustive storehouse of facts relating to important and interesting discoveries in modern experimental biology.

BERLIN, March 30. -- The North German Gazette, in its issue of this morning, contains an authoritative expression of the Government's position in relation to the prohibition of meats prepared with boracic acid, with special reference to the assertion that the prohibition is aimed against the United States.

Occasional correspondents are much exercised over the fact that President ROOSEVELT allows a French artist to make the portrait of Mrs. ROOSEVELT when there are plenty of American painters who could do it as well and perhaps better. Parallels for sensitiveness of this kind may be found abroad.

With all that appertains to coronation ceremonial at the present time, and the newly made treaty with Japan, special interest attached to the lecture given at 20 Hanover Square by Mr. Goji Ukita, Chancellor of the Japanese Legation, on the imperial regalia of Japan.
