These emblems consist of the mirror, symbolic of knowledge; the sword for courage, and the divine jewels for mercy.

BALTIMORE, March 29 -- The past week has been as utterly dull in Baltimore as elsewhere and society has devoted itself altogether to the finishing up of its penitential duties in anticipation of the Easter season, which will be an unusually gay one. On Monday afternoon Mile. Baillieux held the final one of a series of very successful matinees Francaise she has conducted during Lent, at the residence of Mrs. Garrett on Mount Vernon Place.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 29 -- The expectation that Mrs. Haines, who is being tried on the charge of murdering her two-year-old stepdaughter, Gwendolyn, would testify on her own behalf to-day attracted another large crowd to the courtroom. A short session was held, however, and the accused will not give her evidence until Monday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report that Great Britain has called upon Canada to furnish 2,000 additional cavalry for South Africa suggests some grave considerations for the American Government.

A wrangle which grew out of crowding on the One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street station of the Third Avenue Elevated Railroad last evening terminated at the One Hundred and Thirty-third Street station of the road in a general scrimmage, in which several men, guards, and a ticket chopper took part, while the engineers of two trains tooted their whistles as a signal for the police, who did not respond to the alarm.

PARIS, March 13 -- Among the measures discussed and adopted by the present Chamber there is one of especial interest, even to the foreigner. This is the bill recently passed for reducing the postage on newspapers and periodicals. These at present, if not exceeding 50 grammes in weight, pay 1c. if addressed within the department in which they are published or the adjacent departments, and 2c. for the rest of France.

LONDON, March 29. -- Charles Frohman, having concluded arrangements to retain the management of his London theatres, now is trying to arrange American tours, in which he hopes to include Charles Wyndham, Beerhohm Tree, and Mrs. Langtry.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 29. -- The Spring athletic season at the Naval Academy promises to be the most interesting in the history of the institution. Besides baseball and rowing, there will be track competition with Johns Hopkins University of Baltimore, and the Seventh Regiment of New York.

Two interesting programmes of military exhibitions and athletic competitions were given yesterday at the military show in Madison Square Garden. At both the matinee and the evening performance the vast Garden was thronged, standing room again being at a premium at the farewell drills of the soldiers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No one who has watched the New York Central and the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroads in the past can have sanguine expectations of their improving the tunnel service any faster than the pressure of public opinion compels.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Republican National Congressional Committee, when it begins its campaign work, will lay its plans, undoubtedly, to hold, if possible, all the States now solidly Republican. A glance at the list of those "solid" States, and a little consideration of political conditions in some of them, will make clear the difficulty of repeating all the Republican victories of November, 1000, in the Congressional districts.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 29 -- The Erie and Central New York Railroad, running a distance of ten miles from Cortland to Cincinnatus, was sold at auction to-day on a mortgage by George Kernan of Utica. It was purchased for $130,000 by W.W. Montgomery of New York, who said he bought it for private parties.

LONDON, March 29. -- Miss. Ellen M. Stone, the American missionary, arrived in London to-day, (from Salonica, by way of Vienna.) She looked to be in good health, but was extremely nervous. Of her recent experiences she said:
HOBART J. MOORE. Chairman of the Steuben County Board of Supervisors, died yesterday at his home in Hammondsport, N.Y.

LONDON, March 29. -- Some credence has been given here this week to the statement which, however, had not beer printed, that the Russian Government has gone so far as to address a note to Washington asking what course the United States would pursue if trouble arose in the Far East on account of the opposition there of England and Japan on one hand, and of France and Russia on the other.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29. -- According to a Supreme Court decision rendered to-day Mayor A.T. Rogers of Bradley Beach will have to turn over his office to his Republican opponent, Pratt. Justice J. Franklin Fort of the Supreme Court signed the report of the County Board of Election in the Mayoralty fight.

IT savors somewhat of lese-majeste to "go for " a sovereign, but as far as can be learned conditions in the faraway land of Congo, over which Leopold, King of Belgium, supposedly holds supremacy, are of singularly unfortunate character. In THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 17 the Rev. De "Witt Clinton Snyder, a missionary of the Congo Free State, who had just returned from Africa, explained what was the present status there.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A new form of swindling has developed itself in this city within the last few years. The manner in which it is done is this:

"EE'S a vara bad man. All the ladies loave him, but he no loave any of them, that feller. He only loaves the money," explained the little Itallan tailor in a slouch hat who sat on the bench in front of us.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Assistant Secretary Taylor of the Treasury Department to-night received telegrams from New York representives of two transatlantic steamship companies protesting against the granting of a holiday to-morrow to the immigrant Inspectors on Ellis Island.

AT the dinner given by Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt to Prince Henry of Prussia one of the dishes served was one but comparatively little served at dinners -- artichokes. These were served after the lettuce salad.

RECENT heavy rains in the eastern part of the United States have enabled the hunters of muskrats to secure unusually large numbers of these animals. The high water has driven them from their semi-aquatic haunts, and hundreds of thousands of pelts have been added to the already large catch for the present season.

To the musical clang of steel fencing foils a trio of trim West Point cadets last night won the first honors in the championship intercollegiate fencing tournament. The final bouts were held in the gymnasium of the New York Athletic Club before a throng of spectators, among which the gay-colored costumes of women predominated and gave a pleasing touch of color to the scene.

By far the most active of the issues traded in on the curb during the past week were Colorado Fuel bonds, which for some time have been given much attention. The advance in the company's common stock, into which these bonds are convertible, resulted in a large demand for them, and this in turn brought about a sharp upward movement in the quotation.

In spite of the steady downpour of rain, there was a large attendance of members at the weekly shoot of the Crescent Athletic Club at the Bay Ridge traps yesterday afternoon, as the shoot was the last of the regular season, and decided the ownership of the several important trophies for which the club's marksmen have been competing during the past season.

Threatening Situation in Turkey. Although taken separately, recent communications from Constantinople to the various European capitals show little more than isolated acts of curious persecution on the part of the Porte, together they reveal that the Sultan is apprehensive of a formidable armed uprising on the part of the Young Turks, and is taking most extraordinary means of suppression.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Democratic members of the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day agreed upon a substitute for the Philippine Government bill. It provides that the United States shall relinquish all claim of sovereignty over the Philippine Archipelago, but that the United States shall continue to govern the archipelago until the natives shall have established a Government.

A party of about 200 friends of Frank L St John of the New York Yacht Club and the New Rochelle Yacht Club witnessed the launching of his new schooner yacht Marjorie at Robert Jacobs's yard at City Island yesterday afternoon. A number of people went from Brooklyn to City Island on a tug and many others went by coach from New York.

If anything can prevent the company of admirable actors that has gathered together at the Bijou Theatre under the name of Miss Amelia Bingham from achieving a high popular and artistic success it is the peculiarly puzzling and unsatisfactory material they have to work with.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The frequent changing of the names of vessels belonging to the city has caused considerable comment, and some amusement among people interested in shipping. The fireboat Strong was renamed the Van Wyck when the reform administration went out of power a few years ago, but the present administration has restored the name under which she was launched.

A REMARKABLE effort on the part of blind children was the recent presentation of a play at the Perkins Institute, in South Boston. The piece presented was "Undine." and eight little girls were engaged in the cast.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. "William Henry Haworth, in his letter to the public under date of March 24, published in your columns of March 27, arraigns the Pubiic School Board.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A plea to make our public school system denominational is made in a communication to you signed William Michael Byrne. He speaks of "the magnificent educational work of the Roman Catholic Church," and adds that "it is hard for the Catholics to support the public school by taxation and the parochial school by contribution."
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 20. -- The royal invitations for the coronation ceremonies have reached their recipients in these colonies and have given rise to some discussion.

The complaint against high prices is almost universal among operators, yet, in spite of this, the remarkable feature of current dealing continues to be the large amount of buying in all regions of recent activity. In the sixties and lower seventies, between Park and Lexington Avenues, scarcely a day passes without a slight readjustment of figures, or the reporting of a transaction, which, it is claimed, establishes a new high record for that locality.

In no country in Europe is the telephone brought to such a pitch of perfection as in Sweden, where the instrument enters into the daily life of the people in a manner that would cause unbounded astonishment in this country. There are two classes of telephone in use -- the "Riks," or Government variety, and the "Allmanna," or general.

The Manufactured Star. As we wore saying when the first night notice of "Soldiers of Furtune" was hurried to the pross, the intelligence of the American manager must have suffered a shocking fall to enable him to see so many hitherto unrecognized stars.

Five young negroes, educated at Tuskegee, Ala., in Booker T. Washington's school, en route to the German colony of Togo, West Africa, where they will teach the uncivilized natives the arts of agriculture, sailed from this port yesterday on the Hamburg-American Line steamship Moltke. The party goes under the direction of J.N. Calloway, a teacher of agriculture in the Tuskegee school.

Unusually fine floral displays for Easter will be made in the various churches of the city this morning. During the greater portion of the night skilled hands were busy draping and arranging the finest products of the hothouses hereabouts to aid in excelling the decorations of former years in beauty and attractiveness.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Depending upon your fairness, as continually evident in every department of THE TIMES, I submit horewith the bear view of the present security market's position -- using the word "bear" in its technical Wall Street sense. I am not a professional pessimist; I am a believer in our country's magnificent destiny, and recognize the abundant evidence that prosperity is vastly broadening National scope.

WILLIAMSTON, W.Va., March 29 -- Reports were received to-day about another fight with the Hatfields, in which four were killed, among them being Harry Watts, proprietor of the Palace Hotel here. John Rutherford, a detective, had a warrant for the arrest of Ephraim Hatfield, who is wanted in South Carolina.
The following philosophic remarks are from the financial review given prominence in London Truth -- not unfairly representative of the tone assumed by most journalistic financial critics abroad:

THERE appear in the English-speaking papers of New York an average of one hundred advertisements per week under the heading of "Lost and Found." This classification is, to a large degree, a misnomer, for seldom it is that a person who has found anything celebrates his good luck by taking the public into his confidence.

IN Ireland a man is scaling the snow-covered glaciers. The temperature is far below zero. The sun shines brightly, and the rays of light are reflected from the vast snow expanses. Strange is it that the explorer should suffer from sunburn, and complain of an irritation of the skin.

HAVANA, March 29. -- The verdict in the Cuban postal fraud cases, as given out, finds C.F. W. Neely, W. H. Reeves, and Estes G. Rathbone guilty of the main charge of embezzlement of over $100,000, and that Neely and Reeves originated the idea of burning the stamps, to which Rathbone consented, profiting thereby, though to what extent could not be specified.

Visitors to the new monkey house in the New York Zoological Park are quite taken aback by the sight of a very black and very hairy rhinoceros in what used to be the cage of "Sally," the orang-outang, contentedly grinding away at Australian oat hay as if she were paid by the hour to masticate.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 29. -- It is probable that all of the great flour mills in Minneapolis will use Texas oil as fuel, instead of coal. Several of them are at present conducting experiments to determine the utility of this product, and the managers say that thus far they have been very satisfactory.

Broken by the Easter holidays, the Wall Street week has had scant development of interest. The market has been narrow, albeit firm. Some of the mercurial specialties have jumped up and down; but standard issues have shown little fluctuating disposition. Money market conditions have been free from any sign of the stringency so much predicted.

THE late Prof. Alfred M. Mayer of the Stevens Institute, in addition to being a physicist of distinguished merit, was an archaeologist and a careful student of the art of the most remote periods. The drawings or etchings of the man of the Stone Age has for its principal subject animal life.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 29 -- To the Easter visitors who have thronged in here during the week, Lakewood seems like a bit of Florida dropped down in the Jersey pines by mistake. The days are so warm and sunny that the visitors have had to put away the heavy overcoats and fur boas they wore when they came here.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 29. -- Lafayette's baseball nine defeated the cadet team here this afternoon in a highly interesting game by the score of 5 to 4.
The Albany Evening Journal has just passed its seventy-second anniversary. It has ever been a valuable newspaper, a credit to the Capital City.

IN the last months of his life Eugene Field was an invalid and suffered particularly and abnormally from anything like cold weather. Upon his doctor's advice he went to California and visited a cousin, Henry Field, who lived at Alameda, near San Francisco. While there he heard dully the usual glorification of the splendid climate of California, but in his extremely sensitive condition did not take kindly to it.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29. -- The sixth annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science will be held in this city April 4 and 5. The general topic of the meeting this year will be "Social Legislation and Social Activity." There are to be four sessions. The opening session will be devoted to the question of "Child Labor."
ALBANY, March 29. -- Gov. Odell's action in falling to reappoint Col. Ashley Cole as a member of the Railroad Commission is giving the Republican leaders some concern.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The testimony in the Northern Securities case of Mr. Morgan and others shows that if the question as to whether the company is intended to "restrain trade" may be answered by the originators and controilers of that company, it will be in the negative.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is safe to say that your editorial in to-day's TIMES on the conviction of Patrick voices the sentiment of nine out of ten citizens of the city, and adds to the mystification that is gradually filling the minds of the public at large as to the results of these notorious trials, which are the only ones the general public has the opportunity of knowing anything about.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

NEW HAVEN, March 29. -- A conservative attitude has been definitely adopted by the country town majority in the Constitutional Convention and that majority seems bent now on refusing to adopt any of the several amendments offered that in one way or another affect the larger centres of population or the people at large in the State.

SOME very good stories are told of the impression made upon those who attend for the first time the very High Church Episcopalian service, with its elaborate ritual and its extraordinary musical features, at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin. The reply of a very prominent Catholic priest, when asked by the friend who had taken him there how he liked the service, "Well, really.

The action of the German Government in excluding American meats treated with antiseptic preparations has given rise to a great deal of discussion, some of it intelligent and more of it otherwise. The propriety of its action in this instance may be said to be almost an open question, and the disagreement of what passes for expert opinion on this subject is extremely confusing to the disinterested seeker after truth.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 29 -- James Robinson, seventy years old, a recluse, who has lived in a tent in Linden, near this city, for some years, was brutally beaten and burned by four masked men early Thursday morning. Robinson was tortured by the men because he said he had no money.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 29 -- Holy Week has been a history maker for this city, as more of the ultra-society folks have been here than ever before at any like season. All of the big hotels are crowded to the attic, and several unoccupied houses in the cottage section have been rented by hotel proprietors to accommodate guests.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 29 -- Word was received here to-day that Harriman was destroyed by the flood, on account of the overflow of the Emery River. The damage is estimated at a quarter of a million dollars. It is reported that two lives were lost and many more are supposed to have been drowned.

Every circus has a press agent, and Whiting Allen does the dreaming for the "Great Adam Forepaugh Sells Brothers' Enormous Shows United." Mr. Allen is a mild-mannered, pleasant man, who knows his business. The circus was coming to town, and so yesterday he changed the old lines that ran:

BOSTON, March 29. -- The presence of J. Edward Addicks of Delaware in Boston and the report that he had come to secure control of the Whitney gas interests in Boston have brought out on authoritative statement that Whitney holdings in Boston Gas are now in the control of D. J. W. Seligman of New York, bankers, who have an option on the voting powers of the stocks of Messrs.

SEATED at the same table at dinner last Sunday evening were Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Ogden Mills, Mrs. Whitney Warren and Miss Evelyn Burden. Mrs. Vanderbilt, who is seldom seen in black, wore a net gown, black, moderately spangled. The bodice had an unlined yoke and the elbow sleeves were also unlined, and had full and deep frills.

THE regularity of the Winter mail service up and down the ice-bound Yukon, between Dawson and Fort Gibbon, a distance of 800 miles, has called attention to one of the greatest feats ever performed by a star route contractor in the employ of the United States Government. A weekly service is being maintained, and it matters not whether the thermometer is 20 above or 60 below zero.
WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Robert P. Skinner, United States Consul General at Marseilles, has sent to the State Department the following report:

OMAHA, Neb., March 29 -- "For fifteen years I have farmed in Nebraska and have paid tribute to protection, with the idea that it was protecting the infant industries of this country," said H.G. Leavitt, President of the Standard Beet Sugar Company, at Amos, who has just returned from Washington.

The second annual dual scholastic games of Barnard School and Hamilton Institute were held yesterday afternoon in the armory of the Twenty-second Regiment. As It was an invitation meet, all the schools in the Interscholastic League were well represented, the crowd present being very large.

At the Garden Theatre to-morrow night the annual big production of that house will be offered. Anson Bond's New York drama, "Life," has been selected for this production, and it will be placed upon the stage by Messrs. Rich and Harris. "Life" calls for the reproduction of nearly a dozen well-known localities in New York; it is promised that many of the stage pictures will be of imposing and remarkable construction.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am moved by the almost daily complaints in THE TIMES of the continued mischievous and alarmingly dangerous work going on in the subway to refer again to the abuse of dynamite in the excavation of rock, especially along the line of residences.

KANSAS CITY, March 29. -- Pigeon shooters from all parts of the country have been arriving here to compete in the Grand American Handicap, which will begin Wednesday, April 2. The winner last year at Interstate Park, L.I., was E.C. Griffith of Pascoag. R.I., and he is rated at the handicap of 31 yards.

It is now abundantly established that migration is mostly carried on at night and further, mainly during clear nights. Only a comparatively few species, such as ducks, cranes, certain large hawks, swallows, swifts, and nighthawks, migrate during the daytime, and these, it will be observed, are either rapacious birds or mainly those that enjoy such power of rapid flight as to be relatively safe from capture.

It is difficult to make an Easter prediction. According to tradition, to-day should be one of brilliant sunshine and Phoebus himself should perform a little pas seul in the heavens, while Fifth Avenue will be one bright-hued procession of light gowns and flowered hats adorning the persons of many who come from the neighboring suburbs to join in the parade.

American visitors to Europe this Summer will find an attraction in Turin, the ancient capital of Piedmont, where an International Exposition of Modern Decorative Art is to be held, in which American products will be largely represented. An American commission appointed by the Italian authorities has general supervision of the products of this country which will there be seen.

The late Sir Conrad Reeves, a negro, who, through his remarkable intellectual ability and force of character, rose from the post of office boy in the employ of the famous negro reformer, Samuel Jackman Prescod, to the position of Chief Justice of Barbados and to the knighthood of Great Britain, was honored upon his death by many tributes from distinguished officers of the British Government.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 29. -- It is confidently expected that James R. Keene will be able to go to Castleton to-morrow. He has been suffering from an acute attack of dysentery, and to-night Dr. Barrow pronounced his trouble stomach inflammation. Mr. Keene has never been in Kentucky before, and is extremely anxious to see his horses, in which he has probably $1,000,000 invested, at his noted farm.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whatever may have been the motive that inspired the recent decree of the German Government excluding American medicated meat from that country, the act itself is commendable, and should our Government in a spirit of retaliation, or from any other motive, exclude German food products that are sophisticated or doctored with drugs, this also would be commendable.

LONDON, March 29. -- In financial markets the trading has been light all the week; but, in spite of the professed unbelief in a good outcome of the peace negotiations, they have inevitably affected both Kafirs and consols, while some really favorable news from the seat of war also strengthened prices.
The annual report of the Indian Industries League for 1902 shows what the organization is doing in civilizing and promoting industry among several tribes of Indians.

Additional evidence in the case of Mrs. Michael J. Murray, the wife of a policeman attached to the Charles Street Station, was given in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. Mrs. Murray is charged with having attempted by means of a pawn ticket made out to Mrs. Catherine Voelpel to redeem a gold chain which was pawned by the murdered woman.

LONDON, March 29. -- The tobacco war here has created a degree of national interest far greater than usually associated with trade disputes. Academic organs, like The Spectator, devote many columns to a serious discussion of the results of such a wholesale disintegration of a British system by American capital.

IN several libraries here, as in other cities, patrons are allowed to walk about among the book stacks, and thus select the books they would read. In several cities this is not allowed, however, because the privilege has been so abused by that meanest of all thieves -- the engraving or picture collector, who, unable or unwilling to buy the picture he wants, stea's it.

Mr. OSWALD GARRISON VILLARD has performed a public service in writing his article on "The New Army of the United States," published in the current Atlantic. It is a clear and popular exposition of the reforms effected and proposed in the army by Secretary ROOT, beginning with a showing of the necessity of reform.

COPENHAGEN, March 29 -- In an interview to-day on the subject of Congressman Richardson's resolution for the appointment of a committee to investigate charges made by Capt. Christmas in connection with the negotiations for the sale of the Danish West Indies, a high official said:

SCRANTON, Penn. March 29. -- Further concessions received to-night by the Central Labor Union, almost positively assures the immediate settlement of the six months' street car strike. It is almost certain that the strike will be declared off to-morrow.

One often bears residents along the rapid transit subway expressing doubt that the work will be completed on time. The reason the skeptics give for their unbelief is the continuity of street wreckage along the route. Why, they ask, are the pavements still torn to pieces and the crossings still blocked, if the tunnel is really going ahead as fast as the engineers say it is?

Justice Truax in the Supreme Court yesteday took a hand in the baseball controversy which has interested devotees of the game more or less for the past four months. The Justice's decision, while not favorable to the Spalding faction, will have, however, no bearing looking toward a cessation of the sport as far as the National League is concerned.

John J. Byrne took title yesterday to several parcels of real estate which he purchased at the recent auction sale of properties belonging to the Peyton estate, in which purchases he was generally credited with being the representative of ex-Deputy Police Commissioner Devery.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Pension Commissioner Evans's antagonists are much pleased at the news that he is at last to go. It is the general impression here that Dr. J.F. Raub, the medical referee, will follow him, as well as some other officials who have been closely identified with Mr. Evans's administration.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Mrs. Roosevelt resumed her informal afternoons at home to-day, when she received some twenty visitors in the Blue Room. Major Charles McCawley, United States Marine Corps and Miss Hagner assisted, the former making the introductions and the latter pouring tea.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is stated that the engineering corps of the West Virginia Central and Pittsburg Railway, which has been at work in the mountains of West Virginia for a year or more, is still in the field. The corps is eneased in running lines from the Coal and iron Railway, in Randolph County, West Va., to Harrisonburg, Rockingham County, Va.

A writer in The Troy Times reminds us that we must yet go from home to learn the news -- even new history. And more than that. While it is common report that the chronicler is too prone to make history without regard to the actor in events, the historian of The Troy Times proves himself to be both chronicler and actor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I believe it is now nearly two years since the overcrowded condition of the Brooklyn Bridge has become so acute as to arouse universal interest, and yet we are to-day exactly where we were at the time when Mr. Philbin first took official cognizance of the matter.

The report has been extensively circulated during the week that the heir to a large fortune had betaken himself to a gambling house and there dropped "something in six figures." This is by no means so serious as the report that the trusted manager of a great industrial corporation, who receives the highest salary paid in the United States for attending to its interests, had been "plunging" heavily at Monte Carlo.

LIVERPOOL, March 29 -- The Secretary of the North Atlantic Steamship Conference announced to-day that the Continental lines had signed the agreement fixing minimum saloon passage rates. The agreement becomes effective March 31.

One after another, within a very brief period, the reports of three of the prominent anthracite coal mining and carrying companies have been published in such form as to enable a fairly intelligent estimate to be made of the progress recorded during the late year. These companies are the Central Railroad of New Jersey -- familiarly known as Jersey Central -- the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western, and the Delaware and Hudson.

WAS awakened from my afternoon nap yesterday by the station agent's boy, who had come with a telegram from my friend Silas Larrabee. The telegram was dated at Dover, N.H., and requested me to meet Mr. Larrabee at the station, with a horse and wagon, on arrival of the 4 o'clock train.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whether you exert the influence of your paper in behalf of street-car transfers or not, you are certainly entitled to thanks for presenting to your readers the statement made by Mr. Ellison.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The President to-day sent to the House of Representatives the correspondence and papers bearing upon the request of Lieut. Gen. Miles to be assigned to duty in the Philippines. The papers were sent to the House in response to a resolution introduced by Mr. Burleson of Texas, and passed by that body.

Sadatsuch Uchida, Consul General for Japan at New York, has received reports from Tokio dealing with the foreign trade of his country for 1901 and the development of its railways. The reports showed that in both fields there had been substantial gains over previous years. The report on foreign trade says:

William Marconi, the inventor of the wireless telegraph, replied yesterday to the threats reported in a published dispatch from Berlin to have been made by the German Government, which is supporting the Slaby-Arco system in its fight against the Marconi people, to call an international commission to perfect means by which the different wireless systems will be compelled to honor one another's signals.

Imprisoned Elephants. WARNER SCOTT, a Western veterinary surgeon, visited the menagerie in Central Park last week. He spent some time in the elephant house, and incidentally met Snyder, the master of many ugly tempered beasts.

The Stock Exchange was closed again yesterday, in continuation of the Easter holiday, but this nevertheless did not prevent a number of conferences being held during the day by several important financial interests who are agreed that the situation -- financial and market-wise -- is much more favorable than at any time in recent months.

TACOMA, Washington, March 29. -- The lumber interests of Puget Sound have just received official information that the timber of the Philippine Islands cannot compete with the fir and other woods of the Pacific Coast. It is therefore certain that a large trade in Pacific Coast lumber ultimately will be secured in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- At last the path of the Cuban Reciprocity bill has been cleared, and the measure is now to be pushed through with all the vigor for which the House leaders are celebrated. The last obstacle was removed to-day When the Ways and Means chieftains achieved their object -- the capture of Mr. Babcock.

TRENTON, March 30. -- Ferdinand Roebling, the Treasurer of the John A. Roebling Company here, who are the builders of the East River Bride in New York, is concerned in a project to give Trenton a large new theatre. He has an option on the old United States Hotel, on Warren Street, which has a large frontage and extends back a block.

NEWARK, N.J., March 30. -- Dr. Thomas Dunn English still hangs on to life with a tenacity that is surprising to his physicians and family. He has been unable to take any nourishment for the past seventy-two hours, and Drs. Lehmbach and Kent have been at his side almost constantly. His family has also been at the bedside anxiously awaiting the end.

The parsonage in the rear of St. John's German Lutheran Church, at 1,343 Fulton Avenue, in the Borough of the Bronx, was entered by burglars yesterday morning. The house is occupied by the Rev. Henry Beiderbecke, the pastor of the church. Entrance was gained by the burglars through the parlor windows, which face on a small park adjoining the church.

WOOD'S HOLE, Mass., March 30. -- The iron steamer Indian, Philadelphia for Boston, went ashore on the famous Sow and Pigs Ledge, off Cuttyhunk Island, at the western entrance of Vineyard Sound at 6 o'clock last night during a heavy fog, and is likely to become a total wreck.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The friends of the Oleomargarine bill hope to secure a vote upon that measure on Tuesday of the present week, and as soon as it shall be disposed of the Chinese Exclusion bill will be called up.

It detracts nothing from the sympathy felt for the individual property owners along Park Avenue, whose house fronts have fallen into the subway excavation, that the average citizen will find much cause for congratulation that this particular misfortune has happened to gentlemen so well able to look after their own interests and those of others similarly situated.

TACOMA, Washington, March 30. -- D.O. Mills and his San Francisco associates Alvinza Hayward and P.B. Cornwall have just announced their intention of extend- ing the Bellingham Bay and British Columbia Railroad from Maple Falls, Whatcom County, across the Cascade Mountains to the Methow and Chanogan mining districts.

PHOENIX, Arizona, March 30. -- A company of capitalists has been organized to mine ice from the curious and famous ice caves in Northern Arizona and supply the towns on the Santa Fe Railroad with the product during the long, oppressive Summer. It is expected that a supply sufficient also for the Arizona division of other railroads will also be procured.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 30. -- Reports from the flooded districts of Tennessee estimate that the damage resulting from the storm of rain and wind will reach $4,000,000. Twenty-two lives are believed to have been lost. Several counties known to have suffered heavily are yet cut off from communication and the loss in property and life may reach larger figures when additional information has been received.

Whatever may have been the motives of Gen. MILES in the correspondence he has had with the Department of War, it is greatly to be regretted that the circumstances in which the publication of the correspondence and the documents connected with it place him in such an undignified situation as he finds him- self in.

ALBANY, March 30. -- The State Board of Tax Commissioners has fixed the valuations of special franchises operated in New York City for the current tax year under the Special Franchise Tax act. The aggregate amount of the valuations is $220,620,155, as compared with $210,306,931 in 1901.

The steamship Pretoria of the Quebec Line returned to this port last night with fire in her forward hold. Her passengers came in a short time previously on the steamer Noordland of the Red Star Line, having been transferred at sea.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 30. -- A windstorm swept over the eastern suburbs of the city this evening, doing considerable damage. Trolley poles were twisted, splintered, and broken, sidewalks were torn up and hurled great distances, and small trees were uprooted. Fortunately the storm spent its force in an almost unpopulated part of the city, and its path was very narrow.

RUSSIA AND MANCHURIA. -- Ever since Russia announced, through the amended articles of the Chino-Russian convention, that Manchuria was to be restored to China with full sovereign rights there has been a notable falling off of anti-Russian sentiment in the press of certain European capitals.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30. -- The transport Kilpatrick arrived to-day from Manila with the Seventeenth Infantry and discharged soldiers, nearly 1,000 in number. There were five deaths on the voyage. Shortly after leaving Manila Mrs. B.F. Pope, widow of Lieut. Col. B.F. Pope, died. Mrs. Pope was bringing the remains of her husband home.

A suggestion made by a professor in the University of Chicago that the students of the Art Institute should try their prentice hands on the decoration of the schoolrooms of the city, has been taken up, and three students at the institute have begun to make designs. The Architectural Club is holding its annual exhibition at the institute.
The Board of Managers of the Willard State Hospital has issued the following statement:

ALBANY, N.Y., March 30. -- The quarterly bulletin of the State Department of Labor shows that for the last quarter, ended Jan. 1, 1902, the decreased idleness in building, clothing, and baking trades was noticeable.

A bill is pending in the House of Representatives, introduced by Mr. LOVERING of Massachusetts, which is entitled, and correctly, "A bill to encourage the sale and exportation of articles of domestic manufacture."

PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- With the greater part of her crew of eleven men asleep in their bunks below deck, the little fishing schooner Edna Earl was run into and sunk in Delaware Bay, off Reedy Island, Del., late last night, and three of her crew were drowned. The drowned men are William Smith, Dennis Ford, father-in-law of Smith, both of Philadelphia, and Patrick Nolan of Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Large crowds attended the Easter services at the churches to-day. In the morning the weather was delightful, with bright skies and sunshine, but in the afternoon a severe thunderstorm marred the pleasure of the people who sought outdoor recreation.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., March 30. -- This village and its authorities are much worried lest it is to have many thousands of dollars' worth of damage suits on its hands. For years and years there has been frequent flooding of the streets, and especially the paved block of Division Street between South and Main Streets.

With the holidays over and April disbursements at hand, anticipation of better security markets develops. Money stringency threats disappear. The country's "outside" prosperity -- certified by all commercial and industrial reports -- can be expected to find natural reflection in Wall Street, after all the tests that have gone on record "inside" as well as "outside."

Golf in the metropolitan locality will present real activity this week. A larger number of local competitions has been arranged for Saturday than has been since the close of the Fall season. Lakewood, Dyker Meadow, Crescent Athletic, Newark Athletic, Baltusrol, St. Andrew's, and several other clubs will all have competitions of interest.

Forty members of the Police Department, all of whom are men in uniform attached to the Twentieth Precinct or the West Thirty-seventh Street Station, under command of Capt. Michael E. Foody, last night came out in open rebellion against existing conditions in the matter of the non-observance of the Sunday closing law as applied to saloons in Manhattan.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., March 30. -- Charles W. Lynde yesterday sold his residence and property on the west bank of Tuttle's River at Blue Point to Edward N. Baldwin, a horseman of Farmingdale. The price is said to be $7,000. It comprises about sixty-five acres and is one of the finest places along the south shore.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The news from Arkansas about the defeat of Senator James K. Jones, the Democratic leader in the Senate, is received with more or less apathy by the Democrats here.

The recent action of the courts in Illinois on the initiative of the Inter-State Commerce Commission is a substantial contribution to the solution of the problem of the abolition or restraint of secret ratemaking -- the one crying evil of the railroad situation. It is very far from solving the much broader problem of the regulation of the roads, but it is in itself good.

PITTSBURG, March 30. -- One of the fiercest wind storms ever known in this section struck the city to-day just before noon, did almost incalculable damage to property, and injured many people, some of whom may die from the effects of their wounds. Scores of houses were unroofed, many trees were blown down, mill stacks toppled over, and telegraph and telephone wires generally disabled.
following sales at auction are shown to-day at 111 Broadway:

Road drivers and the many pedestrians who journeyed to the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning were agreeably surprised to find the roadbed in good condition despite the rain of Saturday. The strong west wind that blew all night, combined with the early morning sun, had worked wonders with the course.

Crossed telegraph and electric light cables, which form a big tangle under the elevated structure at the southwest corner of Dey and Greenwich Streets, caused a blaze last night, which put about 100 wires into the Western Union Building out of commission.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 31. -- James Sheckard, the baseball player, has signed a contract to play with the Baltimore American League Club during the coming season, and is on his way to join the club at Savannah. Sheckard had previously signed with the Brooklyn National League Club.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31. -- Everything except Reading was cheerful and strong in the local market to-day. The most surprising development was the stubborn strength of Asphalt, this being the first market day since the Audit Committee's report was made public. In Electric Storage Battery common there was a sensational rise of nearly 5 1/2 per cent., and Union Traction rose 1 1/4 upon persistent buying.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 31. -- Mrs. Mabel Fenton Haines, charged with the murder of her two-year-old stepdaughter, Gwendolyn, who died on March 31 last, was on the witness stand for four hours to-day. She made a general denial to all the testimony offered by the prosecution. She positively denied by that she gave the child arsenic or cruelly treated her.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The vote on the Cuban Reciprocity bill in the Ways and Means Committee to-day stood 12 to 5. Two Republicans -- Tawney of Minnesota and Metcalf of California -- voted against it. The final vote in detail was:

ALBANY, March 31. -- Representatives of the Republican county organization of New York and of Tammany Hall were here today, ready to go on with the hearing before the Governor on the Weekes Primary Election bill, but the representatives of the Greater New York Democracy, evidently alarmed by Tammany Hall's espousal of the measure, asked for further time, and a postponement was finally granted by the Governor until Wednesday afternoon at 3 o'clock.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 31. -- At 4:45 o'clock this afternoon an explosion of gas in the Nelson mine of the Dayton Coal and Iron Company at Dayton, Tenn., ignited the dry coal dust in the mine and caused a terrific explosion. Twenty-two men are known to be dead. Ten bodies have been recovered and twelve bodies are reported to be yet in the mine.

The Mayor must be very blind indeed if he does not see that the forty patrolmen of the Twentieth Precinct who went out to do their sworn duty on Sunday by enforcing the excise law have dealt a fatal blow not only at the system of police blackmail and "protection" but also at his own "system" of tolerating open and habitual violation of the law.

HELENA, Mon., March 31. -- The changing of the method of listing stocks on the Board, adopted by the New York Stock Exchange to-day, came near causing a riot in Great Falls before the true status of affairs was discovered. According to the resolution of the New York board, in effect to-day, all mining stock of a value of over $10 per share is listed by percentage instead of by dollars.

There was a field day of the Board of Health yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions. Members of the board brought out the fact that the produce dealers on the east side are violating many laws of health and that the chief offenders are those who sell polluted milk, and that if this continues into the Summer time the infant mortality will be enormous.

Yesterday's stock market had to withstand a good deal of pressure. Rumors intended to be disturbing were given currency and there were coincident sales of short stock in an aggressive way. One falsehood given wide distribution and telegraphed out of town reported Mr. James R. Keene dying.
EL PASO, Tex., March 31. -- Sunday's bull fight at Jaarez, Mexico, was accompanied by a somewhat unusual feature, the goaded animal turning the tables on the matador.

The house bill at the Victoria Theatre last night said "Mr. Oscar Hammerstein presents French Opera Comique." "La Fille du Regiment" is French opera comique, but Offenbach's "La Jolie Parfumeuse," which was porfermed last evening, is not. It is opera bouffe, a vastly different thing.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, March 31. -- The Northern Pacific Railway Company has learned something of the way they do things in Canada that has opened its eyes. At the same time other American railways have been given notice to keep out of Manitoba; that the province proposes to monopolize its own railways, and to keep American lines south of the international boundary.

The traffic managers of railroads in the territory between New York and Chicago and St. Louis and of the steamship lines plying on the Great Lakes have reached an agreement which establishes a new flour and grain freight rates from the West to the Atlantic seaboard, and which, it is expected, will prevent the demoralization of rates and the complaints of small shippers about preferences and discrimination in favor of large shippers.

William G. Street of the stock brokerage firm of Street Norton, at 28 New Street, and a prominent club man of this city, was thrown from a saddle horse on the bridle path in Central Park last night, receiving a fracture of the skull, which the physicians at the Presbyterian Hospital say will cause his death.

-- One of our advertisers makes the interesting and decidedly impressive statement that in the last six days he has sold to hungry New Yorkers twenty-three carloads of eggs, which is 9,202 cases of thirty dozens each, or, to be still more explicit, 3,312,720 single specimens of the hen's best gift to man.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- The Grau opera season was opened to-night with "Aida," a work which has never been popular here, and the audience, which was a fashionable one, fell far short of filling the house. The boxes presented a gorgeous appearance, and the brilliant show they made in part compensated for some of the empty seats.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Navy Department about a month ago heard a report that Capt. Perry of the Iowa, at a banquet in Chile, had said that the Chileans could whip any other country in South America. The report, it was said, had caused a vast amount of excitement in the Argentine Republic, with which Chile is not on the best terms.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Mr. Lodge, Chairman of the Committee on Philippines, to-day reported to the Senate the bill temporarily to provide for the administration of the affairs in the civil government of the Philippine Islands. He said that he hoped to call up the measure for consideration at an early date.

The Democratic Party throughout the country can bear with much equanimity the retirement of Senator JAMES K. JONES of Arkansas, who for so long has held the post of leader or the minority in the Senate. Our dispatches from Washington intimate that this equanimity prevails in the Senate itself.
The revolt of the patrolmen of the WestThirty-seventh Street Station on Sunday night against the practice of reporting but few excise violations has spread to at least one other precinct.

Thomas L. Hamilton, the County Clerk of this borough, began yesterday a sweeping change which he intends to make in his office by removing seven of His subordinates. Among these men is one who has held the post from which he was dismissed, on a few hours notice, for twenty-seven years.

"Life," the "new drama" by Anson Pond, might better have been called death, or any other creature. It is the story of the Trouble Sisters, whb didn't want to be happy, and engaged the services of a sympathic dramatist to keep them out of the way of the happiness that pursued them.

The outcome of the meeting of the opposing forces in the National League of Professional Baseball Clubs, which is scheduled to take place this evening, will be awaited with considerable interest by lovers of baseball. For several months the League has been split into two factions, and a truce, even if it should only be of brief duration, will be welcomed by many.

About two months ago Commissioner Partridge told the Sire brothers, managers of the New York Theatre, that, they would have to get a separate license for the roof garden, and they at once made application. They were allowed as is usual in the case of theatres to continue their performance pending the granting of the license.

BOSTON, March 31. -- Call loans were marked up to-day, but demand was relatively light. The favorable New York bank statement has served to give some reassurance regarding the future of the situation, but as against this is an advance in sterling exchange rates to-day which suggests the possibility of early gold exports.
The police made a very satisfactory haul of reckless automobilists on Sunday. Five of them were caught and bagged and put under bonds for their appearance in court.

LONDON, March 31. -- Mrs. Brown Potter made a successful appearance this evening at Her Majesty's Theatre in the role of Calypso in Stephen Phillips's "Ulysses." She gave a new and charming reading of the part, though her acting is regarded as being somewhat marred by defective elocution.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 31. -- New York exchange was at 10 cents premium to-day. Time and call loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent. Biscuit common, after a rest of several days, suddenly came to life again in the local market this morning, and on the buying of a comparatively small amount of stock jumped two points, to 52 1/4.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 31. -- At Castleton to-night Lady Reel, dam of Hamburg and Frankfort, foaled a black filly by St. Simon. This is the first of the get of this noted sire in America. Lady Reel cost Mr. Keene $11,000 at the Daly sale, and Mr. Belmont paid $25,000 for a full brother to the youngster.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- "It is the purpose of the Inter-State Commerce Commission to employ every means within its power to secure an absolute observance of the provisions of the Interi-State Commerce act. The commission is not going to cease work because injunction suits have been begun with the same end in view."

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Immediately after the approval of the Journal to-day the House went into Committee of the Whole, and entered upon the consideration of the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill. Mr. Cannon, Chairman of the Appropriations Committee, in a brief preliminary statement explained that the bill carried $49,323,895, being $12,455,542 less than the estimates, and $12,572,012 less than the current law.

Encouraged by their splendid showing last season, the oarsmen of the New York Athletic Club have moved early this year toward placing crews in active training. Twoscore men journeyed to Travers Island yesterday and the day previous to participate in the first of the practice spins on the water.

It is plain enough that China has not yet learned her very costly lesson. The mining "concessions" offered to foreigners are no concessions at all. Twenty-five per cent. of profits might not be prohibitive, although such an exaction would prevent the exploitation of mines in which a large profit was not "in sight," and without much risk.

The fire in the hold of the Quebec Line steamship Pretoria was extinguished yesterday. The firemen experienced great difficulty at times in getting their hose in a favorable position, especially when the cargo of oil in the liner's forehold was endangered.
LONDON, April 1. -- The Times prints an article on the peace negotiations in South Africa, in which it is urged that the negotiators must not be hampered by the premature publication of terms.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Despite the threatening weather and a cold wind an immense throng journeyed to Bennings today to witness the Easter card of seven races. Four favorites won.
LONDON, March 31. -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Ancirew Clarkf, Agent General for Victoria, is dead.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

Wright Barclay has sold for George E. Ketcham the southwest corner of Broadway and Eighty-first Street, a plot 76.4 by 104.3, now covered by old two-story buildings. It is reported that Joseph Hamershlag is the buyer.

Cleopatra and her ladies of the Egyptian Court wore diaphanous skirts of brilliant tropical colors and held plain, every-day black umbrellas over their heads in the first outpuoring of the wonders of the Forepaugh Sells Circus for this season as the amazing aggregation of wonders turned out of Madison Square Garden last night and ventured into the stormy, chilly night.

PITTSBURG, March 31. -- A. Wellsburg, West Va., report says that the historic Franklin Methodist Episcopal Church, four miles east of Wellsburg, is in ruins, its venerable pastor is seriously injured, and several others are wounded. The Rev. Mr. Allshouse had reached the peroration in his impressive sermon on the resurrection when suddenly the gable end of the church was blown in.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was fairly well distributed, but very few stocks showed much activity. In the issues which attracted most attention prices were strong, and in a number of cases the final transaction showed substantial net gains. The list as a whole, however, was irregular, and a number of fractional declines were recorded.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- When Chairman Payne presented to the House the report on the reciprocity bill he gave notice that he would call the measure up one week from to-morrow. After reciting President Roosevelt's recommendations in behalf of Cuba, Mr. Payne says:

On Christmas Eve, in 1898, the husband of Mrs. HATTIE WOODWORTH was killed by a train on the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad at the Montrose crossing in Cortlandt County. The widow sued the company for $10,000 damages, not an excessive claim, certainly, if the company were at fault in the matter.

Matthew J. Ward Co. have sold the lease, furniture, and fixtures of the Hotel Gerard on West Forty-fourth Street for J. P. Hamblen's Sons to George E. Korst Co. Mr. Korst was formerly the proprietor of the Tremont and Beach Hotels, at Galveston, Texas.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- In the executive session of the Senate to-day Senator Bacon of Georgia offered a resolution requesting the President to defer the issuing of his proclamation announcing the acquisition of the Danish West Indies under the terms of the treaty recently negotiated with Denmark until the pending investigation of the charges of bribery made in connection with that treaty should be concluded by the House of Representatives.

BALTIMORE, April 1. -- The upward movement of Atlantic Coast Line common and preferred was the most conspicuous feature of to-day's market. The Street heard semi-official authentications of the report that the Southern Railway and the Atlantic Coast Line Company had secured control of the Plant system.

Columbia will hold a carnival of gymnastic events in the Columbia Gymnasium a week from to-night. The university, individual, and all around gymnastic championships will be decided, together with the interscholastic championships of the New York schools. The Columbia wrestling honors at middle, heavy, and light weights, will be contested, and there will be an interclass basket ball match between the sophomores and juniors.
LONDON, April 2. -- The Vienna correspondent of The Daily Telegraph says he believes from the indications that the Balkan situation has entered on a critical stage.

CHICAGO, April 1. -- At the session of the Inter-State Commerce Commission held here to-day the traffic managers and general freight agents of the Rock Island, Santa Fe, Milwaukee and St. Paul, Chicago and Alton, Burlington, Missouri Pacific. Wabash, and Chicago Great Western Railroads were examined as regards their knowledge of cutting rates on export traffic from the Missouri River to the Atlantic seaboard.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The announcement was made to-day from the White House that William Williams had accepted the position of Commissioner of Immigration at New York. He succeeds Thomas Fitchie, whose retirement was predicted in THE TIMES several months ago. To-morrow the names will probably be announced of the persons who are to succeed T. V. Powderly as Commissioner General of Immigration, and Edward McSweeney as Assistant Commissioner at the Port of New York.

While our sympathy is of course going out to the Mayor and the Police Commissioner, standing aghast at the showing how feasible it really was to enforce the excise law, and how farcical the pretenses that they have been making that it was enforced, there is another class of public servants who equally claim the sympathetic tear.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Senate Committee on Indian Affairs, at the instance of Senator Rawlins of Utah, agreed to-day to the incorporation in the Indian Appropriation bill of a section which will throw open to settlement the Uintah Indian Reservation, in his State. Subsequently the measure was reported to the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 1. -- Fearing that he would be arrested for theft, William H. Lane, a colored butler, shot and killed his employer, Mrs. Ella J. Furbush, her twelve-year-old daughter Madeline, and probably mortally wounded another daughter, Eloise, aged seven years, at their home, 652 North Fifteenth Street, shortly before noon to-day.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The investigation of charges made in connection with the Danish West Indies purchase was begun to-day before the special committee appointed by Speaker Henderson. Niels Gron, who brought the charges to the attention of Representative Richardson, was the first witness sworn by Chairman Dalzell.

LOUISVILLE, April 1. -- Delegates from all parts of the country are arriving here to attend the National Convention of the Allied Party, which will begin at noon tomorrow. Five hundred delegates are expected, representing the Populists, Socialists, Union Labor. Union Reformers of Ohio, the Public Ownership Party of St. Louis, the Liberal Party, recently formed in Ohio; the United Christian Party, and all other elements not associated with the Republicans or Democrats.

W. B. Dinsmore Jr., and L. M. Stockton the former National champion, were the winners yesterday in the opening matches of the tournament for the court tennis championship of America. The scene of the tournament was the courts of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club, West Forty-first Street.

The Sacred Ten have foregathered this year, taken themselves in hand, whipped up the laggards and malingerers, and stepped out together as one man. There was need, after the somewhat indifferent exhibitions of the past two years, and in view of the superior attractions offered by the Society, of American Artists, from which they seeded.

Alter many months of wrangling between the owners of baseball clubs in the National League, the leaders on both sides of the chasm of dissension met last night at the Fifth Avenue Hotel and, so far as reported, held a peaceful session. It was after 8 o'clock when they began business, and the first thing they did was to unanimously select "Nick" Young as presiding officer.

It was under hard conditions that the Treasurer and the friends of Barnard College set about the work of meeting the conditions of Mr. JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER'S gift. He had promised the college $200,000 on condition that a like sum be raised from other sources by midnight of March 31.

The New York Central Railroad is preparing to spend millions of dollars this Summer in improvements, the plans for which were prepared during the past Winter. The improvements will be mostly in the nature of new alignment of the roadbed, the elimination of curves by the construction of tunnels, and the like.
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Georgetown and Yale University baseball teams played a highly interesting game here to-day, though the former won by the margin of a single run. The score:

PHILADELPHIA, April 1. -- Trading was active in the local market to-day, and there were marked advances in a number of issues. Union Traction, Choctaw, Reading, Cambria Steel, and Consolidated Lake Superior common were the features and supplied 90 per cent, of the day's dealing's. In the forenoon a lively demand for Union Traction set in and carried the price up to 43, the highest since June, 1899.

Mayor Fagan of Jersey City has approved the new water contract, by which the East Jersey Water Company assumes the construction of the water plant begun by P. H. Flynn of Brooklyn and the Jersey City Water Company, and which should have been completed on Feb. 28 last.
Wrignt Barclay has sold for Daniel E. Seybel, for about $100,000, the five-story store and loft building 95 Duane Street, 26 by 116.9.

The movement which ex-Mayor Charles A. Schieren and other prominent independent Republicans of Brooklyn started some weeks ago to bring about a general change in the affairs of the party in the borough will take definite shape next week when the appointment will be announced of a committee of fifteen to take charge of the work of organization.

LONDON, April 1. -- Sir Henry Irving, Miss Ellen Terry, and their party, who were passengers on the Atlantic Transport liner Minneapolis, from New York, March 22, which reached her dock here at 8:30 o'clock this morning, were welcomed on their arrival by many theatrical friends.

The first of the changes toward a thorough reorganization of the Fire Department in Brooklyn, as planned by Commissioner Sturgis, took place yesterday, when Deputy Chief James Dale, who has been in charge in the borough for many years, and Deputy Chief John H. Perry were retired and younger men assigned temporarily to fill their places.

Yesterday was not as busy socially as the day previous. The Bachelors and Spinsters dance, dinners given by the Elbridge T. Gerrys, Mrs. Fowell, Thomas Gushing, and a luncheon by Miss de Peyster and several minor events made up the sum total of the entertaining. This evening the Century Cotillion will take place at Delmonico's.

A committee representing the United Real Estate Owners' Association of the City of New York called upon the family of the late Justice David McAdam at the McAdam home, 354 West Thirty-third Street, last night and presented to its members a set of resolutions in memoriam of the Justice as a token of the great esteem in which he was held by the association.
LONDON, April 1. -- The demand for money slackened to-day. Discounts were quiet.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Indian Appropriation bill as reported to the Senate carries a total appropriation of $9,415,339, a net increase of $973,834 over the total as the bill passed the House. The increases are generally comparatively small. The largest item of increase is $130,000 on account of the Delaware Indians.

[Telegram.] Lakehurst, N. J., April 1. To the Editor of The New York Times: We had supposed that the administration was going to reform the police. It looks as though the police were going to reform the administration. C. H. PARKHURST.

BOSTON, April 1. -- The money market is firm. Clearing House rate, 4 per cent. New York funds, 10 and 15 cents discount. Call loans, 4 to 5 per cent. Time money, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Clearing House exchanges, $20,724,026. Balances, $1,853,135.

Any unfavorable comment on the action of Germany in ruling against American meats treated with chemical preservatives would seem to be effectually estopped by the announcement that under the new meat inspection law, which goes into effect Oct. 1, 1902, not only the importation of such meat, but its production and sale in Germany, is prohibited.

SEATTLE, April 1. --Advices from Skagway state that Richard Frasier, an official civil engineer of the Canadian Government, and one of the most prominent civil engineers in Canada, has destroyed a Russian boundary monument. The monument was of stone, resting on a stone base, and there was a Russian inscription on it.

Alderman Bridges of Brooklyn was again the central figure at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday afternoon. The feature of the session was a lively tilt, in which President Fornes, Aldermen McInnes, Bridges, and Culkin participated.

The first annual statement of the United States Steel Corporation was made public yesterday after a meeting of the Board of Directors. The full statement from April, 1901, to March, 1902, with net earnings of each month, the earnings for the last month being estimated, is as follows:

BALTIMORE, Md., April 1. -- Members of the Fuller syndicate and the Varney Philadelphia syndicate arrived this evening to attend the open meeting of the City Council's committee to-morrow afternoon, at which the committee will likely either announce the acceptance of one of the four bids for the Western Maryland Railroad, or a recommendation that the bidders be given more time to revise their proposals.
LONDON, April 2. -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times says further particulars, compromising to Sarafof, (the Macedonian leader,) have transpired in regard to the capture of Miss Ellen M. Stone.

If anything were still required to prove the unfitness of the present Director of the Metropolitan Museum for the place he incumbers it would be the wish, expressed now many times by him and printed in divers newspapers without denial, that the big bronze called " Saturnalia," designed by BIONDI, should be bought and made part of the permanent sculpture in the museum.

ALTOONA, Penn., April 1. -- After mass meetings of the Rochester and Pittsburg Coal and Iron Company's miners had been held at Punxsutawney and Sykesville today, the threatened strike was formally declared. It involves 10,000 miners and will have the effect of curtailing the employment of nearly as many more railroad men employed by the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad Company, whose freight traffic will be nearly paralyzed in consequence of the strike.

BERLIN, April 1. -- The German preserved meat dealers, the strenuous allies of the American packers, in opposing the prohibition of the introduction of meats prepared with borax into this country, are organizing in their efforts to influence the Government not to enforce the proposed regulations. The dealers say the enforcement would work great injury to them.

The International Nickel Company, the $24,000,000 corporation recently organized to control a large part of the nickel output of the world, gave out an official statement yesterday regarding its composition, its intentions, and its organization.

The " pernicious activity" of those who are trying to crowd the metric system of weights and measures upon the country has been so far successful that they have succeeded in inducing the House Committee on Coinage, Weights, and Measures to report favorably the Shaforth bill, which imposes it upon every department of the United States, Government and makes it " the " legal standard after July 1, 1904, in all unofficial work and trade.

The security market was yesterday as narrow as has recently been the rule, and heaviness was shown by most of the list. A number of stocks in which manipulation has lately played a large part were inclined to weakness. The kiters of Colorado Fuel, for example, let that stock down sharply, after a spurt rise, but the mystery worked there still remains, and erratic quotations are not likely immediately to disappear.

ln the metropolitan championship bowling tournament last night the Prosperity bowlers defeated the Palace team, and the Manhattan five won from the Monarchs. The Stock Exchange games were postponed. The scores:

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Secretary of State and Mrs. Hay gave a dinner this evening, at which they entertained for the first time the President and Mrs. Roosevelt. The members of the Cabinet present to meet the guests of honor were the Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Shaw, the Secretary of War and Mrs. Root, the Attorney General and Mrs. Knox, the Postmaster General, the Secretary of the Navy and Mrs. Long.

Two mysterious fires in the home of William Hobson of 2,436 Morris Avenue, one with serious consequences, within the last five weeks have caused great alarm among the residents of old Fordham and Tremont villages, close to the boundaries of which the property is located. The first fire was on the night of Feb. 11, and endangered the lives of the family.

LOUISVILLE, April 2. -- The movement for the formation of an allied party, comprising adherents of all parties opposed to the Republicans and Democrats, or, as the call for the meeting stated, "a union of reform forces against plutocracy," took definite shape this afternoon when a convention, attended by about 200 delegates, representing eight States and as many different parties, was called to order in this city.
According to Sharon, Penn., dispatches the Sharon Steel Hoop Company has begun a one-million-dollar extension to its plant.

Except in a few stocks, trading in the outside market yesterday was dull, the transactions being even smaller than on Tuesday. Prices showed considerable irregularity, advancing sharply in some instances and falling off in others. Some new interest was added to the market by the introduction of the stock of the North American Lumber and Pulp Company, which was traded in to a fairly large amount.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont arrived to-night to inspect their villa, By the Sea, preparatory for the Summer's occupancy.

WASHINGTON April 2. -- A number of labor leaders who want the Government to build its own battleships were heard this morning before the House Committee on Naval Affairs. The result of this hearing was a distinct disappointment to the committee, who had been given to understand that witnesses would furnish expert testimony to show that the United States would benefit greatly by constructing her cruisers, from both a financial and a scientific standpoint.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., April 2. -- Chained to the floor of the kitchen of his home, on Elizabeth Street. Patrolman William Mc-Dermott this morning found Woitjec Sabalinsky, a ten-year-old boy.

Harmony, spiced with a dash of acrimony, reigned during the two sessions held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday by the baseball owners who control the destinies of the National League of Professional Baseball Players. The Freedman and Spalding factions got together for a peaceable settlement of their troubles, and they went at their work in a very businesslike manner.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Looking at the Patrick case without passion or prejudice, the verdict of guilty, from a medico-legal point of view, is simply, astounding. Patrick may be guilty, and the verdict may be in accordance with exact justice, but the public has not been put in possession of any evidence, either direct or circumstantial, of such guilt.
Mayor Low has issued a statement complimenting and indorsing Police Commissioner Partridge, and outlining the present city administration's attitude on police matters.

HAVANA, April 2. -- As the result of an interview between Lieut. Matthew Hanna, Commissioner of Schools for Cuba, and a secretary of Andrew Carnegie, the Mayor of Havana has received a letter from Lieut. Hanna in connection with a proposal from Mr. Carnegie to give $250,000 to the municipality for a public library.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The President to-day appointed Brig. Gen. R.P. Hughes a Major General, and Cols. Isaac D. De Russy, Andrew S. Burt, and M.V. Sheridan to be Brigadier Generals in the regular army, to fill existing vacancies caused by retirements.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 2. -- Society circles were surprised to-day by the marriage of Mrs. Robert Garrett, widow of the former President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, to Dr. Henry Barton Jacobs, formerly of Boston, and member of a prominent Massachusetts family. She is fortyseven and he is forty-five.

ALBANY, April 2. -- At a regular meeting of the State Commission of Prisons to-day, the Secretary presented reports of inspections of the jails of Ulster and Sullivan Counties, and of the Orange County jail, at Goshen. These reports show that the work of remodeling the old jail at Kingston into departments for women and juveniles, and rooms for hospitals and witnesses, has been completed.

BOSTON, April 2. -- The House this afternoon, after a long debate, refused to accept the adverse report of the Committee of Railroads on the bill making the maximum rate on railroads in the State 2 cents a mile, and substituted the bill for the report. The debate was led by Mr. Reed of Taunton, while the Railroad Committee were defended by Mr. Bullock of Newton.

TORRINGTON, Conn., April 2. -- The formal sessions of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Churches opened in the Methodist Church here this morning with the greater part of the ministerial and lay delegates accredited to the Conference in attendance.
Janpole Werner have sold the fivestory apartment house at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, 35 by 100.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- The steel tube mill planned by Andrew Carnegie just before the formation of the United States Steel Corporation is to be built near Conneaut Harbor, Ohio, this year. This information, it is said, came from Pittsburg and from a semi-official source.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- First Chord, Tamarin, Galgary, and Meistersinger were the winning favorites at Bennings to-day. Tamarin won the hurdle race easily, and Orontas, the outsider in the handicap, handily won from the odds-on favorite, Lamp O'Lee. Weather clear; track fast. Summary:

CHICAGO, April 2. -- Members of the Illinois Manufacturers' Association and their invited guests were present at the banquet of the organization which was held this evening. The program called for but one set speech, which was delivered by InterState Commerce Commissioner Charles A. Prouty of Vermont.

Mr. JAMES BRYCE is so well informed and so fair minded that the observations induced by his recent visit to Cuba, and published in the current North American, would be valuable for Americans desiring to inform themselves on the subject, even if he were himself an American.

LONDON, April 2. -- "Merrie England," an opera on the Gilbert and Sullivan pattern, by Capt. Basil Hood, librettist, and Edward German, composer, was produced at the Savoy Theatre this evening. It proved to be a delightful work. The characters represented include Queen Elizabeth, Sir Walter Raleigh, and the Earl of Essex.

Nevada N. Stranahan, the new Collector of the Port of New York, took the oath of office yesterday morning at 10 o'clock in the Collector's office, in the Custom House. The oath was administered in the presence of Collector George R. Bidwell by United States Commissioner Shields. The ceremony took only a few moments, and Mr. Stranahan then left here for Washington.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., April 2. -- What is perhaps the biggest mining suit in the history of Colorado has been filed in the District Court, and involves mining property valued at more than $5,000,000. The property affected is all located in the Cripple Creek district, and includes the famous Gold Coin mine.

ALBANY, April 2. -- Senators Brown and Malby, at the hearing before Gov. Odell to-day on the bill introduced by Senator Brown to permit the condemnation of riparian rights on any stream of the State which is or shall be recognized by law or use as a public highway, took occasion to criticise with much sarcasm the attitude of certain of the millionaire owners of estates in the forest preserve.

Lewis Nixon made several announcements yesterday about politics. He said that it was certain that Richard Croker would remain in Wantage, England, and would not return to this country to take part in the campaign this Fall. Mr. Nixon also denied the rumors that he was about to retire from the leadership of the Wigwam.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: Your editorial of this morning in opposition to the bill introduced in Congress for the establishment of the metric system is so at variance with the intelligent treatment one is accustomed to find in THE TIMES on all commercial questions, that I cannot refrain from expressing my surprise at your attitude.
