A joke at the expense of a bank is rare, but one turned up yesterday, and this one is on the Directors of the Mutual Bank, which for the past three years has been doing a profitable business at Broadway and Thirty-third Street.

Controller Grout made a statement at the meeting of the Board of Estimate which surprised Mayor Low and the other city officials present. The budget of the Supreme Court was being considered, when a representative of the Justices stated that the salaries under discussion were fixed by statute and, therefore, could not be changed by the Board of Estimate.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 2. -- "Butts" Underhill, the star pitcher of the Princeton 'Varsity team, returned this morning from Charlottesville, suffering from a severely wrenched knee, which will keep him out of the game for a week or two. Stevens and "Dana" Kafer will be relied upon until Underhill is again able to enter the box.

Now that the State Railroad Commission has had its authority extended by the Legislature to include the terminals of the elevated railroads in New York, we shall be interested in seeing how they will solve the problem of the nightly crush at the City Hall terminal of the Third Avenue line.

The tie between the Friendship Boat Club and the Wyanoke Boat Club for third and fourth prizes, in the Harlem Navy Bowling League tournament, was decided last night, the Friendship bowlers winning the larger prize. To-night the Ravenswood, Lone Star, and Bohemian teams will decide the tie for sixth prize.
LONDON, April 2. -- Money was decidedly easier to-day and discounts weakened.

ALTOONA, Perm., April 2. -- Not a mine of the Rochester and Pittsburg Coal and Iron Company was worked to-day. President Gilday, Secretary Gilbert, and National Officers McKay and Rice are in conference at Clearfield to-night. They telegraphed for National President Mitchell, but he answered that he was unable to visit this district at present.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 2. -- Chairman Newcomb of the Bankers' Committee managing the financial affairs of the EverettMoore Syndicate said to-day that it had been foiled impossible to secure the consent of parties holding a majority of the stock of the Detroit United Railway Company to sell the property on a basis of $70 per share, as proposed by the committee.

ALBANY, April 2. -- The feature of the hearing before Gov. Odell to-day on the Weekes Primary bill which aroused the most interest was the failure of the representatives of Tammany Hall to make an appearance. The hearing upon the bill was originally set for Monday. At that time Tammany was represented by ex-City Chamberlain T.C.T. Crain, Charles H, Knox, and Senator Grady.
"Rome was not built in a day." says the Mayor, "neither can a police force that has been growing more and more demoralized for years be purified in three months."

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 2. -- Contrary to expectation, the case of Mrs. Mabel F. Haines, accused of murdering her step-child Gwendolyn, was not given to the jury to-day. Both Mr. Budd, her counsel, and Jacob C. Hendrickson, for the State, occupied a much longer time than had been intended in their addresses to the jury, and the court rose as soon as Mr. Hendrickson had finished.

LONDON, April 3. -- Lord Kitchener, in a dispatch from Pretoria, made public last evening, announced that the Second Dragoon Guards fought a sharp rear-guard action near Boschman's Kop, Transvaal, on the evening of March 31. Four officers are known to have been wounded.

NEWARK, N.J., April 2. -- The final hearing in the suit of Henry J. Dittman and other stockholders to compel the Directors of the Distilling Company of America to pay dividends out of earnings which, it is claimed, they have been holding back to swell the working capital, was held before Vice Chancellor Emery to-day.

Aurel Batonyi, the well-known whip, returned to New York a few days ago after a three months' absence in Europe, and he stated yesterday that he would drive the coach Good Times this season as he has done in the last six years, when it usually ran from the Waldorf-Astoria to Inwood. The coach was sold last year to William L. Beadleston and George B. Hulme, both members of the American Coaching Club.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

The American Machinist has made a remarkable and significant collection of letters from the manufacturers of machinery in the United States as to their views on reciprocity and the tariff and the effect of these on the export trade. The circular letter by which these replies were obtained asked in general for opinions as to the passage in Mr. McKINLEY's Buffalo speech relating' to reciprocity, and, specifically, among others, these two questions:

BUTTE, Mont., April 2. -- Three thousand miners, employed in Anaconda, Parrott and Washoe properties, are walking the streets to-day, as a result of the strike of the stationary engineers at the mines of the companies.

C.M. Folsom won the handicap billiard tournament of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club in the final game last night. He met the winner of the first-class set, Florian Tobias, who had 200 points to go while Folsom had 115 to make. The latter secured his limit to 157 for Tobias. The winner's average was 2 15-50, and his high run 23, while Tobias made a high run of 35 and his average was 3 4-49.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- "Jack" Sheridan, the veteran baseball umpire, has signed for the season with the American League. Ban Johnson made the announcement upon his return to Chicago to-day. There has been considerable talk that Sheridan would jump to the National League.

BOSTON, Mass., April 2. -- Money was easier to-day. Clearing House rate, 4 per cent. New York funds, 10 cents discount. Call loans, 4@4 1/2 per cent.; time money, 4@5 per cent. Exchanges, $34,354,206. Balances, $2,571,655. The stock market was strong and active. Complete transactions were as follows:

BALTIMORE, Md., April 2. -- The market evinced a little more animation to-day, with a slight improvement in volume of sales and a firmer tone throughout the list. Cotton Duck issues loomed into a little prominence, the common stock scoring a good fractional gain, while the income bonds were very resisting at 46.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 2. -- With 493 entries and 456 actual starters, the Grand American Handicap opened at Blue River Park this morning, and at the end of the day 143 winning shots had a straight score of eight birds. There will be eight rounds each day until the list of withdrawals shall make it possible to shoot more.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- "The Commerce of the Pacific" was the subject of an address by O.P. Austin, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, delivered before the National Geographical Society at the Columbia Theatre in Washington this afternoon. In the course of his address Mr. Austin said:
LONDON, April 3. -- A Parliamentary paper issued yesterday gives correspondence respecting the comparative merits of the American, British, and Belgian locomotives now in use in Egypt.

The result of the outbreak of the Boxers, and of its sequels, upon China, according to the Shanghai correspondent of The London Times, whose account of it we have reprinted, was what might have been expected. That result is that it is necessary to modernize China, but very undesirable to Christianize it.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The newest thing in Cabinet rumors is a story that the President wants Senator Hanna in his Cabinet and purposes to offer him a choice of two portfolios. Those who are to retire from the Cabinet, rumor says, are the Secretary of State and the Secretary of the Interior.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- After consulting Chairman Dalzell of the special committee to investigate Capt. Christmas's charges in connection with the transfer of the Danish West Indian Islands. Secretary Hay has indicated to the committee his intention to appear in person before it as a witness.

WASHINGTON, D.C., April 2. -- The "Cotillion of Sixty Couples" held its Spring dance this evening under the auspices of Mrs. Charles H. Campbell, Mrs. John C. Poor, Miss Myer. Mr. Campbell, and Mr. Addison leading the dance.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 3. -- Mrs. Mabel Fenton Haines, who has been on trial here for the last nine days, charged with killing her two-year-old stepdaughter, Gwendolin, was acquitted to-day by the jury, which was out only an hour and a quarter. Mrs. Haines did not move when she realized that she had been freed of the charge.

With a great stock of brand-new fish stories, Hugh McLaughlin, the "only original political boss," as he proudly describes himself, returned yesterday to his home in Brooklyn from a long stay in Florida. The old leader of the Kings County Democracy, with his wife and the other members of his party, arrived in Jersey City late yesterday afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The press accounts of the hearing Wednesday before Gov. Odell on Senator Brown's bill amending the navigation law omitted reference to an illuminating re- mark by Senator Malby which was the sensation of the hearing, if one might judge from the hilarious demonstration which it evoked.

TAMPA, Fla., April 3. -- A mortgage for $2,000,000 was recorded here to-day by the Central Florida and Gulf Coast Railway to the Standard Trust Company of New York. The road is to be 135 miles long, and will run from Plant City to Boca Grande, Fla. Work is to commence in a few weeks.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 3. -- Fire of unknown origin destroyed property estimated at over $1,000,000 here to-day in the most valuable section of the city. The track of the fire burned all of that portion from the boardwalk between Illinois Avenue and South Carolina Avenue, extending back toward Pacific Avenue 250 feet.
LONDON, April 3. -- William Gillette gave a farewell supper in the famous " Beefsteak Room " of the Lyceum Theatre tonight to some of his London friends.

At the Methodist Conference yesterday Dr. Charles W. Millard, Presiding Elder of the New York District, which includes the greater part of Manhattan and the Bronx, reported remarkable progress during the past year. He deplored, however, the perplexing problems which have arisen from the peculiar social conditions on the lower west side and the crushing debts on enterprises which he said were built more on expectations than on common sense.

NEWARK, N.J., April 3. -- William M. Rice, President of the Distilling Company of America, was on the stand to-day in Chancery Chambers in the proceedings brought against that corporation by Henry I. Dittman and other stockholders of the Kentucky Distilling and Warehousing Company, one of the subsidiary companies controlled by the defendant corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The Senate bill to promote the efficiency of the revenue cutter service passed the House to-day by a vote of 135 to 49. The opponents of the measure fought it to the last ditch. At the very end they attempted to filibuster, but were swept aside by the overwhelming majority in favor of the measure.
LONDON, April 3. -- Money was in fair demand to-day, and discounts were firmer.

There was a lively domestic tilt in two of the parts of the Supreme Court yester- day growing out of the secret marriage of Emma Drew to John Galeano, both of 191 First Avenue, in the course of which the mother of the young woman said many hard things about her son-in-law, and accused her daughter in expressive language of unfilial conduct.

MONTREAL, April 3. -- A cablegram from London announces that Major Gen. the Earl of Dundonald, who headed the relief party into Ladysmith, will assume command of the Canadian Militia at the termination of Gen. O'Grady-Haly's term of office. Lord Dundonald has a great belief in the citizen-soldier as an increasingly important element in the defense of the State.

The powers and privileges granted by the Bedell bill, under which the New York Central Railroad purposes to im- prove its terminal facilities, would be subject to no control whatever by any local authority. They would be exercised subject only to the will of the State Railroad Commission, a body owing the appointment of its members to a political source and their compensations to the railroads themselves.

LONDON, April 3. -- So steadily does America's industrial invasion of Europe progress that even the monotony of American success cannot dull the keen interest and apprehension with which it is viewed on this side of the Atlantic. For instance, there is scarcely a London daily newspaper to-day but contains some reference to the inroads made by American enterprise.

BOSTON, April 3. -- Money conditions are slowly working easier. The banks are more inclined to let money out than in some time past, and rates, too, are shaded more readily. There is a slightly increased demand for loans, but the supply seems to be ample for all the calls. Sterling exchange continues very firm.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Senator Allison, Chairman of the Republican steering committee of the Senate discounts considera- bly the statement that the committee has decided there shall be no canal legislation this session. Speaking of the matter today, Mr. Allison said:
LONDON, April 4. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times quotes the views of "an important Dutchman," well acquainted with the Transvaal in regard to the South African war.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The investiga- tion of charges in connection with the Danish West Indies negotations was resumed to-day by the House Special Committee having it in charge. Among those present when the hearing began were Abner McKinley, Col. W.C. Brown, Carl Fischer Hansen, and Representative Gardner of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- It is positively determined that Lieut. Gen. Miles shall be retired under the provision of the law which permits the Chief Executive to plane on the retired list any officer who has served forty-five years, or who has reached the age of sixty-two. The date of retirement is not fixed, but it will not be postponed many months, and it may come within a week or ten days.

KANSAS CITY, April 3. -- At the close of the second day of the Grand American Handicap the number of wing shots with straight scores was materially reduced. Of the 143 who had not missed a bird when the shooting ended yesterday 89 dropped out to-day, leaving 54 who still have a straight score.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The first of the minority reports on the Cuban Reciprocity bill was filed to-day by Representative McClellan of New York, a member of the Ways and Means Committee, who argues that the bill gives Cuba much less in the way of relief than she is justly entitled to. He cites the Teller resolution and the Platt amendment as establishing our assurances to Cuba and the world.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 3. -- The market to-day was again dull, but firm. The Atlantic City fire had a diverting influence for a while, because a number of leading operators had families down there, and they forsook the Street to hurry to the seaside. Cotton Duck issues attracted some attention, the common stock advancing a shade higher, while the income bonds jumped a full point.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3. -- Union Traction and Choctaw showed considerable strength at the opening to-day and imparted a cheerful feeling to the general market. United Gas Improvement and Pennsylvania Steel were also notably active. A belief that Pennsylvania Railroad is increasing its holdings in the latter stock had something to do with the advance of nearly 3 points.

While James Tweed, a ticket seller on the Manhattan side of the Brooklyn Bridge, was away from his box returning his unsold tickets on Wednesday evening, the door of the box was forced open and $111.20 stolen. Tweed was only away three minutes. The thief vanished.

Yesterday was not brilliant socially; there were a few weddings, several dinners, and a number of teas and bridge and other card parties, and the series of dances known as the Saturday Junior Cotillions had their Easter dance at Delmonico's.

LOUISVILLE, April 3. -- Under the name of the Allied People's Party of the United States a new political organization was fromed here to-day, composed of reform elements opposed to the Democratic and Republican Parties.

BERLIN, April 3. -- The programme for the regatta at Kiel this Summer was published to-day. There will be thirteen races between June 26 and July 4, with supplementary events in adjacent waters lasting until July 14. Emperor William and most of the Princes will attend the regatta.

It is to be regretted that on the subject of the engineering management of the work of the Rapid Transit Commission public opinion is becoming hysterical. In these circumstances it is very easy to erect into sensations facts which are merely the necessary incidents of a great and, under the most favorable conditions, extremely inconvenient public work.
The Provident Realty Company has bought from James M. Fitzpatrick the property 57 Maiden Lane. Upon the expiration of existing leases, the purchasers will erect on the lot a twelve-story building.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- A statement prepared in the office of the Controller of the Currency shows that during the period beginning March 14, 1900, (the date of the passage of the act authorizing the organization of National banks with a minimum capital of $25,000, ,) and terminating on March 31, 1902, there were added to the system 919 National banking associations, with capital of $30,269,000 and bond deposit as security for circulation of $13,339,500.

Herr Ferdinand Bonn, who appeared for the first time in America last night at the Irving Place Theatre in Schiller's " Die Raeuber," is especially celebrated for the range and variety of his impersonations, a topic on which it is at the present moment, of course, impossible to speak. His first performance, however, revealed a highly striking artistic individuality.

Charles Ayer Whipple of New York must be a portrait painter of unsuspected greatness since that famous expert on art, Representative Amos J. Cummings, has introduced a bill in the House appropriating a sum " not exceeding $20,000 " for the purchase of a portrait of the late President painted from life by Mr. Whipple.

There is no question about the wit of Dr. PARKHURST'S epigram that whereas the administration was expected to reform the police, the police seemed to be reforming the administration. It is worthy of the vogue which it has at once attained. And the vogue of it shows that it appeals to the popular estimate of the facts in the case.

The Sons of the Revolution have exercised their option on the two lots 146 and 148 West Fifty-fifth Street and have acquired the property as the site for the organization's new building. Charles T. Barney is the seller and it is understood that the purchase price is $62,000. Plans have already been prepared for the new structure the distinctive features of which will be an assembly hall, a library, and a museum.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 3. -- The six prin- cipal Winter wheat States now promise to raise about as much wheat as last year. Conditions have improved materially the past fortnight. Kansas will plow up some, Ohio a little. The dry weather did the damage, and not the Hessian fly. Farmers are in good financial condition.

The Mayor yesterday approved what is known as the "sweep bill," which put in the exclusive control of the Board of Estimate the power to fix the salaries of city officials. He also approved the bill by which the office of Superintendent of Small Parks wag abolished, and giving to the New York Zoological Society the control of the Aquarium in Battery Park.

Senator Platt's son, Frank H., declared at the Republican Club dinner to the Republican Editorial Association of New York State last night, that he did not believe much of the blackmailing in this city which went on under the Tammany administration was prevented now. He made this statement in the presence of Mayor Low and other guests of the dinner.
LONDON, April 4. -- The opening sentence of an article dealing with German emigration to the United States, contribut- ed to The Morning Post by Poultney Bige- low, is as follows:

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., April 3. -- W. J. Carton, sixty-two years of age, a wealthy merchant of Utica, N.Y., who has been stopping at the Antlers in this city, lost control of a team which he was driving to-day and was thrown out of the buggy and killed.

A member of the uniformed police force in East Twenty-second Street Station said last night that members of both platoons in the Eighteenth Precinct will meet to-day to discuss the feasibility of joining with the other patrolmen throughout the city in the revolt against existing conditions in the matter of the enforcement of the excise law.
WASHINGTON, April 3. -- At the conclusion of a lively debate to-day the Senate passed the Oleomargarine bill by a vote of 39 to 31.
CAPE TOWN, April 3. -- Throughout this morning a continuous stream of people passed by the coffin containing the body of the Right Hon. Cecil Rhodes as it rested in Parliament House.

DUBLIN, April 3. -- The freedom of the City of Dublin was conferred to-day on John G. Redmond, M.P., (Chairman of the United Irish League and of the Irish Par- liamentary Party,) and Patrick A. McHugh, (Member of Parliament for the North Di- vision of Leitrim, who, with Mr. Redmond and Thomas O'Donnell, M.P., recently made a tour of the United States in the in- terests of the Irish League.)

ALBANY, April 3. -- Some plain language was used to-day at the hearing before Gov. Odell on the Greene bill to authorize the savings banks of the State to invest in the municipal bonds of Los Angeles. There was a delegation of bankers on hand to oppose the bill, John Harsen Rhoades, Andrew D. Mills, and Simon Rosendale acting as the spokesmen for the delegation.

A storm of adverse criticism on what is known as the Bedell bill has been aroused, and at the coming hearing before the Governor it is predicted there will be some very plain talk. The opposition is not confined to any one party or class. It has opponents everywhere.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained this evening at a musicale in the East Room, when Paderewski was the artist to delight a company of 300 guests. Preceding the musicale Mr. and Mrs. Paderewski were entertained at dinner by the President and Mrs. Roosevelt.

Serious objections to the Krum Corporation Tax bill were set forth in the statements submitted to the Governor at the hearing yesterday by Mr. LAWSON PURDY, Secretary of the New York Tax Reform Association.

A remarkable engineering work is now in process of construction on the Sault Ste. Marie at the point where Lake Superior empties into Lake Huron. To develop the 175,000 horse power caused by a 3,000 foot fall of the rapids at that point, a contract has been awarded for no fewer than forty generators, the impulse wheels to drive which are already in place.

BOSTON, April 3. -- In recognition of his long, busy, and fruitful life as a journalist, a theologian, a philanthropist, and a man of letters, several thousand of Boston's leading citizens gathered in Symphony Hall to-night to honor the Rev. Dr. Edward Everett Hale on the occasion of his eightieth birthday.

To that particular brand of humor of which George Grossmith is both creator and purveyor a large audience at Mendelssohn Hall listened last night with every evidence of delight. That a large number of those present were simply renewing a familiar pleasure was evidenced by the quickness of response in laughter to Mr. Grossmith's efforts -- the laugh not infrequently preceding the witty speech or the telling gesture.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 3. -- The students of the Yale Divinity School have for the first time in the history of the department organized a baseball nine, and nave secured the Faculty's permission to play a schedule of games. Captains were to-night appointed for the several class nines which have been organized to stir up enthusiasm in baseball and make, if possible, 'Varsity material for next year.

Mysterious influences by which policemen evade punishment for alleged misdeeds were evidenced at the trials of delinquent members of the force before Deputy Commissioner Thurston at Headquarters yesterday. In two cases policemen were called to answer charges of shamefully abusing young boys whom they had as prisoners.
Mr. PROUTY of the Inter-State Commerce Commission made a strong argument in Chicago on Wednesday in favor of the fixing of railroad rates by the Government.

Features of exceptional sort marked yesterday's Stock Exchange market. Narrow, important financial interests still waiting, the market's interesting features had to do with the specialties. The development most inspiriting in yesterday's market movement was an advance under investment demand of shares like those of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway, St. Paul, Omaha.

TORRINGTON, Conn., April 3. -- At the New York East Conference of Methodist Churches' business session this morning was the Rev. Dr. George E. Reed, President of Dickinson College, against whom charges were preferred by Dr. S.C. Swallow, formerly Prohibition candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania.

For the woman who likes associations with her wearing apparel, there are leather goods made at the smart harness maker's, which will please her. She can get a chatelaine bag made of pigskin, with a businesslike looking metal catch at the top, and she can have her belts made there, too.

LONDON, April 5. -- The London morning papers all comment in various terms of eulogy on the remarkable character of the munificent bequests of Cecil Rhodes, and the strong personality displayed in his testamentary dispositions.

The Alwil Shop of Ridgewood, N.J., has recently issued two privately printed volumes, "Hold Redmere; a Tale," by Thomas Wood Stevens and Alden Charles Noble, in an edition limited to 450 copies on paper and 50 on Japan vellum, and an unlimited reprint of Browning's "Pled Piper of Hamelin," which are far from being as pleasing in their mechanical details as were the shop's earlier publications, and notably its reprint of "The Apology of Socrates."
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The Senate today began consideration of the Chinese Exclusion bill.

Incarnation Episcopal parish, which has come to equal the more famous ones of St. Bartholomew's and Grace, under the rectorship of the Rev. Dr. Grosvenor, is to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of its founding a fortnight hence, and lay the cornerstone of a new chapel for Us east side work.

KANSAS CITY, April 4. -- Thirty-three wing shots made a straight score of twenty-five birds to-day in the Grand American Handicap, and at the end of the tenth round of the shoot-off fourteen men remained who had not yet missed a bird. The shooting then stopped on account of darkness. Fred Gilbert of Spirit Lake, Iowa, is the only thirty-two-yard man left in the race.

In the following list "mig" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

RECENT discussions in the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of biography and fiction have been both interesting and valuable. That biographical works, no matter how well written or how important the subect, invariably fall away behind the sloppiest of so-called novels, from the commercial or "selling" point of view, may be a deplorable fact, but it is none the less a practical one.

On Friday, March 14, Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge sold in London a second portion of the small but remarkably choice library of the late Earl of Orford. The first part, sold on June 10 and 11, 1895, comprised 340 lots and realized u2,609. The portion just sold included 217 lots, for which a total of u2,281 was paid.

LONDON, April 5. -- The will of the Right Hon. Cecil J. Rhodes provides for the establishment of colonial scholarships; for two scholarships to each of the present States and Territories of the United States, and for five scholarships for students of German birth. All the scholarships are for education at Oxford.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 4. -- Ex-Commodore and Mrs. E.T. Gerry arrived this morning to inspect the work on their villa and steam yacht Electra.

"The White Man's Burden" is the negro in the South, of whose character and destiny Mr. Dixon takes the most gloomy view possible. He has written a story dealing with the times of Reconstruction and with the negro problem, and he has packed into it every species of horror connected with that dire time and that unhappy race.

LONDON, March 26. -- In the course of his "real conversation" with William Archer in the latest number of The Pall Mall Magazine, William Heinemann, one of the most successful and progressive of London publishers, remarks that many booksellers in England never see a book of any value or importance, but live entirely by peddling novels, old and new.
LONDON, April 4. -- There was a good demand for money to-day, and discounts were firm.

Through Charles A. McCully, Secretary, and William A. Engeman, Treasurer of the New York Trotting Association, a contract for a match race between the trotting horses The Abbot, owned by ex-Fire Commissioner J.J. Scannell, and Liord Derby, owned by E.E. Smathers, was signed yesterday at the Hotel Rossmore, the race to be decided at the New York Trotting Association's Summer meeting at the Brighton Beach race track, between the dates Aug. 11 and Aug. 16.

Recent discussion in Paris discloses the impression, on the part of at least one of his most friendly critics, that Alphonse Daudet's philosophy of life was that of the fatalist and the cynic. We do not so read his books, which for thirty years had a strong influence on the French mind.

On March 17-21 Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge held in London, what was probably the finest book sale of the season, 1,314 lots bringing the large total, of u14,529 14s, -- the largest London auction total in three years, with the exception of that of the Fraser sale a year ago, which was u20,334 18s. 6d.

"Billy" McQuinn, able seaman on the schooner Isaac T. Campbell, and famous as a lawyer of the deep sea class, had an inning before Magistrate Marsh, in Stapleton, S.I., yesterday morning. "Billy" was the representative of himself and three other sturdy fellows who were before the Magistrate charged with a mutiny that occurred within the Harbor of New York and in plain view of the Statue of Liberty yesterday morning.

On Thursday, March 20, Bernard Quaritch, the son of the great bookdealer, gave u2,225 for the finest copy in existence of "The Ryall Book; or Book for a King," printed by William Caxton about 1487. The price is not only a record price for the book, (u1,350 was given last July for a copy,) but it is also the record price for a Caxton imprint, and the fact is one of unusual interest.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 4. -- The beach front between Illinois and New York Avenues to-day presents a scene of utter ruin and desolation. Of the many fine hotels which were situated in the district visited by yesterday's conflagration there remain standing the unburned portion of the Windsor Hotel, at the boardwalk and Illinois Avenue, and the charred framework of the Rio Grande Hotel on New York Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- There was a cheerful feeling in the local market to-day, but price changes were trivial. Strength was noticeable in Electric Company of America and Philadelphia Electric, both of which have been growing in favor the last few days. Union Traction, on the other hand, was much less active than at any time this week, and was inclined to droop, selling off one-half of 1 point during the last half hour.

Last evening was an especially busy one with several, dancing class meetings, pingpong tournaments, dinners, and bridge whist parties. To-day Mrs, James E. Martin will give a bridge party, and there will be several weddings.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The House today began consideration of the Chinese Exclusion bill. No opponents of the general principle of exclusion appeared, but members were divided in their support of the two bills presented.

LONDON, April 5. -- There was severe fighting all day long on March 31 in the neighborhood of Harts River, in the southwestern extremity of the Transvaal, between part of the force of Gen. Kitchener (Lord Kitchener's brother) and the forces of Gens. De la Rey and Kemp, resulting in the repulse of the Boers after heavy losses on both sides.

One of the most remarkable instances on record of equine nidification has been discovered by Mr. POULTNEY BIGELOW and described in The London Morning Post. It is nothing less than the unmasking of the purpose of Prince HENRY'S visit to the United States. The real object of that excursion was, it appears, to pave the way for a German "imperium" in our "imperio," to found a German State in the United States.

Toward the end of September last Dartmouth College celebrated the one hundredth anniversary of the graduation of Daniel Webster. The programme was such as usually obtains at similar celebrations -- ceremonies, banquets, with speeches, addresses, anecdotes, and poems dedicated to and explanatory of the character of the subject which had drawn those assembled together.

BY the New York State Library each January is Published a list of 500 book of the previous year as the best of the 5,000 published, and submitted to the librarians of the State and others interested for a vote as to which are the best fifty for the uses of a village library.

Local athletes carried off the honors in a majority of the open events at the annual games of the Fourth Regiment National Guard, New Jersey, at the armory, on Bergen Avenue, Jersey City Heights, last night, while the team of Company G won most of the prizes in the closed races. Summary:

What is a desirable length in a story? This is a question that often puzzles the beginner in literature. And yet it is by no means difficult to answer. Most editors of periodicals agree with regard to the ideal length of the short story; that it should be between 2,000 and 5,000 words.

When the adverse criticism upon the Bedell bill was read yesterday morning, copies of the bill were procured wherever possible by those interested. Several men who had read the opinion of John De Wilt Warner of the bill, said that his plain, outspoken words were none too strong.

The principal portion of the library, of A.J. Morgan of this city was sold at auction by Bangs Co., April 1 and 2, the 496 items, chiefly first editions or nineteenth century English and American authors, bringing large and in some instances record prices.

As a thoughtful study of the Indian problem Mr. Hamlin Garland's latest novel is worth attention, aside from any consideration of the love story which is deftly woven into the narrative. It is the misunderstood redmen that Mr. Garland has undertaken to interpret, the silent, sorrowful people who seem forever to be beaten back by the repeated incursions of the white men.

ON Jan. 11 a review was printed in these columns of an English work entitled "The Chronicles of the House of Borgia," by Frederick Baron Corvo. It was intended to be a severe criticism, pointing out inaccuracies of statement, material badly put together, and general want of constructive skill.

Through the whole gamut of European travel and sojourn about every phase has been expressed in a variety of ways. From the authoritative volumes of professional tourists to the impressions and emotions of the observing amateur set down in familiar letters to journals at home, about everything has been said.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: A short time ago I read in a Parisian paper an article on Philadelphia. What particularly struck me was that the author, toward the end of his article, said that the city did not possess the titles of its foundation, which titles, written in French, had without doubt been lost or destroyed.

BALTIMORE, April 4,. -- The market manifested a continued firmness without developing any marked activity. Cotton Duck issues were in large evidence, there being some marked signs of a willingness to support them at present figures, and even to carry them to a better level. There was an obvious attempt to hold them down arbitrarily without inflicting any hurt.

BOSTON, Mass., April 4. -- The money market is now very nearly back to a normal condition. Rates are gradually working easier, the banks are letting out money more freely, and the situation generally is quite comfortable. Clearing House rate, 4 per cent. New York funds, 8c and 10c discount. Call loans, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

"The Rochesterian," who conducts an infallibly interesting department of his own in The Rochester Post-Express, makes a suggestion which one would say was obvious, but is certainly not trite. It is made in the course of some comments upon a recent vote by the undergraduates of Rochester for their favorite novelists.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 4. -- Janitor George Rhodes was dusting off the shelves in C.H. Shinn's bicycle store at 1 o'clock this afternoon, when a messenger boy walked up to him with a telegram. Feeling sure that it contained bad news of some sort he opened it with a trembling hand. This was what he read:
LONDON, April 4. -- High diplomatic circles here are discussing plans, believed to be far advanced, for a visit by the Prince of Wales to the United States.

Applications for eldership by a number of preachers were considered at the morning session of the Methodist Conference in Grace Church, in West One Hundred and Fourth Street, yesterday, at its fourth day's session, when as before the delegates and visitors filled the edifice to the doors.

Although the beauty of trees has always appealed to landscape artists, who rely largely upon them for giving expression to the scenery they depict, they have not often taken much place in the literature of nature. Ruskin calls attention to them again and again in his delightful discourses upon the artistic appreciation of nature, and Starr King is conspicuous among the few writers who have done so in a literary way.

The charges against Capt. Foody were taken to Police Headquarters yesterday by Assistant District Attorneys Sandford and Train. Commissioner Partridge would not make them public. He will sign them today and they will be served on the accused officer, who is on sick leave. The date of trial is uncertain.

THE splendid collection of Marshall Clifford Lefferts of this city, which was privately sold last Fall to George H. Richmond, is to come upon the open market, Bangs Co. selling the early English literature portion in seven sessions, April 21-24, and the Americana going to Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge, for sale in London, some time in May.

By Three Men in Public Eye. Andrew Carnegie's new book, to be published by Doubleday, Page Co. April 12, is called "The Empire of Business." In this volume Mr. Carnegie, whose direct style and felicity of phrase are well known, talks of matters in which he has shown himself one of our masterful figures.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, April 4 -- The condition of the retail book trade in the United Kingdom is illustrated in the announcement of a Manchester dealer who sells six-shilling novels at the rate of twelve for 20s.; to the trade prices are considerably lower.
Trade reports to the several commercial agencies continue most hopeful. Bradstreet's sums the situation up as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The time of the Cabinet to-day was taken up almost entirely with the communication which the President has received from the Governor of Louisiana protesting against the camp alleged to be maintained in that State by agents of the British Government for the purpose of supplying mules and teams to the British Army in South Africa.

One gets an insight into queer old days when one gets hold of an old newspaper. Here are some facts from the City Record, as one might call it, of nearly 200 years ago. It is a curious specimen of a newspaper, The London Gazette, Published by Authority, from Thursday, Dec. 8 to Saturday, Dec. 10, 1709.

An extraordinary tale is that told elsewhere in these columns by the author of "The Chronicles of the House of Borgria." It is not often that we hear of such utter disregard of the rights of authors. As a rule publishers are cognizant of the ground upon which their relations to the author exist, and respect the unwritten law.

JULIA CARTRIGHT, Mrs. Henry Ady, has given us, in her account of Dorothy Sidney, First Countess of Sunderland, a most readable chronicle not only of the Sacharissa of Waller's poems, but of the entire Sidney family, and many of the descendants, as well of the Spencers, her husband's family, and of a large circle of friends.

"LETTERS OF DANIEL WEBSTER" will be an important contribution to American history to be brought out this Spring be McClure, Phillips Co, Letters sent and receives by Webster were collected for many years by C.H. Tyne, a Fellow in History, University of Pennsylvania.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday went beyond a million shares. The foremost commission firms of the Street figured conspicuously in this new activity. On these two accounts -- the broadening of the market and the character of interests seeming most largely to participate in it -- the day's record gets attention.

It is an earnest of good things in the future that "Parables of Life," by Mr. Mabie, should be the first volume issued by The Outlook Company and that it should be dedicated to Lyman Abbott. The two names stand for active faith in life and humanity. The buoyant energy and the steadfast spiritual vision that illuminate the pages of the book make it a helpful companion for a working day or a dull day.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- Dr. Thomas Dunn English, who died this week in Newark, was born in Philadelphia in 1819, and was graduated in medicine at the university here twenty years later. He began his literary career while still a resident of this city, when at the age of sixteen he contributed to the old Advertiser and other Philadelphia journals.

The muddled Shrievalty situation in Brooklyn was further complicated yesterday by a decision rendered by Justice Gaynor, in which he declared that Charles Guden, whom he recognizes as Sheriff, must have access to Raymond Street Jail, and must not be interfered with by Col. Norman S. Dike, Gov. Odell's appointee.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- Lajoie, the second baseman of the Philadelphia American League Club, to-day refused an offer of a salary of $7,000 a year for three years made by an agent of the New York National League Club. Lajoie said: "I have received nothing but the best treatment possible from President Shibe and Manager Mack.

It is gratifying news that Russia has been induced to make specific those vague promises in respect to the evacuation of Manchuria with which she has been amusing mankind for years. The credit of extracting this promise is immediately due, doubtless, to the publication of the Anglo-Japanese agreement.

The quarterly statement of the United States Steel Corporation has the conspicuous advantage of containing no surprises, and its discussion in financial and business circles has called out nothing of greater general interest than an agreement that the policy of the company in holding the market steady in the face of diminished net earnings is very wise and far sighted.

Negotiations have been completed under which the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company will acquire on or before July 1, 1902, the Savannah, Florida and Western Railway Company, the principal of the railroads comprising the Plant system, which is to be consolidated with and made a part of the purchasing company.

LONDON, March 19. -- The more one studies the publishing trade the more abstruse do its mysteries because the approaching coronation will disastrously affect the book trade. They want us to believe that because there is to be a great street pageant on a day in June people will decline to buy or read books in April and May.

The Commercial State Bank will open its doors for business about May 1, in the McCreery Building, at the corner of Broadway and Eleventh Street. The institution was organized especially for the accommodation of the vast colony of retail, jobbing, and wholesale merchants in that section of the city.

With the announcements of the complete playing schedule yesterday in the National League games the lovers of baseball have an excellent series of contests in an eightclub circuit ahead of them, and the amicable settlement of difficulties is appreciated by all genuine admirers of the sport.

A meeting was held yesterday in the hall of the Central Metropolitan Tabernacle. Seventh Avenue and Fourteenth Street, by a number of policemen's wives, mothers, sisters, and sweethearts, to uphold the policemen who have recently "revolted" and to speak in favor of the three-platoon system.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Outsiders came to the relief of the bookmakers at Bennings to-day, only one favorite. All Saints, winning. The attendance, owing to rain, was reduced materially. Track good. Summary:

LONDON, April 5. -- The correspondent of The Times at Madrid says that apparently Senor Sagasta has come into office with one clear and decided policy -- to remain in power at all costs and with the sacrifice of any principles. At the present moment he has no great question to decide, but he has chosen an alliance with the progressive radicals and will surely have to pay.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Perhaps a point may be added to the arguments of the editorial, "The Scarcity of Poetry," in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of the 8th inst., and the two newspapers therein quoted. Probably as much good verse is being written to-day as ever, but not all of it "breaks into print."

TRENTON, N.J., April 4. -- The Cummins Indian Congress and Wildest West Company, capital $1,000,000, was incorporated here to-day, to own and manage Indian and wild west shows. Incorporators -- Frederick T. Cummins, J. Hardy Kugler, and Charles Stow, all of New York.

Mr. EDWARD F. McSWEENEY, the Assistant Commissioner of Immigration at this port, has performed the duties of his office with such fidelity to law and the public interest that earnest protests against his removal, reported to be impending, have been made by the principal church and charitable organizations Whose immediate interest in the welfare of immigrants has given them knowledge of the working of the bureau.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: "American Authors and Their Homes" to one of its readers has revived old acquaintances and introduced new ones. A companion volume would be acceptable, giving the homes of our women authors. An unexceptionable list of such is en evidence, their habitat not confined to the Atlantic seaboard.

NEWARK, April 4, -- An insight was given to-day into the value of distilling plants, and of the whisky business in general, by President Edson Bradley of the Kentucky Distilling Company during his testimony in the proceedings brought by Henry I. Dittman against the Whisky Trust, officially designated as the Distilling Company of America, to enforce the payment of dividends to stockholders given before Vice Chancellor Emery.

KATE DOUGLAS WIGGIN, in private life Mrs. George C. Riggs, the author of the "Penelope" rambles in Ireland and Scotland, the fortunate writer whose story, "The Birds' Christmas Carol," has been translated for readers of every known race in the world, including those strange textbooks that are tenderly understood by the blind, lives in New York during the Winter months.

THESE attractive volumes present the most serious attempt yet made to portray the history of a state which has borne an important but often unrecognized part in our National career. Overshadowed in her position between the two greatest States of the Union, and the recipient of many titles the reverse of complimentary, New Jersey -- has persistently and effectively minded her own business and realized her State motto of Liberty and Prosperity.

JOPLIN, Mo., April 4. -- Unusual conditions prevail in the zinc ore market this week, and for the first time since, the boom of 1899 all of the mine owners refuse to sell their ore at high prices offered by anxious ore buyers. Many mine owners refused to sell at the top price paid for zinc ore last week, $37.50 per ton, and $40 ore is one of this week's probabilities.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- The decision of Judges Grosscup and Humphrey of the Federal Circuit and District Courts, respectively, in the injunction cases brought by seven Chicago public utility corporations to prevent, the collection of taxes assessed as a result of mandamus proceedings in the State courts some time ago, was read from the bench by Judge Grosscup to-day.

ST. LOUIS, April 5 -- Most sensational charges are made by the Grand Jury, which has been investigating bribery and official corruption in the Municipal Assembly, in its final report to-day to Judge O'Neill Ryan in the Criminal Court.

In Mrs. Heekford's account -- she speaks as "an old resident in the country districts of the Transvaal" -- of the pass laws and the way they were worked: "Any white person meeting a Kafir walking quietly through the country outside a Kafir location had the right of stopping him and demanding his pass.
CHICAGO, April 5 -- New York exchange was 25c discount before call and 10c discount alter call. Time and call loans, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent.

The Adapter and the Ass's Head. "A Modern Magdalen," the piece for which Miss Amelia Bingham has discarded "The Climbers" at the Bijou Theatre, is an admirable example of the monstrosities inflicted upon a long-suffering public by the adapter of foreign plays.

PARIS, April 5 -- France has entered into the throes of an election period. Immediately after the session closed Sunday the members of the Chamber of Deputies left Paris for their respective constituencies, and they are already engaged in canvassing. Thursday was the first day for the declarations of candidacy, and up to yesterday a thousand candidates had presented themselves.

LONDON, April 5 -- As might have been expected, professional dramatic criticism is as hostile as possible to "Ben Hur" at Drury Lane, and several newspapers note the boos and hisses at the scene on the Mount of Olives at the first performance, although I remained in the theatre till the last curtain and heard nothing but generous applause and saw nothing but respectful attention.
BOSTON, April 5 -- There is wailing in the bosom of the Somerset Club, and the souls of its aristocratic residents of the Back Bay are filled with grief, all on account of Senator Henry Cabot Lodge.

The tournament of the Morning Newspaper Bowling League has been concluded, the teams finishing in the following order: First, New York Tribune; second. New York Herald; third, New York Journal; fourth, New York World; fifth, New York Commercial Bulletin; sixth, New York Times.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 5 -- The Newark Metnodist Episcopal Conference met behind closed doors in St. James's Church this morning and for two hours considered matters relating to the support of conference members and charges and the qualifications of probationers and candidates for the ministry.

The charges against Capt. Michael E. Poody of the Twentieth Precinct, which were prepared under the supervision of District Attorney Jerome, were yesterday signed by Commissioner Partridge and Senior Inspector Cortright and served on the defendant. The date of trial was set for next Wednesday, but Capt. Foody is on sick leave, and until he reports for duty or is ordered to so report by a Police Surgeon the trial will not proceed.

President Louis F. Haffen of the Bronx, in a letter yesterday morning to Mayor Low as Chairman of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, notified him that he would introduce the following resolution at the next regular meeting of the board:

Louis Goldstein of 43 Belmont Avenue, Brooklyn, who says he was expelled from the New York University Law School as the result of a charge of "flirting" by mail with Miss Lillian S. Newmarck, another student, considers the action of the Faculty unjust and declares that he will bring legal proceedings for reinstatement.

The declaration by the Directors of the Southern Railway Company of 2 1/2 per cent on the preferred stock puts the $60,000,000 of that issue for the first time on its full 5 per cent. basis. The incident signalizes progress by a property which has emerged from a condition in which few of the railroads of the country found themselves even at the worst periods of their history.

FOR over a century Long Island has enjoyed the distinction of being the great pleasure ground for the inhabitants of New York. Within the last twenty-five years this fame has been augmented to a remarkable degree by the rapid growth of country homes, club life with its attendant variety of sports and seashore attractions almost unlimited in scope.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 5 -- While there was an exodus of visitors to their homes on Monday last, and notwithstanding the big fire there are many thousands of guests remaining who intend to spend the early Spring here. Only three of the really prominent hotels were put out of business by the fire and the larger hotels are all crowded.

The President of the Merchants' Association, D. Le Roy Dresser, in accordance with the resolution adopted unanimously at the recent meeting of the Board of Directors, yesterday appointed William Edmond Curtis, one of the Directors; S.G. Mead, Assistant Secretary, and William R. Corwine, a committee for the purpose of considering the Bedell bill.

IF the Chinese pot is only simmering just now, will there be a bolling over in the future? Dr. Morrison, the most reliable of correspondents, whose opinions as printed in The London Times are given dally in THE NEW YORK TIMES, certainly takes no pleasing view of coming conditions in China. In a recent number of The Forum the Hon. Charles Denby, our former Minister to China, explains what were his experiences.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The State Department to-day made public the correspondence that has so far taken place between the United States Government and the Government of Louisiana respecting the latter's statement touching the shipment of live stock and supplies for the British army in South Africa from Chalmette, La.

Zinc ore has jumped up to a price hitherto unprecedented. Kansas and Missouri arc enthusiastic. Following is a review of the improved conditions from an authority at Joplin, the central point of Missouri production -- of the country's producing zinc territory:

MORE than half the news appearing under date lines in the daily papers of the country is furnished by correspondents. Some of these are attached to the regular staff of the journal, but by far the larger portion is from those who live in the communities from which they write, and upon whom the paper must depend absolutely for its authority.

Theatrical managers of this city were going about yesterday with gloom covered countenances, asking each other and everybody else "What next?" For an action just brought against Oscar Hammerstein has added another problem and another woe to theatrical managers, already, by their own account, over-burdened with vexing questions.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Representative Fowler's bill, "to maintain the gold standard, provide an elastic currency, equalize the rates of interest throughout the country, and further amend the National bank laws," is to be favorably reported. The House Committee on Banking and Currency so voted to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on "Mayor Low and the Police" is timely and to the point. The action of the patrolmen in various precincts proves two things very conclusively -- first, that the laws have been openly disregarded and violated, and, secondly, that it is possible, and even comparatively easy, to enforce the laws.

Joshua Crane, Jr., of the Boston Athletic Association, yesterday won the amateur court tennis championship of America for the second consecutive time. His opponent was L.M. Stockton, Boston Athletic Club, former National champion, and the competition was played on the court of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club before a crowd of experts that filled every available place from which the match could be viewed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your editorial in to-day issue of your paper, "China and Christianity," is it not too early to pass judgment and ren- der a final judgment? for you sum up the whole problem stating, "To modernize China, but very undesirable to Christianize it."

Arrangements were completed yesterday by which the West End Lawn Tennis Club obtained the lease of grounds for new courts. The plot is located on the south side of One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, on the block bounded by Amsterdam and Morningside Avenues. They also secured the option on another section of the same block, which adjoins the property leased.

The policy of providing at public expense an educational institution for the training of youths to enter upon commercial pursuits is one in which toe City of New York, as the greatest seaport in the New World, has more than an ordinary interest.

Nathan B. Chadsey, a young man who was a business associate of John Frederick Pelham Suffield, the lawyer and magazine writer who was fatally injured on the Sixth Avenue elevated tracks near Bleecker Street on Wednesday last, thinks that his friend was murdered. He so informed the Coroner and Capt. Titus on Friday last, and yesterday gave out statements for publication amplifying what he told the two officials.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a married man. Should you ask, With or without? I would say without issue. It would therefore seem that the way should be an open one. I am one of a lot roaming the world seeking the realm where comfort entertains her chosen few. I want to be put among those that have sought alleviation and have been permitted to find it.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 5 -- All doubt that the Goulds and the Wabash Railroad Company are interested in the West Virginia Central Railroad syndicate headed by Edward L. Fuller, which now seems to be in the lead of the bidders for the Westera Maryland Railroad, was removed to-day when Mayor Haves received this note:

BALTIMORE, April 5 -- The marriage of Miss Mathilde Keyser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Keyser, to William Manly, will take place on April 23, and that of Miss Mary Vickery to Charles Playforth on April 21.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 5 -- Polo practice on the Georgian Court grounds brought out a large crowd of spectators this afternoon. A team consisting of George J. Gould, Kingdon Gould, Jay Gould, and P. J. Collier played a match with Charles Snowden, Isaac Blair, James Blute and James Duncan.

Stock Exchange activity -- in character and volume a reminder of records made in the early stages of last year's security market movement -- has marked the close of the Stock Exchange week. Generally the market has not materially broadened; but under the leadership investment stocks like Northwest, St. Paul, Louisville and Nashville, and Union Pacific a much improved sentiment has developed, and the list of net changes for the week include many inspiriting advances.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 5 -- The trading in the local stock market to-day was quiet and very steady. Union Traction held around 43 /3/3 discounting the future. Philadelphia Electric issues reflected an undercurrent of strength and closed with a slight gain. While the boom in Choctaw shares is believed to be practically over, the common rose from 80 to 80 1/4 on the second sale, but there was the activity.

When the digestive organs are in a healthy condition, these organs extract from the food all that goes to make good rich blood, firm muscles, steady nerves, and a sound, healthy body. When irritated, congested, or inflamed, they fall to do their work properly and loss of flesh, shattered nerves, indigestion, sour stomach, flatulency, and heart burn follow.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- [Special.] -- Under the general title of "Col, Watterson's Bogy," THE NEW YORK TIMES, prefacing its ill-opinion of a recent speech of mine to an association of Virginia Democrats by some observations of a kind rather flippant than convincing, proceeds to say:

LONDON, April 5 -- Money was somewhat easier to-day and discounts were firm. Business on the Stock Exchange remained dull, the public keeping aloof, awaiting the elucidation of the situation in South Africa. Consols and gilt-edged securities were easier. Home rails were motionless. Grand Trunks were harder.
The joint athletic games of Company H, Eighth Regiment, and the Xavier Athletic Association, were held last night in the armory of the Eighth Regiment, a big, enthusiastic crowd witnessing them.

TELLURIDE, Col., April 5 -- Col. S.B. Ludlum, Superintendent of the Keystone Placer Mining Company, whose mines are located about four miles west of town, was almost instantly killed, and Peter Epswich was seriously injured by a hydraulic giant which became unmanageable.

LONDON, April 5 -- There is no disguising the fact that there is a great deal of anxiety on all hands concerning the new budget, the introduction of which in the House of Commons next Thursday by the Chancellor of the Exchequer promises to be the most absorbing topic of the week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent issue of your paper I notice an article in which you quote from Dr. Edward J. James, President-elect of the Northwestern University. Dr. James claims that "co-education is losing ground in the very territory that it had completely won." This refers, I suppose, to the Central West, which is more or less influenced by some of the Eastern ideas on this subject.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A correspondent, whose letter is published in to-day's issue of your paper, is, in a great measure, mistaken as to the "kindness" of the elephant.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wadsworth brought the evening events of the week to a brilliant close by a musicale last evening at their Dupont Circle home, the occasion being the first concert of the singing class which has been holding weekly meetings in Mrs. Wadsworth's ballroom.

A big mastiff created terror in the vicinity of Flushing and Knickerbocker Avenues, Williamsburg, last evening. He bit sixteen-year-old William Matz so severely that the fingers of his left hand may have to be amputated, and also slightly lacerated the legs of Lizzie Schmidt, seven years old, of 1,070 Flushing Avenue.

MR. EMIL PAUR'S infatuation for Richard Strauss went to considerable lengths when it placed an air from that composer's "Guntram" between the first and the last of Beethoven's symphonies at the final Philharmonic concert of the season. The announcement was to the effect that a Beethoven programme be performed in celebration of the conclusion of the society's sixtieth year.

Entries for the court tennis championship of the Eastern States closed yesterday at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club. The matches will be played in the court at Tuxedo, N.Y., beginning Ariril 12. T. Suffern Tailer has offered a gold racquet as emblematic of the championship, which will be played for the first time at this tournament.

New York was "dry" during the early hours of this morning. The police were out in full force and on the watch, but the saloon keepers closed up without any warning and as if they were actually scared. Even the Raines law hotel keepers closed up, with quite a number of exceptions, however, and bars were exposed all over the city.

GLASGOW, April 5 -- The great crowds which gathered at Ibrox Park to-day to witness the last international association football contest between teams from England and Scotland caused the collapse of a portion of one of the spectators' terraces, resulting in the death of five persons and the injury of 125 others, mostly all men.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A real but not intended commentary upon the hypocritical character of our reform administration appears on the last page of this morning's TIMES under the heading, "Unlucky Spitters Fined." It appears that twenty-six sad unfortunates were accused of the fearful crime of expectoration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Verily THE TIMES was liberal to the point of prodigality in its assignment of space yesterday to the mess of verbiage and twaddle contained in the letter signed "Fiat Justicia" by the man who had lashed himself into an ecume over the Patrick verdict.

WASHINGTON, D.C., April 5.-A large crowd witnessed the sport at the Bennings track to-day. Only two favorites finished first. The Hunter's Steeplechase was captured by Headland, an odds-on favorite, after a hard drive from Champion. The handicap steeplechase was won in hollow fashion.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 5 -- The local market to-day, while not active, was quite firm. The general undertone indicated a growing belief in an approaching advance to a higher level in prices. As a consequence the majority of issues traded in commanded a better figure. The Cotton Duck issues again attracted attention, being-among the most prominent, both by reason of frequent appearance on the tape and the tendency upward.
The representative of a newspaper, a young man, sat for his picture yesterday morning in the Rogues' Gallery. His companion did not need to be photographed. His picture was already there.

Columbia University is preparing for the installation of Nicholas Murray Butler as President of the institution. The official part of the occasion is confined to Saturday, April 19. Alumni and students have arranged for a celebration that shall last for three days. There are to be dinners, athletic sports, formal speeches and greetings, and a ball on a larger scale than ever attempted before by the Columbia students.

Every sub-contractor on the Rapid Transit Subway has suffered because of the two recent disasters on one section of the work. That section was No. 4, Major Ira A. Shaler's, and he naturally sustained the most direct injuries, but all the others have lost money through a popular revulsion of sentiment following the accidents.

Every saloon in every borough of the city not provided with and acting up to a Raines law hotel license is to be closed to-day. This was the determination reached by the patrolmen in council, and at least 5,000 of them will be on duty to carry this determination out.
In no other country save ours could one meet with the sight that greets one in the gallery and lounging room of the Democratic Club.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 -- The baseball season opened here to-day with a game between the local American League club and the Yale University team. Leary, who pitched last year for the University of Pennsylvania, was on the rubber for the local team, all of the regular pitchers being still in the South.

TORRINGTON, Conn., April 5 -- At the business session of the New York East Conference of Methodist Ministers to-day a dispatch was read from New Haven announcing the death of one of its members, the Rev. Morris Hill. A telegram of sympathy was ordered sent to the family.
F.A. Hood is in receipt of the following letter from W.J. Bryan in response to a letter written to Mr. Bryan just after the recent anniversary banquet:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 5 -- The Country Club held its Spring open handicap golf tournament to-day, and there was also an open handicap on the links of the Golf Club of Lakewood. In the Country Club tournament there were over forty players, and thirty-one returned cards. George T. Brokaw of Princeton led the field with a net score of seventy-six.

Under the leadership of the veteran President they form a powerful, well-organized party within which personal ambitions are loyally subordinated to public ends; and the eventual successor to President Diaz is already practically determined upon, so that the fear sometimes expressed lest upon the death of that great ruler the country should be in danger of a revolution has no reasonable foundation in fact.

Henry A. Reed of the Bishop Gutta Percha Company of this city, who is one of the first experts on the commercial and industrial staple in which his corporation is interested, read with interest the following cable message published the other day in THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Sixteen automobiles drew up in line before the clubhouse of the Automobile Club of America yesterday morning, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, to take part in the first run of the season to Ardsley. President A.R. Shattuck lea the procession, acting as pacemaker, as no attempt for fast time or record was allowed.

The cycle racing season in the East will open earlier this year than heretofore. The opening date, April 13, at Vailsburg, N.J., is the earliest day ever scheduled for an outdoor meet in the history of the sport. For several weeks the professional racers in the different training camps about the country have been preparing for a hard campaign this year, and indications point to a very large turnout of riders at the initial meet.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent request from Gen. Wood to Secretary Root to have the wreck of the ill-fated Maine raised, recalls attention to a subject of absorbing interest.

FOR the past ten days Washington has been full of tourists. The general notion that early Spring is the best time to visit Washington, coupled with the numerous teachers' excursions due to the Easter holidays, have filled the Capitol galleries daily with a more admiring and appreciative throng than the Nation's solons get all Winter.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

EVEN to this day it is a mooted question why a salmon takes a fly. Is it because the salmon is hungry, or is it that curiosity is the motive? The life work of Prof. Miescher of Basel was devoted to the study of salmon, and in The Popular Science Monthly Prof. Yandell Henderson of Yale University presents the results of Miescher's investigations.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Democrats in the Senate are divided on the question of Cuban reciprocity, and it is very probable that a majority of them will oppose the bill when it passes the House and comes before the Senate.
Under its new charter, signed by Gov. MURPHY while the fire was raging most fiercely, all buildings hereafter erected within the municipal limits of Atlantic City must be fire-proof.

There will be a number of presentations at court this year in London, and among the women who are to make their bows before the King and the Queen Consort will be more Americans than usual. The Lord Chamberlain has recently issued a circular to those who are to be presented, and several copies have reached America.
It is easy to applaud CECIL RHODES'S noble desire for Anglo-Saxon unity, less easy to approve the testamentary arrangements by which he hoped to promote its accomplishment.

The meteoric career as a man about town of Harry Watson, thirteen years old, wound up last night when he landed in the clutches of Capt. James Reynolds, Chief of Detectives in Brooklyn. Young Mr. Watson was caught behind the scenes of the Montauk Theatre after he had been "doing" the town for three days with money which he had stolen from his mother.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter by Mr. Moreton Frewen, which appears in your Sunday issue under the above heading, calls for a word of sane comment. It really is distressing to find such a large number of people, like Mr. Moreton Frewen, possessed of a furor scribendi which leads to an exhibition of their own ignorance and bumptious conceit.

Capt. Elmer W. Hubbard, Artillery Corps, will return to his station. A board of officers, to consist of Capts. Beverly W. Dunn, William S. Peirce, and John W. Joyes, Ordnance Department, is appointed to meet at the Army Building, New York City, to prepare questions for the examination of First Lieutenants of the line who may apply for detail to duty in the Ordnance Department.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I cull the following remarks from your issue of to-day as being delivered by Mr. Frank H. Platt at the dinner of the Republican Club held last night:
THE old practice expressed in the phrase "When sick call a doctor," has gone out. It is no more the vogue. The new order of things is "Pay a doctor to keep you well."

ALTHOUGH such fashionable members of "the smart set" as attend church services long since abjured Fifth Avenne on Easter Sunday, many of them, mainly because they live near there and because their churches are close at hand, walk to and from their respective places of worship every fine Sunday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I know it is of little use to answer the criticisms of a newspaper that has already shown its opposition to a measure in which it is not directly interested, but the end sought justifies endless discussion of a subject of such great importance as the patrol system of this great city.

At a fire which started yesterday morning in rooms occupied by a Fifth Avenue dressmaker and caused $500 damage, a colored woman attacked the flames with a stream of water from a house hose until the firemen arrived, and she was all but overcome by the heat and the smoke.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- After passing the Indian Appropriation bill to-day the Senate considered the Chinese exclusion measure for nearly three hours. The principal speech of the session was made by Mr. Fairbanks of Indiana in support of the bill. He analyzed its provisions to demonstrate that they were not in contravention of our treaty with China, and discussed at length the right of Congress to enact exclusion legislation.

The second game of the exhibition series Between the New York National League team and coilegiam baseball players took place yesterday afternoon on the Polo Grounds and too local professionals won by a score of 2 to 0.
Open swimming races were held in the pool of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club last night, in which teams from the club, Yale, Columbia, and the New York Athletic Club competed.
SILAS LARRABEE declines to get excited over the suggestion that the South may take hold of the Democratic Party and lick it into fighting condition.

One of the interesting questions now engaging the attention of Wall Street and of the business world generally involves the ability of the railroads of the country to maintain net revenues at present figures. Manifestly, were the remarkable prosperity of the country to continue indefinitely there would be no reason for doubt in the matter; there would be improvement even upon the astonishing and gratifying records of the past few years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is no doubt but that our educational methods have gone far astray, and are in need of a general overhauling and reforming. The tendency of late years has been too much for mere show. Too much valuable time is wasted by pupils in schools. A large portion of this time could be better spent elsewhere in practical education.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The Persians say ten measures of talk were sent down from Heaven and that woman took nine. No one doubts it!

Of a sudden during the past week the security market broadened. Good stocks became active. Stock Exchange transactions were on Friday and Saturday at the rate of a million shares a day. This record, naturally enough, recalls the boom of a year ago, and Wall Street sentiment is consequently veering strongly to the bull side.

A Precarious Profession. The precariousness of the actor's profession has been strikingly illustrated again -- this time in the case of "Life," which had a very short lease of it at the Garden Theatre. In this particular case, the fact that several of those engaged in the performance left other companies to assume roles in what apparently promised to eke out a not overprosperous season with from six to eight weeks' salary, is especially striking.

Three armory records went by the board in the closed games of the Seventh Regiment last night. C.B. Marshall, the Columbia College runner, while giving big allowances to his opponents, ran third in the half-mile race, and his actual time of 2:04 3-5 beats the best previous armory record by 0:01 4-5.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of a paragraph in to-day's issue, complaining of the backwardness of the English railway methods as compared with American ways, and per contra, permit me to relate one or two personal experiences.

The bill providing that the Department of Parks shall have charge of all the trees and of all tree planting on the city streets should be approved without unnecessary delay. All classes of citizens want as many trees as possible, and the chance of getting them through misdirected private enterprise is extremely small.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am inspired by the appearance of the letter of "Proteus" in the last issue of your Financial Supplement to ask space enough to put a few accents upon what your correspondent wrote concerning the bear position. His statement of the case, to my mind, is altogether too mild, and fails to show the bear points in the situation in their true light.

The inherent sovereignty of commerce in the modern world is shown in a strik- ing manner when the heir apparent to the throne of the greatest commercial empire of the time is invited to be the guest of an ancient and influential cor- poration in the greatest commercial Re- public of the time, and the acceptance of the invitation is regarded as assured.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 -- Senator Hanna was the principal speaker to-night at the closing session of the sixth annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science. He divided his Subject with Samuel Gompers, President of be American Federation of Labor, and the question of the relation of capital and labor was ably discussed by the two speakers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES has many friends who regard it as a leader in thought and its utterances as models of happy expression. No doubt it will continue to have such friends, although the editorial in its issue of April 2, entitled "The Metric Force Bill," gave at least one of them a rude shock.

Andrew Carnegie presided last night at the concert of the Philharmonic Society of New York. The society thus concluded the sixtieth year of its existence, and, incidentally, the most successful of its sixty seasons, with a gala performance at Carnegie Hall.
