The stage was decorated with palms and carnations, the centrepiece being an immense wreath of ivy, on which "6" and "0" were done in carnations.

The triple bill of one-act plays, which was apparently devised to show the versatility of Herr Ferdinand Bonn, has added little to our knowledge of the newly imported German player at the Irving Place Theatre and less to our admiration of him. Out of nothing nothing comes, as the Latin primer used to say, and this astute observation, is never more pertinent than when applied to mediocre plays, however admira- bly they may be acted.

The ways of Colonial Bishops have been strange since and before Mr. GID BERT set forth the peculiarities of his right reverence of Rum-ti-foo in a delightful "Bab ballad." But of all Colonial Bishops he of Honolulu, who has been misguided into making public proc- lamation of his grievances, seems to be the strangest.

Charles N. Leigh, who advertises as a chemist, and conducts a drug store in the Park Avenue Hotel, pleaded guilty last week to the charge of refilling Poland Water bottles with bogus water, and selling them at the prices of the genuine water.

THE total population of the United States, including residents or Alaska and Hawaii, and Americans stationed abroad in the military and naval service of the Government, but not including Porto Rico or the Philippines, is 76,303,387. Of these people, 10,460,085, or 13.7 per cent., are foreign born.

Firemen were called shortly after 5 o'clock yesterday morning to extinguish a fire in the cloak and suit establishment of Blauner Brothers Co., on the ninth floor of the ten-story building 23 to 29 Washington Place. Standpipes in the building greatly facilitated the work of the firemen.

Promoters and backers of gambling enterprises in New York are puzzled sorely over changes that have taken place in the scheme of "protection" -- the unwritten law for law breakers. Doubt of the efficacy of the only protection that the old system now can provide and uncertainty as to the course that the city administration may take on the question of gambling combine to keep the gamblers hesitating.

OF all the money expended by the City of New York for the amusement of its citizens, there is probably none that affords so much genuine enjoyment and satisfaction to so great a number as the very trifling amount spent in caring for the squirrels in the public parks of the city.
The new pictures at the Noe Art Galleries (formerly the Avery) are some landscapes by Charles Melville Dewey, which may be seen at 368 Fifth Avenue from the 7th to the 19th of April inclusive.

To the Editor of The New York Times: All lovers of nature, all true descendants of Nimrod, and all disciples of Walton, in whom throb a pulse which responds to the great heartbeats of nature, have a deep-seated passion for the preservation of her primitive conditions. With horror they observe and feel the destruction of those conditions -- those life-compounding laboratories and health-preserving and recuperating retreats.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial in your issue of March 12, entitled "Rebels in the House of Commons," you denounced the Irish members of Parliament as public enemies for the reason that they cheered when it was announced in the House by Mr. Brodrick that Gen. Lord Methuen and his forces (those of them who did not run away) were cut up and captured.

"QUESTION of identity," said a distinguished Judge, "present many difficulties. I am not going to discuss the rules of evidence. They are founded on the dictates of reason and common sense. Nevertheless, cases of mistaken identity give much trouble. ' I saw, John Smith yesterday,' some one testifies, with an emphasis on yesterday.

Ferdinand Bonn, who began his star engagement at the Irving Place Theatre on Thursday last in "The Robbers," will be seen in two different plays this week. "The Violinmaker of Cremona," "Farewell to the Regiment." and "The President" will be repeated to-morrow (Monday) and Tuesday evenings.

A bold scheme was laid bare last evening when two of Capt. Halpin's plain clothes men of the Church Street Station arrested two boys and a man on a charge of running a hand-book on the street. The two lads broke down in the station house when they were arraigned, and confessed their part in the game.

A successful case of skin grafting has just been performed in Jersey City. The patient is Alfred Schill of 295 Central Avenue. He is a mechanic and is employed in the Pennsylvania Railroad shops on the Hackensack River. Some time ago he met with an accident, his left arm having been caught in a revolving belt.

The Russian Military Scandal. The Russian press continues to maintain the most profound mystery in regard to the case of Col. Grimm, who was recently sentenced to death by a court-martial in Warsaw on the charge of treason.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article which appeared in your paper of the 3d instant, signed "Merchant," gives me an opportunity to say a few words in addition to its judicious, impartial criticism of your opposition.

There is no speculation in the dull eye with which HENRY WATTERSON'S bogy glares at him. He cannot kindle the fires of life under its ribs of rag and straw. He may brandish the thing in the streets, but it would never occur to the tenderest blue-eyed babe to be frightened thereby. The child would turn from it to him and only wonder what the gentleman was doing with his old stuffed doll.

LONDON, April 5 -- The war in South Africa, politics, and every topic usually of interest were forgotten to-day in the absorbing discussion of Cecil Rhodes's will. Regarding that extraordinary document, The Associated Press has ascertained some new facts. The total of Mr. Rhodes's fortune is likely to prove to be L5,000,000, ($25,000,000,) or slightly under that amount.

THERE is in a Massachusetts town a florist who sends out catalogues in which he announces that he makes a specialty of shipping in first-class condition all sorts of wild flowers and ferns indigenous to New England. He guarantees to send the plants with so much earth around their roots that they may be transplanted to any soil successfully.

At 11:30 o'clock, just half an hour before the expiration of the allotted time, there came a note from the President of Columbia College announcing that an "anonymous friend of education" had contributed in a lump the extra $50,000 to the Barnard College Fund, and that Mr. Rockefeller was in for a two-hundred-and-fifty-thousand-dollar contribution.

IT takes a man to go into things scientifically, even in winning children's affections. This is a recipe given by one man who says he has never known it to fail. At first upon seeing a child he takes no notice of it. This, if the child is timid, is reassuring, and if it is a child accustomed to receiving attention, piques it somewhat.

BOSTON, Mass., April 5 -- The money market is still slowly working easier. Demand is slightly better, but the supply is abundant. Rates to-day showed little or no change. Sterling exchange is quiet and firm. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 and 4 per cent. New York funds, 10c and 5c discount.
EASTER coming very early this year the fashions for men for the Spring and early Summer were not much in evidence. The coming season cannot, however, be more than a fortnight off.

GOSSIPING with a friend the other day, a woman said: "When you want a standard of saintlike temper, Joblike patience, and an urbane courtesy which could give points to Chesterfield, seek your ideal in an adjuster of one of the big department stores.

OAKDALE, L.I., April 5 -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt and party arrived at W. Bayard Cutting's country residence here at 7 o'clock this evening. The trip from Jamaica was made in good time, but there was no attempt to break the records. The party will be guests of Mr. Cutting until 1 o'clock to-morrow afternoon, when they will return to Manhattan.

Very little need be said of the present money market situation, for the reason that there have been no important developments during the week to affect the position of the banks. It can hardly have escaped attention that the market has been steadily tending to greater ease, and this despite the stock market activity that developed toward the close of the week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your Issue of yesterday's date the Rev. Minot J. Savage is reported as having made the following statement in his sermon on Sunday morning last: "If a person asks me whether I think there is satisfactory evidence that the body of Jesus was raised from the dead.

There was very little in the trading in the outside market yesterday to attract more than passing attention. The same stocks which for the past week have held the places of most prominence continued to supply the bulk of the transactions, but even, in these shares the totals were relatively small.
The Mayor's office was crowded yesterday morning with delegations of citizens of Brooklyn in opposition to the bill recently passed by the Legislature known as the Morgan Library bill.

ROCKVILLE, Conn., April 6. -- The delegates to the New England Southern Conference to-day participated in services at all the churches both here and in nearby towns, and in most cases sermons were preached by the visiting clergymen. The principal event of the day was held at the Methodist Church.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 6. -- Early this evening fire caused a loss of $20,000 at the lumber yard of Smith Sowers, on the West Side. A few hours later fire destroyed $15,000 worth of lumber at Conee Menefee's yard, in the same vicinity. The fires were of incendiary origin.

A tall, well-dressed man of military bearing, giving his name as H. Bloomfield Smith, went into the West Thirtieth Street Police Station at about 11 o'clock last night and told Sergt. Dillon that his baggage, which he said contained valuable Government papers, had been stolen by the driver of a hansom cab.

Saturday's bank statement, showing a decrease of $4,500,000 in cash and a shrinkage in Clearing House surplus reserves of $4,300,000, was made much of by the Stock Exchange bear element. The market was put under severe pressure and some substantial recessions were forced.

ORANGE, N.J., April 6. -- An interesting tournament is being arranged by the Orange Riding and Driving Club, to be given in the clubhouse on Halsted Street, East Orange, on Friday night, April 18. Members of the club will give exhibitions of fancy riding, and the Union County Hounds and Union County Hunt will also give an exhibition of horsemanship.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The Department of Agriculture has issued a statement of the foreign trade of the United States in agricultural products. It shows that during the fiscal year 1901 foreign countries purchased American farm products to the value of $952,000,000, representing the largest agricultural exports in the country's history.

John Henry George, a "cabby" who for the past twenty years has been a familial figure around the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and who is best known as "Foxy Grandpa," owns a horse which wears a false tail. The tail, which is of the long silken variety, for some years, both as regards ornament and use, has answered as well as the real thing.
"Conference Sunday" was celebrated yesterday in all the Methodist churches, and the pulpits of most of them were filled by out-of-town clergymen, visitors to the Conference.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 6. -- Trouble which has been brewing for several months in the ranks of the Reform Club culminated last night when President John Goodwin resigned as the chief executive. The reason given is owing to a recent resolution adopted by the members making two blackballs sufficient to bar an applicant.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The crowded condition of our court calendars is a great and increasing evil. It has caused, and is still causing, earnest discussion, which does not, in my opinion, touch the cause of the difficulty. We have resorted to the novel and illogical expedient of establishing two Courts of Appeal.

BERLIN, April 6. -- The phenomenal success of the Russian loan has not influenced the Boerse, and all departments, last week exhibited a stagnation bordering on lethargy. The hopes of those who looked for an improvement in business with the new quarter have been sharply disappointed.

With the completion of the running track on South Field, Columbia's track athletes will start their long-delayed outdoor practice this week. The men will establish a training table in the college dormitory, at One Hundred and Twentieth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, and will live on the top floor of West Hall.

Sardine boxes! No one would suspect that they were not the real thing, not at first, but really they are sliver paper covered boxes and the sardines packed -- as closely as sardines -- inside are of A No. 1 chocolate.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 6. -- O.G. Frantz, Harvard, '03, first baseman on the Harvard baseball team last year, has been declared ineligible for the nine this year by the Harvard Athletic Committee, on the ground of professionalism.

The rain of yesterday afternoon spoiled the day quite effectually for the Harlem River oarsmen, as it came just at the time of day when the attendance at the club-houses is the greatest, and kept all the pleasure seekers and most of the crews off the water, compelling them to seek diversion inside the clubhouses with handball, pins pong, and other indoor games.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 6. -- Promise of unique opportunity to witness a large section of the most popular resort on the Atlantic Coast in ruins attracted tremendous crowds to Atlantic City to-day. They came by the train load from Philadelphia, while a very considerable number of New York people were here as well.

HELENA, Montana, April 6. -- Three rich gold strikes in as many different mines in three days is the record of Madison County for the last week. The Fourth of July Mine, near Pony, which was recently purchased by the Largey estate, was the scene of the first strike. An unusually rich streak of gold ore in the tunnel was found, and while its extent is not yet known, the outlook is considered most promising.

The excise laws were enforced more strictly throughout the city yesterday than they have been on any Sunday since the present statutes came into effect. It was the "dryest" Sunday New York has known since the celebrated time when Theodore Roosevelt was head of the Police Board, and started out to show just what a strict enforcement of the law meant.

It is reported from the West that the party leaders are very reluctant to take up the Ship Subsidy bill as a party measure, first, because they are afraid that they cannot hold all the members of the House from that region for it, and, second, because they are afraid of the effect on the elections this Fall.

Excitement ran high on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning, when, after several hours of exceptionally good brushing between star performers, the crowd of spectators lining the sidewalks of the upper stretch witnessed a thrilling capture of a runaway horse by a mounted policeman.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The "Hanna Presidential boom" is a great comfort to a good many of the Washington correspondents; lots of picturesque paragraphs countenancing it have been written and sent over the country. Such information as reaches Washington as to the impression these paragraphs have made is that they everywhere have been regarded as the products of humorous writers.

Ex-Senator B.F. Jonas was the Wednesday lecturer at Tulane University. His Subject was his recollections of his term in the United States Senate. He spoke for more than an hour, and the talk was enjoyed very much, as it was filled with anecdotes.

The rapid increase of cases of death by that dread disease cancer is exciting attention in Europe as it has here. Statistics warrant a German physician in saying that fatal cases in Germany have doubled in the last decade as compared to the decade before, and that it attacks younger people with greater frequency than was formerly the case.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In contradistinction to the sensational rot of several of the city papers regarding the cause of the present high price of meat, the newsmongers of those scintillations are invited to review Dun's publicatication tion of relative prices when compared with those of a year or more ago.

The accumulations of an enterprising dealer in old and modern pictures will be sold at Mendelssohn Hall on the evenings of Thursday and Friday next, and are to be seen until Wednesday night at the American Art Galleries, 6 East Twenty-third Street.

It is now hoped by the horse leech's daughters under the lead of OXNARD that they will be able to defeat even the inadequate measure of justice accorded to Cuba in the House bill. This hope is based on the Senate rules as to unlimited debate. The advocates of greed and opponents of decency are expected to talk the bill to death.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now after more than three centuries have passed away since first Christopher Columbus and his conscienceless crews Invaded the Cuban shores, and with the cruelty and butchery of ruffians and freebooters crushed the lives out of a better race of people than their own ancestry, Cuba redeemed, rescued, and regenerated is about to begin a career of independent government.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 6. -- Alfredo De Oro of New York City, the pool champion of the world, last night established a new world's record for consecutive runs by pocketing 84 balls without a miss. The previous world's record was 79 balls, made by De Oro in Chicago and recently equalled by Grant Eby in New York.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., April 6. -- John M. Shedd, son of the Rev. William G.T. Shedd, thinks that the few old trees cut down in front of his property at Montrose by order of the Highway Commissioners of the town of Cortlandt are worth $3,000. At least he handed a claim for that amount to Supervisor James H. Haight for the destruction of the trees.

CHICAGO, April G. -- A certified check for 55,000, drawn to the order of President Roosevelt, was forwarded to the President on March 28 by the committee of citizens which Gov. Yates appointed in December last to raise funds for the relief of Boer women and children sufferers in the concentration camps of South Africa.
LONDON, April 7. -- The Daily Mail this morning gives the opinions of some distinguished Oxford Dons concerning the Rhodes scholarships.
WASHINGTON, D.C., April 6. -- The expectation of the friends of the Chinese Exclusion bill is that its consideration by the Senate will be concluded by the middle of the present week, if not before.

KLERKSDORP, Transvaal, April 6. -- Details of the battle at Doornbalt Farm on March 31 (in which the British had 3 officers and 24 men killed and 16 officers and 131 men pounded, while the Boers had 137 men killed or wounded) showed that quite 2,000 Boers opened a strong attack from different points with three guns and a pompom.

BALTIMORE, April 6. -- The silver jubilee of Pope Leo XIII, was observed with solemn and unusually elaborate services at the Cathedral to-day. The ceremony Was marked by the presence of two Cardinals. Cardinal Martinelli, the Apostolic Delegate, who came over from Washington last night to take part in the services, pontificated, and Cardinal Gibbons preached the sermon.

Frightened at the sound of an automobile, a horse attached to a buggy broke loose from its harness last night, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, threw two occupants of the vehicle to the street, and then dashed at a mad gallop down Fifth Avenue to Thirty-fourth Street, where it collided with a cab.

More than ordinary interest attaches to the consensus of opinion called out by the recent correspondence of Labor Commissioner O'DONNELL of Minnesota, as showing how the wage earners are beginning to view the effect of great industrial combinations on the interests of labor.
TUSCUMBIA, Ala., April 6. -- Three men are dead, three mortally wounded, and four seriously wounded as the result of Sheriff Gassaway attempting to-day to arrest Will Reynolds, a desperate negro.

Echoes of that caucus meeting of Aldermen at the City Hall on Saturday could still be heard yesterday by those who got near enough to any member of the board who was present. Although not every one would be quoted, enough was said, and sparks enough flew from what they said to make it clear that things happened at the meeting.

The plan now under consideration at Hazleton, Penn., of filling vacancies in the local police by appointing the applicants who place the smallest value upon, their services and tender the lowest bids in the matter of wages will strike the average reader as an extremely novel and ingenious expedient for making the police corrupt.

CLINTONDALE, N. Y., April 6. -- The women of this town and the neighboring villages of Lloyd and Plattekill, and especially the members of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, have stolen a march on John Auchmoody, who proposed establishing a hotel here where liquor was to be sold.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 6. -- Arrangements are being perfected for the dedication of the new First Reformed Church and the unveiling of the McKinley and Hobart window on Wednesday, April 16.

BERLIN, April 6. -- "This bequest shows the wide reach of Cecil Rhodes's mind and his vision of the future," said Emperor William to Dr. von Lucanus, the Chief of his Majesty's Civil Cabinet, who alluded to the will of Mr. Rhodes in an audience with the Emperor yesterday morning.

George F. Seward, Chairman of the Committee on State and Municipal Taxation of the Chamber of Commerce, has sent a letter to Gov. Odell protesting against the Krum Corporation Tax bill, in which he says:

The automobilists of the New York Athletic Club held their initial run from the clubhouse, in West Fifty-ninth Street, to their country home, Travers Island-on-theSound, yesterday. One hundred and fifty members and guests made the trip in thirty-two machines, covering the distance in an hour and twenty-five minutes.

From The London Telegraph. Many and various attempts have been made in Paris to improve the ordinary motor goggles, which are in their present form a hideous necessity. Some such kind of protection for the eyes will always have to be worn by automobilists. But ladies in particular would be glad if some new apparatus, equally effective but less unsightly, were invented.

Two burglars who tried to rob the room of Louis Eucher, over the saloon of Angelo Feraro, at 310 Driggs Avenue, Williamsburg, early yesterday morning met with a warm reception. Both were shot by Feraro.

PRETORIA, April 6. -- Details received here of the rear-guard action on the night of March 31 between the Second Dragoon Guards of Col. Lawley's column and the Boers, near Boschman's Kop, show that a force of 200 British, while endeavoring to surprise a Boer laager on a dark night, rode straight into a force of 600 Boers.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 6. -- The police today arrested Edward W. Kappel, Superintendent of Agents for the Equitable Life Assurance Society of New York, residing in Buffalo, and Edward W. King, Secretary-Treasurer of the Nash Improvement Company of Niagara Falls and Suspension Bridge, New York.

The extraordinary spectacle witnessed in New York yesterday is without precedent, except for one or two Sundays when THEODORE ROOSEVELT was President of the Police Board. But the later example promises to be much more fruitful than the earlier.

A novel scheme for alleviating customs abuses is being planned by Secretary of the Treasury Leslie M. Shaw. He was in the city yesterday, and said he had given the subject of trunk examinations by the officials on piers much attention recently, and that every effort would be made to reduce the inconveniences of oceanic travelers.

BALTIMORE, April 7. -- The local market to-day, while lacking in special feature was steady to firm in tone. Cotton Duck issues were higher. Insiders admit that the company is earning not only enough to pay the full semi-annual interest on the income bonds, but also earning something on the common stock. These facts are having a favorable influence on both buyers and holders.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Attorney General Stratton of the State of Washington to-day brought to the attention of the United States Supreme Court the desire of that State to bring suit to prevent the merger of the Northern Pacific and the Great Northern Railroads by moving for leave to file a bill of complaint on behalf of the State vs. the Northern Pacific, the Great Northern Railroad Company, and the Northern Securities Company.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7. -- There was little activity In the stock market to-day, most of the transactions being in the Readings and for New York account. A spirited demand for United Gas Improvement resulted in a material advance in that stock. The buying of Philadelphia Electric continued on a fair scale, and the price responded fractionally.

ROCKVILLE, Conn., April 7. -- The Southern New England Methodist Conference this morning heard a short address by the Rev. Dr. W.F. MacDowell, Corresponding Secretary of the Board of Education of Boston.

The first match of a home and home ping-pong tournament between Yale and Harvard graduates was played last night at the Yale Club, 30 West Forty-fourth Street. Four players were on each side and the result was a tie, each side winning eight games and losing one. The Yale ping pongists included L.E. Brown, Paul Kennedy, Marcus Goodbody, and George C. Hollister.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- The House today passed the Chinese Exclusion bill after incorporating in it several amendments which increased the drastic character of the measure. The principal one not only excludes Chinese by birth and descent, but all Chinese of mixed blood.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Anson A. Gard of Montreal, formerly of New York, visited the President to-day in company with Senator Proctor. Mr. Gard is in the United States on a peculiar mission. He has been through Canada examining the public schools to find out how much the pupils know about the United States, and he is now finding what the pupils in this country know about Canada.
LONDON, April 7. -- A large supply of dividend money being available to-day, discounts were steady.

QUEENSTOWN, April 7. -- The Lord Mayor of Cork, Mr. Fitzgerald, and a number of the residents of that city have arranged to meet J.P. Morgan on board the White Star Line steamer Oceanic, when she arrives here, and urge him to send the Columbia to Cork Harbor to meet the Britannia, the Shamrock, and the Meteor in the forthcoming contest for the King's Cup.

Police Commissioner Partridge said yesterday that it would not perhaps be wise for him to express an opinion on the enforcement of the excise law in this city on Sunday. When it was suggested to him that the 122 arrests made in the city on that day, a greater number than on any day of the Roosevelt regime, was accepted by some that the patrolmen's activity was widespread, he said:
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 7. -- The thirty-seventh annual conference of the German Methodist Episcopal Church came to a close this morning. The appointments follow:

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a constant reader of your paper for many years, I was very sorry to see your editorial on April on "China and Christianity," because it betrays an ignorance of the facts which is very misleading to any one not particularly interested in the subject.

ALBANY, April 7.-- Gov. Odell has vetoed the Weekes bill amending the primary election law by abolishing the Spring enrollment in New York City. In connection with the veto he filed the following memorandum:
A copy of the above letter was shown to Mr. Collier in his dressing room at the Madison Square Theatre last night.

Commissioner Dougherty of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity has sent to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment a communication, containing his estimates of bonds necessary for the maintenance of his department. This is in compliance with a request from Controller Grout to submit all requirements that could be met by the issue of corporate stock.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- In the United States Supreme Court an opinion was delivered to-day by Justice Brewer in the case of Pine and others against the City of New York and ex-Controller Bird S. Coler, involving the right of the city to appropriate all the water of the Byram River, along which the complainants resided.

Important changes were discussed and some adopted yesterday at a meeting of the National Cycling Association, held in the Astor House. One of the most radical was a proposition by A.G. Batchelder, Chairman of the Board of Control, providing for three classes of franchises in the association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Even the most severe critic of the imperial policy in South Africa, and of its great director -- so lately passed from us -- can hardly fall to recognize the deep obligation under which the will of Cecil Rhodes has placed the whole Anglo-Saxon race and peculiarly ourselves.

BOSTON, April 7. -- The demand is still for money, while the April disbursements, now well out, have apparently added greatly to the available loanable supply. Sterling exchange continues firm. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent. New York funds, 10 cents discount and par. Call loans, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

J. Ross Stevenson, the newly chosen pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, addressed the members and guests of the Presbyterian Union of New York at the monthly meeting of that body held at the Hotel Savoy last night. This was Mr. Stevenson's first public address since his coming to New York, and his first chance to meet the members of the New York Union.

Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court has decided that it is not libelous to publish of a person that he has consumption or that he once had it. The presumption that words not libelous per se do no damage may; however, be rebutted by pleading and proving what is called special damage -- that is, reciting particular items of damage.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 7. -- Albert T. Patrick reached Sing Sing Prison on the 2:20 train. Mrs. Patrick also alighted from the same train. She did not accompany her husband to the prison. They kissed each other a dozen times on the station platform, and then Patrick was placed in a hack which was waiting, and he and the two deputies were driven to the south gate of the prison.

Some details of the movement started by ex-Mayor Charles A. Schieren and other influential Brooklyn Republicans for the overthrow of the present management of the party in the borough were made known yesterday. An appeal for support to the Republicans of the county has been prepared by a committee, and this will be distributed broadcast among the enrolled members of the party.

Albert T. Patrick, convicted on March 25 of murdering William Marsh Rice, is in Sing Sing under sentence of death. Recorder Goff in pronouncing sentence yesterday was very brief. He condemned Patrick to die, according to the law of the State, some time in the week beginning May 5.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a constant reader and great admirer of THE TIMES, (as are many in New England.) But, in all honesty, I cannot let your editorial of Thursday regarding "Christianity and the Chinese" pass without protest.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 7. -- Golf of recent years has not been very popular in Newport. Tennis, yachting, and the other amusements have detracted from the number of players on the course of the Newport Golf Club. Last year the old nine-hole course was sufficient to accommodate all who wished to play.

Beyond one small dance and several informal affairs, there was rather a dearth of incidents in society yesterday. To-day will take place the reception given by Mrs. Lindley Hoffman Chapin at Sherry's. Miss Julia Chester Wells will give a card party at her residence, 30 West Thirty-first Street.

Those who remember the Parisian Faquarette and her charming grotesqueries will be able to form some conception of Miss May Edouin, who disclosed her many attractions yesterday at Keith's. Paquarette's pretty features are perhaps more regular; and she may possibly have a lighter grace in her absurdities of facial contortion; but Miss Edouin is exceedingly pretty and exceedingly droll; and more than this, she is what the Parisian is not -- a consummate little comedian.

The introduction of a full orchestra at the One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, where the Proctor Stock Company is presenting " Our Boarding House," seemed to be a popular innovation. The distribution of souvenirs to lady patrons at the matinee is another feature. " The Rift "Within Dove's Clouds " is the curtain raiser, and this week's vaudeville has George Thatcher, in black-face monologue, and Wright and Doody as the headliners.

The hearing before Gov. Odell at Albany on the Bedell bill granting extraordinary privileges to railroad companies having terminal facilities in cities of the first-class -- New York and Buffalo -- will take place to-morrow. In what are considered wellinformed circles the opinion was expressed yesterday that Gov. Odell will disapprove the measure.

Just after Andrew Carnegie had taken his seat after speaking at the dinner in his honor given by the Society of American Authors at the St. Denis Hotel last night, a smooth-shaven, intelligent-appearing man in clerical dress arose from the middle of the crowded room and called in a sharp, distinct voice:

BALTIMORE, Md., April 7. -- The Rev. W. A. Crawford Frost has for several years been the rector of the Protestant Episcopal Memorial Church of the Holy Comforter in the eastern part of this city, his congregation being composed largely of working people. His sermons are frequently of a rather sensational character and a Socialistic coloring, and attract widespread attention.
BOSTON, Mass., April 7. -- The Summer schedule of open, invitation, and championship tournaments of the National Lawn Tennis Association was issued to-day.

F. De Forest Simmons has sold to Leroy W. Baldwin, for a Mrs. Cooksey of California, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling, with dining room extension, 8 East Seventieth Street, on lot 17.3 by 100 The price was about $82,000.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

Money market considerations were the factors of chief influence in yesterday's security market. Transient loan rates rose to 7 per cent and a number of conspicuous banks called loans, one Institu- tion with close Standard Oil affiliations being credited with the withdrawal from customers of several millions of credit.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, April 7. -- News has reached here that the seaport of Tucacas, in the State of Lara, Venezuela, was taken on April 3 by revolutionary forces under Solagny.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Senator Depew of New York appeared to-day before the special House committee investigating charges in connection with the Danish West Indies negotiations. His statement was brief. He expressed astonishment at having seen his name in the Christmas report.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 7. -- A jury having been completed on Saturday to try Willis, Burton, and Fred Van VVormer, on the charge that they shot to death their uncle, Peter A. Hallenbeck, on Christmas Eve last, the case was resumed to-day. Elting was the first witness. He heard shots on Christmas Eve, and went to Hallenbeck's house, where he found that a murder had been committed.

It ought not to be especially complimentary to say of a prominent Democratic Representative that he is sane, but unfortunately sanity is a real distinction in this class. We note its existence in the case of Mr. GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN, Democratic member of the Ways and Means Committee, in a marked and highly satisfactory degree.

Controller Grout made an attack on the volunteer fire companies in the outlying boroughs of the city at the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday. The budget of the Fire Department was under consideration, and Commissioner Sturgls was explaining that there was no alarm system in the Boroughs of Queens and Richmond.

Capt. Michael Sheehan of the Tenderloin Station, backed by a dozen policemen, yesterday afternoon broke open the steel doors of the alleged poolroom of "Joe" Vendig, located on the top floor of the "Chimney Corner," on the northeast corner of Sixth Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, and drove the occupants, whom he found singing hymns, upon the roof and then into the street.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 7. -- A bitter fight over the Western Maryland Railroad took a sensational turn to-night in City Councils and as a result all bids are off and Mayor Hayes will have to advertise for new proposals.

The behavior of the Democratic members of the Senate Committee on the Philippines does not indicate any more political sense than patriotism. They are now endeavoring to make some political capital out of that sentence in Gen. MILES'S letter to the President, which justly aroused most indignation on the part of the Secretary of War, the President, and the country.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were considerably below the average of last week practically all important issues with one or two exceptions showing relatively small totals. With this decrease in activity there appeared considerable irregularity in prices. In some few instances last week's advances were added to, but in a larger number of cases a reactionary tendency appeared.

The foundation of American scholarships at Oxford for American students by the late CECIL RHODES will be likely to revive a somewhat waning interest in the discussion whether training in the humanities or in the applied sciences has the greater value as a preparation for usefulness in the modern world of affairs.

Senator HANNA'S tribute to the work of the Industrial Department of the Civic Federation at the meeting of the American Society of Political and Social Science was fully warranted by the record it has made in settling seven strikes and aborting two which, if left to develop, would probably have attained large proportions.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

LONDON, April 9 -- An article on the Right Hon. Cecil J. Rhodes, by William T. Stead, will appear in the forthcoming number of The American Review of Reviews. The article, excerpts from which follow, consists of a frank, powerful explanation of Mr. Rhodes's views on America and Great Britain, and for the first time sets forth his own inmost aims.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 8 -- The hope of President Roosevelt last night that he might see sunshine in the morning was fully realized. The downpour of rain which had marked the trip almost from the moment of departure had ceased, the heavy black clouds disappeared and the day broke with a cloudless sky.

ALBANY, April 8 -- A hearing was given by Gov. Odell to-day on the bill of Assemblyman Colby, which permits the charging of carbonic acid gas tanks in buildings which are occupied in part as dwelling houses. The chief argument in opposition was made by Judge Dittenhoefer, who declared that if the bill became a law it would greatly increase the dangers of tenement houses in the cities.

As the result of a trap set several weeks ago by District Attorney Jerome, in conjunction with the Civil Service Commissioners, Mrs. Mary G. Gilbert, thirty years old, living at 116 East Eighty-fourth Street, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Mott, in Harlem Court, charged with a violation of Section 53 of the Penal Code in accepting money to obtain a position on the police force for a (supposed) candidate.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon heard argument on the appeal from the order of Justice Gaynor directing Col. Norman S. Dike to turn over to Charles Guden the books and papers of the office of Sheriff of Kings County or stand committed to the County Jail if he failed to Comply with the direction of the court.
The City Committee of the Citizens' union has sent the following letter to the Board of Estimate:

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment sent out a notice to all the heads of departments and Borough Presidents yesterday that the salaries of all clerks must be reduced 10 per cent. The salaries of the various clerks and officials graded in the civil service, it is recommended, also should be fixed at certain figures.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 8 -- Dr. Van Hoesen resumed his testimony at to-day's session of court in the trial of Burton, Willis, and Frederick Van Wormer, who are accused of the murder of Peter A. Hallenbeck on last Christmas Eve. Dr. Van Hoesen explained to the jury, by means of a skeleton chart, the location of the bullets found in the body of the murdered man.

Poor Lord SALISBURY will miss his antagonist of so many years, the leader of "his Majesty's Opposition" in the House of Lords. The Prime Minister has always declined to accept Lord ROSEBERY in that capacity, and, indeed, Lord ROSEBERY, by his own choice, although an ex-Prime Minister, and in that capacity the natural leader of the Liberal peers, had accepted the position of a free lance.

PITTSBURG, April 8 -- A telegram from Mexico City announces that as a result of the visit of the party of American railroad men, in company with Gen. Charles Miller of Franklin, Penn., a new railroad will be built, connecting Mexico City with the Pacific Coast. In the party with Gen. Miller are President L.F. Loree of the Baltimore and Ohio and President S.R. Callaway of the American Locomotive Company.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 8 -- A repre- sentative of The Herald has returned from Quebec, where he saw John F. Gaynor and Capt. B.F. Greene, who are wanted at Savannah, Ga., for trial in the United States Courts on charges of defrauding the Government in contract work in that harbor. In an interview Col. Gaynor said:

Last night the Kneisel Quartet gave the last one of this season's concerts at Mendelssohn Hall, before an unusually attentive and appreciative audience. The programme, a very attractive one, was made up of the Schubert D minor posthumous quartet, the Bach A major sonata for violin and piano, and the Caesar Franck quintet.

The police-excise situation was not cleared or improved by the meeting yesterday of the saloon and hotel keepers. They took no action in a session of four hours and a half, and when they adjourned matters were as they were when the meeting was called to order.

ALBANY, April 8 -- The New York and Jersey City Terminal Underground Railroad Company was incorporated to-day with a capital of $100,000, to operate an underground tunnel railroad from a point on the bank of the Hudson River at the boundary line between the States of New York and New Jersey to the intersection of Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, New York City.

London surprised Wall Street yesterday morning by turning up as a buyer of American stocks. Louisville and Nashville was the favorite, and foreign quotations received before the New York Stock Exchange opened recorded substantial advances. When business started here the sagging tendency characterizing Monday's market movement continued but a little while -- the London-Louisville exhibit being construed on every side as significant of no mere passing manipulation.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Frank H. Mason, Consul General to Berlin, has reported to the State Department on the "Outlook for Export Trade to Germany" as follows:

J.G. Carlisle and William Edmond Curtis yesterday presented to members of the Merchants' Association of New York a copy of the argument to be made by Mr. Carlisle before Gov. Odell to-day against the Bedell bill, granting extraordinary privileges to the New York Central and other railroad companies having terminal facilities in cities of the first class -- New York and Buffalo.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 8 -- The local market was dull and a shade easier to-day. There was, nothing in the way of special price movements. Rumors still circulate with reference to Seaboard Air Line connections with St. Louis and San Francisco at Birmingham, the same to be accomplished by the building of a joint road from Atlanta to Birmingham.
LONDON, April 8 -- Money continued to be in strong demand to-day. Discounts were firm.

The plea of Commissioner DOUGHERTY for a bond issue of $8,429,000 for an increased water plant for the several boroughs of New York would have been stronger if he had not made the mistake of endeavoring to prove too much. For example, his report would have been much more convincing if he had omitted the following:

The Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company has bought from Johnston Livingston, through L.J. Phillips Co., for about $300,000, the plot of about five and a half lots at the southeast corner of Broadway and Sixty-ninth Street, 112.11 feet on Broadway, 161.8 feet on the street, 100.5 on the easterly line, and 110 feet on the southerly line.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- Except for the strength in Union Traction, Reading and Lehigh Valley, the Philadelphia, market took no part in the advance movement that characterized the New York list, but prices acted as though they wanted to improve and small net gains stood to the credit of most shares.

The reception given by Mrs. Lindley Hoffman Chapin and several weddings comprised the more notable events of yesterday. The meeting of the Knickerbocker Bowling Club, a few luncheons and dinners, the wedding of Miss Mildred Caruth Dix, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Dix, to Robert Ainsworth Leeson, will be among the events of to-day.

Seven hundred girls employed by the American Can Company joined the strikers yesterday, and a number of them trooped through the rain to the strike headquarters, New Irving Hall, Broome Street, near Norfolk. Of these, about five hundred were from the Brooklyn factories, and 200 from Manhattan.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 8 -- The conference held this afternoon between the business exchanges of New Orleans and the passenger chiefs of the various lines centring in New Orleans was sensational in the extreme, the railroads being requested to explain apparent collusion with scalpers. Every business exchange in New Orleans was represented.

LONDON, April 8 -- The Pall Mall Gazette says that Justice Woodfall issued an order to-day for the committal to Holloway Jail for twelve days of Elfie Fay, the American comedienne, for defaulting in the payment of a judgment secured against her for debt.
Mayor Low returned to Albany yesterday as not accepted by the city the following bills:

LONDON, April 9 -- A special order was issued yesterday to the customs staffs of all the ports of the United Kingdom, forbidding them to issue the usual orders for entry to vessels carrying free goods. This applies not only to timber, but to all cargoes at present free of duty.
TRENTON, N.J., April 8 -- Gov. Murphy to-day set apart April 25 as Arbor Day.

The Board of Aldermen held a long session yesterday which was attended with much excitement. The Fusion majority of the board melted under the onslaughts of the Tammany members, aided by the Brooklyn Democrats, and on a test vote on the police three-platoon resolution the administration forces could only round up on roll call twenty-one members while the Tammany-Brooklyn Democrats rolled up forty-seven votes.

An alleged "green goods" man was arrested late yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn by Central Office detectives, after a lively chase. For some time past the local detective bureau has received evidence to show that Brooklyn has been the centre of distribution of large quantities of "green goods" circulars.

TORRINGTON, Conn., April 8. -- At the opening session of the New York East Conference at the Methodist Church to-day, Dr. T.M. Poulson, Lawrence, L.I., presented a report of the Temperance Committee, which declared itself opposed to the opening of saloons any part of Sunday. The Rev. Charles E. Barto, Long Island City, L.I., read a report of the Church Aid Society, and the Rev. Edward Cunningham Islip, L.I., presented the report on missions.

QUEENSTOWN, April 8 -- The delegation from Cork, headed by the Lord Mayor of that city, which purposed to meet J. Pierpont Morgan when the White Star liner Oceanic arrived here to-day and urge him to send the Columbia to Cork Harbor to compete in the forthcoming contests for the King's Cup, missed the tender and was therefore unable to board the Oceanic.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The great battle over Cuban reciprocity began in the House to-day. It is going to be the liveliest fight of the session, not because there is any serious doubt for the bill's passage, but because both parties are split, and there is stronger feeling than over any other bill that has come before the House.

LONDON, April 9 -- The Times prints a poem by Rudyard Kipling, which is to be read at the burial of Cecil Rhodes on the hill called "The View of the World," in the Matoppo Hills, Rhodesia, to-morrow. The poem is as follows:

The Mayor's statement adds to the wonder how the administration, and especially how the accomplished and experienced Corporation Counsel, came to approve of the Bedell bill giving such extraordinary privileges to the New York Central Railroad and to other roads. That either the Mayor or Mr. RIVES was influenced by improper motives has been suggested by no one.

A victory for the Metropolitan Street Railway Company was gained yesterday, when Justice Gildersleeve, in the Supreme Court, vacated the temporary injunction granted by Justice Greenbaum to restrain the company from executing the lease by which it sought to transfer its properties and franchises to the Interurban Street Railway Company for a period of 999 years.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Oxnard, Democrats came out at the little end of the horn in the conference to-night of minority members of the House. The conference was called at their request, and they expected, when the call was made, that they would be able to control the conference and secure the adoption of resolutions declaring against the passage of the Payne Cuban Relief bill.

Appearance at the regular annual societies seems to stimulate artists to one-man exhibitions, perhaps because they feel that the few pictures accepted do not adequately represent them. At the Society of American Artists a slender figure of a young woman in black skirt, white waist, and black hat, signed Robert Henri, deprives the little east room of much of its mournfulness.

ROME, April 8 -- In spite of the opposition of Cardinal Rampolla, (Papal Secretary of State,) the Pope has decided to send important special missions both to the coronation of King Edward and to the festivities in Spain attendant upon the coming of age of King Alfonso.

Preliminary bouts for the amateur championship with foils and French dueling swords were held last night at the Fencers' Club, 39 West Twenty-second Street, and provided excellent sport. The entry list is more numerous than in former years, and includes the foremost men of the Amateur Fencers' League from Boston, Washington, and this city.

BALTIMORE, April 8 -- At the home of the Rev. W.A. Crawford-Frost to-day it was said that he went to New York yesterday to attend last night's banquet of the Society of American Authors, and great surprise was expressed at what had happened there. Dr. Frost has criticised Mr. Carnegie from the pulpit, asserting that more good could have been accomplished if that gentleman had bestowed his money in other ways than founding libraries.

Justice Mayer in Special Sessions yesterday threatened to call the attention of the New York Bar Association to the procedure of an attorney trying cases in his court. He also took occasion to censure the attorney from the bench.

The eleventh Spring horse show of the Durland Company was opened last night in the riding arena of the Academy, Sixty-sixth Street and Central Park West, with an attendance of patrons of the horse, whose enthusiasm made the exhibition a success in spite of the disagreeable weather. The crowd practically was made up of riding and driving people, and included many of the prominent and wealthy exhibitors at the great horse shows of the Fall.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

MANILA, April 8 -- Major Littleton W.T. Waller of the Marine Corps, at to-day's session of the court-martial by which he is being tried on the charge of executing natives of Samar without trial, testified in rebuttal of the evidence given yesterday by Gen. Jacob H. Smith, who commanded the American troops in the Island of Samar.

Thomas B. Mead, said to have been once a prominent broker in Philadelphia, but who since business reverses came has been a small operator in the Wall Street district, having desk, room with William Cossitt Cone Co., at 44 Broad Street, was found unconscious on the steps of 138 West Sixteenth Street at 2 A.M. yesterday.
A well-equipped Illicit whisky still, with a daily capacity of 1,500 gallons, was raided on Tuesday night by Revenue Agent F.G. Thompson and three of his deputies.

Board of officers appointed to meet at the call of the President thereof at Fort Sherldan for the examination of such officers as may be ordered before it to determine their fitness for promotion. Detail for the board:

PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- There was a marked change for the better all over the Philadelphia market to-day. Prices for the most part were 1/4 to 1/2 higher, the only prominent stock failing to share in the rise being Union Traction. The most striking improvement was a two-point elevation in Electric Storage Battery.

The market broadened materially yesterday. Louisville and Nashville made a further substantial rise, the trading of it being on a more extensive scale than that stock has known in years. Following the Louisville advance came buoyancy in the Southern Railway issues. A single transaction in Southern Railway reached 10,000 shares, and over and over again 5,000 shares and more were quoted at a time.

Rear Admiral Schley was the guest of honor at the dinner of the Maryland Society at Sherry's last night, and his counsel before the Court of Inquiry, Capt. James Parker, although not down on the list of speakers, was also present and made an address, throwing new light upon the Sampson-Schley controversy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Controller Grout's attack on the volunteer fire companies in the outlying districts of Queens and Richmond at the Board of Estimate meeting yesterday is such that every volunteer fireman should resent. Controller Grout is quoted as having made the following statement:

Fined for Selling Bogus Mineral Water. There is hardly a day passes without some case being fought, either between attorneys or in the Courts, against persons who are counterfeiting medicinal preparations and selling them as genuine, thereby defrauding and endangering the lives of the public.

BALTIMORE, April 9. -- The market developed very little to-day in way of feature, though there was some liquidation of gas and railway issues by reason of mistaken apprehension as to what the extra session of the Legislature may do. Atlantic Transport maintains its bounding tendencies in anticipation of benefits hoped for in the event the transatlantic ship deal is consummated.
"In short meter the saloon keepers will next Sunday do the best they can for the accommodation of their customers."

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Chairman Ray of the House Committee on Judiciary to-day filed the report of the majority of the committee in favor of the bill to limit the meaning of the word "-conspiracy" and the use of injunctions. This bill, which is intended for the benefit of organized labor, was introduced in the Senate by Mr. Hoar and in the House by Gen. Grosvenor.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The marriage of Miss Edythe Pratt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Frederick W. Pratt, to Capt. Francis Williams Dickins, United States Navy took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 124 Iowa Circle, in the presence of a company of relatives and close personal friends.

Justice Scott of the Supreme Court yesterday rendered a decision construing the will of ex-Judge Henry Hilton. He finds that the will worked an equitable conversion of all the testator's real estate into personalty, and directed the executors to distribute it in a manner set out in the instrument.

Light sabres rang merrily last night in the preliminary and nullifying bouts at the Fencers Club, 30 West Twenty-second Street. The contestants were the pick of the amateur ranks and were striving to win places in the final competitions for the championship of the Amateur Fencres League.

As it has been finally signed, the Manchurian treaty appears to have had two "strings" affixed to it by Russia. The evacuation of Niu-Chwang by Russia is made conditional upon the evacuation of Tien-Tsin, now held as a hostage for the performance of certain Chinese obligations by the "allies," which practically means by the Germans.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 9. -- Thomas F. Cushing and his daughter, Miss Edith Cushing, arrived here to-day to inspect their cottage before sailing for Europe. They will return to Newport in July for tho season.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- T.V. Powderly, Commissioner General of Immigration, today made a statement in reply to the attacks made upon him for a letter which he wrote to Immigration Commissioner Fitchie in 1898. In that letter he asked Mr. Fitchie to use his influence in behalf of Mr. McKinley's private secretary, John A, Porter, who wanted to be Governor of Connecticut.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 9 -- At Calhoun's funeral, when Hampton made his great campaign speech here in 1876, when the Confederate reunion was held here in 1899, great bodies of marching men filled the streets of this ancient city, and its side-walks and doors and windows were filled with enthusiastic thousands, but all those great outpourings of the people were small compared to the procession which followed President Roosevelt to the Exposition grounds to-day.

ALBANY, April 9. -- Gov. Odell gave a hearing this morning on the Employers' Liability bill of Senator Slater. In opposition there appeared Dwight W. Morrow of Reid, Simpson, Thacher Morrow, representing the American Locomotive Company; ex-Assemblyman A.W. Litchard of Allegany County, representing the various organized bodies of agriculturists, and B. Larnard Hand, representing the General Electric Company.

CHICAGO, April 9. -- New York exchange was 10c discount. Time and call lonas, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Union Traction showed further strength in the local market, to-day, the common advancing to 20 5/8 and the preferred selling at 57 1/2. Tin Can was quiet, but the report that the Nortons were soon to retire from the management of the property gave rise to considerable discussion.

TORRINGTON, Conn., April 9 -- After announcing the appointment of ministers for the coming year, the New York East Conference adjourned finally to-day. The appointment include the following changes from last year:

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- A bill providing a pension for Mrs. Sarah Frances Taft, widow of Dr. Charles Sabin Taft, late Acting Assistant Surgeon United States Army, the first, surgeon in attendance upon President Lincoln after his assassination, now awaits the signature of President Roosevelt to become a law.
BRUSSELS, April 9 -- -King Leopold was mobbed by Socialists this afternoon on his arrival here from Biarritz.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- One of the strangest sights in recent politics was witnessed to-day in the House of Representatives. It was the sight of William Alden Smith of Michigan, a beet-sugar Republican, arguing the tariff question with such old wheel-horses of protection as Messrs. Payne and Grosvenor and using against them the most elementary arguments of protection.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 9. -- Mrs. Catherine Hallenbeck, sister-in-law of Peter A. Hallenbeck, was the first witness to-day in the trial of the three Van Wormer brothers on indictments charging them with the murder of Peter A. Hallenbeck. The witness said she and her husband lived at her dead brother-in-law's house.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- There seems little doubt now that Harvard, Columbia, Cornell, and Pennsylvania will meet in a quadrangular boat race over the Lake Cayuga course on Memorial Day, May 30. If they do not meet the blame can be attributed to Pennsylvania, as upon the Quakers it now rests to make complete arrangements.

Yesterday, with its varied temperature, had much to offer to society. In the first place there were the weddings, among which the more notable were those of Miss Mildred Carruth Dix, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred D. Dix, and Robert A. Leeson of Boston, and Mrs. Natalie Edsall Alexandra and Paul Russell Bonner.

M.E. Ingalls, President of the Big Four Railroad Company, who is also the representative of the State of Ohio on the Taxation Committee of the National Civic Federation, discussed at the Waldorf-Astoria last night the tax reform movement in his State.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- Announcement was made to-day by Edward B. Smith Co. of this city, bankers, that the Choctaw, Oklahoma and Gulf Railroad Company had been sold to Speyer Co., bankers, of New York. The announcement is as follows:

ALBANY, April 9. -- A meeting of representative Republicans of Ulster, Schoharie, Delaware, and Otsego Counties held at the Ten Eyck to-day for the purpose of fixing the apportionment of delegates to the Republican Congressional Convention of the Twenty-fourth District ended in a deadlock, because the representatives from Ulster demanded more than the others would allow.

COPENHAGEN, April 9 -- The Landsthing (upper house) to-day concluded its secret debate, on the treaty providing for the sale of the Danish West Indies to the United States. Reports on the subject have been prepared.

A man and a woman who registered at the Wigwam Hotel at Broadway and Forty-ninth Street at 2 o'clock yesterday morning as John G. Brigham and wife were found dead in a room on the second floor in the evening, two gas jets in the room to which they had been assigned turned on full, and every indication pointing to a double suicide.

Under a Tammany Mayor and a Tammany Corporation Counsel public clamor against the Bedell till would have been raised in vain. It is creditable to Mayor Low and to Mr. RIVES that when enlightened by public criticism and warned by public protest, they have promptly reversed themselves.

ALBANY, April 9. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners has granted the application of the New York and Port Chester Railroad Company for permission to construct a four-track railway from Willis Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-second Street, New York City, north-easterly through Fordham, William's Bridge, Mount Vernon, and New Rochelle, to a point on the boundary line between New York and Connecticut, a distance of twenty-one miles.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were quite large, and more issues appeared in the list of sales than on any recent day. In a number of stocks the transactions were heavy, although for the most part the movement of prices was within narrow limits. Net changes for the day showed considerable irregularity, a number of stocks, including several prominent issues, declining, while elsewhere the changes appeared as net gains.
At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the United States Rubber Company, held yesterday, E.C. Benedict of Messrs, E.C. Benedict Co. was elected a Director to fill a vacancy on the board.

Chairman PAYNE will find it impossible to sustain by fact and evidence his statement that the 20 per cent, reduction on Cuban sugar will "save the planters from bankruptcy until the removal of the bounty system in Europe which the Brussels Council abolished, to take effect Sept. 1, 1903."

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The Senate Committee on Immigration to-day reported the House Chinese Exclusion bill to the Senate. This action was taken without any definite intention of substituting that bill for the Senate bill, but with the view of having it available for that purpose if considered desirable.

ALBANY, April 9. -- The largest hearing in point of attendance given by Gov. Odel on a legislative bill this year was that given this afternoon on the bill of Assemblyman Bedell, changing the railway terminal law. Large delegations were present from New York City and Buffalo in opposition to the bill, and the hearing lasted from 3 until 6 o'clock.
TRENTON, N.J., April 9 -- Joseph Parker, an old man, who was brutally beaten by Charles Burke and Joseph Schum on March 7, died this morning at his home.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 9. -- The Cornell University baseball team defeated the Naval Cadets here to-day by a score of 10 to 6 in a game that flourished with errors. The game began shortly, after 4 o'clock and by agreement playing was stopped at 5:35 in order that the Ithacans might catch the evening train, and six inning's were completed.
LONDON, April 9. -- SS St. Paul, Capt. Jamison, from New York, passed Hurst Castle at 8:40 P.M. and arr. at Southampton to-day.

-- One of our readers -- who is evidently a man of great and determined originality of mind, since he spells "Carnegie" with "K" for initial letter -- complains with some bitterness because the founder of libraries, when speaking at the American Authors' dinner, referred to "Home, Sweet Home" as one of the two American songs "that are perhaps the most famous songs in the world."
LONDON, April 9. -- Money to-day continued to be in strong demand. Discounts were firmer.

For the frequency with which physicians are made defendants in suits for damages by patients alleging malpractice the leading members of the profession are largely to blame. In compromising claims which are an insult to their professional skill and an impeachment of their honesty as practitioners of the healing art they have given substantial encouragement to conspiracies of physicians without professional pride and lawyers without honor.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Throughout today's session of the Senate the Chinese Exclusion bill was under consideration. Mr. Gallinger of New Hampshire and Mr. Dillingham of Vermont opposed the bill, and Mr. Turner of Washington supported it. Mr. Gallinger urged that the pending bill was "unnecessary, unjust, and un-American," and was clearly in contravention of our treaty obligations with China.

BOSTON, April 9. -- There was a slightly increased firmness in the money market to-day. There is still a very light demand. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent. New York funds, 10 cents discount. Call loans, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Time money, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Clearing House exchanges, $23,235,202; balances, $1,435,347.

Astonishment will always greet the fact that nature appears under different disguises to different men, that the same landscape, for instance, painted by half a dozen artists from the same place under the same effects of light may, and probably will, appear to be six different views, especially if the six artists are past their salad days and have acquired each a manner of his own.

B.C. F.T. Barry have sold for Richard and M.P. Collins 649 and 651 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of Sixtieth Street, a plot 50.5 by 90, now occupied by two fourstory dwellings altered for business purposes. The buyer is Albert I. Sire. The price is reported to have been a little over $210,000.

The enthusiasm with which the President was greeted at Charleston may have been in part induced by the desire on the part of the gentlemen of South Carolina to make amends for the stupid and boorish insult offered to him by a South Carolinian official, who usurped authority in order to offer it.

SARATOGA, N.Y., April 9 -- While Bishop James' N. Fitzgerald of St. Louis. Mo., Secretary of the Board of Bishops, will not formally call to order the seventieth annual session of the Troy Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church until to-morrow morning, the preliminary labors have been in progress all day.

Silver bullion yesterday in the London market sold down to the lowest price on record, 23 3/4d. per ounce -- a figure only once before recorded, in the Fall of 1897. The weakness, which marks a 3 1/2d. decline in a year, is ascribed to the poor trade situation in India, the small purchases by France, Russia, and Spain, and the unsettled state of the Chinese market.

Commissioner Partridge at a late hour yesterday afternoon was hastily called from Police Headquarters for a conference with Mayor Low in the City Hall. At the end of the interview he would not tell what it was about. The Mayor was equally uncommunicative. The Police Commissioner was not in a pleasant frame of mind when he left the Mayor.

In his new book, "The Empire of Business," Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE says many wise and witty things, and none are wiser or wittier than such as relate to wealth, and wealthy men. For example, one may find no little of instruction as well as entertainment in the following clever description of the uses of the millionaire:

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- The Standard Company has not paid dues and its stock has been dropped from the Mining Exchange list. If there are any sales they are outside the floor of the Exchange and do not figure in reports. The official clposing quotations to-day and yesterday were as follows:
VIENNA, April 10. -- A rumor is current here that M. Sarafof, the Macedonian leader, is dead. The report lacks confirmation.

The opponents of the management of the Rubber Goods Manufacturing Company won a complete victory at the special meeiing of the stockholders, held in Jersey City yesterday. Not only were the proposed new by-laws and the amended certificate of incorporation, providing for a classification of Directors, defeated, but the opposing faction elected a new Board of Directors, in which it has a two-thirds representation.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- A beautiful wedding took place this evening at St. Peter's Church on Capitol Hill when Miss May Gillespie Blaine, third daughter of the late Robert G. Blaine, became the bride of Charles Eppa Lipscomb of Pittsburg. The ushers who seated the large congregation were: Charles F. Bryne of Virginia and Edward W. Callahan, Aubrey L. Clarke, William A. Graham, and Harry A. Lattimer, all of this city.

COLUMBUS, Ga., April 10. -- Early tonight fire broke out in the plow shop of the Southern Plow Works and by 11 o'clock two entire blocks were in ashes and another building, a warehouse, was burning rapidly. The loss to the two blocks burned is estimated at over $200,000, and the damage to the warehouse will run the amount up to $250,000.

ALBANY, April 10. -- Six judicial offices are to be filled by the electors of New York State this Fall. The electors of the entire State are to vote for an Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals, and the electors in four judicial districts are to elect five Supreme Court Justices.

In the opinion of Albert B. Boardman, one of the counsel for the Rapid Transit Commission, the defeat of the Bedell bill would in no way delay the improvement of the terminal facilities of the New York Central Company, provided the measure amending the Rapid Transit Commission act is approved.

LONDON, April 11. -- "This," said Charles T. Yerkes yesterday, "is a grand finish of six months' work." He referred to the arrangement, just completed, by which Speyer Brothers of London, Speyer Co. of New York, and the Old Colony Trust Company of Boston form a new company, with u5,000,000 capital, for the purpose of carrying out Mr. Yerkes's electric underground Plans in London.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10. -- The depression in New York caused a selling movement in the Philadelphia market, and other stocks with listings in both markets were weak, but a number of local issues were stronger, among them being Electric Storage Battery and Choctaw. The latter was favorably influenced by the deal for the acquisition of the property, as reported, for the Rock Island and Pacific.

C.S. Cowenhoven and Alphonse Voullaire were discharged yesterday by Magistrate Cornell, in the Centre Street Police Court, after there had been a lively interchange of compliments by Abraham Gruber, attorney for Detective Sergeants Butler, Finley, Cronin, and Hennesey of the Central Office. Mr. Cowenhoven, a reporter, and Voullaire were charged with burglarizing an upper west side house, the owner consenting.

The Century Realty Company has bought, through Herbert A. Sherman, 126 East Seventy-third Street, a three-story brownstone front dwelling, 18.9 by 100; also, 52 East Forty-ninth Street, a four-story brownstone-front dwelling, 20 by 100; also, 56 East Forty-ninth Street, a four-story brownstone-front dwelling, 20 by 100.

The American flag, floating from the staff of the Drury Lane Theatre is the most attractive thing in London, in the opinion of A.L. Erlanger of the firm of Klaw Erlanger, who arrived on the Deutschland yesterday. Mr. Erlanger went to London to direct the staging of "BenHur."

PHILADELPHIA, April 10. -- By the terms of the will of Col. John McKee, who died a few days ago and is said to have been the wealthiest negro in the United States, Archbishop Ryan of the Archdiocese of Philadelphia will come into the possession, as Trustee, of an estate valued at upward of $2,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- American members of the Legion of Honor gave a dinner at the New Willard Hotel to-night complimentary to the French Ambassador, M. Cambon. The dinner was one of the most brilliant affairs ever given in Washington.

District Attorney Jerome and Commissioner Partridge, although working in harmony, do not quite agree in regard to the James McAuliffe case. Col. Partridge announced yesterday that there was enough evidence for an investigation by the Grand Jury of the charge that the man was murdered. Mr. Jerome stated that there was not yet sufficient evidence to present to the Grand Jury.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 10. -- The testimony in the trial of the Van Wormer brothers to-day was for the most part confined to the location of the footprints in the snow around the Hallenbeck house and the fitting of the shoes in the tracks. Sheriff Best, Coroner Lisk, Lewis J. Elting, and Edwin H. Hallenbeck had the witness stand all day, with but two interruptions.

CHICAGO, April 10. -- Unless present plans fall through, Chicago will have at least two new theatres in about another year. The theatrical syndicate has secured a site on Randolph Street, just east of Dearborn, and will build a theatre there in 1903 to cost $400,000. Plans are already drawn for this house, which the promoters say will be the finest theatre in America.

CHESTER, S.C., April 10. -- The President has been given a warm greeting by the people of South Carolina on his return journey to Washington. At Branchville, S.C., a small station on the Southern Railroad, a stop was made for water. The President came out on the rear platform and bowed his acknowledgment to the 300 people who rushed for his car and cheered him.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 10. -- Dr. Clifford Colgate Moore, a retired New York physician, and his wife and Frederick Payne are at their respective homes suffering from injuries sustained through runaways resulting from reckless driving of automobiles.

SARATOGA, N.Y., April 10. -- The seventieth annual session of the Troy Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church began with the sacrament of the Lord's supper this morning. Bishop Fitzgerald of St. Louis, Mo., was assisted in the service by the Presiding Elders, the Rev. Drs. Stevens, Brown, Eaton, Hughes, and Gates.
BRUSSELS, April 10. -- Repeated charges of police and mounted gendarmes with drawn sabres resulted in the dispersal of rioting mobs here early this morning.

MANILA, April 10. -- The insurgent Gen. Lukban, who surrendered to Lieut. Strebleer of the Filipino Scouts Feb. 22, in the Island of Samar, and who was brought to Manila, has been sent to the Maligi Island prison, where he will occupy special quarters.
HONGKONG, April 10. -- The imperial forces hold most of the mountain passes in the disturbed districts of South China, but the rebels still have access to their filibustering base.

LONDON, April 10. -- Capt. Bradford, skipper of the cutter Galatea, which was defeated by the Mayflower in 1886, in the races that year for the America's Cup, fell dead on the deck of the Galatea, at Dartmouth, yesterday.

BULUWAYO, Matabeleland, (Rhodesia,) April 10. -- Amid an immense throng of soldiers, civilians, and natives, the body of Cecil Rhodes was to-day committed to its rock tomb in the Matoppo Hills. The coffin was shrouded in a union jack and the wreath sent by Queen Alexandra was laid upon it as it was lowered into the grave.

-- We comply very willingly with a request from Mr. D.T. MACDOUGAL, the Acting Director in Chief of the New York | Botanical Garden, to call attention to the fact that the first of the annual prizes supplied by the Caroline and Olivia Phelps Stokes Fund has been awarded to Dr. F.H. KNOWLTON of the United States National Museum for an essay entitled "Suggestions for the Preservation of Native Plants."

Capt. Walsh of the Eldridge Street Police Station last night, shortly before 11 o'clock, raided the premises at 96-98 Forsyth Street, known as Odd Fellows' Hall, stopped a prizefight in full progress, and captured 200 prisoners, among whom were three reporters of a morning newspaper.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., April 10. -- In the finals of the Swannanoa Count Golf Club's tournament to-day McClosky and Miss Croker of New York and Rumbugh and Miss Collins of Kansas City tied for the Manor Cup in the mixed foursomes.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 10. -- Prof. Morse Stephens, in his lecture at Cornell University to-day, in the course on the history of the British Empire, referred to the bequests of Cecil Rhodes. Prof. Stephens is a graduate of Oxford.

SALISBURY, N.C., April 10. -- The first stop in the Tarheel State was Charlotte. The demonstration there was no less enthusiastic and hearty than it was in the Palmetto State. The President was forced to make a speech, in which he said:

The acquittal of KRUITZINGER is on all accounts very fortunate. It is calculated to do away with the unfortunate impression made by the execution of SCHEEPERS. There seems to be really no dispute that SCHEEPERS was captured in violation of the Geneva convention, and this fact would in any case bring suspicion upon the fairness of his trial.
