The racing season in New York will open to-morrow, and the professional element of the turf is in a flurry of expectation over the advent of the new turf year. Following a recent custom, the opening will be at the Aqueduct track, where a fourteen days' meeting will be held under the management of the Queens County Jockey Club, the Carter Handicap being fixed as the feature of the first day.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 13. -- Secretary Shanklin of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association has closed the Kentucky Futurity with 1,145 entries from thirty-eight States and Canada. Kentucky sends 424, New York, 134; Massachusetts, 119; Illinois, 91; Ohio, 46; California, 44; West Virginia and Georgia, 30 each; Indiana, 24; Pennsylvania and New Hampshire, 19 each; Kansas, 16; New Jersey,. 14; Tennessee, 13; Nebraska and Texas, 11 each; Canada, 15.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A drastic, but the only effectual, remedy for Deveryism in the body of public servants, which, like the Mamelukes, Janissaries, and Pretorian Guards, has attained entirely too much political power, is to wipe them out, lock, stock, and barrel.
BRUSSELS, April 14. -- King Leopold went to Ostend yesterday and returned to Brussels last evening. His trip was uneventful.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 13. -- "A rush of fortune seekers will be seen in the next few weeks which will equal that caused by the oil discoveries in Texas last year," said D. R. Beatty, the Beaumont "Oil King," at the Planters' Hotel to-night, "Their destination will be the shale gold fields of Western Kansas.

A man in a frock coat, white vest, and silk hat, who described himself as James Reilly of 80 West Thirty-fifth Street and who the police say is a well-known actor and a star using an assumed name, was locked up in the West Sixty-eighth Street Station last night for smashing the windows in the basement of Fay Templeton's House, at 208 West Seventy-ninth Street.
ALBANY, N. Y., April 13. -- Gov. Odell has vetoed the following bills of interest to New York City:

COLUMBIA, S. C., April 13. -- Persons who attended the funeral obsequies of John C. Calhoun, for which preparations were made by the State for a week, declare the demonstration this afternoon when the body of Wade Hampton was buried in the family lot in Trinity Church yard was greater notwithstanding an effort was made by the family to have this a quiet funeral.

Some unusually interesting matches were played at the Jersey City handball courts yesterday afternoon. "Mike" Egan played a single-handed match against T. McCabe and J. Hanlon, and won three straight games. The set was played out, and McCabe and Hanlon won the remaining two games.

LONDON, April 14. -- The announcement of the presence at Pretoria of the Orange Free State and Transvaal leaders and Generals, who have been at Klerksdorp: considering terms of peace, has caused a, decided increase in the hopefulness of the public concerning the possibility of peace.

LONDON, April 13. -- It is impossible to record any great activity on the Stock Exchange during the past week. Neither the money conditions at home nor the war outlook in South Africa was such as to encourage speculation or commitments. Cash has been distressingly scarce, although the Treasury released enough consol dividends and other funds to permit the market to repay u7,750,000 of its indebtedness to the Bank.
LONDON, April 14 -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says that twentyfour potteries out of the thirty-three at Limoges have closed. The strikers now number 8,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The able letter of Mr. William Edwards in your issue of Sunday last suggests many considerations, and among them is the fact that so many cultivated men are anxious to indulge in criticism and condemnation of the British Government in its efforts to reconcile Irishmen to the rule of Great Britain and of its policy in regard to the Boers and the war now unfortunately in progress.

Golf will experience its real opening for the season on Northern links this week. The Lakewood Golf Club will give the game its annual impetus, as that club usually does, by its Spring open tournament. The event will begin next Thursday with a thirty-six hole qualifying round for three sets of cups, three sets of sixteen to qualify for the respective trophies.

Patrick Fivey of 76 Bevan Street, Jersey City, was left alone in the house yesterday while his wife went to church. Shortly after her departure he armed himself with a rifle and began parading up and down the rear yard. After half a dozen turns he halten and went through the manual of arms.
The fact that ex-Gov. D. B. Hill will attend the reception at the Democratic Club to-night was the cause of much speculation among Democrats yesterday.

The strong wind of yesterday interfered materially with the pleasure of the Harlem River oarsmen, though there were more crews out than on the two preceding Sundays. Several new crews, candidates for honors at the coming Harlem regatta, made their appearance, and the selection was announced of several more, who will begin training this week.

For the first time since it came into existence the present excise law yesterday was enforced in this city with comparatively little friction. The public, the police, and the proprietors of the Raines law hotels each seemed to have a clearer apprehension of their rights under the law than was the case the previous Sunday, when the first thorough enforcement was attempted.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The issues are fairly joined between the Lieutenant General and the Secretary of War. The troubles which began long ago under the Cleveland Administration have finally reached so critical a stage that the compulsory retirement of Gen. Miles at an early date is an open secret and is not denied at the White House.

The effect of the state of mind into which the saloon keepers have been plunged for the past two weeks has been to produce a general closing of the saloons on Sunday, with a general opening of the Raines law hotels and a somewhat more strict observance of the conditions imposed by the law.

Fire was discovered at 1 o'clock this morning in the cellar of the Royal lodging house at 329 Bowery, and 100 patrons were sent hurrying to the street in all stages of undress. One man, whose name the police and firemen did not obtain, was partially overcome by smoke, but was not taken to the hospital.

THE CAPITAL OF THE TRANSVAAL COLONY. -- British financial and industrial centres with interests in South Africa have been much disturbed by Mr. Chamberlain's recent statement in the House of Commons that the Government had not yet decided whether Pretoria or Johannesburg was to be the administrative capital of the Transvaal.

SARATOGA, N.Y., April 13 -- The exercises to-day in connection with the seventieth annual session of the Troy Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church proved interesting. They covered substantially the entire day, opening this morning with the conference annual love feast, led by the Rev. Dr. Thomas A. Griffin of Troy.
When Pension Commissioner EVANS sent his resignation to President ROOSEVELT, the President might with great propriety have returned an answer of this tenor and effect:

The bill introduced by Senator SPOONER on the 4th inst. " to regulate the sale of viruses, serums, toxins, and analogous products in the District of Columbia, to regulate inter-State traffic in said articles, and for other purposes," would involve a dangerous expansion of Federal authority if it were not aimed to correct an evil yet more dangerous as directly and immediately affecting the public health.

The riots in Belgium are much of the same character, but not yet so general or violent, as those that prevailed at the last change in the conditions of suffrage some ten years since. As at the former period there is a good deal of trouble with the purely lawless element in the cities, but apparently there is a concerted movement, led by the Socialists, to force the Government to a wider basis of suffrage.

Mr. PUGSLEY of this State, in an interview which we published yesterday, first declares that the currency should not be made a political issue and then proceeds to express his satisfaction with the fact that the Democrats can derive from the bill now before the House a very plausible declaration for the Fall campaign: "Opposition to a branch bank system and to an unsecured currency."

Before the Society for Ethical Culture, in Carnegie Hall, yesterday morning, Prof. Felix Adler discussed two subjects -- "Is it treason to condemn a war waged by our country while the war is still in progress?" and "Are civilized nations justified in adopting uncivilized methods of warfare?"

A number of gallant rescues were made by policemen at a fire which occurred at an early hour yesterday morning in the three-story brick apartment house at 576 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn. The fire started while the tenants were asleep and all had to flee for safety clad only in their night clothes.
MANILA, April 13. -- Major Littleton W. T. Waller of the Marine Corps has been acquitted. He was tried by court-martial on the charge of killing natives of the Island of Samar without trial.

BOSTON, Mass., April 13. -- The New England Methodist Conference is face to face with a Joss of nearly $20,000 -- to be exact, $18,941.81 -- as a result of unwise speculation by former Trustees. So the special committee appointed to investigate the trust funds reported at the executive session Saturday morning.

EL PASO, Texas, April 13. -- From a standpoint of brutality to-day's fight at the Juarez bull ring between a four-year-old South African lion and a savage Mexican bull was a success. The lion was caught time and time again by his fierce antagonist and tossed about on the enraged bull's horns like a stuffed animal.

Columbia's strong men who are to take part in the annual competition to select the fifty strongest men in the American colleges are already beginning to take tests, of which the records must be sent to Dr. Sargent of Harvard before May 1. The system of the tests was originated by Dr. Sargent of Harvard.

The New York Branch of the Israelite Alliance of America met in Ahawath Chesed Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, yesterday afternoon to take some measures to relieve the condition of the persecuted Jews in Rusisa and Roumania.

The most significant item of current business news records the success of the negotiations for the formation of a merger of the representative jobbing concerns of the United States dealing in hardware. For those who have intelligently followed the course of industrial development in this country through a period of years, this appears to be a step in a perfectly natural and normal progress along the lines of least resistance.

Since THE TIMES refuses to accept any of the issues suggested for his party by Mr. WATTEHSON, what would it advise the Democrats to do in order to "regain the confidence of the people "? -- From The Louisville Courier-Journal, April 9.

BERLIN, April 13. -- The past week on the Boerse was quiet and uneventful. The first half of the week showed declining values in all departments, but an improvement began on Friday with the more favorable prospects of peace in South Africa, which the Berlin market now judges very optimistically. Nevertheless it maintains a waiting attitude until definite news is received.

Ex-Judge William Rumsey, as referee in the suit brought by William Whitewright Stewart against the Union Trust Company for a construction of certain provisions in the will of William Whitewright, reported his decision yesterday, which was practically in favor of the contention of the trustees of the estate.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 14 -- Harvey Bruce, cousin of the three Van Wormer brothers, on trial for the murder of their uncle, Peter A. Hallenbeck, at Greenport, Christmas Eve, testified to-day. He told the story of the killing of the old man in full detail. Bruce, when he took the witness chair, was pale and trembling, but told his horrible story to the end and without faltering.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent, "M.A.D.," writing concerning, the priesthood and Catholicism in Porto Rico, deals in characteristic fashion with Dr. Carroll, who had dared to say: "I found the whole people in revolt against the Roman Catholic Church," and who criticised the priesthood in other strong terms. "M A.D." politely calls Dr. Carroll a liar, and calls upon him to prove his statements.
BY THE HOUSE. To grant to the Mobile, Jackson and Kansas City Railroad the right to use a tract of land at Choctaw Point, near Mobile, Ala., for railroad purposes.

LONDON, April 15 -- In a dispatch from Johannesburg a correspondent of The Daily Mail says the leading Boer delegates conferred at Pretoria yesterday with Lord Milner, (British High Commissioner in South Africa,) and that Lord Kitchener was present at this conference.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- People in the Navy Department are pleased and relieved over the acquittal of Major-Littleton W. T. Waller, charged with murdering Filipinos, but there is not so much jubilation in the War Department. There has never, apparently, been any doubt that the marine officer did kill the Filipinos, but he has contended that he did so under orders from Gen. Jacob H. Smith.

THE HAGUE, April 14 -- From those closely in touch with the Boer leaders here it appears that the latest secret dispatches from South Africa outline the peace proposals now under discussion at Pretoria. They closely follow the summary given last Saturday by The Evening News of Edinburgh, with the following additional details:

ASHTABULA, Ohio, April 14 -- News reaches here from Conneaut to the effect that the Carnegie lands cast of Conneaut, the original site of the Carnegie projected tube mill, are being leased to renters for another year. This is believed here to discredit the recent reports in New York regarding the erection of the big tube mill at an early date at Conneaut.

The rumors of negotiations with the Boers have received, for the first time, an official color of authenticity. This was effected by Mr. BALFOUR'S announcement in the House of Commons that "a message had been received from the Boer leaders, and that a reply had been sent to them."

ROSELAND, N.J., April 14 -- Roseland, which for forty years had a school house at which most of the inhabitants of the village received their education, has been deprived of it, and Essex Fells is now the building's proud possessor.

MONTAUK POINT, L.I., April 14 -- Perry Clark, Principal of the district school, will have a hearing to-morrow at East Hampton on a charge of assault, in the third degree, upon Edward Payne, seventeen years old, son of Ulysses Payne, proprietor of Second House, at the point.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly allow me to make one addition to the very complete and satisfactory notice of the "Elye Genealogy" in the Sunday issue of THE TIMES, and to correct one error in the last paragraph?

Because he could not see his way clear to accept Adam as a historical person, a young applicant for a preacher's license was rejected yesterday by the New York Presbytery and turned over to the tender mercies of a committee, who, in the words of one minister who was present, will "pray with him, wrestle with God for him.

YONKEKS, N.Y., April 14 -- Because she is not as light and agile as she once was Mrs. Sally Eisler of 82 Riverdale Avenue, is in St. John's Hospital with one of her legs broken in two places, a series of bruises, and a general shaking up.

Mortimer M. Singer won the ping-pong tournament of the Fox Hills Golf Club of Staten Island by defeating William Williams in the final round in three straight sets. The scores of the tournament follow:

BALTIMORE, Md. April 14 -- The vaulting gymnastics of Louisville and Nashville in Wall Street to-day was entirely too unusual to permit of the proper local, feeling for any bullishness in general movement. The list here held firm without working out any very special price changes there being nothing to give any group a particular impetus.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Senate Committee on the Philippines began the week with the intention of making an investigation of the charges to the effect that the "water cure," so-called, is practiced on the insurgents, and Charles S. Riley of Northampton, Mass., formerly a Sergeant in Company M, Twenty-sixth Volunteer Infantry, was the first witness called with that end in view.

Christian Science was the subject discussed at the regular meeting last evening of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence at 17 West Forty-third Street. The principal speaker was Charles M. Demond of the New York bar, and his paper was entitled "Legal Prohibition of Unprofessional Mental Healing."

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $300 of consideration over, $3,000.

Trading in the outside market yesterday presented few developments of special interest. For the most-part the stocks which were the most active were those which for some time, past have supplied the bulk of the trading in the outside market. In some of the copper stocks there were evidences of new buying, and in one or two instances prices were actively advanced.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was rather stirred up by the report of Sunday a week ago that Staten Island had a "dry" Sunday. They may have had at Prohibition Park, but nowhere else that I am aware of. Certainly not in Stapleton. Is it possible that the reporters also belong to the "system," and, like the patrolmen, report "no violations," according to orders?

There are enough people left in town to make it reasonably gay, but there are no large entertainments on the programme. There was one wedding yesterday, that of Miss Gertrude Spurr Whitman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Whitman, to Vincent Allen Howells, and there was also a musicale at the residence of Mrs. Henry Villard for the benefit of the New York Diet Kitchen.

SARATOGA, N.Y., April 14 -- After a session of five days, the annual meeting of the Troy Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church closed this afternoon. The general understanding is that it will reassemble here in April, 1903. The appointments made by Bishop James N. Fitzgerald of St. Louis, Mo., rounded out the concluding session.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "Before my God, I might not this believe Without the sensible and true avouch Of mine own eyes.''

Antimo Barretto, an Italian murderer, recently released from the Italian Government penal establishment at Naples, was permitted to land at New York by the immigration authorities yesterday, despite the fact that his coming was known and it had been officially called to the attention of the Registry Division, through which all immigrants have to pass before being permitted to land on American soil.

A blockade lasting more than five hours occurred on the Brooklyn Bridge railroad early last evening as a result of the derailing of a car near the Brooklyn terminal. The accident happened shortly before 7 o'clock. The car which jumped the track was the last of a four-car train bound from Manhattan to Brooklyn.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 14 -- The Orchard Grove, situated in Monticello, one of the best-known Summer resorts in Suluvan County, was completely destroyed by fire to-day. The loss of $10,000 was partly covered by Insurance.
Romaine Warren, a fifteen-year-old girl, died suddenly at 11:45 Sunday night at the home of Dr. August Reinhold, who conducts a "nature cure" sanitarium at his home, 823 Lexington Avenue.

Herbert A. Sherman has sold for the various owners the following dwellings of East Fifty-fifth Street: No. 125 to Stuyvesant Wainwright, No. 127 to Parke E. Bell, No. 120 to H.R. Tibbetts, No. 131 to J. Mayhew Wainright, No. 133 to Richard T. Wainwright, No. 108 to J. Howard Wainwright, No. 114 to Charles C. Marshall.
Many stocks were active in yesterday's market, many stocks were strong-but only Louisville and Nashville commanded real attention. It jumped up a dozen points or more, and closed almost at the top.

BOSTON, April 14 -- "The Proper Function of Open Air Statuary" was the subject discussed by F.W. Ruckstuhl, a sculptor, Vice President of the Municipal Art Society of New York, in the lecture course at the Public Library this evening. He said in part:

The heavy and continuing drain of the South African war has forced the British Ministry to impose once more a class of taxes which more than half a century ago Sir ROBERT PEEL abandoned, yielding to the results of the agitation which made COBDEN famous. Wheat and other grain imports are made to bear taxes in the budget scheme which the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir MICHAEL, HICKSBEACH, submitted yesterday.

By a score of 3 to 4 the New York base-ball team defeated the Montreal representatives at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. This was the first time this, season that the New York players had met a professional team, and the Eastern League men gave them a close fight. During the first five innings Mathewson's work in the box was excellent and his fielding from that position was equally good.

AUSTRIA'S MILITARY STSTEM -- When the bill providing for the annual contingent of military recruits comes before the Austrian Reichsrath it is likely that there will be a strong movement on the part of the non-German factions for a two-year service law, similar to the measure now being discussed in France.

The true character and effect of the peculiar scheme which the Senate committee has reported for the currency of the Philippines is to be detected in the fact that it provides for another trade dollar of the same mischievous sort that we once possessed and rejected, but with vices which that one did not have.

From The Cincinnati Commercial Tribune. The attitude of President Roosevelt toward the hundreds of eleventh-hour bills before the Congress to purge the records of numerous bounty jumpers and deserters of the stigma which they and their friends have permitted to rest against them unquestioned and undisputed for thirty-five years will meet the hearty approval of the rank and file of the old army of the late civil war.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 14 -- Cornell's athletic management was given a benefit performance in the Lyceum Theatre to-night, to which practically every organization in the university contributed. The morning on the campus was given over to an informal programme, the chief feature of which was inter-college tug-of-war contests, in which the College of Law defeated Silby College.
LONDON, April 15 -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, rose in the House of Commons at 4:25 o'clock yesterday afternoon to make the budget statement.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- "That is the first speech delivered during the reciprocity debate which can be circulated this Fall as a Democratic campaign document," said Champ Clark of Missouri, one of those who congratulated William G. Brantley of Georgia at the close of his speech in favor of the Cuban reciprocity bill in the House to-day.
BRUSSELS, April 15 -- In accordance with the decision of the labor leaders a general strike was yesterday begun in a large number of trades throughout this country.

Ex-District Attorney Philbin, in the course of an address on the general subject of municipal affairs delivered before the members of the Phi Delta Phi Club of New York at the Hotel Marlborough last night, took exception to the views expressed by Mr. Jerome last Thursday night before the Men's Club of the Judson Memorial.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The dispatches of this morning contain the following in regard to a recent murder in Detroit:
OMAHA, Neb., April 14 -- "The American people will pay much higher prices than the present for their meats, before they pay less."

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at a musicale this evening, which is likely to be the last event of the kind to take place at the White House this year. The 400 guests were seated in the East Room after greeting the hostess in the Green Parlor. Col. Bingham and Major McCawley making the presentations.

John A Hendrick met his first defeat last night in the fourteen-inch balk-line billiard championship tournament of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, Florian Tobias winning an interesting game in which each man made a high run of 34 points, by a score of 300 to 281. At no time during the content of fifty-six innings did either man have a decisive advantage, Hendrick and Tobias alternating in the lead.

Among the defacements of New York street signs are very conspicuously offensive. Things are not so bad in the business quarters down town as they used to be. The owners of the great office buildings take generally successful pains to prevent their tenants from disfiguring their buildings with crude and monstrous proclamations.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 14 -- John Herr Landis, the new Superintendent of the Mint, is a Quay Republican, and was formerly Representative and State Senator from Lancaster County, and was appointed Chief Coiner of the Philadelphia Mint by the late President McKinley in January, 1898, to succeed W.E. Morgan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I had never been burglarized before, and, therefore, had no practical knowledge of the business. To be sure, I had a theory -- for what thinking man hasn't? -- often a large and generous supply, perhaps, too.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

It is not infrequently suggested that the National banks are guilty of some sort of disloyalty to the Government from which they derive their privileges in withdrawing their circulation so largely as they have. It is true that this suggestion is not in accord with the belief that usually goes with it that the privileges of circulation are unduly valuable.

It is well known that Mr. Jerome is quite unable to write one of his sentimental domestic comedies without a teakettle on the hearth -- unless, indeed, he has a whole dinner on a cookstove, as he did in "Miss Hobbs," even though to get it there he had to use the yacht's cabin as a galley. But the teakettle in "Barbara" yesterday afternoon at the Madison Square Theatre played more than its proper part.

While there were no authoritative statements forthcoming yesterday regarding the new control of the Louisville Nashville Railroad, there were plenty of rumors to make up for facts. There was also much activity among those, who are supposed to be most closely identified with the present disturbance in the property.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Chinese Exclusion bill occupied the attention of the Senate throughout to-day, Senators Foraker and McLaurin (S.C.) making extended speeches in opposition. Mr. Foraker contended that the pending measure was violative of our treaty with China, and was calculated to prevent our commercial expansion in the far East.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Grant Statue Commission has report the designs of Henry M. Shrady and Charles Henry Neihaus, both of New York, to be respectively first and second in intrinsic merit of the models selected for the proposed statue of Grant to be erected in this city.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The President has decided to appoint Gen. James S. Clarkson Surveyor of the Port of New York to succeed Silas C. Croft, deceased. The appointment is to be made primarily to satisfy the Iowa Congressional delegation, which for a long time has been demanding that Mr. Clarkson be taken care of.

LONDON, April 15 -- News of severe fighting at the end of last week has been sent by Lord Kitchener, who reports that about two hundred Boers were killed, wounded, or captured. There were about a hundred British casualties.
LONDON, April 14 -- The demand for money slackened to-day. Discounts were slightly easier.

One of the severest of all tests of a play, and especially of a play of the lighter sort, is the lapse of years. The comic muse is a lady of singular tribulations in this respect. But the seven years that have slipped away since the production of "The Importance of Being Earnest" are the least of its misfortunes.

Twenty-three delegates, representing as many clubs in the Polo Association, met at the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street, last night for their annual meeting. H.L. Herbert, Chairman of the association, presided, and the former officers were re-elected for another year, consisting of the Chairman, W.A. Hazard, Secretary, and on the Executive Committee Robert L. Agassiz, George J. Gould, John C. Groome, Thomas Hitchcock, Jr., and W.A. Hazard.

Commissioner Partridge would not yesterday discuss the police-excise question. There was much activity among saloon keepers who are regarded as leaders in the Central Association, many of them doing what was termed "missionary work" among those not prominent in the councils of the organization.

The mystery surrounding the Louisville and Nashville affair was partially cleared up yesterday by statements made by the chief parties in interest, namely, Harris, Gates Co., J.P. Morgan Co., and August Belmont Co. The statements by themselves, while explaining many things, leave just as many questions unanswered, but it was imposible to get anything more in explanation from those in authority.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 15 -- The strength of the Seaboard group was the central point in to-day's market. The buying was based upon expected benefits which will accrue in the event of the development of a community of interest scheme among the railroads in the South. It is believed that the change in the Louisville and Nashville ownership will precipitate a project of that kind somewhat ahead of the intended time.
John Arbuckle, the wealthy coffee merchant, has put the Executive Committee of the Brooklyn Congregational Club in a great stew by his attack on the recent dinner given by the organization.

BRUSSELS, April 15 -- The Government has firmly declined to yield on the question of suffrage revision, and unless King Leopold should override the Government, there seems to be nothing to prevent the development of a serious situation.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Leaning over the roof of his house, lighted by the flames from a burning building next door, at an early hour to-day John Walsh passed to his wife, who clung to the edge of a window below, two little children whose lives he had saved from the fire at the risk of his own.

ALBANY, April 13 -- Gov. Odell to-day announced that he had vetoed in the annual Supply and Appropriation bills items which aggregate $372,500. This makes a total of $832,000 which the Governor has cut out of the appropriation bills, both general and special, since the Legislature adjourned.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 15 -- The seventh annual convention of the National Association of the Manufacturers was called to order to-day in the Hall of Representatives, State House, by D.M. Parry of Indianapolis.

The Grand Hotel, in the Catskills, has been leased to C.A. Linsley, who was last season proprietor of the Brighton Beach Hotel. Fifty thousand dollars will be expended on the Grand Hotel in refurnishing and improvements.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Senators who favor the House resolution providing for the election of Senators by popular vote heard this morning with dismay that the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections had voted to amend the resolution by adding the amendment offered by Senator Depew.

Esther Kohen, fifty years old, a widow; her son Henry, twenty-three; a daughter, Lena, seventeen, and a Hungarian friend, Edith Flow, sixteen, were found dead from illuminating gas at 8 o'clock last night in the apartments of the Kohens, at 1,157 Third Avenue. A gas jet was turned on in the parlor, where Henry lay dead on a lounge.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 15 -- The Minister of the Interior, M. Sipiaguine, was shot and fatally wounded at 1 o'clock this afternoon in the Ministerial offices. He died an hour afterward.

Assignments in the Artillery Corps: Second Lieut. Marion B. Wilhoit to the Ninety-first Company. Coast Artillery. Second Lieut, Frederick L. Dengier to the One Hundred and Sixteenth Company. Second Lieut. Archibald G. Hutchinson, recently appointed, is assigned to the Third Infantry. He will report to the commanding officer of Jefferson Barracks for temporary duty until the arrival of his regiment at its station in the United States.

BOSTON, Mass., April 15 -- The demand for money continues light and supply abundant. Sterling exchange is quiet and steady. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent. New York funds, 3 to 5c discount. Call loans, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Time money, 4 to-5 per cent. Clearing House exchanges, $26,326,365; balances, $1,671,724.

After a day's business extraordinary -- and, under the circumstances, unprecedented -- in Stock Exchange annals, the security market closed yesterday afternoon calmly strong. In many important ways it contrasted with the excited movement of the day before. Then there was apprehension, producing weakness, Wall Street being filled with gruesome rumors suggesting calamity.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The debate on the Chinese Exclusion bill was practically concluded to-day and voting on the bill and amendments will begin at 1 o'clock to-morrow. By general consent a vote was taken to-day on two important amendments, offered by Mr. Fairbanks of Indiana, striking out of the definition as to Chinese students and teachers, and they were agreed to without division.

ALBANY, April 15 -- The court to-day denied the motion of the District Attorney of New York County for a reargument in the "The" Allen poolroom case. The court some weeks ago dismissed the indictment against Alien and several other men of New York City on the charge of having violated the Anti-Poolroom act.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The President to-day nominated Gen. Michael Kerwin to be Pension Agent in New York. This is a reappointment.

LONDON, April 16 -- The loan of L32,000,000 provided for in the Budget, was adopted by 220 to 103 votes by the House of Commons yesterday. The loan is to be raised by an issue of 2 3/4 per cent, consols.
CAMDEN, N.J., April 15 -- The first annual meeting of the Pennsylvania Steel Company was held here to-day. The report of the Board of Directors, submitted by President E.C. Felton, was approved.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Democrats to-day disclosed their hand on the Cuban reciprocity fight, and so did the beet sugar Republicans, though it was involuntary in the case of the latter. While the majority of the Democrats are in favor of reciprocity, some of them will vote against it; but the Democrats have agreed to vote as a unit for the amendment abolishing the differential on refined sugar.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- After the close of the Cuban reciprocity debate in the House to-day, the leaders announced that all danger of the bill being weighted down with undesirable amendments was over, and that they felt assured the bill would pass in the shape in which it came from the committee.

LONDON, April 16 -- The restoration by the Chancellor of the Exchequer of the registration tax on grain is objected to or supported here according to men's environment or settled convictions. The Parliamentary opposition will argue against it with little help from the other side.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- Southern Railway overshadowed everything else in the local stock market transactions, aggregating over 21,000 shares. At times the confusion was so great that the stock was selling one-half to a point above the price in New York. The dealings in this stock were confined largely to traders who were doing an arbitrage business.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 15 -- When court was opened to-day in the trial of Willis, Burton, and Frederick Van Wormer for the murder of their uncle. Peter A. Hallenbeck, on Christmas Eve, the cross-examination of Harvey Bruce was resumed. Ex-Judge Cady conducted the cross-examination. Bruce said he lived in New Jersey for a time up to August last.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 15 -- Disguised as a woman in clothes and wig bought for the purpose, Bernhard Weidhaas of this city obtained entrance into the Highland Hotel on Hillman Street, about 9 o'clock to-night, and shot and killed his wife, who was employed there. In trying to escape he shot a bartender and fired at a hotel guest.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Edward F. Carey, as trustee, the two-story brick building 21 and 23 East One Hundred and 9 Twenty-fifth Street, on plot 75 by 99.11. Under lease to the city, the structure has been occupied for several years by Public School No. 95. Formerly it was for a long time the home of the Harlem Democratic Club, several members of which bought the property about twenty years ago.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- As a result of the consideration by the Cabinet to-day of the charges of cruel treatment of Filipinos by United States soldiers, Secretary Root has made public the following correspondence:

Julio Jose, Marquis de Apezteguia, of 565 Park Avenue, the leader of the royalist party in Cuba previous to the Spanish-American war, died early Monday morning in the fifty-ninth year of his age. He is survived by three daughters and one son, his wife, the daughter of the Rev. M.R. Vincent of Union Theological Seminary, having died in Madrid four years ago.
LONDON, April 15 -- Money was plentiful to-day, and the demand was stimulated by heavy repayments to the Bank of England. Discounts were weaker.

The Board of Aldermen held a breezy session yesterday afternoon, Aldermen Bridges and Brenner taking prominent parts in the proceedings. In the absence ou President Fornes, who was in attendance at the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, Alderman McInnes pre sided.

KINGSTON DEPOT, N.Y., April 15 -- Miss Katharine Gardiner Sahler, niece of John H. Starin and a cousin of Mrs. Edwin Gould, was married this afternoon to Robert Bayard Coykendall, youngest son of Samuel D. Coykendall, a well-known transportation owner and millionaire banker, at the Reformed Dutch Church at Saugerties.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Gov. Odell to-night signed a number of important bills, among which were some that were included in the omnibus veto made public Monday morning, but which were afterward reconsidered. The Slater Employers' Liability bill, which was passed at the request of the State Workingmen's Federation, is among the number signed, as was that of Senator Green permitting savings banks to invest in the bonds of the City of Los Angeles, Cal.
PARIS, April 15 -- President Loubet to-day received James H. Hyde, President of the Federation of the Alliance Francaise in the United States.

If we are to suppose that it is the intention of President ROOSEVELT to appoint Mr. CLARKSON, formerly of Iowa, to be Surveyor of the Port of New York, we must assume that the President has very seriously modified his views as to the principles that should govern the civil service.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Funeral services were held at the Church of the Covenant this afternoon over the body of the Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage. The large church was crowded to the doors.

Gov. Odell on Monday signed the bill in its amended form providing for a Children's Court in this city. Although the court was to be opened in the Old Charities Building, at Third Avenue and Eleventh Street, on Jan. 1 last, amendments in the law necessary for its management and other delays have deferred the opening.

A total of 1,009 names appears on the new official handicap list of the Metropolitan Golf Association, issued yesterday by the committee appointed at the annual meeting to revise the schedule for this season. This is a larger number of players than has ever been handicapped in the Spring list before, and of these 358 are eligible to compete in the annual metropolitan championship tournament.

There is ceremony in the departure of President-elect T. Estrada Palma from the country in which he has spent so many years of exile from the island he is to govern after the 20th of next month. Accompanied by his secretary and a few others, he will leave this city, where he spent last night, at 9:25 o'clock this morning.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, April 15 -- The Supreme Court of Porto Rico rendered a decision to-day in the appeal of Santiago Iglesias, President of the Federation of Workmen of Porto Rico, who was sentenced last December to more than three years imprisonment on the charge of conspiring to raise the price of labor in Porto Rico, acquitting him of all the charges against him, reversing the decision of the lower court.

BABYLON, L.I., April 15 -- A bull terrier, owned by Frank S. Berry, a well-known clubman of this place, stopped his master's runaway horse on Main Street this afternoon. The horse had taken fright and broken away from the hitching post. The reins had fallen to the road. When the horse started to run the dog began to jump at his nose and bark.
PARIS, April 15 -- The gala matinee performance at the Opera Comique to-day in aid of the fund for a memorial to President McKinley at Canton, Ohio, was a great artistic and financial success.

In the eyes of Populists and professional friends of man a group of financiers, rich, powerful, and friendly, become an octopus when they firmly hold the control of a great railroad system. With equal austerity the friends of man denounce such persons as Mr. JOHN W. GATES as stock gamblers, raiders, and disturbers of values.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A letter from Attorney General Knox relative to the so-called beef trust was made public to-day by Representative Ray of New York, Chairman of the House Committee on Judiciary. In view of the Attorney General's letter the committee decided without division to recommend that the resolution of Representative Thayer of Massachusetts, asking the Attorney General what steps he had taken against the Beef Trust, lie on the table.

After a careful study of the weather signs Ex-Senator HILL expresses the belief that Democratic prospects are brighter. It would seem so, since he was able to appear at the Democratic Club on Monday evening without getting himself thrown down stairs.
LONDON, April 16 -- The Daily Mail says it understands that a serious hitch has occurred in the peace negotiations in South Africa.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 16 -- Princeton easily defeated Lehigh's baseball team here to-day by a score of 13 to 0. The game was fast and cleanly played by the Tigers, who took advantage of every misplay of the visitors to score. The score:
Money rate: Collateral loans on call, 4 @ 5 1/2 per cent.; at three months, 4 1/4 per cent.; at six months, 4 1/2 per cent. Commercial paper, sixty to ninety days, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.

Charles J. Fitzpatrick, a physical instructor, was arrested last night at his home, 217 East Fifty-ninth Street, on a warrant issued by Justice Mayer of Special Sessions,, in which, he was charged with bribery and forgery of an entry in the records of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 16 -- President Samuel Spencer, of the Southern Railway Company sent the following telegram to-day to S.M. Inman, one of the Directors of the Southern and a member of the Executive Board:

ALBANY, April 16. -- Gov. Odell announced to-night that he will confer with District Attorney Jerome and Police Commissioner Partridge on the McAuliffe case in New York City on Saturday. The conference was to have taken place in this city tomorrow, but Gov. Odell is going to Newburg in the morning, and it was necessary to postpone it.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 16 -- The local market to-day was full of rumors with a fair degree of activity and a touch of profit taking. The interest circled around the Seaboard group principally. Those stocks reacted a point from yesterday's high figures, the sales being principally of a realizing character on the part of those who bought speculatively on the recent bulge.

The Brooklyn Amateur Baseball Association has reorganized for the season of 1902, consisting of the following clubs, viz.: Bay Ridge Athletic Club, St. Joseph's YoungMen's Union, Resolute Baseball Club, Fulton Baseball Club, and Brown's Business College Baseball Club.

LONDON, April 17 -- The Associated Press has excellent authority for saying that up to a late hour last night there had been no definite developments in regard to the South African peace negotiations. It is learned that Lord Milner, the British High Commissioner, has defined certain propositions on which peace may almost immediately be secured, but the Cabinet, at its meeting yesterday, is said to have disagreed upon the merits of Lord Milner's terms.
LONDON, April 16 -- There was a fairly good supply of money and a small demand in the marKet to-day. Discounts were quiet.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Gov. Odell to-day ordered the members of his staff to meet him at Charleston on April 23 to participate in the exercises on New York State Day at the Charleston Exposition. The staff will leave New York City on a special train on April 21.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Mrs. Roosevelt, Miss Alice Roosevelt, and Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., returned this afternoon from a twenty-four-hour trip down the Potomac on the yacht Sylph.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April, 16 -- In a practice polo game on the Georgian Court grounds this afternoon Kingrdon Gould, eldest son of George J. Gould, was thrown from his pony in a scrimmage at the lower tend of the field. The fall stunned him, and he had to be carried off the field. He was taken in an automobile to the Casino, where he soon revived.
Second Lieut. Paul A. Barry is transferred from the Fourth Infantry to the Artillery Corps, with rank from Oct. 1, 1899, and assigned to the One Hundredth Company, Coast Artillery.

BERLIN, April 16 -- The Tariff Committee of the Reichstag, after reconsideration of the bacon clause of the new bill, has fixed the duty on bacon at 36 marks ($8.56) per double hundred-weight, but bacon is not to be subject to the minimum tariff for reciprocity purposes, as in the case of other meats.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Senator Depew is confident that the Governor will sign the Bedell Railroad Terminal bill. He and Dr. W. Seward Webb and President William H. Newman made a friendly call on the Governor, and subsequently Mr. Depew said to THE NEW YORK TIMES'S correspondent:

The golf links of the Rockville Centre, L.I., Country Club were to have been opened for the season yesterday, but intending players found that a neighboring land Owner, with whom the club had had some difficulty last season, had plowed a large section of the course, on which he claims to have a lease.

The 1902 baseball season will open to-day with four National League games, two of which will be in New York. The New Yorks will meet the Philadelphia team on the Polo Grounds, while Boston will come to play Brooklyn at Washington Park. In the West the games will be at St. Louis, between St. Louis and Pittsburg, and at Cincinnati, between Chicago and Cincinnati.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 16 -- The Cincinnati, New Orleans and Texas Pacific Railroad Company of Cincinnati, operating the Cincinnati Southern Railway, filed to-day a certificate increasing its capital stock from $3,000,000 to $6,000,000, the whole of the increase being 5 per cent. preferred stock.

Despite strenuous objections on the part of counsel for Albert T. Patrick, who was convicted of the murder of William Marsh Rice, Surrogate Fitzgerald yesterday began the trial of the contest over the wills of the dead millionaire.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Platt amendment to the Chinese Exclusion bill reads as follows:
Details will be found in another column relative to the sale of the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street by the Paran Stevens estate.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The friends of the Cuban Reciprocity bill won a substantial victory in the House to-day by carrying a motion to close general debate on Friday at 3 o'clock. The vote was 133 to 123. Thirty-three Republicans voted against the motion, but this defection was offset by thirty-two Democrats who voted with the great body of Republicans for it.

BRUSSELS, April 16 -- The diplomatic, private, and public galleries of the Chamber of Representatives were filled to their capacity to-day, when the debate on the proposed revision of the Constitution began.

It sometimes happens that the wisest forecast of the industrial and commercial future of a country is that of an intelligent foreign student of its business conditions. Distance may be needed to give a proper perspective, and one must be wholly dissociated from the excitements of local business activity to understand what is really happening and trace correctly the tendencies of controlling forces.

Diners in Delmonico's, at Fifth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, last evening witnessed a daring feat of superior horsemanship when Bicycle Policeman John D. Ormsbee stopped a runaway horse by throwing him to the ground when it seemed as if the animal would dash into a carriage at Fifth Avenue.

After the special meeting of the Aqueduct Commission yesterday it was announced that Commissioner Dougherty of the Department of Water Supply had sent a communication to the commission asking that he be admitted with full powers of a Commissioner. He claimed this right under his present position.

Prices in the outside market yesterday were irregular. The upward movement in several important stocks which had been in progress several days was interrupted, and similarly a number of less prominent issues sold off fractionally. These declines, however, were in large part offset by gains made in other parts of the list.

BOSTON, April 16 -- Call money is now obtainable by the best borrowers at 4 per cent., but the general rate is 4 1/2 per cent. Time money is in only moderate request. In New York rates are still firmly held, but there are no indications of their being lifted in the immediate future, the business doing is extremely light.

There were a number of weddings yesterday. In fact, more than there have been on any one day, perhaps with one exception, since Easter. Thev Knickerbocker Bowling Club had its usual meeting, and the coach, with Mr. Alfred G. Vanderbilt as whip, went out in the morning. Mrs. Vanderbilt, Miss Hare, Miss Rives, and Mr. Gerry were on it.

ORANGE, N.J., April 16 -- Articles of incorporation were filed this afternoon by the Citizens' Trust Company of Orange, which will begin business in this city with a capital of $100,000, fully paid up. All the stock is held by Directors, officers, and stockholders in the Orange National Bank.

It was long ago foreseen that the best attainable result in the matter of Chinese exclusion would be the passage of a law reasonably accomplishing the desire of the majority of the American people to keep out Chinese laborers with the minimum of restrictions upon the coming of other Chinese.

The United States gunboat Marietta, Commander Rodgrers, which sailed from Colon on the 7th inst., arrived yesterday. The gunboat has been protecting American interests on the Atlantic side of the isthmus since November, Commander Rodgers said conditions were quiet when he left the isthmus.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 16 -- The annual meeting of the Executive Commis sion of the Alliance of the Reformed and Presbyterian Churches throughout the world is being held here. The first session began at 10 o'clock this morning, the Rev. Dr. R.P. Kerr of Richmond, Va., presiding. The reports of the Rev. Dr. W.H. Roberts of Philadelphia, Secretary, and Frank H. Hippie of Philadelphia, Treasurer were then read.

A meeting of Tammany Democrats of the Twentieth Assembly District opposed to the leadership of James P. Keating was held last night at Tecumseh Hall, in East Thirty-third Street, near Third Avenue, Stephen O'Brien presided.

The fact that Hugh McLaughlin, the Democratic leader of Kings County, is the owner of a large tract which will be acquired by the city if the proposed plan for the extension and beautifying of the east side lands, adjacent to Prospect Park, Brooklyn, is carried out, became known yesterday.

LONDON, April 17 -- J. Pierpont Morgan, the Barings, and the Rothschilds have secured an aggregate of L16,000,000 of the new British loan of L32,000,000. The remaining L16,000,000 will be subscribed by the public.
The State authorities, according to excellent authority, are about to start a searching investigation into the methods of the Beef Trust.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President-elect Tomas Estrada Palma of the new Cuban Republic passed through here this afternoon en route to Cuba. The President-elect is suffering from a cold which made talking a serious strain, and his health, apparently, is far from perfect.

TRENTON, N.J., April 16 -- Gov. Murphy to-day signed the bills which, if adopted by the voters of North Plainfield, will annex that borough to Union County and to the City of Plainfield. The Governor filed a memorandum with the bill.

COLON, Columbia, April 16 -- A launch belonging to the Panama Canal Company returned here this morning from Bocas del Toro, bringing reports that the situation there is growing more serious. The Liberal troops under Gen. Buendia have reached Old Bank, a settlement on an island near the entrance to Bocas del Toro.

In the following list "mtg" stands for morgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The wa revenue law as amended provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 16 -- The Rev. and Mrs. Roderick Terry will not occupy a Newport cottage the coining Summer. They had rented the Theodore Phinney cottage, Hilltop, corner of Ruggles and Carroll Avenues, which they occupies last Summer, but have given up the lease and will spend the Summer in Europe.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 16 -- Soon after the convention of the National Association of Manufacturers opened to-day the Committee on Resolutions reported. Without a dissenting vote the following resolution, indorsing the work of the National Reciprocity Convention at Washington, was adopted.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Senator Turner opened the final debate on the Chinese Exclusion bill to-day, in reply to the speech made yesterday by Mr. Spooner. He repeated his assertion that the shipping interests and the transcontinental railroads have agents in Washington using their strongest efforts to defeat the pending bill.

District Attorney Jerome's investigation before Justice Mayer, acting as a Magistrate, into the case of James McAuliffe, the Glennon witness, who died on Feb. 16 of a fractured skull and who, it is charged, was killed by policemen in the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station, was continued yesterday in the Chambers adjoining the Court of Special Sessions.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Southern Democrats are beginning to be almost outspoken in their repudiation of Bryan. They are completely ignoring him in their discussions about the next Presidential candidate of their party. The South is prepared to take any good man for the Presidential candidate and apparently is not inclined to dictate who he shall be.

LONDON, April 17 -- The Madrid correspondent of The Standard says the Foreign Office seems willing to adopt the suggestion, made by several Spanish newspapers, that steps be taken by Spain to be among the first of the foreign Governments to recognize the new regime in Cuba and to enter into diplomatic relations with the new Republic.

Robert McKay was murdered, according to the verdict rendered by a jury before Coroner Goldenkranz yesterday. The man died at his home, 102 East One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, where he was taken after he had been found lying unconscious in the street in front of a saloon at One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street and Park Avenue.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Gov. Odell has commuted the sentence of Robert W. Ahern, who was convicted in New York in May, 1901, of bigamy and sentenced to Sing Sing for four years and eight months, on the recommendation of the District Attorney with the approval of the Judge on the ground of Ahern's ill-health.

GENEVA, N.Y., April 16 -- Dr. William B. Brooks, Director of Smith Observatory and Professor of Astronomy at Hobart College, announced the discovery of a new comet. It is in constellation Regasus. Its position is right acension 23 hours 8 minutes 10 seconds, declination north 27 degrees 25 minutes.

Nothing could be theatrically less appropriate, or politically more appropriate, than the departure of President PALMA to take charge of the destinies of a new nation. He took quiet leave of the friends of his many years of exile and started for Cuba like any ordinary traveler.

It has often been noticed that artists who have begun life by painting imaginative pictures, genre pictures, historical scenes, or religious subjects, gradually work less and less in these lines, and settle down to portraiture. Whether this be forced on them or not, there are artists devoted to portrait painting who sincerely, or by way of making of necessity a virtue, maintain that the human likeness is the greatest of all the fields of art.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 16 -- Bernhard Weithaas, murderer of his wife, dramatically continued his crime to-day by attempting to drown himself when brought to bay by a posse near Palmer. With great difficulty he was resuscitated and then taken through shouting mobs of people to the Springfield Police Headquarters, where he fully confessed his deed.

ORANGE, N.J., April 16 -- Ex-District Attorney Philbin of New YorK County delivered an address at Seton Hall College, South Orange to-night on the subject of "Office and Duties of the District Attorney of New York County." Mr. Philbin is a graduate of Seton, and was warmly received.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 16 -- When court was opened to-day in the trial of Willis, Burton, and Frederick Van Wormer for the killing of Peter A. Hallenbeck at Greenport on Christmas Eve, Burton Van Wormer was recalled to the witness stand. Under cross-examination he said: "When at the barn before going to the house, and while changing my clothes, I did not give any instructions when to fire.

BOSTON, April 16 -- The event of the Horse Show to-day was Thomas W. Lawson's clean sweep in the trotting stallion class, with Dare Devil taking first prize, Ponce de Leon second, Highland Baron third, and Belford fourth. John Shepard won with Altrol L. in the class for driving trotters.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- After spending an afternoon in voting on innumerable amendments to the Chinese Exclusion bill, the Senate composedly dropped that measure and adopted the Platt substitute by a vote of 48 to 33. Having made this substitution, the Senate passed the amended bill by a vote of 76 to 1, Mr. Hoar alone voting in the negative.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 17. -- Over seventy golfers took part to-day in the annual Spring open tournament of the Lakewood Golf Club. The round was thirty-six holes, medal play, from which three sets of six. teen qualified for as many cups, and they will meet at match play to-morrow and Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The Italian Ambassador and Mine. Mayor des Planches, who are being welcomed to Washington society by a round of delightful dinner parties, were this evening the guests of the Assistant Secretary of State and Mrs. Hill. To meet them were the Japanese Minister and Mme. Takahira, Gen. Miles, the Assistant Attorney General and Mrs. James M. Beck, Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Spaulding.
WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The Democrats of the House at a caucus held to-night by a very large majority, estimated at 3 to 1, adopted the following resolution, introduced by Mr. Swanson of Virginia:
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Chairman Payne of the Ways and Means Committee to-day introduced a bill admitting free of duty the Rochambeau statue, which is to be erected in Washington.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 17 -- The Aetna Indemnity Company of this city was today sold to a New York syndicate, which takes 1,300 shares of the total issue of 2,500 shares. The price paid is $110 a share. The stock was deposited with the Connecticut Trust and Safe Deposit Company of this city.

The annual exhibition of the school department of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen was held at Mechanics' Institute, in West Forty-fourth Street, last night. More than 2,500 persons came on invitation to inspect the work of the scholars for the season of 1901 and 1902, which ended on April 16.
BRUSSELS, April 17 -- The debate on the proposed revision of the Constitution was resumed in the Chamber of Representatives to-day.
LONDON, April 17 -- Money was in good demand to-day and rates were distinctly harder, owing to large applications for the new consols. Discounts were steady.

The baseball season was opened yesterday at the Polo Grounds and an enormous crowd was present. The official report of the clicking turnstiles showed that over 24,000 persons witnessed the game which, was won by the New York team from the Philadelphias by a score of 7 to 0.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 17 -- Although M. Sipiaguine (the Minister of the Interior, who was assassinated on April 15 toy a student named Baisahonstt.) was not actualiy the leader of the Russian Reactionary Party, he was the tool of those who, in the opinion of many, are responsible for the prevailing situation.

LONDON, April 18. -- The Daily Mail claims to have authority to announce that bases of peace have been practically agreed upon at Pretoria, but it says that some little time will elapse before the details of the plan can be perfected.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- An argument was made before the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries this morning for the restoration of that provision of the Ship Subsidy bill allowing small, wooden sailing vessels under 1000 tons capacity to participate in the subsidy. Fields S. Pendleton of New York, President of the Atlantic Carriers' Association, was the witness before the committee.

LONDON, April 18. -- All the official dispatches referring to the defeat sustained by the British troops under Gen. Sir Redvers Buller at Spion Kop, Natal, on Jan. 24, 1900, were given out yesterday morning. The dispatches hitherto unpublished merely emphasize how hopelessly muddled were the preparations for that engagement.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 17. -- A special meeting of the stockholders of the American Alkali Company was held here to-day for the purpose of considering the report of the committee appointed to investigate the accounts of the company alter an assessment of $10 a share had been levied on the preferred stock.

-- Without anticipating any large or immediate results from the war upon " Christian Science " which was declared by the Society of Medical Jurisprudence at its meeting this week, one can still commend no less for accuracy than for vigor the characterizations of Eddyism made by the several speakers.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law as amended provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 17. -- While Gov. Odell's young son, Benjamin Bryant Odell, was riding here to-day, the horse slipped and fell, and the boy's right leg was broken between the knee and ankle. He was taken to the home of his grandfather, where the bone was set by physicians. The Governor was here at the time, having come from Albany this morning.

The annual meeting of the Eastern League of professional baseball clubs was held yesterday at the Victoria Hotel, with President P.T. Powers in the chair. The principal business of the session was the adoption of the playing schedule for the ensuing season, and the appointment of umpires.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 17 -- The local market to-day held fairly well, though there was still some selling of Seaboards. The latter, however, closed above the low figure for the day. Consolidated Gas continued in good demand and forged ahead to a higher figure than has prevailed for quite a long while.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The members of the House who have been chiefly interested in advancing the Chinese Exclusion bill, after informal conferences to-day, decided to accept the Senate substitute yesterday continuing in force the present laws and applying them to our insular possessions.

Carter, Hughes Dwight, lawyers, of 96 Broadway, who are pushing various claims against the Government growing out of the war with Spain and the Cuban insurrection preceding it, have received a brief on demurrer to their petitions, in which the Federal lawyers assert that Weyler's reconcentrado order was justifiable under the rules of civilized warfare.
The Dwight Alumni Association, organized in memory of the late Prof. Theodore W. Dwight, held its tenth annual meeting and dinner at Delmonico's last night.

ALBANY, April 17. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed the bill fixing the State tax rate for the next fiscal year at thirteen-one-hundredths of a mill. There would be no direct tax but for the Constitutional provision, which requires a levy to be made to pay a part of the canal debt. Gov. Odell filed with the law the following statement:

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 17 -- The will of Adolph F. Braidich, late of Babylon and New York, was admitted to probate by Surrogate Petty yesterday afternoon. The estate is estimated at $300,000. personal property and $75,000 of real estate. The testator's only heir at law is a sister.

Mr. WILLIAM ABRAHAM, M.P., one of the ablest and most influential labor leaders in Great Britain and a power among the Welsh miners, lately visited this country to study industrial conditions here, and in a recent address to his constituents of the Rhondda Valley he gave substantial evidence of the fact that he employed his time while here to good purpose.

The " Holy Family," by Rubens, the gem of the F.O. Matthiessen art collection, has been presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by James Henry Smith, and was delivered at that institution on Tuesday.
A statement regarding the Louisville and Nashville affair was put out yesterday purporting to come from a member of J.P. Morgan Co., giving some alleged details. The statement read as follows:

INDIANAPOLIS, April 17. -- D.M. Parry of Indianapolis was elected President of the National Manufacturers' Association today by the convention, now in session in this city. E.H. Sanborn of Philadelphia was elected Secretary and Hamilton Carhart of Detroit Treasurer.

ALBANY, April 17. -- This afternoon the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association of New York received its charter as an old-line company. Under its new title, Mutual Reserve Life Insurance Company, the organization now is a purely mutual life insurance institution, incorporated under the legal reserve statute of New York.

We suppose that it is just as well that Senator DEPEW should appear openly as the advocate with the Governor of the exposed and discredited Bedell bill for extending unlimited privileges to the Central Railroad. There has, of course, been no doubt that the company he represents -- and has so long and successfully represented -- in the lobbies and ante-rooms of the Capitol would do everything in its power to secure these privileges.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

The President's appointment of JAMES S. CLARKSON as Surveyor of Customs at this port is amazing and incomprehensible. The most indulgent and apologetic friend of the Administration must feel that no explanation of it can be suggested or invented that would not be harmful to the reputation of Mr. ROOSEVELT.

DENVER, Col., April 17. -- The world's record has been broken in a ran of 14.8 miles on the western division of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railway, when an average of nearly one hundred miles an hour was made by a regular passenger train. The run was made by train No. 6, east bound, which left Denver March 26 behind time.

BOSTON, April 17 -- Money at the Clearing House to-day was 3 1/2 per cent.; New York funds par and 5 per cent, discount; call loans, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.; time money, 4 to 5 per cent. Clearing House exchanges were $25;334,931, and balances, $1,566,572. The stock market, after an irregular day, closed fairly active and firm Complete transaction's follow :

At the dinner given last evening in the Harlem Casino by the Harlem Democratic Club in honor of the birthday of Thomas Jefferson, Edward M. Shepard, late Democratic candidate for mayor of New York, who was received with wild applause and acclaimed as "the next Democratic Governor of New York," made the first public criticism which he has indulged in, of Mayor Low's administration.

Next week there will be held at Athens, Ga., the fourth annual session of the Conference for Education in the South, and a considerable party will go from this city as the guests of Mr. ROBERT C. OGDBN, whose energy and intelligence in the promotion of the cause of education in the South have been invaluable.
A stirring time resulted at Wallack's Theatre yesterday afternoon, where the Professional Woman's League was advertised to give a matinee performance of a play by Maude Banks, one of its members.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Secretary Root, before leaving for Cuba yesterday, made an order relieving Gen. William Crozier and Capt. I.N. Lewis, Coast Artillery, from further duty with the Board of Ordnance and Fortification. It is understood that this action was taken out of deference to the Military Committee of the Senate.

The reports we received by mail from London of the recent rioting in Jamaica are fuller than those which came to us direct. The correspondent of The London Times assured that journal, on April 6, of the rioting at Montego Bay on the day before, that " the incident is purely local and is of no political significance whatever."

The Rev. Dr. Joseph H. Hertz, who was a member of Lord Milner's High or Advisory Committee in South Africa, and Chaplain of the Rand Rifles, was among the passengers who arrived on the White Star liner Teutonic yesterday. When the war broke out, Dr. Hertz was expelled from Johannesburg by Mr. Kruger for being a Uitlander.
LONDON, April 17. -- J. Reiff, the American jockey, has been licensed to ride in England.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- Heavy arbitrage trading in the Readings was the feature of the local market to-day. The movement followed closely that in the New York market, but quotations often ran ahead of those in Wall Street. The buying was very brisk from the opening, and the record of the day's activity is the highest for a year.

George McAneny, Secretary of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, yesterday sent to Police Commissioner Partridge a letter stating that the appointments of the nineteen Sergeants to the rank of Captain by the York-Sexton board shortly before it went out of office are invalid and must be revoked.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 17. -- The jury in the case of the three brothers Van Wormer. the young men on trial for the murder of their uncle, Peter A. Hallenbeck, is now considering what verdict it will bring in. The attorneys finished their addresses, and the Judge charged the jury in the afternoon, and at 4:40 o'clock the latter retired.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- The International Society of La Savateur of Paris, France, has awarded Emma C. Sickels, a Chicago woman, a gold medal, "for exceptional bravery in checking the Indian war of 1890."

LONDON, April 18 -- In the House of Commons yesterday John E. Redmond, the Irish Nationalist leader, speaking of the Crimes act proclamation issued on Wednesday night by the Lord Lieutenant. Earl Cadogan, said an infamous conspiracy was on foot in England to foment crime in Ireland, where none now existed.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- General debate on the Cuban Reciprocity bill closes tomorrow at 3 o'clock, and it is the intention of the House leaders if possible to force a final vote on the passage of the bill before adjournment to-morrow night.

The general tenor of dispatches from correspondents of R.G. Dun Co. is encouraging for a large yield of Winter wheat At most points the acreage is equal to or larger than last year's, and even in the few reports of a decreased area the loss is only put at 10 per cent., while the most hopeful statements make the increase 50 per cent.

In an opinion handed down yesterday, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in the Second Department, unanimously reversed the decision of Justice Gaynor in the Guden-Dike controversy, and declared that Gov. Odell had acted within the limits of his duty in removing Sheriff Guden from office.

The landscapes by Mr. Dwight Tryon are not painted in a week or in a month, but represent no little labor pursued with a faithfulness that does not end by dulling the artist's zest or diminishing the charm of his original impression. They are not rich in tones or dramatic in construction. Rather are they neutral and reserved; they do not give themselves eagerly to the beholder.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 17. -- The special committee of the City Council on the Western Maryland Railroad met to-day and received replies from all the original bidders to the ordinance naming the conditions of sale of the city's interest in the Western Maryland Railroad.

No one was arrested yesterday in connection with the McAuliffe case. There were no new developments other than that the identification by Mrs. Luigs of Detective Sergeant Kiernan was brought into question. It was discovered yesterday morning that the woman has served time in prison, so that there was doubt thrown on her credibility as an identifier.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Presbyterian Creed Revision Committee completed its labors to-day and adjourned The committee agreed unanimously upon a report to be maid to the General Assembly, which meets in New York on May 15. The members reserved the right to differ upon minor matters in the report to be made to the assembly, but the final report, an authorized statement says, was unanimous and hearty.
MANILA, April 17 -- Gonzales, the insurgent leader, has agreed to obey Malvar's order and will surrender.

AMSTERDAM, April 17 -- An official bulletin, issued early to-day said that Queen Wilhelmina passed a somewhat less tranquil night. The fever, however, had not increased, and the Queen's condition was comparatively satisfactory.

LONDON, April 17. -- Sir Thomas Lipton reiterates that he is prepared to place the Shamrock I. in commission immediately after J. Pierpont Morgan decides what he will do with the Columbia. In an interview Sir Thomas says the British yacht clubs will provide the rivals for the America's Cup with a series of races round the coast.

Important developments growing out of the turning over of the Louisville and Nashville control to J.P. Morgan Co. contributed the influential factor to yesterday's security market. This showed in various ways, in various quarters. It showed in Louisville and Nashville shares especially -- early weakness being quickly followed by an advance of six points and more.

Hopton Weeks have sold for A.J. Thomas the dwelling, 428 Fifth Avenue, between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Streets, purchased by him about two weeks ago from John S. Huyler. The same brokers have also sold for the estate of George L. Kingsland to a Mr. Alexander the adjoining property, 430 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Edward J. Davis of Greenfield, Mass., who was a Sergeant in Company M, Twenty-sixth Volunteer Infantry, was before the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day. He was present in the convent at Igbaras Nov. 27, 1900, when the " water cure " was administered to the Presidente or the town of Igbaras, as testified to by Sergt. Riley and Private Smith.

Sixteen hundred thousand shares were traded in yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, equaling the average records in the hitherto unequaled boom of last Spring. Of course, much manipulation showed, many of the movements of the day having pool origin; but the great bulk of the day's business was from commission houses; and that the public had come into the market was not doubtable.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The statistics of Mr. John Cotton Dana regarding periodicals are valuable and interesting, but it is obviously misleading to consider only the 1,000,000 new books in drawing inferences as to "what people read."

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 18. -- Walter J. Travis and Findlay S. Douglas still remain in the contest for the chief cup in the Lakewood Golf Club open tournament, and from the draw these two rivals will come together in the final round to-morrow afternoon, provided they win their semi-final rounds in the morning.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- The Rev. Dr. Charles Wood, pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church here, whose name has been mentioned as a possible successor to the late Dr. Maltbie D. Babcock, as pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, New York City, will not leave this city.

BOSTON, April 18. -- Money is working easier. At the Clearing House to-day the rate was 3 per cent. New York funds sold at par and 5c discount. Call loans, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Time money, 4 to 5 per cent. Clearing House exchanges, $23,424,624; balances, $1,260,175. The stock market was strong and higher, with the coppers very firm.

LONDON, April 9. -- Clarence Mcllvaine, manager of the London Branch of Harper Brothers, is greatly interested in his forthcoming series of trade handbooks or, as he terms them, "Guidebooks to the Wealth of Nations." Some few particulars of the plan of this series have already been cabled to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW.

IT is always interesting to see and hear the other side of a question, and when that other side is one to which we have given comparatively little attention and is presented without prejudice it invites interest and commands respect.

Mr. W. J. Loftie, who has written frequently during the last quarter of a century upon subjects closely related to those described in the various portions of the present book, " London Afternoons," has therein given some valuable chapters on the early social life, architecture, and records of London and its neighborhood.

ORANGE, N.J., April 18. -- Thirty of the butchers of this city met last night to effect a preliminary organization. James R. Stewart presided. There was a general discussion of the prevailing high price of meats, and there were advocates of the retailers establishing a uniform price for all meats.
ROTTERDAM, April 18. -- The Managing Director of the Holland-America Steamship Company said to-day in an interview:
