WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The American Social Science Association began its general meeting here to-night at the Columbian University. The opening address by President Oscar S. Straus was entitled "Our Diplomacy, with Reference to Our Consular and Diplomatic Service." He said in part:
PARIS, April 21. -- W.K. Vanderbilt's Cleopatre II, came in third to-day in the race for the Prix des Amazones at the St. Cloud meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Senator Dietrich to-day introduced a bill to authorize the President to enter into a reciprocal agreement with the permanent Government of Cuba respecting trade between the United States and Cuba. It provides that when such permanent Government is estab- lished the President is authorized to enter into such agreement with Cuba whereby the United States binds itself for the period of five years to pay to the Government of Cuba:

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day resumed the examination of witnesses in connection with the investigation of affairs in the Philippine Islands. Grover Flint of Cambridge, Mass., who served as First Lieutenant in the Thirty-fifth Volunteer Infantry, testified that early in May, 1900, he had been a witness to the water cure, as administered to the natives by the Macabebe scouts.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 21. -- Another week of dry weather has tested the vitality of Kansas wheat to the utmost. Sunday was the hottest, April day in Kansas on record, 94' degress being registered, with a strong southwest wind. To-day the wind continues, but the temperature is 20 degrees less and the sky is overcast.

The allotments of stock in the new shipping combination were all taken up yesterday, both in Europe and in this country, and the syndicate was closed. It Is understood that this syndicate is practically the same as the United States Steel Syndicate, and that its subscription to this new combination represents the profits made on the financing of the Steel Corporation.

Opposite St. Paul's Chapel yesterday after ernoon, at Broadway and Fulton Street, there was the liveliest sort of a raid on an alleged policy shop, which Capt. Goddard of the Anti-Policy League says was the headquarters for thirty-six down-town policy places. The premises raided were above a hat store, and on the second floor of the building.

OMAHA, Neb., April 21. -- Labor troubles caused an unpleasant wait of an hour at the funeral of Joseph R. Stafford, which took place here Sunday. Stafford was a Past Master of the Masons, and his lodge made arrangements to hold services at the grave. The family had ordered a hearse and two carriages from an undertaker, while the lodge had secured ten carriages from another house.

With the exception of the Pioneer coaching party, there was very little of interest in society yesterday. There are still a number of people in town, some of whom are preparing to go abroad or to the suburbs or to the country. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Harold Hedden gave a reception in honor of the fifth anniversary of their marriage.

LONDON, April 21. -- The Admiralty has ordered the British third-class cruiser Bellona to join the second-class cruiser Thames in searching for the missing Allan liner Huronian. The Bellona will cover 21,000 miles of the northwestern part of the Atlantic.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

We confess to a certain feeling of fatigue at the constant complaint by members of the present administration in this city that they find unfit men in the various departments "protected by the civil service rules."

Mr. Maurice Grau's aggregation of celebrated singers arrived in New York on Sunday afternoon in a state such as might have been expected after several weeks of changing cars, changing hotels, and changing operas. They had been gyrating around that cheerful and indeterminate realm known as "the road."

It is a guarantee of the good faith with which the Government is proceeding in relation to the charges against our army in the Philippines, that the acquittal of Major WALLER should be so promptly followed by the court-martial of Gen. SMITH, behind whose orders the previous culprit took refuge.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The will of the Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage was filed here to-day. It leaves an estate valued at more than $300,000, of which about $250,000 is in personal property, consisting of secured notes, United States 4 per cent, bonds, stock and cash in bank, furniture, pictures, and household effects.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 21. -- Gov. Van Sant, on hearing of the action of the Federal Supreme Court, said:...

Nearly two million shares of stock were traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday -- surpassing the averages that ruled in the boom of a year ago. After a strong opening, sharp reactions took place, and throughout the day the market was irregular till, just before the close, new confidence developed and quotations went upward easily and substantially.

"We do not unwisely hope to see the time when messages will be sent around the world without the aid of wires," said Lord Kelvin, speaking of Marconi and his work last night at a reception given in honor of his Lordship and Lady Kelvin at Columbia University.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- Although denied by a prominent packer at the Stock Yards, a report originating with an ex-official of one of the packing companies states that a " beef trust " actually exists; that the combine meets every Wednesday to fix prices, and that whenever rates are found to have been cut by one of the combine fines ranging from $5,000 to $10,000 are assessed on the offender.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Consideration was begun in the Senate to-day of the Philippine Government bill. Mr. Lodge, Chairman of the Philippine Committee, in response to an intimation from Mr. Bacon said he had no desire to discuss the measure at this time, his explanation of the bill having been made fully.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 21. -- Judge Archibald of the United States Federal Court of the Middle Pennsylvania District on Saturday filed an opinion in the Blooming Grove game case, in which seven prominent men of New York and New Jersey were charged with violation of the Lacey act, a recent enactment of Congress to prohibit the taking of hilled or trapped game outside of the State.

Mayor Low's letter to Commissioner PARTRIDGE advising the non-enforcement of the Sunday laws during the Jewish Passover is open to two objections; one is that it was uncalled for, the other that it was wrong in principle and conclusion.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

That beef is scarce and high priced this month everybody knows. What has caused the scarcity is a question about which there has been much talk during the last few weeks. It has been said that a gigantic trust has been cornering the market and making arbitrary values, that a combination of five great packing concerns has been formed to oppress independent shippers, retailers, and the public.

The statement that the Pabst Hotel at Broadway and Forty-second Street had become the property of the Subway Realty Company for Rapid Transit was yesterday on excellent authority pronounced premature or not likely to occur. James B. Regan, proprietor of the hotel, however, has terminated his business there, and the equipment of the establishment is to be sold at auction, beginning next Friday

The racing at the Aqueduct track passed its sixth day yesterday with the same clear and pleasant weather that has char- acterized the meeting to date. The feature of the day was the race for the Canarsie Stakes at four and a half furlongs for two-year olds, the fourth contest on the card, which resulted in a victory for N. Bennington's highly-tried and much-tipped colt Bensonhurst.

LONDON, April 22. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times says the Novoe Vremya publishes an article on the murder of M. Sipiaguine which illustrates the half-hearted and theoretical indignation with which the outrage is regarded by Russian public opinion.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 21. -- The Readings dominated the local market today. The trading was very heavy and prices were marked up to the highest since the reorganization, the quotations frequently running ahead of the New York prices. The demand from New York was regarded as phenomenal, and it was soon disclosed that the floating supply of the stock in this market was pretty cleanly swept up.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."
LONDON, April 21. -- Money was in good supply and in fair demand to-day. Discounts were steady.

Complaints of blackmail by men who represent themselves as being attached to the Bureau of incumbrances, which reached Borough President Cantor from the Merchants' Association, were followed last night by the arrest of William C. Carr and William E. Edgeworth. Both gave 30 Seventh Street as their residence.

BOSTON, April 21. -- The money market is still showing a tendency to ease. The situation is dull, and rates generally are satisfactory, with apparently an ample supply of funds to meet all present requirements. Clearing House rate, 3 per cent New York funds, par. Call loans, 3 1/2 to 4 1/2.

The trial of Capt. Foody of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station, on charges of neglect of duty in not closing the saloons and enforcing the excise law in his precinct, was begun yesterday before Commissioner Partridge, at Police Headquarters, who will decided whether Capt. Foody shall be permitted to retain his shield.

MANILA, April 21. -- A court-martial has been ordered for the trial of Gen. Jacob H. Smith, who was in command of the United States troops on the Island of Samar. It consists of Gen. Lloyd Wheaton, Samuel S. Sumner, James M. Bell, and William H. Bisbee and Cols. Chambers McKibbin, William A. Rafferty, William E. Dougherty, Alfred C. Markley, and Jesse M. Lee.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- The Supreme Court to-day reversed the decision of the Court of Common Pleas, No. 5, in the case of Napoleon Lajoie vs. the Philadelphia National League Baseball Club. This de- cision upholds the validity of the reserve clause in the National League contracts. Lajoie, who formerly played second base for the National League Club in this city, signed with the Philadelphia American League Club for the season of 1901 and 1902.

The British Diplomatic and Consular Service in the Far East has in the past commonly represented with great accuracy the British mercantile interests there. But in this respect, as in several others, British diplomacy seems of late to have fallen below the standard so long maintained by Sir HARRY PARKES.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 22. -- The local market assumed a waiting attitude to-day. There is little inclination to buy until it is first seen whether Monday's realizing is a prelude to another general setback in New York. There was a continued absorption of Seaboards, the rumor being that a basis of community of interest between Seaboard and Southern has been arranged.

In a moment of despondency because of a wrong she said she had done to her dead husband, a young woman had herself locked up in the Tenderloin Police Station yesterday, asking that she be sent to prison. Later, when sentenced in Jefferson Market Police Court to a three-year term in the State Reformatory, she changed her mind and begged for a shorter sentence.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 22. - The letter of Senator Hanna, which was read at the mass meeting of weavers at Olneyville to-night, follows:

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The question of reciprocity with Cuba formed the subject of an important preliminary conference on the part of a majority of the Republican Senators to-day. The result of the meeting may be summed up as follows:

The capitalization of the new shipping combination will be approximately $170,300,000. Of this amount $120,000,000 will represent the capital stock, which will be divided into preferred and common stock. The common stock will amount to $00,000,000, and the preferred will be $60,000,000. The preferred stock will bear dividends at 6 per cent., and these will be cumulative.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 22. -- The Rev. Dr. Alexander H. Vinton was consecrated Bishop of the Diocese of Western Massachusetts in All Saints' Church to-day. The services, which began at 10:30 o'clock, were presided over by the Right Rev. Dr. Frederick Davies, Bishop of Michigan, assisted by the co-consecrators, the Right Rev. Dr. Frederick Daniel Huntington, Bishop of Central New York, and the Right Rev. Dr. Chauncey Bunce Brewster, Bishop of Connecticut.

The marriage of Richard T. Dana, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Starr Dana, and Miss Mary Meredith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Meredith, was celebrated at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in Grace Church by the Rev. Dr. William R. Huntington. The chancel was elaborately decorated with masses of greens and marguerites, and each pew on the centre aisle had large bunches of bride roses tied to it.

CHICAGO, Ill., April 22. -- Frank H. Cooper, the ex-Vice President of Siegel, Cooper Co., may be a cripple for life as the result of jumping from a moving street car. He will not know for a certainty until after the right leg is released from a plaster cast that now encases it.

Gen. Egbert L. Viele died at his home, 342 West Eighty-eighth Street, early yesterday morning from a sudden attack of indigestion and heart disease. He came to New York on Monday from his Summer home in Tarrytown, intending to attend a banquet at Delmonico's that evening, and he expected to be present at the wedding of a friend yesterday morning.

The stock market yesterday was in large measure a weather and crop market. The movement of prices for the most part hinged upon the crop situation, and as the reports from the Winter wheat belt were generally pessimistic not a little selling of stocks was induced thereby.

LONDON, April 23. -- Clinton E. Dawkins, a member of the firm, of J.S. Morgan Co., testified yesterday before the House of Lords Committee which is investigating the whole question of London underground transit.

Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
The Aldermen yesterday took cognizance of the provision situation by unanimously passing a resolution, which read in part as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 22. -- This city and vicinity had the first touch of midsummer weather to-day, when the United States Weather Bureau thermometer registered 86 degrees at 4 o'clock this afternoon. At 8 A.M. 59 degrees was recorded and at 8 o'clock to-night the mercury stood at 76.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows:

The circular or the Merchants' Association dealing with the question of sidewalk obstructions and taking initial steps looking to the suppression of the blackmailing of merchants by Inspectors of the Bureau of Incumbrances is interesting, but it insensibly reminds the reader of the venerable story of the hunter who followed the bear's tracks until they were so fresh that it was deemed discreet to abandon the chase.

BERLIN, April 22. -- The German steamship companies will not be bought outright by the Morgan interests; they enter a close business confederacy with the American and British lines; their ownership will not be merged; their independence is safeguarded, subject only to certain comprehensive and advantageous contracts.

LAKE WOOD, N.J., April 22. -- Samuel D. Andrews of New York, who was a partner of John D. Rockefeller in the early days of the Standard Oil Company, was seriously hurt in a runaway accident a few miles outside the village this afternoon.

Doubts that have been growing concerning the ability of the new crop of Castleton horses, bred by the Keenes, father and son, were set at rest yesterday at the Aqueduct racetrack by the performance of Gillie, who carried the white with blue spots in their first actual victory of the season by winning the last race in a big gallop after outrunning his field all the way.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 21. -- It is now certain that the earlier reports of the identity of the assassin of M. Sipiaguine were incorrect. Instead of living nine days in St. Petersburg just previous to committing the crime he spent the nine days in a deserted barn at Terioki, just across the Finnish frontier.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22. -- Not all the Philadelphia list had participated in the uplifting of prices in New York, and it was only the stocks with a collateral interest in both markets that suffered on the local exchange when the Gotham list sagged today. Reading, Lehigh Valley, and Pennsylvania fell off, but the strictly local shares held within 1/8 to 1/4 of yesterday's best figures.

With 204 picked men from fourteen police precincts Inspector Adam A. Cross last night made one of the biggest raids on alleged disorderly houses that have ever been instituted, it is said, in the history or the Police Department or this city. The raids all occurred in the Fifteenth Precinct, under command of Acting Captain Churchill, and over the head of that official.

REFUSAL TO PAY A RAILROAD FARE. -- Samuel B. Behr sued the Erie Railroad Company in the Supreme Court to recover damages for injuries which he alleged he received by being unlawfully ejected from one of defendant's trains while a passenger between New York and Spring Valley. Traveling with Behr was a young boy, for whom the conductor demanded a fare, saying that the lad was eight or nine years old.

LONDON, April 22. -- The opening day of the Epsom Spring meeting at Epsom today was, socially, more important than usual, owing to the presence of King Edward, who was attended by a small party of intimate friends. The fields were fairly large, and the sport was of a good character.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- To-day's statement of the Treasury balances in the general fund, exclusive of the $150,000,000 gold reserve in the Division of Redemption, shows:

After much study of the subject, which the public had reason to fear would be barren of results of practicable magnitude and appropriate timeliness, Commissioner LINDENTHAL has approved the plan for the relief of the congestion at the New York end of the Brooklyn Bridge proposed by Chief Engineer MARTIN in his report of Nov. 25, 1901, and proceeded to carry part of it into effect with a rush.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Casualties among industrial workers and the policy of indemnification of the victims formed the theme of to-day's discussions of the American Social Science Association. John Graham Brooks, Chairman of the Department of Social Economy of the association, praised the system in European countries, recognizing that in at least 70 per cent, of industrial accidents the blame could not be properly traced to any person.

Highly significant and interesting are the observations of President JAMES J. HILL upon being informed that the Supreme Court had consented to take original jurisdiction of the suit brought by the State of Washington enjoining the merger planned under the Northern Securities Company:

BOSTON, Mass., April 22. -- Local money conditions continue quiet and fairly easy. Demand is still light, but there appears to be a plentiful supply of loanable bonds, notwithstanding the fact that many of the banks are well loaned up. Strong borrowers are not finding it difficult to shade quoted rates.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22. -- President Benjamin F. Shibe of the Philadelphia American League Club, after consultation to-day with the club's attorneys relative to the Supreme Court decision in the Lajoie case, said:...

Japanese cottons have something of the quality of the Japanese cotton crepes. They come in dress lengths, polka dots -- how are the Japanese fallen! -- of different sizes, $1 for a ten-yard piece of the cotton, which is rather narrow.

We do not know that Mr. RIVES is particularly sensitive to criticism. But it seems that even through the hide of a rhinoceros the winged words of his predecessor in office might penetrate. "I have every reason to believe," observes the Hon. JOHN WHALEN, as reported by The World, "that Mr. RIVES, for whom I have the highest regard, will in the end prove a very competent official."
After half a day of parading and other celebrating, the Old Guard ended up its seventy-sixth anniversary with a dinner in the armory last night.

During the progress yesterday of the trial of Capt. Michael E. Foody of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station, who is facing Commissioner Partridge, at Police Headquarters, on charges of neglect of duty in not closing the saloons of his precinct, District Attorney Jerome, who is prosecuting the case, and whose detectives gathered the evidence against the Captain, abruptly arose and announced that he had received an important message.

HAMPTON, Ta., April 22. -- Verification was had here to-day of the report that has been current for some time that John D. Rockefeller has placed in the hands of Robert C. Ogden of New York $1,000,000 to be distributed among educational institutions in the South. Of these the Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute, which began to-day its thirty-fourth anniversary, will, it is understood, receive a generous share.

NEWARK, N.J., April 22. -- The butchers of Central Market have formed a pool, and propose to fight the Beef Trust. They are going to buy the cattle on the hoof in the West, do their own slaughtering, and hope in that way to be able to supply their customers at a much lower figure than they are now able to command.

Walter Alexander, who recently purchased 428 and 430 Fifth Avenue, has resold those parcels to Frank V. and John Howes Burton, owners of the adjoining Hotel St. Mare property. The Messrs. Burton now control a T-shaped plot, having frontages of 100 feet on Fifth Avenue, 47 feet on Thirty-ninth Street, and 16 feet on Thirty-eighth Street.

PATERSON, N.J., April 22. -- There is rioting in the Riverside section of Paterson to-night, and the police reserves have been called out. The trouble is among the dyers' helpers in a number of the silk mills who went on a strike to-day.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 22. -- The Presbyterian Church throughout the United States has been greatly alarmed for some months lest its large boards should come into the General Assembly to be held in New York reporting enormous debts. For several years this has been the case with several large denominations.
LONDON, April 22. -- W. Bourke Cockran of New York, who sails for the United States to-morrow, described to-day his recent audience with the Pope. He said:

CAMDEN, N.J., April 22. -- At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Electric Company of America, held here to-day, a resolution was adopted authorizing the Board of Directors to render the stock non-assessable. The Directors will reduce the capital stock from $25,000,000 to $3,000,000, and the par value of the shares will be reduced from $50 to $10.

THE HAGUE, April 22. -- To-day's news from Castle Loo leads to the impression that a favorable turn has occurred in Queen Wilhelmina's illness, which renders it possible that afftirs of State will soon resume their normal course. The rumors of the intention of the Government to take steps looking to the establishment of a regency will, therefore, probably not materialize.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- There is no longer any attempt to conceal the, breach between the War Department and the Committee on Military Affairs of the Senate. Gen. Hawley, Chairman of the committee, to-day introduced a bill which, like Secretary Root's bill, is "to increase the efficiency of the army."

District Attorney Jerome and Controller Grout have disagreed over the question of the payment of the bills of county detectives for expenses incurred in securing evidence of violations of the liquor and gambling laws, and the maintenance of disorderly houses.
LONDON, April 22. -- Money was fairly abundant to-day, but the market traded largely on money borrowed from the Bank of England. Discounts were unchanged.

LONDON, April 23. -- The assassination of M. Sipiaguine, says the St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times, has been followed by an event scarcely less significant -- the resignation of Gen. Vanovsky, the Minister of Education, who was appointed to that post after the murder of M. Bogoliepoff.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 22. -- Showers throughout Wisconsin late to-day brought an end to the hot weather which threatened for a time to ruin the crops in many parts of the State. This morning it was intensely hot, but before 3 P.M. there was a change in the temperature.

DULUTH, Minn., April 22. -- To-day will long be remembered by vesselmen at the head of the lakes. The high gale and scarcity of tugs practically paralyzed all boat operations. There were several accidents and many delays.

The Maritime Association of this port held its annual election of officers at the Exchange yesterday, and the ordinarily quiet formality was fraught with considerable excitement as the result of the efforts of the New York Towboat Association to prevent the re-election of Gustav Schwab of the North German Lloyd Line, whose name had been reported by the Nominating Committee as one of the six members of the Board of Directors, Mr. Schwab was defeated.

Serious charges affecting the integrity of certain politicians and citizens were made yesterday at a hearing before Mayor Low on the application of the Brauer Steamship Company to secure Pier 33, East River, as a closed pier.

Yesterday was the hottest April day since 1896. At 2 o'clock in the afternoon the thermometer registered 82 degrees and New Yorkers felt the effects, undergoing much discomfort. As morning broke there was every indication of a balmy Spring day, but shortly after noon the sun's rays became hotter and hotter, until at 2 o'clock Spring overcoats were discarded and fans were brought out.
BERLIN, April 23. -- Emperor William is showing extraordinary interest in motors in which potato alcohol is used as fuel.

ALBANY, April 23. -- Attorney General Davies announced to-night that he had notified Charles H. Knox, Charles W. Dayton, and M. Warley Platzek, the Tammany Hall Beef Trust Committee, that he had received a communication from them which stated that they had information which would prove that an agreement existed between the wholesale meat dealers of the country to keep up the price of meat.

PLYMOUTH, April 23. -- The Hamburg-American liner Deutschland, which left New York on April 17 for Plymouth, Cherbourg, and Hamburg, was sighted at 2 P.M. to-day eighteen miles south of the Scilly Islands, with her steering gear disabled. The vessel passed the Lizard at 4:10 P.M. She signaled:

The improvement of another vacant corner on Broadway is foreshadowed by a transaction which came to light yesterday. The Blodgett estate has sold its plot at the northeast corner of Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, having frontages of 102.2 feet on the former and 107 feet on the latter.

Wall Street nervousness over the Western crop outlook was relieved yesterday. Invigorating rains were reported throughout the wheat territory, and the crop disaster which crowding bear oracles have been making outcries over evaporated forthwith. Prices of stocks which had been forced down declined further during the early part of the day, but in the late trading a rally was recorded throughout the list.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The watercolor portrait of Mrs. Roosevelt and her little daughter Ethel, recently completed by Cecilia Beaux, was hung in the East Room this morning, where it will be on view for several days.

TRENTON, N.J., April 23. -- State Factory Inspector John C. Ward was told yesterday by Gov. Murphy in unmistakable terms that the factory child labor Inspectors were not doing their duty, and that there must be a material change in the methods of Mr. Ward's department.

HAMPTON, Va., April 23. -- The Board of Trustees of the Hampton Normal Institute met in annual session to-day. The selection of a site for the establishment of the $100,000 library building recently given the school by Mrs. Collis P. Huntington was made by the trustees. It was decided to keep secret for the present the location.

LONDON, April 23. -- The popular handicap, the City and Suburban, and the presence of King Edward and his suite attracted a big crowd to Epsom Downs this afternoon. The high-class field in the principal event included winners of the Two Thousand Guineas, the Derby, and the St. Leger.

COPENHAGEN, April 23. -- The Landsthing by 34 to 30 votes, to-day adopted the majority report on the treaty providing for the sale of the Danish West Indies to the United States. The treaty now goes back to the Folkething, (lower house.)

The exchange of letters by the District Attorney and the Controller has reached an acute stage. In a letter given out yesterday by Mr. Jerome he takes exception to the communication of the Controller having been made public by Mr. Grout on Tuesday before he had received it and could reply to it.
WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Representative McDermott of New Jersey to-day introduced a bill abolishing all duties upon meat and poultry imported from foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Nobody knows get what the Senate will do with the Cuban Relief bill. Senator Platt of Connecticut went about the Senate to-day exhibiting a bill which he said he thought would be the proper thing. The bill provided for a 50 per cent, tariff reduction on Cuban products and also wipes out the differential. Mr. Platt would like to see such a bill become a law.

The question "how to beat the Beef Trust" has found its solution in the banana, if the words of A.F. Spawn, which thrilled a large audience made up of the members of the Vegetarian Society at Civic Hall, 128 East Twenty-eighth Street, last night, were to be taken as final.

PATERSON, N.J., April 23. -- Striking dye helpers to-day stormed the establishments that were still running, and by force compelled a complete suspension of business in their trade. Nearly 3,500 men have now quit work. They engaged in a series of running fights with the police and plant managers, and in one of the severest clashes exchanged a volley of pistol shots with them.

BALTIMORE, April 23. -- The local market was very dull again to-day and featureless. Speculative ardor has somewhat abated since the check in bullish aggressiveness in Wall street. The street is now interesting itself more in rumors than trading. National Compositype stock is attracting attention.

The annual report of the Lake Shore Railroad for the year 1901, which was issued yesterday, gives the first authoritative statement regarding the Vanderbilt holdings of Lehigh Valley Railroad stock. It appears from this report that the Lake Shore road holds in its treasury $3,200,000 par value of the Lehigh Valley stock, or 64,000 shares, the Lehigh stock being $50 shares.

The Democrats of the Thirty-fifth Assembly District in the Borough of the Bronx, filled Zeltner's Hall, at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Seventieth Street, last night at a meeting, held nominally to commemorate the birthday of Thomas Jefferson, but really to arouse enthusiasm and "get the party into line" for the next campaign.

The Independent Democracy and the Bryan Democratic League (Chicago Platform Democrats) agreed at a conference in the Mills Building, 15 Broad Street, yesterday afternoon, to unite their political fortunes with those of the Greater New York Democracy.

The one hundred and sixteenth annual dinner of the St. George's Society of New York was held in the banquet hall of Delmonico's last night. The decorations of the banquet hall were simple, the color distinctly red from the roses in the centre-pieces in the thirty-nine tables of the guests and members of the St. George's Society.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23. -- Following up the decision of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court against Napoleon Lajoie of the Philadelphia American League Baseball Club, John I. Rogers of the Philadelphia National League Club to-day secured a temporary injunction restraining the second baseman from playing with any other organization than the Philadelphia National League Club.

The circular of the company which has undertaken the commercial development of the Marconi system does not change materially, if at all, the conviction of those who are best qualified to judge that while as an invention it may be classed as "the most beautiful thing that ever happened," as one eminent electrician has said, it has not yet reached the point of mechanical or commercial development warranting its flotation as a business proposition.

Everybody who has paid any attention to the adventures of the present Earl RUSSELL must admit that he has had an extraordinarily hard run of connubial luck. Brooding upon these things in his luxurious privacy of a first-class misdemeanant, undergoing a relatively derisory sentence for bigamy, he has ex-cogitated a project of law to prevent the like persecution of others.
MADRID, April 23. -- In the Senate to day the Minister of Marine, the Duke of Veragua, announced the intention of the Government to order several new battleships.

The gift of a million dollars by Mr. J. D. ROCKEFELLER to promote the cause of Southern education, coupled with and supplemented by the large sums previously placed in the hands of Mr. ROBERT C. OGDEN and his associates for discretionary disbursement or pledged to them, places the newly organized General Educational Board in a position to accomplish a great and permanently beneficial work in promoting the cause of education in the South.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 23. -- At the opening of the Republican State Convention in Tomlinson Hall this afternoon Senator Albert J. Beveridge delivered an eloquent address, in which he outlined the principles upon which the Republicans of Indiana will enter the next campaign. It is understood that the planks in the platform will not vary widely from the general statements made by Senator Beveridge.

COLON, April 23. -- The German steamer Heroynia, which left this port for Bocas del Toro several days ago with reinforcements of Government troops on board, returned here this morning and announced that Bocas del Toro, which was captured by the insurgents, was again in possession of the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23. -- The ability to hit when hits were needed gave the Philadelphia baseball team another victory over Brooklyn to-day. The fielding of the visitors was ragged, while the local players played cleanly throughout. Score:

CINCINNATI, April 23. -- About fifty of the leading manufacturers in the United States of pickles, sauerkraut, tomato catsup, preserves, mince meat, , have met here and permanently organized a National association that was temporarily formed about six months ago. The National Association of Manufacturers of Food Products is the name of the organization.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 23. -- Miss Charlotte Storer Shepherd, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Rubens Shepherd, was married at 4 o'clock this afternoon to Marshall Stearns, a New York lawyer and a graduate of Harvard, class of '99. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Rockwell Harmon Potter at the Centre Congregational Church.
LONDON, April 23. -- Money was in keen demand to-day. Discounts were maintained.

Graham C. Voorhis, Superintendent of Sub-Station S of the General Post Office, at Broadway and Howard Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon in a Broadway restaurant by Post Office Inspectors Jacobs and Meyer on the charge of having abstracted money from letters sent through the mails.

The good fortune of the Queens County Jockey Club in the matter of weather passed its eighth day at the Aqueduct race track yesterday without a break in the conditions that have favored the club since the opening of the meeting.

The Manhattan College baseball team added another victory to its goodly list to-day by easily defeating the Rutgers College nine by the score of 7 to 3. At no stage of the play was the game in doubt, as Callahan and McPhlllips always had the upper hand of their opponents. The score:

A second pastor has within a few years given up to the noise which interrupts the services of the Bedford Baptist Church, at Bergen Street and Rogers Avenue. The last to leave the church is the Rev. William M. Tinker, who is young and energetic, but cannot make himself heard frequently, because of the noise of the trolley cars just outside the door of the church.

BALTIMORE, April 23. -- The Merchants' Trust Company of New York entered into an agreement here to-day by which it became the purchaser of the following Southern companies: Virginia Electrical Railway and Development Company, capital $1,000,000; Richmond Traction Company, capital $1,000,000; West Hampton Park Railway Company, capital $300,000.

A report of an expert accountant, Duncan MacInnes, under Controller Grout, as to the distribution to the boroughs of appropriations made by the Board of Estimate for the City Government for the year ended Dec. 31, 1901, was made public yesterday.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 23. -- After having been, in speeches of introduction made to-day, twice nominated for the Presidency in 1904, Gov. B.B. Odell of New York made this very pointed and positive statement before a large assemblage:

We presume that Controller GROUT is perfectly conscientious in his hesitation to accept the conclusion of the Corporation Counsel as to the propriety of the employment of money by the District Attorney in his vice investigations, and that in refusing to pay the bills for disbursements by the county detectives employed in discovering excise violations in Capt. FOODY'S precinct he obeys his own convictions of duty.

Mr. PIERPONT MORGAN'S steamship consolidation has thrown some of the London newspapers into a fright which appears to be as genuine as it is causeless. The Daily Chronicle looks upon the consolidation as a menace to the national position. A truer sense of proportion would have saved our London contemporary from falling a victim to this amusing exaggeration and from the apprehension that "the supremacy of the British mercantile marine is practically annihilated."

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The War Department to-day made public the telegraphic cable correspondence which has taken place up to date respecting the Moros outbreak in Mindanao. The important feature of the correspondence is a dispatch showing that Gen. Davis's expendition is not arbitrarily stopped, but that Gen. Chaffee is allowed to exercise his discretion.

The dislike of the average anti-imperialist for Senator BEVERIDGE is deep and well founded. Populists and Bryanites also loathe him, and with good reason. The Indiana Senator knows and practices more ways of making himself offensive to anti-imperialists and Bryanites than any other American now in public life.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Senator H.D. Money of Mississippi had an altercation with a conductor on a street car this morning, which resulted in the Senator's receiving two blows from the conductor and the conductor being cut in the right hand with a knife.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 24 -- Richard Mansfield, now in Pittsburg, intends to give next season the grandest revival of the Shakespearean drama Americans have seen since Booth and Barrett. To-day Mr. Mansfield announced that beginning in Chicago about October, he will produce nothing but plays written by the Bard of Avon.

ATHENS, Ga., April 24 -- In the chapel of the University of Georgia welcome was given to-night to Robert C. Ogden and his party of philanthropists by an assemblage composed of prominent educators from all parts of the South, jurists, business men, and students who came here to be present at the first session of the fifth annual conference for the development of education in the South.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 24 -- As the result of two runaway accidents which were caused by J.H. Proctor's big white automobile the wrecks of two wagons littered Second Street in the fashionable cottage section this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Secretary of the Navy and Mrs. Long, who will leave Washington, next week on the retirement of the Secretary from his present position, entertained at their last Cabinet dinner this evening when the President and Mrs. Roosevelt were their guests aboard the Dolphin, now anchored at the Navy Yard.
John D. Rockefeller, Jr., has provided for the up-town branch of the Legal Aid Society two rooms at 741 Tenth Avenue, and has promised $700 a year to maintain the rooms.

LONDON, April 25 -- The forcible detention in South Africa of Albert Cartwright, who, while editor of The South African News, charged Lord Kitchener with ordering his officers to shoot all prisoners, formed the subject of a heated debate in the House of Commons last evening.

BAYONNE, N.J., April 24 -- The clubhouse recently erected by the Bayonne City Democratic Club, of which Mayor Egbert Seymour is President, was opened this evening. Hosts of prominent Democrats from various parts of Hudson County and adjacent counties of New Jersey and New York were guests.
Nine members of the crew of the whaling bark Kathleen of New Bedford reached this port yesterday with a wonderful story of wreck, hardship, and rescue.

Unless Cornell retreats from its present position in regard to the junior Varsity crew race, that contest on May 30 on the Schuylkill River, at Philadelphia, is likely to have only Columbia and Pennsylvania as competitors.

LONDON, April 25 -- A St. Petersburg dispatch printed in a Slav news sheet published in Vienna is quoted toy the co-respondent of The Times in the Austrian capital. The dispatch says serious symptoms of revolutionary agitation have appeared both in the ranks and among the officers of the Russian army Students, especially women, are actively promoting the revolutionary propaganda among the troops.

with Mathewson pitching and the Boston players hitting opportunely, the game between the Boston and New York baseball representatives at the Polo Grounds yesterday was won by the New Englanders by a score of 8 to 4. Shortstop Long, for the visitors, was wonderfully successful, as he accepted thirteen chances without the slightest mistake.
Providing that certain clerical defects in naturalization cases in territorial courts that have gone out of existence may be remedied on proper hearing.

Entire sets of buttons in the finest smoked pearl with diamond centres are in favor for men. One of these sets has in the centre of each button a tiny square of gold in which the diamond is set. The buttons include six for the vest, a pair of cuff links -- four more buttons -- and three smaller buttons for the shirt.

LONDON, April 25 -- In the House of Commons yesterday the Parliamentary Secretary to the Admiralty, Hugh O. Arnold-Forster, in reply to a question, said the Admiralty was considering the whole matter of ship subsidies with a view to defining its rights in the event of contingencies arising such as the suggested shipping combine.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The situation to-day in the Senate with reference to the Cuban relief bill was sized up pretty well by a Democratic Senator, who said:

The Executive Committee of the National League of Professional Baseball Clubs met at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night for the purpose of taking action on the recent decision handed down by the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, as well as passing upon other matters of import in connection with the League.

The Greenpoint section of Brooklyn was violently shaken early yesterday morning by an explosion which blew up the tugboat John Anson, belonging to Capt. William Reichert, the skipper, killed John Donnelly, a fireman on the vessel, and injured James Cunningham, also a fireman; John Kennedy, the cook, and Andrew Moran, a watchman.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- It is impossible to-night to learn anything of consequence about the evidence upon which the Attorney General based his determination to move against the Beef Trust. What companies are to be made defendants in the proceeding about to be instituted in the Federal Court can only be surmised: no information on this point is vouchsafed by the Attorney General.

The circular giving the details of the exchange of preferred stock for bonds of the United States Steel Corporation were mailed to stockholders late last night, but the text of the circulars were carefully guarded. According to the statement of one who claims to have seen them, the circulars give some idea of what the company proposes to do and of its prospects.

BALTIMORE, April 24 -- There is now a strong probability of the passage of the ordinance acpepting the bid of the Fuller Syndicate for the city's interest in the Western Maryland Railroad, provided the syndicate will increase its bid from $8,751,370.45 to $10,001,000, the amount which the Reading Railroad offers.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Writing under date of Feb. 14 from Niu-Chwang, Consul Henry B. Miller discusses the timber market in China, predicting that there will be an extensive and permanent demand there for Pacific Coast lumber. He says:
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 24 -- The Republican State Convention to-day nominated the following ticket:

Throughout yesterday market quotations were strong, many substantial advances being scored. Commission house buying was one of the conspicuous features of the day. There was incidentally a free covering of shorts, though the short interest still stays extended.

Archbishop Michael Augustine Corrigan, head of this diocese of the Roman Catholic Church, is ill with pneumonia at the Archiepiscopal residence, in Madison Avenue, in the rear of St. Patrick's Cathedral, and it was admitted at midnight that his condition is such as to cause grave apprehension. The fact of his severe illness became known to the world outside at 2:30 P.M.

LONDON, April 25 -- Cabling from Amsterdam, a correspondent of The Daily Mail says he is assured that the Queen's condition gives no cause for alarm. A rumor that peritonitis has supervened is not confirmed.

The action of the National Association of Manufacturers at its Indianapolis meeting, relative to the bill favorably reported by the House Committee on Coinage, Weights, and Measures, making the metric system the legal standard in the United States, will meet with approval of all who are not indifferent to the vast public inconvenience and injury which would result from such an enactment.

That is evidently a serious and threatening state of things which confronts us in Mindanao. During all our troubles in Luzon we have had the satisfaction of knowing that our relations with the inhabitants of the great southern island were peaceable and friendly. The early "pacification" of Mindanao was at the time attributed to the skill of Gen. BATES, our pioneer in the island.

Early man didn't mind a heap of carrion close beside the entrance to his cave. Anthropologists find indications of the kitchen midden or heap of refuse at the very door of his primitive dwelling His nose, like the rest of him, was primitive. He was not made the least uncomfortable by odors that no civilized person now willingly endures.

Mayor Low attended the meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday and succeeded in infusing unusual vigor into the proceedings, the most important action resulting in a decided impetus to the advancement of rapid transit plans for the Borough of the Bronx, though the bridge problem and the need of hurrying certain portions of the work also received their due share of attention.

County detectives attached to the staff of the District Attorney started last night to raid poolrooms and policy shops, in the precinct of Capt. Vredenburgh, who recently offered to bet $500 that there were no disorderly houses, poolrooms, or policy shops anywhere near the Oak Street Police Station.

-- One of the French papers devoted to the exploitation of automobiles and their users exultantly declares that the horse is fast disappearing from the large cities of Europe. The number of horses in Paris is said to have decreased about 6 per cent, in the last year, in London 10 per cent., and similar statistics come from Berlin, Vienna, and St. Petersburg.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 24 -- The torpedo boat destroyer Hopkins was launched at the yards of the Harlan Hollingsworth Company in this city this afternoon. Mrs. Alice Gould Hawes of Washington, D.C., named the vessel.

Some revelations made by the efforts of the Committee on Elections of the House of Representatives to determine whether JOHN J. LENTZ or EMMETT TOMPKINS was elected in 1900 from the Columbus district of Ohio, possess a certain interest as illustrative of the strenuousness of politics in the Buckeye State.

The "opera comique" which Mr. Hammerstein presented at his Victoria Theatre last night was a burlesque. It was Herve's "Le Petit Faust," nominated a comic opera on the bill, but simply and entirely a burlesque. It is so long since a real burlesque has been seen in New York that even a poor performance of one is delightful.
JOHNSTOWN, N.Y., April. 24 -- At the Assembly District Convention for the Counties of Fulton and Hamilton, held in this, city, to-day, Clarence W. Smith was renominated for Assemblyman.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some time ago I wrote you a note to the effect that the Englishman's day as star tourist had passed and that the Yankee had taken his place. Now the world knows very well the reputation of the touring Englishman -- his superciliousness and domineering ways.

PATERSON, N.J., April 24 -- It was announced at the meeting of striking silk dyers' helpers at Riverside to-day that the Gautschy Dyeing Company had signed the scale. Thirty men from that shop were on strike and it was unanimously voted to permit them to return to work at 1 o'clock this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Before the last election the swiftest automobiles could not take the candidates for public office around quick enough to tell the dear voters how much those patriots loved them, how industrious, honest, and good they would be if elected, and how nothing on earth could deviate them from their straight path of duty.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 24 -- Capitalists, most of whom live in Milwaukee and Chicago, have organized a company to be known as the Del Norte Lumber Company of Eau Claire, Wis., capitalized at $1,500,000. Officers elected are: President -- N.C. Foster, Fairchild; Vice President -- J.H. Stout, Menominee; Secretary -- John S Owen, Eau Claire; Treasurer -- William Bigelow, Milwaukee.

DENVER, Col., April 24 -- A statement which General Frederick Funston is credited with having dictated, concerning the order of President Roosevelt, directing him to cease discussion of the Philippine question, appears in the Republican to-day, in part Gen. Funston says:

The Directors of the National City Bank of New York yesterday unanimously recommended to its shareholders that the capital stock of the bank should be increased from $10,000,000 to $25,000,000 by the issuance of 130,000 additional shares of stock.

The Coroner's office was notified by the authorities of the J. Hood Wright Hospital last evening that Michael Lauch, fifty-six years old, of 742 Columbus Avenue, died at that institution at 7:45 P.M. as the result of morphine taken with suicidal intent. The slip is brief, and beyond notifying the Coroner gives no other information.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., April 24 -- During the past forty-eight hours the furious sweep of forest fires in the central section of the State has caused devastation to a vast amount of property and in two cases the loss of life is attributed to the fire. From Sinnemahoning come meagre details of the fate that befell two men and the escape of four others.
LONDON, April 24 -- The demand for money was maintained to-day. Discounts were firm, owing to the scarcity of money and the uncertainty as to the future.

The American Railway Association, which has been meeting in this city for two days, voted yesterday, after three hours' discussion, to accept the report of the Committee on Car Service recommending the adoption of the per-diem system, to take the place of the present mileage system, of charging for the use of freight cars of one railroad company by another railroad.

William E. McFadden, the Collector of Assessments and Arrears, sent a communication to Controller Grout yesterday regarding the collection of assessments and arrears so far this year, in which he says:

BOSTON, April 24 -- The money market shows little change. If anything it is working toward easier conditions and going rates' show a very general shading to the right borrowers, and on the best of collateral. Clearing House rate, 3 per cent. New York funds par; call loans, 3 1/2@4; time money, 4@41/2; Clearing House exchanges, $23,379,446; balances, $1,675,442.

The first disqualification of the New York racing season contributed a sensational finish to a most unsatisfactory afternoon's racing at the Aqueduct track yesterday, for, in spite of the ninth consecutive day of pleasant weather, a fast track, and close contests, the defeat of five popular favorites clouded the enthusiasm of the betting people, who practically make up the attendance at the Queens County course.
BANGOR, April 24 -- Many of the Bar Harbor cottages have already been taken and a successful season is assured. Among the houses thus far leased are the following:

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The funeral of Frank R. Stockton, the author, who died in Washington last Sunday, took place to-day from the home of his sister in this city. Services were held in St. Philip's Episcopal Church. Hundreds who had known Mr. Stockton in life viewed the body.

There is considerable mystery in the death of a man whom the police identified as Patrick Mulcahey, forty-two years of age, 344 East Seventy-fourth Street, who was found in the yard of 300 East Seventyfourth Street at midnight Wednesday, suffering from injuries from which he died in the Presbyterian Hospital a few hours later.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Philippine Government bill was laid before the Senate, Mr. Carmack, (Tenn.), a member of the Philippines Committee, addressed the Senate in opposition to the measure.

EAST LIVERPOOL, April 25 -- A combination of flint spar and clay manufacturers has just been effected in this city by William S. Hancock, Barker Gummere, Jr., and Hugh H. Hamil, of Trenton, which will control the market of the country for these materials under the name of Golding Sons and Company, of this city.

G.P. PUTNAM'S SONS have made arrangements with Christine Terhune Herrick vice to Produce a book giving advice to housekeepers of small incomes. The book, which has no title as yet, "owes the basic idea of the suggestion to James L. Ford, in which they spoke of some of the books that had never been written."

The long-expected, circular to the stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation was made public yesterday. While it consists of more than five printed pages, it does not contain much additional information of detaiis of the proposed exchange of preferred stock for bonds. The circular is made up mostly of arguments and explanations in a general way to justify to the stockholders the proposed increase in capitalization by the issue of $50,000,000 additional bonds.

A writer in The Providence Journal, discussing a recent opinion that Mrs. Oliphant did not rise to the higher level of Charlotte Bronte and George Eliot and that her work is destined to oblivion, says, by way of protest:

S. Osgood Pell Co. have sold for Joseph Hamershlag to the City Real Property Investing Company the plot on the south side of Eighty-ninth Street, 102.2 feet east of Fifth Avenue. 179 by 100.8, together with an abutting plot on the north Bide of Eighty-eighth Street, 75.5 by 100.8.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 24 -- A representative of The Associated Press who has just returned from Helsingfors interviewed the patriotic leaders and others there. They declared that the Government was distorting every report of the disorders in Finland, with the view, in the near future, of proclaiming martial law.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Roosevelt, although not hopeful that Congress will pass a canal bill at this session, is doing all he can to encourage those Senators who desire that action on the pending measure shall not go over to December. At the Cabinet meeting to-day he made known his intention to submit at once to Congress the propositions made by the Nicaraguan and Colombian Governments.

B.D. Caldwell and E.E. Loomis were yesterday elected Vice Presidents of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad at a meeting of the Board of Managers, Mr. Loomis will be in charge of the coal department and Mr. Caldwell will have charge of the traffic department. The Lackawanna Railroad has had no Vice Presidents for some time.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Nobody undertakes even to guess how long the Philippines Civil Government bill will be before the Senate. Present indications are that debate on the bill will be more extended than that which took place on the Philippines Revenue bill. "Three or four weeks" is the usual answer when a Senator is asked how long he thinks the pending measure will wait before it gets to the voting stage.

This is a story of London society life, and in it are presented many types of character, some skillfully depicted, although the canvas is too crowded for great excellence to prevail. The best-drawn figure is that of the heroine herself. Charlotte is one of those women possessed of great beauty and exceptional magnetism, who subjugate, more or less, all specimens of masculinity upon whom they try their spells.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 25 -- The local market continues to be puzzled over the movement in Seaboard issues. The centre of trading interest in the issues seems to be fast affixing itself to the New York curb, so much so, in fact, as to make the local market a mere reflection of the ups and downs there.

SIR WALTER BESANT could not anticipate an editor's approach to his "Autobiography" of a less assuring character than that contrived by Mr. Sprigge. It would have been much better if the matter contained in Mr. Sprigge's "prefatory note" had been transferred to the end of the book. Then we should have come at once face to face with Sir Walter and made up our own minds as to the qualities and deficiencies of his work.

BOSTON, Mass., April 25 -- The money market is still working easier, and, as loanable funds are showing a steady accumulation, the banks are showing an increased inclination to shade rates. Business is still very dull and rates for call loans to the best borrowers have now worked off to 3 1/2 per cent.

The business transacted in the outside market yesterday was the largest since last Spring, but it was one stock that supplied nearly all of the day's trading. General Carriage attracted universal attention, and the trading in it was at times so wild that it very materially interfered with business in other stocks.

Following is a statement of books which have sold best in regular book and department stores in New York, Philadelphia, Boston, Cincinnati, Chicago, Baltimore, Washington, St. Louis, and San Francisco between March 24 and April 24 of this year. The statement is based on reports received from the regular correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in those cities, personal inquiries having been made for the information sent to us.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The longer I live in America the more convinced I am how profound an aversion even the lovers of foreign literature in this country seem to feel to the study of the poets of the earlier centuries, and how ready they are to discard as old rubbish all those who lived in Germany before the era of Schiller and Goethe.

John F. Lovejoy, Howard W. Coates, and Frank Hardy comprising the Regatta Committee of the Larchmont Yacht Club, have announced the racing fixtures for the coming season. The Spring regatta, open to all classes, will be sailed on Saturday, June 21. The annual regatta will be held, as usual, on July 4, and it will be open to all classes, with a special competition of the 93-foot class of schooners for the Colt Cup.

With the Meadow Brook Hunt and a number of parties and the opening of the golf club at Morristown for the season, there will be quite a number of suburban events for the week end. The usual house parties will be given.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

OMAHA, Neb., April 25 -- J.A.R. Elliott won from W.R. Crosby of O'Fallon, Ill., the 100 live-bird race, by a score- of 97 to 91, and thus retains the cast iron medal title of championship wine shot of the world. Elliot clearly outclassed Crosby throughout the match, making several sensational shots, and each of the birds he lost fell dead outside of bounds.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Thursday evening at the regular monthly meeting of the Philobiblon Club, Dr. George McClellan read a paper on "The Wanderings of a Player's Skull," the somewhat gruesome subject of his talk being the relic of George Frederick Cooke, the English actor.

Fourteen hundred thousand shares traded in and quotations almost uniformly higher -- some advances being several points apiece -- represented Stock Exchange business yesterday. Two stocks passed the hundred-thousand-share mark -- Union Pacific, which rose between 1 and 2 points on transactions of 105,000 shares and Southern Railway common, whose advance of a point and more was brought about in recorded sales approximating 205,000 shares.

The department of comparative literature at Columbia University, of which George Edward Woodberry is professor, has always made it a rule that all of the publications of its officers and students shall be not only distinct contributions to knowledge, but also, and what is much rarer in university-fostered volumes, readable books.

Ashley W. Cole, Chairman of the Board of State Railroad Commissioners, which has been engaged during the past few days in examining into the condition, affecting the City Hall station of the Manhattan Elevated Railway, with a view to relieving the confusion which exists there in the "rush" hours, gave out the following statement yesterday:

As an authority on Russian and the other Slavonic languages, Mr. Morfill is unquestioned, and his familiarity with that immense storehouse of facts open only to the Student who knows these languages, must give weight to his "Story of Russia" in Putnam's Sons "Story of the Nations" series, and to his "History of Russia from Peter the Great to Nicholas II.," just published.

LONDON, April 25 -- There is already much talk here about Lucas Malet's new novel, which will appear in the Autumn. The concensus of opinion is that it must equal or surpass "Sir Richard Calmady" in ingenuity and strength in order to satisfy the eager expectations of her readers, whose ranks in the last twelve months have been greatly enlarged.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- The general rain throughout the West and Northwest caused a drain in the grain market. Wheat opened 1/2 to 1 5/8 cents lower than the closing price yesterday on the reports of a heavy downfall in Nebraska. Missouri, and Illinois. Corn went down 3/4 to 2 1/8 cents.

The recent passing of the control of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad into the hands of men who have it in their power to establish a "community of interest" between it and the Southern Railway, prompts The Louisville Courier-Journal to speak contemptuously of the assurance of President SPENCER that no consolidation of the two systems is contemplated or will be made, now or at any future time.
FRANK R. STOCKTON is dead, and his countrymen mourn as they rarely do for any man.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- In the House to-day Mr. Cochran (Mo.) made a speech on the universal spread of trusts and combines in this country and the necessity for curbing them. He declared that corporation lobbies were Republican in Republican States and Democratic in Democratic States.

MANNING, S.C., April 25 -- Senator B.K. Tillman to-day addressed a crowd of 1,500 people here. The editor of the Clarendon County newspaper, Louis A. Appelt, formerly an enthusiastic follower of Tillman, but more recently an ardent advocate of "Commercial Democracy " and supporter of Senator McLaurin, had for several months made charges against Senator Tillman, claiming that he had received rebates from great whisky firms dealing with the South Carolina dispensary.

The vigorous part taken by Mayor Low at the meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission on Thursday will probably result in important advantages to the city. He spoke to the point and gave it to be understood that he will not be a party to any easy-going neglect of matters which are of exigent importance and which depend for their satisfactory solution largely if not exclusively upon the initiative of this commission.

THE Sub-Dean of King Edward VIL's Chapel Royal, Edgar Sheppard, D.D., has prepared a superbly illustrated chronicle of a palace closely connected with the history of the Tudor and Stuart Kings -- the old Pulace of Whitehall, noteworthy alike for its antiquity and historical associations.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 25 -- The Cleveland and Sandusky Brewing Company yesterday secured control of the Schlather Brewing Company at a consideration, it is said, of $1,500,000. This purchase gives practically a clear field to the Cleveland and Sandusky Brewing Company in this city and vicinity for the brewing and sale of beer.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 25 -- There was filed with the County Register to-day a mortgage given by the Westchester Traction Company to the New York Security and Trust Company for $1,500,000. The mortgage is given to secure bonds to the same amount, and covers all the trolley lines of the company in Westchester County.

Assignments of officers of the Artillery Corps recently promoted: Col. James B. Burbank, to the Coast Artillery. Lieut. Col. Richard P. Strong, to the Coast Artillery. Lieut. Col. Strong is relieved from duty as Assistant Adjutant General. TRANSFERS. In the Artillery Corps, Capt. Robert E. Wyllie, from the One Hundred and Eighth Company to the Forty-third Company, Coast Artillery.

READERS Will find printed below lists of the contents of the principal American magazines for May. The lists are restricted to periodicals which appear once a month, and, while the contents are not absolutely complete, the omissions relate mainly to regular and familiar departments and some of the minor contributions.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- The Readings and Consolidated Lake Superiors were the leading issues in the local market today. There was a better general tone all over the list, and the range of trading was broader than at any previous time this week. Conspicuous gains were made by Electric Storage Battery, Pennsylvania Steel preferred, and Lehigh Navigation.

PATERSON, N.J., April 25 -- The strike of the silk dyers' helpers, which began on Wednesday and immediately developed violence, which was continued on Thursday, has now apparently settled down to a waiting fight between the men and their employers.

President Roosevelt has promised to come to the jubilee celebration of the centennial of Presbyterian home mission effort, and will speak at a mass meeting to be held in Carnegie Hall, Tuesday evening, May 20. This meeting will be the culmination of the home mission celebration, which will be opened on the Sunday preceding with a home mission, service in every Presbyterian church in New York.

PARIS, April 25 -- The following is the list of the members of the French Mission to the unveiling of the Rochambeau Monument at Washington on May 24, as communicated to United States Ambassador Porter to-day:

LONDON, April 19 -- The Ancestor, the new review, has made its appearance. It is very large five shillings' worth, at least in point of quantity and the first number is certainly interesting, both to those who have and those who have not ancestors.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- A romance which began a year ago on the Overland Limited Express in California ended last evening in a marriage in the First Presbyterian Church. The father of the bride, who was at the Auditorium Annex, knew nothing of he affair.

JOPLIN, Mo., April 25. -- Joplin was visited to-day by the most destructive storm in its history, during which at least three persons were killed outright, six fatally injured, a score or more seriously hurt, and $300,000 worth of property was destroyed.

Rumors of impending large gifts to Columbia University have been going the rounds of late, but so indefinite were they that neither scholarships, land, nor money was specified. When asked last week about these rumors, President Nicholas Murray, Butler said that if the university were to receive any gifts, large or small, the announcement would be made at Commencement, which lakes place during the last week in June.
LONDON, April 25 -- Money was much wanted to-day in connection with the settlement, and supplies were scarce, which hardened discounts.

LONDON, April 26 -- Further questions in the House of Commons yesterday on the subject of the shipping combine elicited information showing that the Government is taking steps to cope with the situation, which is evidently officially considered detrimental to Great Britain.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Chicago packers place themselves on record as welcoming the coming investigation of what the Federal Government insists is a combine in restraint of trade. They are awaiting developments, and are apparently not disturbed by the information from Washington to the effect that a representative of the Department of Justice is on his way to Chicago to prosecute them on orders from Attorney General Knox.

"Who reads an English took novel?" in effect inquires Col. G.B.M. Harvey, if he be correctly reported in a cable dispatch to The Chicago Record-Herald. And this not at all by way of repartee to the fine old crusty British sneer about American literature, but merely as the judgment of a publisher looking with eagerness for what will pay him to publish or republish.

SYRACUSE, April 25 -- Syracuse University won the baseball game with Columbia to-day rather easily by a score of 12 to 4. Poor fielding marked the work of each team. Moore, however, pitched a better game than Tilt of Columbia, who was hit safely fourteen times.

Of course, the bill which Gen. HAWLEY has introduced into the Senate, not, be it noted, in his capacity of Chairman or member of the Military Committee, was not meant to be enacted. It is not to be discussed as a serious project of law. If it were one might point out that, so far from settling the chronic differences between "Headquarters" and "The Department," it greatly aggravates and embitters them.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Senator Her- nandez D. Money of Mississippi to-day was placed in custody on information sworn out by Orpha D. Shaner, the street-car conductor, who ejected the Senator from his car yesterday. The information charges the Senator with assaulting the conductor during the disturbance, and the conductor produced a witness who corroborated his version of the story.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 25 -- Mr. Henry Redmond of New York has rented of Mrs. L.M. Sargent her cottage on Kay Street and Rhode Island Avenue for the Summer. Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Thayer of Boston are guests of Mr and Mrs. Louis L. Lorillard at Whitehall.

TRENTON, April 25 -- The Sea Girt camp grounds and rifle range, where the National Rifle Association hold their annual shooting contest, are to be greatly improved, and when the improvements are all made it will be the finest range in the world, it is declared. The work will be completed in time for the annual camp and for the rifle shooting season and the meeting of the National Rifle Association.

When the terms of CECIL, RHODES'S benefaction were made known the comment upon them of the Dean of Christ Church, at Oxford, was peculiar. He said that a frugal youth might perhaps manage to get on at Oxford during term time on three hundred sterling a year, but he did not see what the poor fellow was to do during vacation.

ON April 21-24 Bangs Co. sold the principal portion of the collection of early English Prose and poetry formed by Marshall Clifford Lefferts of this city. Some of the best books had been previously disposed of privately, and this fact being well known made some parts of the sale somewhat uninteresting, notably in the Milton section.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 25 -- The Sage College Dramatic Association of Cornell announces that during June of this year an open-air performance of Tennyson's "Foresters" will be given. About twenty-five women will take part.

How full of the fragrance of May is this lesson! The seed which we recently saw scattered by the wind in Jerusalem, we now see springing up not only in Jewish soil but in Gentile soil as well. And it is not only springing up. but it is beginning to bud and blossom and bear fruit all through the land, even to "Phenice, and Cyprus, and Antioch."

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Mrs. Roosevelt issued cards to-day for a garden party next Tuesday afternoon from 4 to 0 o'clock, when she will receive 500 guests in the grounds south of the "White House. The Marine Band will play during the afternoon, and light refreshments will be served on the lawn.

It is profoundly interesting when so large a part of physical science is turned directly to account in inventions and discoveries that pay so well from an economic standpoint, to take up such a book as Dr. Charles E. Beecher's "Studies in Evolution." Physical science has barely escaped deification in a selfish material age that worships creature comforts and modern improvements.

The Executive Committee of the Road Drivers' Association held a meeting last night at the Hotel Rossmore, with President John F. Cockerill in the chair. The Speedway Day Committees made favorable reports.

ONE of the features of the dinner which the alumni of Columbia University gave last Saturday evening at Sherry's after the installation of Nicholas Murray Butler as President of the university was an address by Dr. Albert Shaw, editor of The Review of Reviews, on the subject of "Letters."

An incident that created intense excitement occurred during the performance of Buffalo Bill's Wild West at the Madison Square Garden last night in the course of the military musical drill. In this act some fifty horsemen take part.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Omnibus Public Building bill, which will be reported to the House to-morrow, carries a total of about $17,000,000, and will be considered in the House next Monday or Tuesday.

LONDON, April 26 -- In an editorial article to-clay on the Atlantic shipping combination The Times says the objection to the unification for business purposes by an American house of great groups of steam tonnage, largely British is principally sentimental. The regret expressed is natural, but properly speaking, it should have been regret for the cause, not the effect.

Walter Pater, the gracious and subtle interpreter of Greek and Latin thought, illustrated by the bland pencil of Raphael, is a combination not to be ignored wherever met. The present volume consists of Mr. Pater's translation of the beautiful tale of Cupid and Psyche as Apulelus has told it, with reproductions of the frescoes and studies for frescoes made by Raphael in illustration of the story.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Senate Committee on Cuba to-day decided to institute an investigation into the charge that the greater part of the present crop of Cuban sugar is held by the Sugar Trust of this country, as directed by the resolution introduced in the Senate by Mr. Teller on the 10th inst.

The career of the drum and trumpet style of novel is one of fluctuations. We have lately had the swelling and apparent culmination of one of the mightiest waves in this rising and falling career. Never were so many writers engaged in penning novels of incident. Never was the field of polite fiction so near the domain of the dime novel.

The annual ladies' day at the Grolier Club was observed in customary fashion on Friday, the 18th of April. The attractive little clubhouse was crowded by the women friends of the members, for whom they had provided an excellent programme. Music was furnished by Josephine Sullivan, harpist, and Lillian Littlehales, cellist, who played both before and after the address; after which the clubhouse was thrown open for inspection and ten was served.

LOUISVILLE, April 25 -- Beyond making a denial. Dr. W. Godfrey Hunter, United States Minister to Guatemala, who arrived in Louisville several days ago, refuses to discuss Mrs. Barrios's charges. He is, however, preparing a statement for publication concerning his administrtion of the office of Minister to Guatemala.

According to the bulletin issued at 10:15 o'clock last night, Archbishop Corrigan passed a very comfortable day. His malady is diagnosed as a true case of acute pneumonia, and his condition is still critical. The crisis will not arrive for some four or five days, and until that time it will be impossible to say what the outcome is likely to be.

New Edition of the Works of John Fiske. An edition de luxe of John Fiske's works is on the press of Houghton, Mifflin Co., printed entirely from new plates. The edition will comprise his historical, philosophical, religious, and scientific writings, together with a large collection of shorter essays, speeches,

LONDON, April 26 -- The papers this morning again give the first place to the Atlantic shipping combination, publishing all kinds of statements, counter-statements, interviews, opinions of prominent men, and alarmist editorial articles on the political bearings of the combine.

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 25 -- The case of Berry Howard, on trial as the alleged principal in the Goebel assassination, was given to the Jury at 10:05 o'clock. At 12:10 the jury brought in a verdict of not guilty.
