The edition will comprise his historical, philosophical, religious, and scientific writings, together with a large collection of shorter essays, speeches,

LONDON, April 26 -- The papers this morning again give the first place to the Atlantic shipping combination, publishing all kinds of statements, counter-statements, interviews, opinions of prominent men, and alarmist editorial articles on the political bearings of the combine.

Attorney General KNOX, has gone to work in the right way to ascertain whether there is or is not a Beef Trust. A writ of injunction will not operate against a phantom, a myth, or a fabulous monster. In the nature of things the process server and the writ would come back, both unsatisfied.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- In the Senate to-day Mr. McCumber, (N.D.,) Chairman of the Committee on Manufactures, addressed the Senate on the bill "to prevent the adulteration, misbranding, and imitations of food beverages, candies, drugs, and condiments in the District of Columbia and the Territories and for regulating inter-State commerce therein."

In this strenuous commercial period a recent mad chase after a copy of a book almost 300 years old seems worth narrating. Prof. Felix E. Schellinsr of the University of Pennsylvania on Thursday of last week was in urgent need of a copy of the first edition of "Eastward Ho!" a play written by Ben Jonson in collaboration with two other writers.

BOSTON, April 24 -- Sir Walter Besant's novel, Du Maurier's pictures, and Mr. Hichens's "The Green Carnation" have hitherto been the only trustworthy and easily accessible guides to the character of Oscar Wilde, for between affectation and "ghosts" there was no certainty as to the authorship of the verses, novels, and plays published under his name, or as to their honesty of expression.

SHE has revived the art, wellnigh lost in these days, of the essayist. There is no province of the essayist that she has not touched, and there is nothing which she has touched that she has not adorned. Her wisdom is illuminated by her wit, and her wit is controlled by her wisdom."

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 25 -- The case of Berry Howard, on trial as the alleged principal in the Goebel assassination, was given to the Jury at 10:05 o'clock. At 12:10 the jury brought in a verdict of not guilty.

TECHNICAL, dry, and altogether uninteresting seems the career of the handwriting expert when on the stand in a murder trial. But there is another story to the Work of the professor of pothooks. From start to finish it is an interesting chapter of human ingenuity and eunning, of tragedy and comedy, involving as it does many instances of strange cases about which the public never hears.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Joseph Jefferson will begin his annual engagement of one week at the Harlem Opera House to-morrow evening. Mr. Jefferson is reported to be in excellent health. Beyond that little remains to be said at this time of an actor whose place is unique in the estimation of American playgoers. Mr. Jefferson's offering's are too familiar to require any extended comment.

VIENNA, April 26 -- A dispatch to the Allgemeine Zeitung, from St. Petersburg, published to-day announces that serious riots of strikers have taken place at Moscow, and that the military dispersed the rioters with much bloodshed. One report says that fifty persons were killed or wounded.

BOSTON, April 26 -- That the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is about to pass into the joint control of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central is the general belief here, and it is thought that buying for this object is the cause of the recent great advance in the stock.

While driving his $9,000 French gasoline automobile yesterday evening Royal Phelps Carroll, the well-known clubman and yachtsman, ran over, at Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, Felix Weill, eleven years old, of 14 East One Hundred and Twentieth Street, and in consequence spent a rather unpleasant hour in the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Police Station.

The expense incident to the feeding of the fish amphibians, , in the New York Aquarium are again on the increase. This fact is due to the Spring awakening of the creatures. Every year during the cold months all the fresh-water fish lose their appetite. The catfish, mud puppies, and hellbenders go to the bottom of their tanks, drop off to sleep, and refuse to wake up for about six months.

Brooklyn's tenth annual Horse Show was concluded last night after what was practically an all-day session, beginning at 1 o'clock in the afternoon and lasting until midnight, except for an intermission at dinner time. Twenty classes were judged in the afternoon and evening.

Cologne, that home of perfumes and the reverse, is proud of her thoroughly Germanic past. As the town beyond all others associated with dear old Father Rhine, and all his traditions of Nicker and Nibelungen, Cologne the superb has rather prided herself on spelling her name Koln.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, April 26 -- The financial market was rather slack most of the week, and was, indeed, a waiting market, but with a very strong undertone. Toward the close the volume of business increased slightly and the tone was even more cheerful.

Wall Street's money-market scare disappearing, crude crop destruction canards being disposed of, and -- more than anything else important -- public interest aggressively developing, the security market makes an extraordinary record for the week. The list of net changes is almost uniformly a list of advances.

In two weeks Lieut. Gov. Woodruff has raised $87,014.60 of the $125,000 necessary to secure for Adelphi College the conditional gift of $125,000 offered by Mr. John D. Rockefeller, the condition being that an equal amount be raised by the friends of the Institution.

LONDON, April 16 -- No actor-manager in London has lately been at greater pains to secure a new play, and been less successful in that pursuit, than Charles Wyndham. Once again, after a recess at his theatre which was but a confession of failure, he has brought out a raw, tedious, unreasonble piece by a playwright seemingly devoid alike of inspiration and tact.

A TABLET to the memory of Margaret Corbin, a heroine of the battle of Fort Washington on Nov. 16, 1776, is to be unnveiled at Holyrood Church. One Hundred and Eighty-first Street and Broadway, on Wednesday afternoon next under the aucpices of Mary Washington Colonial Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

A GREAT change has taken place within the last few years in the wax ladles who live in our shop windows. At one time each one was exactly like her neighbor in hair and complexion, usually a golden-haired blonde, who endeavored to educate the taste of women shoppers by wearing the smartest of frocks, hats, and coats.

JUSTICE HENRY BISCHOFF of the Supreme Court was a widower for several years. Recently he announced his forthcoming marriage to Mrs. Collamore, an old friend of his family. His daughter, who is married, asked him how she should in future address her stepmother.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26 -- Harvard's wealthiest and most prominent students entertained Cambridge and Boston society to-night when the Hasty Pudding Club gave its first public performance of its new three-act operetta "Hi-Ka-Ya."

To the Editor of The New York Tunes: That large though insufficient number of Democrats who supported Mr. Shepard in the late campaign, not because they indorsed the actions of the Tammany administration, but because it seemed to them more probable that New York would obtain permanent good government under his guidance than under the guidance of his successful rival, feel the event is amply justifying their position.

On Thursday the Directors of the American Chicle Company declared a dividend of 1 per cent. on the common stock of the company. Although it was not stated for what period the dividend was declared, it was said that this action of the Directors was the beginning of the payment of 1 per cent. a month on the common stock.

Yesterday's stock market was generally strong and fairly active, with especial strength appearing in New Haven, New York Central, and Pennsylvania. New Haven rose a dozen points, on the execution of buying orders understood to come from Pennsylvania Railroad interest, the talk persisting that Pennsylvania is to have absolute control of New Haven -- this in face of official denials to the contrary.

LONDON, April 16 -- Besides its usual Spring cleaning, always sadly needed when the season of fog and mud has ended, all London seems to be getting a coat of cream-colored paint this Spring. The east winds have subsided at last, and the work of freshening up the town for the coronation festivities has begun.

There has not been very much to chronicle this past week -- only a few weddings and small entertainments and some gossip. The Spring has come in to stay and the Park is a perfect tangle of carriages and motor cars. The coaching parties have been very successful and the Pioneer's trips to and from Ardsley have been among the social functions.

LONDON, April 26 -- One of the most important parts of the preparation for the coronation festival concerns the police: it is generally felt that the metropolis has not enough police to look after properly the huge crowds on the lines of the processions and attend fully to their regular work in all neighborhoods during those busy days.

To the Editor Of The New York Times: I am not in the way of writing for newspapers, but having just bad three "snifters" of Scotch whisky and carbonic, my soul rises masterful within me to protest against that most inadequate editorial in THE TIMES of 22d Inst., headed "Old Age."

THOSE animals of the deep sea which live habitually in water just above the freezing point, in darkness that is profound, are among the most grotesque and singular of living beings. The fishes, so far as known, are of small size; but this does not prove that there are no large animals in the deep sea.

SILAS LARRABEE wants Mr. Henderson to resign from the Speakership of the House and Messrs. Payne, Dalzell, and Grosvenor to relinquish the committee places, though albeit they acquired the right to share with the Speaker in the management of the House.

NEW HAVEN, April 26 -- The Yale baseball nine met defeat this afternoon in an exciting eleven inning game with Holy Cross on Yale field. The decision of the umpire in calling Baldwin, who made the winning run for Holy Cross, safe at the plate was doubted by many, as Winslow, the Yale catcher, appeared, even to Holy Cross men, to have touched him out.

The latest "community of Interest" project, that of prominent steamship lines on the Atlantic Ocean, is in line of completing what has been done among the railroads on this side of the water to foster American trade; it has a bearing on the mineral industry of this country far beyond the conception of the average reader, or the careless student of the march of events.

Controller Grout yesterday answered District Attorney Jerome's letter in reference to the bills of county detectives for money spent in getting evidence of violations of law in liquor saloons and other places. Controller Grout examined County Detective McLellan's bill and his reply to District Attorney Jerome follows in part:

NEW YORKERS have Heard nothing about It, not a ripple of the excitement caused has touched the currents of city life, but all this past year throughout the dairy districts to the north of the metropolis there have been a series of whirlwind campaigns that have agitated the countrysides and put into them fresh, new, and startling thoughts.

The regular weekly Clearing House statement issued yesterday was in all respects a favorable one. Surplus reserves increased $2,882,400, loans decreased $1,097,300, legal tenders increased $2,563,900. specie increased $761,600, and deposits increased $1,772,400.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to the report of a sermon by the Rev. Dr. MacArthur which appeared in your issue of April 14, in which that reverend gentleman utters a warm eulogy of Cecil Rhodes, "the empire builder," (SO called,) and holds him up to his congregation as an example of high and noble strenuous life.

BOSTON, April 26 -- The week closed with the money market in a materially improved position. The business doing in the local market is still very light, but there is more of an inclination to shade rates than has been seen in some time. Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds, 5, 8, and 10 cents discount.

Col. WOODRUFF, appearing as counsel for Gen. JACOB H. SMITH in the courtmartial now sitting in Manila, admits that most of the accusations made against the General are true. This not only simplifies the trial and foreshadows the setting up of justification as a defense, but fully discloses the state of Gen. SMITH'S mind.

The Constant Misreader and His Own Petared. There is a comfortable saying that it is the exclusive privilege of mediocrity to be understood. If so, there is probably no easier way of rising above mediocrity than to write, or to attempt to write, dramatic criticism.

The conference between the representatives of the coal-carrying companies and the anthracite miners before the Conciliation Committee of the National Civic Federation in the Mission Building, 281 Fourth Avenue, yesterday, while it did not result in a settlement of the points in dispute, had the effect of bringing about a better understanding on both sides.

MY experience in feeding birds that are residents of Central Park in the Winter months has brought me a host of interesting facts at to bird life as well as some interesting experiences. Birds are moody as well as humans, and the strains and stress of life try them as ours try us.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- Heavy hitting by both clubs was the feature of today's baseball game between Boston and Philadelphia. Iberg and Pittinger were forced by the bombardment to retire and Mullarky, who was substituted by Boston, was more effective than Voorhees, who took Iberg's place.

The Rev. Dr. George W.F. Birch, pastor of Bethany Presbyterian Church, at Willls Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street, famous for his knowledge of Presbyterian law and as prosecutor in the Dr. Briggs heresy case, died at his home, 677 East One Hundred and Thirty-sixth Street, yesterday morning from bronchltis.

The first step toward the creation of a permanent endowment fund for the United Hebrew Charities was taken Thursday by William Guggenheim, a member of the Board of Directors, when he sent to the President of the organization. Henry Rice, a check for $50,000 for that purpose and a promise of $50,000 more upon the fulfillment of certain specified conditions.

BERLIN, April 26 -- Herr Ballin, Director General of the Hamburg-American Line, and Herr Wiegand, Director General of the North German Lloyd Line, are reassuring the perturbed shareholders of their companies that when they see the text of the agreement of the Anglo-American shipping combine it will be perceived that the German lines, instead of being overreached by J. Pierpont Morgan, have really strengthened their position enormously.
Ex-Gov. Morrill's apple orchard in Kansas now contains over 64,000 trees, and is said to be the largest single apple orchard in the world. Eight thousand trees have been set out this Spring.

SOME recent experiments in growing red wheat from seed certainly 3,000 and perhaps nearer 4,000 years old, have set me thinking about a subject which just now engages the attention of every lover of nature. The seed mentioned was found inclosed in the cerements of a mummy of the period of the Twentieth Dynasty.

LONDON, April 26 -- Many university students witnessed the conclusion to-night of the intercollegiate chess match between teams representing the American College Chess League and the Oxford-Cambridge Chess Club, and all conceded the strong playing or the Americans, who were easy winners.

The new wing of St. Vincent's Hospital, at Seventh Avenue and Eleventh Street, was threatened by fire yesterday morning, through an explosion of gas in a cellar, in which a carpenter's shop is situated.

Automobiles virtually owned the Long Island roads yesterday within the territory bounded by Jamaica, Oyster Bay, and Massepequa. Never before have so many machines propelled by gasoline, steam, and electricity been seen together in that locality engaged in a test run of 100 miles to show the public just what they are good for in getting around the country convenlently and at a tolerable speed.

The Social Reform Club gave a complimentary dinner last night at the Clarendon Hotel complimentary to Dr. Jane E. Robbins, who for some twelve years has been identified with college settlement and civic reform work in this city. The occasion of the dinner was Miss Robbins's approaching removal to Cleveland to engage in similar work among the Italians there.

The efforts of sidewalk ticket speculators were continued last night at the Criterion Theatre, notwithstanding the decision handed down in the Supreme Court and upheld by the Appellate Divisions, that a ticket is a revocable license and could be refused by the manager if he saw fit to do so.

PARIS, April 19 -- Where are the snows of yesteryear? Where are the old parties of the last electoral campaign in France? They and the numberless newspapers which represented them have passed away into the limbo of disused and forgotten things. There is no more Rochefortism, even if the Intransigeant survives; no more Possibllism, nor Solutionism, nor Clemenism, nor Boulangism, nor Christian Socialism, nor Revisionism, nor even Opportunism.

Canadian Pacific. Glasgow (Scotland) bankers just returned from a tour of inspection over the Canadian Pacific have been among the largest buyers of the stock of that company, which sold up to a new high record, while James J. Hill and his Great Northern friends are also understood to have been active on the buying side.

MOST wonderful of all the so-calied "bottomless lakes " is undoubtedly Mystery; or, Deep Blue Lake, as it was named by its white discoverers half a century ago, but better known nowadays as Crater Lake, in Oregon. There are very few places in it where the depth is less than 1,500 feet, and no other lake on the Western Hemisphere approaches this.

They are always gay, and bring merriment wherever they go, and therefore, in spite of their somewhat evil reputation, are generally welcome. Hostelries and fairs are often thronged by these gaudy visitors, whose nudity is barely covered by their bright-colored rags, whose jokes are loud and spirited, and whose recklessness is unequaled.
The man at the desk frowned discouragingly.

DERBY, Conn., April 26 -- Because he has decided to oppose to the last resort compulsory vaccination for his children, John McGuigan, a resident of this city, has received hundreds of letters from all parts of the country, and many of the missives contain offers of aid, pecuniary and otherwise.

AMONG all the products of the sea the pearl is pre-eminent for natural beauty, and rivals in splendor and value the choicest gems of the earth. Unlike the latter, it requires no aid from art to reveal its beauty and lustre, and doubtless for this reason it met with highest favor among the ancients.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 26 -- It is reported that John W. Gates has leased the Robert W. Cummings cottage at Sea-bright.

Whenever reports, or even rumors, appear which give the crop outlook a dismal cast, no matter whether it be Winter or Spring wheat or corn, there are always to be found timid souls seized with the desire to sell their holdings of stocks. Oftentimes, the better the stocks the greater the desire to get rid of them.

WIERS POINT, Roanoke Island, N.C., April 26 -- While the newspapers have been resounding with accounts of the invention of various wireless telegraph systems, all of which fall short of complete practicality in some respect, the United States Government has been quietly at work for the past two years in perfecting a system of its own which it believes has overcome all the obstacles and remedied all the defects of the other systems.

TWO significant concerts fell under the observation of THE NEW YORK TIMES'S reporter of musical, doings within the last two weeks. One was the performance of Handel's "Israel in Egypt" by the People's Choral Union and the other was the final entertainment in the series of Peoples' Symphony Concerts at Cooper Union.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- New York exchange to-day was 5c discount before clearings and par afterward. Time and call loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent. Trading in local stocks was moderately active, but prices in most cases were practically stationary. There was some demand for Can common around 13 1/2, Biscuit common at 30 1/4, Carbon common at 23, and Union Traction common at 21 1/4.

EXCITEMENT is beginning about the color question which promises the clubwomen of the National Federation no end of interesting matter, to talk about at their meeting in California this coming month, and people who are only generally interested a little spicy reading.
BUFFALO, April 26 -- A special from Niagara Falls says:

LONDON, April 26 -- The Americanization of the British mercantile navy will again be the principals subject at "Questions Time " in the House of Commons Monday. Members have given notice of a dozen inquiries, covering a variety of points and indicative of widespread apprehension that, despite assurances to the contrary, the shipping combine menaces not only Great Britain's naval resources, but her commercial interests.

It is just twenty years since a Republican President vetoed a River and Harbor bill upon the ground of gross extravagance and disgraceful collusion. It was in that veto message that President ARTHUR made his famous characterization of "the log rolling" by which so vast an amount was to be taken from the Treasury: "Thus, as the bill becomes more objectionable, it secures more support."

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Mr. Carmack of Tennessee in the Senate to-day completed the speech on the Philippine Government bill which he began yesterday. He continued his criticism of the Administration's policy. By the terms of the pending bill, he said, the islands were for the Filipinos as the pasture was for the sheep -- they lived and browsed there in order to raise wool for others to wear and mutton for others to eat.

There was another meeting yesterday in the Appellate Term room of the Supreme Court of lawyers and Judges who have organized a committee for the purpose of arranging a suitable memorial to Noah Davis, for many years a Justice of the Supreme Court. Secretary of the Memorial Committee Theodore M. Roche read a number of letters of regret from prominent men, among them the following letter from exPresident Graver Cleveland:

Yesterday was another General Carriage day in the outside market. Some few other stocks were fairly active, but the enormous transactions in this one stock made other issues seem dull by comparison. Electric Vehicle was irregular and active, but was not as prominent as it had been on Friday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dogs are all right! Excepting of course some that are not. Those that are not have increased in number in New York the last year or two, and ever since Mr. Low took the chair to preside over us, have broken the silence of night and cut a bad figure in these days of reform.

German military men, as well as historians, hold ill-regulated and undisciplined and disorganized valor in low esteem, except, apparently, when employed against the British. This is how the person's whom the French call gallant and devoted Franctireurs are described in Niemann's wellknown treatise, translated by Gen. Newdigate, Page 190:

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the last few months have read in your journal many fervid letters and several fervid editorials condemning the manner in which the United States customs laws are enforced at the port of New York. At each reading I have felt moved to relate my own experience, and I now beg the privilege of doing so.

EVERY now and again some complaint is made against the public officials of the city, but there is one man who apparently always does his duty well. This is the city fumigator. If you don't believe it, send for the gentleman to fumigate your apartment, and when he has done his work ask the other people in the building.

ST. LOUIS, April 26 -- It was stated on good authority in financial circles to-day that the Mercantile Trust Company has finally closed a deal by the terms of which it pledges itself to finance the Tennessee Central Railroad to the amount of $15,000,000.

By mutual consent the hand-tennis players competing in the championship tournament of the New York Athletic Club agreed yesterday to postpone the semi-final matches until Tuesday. James Haslin, the player whose collapse on Friday was due to heart failure, was reported to be in better condition and recovering.

AT the Grau benefit on Monday evening at the Opera House there were several notably handsome costumes in the parterre boxes. Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney displayed one of them. It was a white satin, pailleted in moderately large fleur-de-lys designs in silver; and these were some distance apart.

LONDON, April 26 -- The form of the coronation service, as finally amended and approved by the King, was announced today. It consists of twenty-six distinct sections. The King and Queen will enter the great west door of Westminster Abbej. They will be welcomed by the shouts of the King's Scholars of Westminster School and by an anthem.
The Rev. MICHAEL CALLAHAN of Boston died suddenly yesterday at St. Clement's College, the Saratoga retreat of the Redemptionist Fathers.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 26 -- Visitors continue to flock to this resort in increasing numbers, and the hotels are filling; up rapidly.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 26 -- The eighth annual intercollegiate and interscholastic relay races, under the auspices of the University of Pennsylvania Athletic Association, were held on Franklin Field this afternoon, and attracted an enthusiastic crowd of almost 10,000 spectators. It was the greatest event of its kind ever held in America, the entry list including more than 125 colleges and schools, while more than 600 athletes competed in the several events.

George J. Pool of 255 East Seventy-second Street was arraigned yesterday before Judge Newburger in the Court of General Sessions on a bench warrant charging him with grand larceny. The man was held in $1,000 bail for trial. T.F. Alden of the General Accident Insurance Corporation was the complainant.

DID you ever see a squirrel run a sewing machine? If not, you may, by journeying to East Fifty-ninth Street, where an enterprising sewing-machine company has hit upon this novel method of attracting attention to its store. The exercise wheel in the squirrel's cage is attached by a leather band to the wheel of a machine, which is about four feet distant.

-- On the ground that "the condition of the public roads of the United States calls for the attention of both State and National Governments," Representative J. A. BEIDLER of Ohio recently introduced a bill -- now in the hands of the House Committee on Agriculture -- which may prove to be the beginning of a new movement for "good roads."

That there should be shown in Stock Exchange circles genuine interest in the prospective wheat crop of Kansas is quite understandable. More than one railroad whose stocks are among the active specialties, and some of whose securities are of investment as well as speculative value has a considerable volume of traffic and a no less considerable volume of earnings depending upon the agricultural output of Kansas.

ABOUT himself he had little or nothing to say. There was a scar across his face, and he wore and empty sleeve. He had seen service in South Africa .The man of the Montreal Hotel said that the Canadian Captain had been, gazetted twice for gallantry in the field.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 26 -- The oppressively hot weather of the last week has had the effect of bringing the Spring season to a close much earlier than was anticipated. The cottagers have begun to pack up, and many of the society people here will leave for their country places during the coming week.

There was scarcely a loud word spoken during the game between the New York and Brooklyn Baseball Clubs at the Polo Grounds yesterday, which was won by the New Yorks by a score of 4 to 1. This was in strange contrast to the noisy and exciting game which began the series between New York and Brooklyn at Washington Park on Friday.

NEW YORKERS may not be as cold-blooded, figuratively speaking, as they are often said to be by strangers from the West and South who are accustomed to more cordial ways. What sometimes passes for indifference and even suspicion is likely to be only a superficial expression of conditions demanding haste and perhaps abruptness.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 26 -- At Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Oakland Farm, in Portsmouth, a large gang of workmen is engaged in fitting up the polo field, which promises to be one of the best private fields devoted to polo in the country. Last year's field has been enlarged, and to make a level playing surface the sod is lifted and rolled, the surface graded and the sod replaced.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- Persistent demand for Pennsylvania Railroad and a reawakening in the "Gibbs specialties" were the features of the local market to-day, and the general list suffered from neglect, and following the example set in New York, nearly everything closed below last night's prices.

BALTIMORE, April 26 -- The local market to-day was of little interest outside of Seaboards, which were in continued demand and higher. They reached the best figure to-day that has been attained for over six months. The buying is considered as still good, though there are some signs of unloading by those who bought lower on tips from insiders.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 25 -- The transportation of 136,000 homeseekers from the Eastern and Southern States to the North-west within a period of sixty days seems almost beyond comprehension. The figures, however, are rather under than above the actual count. The railroads entering the Northwestern States have compiled statistics covering the last two months, ending with April 12.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- When the Senate convened to-day Mr. Jones (Nev.), Chairman of the Committee on Contingent Expenses, reported favorably the resolution of the Committee on Relations with Cuba providing for an investigation by that Committee of the alleged control of the Cuban sugar crop and sugar lands in Cuba.

IN the frozen regions of Alaska, not far distant from the gold fields of the Klondike, under the circumpolar sun, where the horizon dips to meet the ice flelds, the Government is superintending one of the queerest breeding establishments in the world. To attempt to stock Alaska with the reindeer of Northern Europe was a bold experiment that required for its successful attainment a man or accurate knowledge and of unusual scientific imagination.

LONDON, April 26 -- In the contest at the Queen's Club to-day for the lawn tennis covered court championship, H.L. Doherty retained the title of champion, defeating J.G. Ritchie by a score of 3 to 1. In the double championship R.F. and H.L. Doherty retain the title. They defeated Ritchie and Sweetman by 3-0.

LONDON, April 26 -- Money was at 2 1/2 per cent. to-day; there was a better supply and the demand was less pronounced. Heavy repayments to the Bank of England will have to be met next week, and, possibly, the market will not be free from debt for some time, unless gold is received from America.

The interest in lawn tennis promises to be greater than ever during the coming season, and in some localities tennis has superseded all the other open air sports. The upward tendency began with the coming of the famous English team two years ago to challenge for the Davis International Challenge Trophy, and has been further advanced this season by the popularity of ping-pong.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Chairman Gardner of the House Committee on Labor will on Monday make a report to the House recommending for passage the bill providing an eight-hour system for laborers and mechanics employed upon work done for the United States, or any Territory, or the District of Columbia.
Amateur fencers brought the National championship tournament to a close last night at the New York Athletic Club. The events to be decided were with French dueling swords and the lightweight sabres.

HOW long it takes to impart a polish to common red brick by attrition alone has not been satisfactorily determined. Certainly for the last three-quarters of a century humanity has been squeezing itself through, that stunted arch which serves as an opening to an ugly alley in the Armenian-quarter of New York.

College golf was the great feature in the metropolitan district yesterday. Yale, Princeton, and Columbia all played team matches with neighboring clubs. Yale met Garden City and won by 16 holes to 6. Princeton beat the Richmond County team at Staten Island by 26 holes to 19, and Columbia was beaten by Baltusrol by 22 holes to 13.
Fifth Avenue again contributed last week nearly all of those market happenings which were in every respect noteworthy.

Messrs. Thornycroft, the well-known shipbuilders of Chiswick, are experimenting with a new oil engine which may not only revolutionize private Yacht propulsion, but may also effect a remarkable change in the adaptability and all-round efficiency in the smaller craft of our navy.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- The Government attorneys are busy to-night consulting on the eve of battle with the Beef Trust and mapping out the plan of the struggle. Judge Day, who arrived here this morning, is said to have brought with him evidence secured in New York and other Eastern cities concerning the methods of the meat combine.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 27 -- The mines throughout this region will work tomorrow despite the fact that the thirty-day truce ended yesterday and according to the terms of the Shamokin Convention a strike should be declared. The committee now in New York has notified the mine workers that they should continue as at present until they get instructions.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., April 27 -- The most disastrous fire since 1864 visited Glens Falls early to-day, entailing a property loss conservatively estimated at over $500,000. The fire started in the clothing store of Webb Brothers, and thence spread to the large plant of the Joseph Fowler Shirt and Collar Company, occupying the upper story of nearly the entire block.

The crusade against Sunday baseball in New York, and particularly in the Bronx, which has been started by the Sabbath Association and others, who made complaints to Commissioner Partridge, was actively aided yesterday by the Westchester police, who, at the command of Capt. Walsh, visited all the places in the precinct where the game is usually indulged in on Sundays and warned several hundred boys that their pleasure would no longer be permitted.

TRENTON, N.J., April 27 -- The wholesale milk dealers of this county and of Bucks County, Penn., numbering sixty-two concerns, have formed a corporation for the purpose of keeping up the price of milk this Summer. The price is to remain at 4 cents per quart so that the retail price must remain at 8 cents, and not to be reduced to 6 cents, as it usually is in Summer months.

PARIS, April 28 -- The outcome of the general elections in France is in doubt. Results from 413 districts have been received. They are divided as follows: 163 Ministerialists, 125 Anti-Ministerialists, and 128 reballots.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 27 -- Gov. B.B. Odell of New York, who has been resting in Atlanta two days, will leave for New Orleans to-morrow after calling on Gov. Candler. Gov. Odell expressed himself to-night as greatly impressed with the South and said he believed the period of industrial development which this part of the country had entered upon would be lasting.

The Newark Baseball Club of the Eastern League and the Brooklyn players of the National League met yesterday on the Newark Club grounds and the Brooklyns were defeated by a score of 19 to 8. Capt. Keeler of the Brooklyns was unable to play himself, as he injured his ankle at the finish of the game at the Polo Grounds on Saturday and he only put in a very weak team against the Newark players.

That attitude of indifference relative to the enforcement of the excise and the general Sabbath laws manifested by the police on the previous Sunday was again apparent yesterday all over the city. Few excise arrests were made and fewer prisoners locked up for selling merchandise.

WASINGTON, April 27 -- The plans of the Senate for the week do riot extend beyond the continuation of the debate on the Philippine Government bill and the consideration of minor matters when there is no one prepared to speak on the Philippine bill. There is no prospect thus far for speeches in support of that measure, and, consequently all the talk bids fair to continue to be on the negative side of the question.

The condition of Archbishop Corrigan yesterday continued satisfactory, an though it is said that the crisis is not expected until to-day, the physicians in at tendance were gratified at the patient's condition. They held their morning consultation about half an hour later than usual, and at 10 o'clock issued this bulletin:

Sheltered from the high wind by the bluff on the west, the Harlem River Speedway, with the roadbed well sprinkled and free from dust, offered opportunity for sport yesterday that delighted the many road-drivers, who braved the seemingly unfavorable weather conditions, and throughout the day the drive was thronged with fast and famous harness horses.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 27 -- The sixteenth annual convention at the Theosophical Society of America met in executive session here to-day. The society dedined to consider any overtures toward a coalition with the Besant branch of Theosophists, and took favorable action toward uniting the American, English, German, and Scandinavian branches of Theosophical believers under one Constitution.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In you issue of this morning "E." refers with approval to my suggestion that an Aerial Club should be formed here, and, as the subject is of considerable importance, and must soon become of general interest as well, I trust that THE TIMES will again favor me with a little of its valuable space.

CAPE MAY, N.J., April 27 -- Under the personal direction of General Superintendent Garrett of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad and District Superintendent McCausland, a trolley railroad was built for three blocks along Ocean Street, the principal thoroughfare, between 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon and this evening.

CLEVELAND, April 27 -- The schooner Barklow, from Marine City, foundered in Lake Erie, half a mile from Put-in-Bay, late Saturday afternoon, and three persons lost their lives. The dead are Capt. Robert Pardy of Marine City, his wife, and his step-son. Alexander Morris, aged sixteen years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Carefully reading the daily papers in regard to the present high prices of meat and food stuffs produced by the short wheat supply I have failed to notice any reference to the fact that our northern neighbor is becoming (in fact has almost become) a dangerous competitor to our domestic and foreign trade in wheat and bread stuffs.

BERLIN, April 27 -- The characteristic feature of the Boerse during the last week was the growing ease of money without a resultant animation in speculation; consequently the monthly settlement is passing under the easiest money rates, perhaps, ever known in Berlin. The private rate of discount during the past week reached 1 1/2 per cent., the lowest rate ever recorded.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 27 -- "The West Virginia Central and Pittsburg Railway Directors have determined to extend the line to Baltimore whether the Fuller-Gould bid for the Western Maryland is accepted or not," says Col. T.B. Davis, a controlling stockholder of the West Virginia Central in a dispatch from Keyser, West Va.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Tlie Insular Division of the War Department has prepared for publication an extract showing in comparative form the commerce of the Island of Cuba for the seven months ended January 31, 1902, and 1901.

A new political club is being formed in Brooklyn by the radical element among the Democrats of the borough. While the announced purpose of the organization is to seek to hold the Democrats of Brooklyn to the principles of the Kansas City platform of the Democracy, eliminating the freesilver features of the same, the belief obtains that the new club will also strive to further the political ambitions of ex-Controller Coler.

YONKERS, N.Y., April 27 -- The police here have evolved a new-plan for arresting the drivers of motor vehicles which run faster than the laws allow. Three were gathered in to-day at a single swoop. Among those riding in the machines corralled were Jefferson Seligman and Isidor and Maurice Wormser, the bankers.

Golfers have an unusually busy week in store for them, for besides the invitation tournament of the Garden City Golf Club, which will begin on the first day of May, there will be formal openings on a number of local links which have not yet commenced their competitive contests. The star attraction among the big players will be the three day tournament at Garden City.

Closing prices on the Stock Exchange at the end of last week were distinctly encouraging to the advocates of and the believers in higher stock market values. While not actually buoyant the market ended the week distinctly strong and with many net gains appearing as compared with the close in the preceding week.

All the buildings on the eastern end of South Beach were destroyed by fire last night. The flames also ate away all the structures on the new portion of the beach and involved a loss which was estimated at from $125,000 to $150,000. On this there was very little insurance.

Andrew Carnegie was walking leisurely up Fifth Avenue, past Fifty-eighth Street, yesterday shortly after noon when he was accosted by a seedy-looking young man who, politely lifting his hat, told him that he was starving. Mr. Carnegie instinctively thrust his hand into his pocket and, bringing out a roll of bills, was about to pass one to the man when, suddenly prompted by curiosity, he questioned him first.

Excitement was rife in the Bronx last evening. Scores of persons were panic stricken and for hours excitement prevailed. The trouble started when it was discovered that James Butler, thirty-two years old, a hostler, and his wife, Kate, who lived on the third floor of the four-story tenement at 2,617 Third Avenue, were suffering from smallpox in an advanced stage.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- New and important evidence against the packers charged with being members of an illegal combination to maintain the prices of beef was brought to the attention of United States Attorney Bethea and Special Attorney Day to-day.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., April 27 -- Lord Kelvin, the eminent English scientist, visited Niagara Falls to-day. Lord Kelvin has been greatly interested in the power development at the Falls since the inception of the scheme, for he was one of the men consulted preliminary to the work of harnessing the waterfall.

The great investing public has not yet turned its attention to real estate, in the same way as to general stocks and bonds, as the final repository of its surplus funds. In other words, real estate, practically alone of all forms of investment, has not yet felt in full the effect of prosperous times.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 27 -- Attorney General Knox assured the local provision dealers that he would take their charges in hand and if the railroads were discriminating in freight rates in favor of Western packers, redress would be had through the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

LONDON, April 28 -- It is difficult, says the Moscow correspondent of The Times, to exaggerate the state of unrest among the working population of Central Russia. The alarming progress of the revolutionary agitation forms the main subject of conversation of all classes, especially manufacturers and commercial men.

In the announcement issued last week for the Department of Comparative Literature of Columbia University for the colege year 1902-03 the name of Lewis Nathaniel Chase, A.M., for the past year a tutor in the university, is dropped from the list of instructors for the coming year.

A meeting for the purpose of increasing the interest in the proposed Jewish Hospital, in Brooklyn, was held yesterday afternoon at Temple Israel, Bedford and Lafayette Avenues, that borough. The meeting was very largely attended, and much enthusiasm over the project was manifested.

TRENTON, N.J., April 27 -- What appears to be a well-defined likeness of St. John has appeared on the front of the Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in South Trenton. The features are plainly those of the most generally accepted painting of St. John. The picture is above the main entrance, and its appearance has created a big flurry in Catholic circles in the neighborhood.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- The programme of the eighth annual meeting of the National Municipal League, and tenth National conference for good city government to be held at Boston May 7, 8, and 9, has been completed.

ELIZABETH CITY, N.C., April 27 -- Prof. R.A. Fessenden's tests of his new wireless telegraphy system were continued yesterday in the presence of Superintendent Tittman of the Coast and Geodetic Survey and his assistant, Dallas B. Wainwright, and Lieut. Beecher of the navy. Lieut. Hudgins left after the first test, perfectly satisfied with what he had seen, and enthusiastic about the invention, as are ail the other Government experts.

The Thirteenth Street Presbyterian Church, a white brick edifice extending from 141 to 145 West Thirteenth Street, and one of the historic churches in the city, caught fire at 5:30 o'clock last evening and the interior was destroyed. The fire started under the altar, supposedly from a defective electric wire, and the flames spread so rapidly through the church that when the firemen arrived the whole interior was burning like a roaring furnace.

Brevity is commendable, but in the enunciation of great truths it is possible to stop just short of completeness of statement which leaves the seeker after information at a loss to know how to apply such knowledge after the manner in which our Puritan ancestors applied all Scripture -- "By way of improvement."

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- The anthracite coal trade is very active, and the April output is expected to total up to large figures, possibly 4,500,000 tons. The weather has favored full working at most of the collieries, and the expectation of continued coal mining without any labor troubles this Spring has produced a condition of restfulness and satisfaction throughout the whole mining district.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why should there not be an eclectic school of cookery in New York? True, there are schools where cooking is taught, but the methods employed are exclusively American. Cosmopolitan requirements evoke dissatisfaction with uniformity of diet.
Charles Ritz of 16 First Street was arraigned before Magistrate Flammer in the Centre Street Court yesterday morning, charged with disorderly conduct.

Such stunning designs as there are in the fluffy things for the neck! One hardly knows what to call them now that they are getting away from the boa shape. Fichu seems hardly the word for anything for the neck, which is intended for outside wear -- an apology for a wrap when no other is worn -- or to be worn over light wraps.

The astonishing development of underground railroad enterprises in London is illustrated by the fact that there are now awaiting consideration in the House of Lords fourteen bills authorizing the construction of as many separate tunnels to be operated electrically for passenger conveyance.

Games between the two leading teams and the rear guard twain in the National Baseball League race for the pennant yesterday put Pittsburgh pronouncedly in the lead, but left St. Louis a little less emphatically last.

Hundreds of bicycles and scores of automobiles, carriages, buggies, and pedestrians crowded that section of Fort Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, bordering on the south side of Prospect Park, near the beginning of the Ocean Boulevard yesterday afternoon, when from the vicinity of Flatbush Avenue was started the shouts and cries of excitement and fear.

The question of the high prices of meats again caused a commotion at the meeting of the Central Federated Union yesterday. Nearly all the men who took part in the discussion a week ago on the question of abstaining from meat a month were present, and the subject was launched in a new form by the offering of the following preamble and resolution by Delegate Snyder of the Paper Hangers' Union:

Not only the good people of the Netherlands, but those of every civilized country, watch with anxiety for the bulletins announcing the condition from day to day of the young Queen of Holland. Somehow she has won a warmer place in the affections of strangers and outlanders than any sovereign of Europe.
CHICAGO, April 27 -- J. Sterling Morton, ex-Secretary of Agriculture, died at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon at Lake Forrest, at the home of his son, Mark Morton.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me on behalf of the Good Citizenship Committee of the Christian Endeavor Union and of the church-going people of the east side, to thank you for the able articles published in THE TIMES which have so accurately described the conditions on the streets on the last two Sundays.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 28 -- The opening game of the Lakewood Polo Club's tournament to-day was a match between the Rockaway Polo Club and the WestChester Country Club for the Herbert trophies. The Rockaways were handicapped at sixteen and their opponents at fourteen, giving the Westchester team two goals advantage.
The Aqueduct race meeting entered its last week yesterday, with the same weather conditions that marked the opening of the New York season.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- If we can't get control of the Western Maryland Railway, we'll build a line of our own," declared Richard C. Kerens of St. Louis, discussing the attempt of George Gould to get control of the little road owned by the City of Baltimore, and which, if Gould gets it, will give him a transcontinental system.

The lesson of the legislative elections of this year in France is the same as that of the municipal elections of last year. It is that, in spite of the proverb, Paris is not France. It seems to be almost equally clear that this is a good thing for the French Republic.

YONKERS, N.Y., April 28 -- The cases of the three drivers of automobiles arrested on Warburton Avenue yesterday charged with exceeding the speed limit while passing through the city, were called this afternoon in the City Court. There was a large attendance of owners of automobiles who came to see what action would be taken and how severe the penalty would be in case of conviction.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The naval programme for 1903, as presented in the Naval Appropriation bill and accompanying report filed to-day by Chairman Foss of thE House Naval Committee, is one of unusual interest. The report does not take as optimistic a view of our naval prowess us is generally held.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- There are no indications of an early agreement in the Senate on the question of relief to Cuba. There seems to be ground to fear that the Senate will fail to pass a Cuban bill and that Congress will adjourn without meeting the wishes of the Administration and the country in respect to the Cubans.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

Some 600 persons listened last night to Miss Ellen M. Stone's story of her experience with brigands in Bulgaria and Turkey. It was the first of a series of lectures the missionary is to give under the management of Major J.B. Pond. The lecture was held in the auditorium of the Broadway Tabernacle, at Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street.

BOSTON, Mass., April 28 -- The money market is considerably easier in tone. The fact is shown more in the increased willingness of the banks to put out loans than in any actual shading of rates, although concessions are now being freely made. Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds, 15 cents discount.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- It was an unusually active market in this city for a Monday, with numerous bright spots scattered over the list, and before the day closed the highest figures of the year were reached for a number of shares. The greatest activity was in Reading common, but it was in Consolidated Lake Superior that the most pronounced gain was registered, the common advancing 3 and the preferred 1 5/8.

The consternation which has seized the representatives of the ancient nobility of Germany at the discovery that the Emperor at times prefers the company and counsel of "vulgar tradesmen and base mechanicals" to that of the representatives of the old families which have been the bulwarks of Prussian aristocracy for generations is more amusing than surprising.

A number of stocks in the outside market yesterday showed large totals. General Carriage was again traded in on an enormous scale, but business was not confined to this one stock to as great an extent as was the case during the latter part of last week. Several of the transportation stocks were very active, including one of two which held places of prominence during the past week.

DALLAS, Texas, April 28 -- A telephone message from Morgan, Texas, received to-night, states that a tornado passed over Glen Rose, a small town in Somervell County, between 5 and 6 o'clock this evening, killing five persons, injuring forty more, and demolishing much property.
PARIS, April 29 -- The latest election figures made public by the Ministry of the Interior show that 248 Ministerialists and 163 Anti-Ministerialists have been elected to the Chamber of Deputies.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 28 -- An exact duplicate of the monster works to be built at Economy by the American Bridge Company will be erected at Chicago at a cost of between $2,500,000 and $3,000,000. This decision was recently reached by the Directors of the United States Steel Corporation and will be one of the results of the pending bond issue of $50,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Representative Sibley (Penn.) in the House to-day, during the general debate on the Agricultural Appropriation bill, severely denounced Gen. Jacob H. Smith for the orders he issued in the Samar campaign.

PITTSBURG, April 28 -- Work will be started within a few weeks by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company to double the capacity of the monster works at East Pittsburg at a cost of $1,500,000. The contract has been awarded and it is expected the new building will be completed early next year.

Capt. Max Schmittberger, who recently took command of the West Forty-seventh Street Station, started out last night, and as he promised when he succeeded Capt. Donohue, waged a vigorous war on disorderly houses in the precinct. With thirty-five picked men in civilian clothes, his detectives and three patrol wagons, he swooped down on five alleged disorderly houses in his precinct and captured fifty prisoners.

The trial before Commissioner Partridge of Police Captain Michael E. Foody of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station on charges of neglect of duty was resumed yesterday morning at Police Headquarters The proceedings, which were adjourned till to-morrow morning, were characterized by constant and sharp tilting between ex-Judge Olcott, the counsel for Foody, and District Attorney Jerome, who, with his assistant, Sandford, was present to prosecute the case against the Captain.

The first of the eight mammoth granite monoliths to adorn the Chambers Street front of the new Hall of Records Building was successfully placed in position yesterday in the presence of several hundred interested spectators.
ALBANY, April 28 -- In general orders issued from the headquarters of the National Guard to-day, instructions and details for the season at the State Camp are given.

The skyscraper builders of New York have been redoubling their energies of late to complete work on a dozen office buildings by Thursday. Many of these structures will be completed on time. Superintendent Stewart of the Building Department has kept his inspecting staff busy to see that no violations of the law are committed.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Nothing is known here of the arrest in Venice of three naval officers. It will be reported by Capt. Dayton, commanding the Chicago, but he will probably make his report by mail.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 -- The meeting of the General Federation or Women's Clubs in Los Angeles during the present week will develop the details of a political campaign among the clubwomen second only to the assembling of the convention itself.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Sol Smith Russell, the actor, died at the Richmond Hotel, In this city, this afternoon, of perpetual hiccoughs. Mr. Russell had been ill for some time from this malady, but during the past few days the disease took a serious turn, and since early morning the end had been hourly expected.

LONDON, April 28 -- Joseph H. Choate, the United States Ambassador here, and Mrs. Choate gave a brilliant reception at their residence in Carlton House Terrace to-night. There was an endless stream of carriages to their door throughout the evening.

BAYONNE, N.J., April 28 -- Union carpenters of Bayonne united in striking for higher pay and shorter hours to-day, stopping extensive rebuilding operations of the Pacific Coast Borax Company, recently visited by fire. Sixty men quit, none staying. The Standard Oil Company had eighty carpenters on strike, one dozen remaining.

Judge Lacombe of the United States Court yesterday remanded to the State courts for trial the suit of Moritz L. Ernst and other stockholders of the American Spirits Manufacturing Company against the Directors or the American Spirits Manufacturing Company, the Distilling Company of America, the Spirits Distributing Company, the Standard Distilling and Distributing Company, and the Kentucky Distilleries and Warehouse Company, forming the so-called Whisky Trust.

AUBURN, Ala., April 28 -- The Ogden party arrived in Auburn this afternoon. The party went to Langdon Hill, where the members were welcomed by the Faculty of the Alabama Polytechnic Institute, the corps of cadets, and the citizens of the town. President C.D. Smith introduced the members in a few appropriate words, and Gov. Jelks welcomed them.

"This is the eleventh time we have soaked them," was the official announcement on the annual programme of the Society of American Fakirs, a body of embryo paint brush geniuses who amuse themselves and others at the end of each year's work by giving an exhibition of pictures parodying whatever celebrated paintings happen to be exhibited during that year by the Society of American Artists.

BALTIMORE, April 28 -- The local market to-day showed no special change one way or the other. The active interest in Seaboards flagged somewhat. The general trading moved as though no one was convinced exactly as to what the market's true status really is. As a consequence there was an intermixture of gains and losses, neither of which was of any significance.

McVickar Co. have sold for Senator Chauncey M. Depew the dwelling formerly occupied by him at 22 East Forty-fifth Street, 22 by 73.5. The buyer is Thomas B. Hidden, who has also secured under a twenty-one years' lease, with privileges of renewals, the Jackson estate's house, 348 Madison Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- The preliminary injunction granted last week restraining Napoleon Lajoie, second baseman of the Philadelphia American League baseball club, from playing with any other than the Philadelphia National League club was to-day made permanent by the Court of Common Pleas.

DOVER, N.J., April 28 -- By the explosion of its boiler, a mile east of this place, this morning, Engine 941, hauling the Hackettstown mail train on the Lackawanna Railroad, was demolished and its engineer and fireman killed. The victims are:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 28 -- Honors were evenly divided to-day in the boat races between the Varsity and freshmen crews of the University of Pennsylvania and the Naval Cadets first and second crews. The Varsity and first crew race was rowed over a two-mile course, straightaway. The race between the freshmen and second crews was held over a mile and a half of the same course.
Pauline Solomon ran away from her step-mother, Mrs. Alice Howley, of 1,404 Jefferson Street, Philadelphia, yesterday morning, and was captured in this city last night after an exciting chase.

News of the formal incorporation in New Jersey of the United Copper Company, the new Heinze combination of copper properties, was receive in Wall Street yesterday about the same time that dispatches from Boston announced that the Calumet and Hecla Mining Company, one of the oldest copper companies, had cut its dividend from $10 to $5 a share.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, April 28 -- The fishing steamer Louise, which arrived here this afternoon, brought the survivors and the first details of the story of another lake disaster. The schooner Grace Gribbie of Cleveland, Capt. Thomas Wilson, went to pieces on Point Pelee on Saturday, and three of the crew were drowned.

A deer broke loose up in the Bronx yesterday and transformed a cheerful, sun-illumined day into a raid night on the Bowery for the police of the High Bridge Station. Chasing the fleet-footed animal was interesting enough in the crisp air of 6 o'clock in the morning, which was when Milkman Joseph Campbell of Ogden Avenue first saw it, but by noon the animation of the chasing policemen was ebbing fast.
LONDON, April 28 -- There was a strong demand for money to-day, mainly owing to repayments due to the Bank of England every day this week, besides month-end requirements. Discounts were firm.

New high-price records for a number of conspicuous stocks were made yesterday. Until the last hour of business quotations were buoyant and then recessions were scored only because there developed a free profit-taking movement -- most traders selling out such speculative lines as they recently had accumulated.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Oleomargarine bill, as it came from the House, was taken up in the Senate, and Mr. Culberson (Tenn.) moved that it be referred to the Committee on Agriculture. The motion was defeated -- 26 to 35.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Representative Shattuc, discussing statements which have appeared in Cincinnati papers referring to the speech made by Mr. Cushman of Washington, in which he assaulted the Committee on Rules and the Speaker, said:

It seems to be accepted as a fact in Manila that the insurrection in Samar is at an end, that the surrender of GUEVARRA is the last act of it. And it is to be noted that, in all our varied experiences in the islands, there has been no recrudescence of an insurrection once officially reported to have been subdued.

Blasting in connection with the erection of the New York Public Library has caused the residents of the block in West Fortieth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, to make vigorous war on the contractor who has the task of removing 2,300 cubic feet of solid rock along the north sidewalk of the block.

Gen. FRANK D. ASKEW, a pioneer business man, died yesterday at Kansas City, aged sixty-five years. He was born in St. Clairsville, Ohio, served with the Fifteenth and Seventeenth Ohio Volunteers during the civil war, and was brevetted a Brigadier General.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A number of minor bills were passed in the Senate today, and consideration was resumed of the Philippine Government bill. Mr. Simmons (N.C.) addressed the Senate in opposition to the measure. He referred to the treatment of Cuba by the United States, and said he had no disposition to discuss the motives of the Republican Party in pursuing one line of policy toward Cuba and an opposite policy toward the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Attorney General Knox to-day conferred with the President regarding the progress of the proceedings against the Beef Trust. The Administration is well satisfied with the Outlook and is confident that the testimony now in the hands of the Attorney General will result in the success of the prosecution recently instituted against the meat companies.

Cable advices from Hamburg bring news about our townsman Mr. J. PIERPONT MORGAN that will be received here with derisive unbelief. The dispatches profess to give the substance of the agreement between the Atlantic steamship combination organised by Mr. MORGAN and the German steamship lines:

The work on the budget for 1902 has been completed by the members of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, and to-morrow at 10 o'clock a special meeting will be held to formally approve it. It is now certain that the budget prepared by Mayor Low, Controller Grout, and the other members of the board will not be any higher than that prepared by the Board of Estimate presided over by Mayor Van Wyck.

-- An attentive reading of the letter from "A Friend of M. le Roux" which we published Monday does not reveal any particular reason for withdrawing, or even modifying, our recent comments upon M. LE ROUX'S claim to have written "La Belle Nivernaise." We did not deny the accuracy of his statement, nor did we charge him with lack of affection for ALPHONSE DAUDET.
LONDON, April 28. -- Money was much wanted to-day. The uncertainty as to the future maintained discount rates.

BALTIMORE, April 29. -- The local market was again dull and featureless. Seaboards continued quite firm without being so active as they have been during the past two weeks. The Street is still of the opinion that some deal will evolve from the Louisville and Nashville episode which will inure to the advantage of the Seaboard system.

The rowdyism of certain officers of the United States Navy and Marine Corps in a public place in the City of Venice has drawn upon themselves the attention of the police and upon the United States that of other nations. Is it possible that this out-break is one of the signs of our newly acquired dignity and standing as a world Power? -- From The Evening Post.

About the best horses that have figured in the racing at Aqueduct this Spring made up the programme at the Queens County track yesterday, though in strong contrast with the earlier, part of the meeting, the weather was wintry and with almost a gale blowing in from Jamaica Bay, there was scant comfort for the large crowd that gathered.

The cable has told us curiously little of a matter which has lately been occupying the House of Commons to an extent only second to the chronic question of the South African war itself. That is the latest acute outbreak of the still more chronic Irish question.

The joint committee of representatives of the anthracite coal miners and of the coal carrying companies appointed to try and effect a settlement of the disputed points between the miners and the operators, adjourned yesterday after a session of nearly four hours in the offices of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, without reaching any agreement.

BERLIN, April 29. -- Capt. Adolph Albers of the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland fell dead from heart disease in the charthouse of his vessel as she was approaching the port of Cuxhaven. He expired in the arms of his first officer, who caught him as he fell. The long hours spent by Capt. Albers on the bridge of the vessel after the recent loss of her rudder at sea probably hastened his collapse.

Abraham Conhaim, a well-to-do cloak manufacturer, and Leo Asher, his traveling salesman, were arrested yesterday morning, accused of complicity in the death of Harriet La Rocque, the cloak model who was transferred just before her death from the home of Dr. Mary E. McCleary, 148 West Thirty-fourth Street, to the New York Hospital.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- New York Exchange to-day was 10c premium; time and call loans, 4 1/2 and 5 per cent. Union Traction common was active in the local market to-day at 22 7/8 for the common and 59 1/2 for the preferred. New York interests have been liberal buyers of the common lately, one house there being credited with the purchase of about 50,000 shares.

Prof. FESSENDEN and Mr. MARCONI have full faith in the commercial future of their respective systems of wireless telegraphy. The Marconi system is already in practical observation under commercial conditions, while the professor exuberantly foretells the sale of existing ocean cables for junk.

KEOKUK, Iowa, April 29. -- The California Limited, on the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Road, east bound, was derailed on a curve at Cama, a switch five miles west of Medill, Mo., to-day, while going at tremendous speed. Four persons were killed and twenty-three injured.

At the dinner of the British Schools and Universities Club, which was served in the rooms of the Aldine Association last evening, the subjects of the toasts leaned greatly toward explosives. Hudson Maxim responded to the toast "High Explosives in Modern Warfare," and the Rev. Jean Charlemagne Bracq, Professor of French at Vassar, characterized his speech as a series of firecrackers.

BOSTON, April 29. -- The money market is still in a very easy condition, and with the business doing extremely light. The feeling is now general that present conditions will continue unbroken for some time to come. Sterling exchange is quiet and steady. Clearing house rate, 2 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 8c discount to par; call loans, 3 1/2 to 4; time money, 4 to 4 1/2; exchange, $27,780,525; balances, $2,540,447.

LONDON, April 29. -- The social success of the first Spring race meeting at Newmarket, which commenced to-day, has been assured by the presence of King Edward. The feature to-morrow will be the race for the 2,000 Guinea Stakes, for three-year-olds. in which a number of the Derby candidates will meet.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 29. -- Gov. Gen. William H. Taft of the Philippine Islands was well received this evening, when he addressed about two thousand persons in College Street Hall, at Yale. He was introduced by President A.T. Hadley, who facetiously referred to their college days. Judge Taft in turn complimented President Hadley upon being the man chosen to succeed Dr. Timothy Dwight in the Presidency.
LONDON, April 29. -- United States Consul General Osborne died at his residence in Wimbledon, near here, at 10:30 o'clock this morning.

Considering that our new navy is, in point of ships, scarcely more than a dozen years of age, it has become quite as formidable as we could hope. The magnificent showing of the fleet during the war with Spain made it a common saying in Washington that "the navy could have anything it wanted."

In spite of apprehensions over Archbishop Corrigan's illness excited by the apparently sudden summoning of Dr. E. G. Janeway and the weakness of the patient, the doctors considered the condition of the Archbishop to be so satisfactory last night that no bulletin was issued.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were again of a diversified character, and the trading was on a scale as large as any the market has recently seen. The centre of interest was moved from General Carriage to some other stocks, one of which, Bay State Gas, showed a total of 150,000 shares.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 29. -- May Day is awaited with considerable misgiving in consequence of the anticipations of disturbances. The factories and workshops have been thoroughly canvassed, with the object of promoting the general observation of the day, and the men have been supplied with Social Democratic literature of all kinds, much of a which is couched in markedly temperate language, though the illustrations are somewhat inflammatory.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- A spirited discussion of the Philippine situation occurred in the Senate to-day. It revolved around the order alleged to have been issued by Gen. Jacob A. Smith to make the Island of Samar "a howling wilderness," and to "kill all male inhabitants over the age of ten years."

NEWPORT, R.I., April 29. -- To-day the finishing touches were placed on a memorial window in Trinity Church, the gift of Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt in memory of her husband. The window occupies a prominent place near the north entrance to the church, and as nearly opposite as possible to the pew which for many Summers Mr. Vanderbilt occupied.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 29. -- Kingdon and Jay Gould, the sons of George J. Gould, have the distinction of being the youngest players to wield a mallet in a tournament of the American Polo Association. They played with their father and Ben Nicoll today against the Somerset Polo Club on the Georgian Court grounds, in the second match for the Herbert trophies.

For the first time in several weeks transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday fell below the million share mark. Notwithstanding this the market was a broad and healthy one, with trading well diversified and a substantial public interest appearing. On the whole, though price movements were at times irregular, the undertone was essentially sound, and at the close of the day net advances were the rule and net declines the exception.
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows:

Hugh McLaughlin, the veteran Democratic leader of Kings County, left the Willoughby Street auction room hurriedly yesterday afternoon and walked around to a sporting goods shop on Fulton Street. where he looked over the stock of baseball bats.

Mr. WILLIAM H. CHADWICK, Chairman of the Transportation Committee of the Chicago Board of Trade, advances an interesting argument in favor of irrigation for the arid lands of the West, which, perhaps, has less weight than its ingenious author attaches to it. He says:

Testimony was heard yesterday before Justice O'Gorman in the Supreme Court in the suit brought by Henry H. Wibert against Mrs. Julia Curtiss of 142 West Eighty-sixth Street, who is a sister of Archibald Watt, owner of the yacht American, and of Thomas L. Watt of 509 Fifth Avenue.

The General Committee of the Greater New York Democracy met last evening in Cooper Union, and plans for reorganization for the ensuing year and the coming State campaign were adopted. The meeting was harmonious, and every time any speaker mentioned the name of John C. Sheehan there were cheers.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 29. -- The Ogden party reached Tuskegee early to-day, and the members were driven to the Alabama Conference College, where they were given a reception. They visited the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, Booker T. Washington's school for colored students.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration ever $3,000.
Details will be found in another column relative to the purchase of a residence site on East Fifty-fourth Street by John R. Drexel.

In the rooms of the Barnard Club, at Carnegie Lyceum, yesterday afternoon, Joseph Jefferson gave an address on acting, and answered some questions afterward; questions written upon slips and handed to him. In his talk, Mr. Jefferson insisted that the thing which distinguished the actor's art from all others was the fact that it required constant reproduction.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Owing to the threatening weather the guests invited to Mrs. Roosevelt's garden party this afternoon were received in the East Room, and all outdoor features of the fete were abandoned. The Marine Band was in attendance and played in the red corridor from 4 until 6 o'clock.

By the purchase of the full rights which were recently granted by letters patent to Prof. Michael I. Pupin, of Columbia University, for his system of electrical tuning and receiving, the Marconi Wireless Telegraph Company of America has obtained means of perfecting its present system to a point which they believe will irrevocably distance world-wide competitors in the field of wireless telegraphy.

The Constable Stock Exchange party, the coaching, the smaller entertainments of musicales, luncheons, and dinners gave to yesterday quite an air of gayety. Today the principal event will be the wedding of W. Scott Cameron and Miss de Goicouria, at 12 o'clock, in St. Bartholomew's Church.

LEWES, Del., April 29. -- An explosion which injured half a dozen persons occurred on the submarine boat Fulton today as she was running into the harbor of the Delaware Breakwater. The boat was bound from Brooklyn to Norfolk, and was partly submerged when the accident occurred.

CAPE TOWN, April 29. -- At to-day's hearins, in the Supreme Court, of the charges of forgery brought against Princess Radziwill, the defendant, testifying in her own behalf, swore that the notes were not forgeries and said they were handed to her by Mrs. Schultz, whose husband died since the case was opened.

ROME, April 29. -- The arrest at Venice last Friday night of Capt. Robert F. Wynne, commanding the marine guard of the United States cruiser Chicago; Robert E. Ledbetter, Assistant Surgeon of the Chicago; Lieut. John S. Doddridge of the Chicago, and a marine named Wilfred Langley, on the charge of disorderly conduct, and the sentences of imprisonment imposed upon them yesterday continue to cause a sensation here and at Venice.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Alleged secrets of the Dreyfus case, unknown to many Frenchmen who followed closely the proceedings of the trial, were confided to University of Chicago students yesterday by M. Hugues Le Roux. The French lecturer declared that Capt. Dreyfus admitted guilt at the time he was pardoned.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -- Consolidated Lake Superior was the leader in strength and activity to-day, and imparted a cheerful spirit to the whole market. Consolidated Lake Superior common advanced 8/4 and the preferred 1/2 at the opening. The former then rapidly ran up to 36, the highest price of the recent movement, and the preferred crossed 80.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 29. -- Col. and Mrs. A.L. Wetherell of Philadelphia have arrived at their cottage at Jamestown.

BERLIN, April 29. -- The taking of testimony at the third trial of the two non-commissioned officers, Sergt. Heckel and Sergt. Marten, charged with murdering Capt. Krosigk of the Prussian Cavalry, on account of his harshness, was concluded to-day.
