The Maynooth Alumni Association of the United States had its fourth annual banquet yesterday afternoon at the Catholic Club. The election of officers resulted as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Gen. MacArthur to-day continued his testimony before the Senate Committee on the Philippines, which resumed the examination of witnesses in connection with the investigation of affairs in the Philippines. In the course of his remarks Gen. MacArthur disclaimed any responsibility for the orders of Gen. Jacob H. Smith to make Samar a howling wilderness.
LONDON, April 30. -- Another "authoritative statement" in regard to the shipping combination appeared in yesterday's Liverpool Express.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Argument was heard to-day in the Supreme Court for and against the validity of the findings of the court-martial which declared Capt. Peter C. Deming to be guilty of misappropriation of Government funds, and, in addition to dismissal from the army, imposed a sentence of three years at hard labor in the military prison at Fort Leavenworth, Kan.

W. Bourke Cockran, who has been absent for a month in Europe, returned yesterday on the Kronprinz Wilhelm. He met the reporters smilingly, and apparently was ready to talk on any subject. Before he answered questions he inquired as to the condition of Archbishop Corrigan.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The Omnibus Public Building bill was passed by the House to-day, and the committee's disposition of the New York Post Office matter was the occasion of a hot controversy. Instead of appropriating a certain sum of money for the purchase of a site and the erection of a building.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Discussion of the appointment of James S. Clarkson as Surveyor of the port of New York, continues It is admitted by about all who participate in the discussion that the appointment referred to was an extraordinary one to be made by a President who ever since his political life began has been rated a civil service reformer.

STREET CAR ACCIDENT. -- On the first trial of John George Eberhardt's suit against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company to recover damages for personal injuries, the jury gave him a verdict for $1,000. The trial Justice, however, set it aside as inadequate, and on a trial before another jury the plaintiff succeeded in getting $7,000.

LODI, N.J., April 29. -- Deputy Sheriffs are patrolling the streets and preserving order. The gates of the two silk mills here are guarded carefully, and the bridges leading across the Saddle River are watched because the authorities fear that the striking dyers' helpers of Paterson will come down and wreck the mills.

One of the most exciting poolroom raids which has ever taken place in the Tenderloin was made yesterday afternoon by Capt. Michael Sheehan at an alleged place at 7 West Fourteenth Street. During the space of ten or fifteen minutes he and three of his detectives maintained a fierce hand-to-hand fight with a mob of frantic men trying to escape from the poolroom.

NORFOLK, Va., April 30. -- Prof. R.A. Fessenden, the inventor and developer of the new system of wireless telegraphy, will in future receive and transmit all his Government business over the wireless telegraph from Roanoke Island to Cape Hatteras, and thence by direct Government wire to Norfolk and Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- When consideration of the Philippine Government bill was resumed by the Senate to day. Mr. Patterson (Col.) offered a resciution, for when he asked immediate consentration, directing the Secretary of War the cable Major Gardener,formerly Civil Governor of the Province of Tayabas, to return to the United States to appear as a witness before the Philippine Committee.

Ignace Paderewski, the pianist, who took occasion before his departure to remark that he was $125,000 richer than he was when he landed in America some weeks ago, sailed for Liverpool on the White Star liner Oceanic yesterday. A lot of women were at the pier to see the pianist sail, and many were the complimentary things they said about him, some of which he heard and some that he did not.

Wall Street yesterday was treated to a decided and by no means pleasant surprise in the form of a sharp break of no less than 78 points in the shares of the international Power Company, whose affairs have lately been much before the public. Three weeks ago the stock of the company was selling around par and appeared to be fairly well established there.

The marriage of W. Scott Cameron, son of Mrs. A. Scott Cameron, and Miss Rosalie W. de Goicouria, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert V. de Goicouria, was celebrated at 12 o'clock yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Church, by the Rev. Dr. David H. Greer, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Bridges of Islip, L.I.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- An unfortunate accident to a deaf-and-dumb boy, Isador Baccus, was to-day directly responsible for the death of eight girls and young women, the fatal Injury of three othtrs, and the serious injury of more than two-score of girls employed in the cigar factory of Harburger, Homan Co., a branch of the American Tobacco Company, located at Tenth Street and Washington Avenue.
Yesterday's market was irregular; at times it showed pronounced weakness; net changes for the day were generally declines. Two or three stocks broke badly -- one sensationally.

About 6 o'clock last evening, when Fifth Avenue was crowded with people and vehicles, a team of horses dashed out of West Thirty-first Street and crashed into a carriage occupied by three women, and scared their horses in turn, thus causing a double runaway down the avenue.

An army board, which conducted the test of the Gathman gun at Sandy Hook last year, met yesterday at the Army Building to consider a statement made by Dr. Gathman to the President and the War Department with regard to the results of that test. Dr. Gathman agreed to blow to pieces with his eighteen-inch gun a target put up by the board.

Ten landscapes by Mr. W.L. Lathrop will be on exhibition at the Macbeth Gallery, 237 Fifth Avenue, until May 11. During the past two years this painter has shown himself in the forefront of the landscapists through the justness and delicacy of his touch, the sobriety and gentle charm of the brush work that renders in preference the quietest scenes of Winter and Autumn in the country.

Commissioner STEWART of the Building Department has set an example of impartial and intelligent law enforcement in the matter of fire-proofed wood which is at once educational and disciplinary to those who under the malign rule of Tammany had things wholly their own way -- provided, of course, they lubricated the way adequately.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Secretary Long closed his official career as the head of the Navy Department to-day. The event was unmarked save by the calling of many friends to take official leave of the retiring Secretary. Among to-day's callers were Secretary Hay and Mr. Moody, Secretary Long's successor.
With about the worst class horses in training making up the programme for the six races of the afternoon, the inducements of the sport offered at the Aqueduct track were tested fairly yesterday.

Henry H. Wibert, seventy years old, who sued Mrs. Julia Curtiss for $23,500, the balance of $25,000 alleged to be due to him for services he had performed for the defendant in bringing about her marriage with Dr. Rollin A. Curtiss, recovered a verdict before Justice O'Gorman in the Supreme Court yesterday of $13,500.

LOUISVILLE, April 30. -- The wedding of Miss Katherine Price and Herbert Spencer of St. Louis took place at 4 o'clock this afternoon at the Second Presbyterian Church. The church was elaborately decorated in white and green. The altar was banked in tropical greens, augmented by large clusters of Ascension lilies.

Wilbur Stephens, the eight-year-old son of Elwyn J. Stephens, a grain merchant of Wilkesbarre, Penn., was killed yesterday in Central Park. He was run over by a hansom cab on the west drive, near Seventy-second Street. This was at the crossing which the nurses and children must use to go to the Mall.

BERLIN, April 30. -- Business on the Boerse to-day was quiet. Internationals were steady. Italians advanced sharply. Railroad obligations and Mines were stronger on bear covering. Canadian Pacifies were easier on London advices.

The Manhattan College baseball team was victorious at Jasper Oval yesterday in the game with the Columbia University nine by a score of 6 to 1. For Manhattan, Callahan's pitching was the feature of the game, and at critical moments he always proved equal to emergencies. He allowed five hits to be made off him in addition to two bases on balls, but he struck out four men.

BOSTON, April 30. -- The money market showed a slightly firmer tone to-day, the usual accompaniment of the closing day of the month. Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 and 3 per cent; New York funds, 5c discount; call loans, 3 1/2 to 4 per cent.; time money, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $26,791,227; balances, $1,721,642. The stock market was weak to-day, the coppers being all off.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 30. -- The members of the Robert C. Ogden party were royally entertained in Knoxville to-day and to-night. The Ogden special reached this city at 1:20 o'clock, and was met by a large Reception Committee, headed by Dr. Charles W. Dabney, President of the University of Tennessee.

The proverbial suitableness of goose sauce as a condiment for the grander seems to have escaped the attention of the farmers of Kansas who have undertaken to "throttle the Grain Trust" by a combination in restraint of trade which, being of their own making and for their own benefit, seems to them all right.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 30. -- The Lakewood second team defeated the polo team of the Camden Country Club on the Georgian Court grounds this afternoon in the third game for the Herbert trophies. George J. Gould was referee. The Camden players received a handicap allowance of five goals. They earned but one goal in addition, and lost half of this in penalties for making safety plays.

The Century Run Committee of the New York State Division, Century Road Club of America, has arranged a decided innovation for the finish of its sixth annual open Spring century run from Brooklyn to Oakdale, L.I., and return on May 18. After dinner at Babylon, a racing division will be formed which will race the thirty-seven miles from that place to the finish at Bedford Rest, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Ma 1. -- The Associated Press has been informed that all the steamship lines concerned in the Atlantic shipping combination, with the exception of the White Star Line, have already arranged with their, stockholders to enter the combine.
CAPE HAITIEN, Haiti, April 30. -- The Dominican revolutionists are at present in the vicinity of Santo Domingo and Cotui, which cities, it is reported here, they contemplate attacking to-morrow.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- District Attorney S.H. Bethea heard to-day the stories of two men who will be valuable witnesses for the Government in its efforts to prove the existence of the Meat Trust. One of them, Fred Silberhorn of 6,825 Perry Avenue, told of the effectual nature of the packers' blacklist agreement.

The basket ball tournament for the championship of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, now in progress in the gymnasium of the National Athletic Club, 11 and 13 Cedar Street, Brooklyn, was practically decided last night as far as the championship is concerned by the victory of the Seventeenth Separate Company of Flushing over the team of the National Athletic Club, their strongest rival.

E.P. Price won the remaining semi-final match yesterday afternoon in the championship hand tennis tournament at the New York Athletic Club. His opponent was Samuel T. Shaw, who failed to stand before the smashing tactics which Mr. Price put into practice. At no stage of the competition did Mr. Shaw make an adequate defense.

LONDON, April 30. -- This year's exhibition of the Royal Academy, the private view of which is to be held on Friday, will, it is expected, surpass the shows of recent years both in variety and excellence. Americans will, as usual, be largely represented among the exhibitors.

Samuel Goldsticker has sold for Jerome Bernheimer, as trustee, to Robert W. Tailer 644 Madison Avenue, a lot 25 by 108, now occupied by a four-story dwelling. The property adjoins the Hoffman Arms apartment house at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. It is said that Mr. Tailer intends to erect a ten-story building on the lot.

One of the best stones for men's wear is the cat's-eye, and it is always in good taste. One of the big jewelers has a beautiful stone, large and deep, mounted in a scarfpin, simply, with only the tiniest rim of gold showing. The cat's-eye is too beautiful a stone in itself to be spoiled with diamonds, which make it tawdry.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission is to be reorganized and the present Commissioners have agreed to resign. This news was made public yesterday by Mayor Low after the meeting of the Board of Estimate, at which it was voted to give to the new President of the Municipal Civil Service Commission a salary of $6,000 a year.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, April 30. -- The wedding of Bertrand F. Bell of New York City and Miss Beatrice Boggs of Chillicothe, took place this afternoon at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Chillicothe. The Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix officiated.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- If it had been left to the New York delegation to write the provision with reference to a new Post Office for New York City that was to go into the Public Buildings bill undoubtedly the clause would have carried an appropriation. At the same time, only a few of the delegation complain much about the provision as it stands.

The curb had a somewhat exciting day yesterday. The sudden drop in General Carriage was the principal event of the day and the principal direct cause of the unsettled state of the market at the close. A number of the stocks which had been advancing with General Carriage were unfavorably affected, and closed weak, although none of them suffered to as great an extent as did Carriage.

All liquor tax certificates issued under the Raines law for, 1901 to 1902 expired at midnight last night. The prediction was made at the, office of Deputy Commissioner George Hilliard and at the offices of the bonding companies at 1 Madison Avenue that many places that were open yesterday would be closed to-day.
LONDON, April 30. -- A strong month-end demand for money to-day caused discounts to become firmer.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day, by a strict party vote, refused to subpoena Major Cornelius Gardener, Aguinaldo, Sixto Lopez, and Mabini. The question of send- ing a sub-committee to the Philippines to continue the investigation was passed over.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 30. -- The first extra inning baseball contest of the season on the local diamond was won by New York this afternoon by the score of 6 to 5. It required twelve innings to decide the game, which was by far the best that has been witnessed in this city this year. New York won through the magnificent pitching of Sparks.

Three policemen of the East Fifty-first Street Station had an exciting time at 1 o'clock this morning in a man chase through Madison and Fifth Avenues, about Forty-sixth Street, and the residents of that district were thrown into great excitement when a half dozen pistol shots rang out, and they heard cries of "Stop or we'll Shoot."

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The present anti-imperialist campaign against the American army, based on the severity of the recent warfare in the Philippines, proceeds on the theory that such incidents are unknown in American history, and that in undertaking to subjugate an Asiatic people the American character has become debased and ferocious.

Negotiations now pending between prominent real estate interests will, it is believed, result in the sale of the Plaza Hotel. John A. McCall, President of the New fork Life Insurance Company, which corporation holds title to the property, could not be reached last evening. From an authoritative source, however, it was learned that a deal involving the hotel is in process of development.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Miss Laura Robie, daughter of Commodore and Mrs. E.D. Robie, and Dr. A.G. Gunwell of the United States Navy were married at the Church of the Covenant this afternoon by the Rev. Tunis S. Hamlin. The ushers, who seated the company and later led the bridal party, were all brother officers of the bridegroom, and, like him, were in full dress uniform.

CAPE TOWN, April 30. -- Princess Radziwill, who has been on trial here before the Supreme Court on the charge of forgery in connection with notes purporting to have been indorsed by the late Cecil Rhodes, was sentenced to-day to two years' imprisonment.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration ever $3,000.

Yesterday was a day of weddings and departures. There were any number of nuptial events, and the ships bound for the other half of the world sailed away with crowded passenger lists. To-day being Mayday, there is very little on the tapis.

Transactions in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange during the month of April were, in the aggregate, far in excess of any month since last May, while the sales of bonds reached a heavier total than in any month since April of last year.

The cost of governing the City of New York in 1902 will be $98,619,600. The Board of Estimate, presided over by Mayor Van Wyck, adopted a budget last October appropriating $97,974,541. The budget approved yesterday by Mayor Low and the other members of the present Board of Estimate shows an increase of $645,059 over the Van Wyck budget.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 1. -- There was pronounced dullness in to-day's local market, the general list being more or less lagging in movement, except Maryland Telphone 5s and Western Maryland stock. The latter was higher on expectations of deriving good terms from the Fuller syndicate, which, it is now generally believed, will secure the road.

There will be no large entertainments of any description to-day nor in fact any notable events. To-morrow the opening of the Morris Park races and the coaching parade, the golf at Ardsley, the golfing afternoon at Morristown, hunt at Meadow Brook, and the polo at Lakewood will be among the diversions which at this time of the year are chiefly suburban in character.
WASHINGTON, May 1. -- It will be at least two weeks, I reckon," a Democratic Senator said to-day, "before we get to voting on the Philippines Civil Government bill."
District Attorney Jerome yesterday morning had some things to say in regard to an attack by a morning newspaper on the administration of his office.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- The Philadelphia market continued to present a more cheerful aspect. Philadelphia Company again crossed 50, and showed an inclination to improve, albeit the usual amount of long stock was forthcoming in the advance. The Readings were in good demand on the belief that the conference on the labor situation had agreed on a basis of peace.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Major Gen. MacArthur to-day continued his testimony before the Senate Committee on the Philippines. Answering a question by Senator Culberson, the General stated that Aguinaldo and the Filipino people were justified in concluding that the actions of the United States Army were sympathetic.

GALVESTON, Texas, May 1. -- During the last three months more than 1,000,000 tons of steel rails have gone into Mexico via this port, caused by the railroad building now under way in the southern republic.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The French Ambassador and Mme. Cambon were "at home" this afternoon at the new Embassy on Rhode Island Avenue. On this occasion Washington society had its first opportunity of meeting Mme. Cambon, who until now has been prevented by the illness of their young daughter from living with her husband in the American capital.

The lecture by Prof. E.S. MEADE of the University of Pennsylvania on the United States Steel Corporation, which we reported yesterday morning, discusses in a somewhat radical fashion questions of great interest, not only to shareholders in the Steel Corporation, but to the entire business community.

When the British freight steamship Sir Richard Grenville, from West Indian ports, loaded with sugar, arrived yesterday afternoon, the Captain, David Jones, told of the tragic death on board his vessel of two West Indian stowaways.

Col. Michael J. Dady of Brooklyn is cast down and sad of heart these blithe May days. The Colonel wants to get out of politics, but his friends won't let him. Despite most strenuous and determined efforts on his part to retire from public life he is still in it, reluctantly drawing $5,000 a year as an Elections Commissioner.

At the hearing given by the ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives on the bill introduced by Mr. LOVERING of Massachusetts, to simplify the drawback system, the testimony presented was well calculated to show that the provisions of the Dingley bill on this point were designed to "keep the word of promise to the ear and break it to the hope."

LONDON, May 2. -- An attempt was made in the House of Commons yesterday to induce the Government to pledge itself to prevent the transfer of British steamships to a foreign flag, pending the report of the committee (under the Chairmanship of the Earl of Camperdown) recently appointed by the Admiralty to inquire into the subject.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- President Henry O. Havemeyer of the American Sugar Refining Company testified to-day before the Senate Committee that is charged with ascertaining what amount of Cuban sugar the company owns and what, if any, interests it has in securing tariff reductions by the United States in favor of Cuban products.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Replying to questions by Senator Platt, at the Cuban sugar investigation, begun to-day; H.O. Havemeyer said his company was generally known as the Sugar Trust and that its refineries are located as follows: In New Jersey, 1; New York, 3; Massachusetts, 2; Philadelphia, 2, and New Orleans, 1.
Mayor Low and Bridge Commissioner Lindenthal explained to the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday afternoon the plans for relieving the congestion of traffic at the Brooklyn Bridge.

NEWARK, N.J., May 1. -- Judge Swayze in the Circuit Court to-day granted a rule to show cause why the verdict of $9,000 recently obtained from the North Jersey Street Railway Company by John Vogel, a boy who lost his leg by being run over by a trolley car, should be set aside.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The Senate to-day resumed consideration of the Philippine Government bill, and Mr. Carmack (Tenn.) continued his remarks of yesterday. He said he could see no good reason for the majority's refusal to summon Aguinaldo, Mabini, and other Filipinos to appear as witnesses before the Senate Committee on the Philippines.
ST. LOUIS, May 1. -- A statement was given out this evening by President David R. Francis of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition Company, in which he says:

The water-curists of New York, who for some months have been looking forward to May 1, enjoyed yesterday for the first time this year their regular morning openair indulgence in mineral waters at "Little Carlsbad" in Central Park.

ORANGE, N.J., May 1. -- To-day being the feast of St. Philip and St. James in the Anglican calendar, was chosen by the rector, wardens, and vestry of Grace Church, Orange, for the "service of benediction" of the new choir and sanctuary of the church, which constitutes the Anthony Schuyler Memorial.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The season for the passing of work is approaching. Fishermen that fall to mend their nets cease after a while to catch fish. Those that have cast and hauled month in and month out without repair need soon to sit aside and have mending done.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 1. -- Hundreds of delegates representing every section of the United States were present at the opening of the biennial convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs in Simpson Auditorium this afternoon.

The Socialist Labor Party and their kindred organization, the Socialist Trades and Labor Alliance, celebrated yesterday their international festival known as May Day. In the evening the amphitheatre of Cooper Union was filled to the doors with sympathizers, who listened with great enthusiasm to the speeches.

E.P. Price won the hand tennis championship of the New York Athletic Club yesterday afternoon. His victory gives him the title for the second consecutive year, and the performances of this sterling player on the indoor courts mark him as the ranking player of the game in this country.

Coroner Scholer yesterday inquired into the case of Theresa McMahon, who died on Monday in the Manhattan State Hospital for the Insane, on Ward's Island. Though the death certificate ascribed death to pneumonia, Coroner's Physician Weston, at the autopsy Wednesday afternoon, found a number of injuries on the body, and thought it probable that death had resulted from pleurisy superinduced by the injuries.

The representatives of the United Mine Workers who are in this city held an informal conference at the Ashland House yesterday, but declined to talk on the question as to whether any concessions had been made on Wednesday at the meeting in the office of the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

Fifty-five golfers finished the qualifying round yesterday at Garden City in the opening event of the club's invitation tournament. In respect to excellent golf material, it was one of the best fields that has been brought together in a long time. The only particularly prominent local player not in evidence was Findlay Douglas.

DUSSELDORF, May 1. -- Crown Prince Frederick William opened the exposition of Rhenish-Westphalian Industry and German Art here to-day. The President of the exposition, in the opening address, made use of the words of President McKinley: "Expositions are the timekeepers of progress."

The present low level of our exports of iron and steel reflects very clearly the indifference of manufacturers under the conditions existing at the moment to the creation and conservation of foreign outlets for their products. They have no surplus for export, and while this is true they cannot be expected to show much enterprise in looking after foreign business.

ALBANY, May 1. -- Ex-Controller Bird S. Coler of New York City held a long conference with ex-Senator David B. Hill here to-day. He stated that his visit was for the purpose of discussing plans for organizing the Democratic Party. Asked if the names of any available candidates for Governor had been discussed, he said they had not.

All sorts of odd things in veils. One lot looks as if they had pussy willow all over them. Queer pussy willows, to be sure, but then there is the resemblance. The dots are of chenille, of an odd, soft olive green shade, and in the centre a little touch of rose. Other dots in similar style have black with blue in the centre or with white.
The order directing First Lieut. Herman W. Schull, Artillery Corps, to report to Major William F. Stewart, Artillery Corps, for examination for detail in the Ordnance Department, is revoked.

We have been outdone in politeness by the King of Italy, whose pardon of the officers of the Chicago recently sentenced for rowdyism in Venice accompanied by an order for their release will everywhere in this country be regarded as a most friendly act, a proof and confirmation of the amicable relations subsisting between the two countries.

A statement has been issued by the New York Life Insurance Company confirming the reports published yesterday that the Plaza Hotel property has been sold for about $3,000,000. The purchasers, it is announced, are a syndicate which includes "Some of the shrewdest real estate holders who have been investing very heavily of late in Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street properties."

More than 150 members attended yesterday the one hundred and thirty-fourth annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce at the headquarters, 32 Nassau Street, Morris K. Jesup presided. Secretary George Wilson was absent owing to serious illness.

For the second time this season, with Mathewson pitching, the New York baseball team "shut out" the Philadelphia Club at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Not a man on the Philadelphia team reached third base.

A marked falling off in transactions occurred in the outside market yesterday. For the first time since the beginning of the recent activity totals in nearly all stocks were small and, for the most part, the fluctuations in prices were unimportant as compared with the movements which were in progress during the preceding ten days.

Dr. Watson L. Savage, Director of the Columbia gymnasium, yesterday sent to Dr. Dudley A. Sargent of Harvard, Chairman of the Intercollegiate Strength Test Committee, the list of Columbia's fifty strong men, who are the representatives of the university in the annual competition to select the intercollegiate fifty strong men of the United States.

The twelfth annual dinner-of the lecturers and others interested in the free lecture courses of the Board of Education was held at the Hotel St. Denis last evening. There were about 250 people present, and a reception preceded the dinner, at which the diners were presented to the principal guests of the evening.

International Power stock, which on the Slock Exchange on Wednesday broke precipitately 78 points from 198 to 120, further distinguished itself yesterday by another sharp drop -- this time of 19 points, to 101, with the closing figure but two points above this low price, and marking a net decline for the day of 17 points.

PITTSBURG, May 1. -- Nine organized building trades in the Pittsburg district started the conflict this morning for higher wages. Many of the employers agreed to the demands during the day, and at its close there was every indication that the struggle will be of short duration. Of the 12,000 men who were ordered out this morning, probably not more than 6,000 will be idle to-morrow.

"Die Rothe Robe" by Eugen Brieux, was produced Wednesday night for the first time in America at the Irving Place Theatre, and, as it affords exceptional opportunities for an all-star cast of the visiting players, it will be continued for the rest of the week. It is a theatrical ventilation of the evils of the law, and especially of French law.

Wearing neither hat nor coat and quite urable to give an account of himself, a man was found last night by Policeman Corey of the Delancey Street Station wandering aimlessly about East and Grand Streets. He said he was a broker and that he was married. Asked his name by the Sergeant in the station house, he said he was not sure about it.

The pertinacity with which the search for new remedies for snake bite is carried on by medical men and others is amazing. Not that the danger from snakes is not serious, for it is. The Indian Lancet is gratified to note that "only 893 persons in India were killed by snake bites during last year, which is a great decrease as compared with preceding years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial under the above caption appearing in your issue of April 28 in terse and concise manner covers the ground of the present conditions existing in Holland. The relationship between Queen and nation is relevantly declared. The results of an unhoped-for fatality are not so well put forward.

-- Intimately mingled grief and indignation fill the breast of The Halifax Herald because a Toronto manufacturer has just received from an English merchant a letter in which the merchant adds to his order the direction: "Supply us with a Consular certificate, proving your goods to be American, to enable us to return them to the United States free of duty."

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The monthly comparative statement of the Government receipts and expeditures shows that during the month of April, 1902, the total receipts were $45,215,390, a decrease, as compared with April, 1901, of $2,552,000. The expenditures for the month aggregated $40,799,263, which leaves a surplus for the month of $4,316,000.

The playing season of the Eastern League of Professional Baseball Clubs began yesterday. The Canadian teams from Montreal and Toronto played in Rochester and Buffalo respectively, and the New Jersey teams from Newark and Jersey City played as named in Worcester and Providence.

BERLIN, May 1. -- American energy and American millions are making themselves felt in China more and more powerfully," said Field Marshal Count von Waldersee in an interview at Dresden, where he is visiting the King of Saxony. He added:

At the Victoria Theatre last night the Roberval company from New Orleans presented Lecocq's "Le Jour et la Nuit." This work is quite unfamiliar to the local public, but might readily bear a better acquaintance. It would always have to be performed in French, for a translation into English would either cross the line of the accepted proprieties or eliminate from the book the points which make it amusing.

"Ganymede," described as a slight opera in three acts, produced for the first time in New York, the libretto and music by Stella Prince Stocker, served as the entertainment for the annual benefit of the Vassar Students' Aid Society, given at Carnegie Lyceum last night before a fashionable audience which filled the theatre.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In a recent excellent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS upon "Biographies." the writer made some very unjust criticisms upon modern novels. He made the assertion that women, half-grown girls, and boys were the chief readers of fiction, and then said that "the fiction" of the day "could not possibly be worse than it is, nor could it show fewer signs of improvement."

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The War Department is just now receiving a terrific hammering because of its alleged efforts to conceal the cost of maintaining control of the Philippines, the statistics about which the Democrats are anxious to get. A Washington newspaper began it with a charge that Secretary Root was withholding the information which had been demanded by the Senate, Senators Culberson, Wellington, and Carmack confirmed this on the floor of the Senate.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- William A. Brady announced to-day that he had secured "Frou Frou" from the Augustin Daly estate, and will make a special production of the play, with Grace George in the role of Gilberte. The first performance will occur during Miss George's engagement at the Grand Opera House here, and afterward the piece may be presented on a Spring tour of the country.

Robert Little, editor of The North China News, which is published at Shanghai, is the city, and is stopping at the Buckingham. Mr. Little, who is one of the best posted men in the Far East on Chinese affairs, talked interestingly last evening about present conditions in China.

Superlatives only are in harmony with the expectations of turf leaders for the opening this afternoon of the Morris Park Spring meeting. Then, according to the Jockey Club calendar, the racing season in New York will have its real opening.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 2 -- The instigators of the peasant riots in the Voronezh and Kharkoff Governments (who succeeded in bringing the peasants and land owners into collision by circulating the report that the Czar had ordered the lands of the nobles to be divided among the emancipated serfs) prove to be identical with the organizers of the student movement here.

Fifty thousand dollars' worth of jewelry, consisting of thirteen pieces, set with over one hundred diamonds, more than four hundred pearls, besides amethysts and emeralds, were stolen from Mr. and Mrs. Henry Steers, 10 East Thirty-eighth Street, on April 17 and recovered last night. Mr. Steers is President of the Eleventh Ward Bank.

MANILA, May 2 -- The trial by courtmartial of Arthur Howard, alias Waller, a deserter from the United States Army, who was captured in August last by Lieut. Hazzard of the Third Cavalry, was concluded to-day. Howard's trial on the charge of desertion was delayed owing to his being used as a civilian scout under Gen. J. Franklin Bell in the latter's campaign against the insurgents in Batangas Province.

FROM the press of the Macmillan Company, May 7, will come "The Deer Family," by Theodore Roosevelt, T.S. Van Dyke, A.J. Stone, and D.G. Elliot. It is the first volume of the American Sportsman's Library, edited by Casper Whitney, which will be completed in ten octavo volumes.
LONDON, May 2 -- King Edward's second Court was held this evening at Buckingham Palace.

LONDON, April 15 -- Mr. Rhodes's will is the topic of the hour. Every one seems to approve of the provision for sending Americans to Oxford, but no one seems to be quite sure as to what the result will be. Will the Americans Americanize Oxford, or will Oxford Anglicize the Americans?

A number of people, perhaps twenty-five in all, were gathered in front of the tall Queen Building, at Cedar and William Streets, last night about 7 o'clock, watching the motor wagon of the Hall's Safe Company with its electric hoisting apparatus taking a three-ton safe from the eighth to the fifteenth story of the building.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- The course of prices in the Philadelphia stock market reflected the decline in Wall Street, and outside of Electric Storage and a few minor stocks all issues closed lower. The Readings were notably heavy, and following their downward lead the market ran off quite easily in the last ten minutes.

Col. Partridge, Commissioner of Police, expressed his latest opinion of the police force yesterday. He said he thought the force had improved very much since he had been made Commissioner. Several months ago, he recalled, one could see patrolmen chatting in groups of two or three in the streets, whereas now they kept their coats buttoned and assumed a much better appearance.

The fourteenth Arbor Day was observed extensively in the city yesterday. School children, beneficiaries, and teachers in missions, and the social settlement contingent were the principal ones who honored the occasion.

FISHKILL LANDING, May 2 -- To-day Gen. Duboist Brinckerhoff, a veteran horse owner and trainer, is thankful that ex-Fire Commissioner John J. Scannell of New York chanced along through this part of Dutchess County just as his home was about to be sold.
Trade advices to the several commercial agencies continue altogether favorable. Bradstreet's reviews the situation as follows:

FOR many years Mr. Colquhoun has been known to a pretty important public as a traveler, an administrator, and a writer, and he is something of a student. He is observant, he writes agreeably, and he has the gift of keen interest in his subjects. He collects great bodies of real information and he conveys that information to his readers in a manner so simple and lively that one may read his books without fatigue.

M. L. Hess have sold for Frederick T. Mason of Philadelphia 11, 13, 15, and 17 Wooster Street, old buildings on a plot 104 by 100, together with the abutting plot 311 to 319 West Broadway, 96 by 100. The purchasers are Samuel Green, William Rosenzweig, and Bernard Klingenstein. This property has been held in the Mason family for over forty years.

LONDON, May 3 -- In the House of Lords yesterday the Earl of Rosslyn (who served with Thorneycroft's Horse in South Africa and afterward acted as war correspondent for a newspaper) questioned the Government on the subject of the money distributed to British prisoners of war at Pretoria early in 1900 by ths late Adelbert S. Hay, (United States Consul at Pretoria.)

Dr. Bixby's book takes its title from its first chapter, but while all the chapters have an underlying unity of thought, of formal connection among them there is not very much. What we have, in fact, is a series of articles written from different impulses at different times, and now brought together in an arrangement that gives them the utmost possible appearanoe of coherency and continuity.

BALTIMORE, May 2 -- Congressman Amos J. Cummings of New York died at 10:15 o'clock to-night at the Church Home and Infirmary in this city. The cause of death was pneumonia, incident to an operation. The Congressman's wife and cousin, Charles H. Cummings, were at his bedside when death came.

In his recent address before the Massachusetts Library Club President Eliot of Harvard said he had "asked, and proposes to continue to ask, for another method of storing books than we have now in use." He bases his request on the fact that books may be divided into the live and the dead; books which are often needed and those which are very rarely, if ever, needed.

As the United States of America take on years and grow further away from that era which was to us in a sense a Heroic Age -- the Colonial Period -- those characters who figured proudly and struck boldly in that time will come to us with a new meaning, with a story vibrant with charm, and with a lesson which has not been learned.

Yesterday's security market was disturbed. Quotations declined, not largely, but persistently, throughout the day, closing prices being very generally the lowest. Money rates on call were still stiff, some hardening showing in time loan rates; and this feature was accepted by the theorists of the Stock Exchange as accounting for weakness in stocks.

A Board of Survey, to consist of Major Charles Byrne. Thirtieth Infantry, and Capt. Joseph P. Clark, Assistant Surgeon, is appointed to assemble from time to time at the General Depot of the Quartermaster's Department, Philadelphia, for the purpose of ascertaining and fixing responsibility for any deficiencies or damage to Quartermaster's property received at that depot during the present calendar year.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The House today passed the Anti-Conspiracy bill reported, from the Judiciary Committee without debate. Mr. Littlefield, (Me.,) who had filed a minority report and intended to offer amendments, came in just as it was put upon its passage, and the vote was taken before he realized it.

W.H. Moody, the new Secretary of the Navy, will be the guest of honor at the opening exercises of the handsome six-story building just completed for the Naval Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association in Sands Street, Brooklyn, only a few minutes' walk from the navy yard. Miss Helen M. Gould save the money for the erection of the building, and it is expected that she will participate in the dedication.

Wall Street was surprised yesterday by a most discomforting sequel to the collapse of International Power in the shape of heavy declines in all the stocks of the so-called Webb-Meyer syndicate, some of them traded in on the Stock Exchange and others in the outside market. The market for all of these stocks practically disappeared, with the result that the whole market was unsettled, and closed with numerous losses through the list.

The baker's dozen of American painters who have been chosen as representatives of American art are selected without reference to period or school. They seem to have occurred to the writer as men whose works make the greatest impression on him, not as men whose output has been epoch-making or represent a class.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Arthur Donner, Treasurer of the American Sugar Refining Company, to-day testified before the Senate Committee on Cuban Relations concerning American holdings of Cuban sugar. He said that Mr. Havemeyer's statement yesterday to the effect that his company had purchased 93,000 tons of sugar since the 1st of January last was correct.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- President Roosevelt himself may have to take the responsibility of passing upon the charges that have piled up against the Chicago packers. So serious has the evidence before District Attorney Bethea become that he feels the whole matter should be laid before Attorney General Knox, who is in close touch with the White House.

Several days ago an account was printed in the main sheet of THE NEW YORK TIMES of the curtailment of the teaching force in the Department of Comparative Literature at Columbia, of which Prof. George E. Woodberry is the head, and of the wide criticism which had been aroused by the step.

The young men of the University of Indianapolis who were chosen to maintain in public debate "that pie is of greater service to mankind than ice cream "were not faithful to their important trust. Probably a chivalrous sentiment toward the young women who took the ice-cream end of the controversy led them to withhold the convincing facts of their side.

LONDON, May 2 -- The announcement that King Oscar of Sweden is writing his memoirs has caused some excitement in the book-publishing world, as the work is sure to have a tremendous sale, no other man in Europe to-day having so large a knowledge of international affairs from the inside.

VICTOR HUGO began his career with the legend "Je veux etre Chateaubriand." It was at a time when the literary reputation of the author of "Atala," "Rene," and "Genie du Christianisme" was at its height.

THERE are no revelations in Sir Wemyss Reid's "Life of William Black." It portrays just the man a reader of Black's novels would expect to find -- hard-working, upright, kindly, never rising to great heights or sinking to low depths of mental efficiency, fond of nature, fond of friends and family, and with a strain of pure romance united to a Scotchman's native reticence.

WORK that will attract wide attention, and from the point of view of the critic,meet with strong approbation or disapprobation, is Charles A. Hanna's "The Scotch-Irish." The historian has delved into well-nigh virgin soil.

LODI, N.J., May 2 -- There was danger of serious trouble here to-day. The strikers have become unruly and are making threats. Violence was feared all day, and every precaution was taken to meet the threatened outbreak. Early this morning Deputy Sheriff Blauvelt, who was in charge of the special officers, telephoned to Sheriff Soley for twelve more men.

PATERSON, N.J., May 2 -- There was great cheering at the meeting of the striking carpenters to-day when it was announced that J.P. Vanderbeek, one of the bosses, had signed the men's schedule. No other change was reported in the situation.

From Birmingham, England, emanates an eight-page "list of books wanted" by a well-known bookseller. The list includes the titles of many rarities, some of exceeding value, so seldom seen, indeed, that only two or three copies have come into the auction room within a long experience, and all are priced at low sums.

The appointment of Commissioner of Pensions EVANS to be Consul General at London must, we suppose, be taken as the "promotion" which is expected to close the incident of his removal from the post which he has occupied so long and with such conspicuous fidelity and efficiency.

The Rev. Dr. Beverley Warner is one of the shining lights of the Episcopal Church in the South. He is rector of Christ Church, New Orleans, and an active participator in the progress of his adopted city. He has shown himself to be a man of catholic tastes and solid scholarship in his two books, "The Facts and the Faith," and "English History in Shakespeare's Plays."

HOW many years must a man have lived to be rightfully called aged? Of course, in the case of a woman this question would be regarded as inadmissible. I have lately seen drifting through the newspapers a paragraph in which Joaquin Miller was twice referred to as "the aged poet."
Under the above caption an evening newspaper a few days ago published the following dispatch from Washington:

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- There was a conference here to-day regarding the anthracite coal mining labor situation, participated in by Senator Hanna, the Chairman of the Conciliation Committee of the National Civic Federation; President John Mitchell of the United Mine Workers, and Frank P. Sargent of the Locomotive Firemec.

It was hardly necessary for the District Attorney to defend his action and inaction in the McAuliffe case. "Trial by newspaper" has some advantages in some cases which lawyers are very reluctant to allow it. It has its serious drawbacks which journalists are very seldom willing to admit, and which they are never willing to admit in a case in which they themselves are playing the part of public prosecutor.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 2 -- From present indications when the sixth biennial of the General Federation of Women's Clubs shall have closed there is a strong possibility of there arising two distinct federations. That this is not only a possibility but a probability is a turn of affairs that many already are preparing to accept.

With the establishment of the new National University, indorsed by Mr. Andrew Carnegie, Washington will take a long step toward becoming the literary centre of America, that the city is ideally fitted to be. The university will, of course, attract many of the loading scholars of the country, as well as many of those people directly or indirectly associated with letters who enjoy living in a literary atmosphere.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 2 -- President Roosevelt to-day personally handed his diploma to each member of the graduating class at the Naval Academy, and he addressed the class as a whole upon their duties as officers of the United States Navy. The special train that conveyed the President arrived here at 9:45 o'clock this morning.

There are moments when Mr. Howells compels the whole-hearted allegiance due a "captain of letters," and other moments wherein one is tempted to send the volume in hand careering on a swift "errand of emphasis" to the furthest corner of the room!

LONDON, May 3. -- The Earl of Rosslyn, who has been known as an actor under the name of James Erskine, has figured in the Divorce Court, has been amusing as a war correspondent, and who lately tried in vain to break the bank at Monte Carlo, appeared for a change yesterday as a hereditary legislator.

Cyrus Townsend Brady's "Hobeozollern". A friend of Cyrus Townsend Brady recently received a communication from the writer, in which he corrects a "few errors or misapprehensions" in certain reviews of his book.
LONDON, May 2 -- The tendency of money was somewhat easier to-day, though there was a good demand.

In devoting a volume to the study of the chronicle plays or historical dramas, Prof. Schelling has brought forward into its true literary perspective a body of material most important for the study of the Elizabethan drama as a whole, but which has been too often slurred over in order to give in more detail the facts connected with the Italian influences and the classical movement of that period.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Republican Senators have decided to join actively in the debate on the Philippine Civil Government bill. When the debate opened their plan was to allow the Democrats to do the talking, and when they had talked themselves out, to say a few words in reply, and then let the bill go to a vote.

HENRY S. HARRIS, ex-Member of Congress, died suddenly of heart disease yesterday at Belvidere, N.J. He was fifty-two years old. He was a leading member of the New Jersey bar, and was at one time Prosecutor of Pleas of Warren County. He leaves a wife and one daughter.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 2 -- The local market seems to be falling back into a dull rut. Nothing is active or strong except those issues which are affected by rumors of deals. Maryland and Pennsylvania stock advanced further to-day, the gossip being that there is a dicker going on between the Reading and Alexander Brown Sons, which latter own the controlling interest in the road.

Reports current in educational circles are to the effect that Dr. W.H. Maxwell will resign as Superintendent of the Public Schools to accept the Presidency of the College of the City of New York, from which Gen. Webb is expected to retire on the pension provided for by an act passed by the Legislature last Winter.

LAKEWOOD, N.J, May 2 -- The WestChester Country Club met defeat for the second time in the polo tournament on the Georgian Court grounds this afternoon. The Lakewood first team, consisting of George J. Gould and his sons, Kingdon Gould and Jay Gould, with Ben Nicoll, won the semifinal match for the Herbert Cups, by a score of 4 1/2 to 2.

Alderman Bridges of Brooklyn became a lion of society yesterday in the City Hall. The Alderman conquered the exclusive circles in one bound and by one speech. Some of the women of these circles shook his hand and treated him with much effusiveness. The occasion was a hearing of the Committee of Public Education on a plan to make of the old Hall of Records a National Historical Museum.

BERLIN, May 2 -- To-day's meeting of the Tariff Committee of the Reichstag was largely devoted to a discussion of the monopoly of the Standard Oil Company in Germany, and various motions with a view to breaking this monopoly or encouraging the substitution of alcohol for petroleum were proposed.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I wish to bring to your notice a system of free traveling libraries that has accomplished magnificent results in the South. No recent movement for the public weal in the South has won such quick and ready sympathy as the Andrew Carnegie Free Traveling Libraries.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Philippines Government bill was laid before the Senate, and Mr. Pritchard (N.C.) addressed the Senate in support of the measure. He declared that a majority of the people of North Carolina and of the South were in favor of the proposition of the majority of the Philippine Committee, and he quoted The Charlotte Observer as a leading Democratic paper of the South in support of the retention of the Philippines.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Has the press grown so wayward in this era of rush and linotypes that its errors defy correction? Has exact proofreading in consequence become a lost art? Or, if not, why is it that the eyes of the careful reader must be so constantly offended by typographical inaccuracies?

On April 9-12 Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge of London sold the small but extremely important library of the late Lieut. Col. Edward George Hibbert, formerly of the Grenadier Guards, 914 lots selling for the large total of L12,097 12s. 6d. -- an eloquent tribute to Mr. Hibbert's taste -- for his books, it is said, were collected within recent years and cost him only L8,000.

The annual rearrangement of the Metropolitan Museum's collections brings with it some loans of different value, the most important of which are the greater number of the foreign pictures acquired by the late William H. Vanderbilt. They are hung in the long gallery between the Marquand and Catherine Wolfe collections.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- L.E. Hallock of Boston, Mass., formerly a Sergeant and later a private in Company I, Twenty-sixth Volunteer Infantry, testified to-day before the Senate Committee on the Philippines concerning the practice of the water cure in the Philippine archipelago.

VIOLETS by the million, perfuming the atmosphere of a whole valley, and enhancing the beauty of 10,000 fair votaries of fashion throughout the cold Winter and Spring months, are the artificial products of an industry which adds a round million dollars annually to the income or professional florists.

LENOX, May 3 -- Lenox is promised one of the most prosperous seasons in its history. The building of the new hotel, which will accommodate 500 guests, the construction of several cottages, including those of R.W. Patterson, Samuel Frothingham, Dr. Jaques, Edward E. Wharton, and a number of others, will add much to the attractiveness of the place, and to the social gayety.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- At the conclusion of routine business in the Senate today, the resolution previously offered by Mr. Patterson, (Col.,) requesting the President to cause the Secretary of War to cable Major Gardener, in the Philippines to coma to Washington to appear as a witness before the Philippine committee, was laid before the Senate.

Seth M. Milliken having begun proceedings to foreclose a mortgage of $30,000 on the historical Jumel mansion, interest has been revived in the progress which is being made toward the purchase of the property by the city. The American Scenic and Historic Society has for a considerable time been urging an appropriation sufficient to purchase the entire property, which embraces 67,391 square feet of territory, held at a price of $157,125.

The plan of the Municipal Art Society for the organization of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition in St. Louis on the basis of a model city to serve as an object lesson in perfect municipal government is interesting. How far it can be carried out and what possibilities of disappointment may be found to reside in the practical business of administration are matters of conjecture.

BALTIMORE, May 3 -- The local market was exceedingly flat to-day, the strength of the Maryland and Pennsylvania issues being the nearest approach to anything like a feature. The bonds and stocks of this company were both in demand, a fact which attracts extra attention, owing to the persistent inertia, which, as hitherto, characterized the group.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 3 -- In Cornell's regular Spring track and field meet, which was held at Percy Field to-day, the work of Fredericks in the pole vault was the feature. His height of 11 feet 3 inches establishes a new Cornell record. The work in other events was not above ordinary. The unfavorable conditions, however, were responsible for the slow time.
So far the year 1902 has broken the record of the past decade for immigrants landing at this port. January and February showed a large increase on the figures for the same months last year.

VIENNA, April 11 -- The members of the Vienna Jockey Club who were concerned in the baccarat trial which was concluded yesterday are all well-known personages in society. Naturally, the chief interest is centred in Count Joseph Potocki and Herr Nikolous von, Szemere, whose sensational game at baccarat caused so much comment at the time.

A great crowd gathered at the White Star Line pier yesterday, when the Celtic docked there late in the afternoon. The big liner brought over 402 saloon passengers, 365 of whom were tourists, who left this port on the Celtic three months ago on a voyage to the Orient. So many friends came down to greet them that the Collector issued an order to allow no person within the customs lines.

FEMININE fashions, from the time when Eve or Adam first introduced them, are always interesting. Since the original simplicity of costume only two periods of modern civilization have dared to go back to the beginnings of things. They did it "under the Directory," in the last century, when, as may be paraphrased, a woman's clothes, like language, "were given her to conceal her thoughts," and they ventured it in the Summer of 1901.

MAY 17, Alfonso XIII., then entering his seventeenth year, will become entitled, according to the Constitution of 1876, to exercise the prerogative of a Spanish sovereign. On that day, before the assembled Cortes and the grandees of Spain, his Catholic Majesty will swear to maintain the Constitution, and by this act will terminate the regency of the Queen mother.

Many anecdotes are recorded of the famous restaurateur Bignon, whose death was announced recently. One of them is rather amusing, and shows how the celebrated caterer treated four of the golden youth who went to have supper at his restaurant after an Opera masked ball, and made him wait on them.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- The local market to-day was dull and narrow, and there was little manifest inclination to follow the recovery in New York. The Readings and Lehigh Valley were active at lower prices, though the latter stock was moderately steady. Declines were marked in two of the recently strongest stocks -- Consolidated Lake Superior and Electric Storage.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The circular issued by the Merchants' Club on the question of blackmail is, to say the least, a singular production. No merchant will volunteer his services to antagonize the police, however favorable he may be to the movement. Every one knows the almost unlimited power given to the force, and the various ways it could be used to harass and annoy the business man.

The growing trade of the United States with South Africa is disquieting to British manufacturers. Heretofore our trade has been in goods that were non-competing with British goods, such as flour, the cereals, meats, c. For 1901 these comprise only one-fourth of our imports into South Africa, the remaining three-fourths being manufactured goods which compete with British goods.

IN A week or two the entire town will be abloom with straw hats. As stated some time since, the Panama hat is to be the most fashionable this Summer. A good Panama, paid for at quite a stiff price, lasts a man a number of years, and, as the fashions for the sterner sex are less liable to change than those of his sisters, it is a fair investment.
The statement regarding the affairs of the Meyer Syndicate Companies issues yesterday by M.L. Muhleman was as follows:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 3 -- The Rockaway polo team, which won the Junior championship at Brookline last season, went down in defeat before the Bryn Mawr team in the tournament at Lakewood today for the Georgian Court Cups. The Philadelphias were the stronger team. It looked like Rockaway's game up to the end of the third period.

All negotiations looking toward a settlement of the demands of the anthracite miners are now off, and unless something entirely unforeseen happens in the meantime to change the situation, a strike of 147,000 miners will be ordered in the anthracite regions on Wednesday. The following official statement was given out to the public last night by John Mitchell, President of the United Mine Workers:

ACCORDING to the chambermaids and housekeepers in high-class boarding houses and family hotels the manufacturers of furniture have got to add another piece to a full bedroom set, or they will be lost in the shuffle of latest improvements.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me, through THE TIMES, to take exception to "S.S.B.'s" statements in the issue of April 28 that "teachers had a soft snap already," and that "the proposed reform is the proper thing," meaning an unauthorized announcement in regard to lengthening the school day and shortening vacations.

MANILA, May 3 -- The trial by courtmartial of Gen. Jacob H. Smith ended today. The findings of the court will be forwarded to Washington. The general impression here is that he will be acquitted, as it is not believed anything has been proved against him contrary to General Order No. 100.

HE IS a wealthy merchant of amiable mien, but penurious mind. The other day he dropped in to call on an old family servant. She is now married to one of the merchant's employes. The family make their home in the business building, and the merchant, who delights in home cooking, to say nothing of economy, frequently takes his luncheon with the onetime servant, who for old-time's sake refuses remuneration.

BERLIN, May 3 -- Count Douglas, a descendant of a Scotch soldier of fortune, has proposed a resolution in the Prussian Diet asking the Ministry to bring in a bill imposing more rigid restructions on the liquor traffic. All parties except the Radicals supported the measure, and the Radicals did not speak against it.

Villages in all parts of Germany still maintain "night watchmen," who act as guardians of the community, and carry when on duty a long lance, something of the nature of a halberd, in their hand, as they perambulate their beats during the long, dark hours of the night. They also have a whistle with them, with which they proclaim to the non-sleeping inhabitants and to prowling men and beasts what o'clock it is.

Criticism cabled over from London of the compensation to be awarded to the syndicate which is underwriting the securities of the new shipping combine has excited interest in the history of the development of these syndicates, and the extent of their profits in this country. The present criticism is over the fact that the underwriting syndicate for this consolidation is to receive a bonus of $25,000,000 in common stock and $2,500,000 preferred.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 3 -- The sixtg annual interscholastic track games were held here to-day, and were won by the Dwight School of New York City, with a total of 20 points. Mercersburg was seeond with 19, Lawrenceville third with 18, Penn Charter 16, Hill School 15, and Philadelphia High School 14.

During the early part of the week just past the conditions prevailing in the outside market were a repetition of those of the previous week. The general advance in prices continued, and trading was on a scale about as large as any that the outside market has seen, at least within the past two years.

YOU may boycott your own sweet self, turn the tables on the Beef Trust by a discriminative embargo -- that is to say, close your port (mouth) to butcher's meat. Suppose such a measure became general and the crusade having been preached, millions at people at home and abroad became total abstainers.

The dealings of the last few days have not been of such a character as to justify any belief in a declining interest in the market, such as might reasonably be expected at this time. The volume of business has shown no appreciable decrease, while substantial transactions in districts remote from the much-favored Fifth Avenue section have added a degree of variety greater than that to be found in the reports of any recent week.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 3 -- Davenport Tracy have granted the molders employed in their iron foundry here an increase of 8 per cent. in wages. The increase is effective Monday. The shop is a union institution. Last Week the molders asked for an increase of 15 per cent, because of the prosperity of the iron business and the high price of the commodities of life.

Many curious things have happened during the past Wall Street week. A variety of "deals" have fallen down. Some extraordinary manipulations have had distressful sequels. Conspicuous "leaders" have been shorn. It has been a leveling-down week.

LONDON, May 3 -- The American polo players, who hope to recover the International Cup, won their first match of the season at Ranelagh this afternoon, defeating the Old Cantabs by 4 goals to 0. The Americans were handicapped by the absence of Foxhall Keene, their strongest player, but they played an exceedingly strong game throughout, and the impression both men and ponies made was excellent.

AN expert from the Department of Steam Boiler Inspection and his gang of assistants emerged from the cellar of a Park Row skyscraper. All day long they had been testing the "battery" of great boilers ranged far under the sidewalk, like the boilers in an ocean greyhound, Heat, light, elevator service, electricity, and even the cooling breezes of the revolving fan emanated from the great boilers just inspected.

Those members of the Presbyterian Church who have demanded a radical revision of the Westminster Confession of Faith will be disappointed at the report which is to be presented by the Committee on Revision when the General Assembly of the Church convenes in annual session at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in this city on May I8.

BOSTON, May 3 -- In the money market business is light, and, while the banks are for the moment holding back a little on new loans, the right borrowers are able to secure all that they need at quoted rates. Considerable Boston money is now being loaned in New York, and certain lenders are reported as obtaining from 6 to 8 per cent., the latter on railroad securities.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- Over 6,000 spectators saw the University of Pennsylvania, baseball team defeat Yale by the score of 4 to 2 on Franklin Field this afternoon. It was one of the best and hardest contests ever fought on the Pennsylvania diamond. The Quakers won because they outplayed the New Haven collegians at all points of the game.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial concerning the shipping trust now being formed, it seems to me you miss an important point. You say: "Low cost of production through the economies of concentration is the whole gospel of trust-making. The refusal of the share that saving with the consumer is an infallible sign of stupidity and shortsightedness in the management."

The annual Spring century run of the Century Road Club Association, although originally announced only two weeks ago has received already nearly 150 entries. The run will be held on Sunday, May 18, and is to be paced by such well-known century riders as C.P. Staubach, D.M Adee, W.H. Mackey, John T. Wall, Jobs Castles, D.H. Lodge, C.H. Fessenden, G. S. Rowell, E. Webster Fleet, and T.J Moore.

"ON the contrary," I said "I have the very highest regard for matinee girls, and for you Perilla, in particular." It is just possible that I had not always expressed this sentiment; but then I had not always been looking into Perilla's blue eyes.

Justice Leonard Giegerich of the Supreme Court said last night that he had issued an order of arrest during the afternoon for a man of the name of Meyer in charge of fraudulent transactions in a series of stock deals. He did not recollect the initials of the man wanted.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 3 -- The final hearing on the accounting of Frederick Mead of New York, executor of the estate of the late Solomon Mead, took place in the Greenwich Probate Court to-day.

A LITTLE rabbit gave a quick, sharp cry, resembling the piteous, terrified shriek of a child. Next moment the cat that had pounced upon him glided silently through the grass with the soft, furry body dangling limply between her jaws. When she had gone the crickets resumed their chirping.

PITTSBURG, Slay 3 -- The failure of the bituminous coal operators to agree to recognize the organisation of the United Mine Workers of America can only end in a strike. The miners are not so thoroughly organized in the hard-coal regions of Eastern Pennsylvania as they are in Illinois, Ohio, Indiana, and the Pittsburg districts.

FEW people who travel or who daily depend upon the railroads of the country for the hauling of freight have any idea of the part which the army of men who work on repair only, play in the world of transportation, nor of how many thousands of human lives are annually saved by the conscientious attention of these men to their work.

LONDON, May 3 -- The exhibition opened this week at Dusseldorf is the largest of its kind ever held to Germany, the grounds covering 150 acres on the right bank of the Rhine, and the electric display and the exhibit of Krupp's gunworks being the most notable, although the fine arts show, as befits the ancient reputation of Dusseldorf, is also uncommonly good.

MADRID, May 3 -- Advices received here from the Portuguese frontier indicate that the situation in Portugal is becoming extremely grave in consequence of the excitement caused by the bill which passed the Chamber of Deputies approving the convention with the foreign creditors for the purpose of converting the foreign debt.

The Boer War and the King's Prerogative. Either inspired by representations of the Boer European Committee or their own Ignorance, the European papers, with singular unanimity, consider that the recent peace negotiations at Pretoria were entirely the work of Edward VII., owing to that monarch's exercising his royal prerogative.

CINCINNATI, May 3 -- The International Police Journal says that owing to the quetion of Anarchy and the consideration of a uniform system of identification the world over the annual convention of the Associa- tion of the Police Chiefs of the United States and Canada at Louisville, May 7, will be the most important and moat largely attended in the history of that organization.

It was rather a cheerless day for the coaching parade, and the threatening weather prevented a large crowd from assembling at the Mall in Central Park, where the meet was held. There was, however, an excellent showing yesterday, and the women, notwithstanding the prospects of rain, were gowned in gauze materials and in delicate colors.

LONDON, April 23 -- To nine-tenths of the people in London during the royal festival of the last week in June, seeing the coronation will mean merely seeing the great procession of the second day, June 27, the royal progress of Edward VII, and his Court through the metropolis of his dominions.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The real fight of the session Is now on in the Senate. It is over the Philippine Civil Government bill. Within the past few days, and even the past few hours, the polities of both parties have changed considerably, and both are now lining up for battle.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If "S.S.B.," whose letter stating that the pension system had been saddled on the public, although the teachers had a soft snap already, which letter appeared in your issue of the 28th ultimo, could accompany some of the teachers to their homes he would think, write, and talk in a different vein.

THOSE small people over in Brooklyn who frequent the only children's museum in the world -- the one in Bedford Park -- have begun their Spring work. Besides having the advantages of the only children's museum, they belong to the great Children's Nature Club, with its 800 members.

SAID a Columbia student the other day: "The old time-honored idea of what a college professor is like has not yet died out in the minds of most people. According lo this idea he is a stately, dignified-looking man, never condescending to smile or joke, nor to use words of less than three syllables if he can possibly avoid it.

USE OF PARTNERSHIP NAME AFTER DEATH OF SOLE SURVIVING PARTNER. -- Henry G. Fisk, when he died, in March last, was the sole surviving member of the firm of Fisk, Clark Flagg. A controversy arose between his administrators and several persons who have, since Mr. Fisk's death, organized a corporation and adopted the name of Fisk, Clark Flagg as to the right to use that name.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with much satisfaction the communication of "C.H.W." on barking dogs in your issue of last Sunday. Like your correspondent, I am a friend of nice, sensible canines, but I abominate the worthless, peace-disturbing cur as I do an Anarchist.

Miss Mary G. Pinkney, whose name figured prominently in a suit brought in the Supreme Court last week by Henry E. Wibert against his niece, Mrs. Julia Curtiss, to recover a balance of $23,500 for arranging a meeting between her and Dr. Rollin A. Curtiss, whom she married in 1898, and which resulted in a verdict of $13,500 for the plaintiff, is probably one of the most remarkable women in this city for her age.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 3 -- The strain has been removed in the political situation at the Club Women's Convention by the withdrawal of Mrs. Robert J. Burdette from the Presidential race. In a letter which she issued to the press she gave her support to Mrs. Dimies Denison of New York, so that the ticket, unless a dark horse shall appear, promises to stand:
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The President to-day sent the nomination of H. Clay Evans to be Consul General at London to the Senate.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 3 -- In an address here before the Board of Missions of the Southern Methodist Church, of which he is President, Senior Bishop A.W. Wilson last night made an impassioned appeal for additional missionaries to Asia.

The Road Drivers' Association of New York opened its new clubhouse on the Speedway yesterday with a beefsteak dinner, at which 150 members and their friends participated. Dr. Kane, an ex-President of the association, raised the large flag in front of the clubhouse promptly at 3:30 o'clock, and this was the signal for the festivities to begin.

Yesterday's session in the outside market was a very quiet one. It is true that somewhat startling declines occurred in Dominion Securities and Hackensack Meadows, the former selling at 70 and the latter at 45, but the events of the previous day had foreshadowed the selling down of these stocks, and the declines were taken more or less as a matter to be looked for.

What will be the first opportunity afforded the general public for the enjoyment of the paintings collected by William H. Vanderbilt has been arranged for by the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The pictures will be shown at a private reception to-morrow afternoon, after which they will be on general view.

The experiments made on Thursday to determine how quickly an automobile of one type or another can be stopped by its brake when run at varying rates of speed were extremely interesting but not of great practical value. They showed that when run at speed considered slow for motor vehicles, six to eight miles an hour, stops in from 3 feet 10 inches to 5 feet 9 inches are possible.
The steam yacht Undercliffe, owned by F. Lewis Clark, which is lying at Port Jefferson, L.I., will go into commission on June 20.

LONDON, May 3 -- English theatregoers are mightily worked up over George Edwardes's suggestion to raise the price of admittance to the stalls in London playhouses from 10s. 6d. ($2.62) to 12s. 6d., ($3.12.) Mr. Edwardes holds that the increased amounts paid to musical comedy stars and the cost of producing up-to-date pieces of that nature are quite disproportionate to the receipts.

Most notable among the many recent accessions of the American Museum of Natural History is a group of five caribou now being mounted by the Museum's taxidermist. These hail from the Barren Lands of the Alaskan peninsula, and are of an entirely new species. They have been named from Madison Grant, Secretary of the New York Zoological Society, and are called "rangifer granti," or the Grant caribou.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The story that the President had determined to take the stump this Fall in support of Republican candidates for Congress doubtless was an outgrowth of the well-recognized fact that the President has a strong personal interest in the coming campaign.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The publication last Sunday in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the article entitled "The First Seedless Oranges," led to an Investigation by W.A. Taylor of the Agricultural Department, the purpose of, which was to trace the history of the seedless orange in this country. Mr. Taylor reports his conclusions in a paper entitled "The Bahia or Washington Navel Orange in the United States.

The motives of those ladies and gentlemen who are trying to secure the retention of the old Hall of Records in City Hall Park and its conversion into a historical museum are so very good that it is hard to find fault with their action.
