We observe with interest that they have made the difficult conquest of Alderman BRIDGES, so difficult to win to the support of any cause even superficially that of civilization.

LODI, N.J., May 3 -- The inhabitants of this place were in a state of excitement early to-day, as it was feared the strikers would attack the men who are now at work in the Boeltger Alexander dye works. The strikers were assembled near the mills, but Sheriff Soley read the riot act to them and threatened to call out the militia.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will THE TIMES, as a promoter of good cheer and the amenities of life, permit me to pay a tribute to a character who has just passed away?

Mr. BURK of Pennsylvania has introduced a fearful and wonderful joint resolution into the House of Representatives. The resolution requests the President to issue a proclamation "declaring the shipment of horses and mules contraband of war." The President is as likely to issue a proclamation requiring the bumps of Mr. BURK to be publicly felt by the common phrenologist.

The telephone man has his working togs on just now. The extra amount of work which falls to his lot is due chiefly to the annual May "shake-up," and, although everybody who makes a move about this time doesn't own a telephone, the number who do own instruments and want to bring them along makes work enough for all the men the telephone company can find who are able to do it.

THERE is no more glorious sight at this period at the year than to watch the gradual clothing of nature in her fresh, pure garment of green. The lawns in the parks have suddenly burst forth into new joyousness of life and the trees no longer stand, solitary or huddled together, bereft of all semblance of beauty except that acquired by their fanciful spread of branches.

Aurelien Scholl, who was born at Bordeaux in 1833, was at the early age of seventeen already an accomplished "boulevardier." He had all the qualities necessary for the "metier," wit of a sparkling, sarcastic, and unkind description, "cheek " in plenty, and an unbounded confidence in himself.

On transparencies and by the speakers the Beef Trust was attacked yesterday during the Mayday demonstration of the Social Democratic Party. The demonstration included a parade of 20,000 persons, men and women, and concluded with a meeting at Madison Square, which ended shortly before midnight.

During the past week it has become known to some of the friends of Major John M. Burke that he has selected as his burial place a lofty peak in the Big Horn Basin, where his mausoleum will consist of huge boulders from the native marble, surrounded by the eternal snows.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The death of Representative Amos J. Cummings of New York in Baltimore last night caused general regret and sorrow in the House today. Above the hall the flag fluttered at half-mast, and on the floor the old familiar desk on the centre aisle near the front row which Mr. Cummings occupied for so many years was draped in black and covered with a profusion of purple orchids and Spring flowers.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 3 -- Cornell won easily from the University or Pennsylvania at lacrosse here to-day. The visitors failed to score, while Cornell tallied 5 goals.

THE wedding gown of Miss Edith Hoadley, who married George Lorillard Ronalds, showed some small divergence from the usual wedding frock. The bodice had a deep yoke of point lace, unlined with narrow box plaits of satin, extending from the lace stock to the belt -- the latter a fold of satin.

LONDON, May 3 -- W.K. Vanderbilt will, in all probability, win the Coronation Derby if he secures R.S. Sievier's Sceptre, (the winner of the Two Thousand Guineas Stakes and of the One Thousand Guineas Stakes,) for which he is reported to have offered Mr. Sievier 40,000 guineas, ($210,000,) after the filly won the One Thousand Guineas Stakes, yesterday.

SILAS LARRABEE had something to say last night about the Presidential campaign of 1904. His remarks were in response to a question put to him by one of a group or gentlemen who had assembled on the back porch of our boarding house.

Our Madrid correspondent writes under date April 8: "The ceremony of 'head covering' was yesterday performed by a number of Spanish Peers, who thereby passed to the rank of Grandees of Spain. The ceremony, interesting on account of its antiquity and its historical signification, is, like many Spanish customs, remarkable for its extreme simplicity.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer of the article, "The First Seedless Oranges," printed in yesterday's Sunday TIMES, is a trifle off in crediting California with the first production of navel oranges in the United States.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 -- To the cheers of thousands, Alan-a-dale, the son of Halma, the latter himself winner of the '95 Derby, this afternoon passed under the wire winner of the twenty-eighth Kentucky Derby. The Inventor was second and The Rival third. The outpouring of the people, such as always characteries a Kentucky Derby, was one of the features of today's big event.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is with a deep interest that I read the communication from Malcom R. Birnie, member of the Good Citizenship Committee of the Christian Endeavor Union, published in your issue of the 29th inst. I myself having been a resident of the lower east side for many years know the conditions that prevail there.

Just five years ago -- to be exact, in April, 1897 -- Rock Island shares were quoted at a small fraction above 60. The company had paid 2 per cent, dividends on the stock, and its fiscal year, which ends on March 31, had closed with a surplus of $520,480 above this small requirement, which on $46,155,800 of capital amounted to only $923,116.
MISS ELMER GRIFFING, whose sphere of usefulness is in the Bureau of Licenses and who is the only woman employed in the building, has the story-telling habit. Here is one of her latest:

Barclay H. Warburton left Philadelphia at 6:35 o'clock yesterday morning in a racing automobile ostensibly for the purpose of breaking the motor vehicle record from that city to New York, and incidentally with a view of seeing the Metropolitan Handicap run in the afternoon at Morris Park.

Treasury Department statistics of immigration support the conviction that the present trend of immigration is greater than in former years to the West and Northwest, and that the majority of the aliens who go there left their native countries to become tillers of the soil in the United States.

NEW HAVEN, May 3 -- Annnouncement was made to-day that the transfer of the estate of the late Henry Bradley Plant, amounting to $18,000,000 or $20,000,000, from Connecticut to New York courts will be vigorously opposed by Horace G. and Charles B. Hoadley of Waterbury, Conn., sons of the late Horace P. Hoadley of this city, who was a half-brother of the deceased millionaire.

LONDON, May 3 -- Money was more plentiful and less wanted to-day, as usual at the week end. A million pounds sterling ($5,000,000) was released by the maturing of London County Council bills. Discount rates were thereby made easier.

The Light rain which fell yesterday afternoon prevented the local enthusiasts from enjoying the baseball games scheduled between New York and Philadelphia at the Polo Grounds, and Brooklyn and Boston at Washington Park. The managements at both places decided that the grounds Were too wet, and postponed the games.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 3 -- First play for the Boys' Cup took place on the Hillside Tennis and Golf Club links to-day. Kerro Knox won the first three points, while Wickham Corwin and H. Lapsley tied for second honors. The result of the play follows:

OUR general ideas regarding the incubating season of feathered creatures are associated with the early Summer. When the trees attain their foliage, affording more secure hiding places for the nests, and warm weather hurries in the delinquent migratory birds from the South, is the time usually allotted to the birds' domestic duties.
MULTI-MILLIONAIRES get so used to making money that even in the recreations of their country life they cannot forbear to follow the same custom.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3 -- The lacrosse team of the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn beat Harvard to-day on Soldiers' Field in a fast and interesting game by the score of 11 to 8. Beautiful team play characterized the work of the visitors, and at times they played "horse" with Harvard.

Severely tested as it was, the enthusiasm of the racegoing public triumphed at the Morris Park race course yesterday when the Metropolitan Handicap was won by the long chance outsider Arsenal, from A. Featherstone's stable. Wet and miserable as was the afternoon, and for that, the whole day, the crowd more than justified atticipation.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 3 -- H.W. Kerrigan of the Multnomah Athletic Club has broken two world's swimming records in an exhibition here. He established a new mark of 6 feet 2 3/8 inches in the running high dive, and cleared 15 feet 3 1/2 inches in the running long dive, adding 20 inches to the world's record.

Within the last fortnight the dredging of the Harlem River for the subway tunnel has been completed, and everything is in readiness for the sinking of the wooden caisson in which the men will work while laying the two steel tubes in which the rapid transit trains are to go under the stream.

Considering all the circumstances and in view of the many alarming reports and rumors, yesterday's stock market behaved well. Prices, it is true, declined further in some parts of the list; but, on the other hand, not a few stocks showed decided strength, closing with net gains, some of which were not unsubstantial.

The education of John Chinaman, Jr., and his little sister in New York Chinatown has been begun under the most promising circumstances. A school, the first of its kind in New York, has been opened at 11 Mott Street during the past week, and has already thirty-five regular pupils who attend daily, and all of whom are the children of the Chinese residents of the quarter.

We think that it is hardly appreciated in this city what has been the significance and what are likely to be the influence and effect of the movement in connection with which Mr. ROBERT C. OGDEN organized the trip to the South with the party who returned last evening.

LONDON, May 3 -- There have been some interesting developments in the battle between the American millionaires for control of London's rapid transit system. One feature that stands out more than any other is Charles T. Yerkes's ability to beat English lawyers at their own game. Counsel for the Morgans' projected "tube" line had Mr. Yerkes on the stand before the House of Lords' Committee for an hour or so one day this week.

LONDON, May 3 -- The sensational prices realized at the auctions of art objects, books, pictures, furniture, and old silver in London this week easily eclipsed all records. The dispersal of the celebrated Dunn-Gardner collection of old silver attracted buyers from all parts. A silvergilt Tudor cup, dated 1521, was sold April 29, the first day of the sale, for L4,100, ($20,500,) or about L290 ($1,450) per ounce.

In 1885, when rate troubles were cutting things railroadwise to pieces, when the Vanderbilts saved themselves by fixing their grip on the West Shore for 475 years, the Western system in which New York Central interests were closely bound up (namely, the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern) passed its dividend.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 3 -- Princeton's baseball team won from Brown here today after eleven innings of the best playing seen in Providence for a long time. The fielding of both teams and the pitching of Hatch for Brown were the features. In the eleventh Hier landed the ball near the foul line and Stevens scored.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of your correspondents lately suggested that it would be better to stop theorizing as to the manner of dealing with the beef trust and asked that those who lived without meat for food to give their experience.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A cablegram has been received at the War Department from Gen. Chaffee, replying to Secretary Root's message regarding investigating of Major Gardener's charges. Following is an extract from the message:

There was a big distribution of golf prizes yesterday at the conclusion of the Garden City invitation golf tournament. All of the cups at match play which had been in competition since Thursday morning were played for in final rounds of thirty-six holes and in addition there was an eighteen-hole handicap.

MUCH concern is expressed in many quarters about the musical state of this city. It is comforting to New Yorkers to know that Kalamazoo and Butte and Ogunquit are as deeply interested in their welfare and as willing to supply them with advice as Boston and Chicago.
At a regular meeting of the Board of Jewish Ministers, held Thursday, May 1, the following resolution was unanimously adopted:

OUT of ten crochet needles plied by women, eight of these implements axe made of bone, and in the material so employed may be noted a survival of that time when bone and horn were used in lieu of stone or supplementing it. A toothbrush handle may not be archaeologically suggestive, nevertheless it recalls that remote period when bone served for innumerable purposes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the recent intimations of the possible destruction of the Hall of Records, the undersigned were appointed a committee at the Trustees' meeting of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society last evening to call public attention to the fact that any injury done to this building would be in the nature of an irreparable loss to the city.

THE Conference for Education in the South, which met at Athens, Ga., from the 24th to the 27th of April, bears a name more significant for many of those who attended it than might be supposed. For a number of the visitors from the North their own education within the boundaries of the South, on the intensely interesting and important subject of the South, was its most important result.

-- Cigarette smokers have an Industrious friend in The London Lancet. Months ago that venerable representative of the medical profession took much pains to prove that the stories about narcotics in cigarette tobacco and poisons in cigarette paper were quite without foundation, and now it argues elaborately that the despised "coffin nails" are safer than pipes.

The firm of Francis H. Lessett Co., wholesale grocers at Franklin Street and West Broadway, procured the indictment of Max Borchardt in November last, upon the charge that he had embezzled from them $25,000, which he had collected from outstanding accounts.
A Joke with somewhat serious consequences was practiced early yesterday morning upon J.A. Callahan by his wife. Sarah Callahan, at their home, 374 Hancock Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, May 3 -- Thus far all the City has to felicitate itself on the "good tone" in the stock market. Rumors of certain peace are persistent and credible, as they have been coming from trustworthy sources, but the outside public still bides its time, taking nothing but Consols and other good investment securities and leaving speculation for the present to professional speculators.

The project to erect a suitable memorial in the Criminal Courts Building to the memory of Mrs. Rebecca Salome Foster, the "Tombs Angel," is well under way, and is everywhere received with marked favor.

Handball players put in a busy day at the various local handball courts yesterday. At the Jersey City Handball Courts, on Mercer Street, a large crowd gathered to watch the exhibition matches by Oliver Drew, the Irish champion, who arrived on Saturday, and who is matched to play Champion Michael Egan for the world's championship and a wager of $250 on May 18.

The suggestion made by Mr. LEWIS NIXON at the dinner of the Sculptors and Murals in the Arts Club, that when the Government builds a ship care should be taken to introduce the artistic as well as the useful -- if it be only in the form of a figurehead -- struck a note that should cause to vibrate a sympathetic chord in the mercantile marine as well as the navy.

LONDON, May 5. -- The Times prints an editorial article on the recent visit of Miss Alice Ravenhill to the United States. She was sent by the British Education Department and several other public bodies to inquire into the practical conduct of American schools and colleges.

The battleship Indiana of the North Atlantic Squadron arrived at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday, after a cruise of some months in West Indian waters. The warship proceeded direct to the yard upon her arrival in port. She will remain then for several weeks undergoing an overhauling, and will then take out a crew of apprentices on a training cruise.

Capt. James K. Price of the Thirty-seventh Precinct aided by three mounted policemen, two bicycle policemen, three patrolmen, and one detective in plain clothes, brought the open handicap run of the Shamrock Harriers, on Jerome Avenue, yesterday afternoon, to an unexpected conclusion by arresting five of the runners and the proprietor of the Jerome Avenue Hotel, where the run started and ended, on a charge of violating the law against public sports on Sunday.

Arthur L. Meyer of the Meyer-Offenbach, syndicate remained in his house, 38 West Stventy-second Street, the greater part of yesterday and made no attempt to evade service of the order of arrest which it was said had been issued for him on the application of Pierre M. Brown on Saturday evening.

ALBANY, May 4. -- The supplementary annual report of Superintendent of Insurance Hendricks, which deals with life, casualty, title, credit, and mortgage guarantee insurance companies, was made public tonight. The gross assets of life insurance companies doing business in this State on Dec. 31, 1901, were $1,879,624,504.08.

At the cycle meet at the Valesburg track, Newark, yesterday, Frank Kramer clipped a fifth of a second from his world's record of 0:28 2-5 for a quarter of a mile, flying start, making it in 0:28 1-5. "Teddy " Billington defeated Charles Schiee in their half-mile match race. Summary:...

BERLIN, May 4. -- The stagnation of the Boerse scarcely abated during the past week, but values were somewhat better maintained. While business on domestic Boerses is diminishing, the representatives here of New York and London houses are getting increased orders for foreign securities from German investors.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, May 4. -- The Iowa Transvaal Committee at Orange City, Iowa, has collected a fund of $6,000 for the fighting Boers in South Africa, and will send its first installment of $2,000 to Dr. Leyds at Brussels next week. The shipment will be followed by others in the near future.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Under date of May 3, Senator McLaurin of South Carolina has issued an address to the people of South Carolina, in which he defends his political policy and urges the overthrow of the Tillman machine. He begins by reviewing the political history of the State and the causes which led to the "farmers' movement" inaugurated by Senator Tillman and others, including himself, in 1890.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Republican Senators this week will relieve the Democrats of the necessity of supplying all the speakers in the Senate on the Philippine Government bill. The events of last week caused them to decide to take part in the debate, and they will lead off when the bill is laid before the Senate at 2 o'clock to-morrow.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 4. -- The ardent admirers among the clubwomen of Mrs. Decker have gathered their forces, and, notwithstanding Mrs. Decker insists that she is not a candidate and that Mrs. Denison should be elected, they have arranged that when Mrs. Decker shall appear on the programme Tuesday she shall be given a rousing start toward the Presidential chair.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- Potter Palmer, for nearly half a century one of Chicago's most prominent business men, died to-day at his residence on Lake Shore Drive. The immediate cause of Mr. Palmer's death was heart failure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The events of the past few days suggest to a looker on who owns no shares, but is interested solely as a student of industrial organization, a few thoughts on demonstrated and undemonstrated industries, capitalization, and earning power.
Dr. Keyes announced last night after his visit to the bedside of Archbishop Corrigan that the patient's condition is still dangerous.

About thirty members of the City History Club of New York yesterday afternoon tools a long walk, mainly over historical ground. In the course of their outing they visited several of the historical landmarks on Mornineslde Heights and Convent Hill. The gathering broke up among the historical cluster of gum trees, at Convent Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-second Street, which were planted by Alexander Hamilton.

In notifying the Merchants' Association that he will welcome its co-operation and assistance in devising a better plan than that now in use for assessing and collecting the water revenues of the city, Commissioner DOUGHBRTY has shown much practical wisdom, upon which we congratulate him.

Only one National League baseball game was played yesterday. Pittsburgh at Cincinnati, continued victorious, and took a more pronounced lead in the race for the National League pennant. At Chicago rain caused the postponement of the Chicago-St. Louis game.

BURLINGTON, Vt., May 4. -- Dr. W. Seward Webb, who has been spending Sunday at his home, Shelburne Farms, started for New York to-night, and will arrive there to-morrow morning. While waiting at the station he was interviewed in regard to his relations with Arthur L. Meyer.

[Respectfurly dedicated to Mrs. Sol. Berliner.] To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read a funny letter, Or an extract would tie better. Appearing in your issue 11th March, Being Mrs. Sol's idea Of how we English do appear. Untidy and without a sign of starch.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- Senator Hanna, in an interview to-day, characterized the situation in the anthracite coal region as extremely delicate and for that reason said it would be unwise for him to express an opinion as to the probable result of the meeting of the Executive Committee of the United Mine Workers for the three anthracite districts called for next Wednesday at Scranton, Penn., by National President John Mitchell.

MANILA, May 4. -- The demurrers in the case of the editor of Freedom, who is charged with sedition for publishing in his paper remarks censuring the United States Philippine Commission's rule, were heard yesterday. The defense claims that the articles and remarks in question were neither seditious nor libelous.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Farkhurst discoursed upon the Philippine policy and the practices attributed to the American soldiers in those islands in his sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church. Frequently during his discourse there were audible expressions on the part of the congregation, but they were too subdued to betray whether they were exclamations of approval or dissent He said in part:
In the annual budget published on the 1st of May for this city the following appropriations appear for schools:

Intercollegiate golf will be the feature this week. Team from five universities will meet to-morrow on the links of the Garden City Golf Club for their annual team and individual championship tournament. The college lads have been practicing faithfully for this event for over a month, and the excellent work done by the Princeton and Yale golfers in the Garden City contest last week shows that they are in good trim for a severe test.

-- There was a slightly amusing hint at unpleasant personal experiences with the telegraph magnates in the statement by Prof. PUPIN as to the welcome which inventors get when they call upon those magnates with suggestions for improving the service. "The Western Union and Postal Companies," he said, "are both using antiquated methods.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., May 4. -- Two were killed and forty-five injured, two probably fatally, in a head-on collision between an immigrant train and a fast freight near Rockwood, on the Connellsville Division of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad today. The two trains dashed toward each other on a straight stretch of track, and this fact alone averted what otherwise would have been the worst wreck in the history of the road:

Whether the legal proceedings which appear to have been begun to bring to account one of the men most prominent in the exciting occurrences of last week in Wall Street come to anything or not is very doubtful. The law does not take great care of the class of people who were the chief sufferers in these matters.

Emil Deickler, a cigarmaker, forty-two years old, of 235 Central Avenue, Williamsburg, died early yesterday morning in a saloon conducted by John Busch, at 94 Cedar Street. His death is believed to have been due to cyanide of potassium placed in his glass of beer by one of his companions for the purpose, as the police think, of robbery.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The War Department to-day received a cablegram from Gen. Chaffee indicating that the campaign against the Sultan of Bayan. one of the principal Moro chiefs, had been completely successful. The result was accomplished by a gallant assault on the principal Moro fort and its capture after a number of the leading Moros had been killed.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- First Assistant Postmaster General Wynne to-night received the first word that has come to this country direct from any of the officers of the Chicago arrested in Venice. It was from his son, Frank, who is Captain of the marines on the Chicago, and was in response to cablegrams sent when the first news of the affair reached this country.

It is one of the most satisfactory of cozy corners for the Summer. Cozy corners have not the power of attraction in the warm weather, when it is more comfortable to swing in the open in hammocks or in those delightful swinging seats, but if one must have something in the way of a draperied nook, there is nothing better than this.

Senator J.H. Mitchell of Oregon, who is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, stated to a NEW YORK TIMES reporter yesterday that probably no man in Congress could accurately foretell the outcome of pending legislation relative to Cuba. He Hoped that some agreement would soon be reached.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer of the editorial paragraph on "Americans" in to-day's TIMES can hardly have had as extensive an experience In foreign parts as he would like to make us believe: otherwise he would not say that "for all foreigners there are no 'Americans' except those that live in the United States."

Miss Ada Brown, who lived with her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hartnett on Commonwealth Avenue near the West Farms Road, was married on Jan. 15 to Thomas Mangin. On the evening of the marriage she had a little talk with her new husband about the payment of the caterer for the evening's festivities.

Yesterday marked the beginning of a new era in the history of the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, in West One Hundred and Sixth Street, the occasion being the annual meeting, at which the Finance Committee reported that the institution was free and clear of debt and that in the future it would be dependent upon voluntary contributions for its support.
For the current week the offering's at theatres where runs do not prevail offer considerable diversity. This is the list of this week's entertainments at such houses:
John H. Berry has sold for the McMulken estate to a client the six-story elevator apartment house, 215 West One Hundredth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The announcement was made to-day that Herbert G. Squiers was to be appointed Minister to Cuba. This appointment has been expected, and it was made known some time ago that President Roosevelt had practically no one else in mind.

TOULON, May 5. -- The mission which, is to represent France at the unveiling of the Rochambeau monument in Washington on May 24 arrived here from Paris at 11 o'clock this morning. Vice Admiral Maigret, commanding the Mediterranean Squadron, and Rear Admirals Jaureguiberry and Gigon met the members of the mission at the railroad station.

The lawn tennis players of Columbia University began play yesterday in the annual championship tournament for the collegiate honors. Seventeen men are entered for the singles and six pairs in the doubles. The dirt courts at South Field were in prime condition and contributed greatly to the enlivening sport furnished by the matches which were in the first round of the singles.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Gen. Chaffee has cabled the War Department the following list of casualties at the battle of Bayan, Mindanao, May 2, which was described in his dispatches made public yesterday:
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Republicans of the Senate to-day made their formal appearance in the debate over the Philippine bill, in accordance with the announcement made last week.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., May 5 -- Capt Charley Barr of the yacht Columbia, who resides here, it is learned, will sail the seventy-footer Mineola, owned by August Belmont, this season against the two new sixties building, which it is expected will race in the same class.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

The season at the Irvlng Place Theatre closed last night with the performance of three one-act plays. Each of the plays was the vehicle for one of the visiting German actors; each was given for the first time in America, and each was so sad that it would have been depressing if it had not been as spiritual as it was sad.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note in the dispatches from Manila relative to the court-martial of Gen. Jacob H. Smith that Col. Woodruff, counsel for the defense, refers to the " hysteria " displayed by the American people in connection with the accusations against the General.

BALTIMORE, May 5 -- The stockholders of the United States Fidelity and Guarantee Company of Baltimore at the annual meeting to-day authorized an increase of $500,000 in the capital of the company. Of this $250,000 will be used in connection with the acquisition of the Lawyers' Surety Company of New York and the balance held in the treasury subject to the Board of Directors for future use.
If the Republican leaders are wise they will endeavor to pass the measure reported from their Committee on Banking and Currency at the present session.

Three Stock Exchange houses were forced to the wall yesterday as a result of the collapse of the Webb-Meyer syndicate stocks. One of these firms intimated that absence of expected support from Dr. W. Seaward Webb was responsible for the crash. There were many evidences of bad blood, and suggestions that civil actions might be accompanied by vigorous interference on the part of the New York Stock Exchange.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 5 -- After two hours' discussion of the question of admission of colored women into the Women's Federation, the anti-colored women won the day when the convention voted over-whelmingly to accept what is known as the compromise amendment agreed upon in New York several weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Mr. Lodge addressed the Senate on the Philippine Government bill. One of the objects of the bill, he said, was to help the development of the islands. The opponents of the bill, he said, had charged that it opened the way to exploiters, syndicates, and carpet baggers.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The first of a series of diplomatic dinner parties, in honor of the French Ambassador and Mme. Cambon, was given this evening by the Russian Ambassador and his daughter, Countess Marguerite Cassini, the latter deferring her departure for Paris, which was to take place to-day in order to do the honors of the embassy on this occasion.

The coaching parade over, the races begun, and the various suburban golf and other clubs putting out attractive programmes, the season in town has ended. During the week there will be a few interesting entertainments. Yesterday was the celebration of the golden wedding of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Miller and the thirty-eighth annual reception at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which was largely attended.

New York played an errorless game against the Philadelphia baseball team at the Polo Grounds yesterday and won by a score of one to nothing. This made the seventh straight win for the local players, and they still stand second on the percentage list, with the Pittsburg men leading by a good margin.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- There is no indication in the Senate of opposition to the confirmation of the nomination of Henry Clay Evans to be Consul General at London. When it was announced several weeks ago that the President would appoint a new Pension Commissioner and give Mr. Evans a better place, there was a lot of talk about defeating the nomination the President might make in favor of the then Commissioner of Pensions.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Havemeyer of the American Sugar Refining Company to-day continued his testimony before the Committee on Relations with Cuba. He was questioned by Senator Teller regarding the reduction on the price of sugar at Missouri River points. He said that beet sugar generally sold 10 points below cane sugar at the points affected.

That American citizen is little to be envied who has wrought himself into such a condition of mind that he is unable to take any patriotic pride in such a gallant feat of arms as Col. BALDWIN'S command has just performed in Mindanao. Of such is evidently not the President of the United States.

BALTIMORE, May 5 -- The market to-day fell into one of mere perfunctory tending. Nobody would take hold of any group to give it a bullish turn. The backwardness was due entirely to the general weakness in New York. It was feared here that the conditions pointed to a coming period of heavy liquidation which, if it eventuates, will mean a corresponding set-back locally.

WILLIAM CAVAN died at his home, 39 Madison Street, Jersey City, yesterday of general debility. He was born in New York in 1821, and for many years was engaged in the towing business, but retired in 1890. He leaves one son and one daughter.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 5 -- Plans are completed for a new Dental School for Harvard, to cost $300,000, and to be located on the northwest side of the new Medical School in Brookline. The new building promises to be one of the finest that Harvard owns. It will be three stories high, and the main body will be 150 by 50 feet in dimensions.

ST. PAUL, May 5 -- The answer of the Northern Securities Company, the Great Northern Railway Company, the Northern Pacific Railway Company, and others to the petition of the United States through Attorney General Knox was filed to-day in the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Minnesota.

The stock market improves. It has had searching trouble; its sturdiness has been challenged, its soundness tested -- and the result is encouraging. Three Stock Exchange failures were recorded yesterday, and other weaknesses had been found out; money rates were at 20 per cent, and loans were called in many quarters where accommodation was sorely needed.

Forgetful of his own danger, an eighteenyear-old boy of the east side lost his life yesterday morning in a fire at 304 Pearl Street while trying to save a fellow-worker, a young woman, who had been overcome by smoke twenty feet away from a window out of which he himself might have escaped unharmed.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Two desks were draped in black and covered with flowers when the House met to-day. One was that occupied by Representative, Amos J. Cummings, whose public funeral was held in the House yesterday, and the other was that of Representative Peter J. Otey of Virginia, whose death occurred at Lynchburg yesterday.
ALBANY, May 5 -- An amended certificate of incorporation of the New York and New Jersey Railroad Company was filed with the Secretary of State to-day.

The announcement of the failures in the Street yesterday was followed by a sharp break in the stock market in the early trading. Prices opened down, as compared with Saturday's close, anywhere from one to three points, and in not a few instances immediately sold lower on short selling and liquidation enforced because of impoverished margins or induced through fear of a repetition of the May 9 panic.

District Attorney Jerome, from a statement made after the trial of Police Captain Michael E. Foody, resumed yesterday at Police Headquarters before Commissioner Partridge, was evidently not pleased with the day's proceedings.

The sudden death on Saturday of Marianna F. Mason, the twenty-two-year-old daughter of the Rev. John Mason, who is the pastor of the Orchard Primitive Methodist Church, in Oakland Street, near Nassau Avenue, Greenpoint, is surrounded with mystery. An autopsy made yesterday by Dr. Charles Wuest, the Coroner's physician, disclosed traces of an irritant poison in the young woman's stomach.

The Sunday raids on baseball playing north of the Harlem River came up in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday morning before Magistrate Meade, when prisoners who were arrested the day before charged with an alleged violation of the law were arraigned. The prisoners were William Leyden, eighteen years of age, and Thomas Molloy, nineteen years of age, who gave their address as the Catholic Protectory.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- The effect of the decline in New York was felt in the Philadelphia market, but not to the extent which might have been expected. The selling movement converged largely upon the Reading issues. Both the common and second preferred issues were extensively dealt in.

The attitude of the anthracite mine operators is much to be regretted. From the inception of the trouble which is now nearing a culmination they have behaved in a way to encourage the belief that they were desirous of having a strike and were prepared to do all in their power to bring it about.

Belmont Prince, the crack Western trotter that has been showing excellent form on the Speedway, proved an easy winner yesterday in two straight half-mile heats over Teto, and his owner, Clarence Ware, pocketed the $1,000 that was wagered on the match race. The trotters contested on the Empire City track, near Mount Vernon, and did their work while more than 500 prominent horsemen, members of the Road Drivers' Association, looked on.

The Rev. JOSIAH STRONG, D.D., is back from the Mediterranean. He is enthusiastic about the greatness and power of his country. He is encouraged also by the broadening influence of Protestant missions. He reports that when a mission was established in the Madeira Islands the resident Catholics wanted to " roast" the Protestants.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 5 -- Before a background of the American and English flags interdraped. William Thomson, first Lord Kelvin, of the University of Glasgow, this afternoon received from Yale University the honorary Degree of Doctor of Laws. The ceremony took place in Battell Chapel.

A stirring afternoon's sport, under the pleasantest possible conditions, rewarded the patrons of the turf who in spite of a very unpromising programme gathered at the Morris Park race track yesterday. The weather, which was suggestive of midsummer, aided materially in drawing an attendance that numbered about eight thousand.

President Smith M. Weed of the Santo Domingo Improvement Company has received dispatches confirming the fall of the Jimenes Government and stating that Vice President Horacio Vasquez, in command of the revolutionary forces, is in possession of Santo Domingo.

BERLIN, May 5 -- The illness of Queen Wilhelmina is watched with especial interest in Germany, because both the heir apparent and the heir presumptive to the Dutch throne are Germans. Under the law of succession in Holland, which was adopted in 1884, the ruling Grand Duke of the Grand Duchy of Saxe-Weimar.

The arrest yesterday of Rudolph Koeppel, who had been in the employ of the music publishing firm of S. Bramard's Sons Company, at 20 East Seventeenth Street, promises to create a great disturbance in the trade. Ostensibly, the prisoner is accused of forging an indorsement to a check for $32, but there are other charges against him of raising receipts and bills and receiving stolen property involving thousands of dollars.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- At a special meeting to-day of the stockholders of the Union Traction Company, which controls all of the street railway lines in this city, resolutions were adopted favoring the lease of the company's franchises to the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company, and empowering the officers to execute the lease which becomes operative July 1.

BOSTON, May 5 -- In the money market the business doing is still very light. The high prevailing rates are really the accompaniment of the market disturbances that have just been encountered, and it is good opinion that they will disappear within a few days at the most. Clearing House rate 5 per cent.; New York funds 15 per cent, discount; call loans, 3 1/2 to 5; time money, 4 to 4 1/2.
LONDON, May 5 -- Repayments to the Bank of England to-day hardened the rates for money. Discounts tended to be firmer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of your "Topics of The Times" in Monday's issue struck me as being some-what mediocre for a progressive paper such as THE NEW YORK TIMES is. Where you gathered the ideas not directly attributed to Sir Nevile Lubbock with regard to the West Indian sugar question I cannot Imagine.

WINSTED, Conn., May 5 -- Winsted, usually Republican in politics, to-day elected Gustav A. Reutter. a young German-American and a Democrat, Warden of the borough, over Jay E. Spaulding, a leading manufacturer, who was the nominee of the Republicans for that office.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows: Nearly the entire country east of the Rocky Mountains has experienced a week of highly favorable temperature conditions, and the central valleys, lake region. Middle Atlantic States, and portions of Texas and Oklahoma have received generally ample but in places unevenly distributed rainfall.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs completed the Army Appropriation bill to-day. Increases recommended by the committee bring the total appropriation made by the bill up to about $100,000,000. Important amendments suggested by the committee are as folows:

Such smart designs as there are to be found in a mackintosh nowadays! One is a very pale gray, almost white, or perhaps more of a pearl color, finished with a black velvet collar, made in the form of a long, straight coat, and fastened at the front with square buckles in gun metal in a stylish art nouveau design.

In connection with the death of the Archbishop of the Province of New York there is no question that excites more general interest among the Catholics of the city than the matter of succession to the high office just made vacant. A number of priests were interviewed yesterday in reference to this.

In the presence of nearly all the Rowan Catholic prelates of the United States the funeral of Archbishop Corrigan, who died late Monday night, will be held in St. Patrick's Cathedral at 10 o'clock on Friday morning. Archbishop Ryan of Philadelphia will give the eulogy and Bishop McQuaid of Rochester, the senior metropolitan of this province, has been chosen to celebrate the funeral mass.

For one achievement in his professional career, even if his biographer could dwell upon no other, WILLIAM T. SAMPSON would have been distinguished in the chronicles of naval strategy and strife. The credit and the glory of organizing the blockade off Santiago de Cuba are his, and his alone, and no squadron commander ever performed with greater efficiency any task assigned to him.

Perfect lawn tennis weather yesterday contributed to the successful completion of the first round of singles in the Columbia University championship tournament on the courts at South Field. Lyle E. Mahan, the collegiate title holder, demonstrated his superiority by winning his match in the easiest sort of style.

If the real estate deal which has secretly been under consideration for some time past between a syndicate composed of wellknown citizens of New York and the Board of Governors of the New York Hospital is consummated, Columbia College will add a large territory to the ground which the institution now occupies.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- When the Philippine Committee met to-day Senator Lodge presented a cablegram from Gen. Chaffee giving the charges and specifications of Major Gardener relative to Tayabas Province. The cablegram was received at the War Department May 4, and is as follows:

"What higher or more eloquent tribute could I pay to the character of our dead friend than that of this large and griefstricken assemblage, of men from all walks of life. He certainly endeared himself to all who knew him, which is the best test of the possession of noble qualities."

Proof of the allegations made in the answer of the Northern Securities Company in the action brought in the United States Circuit Court in Minnesota would put it out of the power of the petitioner to show injury or wrongful act, would satisfy reasonable public opinion and leave the corporations and parties defendant free to continue the business policy upon which they have entered.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- For almost four hours to-day a fiery discussion of the Philippine situation raged in the Senate. It was started by Mr. Beveridge of Indiana, who made shome sharp strictures on the members of the opposition because, as he said, they persisted in telling in their speeches only one side of the story.
There are no social entertainments today. The Pioneer will go out as usual with a gay party, and the ships sailing for Europe will have quite a number of wellknown people.

Mrs. Fiske's Tess in Lorimer Stoddard's stage version of the novel by Hardy, with which she opened her Spring season at the Manhattan Theatre last night, has not altered materially since the first performance at the old Fifth Avenue Theatre, in 1897. In some moments its technique seems firmer and more consistent, her remarkably simple and varied means of restrained expression being employed with more sustained effect.

Francis Bret Harte was the creator of a new literature that was purely American, and found many subsequent exponents, such as Eggleston, Cable, and Miss Murfree. His writings were more distinctively racy of the soil than anything that had hitherto appeared in this country, and they quickly placed him in the very front rank of literary men.

President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers left this city at 6 o'clock yester day for Scranton, Penn., to attend the strike convention of the anthracite miners which opens in Scranton at 10 A.M. to-day. He was accompanied by John Fahey, President of Anthracite District No. 9.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 6 -- Three policemen were added last night to the local force. All was quiet to-day at the Passaic Silk Works, but it is rumored that a demonstration is planned for to-morrow morning.

Two sketches, new to the vaudevilles, are introduced at Keith's. Both are marked by rather more delicacy in the writing and in the acting than is ordinarily the case in the continuous offerings. The actors, too, succeed by purely legitimate methods, as contrasted with much of the horse play and boisterousness which prevails not only in vaudeville houses, but on the stages of theatres making more pretense to artistic achievement.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 6 -- Wholly unaware that two of his ribs were broken, P. F. Collier played polo for two hours on the Georgian Court field last Saturday in the match between Rockaway and Bryn Mawr. He learned this morning for the first time that his ribs were fractured and he is now confined to his home in New York.
Negotiations are under way for the consolidation of the Metropolitan Trust Company and the Atlantic Trust Company, the combined resources of which are about $32,000,000.

All flay long yesterday Wall Street waited to hear the announcement that an arrangement had been made according to Which Dr. W. Seward Webb would come to the relief of the Stock Exchange houses which went to the wall on Monday because of the pricking of the Webb-Meyer syndicate bubble.
LONDON, May 6 -- Money was in good demand to-day, and supplies were fairly large, as a result of Government disbursements. Discounts had a tendency to be easier.

We think that the country owes a debt of gratitude to Senator LODGE for the manly and effective speech in support of the Philippine Government bill, delivered in the Senate on Monday. We have by no means always been in sympathy with the views of the Senator from Massachusetts, nor always able to admire his methods in public life, but the line be took on Monday was states- manlike, candid, and worthy of his position.

Sanity ruled again in the security market yesterday. The hit-and-miss performances of preceding days were in no further evidence. Foolish rumor mongering was less rampant, decisive exposure having been made of the falsity of nine out of ten of the sensations hippodromed in Monday's excited situation.

Harvard and Yale will meet to-day on the links of the Garden City Golf Club to determine the intercollegiate team championship for the coming year. The Cambridge lads hold the honor now, having beaten Yale last year at Atlantic City for the third consecutive time.

NEWCASTLE, Penn., May 6 -- A cyclone which struck this city this afternoon wrecked the Shenango Tin Plate Works, the largest in the world. Dozens of houses were unroofed, several blown down, and the property loss will reach over $100,000. No lives were lost and no person was seriously injured.
Army. Contract Surgeon Joseph Pettijohn is relieved from duty in the Department of the Columbia and will proceed to his home for annulment of contract.

Payment of subscriptions for the $24,000,000 Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific 4 per cent, gold bonds of 1902, now being offered by Speyer Co., is to be made to-morrow. Applications must specify the amount wanted and the series. There are sixteen series, maturing annually, and the price of all is computed on a 4 1/8 Per cent, basis of return to the investor.

LONDON, May 7 -- The Times devotes a longer obituary notice to Admiral Sampson than it does to Bret Harte. The paper describes the Admiral as one of the best seamen the American Navy ever possessed, and says his personal energy entered more largely than that of any other officer into the construction, armament, organization, and fighting qualities of the fleet that deleaved the Spaniards.

The racing at the Morris Park track yesterday fairly bubbled over with exciting incidents. Not all of these were of a pleasing character to the general public, however, and so the patrons rounded out the afternoon in their own fashion. Many were indignant and savagely critical of the doings and rulings of racing officials.

The Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York convened its one hundred and twenty-first annual communication yesterday afternoon in Masonic Hall, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue.

Controller GROUT is beginning to discuss matters connected with the improvement of facilities of intercommunication between Manhattan and Brooklyn with a good deal of intelligence. He is looking ahead, and those who fail to do this are not likely to contribute anything of value to the solution of this great and anxious problem.

The defense in the trial of Capt. Foody of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station rested yesterday and the case has been completed except for the submitting of briefs by Judge Olcott, the Captain's counsel. The decision will probably be given by Commissioner Partridge in about ten days. The usual motion to dismiss the charges was made by the accused's counsel and denied by Col. Partridge.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- Buying of Reading in the Philadelphia market was very heavy to-day, and this issue was the leader in strength. Brokers acting for Drexel Co. and for Cassatt Co were said to be the heaviest purchasers. Later other firms joined in the buying, and carried the stock up to 33 11-16, against 31 5/8 last night.

At the monthly meeting of the Board of Directors of the United States Steel Corporation, which was held yesterday. President Schwab read a report giving statistics of steel and iron productions in various countries for the year ended March 31, 1902, as well as details of the operations of the company which have not before been published.
THE HAGUE, May 7 -- Advices received here from Castle Loo, dated 1 o'clock this morning, state that Queen Wihelmina's condition again excites grave anxiety.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Mme. Godoy, wife of the Secretary of the Mexican Embassy, entertained this afternoon at a large reception which served to reopen her hospitable home after a six months' stay in Mexico. The house was decorated beautifully throughout, the dining room being especially attractive in great masses of snowballs and green foliage plants.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo.. May 6 -- At the opening of the beef trust inquiry in the State Supreme Court to-day Mr. Hagerman of Kansas City, representing the Armour, Cudahy, Swift Morris, and Hammond interests, filed an objection to the progress of the inquiry Mr. Hagerman, who was accompanied by Alexander New, said that he proposed to bring in question the validity of the State anti-trust law.

There is no administrative post in the world of which we may be more sure that the holder of it has attained it by merit, by dint of being the fittest man for it, than that of an Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Church in these United States. That a priest is the Archbishop of New York is evidence that he is an important man.

BOSTON, May 6 -- Money is firm; Clearing House rate, 6 per cent.; New York funds, 20c, 15c, and 10c discount; call loans, 4% to 6 per cent.; time money, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $28,185,433; balances, $2,020,994. The stock market rallied to-day, the coppers having an especially good day.

The City Real Property Investing Company has bought 62 Wall Street, a sixstory building on lot 25.5 by 117.8. The same company recently leased for three years, with the privilege of purchase, 58 and 60 Wall Street, and now controls a frontage of 61 feet. The owner of record of 62 Wall Street is Cordelia Schermerhorn Jones.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 6 -- The closing exercises incident to the ninetieth annual commencement of the Princeton Theological Seminary were held to-day. At the graduation exercises this morning William H. Stratton of Salem, N.J., made the final address to the class, after which Prof. Benjamin B. Warfield made the announcements of fellowships and distributed the diplomas.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Rear Admiral William T. Sampson, retired, died at his home in this city at 5 o'clock this afternoon. The immediate cause of death was a severe cerebral hemorrhage he suffered this morning. He had been in a, semi-conscious state for several days. At the bedside when the Admiral breathed his last were Mrs. Sampson, Mrs. Cluverius.

LONDON, May 7 -- The first meeting of the executors of the will of Cecil Rhodes was held in London yesterday, Dr. Jameson and L.L. Micell having arrived from South Africa with Mr. Rhodes's final instructions.

ROME, May 6 -- The Pope became greatly depressed when informed of the death of Archbishop Corrigan. His Holiness had been a constant inquirer for news during the Archbishop's illness, sending daily to the American College for information.

Heretofore it has been the custom with Sheriffs of Kings County to make up their juries from among the hangers-on about the Court House. Now, however, there is to be a change. Sheriff Dike, who is himself one of the best-known society and clubmen of Brooklyn, will have none of the Court House hangers-on in his juries.

BALTIMORE, May 6 -- The local market was again dull. Wall Street's weakness on Monday checked the trading, and Wall Street's strength to-day so amazed traders that they were unprepared to re-enter the market. There was some little improvement in Cotton Duck. It is expected that these issues will work higher, owing to the admitted good results in business now being accomplished.

Favored by the general strength of the Stock Exchange market, prices in the outside market yesterday showed a number of advances over the closing figures of Monday. With few exceptions the transactions were small, although a larger number of stocks participated in the trading than on the previous day.

It is just about a generation since the voice of BRET HARTE first came across the continent as the interpreter of the "Slope." There have been but few literary beginnings so striking. The Overland Monthly no sooner made its slow way across the continent than the scissors of every discerning reader for the newspapers of the East was busy with the successive contributions of its editor, alike in prose and verse.

CHICAGO, May 7. -- "Dummy" Taylor, the pitcher secured from the New York National League baseball team by Cleveland of the American League, has made another jump and has gone back to New York. He arrived at Chicago this morning in company with Catcher Bowerman of the New York Club, and admitted that he had left Cleveland, and would play with New York for the rest of the season.

In an article published in a recent issue of The Congregationalist and Christian World, Mr. EDWARD P. CLARK of the editorial staff of The Evening Post discusses the changes in journalistic practice during the last third of a century. Of these the most prominent in his judgment is the "democratization" of the press.

BOSTON, May 7. -- All sections of the country were represented in the delegates gathered here to-day to participate in the eighth annual meeting of the National Municipal League and the tenth National conferance for good city government. The sessions will continue until Friday evening. The first session was at the Twentieth Century Club, James C. Carter, President of the league, presiding.

Detective Sergeants O'Connell and Pepperted of Capt. Titus's staff yesterday made an important arrest in the apprehension of two San Francisco men, one of whom is charged with stealing the blue prints of the original plans of the Holland submarine boat and attempting to sell the same in this city.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 7. -- News believed to be perfectly reliable was received here to-night to the effect that Senator Hanna has cabled J. Pierpont Morgan, asking him to insist upon the coal operators granting the miners some slight concessions, and the officers of the United Mine Workers are awaiting Mr. Morgan's reply.

NEW ORLEANS, May 7. -- The question of the transfer of the Jewish Sabbath to the Christian Sunday engrossed the attention of the American Conference of Rabbis today, and the most important and interesting session in the course of the meeting resulted. The idea had its opponents and advocates -- the opponents basing their arguments upon creed and the advocates theirs upon the necessities of the times.

LOS ANGELES, May 7. -- The Nominating Committee of the National Federation of Women's Clubs has completed its list of officers, which is to be voted upon by the Federation to-morrow. The ticket follows:

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- According to the present arrangement, the funeral ceremonies over the remains of the late Rear Admiral Sampson will be held Friday morning at 10:30 o'clock at the Church of the Covenant. The remains then will be taken to Arlington for interment, accompanied by a military and naval escort.

Weakness marked the close of yesterday's Stock Exchange market, the depressing influence being contributed by reports representing that, after all, a big anthracite coal strike is imminent. In support of these reports no evidence of character was forthcoming; and, in fact, it was recognized that the statements came from speculative sources; but the Street accepted, offhand, the tales as they arrived, and the result was weakness throughout the whole stock list.
Dr. William Seward Webb gave out the following signed statement last night:

Yesterday was an extremely quiet day in the outside market. Practically no attention, at all was given to the Webb stocks, which recently have been the centre of interest, and in other parts of the list the transactions were generally so small that they attracted only passing interest. Prices were somewhat irregular, several sharp declines-occurring, while the majority of quotations showed little or no change.

William R. Smith and George McLaughlin, composing the firm of Worthington, Smith Co., wholesale dealers in millinery at 7 West Twenty-second Street, have filed a petition in bankruptcy with liabilities $115,877 and assets $86,690. The assets consist of stock, $20,000, pledged; accounts, $60,239, pledged; accounts not pledged, $2,916; bills of exchange, $1,393; fixtures, $1,550, and cash, $592.

The entertainment which was to have been given at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon by the boys of the Choir School of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was interrupted by the unexpected illness of Bishop Henry C. Potter.

The American Tract Society held its seventy-seventh annual meeting yesterday afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. President Roosevelt was elected an honorary Vice President, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of President McKinley, and the Rev. J. Ross Stevenson and William C. Bitting were elected to fill vacancies on the Board of Managers.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Senator Tillman was to-day treated to a severe and extraordinary rebuke by the entire Democratic side of the Senate, with the single exception of Senator Teller. The rebuke was delivered in a dramatic manner, and in the presence of a Senate crowd in the galleries and on the floor.

The remarks of the President-elect of Cuba in the island are marked by the spirit which every friend of the Cuban Republic must rejoice to see. He has made it plain that the new Government starts with a clean slate. It has no grudges to satisfy, no enemies to punish.

Mrs. Lillian Kelty of 154 West Thirtyfifth Street went to the Tenderloin Police Station yesterday afternoon, and asked that a policeman be sent to her house, as she expected trouble among her boarders. Although a policeman was sent, her expectations were realized, for at about 6 o'clock a young woman rushed into the police station and said to the Sergeant:
The resignation by Brig. Gen. Charles Bird of his commission as Lieutenant Colonel and Deputy Quartermaster General only has been accepted, to take effect May 5.

Racegoers at the Morris Park track yesterday put in an afternoon of tranquil enjoyment that contrasted pleasantly with the earlier days of the meeting. The sport was excellent, but without any unduly exciting incidents in the way of disqualifications or mishaps to favorites, and it added much to the satisfaction of an attendance of about 7,000 persons that the best-backed horses divided all the prizes.

Excited Broadway crowds yesterday witnessed what they thought might be destructive fires at the Fifth Avenue Hotel and the Hoffman House while the guests of the hotels wore entirely unconscious of the fancied danger.

The adjournment of the coat miners' convention at Stranton until to-day without definite action one way or the other on the question of a strike indicates that conservative counsels have thus far prevailed. The longer a strike' is postponed the less likely it is to occur. Everybody in interest is extremely mys- terious, answering questions very guardedly and carefully avoiding predictions as to the possible or probable outcome of the discussion.

At the annual meeting of the Mexican Central Railway yesterday, the old Board of Directors was re-elected with the exception that four new Directors, Gabriel Morton, Vice President of the Mexican National; E.N. Foss, Breckinridge Jones of St. Louis, and Pablo Martinez del Rio of Mexico, were elected to succeed E.R. Morse, John R. Davis, Charles J. Paine, and Joakum Rives.

BERLIN, May 7. -- Prof. K. Birkeland, the Norwegian physicist, has been in Berlin recently for the purpose of demonstrating the powers of his electro-magnetic gun before a number of experts in electrical artillery.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 7. -- The Tax Assessors to-day completed their assessment for the year and fixed the tax at the rate of $11.40 on each $1,000, last year's rate being $11 on $1,000. The real estate increased from $32,931,500 to $33,853,200, and the personal property from $7,694,400 to $7,900,000, making a total increase of $206,500 in valuation.

Bail to the amount of $12,000 was forfeited yesterday when Alfred R. Goslin failed to appear at the opening of the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court. Shortly after noon the man appeared with one of his counsel to surrender himself. He said that he had understood he was to have appeared at noon and had been slightly delayed in arriving.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 7. -- The dull record of the local market was very little changed to-day. Seaboard made another feeble effort to rally, but scored very little success. The trading continues indifferent. The Seaboard group could not be stimulated by even the report that the South is alarmed for fear lest the Southern Railway is preparing to swallow up the Seaboard system.

The four-story dwelling 426 Fifth Avenue, 22 by 100, has been sold by Edgar B. Van Winkle to F.V. and J.H. Burton for about $200,000. The purchasers, who are the owners of the Hotel St. Marc property, also acquired recently 428 and 430 Fifth Avenue, so that they now control a T-shaped plot having frontages of 122 feet on Fifth Avenue, 47 feet on Thirty-ninth Street, and 16 feet on Thirty-eighth Street.

Frank P. Sargent of the Arbitration Committee of the National Civic Federation, who was stopping at the Herald Square Hotel and had been hoping that the services of the committee might be asked to arbitrate the anthracite coal miners' troubles at the last moment, went to Albany yesterday.

LONDON, May 8. -- The Nationalist members of the House of Commons unsuccessfully attempted last night to force a vote of censure on the Speaker of the House, the Right Hon. William Court Gully, in connection with the suspension from the House for one week of John Dillon, (Nationalist,) who on March 20 called the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary, "a damned liar."

Dr. O.F. Britton of Indianapolis, Ind., better known among trap shooters by his shooting name of Dr. Fartington, won the preliminary handicap at 100 targets in the third annual Grand American Handicap target tournament at Inter-State Park, Long Island, yesterday, after a double tie with Edward Rike of Dayton, Ohio. Dr. Britton shot at 17 yards' rise and Rike at 18.

LONDON, May 7. -- There was a strongdemand for money to-day, though the pressure did not equal expectations. The trend of the market depended almost wholly on the magnitude of the Government disbursements. Discounts were steady.

SANTO DOMINGO, May 7. -- The Dominican capital capitulated to-day to the revolutionary forces commanded by Gen. Horatio Vasquez, the Vice President. President Jimenez sought refuge in the French Consulate, and many Government officers obtained shelter in the French and United States Legations.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Secretary Root has made the following response to the House resolution calling for copies of all orders sent to Gen. Smith and other officers relative to the campaign in Samar:

ALBANY, May 7. -- The judgment of conviction in the Supreme Court, Albany County, of Thomas J. Diamond, ex-Police Captain of New York City, for violating his duty as a public officer in permitting a disorderly house conducted by Lena Schmidt to remain open was to-day affirmed in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Third Department.

The New York and North Shore Railroad, a trolley line operating between Flushing and Jamaica, was sold at public auction in the Queens County Court House yesterday under foreclosure of a mortgage held by the New York Security and Trust Company. The road was bought in by William E. Stewart, counsel for the New York and Queens County Railroad Company, who said he had made the purchase for E. Clarence Miller of Philadelphia.
CLEVELAND, May 7. -- At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway Company, held here to-day, the following Directors were elected:

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A new move in the Philippine situation is contemplated by the Democrats, and will soon be brought up in open Senate. The Democrats will refrain from attempting to prevent the bringing of the bill to a vote, but they will insist that the Philippine Committee shall go to the archipelago this Fall and shall continue there the investigation which is now going on here.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- Despite the fall in the Readings the local stock market had a good tone, and nearly the whole array of active stocks kept up to last night's prices. The trading in Reading was very heavy for this market. Lehigh Valley was somewhat active but irregular. Other stocks which improved were Union Traction, Philadelphia Company, American Cement, Camden Land, and Consolidated Lake Superior.

ALBANY, May 7. -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, has handed down a decision declaring that policemen and firemen are public officials and that they come within the law which prohibits public officials riding upon passes or receiving free transportation because of the fact that they are connected with the administration of a city or village.

BOSTON, Mass., May 7. -- Rates for money except on call are purely nominal. A few sales of high grade paper have been made at 4 1/2 per cent., but banks prefer to take advantage of the 8 per cent. call money. Clearing House rate, 6 per cent. New York funds, par. Call loans, 4 1/2 to 6 per cent. Time money, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Manuel Rionda, a member of the sugar brokerage firm of Czarnikow, MacDougall Co. of New York and London, was before the Senate Committee on Relations with Cuba to-day. He estimated the annual product of the independent sugar refineries of the United States at 536,048 tons, and said that his firm sells more Cuban sugars to the independent refineries than to the trust.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The following hororary pall bearers have been selected to officiate at the funeral of Rear Admiral Sampson to-morrow:

ALBANY, May 8 -- Judge Earl, referee in the matter of the constitutionality of the New York State franchise tax law, declares the law constitutional on every point, and holds that the companies must pay the tax to their localities. The franchise tax law was passed during the administration of Gov. Theodore Roosevelt.

SALISBURY, Md., May 8 -- One of the largest timber transactions of the year has just been consummated here. Two-thirds interest of the Jackson Lumber Company of Lockhart, Ala., was sold to Edward S. Crossett and J.W. Watzek of Davenport, Iowa, and to Charles W. Gates of Fordyce, Ark.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 8 -- To 3/4 night the situation in the threatened miners' strike hangs on answers that are expected to come to a proposal of arbitration emanating from this morning's session of the Miners' Committee.

Judge Newburger was presiding in some policy cases yesterday when a pigeon flew in through the open window from its home under the eaves of the new city prison. Bewildered, it flew wildly about the court, and at length swooped near the jury. They tried to catch it, and the bird darted toward the Judge, but turning and flying low, made a swift drive past Assistant District Attorney Train, who grabbed at it frantically.

The home for decrepit and superannuated actors, which has been the dream for years of many of the leading members of the theatrical profession, became a reality indeed yesterday, when, amid the music of bands and speeches of noted men, the fine building at West Brighton, Staten Island, was dedicated and thrown open to the public for inspection.

Malcolm Ford was born in Brooklyn in the Clark Street house on Feb. 7, 1862. From his earliest boyhood days he exhibited an extraordinary enthusiasm for athletic sports, and contrary to all the traditions of his family he considered recess the best feature of his school life, for then in his own words: "I could get out and show all the boys what poor runners, jumpers, and wrestlers they were."

LONDON, May 9 -- The production at a special performance yesterday afternoon at the St. James's Theatre of a new play by Netta Syrett, called "The Finding of Nancy," had unusual significance, because the play was selected as the prize winner from some hundreds of manuscripts submitted to the Playgoers' Club.

A peculiar phase of east side life was illustrated yesterday in the incidents relating to the disappearance of Louis and Reuben Bonwell, aged twelve and ten years respectively, of 13 Pitt Street. The children left home last Monday morning ostensibly to attend Public School No. 3 on Henry Street.

The confirmation of Old England's success in the Toboggan Handicap, by another win of the California colt in even more impressive style for the Crotona Handicap, and the victorious first appearance this season of the famous black horse, Watercolor, the Winter favorite for the Suburban Handicap, stood out prominently as the features of an afternoon's racing at Morris Park yesterday.

Criticism on the part of the painters is sometimes heard directed against the exhibitions held at the National Arts Club to the effect that during the season more time is devoted to the arts and crafts, to municipal art, to mural work and stained glass, to sculpture, and so forth, than to painting, whereas the painter remains as he was before, the strongest element in the body artistic, and ought to be oftener recognized.

The ordinance of the Board of Aldermen designed to prevent the transfer of passengers at the convenience of the street railway companies when they desire to return cars to the depot, having been amended with a view to the elimination of some of the absurdities which characterized it in its original form, has been signed by the Mayor and is now law.

Private individuals have started a fight against the racing associations, basing their actions on the alleged fact that the latter are daily and openly violating the provisions of the State liquor law.

In modern medicine the tendency seems to be toward such a modification of ancient opinions and beliefs, long supported by the most eminent of students, investigators, and practitioners, as to indicate an ultimate confidence in the possibility of cure of most of the ills commonly described as incurable.

LONDON, May 8 -- Andrew Carnegie (who sailed from New York on April 30 on the American liner St. Louis) arrived in London to-day. In an interview he said there was no cause for British alarm re- garding the shipping combine.

The principal event of the third annual Grand American Handicap target tournament now in progress at Inter-State Park, L.I., was decided yesterday aftetrnoon, and was won by Charles W. Floyd, an amateur trap shooter of this city, who broke 90 of the possible 100 targets in the Grand American Handicap.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 8 -- The Rev. Martin Gessner, rector of St. Patrick's Church, fainted on the altar this morning while saying the high mass in recognition of Ascension Day. There were 1,000 worshippers in the church at the time. Father Gessner was carried to his room in the rectory and was fully revived.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., May 8 -- Mrs. Fayne Moore of New York City was to-day granted an absolute divorce by Judge Julian Bennett at Watertown, S.D., and given the right to resume her maiden name, Fayne Strahn. The divorce was granted on the grounds of extreme cruelty, non-support, and conviction of felony.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 8 -- Despite the fact that the coal operators, it is thought, show an unwillingness to consent to arbitration of the grievances of the coal miners, there is excellent reason to believe that there will be no coal strike.

The class of 1902 of New York University grave an entertainment last night for the benefit of the class debt, which as a show was the most successful ever held at University Heights. "The Senior Stunt in One Dozen Spasms" was the title of a humorous programme which contained not only the names of the performers, but also many "grinds" on the artists and audience.
MONTREAL, May 8 -- Archbishop Bruchesi, Vicar Gen. Rouceit, and the Rev. Father Callaghan, representing the Sulpicians, left for New York this evening to attend the funeral of the late Mgr. Corrigan.

PATERSON, N.J., May 8 -- The dyers helpers who are on strike for higher wages and shorter hours are still out. Some of the men who went to work in shops which had signed the schedule early in the strike came out again, claiming bad faith on the part of the employers, who they claimed had twisted things so that they could earn no more under the new scale than under the old one.

The Executive Committee of the United Irish League of America at the Hoffman House yesterday discussed the suspension by the English Government of the Constitution in Ireland. W. Bourke Cockran, William Redmond, Joseph Devlin, and others made speeches, and it was decided to issue an address.
LONDON, May 8 -- Money was somewhat easier to-day, and the demand was fair.

The annual report of the Michigan Central Railroad for 1901 was made public yesterday. The report shows a heavy increase in passenger traffic and earnings as compared with freight traffic and earnings. Passenger earnings increased by $754,474, while the increase for 1900 was only $289,731, and the increase in freight earnings was $982,418, as against an increase of $875,351 during 1900.

The estrangement of Malcolm W. Ford from his parents and his six brothers and sisters was due entirely to his taste for athletics and the stubbornness with which he persisted in appearing in public contests despite their protests. His ancestors for generations back had become prominent in the literary world, and with the one exception of Malcolm Ford, their tastes had descended to all the children of the present family.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8 -- The intercollegiate strength test recently ended has been won by Harvard with a total of 74,596.1 points, this being the aggregate score of her fifty strongest men. Columbia is second with 72,648.7; University of Minnesota third, 66,813.2; Amherst fourth, 55,307,1.
Paul R. Towne has sold the plot of seven lots at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street, 100 by 175.

The acephalous condition of the Democratic Party was again forcibly illustrated in the Senate on Wednesday.
