This particular demonstration seemed to indicate acephalousness not only in the sense of lack of leadership, but in the sense of lack of brains. We are informed that all the Democratic Senators left the chamber in order to mark their sense of the impolicy of the speech of Senator TILLMAN.

BALTIMORE, May 8 -- The local market was better to-day. The afternoon session found the market more active than has been the record for more than a week. The favorable outlook in the strike controversy prompted some better buying, because the Street concluded that no strike in the coal regions will mean a resumption of bull sentiment in Wall Street.

The baseball season of the Eastern League in Jersey City was opened yesterday with a game between Jersey City and Montreal, which the home team won by a score of 8 to 3. The covered and uncovered stands on the new grounds were taxed to their utmost capacity, and a fringe of spectators stood along the fence back of the right field foul line.

BALLSTON, N.Y., May 8 -- Mrs. Eliza- beth Gross Casey, mother of Mrs. Samuel Smith, and grandmother of Cora, Countess of Strafford, and Sydney Smith of New York, died at her home here to-day, aged ninety years.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 1 -- The latest news from Guatemala says that as a result of the earthquake on April 18 over 1,000 persons were killed and more than 30,000 are homeless. The town of Quezaltenango was almost totally destroyed.

It is a turtle, about natural size and looking very much like the genuine article until its back is up, and then it may be seen that it has utilitarian value. The back of the turtle being raised discloses the long wick of an alcohol lamp, for the turtle is intended for the frivolous girl who curls her hair with the curling tongs.

BOSTON, Mass., May 8 -- Call money has been quite generally marked up to 5 per cent., and much of the business is being done at 6 per cent. Time loans are also firmer. Clearing House rate, 6 per cent. New York funds par. Call loans, 5 to 6. Time money, 4 1/2 to 5. Clearing House exchanges, $20,962,438.

LONDON, May 8 -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve decreased, L276,000; circulation increased, L119,000; bullion decreased, L157,482; other securities decreased, L4,444,000; other deposits decreased, L2,300,000; public deposits decreased, L2,453,000: total reserve decreased, L278,000; Government securities increased, L20,000.

Despondent because of financial reverses, as is believed, Harry H. Starkey committed suicide yesterday morning by shooting himself in a room in the club house of the Brooklyn Union League Club on Grant Square. Mr. Starkey was about forty-two years old and lived with his wife at the St. Mark's Hotel, Bedford and St. Mark's Avenues, Brooklyn.
GUATEMALA CITY, April 24 -- For nearly a week earthquakes have been tumbling down cities, towns, and villages on the western slope of the Sierras in this republic.
The most remarkable of volcanic outbreaks on record are those of Etna, almost from time immemorial, and the great eruption of Vesuvius in 70 A.D., which destroyed Pompeii and Herulaneum.

Total transactions on the Stock Exchange fell yesterday below what recently have been average aggregates; instead of passing the million-share mark, the figures were around 600,000. This relative inactivity is easily traceable to the uncertainty, not to say uneasiness, induced by the coal trade controversy.

Malcolm W. Ford, the athlete and magazine writer, yesterday morning murdered his brother, Paul Leicester Ford, the invalid and novelist. Malcolm W. Ford was insane, according to the testimony of those who knew him best. Members of his family say he had been partially demented some time, but that there appeared to be no reason for confining him in an asylum.
BOSTON, May 8 -- In a paper on " A NonPartisan Administration," delivered before the National Municipal League to-day here, E.A. Philbin, ex-District Attorney of New York, said:

Paul Leicester Ford was born in Brooklyn, March 23, 1865. He was one of seven children of Gordon L. Ford, who died in November, 1891. Gordon L. Ford was born in Connecticut in 1823, and moved to this city in 1835, and began the study of law. He was admitted to the bar in 1850. In 1852 he was chosen President of the New London, Willimantic, and Palmer Railroad Company.
Capt. William H.H. Chapman, Twenty-fifth Infantry, is transferred from Company K to Company H of that regiment.
ST. THOMAS, Danish West Indies, May 8 -- 7 P.M. -- The British steamer Roddam, Capt. Freeman, which left St. Lucia yesterday for Martinique, returned to St. Lucia at 5 o'clock this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- The Philadelphia market to-day was irregular and dull, excepting Readings, which followed the course in New York. Price movements were commonplace, though generally slightly upward. An exception was Electric Storage Battery, which declined 2 1/2 points in the early trading, the loss being subsequently regained.

Two steady streams of people of all ages and conditions of life flowed through St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday from early morning until late at night paying silent homage to the mortal remains of Archbishop Corrigan. Stationed at the head and foot of the stately catafalque, on which the body of the dead Archbishop reposed, were two soldiers of the Sixty-ninth Regiment of the National Guard of New York with arms at rest.

Halstead Lindsley of Harvard, who held the individual intercollegiate golf championship during the past year up to yesterday, was defeated in the first match play round in defense of his title for the coming year. A new champion will, therefore, arise at the close of the present intercollegiate tournament at Garden City tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Secretary Shaw to-day issued amended regulations governing the inspection of baggage of incoming passengers at the ports of the United States. The Secretary also has prepared a circular which will be distributed among passengers on all outgoing steamers giving information as to rates of duty on goods usually purchased abroad by tourists.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 8 -- The Gould team won the finals in the Lakewood polo tournament series for the Herbert trophies this afternoon. They played against Rockaway, defeating them by a score of 10 3/4 goals to 7. The Lakewood team was composed of George J. Gould, his sons, Kingdon and Jay, and the veteran Ben Nicoll.
Concerning the report of Referee Earl in the franchise tax cases. President Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway said:
LOS ANGELES, May 8 -- Mrs. Dimies T. S. Denison is elected President of the General Federation of Women's Clubs by a ballot vote of 667, to 258 for Mrs. Sarah Platt-Decker.

At the public hearing of the Rapid Transit Board yesterday, schemes were submitted for relieving the pressure on the Brooklyn Bridge, that involved everything from making a station out of the Pulitzer Building to acquiring the City Hall Park, condemning the Staats-Zeitung Building, building a tunnel under the East River, and digging a subterranean passage from the end of the Brooklyn Bridge in Manhattan, to the end of the new Williamsburg Bridge.

Mrs. Hetty R. Green, the richest woman in America, now carries a revolver. She says she has been threatened several times, and, as she frequently has much money and negotiable paper about her, she wants to be in a position to protect herself.

"Little Miss Mouse," which was given in an author's matinee at Wallack's Theatre yesterday, was translated and abridged by Katherine Berry di Zerega from the French of Edouard Pailleron and arranged on the stage by Dore Davidson.

A complimentary dinner was given in honor of Lord and Lady Kelvin yesterday evening at Delmonico's by A.N. Brady, at which some fifty men well known in the field of electricity, electric railroading and lighting were present with their wives. They sat around a large oblong table decorated with evergreens and roses.

Dr. Robert Stewart of the Jersey City Health Board yesterday went before the Second Criminal Court and made complaint against three women known as Sisters Earle, Carter, and Cressy, claiming to be "divine healers" connected with the Elsey Memorial Church of the Faith Curists.

LYNN, Mass., May 8 -- "Impossible! Impossible! Impossible!" cried Worthington C. Ford to-night when informed by a reporter that his brother Malcolm had shot and killed his brother Paul and then killed himself.

The Presidents of the principal anthracite coal roads met late yesterday afternoon in the office of Coxe Brothers, at which the coal situation was considered. Nothing of a positive nature could be learned about the result of the meeting, but it was reported that there would be no concessions to the miners.

LONDON, May 8 -- At this morning's session of the Iron and Steel Institute it was announced that the Andrew Carnegie scholarships for this year had been awarded to William Campbell of Columbia University. New York; to three Englishmen, to a Parisian, and to a resident of Berlin. The scholarships are intended to promote researches in metallurgy.

Negotiations are under way for a change in control of the Detroit Southern Railway. There are two large systems after this road, but neither of them has as yet been able to close the deal. One of these systems is supposed to be the Norfolk and Western, for which the Detroit Southern Road would make an excellent connection to the lakes.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 8 -- The result of the Republican State Convention held here to-day was a decisive victory for the State administration and for what is known as the "Yates-Hopkins-Lorimer-Northcott combination." The convention indorsed the administration of Gov. Yates and the candidacy of Congressman Albert J. Hopkins of Aurora for the United States Senator-ship by an overwhelming majority.
LONDON, May 8 -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Associated Press, after a personal investigation of the situation in southern Russia, writes from Moscow, under date of May 3, as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The United States has won a sweeping victory in the matter of the arbitration of the dispute with the Republic of Salvador over the claim of the Salvador Commercial Company and other citizens of the United States, stockholders in the corporation El Triumfo Company, Limited, created under the laws of Salvador.
PARIS, May 9. -- The commander of the French cruiser Suchet has telegraphed to the Minister of Marine, M. de Lanessan, from Fort-de-France, Martinique, under date of May 8, 10 P.M., as follows:
Twin City Rapid Transit Company to sell 15,000 shares of common stock at par to present holders.

LONDON, May 9. -- Supplies were scarce to-day, rates hardened, and money was much wanted for repayments to the Bank of England and for tenders amounting to u2,300,000 in Treasury bills. Discounts were firm.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two of your correspondents, "E.S.O." and "Justice," took exceptions, in last Sunday's TIMES, to my previous approval of the action of the Board of Education in making certain reforms.

Whatever, in the tangled web of possible motives, may be the true clue to the awful act of MALCOLM FORD, no one can be insensitive to the loss the act has inflicted on American letters and on the social and intellectual life of the community in which its victim dwelt.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- At the meeting of the Senate Philippines Committee this morning Chairman Lodge read a letter he had received from Gen. Funston, saying that John Nicholson of Norfolk, Va., formerly a Sergeant of the Fourth Cavalry, had accused him (Funston) of originating the "water cure."

In the Eastern League game between Montreal and Jersey City at West Side Park yesterday the Canadian baseball players defeated the home team in ten innings by a score of 7 to 4. A strong wind was in evidence throughout the game, and the spectators and players alike were chilled with cold.

St. Pierre was one of the most beautiful cities in the West Indies. Here were splendid homes, great factories, and magnificent estates. The loss of the city means the destruction of millions of dollars' worth of property, according to men who have been to St. Pierre and are familiar with its business affairs.

ONE of the striking facts in the lives of Paul Leicester Ford and his brother, Malcolm W. Ford, was the complete success which each brother won in his chosen field, and in the various kinds of work into which those fields may, be divided.

Mont Pelee, from whose immense crater has gushed forth all the terrible destruction, wrought in Martinique, was up to a few weeks ago a most peaceful mountain. After the short eruption of 1831, the fumes and fires sank back into the earth, and in the heart of the cone only a small lake was left.

The latest news from Scranton, where the Executive Committee of the United Mine Workers is in session, is that a general strike of the anthracite miners has been ordered for Monday. How much or little importance to attach to this announcement it is impossible to say at the moment.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of April 23 it is told on the editorial page that Mrs. Sarah Cowell Le Moyne. the wellknown actress, is preparing her reminiscences, and that they will probably be given to the public next year. Then the article goes on to say:

The death of Bret Harte invites attention to the wonderful power of this man in preserving the freshness of his fancy in a field which he had cultivated for so many years. His stories of the life of the western coast of the United States never lost their charm, their striking vitality, their convincing verisimilitude.
Reports current yesterday relative to the establishment of a new dry goods store on the McAlpin estate's property at Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street, are referred to in another column.

BOSTON, May 8. -- Mr. Charles G. D. Roberts's "The Kindred of the Wild," will be ready next Thursday. It resembles "Earth's Enigmas" rather than "The Heart of the Ancient Wood," and like both of them, it does not imitate Mr. Kipling, Messrs. L.C. Page Co., Mr. Roberts's present publishers, also announce "The Best of Stevenson" for issue this month, and "The Best of Poe," for August.

Louis N. Chase, the former California lawn tennis champion, and Louis V. Ledoux played a fiercely contested match yesterday for the place in the final round of the Columbia University championship tournament before Chase gained the victory. It was the most bitter competition that has taken place on the South Field courts.

Materially less than half a million shares were traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, and few movements of noteworthy character were recorded. It was in many ways a waiting day -- traders big and little being disposed to look on rather than engage in activity.

SOME sixteen years since two young men, graduates respectively of West Point and Annapolis, were thrown much together in a far Western city; first, because they happened to live in the same boarding house; second, because there was a thorough congeniality between them, fostered, perhaps, by the fact that they represented the miltary and naval training bestowed by the United States at the schools mentioned.
LONDON, May 10 -- The belief now exists that the British West Indian Islands of Dominica and St. Vincent have suffered severely:

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- The weakness of the Wall Street market did not have much effect here. While most of the issues closed with slight losses, in some instances there were notable gains. United Gas Improvement, Union Traction, International Power and Dynamite, and Marsden were better.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

LONDON, May 9. -- Distrust and resentment are the keynotes to the comments of all the afternoon newspapers here on the shipping combine agreements. They all refer wrathfully to the recent denials of Messrs. Ismay and Pirrie, respectively, of the White Star Line, and Harland Wolff, of what now proves to have been absolutely true.

On the steamship Roraima, which is reported to have gone down in the harbor of St. Pierre with all hands, were consignments from some forty shippers. Almost every American exporter doing business with Martinique was represented.

LONDON, May 10. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times telegraphs that no serious results of the recent outbreaks in Kharkoff and Poltava and at Moscow are apprehended immediately. The revolt among the Southern peasants has been suppressed and there is a lull in the Moscow labor agitation, the mass of the workmen having gone to their villages to keep the Easter holidays.

THE new edition of Chambers's Cyclopedia of English Literature, "a history, critical and biographical, of authors in the English tongue, from the earliest times till the present day, with specimens of their writings," adequately fulfills this description of itself which is printed on its title page.

LONDON May 9 -- King Edward has commissioned J. E.C. Bodley to write the official account of the coronation ceremony, which will be published in two editions, one of which will be for popular circulation.
ST. THOMAS, Danish West Indies, May 9. -- It is now estimated that forty thousand persons perished as a result of the volcanic eruption in the Island of Martinique.

It is a century and a half since there has been so destructive a "convulsion of nature" as that which has now annihilated the principal town of Martinique, and the most populous of the settlements remaining under the French flag on this side of the Atlantic. 1755 --

BOSTON, May 9. -- So far as is known no Boston vessel was at St. Pierre or in the immediate vicinity at the time of the destruction of the place. Grave fears, however, are expressed for the safety of the three-masted schooner Anna E.J. Morse, Capt. Crocker, which arrived at St. Pierre on April 24 from Philadelphia with a cargo of coal, and which is thought to have been lost there.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 9. -- The Wage Committee of the Window Glass Workers' Association, representing the Burns faction, met in conference to-day with the American Window Glass Company and agreed to the proposition of the company to close the fires from May 24 until Oct. 1.

Mrs. HETTY GREEN is commonly described, we know not how truly, as "the richest woman in America." She also describes herself, we know not how acurately, as a good business woman, or words to that effect. That she is an extremely unfortunate or else a highly litigious woman no reader of the newspapers can entertain a doubt.

A correspondent appeals to us to expose what he describes as a "literary fraud." A periodical which we do not particularly care to help him advertise arranged a "story tellers' tournament," offering prizes ranging from $100 to $2,100. One of the conditions was that each competitor should subscribe for the periodical in question.

Charles Hitchcock, Jr., of Yale and H. B. McFarland of the University of Pennsylvania will meet to-day in the final thirty-six-hole round on the links of the Garden City Golf Club, for the intercollegiate championship. Hitchcock now holds the championship honors of his university, and last year he was runner-up for the greater honor to Halstead Lindsley of Harvard, at Atlantic City.

The President of one of the leading anthracite coal roads said yesterday that an important message had been received from Scranton, but he declined to disclose the nature of the communication. Any word of this sort, he said, would have to come from the miners.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 9. -- A general striKe of the miners of the anthracite region has been ordered for Monday next, but the order has a reserve qualification attached. The question as to whether the strike is to be made permanent is left to the decision of a convention of delegates of all the local organizations of the mine workers to be held at Hazleton next Wednesday.

Mr. Arthur Machen has written an interesting book entitled "Hieroglyphics." That is to say, it is interesting to bookish people. Mr. Machen has a theory as to what constitutes the highest excellence in literature, and he unfolds his theory in his new book in a way that is probably convincing to himself, whatever it may be to other people.
Copyright, 1902. by John R. whitney. SUBJECT -- The early Christian missionaries. Acts, xiii., 1-12.

DOVER, Del., May 9 -- The "Union Republican" members of the Legislature, who are in the majority and who stood out for the election of J.E. Addicks as one of the two United States Senators from Delaware, thereby causing a dead-lock and consequent failure to elect, met at the State House here to-day and reiterated their determination to insist upon their right to name one of the Senators.

I SUPPOSE I am one of the few remaining writers who welcomed Bret Harte on his triumphant arrival in New York after the success of his "The Luck of Roaring Camp." It was my great good fortune to remain his friend through all his life, occasionally to correspond with him, to see him London in 1880-7 and subsequent years, and to remain one of his literary adorers to the last.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Although Senator Lodge was not successful this afternoon when he made an effort to have a time fixed for voting on the Philippines Government bill the discussion on his request indicated clearly that there is no intention on the part of the minority of the Senate to kill the bill with talk.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- The New York baseball team suffered another crushing defeat at the hands of Chicago to-day when they were beaten by a score of 5 to 0. Evans, who had won all his games so far, was evidently in poor form. Besides being hit hard, Chicago profited by his wildness, six bases on balls, two batsmen hit, and three wild pitches doing their share of damage.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., May 9. -- The gun tests of the ships of the North Atlantic Squadron outside of the capes at the Southern drill grounds this week resulted in a remarkably good showing by all of the vessels, and a phenomenal record for the battleship Kearsarge, which is a product of the Newport News Ship Building and Dry Dock Company, and which will come here to-morrow for coal.

BERLIN, May 9. -- A conference of chemists and meat packers was held here today to protest against the prohibition of the Bundesrath concerning the use of boracic acid in the preservation of meat and the importation of meats so preserved, served.

To the reader of a deliberate turn of mind "Michael Ross, Minister," presents some difficulties. The author does her best to make it understood that Great Lowlands, some small English provincial town, is a hotbed of emotions. With but few exceptions all the marriageable females in the place set their caps for Michael Ross, the young Independent clergyman.

What the police consider the most successful of recent poolroom raids was that made by inspector Brooks, Capt. Chapman, and a force of disguised policemen yesterday on "The" Alien's West Side Club, 80 Sixth Avenue.

Is "The Winding Road" to be called a sentimental journey with violin obbilgatos and harp arpeggios? Musical in a certain sense is the romance, for there are Hungarian airs and gypsy strains, with reminiscences of Grieg, but the story may stand alone, and does not want any string accompaniment. "The Winding Road" is as wild a story as ever was thought of, and in its conception undoubted talent has been shown.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 9. -- There is the liveliest kind of a fight between the Louisville and Nashville and the Southern Railroads. They have entered an agreement about equally dividing the Clear Fork Valley, and neither road shall enter with a construction crew in the part assigned to the other without giving twenty-four hours' notice.
"The Confessions of a Wife." Whoever Mary Adams may be, she is giving to the public an uncommonly clever plece of work in her "Confessions of a Wife." begun in the April number of The Century.

The involvement of Inspector CROSS in the charges against Sergt. CHURCHILL, for dereliction of duty as acting Captain of one of the east side precincts which was shown by raids to be honeycombed by vice of the most flagrant and outrageous kind, suggests a wonder that in the prosecution of delinquent Captains the Inspectors have not hitherto been included as a matter of course.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- With a pomp and circumstance exceeding that of any naval funeral in this country, in recent years at least, the remains of the late William Thomas Sampson, Rear Admiral in the United States Navy, and Commander in Chief of the United States naval forces on the North Atlantic Station during the war with Spain, were to-day laid at rest.

Troubles at Columbia University which culminated in the failure to provide for the employment of Lewis Nathaniel Chase as a tutor in the Comparative Literature Department for next year, thereby curtailing the teaching force of the department and exciting protests from alumni, students, and others, brought forth a statement from President Nicholas Murray Butler and a counter statement from The Columbia Spectator yesterday.
The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I send you the inclosed "screamers," clipped from a local paper. They are undoubtedly genuine, and the work or highschool scholars:

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 9 -- Attorney General Crow to-night filed in the Supreme Court ouster proceedings against the Armour Packing Company, the Hammond Packing Company, the Cudahy Packing Company, Armour Co., and the Krug Packing Company for alleged violation of the State anti-trust laws in combining to fix and maintain prices and to control the supply of dressed, cured, and smoked meats and lard in Missouri.

Controller Grout and President Cantor of the Borough of Manhattan had a heated discussion at the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday as to the appropriation of $40.000 for illuminated street signs in the Borough of Manhattan. President Cantor has shown great interest in this matter, while Controller Grout has opposed the amount of the appropriation.

We have already alluded to the childish behavior of the Democratic Senators in connection with their inconveniently candid colleague from South Carolina. We do not wish to be understood that it is the Democrats alone who have erred and erred seriously, in the temper with which they have conducted the so-called debate oh the Philippine question.

ROME, May 9. -- There was a memorial service in honor of Archbishop Corrigan of New York this morning in the chapel of the American College here. Bishop McDonnell of Brooklyn, N.Y., celebrated a requiem mass and Cardinal Satolli assisted.

In considering Miss MacLane of Montana -- who naturally comes to us via Chicago -- one wonders whether one has really a young woman to score with or only a tub thrown to amuse whales. Though the book is professedly diarial, many may be Betsy Priggish enough to declare a belief that there's no such person.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Senator and Mrs. Hanna gave a dinner this evening in honor of the French Ambassador and Mme. Cambon. The additional guests included the German Ambassador. Gov. Taft, Senator and Mrs. Hale, Senator Allison, Mrs: Wetmore, the Assistant Secretary of War and Mrs. William Gary Sanger, Mr. and Mrs. Crackanthorpe, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Walsh. Mrs. Slater, Miss Patton, Miss Phelps, and M. Boeufve of the French Embassy.

THIS memoir of Anna Amalia, Grand Duchess of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach, and the founder and leading spirit in the classical circle of Weimar in the days of Goethe, Richter, Wieland, Herder, and others, now for the first time presents this famous woman to English readers.

CINCINNATI, May 9 -- James Gilmore is twenty-six years of age, and is a son of Virgil Gilmore, a retired Banker of Cincinnati. The family is one of the oldest in the Ohio Valley and one of great wealth. James went abroad about six years ago to perfect his studies in engineering and mathematics.

Fifty Inspectors of the Health Department, with a, number of policemen of the Sanitary Squad and many more patrolmen of the Police Department, numbering over a hundred men in all, started out about 10 o'clock last night to make raids on some 250 of the milk dealers who bring milk into this city every night.

LONDON, April 30 -- Mrs. Everard Cotes, who is better known as Miss Sarah Jeannette Duncan, is a woman with a true sense of humor. There are several professional male humorists who have made a reputation for humor, but who have not half Mrs. Cotes's knowledge of what real humor is.
Trade reports to the several commercial agencies of the country continue favorable. Bradstreet's sums the situation up as follows:

BOSTON, May 9. -- The money market shows little change; business is light. Clearing House rate, 6 and 5 per cent. New York funds, par. Call loans, 5 to 6. Time money, 4 1/2 to 5. Clearing House exchanges, $23,033,780; balances, $1,540,767. Mass, Copper Range, and Adventure led the copper stocks in an upward movement to-day, which, however, eased off in late dealings.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- "Hearts Courageous," Hallie Ermine Rives's new novel, to be published within the week by the Bowen-Merrill Company, is destined to create more than mere interest in this Quaker city. It is a historical story of the most engrossing period of the country's struggle for liberty and contains stirring scenes.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 9. -- A dispatch from Monterey, Mexico, says Philip C. Hanna, United States Consul General at Monterey, has compiled a statement showing that $200,000,000 of American money has been invested in mining and industrial enterprises in Northern Mexico during the last two years.

"MYRA of the Pines," by Herman K. Viele, author of "The Inn of the Silver Moon" and "The Last of the Knickerbockers," is a story of modern times. It tells of a family who at the lowest ebb of their fortunes find refuge in the pinelands, a large tract of uncultivated land that a mythical "company" is going to explore some time.

When the novel called "The New Americans" was published a few months ago, the literary critics saw that a new and ambitious figure had appeared on the literary horizon. But Alfred J. Hodder had already made himself known to students of philosophy by an equally ambitious philosophical work, published last year, and highly praised by authoritative reviewers.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Senator Depew seems to have pretty effectually killed the resolution for the popular election of Senators with his little amendment providing or Federal supervision of such elections. By a combination between the people opposed to the resolution and those in favor of Federal supervision, the amendment as been tacked on to the resolution in committee, and the result is a dead-lock.

BALTIMORE, May 9. -- The movement in Cotton Duck incomes attracted attention to-day, as the buying was of a character which indicated that insiders were likely to fail in their wishes to keep the price down. Outsiders seem to be taking the market a little in their own hands. The Street has positive statements from members of the Directorate that the accruing interest on the incomes are being earned.

Mr. Quiller-Couch on Lady Novelists. An interview between Mr. Quiller-Couch ("Q") and Harold Begble was recently published in a London paper. The author discussed women as novelists. He said that they think of nothing but what "they call the sex problem."

Reports which have been current for some time, but concerning which authoritative information is withheld, lead strongly to the belief that the D.H. McAlpin estate's property on the east side of Broadway, between Thirty-third and Thirtyfourth Streets, will soon be made the site of a new department store.

There will be much of interest in the suburbs to-day. At Morristown there is to be the Saturday tea and golf match; Tuxedo, Meadow Brook, and Ardsley have all attractive programmes, and there are many week-end parties. Among those entertaining are Mr. and Mrs. H. McK. Twombly at Florham, and Mr. and Mrs. George Gould at Georgian Court.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Senate today confirmed the nomination of H. Clay Evans to be Consul General at London.

Senator DEPEW is to be congratulated upon the device by which he has so amended in committee the proposed bill providing for the election of Senators by the people that it now suits nobody, least of all its original advocates. The Senator's position is quite logical. The Constitution provides that Senators shall be elected by the several Legislatures.

The news cabled from Rome yesterday to The Baltimore Sun was nor unexpected by a few persons who were aware of the value of the Massaranti collection, knew that its owner wished to sell to America and had hoped that it might be secured for New York. The price given, $1,000,000, will seem large only to those who do not know what the collection contains.

IT is astonishing how much the ordinary mortal who has loved and possibly cultivated plants for half a lifetime doesn't know about them. Here are some hints which at this season of the year will be welcome to amateurs.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- To-day's statement of the Treasury balances in the general fund, exclusive of the $150,000,000 gold reserve in the division of redemption, shows:

ALBANY, May 10 -- The American Railroad Company at Porto Rico, with its principal office in New York City, was incorporated to-day, to operate a narrowgauge steam road which has been partially built and is being operated at present between various cities and towns of the Island of Porto Rico by the Compania de Los Ferrocarrilles de Puerto Rico, a Spanish corporation.

ANNAPOLIS, May 10 -- Yale defeated the naval cadets in the eight-oared race on the Severn this afternoon by two lengths over a two-mile course. The winning crew rowed the course in the fine time of 9:40 1/2, with some wind aiding them, Annapolis finishing four seconds behind.

Wall Street's week closes with a bank statement which is characterized as "bad." Aproximately $8,000,000 deposits disappear, while loan accounts decrease only about a quarter as much, changes in the item of specie and legaltender holdings diminishing $3,300,000 and $2,600,000 respectively -- the showing involving a decline of over $15,000,000 in reserves and a surplus shrinkage beyond $4,000,000.
With additional information of the calamity at St. Pierre, Martinique, its horror increases.

THE season had ended. The music critic was seated in a low chair before a smoldering fire. He was weary and ill at ease, and more than half suspected that he was suffering from tenosynovitis, complicated with heart fag. He was silently contemplating a vellum ping-pong racquet and cursing it because it was out of tune with its fellow.

MELROSE, Mass., May 10 -- Miss Alice Fry, sister-in-law of Thomas T. Prentis, United States Consul at St. Pierre, thinks that he and his family may have escaped, as a tetter she received from Mrs. Prentis this morning indicates that they appreciated their danger when the Mount Pelee volcano first displayed signs of activity, about April 25, which date the letter bears, and had made plans to leave if occasion arose.

For the appreciation which has taken place in the market position of the stock of the Canadian Pacific there is the substantial basis of increased earnings and profits. Gains have been marked. In fact, they have given rise to no little discussion concerning the awakening of Canada, the development of the Dominion on broader lines of trade and commerce, the growth of its industries, and like encouraging features in the progress of our Northern neighbor.

SOUTH CHANGE, N.J., May 10 -- The results in the first round in the contest for the May Cup at the South Orange Field Club links, held this afternoon, were: Class A -- Frank Hodson, Jr., beat Dr. M.E. Waldstein by default; C.B. Jenkinson, second, beat George W. Hutchinson, 5 up and 3 to go; E.E. Lethbridge and Joseph F. Taylor, match not finished; M.M. Armstrong beat J.D. Gordon, 3 up and 1 to go.

News of the arrest in Burlington, Iowa, of W.R. Mahannah, formerly an Adams Express Company messenger, for alleged connection with the theft of a $20,000 package from the Commercial National Bank in this city two years ago, brought much satisfaction to the officers and employes of that institution.

LONDON, May 10 -- Beerbohm Tree is preparing a series of special Shakespearean matinees for the coronation season. The first play will be "The Merry Wives of Windsor." He is also arranging a notable matinee benefit for Herman Merivale, who is ill and poor. Aug. 30 has been fixed as the date for the first performance of Huntly McCarthy's "If I Were King," at the St. James's Theatre.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noticed the communication, from "A. B.J." in THE TIMES of May 4 and regarded it as the extreme view of an ultra-protectionist who is willing to make use of any argument to sustain his position.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 10 -- With hundreds of people on the beach in the mornings, and a score or more in bathing, one can imagine that Summer is already here, although the scene is not as animated as in July or August.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 10 -- The Stationary Firemen's Executive Committee held a meeting here this evening and issued the following statement through State Secretary J.F. Mullahy:

BOSTON, Mass., May 10 -- The money market closes the week dull but firm. Clearing house rate, 6 per cent. New York funds, par and 5 cents discount. Call loans, 5@6 per cent. Time money, 4 1/2 @ 5. Clearing house exchanges, $20,298,71; balances, $1,330,997. The stock market to-day was rather dull, but the coppers held fairly well.

Early last evening the physician who has been attending the three-year-old son of Thomas Kiernan, the caretaker at the Road Drivers' Association's new club, discovered that the boy was suffering from a bad case of smallpox. The Board of Health was notified and arrangements were at once made to have the child conveyed to North Brother Island.

A little group of literary men were discussing the distinct loss sustained by American letters in the death of Bret Harte. One of them related the story of how Harte came to lose his post as Consul at Glasgow.

Japanese artists, having little or no knowledge of anatomy, could not draw the human figure with anything approaching classic accuracy; but the history of Matsumoto Kisaburo and his school completely upsets this theory. This man, in the rank of an ordinary mechanic, suddenly began to sculpture wooden figures as faultlessly anatomically as the works of Greek masters.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- With the full approval of Attorney General P.C. Knox, representing the National Government, District Attorney S.C. Bethea this evening filed with the Clerk of the Federal Circuit Court here a bill for an injunction, sweeping in character, designed to destroy the alleged giant conspiracy to illegally control the meat trade of the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- It is not improbable that the disaster at Martinique is merely the first of a series of disturbances, either by volcano or by earthquake. Prof. Robert T. Hill of the Geological Survey, who was the geologist of the Agassiz West Indian expedition and is one of the best-posted men in Washington on the subject, said to-day:

A fire which started in the hay mow on the top floor of the San Francisco Boarding Stable, occupying the buildings from 120 to 126 West Fifty-second Street, at 8:30 o'clock last evening, caused some lively scampering among a lot of very fine horses. It caused considerable activity among their owners also, for many of the animals which were stabled in the place cost the owners $1,000 or more.

Charles Drabow, assistant engineer, and Charles Butler, assistant purser of the steamship Imogene. now lying at Bayonne, N.J., messmates and friends, had a most peculiar meeting on the board walk at Thompson's Walk and the Bowery, Coney Island, shortly before midnight last night. They were both off duty and had reached the island by different ways, and neither knew of the other's presence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A great deal is said about our dirty streets, and New York is pointed out at home and abroad as the place where dirt and wickedness must be expected, despite the large amount of good that is accomplished.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Senate today, in the course of its discussion of a proposition relating to the special Embassy to the coronation of King Edward, practically declared its disapproval of the Embassy and its wish that no other embassies of similar character ever should proceed from this country.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- An interesting suggestion in connection with the Martinique eruption was made to-day by an expert in one of the scientific departments of the Government, who did not wish his name used. It was with regard to the probable effect upon the Nicaragua Canal, should it be built, of disasters similar to the one which has just occurred.

Yesterday was the dullest day that the outside market has had in several weeks. With the exception of General Carriage, the trading in which reached a fairly large total, the transactions were small, and prices moved within narrow limits. Quotations showed some irregularity, but most of the declines that occurred as well as the advances were fractional.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 10 -- The Princeton-Amherst dual track meet held here this afternoon was closely contested throughout and was not decided until the last events were run off. Princeton won with 63 1/2 points against 53 1/2 for Amherst. Notwithstanding the strong wind which was blowing up the track, good time was made.

My French Lesson. Down in the garden, in the shade. Where Cupid placed an artful bench I linger with the little maid Who daily tries to teach me French; But ah, my lips will learn no more Than "Je vous aime, je vous adore."

Charlemagne Tower, the United States Ambassador to Russia, arrived yesterday on the American Line steamship St. Paul. He said that his trip here had for its purpose an interview with President Roosevelt, with whom he had not spoken personally since he had taken his oath of office.

OMAHA, Neb., May 10 -- Coroner Brailey to-day impaneled a jury and proceeded to the home of Judge Eller, accompanied by the Sheriff and demanded that he be permitted to hold an inquest over the remains of Donald Eller, the Judge's son, who died, it is alleged, under Christian Science healing.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

THE wedding gown of Miss Rosalie de Goicouria, now Mrs. W. Scott Cameron, was of point lace over chiffon -- a princesse robe. The train, very long but not very full, was of plaited chiffon ruffles veiled with point lace. The back of the bodice was of chiffon or crepe, with vertical rows of feather stitching and was laid at the waist line in tiny plaits.

The French Cable Company's offices in this city were advised yesterday that their repair steamer Pouyer Quertier had arrived at Fort de France, having rescued 450 persons from St. Pierre. She has returned immediately to the scene of the disaster to search for further survivors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The cartoon representing the murder of Filipino children by American troops was, of course, untrue as picturing a fact. Probably it was not a forecast of a possibility. Were I a soldier, I would be shot for mutiny before I should do any such cruel deed, and I doubt not that many others would feel like me.

BERLIN, May 10 -- The theatrical season here is concluding with a Verdi festival of operas and a series of master plays, socalled, by Shakespeare, Goethe, and Schiller, and some of the best modern plays, including works of Grillparzer and Ludwig.

TUXEDO PARK, May 10 -- Tuxedo colony has again begun to be full of gayety. The cottages have all been leased for the Summer season, and the clubhouse will be crowded all the Spring and early Summer, as rooms have been engaged far in advance.
To the Editor of The New York Times: During the past two years I have been somewhat amused at the items under the above and similar captions assiduously cabled from Vienna.

Educational authorities held a conference upon entrance requirements in English for college examinations, at the university building in Washington Square yesterday. It was the first meeting of the kind in three years, and lists were prepared to be used by students who expect to attend examinations for admission to colleges during the years 1906, 1907, or 1908.

IT may surprise some to learn that shells rank among the principal "fishery" products of the world. This refers to those used for industrial purposes and not to the large supplies for museum and cabinet collections. In London the sales of pearl shell or mother-of-pearl amount to about $4,000,000 each year, and the annual imports of this material into the United States usually exceed $1,000,000 in value.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 10 -- In a hard-fought and well-played baseball game to-day the Naval cadets went clown in defeat at the hands of the Seventh Regiment of New York by a score of 10 to 7. Both Dissosway and Raudenbush were hit very hard, but the visitors' hits came when they were most needed.

A BRIEF HISTORY OF THE DISCOVERY OF FIRST PRINCIPLES. It was in 1866 that Prof. Clerk-Maxwell, of Cambridge University, England, proved, by a mathematical demonstration, that electro-magnetic waves existed and that they could be created by the action of an induction coil.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Thurber, whose name appears to carry weight, as an authority on economic subjects, appears to defend the trusts (in your issue of the 5th inst.) by citing their "earning power," at the foundation of which he says are steam, electricity, and machinery.

PATERSON, N.J., May 10 -- Between 500 and 600 of the striking dyers' helpers at Blume Brothers' dying works, Lodi, returned to work this morning. Their action practically ends the trouble in the Bergen County village, where about fifty deputies have been on guard since the trouble started.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have not seen the report of my address last Sunday evening on "America's Influence in the East," but, judging from the editorial which you base on it in your issue of this morning, it was far from accurate. I did not say that 200 persons were recently put to death in Constantinople. I stated that an undoubted authority said to me:
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been Interested in reading the letters "against barking dogs" in THE SUNDAY TIMES, because I am a dog owner, and also a lover of dogs.
PARIS, May 10 -- The Minister of Marine has received the following undated dispatch from Pointe a Pitre Island of Guadeloupe, from the commander of the French cruiser Suchet:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 10 -- Representatives of seven leading colleges met here to-day and reorganized the American Intercollegiate Fencing Association, which for some years has been practically defunct.

LONDON, May 10 -- United States Ambassador Choate was the central figure at a dinner given at the Criterion to-night by a representative body of English journalists to American and colonial newspaper men in celebration of the coronation.

BOSTON, May 10 -- John D. Long, ex- Secretary of the Navy, was welcomed back to Boston by his old friends this after- noon in the form of a dinner by the mem- bers of the Massachusetts Club at Young's Hotel. It was a Republican greeting, and the majority of those present were of the staunch old Massachusetts Republican or- der, who had cast their ballots at no less than a dozen Presidential elections.

The Atlanta (Ga.) Journal having remarked casually that "it begins to look like the Southern Securities Company is on the way," certain Eastern newspapers refer to this mode of expression as characteristic of the South, and to declare that nearly every part of the country has its peculiarities of speech.

As fuller and more exact news is received the horror of the great disaster in the Windward Islands grows. In many respects it is the most appalling calamity of modern times, and emphasizes the fact that the sleeping volcano may at any moment awake to cataclysmic activity, disrupting geological strata as firm as those of the granitic and gneissose plateau of Central France.

At the residence of Jacob H. Schiff, 963 Fifth Avenue, the Directors of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America gave a reception last night to Dr. Solomon Schechter, the newly arrived head of the Faculty of the institution.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, May 10 -- In a letter to the Presidency of the Mormon Church, dated April 25, from Paul Henning, Elder and representative of the Church in Guatemala, further details are given of the disastrous earthquakes in that country.

The Southampton Horse Show Association of Southampton, L.I., in addition to the annual exhibition of horses to be held in August, this year will make a departure from the beaten track by conducting a pony race meeting preceding the horse show. The Executive Committee has claimed as the date for the races Aug. 16, and as the dates for the horse show Aug. 22 and 23.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 10 -- There is a strong sentiment among the miners in this district that President Mitchell is opposed to a strike, and that no matter how the operators may view it, the mineworkers' union can afford to refuse to engage in the conflict, which the men say the operators are inviting.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Perhaps the saddest feature of the tragedy which within the space of a few minutes terminated the careers of two men, each exceptional in his particular sphere, is that, judging from current reports, it might have been prevented by the exercise of a moderate amount of good judgment.

BOONTON, N.J., May 10 -- The funeral of Congressman Joshua S. Salmon, who died on Tuesday, took place here this afternoon. As a mark of respect, the mills of the town were closed at noon, and later, while the body was being carried to the cemetery, all business was suspended. In addition to the Congressional Committee, prominent persons from all parts of the State and delegations from each county in this Congressional district, were present.

WILLEMSTAD, Island of Curacao, May 10 -- The Italian steamer Pedemonte, which arrived this morning at La Guayra, reports that while parsing near the Island of St. Vincent Thursday night her deck was covered to a depth of two inches with ashes and her passengers were nearly suffocated with the smell of sulphur.

PUTTING aside the delight of the mother, how much more satisfaction may it not give the little child who for the first time hears itself say "Da-da"? Who can dwell on that physical action which has taken place before the tongue and the lips acquired their proper mechanical coordination, disregarding the motive brain function.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 10 -- The Cornell baseball team was defeated to-day by Princeton, the score being 18 to 6.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 10 -- Four new records were made in the annual athletic games of the young women of Vassar College, held to-day. In the 100-yard dash Miss Fannie James of Kansas City, Mo., a member of the class of 1904, covered the distance in 0:13 1-5, breaking the former record of 0:13 2-5, made by L.S. Holmquist, 1901, of New York City.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It may seem like minding other people's business, but I wish you would deem it as simply consistent with the general public interest in newspapers, as such, if I congratulate you, as I wish to do most gratefully, upon the editing of THE TIMES of yesterday -- Friday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From the view point of the special pleader and an advocate who is as much smirched with guilt as the particular criminal whose cause he chances to champion, the defense by the Junior Senator from Massachusetts -- "the cradle of liberty" -- of the army methods in the Philippines that are at present engaging public attention, is able and ingenious.

With perfect Spring weather, it was to be expected that there would be a rush to he counter, and the town would gradually be deserted by the fashionable element. But the country is a little cold as yet, and New York is extremely attractive. People seem loath to leave, and the afternoon on Fifth Avenue and in the Park is quite a brilliant spectacle.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of May 4 Archibald Y. Comstock gives an interesting letter full of suggestions, as to means for the defense of the Republic.

WASHINGTON, May. 10. -- Private William J. Gibbs of the Ninth Infantry to-day continued his testimony before the Senate Committee on the Philippines. He was questioned by Senator Patterson concerning the cleaning of the town of Balangiga previous to the massacre there. He said that seventy-five natives brought from the mountains for that purpose were ordered Into the tents in which they were confined.

The Trustees of Columbia University have taken an important step toward the development of a School of Fine Arts at Columbia. The plan has been under consideration for some years past, but lack of money and the necessary buildings prevented its being put into operation.

CASTRIES, St. Lucia, B.W.I., May 10 -- Mont Pelee, a volcanic mountain five or six miles north of St. Pierre, the commercial capital of Martinique, the mountain which made a faint show of eruption fifty years ago, on May 3 last began to throw out dense clouds of smoke.

The King's levee the other day brought the importance of the Diplomatic Corps as a social force very much to the fore. But at drawing rooms, Courts, or any royal function at which ladles attend, it is the "Ambassadress," not the Ambassador, who has to be most considered. Sometimes she is a very touchy personage indeed.

Acting and the Commercial Drama. One of the incidents of the modern system of theatrical management is that the public has little or no chance to study acting and to form a discriminating taste as to what effects are admirable and what means are legitimate in achieving these effects.

POINT-A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, May 10 -- The morning of May 5 Guadeloupe learned that the Mont Pelee volcano, in Martinique, had been in a state of eruption since Saturday, May 3, throwing out ashes. The same day violent thunderstorms began here. Tuesday a very heavy storm occurred, and loud detonations were heard.

The ordering of a general coal strike -- provisional in nature, because yet to be ratified, if ratified at all, at Wednesday's convention of delegates representing all the mine workers directly -- did not result in any stock market demoralization, as in some quarters had been predicted, nor yet did it induce any considerable selling pressure.

-- Viewed from St. Pierre or the sea in front of it, Mont Pelee -- the people of the island call it "Morne Pelee," meaning the skinned, that is, the cleared, mountain -- looked like the safest of neighbors, with nothing in its appearance to recall its previous activities or to threaten their resumption.

What with the week's developments in the neighborhood of Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street, a well-sustained interest in both middle and upper Fifth Avenue holdings, an apparently increasing demand for residential property on the west side and several transactions of goodly proportions in the downtown district, the business of the last few days cannot but be regarded as satisfactory.

Favored by the weather and with a last and safe track at Morris Park yesterday, the oldest of the famous Eastern stakes for three-year-olds, the twenty-ninth running of the Withers Stake, was decided under conditions that made the racing half holiday at the Westchester course a fair rival in popularity to the opening attraction at Morris Park of the Metropolitan Handicap.

NEWARK, N.J., May 10 -- At a meeting held here to-day the stockholders of the National Newark Banking Company ratified the plan of consolidating with the Newark City National Bank. The name of the new institution will be the National Banking Company. The Directors of both banks were elected Directors of the new concern.

By the pluckiest sort of lawn tennis Floyd Smith yesterday won the Columbia University interscholastic championship. The entire tournament of thirteen matches was played on the South Field courts, and was the best meeting for scholastic honors ever held since the title was inaugurated. There were fourteen entries, representing nine schools, as follows:
At the Garrick Theatre to-morrow evening Genevieve G. Haines's drama of social life, "Hearts Aflame," will be submitted for public approval.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., May 10 -- Julius Newton, at one time well known in Wall Street as a partner in the banking house of I. S. Wormser, committed suicide this morning at his home, at Edwardsville, near here, by shooting himself through the heart with a shotgun.

It was current report in political circles last night that ex-Senator David B. Hill was very much displeased with John C. Sheehan, leader of the Greater New York Democracy. The latter, it is stated, has failed to fall in with the views of Mr. Hill with relation to the coming campaign in which Mr. Hill wanted Mr. Sheehan to aid Lewis Nixon in the election of Senators and Assemblymen in this county.

MAMBAJAO, Camiguin, Philippine Islands, March 4. -- Spanish is by no means the general means of expression in these islands. The most widely diffused tongue is that of the Visayas, who inhabit the majority of the islands. There are other dialects as the Tagalog, the Ilocano, the Bicol, all more or less like the Visayan, and the Manobian, the Negrito, the Moro, with variations, and the host of pagan tongues in Mindanao.

Dwight School won the championship of the New York Interscholastic Athletic League at the annual field and track meet at the Berkeley Oval with a total of 54 points, and will be the holders of the new championship cup of the association for the coming year. Cutler School, whose victories of last year and the year before gave it permament possession of the original trophy, was second, with 31 points.

SILAS LARRABEE never loses his temper; but he came near losing it last night. He chanced to be in my room while a number or gentlemen, including a couple of Democratic Congressmen, were discussing the Philippine question. One of the Congressmen talked just about as Mr. Carmack talked in the Senate last week when he vilified everybody connected with the conduct of affairs in the Philippines, from the President down.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 10 -- The final match in the Lakewood polo tournament series for the Georgian Court Cups was played by the Lakewood first team and Bryn Mawr this afternoon. The Gould team won, defeating the Bryn Mawr players by a score of 12 3/4 goals to 9 1/4. A mishap marred the third period.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Secretary of the Navy Moody has cabled Capt. McLain, the commander of the cruiser Cincinnati, who reported his arrival at San Domingo City this morning, to proceed to Martinique and render such aid as possible.

WHEN Mark Twain wrote a paper describing his experience with the "Appetite Cure" in Germany, and urged upon his countrymen the desirability of missing a meal occasionally, he was generally applauded as a humorist at his best. That, of course, is the fate of the writer whose profession is the joke.
Wall Street has just passed the first anniversary of its memorable Northern Pacific "corner," and the consequent panic of May 9, 1901.

Charles Hitchcock, Jr., of Yale won the individual intercollegiate golf championship yesterday in the final match of the tournament on the links of the Garden City Club. He defeated in the thirty-six-hole round H.B. McFarland of the University of Pennsylvania by the high score of 11 up and 10 to play.
Senator Thomas C. Platt, apparently much improved in health, came on from Washington, and talked freely on political matters with reporters at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night.

LONDON, May 10 -- Now that the terms of the purchase of the Atlantic lines are known annoyance rather than anxiety it the word which test expresses the British feeling on this subject. As The Spectator says to-day, that annoyance will do little good unless it wakes up the English people to the energy of competition.

LONDON, April 30 -- To begin with, one who remembers Wills's spectacle called "Faust" as it was produced by Henry Irving in the middle eighties is able to note few histrionic deficiencies or modifications in the famous actor's present embodiment of the Spirit that Denies. Irving's Mephistopheles was always grotesque and always verged on travesty in the passage with Martha and a few other scenes.

Mr. JOHN CORBIN's book, "An American at Oxford," just published, is of a singularly lucky timeliness, the publication having, in fact, been delayed just long enough to enable the author to prefix a preface, relating it directly to the remarkable benefaction of CECIL RHODES.
BABYLON, L.I., May 10 -- Ex-Judge John R. Reid died this morning at his home on Reid Avenue, this place. He leaves a wife, one son, Willard P. Reid, and one daughter, Miss M. Loreign Reid.

This week will see the beginning of the tearing down of more of the few old houses on "Political Row," (East Seventh Street, between Avenues C and D.) where more politicians of every party were born and brought up than on any other street in this city. In the place of these old houses will be built double tenements, six stories high, and equipped to accommodate forty-eight families.

The address of Bishop Benjamin J. Keiley at the Confederate Memorial Day services in Savannah, Ga., in which the President of the United States was severely criticised, was called to the attention of President Roosevelt by the correspondent of The Sun to-day.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a little curious and pertinent, in view of recent happenings, to inquire into the evolution of the stage Irishman.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 10 -- Fire was discovered early this morning in the house at the corner of Connecticut and Arctic Avenues, and the inmates of the house were compelled to flee for their lives.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Gov. Taft to-day closed up business here in connection with affairs in the Philippines and left for Cincinnati, where he will attend to some private business prior to his departure from New York on the 17th inst. on his return to his post at Manila. He will stop at Rome in order to discuss the question of the friars in the Philippines with the authorities of the Vatican.

The State Civil Service Commission held an all-day session at the Manhattan Hotel yesterday to consider the recommendatioins of Mayor Low and the Civil Service Commission of New York for a reclassificatioin of the civil service in this city and the exemption from the competitive class of a number of offices in the various departments of the City Government.

Suffering under symptoms of insanity and fearing his removal to a private sanitarium, Anthony Kemper, a retired grocer, forty-three years old, committed suicide yesterday morning in his home, at 239 West Thirtieth Street, by inhaling illuminating gas. Kemper was married, and two children and his widow survive him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A reference to Prof. Pupin's remarks anent the unprogressiveness of the telegraph business of the country in your issue of the 5th inst., under "Topics of the Times," reads somewhat like an apology for conditions which are universally recognized. Doubtless Prof. Pupin had excellent reasons for permitting the inference that personal experiences led him to say that inventors and scientists are "not wanted."

The weekly Clearing House statement issued yesterday was a disagreeable surprise to the Street. Surplus reserves decreased $4,023,000, loans decreased $2,224,500, specie decreased $3,360,000, legal tenders decreased $2,651,500, and deposits decreased $7,954,000.

DETROIT, May 10 -- It has been learned here that Napoleon Lajoie, the enjoined Philadelphia second baseman, has agreed to play in Detroit and that Mr. McNamara of the Detroit American League team will leave to-night for Philadelphia to close the deal with the Philadelphia owners. It is to be a cash transaction between the two clubs in which the transfer of other players than Lajoie will not figure.

BALTIMORE, May 10 -- The local market was dull again to-day. The strike outlook did it. The reaction in New York incident to that turn caused the local market to halt again, on account of the resultant check in buying demand. The strength of Maryland and Pennsylvania mid of Western Maryland were the only semblances to a feature.

Not long since there came to the office of the Mayor's Marshal eight lusty Roumanians, any one of whom could have pulled a horse car or done a full day's work at any useful labor. None of them spoke English. They were all married and had an average of seven children each, representing a group of seventy-two persons.

The President has been subjected to a good deal of adverse criticism because of a remark he is reported to have made at the banquet of the Sons of the Revolution in Washington, to the effect that it was the evident purpose of those present that when the flag of the United States was raised it should "stay put."
TWO shiplods of school teachers propounding to ten thousand Filipino children the A B C's of an English education argues well for the coming generation in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Frank H. Mason, United States Consul General at Berlin, has sent a communication to the State Department on "High Railway Speed in Germany: Electricity or Steam?" He writes of the experiments made over the specially prepared and repaired railway line between Berlin and Zossen, to try to accomplish a speed of 125 miles to 150 miles in hour by high-speed electrical traction.

Four of the five Manhappot racebouts that made such an excellent record in yacht racing last year, met for t time this season in the first of the club series of races for this class yesterday afternoon. The race was sailed in the bay off the clubhouse of the Manhasset Yacht Club, and the entries were the Arizona, Lambkin, Bab, and Mist.
