ITHACA, N.Y., May 10 -- The Cornell University Faculty, at its meeting to-day, elected the fellows and scholars for next year as follows:

At the National Athletic Club, 11 and 13 Cedar Street, Brooklyn, last night two games were played in the basket ball tournament for the championship of the Metropolitan Association, of the Amateur Athletic Union. In the first contest the Grace Athletic Club team, of Manhattan defeated the five of the National Turn Verein of Newark by a score of 50 to 45.

SHE had just returned from Europe bedecked with any number of little trinkets that she wouldn't have dreamed of wearing before taking a trip abroad. In all this wealth of strange adornment there was one ornament that appealed with especial force to the curiosity of the visitor.

There are now two cable routes open to Martinique. On Saturday notices were sent out by the French Telegraph Cable Company announcing that direct communication had been reopened with Fort de France from the south, and that messages would be sent at a cost of $2.15 a word.

ORANGE, N.J., May 11. -- The Rev. Adolph Roeder, pastor of the New Church (Swedenborgian) of this city, in a sermon this morning chose as the theme of his discourse. " The Story of Adam and Eve Is Not History, but Allegory." He said in part:

The next great attraction for golfers will be the Metropolitan Golf Association championship, which will begin on the Tuxedo Club links on Thursday. May 28, and will continue through that week, but the local clubs will not be idle in the interval. A number of club competitions are arranged for the coming week, and competition of some kind will be in progress nearly every day.

It is reported from St. Thomas, Danish West Indies, that Fort de France, Martinique, is threatened by the eruption of Mont Pelee, which continues very active. It was to Fort de France that the French Cable Company's cable ship Pouyer Quertiar sailed after the St. Pierre disaster with 450 survivors of that calamity.
LONDON, May 12. -- The Times this morning relates the course of the South African peace negotiations as follows:

CINCINNATI, May 11. -- Fire which originated in the Ohio Scroll and Lumber Company's works in Covington, Ky., last night caused a loss of $75,OOO. The fire spread to the Anthe Machine Works and thence to the Phoenix Furniture Factory, but the most serious damage was to the Ohio Company's plant.
BEZIERS, France, May 11. -- Barnum Bailey's circus was the cause of a serious riot here this afternoon.

On the eve of taking up the honorable and responsible position to which he has been appointed by the President, with the "advice and consent" of the Senate, Mr. EVANS issued to the public what must be accepted as his final explanation of the peculiar and interesting recent changes in his official relations.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Senator Rawlins, senior Democratic member of the Senate Committee on the Philippines, today expressed the opinion that a vote could be reached on the Philippine Government bill toward the end of the present week. Other members of the committee think the date of the vote may be postponed until some time next week, but none of them place the vote later than the 24th int., two weeks hence.

An American who found it necessary to arrange the details of a wedding in an Italian city, the bride being Protestant and the bridegroom Catholic, was surprised at the rudeness of the high ecclesiastic who had agreed to tie the knot. In conversation with Monsignor after the ceremony the American called his attention to the lapses of good breeding of which the prelate, an exception in his church, was guilty -- and thanked him warmly.

The advocates of universal peace may derive much substantial comfort from the fact that forces vastly more powerful than their arguments are at work to discourage war and permit general disarmament. The London Statist, from the best figures obtainable, estimates the cost of the Boer war to Great Britain at u219,117,000, or, in round numbers, about $1,200,000,000.

Jacob Sedelsmeyer was the principal point winner in the weekly games of the Brooklyn Athletic Club held at the Grand Street Park, Maspeth, L.I., yesterday, obtaining first place in the 220-yard run, second in the 100-yard, and third in the half-mile. The summary follows:

A fire which for a time gave the firemen considerable trouble to extinguish, and which was attended by several accidents, all of a slight nature, completely destroyed the wooden packing box factory of John Ryan Son, at 137 and 139 King Street, near the corner of West Street, yesterday afternoon.

The fine arts jury at the Charleston Exposition having decided to bar from competition all works of art which have received medals or awards at previous exhibitions, the following painters were awarded gold medals: Winslow Homer, William M. Chase, J. Carroll Beckwith, R. Swain Gifford, Henry Mosler, J. Francis Murphy, Henry W. Ranger, Horatio Walker, H.O. Walker, and R.W. Vonnoh.

At the St. George Cricket Grounds, Hoboken, yesterday, the Boston American League baseball team was defeated by the Hoboken nine by a score of 6 runs to 3. Mcphillips, the local club's pitcher, was hit harder than Mitchell, but the errors of the Boston players when men were on bases proved costly.

Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE is always entertaining and sometimes instructive in his discussion of public matters. In an interview on the subject of the shipping, combine, to which he submitted himself with his customary enthusiasm on his arrival in London, he answered the nonsense, which is just now making so many of the English newspaper ridiculous, thus conclusively:

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 11. -- Bishop Alexander Walters of the New Jersey Diocese of the African Methodist Episcopal Church was arrested here this afternoon by Chief Wallermire upon a warrant issued by Justice Heath on a complaint charging the Bishop with assault and battery upon Sadie Billings, seventeen years of age, a colored girl.
The closing exercises of the Society for Ethical Culture, and the twenty-fifth anniversary of the society, were celebrated yesterday morning under the direction of Prof. Felix Adler at Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The Cuban Relief bill is getting very little attention these days, and probably it will be practically neglected until the end of the Philippines debate shall be in sight.

KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent. Saturday, May 10, via Castries, St. Lucia, May 11. -- After numerous earthquakes during the preceding fortnight, accompanied by subterranean noises in the direction of the Soufriere volcano, in the northwestern part of the island, a loud explosion occurred last Monday from the crater, and the water in the crater lake ascended in a stupendous cloud of steam and exploded heavily.
Lewis Nixon, leader of Tammany Hall, referring to John C. Sheehan's statements published yesterday, dictated the following to reporters at the Waldorf-Astoria last night:
HAVANA, May 11. -- At 7:37 this morning a large Cuban flag was hoisted over Morro Castle here.

For the purpose of launching an organization to tie known as the Brain Workers' League, which it is intended shall benefit needy artists, sculptors, authors, and journalists, an entertainment was given at Carnegie Hall last evening. The purpose of the proposed new organization was explained by William d'H. Washington, who stated that the scheme had originated in his mind, although, he said, he was not a brain worker himself.

The stirring scenes of "Speedway Day" were duplicated on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday, when many brushes between crack trotters and pacers that were postponed from Saturday, because of the crowd attending the annual parade, were decided in the presence of thousands of spectators.
There will not be a particle of "kosher" meat on sale in any of the east side butcher's shops to-day and to-morrow, a boycott having been declared yesterday by more than 1,500 retail dealers.

NEW ORLEANS, La., May 11. -- The French cruiser Tage finished loading between $4,000 and $5,000 worth of provisions and supplies to-night at 11 o'clock, and Admiral Servan announced that he would sail for Martinique to-morrow morning at daybreak. There was great generosity in the raising of subscriptions and dispatch in securing the supplies and loading them.

Saturday's unfavorable bank statement was made much, of by the bears and pessimists in the Street. Surplus reserves had been cut in half; there was a shrinkage of more than $6,000,000 in the cash holdings of the banks; and, in the face of a week of heavy stock market liquidation, loans had decreased barely $2,000,000.

LONDON, May 12. -- The latest reports received here in regard to the state of affairs at St. Vincent create grave alarm, especially as dispatches from Dominica, forwarded yesterday, reported that the Soufriere volcano was still in active eruption.

Persons connected with the New York and Portchester Railway Company, acting as individuals, but not as officials of the company, have purchased about 200 acres of land in the Bronx, extending north from One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street to Morris Park Avenue and other highways in that section.

BERLIN, May 31. -- The incidents in Wall Street absorbed the entire attention of the market here during the past week, and German Boerses were chiefly under the influence of New York. The weekly financial reviews, with their usual warnings, again indulge in moralizings upon the subjection of the German Boerses to the American lead.

BRYN MAWR, Penn., May 11. -- The English department of Bryn Mawr College announces changes of importance for the coming year. The general English course required for every student must now be taken in the proper order. The course is a two years' one, and heretofore a student could, begin with either year.

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, May 11. -- The latest reports received here show that lava continues to pour down the slopes of Mont Pelee, slowly engulfing the whole north side of the island, while fresh crevasses are continually opening.

HAZLETON, Penn., May 11. -- Anticipating the action of their employes, two of the individual coal companies in this region have practically locked out their men. This step was taken last night, when Coxe Brothers Co., operating the Beaver Meadow Colliery, and Calvin Pardee, Sons Co., owners of the Lattimer Mines, notified their employes that they need not report for work until ordered to do so.
"Scotland, with all thy faults, I love thee still." is engraved upon a crystal jug, the stopple also of crystal, but shaped like an everyday cork.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- Gen. C.H. T. Collis of New York died at 11:45 o'clock to-night in Bryn Mawr Hospital, Bryn Mawr. His three children, two sons and a daughter, were at his bedside at the time.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Probably 2,000 persons attended the memorial service at Chase's Opera House this afternoon In honor of Congressman Amos J. Cummings of New York, held under the auspices of Columbia Typographical Union of Washington. The exercises took the form of personal tributes from intimate friends of the dead printer, editor, soldier, and statesman.

PARIS, May 11. -- The Minister of Marine, M. de Lanessan, to-day received a cable dispatch from the commander of the French cruiser Suchet, dated Fort de France, Martinique, saying that he conducted a search at St. Pierre yesterday. The Captain reports that the town is now a mere heap of smoking ruins, under which the victims of the catastrophe are buried.

A remarkable demonstration of activity was made by the Harlem River rowing clubs in their water carnival yesterday. Two parades were held, one in the morning and one in the afternoon, and in all about 150 boats and over 600 oarsmen took part. In addition, several thousand persons watched the passing show from the clubhouse balconies or the docks and bridges along the route.

For nearly two hours John MeGaw Woodbury, Commissioner of Street Cleaning, talked to the Central Federated Union yesterday on the complaints made by that body and others against the department and answered a fusillade of questions with good humor. He had to break away in the middle of the questions in order to avoid being kept in the hall all evening.

PARIS, May 12. -- The Parisians in those municipal districts where reballoting took place yesterday for the election of members of the Chamber of Deputies crowded early to the polls and voted quickly. They then proceeded to profit by the beautiful weather and enjoy themselves in their customary Sunday manner.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 11. -- William Jackson, a negro, is under arrest in the jail, heavily guarded and shackled, this morning. A negro, said to be Jackson, entered the residence of Adam Wagner, who did not awaken. It is thought the intruder hit him on the head with a heavy weapon.
PARIS, May 12. -- Augusto Severo, the Brazilian aeronaut, and one of his assistants were killed by the explosion of Severo's airship La Paix this morning.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."
All the old residents of the Ninth Ward, or Greenwich Village, were familiar with the figure of William A. Washington, the money changer.

ERRONEOUS ADMISSION OF EVIDENCE. -- Duncan Young was convicted of murder in the second degree in killing George Eberhardt on the night of Jan. 24, 1899. It was charged that the act was committed while Young and two others were attempting a burglary. The Appellate Division has granted the convicted man a new trial on the ground of error in admitting in evidence a statement made by one of his companions.

Rumors which have been current lately to the effect that the Morris Park race track has been purchased by the New York and Port Chester Railroad Company were revived yesterday in real estate circles, only to be met by noncommittal statements on the part of the prospective buyers and sellers in such a transaction.

Lakewood had an easy victory over the Great Neck polo team yesterday on the field of the Westchester Country Club. The competition was the first In the Country Club's annual tournament, and it was for a set of trophies known as the Country Club Cups. The winning team was the second one of the Lakewood Club, and it won by 13 1/4 goals to 5.
LONDON, May 13. -- The Times prints a statement by the Right Hon. W.J. Pirrie, Chairman of the Belfest shipbuilding firm of Harland Wolff, regarding the shipping combination.

It was learned yesterday that Vincent Noll, the young theological student whose application for the ministry was rejected by the New York Presbytery at its April meeting because he save the impression that he considered the Adam and Eve narrative as allegorical rather than historical, had become since that meeting a victim of hasty consumption, induced, his sister says, by the fact of his rejection by the Presbytery.

In the basket ball tournament for the championship of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, which was continued last night in the gymnasium of the National Athletic Club, 11 and 13 Cedar Street, Brooklyn, the team of the Mohawk Athletic Club of Flushing defeated the Grace Athletic Club five of Manhattan by a score of 61 to 29.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- In the Senate to-day during the consideration of the Philippines Government bill Mr. Foraker (Ohio) addressed the Senate in support of the measure.
Recorder Goff in a lengthy decision yesterday held that Police Magistrates have not the right to try oases of persons charged with the misdemeanor of exceeding the speed limit for vehicles.

Justice Gaynor, in the Brooklyn Supreme Court, yesterday decided the suit brought by Ottilie M. Steinway, Clara Steinway, and Gertrude M. Steinway, the minor children of the late George A. Steinway, for the removal of Louis Von Bernuth as executor under their father's will.

Checks aggregating $10,000,000 were sent out yesterday by J.P. Morgan Co. in payment of the second distribution of profits to the syndicate which underwrote the United States Steel Corporation. The amount of cash advanced by the syndicate was $25,000,000 but this was returned soon after the first six months.

The performance last night of "Hearts Aflame." which the programme of the Garrick Theatre calls "a play of social life," was a benefit performance in behalf of Mr. Clyde Fitch. It was perhaps not intentionally given for his benefit. The brotherhood of the stage in almost all ways is generous to a fault, but there is one way in which it has a parsimony quite its own.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The President to-day sent the following message to Congress:

The members of the Alumni Association of the General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Avenue, sat down to their annual dinner last evening in Hoffman Hall, which faces the Tenth Avenue end of the seminary grounds. About ninety members were present, many of whom had come from a distance for the occasion.

LONDON, May 13. -- The Parliamentary Secretary to the Admiralty, H.O. Arnold-Forster, announced in the House of Commons yesterday that the agreement of the Admiralty with the White Star Line was about to be renewed, with an additional provision, as follows:

M. SANTOS-DUMONT found his visit to this country extremely unsatisfactory, and he left it greatly disappointed and not a little disgusted by reason of the fact that our people persisted in regarding him as a showman and not as a pioneer in useful progress toward the practical in aerial navigation.

Wall Street tried to persuade itself into a condition of nervousness yesterday. The security market was soft all day long, and some substantial recessions were recorded. In two or three instances declines were sensational, yet with scarcely an exception the net changes of the day reflected nothing new and nothing genuinely serious in the financial situation.

At West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday the Toronto Eastern League baseball team defeated the Jersey City nine by one run. Both pitchers were wild, but the Canadians gave Thielman better support in the field than was accorded Luby, the Jersey City team.

Major George P. Screven. Signal Corps. and Capt. Thomas J. Lewis. Second Cavalry, are detailed for duty pertaining to the unveiling of the statue of Marshal Rochambeau, and will report soon as practicable to Col. Theodore A. Bingham, Superintendent of Public Buildings and Grounds in Washington, for instructions.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Senator Foraker made a speech to-day on the Philippines Civil Government bill which is regarded by his Republican associates In the Senate as a most admirable and effective reply to the speeches that had come from the minority side of the Chamber. It was rot so much a discussion of the bill as of the questions of policy which have been brought into the debate by the Democratic Senators.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire to record my gratitude to the Beef Trust for the great service it has done to me personally and to my family.

The unfavorable influences which resulted in numerous declines in the Stock Exchange market were reflected to only a slight degree in the outside market yesterday. Some declines occurred, but for the most part prices showed considerable firmness, and in a few issues closing prices showed net gains.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The vote in the House, by which the bill granting $200,000 for the relief of Martinique sufferers was passed to-day, stood 196 yeas to 9 nays. Those voting in the negative were:

There is much comment already indulged in by Commissioners to the Presbyterian General Assembly, which is to assemble at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church on Thursday, over certain methods which are being used to promote the candidacy of several ministers who will be nominated for the Moderatorship of that body.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 12. -- At the meeting of Congress, called to elect a President of the republic, which opened at noon to-day, the Minister of the Interior formally handed the resignation of President Sam to the house.

strike be declared an advance in price will probably take place at once, and if the strike, as is expected, be a long one, they will look out for the interests of their regular customers first when coal becomes scarce and let transient customers take their chances.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12. -- Mine workers throughout the entire anthracite coal regions of Pennsylvania to the number of 145,000 formally began their struggle today for increased wages and shorter hours. Never in the history of hard coal mining has a tie-up been so complete, not one of the 357 collieries in the territory being in operation.
Big prices were realized yesterday at the auction sale by John Anderson, Jr., 20 West Thirtieth Street of Part VI. of the library of the late Thomas J. McKee.
LONDON, May 12. -- The demand for money was unabated to-day while wait- ing for liberal Government disbursements.

The boycott on beef by the Jewish residents of the east side, in sympathy with the butchers of that race who are fighting the wholesalers, in keeping their shops closed until the price of the kosher meat is reduced, assumed larger proportions yesterday when it was announced that the boycott had spread to all the borougrhs.

LONDON, May 12. -- The American polo team was beaten to-day by Rugby by 6 goals to 4. The contest was played on the Roehampton Club's field and was the second match in the Coronation Cup tournament series. R. L. Agassiz played instead of Foxhall Keene for the American team. The Rugby team was composed of the three brothers Nickolls and George Miller.

The committee of 250 local Republicans organized under the direction of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club to bring about a change of conditions in the party in the borough held its first meeting last night, in the Johnston Building, in Nevins Street. The committee has been named the Enrolled Republican Primary Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12. -- It was a heavy and sluggish market in Philadelphia to-day, few stocks escaping without some mark of depression. At the outset the market wavered, but yielded when the weakness became pronounced in New York. Readings, Electric Storage Battery, and Consolidated Lake Superior were the sensitive spots, and subsequently the shading-off process percolated through the whole list, with the single exception of Union Traction, which was immovable.

Relief parties from Fort de France have effected a landing in St. Pierre. It is estimated that 30,000 dead strew the streets. Decomposition of the bodies has set in, and to prevent an epidemic, the work of cremating corpses has been begun by a detachment of French troops from Fort de France.

News was received in this city yesterday of the death late the previous evening at Oakdale, L.I., of Henry W. Maxwell, one of the best-known residents of Brooklyn. The cause of Mr. Maxwell's death was apoplexy. Mr. Maxwell was a widower and lived in an old-fashioned residence at 72 First Place, Brooklyn.

Charles W. Labagh of Cold Spring Harbor, who since Friday last has been a guest of the Hotel St. Andrew, Seventy-second Street and Broadway, made a desperate attempt to end his life yesterday in the home of his brother-in-law, Joshua I. Jones, at 241 West Seventy-first Street. That he did not succeed is regarded as remarkable by the surgeons of the Roosevelt Hospital, to which institution he was hurried.

BALTIMORE, May 12. -- News from the strike section had very little adverse effect on the local market, other than to reduce the volume of trading. The tone was quite steady all through the list. Interest centred around the Maryland and Pennsylvania stock, which is closely held. It is figuring in a deal.

It is very gratifying to know that the curiosity in Washington is so keen about the Secretary of War's reply to the Senate resolution of inquiry concerning the alleged orders of Gen. BELL and Gen. SMITH in the Philippines. The reply (Senate Document No. 347) has been in such request that the edition has been exhausted and an additional edition ordered.

MADRID, May 12. -- Brilliant weather today encouraged the crowds to pour out into the streets of the city, and every thoroughfare was filled with merrymakers who were apparently in the happiest humor.

FORT DE FRANCE, Island of Martinique, May 12. -- It now seems to be generally admitted that about 30,000 persons lost their lives as a result of the outbreak of the Mont Pelee volcano at St. Pierre on Thursday last. Careful investigation by competent Government officials show that the earlier reports of The Associated Press were accurate.

The Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company and the Century Realty Company have bought from Franklin Lee the seven four-story brownstone-front dwellings, 133 to 145 West Seventy-fourth Street. Three of the houses are 20 feet front, two 22 feet front, and two 23 feet front -- making in all a plot 150 by 100.

One of the rare pleasures which accrue from time to time to the person who follows the picture shows with assiduity, noting the work of living artists and comparing it with that of their fellows and with their own work five or ten or twenty years ago, is to realize the changes that take place in the technique of certain artists and find the changes good.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Assistant Secretary Peirce, Chairman of the Committee on Arrangements for the Rochambeau Statue dedication, has made public a detailed programme of ceremonies and a full itinerary of the movements of the French visitors.

NEWARK, N.J., May 12. -- The Rev. E.O. MeFarland, pastor of Bethany Church, was preaching last night when he was interrupted by Joseph M. Hauber, Treasurer of the church, who took exception to some of the minister's remarks. A heated discussion ensued. The pastor was preaching on the subject of having a purpose in life.

There is one very general need of intelligent travelers which the railroad managers of this country too often neglect, and which they might stimulate and satisfy with profit to their roads and to the travelers. It is the need of interesting information as to the country traversed by tourists.

WINSTED, Conn., May 12. -- Miss Fairfield of New York City, who is prominently connected with the West Side Settlement of the Young Women's Christian Association in that city, has purchased of Town Clerk Jason C. Fenn of Terryville, this county, the well-known Fenn homestead, ated on a summit between Plymouth and Terryville, 900 feet above the sea.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Both the executive and the legislative departments of the Government were busy to-day preparing for the work of rescue and relief in Martinique. The cynical sentiment expressed in the House on Saturday that France is able to care for her own people has met with no echo, and the United States has taken the lead among the nations in helping France to do it.

There is to be no delay in sending relief from this country to the survivors of the disaster in the West Indies. Already the United States Government, through its army representation in this city, has taken action, and many plans are being formulated by organizations and individuals of New York.

BOSTON, May 12. -- The money market shows a general hardening tendency, both for call and time money. Sterling exchange is weak, and posted rates are off a fraction all around. Clearing House rate, 6 per cent. New York funds par; call loans, 5 to 6 per cent; time money, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $19,049,132; balances, $2,755,789.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Returns to the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture made up to May 1 show the area under Winter wheat in cultivation on that date to have been about 27,103,000 acres. This is 4,868,000 acres, or 15.2 per cent. less than the area sewn last Fall, of the department's estimate of which no modification, except for acreage abandoned, is considered necessary.

President ROOSEVELT has not overstated the duty of this country in recommending that half a million dollars be appropriated by Congress and made immediately available for the relief of the homeless and starving people of Martinique and St. Vincent. The appropriation of $100,000 provided in the Senate bill should be promptly increased to the sum recommended by the President.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 12. -- Prof. Willlam B. Scott, the geologist, made the following statement this morning concerning the destructive earthquake and volcanic eruptions.

There was a public hearing in the Council Chamber yesterday in the City Hall of persons who are advocating the restoration of the three-platoon system in the Police Department. Mayor Low presided. In the rear of the Council Chamber were several hundred policemen in citizen's clothes, and in the front row of seats many clergymen and well-known citizens were present to make speeches.

FORT ERIE, Ont., May 12. -- Joe Gans, the negro lightweight pugilist of Baltimore, defeated Frank Erne of Buffalo to-night in the second round of what was to have been a fight of twenty rounds. The sudden termination of the combat threw the sporting crowd into temporary consternation, for the men had hardly got warmed up to the fray before Erne was down and out.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 12. -- Four distinct explosions wrought ruin in the Chartiers Valley this evening. It is estimated 25 persons are dead and between 100 and 150 are burned, many of whom will die. The first explosion occurred in the Sheriden yards of the Pan Handle Railroad, about five miles from the Union Station in this city.

HAZLETON, Penn., May 13 -- The situation regarding the continuation of the present suspension of work in the anthracite coal fields of Pennsylvania is a trifle clouded to-night. The apparent overwhelming sentiment for a strike which was in evidence yesterday is not quite so prominent now, and predictions were freely made to-night that, whatever the delegates in the convention to-morrow determine upon, the winning side will have only a bare majority.

Those who attended the alumni dinner of Union Theological Seminary at the Hotel St. Denis on Monday night were very generally discussing yesterday a speech made at the dinner by the Rev. Dr. W.S. Rainsford, in which he assailed a number of features of the life of the modern Church.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 13 -- Further fighting occurred in the streets here before and after midnight last night. The situation is very serious.

In the dining saloon of the French Line steamer La Lorraine there was a gathering last night of the Get Together Club. Ex-Postmaster General Thomas L. James presided. At the conclusion of an elaborate banquet he asked the members of the club and their guests to stand and drink to the health of the President of France, stating that on the French vessel they were on French soil.

According to merchants who do business with Martinique, the amount of the trade between this country and the island has been about $750,000 a year at the most. Most of the goods supplied to the island by the United States are exported from New York, and to many mercantile houses of the city the ruin of the island will mean great losses.
PARIS, May 13. -- Many American firms and individual Americans are subscribing to the Martinique fund, which now amounts to 100,000., ($20,000.)

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- So comprehensively laid were the plans of the War Department yesterday, even before the passage by Congress of the joint resolution providing for the relief of the volcano sufferers, that there was really very little remaining for the officials to do to-day.

Bishop Worthington of Nebraska, Bishop Doane of Albany, the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix of Trinity Church, Dean Hoffman, Bishop Seymour of Springfield, Ill., and thirty other Bishops and prominent dignitaries of the Episcopal Church, forming the Board of Trustees of the General Theological Seminary, met in the seminary on Chelsea Square yesterday and for four hours tried to devise means of getting the Rev. Dr. Thomas Richey out of the Chair of Ecclesiastical History.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Miss Alice Roosevelt entertained a party of young people on board the Government yacht Sylph this afternoon, the boat leaving the navy yard for a sail down the Potomac at 2 o'clock and returning at 7.
There was one point or exceeding force -- indeed, there were many, but this was of especial pertinence -- in the speech of Mr. FORAKER in the Senate on Monday on the Philippines bill.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 13. -- Referring to the eruption of Mont Pelee, James H. Stoller, Professor of Biology and Geology at Union University, said to-day:

After an early break of five points, said to be due to selling by some weak outside holders who had "tailed on" after the Gates following, Northwest rallied sharply six points, closing at the highest price for the day. It is still insisted that the Moore brothers are to receive representation on the Board of Directors, being credited with holding some 100,000 shares of the stock.

--Unlike most of the sailboat authorities in this country, The London Yachtsman not only finds it easy to believe that Capt. JOSHUA SLOCUM'S Spray can sail a true course for days at a time without a touch of its navigator's hand upon the tiller, but has evolved a detailed explanation of the miraculous performance.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 13 -- The fifteenth music festival will begin in this city to-morrow evening, when Caesar Franck's "Les Beatitudes" will be performed. There will be in all five concerts, scheduled for Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday evenings and Thursday and Saturday afternoons.

Westchester defeated the Camden Country Club of South Carolina yesterday in the second polo game for the Country Club Cups played on the field of the Country Club of Westchester. The victors only won by a single goal, the final score being 15 to 14. The winners, however, were the stronger team, and earned all of their fifteen points, while the defeated quartet only earned 6 goals, the other eight being allowed by handicap.

The advance sale of seats for the special performance of "The Henrietta," by Robson and Crane and a selected cast of players, to benefit the Actors' Fund, which is to take place to-morrow afternoon at the Knickerbocker Theatre, indicates the likelihood of a large attendance.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 13 -- The discussion as to Archbishop Corrigan's successor has renewed also the much-discussed question of a division of the archdiocese of New York. It has longs been considered that the diocese was much too large and a division was looked upon as likely at any time. It is thought to be a solution of the difficulty in the successor for the dead Archbishop.
There is something amusing in the treatment awarded to the recent triumph of M.WALDECK-ROUSSEAU by The London Saturday Review. It says:
Pease Elliman have sold for John R. Suydam to a client, the dwelling, 12 East Forty-first Street, 20.11 by 98.9.

LONDON, May 13 -- At a luncheon party given by Gilbert Parker, M.P., at the House of Commons this afternoon to representatives of the American and colonial press, the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary, made an impromptu speech in a pleasant vein.

LOUISVILLE, May 13 -- Walter N. Haldeman, President of the Louisville Courier-Journal Company, and one of the oldest active newspaper men in the country, died suddenly at 3 o'clock, from the effects of injuries received by being struck by a trolley car Saturday morning. He was over eighty-one years old.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The Philadelphia market was irregular from the opening to-day, but a large part of the list was stiffened by the recovery of the Readings. Electric Storage Battery was the strongest issue in the Philadelphia list. After opening down 2 points to 80, it steadily advanced to 83 1/2.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The President has directed Secretary Root to confer upon the Cuban Court of Appeals the right to review the testimony in the case of Estes G. Ratnbone, convicted of complicity in the Cuban postal frauds, with authority to take additional evidence if it so desired. This authority will be immediately conferred and it is presumed the court will act at once.

The Hebrew Retail Butchers' Association, the members of which have kept their stores closed during the past few days on the lower east side, in the effort to force the wholesale dealers to reduce the prices on the kosher beef, yesterday agreed to reopen all their stores to-day.

MADRID, May 13 -- The streets of this city are assuming gala attire. A large section of the route to be followed by the procession next Saturday, the day of the coronation of King Alfonso, has been hung with festoons of foliage and flowers, among which are hidden multi-colored electric lamps.

ST. LOUIS, May 13 -- An extra inning was required to decide the baseball game between New York and St. Louis to-day, the visitors winning by scoring two runs in the tenth inning. St. Louis tied the score in the ninth inning, and a decision of the umpire declaring Wicker out at third in this inning prevented further scoring.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- Harry G. Bell, who, until March 29 last, was receiving teller of the Riverside National Bank of New York, was arrested here to-day on a fugitive warrant, charging him with the larceny of bank funds to the extent of $40,000. The original warrant charged Bell with embezzling $23,000, but a further examination of the books of the institution showed a deficit of $40,000.

Those who are engaged in organizing expeditions for the relief of the suffering survivors of the frightful calamity which has destroyed St. Pierre and necessitated the evacuation of St. Vincent by all who can get away do not need to be reminded of the exigency of the conditions which it is sought to relieve.

Army. The following-named officers will report on board the Dixie, New York City, for the purpose of proceeding to Martinique to distribute the stores under their charge at such ports as may be designated by the officer of the navy in command of the vessel named: Capt. Hugh J. Gallagher, Commissary; Capt. Robert Sewell, Quartermaster.

If the 40,000 or more survivors of the Island of Martinique can get enough to eat for the next two days, they need have no fear of a famine after that. A shipload of provisions, sufficiently large to supply their wants for ten days, will arrive at Fort de France late to-morrow on the steamship Madiana from St. Thomas.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The following was issued from the White House this afternoon:

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Traffic officials of the Western roads at a meeting held today considered the refusal of their Eastern connections to participate with them in the reductions they have announced on wheat and flour shipments from St. Paul and Minneapolis to the Atlantic seaboard.

To-day there will be quite a number of people galling for Europe. Wednesday is always most important, as more people leave and arrive on that day than on any other in the week. James Henry Smith, who is booked on the St. Louis, will be absent several months. He will cruise in the Margarita, the yacht belonging to Mr. and Mrs. Drexel, and which was chartered by Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Alexander.

FORT DB FRANCE, Martinique, May 13. -- The United States Government tug Potomac, which came to Martinique from San Juan, Porto Rico, cruised along the coast of this island yesterday afternoon. She encountered an inky-black column of smoke, which made it necessary for her to go five miles out of her course.

The course of yesterday's stocK market disposed of the foolish representations and predictions to which Wall Street has been obliged recently to listen. At the opening of the day's business there was the usual abundance of oracular declarations that tight money and labor troubles, weak accounts, and anxious brokers must soon produce market demoralization -- all this insistence being loudly proclaimed.

Prof.G.E. Woodberry's reply to the statement issued by President Nicholas Murray Butler on Friday last, an outline of which was printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday, is published in full in The Columbia Spectator, the students' organ. It reads:
The bunching of hits in the eighth inning enabled the Jersey City baseball team of the Eastern League to defeat the Toronto Club at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday by a score of 6 to 5.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Presbyterian ministers in this city expressed themselves as extremely shocked that Vincent Noll, the young student of Union Theological Seminary, who expressed doubts of the historical existence of Adam, should have died even before the news that he had been accepted by the New York Presbytery at its meeting Monday afternoon could be conveyed to him.

ALBANY, May 13 -- Attorney General Davies personally made application to Supreme Court Justice Chester at his chamber late this afternoon for the appointment of a referee to take the testimony of certain witnesses in the matter of the so-called Beef Trust preliminary to framing a complaint.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 13 -- Several hundred bankers are in the city to-day to attend the convention of the Bankers' Associations of Missouri, Kansas, and Oklahoma and Indian Territory. Three separate gatherings were in session this morning, the Kansas bankers meeting in Kansas City, Kan., and the Indian Territory and Missouri bankers convening on the Missouri side.

The Court of Appeals yesterday rendered a decision declaring the law under which City Magistrates were elected in Brooklyn last Fall to be unconstitutional. This settles the question in favor of the Magistrates appointed by Mayor Van Wyck in the Spring of last year.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was less active than on Monday, and fewer issues shared in the day's transactions. As for some days past the principal activity was in some of the speculative issues which recently have commanded more or less attention. Of the more important issues, the one that was the object of most interest was Northern Securities, which showed some weakness.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 13 -- A careful and systematic search for the dead and injured in the Sheridan horror of yesterday reveals to-night a list of 23 dead and 202 injured. The complete list of the injured may never be known, as many were able to get away without making known their identity.

LONDON, May 13 -- Money was slightly easier to-day, but no material decrease in rates is anticipated, while the market is largely indebted to the Bank of England, which has to renew a proportion of the loans due to it.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- Coal operators in this city are optimistic regarding the situation in the coal fields. Whether they have inside knowledge as to facts, or whether they are guarded by their expert ideas regarding the conditions, they all seem certain there there will be no strike.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Hugh Kelly of New York, extensively interested in Cuban sugar growing, was before the Senate Committee on Relations with Cuba, to-day. He asserted that the sugar growers would be the beneficiaries of any reduction that was made in the duty by the United States.

LONDON, May 14 -- A correspondent of The Times, wiring from Johannesburg, says two more mines, together having 100 stamps, have been started. More than 2,000 stamps are now in operation, and it is believed that more than half the gold-mining industry will be working by July.

BOSTON, May 13 -- The money market is extremely dull, with quoted rates showing little or no change. Sterling exchange is soft and rates are off another quarter cent all around, the shading being due to the prevailing high money rates. Clearing House rates, 6 per cent.; New York funds 5 cents discount; call loans 5 to 6; time money, 4 1/2 to 5.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- Prof. Amos P. Brown, head of the Geological Department of the University of Pennsylvania, believes that a second eruption of Mont Pelee may be looked for very soon. He said to-day:

MADRID, May 13 -- Dr. Jabez L.M. Curry, the special representative of the United States at the coronation of King Alfonso, arrived here at 3 o'clock this afternoon, and was received at the railroad station by Stanton Sickles, the Secretary of the United States Legation, and Mrs. Sickles, and by the Marquis de Vallalobar, representing the Spanish Government.

NORTH BEND, Neb., May 13. -- An effort to hold up and rob the Overland Limited train on the Union Pacific was frustrated four miles west of here last night by the bravery and determination of the flagman, Henry Trout.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Gen. John M. Wilson, the First Vice President of the American National Red Cross Association, was directed at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the association to-day to issue the following public appeal for aid for the sufferers from the Martinique disaster:

HAZLETON, Penn., May 14. -- The conveution of the anthracite mine workers, called at the instance of the Executive Boards of the three districts comprising the Pennsylvania hard coal fields, held two sessions to-day, and, without taking any action on the question of a permanent strike, adjourned until to-morrow morning.

W.L. Stow and some of his associates announced yesterday that they had purchased the Des Moines and Fort Dodge Railway, which is now operated under a lease by the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific. This lease expires in 1905, and it is understood that the new interests will insist that in the event of a renewal the terms must insure an adequate return to the holders of the common stock.

Lewis Nixon resigned as leader of Tammany Hall yesterday, and his leave-taking of the politicians was abrupt and picturesque. Since last December, when Richard Croker retired to Wantage, England, and placed the mantle of leadership on Mr. Nixon's shoulders, there has been activity between two factions in Tammany Hall.

Such activity as showed in yesterday's security market was attended by strength. Though the coal strike issue had reached the critical point, scant attention was given to it on the Stock Exchange, anthracite securities being in the group that was strongest. A number of specialties advanced; none significantly declined.

The yachting season on the Sound will open on Saturday, when the Spring regatta, of the Huguenot Yacht Club of New Rochelle will take place. This regatta brings together for the first time a number of new boats of the small classes. The racing will be confined to the twenty-one-foot raceabout class, the twenty-flve-foot special class of sloops, the Manhassett one-design raceabouts, and one-design dories.

Of the many happenings that combined to irritate the betting element at the Morris Park race track yesterday, the disappointment in the race for the Laureate Stakes so far took precedence that the defeat of five favorites and the disqualification of the best horse, after he had won the hurdie handicap, were all but overlooked, so nearly unanimous was the crowd in opinion concerning the carelessness and overconfidence of A. Featherstone's jockey.
Discussing the condition of the iron and metal trades The Iron Age will to-day say:

Notwithstanding the strike talk from Hazleton, Penn., the operators yesterday expressed the belief that the anthracite miners' convention would adjourn without ordering a strike. President Truesdale of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, said:

The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

The Democratic Club was crowded last evening. There were more district leaders gathered in the red room and in the other parts of the building than have congregated since the retirement of Richard Croker from the leadership.

LONDON, May 15. -- At the request of the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary, Sir Joseph Dimsdale, the Lord Mayor of London, has opened a fund at the Mansion House for the relief of the victims of the volcanic eruption on the Island of St. Vincent.

Frank J. Gould, with Bedell Harncd, in an automobile of the New York Electric Company and steered by Charles R. Gaurdorf, were yesterday hurrying to the Custom House when Policeman William Tyndall arrested the chauffeur for being on the wrong side of the street.

NEW ORLEANS, May 14. -- Col. Lamar C. Quintero, Consul at Costa Rica in New Orleans, returned last night from San Jose where he attended the inauguration of Ascension Esquival as President of the Costa Rican Republic and witnessed the quelling of the incipient revolution May 3.

KANSAS CITY, May 14. -- Missouri and Kansas bankers, at their convention here to-day, adopted strong resolutions against the system of branch banking proposed in a bill now pending in Congress. The question came up at the morning session and caused much discussion. In the afternoon the discussion centred around the addresses delivered by J.H. Eckels and Charles G. Dawes, ex-Controllers of the Currency, who took for their theme, "Assets currency."

A.L. Mordecai Son have sold for Francis M. Jencks to the West Side Construction Company the plot, 65 by 100, on the south side of Ninety-fourth Street, 135 feet east of Riverside Drive, upon which the buyers will erect a six-story apartment house.

MADRID, May 14. -- The Dukes of Genoa and Oporto arrived here to-day to attend the coronation of King Alfonso, and have been lodged in the palace. They were received by the King, who accompanied them to their apartments.

The athletic carnival of track and field games arranged by the Greater New York Irish Athletic Association for Decoration Day at Celtic Park, Long Island City, will be one of the most important local athletic events of the season.

A new trust company is about to be organized under the laws of the State of New York. The name of the corporation will be the Eastern Trust Company, and if will have a paid-up capital of $1,000,000, with a surplus of $1,000,000. The President is to be Charles M. Jesup, a nephew of Morris K. Jesup, and formerly Vice President of the Metropolitan Trust Company.

Honors again went to Lyle E. Mahan and Alfred E. Thurber yesterday in the final match of the Columbia University lawn tennis tournament. The pair captured the championship title and trophy for the doubles for the second consecutive year. Lewis N. Chase an ex-champion of California, and Robert Le Roy, the indoor title holder, composed the opposing team.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- According to report, the Department of Justice is likely to proceed against those persons and corporations which control the output of anthracite coal. A Washington paper, discussing the report, says:

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- The police here strongly suspect that the pretended servant who robbed the house of Mrs. Chambers in New York last Saturday was none other than "Tillie" Kelly, alias Scott, the "servant girl with the gold tooth," who of the night of March 28, escaped from Moyamensing Prison, in this city.

PARIS, May 14. -- Ex-President Kruger has sent a message of condolence to President Loubet, in which he says that, although handicapped by circumstances, he desires to emphasize his sympathy by contributing 800f. ($160) toward the Martinique fund.
LONDON, May 14. -- Money was much wanted to-day for the settlement, notwithstanding considerable preparations. Discounts were steady.

The final game of the present series between the Jersey City and Toronto baseball teams at Jersey City yesterday was won by the Canadians. A base on balls, an error, and three hits gave Toronto three runs in the sixth inning. The score:
ALBANY, May 14. -- The Manhattan Transit Company, with a capital stock of $10,000,000, was incorporated to-day with the Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Mrs. Roosevelt and family will leave the White House for their Summer home at Oyster Bay Monday, June 9, making the journey by sea aboard the Dolphin. This boat is now at the navy yard being put in order for the trip.
LONDON, May 14. -- The Governor of the Windward Islands, Sir Robert B. Llewelyn, has telegraphed to the Colonial Office from St. Vincent, under date of May 13, as follows:

The thirty-first annual meeting of the National Association of Stove Manufacturers of the United States was convened in the East Room of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday morning. The meeting is the most important one ever held by the association and about two hundred manufacturers were present.

Whitelaw Reid was the guest of honor at farewell banquet given at the Union League Club last night in anticipation of his approaching departure for London as special ambassador of the United States at the coronation of King Edward VII.

BOSTON, May 14. -- The money market is very dull and rates are unchanged. Clearing House rate, 6 per cent; New York funds, 50 discount; call loans, 5 to 6 per cent; time money, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent; Clearing House exchanges, $23,512,578; balances $1,870,803. The copper stocks showed improved tone to-day, while the general list was slow Complete transactions were as follows:

CASTRIES, Island of St. Lucia, Tuesday, May 13. -- The correspondent of The Associated Press here has visited St. Pierre, Martinique, by the relieving steamer Kenneth. The destruction there is appalling. The streets are two feet deep in ashes and cinders, which cover thousands of dead bodies, scorched black and shiny as if they had been plunged into boiling pitch.

ST. LOUIS, May 14. -- The New York baseball team won to-day's game here by a lively batting rally in the seventh inning, when Joyce's delivery was solved by almost every man on the team. Four single safe hits produced four runs, and Joyce was requested to give way to Wicker. Three runs were secured while this young man officiated.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Mr. Hepburn, Chairman of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce, said today:

The syndicate of vituperation which Senator DOLLIVER challenged the other day "to name the case of one woman or of one child that had suffered by an order of Gen. SMITH in Samar" is fertile in falsehoods and active in their dissemination. Senator TURNER of "Washington read one of these slanderous inventions in the Senate the other day, and it appears in The Record as a part of his speech.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 14. -- Princeton's baseball team retired the Brown University nine here to-day in a fast game by a score of 9 to 0. The home team took the lead in the first inning on three hits, a balk, and an error. Leland settled down after this and kept the hits scattered. Dunscombe pitched a good game for Princeton, allowing only four hits.

Under the pretense of engaging as a servant, a female thief joined the household of Dr. P.F. Chambers, at 49 West Fifty-seventh Street Saturday morning and in less than three hours disappeared with some fourteen articles of Mrs. Chambers's jewelry, the articles taken being worth about $3,200.
The Civil Service Reform Association, at its annual meeting at the City Club last night, censured President Roosevelt, yet made him a Vice President of the organization.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- In the presence of a large audience, President Roosevelt today laid the cornerstone of the McKinley Memorial Ohio College of Government, of the American University, situated a few miles outside this city, in the northwestern part of the District of Columbia. When completed the building will be devoted to studies embracing diplomacy, municipal government, arbitration, civics, and international law.

The Louisville and Nashville and the Southern Railway jointly have purchased the Chicago, Indiananplis and Louisville, better known as the "Monon" route. This statement is made on the highest authority, although a definite official announcement could not be obtained yesterday.

BABYLON, L.I., May, 15. -- Mrs. Sallie Levey, thirty-one years of age, of New York City, a patient in the Long Island Home, hilled herself this evening by throwing herself in front of the Amagansett Express as it passed through Amityville, near the home.

POUGHKEESIE, May 14. -- Papers filed in the office of the Clerk of Dutchess County this afternoon would indicate that there is an unpleasantness brewing between Mrs. Ogden Mills and Clarence G. Dinsmore, two of Dutchess County's richest residents. On Oct. 11, 1900. Mrs. Mills made application to the Town Board of Hyde Park for permission to divert the post road near her premises to a point about one hundred yards further east.

Superintendent Stewart of the Bureau of Building has discovered violations of the Building Code in the construction of the new Astor hotel, called the St. Regis, in course of construction at Fifty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue. The hotel is being constructed by private contracts with the Astor estate, and is to be a twenty-story structure.

Robert Edeson is the latest volunteer for the testimonial to be tendered Mrs. Lester Wallack Thursday afternoon, May 22, at Wallack's Theatre. Mr. Edeson will present for the first time a one-act play, "Tempesta," and will be assisted by Miss Dorothy Donnelly, Guy Bates Post, and Harry Harwood, who are now appearing with him in "Soldiers of Fortune," at the Savoy Theatre.
CINCINNATI, May 14. -- The fifteenth Music Festival began here to-night with the first performance in Cincinnati of Caesar Franck's oratorio "Les Beatitudes."

NEWARK, May 14. -- An injunction was granted by Vice Chancellor Emery here to-day, restraining the stocknolders of the International Kaolin Company from leasing or discharging any of the property of the concern, a receiver for which was appointed recently. The bill granted by the Vice Chancellor is returnable May 27.

Among the securities listed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday were those of the new National Railroad of Mexico and of the George A. Fuller Company, the first contracting and building corporation to have its stock listed on the Stock Exchange.

Before Coroner Brown and a jury yesterday the inquest was begun into the death of Walter Brooks, who was found in a room in the Glen Island Hotel, and who had died in the Hudson Street Hospital from a builet wound in the head. He had been taken there under the belief that he was suffering from asphyxiation.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- Cattle prices were higher in the Union Stock Yards in Chicago to-day than for the last twenty years. The top price of the day, $7.60, was 10 cents in advance or the high mark last week. All the offerings were snapped up, and the buyers clamored for more. The receipts fell below the estimates, amounting to 13,000 head.

The Legislature and the Governor of the sovereign State of Louisiana are apparently determined to put a stop to the sale of mules to the British, presumably for use in South Africa. Gov. HEARD'S appeal to the President was fruitless, for the reason that the laws of the United States do not forbid the sale of mules and other war supplies to belligerents.

Presbyterian ministers in large numbers arrived in this city yesterday. They are to attend the General Assembly of the Church, which convenes at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 11 o'clock this morning. Two topics were uppermost in the discussions of the arrivals -- the Moderatorship of the Assembly and the revision of the Westminster Confession of Faith.

KINGS PARK, L.I., May 14. -- Richard V.B. Newton, once legal adviser of John Y. McKane, died of paresis in the Long Island State Hospital here late last night. He was brought to the hospital on Jan. 30 and had been gradually sinking ever since.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 14. -- Admiral Killick, commander of the Haitian fleet, has started for Cape Haitien with the warships Crete a Pierot and Toussaint L'Ouverture, having declared himself in favor of Gen. Firmin, the ex-Minister of Haiti at Paris, who is at the head of the revolutionary forces in the northern part of the island.
LONDON, May 15. -- The freedom of the Plumbers' Company was presented to Andrew Carnegie yesterday at the Guildhall. The document was inclosed in a valuable casket of various metals.

The third annual meeting of the Horticultural Society of New York was held yesterday in the Museum Building at the Botanical Garden, and an exhibition in connection with the meeting was opened. President James Wood of Mount Kisco presided at the formal business meeting, and the old officers, including Mr. Wood, were re-elected, as follows:

LONDON, May 15. -- In its City article to-day The Times says the increased pressure on the money market yesterday was due to the increased volume of stock open for the rise which is being financed here for American holders. This increase, which absorbed much more money than was expected, and raised the rate, was the only new feature of the Stock Exchange settlement which closed yesterday.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was broader than on any day since the unsettling of the market caused by the declines which occurred in Dominion Securities and the other issues of this group. While more issues were dealt in, there was also much more display of strength and a number of stocks showed substantial advances.

LONDON, May 15. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times, referring to the reported statements in the United States of Hugues Le Roux on the Dreyfus case, says M. Zola has published a letter formally denying M. Le Roux's assertions.

Nearly forty graduates from a dozen different universities met yesterday on the links of the St. Andrew's Golf Club, near Chauncey, Westchester County, to compete for four prizes. The tournament was the annual golf competition of the University Club, which, by the courtesy of the St. Andrew's Club, has been held on the letter's links for the last two or three years.

In a book called "The Storied West Indies." written by Frederick A. Oher and published by D. Appleton Co., there appear descriptions of the Caribs, the last survivors of which race apparently have been wiped out of existence by the volcanic eruptions.

Patrick Hynes, twenty-one years old, of 616 East Seventeenth Street, formerly employed in the Eagle Pencil Factory, was shot twice just above the heart last night after a bitter quarrel with Edward Scheisler, twenty-five years old, a coal dealer, living at 601 East Fourteenth Street. The police declare that Scheisler did the shooting, and say that he later admitted it, and claimed he had to shoot to defend himself.

Doubtless that is an interesting announcement that certain young billionaires among the automobilists are proposing to construct a special speedway for automobiles from some not given point on the periphery of Long Island City to some point, also not given, in the town of Hempstead.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- After the reading of the Journal in the House to-day Mr. Mahon, (Rep., Penn.,) the Chairman of the Committee on War Claims, arose to a question of personal privilege and called attention to an attack which had been made upon him in a circular purporting to expose the Selfridge board's findings.

Mr. NIXON need not have taken the trouble to resign. As soon as it appeared that he could not control the Tammany organization he was already dethroned, rejected, out of office, an exboss. His formal resignation is nothing more than a paper testimony to an existing condition.

PRINCETON, May 14. -- The ninth general court of the Society of Colonial Wars of New Jersey was held here to-day. At the dinner given to-night at the Princeton Inn Richard Watson Gilder, editor of The Country Magazine, read an original poem, from, which these stanzas are taken:

LONDON, May 16 -- In a statement in the House of Commons yesterday regarding the measures proposed by the Government for the relief of the sufferers from the volcanic outbreaks in the West Indies, the Government leader in the House, the Right Hon. A.J. Balfour, after a reference to the steps taken, said:

WINSTED, Conn., May 15 -- Supervisor McArdle or the Central New England Railroad, who has charge of the work in progress to perfect the branch running from Tariffville, this State, to Springfield, Mass., says the company will have trains running into Massachusetts in two months.

There is reason to fear that with the approach of Summer we shall see a very much more general disturbance of the relations between the trades unions and employers than has been witnessed since the beginning of the present period of prosperity. Until quite recently the most usual item of the daily news related to apparently voluntary and more or less spontaneous advances in wages in nearly all branches of industry.
MADRID, May 15. -- King Alfonso and the Queen Regent to-day received in audience foreign missions appointed to attend the coronation of the King. The function was surrounded with great ceremonial.

An interesting illustration of how reforms may be accomplished if undertaken in the right way is furnished by the success which has attended the efforts of the Merchants and Manufacturers' Board of Trade to minimize the nuisance and public injury resulting from the unnecessary obstruction of the streets from the rubbish and debris of the subway excavation.

BOSTON, May 15. -- Although money was firm at clearing to-day there was no out-Side marking up of rates and the usual run of business doing was very slight. Sterling Exchange is a trifle firmer in tone. Clearing House rate, 6 and 7 per cent.; New York funds, 10c discount; call loans, 5@6 per cent.; time money, 4 1/2@ 5 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $31,337,743; balances, $518,440.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- Dahlen's wild throw in to-day's baseball game between Brooklyn and Chicago was responsible for three bases, and Taylor's hit in the last inning secured the game for the local nine.

Chicago informs us that hereafter all railways will charge the same price for carrying wheat and flour for export. Flour has heretofore paid 2 1/2 cents more per hundredweight than wheat. The price for both is to be 20 1/2 cents. The lower charge is said to fee worth "millions" of dollars annually to the millers of the Northwest.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Capt. Lee Hall, formerly of the Thirty-third Volunteer Infantry, was the witness before the Senate Philippine Committee to-day. He was in command of a company of Macabebe scouts. He said these were deadly enemies of the Tagalogs. He had heard of instances of the water cure, but saw none.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The negotiations between Secretary Hay and the Ministers from Colombia, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica looking to the acquirement of the necessary rights for the construction by the United States Government of either the Panama or the Nicaragua Canal have at last been concluded, and to-morrow the Secretary of State will be able to send to the Senate three treaties covering the ground.

With seven probable starters in the Brooklyn Handicap among the ten runners that answered the call to the post, the last race of the afternoon at Morris Park yesterday took on an aspect that made it the real feature of one of the best programmes that the Westchester Racing Association has offered this Spring.

ST. THOMAS, Danish West Indies, May 15 -- The Danish cruiser Valkyrien has returned here from Martinique. The correspondent here of The Associated Press has had an interview with one of the Valkyrien's officers, who said:

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The arrest of Gaynor and Greene was the result of a carefully prepared and well-matured plan devised by the Government officials, acting under instructions of the Department of Justice of the United States. Its inception dates back to the time Gaynor and Greene left the United States and took up their residence in Quebec.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- Trading in the local market was very light, and the whole list was dull and firm all day. The Readings exihibited heaviness at the start, but there was sufficient buying orders at the decline to restore the lost ground, and Lehigh Valley, which fell 3/4 before midday was finally stimulated by the inherent strength of the Readings.
KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, May 13. -- Scientists who have come here from Trinidad predict another volcanic eruption on St. Vincent within a short time.

Buffalo began a series of four games with the Jersey City baseball club of the Eastern Leagrue yesterday, and although the visitors outbatted the local players the Jerseymen won the game through errors made by Grimshaw and Shaw of Buffalo.

Prompt action by the commanders of four police precincts checked a disturbance that threatened the lower east side of the city with disaster last night. The trouble behind the outbreak was the dissatisfaction over prices of Kosher meat.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Secretary of War has designated Major David L. Brainard, Commissary at New York, to take charge of any contributions that may he made by citizens of New YorK and other cities for the sufferers in the French West Indies, and which the citizens' committees may wish forwarded through the War Department.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15 -- The old yard at Harvard was the scene to-night of one of the most enthusiastic demonstrations held in Cambridge for years, a demonstration held in honor of the Crimson's famous Dean, who, at the end of the present school year, will be Dean from the students' standpoint no more.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of the 13th inst., under the heading "A Sermon Interrupted," it appears that the Rev. McFarland, pastor of Bethany Church, Newark, on being interrupted during his sermon last Sunday night by the Treasurer of the church, who took exception to some of the pastor's remarks, retorted: "That's what you would expect from a Jew."

ITHACA, N.Y., May 15. -- By bunching hits in the tenth inning, Cornell won today's baseball game against the Manhattan College team of New York. It was a warfare between pitchers throughout, with honors even between Bristol and Callahan. At the end of the ninth inning each nine had tallied two runs.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 15. -- A special meeting of the City Council has been called for to-morrow evening to take action regarding the entertainment of the French delegates who are coming to this country to attend the dedication of the Rochambeau Monument in Washington. The delegates will come to Newport on Memorial Day to place a wreath from President Loubet of France on the grave of Admiral de Ternay in Trinity Churchyard.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Mr. Vandiver (Mo.) sent to the desk and had read a statement appearing in The Irish World signed by Corp. Richard O'Brien, Company M, Twenty-sixth Volunteers, giving alleged details of atrocities in the Philippines, the killing of native women and babes under circumstances of unusual cruelty, including the alleged use of dumdum bullets.

The new building of the Naval Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, at Sands and Charles Streets, Brooklyn, erected by Miss Helen Gould, was formally dedicated yesterday. Exercises were held in the morning, afternoon, and evening.

STOCKHOLM, May 15. -- The general strike decreed by the Social Democratic Party in support of the Suffrage bill, the debate on which began in Parliament today, was carried out as arranged, and the tie-up of business here has been practically complete since this morning. Traffic is suspended.

Lakewood second won the Country Club Cups yesterday in the final polo competition for those trophies on the field of the Westchester Country Club. The winning score was 13 goals for the New Jersey players to 8 for the home delegation, but the feature of the match was that the victors were the weaker team on handicap ratings, and were allowed three goals by the defeated side.

The Summer picture party at the Clausen Gallery is made up of half a hundred canvases, the greater part of which, is modern work by living painters. Here and there an exception. A sketch in oils by Homer D. Martin, dated 1904, has sweet, light tones in the sky and a foreground broadly brushed.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Senator Hanna professes to believe there will be canal legislation this session of Congress. When asKed to-day if he thought the Senate would pass a canal bill before adjourning, he said:

In yesterday's security market dullness still reigned -- grew even more pronounced, total transactions barely passing the 300,000-share mark. Only about half a dozen stocks were traded in to the extent of 10,000 shares apiece. Generally fluctuations were insignificant. On every side was shown a waiting disposition -- waiting for money market improvement, for some actual development in the anthracite labor situation.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 15. -- The local trading is still dull. Conditions will not permit otherwise. The buying demand continues nothing and promises to remain so until the speculative prospects in New York clarify somewhat. Besides, the local interest is centring itself around the income bonds of the United Railways Company and the Cotton Duck incomes.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 15. -- Ground was broken to-day in Bayonne by the J.M. Guffey Petroleum Company for the erection of a storage plant designed to supply Texas oil to the New York and Eastern markets. Two storage tanks of 95 feet diameter, having a capacity of 35,000 barrels each, are to be constructed without delay.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 15 -- One sequel to the embezzlement by George Valentine of $300,000 from the Middlesex County National Bank of Perth Amboy came up in court here to-day when James S. Wight, City Clerk of Perth Amboy, and a prominent lawyer there, was called to plead to a charge of embezzling $9,000 of the funds of the Homestead Building Loan Association of Perth Amboy.

Chief Engineer William Barclay Parsons was requested by the Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday to make a report invoiving the building of a complete system of roads connecting all the boroughs, and August Belmont. whose money is back of the building of the present subway, has formally offered to provide the money for any tunnels the city may wish to build for itself in the future.

MONTREAL, Quebec, May 15. -- Col. John H. Gaynor and Capt. Benjamin D. Greene are prisoners on board the tug Spray, on the way from Quebec to Montreal, and in pursuit of them are three tugboats, while another has gone from Montreal to intercept them.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 15 -- The French steamer Olinde Rodrigues sailed this afternoon, taking ex-President Sam and his wife into exile.

LONDON, May 16 -- Two messages expressing sympathy regarding the loss of life at St. Vincent and offering aid have been received by the British Government from the United States Government. One was private and the other official. The former was verbally presented by United States Ambassador Choate, whom Lord Lansdowne, the Foreign Secretary, warmly thanked.

LONDON, May 16 -- The horrors of the Martinique and St. Vincent disasters are beginning to give the pride of place in the London newspapers to discussions as to the probable outcome of the Boer peace conference. Practically all the dispatches describing the scenes at the time of or after the eruptions come from New York, and many of the papers content themselves with publishing the most striking features of these reports.

PERTH AMBOY, May 15. -- A committee of the depositors of the Middlesex County Bank has filed with Receiver Edward S. Campbell petitions asking that the offer of the bank Directors to pay $30,000 in full settlement of the judgment secured against them be accepted.

New York City, through many of its civic bodies is doing a vost amount of work in procuring funds and supplies for the relief of the thousands of sufferers by the volcanic eruptions in the West Indies.
George Ranger has sold, for P. Harmony's Nephew Co., to Charles M Rosenthal, the plot on the east side of Fifth Avenue, 50 feet north of One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, 101 by 110.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Heywood C. Leavitt of Nebraska continued his testimony before the Senate Cuban Relations Committee to-day. He said if the Sugar Trust did not receive all the benefits of the proposed concessions to Cuba it would be because the trust would make a present of the concession to the planters.

The sale of The Philadelphia Record at public auction yesterday for the great sum of $2,897,000 gives proof of the value of an established and prosperous newspaper of high character published in a large city. The history of The Record and its sale demonstrate, moreover, the stability of the value of a successful newspaper.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- The holdings of the Singerly estate in The Philadelphia Record newspaper were sold to-day at auction for $2,874,800 to William S. Stenger, representing unknown clients.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 15 -- The Supreme Court to-day rendered an opinion which practically nullifies the prohibition law in the sixty counties in which it Is" in force in this State. Decision' is in ''the casa of Pat Hanaphy, agent of the Dallas City Transportation Company, who took orders for the shipment of liquor to certain parties in this State.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- It is stated at the War Department that the supplies and stores shipped to Martinique and St. Vincent on the cruiser Dixie from New York and on the collier Sterling from San Juan undoubtedly will be sufficient to meet the urgent needs of the suffering people for fully a month to come.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 15. -- After four months and a half of exciting sessions, the Constitutional Convention came to an agreement to-day and adjourned. The chief contention has been over the matter of representation in the Legislature, the large towns demanding recognition of population and the small towns, who held the majority, insisting that towns must be the basis.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The retirement of Mr. Nixon from the leadership of Tammany Hall is something of a relief to the Tammany members of the House of Representatives. As a rule they did not regard Mr. Nixon as a person admirably fitted for the political post bestowed on him by Mr. Croker.

Reports from Troy and Albany last night contained inquiries as to negotiations said to be under foot at the present time for the consolidation of the companies operating steamboat lines on the Hudson River. The companies believed to be interested in the deal, or consolidation plan, are the Albany Day Boat Line, the people's Line, and the Citizens' Line.

LONDON, May 15. -- The short-loan market was very unsettled to-day, and it was difficult to escape indebtedness to the Bank of England. The brokers' day-by-day borrowings reveal the poverty of Lombard Street, and further large borrowings have ensued, owing to heavy payments for new consols in full, which have denuded the market.

Only 30 cents for the undeveloped fern balls now. That is very little considering the great pleasure they give. They can be started and allowed to grow through the Summer, dried up if one does not care to keep them growing through the cold weather; started another Spring, and kept on indefinitely for a number of years, and there is nothing that Is less trouble and which responds so generously to a little care.
