The district leaders of Tammany Hall discussed somewhat freely yesterday the resignation of Lewis Nixon from the control of the organization on the ground that he was being interfered with by a "kitchen cabinet" headed by Andrew Freedman. Lewis Nixon reiterated last evening his determination to get out of politics and devote his time to shipbuilding.

Commissioners of Accounts Russell and Owens made public yesterday reports to Mayor Low of investigations of the Department of Charities during the administration of Commissioner Keller. The reports show that C.A. Alden embezzled funds of the Charities Department through various accounts to the amount of $18.000 instead of $5,852, as originally discovered when Mr. Alden fled from New York.

HAZLETON, Penn., May 15. -- The anthracite mine workers in convention late this afternoon decided to continue the strike of the 145,000 men against the mine owners and to fight it out to the bitter end. The matter of calling out the engineers, firemen, and pump runners will be decided by the delegates to-morrow.

That element of the Presbyterian Church which calls itself liberai on the subject of creed revision achieved what its adherents considcred a notable victory in the first skirmish of the General Assembly which corvencd at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by electing as Moderator of the body for the coming year the Rev. Dr. Henry van Dyke of Princeton, N.J., acting pastor of the Brick Church of this city.

That Andrew Carnegie's opposition to Philippine annexation was strong enough to lead him to make an offer of $20,000,000 to prevent it has just been disclosed in an article written by President George F. Seward of the Fidelity and Casualty Company for the monthly bulletin published by that company.

Edward Hanlan, coach of the Columbia crews, said yesterday that he is trying to arrange a race between Columbia and the Argonaut Boat Club of Toronto. The Argonauts are going to England in June and the race probably will be rowed on the Hudson River just before the Canadian crew leaves for England, on June 10.

ALBANY, May 15 -- Former Supreme Court Justice Judscn S. Landon, as referee, to-day began an investigation, under the provisions of the Donnelly anti-trust law, to determine whether or not an illegal combination to manipulate the price of meat exists between the large packing houses of the West.
MADRID, May 15. -- The official ceremonies in honor of the majority of King Alfonso opened here to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- In the Senate to-day, Mr. McLaurin (Miss.) addressed the Senate in opposition to the Philippine Government bill. He discussed some of the criticisms made of the minority Senators because of " their attack upon the army " and because of " their slanders upon the army."

-- As soon as the health of Admiral SAMPSON became seriously impaired, which was just after the Santiago blockade ended in a blaze of glory, the friends, self-selected and other, of that lamented officer began to talk about the disastrous consequences upon a sensitive nature of criticism both adverse and unjust.

HAZLETON, Penn., May 16. -- The anthracite mine workers in convention to-day unanimously decided upon a plan which, if carried to successful operation, might tie up all the industries of the country. It is their desire that a special National Convention of the United Mine Workers of America be called as soon as practicable to endeavor to have all the bituminous mine workers, both organized and unorganized, involved in the anthracite miners' struggle.
WIESBADEN, May 16. -- Emperor William last Wednesday telegraphed as follows to the President of the United States:

CHICAGO, May 16. -- The lard refinery of Armour Co., situated at the corner of Forty-third Street and Centre Avenue, was destroyed by fire to-night, and during the fire a number of accidents occurred by which many people were injured. It is not known that any one was killed. Estimates as to the number of the injured are from five to twenty-five.

THERE will be published on May 29 by John Lane "An English Girl in Ports," by an anonymous writer. This is said to be a bright book of clever dialogue, in the course of whose pages the heroine visits for a month the bachelor apartment of her uncle in Paris; there she "does" Parisian society.
LONDON, May 16. -- There was a good demand for money to-day and the pressure was lessened owing to the large sums obtained from the Bank of England recently. Discounts were firm.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 16. -- Mr. Henry A.C. Taylor has added materially to his country seat. Glen Farm, in Portsmouth, by the purchase of an adjoining farm containing about eighty acres. This purchase will give him a private entrance to the Glen Farm on the East Main Road, directly opposite Mr. A.G. Vanderbilt's Oakland Farm, with a driveway nearly one-half mile long from the road to the principal buildings on the estate.

THE name of Sunnybank, an old homestead in Virginia which is also the title of her eighth novel, appropriately names Marion Harland's present home on Ramapo Late, in the picturesque Valley of Pompton, in New Jersey.

BOSTON, May 16. -- In the money market to-day considerable shading of quoted rates was reported. No one seemed to know of any actual loans made at clearing. It was said that money was offered as low as 5 per cent. The easier money rates have resulted in strengthening sterling exchange, rates to-day being marked up 1/4 per cent, all around.

NEW ORLEANS, May 16. -- George Loud and a number of other horsemen, who left here last Winter for Cuba, returned to-day from Havana. They had a hard time of it, and are more than pleased to get back home. The season was not a success by any means, and the horsemen had a hard time in collecting the purses won.

Schoolboys of Horace Mann School held their annual track and field games on the South Field track of Columbia University yesterday afternoon. The track was slow, and this served to prevent fast time, but did not hinder close finishes, of which there were many. Albert Celler carried off the individual honors, winning the 100 and 220-yard dashes, the sixty-yard hurdle, and the quarter-mile run, and also won the relay race for his class.

There was a further sharp break on the Stock Exchange yesterday in Rutland Railroad preferred, one of the Webb-Meyer specialties. The stock, which closed on Thursday at 88, sold down sharply yesterday, at one time 14 points, to 74, later rallying somewhat, and closing at 80, for a net loss of 8 points, on dealings in 3,000 shares.
The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In your editorial article of last week on "Provincial Literature" you say:
LONDON, May 17. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times sends a telegram, from Fort de France, Martinique, dated May 15.

Mr. Oscar Fay Adams of Boston is dissatisfied with "The Merchant of Venice" as Shakespeare wrote it and has added an act that makes it more to his liking. His idea seems to be that Shakespeare has been recreant to his trust in not showing the ultimate result of making Shylock a Christian.

The annual distribution of awards of merit in the Department of Schools of the National Academy of Design, One Hundred and Ninth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, was made last night, at the conclusion of the seventy-seventh school year. Frederick Dielman. President of the academy, made the presentations, which were as follows:

MONTREAL, Quebec, May 10. -- Col. John F. Gaynor and Capt. Benjamin Greene, who are accused of embezzling funds of the United States, and whose arrest in Quebec yesterday caused a sensation, seem likely to enjoy the hospitality of the Windsor Hotel for some time, while the lawyers benefit by a long litigation over their disposition.

We learn from Rome that the steadily growing interest in the life and teachings of St. Francis of Assist has led to the foundation at that place of a Societa Internazionale di Studi Francescani, with the object of creating a library of Franciscan literature and of facilitating the researches or persons anxious to study the development of the Franciscan idea.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- One of the rarest historical documents connected with the political life of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania has recently been purchased by George C. Thomas, head of the banking firm of Drexel Co., whose collection of books and manuscripts is one of the most valuable in the country.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 16. -- The local market, in a smaller way, paralleled the excessive dullness which prevailed in New York. It is now a question of how serious will be the effect of the strike on general speculative sentiment. Local opinion expects nothing more damaging than a continuance of the sluggishness which the recent uncertainty has created.

THE CORNHILL for May contains an admirably written article by Mr. Charles Whibley on "Literary Forgers," a subject which appeals strongly to his sense of humor and upon which he writes with full knowledge and great enjoyment.

After long deliberation, from which it was safe to conclude that wise and conservative counsels would ultimately prevail, the Hazleton convention decided to declare a strike, with a majority of only 111 out of a total vote of 811. The large vote against the strike indicates that the issues involved are not vital.

It is a very good sign that English scholars should have taken to the work of rehabilitating Macaulay. Matthew Arnold's vogue for the last generation has made a great many people shy of expressing the admiration for the stalwart polemic which they really felt. Probably it has made no great difference in the popularity of the writer as evidenced by the sale of his books.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Senator Spooner of Wisconsin was held up to view in the Senate to-day as the cause for the minority's unwillingness to fix a time for the vote on the Philippine bill, and found himself in the surprising position of beng regarded as an obstacle to the passage of a Republican Party measure.

In the midst of our present literary deluge it is restful as well as interesting to be able to go back to the Johnsonian era, when books and booksellers were few, and to read of those who were giants in their day and generation and to whom literature owes sot much. Mr. Marston has happily quoted Charles Knight in his introductory note as follows:

HAZLETON, Penn., May 16. -- A delegation of bituminous mine operators and mine workers' officials from Illinois arrived here to-night to hold a conference with President Mitchell regarding a local difference between the mine owners an their employes at Springfield, Ill. Mr. Mitchell's prolonged stay in the anthracite field necessuatea the journey of the party to Hazleton to adjust the differences.

In publishing the fourth volume of his Cyclopedia of American Horticulture Prof. Bailey brings to a most creditable conclusion an important enterprise, and one that has occupied him and his assistants about five years. The present volume is prefaced by an entertaining account of how it was prepared, and some statistic of the material it includes.

Brooklyn is to have a new twelve-story hotel on Pierrepont Street, the erection of which will be begun within sixty days. James H. Breslin, ex-landlord of the Gilsey House, who is one of the Directors of the Brooklyn Heights Realty Company, recently organized with a capital of $1,500,000, said, yesterday that the building will contain more than 500 rooms and cost in the neighborhood of $1,500,000, exclusive of furnishings.

Sir Spencer Walpole has recently edited a number of hitherto unpublished letters written by Horace Walpole to the Han. Thomas Walpole and to one of the latter's sons, another Thomas, the two latter being Sir Spencer Walpole's grandfather and great grandfather respectively.

Although a few more stocks were dealt in than on Thursday, the transactions in the outside market yesterday were for the most part so restricted that the total for the day was a small one. Prices showed considerable irregularity, several stocks advancing sharply, while elsewhere in the list some heavy losses were being recorded.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, May 16. -- Mr. Theodore Watts-Dunton, well-known as a poet and critic, and the intimate friend of Lowell during the latter's mission at the Court of St. James's, contributes to next week's Athenaeum an article on Bret Harte's position in literature.

SINCE men of letters, who constitute the longest-lived class in the tables of vital statistics, frequently outlive the gifts which made them brilliant in youth and great in the years of their maximum physical and mental vigor, it is not unusual to find in their last works only such evidence of their earlier brilliancy as remains in the afterglow of intellectual twilight.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 16. -- The third day of the great music festival passed in prayerful expectation. There was no afternoon concert, and Cincinnati music lovers endeavored to prepare themselves for the extreme test of the night. The evening conert was devoted to the performance of Bach's B minor mass, given in its entirety for the first time here.

I FIRST came to a knowledge of Bret Harte through the columns of a ras of a sporting paper which I picked up in a frontier barber's shop on the Ozark border sometime in 1869. I had gone into the place to receive the ministrations of its attendant, and having a bad quarter of an hour to wait, picked up according to my wont, the first printed thing that came to hand.

We should say that the disturbances on the crowded east side in this city might give the Beef Combine something to think about rather seriously. It is the most violent and general manifestation of passionate resentment toward what is believed to be the policy of the Combine that has been made, and it is more noteworthy than anything of its kind that has ever happened in this country.

LONDON, May 16. -- Richard Croker began an interview to-day concerning the affairs of the Tammany society with an emphatic protest to the effect that he had ceased to meddle in New York politics "Thirty-seven years of political fighting is enough for one life," he said, "and I am done with it. I tell you, once and for all," Mr. Croker added:

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- President Roosevelt has been consulting a number of Senators recently as to the situation in the Senate respecting Cuban reciprocity. Senator Clapp of Minnesota, conferred with the President on this subject this morning. Senator Spooner and others have gone over the matter fully with the President during the last few days.

Most significant among the occurrences at the session of the Presbyterian General Assembly of yesterday was the enthusiastic cheering which greeted the long-looked-for report of the Committee on Creed Revision. The report was read by the committee's Chairman, the Rev. Dr. Henry Collin Minton of San Francisco, and there was scarcely a stir in the congregation during the more than an hour occupied in its reading.

The almost incalculable influence of geographical environment on the development of man was recently referred to in these columns in a review of a new "History of the World," which is being written by a circle of German scholars. This is the point of view taken by Mr. Hogarth in "The Nearer East," which has just come to hand.

Though very modestly called by its publisher "A Catalogue of a Collection of the Books of Robert Louis Stevenson," George M. Williamson, the well-known book collector, has gathered into the pages of this little volume a quantity of remarkably interesting material. There are only 115 pages in the book, and it is privately printed.

William Travis, a convicted burglar, acted as his own lawyer in the Queens County Court yesterday when placed on trial before Judge Harrison S. Moore on an indictment charging him with having robbed the house of Dr. Lagie, at Richmond Hill, on the night of Dec. 24 last. Travis was found guilty three days ago on a charge of burglary and grand larceny.

The promptness with which we have officially and unofficially come to the rescue of the destitute survivors of Martinique has been warmly acknowledged by the French Government. It has excited the ungrudging admiration of all Europe, even of those who, like Mr. BALFOUR, have not seen their way to emulate it.

The Right Rev. Dr. Brent, the Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the Philippines, will sail for his post to-day on the North German Lloyd steamship Trave. Within the past few days Bishop Brent has received nearly $200,000 from various sources to aid him in the work of building up his diocese in Manila, and establishing churches throughou the Philippine Islands.

Mr. Edgar Stanton Maclay has put forward a new and revised edition of the third volume of his history of the navy. It was in the original edition of this volume that the SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of THE NEW YORK TIMES pointed out on the Saturday immediately following the publication of the book the severe and denunciatory terms of condemnation applied to Admiral Schley.

In addition to the amendments recommended to be made to the Confession of Faith, the Revision Committee drafted two additional chapters on "The Holy Ghost" and "Missions." A supplementary statement was also submitted in accordance with the following resolution, passed by the last General Assembly:

-- As the wreck of the Maine has been an obstruction to commerce ever since the vessel was blown up, and as the inconvenience caused by her presence has been steadily increasing through the formation of sand bars around her, there was some reason why the United States should have, or at least might have, removed the shattered hulk.

A remarkable man is W.H. Hudson, the naturalist. He was born on a sheep ranch in the Argentine, and passed his youth on plains that swarmed with wild life. It is a region where college-bred men have degenerated to the level of the Tehuclches and Puelches that once wet the sod with the blood of many a white man.

In that charming and not widely known volume called "The Prose of Edward Sill," we find a brief essay called "Books of Refuge." The writer explains his title and tells us that these books "make a man ashamed of caring too much whether he be happy or not, and present anew the high aims and better estimates of life."

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The case of Admiral Schley occupied a considerable share of the debate on the Naval Appropriation bill in the House to-day. It was brought into the discussion through some talk about the bureau system in the Navy Department. Mr. Cannon (Rep., Ill.) and Mr. Hepburn (Rep., Iowa) both criticised mercilessly the system by which a great number of officers are allowed to stay ashore doing bureau work.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- In the Philadelphia market practically everything shared in the downward movement to-day. Readings grave the most pronounced reflection of the strike situation. Reading opened here below the New York quotation and yielded further under selling of long stock.

HAVANA, May 16. -- Gov. Gen. Wood today issued an order, making all orders operative only during the military occupation of the island and concerning the subsequent effectiveness of which a question had arisen, binding upon the new Cuban Government until they shall be revoked.

One of Whittier's Loves. In a recent Issue of The Boston Evening Transcript Samuel T. Pickard writes that William Lyon Phelps, in his article in the current number of The Century Magazine, made some errors in the date of a letter mentioned in "A Noteworthy Letter of Whittier's."

LONDON, May 6. -- What share literature is to have in the honors which will be distributed at the coronation is a question which naturally attracts a great deal of interest. Thus far there are only two or three names which are confidently believed to have been selected by the King.
LONDON, May 16. -- Their Majesties third court was held at Buckingham Palace at 10 o'clock to-night.

From late cable dispatches received in this city from points in the West Indies near the scene of the volcanic eruptions, there is good reason to believe that not a few of the people at St. Pierre, Martinique, escaped. Following the message from L. Meyer on Thursday, Middleton Co. of 68 Broad Street yesterday received orders from T. Bellonnie of St. Pierre for a large supply of goods.

A vast subject, a complex one, is "Crime in its Relationship to Social Progress," as explained by Dr. Arthur Cleveland Hall, Fellow in Sociology of Columbia. In Prof. Franklin H. Giddings's introduction he writes that:

NOT all good books are likely to have many readers, and the two before us, though so written as to be eminently "readable," have that in their subject matter which will prevent their being immediately attractive to those who but read the titles at the foot of this column.

John Corbin's "An American at Oxford" is the book for which Americans anxious to know something about that ancient and venerable seat of learning have been waiting. It is so well timed that its author has been able to insert an introductory article on the possibilities of the testament of Cecil Rhodes opening the doors of the group of Oxford colleges to American students.
The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The correspondent referred to in your editorial article of Saturday last under "A Literary Fraud," is wholly mistaken.

For the large sum of u600, Thomas J. Wise, the English collector and bibliographer, has just secured a copy of Tennyson's suppressed "Lover's Tale," 1833, which is perhaps the most valuable first edition of modern English poetry. According to The Athenaeum, which reports the private sole of this important book, only one other copy is known -- the example in the Rowfant Library.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Senator and Mrs. Depew entertained this evening at the largest dinner party they have yet given, at the Corcoran House, the guests of honor being the French Ambassador and Mme. Camhon. The drawing rooms were decorated in white blossoms and the dining room in pink roses and sweet peas.

KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, May 15 (Afternoon.) -- A correspondent of The Associated Press has just returned here from a visit on horseback to the devastated district of this island, during which he traveled fifty miles and penetrated to Within five miles of the Soufriere crater. The ash-covered area of St. Vincent exceeds that of Martinique, which the correspondent has also explored.

There are many excellencies attached to the elaborate Victoria History of the Counties of England, which will form a series of 160 volumes. The first volumes, on Cumberland and Norfolk, are now before us. The scheme of the work is to trace, county by county, the development of England, which of course.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the nomination of Herbert Goldsmith Squiers of New York to be Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to the Republic of Cuba, and Edward S. Bragg of Wisconsin, Consul General at Havana.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I am much obliged to you for drawing my attention to the letter of Mr. Frederic Baron Corvo in your columns on April 5. I am, of course, the publisher referred to by Mr. Corvo, but he gives an entirely false color to the facts.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Examination of the Eastern representatives of the big Western packing houses, which was to have been begun before Justice Chester this morning, was postponed until Monday, May 26, upon motion of Attorney General Davies. He gave as his reason that his representative, E.H. Leggett, who had been directed to subpoena the needed witnesses, had been unable to locate any of theme.
MADRID, May 16. -- Glorious weather prevailed here to-day. The sun's rays poured down on the decorated streets, giving the city the gayest aspect possible.

QUEBEC, Quebec, May 17 -- The legal contest between the courts of Quebec and the Dominion courts for the possession of the two interesting prisoners, Col. Gaynor and Capt. Greene, who are wanted in Savannah for alleged frauds in connection with harbor work, and who were spirited away from this city on Thursday by Detective Carpenter of Montreal and United States Secret Service men, was transferred to this city to-day.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I noticed in your very entertaining and instructive paper of Sunday, May 4, inst., an article headed "The War Horse," from The Spectator.

Recent correspondence from Martinique and St. Vincent gives a better idea of what the volcanic destruction of a country means than could be gained from anything which had hitherto come to hand. One telegraphing from St. Vincent, says: "The whole of the Carib country, over eleven miles in length and from shore to mountainside, is covered with volcanic earth, and only the burned tops of trees are to be seen."

AMOY, China, May 1 -- It would be Interesting to know just what the Chinese think in regard to their rights in and around this port. Possibly they wonder where they stand, as does everybody else who tries to size up conditions. Japan takes in Amoy, as China Land's End for Formosan traffic, such interest, and assumes such privileges, as seem convenient.

Businesswise Wall Street has had a dull week. Sensationwise it has been active enough. Money market complications, much less present than predicted, contributed especial opportunities to the rumormongering crowd who hastened to distribute kaleidoscopic distresses -- all immediately threatening, not one fulfilled.

Perhaps the most remarkable feature of the current building movement on Manhattan Island is the unprecedented production of apartment hotels. In 1901 plans were filed for more than forty hotels of the apartment type, and hardly a week now passes without the announcement of two or three additional enterprises of the kind.
CHARLES BURRIDGE, the old-time dry goods merchant, relates an interesting story of the late Potter Palmer and A.T. Stewart.

PARIS, May 17 -- The Government did not receive any dispatches from Martinique to-day. This causes no alarm at the Ministry of the Colonies, as it is known that Gov. Lhuerre is making a series of journeys of inspection to all parts of the island, in order to ascertain the exact condition of things, and it must often happen that he is unable to return to Fort de France the same day.

THE great duty of the century is the attainment of justice between nations. In this duty the conference to be held at Lake Mohonk in the last week of May has very important business in hand. The gentlemen who meet there are well aware of this, and the eighth meeting of the conference ought to prove the most important of the series.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "S.S.B.," under the caption of "Teachers and Other People,'' in your issue of the 10th inst., understates his case.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 17 -- The Georgetown University eight-oared crew won the first 'Varsity race in the history of its institution this afternoon and moved a step forward among the rowing colleges of the country when it came in a good length ahead of the Naval Cadet crew this afternoon in a two-mile race rowed on the Severn.

HAZLETON, Penn., May 17 -- The arrival here to-night of Ralph M. Easley, Secretary of the National Civic Federation, lends color to reports which have been current for the past few days that the Civic Federation is making an effort to terminate the coal-ininers strike. Mr. Easley met President Mitchell of the United Mine Worker's, with whom he went into conference.

ROME, May 17 -- At the American College here and in other well-informed quarters it is regarded as practically certain that Bishop Charles McDonnell of Brooklyn will succeed the late Archbishop Corrigan of New York.

BOSTON, May 17 -- The latest addition to the list of notable residents at Beverly Farms this season is Levi P. Morton of New York. Mr. Morton has taken a lease of the Tweed house, on West Beach Hill, which place he will occupy this Summer with his family. The place forms a part of what was formerly the estate of Thornton K. Lothrop.

Justice O'Gorman in the Supreme Court yesterday granted a judgment ordering the American Spirits Manufacturing Company and its Directors and the Distilling Company of America, (the so-called Whisky Trust) to convey back upon the application of M.L. and C. Ernst and Frederick G. Reeves the property and assets of the American Spirits Manufacturing Company which was transferred by that company and its Directors to subsidiary companies and thence to the trust.
LONDON, May 17 -- Money was more plentiful to-day at easier rates, but there was less demand, although the immediate future is uncertain. Discounts ruled steady at unchanged rates.

LONDON, May 17 -- Brilliant audiences patronized the opera this week. Wednesday was star night, and marked Mme. Melba's first appearance. Caruso, a new tenor who appeared with Melba, met with a hearty reception.

County detectives yesterday raided two alleged policy shops, and at each place made arrests. The first place visited was in Capt. Foody's precinct, and while the detectives say that the raid was made without the knowledge of the police, the Sergeant of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station gave out a statement to the effect that the raiders from the District Attorney's office were accompanied by a policeman.

POUCHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 17 -- This afternoon the Philalethian Society of Vassar College gave a performance of Aristophanes's comedy, "The Birds," in Greek. They play was given out of doors in surroundings appropriate to the subject. The spectators were seated on the ground upon a sloping hillside, looking down upon the stage, which was set against a background of evergreen trees.

ALTHOUGH the Spring season is full upon us, so far there have been no startling novelties in men's dress. As yet few have ventured to wear Panamas or straw hats, but the very first hot day will bring them out in great numbers. There are, however, two semi-novelties which have been taken up by the coaching and Meadow Brook set.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Yesterday I visited for the first time this season the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which has received an additional charm from the new loan collection whose treasures I have many times seen in the home of William Vanderbilt.

MME. MADRAZO, the wife of Raimundo Madrazo, the artist, on a recent trip to Ardsley on the coach Pioneer, wore a simple but effective gown of covert cloth the color of yellowish linen. The close-fitting skirt was gored to fit, and had about the bottom an applied piece that extended up over the skirt proper in deep scallops.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Several pertinent questions are suggested by the recent calamities in the Lesser Antilles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer has been a constant reader of your paper for some time past, and his only regret is that your editorial department seems to be so averse to the progress of the automobile. I have read several lengthy articles which you have written on the subject, and it would seem that you are hardly treating a new subject, such as this, with due consideration.

On a renewal of the reports of the acquisition of the company by the Tobacco Trust, the stock of the Havana Commercial Company during the past week enjoyed an advance which brought it very considerably above any prices recently quoted for this stock. Later sharp reactions in the quotations occurred, but at the close of the week both issues, nevertheless, showed a substantial rise.

The accession of the young King of Spain is an event which has been watched with sympathetic interest all over the world, and nowhere with more than in these United States. From one point of view his position is most pathetic. From the empire of PHILIP II., on which the sun never set, there has been going on a continual shrinkage.

Staten Islanders, hundreds of forecastle sailors who run into the Port of New York, many other persons associated with the merchant marine, and representatives of the United States Marine Hospital Service at this port are deeply interested in the fate of the amendment to the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill, which provides for the purchase by the Government of the marine hospital situated at Stapleton, on Staten Island.

NEWPORT, May 17 -- The middle of May finds the early season at Newport well started with more than the usual number of Summer residents in their cottages and more coming every day. Already there are seen on Bellevue Avnue many familiar faces of the Pummer visitors, and everywhere there is a hurry and bustle to complete the preparations of the houses and the grounds for opening of more houses.

Nothing could be more cordial and more characteristic than the German Emperor's offer to the United States of a statue of FREDERICK the Great, on the one hand, nor than the President's reply to it, on the other. The psychological likeness between the two men has often been noted.

FEW persons think of New York as a factory town, but recent statistics show that in the extent and variety of its manufacture of highly finished articles and luxuries there is no city in the world which can compete with it. Others may excel in particular respects, but in the aggregate New York is supreme.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- In the absence of Speaker Henderson at the Rosecrans exercices at Arlington, Mr. Dalzell (Penn.) to-day acted as Speaker of the House. Consideration of the Naval bill was resumed.

To The Editor of The New York Times: When in search of "All the News That's Fit to Print" I never fail to peruse the columns of THE TIMES most carefully. In your issue of the 12th inst. I read with considerable interest a letter written by " An American," and entitled "Great Britain and the Boers."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice in a recent issue an item stating that a member of a jury criticised the other day what he supposed was an error in the conduct of the trial by the Judge, and your paper gave us in detail an account of the evident disgust with which this criticism was received by the Judge.
KINGSTOWN, Island of St. Vincent, May 17 -- In the absence of symptoms of further eruptions of the volcano La Soufriere, the inhabitants of St. Vincent are gradually becoming settled.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 17 -- Philadelphia and New York met to-day in golf team competition on the links of the Huntington Valley Country Club at Rydal, and the honors remained with the home team by a total score of 27 holes to 16, the winners leading by 11 holes. The meeting was the fifth of the two golf associations, and it is the first time that the Quaker golfers have come off victorious.

"Fe-fi-fo-fum, I smell the blood of an Englishmun." THEN there follows in that ancient child's rhyme the threat of the converting of the bones of the Englishman into some farinaceous compound. Now old Dry-as-Dust, who is both learned and prolix, might insist that there were several important ideas conveyed in those rhymes.

WEST POINT, N. T., May 17 -- The Annapolis baseball team defeated West Point this afternoon by a score of 5 to 3. West Point expected to repeat last year's performance, and send the navy home like wrecked mariners, but Annapolis has a clever team this year, as the result to-day plainly showed.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- With imposing ceremonies, the remains of Major Gen. William Starke Rosecrans to-day were reinterred in Arlington Cemetery, under the direction of the Society of the Army of the Cumberland. The services were presided over by Speaker Henderson. President Roosevelt, members of his Cabinet, Senators and Representatives, and a host of friends, including many of his old army associates, were present.

In the year 1900 there appear to have been 11,808 English soldiers committed to military prisons at home and abroad. Very nearly half of this total number, or 5,227 in all, had been guilty of offenses held to be such by the civil law. Thus "disgraceful conduct" is the soldier's designation for thefts and frauds, and the whole range at wrongdoing, included in breaches of the obligation to serve.

BOSTON, May 17 -- Luders and Pixley's new musical show "Prince of Pilsen," which is to make its debut at the Tremont Theatre next Tuesday evening, was given a trial performance at the Maiden Auditorium to-night before a large and delighted audience.

"King Lear" and "King Dodo." By a beautiful provision of nature the dramatic season flowers in the Autumn, just as the trees in Madison Square are losing their leaves; and now that the gardener is setting out his hyacinths and daffodils, it is falling into the sere, the yellow leaf.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The approaching erection of a monument to the memory of General Count de Rochambeau for his services at the battle of Yorktown is certainly most creditable. It recalls to me an incident that would seem to be a matter of some historical interest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After reading your editorial in THE TIMES for May 14, entitled "One Touch of Nature," it seemed to me that a little further exposition of the constitutional question involved in the appropriation by Congress for the relief of the victims of the Martinique disaster would be desirable at this time.

BOSTON, May 17 -- A letter from President Roosevelt, in which the Chief Executive declares his determination to discover and punish every instance of barbarity by United States troops in the Philippines has been made public by Bishop William Lawrence of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts.

The so-called Fuller syndicate, which represents the Gould, Taylor, Landstreet, Herrick, Delano, Fuller, and other millions, is to have the City of Baltimore interest in the Western Maryland Railroad -- a controlling interest. It was stated when this party of capitalists first made a bid for the property: "The undersigned represent the purchasers of the West Virginia Central and Pittsburg Railway Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice several letters published in your issue of yesterday concerning Gen. Smith. To say that they all refer to him in uncomplimentary terms expresses the nature of their criticism very mildly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The office of Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of New York, vacant now by the demise of Archbishop Corrigan, is one of large importance, not only to the clergy and laity within that Archdiocese, but to Roman Catholics generally throughout the country.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 17 -- Mrs. Patrick Campbell bade adieu to the American stage to-night at the Alvin until next August, when she will enter on another engagement in New York and will tour the principal cities. Speaking of her experience here, she said:
The Boston Marine Society has by formal vote approved the plan to pension life saving crews on the same basis as soldiers are now paid.

LONG BRANCH, May 17 -- The outdoor sports that are being arranged by the South Shrewsbury Ice Yacht and Boat Club for Memorial Day are expected to attract a large crowd. The Regatta Committee has outlined the different events as follows: Swimming and tub races, weather permitting; rowing and sailing races, 100-yard dash, potato race, sack race, and bicycle race.

Some very plain things on the subject of taking care of disabled and superannuated ministers were said to the Presbyterian General Assembly at its session at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday morning. The church was severely blamed for its alleged neglect of this matter. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Parry of Pittsburgrg, at the climax of his address on the subject, exclaimed at the top of his voice:

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 17 -- The week at Tuxedo was rather dull until Saturday and Sunday, the time being passed by the cottagers getting their cottages in order. Those who arrived the week previous entertained numerous guests. Among the entertainers were Mrs. John Nicholas Brown, who entertained her sister, Mrs. George Vanderbilt, in the Bruce Price cottage, where numerous friends were invited to meet her.

At Earl Hall yesterday afternoon President Butler of Columbia College delivered to Pendieton Dudley, President of the Philolexian Debating Society, which was celebrating its one hundredth anniversary, the "mysterious package," the dowry of the Philolexians who met on the semi-centennial anniversary of the birth of the organization on May 17, 1852.

LONDON, May 2 -- Charles Hawtrey now knows that even the most popular actor of the hour cannot afford to trifle with his audiences. The warmth and vigor of his reception when he made his first appearance since his American engagement could not have been excelled, but his audience resented his production of a play, or stage entertainment, which seemed expressly designed to fool them.
Stock market traducers, rarely at a loss for an "argument," have had the experience lately of finding that most of their efforts have fallen on unheeding hearers.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Second Lieut. Thomas J. Rogers is assigned to the Twenty-eighth Infantry. Lieut. Rogers will report to the commanding officer Fort Sheridan for temporary duty, and upon the completion thereof will join his regiment in the Philippines.
OFFICIAL representatives of relief societies, who spend their time among the poorest class of the foreign population of the city, note some interesting characteristics of the different races.

The kosher meat riots which started on Thursday night in Manhattan, were taken up in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn last night, resulting in several butchers' shops being attacked. The attack was made along Seigel Street, and half a dozen stores had show windows broken and the proprietors were compelled to close their doors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A few additions to my last letter reciting the troublous time I have in securing a seat in the trolley cars at the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge may prove of some interest. Having related my experience in trying to identify one of our guardians of the peace it may not be amiss to give two or three incidents which have happened to me since.

MADRID, May 17 -- The splendid ceremonies in connection with the attaining of his majority by King Alfonso to-day were attended by an incident which, while insignificant in itself, for the moment created considerable excitement among those who witnessed it, and in the Chamber of Deputies, where the story first arrived in a more sensational form than the facts warranted.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- In the House to-day Mr. Mudd (Md.) offered his amendment to exclude from the Naval Academy and from ships and Government libraries the history of Edgar Stanton Maclay.

THERE is a black sheep in the flock grazng in the rich pastures of Central Park. The children call him "Black Beauty." He was among the first of the newcomers of the early Spring. His coming caused a sensation among the sleepy-eyed flock.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- "The Sabbath of the Jews is dead. Let us bury it. God never ordained the Sabbath day. It is an institution of man. Only millionaires and peddlers can observe the Jewish Sabbath in these days of activity. Sunday to all intents and purposes already has become our day of rest.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- The Philadelphia market to-day was dull. Under the depressing influence of the decline in the Readings the other stocks in which there was any activity snowed pronounced heaviness, and the final prices were the lowest of the week. Lehigh Navigation and Lehigh Valley were rather freely offered, and the former at one time fell off 1 1/2.

Very little interest was taken in the trading in the outside market yesterday. In no part of the list did the transactions assume large proportions, except in General Carriage, which sold down on the announcement of the plan for the reorganization of the company. Prices were somewhat steadier than on Friday, and one or two of the stocks which had suffered sharp declines recovered part or their losses.

The Rome correspondent of The Baltimore Sun would be ill-advised if he visited the Monumental City just now, for, on the authority of Mr. HENRY WALTERS, he has interrupted the bargain which the latter was making with Don MARCELLO MASSARANTI, the owner of the great collection of old paintings and sculptures at the Vatican.

BANGOR, May 17 -- Admiral Schley will deliver the Memorial Day address in Bangor on May 30, and has also been invited by the City Council to raise the flag over Chapin Park on May 29. Preparations are being made for his reception. The veteran soldiers and sailors from the neighborhood will come to hear him or to march in the procession.

With the near approach of the end of the season of active theatrical production revivals appear to be in order, and this week will see several familiar old plays presented for the edification of younger playgoers and the reminder of days that are past to those who remember past history of the New York stage.

With the season of large speculative purchases rapidly drawing to a close, the continuance of so large a volume of miscellaneous business as was shown in last week's reports is perhaps better evidence than has yet been afforded of the substantial character of recent market activity.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- Announcement was made at the offices of the Pennsylvania Railroad here to-day that the railroad company had given notice to the Western Union Telegraph Company that the present agreements under which the latter operates lines over the right of way of the railroad would terminate at the end of six months from June 1, 1902.

Columbia University's lawn tennis team, led by their Captain, Lyle E. Mahan, invaded the courts of the New York University yesterday and defeated the latter's team in most impressive style. The competition was the first of a long series of intercollegiate team matches which the Columbia players have arranged.

THERE is a large and growing interest in the proposition that the United States should adopt a National flower -- one which should be to Americans what the rose is to the English and the iris to the French.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your columns are always arrayed on the side of good government, and I hasten to correct your misapprehension as to the attitude of the Merchants' Association in the matter of the projected engagement of Mr. Freeman's services for the Water Department of the city.

PEKING, May 17 -- An important question has arisen between China and the powers interested concerning the payment of the Chinese indemnity. China claims that the protocol stipulates that payment should be made of 450,000,000 taels in silver, regardless of the rate of exchange. The construction put upon the protocol by the foreign Ministers is that China shall pay in gold or in silver the equivalent of gold at the time of payment.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- President Roosevelt met by appointment at the White House to-day George T. Oliver, William McConway, and A. J. Barr, a committee from Pittsburg, accompanied by Attorney General P. C. Knox, to invite him to visit that city July 4 and make an address to the citizens.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 17 -- The proposed making or buying of a public road across the meadows is once more under discussion, and it looks as though at last something would really be done. Automobilists have much to do with stirring up the subject. The only road by which a person can at present get into or out of the city is a toll road, and this may be purchased outright by the county.

SOMEWHAT extraordinary as it may seem, there is reason to believe, from recent developments in practical science, that the mosquito has had his day. The mosquito's doom was sealed, theoretically, when the famous experiments upon the Roman Campagna proved conclusively that under certain circumstances this flying torment was deathdealing.

John P. Carroll was at the Democratic Club last night, greeting all comers with a smile. Mr. Carroll did not care to talk for publication, but his lieutenants freely predicted that ex-Mayor Van Wyck would certainly be elected Grand Sachem of Tammany Hall at the meeting of the Sachems to-morrow night.

LONDON, May 2 -- London will be ablaze the night of Coronation Day. Already many building's in the centre of the metropolis have patriotic legends and decorative devices outlined in gas piping on their front walls, which will blossom forth in fire when the great occasion arrives. Flaming crowns of varicolored electric lights, and the royal arms with lion and unicorn, will burn brilliantly over many doorways.

There is little excuse for most of the weakness of mankind. It isn't natural to be weak. If you are weak, if you are pale and thin or if your blood is poor it is because you haven't used Johann Hoff's Extract. Johann Hoff's Extract is the perfect up-builder of strength. It is nature's own remedy, giving perfect digestion and assimilation of food without which no one can be well and vigorous.

We print on another page a careful and full account of the services rendered by the Kingdom of France to the American colonists in the War of the American Revolution. It is plain enough that the aid which France then gave us was, upon the part of the French Government, given as matter of national policy, given to aggrandize France by weakening England.

HAVANA, May 17 -- None of the Havana papers this morning comments on the composition of President-elect Palma's Cabinet. This does not mean disapproval. It is rather attributable to the Spanish "manana" spirit. It can be said, however, that the selections have made a good impression, especially among the better class of Cubans and the Spanish element.
LORD KELVIN was talking with a young woman at the Waldorf-Astoria last week when she surprised him by asking:

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A cable message from Commander T. S. McLean of the Cincinnati to Secretary Moody, dated at St. Lucia to-day, says that the Potomac reports the situation at St. Vincent very serious. Commander McLean says he thinks the situation there as bad as in Martinique the situation there as bad as in Martinique or worse.

The end of the season in town has come. There has been during the week a general flitting to country places, and before a fortnight is over Fifth Avenue will have assumed its customary Summer appearance. It is, however, nearly two months before the regular Summer watering place season will begin, and in the meantime those who have left town and have closed their town houses will not be far away.

For a number of years up to and including 1894 the railroads of Massachusetts derived a larger revenue from their passenger than from their freight service, a condition peculiar to railroad operation in parts of New England territory, and largely to that in the State named, results for the section at large showing a trifling advantage the other way.

MR. CARNEGIE is of the opinion that freight earnings, dividends, and patriotism are quite separate and distinct things. Yet patriotism had a good deal to do with producing the splendid specimens of marine architecture known as the American packet and clipper ships that Dominated the passenger and carrying trade between Europe and America and China prior to the war of 1860.
BERLIN, May 17 -- Emperor William's Court Marshal has telegraphed to the correspondent of The Associated Press here as follows:

The Comte de Rochambeau and several members of the Rochambeau mission, who are to take part in the ceremonies connected with the unveiling of the Rochambeau statue next week in Washington, arrived here yesterday on the French liner La Touraine.

NOT many years ago the man whose sympathies led him to become a member of the Audubon Society stood in considerable danger of being classified by his more "hard-headed" neighbors as a crank. A love of nature connoted a certain "softness" from which the average man felt, vaguely, that he should protect himself.

PATERSON, N. J., May 17 -- All silk dyers, helpers, and finishers have been called out by their organization, and, as a consequence, all work of the kind performed by them ceased for an indefinite period at 4 o'clock this afternoon, the union having given the men until this time to finish their jobs and get all silk out of possible damage.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In the supplement to last Sunday's TIMES you published an article about West Point and the celebration of its centennial in June.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among the contributions of wit and humor collected under the head of "The Man in the Street," in last Sunday's issue of THE TIMES, I read one story attributed to Mr. John Uri Lloyd of Cincinnati, in which he is made to say: "There is one thing that you have in New York that we don't know in the West.

LONDON, May 17 -- While every capital in Europe is eagerly awaiting the result of the Boer Peace Conference at Vereeniging, Transvaal, London watches it with apparent indifference. This feeling not only extends to the public, who to-day are pouring out of the metropolis, bent on celebrating the Whitsuntide Bank holidays, but also to the King and the Cabinet Ministers.

The players of the Buffalo baseball club of the Eastern League protested a decision of Umpire Rinn in the second inning of their game with the Jersey City team yesterday, and in consequence two of them, Catcher Shaw and First Baseman Law were put out of the game. Donahoe sent a high fly toward Tight field and the baL seemed to fall foul of the line.

Max Singer of 19 Tompkins Avenue, Brooklyn, was painfully injured last night by a horse he was driving, which became frightened by a galolene automobile. Singer was driving along Leonard Street, and when he reached Moore Street the automobile came along and frightened the horse, which began to plunge, nearly upsetting the carriage, and then ran away.

Public-spirited citizens, notably the members of the West Side Association, are displaying a good deal of intelligent interest in assisting the municipal authorities in the selection of a satisfactory type of sign to guide the wayfarer in finding himself. Along upper Broadway, from Sixty-sixth to Seventy-second Street, sporadic cases of street indexing may be discovered and are easily recognized as local outbreaks of enterprise in the propaganda of favorite devices.

Automobiling through sewers is the very latest thing, and to Brooklyn, which is supposed to look with scorn upon anything so unconventional, belongs the honor of the innovation. It was not a bid for notoriety on the part of some rash automobilist, for Mayor Low, accompanied by Controller Grout, Borough Presidents Cantor, Swanstrom, and Cassidy, and several heads of departments, set the seal of his official approval on the novelty by making the first trip.

ALBANY, May 17 -- On the third-of-a-mile track at Albany yesterday the athletes of Cornell romped away with a victory in their annual meat with Princeton. The final score of 77 points to 40 was better than even the most sanguine Cornelllan expected, and the performance of their men yesterday makes the Ithaeans confident of making an unusually good showing in the approaching intercollegiate meet.

The suggestion that in some way or other the bituminous miners might be induced to break their contracts with the bituminous operators and join with the anthracite workers in a general coal strike was responsible for much of the liquidation which appeared in the early part of yesterday's stock market, sending prices off quite generally.
WITH the blotting out of great stretches of the picturesque wild West by Civilization's patchwork coverlid of farms has come about the present scarcity of beef.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 17 -- John Doneto, an Italian forty-five years old, was murdered here to-night by an unknown man. He was stabbed six times in the head and cek, and any one of the wounds would have proven fatal.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 17 -- An effort by officers of the law to arrest negro outlaws, who had barricaded themselves in a store, resulted to-day in the most fatal riot in the history of the city. Eight men were killed, including three policemen, a white citizen, and four negroes. Six people, black and white, were wounded.

The National League baseball teams got in a full day yesterday, and the favorable weather which seemed to prevail in all centres where the game is in vogue, allowed numerous contests to go to a fun issue without provoking disappointments occasioned by climatic conditions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 17 -- Yale fought harder to-day for a baseball victory than she has in many days, but the Blue finally triumphed over the Orange A. C. team after thirteen innings. The last six innings were without scores until Cole's line two-base hit in the thirteenth inning, which won the game.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice an article, "A Plea for Clean Streets," in your columns to-day, wherein the writer says: "I know very little about politics, and care less, but I do know it has not much to do with cleanliness," I assert that the writer, Mr. L.B. Starr, is not a very competent citizen to criticise a city department after such a confession in print.

With the coronation of King Edward VII. so near at hand interest in the ceremonies which will attend that great event increases. The coronation may, indeed, be said to possess the quality of complete novelty since few persons now living remember the time when an English monarch was crowned before, Queen Victoria having reigned for considerably over half a century.

TT is odd the temerity with which men step into the discussions of domestic affairs where angels fear to tread. If women should pretend to get up every now and then upon the lecture platform and discuss the proper conduct of affairs in Wall Street and the way the man of to-day should run his business office, there would be a pretty state of affairs.

Authorities on Catholic procedure say that it will be six months before the appointment of a successor to Archbishop Corrigan is announced by the Vatican. The first step toward the selection of a new Archbishop for the archdiocese or New York will be taken this week, when the irremovable rectors will meet to declare their choice.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reading your editorial of the 15th of May on the subject of the proposed automobile speedway on Long Island, I was impressed with two facts. First, that the article had been written by a thoughtless and misinformed person, and second, that THE TIMES was treating a method of locomotion which is more than a plaything of the rich in a way generally attributed to "yellow journalism."

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 17 -- The music festival came to an end to-day. The day was wholly given up to music. For three hours this afternoon the public listened to a miscellaneous concert in which the chorus did not figure, and this evening for two hours and a half it attended again at another concert, of which the chorus was one of the principal features.
Messrs. Hambleton Co., the Baltimore bankers, philosophize in this fashion apropos of local railway developments:

BOSTON, May 17 -- The week closes with the money market in a somewhat improved position, with demand light and rates showing a tendency to ease off slightly. Clearing House rate, 5 per cent; New York funds, par; call loans, 5 to 6; time money, 4 1/2 to 5 1/2 per cent; Clearing House exchanges, $22,651,082; balances, $1,330,391.

Pennsylvania's athletes triumphed in a most decisive manner over the representatives of Columbia in a dual track meet between these two universities at Columbia Oval yesterday. Eight track and five field events were on the programme for decision, and of these Columbia only scored first in three and divided the honors in one.
A LETTER from Kalamazoo, Mich., came to my friend Silas Larrabee this morning.

HAVANA, May 11 -- This has been a gala day in Havana, one which will long be remembered, for there entered into the city the man who is to be the first President of the Republic of Cuba -- Tomas Estrada Palma. To say that the Cubans are wild with joy would but mildly express the feelings of a people who, in fancy, see themselves one of the great powers of the Western World.

LONDON, May 17 -- The financial week has been made reasonably lively by widespread but generally unconfirmable rumors and some interesting theorizing. The idea that the increased tightness of the money market has been caused by the large increase in the account "for the rise" in American securities because money conditions in New York had been unfavorable is quite generally accepted in the City.

NEW HAVEN, May 17 -- Worcester Academy won the first annual interscholastic meet held under the auspices of the Yale Track Athletic Association to-day by scoring 28 1-3 points. Andover scored 28 points and was second. All the events furnished good contests.

LONDON, May 17 -- J. Pierpont Morgan paid a few days' quiet visit to London this week, and has now returned to Paris. While here he had several conferences with the leaders of the shipping combine. The Associated Press is officially informed that matters are progressing quite satisfactorily, though no new developments can be recorded.

FORT DE FRANCE, Island of Martinique, May 17 -- United States Consul Ayme, Commander Thomas C. McLean, Lieut. Commander J.C. Gilmore, and other officers of the United States cruiser Cincinnati, with a guide, searched the St. Pierre ruins yesterday for the body of United States Consul Thomas T. Prentis.

While civic bodies in this and other large cities are bending their energies in furnishing funds to relieve distress in Martinique and St. Vincent, there was much comment yesterday on a published statement from a newspaper correspondent at Fort de France who declared in the most positive terms that the relief was being greatly overdone, and that there was grave danger that the people of the stricken islands would be pauperized.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- The baseball game between St. Louis and Chicago to-day was one of the most sensational on record, ending in a tie at 2 runs each after seventeen innings of brilliant playing. The champions scored twice on two hits and an excusable error. The visitors made their runs by bunched hitting.

The Kosher beef rioters of the east side, and, in fact, all over the city, took a day off yesterday to rest from their strenuous labors of the past week, though one large meeting was held. Consequently the sections which had been marked with disorder were quiet and free from disturbances. The fact that all the butcher shops were closed induced not a little to this tranquil condition of affairs.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I have read with considerable interest the accounts in THE TIMES of the Cincinnati Musical Festival by your always able and interesting Mr. W.J. Henderson, and this interest has been the more warm and gratifying on account of his frequent and favorable references to Mr. J. Fred Wolle of Bethlehem, Penn.

Mr. HORACE WHITE of The Evening Post delivered an address last week at Kansas City before the joint convention of the Bankers' Associations of Missouri, Kansas, Oklahoma, and the Indian Territory. His subject was "Branch Banking," with incidental allusion to asset notes.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- The coal market here has become tight and retailers are declining to fill orders except for regular customers, who are restricted to limited quantities. A rough estimate puts the supply of anthracite here at 70,000 tons. Some dealers have considerable stocks of soft coal.

LONDON, May 19. -- Whatever may be its issue, says the correspondent of The Times at Pretoria, the Boer conference at Vereeniging will be a notable feature of the history of the war. It is a unique experience for every burgher delegate. some 160 delegates are present and nearly all of them are prominent Boers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is to be regretted that the great strike has at last been declared, which will be disastrous not only to the interests of the miners, but also a blow to the present remarkable prosperity all over the country in all branches of industry. The effect of the strike will be felt keenly by the thousands of railroad men who are employed by the coal-carrying companies.

The election of Mr. JAMES BRENTON as Mayor of Des Moines, the capital city of Iowa, is significant of a popular demand for a good man weighing 315 pounds, and also of something more. It means that the finish of the political orator is in sight.

The twenty-eighth annual meeting and election of officers of the Young Men's Hebrew Association was held yesterday afternoon at the association building, Ninety-second Stret and Lexington Avenue. Addresses were made by Justice Samuel Greenbaum, Jacob H. Schiff, Isidor Straus, and Justice Julius M. Mayer.

PHOENIX, Arizona, May 18. -- After a long and bitter struggle in the Mexican courts and on the Mexican plains Gen. Charles P. Eagan, ex-Commissary General of the United States Army, has won possession and clear title to 2,500,000 acres of mining land in Western Mexico. The property is large enough and rich enough to make a European kingdom.
At West New York Field yesterday the Buffalo Eastern League baseball team defeated the Jersey City nine in a twelve-inning game by a score of six runs to four.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., May 18. -- With the impressive ceremony which characterizes important functions in the Roman Catholic Church. Bishop W.J. Kenny was consecrated in the old cathedral this morning, Cardinal Gibbons officiating.

Graves of Revolutionary heroes who are buried in Trinity Churchyard wore decorated yesterday afternoon by the New York City Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution. The chapter flower is the Easier lily, and decorations were placed on the graves of Capt. James Lawrence, Alexander Hamilton, Commodore James Nicholson, Capt. Benjamin Parkes, the Rev. John Peter Tetard, Lord Sterling. Gen. Matthew Clarkson. Capt. Michael Cresap, and Col. Marinus Willetts.

Fire was discovered at 1:30 o'clock this morning in the six-story building at 49 and 51 Chrystie Street. The blaze started in a stable on the ground floor and spread rapidly through to the front and up to the floors above. The upper floors are all occupied as sweatshops.

Preaching on the theme "Providence and Biblical and Recent Catastrophes," the Rev. Dr. J.B. Remensnyder, pastor of St. James's Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, in his sermon last night spoke, in part, as follows:

It is the opinion of some of the best observers from the inside that there has never been in Tammany since the days of the downfall of TWEED so large a proportion of discontent, disgust, resentment, and discouragement as at the present moment. Some of this feeling is to be traced to the inevitable disintegrating tendencies of defeat and poverty.
BERLIN, May 18. -- Emperor William's purpose of giving a statue of Frederick the Great to the United States was seemingly quite suddenly formed.

Pleasure rowing suddenly became popular on the Harlem River yesterday, and although the racing crews practiced as usual, they were outnumbered by the fleat of barges, gigs, and passenger boats, which crowded the river from morning until night. The clubhouse piazzas and balconies were crowded with spectators, while the docks and bridges were fringed with onlookers.
MADRID, May 18. -- An Anarchist plot against King Alfonso has been discovered, and five arrests nave been made.

HAVANA, May 18. -- The festivities in celebration of the change of Government became general all over the island to-day. In almost every town and village an elaborate programme of popular rejoicing has been arranged. Sunday here, as in all Spanish countries, is not given over to religious observances, but is distinctly a holiday devoted to recreation and amusement.

Under orders from E.E. Smathers, the owner, the harness racing stable trained by the noted trotting horseman, George W. Spears, and now at Memphis, Tenn., will break Winter quarters early this week, and is expected to reach New York within a few days, to resume training at the Empire City track.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It Is to be regretted that "S.S.B." has no argument to sustain his statements in regard to the teachers' "snap." He requests that "parallel cases" be taken "for comparison," and then compares "commercial office workers" with teachers! Truly, an admirable comparison!

The most sensational incident of a day full of surprises and fast and hard-fought brushes on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday, and one that made road drivers blink in astonishment, was when, in one of the prettiest tilts of the day, the undersized green trotting mare Little Helen carried the great Cobwebs off his feet.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 18. -- New Vernon, three miles from this city, was the scene of a lively fracas last night, in which a man supposed to be insane and further inflamed by drink, after efforts to kill several persons with an axe, was shot with No. 8 shot, from 60 to 100 of the pellets entering his abdomen and chest.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The entire time of the Senate for the present week will be devoted to the consideration of the Philippines Government bill, and there is no reason for changing previous predictions that the debate upon that measure will be practically completed before the close of the week.

Lying at the German-American Stores, at Van Brunt Street, Brooklyn, is the British steamship Etona, which arrived yesterday morning. The Etona is just from the West Indies, the first vessel to reach New York with marks upon her made by the eruption of Mont Pelee. She has lava dust on her masts, and her decks are stained from the effects of the eruption in such a way that scrubbing has not cleansed them.

CINCINNATI, May 18. -- The Cincinnati baseball players took kindly to Kennedy's curves in the fifth inning of to-day's game, and by making seven clean singles scored six runs. Evans fared no better in the sixth inning. Ewing was very Steady and effective throughout. The fielding on both sides was sharp.

MADRID, May 18. -- During the ceremonies yesterday attendant upon the accession of King Alfonso, the Queen Mother was seen several times to wipe the tears from her eyes when the King received the ovations of the people.

MANILA, May 18. -- The coronation of King Alfonso was celebrated with much ceremony yesterday by all the Spanish residents of Manila. Acting Civil Governor Wright represented the United States Government at the principal function.
Ex-Controller Andrew H. Green has sent out the following correspondence between himself and Controller Grout respecting the Rapid Transit Commission:

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- It begins to look as though the Administration Senators may be forced to accept the plan of helping Cuba by granting rebates on all duties collected in this country on Cuban products. There is no sign of a break in the ranks of the beet sugar Senators; no indication whatever that they will yield to the demand of the Administration for a reciprocity arrangement with the Cubans.
The pulpits of about every Presbyterian Church in the city yesterday were occupied by members of the General Assembly, which is holding its sessions here.

We published in yesterday's issue a letter, one of a number we have received, with reference to an article in a recent issue on the information which travelers would gladly avail themselves of if it were offered in a convenient form and at a convenient time. We have also received from several railroad companies specimens of their publications intended to meet the want to which we have referred.

HAZLETON, Penn., May 18. -- The visit of Ralph M. Easley, Secretary of the National Civic Federation, to strike headquarters and his conference with President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers late last night were the only incidents of any importance that claimed the attention to-day of the labor leaders and others around the Valley Hotel.

The views of English newspapers on the subject of the business conditions existing in this country and the value of American investments are always interesting and sometimes instructive. More often, however, they are interesting without being instructive. In this classification belongs the article in The London Financier and Bullionist, which warns the credulous British investor against recklessness in the purchase of American securities, as follows:

CHICAGO, May 18. -- Sitting all night on a bench in Lincoln Park was the alternative which presented itself to the mind of Mrs. A.J.G. Mueller to-night, when she found herself penniless and without friends. She began the execution of her plan, with her two boys for company, and stuck bravely to it even after it began to rain.

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, May 18. -- Acting Governor L'Huerre and the other insular authorities and the committee of doctors who embarked on board the French cruiser Suchet proceeded on that ship to St. Pierre in order to determine whether there was danger in permitting the examination of the ruins of that town to continue, inasmuch as a large number of the corpses buried there are in a state of putrefaction.

The stcamship Horace of the Lamport Holt Line arrived at this port yesterday from Brazil and St. Lucia, and those on board of her related experiences they had had in connection with the volcanic eruptions in the West Indies. On the 8th inst., when 100 miles away from Mont Pelee, the Horace encountered the first of the volcanic phenomena.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 18. -- The Rev. Dr. Erskine M. Rodman, for thirty-two years rector of Grace Episcopal Church, announced his resignation at the confirmation service, which was attended by Bishop Scarborough, this morning. He has been made rector emeritus at a salary of $3,000.

In a market that is likely to be dominated, as is this week's, by whatever coal strike developments there may be, it would seem to be of little profit to discuss other and more or less incidental matters. Nevertheless, there is one phase of the present market that it may be well not to lose sight of, even though greatest attention be given the strike issue.

The cornerstone of the new Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Lourdes, on One Hundred and Forty-second Street, between Amsterdam and Convent Avenues, the site of the old Hamilton homestead, was laid yesterday by Vicar General Mooney. Seven thousand persons were present at the ceremony.

NEW HAVEN, May 18. -- The first of the commencements at Yale began this evening when the annual baccalaureate address to the Divinity School graduating class was delivered by the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman of New York in Centre Church. The formal commencement exercises will take place on Wednesday morning in Battell Chapel.

QUESTION AS TO BREACH OF IMPLIED WARRANTY. -- A certain manufacturing company in this city, in selling an engine to the Van Publishing Company for $1,727,45, represented, so the latter claimed, that the cost of running it to produce electrical power for the purchaser's printing plant would be less than the cost of such electricity if furnished from the street lines.

Ping pong is rampant at the Columbia University Club, 41 West Thirty-sixth Street, as a lively tournament has been started to decide the championship of the organization, and also the team of five players who will represent Columbia in the intercollege club tournament. Late last night the first round had nearly been completed, with half of the twenty-two men entered dropping from the lists because of defeat.

Amateur pool experts representing the most exclusive clubs of the metropolis are preparing to engage in a tournament for the championship of the New York clubs. It is the first time that such an interclub competition has been proposed, and the magnitude of the undertaking may be partly understood from the fact that twenty-one organizations will enter teams composed of their four best players.

MONTREAL, Quebec, May 19. -- The legal battle over Gaynor and Greene has entered another stage, and the prisoners are now speeding toward Quebec, in charge of High Constable Gale and ten provincial policemen.

The will of Archbishop Corrigan wag filed for probate in the office of the Surrogate yesterday. It was, as Vicar General Mooney explained, merely the formal will to make possible the legal transfer of whatever property there was in trust in the Archbishop's name to the corporation.

Though transactions were not large -- the day's total approximating 600,000 shares -- yesterday's security market was weak throughout the day, with a small rally at the close. No very great declines were scored, but the recessions extended throughout most of the list, few quotations failing to shrink.

Comte de Rochambeau and many of the members of his party, who came from France to attend the unvelling of the Rochambeau statue in Washington, were the guests last night of Cornelius N. Bliss President of the Union League Club at a dinner at the clubhouse. The meal was served in what is known as the Alcove Room on the third floor.

Letters of historical importance, written during the rebellion by Abraham Lincoln, Gen. Grant, Jefferson Davis, Gen. Shernan, and others, from the collection belonging to Gen. Adam Badeau, were sold at auction last evening by John Anderson, Jr., at 20 West Thirtieth Street.

A festival given last night by the Society of St. Mary, an adjunct of the Italian Church of Our Lady of Loretto, was broken up by an accident which injured several persons and may cause the death of two men.

The dead-lock in the Tammany Society over the election of Grand Sachem was broken last evening. Supreme Court Justice James A. O'Gorman was elected Grand Sachem, and ex-Mayor Robert A. Van Wyck and Thomas Feitner were defeated in their aspirations to hold this office in the Columbian Order.

The Executive Committee of the Associated Committees for the Relief of Sufferers in the West Indies unanimously decided at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday to continue the collection of subscriptions.

The stockholders of the United States Steel corporation at a special meeting held in Hoboken yesterday ratified the proposal of the Board of Directors, the Executive Committee, and the Finance Committee to convert $200,000,000 of the 7 per cent. preferred stock into 5 per cent. bonds and to issue $50,000,000 additional bonds for cash.

John C. Atterbury, a broker with offices at 52 Broadway, and residing at West New Brighton, S.I., met a tragic death yesterday morning in New York Harbor as a result of the ramming of the Staten Island ferryboat Middletown by Edwin Gould's steam yacht Aileen.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has; as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

The town was quite deserted over Sunday, as there were many people who went to the resorts for the purpose of making arrangements for the Summer and opening their villas. In town yesterday there were several small entertainments and the concert for the benefit of the church-building fund at Chatsworth. In the evening Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane gave a dinner in honor of Miss Lila Sloane and William B. Osgood Field.
