WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 19. -- Francis M. Carpenter, County Treasurer of Westchester County, to-day filed his report as transfer tax appraiser in the estate of Robert B. Hopkins, late of Tarrytown. Mr. Hopkins, who belonged to the Standard Oil Company, died a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The Naval Appropriation bill was passed this afternoon after a combination of Democrats and Republican insurgents had succeeded in unending it so as to provide for the buildup, of a ship of each class in Government lavy yards instead of at private plants. This was effected after a long and determined fight.

Clinging to a car gate of a Second Avenue elevated train bound up town, his right leg fractured and the flesh between the hip and knee badly lacerated, James H. Burns, a clerk residing at 68 Monroe Street, Roxbury, a suburb of Boston, was dragged from the Thirty-fourth Street station to that at Forty-second Street shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- In the Senate to-day consideration was resumed of the Philippine Government bill, Mr. Dolliver (Iowa) addressing the Senate in support of the measure. He said the pending bill presented the most important constructive work since the civil war. And yet, he said, he was disappointed that not a single helpful suggestion had been made by the minority.

Reports of increasing activity in tennis are received from every quarter. At the Orange (N.J.) Lawn Tennis Club a substantial testimony to the interest in the game was afforded by the building of a new women's clubhouse on the western end of the grounds, which is expected to be ready for a formal opening on Saturday, June 14.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The time seems to be ripe for a discussion of the question whether there should not be a more complete examination of industrial and other corporations than has hitherto been generally the case. The formation of huge companies, as well as the turning of smaller concerns into the corporation form, has had effects in finance as well as in economics.

DALLAS, Texas, May 19. -- The latest reports from Goliad state that 98 persons were killed and 103 injured by the tornado which passed over that city yesterday afternoon. The property loss in the city and surrounding country will probably reach $200,000. The storm swept the city from end to end, and demolished 150 stores and residences, many of which cannot be repaired.

Beef riots occurred in widely separated parts of the city yesterday, and there was much fierce talk at a meeting held in New Windsor Hall, in the basement of 41 Grand Street, to consider the situation.

NEW BRUNSWICK, May 19. -- Prof. John B. Smith, State Entomologist, who has received from Gov. Murphy the first $1,000 from the emergency fund for the purpose of investigating the mosquito problem in New Jersey, said to-day:

Senator DOLLIVER yesterday put his finger on the weak spot in the Democratic position respecting the Philippines. He prodded it so hard that the patients must have winced when he said that "not a single helpful suggestion had been made by the minority."

It has been the happy fortune of the United States of America to welcome to the brotherhod of nations many younger republics. Beginning with the Helvetic Republic of Switzerland, proclaimed in 1798, we have been the inspiration, the example, and the friend of many countries wherein the will of the people is the supreme law.

PARIS, May 19. -- Martinique mails, forwarded just prior to the disaster in that island, arrived here yesterday. The newspapers print a number of private letters from St. Pierre, giving many details of events immediately preceding the catastrophe.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 19. -- The Princeton University golf team defeated the Hill School team to-day by a score of 24 to 2. The surprise of the afternoon was the defeat of the Princeton Captain, Hugh I. Wilson, by B.D. Smith. Wilson lead at the fifteenth hole, but the "prep" school lad won the next three and the match.

BALTIMORE, May 19. -- The local market to-day failed to develop anything new other than the general gossip about the plans of the bank of Baltimore. That stock has manifested considerable strength during the past few days, due, so it is rumored, to the development of a scheme by which some important out-of-town interests are to be brought into close relationship with the bank.

TRENTON, N.J., May 19. -- Messrs. Mack and Tatnall, receivers for the National Asphalt Company and the Asphalt Company of America, to-day filed an inventory of the assets and liabilities of the two companies with the Clerk of the Circuit Court.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., May 19. -- Considerable excitement prevails among railroad men in this village over an order of the Erie Ralroad officials which went into effect Sunday noon. The order discontinues hostler service in this yard, in addition to many other reductions the Erie has made since the coal strike began.

We publish in another column an interesting communication from Mr. THOMAS L. GREENE as to the nature and extent of the examinations that might profitably be made of business corporations. The writer's unusual experience and high reputation give weight to his suggestions.

It is quite possible that the production of Bulwer Lytton's "The Lady of Lyons" at the Garrick Theatre last night will enhance Miss Mary Mannering's popular reputation as a romantic and emotional actress. The house was filled with fashionable people, and the applause was long and loud.

NEWARK, N.J. May 10. -- Chancellor Magie to-day appointed Algernon T. Sweeney temporary receiver of the American Gear and Vehicle Company, of this city. The application was made on behalf of Perry L. Sisson, President of the company. It was unopposed, although counsel for the company was in court.

There was a small-sized riot in the Tenderloin last evening in which one Belgian farm laborer, one French waiter, two Italian barbers, two colored porters, and three policemen were the active participants.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 19. -- "Piaculous," "Phosphoric," "Piacular," "Phidtia," "Philomath," and "Phosphatic" waited in silence to-day for the preliminary hearing of their case, which begins in the Federal Court to-morrow. At that time the six big packing firms thus designated in a secret code will resist the efforts of the United States Government to show that they have been running a "trust."

HAVANA, May 19. -- The last day of the American occupation of Cuba was devoted by Gov. Gen. Wood and his staff to clearing their desks of official business and to arranging the final details of the evacuation to-morrow. The palace was fairly besieged all day by importunate persons appealing for some last favor before the curtain drops.
Collins Collins have sold for the estate of John C. Tucker, to a client, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 34 West Fiftieth Street, 20 by 75 by 100.5, Columbia College leasehold.

MADRID, May 19. -- The entire population of Madrid seemed to have assembled this afternoon along the broad and leafy Paseo del Prado and Paseo de Recoletos, the grand boulevard of Madrid, there to witness the great military review.
KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, May 17. -- The continued heat thrown off by the lava prevents any one approaching the volcanic mountain.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Ex-Corp. Richard O'Brien of North Adams, Mass., of Company M, Twenty-sixth Volunteers, who served in the Philippines for eighteen months was before the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day.

For two weeks past, in its Sunday issues, THE TIMES has been urging upon wealthy New Yorkers of artistic taste the purchase of a certain Marceilo-Massaranti collection of paintings and sculpture. This gallery is described in THE TIMES'S editorial sheet of yesterday as being "at the Vatican" -- a somewhat celebrated depository of painting and sculpture.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19. -- The last dinner that in all probability will ever be prepared in the Stratford Hotel, this city, was served this evening. This was due to a rather hasty decision on the part of lessee George C. Boldt of New York, who is to erect a fine hostelry on the site of the present structure, to be called the BellevueStratford Hotel.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was very quiet. In the United States Steel bonds and one or two other issues there were movements of interest, but apart from these the market was very flat. Generally speaking, quotations showed some heaviness, but for the most part the declines did not assume size of consequence.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The conviction deepens that nothing better in the way of relief for Cuba will come from the Senate than a rebate bill such as Mr. Oxnard proposed to the President several months ago. It is not certain that even a rebate bill will meet with the approval of the Senate.

Many tributes were paid to the memory of Supreme Court Justice Miles Beach by the various Justices sitting yesterday, and today, with the exception of Special Terms, Parts 1 and 2, all parts of the court will be closed out of respect to his memory.

COAL CREEK, Tenn., May 19. -- The worst disaster in the history of Tennessee mining occurred at 7:30 o'clock this morning when between 175 and 225 men and boys met instant death at the Fraterville coal mine, two miles west of this town, as a result of a gas explosion.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19. -- A twelfthhour recovery in the Reading stocks, and a sharp rally in Electric Storage Battery imparted a more cheerful appearance to the Philadelphia market to-day at the close, but, prior to these movements the list dragged along in a desultory way and inroads were made upon prices.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The House this afternoon passed without division the bill providing for the eight-hour day on all Government work performed by private contractors. It provides that all contracts must contain an eight-hour-day provision. This bill was reported from the Committee on Labor by Mr. Gardner of New Jersey, the Chairman, and there was no debate on it.

BALTIMORE, May 20. -- A deal was consummated in this city to-day by which the Norfolk. Portsmouth and Newport News Company, financed by Alexander Brown Sons and J.W. Middendorf Co. of Baltimore, and John B. Williams Sons of Richmond, Va., will absorb twelve street railways, electric light, gas, ice, ferry, and Summer resort companies at Norfolk and other cities adjacent thereto.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The prestige of the once autocratic coterie of House leaders has been so badly damaged by successive blows that there is not much of it left. Yesterday's vote on the Naval Appropriation bill amendment simply furnished an illustration of how easily the Republican leaders, once deemed invincible, can be overthrown.

The President of the United States made two speeches in this city last night at meetings in honor of the centennial anniversary of the Home Mission Board of the Presbyterian Church -- one, from the stage of Carnegie Hall, to an audience of 3,500 people; the other, from the pulpit of the Central Presbyterian Church, to a congregation of 1,200.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 20 -- A terrific wind and rain storm, accompanied by a waterspout, swept over this locality to-day, causing the loss of six lives and injuring many others. The fury of the storm continued only thirty minutes, but the damage wrought in that time will amount to more than $1,000,000 in the business section of Cincinnati and as much more in other parts of the city and its suburbs.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 20. -- "Mike" Donlin, who is serving a term in the Baltimore jail for assault, signed a contract today to play with the Cincinnati National League team. It is expected that efforts to secure his pardon will prove successful. Should he be obliged to serve the full term for which he was sentenced he will not be able to join the Cincinnati Club until very late in the season.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Mr. Hitt of Illinois to-day sent to the Clerk's desk in the House the following resolution and asked for immediate consideration:

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., May 20. -- It was given out to-day that the Eastern Minnesota system will be entirely absorbed by the Great Northern. The move is to be made, it is said, on account of the enormous profits and dividends shown by the Eastern Minnesota on its ore carrying and other business at this point.

There was a decided falling off yesterday in the subscriptions to the Martinique and West Indian Islands relief funds, they being only about one-third of the amount reported on Monday. It was explained that the sums announced on Monday covered two days' mails, Sunday Intervening.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The stock of the Lake Street Elevated Road advanced to 14 to-day, and at the close was wanted in 1,000-share lots at that price. The sudden advance and inquiry for the shares was the result of information that a pool has now peldged enough shares to control the company.

First Lieut. William McLamodin, recently appointed, is assigned to the Twenty-third Company. First Artillery, and will report to the commanding officer at Jackson Barracks for temporary duty, and upon the completion thereof will join his company at Havana, Cuba.

OMAHA, Neb., May 20. -- President J.J. Hill of the Northern Pacific Railroad, accompanied by the head officials of the Burlington, was in Omaha to-day and inspected the terminal of the latter road. The party occupied a special train of five cars and are touring the system. When asked about the merger, Mr. Hill said:

The people of Fort de Francs at once became panic-stricken, and it is estimated that 20,000 persons, many of them in scant attire, rushed excitedly through the streets of the town, shrieking and praying.

The party occupied a special train of five cars and are touring the system. When asked about the merger, Mr. Hill said:

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- At the residence of Col. and Mrs. John Hancock, 1,308 Sixteenth Street, a small family party assembled at noon to-day to witness the marriage of Col. Hancock's daughter, Mrs. Irene Hancock Sessions, to Lieut. Col. Benjamin Reeves Russell. United States Marine Corps.
BERLIN, May 20. -- "Nate" Hill, the American jockey, won the Saxon Derby on Dr. Lemkes's Alcibiades at Dresden to-day.

BALTIMORE, May 20. -- A deal was consummated in this city to-day by which the Norfolk. Portsmouth and Newport News Company, financed by Alexander Brown Sons and J.W. Middendorf Co. of Baltimore, and John B. Williams Sons of Richmond, Va., will absorb twelve street railways, electric light, gas, ice, ferry, and Summer resort companies at Norfolk and other cities adjacent thereto.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- When the Philippine Government bill was laid before the Senate to-day Mr. Bacon of Georgia vigorously attacked the measure. He said that there was civil Government now established in the Philippines under the war power which was as full in all its powers as was conferred by the pending bill.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The temporary injunction asked for by the Government against the members of the so-called packers' combine is now in force. It was issued this evening by Judge Peter S. Grosscup after the close of arguments in the United States Circuit Court room. The order gives the relief prayed for in the bill filed by District Attorney Bethea on May 10.

As a result of a conference held here yesterday arranging for the payment of the municipal debt of Galveston, Texas, that city will soon commence the construe tion of its long-wished for sea-wall and also the work of raising its site.

HAVANA, May 20 -- The natal day of the Republic of Cuba found Havana arrayed like a Queen to await the coming of her lord. She seemed reinvested for the occasion with the dignity of the prosperous days of her power and wealth. The decorations were universal. In some cases men had worked all night, by the light of torches, to complete elaborate designs.
GOLIAD, Texas, May 20 -- Ninety-five dead and 100 injured is the result of the terrible work of Sunday's tornado. Of the 100 injured it is believed that twenty will die.

According to a statement made yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Father Daley, the meeting of the irremovable rectors of the Archdiocese of New York will be held to-morrow to commence the selection of a successor to Archbishop Corrigan. The fourteen rectors of this diccese will meet in the See House of the cathedral.

The present quarrels in Tammany Hall bring out very clearly the extreme simplicity of the aims and motives of that powerful organization and the striking contrast between the work it undertakes and the work that must be done in an honest administration of this city.

As at Carnegie Hall, President Roosevelt waited into the Central Church alone and the audience stood up to welcome him. It was observed that since his speech in Carnegie, some one had pinned upon the lapel of the President's coat one of the official buttons of the General Assembly. Mr. Roosevelt was immediately introduced, and he spoke as follows:

First Lieut. William McLamodin, recently appointed, is assigned to the Twenty-third Company. First Artillery, and will report to the commanding officer at Jackson Barracks for temporary duty, and upon the completion thereof will join his company at Havana, Cuba.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 20 -- The French cruiser Gaulois, bringing the French Commissioners to represent President Loubet at the unveiling of the monument in memory of the Count de Rochambeau in Washington on Saturday next, passed in the Virginia capes at 7 o'clock this morning, escorted by the Olympia, Kearsarge, and Alabama of the American Navy.

These are busy days in the City Island yacht yards. Great improvements have been made in Robert Jacob's yard, which has been broadened so that it has more room for construction and for Winter storing and repairing and the new marine railway that has been built adds to the effectiveness of the establishment.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 20. -- William Corbett won the first prize in the ping-pong tournament at the Montclair Club, which closed Monday night. The winners in the other events were as follows:

QUEBEC, May 20 -- Col. Gaynor and Capt. Greene are prisoners in the Quebec Jail. They were committed to the prison this afternoon. Sheriff Langlier had prepared special quarters for them. Mr. Tachereau, counsel for Messrs, Gaynor and Greene, notified the court to-day that in a few days he will move for a writ of certiorari for the transmission of the record of the arrest of his clients from Montreal to Quebec.
The only question of general interest respecting the strike of the anthracite miners is, How long will it probably last?

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, May 19 -- The expedition sent to recover the bodies of the American and British Con- suls at St. Pierre nearly resulted in a fearful catastrophe to-day. The vessels taking part in the expedition were the United States steamer Potomac and the British cruiser Indefatigable.

She seemed reinvested for the occasion with the dignity of the prosperous days of her power and wealth. The decorations were universal. In some cases men had worked all night, by the light of torches, to complete elaborate designs.

That the essense of anarchism is mere blind brutishness was never more vividly shown than in the attempt, happily frustrated, upon the life of FRANCIS JOSEPH. The successful attempt upon the life of his Empress had the one additional element of beastliness that the victim was a helpless woman.

Mr. Tachereau, counsel for Messrs, Gaynor and Greene, notified the court to-day that in a few days he will move for a writ of certiorari for the transmission of the record of the arrest of his clients from Montreal to Quebec.
BERLIN, May 20. -- "Nate" Hill, the American jockey, won the Saxon Derby on Dr. Lemkes's Alcibiades at Dresden to-day.

GAYNOR and GREENE -- and, incidentally, for large fees -- one can see, if a little fanciful, traces of the fierce hostility which began in the remote days when the two cities were founded and which has persisted, in various forms and degrees, through all the years that have since elapsed.

PARIS, May 21 -- The Soir, in its issue of this evening, announces that M. Michel Lagrave has been promoted to be an officer of the Legion of Honor. He represents the Department of Commerce on the Rochambeau mission, now in the United States. He is also French Commissioner General to the Louisiana Purchase Exposition at St. Louis.

TSARSKOE SELO, Russia, May 21 -- The Czar, President Loubet, the Czarina, and the Dowager Czarina attended a great review of troops to-day. His Majesty, on horseback, and M. Loubet, the Czarina, the Dowager Czarina, and the Grand Duchess Serge, in a carriage, passed down the front of the troops, attended by brilliant suites.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over 3,000.

The trial of Sergt. James Churchill of the Leonard Street Station was resumed yesterday at Police Headquarters before Commissioner Partridge on charges of neglect of duty when he was in command of the Fifth Street Station. Inspector Cross is the complainant. Lawyer Otto Rosalsky, counsel for Churchill, asked that Inspector Cross be excluded from the courtroom, as he was a witness against Churchill, but this motion was denied.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Judge C.C. Kohlsaat, in the United States District Court, to-day issued a perpetual injunction against the production in the United States of Edmond Rostand's play, "Cyrano De Bergerac," in the suit brought against Richard Mansfield and A.M. Palmer by Samuel Eberly Gross of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The debate on the Immigration bill in the House to-day brought out some plain speaking on lines entirely different from the conventional way of discussing immigration. Some propositions which, if not novel to the country, are new in Congress were advanced by Gen. Grosvenor of Ohio, Mr. Watson of Indiana, and others.

FORT DE FRANCE, May 21 -- Yesterday's eruption of Mont Pelee, which broke out at 5 o'clock in the morning, was ten times as violent as that which destroyed St. Pierre. Colossal columns of volcanic matter were ejected from the volcano, which rained huge, red-hot bolders, many feet in diameter, on the ruins of St. Pierre, and the country near it from an enormous elevation and with fearful velocity.
LONDON, May 21 -- Money was more plentiful to-day and rates were fairly easy. Discounts were maintained owing to the uncertainty regarding the immediate future.

METZ, May 21 -- Emperor William arrived at Chateau Urville to-day on his annual visit to the Reichsland, and received in audience the members of the Executive Committee of Alsace-Lorraine, who conveyed the thanks of the population to his Majesty for the abolition of the dictatorship over the provinces.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Corporal O'Brien, formerly of the Twenty-sixth Volunteer Infantry, was before the Senate Philippine Committee to-day and produced the alleged "dum-dum" or explosive bullets. He said they were not like the ordinary cartridges, because they did not have the letters "U.S." on them.

Foreign missions was the subject which claimed most of the attention of the Presbyterian General Assembly yesterday. In the morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church the Assembly heard the report of the Foreign Missionary Board, and in the evening as many people as could get seats in Carnegie Hall crowded there to listen to speeches on this same subject of Christian work in other countries.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Following the example set by other roads, the Reading Railway Company, after a meeting of the Board of Directors to-day, announced that it had inaugurated a pension system for its employes. The system will supplement the Philadelphia and Reading Belief Association.

More then a fair share of racing misfortune has fallen to the lot of Clarence H. Mackay's stable this Spring, but the combination of ill-luck that beat the Mackay colt Gay Boy for the Van Courtlandt Handicap at Morris Park yesterday about equaled all the total of the stable's other misfortunes.

At a secret caucus of the Sullivan-Croker leaders it was decided last night to revolutionize the political system in Tammany Hall. The result of the open and bitter factional war between the followers of Richard Croker and the men who have allied themselves with John F. Carroll, exMayor Robert A. Van Wyck, and their friends is to be a splitting wide-open of the Wigwam.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Trading in this market to-day was moderately active and the tone was steady. Stocks which were heavy in the early part of the week are now showing pronounced strength, the Readings leading in the upward movement. Lehigh Valley rallied over a point after a report was received that the stock would be placed in the unlisted department in New York.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 21 -- It is expected that to-morrow the Executive Committee may grant the request of several individual operators to be allowed to pay the wages the union demands and work their collieries. If this is done, it is said the big coal-carrying roads will refuse to transport their coal, and that the dissatisfaction of the railroaders will therefore grow until a strike results.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- The San Francisco Athletic Club of San Francisco has secures the Jeffries-Fitzsimmons fight, the terms being 70 per cent, of the gross receipts to go to the fighters. The date of the fight is to be mutually agreed upon later by the fighters, and the club. The pugilists decided upon "Eddie" Graney, a local man, to act as referee.

KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, B.W.I., May 19 -- Another great eruption of the Soufriere volcano occurred last (Sunday) night. Throughout yesterday the adjoining districts trembled, and some of the shocks were felt here. Smoke issued from the craters and fissures of the mountain, and the atmosphere throughout the island was exceedingly hot.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 21 -- The latest estimate of loss of life in the Fraterville coal mine disaster at Coal Creek is 226, including contract miners, day laborers and boy helpers. The last find reported was that of thirteen bodies in an entry. Five of them had written letters before life became extinct.

MADRID, May 21 -- The royal bullfight, the most typically Spanish feature of the festivities in connection with the coming of age of King Alfonso, took place this afternoon in the presence of the King, the Queen Mother, the royal family, and the Special Envoys Many women were present.

After having their first two scheduled games postponed on Monday and Tuesday, the Jersey City and Rochester baseball teams met at Jersey City yesterday and the leaders in the Eastern League were defeated by a score of 14 to 10. The score:

PARIS, May 21 -- The waiting room of the Minister of the Colonies, M. Decrais, was again filled to-day with anxious natives of Martinique and others with interests there. Conspicuous in the throng were two gray-gowned, white-capped Sisters of Charity, counting their rosaries and their lips moving in silent prayer as they patiently awaited admission to the Minister's office.

We may well suppose that President ROOSEVELT had in mind the critics of our Philippine policy when, in speaking of the birth of the Cuban Republic in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, he used these words:

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Roosevelt unveiled to-day the memorial shaft erected at Arlington by the National Society of Colonial Dames in memory of the veterans who fell in the Spanish-American war. Around the platform an immense crowd gathered, among them being many men who saw service in Cuba, Porto Rico, and the Philippines.

Dr. George R. Fowler, the surgeon and chief of the visiting staffs of several of Brooklyn's hospitals, has commenced a number of actions against patients who had received professional services at his hands, and who, when bills were presented to them, declined to pay on the ground that they were patients at the hospitals, and that the doctor's services were rendered as a servant of the institution.

Scenes of extraordinary excitement attended the destruction by fire of the large Bradbury piano factory at the northeast corner of Raymond and Willoughby Streets, Brooklyn, last night. Prisoners in the Raymond Street Jail, close by, of whom there were 320, including 71 women, were panicstricken, and only a strong show of force by the guards, who walked up and down through the prison, prevented an attempt at escape.
LONDON, May 21 -- The American polo Players defeated a Hurlingham team this afternoon by 7 goals to 1.

In the outside market yesterday prices were stronger than on the earlier days of the week, but the transactions for the most part were relatively small. In a few issues, including Northern Securities and United Copper, the trading was fairly active, but for the most part such changes as were effected in quotations resulted from very little trading.

The recent history of the sugar bounty in Germany has important lessons for those who are endeavoring, with OXNARD, artificially to foster in this country the industry which has been fostered in Germany and the other bounty-paying countries until it is recognized to have become a national incubus on each of them, and the urgent question is how to get rid of fostering it any longer.
According to London cables, it is asserted that an Anglo-American syndicate hes arranged a combination of shipping and trading interests on the West Coast of Africa.

News of the death of Edwin Lawrence Godkin in Brixham, England, reached here yesterday morning. His fatal illness followed a hemorrhage of the brain on the 17th. Two years ago he experienced a similar hemorrhage. He spent last Winter in Torquay, going from there to Brixham early this month.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 21 -- The State Democratic Convention met here to-day One of the principal objects of the gathering was the framing of rules to govern the primaries. In accordance with these rule candidates for the United States Senatorship and other offices must pledge their Support to the successful candidate and to the platform of the party.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- There seems to be absolutely no chance of the passage of the Fowler Banking and Currency bill by the House this session. The prevailing view with the Republican members accords with that of Representative Pugsley of New York as set forth in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

As the date of the coronation of King EDWARD draws near and preparations for the event are occupying the attention of all classes of the people, the underwriters of Lloyd's are doing a rushing, business in assuming risks covering all possible contingencies of loss to the insured should anything happen to postpone or interfere with the ceremony.

PITTSBURG, May 21 -- Mathewson, the fading idol of the New York team, regained some of his lost laurels here today by working the defeat of the Pittsburg baseball team. He scored the winning run in the eighth inning by a great sprint from first base to the home plate on Doyle's two-base hit.

The Executive Committee of the Associated Committees for the relief of the sufferers in Martinique and the West Indian Islands met at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. The committee has received no further cable advices, but is waiting to hear from William R. Corwine, who sailed on the Fontabelle last Saturday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The distressing accident happening on the Staten Island ferryboat Middletown, causing the death of Mr. John C. Atterbury, one of the best and most lovable of men, and who was so well known among the bankers and brokers of Wall Street, has caused the deepest sorrow among his many friends.

LONDON, May 22 -- In a dispatch from Vienna to The Times a letter from a correspondent "with exceptional sources of information" is quoted. This correspondent declares that Germany is exploiting the apprehensions created in Great Britain by the North Atlantic shipping combination for the purpose of sowing distrust and jealousy between Great Britain and the United States.

Fire Marshal Alonzo Brymer of Brooklyn died yesterday afternoon in the German Hospital, Brooklyn, of pneumonia. Mr. Brymer was operated upon on Monday for a tumor in the stomach by Dr. George R. Fowler, assisted by Dr. Ferguson, the house surgeon of the institution, and the hospital staff.

Once more the high-price record for real estate in this city has been broken. The new record, moreover, does not belong to any fancy little parcel within the shadow of the Stock Exchange or in the retail dry goods section, but to the little gore lot at the northeast corner of Third Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street.

PARIS, May 10 -- The interest of all Paris is focused on an empty safe at 65 Avenue de la Grand Armee. The opening of this safe by M. Cochefort, Chief de la Surete, and his detectives brought to light the greatest swindle of the century. The principals in the swindle have fled from Paris and are believed to be on their way to America.

Lakewood won the Westchester Polo Cup yesterday in a very one-sided game with the Rockaway Club on the field of the Country Club of Westchester. The pinners scored 13 1/2 goals while the Rockaway men got only 2 1/2. Each one-half goal for a foul. The odd feature of the match apart from the unexpected weakness of the Cedarhurst players, was the fact that the latter allowed the Lakewood poloists three goals by handicap allowance.

William C. Dewey of Springfield, Mass., has bought from the Alliance Realty Company the plot running through from 31 and 33 West Nineteenth Street to 28 and 30 West Twentieth Street, 46.6 by 184, and will erect thereon a store and loft building.
PASSAIC, N.J., May 21 -- Masked burglars about 2:30 o'clock this morning visited Lodi, in Bergen County, and broke into the Post Office, in the Ker Block, smashing the front door to gain an entrance.

Peter Muller, builder, of 605 East One Hundred and Fortieth Street, and his sister, Dorothea Weibel, of the same address, filed separate petitions in bankruptcy yesterday. Mr. Muller's liabilities are $1,182,992, of which $933,000 are secured by bond and mortgage and $249,992 are unsecured, for building materials, labor, Mrs. Weibel's liabilities are $1,172,284, of which $933,000 are secured and $239,284 unsecured.

Certainly of all the queer articles in women's apparel the new golf parasols are the queerest. There is the regular golf club for a foundation, the handle made like a simply designed parasol handle, but finished with something which looks like a coarse grass covering to give a firm hold. Then comes the parasol.

Justice Greenbaum, in the Supreme Court, yesterday listened to argument over the granting of a peremptory writ of mandamus to compel Controller Grout to issue his warrant for the City Chamberlain to pay to Robert S. McLellan and other county detectives employed by District Attorney Jerome $54.30, expenses which they alleged they incurred in collecting evidence upon which Police Captain Michael J. Foody was tried for violation of the excise law.

HAVANA, May 21 -- President Palma took up his official residence at the palace today and received many visitors, but he transacted no business. Governmental machinery and business will remain at a standstill during the festivities, which will not close until next Friday.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 22 -- The local market was unable to develop any new feature to-day. United Railways incomes were in better demand, due to the semi-official assurance that the June coupon would be paid. Those apprised of the management's successes have had no doubt as to the prompt payment of this coupon, and consequently have been ready buyers of the bonds at lower figures than those now prevailing.

Lily Martin Spencer, an artist noted for her work for almost two generations, died suddenly at her home, at the southwest corner of Columbus Avenue and One Hundred and Fifth Street, yesterday. She was seventy-five years old and had been sick, but the full seriousness of her case was not suspected even by her closest relatives.

-- There Is, of course, an element of impertinence in criticising, from this distance, the statements of those who saw the destruction of St. Pierre or who have since visited the scene of the disaster, but it is evident enough that no description, either scientific or accurate, has yet been given of just what happened.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Bishop Thoburn of the Methodist Episcopal Church of India and Malaysia, was before the Senate Committee on Philippines to-day. He said the American occupation of the Philippines should be continued. In the course of his examination he said that the American occupation was an act of God.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 22 -- Chief of Police Tenny and Capt. Peters started this morning for Cleveland, Ohio, to see if a man arrested there is Jeremiah O'Connor, formerly of this city, for whom the authorities have been looking for a long time.

Lyle E. Mahan won the lawn tennis championship In the singles of Columbia University yesterday on the South Field courts. His opponent In the final match of the tournament for this honor was Lewis N. Chase, the former champion of California. The victory gives Mahan the title for the third time, and establishes his supremacy over any player who has ever competed under the light blue and white in the open meetings.

BOSTON, May 22 -- The kosher meat disturbances which have occurred in the North End during the past few days were transferred to the West End section of the city to-day. About 9 o'clock 300 Hebrews -- men, women, and children -- assembled in front of the meat store conducted by Isaac Leibman, on Brighton Street, and threw eggs and decayed fruit at the building.

Jefferson M. Levy has bought from the White estate 686 to 692 Greenwich Street, adjoining the northwest corner of Christopher Street, a plot 90 by 103, now coverea by five-story warehouses. The property is opposite the block which has been acquired by the New Jersey and New York Railroad as a terminal for its Hudson River tunnel.

Tammany Hall's Executive Committee met yesterday and adopted the sweeping changes in the management of the political affairs of the organization, as decided upon by the secret caucus of the Croker-Sullivan leaders on Wednesday night. The leaders of the Carroll-Van Wyck combination were undaunted by the temporary victory of their opponents, and they were busy during the day forming plans to defeat the friends of Richard Croker.

It took the Presbyterian General Assem- bly, meeting at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday, just one hour and forty-five minutes to dispose of the entire question of the revision of the Westminster Confession of Faith, which has provoked such bitter controversy for the past dozen years.

With the aid of a woman detective employed by the postal authorities as a "come on," Henry Montgomery, said by the Inspectors to be a well-known green goods man, was arrested yesterday by Detective Sergeants McConville and Savage, and, after being turned over to the postal authorities, was held by Commissioner Shields in $6,000 bail, in default of which he was sent to Ludlow Street Jail.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was very much interested in reading an article in to-day's issue of THE TIMES giving an account of the merits of an organ performer residing in Bethlehem, Penn. According to the opinion of the writer, this organist is equal, it not superior, to any in this country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It the miners had just cause for complaint they could enlist the sympathy of every fair-minded man, if they made a frank and clear statement of their grievances. If they conceal or misstate them, they engender the suspicion that they are more imaginary than real, and that their burdens may be no harder to bear than those of the average of our laboring classes.

The tenants of the four-story apartment house at 413 West Fifty-seventh Street were thrown into a panic about 9 o'clock last night by dense volumes of smoke, which filled the halls of the house. Dr. Barker, who occupies the third floor, sent in an alarm from the box at the corner of Fifty-eighth Street and Ninth Avenue.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst and Mrs. Parkhurst will sail to-day on the Cymric for their annual vacation abroad. They expect to spend about a month in Ireland, and then will go to their Summer home on Lake Geneva, Switzerland.

Edon Marwig, an actor, twenty-five years of age, and living at 218 West Forty-fourth Street, was locked up in the West Forty seventh Street Station House last night charged with forgery. The complainants are a cigar dealer named W.G. Treadwell of 779 Fifth Avenue and the Fifth Avenue Bank, through Col. Fuller of the Fuller Detective Agency.

The course of yesterday's market further reflected the confidence of traders and investors, though activity was not much extended. Many special stocks were notably strong. A number of stocks recently laggard grew active and advanced. Sugar Trust being conspicuous in that group.

LONDON, May 23 -- A Cabinet council has been called for to-day. While the Government departments are discreetly silent, it is generally believed that the summoning of the Cabinet is directly connected with the South African peace conference. Most of the Ministers are out of town for the Whitsuntide recess, though they went away rather expecting to have their holiday broken up by just such a summons.
SARATOGA, N.Y., May 22 -- James F. Caldwell, the veteran race horse starter, died here suddenly to-day of apoplexy.

The Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association yesterday came to a glorious closing with a very large share of the glory falling to the lot of August Belmont, Chairman of The Jockey Club, Steward of the meeting, and donor of the trophy, which was an important part of the chief stake fixture of the day's card.

Business in the outside market yesterday contrasted favorably with the earlier days of the week. More issues were traded in, and in some the transactions were more than usually large. In the case of nearly all the important issues prices were strong, few stocks declining, while a number of substantial gains were recorded.

The General Relief Committee for Martinique and the West Indian Islands decided at a meeting at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday to suspend, temporarily at least, the collection of subscriptions for the benefit of the sufferers. This action was due to the receipt by Chairman Gustav H Schwab of the Executive Committee of a telegram from George B. Cortelyou, secretary to President Roosevelt, reading as follows:

It may very safely be assumed that the "Western Republican Representative" whom our Washington correspondent quoted yesterday "had some of the pork," both in the River and Harbor bill and in the Omnibus Public Buildings bill. His dread was father to his thought that, " the President is dying to veto something."

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The report sent out from Washington last night that the Republicans of the Senate Committee on Relations with Cuba had come to an agreement on a bill for the relief of that island had no basis in fact. When the report was presented this morning to the chairman of the committee, Mr. Platt of Connecticut, he said there was nothing in it.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 22 -- The seizure here of the alleged counterfeiters and their dies was made so quietly that not even the neighbors knew of it. The family who lived in the house where the capture was made was always a quiet one and had nothing to do with those living near.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 22 -- President Loubet arrived here this morning from Tsarskoe-Selo, and an enthusiastic and popular reception was accorded to him. The railroad station and city were lavishly decorated, and men, women, and children thronged the streets, waving tricolor flags and wearing Franco-Russian alliance souvenirs of all descriptions.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- United States Ambassador Choate at London has informed the State Department that a cablegram from the Governor of the Windward Islands to the Colonial Office reports that the Canadian Government has made a Substantial effort toward the relief of the distress in St. Vincent by supplies of money and otherwise.

BOSTON, Mass., May 22 -- Money is in more abundant supply. Clearing House rate, 4 per cent; New York funds, 4 @ 5c premium; Call loans, 4@ 4 1/2 , Time money, 4 1/2 @ 5. Exchanges, $22,241,944. Balances, $1,659,707. The stock market was slow, but strong in tone, with the coppers in good request.

NEWARK, N.J., May 22 -- Peter Malaguska of 16 Monroe Street was arraigned before Police Judge Schalk in the Third Precinct Police Court this morning and gave $500 bail to await the action of the Grand Jury on a charge of assault preferred by his wife. The prevailing high prices of meat were said to be responsible.

PITTSBURG, May 22 -- About the worst misfortune which has overtaken the New York baseball team this season befell it today when Van Haltren, the veteran centre fielder, fell and broke his leg at the ankle in the sixth inning while trying to steal second base. The injury will certainly lay this sterling player up for the rest of the season, and may possibly incapacitate him for the game after that.

Capt. Titus has men watching the piers at which every incoming European steamer will dock on the lookout for M. Humbert and his wife. Therese, who departed from Paris with the intention, it is believed, of embarking for America, after having secured $12,000,000 from credulous Parisian bankers by means of the most astounding swindle of the century.

MADRID, May 22 -- Dr. J.L.M. Curry (the representative of the United States at the ceremonies attending the majority of King Alfonso) and Mrs. Curry leave Madrid to-night for Paris, where Dr. Curry is to make a speech at the Rochambeau banquet on Saturday.

LONDON, May 22 -- Money was in meagre supply and fair demand to-day. Operators are unable to liquidate their indebtedness to the Bank of England, and fresh borrowings are anticipated next week. Consequently discounts were firm.

In the first game of the present series between the Providence and Jersey City baseball teams of the Eastern League, played at Jersey City yesterday, the home players outbatted the visitors, but lost the game by their errors in the field. The score:

CASTRIES, St. Lucia, B.W.I., May 22 -- M. Labat, the senior Town Councillor of Kort de France, who was among the refugees who arrived here yesterday from Martinique on board the Norwegian steamer Helga, accompanied by his entire family, was interviewed to-day. He said that since the St. Pierre disaster the population of Fort de France had been excited and anxious.

Major James D. Glennan, Surgeon, upon the expiration of his leave of absence will report to the Superintendent of the Military Academy at West Point for duty to relieve Major William L. Kneedier, Surgeon. Major Kneedler upon being relieved will proceed to San Diego Barracks for duty, to relieve Contract Surgeon William Q. Gregory.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The main party of the distinguished Frenchmen sent by President Loubet to take part in the Rochambeau exercises arrived here this morning at 10 o'clock from Annapolis. Only a small crowd was at the depot to greet the visitors.

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, May 22 -- The correspondent of The Associated Press here has had an interview with M. Clerc, a member of the Colonial Legislature, who recently explored the vicinity of Mont Pelee. He said:

Deluded by false hopes, which, she says, were held out to her by Christian Scientists, Annie Meyers, a working woman, poor and sick, stood a prisoner before Magistrate Zeller in the West Side Court yesterday. The cpmplainant against her was Richard P. Varrell of 143 West Forty-eighth Street, who is alleged to be a "healer," working in connection with the First Church of Christ, Scientist, in the same street.

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, May 22 -- The recent rains of ashes and volcanic rocks, weighing as much as 75 grammes, which have fallen here, caused so much consternation among the inhabitants of Fort de France that those who have not left the city are anxious to do so, and large numbers are emigrating to Guadeloupe, where, it is now estimated, 1,200 people from Martinique have already sought shelter.

W.M. McCord of the Knollwood Country Club and Edward Flash of the Harbor Hill Golf Club tied for first honors yesterday on the Knollwood links, near White Plains, in the fifth semi-annual handicap tournament of the Produce Exchange golfers. Their net scores were 78 strokes for the eighteen holes, although McCord had the lesser handicap, 8, while Flash had 18 strokes.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Senator Hoar made his promised speech to-day in opposition to the Philippine Government bill. It was a denunciation of the Administration's policy in the Philippine Islands, which the Senator had spent weeks in preparing. The burden of the speech was that the United States had turned its back upon what Mr. Hoar called the "eternal principle " that there can be no just government without consent of the governed.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 22 -- The tenth day of the anthracite coal miners' strike passed off very quietly. Not a single incident developed which would in any way tend to change the present situation. Rumors were rife that something was about to take place that would alter the status quo condition of the negotiations, but these were promptly denied by leaders of both sides to the controversy.

Buffalo and the Westchester Country Club had a hard fight for polo supremacy yesterday on the field of the Meadow Brook Club, near Westbury, L.I., and after the four periods had ended in a tie, Buffalo scored the deciding point in four minutes' over-time play. The victors' winning score was 12 3/4 goals to 11 3/4 for Westehester.

OTTAWA, Canada, May 22 -- The largest colonization company in the history of the Dominion has been sucessfully floated. A company, with a capital of $3,500,000, and composed of Minneapolis, Duluth, and Western Canadian men has purchased 1,100,000 acres of the finest farm lands in Assiniboia and Saskatchewan.

Inquiries continued to be made yesterday concerning the affairs of the American Elevated Railroad Company, to which wide attention has been drawn by the collapse Of the stock from 45 to 1. The management of the company has all along denied having any Connection whatsoever with the trading in the stock, and until yesterday refused to offer any explanation for the decline which has occurred within the last ten days.

NEWARK, N.J., May 22.--Fish and eggs were at a premium to-day in the Jewish quarter. Women wanted chickens, and although there were plenty on hand, could not get them killed according to the rule of their faith, so that those who cut only "kosher" chickens went without. As on the two precedings days, all the butchers' shops were closed.

Senator HOAR'S speech is very long and very readable. It is full of historical matter and of political theory, mostly very sound and admirable. But the kernel and meaning of the speech, the cornerstone of the anti-imperialist sructure, are to be found in this brief passage:

Irremovable rectors of the Roman Catholic archdiocese of New York met yesterday at the archiepiscopal residence in Madison Avenue to take the first formal steps toward the election of a successor to the late Archbishop Corrigan.

LONDON, May 22. -- The newspapers here regard the death of Edwin Lawrence Godkin, editor emeritus of The Evening Post of New York, as being a distinct loss to Great Britain as well as to America, and comment on his friendship for Great Britain. The Westminster Gazette says:

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- The Philadelphia market to-day was generally irregular, and except in the Readings the trading was of a dabbling character. Besides Readings, Union Traction and Lehigh Valley were fairly active. The latter at one time was over a point above last night, and orders were said to be from New York curb traders.

Capt. Foody and Detectives Beadle and Trogan of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station raided a hall over the saloon of Edward E. Maher, at Thirty-fourth Street and Twelfth Avenue, last night, where they believed a prize fight was to take place, and captured fifty prisoners.
HACKENSACK, N.J., May 22 -- One man was killed and another so seriously injured this afternoon on Terrace Avenue that he will probably die.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Senate took on an unwonted appearance this afternoon at the conclusion of Mr. Hoar's speech. About all of the Senators left their seats and congregated in little knots here and there about the chamber. It seemed as though an unusual number of important conferences were in progress.

HAZLETON, Penn., May 22 -- Matthias Schwabe, a small independent operator, to-day started up his colliery, at South Heberton. All of his miners are to receive the wages demanded by the mine workers. The output will be for home consumption exclusively. It commands $6 a ton at the breaker.

The President of Manhattan Borough contributes an article to The Municipal Journal and Engineer, 253 Broadway, in which he says: "I am in perfect harmony with the ideas and suggestions made by the Municipal Art Society of this city for the development of the aesthetic side of the municipality."

A mob of 1,000 people, with women in the lead, marched through the Jewish quarter of Williamsburg last evening, and wrecked half a dozen butcher shops. Men and women who were seen coming out of the shops with meat and chickens in their hands were attacked. In the throng of women leaders of the mob there were many who carried bottles of kerosene oil.

PARIS, May 22 -- The French Government is considering the possibility of the necessity arising for the evacuation of Fort de France, and even the whole Island of Martinique. The Ministers do not believe that any such emergency will arise, but they are taking all the necessary measures to meet it if it does arise.

The Committee of Fifty organized to oppose the proposed increase rate of speed of vehicles, announced yesterday the result of its effort to learn the views of the residents of New York generally on the subject.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 22 -- The semi-annual meeting of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs was held here to-day in the hall of the Montclair Club. Mrs. Stewart Hartshorn, President of the Federation, called the delegates to order.

Nature has provided for the City of New York a foundation which, so far as the geologists can discover or experience shows, is stable and substantial. We are not in the volcanic chain, and while occasionally enlivened by a bit of earthquake which only a seismograph of exceptionally delicate adjustment would record, anything like a volcanic eruption has been regarded as quite beyond the bounds of probability, if not of geological possibility.

PITTSTON, Penn., May 22 -- A new phase developed here in the mine strike to-day when all the washeries in this district controlled by the Erie Company shut down. They have been running steadily, turning out 6,000 tons of coal daily. The shut-down was due to orders received from New York last night, a conference of the railroad Presidents having been held in that city yesterday, when it was decided to cease all washery operations.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 22 -- Thomas Newbold of New York has rented the De Rham cottage on Bellevue Avenue for the Summer.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 22 -- The wedding of Miss Katherine Morgan Rowland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Rowland, and George Lauder, Jr., of Pittsburg, took place at the bride's home here at 3 o'clock this afternoon, being witnessed only by the families of the contracting parties. Immediately afterward there was a reception, for which 800 invitations had been issued.

OMAHA, Neb., May 22 -- James J. Hill of the Northern Pacific-Burlington combination, while in Omaha this week inspecting Burlington terminals, stated to an Omaha Railroad official that it was his intention to cut rates on lumber from the Northwest to such low figures that lumber rates in the Missouri River cities would take a fall.
The resignation of Second Lieut. Charles B. Baker, Philippine Scouts, has been accepted, to take effect May 22.

Controller Grout, as a member of the Rapid Transit Commission's committee appointed to formulate a tentative contract for the Manhattan-Brooklyn tunnel, submitted a minority report when the commission met yesterday morning. The majority report was signed by Commissioners Alexander E. Orr and Charles Stewart Smith.

BOSTON, May 23. -- As the demand for money slackens there is a steady shading of rates. At present the situation is very comfortable, and bids fair to continue so for some time to come. New York funds are in good demand locally, otherwise the local conditions show no change. Sterling exchange continues steady.
LONDON, May 10. -- The Emperor Tiberius has been successfully defended against the libels of Roman historians, and De Quincey made an attempt to reverse the popular verdict against Pontius Pilate.

Conferences held yesterday in the office of United States Commissioner Shields between representatives of the French Government, including Consul General Bruwaert, are supposed to have been in relation to the extradition of M. Humbert and his wife Therese, who are believed to be fleeing to this country after swindling Parisian bankers out of $12,000,000 by the greatest of bunko games, obtaining loans on a mythical American estate.

IT is one of the modern fads in literature to take appeal from the verdict of history in the case of people who have been condemned to obloquy or infamy as monsters of wickedness, and reargue their cases on a motion for acquittal.

HAMBURG, May 23. -- A special dispatch to the Hamburg Boersenhalle from Guatemala says that the town of Quezaltenango has been wholly destroyed by an earthquake, which lasted three-quarters of a minute. Business is entirely suspended in Guatemala, and a great part of the coffee crop there has been destroyed.

WATERLOO, Iowa, May 23. -- A doubletrack electric railway from the borders of Canada to the Gulf of Mexico will be a realization within the next few years, in the plans of a syndicate of the Mississippi Valley, with Judge John Porter of Eldora, Iowa, at the head, shall be carried out. The railway, according to present plans, will start near the Lake of the Woods, and will follow the Mississippi Valley to the Gulf.

Supreme Court Justice George P. Andrews died at his residence at 2:15 o'clock this morning. He had been conscious during the greater part of his illness, but was in a coma for a time before the end. With him were his wife, her daughter, Mrs. Chapin, the doctor who had attended him, and attendants.
DETROIT, May 23. -- Following close upon the purchase of the Ann Arbor Road by Gould interests comes the news of another important deal which is also evidently in the interest of the greater Wabash.

VANCOUVER, B.C., May 23. -- One of the most terrible mine disasters in the history of the frequent accidents in British Columbia occurred last night in the Crow's Nest Coal Company's mines at Fernie, B. C. Over one hundred men are either dead or imprisoned in the mine, and little hope is entertained of rescuing any who may yet be alive.

SCORES of writers have become known to me in the course of a long life, but I have never known another so fastidious and so laborious as Bret Harte. His writing materials, the light and heat, and even the adjustment of the furniture of the writing room, must be as he desired; otherwise he could not go on with his work.

DENVER, May 23. -- Pugilist William Rothwell, known as "Young Corbett," gained the decision over "Kid" Broad here to-night at the end of their ten-round bout. Both fighters were apparently in good shape at the end of the fight.

AN AMERICAN edition has just been issued of a book which has been very well received in England, where the first large edition was exhausted before publication. This is a biographical account of the life and work of Gipsy Smith, written by himself.

There came to light yesterday another definite and well-supported plan to connect New York City with New Jersey by way of a tunnel under the North River. A corporation called the New York and Jersey Railroad Company asked the Rapid Transit Commission for a permit to build the Manhattan portion of such a tunnel.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 23. -- Mrs. Charles H. Baldwin arrived to-day at her cottage, on Bellevue Avenue, for the season.

It is clear that the negotiations that have been going on in South Africa have at least been serious. It seems that London may not be too sanguine in expecting peace from them, as it seems that all London does. It is not at first clear why the "Free Staters" should have shown themselves so much more stubborn than the Boers of the Transvaal.

ASBURY PARK. N.J., May 23. -- Mayor Bradley and his followers in the crusade for Sunday trains seem to have overreached themselves in their retaliatory act against the Ocean Grove Association for refusing to yield their objections to the cancellation of the old agreement that no trains shall stop on the first day of the week within a mile of their limits.

Following is a statement of books which have sold best in regular book and department stores in New York. Philadelphia, Cincinnati, Chicago. Baltimore, Washington. St. Louis and San Francisco between April 20 and May 20 of this year. The statement is based on reports received from the regular correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in those cities personal Inquiries having been made for the Information sent to us.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- New York exchange was 25 cents premium. Time and call loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent. About the only interesting feature presented by the local market to-day was a drop of 3 points in Title and Trust immediately after the opening on the sale of 150 shares. The shares sold at 134 1/4, which represents a fall of about 16 points from the best price reached a short time ago.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Bishop Thoburn continued his testimony before the Philippine Committee of the Senate to-day. He was examined about various phases of the situation, and especially as to the rights of the United States to dominate the Philippine Islands. He said in reply to one question that chaos would result if England were to withdraw from India.

-- With an appreciative sincerity that does it much credit. The Staunton (Va.) News mourns for Poss. Poss, it seems, was a "small woolly dog, beautiful to those who loved him, and nearly white when he was clean." He belonged to one of the Staunton policemen, and he accompanied his master over his beat, " as vigilant as if he had drawn two salaries from the city."

PERHAPS no man in this country ever exerted so wide an influence with on editorial pen and remained so unknown a personality as did Edwin L. Godkin. Not one person in a thousand in the city where he lived would recognize him on the street.

Keats's Endymion. The Elston Press announces for early issue its tenth publication, "Endymion," by John Keats. The volume will be printed as a small folio, although octavo in size, and will be uniform with the other octavos of the Press.

LONDON, May 24. -- Lord Rosebery delivered a speech at the National Liberal Club last night which seems, more than any of his recent utterances, to bind him to an attempt to reorganize the Liberal Party, and which, consequently gives much less satisfaction to the Conservative papers than his previous utterances.

Mayer S. Auerbach has resold the sixstory building at the northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, 24.8 by 100, to the J.M. Horton Ice Cream Company. Mr. Auerbach purchased the property last Monday.

Senator HOAR declared in his speech addressing his remarks to the millions of his misguided countrymen who support the Philippine policy of the Administration, "you have not only repealed the Declaration of Independence, but you have left of the Monroe doctrine only the principle of brutal selfishness."

The American Machine and Ordnance Company filed its incorporation papers at Albany yesterday. The incorporators are George E. Eouchle, Charles B. Holder, and O. M. Palmer. The capital of the company is $10,000,000. of which $2.000,000 is 6 per cent, cumulative preferred stock and $8,000,000 common stock.

During much of yesterday Stock Exchange tickers stood still; but just before the close something like activity started and with the increased trading came increasing strength, net changes for the day being almost wholly advances. Many gains of over a full point were scored.

Polo was seen at its best yesterday, and the large and fashionable delegation that gathered around the Meadow Brook Club field recalled the palmy days of polo excellence. The competing teams were Meadow Brook and Bryn Mawr, half of the latter team consisting of George J. Gould and his son, Kingdon Gould.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

LONDON, May 24. -- The Associated Press has every reason to believe that peace in South Africa is practically secured. How soon it will be announced depends, apparently, more upon the convenience of the Boer leaders than upon the inclination of the British Government.

Mr. Crockett's pen is so prolific that one's wonder is, not that he so often falls below his best, and falls by ways of copiousness in words and characters, but that he should in spite of these superfluities interest us in his story even if we skip some of its details.
LONDON, May 24. -- The Kingstown, St. Vincent, correspondent of The Daily Mail, cabling under date of May 22, says:

BALTIMORE, Md., May 23. -- The local market was steady to-day without being able to increase its activity. They buying, while slack, was sufficient in volume to make the tendency upward rather than downward. It is still difficult to stimulate any speculative interest, and that keeps the daily business record limited to a very few sales and price changes.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- At this writing the public of this city does not know what man or men have bought the Record. It was a matter of interest affecting all intelligent classes hero that so old and so capable a paper should have been sold at all; it has increased that interest a great deal that the purchasers should have maintained such secrecy as to their identity.

A new illustrated historical lecture has been added to his repertory by William Webster Ellsworth. It is on "Capt. John Smith and Old Virginia." John Smith has been the subject of many writers, and his life forms one of the most picturesque stories in American history. But of late years people have doubted many of the incidents which are recorded in his own narratives, notably the story of his rescue by Pocahontas.

I. Townsend Burden, the wealthy lawyer, who lives at 5 East Twenty-sixth Street, was arrested last night, after a lively chase, by a bicycle policeman, while he was speeding his automobile in Central Park West. Mr. Burden was taken to the West Sixty-eighth Street Station a prisoner, where Supreme Court Justice Francis M. Scott, who had been driving with him, furnished bail, so that Mr. Burden was at once released.

The Board of Estimate yesterday approved more bond issues than at any meeting during the administration of Mayor Low. The first business considered was the improvement of Willinck entrance to Prospect Park, Brooklyn. A delegation of 100 taxpayers, headed by Park Commissioner Young, favored the improvement.
By bunching their hits in the eighth and ninth innings of yesterday's baseball game, the Providence Eastern League team defeated the Jersey City nine by a score of 9 to 1.

"In dealing with books of this description," says Mr. T. Edgar Pemberton in the closing lines of his "Ellen Terry and Her Sisters," "conscientious censors sometimes say that they are replete with eulogy and offer little or no criticism." A censor who was as conscientious in his use of language as in his judgments would rather say that of all the resources of criticism Mr. Pemberton practices only eulogy.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day made public a petition presented by Miss Clemencia Lopez, a sister of Sixto Lopez, to the President for the release of three of her brothers of the Province of Batangas, who have been taken into custody by Gen. Bell and sent to the Island of Talim, where, she says, they are undergoing great hard- ships.

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, May 23. -- All is quiet here this morning. Yesterday passed quietly, and the population is becoming much calmer, especially as the volcano is gradually losing its terrifyingaspect.

BOSTON, May 23. -- One of the very first short stories ever written, called "Lost," was by Mr. Philander Deming, and appeared in the Atlantic Monthly in 1873, when Mr. Howells was editing the magazine, and adorning it with his excellent work. To-day Mr. Deming's manner seems subdued and conservative.
LONDON, May 23. -- A good demand for money and its scarcity stiffened rates today.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- An argument, which will be brought to the attention of Congress by those who desire the passage of the Cuban reciprocity bill, is that England and Germany are endeavoring to capture the Cuban trade; that foreign countries now possess the Cuban markets, and that this condition cannot be overcome except by a preferential tariff.

FORT DE FRANCE, May 22. -- The United States steamer Potomac made her usual trip to St. Pierre to-day with another party of scientists. She found the conditions there unchanged from yesterday. The top of the mountain was clearly visible for a considerable time.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- This was pension day in the House and the usual number of private pension bills were rushed through in the presence of the usual mere handful of Representatives, few of whom paid much attention to what was going on. At the beginning of the pension business, however, an unexpected diversion was created by Eugene F. Loud, (Rep., Cal.,) who made a short speech, attacking the whole private pension business.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 23. -- President Loubet, escorted by the French squadron, left Kronstadt this afternoon for France.

PARIS, May 23. -- A service for the repose of the souls of the victims of the volcanic outbreak in Martinique was held in Notre Dame to-day. Mme. Loubet. wife of the President; the Cabinet Minister's and their wives, the Senators, Deputies, and members of the Diplomatic Corps were among those present.

BOSTON, May 23. -- With a guard of policemen about the premises, the kosher meat stores of B. Solomont, at which serious disturbances occurred among the Hebrews yesterday, were in operation to-day. Everything was tranquil in the three localities, the North, South, and West Ends, where the Solomont stores are situated.

The following titles of books have been submitted by some of our readers in answer 10 "A Grateful Reader's" request for entertaining books appropriate for reading aloud in a "small circle, where the listeners are weary and want to hear something interesting and bright -- the funnier the better."

How long Paul and Barnabas remained in Antioch of Pisidia we are not informed, but it was long enough for "the word of the Lord" to be "published," or "spread abroad," (Revised Version.) "throughout all that region," (xiii., 48.) The substance of the address which we considered last week was evidently repeated over and over again.

EP. DUTTON CO. have just just published "Finland As It Is," by Harry De Windt, F.R.G.S., which tells of the author's travels through Finland, illustrated from photographs and drawings, and with special refenecc to Russification; also "The Early History of Venice," by F.C. Hodgson, M.A., with a topical index.

Apropos of the continued strength of Copper Trust and other copper stocks, it may be interesting to note that The Engineering and Mining Journal to-day will report that the copper market continues to improve, although advances are comparatively slow; that consumption here continues very large, while that on the other side is improving.

The death of Edwin L. Godkin removes not only a strong and influential journalist, but a journalist who had peculiarly close connection with literature. He was not only a literary journalist, but much, perhaps most, of his fame and influence were derived from a literary journal.

The most serious police problem now before Commissioner PARTRIDGE Is the prompt and complete suppression of such rioting as took place in Williamsburg on Thursday if that cannot be done his administration of his department will be a sad and disastrous failure.

By an odd coincidence two books on Morocco, brought out by Messrs. Longmans, Green Co., were both written by Englishwomen who traveled in Northern Africa for the first time last year, but although they both traveled through the same country, from Tangier to Morocco, all resemblance between their works ceases with the subject.

Mrs. Collis P. Huntington has given $100,000 to the General Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, at Central Park West and One Hundred and Sixth Street. The announcement was made in the report of President John E. Parsons of the hospital in the following language:

The athletes of the Adelphi Academy defeated the Polytechnic Preparatory School team in a dual athletic meeting at the Adelphi Field, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon by a score of 26 points for Adelphi to 14 for "Poly, Prep." Ten events were contested, first place counting 3 points and second place 1 point, with two competitors from each school.

A gentleman closely connected with the business of publishing made recently a few pertinent remarks about the chances of the unknown author in our time. He said: "The day of the supremacy of the well-known author, it would seem, is almost past. The young man with his first book, if that book be a good one, containing some genuine popular appeal, is very likely to outstrip his well-known and established rival.

The collection or the late Henry white, sold at Sotheby's April 21 May 2, 2,347 lots bringing u18,116 13s, was chiefly composed of early printed books, fine art works, and Illuminated manuscripts, and was very much like the libraries formed in the old days, when the specialist was unknown. The most Important book in the sale was the editio princeps of Homer, 1488, which was described as a good copy.

Carnegie Music Hall was filled last night at the forty-fourth anniversary and commencement exercises of the Packard Commercial School. Milton I. Southard, ex-President of the Ohio Society, presided, and 162 diplomas were handed to successful students by Superintendent Byron Horton of the school.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- There will be a diminutive gambol at the Chicago Athletic Club to-morrow night, when the Chicago members of the Lambs give a supper in honor of Shepherd De Wolf Hopper and the visiting members of the New York club.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 23. -- The first match in the intercollegiate cricket championship series was played to-day on the grounds of the Philadelphia Cricket Club between Harvard and the University of Pennsylvania and was won by the latter by the score of 158 to 118.

As the fighting legions of Rome held, good fortune is the first qualification of a soldier. To proclaim good fortune, therefore, as one of the most salient features in the life of Sir Harry Smith is not in any way to discount the military ability of the man, the untiring energy which, as it were, seized on success and held it fast; it is simply to show that Sir Harry rend his title clear.

Surprised by the police white making away with the proceeds of a daring burglary in East Harlem yesterday morning, one thief was shot and killed in a desperate runing fight during which dozens of bullets were exchanged, while two other men were cornered in a hallway after their ammunition had been expended and they had been beaten into submission.

The New York Times Saturday review of Books: Will you permit, me to call attention to a rather remarkable criticism vouchsafed by your reviewer of Mr. Howells's "The Kentons"? I refer to his objection to the book because there is not a, "lady or gentelman" in it this possibly sincere? "Ladies and gentlemen" are not promi- nent in many great stories, from the poems of Homer to the novels of Tolstol.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Military circles are buzzing with gossip to-day over two orders Issued by the President, and the general opinion is that both are blows at Lieut. Gen. Miles. The first rescinds the orders issued by President McKinley by which Gen. Miles became Acting Secretary of War whenever the Secretary and Assistant Secretary were away from Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Senator Hanna returned to Washington to-day from a visit to Philadelphia, where he went to attend a social function and not to arrange matters connected with the coal miners' strike.

WHEN, in September, 1901, Dartmouth College celebrated the centennial of Daniel Webster's graduation, the Trustees were fortunate in being able to call from the ranks of the Dartmouth alumni an orator for the day so well qualified as Mr. McCall proved himself in the event.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- Samuel Eberly Gross intends to follow up his victory over Edmund Rostand by suing in the English and French courts and proving there that the French author's play, "Cyrano," was pilfered from Mr. Gross's "Merchant Prince of Cornville." He also intends to write a new play with its plot laid in France and its hero a man resembling Francois Villon.

The recent anniversary of Dryden's death passed practically unnoticed by the great journals of his country. It was simultaneous with the publication of the present laureate's latest volume of verse, and with the sale in New York of an almost complete collection of the works of his great predecessor in the office, "Glorious John."
WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The Senate Committee on Judiciary to-day amended the Conspiracy bill passed by the House so as to read:

LONDON May 23. -- Doubt still exists as to who is to publish in America the Memoirs of Mme. Adam, begun about seven years ago, the first part of which dealing with the childhood and youth of Mile Julictte Lamber, is now ready.

Years have passed since Mr. Charles Major produced his inspiring work, "When Knighthood Was in Flowez." Historical novels have crept upon us. We have grown used to their banality. We have pilled, then embraced them. That fortunate inspiration which sold some hundreds of thousands of copies has entered into the hearts of many a lady desirous of great circulations, and these ladies have produced what seem like hundreds of thousands of books.
