The first three volumes of the Vale Press Shelley have recently been issued in a small and beautifully modern edition, bound in a grayish white cloth, on which the title and volume number are shown in gold. The volumes are entirely without other ornament than lettering, which is perhaps too plain and too small: not standing out sufficiently clear to differentiate these volumes from others on the shelves.

LONDON, May 24. -- The Spectator, in a lengthy article on "How the German Emperor Might Win the United States," begins by paying a tribute to Emperor William's capabilities as a statesman, but declares that he has never yet arrived at a clear understanding of the American people.

BERLIN, May 23. -- Miss Clara Barton, President of the American National Red Cross, and Benjamin Tillinghast are here on their way to St. Petersburg to attend the International Red Cross Congress, which convenes on May 29. The Russian Government has arranged for luxurious free railroad transportation from the Russian border for Miss Barton and the other delegates to the Congress.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 23. -- Peace rumors from the anthracite districts should be accepted with caution. President Mitchell says he knows of no movement in that direction. No forecast is possible and no information as to plans of either side can be had from any one speaking by authority. Rumors are plenty, but impossible of verification.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- In the Senate to-day the Philippine Government bill was taken up, and Mr. Dubois, (Idaho,) one of the minority members of the Philippine committee, addressed the Senate in opposition to the present policy of the Government in the Philippines.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 23. -- The luncheon given to-day on board the French battleship Gaulois in honor of President Roosevelt was one of the most memorable incidents of the visit of the distinguished French soldleis and sailors to this country, who are here to Join in the celebration of the unveiling of the monument to the memory of Gen. Rochambeau, which takes place in Washington to-morrow.

Only by the prompt action of the Moderator, Dr. Henry Van Dyke, was what promised to be a lively debate in the Presbyterian Assembly cut short yesterday morning. The Committee on Bills and Overtures submitted a report through the Rev. Dr. William R. Taylor recommending that no action be taken upon a resolution referred to that committee memorializing Congress not to authorize the publication of Thomas Jefferson's "Life of Christ" at public expense.

The ping-pong handicap of the Strollers' Club, open to members only, will start with eighty entries. There are first, second, and consolation prizes. The first prize is a loving cup presented by Stroller Robert C. Watson, Jr. The second prize is also a cup presented by Stroller Lindsley Tappin.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- The languor in the New York market extended to this city, and it was the quietest day in a long time. Readings declined to 31, but later there was a slight recovery. Local brokers have a story to the effect that Reading is to be supported at 30 in the event of a decline owing to the coal troubles.

MEMORIES of the American Revolution, whose incidents are forever forcing themselves upon our attention, were recalled with marked distinctness by the notable event which took place yesterday in Washington. The particular part of that struggle made pre-eminent was the friendship of France, as expressed in its military and naval aid during the closing years of the war.

Notwithstanding the warmth of the evening Cooper Union was crowded with an enthusiastic gathering to listen to the concert and speeches given under the auspices of the Attereth Zion and the Sisters of Attereth Zion. The auditorium was filled with young women and men, most of their elders remaining at home to leave room for them.

Greetings from the Methodist Episcopal Church were conveyed to the Presbyterian General Assembly at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday morning by Senator Albert J. Beveridge of Indiana and the Rev. Dr. J.M. Buckley, editor of The Christian Advocate. Senator Beveridge, among other things, said:

RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 24. -- Electrically equipped and fitted with all other modern improvements was an alleged illicit distilling plant which was raided here yesterday by Col. William. G. Thompson, United States Internal Revenue Agent; his Deputy Marshal, and several other Government agents.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 24. -- The Commissioners of the Presbyterian General Assembly and many representatives of the Presbyterian churches of New York visited Princeton to-day to witness the unveiling of a tablet commemorating the connection of the founding of Princeton with the Synods of New York and New Jersey and as the successor of the famous Log College of the Tennents.

BERLIN, May 24. -- Prices were firm on the Boerse to-day in anticipation of peace in South Africa. Banks were active. Deutsche-Bank was in good demand, and Disconto Gesellschaft advanced on the dissolution of the underwriting syndicate for issuing new shares. Governments were irregular. Canadian Pacifies improved, in response to New York.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24. -- This was the dullest day of the year in the Philadelphia market, and a number of prominent stocks were without a quotation. Small declines, due to inactivity, ruled throughout the list. Lehigh Valley went off 9/8, but Reading was kept up to yesterday's close by the steadiness in New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For years Herbert Spencer has been in the world as a great intellectual force, but to me it is very pathetic to see a man of his noble qualities near the threshold of eternity and yet all at sea on the greatest of questions that confront humanity.

HAZELTON, Penn., May 24. -- President Duffy of the United Mine Workers' organization of this district to-day notified the owners of the Dusky Diamond Colliery at Beaver Brook and Matthias Schwabe, operator of a small mine at South Heberton, which furnishes coal for domestic use, to close down until after the strike.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial headed "Morals Painted" in to-day's Issue of THE TIMES Is truly refreshing. The statements of various ministers since the recent volcanic outbreak in the West Indies would almost convince one that these "know-it-alls" were each and every one occupying the position of confidential secretary in the employ of the Being whom they refer to as the "Lord Almighty."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 24. -- The delightful weather of the past week has brought many visitors to the shore, and now the crowds are as great as during the forepart of the busy Summer season of former years.

The Harlem River was well patronized with the oarsmen of the various clubs yesterday, and the continued warm weather enabled the crews in training to add to the finishing touches being now put on for the big regatta to be held here, on Friday.

PREPARATIONS are being made at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for a pilgrimage of students in the department of industrial chemistry to the big manufacturing plants in the vicinity of Philadelphia and Newark. N.J. The plan is an example of the growing co-operation between the practical manufacturing establishments and the modern technical schools which are preparing a younger generation to take future places in them.
WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Lord Pauncefote, British Ambassador to the United States, died at the Embassy this morning at 5:35 o'clock.
BRYN MAWR, Penn., May 24. -- Bryn Mawr College announces that there has been collected or pledged to date $209,000 of the $250.000 that must be raised by June 5.

CHICAGO, May 24.--An exile from his home in Kentucky for thirty-eight years for fear of an avenging band, Felix G. Stidger found mercy at the hands of Judge Kohlsaat yesterday for the part he took in breaking up the "Knights of the Golden Circle" in the civil war. The defendant had just pleaded guilty to an indictment charging him with having written improper letters to persons in Crawfordsville and Goshen, Ind.

Rockaway triumphed over the Buffalo polo team yesterday on the field of the Meadow Brook Club by the decisive score of 10 1/2 goals to 4 1/2. The winning team save the Buffalo men three goals by handicap allowance. P.F. Collier did not play, and his place as back on the Rockaway team was taken by W.B. Rand, one of the younger set In the Rockaway Club, but he played a very creditable game.

OTTAWA, May 24. -- An important conference took place here this week between representatives of the Dominion Government and representatives of a number of the provinces in respect to the Canadian fisheries. Until a few years ago it was generally understood that the fisheries belonged to the Dominion, and were exclusively under the control of the Federal Parliament.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to say a word in reply to the letter in your issue of May 18, signed "C.L.B."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The dismissal of Emil Paur from the conductorship of the Philharmonic Society -- for it is a dismissal, and nothing less -- and the election of Mr. Walter Damrosch to that position seems to me a plain slap in the face at the real musical public of this town.
WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The following cablegram has been received at the Navy Department from Capt. McLean of the Cincinnati, dated St. Lucia to-day:

Within easy recollection the purchase of English consols by a syndicate of American bankers was a rare event. This week there have been purchases of consols by private buyers in the New York market upon a liberal scale. This entirely novel fact has been accompanied by sales of United States bonds at relaxing prices.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial on Senator Hoar's speech on the Philippines in to-day's issue of THE TIMES, you give the impression that Senator Hoar ignores the obligation incurred by the United States to restore and maintain order in those islands after Spain had been driven out.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I hope you will allow me a short space to express my dissent from your views which I find in your issue of to-day with reference to Mr. Carnegie's offer to Mr. McKinley to pay $20,000,000 to Spain for the purpose of enabling the Filipinos to try their experiment at self-government.

HOW is a charming little engraving of a house for the heading of one's Summer note paper? That is what one New Yorker has had reproduced upon thin paper, the house making a picture at once attractive and unique.
The following table shows the amount of surplus reserve held by the Clearing House banks at the end of each week in the present year and the corresponding dates in 1901 and 1900:

Conrad S. Keyes, law partner of Borough President J. Edward Swanstrom, was detected by Justice MacLean in the Supreme Court yesterday morning in the act of speaking to a juryman about a case in which he appeared as counsel. The Justice instantly put the case back upon the calendar for a retrial.

IT was a schoolboy who defined a street as "the shortest distance between two points." He could not possibly have had Pearl Street in mind when he mixed up the definitions of a street and a straight line, for in its windings and twistings and turnings this tortuous thoroughfare of old New York outrivals all the crooked streets that bewilder one who gets off Broadway in the region about and below the City Hall.

IT IS now more than a month since the will of Cecil Rhodes became public property, and while the whole document has come in for its share of attention and comment, it is not too much to say that general interest, both here and abroad, has been chiefly centred on the educational bequests.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., May 24. -- The shutdown or the big anthracite collieries has already been felt in the coke region and both production and tonnage are hurrying skyward. All the plants of the region are running six days per week, and the railroads are worried to keep up the car supply.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some years ago two colonies of Jews emigrated from Palestine in two separate sailing vessels. One party set out to the westward, and by way of Spain and the Atlantic Ocean reached New York. The other sailed eastward, and by way of India and the Pacific Ocean continued around South America, and finally reached New York also.

MRS. DALLAS BACHE PRATT, who was the hostess of a recent coaching party that went out to Ardsley on the Pioneer, tooled by Alfred Vanderbilt, was in a green and white ctriped costume. The material was a light wool, too heavy for veiling. The very pale leaf green stripes were a quarter of an inch wide and the white ones perhaps a sixteenth across.

LONDON, May 24. -- The first news of the death of Lord Pauncefote, the British Ambassador at Washington, this morning, was conveyed by a representative of The Associated Press to the British Foreign Office and the United States Embassy.

During the early part of last week trading in the outside market was within very narrow lines, and less interest was shown than at any lime within recent weeks. Later, however, the market broadened considerably, and a number of stocks were dealt in, the transactions at times reaching fairly large totals.
TUXEDO PARK, May 24. -- The warm weather of Saturday and Sunday forced a good crowd of New Yorkers to occupy their cottages, and all rooms at the clubhouses were taken during the week.

Despite sensational reports, including the representation of a war with the Pennsylvania Railroad, Western Union Telegraph stock has not acted as though anything very serious had happened to affect its present large earnings. Breaking 90 is nothing new for the stock, steady 5 per cent. dividend payer though it be, for it has done that every year since the rate named became a steady thing in 1888.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 24. -- The Weld crew of Harvard University this afternoon defeated the cadet eight of the Naval Academy over the two-mile course on the Severn by half a length. The "Middles" rowed a great race, and were only beaten by a margin of time. The contest was the last in the schedule of the Naval Academy rowing season.

AT THIS season of the year Central Park is at its best. Not only inviting as a place in which to sit and rest, to walk or drive, the great wealth of plant life, both native and foreign, offers to the eye and mind vast stores or Knowledge interesting and useful as well as satisfying.

SUCH an enormous quantity of rice is now being planted in the Southern seaboard States where suitable stretches of land for its cultivation exist as to call attention to the importance which rice has assumed among the cereal crops. This is due to several causes, chief of which is the care taken by the Government to foster and enlarge the scope of this industry.

LONDON, May 24. -- This is, musically speaking, particularly a season of violinists, and in view of the vogue of Kubelik, Kocian, and Kreisler it is particularly interesting to hear of one more public appearance of the famous Wilhelmj, who will use a splendid Guarnerius violin he has just obtained.

THAT explorer who penetrates to the interior of one of the Syrian restaurants down on Rector or Washington Street will encounter a suave and smiling proprietor, who will present him the menu card with a flourish. The menu looks exactly as if it were written in shorthand, only up and down the page instead of across.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The tenor of your recent editorial, "The Mayor on Non-Enforcement" suggests bias rather than the conservative temperament of THE TIMES. No act of Seth Low has been actuated by higher motives than his letter to Commissioner Partridge urging a liberal construction of certain Sunday laws in the Jewish localities during Passover.
HAVANA, May 20. -- Once in a lifetime it is permitted to some people to see the beginnings of a new nation; to many not even that one time is given. We who are in Havana to-day are among the "some."

The best of college athletic material will be seen in this city next week and during Friday and Saturday of that week will contest in the annual games of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America at Berkeley Oval.

Golf and hilarity reigned supreme yesterday on the links of the Knollwood Country Club, near White Plains. The sixth annual handicap golf tournament of the Stock Exchange members was played there, and, as is always the case when this memorable event is in progress, a large delegation of Wall Street brokers went up to the course to see the fun.

M. Edmond Bruwaert, the French Consul General in this city, has received from the Paris courts copies of the warrant for the arrest of the Humberts, whose schemes to get money from European money lenders and bankers were so cleverly conceived that they managed before being detected to procure from one source or another no less than $12,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have followed with a good deal of interest the discussion going on in your valuable paper relative to the subject of what is termed by your various correspondents, "Oatmeal," and I desire to enter a protest as to the matter of nomenclature.

PARIS, May 24. -- All the morning and evening papers publish good cable accounts of the Rochambeau festival at Washington, and many of them print a picture of the statue. The Patrie has an Illustrated article, which also shows the Yorktown Monument and the State, War, and Navy Department Building at Washington.

FOO-CHOW, April 25. -- Foreign airs are less assertive at this capital of Fo-Kien Province than at Amoy and elsewhere along the southern borders, and the white and yellow races have always lived in amity hereabouts, even when fanatics were massacring Christians in the neighboring province of Che-Kiang, which is in this vice-regal territory.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 24. -- The Massasolt, designed by Crowninshield of Boston for the Bridgeport Yacht Club as one of the candidates to be selected to go to Canada this Summer and fight for the recovery of the Seawanhaka Cup held by the Royal St. Lawrence Yacht Club, met with an accident off Greenwich last night in one of those sudden squalls that frequent Long Island Sound.

-- When Bishop BRENT, on the eve of starting for the Philippines, made his fare-well address, he seemed to join the necessary with the unnecessary horrors of war in a common condemnation that excited a little apprehension in some quarters as to the cordiality of his future relations with the civil and military authorities of the islands.

A Washington man claims the invention of a stove for the production of cold which will keep the air of an apartment at the temperature of a fine day in Autumn or simulate the pleasant chill of Winter, no matter what the thermometer may be saying to the contrary outside.

The fearful loss of life at Martinique and the suddenness of the destruction seem mysterious to most people, and are scareely to be accounted for by any of the text books relating to volcanic phenomena.
Citizens of Illinois have contributed thus far a little over $40,000 of the $50,000 assigned to that State for the McKinley National Monument Fund.

Edward R. Thomas, the last President of the Seventh National Bank and son of Gen. Samuel Thomas, was riding west through East Forty-fourth Street last evening in his immense red automobile with his wife, brother-in-law, Mr. Otter, and chauffeur, when the party was attacked by a mob of one hundred boys between Second and Third Avenues, and severely dealt with.

LONDON, May 24. -- The American polo players defeated a Hurlingham team today by six to two goals. The Englishmen, Hazeltlne, Shepherd, Thyme, and Hobson, were a weak aggregation. J.E. Cowdin of the American team, was struck in the mouth by the ball in the first five minutes. He sustained a bad cut and had to retire.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The French Ambassador and Mme. Cambon entertained at a large reception this evening, complimentary to Gen. Brugere of the French Army and the officers accompanying him to the unveiling of the Rochambeau statue. The interior of the embassy was splendidly adorned, a background of handsome silk flags of France and America throwing into relief the huge trees of American Beauty roses and white peonies, which formed the principal floral decorations.

It was again uncomfortable yesterday in this city from a heat standpoint. As in the case of Friday, the thermometer started on its skyward flight early In the morning and continued to ascend until 4:15 o'clock In the afternoon, when it reached a maximum of 84 degrees, which was 4 degrees less than the highest temperature registered on Friday.

The British Diplomatic Service hag never lacked able and faithful servants. The system in which they are trained tends to attract and tends to develop them. We have often found this out to our cost, when untrained Americans, who owed their places to the political necessity of doing something for them, have encountered trained Britons in the outlying parts of the world.

In a recent contract for structural steel delivery was not guaranteed for five months -- a condition of affairs which, in connection with the advanced stage of the real estate season, if it may so be termed, readily accounts for the cessation of that class of purchases preliminary to extensive building projects.

A well-dressed young man who said he was John Endres of 2 Vandervoort Street, Brooklyn, was caught after a long chase early yesterday morning and after a policeman had emptied his revolver Grins at him. The prisoner had tried to rob the grocery of Mrs. Lucy Munson, who lives at 148 Leonard Street.

Nurses in the infant's Hospital on the north end of Randall's Island at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon saw a boy who was evidently trying to hide himself behind the rocks along the shore. After watching his movements for a few minutes they telephoned the circumstances to Superintendent Omar V. Sage of the House of Refuge, or prison for boys, at the lower part of the Island.

LONDON, May 24. -- There was the usual Saturday's slackness of demand for money to-day. Discounts were steady. On the stock Exchange conjectures and rumors were rife. In the absence of a clue to the nature of the Cabinet proceedings, the views as to the prospects of immediate peace were conflicting, but there was a general feeling of hopefulness.

Signs of Summer are in the air with the announcement that the Paradise Roof Garden, on the Victoria and Repuplic Theatres, is to be opened for the season tomorrow night. Oscar Hammerstein adds that in carrying out the new orders of the Building Department the garden is now a solid steel and concrete construction, with no less than eight exits and two large elevators.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: The frequency of such catastrophies as related in Monday's TIMES, where, on the 18th inst., in the City of Toledo. Ohio, a girl was run down and killed by a sprinting mobile, inspired, and would seem to justify, a few suggestions from a friend of and firm believer in mechanical, in preference to animal, traction.

Albert Schweisshelm of 56 Jackson Street, Hoboken, was arraigned before Recorder Stanton yesterday charged with having forged notes to the amount of 230,000f. He is said to be the leader of a gang of foreign swindlers who operated extensively until their crimes were discovered, when they fled to this country.

LONDON, May 24. -- Lewanika, King of Barotseland, (or Northwestern Rhodesia,) the only King who will be present at the coronation of King Edward, arrived from his vast territory in South Africa to-day. His appearance is one of many signs of the approaching completion of the coronation arrangements.

Twelve husky Seneca Indian lacrosse players from the Cattaraugus Reservation, up near Buffalo, who came down to Bay Ridge yesterday looking for paleface scalps, met with a warm reception and a sad disappointment, for the expert players at the Crescent Athletic Club defeated their dark-skinned opponents as easily as they would down a college team, and so added another to their already long and unbroken string of victories.

Though yesterday's stock market was comparatively dull, it was nevertheless decidedly strong, with practically every important change for the day on the side of advancing prices. Canadian Pacific, for instance, sold up three points to a new high record, while its associated stocks, such as Duluth, South Shore, and Sault Ste. Marie also advanced; Illinois Central rose a point, and St. Paul, Rock Island, Wabash, and Union Pacific were likewise strong.

CLEVELAND, May 24. -- The Pennsylvania and Mahoning Valley Railway Company was organized by Col. Myron T. Herrick, James Parmelee, and Benjamin F. Miles of this city, who own a controlling interest in the combined properties. The capital stock of $8,000,000 is divided into $3,000,000 5 per cent. preferred and $5,000,000 common stock.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Oliver J. Hughes, United States Consul General at Coburg, Germany, has transmitted to the State Department at Washington a communication regarding gutta percha. In this he says:

IN an out-of-the-way railroad station of a Winter's evening, some twenty passengers were seated around the stove. It was an enforced delay. The conductor had said: "There's some trouble about a bridge six miles ahead, and it's got to be looked into. We may be hung up for an hour or two.

The Coal Stocks. The striking feature of the movement of the coal stocks during the week has been the confident buying in those shares and the steady refusal of the Street to be at all alarmed over the situation. This has been forcibly Illustrated by the advance of practically all of the issues to a higher level, with Lackawanna in one day appreciating no less than 10 points.

Mr. James S.H. Umsted, editor of The New York News Bureau, contributes to current security market criticism a significant review -- making the point that many quoted values are based upon natural expectation that the non-dividend stock of to-day will become the dividend payer of to-morrow, as the dividend payer of to-day was the non-dividend stock of yesterday.

On his first appearance at a banquet of the Royal Academy the young Prince of WALES deplored the fact, which he had picked up in Australia, that the art students of that important colony do not go to London for their education, but to Paris. He suggested that special inducements might be offered them to break their journey and complete their art studies in London.

At West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday the home baseball team defeated providence in the third game of their series by a score of 10 to 6. Woods was knocked out of the box in the third inning. McCann relieved him and held the Providence players down to two hits in the remaining six innings. The score:

Senator Thomas C. Platt was in a happy frame of mind yesterday. He talked politics with many people, and for the first time expressed satisfaction at the outlook for the Republican State ticket this Fall. The troubles in Tammany Hall have interested and pleased Senator Platt, and he made predictions about Richard Croker and Tammany politics.

Many of those interested in the outward market were away from the market yesterday, and the result appeared in a considerable lessening in activity. Prices, however, were firm and most of the day's changes were on the side of gains. In one or two stocks there was considerable show of life giving to these issues places of much more prominence than was assumed by the list in general.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Hoar's speech, as reported in today's TIMES, is interesting as a fine rhetorical effort rather than as a profound states-manlike document. He simply rings the changes on that generality of the Declaration of Independence that all just Governments must depend on the consent of the governed, as if it were an absolute universal principle.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The light vein and delicate, humorous touch in your editorial Topics of the Times are Simpkins, Secretary of the Special Embassy to the Coronation of Alfonso is altogether admirable.
SILAS LARRABEE believes old men do the world a vast deal more of good than they generally are credited with doing.

The past week has given fresh evidence of the evolution that is taking place in the railroad circles of the United States. The financial columns of Sunday and Monday last were blue and dubious, while the men of brain and courage, quietly observing the great natural factors at work, began buying Monday noon and continued so the whole week.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The second of the notable events marking the good will of European nations toward the United States took place to-day in Lafayette Square, where the statue of Rochambeau was unveiled. The popular interest was as great as in Prince Henry's visit, and in addition there was an enthusiasm which was frequently awakened by reference to France's former services to the United States.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 24. -- I learned to-day from well-informed representatives of the mine-owning interests that plans are fully matured for making the order calling out the engineers, firemen, and pumpmen, June 2, the first decisive defeat for the strike management. Nothing which may occur on that date or afterward will take the operators by surprise.

PITTSBURG, May 24. -- Nixon Zimmerman, who own the Alvin Theatre in this plan to erect another playhouse of elaborate proportions. The architect is working on the new Pittsburg house, on which work is to begin Sept. 1, 1902. It is proposed to have it completed for the opening in the Fall of 1903, and "Blue Beard," from Drury Lane, has been booked, to be followed by Irving and other English companies.

BERLIN; May 24. -- An odd misunderstanding has arisen from a conversation which Adjt. Gen. von Plessen had with Adjt. Gen. Corbin when Admiral Prince Henry of Prussia visited Washington. Gen. von Plessen said, courteously:

Unfavorable weather yesterday caused the postponement of the Brooklyn-Cincinnati National League baseball contest at Cincinnati and almost led to a similar result in Chicago, where a game was played after a fall of rain. In almost every other section or the country, however, League and college games were played in abundance, the conditions proving favorable.

"Oh, Mister, don't hurt me," were the last words uttered last night by five-year-old George Bennett of 526 West Thirtieth Street, after he had been knocked down and fatally injured by a truck when the driver picked him up, tenderly enough, to carry him home. The accident occurred in front of 512 West Thirtieth Street.

LONG BRANCH, May 24. -- The work of putting the Hollywood Golf Club links in order is rapidly making headway. Superintendent Lloyd expects to have the grounds ready for play not later than June 1. An artesian well will be driven in a few days at the new clubhouse. Bernard Nichols has been engaged by the club as golf instructor.

The United States has oustripped other nations in the application of electric power to street and suburban railways. While the Germans have been active in the development of electric service, they have not been so progressive in applying their improvements to practical uses. The statistics of operation of all the electric roads in cities with a population of 30,000 and upward in this country make an interesting table, from which valuable deductions can be made.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to reply to the letter of "S.S. B.," which appeared in THE TIMES on Sunday, May 10, and which purported to be a reply to two letters called forth by his letter that appeared in THE TIMES of April 28.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letters you are publishing daily prompt me also to write, asking you to please give this wider publicity to an earnest appeal which was made to the Woman's Christian Temperance Union at their annual convention just closed, by a lady in no way connected with that organization.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 24. -- The United States troopship Buford has arrived from Manila and Honolulu, thirty-one days from the Philippines and nine days from the Hawaiian port. She brought 150 members of the Third Cavalry. 650 "casuals," and 124 discharged men. She had 65 passengers in her saloon.
ROME, May 24. -- The Pope to-day received in audience the Right Rev. Camillus Paul Maes, Bishop of Covington, Ky.

PARIS, May 24. -- A largely attended Franco-American banquet was held at the Hotel Continental this evening. The reception room was ornamented with portraits of Washington, Rochambeau, and Roosevelt, surrounded by French and American flags, and by a model of the Rochambeau statue.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a TIMES reader largely because of its appreciative and intelligent attitude on art matters and its particular interest in American art.
Ryerson Hall have been appointed Newark agents of the Aachen and Munich Insurance, Company of Germany.

Trouble started anew on the east side last night. Several kosher butchers' shops were attacked by excited men and women, and persons who attempted to buy meat were severely dealt with. Capt. Walsh of the Eldridge Street Station was compelled to send out several squads of policemen to disperse the crowds.

Although the local yachting season does not formally open until Decoration Day, enough is already known of the boats that will be in commission to indicate the character of the coming racing season. Generally speaking, the gracing will be largely among the small boats. With two or three exceptions, the classes for the larger boats will be very barren.

There is an apparently hopelessly insane boy chained in the kitchen of Mrs. Robert Scott, 214 Monroe Street, Hoboken. His parents are very poor and have a large family to care for. They are forced to Keep the boy tied to the wall, for there is the constant danger that he may harm himself or the other children.

The largest crowd that ever witnessed a horse race in the history of existing race tracks in New York yesterday saw Albert Featherstone's filly Reina, at 40 to 1, break through tradition at the Gravesend track by winning the $10,000 Brooklyn Handicap, after one of the most sensational contests for the big prize that has occurred in the sixteen years that it has been run.

PRINCETON. N.J., May 24. -- The University of California defeated Princeton today in the second annual dual track meet by 7 points to 6, first placers only being counted. California made their points in the sprints and short events, while the Tigers counted in the weights and distances.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 24. -- Harvard and Yale held a record-breaking meet today, in which the Crimson triumphed over the Blue by a score of 61 1/2 points to 42 1/2. The weather was perfect and everything favored the fastest time.

MAY 30 is Memorial Day, the day when pious hands the country over will place floral tributes upon the graves of the dead of the civil war. The following version of the origin of the custom is told by a veteran who wore the blue.

The most striking and significant feature of the money market in the week just passed was the gradual relaxation in rates, the tendency being steadily down-ward. At the same time it was commented upon as of some consequence that despite this downward tendency the sterling exchange market not only did not go up, but, rather, actually went lower.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Please allow me space to enter a protest against what all true Americans must consider the most un-American act of any administration, namely, the acceptance of the statue of Frederick the Great.
ST. THOMAS, D.W.I., May 24. -- The Norwegian steamer Helga, Gapt. Braastad, is here discharging cargo. In an interview this morning Capt. Braastad said:

BALTIMORE, May 24. -- The report that George R. Webb, Vice President of the United Railways, would become President of the nine-million-dollar street railway consolidation, embracing Norfolk and all cities and towns on Hampton Roads, is denied. The official slate is: President -- R. Lancaster Williams of Richmond, Va.; Vice President -- William J. Payne of Newport News, Va.; General Manager -- E.C. Hathaway of Baltimore.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 24. -- Three engagements of interest to New Yorkers have been announced in Baltimore during the past week. The first is that of Miss Jean McComb Albert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Albert, to Dr. Thomas Richardson Brown. Miss Albert is one of the most attractive debutantes of the season in Baltimore.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

A CORRESPONDENT telegraphed the news of an important baseball game played in a Western city to a New York paper. Here is the story of one inning taken from his account which appeared next morning in print:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noticed in to-day's issue of your esteemed paper that Congressman Watson of Indiana, during the debate on the Immigration bill, declared that he was In favor of the exclusion of Italians. Hungarians, and Russian Jews, by means of an educational test, as they are the people that fill our Jails and eleemosynary Institutions.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 24. -- Harry Oelrichs, younger brother of Hermann and C.M. Oelrichs, is seriously ill at his cottage here. He has been an invalid for many years, dividing his time between Newport in Winters and Jamestown in Summer, but practically confined to his bed.

THANKFUL thoughts for the end of May; we are nearly past the season of pen and pencil pictures of forlorn May moving scenes. When will mere man learn that the great moving season in the metropolis is in the Fall? It is a fallacy which dies as hard as the belief in the Easter bonnet parade.

The Innovation of prearranged Saturday afternoon brushes on the Speedway, under the auspices of the Road Drivers' Association, was tried yesterday afternoon. Although the managers fixed a day for the event, which they afterward discovered to be inopportune, since It proved to be the day of the Brooklyn Handicap, the horses ran before thousands of men and women who flecked the western bluffs of the Harlem River Driveway.

The Municipal Board of Elections has called upon District Attorney Jerome for assistance in exposing fraudulent work in connection with the coming primaries. This work has consisted, the board thinks, in filing bogus enrollment and transfer certificates in order to pass the official primary rolls and permit voting upon the names thus enrolled.

The first of the big open tournaments begins to-morrow on the courts of the Bachelors' Glub, Washington, D.C., the event being the Southern championship. This meeting has invariably ushered in the sea-son following the collegiate tournaments, and has always been remarkable for the number of New York entries in both the singles and doubles.

Controller Grout and Louis F. Haffen, President of the Borough of the Bronx, have become involved in a war of words over the alleged discrimination against the Borough of the Bronx by Controller Grout, who is from Brooklyn. An article appeared in a Bronx newspaper, supporting President Haffen, in which there was a severe attack on Controller Grout, and he was called the "High Priest of Obstruction" of the Low administration.

The Congregationalists have four theological schools in New England -- Banger with twenty-three students, Andover with fourteen, Hartford with eighty-one, and Yale with ninety-six. The four schools are giving instruction to 214 persons, including post-graduates and those pursuing special courses.

Over 200 Catholic students at Columbia University have organized a religious society which will be known as the Newman Club and will be affiliated with a similar organization of the same name at the University of Pennsylvania.

IN THE present era of industrial activity comparatively little is heard of the whale fishery, which formerly ranked among the most extensive of American enterprises. Indeed, most persons are accustomed to regard it as a thing of the past, associated with "fish oil" lamps and spermaceti candles.

Only two of the Bridgeport Challenge Seawanhaka Cup trial boats, Seeress and Nutmeg, appeared In the Spring regatta of the New Rochelle Yacht Club that was sailed yesterday afternoon, and the Seeress won. The Massasoit, owned by a syndicate of Bridgeport yachtsmen headed by Commodore Thomas H. Maodonald, was expected, but was wrecked on her way down from Bridgeport Friday night.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24. -- The dual athletic meet between Cornell and Pennsylvania on Franklin Field to-day was won by the Ithacans by the score of 67 to 50 points. Cornell scored a majority of her points in the one-mile run, the high hurdle, and the field events. The eligibility of Baird, Orton, and Baillie was Questioned by Cornell, but Baird only was prevented from competing.

The venerable master of Dutch painting Josef Israels and the marine painter H.M. Mesdag have sent out hurry calls to their brother artists in Europe and America to contribute works for an International charity exhibition at The Hague during the months of June, July, and August.

NEWARK, N.J., May 25 -- Mrs. Jane O'Hare, fifty-eight years old, of 151 Summit Street, and Thomas F. Craven, fifty-one years old, who has lived at her home or a number of years, occupy adjoining cells in the Fourth Precinct Station. The charge against Mrs. O'Hare is that she shot Craven last night, and he is held as a witness agains her.
At no time of the day yesterday did the temperature reach the point registered on Saturday, although the humidity kept up its work of wilting collars and causing other kinds of discomfort.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 25 -- The bridge of the Pennsylvania Railroad across the Raritan River and the draw at the western end of the bridge over the Delaware and Raritan Canal were moved this afternoon to make room for a new stone bridge. Preparations for the moving of the steel bridge have been under way for more than three months.

If the careful speech of Senator DUBOIS on the Philippines bill is analyzed, the substance of the difference between his view and that of the majority appears to be the difference between a promise of independence and a promise of self-government made to the Filipinos.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 25 -- This was the quietest Sabbath in the Wyoming region since the miners' strike began. The circular which President Mitchell sent out yesterday warning the Polish, Slavic, and Lithuanian miners to remain away from the bituminous region of Virginia and West Virginia, where strikes are now in progress, was read in many of the churches where the foreign miners attend services.

PARIS, Mo., May 25 -- Abe Witherup, the murderer of William Grow, who was killed last month, was taken from the Paris jail at 12 o'clock this morning, marched to the bridge on the north edge of town, and hanged by a mob of more than 100 men, who rode quietly into town at midnight.

Many are the odds and ends which drift into the shops devoted to old furniture, bric-a-brac, and the like. Much, of course, is junk, and much, too, is of the bogus antique order. Every now and then, however, something really fine pops up. Thus, the other day, a genuine small specimen of Adriaen van Ostade turned up, a little canvas once part of the Gouverneur Kembie estate.

The Tammany harmony programme received another set-back yesterday, when members of the Passaconnowa Club, composed of Democrats in the Thirty-fifth Assembly District, made an attack on Louis F. Haffen, one of the triumvirate selected by Tammany to direct its affairs since the resignation, of Lewis Nixon.

MANILA, May 25 -- Gen. Chaffee, the reviewing authority of the court-martial which tried Major L.W.T. Waller and Lieut. John H.A. Day. of the Marine Corps, for executing natives of the Island of Samar without trial, has disapproved the court's findings in both cases. Referring to the case of Major Waller, Gen. Chaffee says:

After long and extremely careful deliberation, the Virginia Constitutional Convention has agreed upon a new Constitution which, as a whole, is a very satisfactory document. Its interest for the people of other States naturally centres in the amended sections relative to the elective franchise.

KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, May 24 -- Another volcanic eruption on the night of Sunday, May 18, caused a greater fall of ashes and stones and more consternation at Chateau Belair, St. Vincent, than resulted from the eruption of May 7.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Daniel Hill, a wealthy real estate owner and partner in the firm of the George H. Phillips Company on the Chicago Board of Trade, was shot and seriously wounded early to-day as he lay in bed at his residence, 797 Monroe Street, Six shots were fired, three taking effect, one behind the left ear, one entering his nose, and the other shattering his right arm.

Services in memory of the Nation's soldier dead were held yesterday in many of the churches of Booklyn. The graves of soldiers in the varioiis local cemeteries were also decorated with flowers during the day by the war veterans' associations and kindred organizations in the borough. In several of the cemeteries memorial, exercises were held under the auspices of Grand Army posts.

The Montgomery (Ala.) Advertiser announces that the Southern Education Board, of which Mr. ROBERT C. OGDEN is President, has appointed as its representative in that State the Hon. JOSEPH B. GRAHAM of Talladega, of whom The Advertiser speaks in high terms. He has been connected with education in the State for many years, and was Chairman of the committee on that subject in the late Constitutional Convention.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The members of the French Mission, which came to Washington to attend the ceremonies incident to the unveiling of the Rochambeau Statue, finished their visit here to-day, and to-night left the city for Niagara Falls on their week's tour of the East before sailing for home.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 25 -- With the impressive ceremony of the Catholic Church the new memorial church at Spring Lake, erected by Martin Maloney, a Philadelphia millionaire, in memory of his daughter Catharine, was consecrated to-day by Bishop McFaul and several of the dignitaries of the diocese of Philadelphia.

A fresh batch of complaints against the present city administration were made by dissatisfied delegates at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union, following a report by its Arbitration Committee. The report stated that Contractor Canavan, who is excavating for the city along Eighth Avenue, will have nothing to do with organized labor and pays no attention to the eight-hour or prevailing rate of wages laws.

WICHITA, Kan., May 25 -- North bound Santa Fe passenger train No. 406, which arrived here this noon, had a narrow escape from a cyclone's fury. For twelve miles Engineer Watts raced from the storm. He barely kept the train ahead, and upon arriving at Winfield he and Fireman Johnson were so nervous and exhausted that they had to be assisted from their cab.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25 -- John Stepurack, who has been living on Temple Street, this city, and the woman he married fourteen years ago in Hungary, have been reunited after a separation lasting a dozen years.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- From present indications the Senate will devote another full week, if not a longer time, to consideration of the Philippine bill. The prediction is freely made that a vote will not be reached before the middle of the following week. There are still a number of set speeches promised on the bill, and some other Senators have not yet indicated whether they will speak or not.

An interesting problem to turfmen just now concerns the future of Nasturtium, the fifty-thousand-dollar race horse, who was sent to England with the special purpose of winning the Epsom Derby for William C. Whitney, and who was returned to the United States last week on the steamer Minnehaha, after a sickness in England that caused Mr. Whitney's trainer to decide that it would be impossible to race the horse successfully in that country.
"Titus will row in the Harlem regatta if the committee will accept his entry at this time," said an officer of the Union Boat Club at the clubhouse yesterday afternoon.

The Marine and Field Club of Bath Beach has issued its yachting schedule for the coming season, comprising thirteen races, of which nine are included in the series of the Yacht Racing Association or Gravesend Bay. Three trophies are offered by members of the club, for competition in the One-design class.

When BRET HARTE died there was scarcely an English journal which did not recall his quaint exposition in rhyme of how the Pacific Coast was "ruined by Chinese cheap labor." It is a singular coincidence that simultaneously the London newspapers were printing testimony to the effect that a similar phenomenon is now observable in England.

Wall Street has usually found that in a dull market prices are inclined to sag. Liquidation by tired and impatient holders, selling by bear operators who mistake passiveness of bull leaders for lack of courage, the very narrowness of the market itself -- these are the factors which almost invariably in times past have made for heaviness and declining prices in a dull market.

Mistaking a strange child for his own little boy, from whom he had been separated for two years, as he claimed, got a man who described himself as Arthur Allison into the clutches of the law in Brooklyn yesterday, through the suspicions of the lad's parents.

BOSTON, May 25 -- Scenes of excitement were witnessed during to-day's session of the American Federation of Zionists, in convention at Faneuil Hall. From beginning to end the meeting was turbulent. The chief cause of the trouble was a resolution submitted by the Committee on Reports of Officers, as follows:

Automobilists will have plenty of activity this week. The Automobile Club of America will hold two interesting and important events, the first being on Friday, Memorial Day, when the 100-mile non-stop endurance contest will be run, while on Saturday there will be the mile and kilometer record contests on Staten Island.

Practically all of the kosher butchers on the east side, served notice yesterday on the Captains of the various police precincts that they intended to open their shops to-day and asked that the police protect them against any attacks that may be made by the women rioters who have been attacking the shops for selling meat, and the customers for buying meat, when a boycott was on against the prevailing high prices.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 23 -- A thunder-storm formed in Spartanburg County this afternoon, and passed through the three towns of Pacolet. Jonesville, and Union. Six persons were killed and fully a dozen seriously injured. The damage to business houses, residences, and crops will aggregate at least $100,000.

The handball players put in a full day yesterday, all the local courts being crowded with players. Oliver Drew, the champion player of Great Britain, was the attraction at Egan's court on Mercer Street, Jersey City, in the morning and at Tarrant's court in the afternoon, and large crowds gathered at both places to watch the playing of the foreign champion.

LONDON, May 25 -- After many weeks of anxious waiting the peace reports have finally crystallized into a strong upward movement on the Stock Exchange. In spite of the lack of definite news, official or otherwise, from Pretoria, the market assumed strength on the general indications that peace was assured.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 -- The meeting of the Terminal Board, held here yesterday, continued many hours in session, and resulted in no definite decision as to the status of the Wiggins Perry controversy -- a controversy involving more than $10,000,000. It is now a question of how soon the constituent lines of the terminal, on one side, and the Rock Island, on the other, can get together.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., May 25 -- Two of the finest vessels of the coastwise fleet, the five-master Arthur Seitz of Portland, Maine, and the four-master Frank A. Palmer, also of Portland, while bound up the coast with heavy cargoes of coal, missed the entrance of Vineyard Sound during thick weather last night, and brought up hard and fast this morning on Wasque Shoal, about five miles southwest of Muskegat Channel.

HUNTINGDON, West Va., May 25 -- It is learned from authentic sources that the United Mine Workers, who yesterday declared a strike of Virginia and West Virginia miners, to begin June 7, expect to nave enlisted 90,000 miners and laborers at the beginning in those two States, which is over three-fourths of the working population of the coal sections.

There were more truants from the Sunday school classes in Harlem yesterday than the teachers can remember in years. The small boy had heard that "Buffalo Bill's Wild West and Congress of Rough Riders of the World "was to arrive, and the chance of seeing the Indians, cowboys, and buffaloes was too much for the small boy.

When John S. Duss left his home in the village of Economy Penn., it was with the avowed double purpose of spreading his fame as a band leader and doing good to the masses through his music. He gave his first concert in this city last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. He expects to accomplish his second object in his popular concerts, which begin to-night at the St. Nicholas Sink.

The Beth Israel Hospital, at Jefferson and Cherry Streets, which has been in course of construction since the early part of 1900, was dedicated yesterday with appropriate exercises. That the public, especially the residents of the east side, were greatly interested in the institution was evidenced by the great crowd that surged in and out of the new building during the hours between 3 o'clock in the afternoon and 10 o'clock in the evening.

BERLIN, May 25 -- The Boerse remained stagnant during the past week, and was without new or striking features. Canadian Pacifies were again to the forefront in interest, Berlin selling to New York takers. The financial press is now advising German holders of Canadian Pacifies to take their profits.

BERLIN, May 25 -- The German crop report up to the middle of May shows Winter wheat to be 2.4 against 2.2 in April, the scale being 1 equals perfect and a equals poorest. Winter rye, in the same report, is snown to be 2.1 against 2.2. The deterioration is due to the windy weather and the frosts and snow.
The Warren Athletic Club of Jersey City will held their annual games at Baldwin Park on June 28.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 25. -- John B. Thompson, President of the Kentucky Distillers' Association, has arrived in Louisville from Washington, where he had been the past few months in the interest of the Outage bill and the measure to reduce the tax on whisky.
CAPE HENRY, Va., May 25 -- The French battleship Gaulois passed out to sea at 4:20 P.M.

Senator PRITCHARD of North Carolina is in politics a Republican, but by reason of his understanding of the commercial interests and the opinions of the Southern people he is a more faithful representative of the Democratic South than Senator CARMACK or Senator TILLMAN. The true voice of the South is not heard in the speeches of CARMACK and of TlLLMAN denouncing in the Senate the policy of the Government in the Philippines.

"Nobody shall comfort us; we will be unhappy." This is the English sentiment over Mr. MORGAN'S little flier in steamships. Our own idea is that he bought the boats to use in the carriage of freight and passengers, and that he can only get these to carry by charging prices which they can afford to pay.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 25 -- The Right Rev. Dr. Philip J. Garrigan, vice rector of the Catholic University of Washington, was solemnly raised to the Episcopate and consecrated Bishop of Sioux City, Iowa, in St. Michael's Cathedral to-day. The ceremony began at 10:30 o'clock and lasted four hours.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 26. -- Despite the efforts of the strike leaders, two anthracite mines remain in operation and produce 15,000 tons a day for an active market. They are the Bernice Drift of the State Line and Sullivan Railroad Company and the Lykens Drift, owned by W. B. Gunton, at Bernice.

Amateur pool experts began play last night in the interclub team championship tournament held at the invitation of the Strollers' Club, at their clubhouse, 67 Madison Avenue. The teams in the opening matches represented the National Arts Club, The Strollers, the Columbia University Club, and the Yale Club.

A great deal more importance than it is entitled to may be permitted to attach to the announcement of the leaders conducting the anthracite strike that they have called out 125,000 miners in West Virginia for a strike to begin June 7. The total number of persons employed in coal mining in West Virginia is only about 32,000 altogether.

ST. LOUIS, May 26. -- James J. Hill, President of the Northern Securities Company, who has been inspecting Burlington terminals here, left to-day for St. Paul. With reference to the Wall Street report that efforts were being made looking to a compromise of the so-called merger suit, Mr. Hill said:
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

Mrs. Fiske's rendering of Sardou's "Divorcons," which was revived last night at the Manhattan Theatre, was, unless memory fails, further removed than ever from the interpretation which the play has so often had at the hands of actresses who regard it merely as an opportunity of showing their powers in legitimate comedy.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Senator Quay to-day introduced in the Senate a bill permitting the President to promote Major Gen. John R. Brooke to the rank of Lieutenant General and retire him. The Republican State Convention in Pennsylvania meets on June 11, and the politicians at once saw in Mr. Quay's action an indication that Gen. Brooke might be the candidate for Governor.

The fight to depose John F. Carroll as the Democratic leader of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District is on in earnest. A circular has been spread broadcast through the district and was sent to every enrolled Democratic voter, stating the political record of John F. Carroll, as viewed by his political opponents in Tammany Hall.

Early in the day the trading in the outside market yesterday showed considerable life, but in most stocks the activity soon quieted down. For the most part the net changes of the day were on the side of advances, but changes of importance were fewer than usual. Special attention was drawn by the heavy trading in the San Francisco issues, which were by all odds the roost prominent stocks of the day.

ANSONIA, Conn., May 26. -- Judge Edwin B. Gager of the New Haven Superior Court to-day issued a blanket injunction restraining relatives or Patrick Moher, deceased, from moving his body. Moher committed suicide, and, though he owned a lot in St. Mary's Catholic Cemetery, belonging to the Church of the Assumption, the church forbade his burial in consecrated ground, and Potter's Field was used.

Three prisoners were locked up in the Union Market Station early last night charged with being connected with an alleged policy shop on the second floor of a tenement at 251 Second Street. Eight men were captured in a raid on the place made by County Detectives Reardon and Brennan and Policeman Walsh of the District Attorney's office, but five were released because of insufficient evidence.

LONDON, May 27. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says the official relief committee has placed at the disposal of the Governors of Guadeloupe and French Guiana 50,000f, and 10,000f, respectively for preliminary expenses in aid of the refugees from Martinique.

After waiting six months while the work was being carried on, the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company has begun a fight in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to prevent the continuation of the improvement of Atlantic Avenue under the management of the Long Island Railroad Company, claiming that its rights in the street will be jeopardized by the changes.
PARIS, May 26. -- Jean Joseph Benjamin-Constant, the painter is dead.

With its team weakened by the absence of Harry Payne Whitney, the Meadow Brook poloists yesterday lost the final match for the Meadow Brook cups, played at Meadow Brook. The steady playing quartet from the Rockaway Hunt Club won the game easily, leading by seven goals. The total score was 10 for the victors and 8 for Meadow Brook.

FINDLAY, Ohio, May 26. -- The largest flowing oil well drilled in Hancock County in the last ten years was completed on the V.H. Conns farm in Marion Township by the People's Oil and Gas Company, of which D.T. Davis is President. The well for about five hours flowed continuously over the top of the derricks.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26. -- New York exhibitors fared well at the eleventh annual Horse Show of the Philadelphia Association, which opened the day at Wissahickon Heights. Seven classes were judged, two of which were closed to local exhibitors and New York horses managed to capture three ribbons in the five open classes.

All the ironwork in the rapid transit tunnel was tied up yesterday by a strike, ordered by the Housesmiths and Bridgemen's Union, of the 500 ironworkers in the tunnel, most of the strikers being unaware of any reason why they should quit work.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Mr. Patterson of Colorado, one of the minority members of the Philippine Committee of the Senate, occupied the floor most of to-day in a discussion of the Philippine question.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The sixteenth annual lawn tennis tournament for the Southern States championship began to-day on the courts of the Bachelors' Club courts. Of the visiting players, Wylie C. Grant, the ex-Columbia interscholastic champion, won his match against A.M. Agelasto, a Washingtonian, in excellent style.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The Navy Department has added one more to the good offices which it has been called on to perform on behalf of the West Indian sufferers by undertaking to transport to the homeless people of St. Vincent a large quantity of building lumber which the Canadian Government has donated.

Two carloads of thoroughbred horses, yearlings, from the Melbourne Stud, of Lexington, Ky., and the property of William Barnes, were derailed near the Sheepshead Bay racetrack, on the Long Island Railroad Sunday night, and several of the animals were severely shaken up by the shock, though none was seriously hurt.

The Wild West Show drew great crowds of people to Olympia Field, Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon and evening. The bucking horses were as usual an interesting feature, and the cavalry drill satisfying from a spectacular view point.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- It is evident from the preparations so far made that the funeral of Lord Pauncefote will be conducted with great dignity, and will be made a memorable occasion. All of the available military and naval forces in Washington and vicinity will take part in the procession.
Mayor Low presented medals of honor yesterday to three members of the Police Department for heroic conduct in the discharge of their duties.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 26. -- Many delegates and visitors to the Republican State Convention, which meets here to-morrow, have already arrived in the city.

Results that apparently ought to have been surprising to the betting public and profitable to the bookmakers at the Gravesend track yesterday in fact were directly the reverse. The afternoon's racing was remarkable chiefly for the number of good "things" that safely went through, every race of the six on the card finishing with the success of some wellbacked horse.
S. Osgood Pell Co. have sold for Isaac H. Clothier to Jacob Wertheim the plot on the south side of Ninety-fifth Street, 102 feet east of Fifth Avenue, 100 by 100.8.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Ex-Capt. McDonald of the Twenty-sixth Volunteer Infantry, one of the officers accused in Corp. O'Brien's testimony, was before the Philippine Committee of the Senate to-day. He denied all of the allegations made by O'Brien, and said O'Brien was on duty elsewhere at the times he claimed to have been present.

Among the passengers on the steamship Caracas, which arrived at this port yesterday from South American and West Indian ports, were Baron de Fontenilliat and Comte de Fitzjames of Paris. Baron de Fontenilliat was in Carbet, a suburb of St. Pierre, at the time of the eruption of Mont Pelee, and at the Hotel Manhattan last evening he gave a very graphic description of the disaster which almost cost him his life.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26. -- William S. Stenger, who, last week, as the representative of a syndicate, purchased The Philadelphia Record at public sale, to-day announced the names of his partners in the ownership of the paper in the following statement to the public:

AUSTIN, Texas, May 26. -- The H. Clay Pierce syndicate is negotiating for the Mexico, Cuernavaca and Pacific Railroad, which runs south from the City of Mexico to a point beyond the Balsas River, in the State of Guerrerro, and it is announced that the deal will probably be consummated within the next few weeks.
LONDON, May 26.--Money was in good demand to-day, and stringency prevailed. The chief requirements this week are for the settlement of monthly demands. Discounts were firm.

BALTIMORE, May 26. -- The local market was slow and featureless. The better tone which manifested itself on Saturday was adversely affected by to-day's lack of response on the part of Wall Street Saturday's favorable bank statement. While the cash increase there was not as large as anticipated the opinion here seemed to be that the figures in connection with the peace negotiations in South Africa would infuse a better feeling in that market.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Senator Depew is thinking of writing a sequel to Edward Everett Hale's story of "My Double and How He Undid Me." Mr. Depew has a double who has been undoing him in Pittsburg by a strenuous existence which Mr. Depew will have to live up to if he ever goes out in that section of Pennsylvania, and he is appalied by the prospect.

No person of sensible mind and law-abiding disposition will view the assault upon Mr. EDWARD R. THOMAS'S automobile party in East Forty-fourth Street in any other light than as an outrage which ought not to be possible in a well-policed city. The haunts and gathering places of young street toughs are well Known to the police, and in those quarters of the city officers of the law ought never to be out of call.

BOSTON, Mass., May 26. -- The money market is dull. Clearing House rate, 4 per cent.; New York funds, 5, 8, and 10 cents premium; call loans, 4 to 4 1/2; time money, 4 1/2 to 5. Clearing House exchanges, $13,708,472; balances, $1,445,873. The weekly statement of the associated local banks, issued to-day, shows a gain of $662,715 in the reserve excess and $628,715 in the New York reserve.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
Although outbatted and outfielded in their game with the Worcester Eastern League baseball team at Jersey City yesterday, the home players won by a score of eight to five.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 26. -- President John Mitchell of the United Mine Workers reached Chicago last night to learn the sentiment of the Illinois men toward the strike in the anthracite fields. He met Secretary W.D. Ryan of the State organization at McCoy's Hotel and held a short conference with him to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Senator Gallinger of New Hampshire to-day introduced a resolution in regard to lynchings, which, although he disclaimed any intention of arousing sectional animosity, immediately roused the Southern Senators. The resolution directed the Committee on Judiciary to investigate the subject of lynching and report whether there was any remedy for the evil.

The conference between Mr. W.J. BRYAN and Mr. TOM L. JOHNSON has given rise to a plausible bit of political gossip. It was said in Chicago, the place of the meeting, that having resolved to break off his habit of running for the Presidency, Mr. BRYAN would give his support to Mayor JOHNSON in the next National Convention of the Democratic Party.

The Republican Club was crowded last evening, the occasion being a complimentary dinner to Gen. Horace Porter, United States Ambassador to France, now in this country on leave of absence from his post.

The committee appointed at a meeting of the stockholders of the Rutland Railroad, St. Lawrence and Adirondack Railroad, Storage Power Company, North American Lumber and Pulp Company, Dominion Securities Company, and Hackensack Meadows Company to secure such information as might be voluntarily given by A.L. Meyer and associates, or the officers of the various companies, made public a statement yesterday.

DENVER, Col., May 26. -- The annual convention of the Western Federation of Miners and the Western Labor Union assembled in this city to-day. There are 300 delegates in attendance, representing over 100,000 workers in the Western States and British Columbia. The two organizations work in harmony, but the conventions meet apart, both in secret session.

DENVER, May 26. -- "Pools are obsolete, in my opinion, and commissions are generally composed of men who know nothing of the operation of railroads. I do not say this unkindly or to criticise, but because I am willing that the public shall understand my views."

There were many witnesses yesterday to testify that they knew that John Clark, who was hilled on East Thirty-fourth Street, near the Long Island Ferryhouse, had threatened the life of John S. Clancy, on trial before Judge Newburger and a jury in Part II. of General Sessions. Mrs. Clancy, the wife of the accused man, sat just back of her husband with some friends.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 26. -- Nine mills under the control and management of the Union Bas and Paper Company and the International Paper Company are affected by a strike which went into effect at 9 o'clock this morning. Four of the plants are situated in Ballston Spa, two in Rock City Falls, and one each in Hadley, West Milton, and Factory Village.

LONDON, May 27. -- The Daily Mail-this morning says that the Cabinet Council to be held to-day will decide upon points of detail, mostly of a financial nature, which have been raised by the Boers in the peace negotiations. The British decisions will then be communicated to the Vereeniging conference by the delegates at Pretoria, and being the best obtainable terms, they will almost certainly be accepted.

The Evening Post was well inspired when it sent a reporter to Commissioner WILCOX to find out why the public was allowed to roam at will over the meadows of Prospect Park and compelled to "keep off the grass" of Central Park, except under strict and irksome restrictions.

BOSTON, Mass., May 26. -- The American Federation of Zionists concluded its convention to-day. It developed during the day that shares in the Jewish Colonial Trust have been sold in Boston to the amount of $6,112.44; in New York, $40,079.70, and in the whole country, approximately, $150,000.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 26. -- The members of the French mission who participated in the ceremonies incident to the unveiling of the statue of Count de Rochambeau, in Washington, D.C., arrived at Niagara Falls at 9:30 this morning. Besides the members of the mission and the families of Lafayette and Rochambeau, there are in the party Ambassador Cambon, Mme.

LONDON, May 27. -- That the Government yesterday fully anticipated the speedy conclusion of peace in South Africa, is believed to be shown by the postponement from yesterday until Friday or later of the Budget bill in the committee stage, with the view, as was frankly admitted on the Government side of the House, of enabling the recasting of the budget in the event of peace being secured.

The world's amateur mile paced cycling record of 1:28, held by Walter Smith of Brooklyn, was broken yesterday by "Joe" Nelson, who covered the distance on the Vailsburg board track, Newark, to 1:26 2-5. Nelson is a brother of "Johnnie" Nelson, the race follower who was fatally injured at Madison Square Garden last Summer.

BERLIN, May 26. -- The Directors of the Hamburg -- American Line have issued a circular divulging the terms of the agreement between the Morgan shipping combination and the Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd Lines.

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, May 25. -- The United States cruiser Cincinnati arrived here from St. Lucia yesterday. The steamer Luckenbach arrived this morning and left her at once for Porto Rico. The steamer Fontabelle reached here at 9 o'clock this morning with 150 tons of supplies from the Chamber of Commerce and citizens of New York.

BERLIN, May 26. -- The Directors of the Hamburg -- American Line have issued a circular divulging the terms of the agreement between the Morgan shipping combination and the Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd Lines.

Irregularity marked the opening of yesterday's Stock Exchange market. Failure to realize the anticipation of Boer peace news was a more or less effective disappointment, though advices from, international bankers were uniformly to the effect that the announcement of settlement would prove to be merely a matter of days, most London cables insisting that the English King has determined that his coronation shall be an event free from the war so long devastating the empire.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 26. -- Mrs. Benjamin Thaw and family arrived this evening at their villa, near Bailey's Beach.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- "The opinion seems to prevail in this country that the Philippine Islands are in a state of warfare and chaos, but four-fifths of the land surface of those islands is as well under peace as Kentucky," said the Rev. Homer C. Stuntz, head of the Methodist Missions of Manila, last night at the First Methodist Church of Evanston.

This is New York's day to honor the French Republic's representatives who came over to attend the dedication of the Rochambeau Monument in Washington on Saturday. There will be a reception by the city authorities in the City Hall, a full-dress parade of the National Guard past a reviewing stand holding the distinguished visitors, and a banquet at the Waldorf-Astoria in the evening.

E.W. Bloomingdale and Gen. Daniel E. Sickles, representing the friends of Daniel P. Hays, of the law firm of Hays Hirshfield, are urging upon Gov. Odell the appointment of Mr. Hays to the Supreme Court Justiceship recently left vacant by the death of George P. Andrews.

John F. Clancy was declared not guilty yesterday of the murder of John Clark before Judge Newburger and a jury in Part II of General Sessions. Clancy killed Clark on June 2 last. The men met near the Long Island ferryhouse, and Clark, who had threatened to first thrash and then kill Clancy, knocked him down.

First Lieut. Edwin R. Stuart, Corps of Engineers, will proceed at the proper time after the commencement of the leave of absence usually granted instructors at the United States Military Academy to Charleston, and report to Capt. James C. Sanford, Corps of Engineers, for temporary duty under his immediate orders, and after his relief from duty by Capt. Sanford will return to his station at West Point on or before Sept. 1.

LONDON, May 28. -- A dispatch to The Times from Valparaiso, Chile, says three protocols have already been signed by Chile and Argentina. They constitute King Edward general arbitrator, cancel the existing orders for warships, arrange for, the equalization of armaments within a year, and recognize the principle of non-interference with, the boundaries of neighboring republics.

According to the provisions of his will, the body of Justice George P. Andrews of the Supreme Court was taken Monday afternoon to Fresh Pond, L.I., where it was cremated. The remains were accompanied by Mrs. Decker, a sister, and other relatives, John H. Judge, and Dr. Matthew Chalmera.

PATERSON, N.J., May 27. -- Robert B. Holmes of Madison. N.J., a lawyer, of the firm of Holmes, Rapallo Kennedy of New York, was the owner of the automobile which was in collision with the bicycle ridden by Charles Whitman of Pompton Plains, Sunday evening, and which resulted in the death of the wheelman.

The New York Realty Corporation has bought, through John F. Doyle, the six-story building 62 Wall Street, on lot 25.5 by 117.8. Negotiations for the sale of this parcel to the City Real Property Investing Company reached an advanced stage several weeks ago, but were subsequently abandoned.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Capt. McDonald continued his statement before the Philippine Committee to-day and presented official statements to refute the testimony of Corporal O'Brien. Capt. McDonald said he gave orders to burn several towns which were in hostile country and sheltered ladrones and insurgents.

BALTIMORE, May 27. -- The market was flat to-day. The list adhered right steady to its recently attained level of prices, but it was unable to develop any activity. Considerable outside dealing in Baltimore City stock was reported, the demand for these securities by the banks and trust companies being still unabated.

-- Looking over the city's roofs yesterday, one saw here and there broad streamers of black smoke floating from tall buildings and big chimneys, but they were not much, if any, more numerous than they were before the coal strike began, and it was evident that a majority of the New Yorkers who have been driven to use soft coal are doing it with a careful regard for the law and public rights.

BERLIN, May 27. -- On the Boerse to-day Internationals were in good demand, owing to the ease and abundance of money and the advance in British Consols. Banks were maintained. Iron shares were considerably higher, on bear covering, in view of the settlement. Navigation shares were well disposed, as the result of large Hamburg buying orders.

The smallest crowd of the season made yesterday's racing at the Gravesend track a somewhat notable occasion, the "regulars" for the first time since racing opened in New York for the new turf year having things their own way and the attendant comfort that comes on an off day. The programme offered was quite up to the average in the way of attractiveness, but the weather was more than the casual racegoers could stand.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 27. -- The situation in the anthracite coal region was discussed at a conference between Gov. Stone, Attorney General Elkin, and Thomas Duffy, T.D. Nichols, and John Fahy, District Presidents of the United Mine Workers, to-day. The mine workers came here by invitation of the Governor to explain the exact situation in the strike region.

THINGS ALLURING TO CHILDREN. -- Francis Bannerman is the owner of a gun and ammunition factory in Brooklyn.
