The factory premises are inclosed by a fence, but adjoining is a vacant lot, owned by Mr. Bannerman, used as a dumping place for refuse from the factory. This open lot has often been used by boys as a playground.

Justice Scott, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, announced yesterday at the conclusion of the evidence in the trial of Police Captain Herlihy, that he would sit continuously to-day until the case goes to the jury. This means that Capt. Herlihy will probably know whether he is guilty of "willful neglect of duty" or not before to-night.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections today ended its deadlock over the House resolution for the popular election of Senators by reporting, in substance, that it was all tangled up. Senator Depew had scuttled the resolution, so far as the committee was concerned, by his amendment providing for Federal supervision of the Senatorial elections.

Yesterday's stock market was very dull, only about 300,000 shares being dealt in all day. Quotations moved irregularly, some of the specialties fluctuating rather widely. Pressed Steel Car went down about 3 points, and International Power fell 10, while Snuff Trust shares jumped up 5 points.
Park Commissioner Willcox gave out a statement yesterday concerning the condition of Central Park.
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- For several hours in the Senate to-day Mr. Patterson of Colorado discussed the Philippine question, concluding the speech which he began yesterday. After reviewing and commenting on the general Philippine question he attacked the pending bill, particularly its provisions regarding the holding of lands.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 27. -- Walter Bolger, eighteen years of age, son of Paul S. Bolger, a wealthy resident of Sunnyside Drive, this city, disappeared from home in November last. To-night the telephone in the Bolger residence rang, and Mrs. Bolger answered it.

Buffalo and the Meadow Brook freebooters opened the polo competition yesterday on the Held of the Meadow Brook Club for the Hempstead Cups. The Buffalo team won after a somewhat spirited match by 11 goals to 5 3/4.

The Social Hall Association, which was recently incorporated with the idea of erecting on the lower east side a modern structure for social and recreative uses, has bought the plot at 151 and 153 Clinton Street, just south of Grand Street.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The House to-day passed the Shattuc Immigration bill after adopting two amendments, the one prohibiting the sale of intoxicating liquors at immigrant stations and the other prohibiting their sale within the limits of the Capitol building. A lively debate preceded the adoption of the first, which was offered by Mr. Bowersock (Kan.)

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 27. -- Attorneys for the Schwarzschild Sulzberger Company of Kansas City to-day filed a motion in the Supreme Court, to quash the alternative writ issued at the instance of Attorney General Crow for the ouster of the defendant for being in the so-called beef combination.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Republican members of the Senate Committee on Relations with Cuba undoubtedly would come quickly to an agreement on a scheme of relief for Cuba, if they could have the assurance that what they are willing to agree to would command practically the unanimous support of the majority in the Senate.

The route through Lake Nicaragua passes directly under the shadow of Omotepe, a volcano capable of doing for that region, without previous advertisement of intentions, all that Mont Pelee has done in Martinique. -- From The Sun.

Three stores of the Terminal Warehouse Company, the largest of its kind in New York City, occupying the entire block bounded by West Twenty-sixth and West Twenty-seventh Streets and Twelfth and Thirteenth Avenues, were yesterday morning badly damaged by a fire involving an approximate loss, it is estimated by the police, of $150,000.

FORT DE FRANCE, May 26. -- Prof. Robert T. Hill, United States Government Geologist and head of the expedition sent by the National Geographical Society, returned here to-day after a daring and prolonged investigation of the volcanic activity in Martinique.

CLEVELAND, May 27. -- The feature of the Republican State Convention here today was the unanimity of sentiment in favor of Senator Hanna. He has been the centre of interest since his arrival from Washington last Sunday. The conferences of leaders with, him continued to-day, but when it came to the meeting of the delegates by Congressional districts at 2 P. M. the sentiment for him was demonstrated in an unprecedented degree.

KINGSTOWN, St Vincent, May 26. -- On Saturday night the dense clouds forming a canopy over the greater part of the island lowered, and a severe thunderstorm, accompanied by a heavy rainfall, broke over St. Vincent and continued until to-day, causing the mud streams in the windward district of Georgetown to become flooded.

The recent utterance of Sir WILFRID LAUPIER as to the purposes of the conference of Colonial Ministers with Mr. CHAMBERLAIN at the time of the coronation have given rise to much discussion in England of the possibility of forming a customs federation between the various parts of the British Empire.

The National Wardrobe Company, whose President, H.W. Raynor, as stated in dispatches from Pittsburg was arrested in that city on Monday, has an office here at 402 Fifth Avenue. The regular manager, it was explained there yesterday, is away because of illness in his family. For him spoke a young woman who was in charge, but refused to have her name mentioned.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27. -- Owing to dullness it was necessary to make price concessions to effect sales in the local market to-day. The losses, however, were slight, and a slight improvement in Reading in the afternoon had the effect of strengthening the whole list. Consolidated Lake Superior advanced slightly, but the common stock was lower.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 27. -- Preparations arc being made for an extensive celebration in connection with the reception of the French Rochambeau Statue delegates, who will come here Friday to place a wreath on the grave of Admiral de Terney, in Trinity Churchyard.

ALBANY, May 27. -- Albany and Troy managers of branch offices of the various Western beef packing concerns were examined relative to the workings of their offices before ex-Justice Judson S. Landon as referee to-day.

Of all the military and naval pageantry that distinguished yesterday's reception of the Rochambeau delegation by the City of New York, the appearance of a hundred French sailors, marching through the streets of the American metropolis with a French flag at their head, was probably the most striking feature.

LONDON, May 28. -- Wiring on May 24, the Pretoria correspondent of The Times says the general impression that the present negotiations will result in peace is so strong that a rumor to the effect that peace would be proclaimed in Pretoria on Victoria Day (last Saturday) met with ready credence, and the Market Square was thronged with an expectant crowd.

CLEVELAND, May 27. -- Napoleon Lajoie, second baseman, and Pitcher Bernhardt, late of the Athletics, arrived in Cleveland to-day and were In conference with Messrs. Somers and Kilfoyle of the Cleveland American League Club and an attorney until 5 o'clock. Another meeting will be held to-morrow when the question of whether or not these players will become members of the Cleveland Club will be settled.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The conferrees of the two houses of Congress on the River and Harbor bill to-day reached a final agreement on that bill. The exact figures showing the aggregate result of their work have not been determined, but it can be stated that of the $9,500,000 appropriation added by the Senate only about $4,500,000 was retained, the provisions calling for the remaining $5,000,000 being disagreed to by the House conferrees.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The engagement is announced of Miss Mildred Williams, youngest daughter of the late Gen. Robert Williams, to Walter Farwell of Chicago, only son of ex-Senator Farwell of Illinois. The wedding is to take place in this city early in July. Owing to the deep mourning of the bride's family, the ceremony will take place at home, and be witnessed only by the immediate relatives.
HAVANA, May 27. -- President Palma's message is published, here to-night and will be delivered to the Cuban Senate tomorrow.

LONDON, May 27. -- The rates for money were firm to-day. The stringency is attributed largely to the lock-up in connection with applications for the New South Wales loan, which is said to have been oversubscribed ten times.

The London Times prints a statement of the accounts of the University of Oxford, which accounts, it editorially observes, "cannot but fill many minds with an uneasy misgiving as to the financial capacity of the university to rise to the full height of the large responsibilities certain to be imposed upon it as a consequence of the Rhodes bequest."

Memorial Day to-morrow is to be marked by an unusual number of extercises, among the important features being the dedication of the Soldiers and Sailors' Monument, at Eighty-ninth Street and Riverside Drive, at 10:30 o'clock in the morning and the attending parade. The monument, which has been under construction for two years.

James P. Blount, who from papers found in his possession appears to have lived at one time in Fort Wayne, Ind., and who for some days past has been a hanger-on about the Forepaugh Sells Brothers' circus, now in camp at Halsey Street and Saratoga Avenue, Brooklyn, crawled into the menagerie tent about 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning and began to tease a big Asiatic elephant called "Tops."

It is interesting to learn that the Pan-Germans in Germany disapprove of the Kaiser's announced intention to present to this country a statue of FREDERICK THE GREAT. There is a considerable number of Americans who are not enthusiastic about it, although they do not see their way to looking in the mouth either a gift statue or a gift hero.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- After an absence from his home of more than six months, during which time his gray-haired father sought him in all parts of the world, Walter F. Bolger, eighteen years of age, who resides in Yonkers, N. Y., has been located and taken in hand by his parents. Paul S. Bolger, the father, found the youth aboard the United States training ship Franklin, lying in Hampton Roads.
About one hundred persons braved the cold to witness the basebase game at West Side Park yesterday between the Jersey City and Worcester teams of the Eastern League.
LONDON, May 28. -- Money was much wanted to-day, incidental to pay day on the Stock Exchange. Discounts were firm.

The Tobacco Trust has acquired the three largest tobacco companies dealing in Cuban cigars and tobaccos, namely the Havana Commercial Company, the Henry Clay Bock Tobacco Company, and the H. de Cabanas y Carbajal Company.

LONDON, May 29. -- The annual meeting of the London Chamber of Commerce, which was to be held yesterday afternoon, was unexpectedly and rather excitedly adjourned, owing to lack of space and air. Hundreds of business men and merchants crowded into the small room provided for the meeting, until they had to stand on the stairs, and some of them were even unable to get any further than the street.

BOSTON, Mass., May 28. -- The money market is working easier, quotations being in many instances nominal. Clearing House rate, 4 per cent. New York funds, 5 per cent and 10c premium. Call loans, 3 1/2 to 4. Time money, 4 to 4 1/2. Clearing House exchanges, $20,807,813. Balances, $1,426,979. The stock market was quiet but firm.
First Lieut. Christopher C. Collins, Assistant Surgeon, is relieved from duty at the general hospital. Presidio of San Francisco, and will report for transportation to the Philippine Islands.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 28.--The engineers, pumpmen, and firemen employed at the mines of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Company: New York, Ontario and Western Company, and People's Coal Company in West Scranton to-day decided not to go on strike. The majority of the firemen are demanding an eight-hour day and are in favor of coming out next Monday, but they were outvoted by the engineers and pumpmen.

The collapse of a temporary sidewalk in front of a new building during the military parade on Tuesday, by which a hundred people were precipitated into a vault excavation, with immediately fatal results to one and more or less serious injury to many others, teaches a lesson which should not be forgotten.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I inclose $100 to furnish bail for and release of the boy who attacked Mr. Thomas in his automobile.
A programme extraordinary in length and uncommon in its mediocrity offered feeble temptation to the racing public at the Gravesend track yesterday.

While speeding through Ludlow Street on the way to the Lying-in Hospital, at Seventeenth Street and Second Avenue, late yesterday afternoon, an automobile ambulance, containing a patient in a critical condition, ran down and killed Maurice Scharasinsky, aged eleven, of 179 Ludlow Street. The ambulance, driven by Joseph Ruppert of 333 West Sixteenth Street and under the charge of Dr. Gordon, had been sent to 151 Ludlow Street for a young Hebrew woman.
WILKESBARRE, May 28. -- The operators to-night gave the following semi-official statement of the existing conditions and their intentions:

A raw and chilly day is excellent for outdoor sports, especially golf, and Tuxedo was one of the points yesterday where the interest of those who are fond of the Scottish game was centred. The Pioneer went out with a jolly crowd, and there was a large representative gathering at Meadow Brook for the polo.

LONDON, May 28. -- The Daily Chronicle this morning asserts that the negotiations in South Africa are practically concluded, and that the present week will witness the termination of the war in South Africa. The paper says it understands that the Government has declined to grant unqualified amnesty to the rebels or to fix a date for the establishment of self government, and that English will probably be the official language in the two colonies.

At the close of business to-day work will be begun upon extensive interior alterations to the Consolidated Exchange Building at Broadway and Exchange Place. Under the contract which has been awarded to Richard H. Casey Co. the work must be completed by Aug. 1, and will be carried on only outside of the business hours of the Exchange.

PITTSBURG, May 28. -- The most important consolidation of banking interests in Pitsburg for many years was announced to-day. The old banking house of T. Mellon Sons, established in 1869, has taken out papers for entering the National Banking Association as the Mellon National Bank of Pittsburgh with paid up capital of $1,000,000, and additional cash surplus of $1,000,000.

Something very closely resembling, or at least suggesting, the eruption of Mont Pelee was brought about by the rumor circulated on the east side that Commissioner HAWKES of the Department of Docks had decided to restrict the music given on the recreation piers this Summer to selections designed to educate the popular taste to an appreciation of the type of composition designated as classical.

Strenuous efforts were made to force weakness at the opening of yesterday's Stock Exchange market, but aside from the extension of the short interest, little was accomplished. Before the first hour had passed strength showed throughout most of the list, anthracite coal issues leading in improvement.

The pool team representing the Columbia University Club met defeat last night by the No. 1 team of the Strollers' Club and relinquished their position as competitors for the interclub pool championship. Only two matches were necessary, as both of the victories were gained by long margins. The players of the Union Club also vanquished the men from the Lambs Club.

BOSTON, May 28. -- Willis, pitcher for the Boston baseball team, struck out thirteen batsmen in to-day's game with the New Yorks. This is the record for the season, though in spite of this excellent work the home team only won by a run, and that the sole tally in the game. Taylor, too, was in good form and held his opponents down to four hits, while Willis allowed six.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The Republicans and Democrats of the Senate succeeded to-day in reaching an agreement for a vote on the Philippine bill at 4 o'clock Tuesday. The relief of Senator Lodge was shown in the conciliatory attitude he displayed, and the eagerness with which he jumped forward to agree to everything the Democrats wanted.

Great progress was made yesterday in the handicap ping-pong tournament at the Strollers Club, 67 Madison Avenue. The eighty competitors advanced to the semifinal round, and the last match will be played by the end of the week. Plans are now being made by Chairman Tappan to hold a championship meeting immediately following the present event.

Under the heading of "The Antiquated Court-Martial," The Evening Post denounces the system of administering justice under which it is impossible for the reviewing authority to add to a punishment which it considers inadequate or to retry a culprit whom it believes to have been wrongfully acquitted.

Walter J. Travis, the national golf champion, showed his marked superiority yesterday over all of his opponents in the local golf world by winning the low score prize at Tuxedo in the qualifying round for the Metropolitan Championship. The feature was not so much his winning the honor as the manner in which it was won.

The contest for the control of the Nineteenth Assembly District between the followers of John B. Sexton, the anti-Sextonites, and the Greater New York Democracy was opened last evening. Meetings were held within a radius of a few hundred feet, and there was as much excitement attending the open skirmish of the fight for the Democratic leadership of the district as if an important election were taking place.
WICHITA, Kan., May 28. -- The Republican State Convention to-night nominated the following ticket:

Archer M. Huntington has bought from H. D. Robbins the plot on the north side of Eighty-ninth Street, about 100 feet east of Fifth Avenue, 4O by 100.8. Mr. Huntington recently purchased the two dwellings 2,080 and 1,081 Fifth Avenue, just north of Eighty-ninth Street, and has acquired the plot at the rear on the street, with the idea of protecting the light and air of these houses.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The remains of Lord Pauncefote, British Ambassador to Washington, to-day were accorded a National funeral, in token of the high esteem set by the American people on the personal worth of the deceased, and as an acknowledgment of the friendly feeling which is cherished toward Great Britain.

The first message of the new President of the Republic of Cuba is very sober. The note of congratulation that the long and patient and heroic struggle for the freedom of the Cuban people is at last crowned with success is accompanied by a serious warning as to what remains to be done for the security, the prosperity, and the honor of the new nation.

The comment of the organs of Southern opinion on the movement of the Southern Education Board is not invariably favorable, though on the whole it is decidedly so. A certain number of the Southern writers are a little suspicious and a little jealous of it. There are those who regard it as a movement for the education of the blacks to the neglect of the whites.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- What one of the Republican Senators is wont to speak of as the "meek and lowly Hanna boom for the Presidency," was talked about a good deal to-day in Washington. This was due, of course, to the news that came from Cleveland as to the feeling in the Ohio Republican State Convention with reference to Mr. Hanna's candidacy.

An early morning call at the Brooklyn ..avy Yard, a drive to Columbia University and Grant's Tomb, a breakfast with Mayor Low, a reception aboard the French battleship Gaulois in the afternoon, and a dinner of the French Chamber of Commerce in the evening made up yesterday's programme for the Rochambeau delegation.
WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The President has decided to appoint Senator John L. McLaurin of South Carolina a Judge of the Court of Claims, and the nomination will probably be made in a few days.

Business in the outside market yesterday was much smaller than it had been the previous day, and there were relatively few events of interest in the day's trading. Prices were fairly well maintained, and in some few instances advanced sharply. New interest was taken in the Tobacco stocks because of the announcement of the purchase of the Havana Commercial Company, and much strength was displayed by these stocks.

The will of President Henry Morton of Stevens Institute, Hoboken, was filed for probate in Jersey City yesterday. It directs that the estate shall be divided equally between his two sons, Henry S. Morton and Quincy Morton, who are made the executors. The former is a patent lawyer of this city, and the latter is still a student at the Institute.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- Nearly all the issues were stronger in the Philadelphia market to-day, the Welsbach securities leading, both the stock and bonds reaching the highest point recorded for several months. The buoyancy is not accounted for. Officials of the company declare no deal of any sort is on.

ORANGE, N. J., May 28. -- " It is now up to the manufacturers of automobiles to produce a cheap carriage," said Thomas A. Edison to-day. " I have, after three years of hard work, solved the problem of an electrical storage battery which can be used for long distance work and which will wear three or four automobiles out before it will succumb itself."

The Board of Education last evening adopted a resolution retiring Associate Superintendent John Jasper, the retirement to take effect Sept. 1, and Mr. Jasper to receive an annuity of $2,000 a year. The resolution was adopted after a lively and heated debate.
CLEVELAND, May 28. -- The Republican State Convention adjourned this evening after nominating the following ticket:
NEWPORT, R.I., May 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Dyer, Jr., arrived here this evening, and will at once open their cottage, on Bellevue Avenue, for the season.

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, May 28, 5 P.M. -- There was a tremendous explosion from Mont Pelee at 8:45 o'clock this morning. It was accompanied by an enormous column of smoke, which rose fully three miles into the air, but which was largely hidden from the view of the people of Fort de France by a heavy mulus.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Consideration of the Philippine Government bill was resumed by the Senate to-day.

QUEBEC, May 29. -- In the Superior Court this morning Justice Andrews ascended the bench to continue proceedings in the Gaynor-Greene case. The prosecution was represented by Senator Dandurand and Mr. McMaster of Montreal. Mr. Erwin. District Attorney for the Southern District of Georgia, and Mr. Stuart of Quebec.
ALBANY, May 29. -- The following companies were incorporated here to-day:

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Executive Committee of the Democratic Congressional Committee was in session here to-day. Messrs. Ben T. Cable of Illinois, Chairman, aud Judson Harmon of Cincinnati being present, with the Senators and Representatives on the committee. The other outside members -- Josiah Quincy of Massachusetts, Edward M. Shepard of New York, E. C. Wall of Wisconsin, and David Overmeyer of Kansas -- were represented by proxies.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- New York politicians who have visited Washington recently have had considerable to say connecting Gov. Odell of their State with the Republican Presidential ticket in 1904. According to their view, Mr. Odell is likely to be the candidate of the Empire State in the National Convention.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Dr. David T. Day, chief of the division of mineral resources of the Geological Survey, announced this afternoon the discovery of platinum in Porto Rico. He does not regard the discovery as necessarily of great importance. It simply establishes the presence of the metal in Porto Rico.

In response to a request from a New York lawyer, THE NEW YORK TIMES has made an investigation of the adequacy of the accommodations that have been provided in the Capitol Building at Albany for the Court of Appeals. The complaint was that the court was being crowded gradually out of the corner of the Capitol on account of the increasing space demanded by other departments.
At the Rochambeau ceremonies on Saturday M. CAMBON said in reference to American aid to the Martinique sufferers:
LONDON, May 29. -- There was a considerable demand for money to-day, and borrowers were dependent on the Bank of England. The indebtedness to the Bank is increasing. Discounts were firm.

William Laimbeer, a member of the New York Stock Exchange and a graduate of Harvard, and Clara Button Bloodgood, the actress, were married yesterday in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church in Stuyvesant Square.

Friendly Sons of St. Patrick to the number of three hundred gathered at Delmonico's last night for a dinner and an uproariously enthusiastic welcome to the delegates from France now visiting this country. It was the last function to be given in this city in honor of the distinguished Frenchmen, and it was likewise the most informal and the most elaborate.

With over 700 athletes competing, the pick of the colleges and universities of this country, the trial heats for the intercollegiate track and field championships will be run off to-day at Berkeley Oval.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- When a newspaper man asked Senator Platt of Connecticut to-day what would be the, outcome of the effort to secure a Cuban relief measure from Congress, the Senator replied:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why are the streets of Manhattan so dirty? Whose is the fault? The state of affairs cannot be attributed to the construction of the subway, for this does not dominate the entire city. I speak of regions which are in no wise affected by it.

LONDON, May 29. -- The first of five test cricket matches between Australia and England commenced to-day at Birmingham. The home eleven batted first and started disastrously, A. C. MacLaren, C. B. Fry, and Ranjitsinhji (the Indian player) only aggregating 22 runs. The subsequent players made a better stand, and at the close of play the score was 351 runs for nine wickets down.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3.000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

The proposition of the Merchants Association to assist the administration in devising a system of municipal accounting which shall make it appear why it costs New York more per head of population for a given municipal service than it does almost any other city in the world is enterprising and public-spirited.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Vice President Finley of the Southern Railway Company to-day made the following statement:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 29. -- Mrs. John Gerken was one of the most prominent exhibitors at the horse show to-day, as she has been during the previous days. Up to date, Mrs. Gerken is third in the matter of capturing ribbons representing a cash value, her winnings amounting to $400.

PARIS, May 29. -- The Commissary of Police, who has been investigating the theft of jewels belonging to Mrs. Thomas Kensitt and her daughter Gertrude, of Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y., reports that while Miss Kensitt was at the Opera Comique the other evening her room in the Athenee Hotel was entered, her wardrobe was opened, and a wallet containing jewelry valued at 25,000f. was taken.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 29. -- The Tennessee Democratic State Convention met at the Capitol to-day and with much enthusiasm nominated James B. Frazer of Chattanooga for Governor and J. Neil McKnight for Railroad Commissioner.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 29. -- A levy on the goods of the National Wardrobe Company at its plant, at 1,200 Fifth Avenue, was made to-day by the Union Realty Company for unpaid rent since the opening of the establishment in April. The President of the company told the police that he had received no money in advance, but many checks with his indorsement have been secured.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day heard the testimony of Col. A. L. Wagner, Assistant Adjutant General of the Army, who spent two and one-half years in the Philippines. He was questioned about the concentration camps, and described the system by explaining the details of one particular camp.

DENVER, Col., May 29. -- " We are all for Roosevelt in New York," said Gov. Odell of New York here in an interview to-day, " and you will find that the sentiment throughout the East, despite the reports to the contrary. While it is too early to predict anything with certainty, the President from all indications can be re-elected if he consents to a renomination.

District Attorney Jerome, before Judge Newburger in Part II. of General Sessions, yesterday asked that a number of indictments for gambling be taken from the calendar, those indicted being lightly fined or one indictment each and sentence suspended on the other indictments. In explanation of his course the District Attorney said:

Two Republican Conventions this week have shown hesitating Republicans in Congress what their constituencies in two important States thought about the question of doing justice to Cuba, justice to the point of generosity, OXNARD to the contrary notwithstanding. Representative DICK of Ohio will be remembered as one of those who were surest that it would hurt the party to do our plain duty to Cuba.

FALL, RIVER. Mass., May 29. -- The sales in the print-cloth market during the week amounted to about 50,000 pieces, all of which were old goods, no regulars having been disposed of during the short week's trading. The market has been extremely dull. The outlook is for a continuance of the present quiet trading for some time.

If Tom Sawyer hadn't had an uncommonly dead cat, and hadn't made an excuse of a wart on Huckleberry Finn's little finger to perform an incantation with it in the graveyard at midnight, things would have gone badly with Lusher Stubbs in the play at the Third Avenue Theatre.

The Judeans, an organization composed of representative Jews of New York, gave a reception, followed by a dinner, last evening at the Tuxedo, Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, in honor of Prof. Solomon Schechter, the eminent Hebrew scholar, who was induced to leave Cambridge University in England to become the Dean of the new Jewish theological seminary which is to be established on Morningslde Heights through the munificence of Jacob H. Schiff and others.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., May 29. -- There is much opposition here to the erection of poles by the new electric light company. Yesterday a gang of Italians began to dig a hole in front of the house of Samuel Berry, one of the Town Trustees. Mr. Berry forbade the men to dig in front of his property, but the foreman told them to go ahead, and they proceeded with the work.
Official announcement of the formation of the American Steel Foundries Company was made yesterday. The six companies which will go into the consolidation are:

TRENTON, N. J., May 29. -- Moses Taylor Pyne, millionaire, a prominent member of New York clubs and a resident of Princeton, who has been an active Trustee of Princeton University for several years, has declined the Republican nomination for Congress in the newly apportioned Fourth District, which consists of Mercer, Hunterdon, and Somerset Counties.

The attitude of President LEDERLE of the Health Department toward consumers of soft coal who do not succeed in securing a perfectly smokeless combustion has been somewhat misrepresented by the reporters who have made it appear that he is superzealous in the enforcement of the smoke ordinances, and that he will stop the use of soft coal if he has to paralyze the industrial activities of the city and stop its transportation systems.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "Smoking or carrying lighted cigars or cigarettes on the platforms or in the cars of this company is strictly forbidden. Train men must enforce this rule."

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, May 29, Noon. -- The crater of Mont Pelee has been approached within one mile. This feat was accomplished on Tuesday afternoon by George J. Kavanagh, an unattached newspaper man, who had accompanied Prof. Robert T. Hill, the United States Government geologist, on the latter's expedition.

BOSTON, May 29. -- Money is very dull. Clearing House rate, 4 per cent.; New York funds par; call loans, 3 1/2@4 1/2 per cent.; time money, 4@4 1/2 per cent. The stock market was featureless. Complete transactions were as follows:

The Kings County Grand Jury for May, the members of which, at the suggestion of Judge Aspinall, recently visited Coney Island individually to look into conditions there, yesterday brought in a presentment in the County Court upon the prevalence of vice at the seaside resort and elsewhere in Brooklyn.
BOSTON, May 29. -- Boston's National League baseball team won from New York to-day by a single run, the score being 5 to 4.

Police Captain John J. Herlihy left the room of the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday morning a tired man. He was overwhelmed by friends who wanted to congratulate him because the Jury that had listened to the testimony against him for willful neglect of duty in the " Red Light District" had failed to agreo.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 29. -- Cornell's baseball players couldn't hit McGeehan, and Holy Cross won to-day's game before Cornell could make a run. A home run by Noonan, with two men on bases, gave the local college team three runs in the fourth inning. Score by innings:

Every year Decoration Day becomes more end more the recognized opening day for out-of-door sports, and the list of events Scheduled for this year includes many meetings that have never before made this holiday the initial one of their season. Naturally, the old-time standbys, such as the Harlem River regatta, the running of the American Cycling Derby over the Irving-ton-Millburn course, and the intercollegiate games, take precedence over all others.

Our readers know that we are not always in sympathy with the well-meaning persons who desire to preserve what they call historical relics in New York. In particular, we have been able to see nothing in the proposition to move the "Colonnade Row," which was one of the sights of New York half a century ago, from its original habitat, in Lafayette Place, to Bryant Park, and set it up there.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Prospects of a rise in the price of meat, and a fight to a finish between the Packers and Teamsters Union No. 10, developed at the Union Stock Yards to-day. Signs of peace faded as the result of an ineffectual conference, and indications of a general strike grew stronger.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- The Philadelphia market to-day was generally firm. The strength and activity of the Reading issues, United Gas Improvement Company stock and warrants, and Welsbach bonds were a feature. Reading common was heavily bought largely by the same interests taking the stock yesterday.

Alfred M. Rau of the Municipal Realty Corporation has sold to Jacob Wertheim, President of the United Cigar Manufacturers, the new seven-story factory building recently completed at the southeast corner of Sixty-eighth Street and Avenue A, on plot 75 by 150. The property is sold subject to a ten years' lease to the United Cigar Manufacturers, but it is understood that Mr. Wertheim's purchase is in the nature of a personal investment.

Though, marking the close of the Stock Exchange for a holiday extending till next Monday, yesterday's market was as active and as firm as recorded during any other day of the week. More commission houses made purchases on substantial scale, and there were indications of new commitments by important financial interests lately conspicuously apathetlc.

A spectacular fire was witnessed by hundreds of excited shoppers yesterday evening, when an automobile runabout belonging to M. Rosenbaum of Central Park West was destroyed in Sixth Avenue, near Twenty-third Street. The vehicle was occupied by Mr. Rosenbaum and Miss Rose Barnett of 32 West Forty-fourth Street, one of the four " show girls " in the production of that name at Wallack's Theatre.

Walter J. Travis and Findlay S. Douglas will meet this morning in the semi-final round at Tuxedo for the metropolitan championship. The winner is firmly expected to win the metropolitan honor, for the players in the other semi-final round will be W. L. Thompson and Frank A. Marcellus.

Two men, bearing every symptom of poverty, sitting side by side on a bench in Central Park, shoulder touching shoulder, were found late last night by Policeman Devanney of the Central Park squad. He thought they were asleep, but discovered that they were dead. On the walk at their feet were two whisky flasks, both empty.

RYE, N.Y., May 29. -- This village to-day has been visited by many prominent persons of New York City and Westchester County, the occasion being the celebration by the venerable Archdeacon and Mrs. W. W. Kirkby of their golden wedding anniversary. Numerous clergy of the Episcopal Church and of other denominations also called to offer their best wishes.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., May 29. -- Lawn tennis and cricket will be more prominent among the Summer sports this season at Seabright, for a reorganization has just been effected of the Sea bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club, and new officers have been elected as follows: President, Cecil Barrett; Secretary, S. S. Auchincloss; Treasurer, Dr. Bayard Clark.

LONDON, May 30. -- The Government leader in the House of Commons, the Right Hon. A. J. Balfour, stated in the House yesterday that he hoped to be able next Monday to announce the result of the peace negotiations in South Africa. Mr. Balfour added:

LONDON, May 29. -- The programme for the coronation tournament, in which boxers and wrestlers from different parts of the world, chiefly America, will compete, was finally agreed on to-day. The contests will be held at the National Sporting Club, afternoon and evening, beginning with the afternoon of June 21, when there will be boxing competitions between representatives of Yale, Oxford, Cambridge, and the English public schools.

LONDON, May 30. -- The capture of Commandant Malan, announced from Middelburg, on Wednesday night, renews attention to the activity of the rebellion in Cape Colony. Commandant Malan took the late Commandant Scheepers's command when Scheepers was captured by the British, and became chief Boer commandant in Cape Colony after Commandant Kruitzinger's capture.
PARIS, May 29. -- Sergt. Hoff, the famous Franc Tireur (sharpshooter) of the siege of Paris, is dead.

There has been no incident in the many and varied manifestations of friendly feeling extended to the Rochambeau delegation more happily significant than the speech of Archbishop IRELAND at the notable banquet of the Friendly Sons of Saint Patrick on Thursday evening.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I inclose what to me Is a very curious old version and variation of the familiar theme or "The House That Jack Built." It was kindly copied for me from the Hebrew Passover Service Book, in which it is printed in Hebrew as well as English. The marginal interpretations, as given, are highly interesting.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 30 -- The citizens of the National Junior Republic, near Annapolis Junction, Md., held an interesting fete this afternoon under the auspices of a number of prominent society women of Washington and Baltimore to celebrate the close the third year of the successful establishment of the Republic.

On Monday evening. May 19, John Anderson, Jr., sold a further portion of the collection of autographs belonging to Gen. Badeau, and principally relating to the rebellion, including many letters and documents of the highest historical importance, written by Abraham Lincoln, Gen. Grant, Gen. Sherman, and others.

THIS volume, entitled "More Letters," and containing 192 is as rich in "FitzGerald" characteristics as those with which we are already familiar. These -- as Carlyle fitly named them -- "human letters" were doubtless waited and longed for by many: and perhaps the hope of still more is entertained by those who have felt their charm.

During the greater part of the thirty years of Mr. Clapp's service on The Boston Daily Advertiser he has been recognized as the leading dramatic critic of New England. The collection of his most memorable observations in book form goes far to entitle him to be rated as one of the leading dramatic critics of the country, with very few equals and probably no superior.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- President Roosevelt, in his Memorial Day address this afternoon at Arlington made some utterances which have astonished Washington and brought down upon him extremely sharp criticism. Democrats in Congress accuse him of "waving the bloody shirt," and of making a bitter, unjustifiable, and senseless attack upon the South.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- The four big packing concerns of the stock yards, at conferences held to-day with union leaders representing the striking teamsters, refused absolutely to grant the concessions asked, or any part, and went openly on record as being unalterably opposed to the recognition of union labor in the yards.

In a beautifully made edition on French hand-made paper, limited to five hundred numbered copies, uniform in every way with "The Personality of Thoreau," by Frank Sanborn, will be found a hitherto unpublished essay by Henry Thoreau, "The Service," which is edited by Mr. Sanborn.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: YOUR most valuable and interesting paper has from time to time passed in review the above name. Will you allow the writer to set the story at rest, for all time, by sending you a true account of the tragic fate of this lovely and accomplished woman?

Pastors of prominence in Manhattan and Brooklyn will be absent from the city during July and August, some of them from June until Sept. 15, but hardly a principal church, with the exception of the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst's Madison Square Presbyterian, will be closed without union services being arranged.

Dead Writers Henored and to be Honored. The Board of Managers of the Society of American Authors, at its meeting May 27, passed five resolutions in reference to the late Dr. Thomas Dunn English. Dr. Henry Morton, Bret Harte, Paul Leicester Ford, and Frank R. Stockton.

The New York baseball players celebrated their return to the home grounds by losing two games to the Philadelphias yesterday. As Brooklyn won twice, the New Yorks are now in fifth place. Twenty-six thousand persons were at the Polo Grounds. Ten innings were required to decide the morning game, Philadelphia winning in the last inning, when Mathewson had to retire, his arm having given out.

We think most of Police Commissioner PARTRIDGE'S fellow-citizens must be driven to the conclusion that he is taking his official responsibilities much too easily. There was a flippancy not much short of shocking in the comments attributed to him upon the presentment of the Kings County Grand Jury on the neglect of the police to enforce the laws in Brooklyn.

EORGE PASTON, a name well known to be assumed, and by some said to conceal the identity of a woman, writer, has given us in "Little Memoirs of the Nineteenth Century," a series of well-written sketches of half-forgotten celebrities who were more than famous in their day.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Gen. William F. Spurgin, recently promoted from Colonel of the Fourth Infantry, has been retired, making two vacancies at present in the list of Brigadier Generals. Col. Samuel M. Whitside, Tenth Cavalry, stationed at Fort Robirson, Neb., will be named for one of the vacancies.

TACOMA, Washington, May 30 -- An account of the manner in which the Columbia River steamer Camano was lost Tuesday morning at Entiat, eighteen miles above Wenatchee was received here to-day. The vessel was in command of Capt. Dwight Barrett and was on the down-river trip, with 500 sacks of wheat aboard.

LONDON, May 30 -- Money was in strong demand to-day. The consols settlement accentuated the stringency, in addition to the indisposition of the joint stock banks to lend freely at the month-end. Discounts were maintained.

Errors on the part of the Jersey City players were responsible for their defeat in the baseball game with Newark at Jersey City yesterday morning. Jersey City scored its runs in the sixth and seventh innings, but in the eighth the visitors made two runs, which placed them in the lead. The score:

Walter J. Travis and Frank A. Marcellus Will meet to-day on the Tuxedo golf course for the metropolitan championship. Travis beat the present title holder, Findlay S. Douglas, in the semi-final round yesterday by the high score of 6 up and 5 to play. It was a remarkable game, for the men finished the entire round, Douglas doing the course in 79 strokes, while Travis made a new record of 72 strokes.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Readers interested in a recently published book containing letters from Mrs. Mary Cowden Clarke to Robert Balmanno may like to know something of her method in preparing her great work, "The Concordance to Shakespeare," as detailed in a letter to S. Austin Allibone, dated May 12, 1852, and accompanied by a dozen pages of the manuscript.

All of the banks and exchanges were closed yesterday, and Wall Street generally took a holiday. Even in the uptown offices -- kept open for the convenience of customers desirous of doing business in the London market, which was open -- there was only a slim gathering of the speculative element.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 30 -- Having honored in Washington the memory of the Count de Rochambeau, commander of the French Army in America in the Revolutionary War, the members of the French mission came to Newport to-day to offer a tribute to Le Chevalier de Ternay, commander of the fleet of war vessels which conveyed the Rochambeau soldiers to Newport, their landing place.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Senor Felipe Buencamino, the head of the Federal Party in the Philippines, accompanied by the Filipinos now in Washington, paid a pilgrimage to Mount Vernon to-day. While there Senor Buencamino made an address at the tomb of Washington, in which he said, in part:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 30 -- Open Trolley Car No. 6 of the New Paitz and Poughkeepsie Traction Company had a head-on collision with a coupled freight and passenger car near Pratts Mills this afternoon and about thirty people were more or less injured.

Twenty-eight yachts sailed in the twentieth annual regatta of the Harlem Yacht Club yesterday, and made fairly fast time over the courses, running from City Island Point to the eastward on Long Island Sound. There was good yachting weather with a breeze that almost demanded single reefs at the start, but that flattened out to a midsummer breath just at the end.

IN HIS Preface to this book Mr Joline disarms criticism, and it would be unfair to be severe upon a performance which, though slight, is in the main pleasing. Indeed, the book is like the curate's egg -- parts of it are excellent.

Mrs. Nellie Collins, wife of Patrick Collins, a laborer, was sitting on the stoop of her home, at 328 East Twenty-ninth Street, last evening, holding her eighteen months' old baby in her arms, when she suddenly exclaimed: "My God, I'm shot!" and, toppling over, rolled to the bottom of the steps.

WEST POINT, May 30 -- For the second time in eight consecutive games played in as many years, the baseball team of the Seventh Regiment Athletic Association of New York was defeated this afternoon by the cadets of the Military Academy. The score was 7 to 2. The day was perfect, and a crowd of 7,400 persons watched and cheered the victory of the cadets.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 30 -- A large field was out at the Fairfield County Golf Club to-day when the first half of a 72-hole medal play handicap for the E.B. Curtiss prize was played. H.W. Slocum led at the close with 155 net; W.T. Bouchelle second. The players and scores are:

BOSTON, May 21 -- An editorial article, entitled, "On Keeping the Fourth of July," will appear in the July Atlantic, and will probably advocate something different from the present barbarous and wasteful methods of celebration, even if Webster did commend them. The article is written especially to introduce a group of papers on the new questions of pith and moment, such as race prejudice in the Philippines.

HONOLULU, May 24, via San Francisco, May 30 -- News comes from Korea by steamer that famine in several districts is causing great misery and many deaths. In the Kyoha district the people were driven to stripping bark from the trees and eating it. Trees around a royal tomb were thus treated, though the keeper warned the starving people they were committing sacrilege.

-- In defending the Western Union Telegraph Company from the charge of unprogressiveness, brought against it by Prof. PUPIN, Mr. J.C. BARCLAY, an electrical engineer employed by that large corporation, did not help his case any by accusing the professor of a lack of knowledge of the telegraph business, and he did not do it much good by describing the speed with which the company serves especially profitable customers, like stock brokers with private wires.

THE fair promise made for this latest and costliest variorum edition is fulfilled typographically the earlier volumes of the Biblophile Society's Horace. The introduction by Archbishop Ireland announced on the title page of Volume II., the first to issue from the Riverside Press, is doubtless reserved for Volume I.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 30 -- The Hillside Tennis and Golf Club held three competitions to-day. The leading event was a handicap for the holiday cup, which was won by W.L. Murray. The leading scores are:

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: You can render great service to many of your readers by publishing from time to time a list of books suited for a modern Sunday school library. I find that a very level-headed committee makes bad blunders in spite of great care -- its members are so busy.

Society was truly rural yesterday. Very few people of fashion remained in town. There were house parties at suburban settlements and attractive programmes of games and out-of-door sports at the country clubs. The Pioneer went out with a jolly party, and many men were at the races.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- The Browning Society closed its year's work on Tuesday night with a stage presentation of " The Flight of the Duchess." The poem had been recast into dramatic form by Prof. Henry Hanby Hay, who made liberal use of the original, and whose own work, wherever it was necessary for him to fill out the original for the purposes of dramatic use, was strong and pleasing.

An hour before the doors of the Metropolitan Opera House were thrown open last evening persons desiring to attend the memorial exercises began to gather in the corridor and before they were permitted to enter there were more than a thousand people crowding and surging in front of the house, blockading the sidewalk, and, for a time, stopping traffic on down-town Broadway cars.

Beginning with the issue of to-morrow, June 1, THE SUNDAY TIMES will be enlarged and in many ways improved. The news is the blood and bone of a newspaper, on Sunday as on other days, and with the immediate news of the day THE SUNDAY TIMES will be better furnished than ever before.

Fifty-five automobiles started on the 100-mile non-stop endurance contest of the Automobile Club of America from this city to Southport, Conn., and return yesterday, and forty-four of them succeeded in completing the run without exceeding an average of fifteen miles an hour, the speed limit, or going below eight miles an hour, which had to be maintained over the entire course to render a vehicle eligible for a certificate.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 30 -- The Yale Art School commencement was held this evening. The address was by William A. Coffin of New York, who spoke on " Art in the United States."

To look for the explanation of inexplicable and unprecedented phenomena is natural enough, no doubt, and very likely we shall have every unusual incident in nature for the next twelve or eighteen months plausibly attributed to the volcanic activities in the Windward and neighboring islands.
Col. George Harvey of Harper Brothers, who has just returned from London, was visited by a TIMES reporter this week, who put a few questions to him. The answers are characteristic.

A new edition of Dickens is an interesting event at any time, even though he seems to have had his share, for each succeeding issue not only reveals something new in the way his books may be handled, but it shows that there is apparently a new class of readers which the publisher deems is eager to be satisfied.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 30 -- The Memorial Day regatta on Lake Cayuga to-day between the junior crew of Cornell, the Newell crew of Harvard, and the second crew of Syracuse was the occasion of a Cornell victory. The course was two miles.

HONOLULU, May 24, via San Francisco, May 30 -- The effects of the volcanic eruption at St. Pierre are supposed to have been felt here. Last night there was a lurid sunset and the sunrise following was equally startling. Without clouds to make such a color, there was a red glare on the horizon as the sun went down and rose, and it was attributed here to volcanic dust from St. Pierre.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Franklin Geoghegan of the Capitol Hill Tennis Club defeated John C. Davidson in the final of the men's singles in the Southern lawn tennis championship tournament here to-day. This victory entitles him to play Raymond D. Little of New York, the present champion, to-morrow.

LONDON, May 30 -- Foxhall Keene, the Captain of the American polo team, today definitely selected the men who are to oppose the English team at Hurlingham tomorrow in the first game of the series to be played for the International Cup. The players are R.L. Agassiz, J.E. Cowdin, Foxhall Keene, and L. Waterbury.

The contests for the championship of the Intercollegiate Association have narrowed down to a duel between the representatives of Harvard and Yale Universities. At Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon trial heats in six track events and trials in all five of the field events were decided, with the result that Harvard's representatives to the number of nineteen qualified, while just eighteen of the New Haven contingent arc eligbile for the semi-finals and finals this afternoon.

Mr. William Cushing Bramburgh, a member of the Players' Club, and associated "in business hours" with the Real Estate Department of the Mutual Life, has shown himself to be a gifted amateur in a book which he has prepared for publication, or, rather, for printing. Taking Chaucer's tale of "The Cok and Hen," he has reproduced the text, while giving an illusion in type and illumination that is an achievement of modern artistic book-making.

"Her Serene Highness" is a story of love and adventure that follows afar -- very far -- off "The Prisoner of Zenda" and "The Princess Aline." Frederick Grafton, a young Chicago millionaire and collector of pictures, goes to Paris in pursuit of a portrait which his father has bought under the impression that it is a Velasquez, and sold on discovering that it is not.

LONDON, May 31 -- The Hon. Michael Henry Herbert, Secretary to the British Embassy at Paris, will probably be the next British Ambassador to the United States, in succession to the late Lord Pauncefote.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 30 -- Yale reversed all forecasts by beating Princeton in the first game of the championship baseball series at Yale Field this afternoon by a score of 10 to 6. The Yale lead was never in danger after the first inning, when, through 3 hits, 2 bases on balls, and 2 errors, Yale made 4 runs.

IT has been said by a high authority that it is easier to make a fortune than to keep one and more difficult to maintain a reputation than to make it. However this may be, it was certainly no easy task to prepare a new edition of the Encyclopaedia Britannica which would sustain the high reputation of the work.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of this morning is an article on Edison's storage battery which contains certain statements and invites certain inferences which are so misleading that I cannot refrain from commenting upon them. The article purports to describe Mr. Edison's battery and to compare it with the batteries now in use.

APOSTHUMOUS story by Paul Leicester Ford will appear next week in Collier's Weekly. It is entitled "A Checked Love Affair," and is the last short story that Mr. Ford wrote before his tragic death. Mr. Ford's widely read novel, " Janice Meredith," was originally published serially in Collier's Weekly.

ONDON, May 20 -- The death of Bret Harte was sudden and unexpected. Although it was known to his intimate friends that he was suffering from a mortal disease, it was not anticipated that the end would come so soon.

Without the slightest apparent difficulty, Samuel La Voice, a cyclist, of Syracuse, won the twenty-five-mile road race yesterday over the Irvington-Milburn road, near Newark, N.J. This was the fourteenth annual race of this event -- in late years known as the American Cycling Derby. The time of the winner was 1 hour 12 minutes 50 seconds, his handicap being 5 minutes and 30 seconds.

It is perfectly safe to take liberties with the deeds of the Kings of Israel or of the Kings of Judah, for only a small number of Gentiles will detect any difference between the true narrative and any moderately incorrect version, and Mr. John W. Harding's "The Gate of the Kiss" should not be condemned because it is less startling than the actual truth as to Sennacherib's ineffective expedition against Jerusalem.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 30 -- W.D. Vanderpool won the championship of the Morris County Golf Club to-day for the second time. He met P.H.B. Frelinghuysen, a Princeton student, but the latter was forced to default after playing three holes, as he injured himself a week ago in athletic exercise, and he found that he was unable to continue the match.

CUMBERLAND, Md., May 30 -- Union and Confederate veterans united here to-day in the observance of Memorial Day. The Confederates usually hold their exercises in June, but here the feeling is so cordial that the former foes now unite in doing honor to their hero dead.

"Madame Butterfly" and "The Fox Woman" established Mr. Long's power to inrerest and attract, and that he possessed in addition to these easily detached and defined qualities that volatile essence which no amount of effort can either achieve or define -- the gift of charm.

In the Spring and Summer of 1901 an associate member of the Royal Institute of British Architects devoted many weeks to visiting American libraries and examining the most recent methods of library construction in the United States. How thorough and painstaking that investigation was may be learned from a paper recently road by him before the Royal Institute at one of its fortnightly meetings.

A selected portion of the fine library of J.W. Ford was sold by Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge May 12-14, Goldsmith's "Vicar of Wakefield," first edition, realizing the record price of u114, and other important English books selling high. One of the most interesting books in the sale was Pope's "Essay on Man," 1732-34, first edition, with manuscript corrections in Part I, by Pope, which sold for u190.

An intimate acquaintance with Rosamond Courtney's family makes it apparent why her young life should have been blighted. Aside from the tragic history of her mistaken marriage to a picturesque villain, the immediate members of the fair Rosamond's household were hopelessly vulgar -- of the species that never realizes its short-comings.

According to the first folio, Dame Quickly reports that when Falstaff lay dying "his Nose was as sharpe as a Pen, and a Table of greene Fields." Mr. Edwin Reed accepts the emendation that makes this line read:

London, May 31 -- Speaking at Leeds last night Lord Rosebery advised the leaders of the Liberal Party to postpone the announcement of their programmes until there was some immediate prospect of getting them carried out.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 30 -- The smallpox quarantine ordered by the Board of Health of Kentucky against Indiana has been suspended, to take effect ten days from to-day, instead of Sunday, as originally provided. This is the result of an agreement reached this afternoon at a conference at the Galt House between the Kentucky Board of Health by its Executive Committee and the authorized representatives of the Indiana Board of Health.
SUBJECT -- The council at Jerusalem. Acts, xv., 22-33.

The lecture on William Blake and his influence, on art given by the Rev. W.M. Guthrie of Fern Bank, Ohio, at the National Arts Club on May 14, was listened to by an appreciative audience of club members and their quests. As the original stimulus to the chin of Pre-Rapaelites later in the century, the works of William Blake will always be interesting, said the lecturer.

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., May 30 -- At the conference on International Arbitration here to-day the platform of the conference was presented by Judge John I. Gilbert. The resolutions recited the achievements of the past year in the cause of arbitration, including the reference of a dispute between the United States and Mexico to The Hague tribunal, which, it was declared, marks an epoch in the adjustment of international controversies and the development of international law.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 30 -- A largely attended meeting of engineers, firemen, and pumpmen was held at Donnolly's Hall, this city, to-night. It is said every colliery in Wyoming Valley was represented. Addresses were made by John Fallon, member of the National Board of United Mine Workers; Henry Collins, and D.J. Reese, members of the executive boards.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 30 -- Joseph Bingham, a colored coachman, employed by George Rogers of North Broad Street, was hitching up a horse in Mr. Rogers's stable to-day, when he suddenly turned away, drew a revolver from his hip pocket, and fired a bullet into his head. The discharge of the revolver frightened the horse, which dashed out of the stable and down the strict.

LONDON, May 31 -- The birthday of King Edward (who was born on Nov. 9, 1841,) was officially celebrated yesterday, it having been decided, as announced in The London Gazette on April 15, that his Majesty's natal day was to be celebrated in London and on the home stations on May 30, as being the most suitable time for a military display.

It was altogether fitting and proper that Joaquin Miller should write about Bret Harte. These two men breathed the spirit of the early West through all their writings. "With Walker in Nicaragua" had in it the revelation of a new phase of life as picturesque and as absorbing as any of Harte's tales of the mining camp and the mountain range.

Senator MORGAN is distinctly one of the "men of light and leading" in his party in the Senate. Although the Senator from Alabama is often prosy, and sometimes appears perverse, there is no Senator on his side, or indeed on either, who takes more pains to inform himself before he speaks.

Has any one ever counted the descendants of Dr. Holmes's two "medicated novels," "Elsie Venner" and "The Guardian Angel" ? "Sir Richard Calmady" is the youngest among the progeny of the elder book; "Roman Biznet," by Mrs. Georgia Wood Pangborn, comes very directly from the younger.
LONDON, May 30 -- New York publishers who have been in London this Spring have generally returned emptyhanded, complaining that they found next to nothing worth buying.

MR. ARTHUR SYMONS has been writing verse long enough 'o acquire a goodly number of admirers. It will be pleasant news to these that has now gathered in two handsome volumes, printed by John Lane, all of his poems that he cares to preserve.

The Rev. J.D. Robertson, M.A., a Scotchman, has given the Christian world a little book calculated to have a wide influence on those who devote themselves to the service of the kingdom of God and its advancement among men. In beginning his studies of this most fascinating and mysterious theme Mr. Robertson avoids the two extremes on which many have been wrecked.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- The University of Pennsylvania crew won the junior 'Varsity boat race from Columbia and Cornell on the national course on the Schuylkill River in Fairmount Park this afternoon, Columbia was two lengths behind Pennsylvania at the finish, and Cornell was five lengths astern of Columbia.

The cornerstone for the new Labor Lyceum Building, on Willoughby Avenue, between Myrtle and Evergreen Avenues, Williamsburg, was laid yesterday afternoon. Fully one hundred labor organizations were represented and there were present also labor union delegates who came from as far as Philadelphia and Baltimore.

The story of the fight of the Revenge against fifty-three Spanish ships of war in the Azores will be as dear to the heart of our British cousins as long as it is necessary for England to maintain a navy. There are, too, possibly few American schoolboys who have not some time or other learned to declaim the ballad beginning:

ASKED to write something reminiscent of Francis Bret Harte. I will try to do So, partly because California is doing herself scant credit by unkindly allusions to this brightest genius that has yet set foot on her soil and partly because I am greatly obliged to him.
Many persons will probably read "The Thrall of Leif the Lucky" through at one sitting, though there be half a dozen other things they had intended to do that evening. So much for its interest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: New York City is noted for its charitable institutions, yet with them all, it is doubtful if any philanthropy is more needed in this city than a day nursery for colored children.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, May 31. -- Frohman and J. M. Barrie have come to an understanding about the production of "Quality Street" in London without Maude Adams, who will soon be here, but will not act. No new play for her or for John Drew has as yet been finally selected, but Barrie is finishing a piece, which will be ready for next season, and R.C. Carton has one well under way.

A CERTAIN young New Yorker who found himself desperately hard up last week was reduced to the necessity of selling or pawning some of his possessions to tide him over for a few days. It wasn't the first time he had been confronted with this necessity and he cast his eye around the room, wondering which of the few objects of value remaining he could best afford to part with.

As a part of the Memorial services in Broadway Methodist Church, ex-President J.H. Martin of Moore's Hill College Sunday night delivered his lecture on "Abraham Lincoln." In simple, forceful sentences he portrayed Lincoln the man and President. He told with eloquence the story of Lincoln's early life and struggles; of his achievements as a lawyer; of his historic debates with Douglas and of his dramatic political career, with its tragic ending.
SHE had lately set up a dressmaking establishment and was chatting of her trials.

PEORIA, Ill., May 31. -- Frank P. Sargent, Grand Master of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen, and a member of the National Arbitration Board, said in an interview here to-day that unless conditions greatly changed the soft coal miners of the United States will be called out in a sympathetic strike within ten days.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The action of the United States in permitting its citizens to sell mules and horses to the agents of the British Government, presumably for the use of the British Army in South Africa, appears to have been considered by some people a breach of neutrality.

The sudden resolve of Emperor WILLIAM to decorate Washington with a statue of FREDERICK THE GREAT has roused a pother in Germany as well as in America. Persons who reveal an amazing absence of the sense of humor, among them correspondents and at least one Congressman, are alarmed lest a bronze Frederick on a bronze horse should put Freedom to flight.

BOSTON, May 31. -- "The Ideals and the Duties of the Republic" was the subject of the address that was delivered by Jacob Gould Schurman, LL. D., President of Cornell University, before the delegates at the convention of the Free Religious Association of America to-day. The sessions were held in Colonial Theatre, President Edwin D. Mead presiding.

The Hide and Leather National Bank will soon move into the front row of National banks in this city if plans now on foot are carried out. It is proposed to increase its capital stock, which at present is $300,000, to $5,000,000, or, possibly, $10,000,000.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Raymond D. Little, Southern tennis champion of 1901, successfully defended his title to-day, defeating Franklin Geoghegan of the Capitol Hill Club in the challenge match. Little won easily and was in fine form.

The London correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES recently called attention to the fact that Swiss hotel proprietors and commercial travelers had by convention fixed a system of tips. This was held at Olten by the Society of Hotel Proprietors, the Society of Commercial Travelers and others interested in the question.
"They are inaugurating a telephone exchange in Fort Benton." said a Northern Montana man recently, "that will put the embryo telephone companies entirely in the shade.

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., May 31. -- Many wealthy New Yorkers will pass the Summer at Mill Brook, Dutchess County. Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and her niece, Miss Johnson of New York, will arrive there on Monday and stay during June. When Lieut. Vanderbilt returns from State camp at Peekskill on Friday next he will join his wife at Mill Brook.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The Secretary of War has transmitted to the Senate Committee on the Philippines a copy of a report made by J.G. Livingstone, Governor of the Philippine Province of Sorsogon, of the killing by soldiers of two native officials of the town of Santa Magdalena of that province.

A SQUAD of police raided the pushcart men on Beaver Street, and amid great excitement managed to round up a dozen in the short block between New Street and Broadway. An Italian ice cream vendor took fright and left his cart and its contents to the tender mercies of the scores of messenger and office boys that infest the neighborhood.

LONDON, May 31. -- The first of the five test cricket matches between Australia and England, which was commenced Thursday at Birmingham, resumed yesterday and and was to have been decided to-day, was abandoned on account of the weather.

DETROIT, May 31. -- "Neighborhood and Civic Improvements" was the general topic of discussion at the first session to-day of the National Federation of Correction and Charities. After Robert W. De Forest of New York had read the report of the committee which has been investigating the subject, papers on various phases of it were read.

Frederick W. Kelsey, one of the original Park Commissioners in charge of laying out the present Essex County, N.J., park system, who has given the subject of public parks much attention and is familiar with the larger park systems, both in this country and abroad, yesterday gave his views concerning Central Park.
TUESDAY, JUNE 3. -- By Philip A. Smyth, executors' sale, 105 West Forty-third Street, north side, 93.6, feet west of Sixth Avenue. 18.6 by 100.5, four-story brownstone front dwelling.
"Did you see that distinguished-looking man who came down the aisle of the theatre and whispered in Mrs. Giddypate's ear?"

THAT many of the familiar phrases and jokes which pass current at the present time are of ancient origin is no longer a matter of mere surmise. It is being established by archaeological and philological research, much to the discomfiture of the modern joker.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 31. -- Tuxedo passed an exceptionally lively week. The metropolitan golf championship attracted many of the social colony, and the week's end at the club houses and among the cottagers was lull of social functions. The cool weather of the first part of the week kept many from coming out to their cottages, but on Saturday there were several arrivals.

Thirty thousand pounds of canned meats, which had long been exposed to the sun, were condemned at the stock yards by Meat Inspector John J. Cashin, just as jobbers were about to negotiate sales with local peddiers. The meat was a relic of the fire that destroyed part of the German-American packing plant last month.

Letter to the Editor of The London Times. Sir -- You have spoken words, I will not say of comfort, but of consolation to us. Time is the consoler, and (in the plural) you have acted in your traditional capacity. As you say, our memory lingers fondly on the one mild May out of a dozen, and so we think the remaining eleven bitter Mays are exceptional.

On the sixth floor of the Capitol, some 180 feet from the ground, in the southeast tower or pavilion, is being constructed out of wooden joists and other fuel for flames another of those cheap apartments which are partitioned off every week or so and called offices of this or that department.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- In that dignified legislative body the Senate, where solemnity reigns and where a casual handclap is rebuked with sternness by the gavel of the President, and a warning that the galleries will be cleared if the offense is repeated, a United States Senator was hissed to-day -- hissed and hooted for a long time without an interruption, and without the slightest admonition from the Chair.
The London Telegrah of May 15 contains the full text of a remarkable speech made by Mr. Andrew Carnegie in Guildhall, when he was presented with the Freedom of the Worshipful Company of Plumbers:

For the third time in four days the New York baseball team was shut out at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. It was a battle of the pitchers, in which Voorhees of the Philadelphia team had a shade the better of it, and the visitors won by a score of three to nothing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your splendid editorial in THE TIMES today on "Southern Opinion" can but force home to the hearts and minds of all lovers and promoters of education that the one main watchword should be "Agitate, agitate, for more education." As Benjamin Franklin said, "A Bible and a newspaper in every house, a good school in every district, are the principal support of virtue, morality, and civil liberty."

Patriotic young America is impatiently awaiting the recurrence of Independence Day, when he can spend the trifling sum of $7,000,000 in celebrating the anniversary of the birth of this great and good Republic under which he moves and has his being. Seven million dollars for fireworks! A mere bagatelle.

-- In the essay which won this year's first prize from the Stokes Fund for the Preservation of Native Plants, the author laid much emphasis upon the importance of impressing on the public mind that wild-flowers are of no actual -- that is, monetary -- value. We questioned the wisdom of this advice, on the ground that to declare a thins worthless was not the way to interest people in its preservation.

The will of Justice Miles Beach was filed for probate yesterday. The value of the estate left by the testator was not stated. His wearing apparel was left to James Campbell, his personal attendant. The residue of his property goes to his nieces, Mrs. Clara Hamilton, and Annie P. Beach. The executors of the will are ex-Judge Augustus C. Brown and John Delahunty.
New York City is again attempting to explain, in a manner satisfactory to herself, why it is that several Chicago millionaires have taken up their residence on Manhattan Island in the last few years.
WILKESBARRE, May 31. -- The following circular was issued from strike headquarters to-night:
I can forgive New York for doing some things in a bigger way than London does them.

AFTER an April in which rain or snow fell on nineteen days, and a raw, cold wind prevailed on several more. May 1 came with a few fleecy clouds above the forest-clad ridges, while the sun-lit air was fragrant with the breath of the balsam groves along the black-water streams. Two-thirds of the calendar Spring was gone, but the days of Adirondack flowers and birds had come at last.

Readers of THE SUNDAY TIMES will learn by our cable dispatches that London complains of the unusually small number of Americans who are there. Many of our countrymen recently arrived in London have fled to the Continent to escape the wretched weather and the exorbitant charges of the keepers of hotels and lodging places.

Unheralded and unannounced the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company has given the public, on the Third Avenue line, what many have been clamoring for in the form of open Summer cars. They include also smoking cars, since, as in the case of the surface cars, smoking is allowed on the four rear seats.

MADRID, Spain, May 17. -- It has been King's weather "to-day in Madrid, for the beginning of young Alfonso's reign. Such weather has prevailed since my arrival. Certainly Spain is trying to make the most of the holiday time.

Early in 1896 Mr. Samuel Eberly Gross of Chicago sought the aid of Mr. Ingalls Kimball of The Cheltenham Press in bringing before the world as a "privately printed book" an original comedy, which filled 168 quarto pases and was deemed by several good judges of the art of bookmaking to be an admirable specimen of mechanical end artistical skill in paper and typography.

Though last night marked the end of the theatrical season proper, and the beginning of Summer, with its open-air concerts and roof gardens, yet not a small number of theatres are scheduled to run on indefinitely. In fact, the announcements of several new plays to be put on this week might indicate the middle of the season, instead of the fag end.
ALPHONZO BUTTERWORTH of Kalamazoo has written another letter to Silas Larrabee. While we were at the Smithsonian Institution this afternoon Mr. Larrabee handed me the letter and asked me to read it.

LAWYER J.M. ROSEBERRY LONG tells a story of a domestic tragedy precipitated by the bursting of a toy balloon which involves a chain of circumstances of remarkable rapidity in sequence and of destructive effect. The balloon, which is one of the pig variety that are being sold in great numbers down town, was purchased by a friend of Mr. Long for his three-year-old son.
