THURSDAY, JUNE 5. -- By Richard V. Harnett Co., public auction sale, Amsterdam Avenue, northwest corner of Seventy-eighth Street, 40 by 102.2, seven-story limestone and brick apartment house.

"Sporche gentel These are not the kind of people I play for on the other side." remarked the First Lover, as he leaned gracefully against the piano in the pit, and surveyed the rough benches and yet rougher men who lounged, sprawled, or lay at length in various parts of the hall, each Smoking a pipe.

THE long parade of stoves that usually stops the way in the Spring season of Holland is now drawing to its end. The thermometer is still hardly above 50 Fahrenheit. The sun out of pure cussedness hides behinds a sky that looks like the wall described by Dante, where even Hope lost courage to step within.

LONDON, May 31. -- If a definite announcement of peace in South Africa is made Monday, as expected, that night will bid fair to rival the celebration which occurred when the relief of Mafeking was officially announced in May, 1900. Throughout London arrangements have been made for numerous peace dinners.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., May -- "Is the lobster a fish?" is a query that may sound absurd at first, but it involves a very nice point of scientific disputation, and two great nations are at a dead-lock over it for years past, the asperities of the problem having more than once brought them to the verge of war.

M. Duball, the French Minister to Japan, publishes some interesting details in The Bulletin Economique of Indo-China concerning the Japanese mercantile marine. The statistics referred to are taken from a report issued by the Japanese Minister of Communications, and they deal with the steady increase in the number of steamers and sailing vessels in the Japanese merchant service during the last four years:

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 31. -- Under the management, and for the benefit, of the Harrison Memorial Association, the first public readings from the works of Indiana authors were given last night in English's Opera House. Senator Fairbanks presided. The audience filled the available space.

BOSTON, May 31. -- With a blue sky and the rays of a sun not too warm, this day opened delightfully for the members of the French Rochambeau mission who came here from Newport. R.I., last night, and are to spend here the last day of their stay to America. They set sail to-morrow on their own battleship, the Gaulois.

Ex-President Cleveland has accepted an invitation to deliver an address at the opening of the new home of the Tilden Club, Broadway near Seventy-fourth Street, on June 19. The speech will be the first delivered to a political audience since Mr. Cleveland's retirement from the Presidency.

Summer plans are matters most of interest to society at the present time. Town houses are closed and nearly all the fashionable element is rusticating. It is only a month before the opening of the Newport season. During that time the Spring suburban resorts are having their full share of patronage.

Taking as text the rapid increase of local indebtedness in England, Robert P. Porter, former United State Census Commissioner, is leading in London an agitation in favor of curtailing further extension of municipal debts; and he is using American illustrations to point his arguments.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Felipe Buencamino, ex-Secretary of State in the Cablnet of Aguinaldo, was heard to-day for the first time since his arrival by the House Committee on Insular Affairs. Senor Buencamino is a type of the best class of Fillpino, about fifty years of age, of dignified bearing, his dark hair just beginning to turn gray.

AS the stogie man stood at the end of the bar he chuckled to himself and blew clouds of smoke until the mixer had serious thoughts of sending in a call for the Fire Department. Fortunately the broker's clerk and the meek man came in together and the oracle let it out.

In one sense national music is any music which is beloved by a nation. Under this head would come "Home, Sweet Home" and "Suwanee River," a more tender lyric of home and its memories than Stephen C. Foster's "Old Folks at Home," of which about 500,000 copies were sold. It was often under interdict during the civil war because it made soldiers down-hearted.

ELECTROPHOBIA is the disease which a woman who rides much in the electric cars says has become chronic with her. It is a most unpleasant disorder. accompanied by irritability, a feeling of antipathy to human beings generally, and in particular a chip-on-the-shoulder feeling at all times when traveling in the street cars.

The demand for the issue of more subsidiary coins, in other words, for small change, in this country has steadily increased for many years. Of late the increase has been very rapid. It used to be the theory of Congress that a limit should be fixed to the issue. The assumption was that coins which pass for considerably more than their face value should be very cautiously provided.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me a word in reply to your editorial of this date relative to the political ambitions and plans attributed to W.J. Bryan and Tom L. Johnson. To such of your readers as are familiar with economic principles and with the views held by these two men it appeals as eminently unjust that you should associate them as you have.

The fact that Dr. J. Koch sat up until early this morning in his room at 53 West Twenty-fifth Street to read Homer is probably responsible that no lives were lost in a fire which occurred there at 1 o'clock this morning.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, May 31. -- The topic of talk in London all this week, which has rivaled even the prospects of peace and the dream of an Imperial Zollverein in popularity, has been the possible successor of Lord Pauncefote in Washington.

LONDON, May 31. -- The most interesting theatrical item of the week in London is the announcement that Charles Wyndham and Sir Henry Irving may act together next season in a new comedy by Henry Arthur Jones, and although absolute confirmation of this is, at present, lacking, it is not unlikely.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The question of the succession to the place in the British Embassy here, vacated by the death of Lord Pauncefote, is attracting attention in official circles to an unprecedented degree. It is the custom of Governments before making such appointments to consult the Government to which the Ambassador is to be accredited before making a selection, in order to insure a favorable reception of the appointee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is always a painful thing to me to see a fault in our Chief Executive, for I admire the man and the President. But if his love of horseflesh did not interfere, no doubt he would see himself just now as others see him.

F.M. Smith's new steam yacht Hauoli was successfully launched at the shipyard of John N. Robins, Erie Basin, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. Superintendent Dickey supervised the launching, which was shortly before 3 o'clock.

The greatly increased quantities and the lower prices of early Spring vegetables of all kinds, and of small fruits, especially strawberries, in New York and other Northern city markets during the present season, as compared with conditions a few years ago, is a matter of common observation. Few persons who have noted and commented on the change have realized the true cause.

Walter J. Travis did what was expected of him yesterday at Tuxedo and won the Metropolitan championship for the coming year. He defeated Frank A. Marcellus of the Yountakah Country Club, Nutley, N.J., by 11 up and 10 to play. The final round was thirty-six holes, but only nine holes of the afternoon round were played, as the match came to an end on the eighth green, or twenty-six holes played in all.

The long-predicted absorption of the Havana Commercial Company by the tobacco trust, which was finally announced during the past week, resulted in material advantage to the holders of Havana Commercial by bringing about a sharp advance in both the common and preferred stocks.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Ontario, May 26. -- Another great water power canal is to be dug by the Clergue syndicate here. It will be the third to use the water of Lake Superior for the Consolidated Lake Superior Company, and will increase the company's power to about 110,000-horse power. All the contracts for this canal will be let this Summer, and heavy concerns are now making estimates.

Probably the oldest meteorologist living cannot recall such an unbroken succession of years as that through which we have passed since 1894 with a continuous deficiency of rainfall. The figures reported by the Astronomer Royal, dating from Jan. 1 to Dec. 31 in each year, are so remarkable as to be worth quoting in detail. They stand thus:

PRIVATE detectives in the large hotels in New York are supposed to have very easy berths. As a matter of fact, they are the hardest worked men to be found in the big caravansaries. They are on duty day and night, and have many peculiar jobs to do. One of the old hotel detectives in New York, who has been in the business for twenty years, yesterday related some queer experiences:

New records were made in the intercollegiate athletic championship meeting, which was concluded on Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon, and the anticipations of those who claimed that new marks would certainly be made in some of the events were more than realized. In all, four intercollegiate records were excelled and one world's record established.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Col. Wagner, Assistant Adjutant General U.S.A., and formerly Adjutant General of the Army in the Philippines, to-day continued his testimony before the Senate Philippines Committee. He said that he knew that one village had been burned because the citizens would not give information of the murderers of a native friendly to the United States.

Whether it be victory or defeat that awaits the great race mare Sceptre in the one hundred and twenty-third running of the English Derby, to be decided Wednesday at Epsom Downs, the very fact that Sceptre will run will make a worthy addition to the records of the race that throughout the world has earned place as the synonym of a supreme trial.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- By direction of the President, Secretary Root has issued a general order decreasing the strength of the permanent military establishment and changing the ratio of its make up, as provided in the general order issued last May to carry out the army reorganization law.
The following letter descriptive of the Boer delegates -- their appearance, mode of life, and views on peace -- has come to The Daily Telegraph of London from its special correspondent in Pretoria:

A stove fire and a burglar alarm caused plenty of excitement last night in the vicinity of 21 and 23 West Fourth Street. An excited man rushed into the house of Engine Company 33 on Great Jones Street and told the firemen that there was a fire in the Fourth Street building. They were about ready to go out when an alarm was sounded from a near-by box.

At the annual commencement exercises of Cooper Union last night, Abram S. Hewitt, Secretary of the Board of Trustees, announced several new gifts to the institution and stated that hereafter the entire building would be used for the advancement of knowledge, the income of the institution now being nearly $100,000.
"Try to bear up, dear," she said when he went to her and confessed that he had lost all; "it may be for the best."

CORK, May 20. -- On arriving at Queenstown, to visit the Cork Exhibition, one is struck by the total absence of anything suggesting coercion or poverty. There was a time, not many years ago, when beggars by the dozen blocked the way from the landing point to the principal hotel. But on this occasion I failed to encounter a beggar either at Queenstown or Cork.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, May 31. -- It begins to look as if the long delay had largely discounted the announcement of peace to the markets. It is a striking fact that this week of "peace markets," for every operator in the City regards peace as assured, and, in spite of the qualifying phrases in Mr. Baliour's statement Thursday, has been a week of many realizations.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- In pursuance of the settlement of the threatened street car strike, President Roach of the Union Traction Company, to-day, reinstated in the employ of the company 90 men, who had been discharged for joining the Amalgamated Association of Street Car Employes.

A Cleveland man has finished a new melodrama that he thinks will be a winner from the word go. He hasn't named it yet hut most any name will do, provided 11 shows up well on the posters, and the dramatist isn't worrying a bit about this trifling detail.
The man of the house happened to be in the kitchen when the peddler called at the rear door.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In speaking of England's attitude toward the United States Government during the war of the rebellion. "A Grateful American," one of your correspondents, says:

The stock market crawled through the four business days of the week showing hardly a single feature of interest. Coal-strike bulletins, Boer war dispatches, crop records and forecasts, and half a dozen lesser topics have had attention -- but none beyond what was purely conversational.

The Humbert case continues to be the sensation of Paris and London. Interest in London in the case has been increased through the development that Mme. Humbert numbered London bankers among her victims.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Representatives Babcock of Wisconsin and Overstreet of Indiana were in conference with the President this morning about the issues of the Congressional campaign.

IN the character and variety of the blessings bestowed no month in the year is so so rich as June. First on the list is the Summer solstice, the culmination of solar glory for dwellers in the Northern clime. The epoch occurs on the 22d, when the sun enters the sign Gemini and the astronomical Summer begins.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 31. -- Mr. and Mrs. W.S. Wells arrived this evening and are occupying their new villa on Bellevue Avenue.

"Down in Esplanade Avenue, near Bayou St. John, there lives a lady who has given much study to birds and fishes," said a gentleman who lives in the old quarter, "and she has quite an interesting collection at this time. She is Mrs. Sudier, and there is scarcely a better-posted woman in the country when it comes to the kind of pets she is fond of raising, canary birds and goldfishes particularly.

THE visit of a party of eminent Frenchmen for the unveiling of the Count de Rochambeau memorial and the raising of funds for the relief of the survivors of the eruption of Mont Pelee on the Island of Martinique have brought into prominence the French colony in this cosmopolitan city of New York.

According to John Hays Hammond, the mining expert and friend of the late Cecil Rhodes, who reached this city from England on the Lucania yesterday, that part of the Rhodes will bearing upon the subject of scholarships for American youngmen is to be administered more in its spirit than its letter.

"Men and women who have visited New Orleans have often commented on the happy system adopted here of naming the streets of the city," said an observant citizen," but it seems to me they have overlooked the real beauty of the system. The classical myths, like Dryades, the wood nymph, are all right, and Clay and Webster, and Calhoun are not bad.

Last week's developments in the money market only served the more strongly to impress how altogether abnormal were the conditions which prevailed two weeks ago when call rates for a time were carried up to 20 per cent, and the average buying figure for the week was between 32 and 15 per cent.

There seems to be no instance of a vote of censure being passed upon a Speaker of the House of Commons. But there is an instance of a Speaker being expelled the House. In 1694 it came out that Sir John Trevor, Member for Yarmouth, Hants, had received "a gratuity" of a thousand guineas from the City of London after the passing of the Orphans bill for services rendered during its passage.

DETROIT, May 31. -- Light Guard armory rang to-night with Republican sentiments uttered by leading men of that party at the seventeenth annual banquet of the Michigan Republican Club. More than 600 members of the club gathered about the banquet tables, and afterward cheered to the echo the addresses of the distinguished men who had come from Washington.

Mrs. Delphine Marie Pumpelly Read, who died in Paris, France, on Thursday, was in many respects a remarkable woman. Born in Owego, Tioga County, she went with her parents to Albany in 1841, where she resided until 1868. She was the daughter of Harmon Pumpelly, a descendant of Jean Pompilie, a famous French sea Captain who came from Avignon.
To the Editor of The New YorK Times: Sitting to-day upon a lonely island in Canada, opening a weekly mail and thinking only of the commonplaces of business, I came upon this note from a young friend:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with regret the well written, but ill-advised, letter in your issue of May 30 signed "Anti-Automobile." No one can doubt the good motives of the writer, but the tendency of such a communication is exceedingly bad. It tends to stir up a bitter feeling of class hatred, i.e., the poor against the rich.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of the 27th, concerning the Presidential prospects of Tom L. Johnson, whom you charge with being a "faddist," you talk about the "historic principles" of the Democratic Party and the possibility of a winning platform being constructed out of the trust and tariff issues.

LONDON, May 31. -- The first test polo match for the American Cup was played at Hurlingham to-day between the English and American teams, the latter winning by a score of 2 goals to 1. The weather was fine and the ground was good, but soft. An enormous crowd, including many ladies, was present.

Doubtless Bishop FALLOWS of the Reformed Episcopal Church and the Diocese of Chicago does well to maintain that he is not a citizen of so mean a city as many might be apt to suppose. But his method of defending its reputation against Bishop THOBURN and against the Rev. FRANCIS TUCK of Newberry, Penn., who had asserted that Chicago was wickeder than London or Hongkong, leaves something to be desired.
The meeting of the Lake Mohonk conference calls attention to the remarkable progress of international arbitration in recent years.

The heroes of Texas of over half a century ago are gathered in Fort Worth in their annual reunion. They are the veterans of the Mexican War, and there are but few of them with the elastic step and the straight, erect form. The greater number are bent with age, and the heads of the majority are as white as snow.
First Lieut. Edward P. Orton, Second Cavalry, will proceed to Fort Ethan Allen for duty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An influentially signed request for three months' delay was last Saturday cabled to the Directors of the United States Steel Corporation from here. The result is given in the telegraphic report of the meeting in The Daily Mail of Tuesday: "The management, of course, had a large majority of proxies, but the minority protested in impassioned speeches.

A small note written on fashionable paper in a delicate penmanship was the cause of a lively struggle in the West Thirtieth Street Station late last night between a well-dressed prisoner who was brought in on a charge of intoxication and a woman who said she was his wife and who had also caused his arrest.

FORT DE FRANCE, Island of Martinique, May 31, 7 P.M. -- The United States steamer Dixie arrived here from St. Vincent last night and left early this morning for New York. Prof. Robert T. Hill, United States Government geologist, and Mr. Russell are passengers on the Dixie.

SARATOGA, May 31. -- When the new Saratoga race track is thrown open to the public it will be found that the course on which so much time and money have been spent during the last few months is about the finest in the country. The Saratoga Racing Association has spent upward of $1,000,000 in building this racecourse, with a turf track and steeplechase within the limits of the principal track.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 31. -- One of the first results of the recent anonymous gift of $20,000 made to the Harvard Astronomical Observatory is a new study table for the Director's office. The table is probably unique among study tables the world over. It was worked out by Prof. Pickering and Mr. W.P. Gerrish, also of the observatory, and is practically six separate tables of ordinary size, each provided with its own bookcase.

LONDON, May 31. -- Unusually high prices prevailed yesterday at the annual sale of William Ashmead Bartlett Burdett-Coutts's stud, composed of harness horses. J.R. Smith of New York was the principal buyer. He paid 450 guineas ($2,362.50) for a pair of chestnuts, and 250 guineas ($1,312,50) for a single harness brown mare.

There is no one, perhaps, who plays will figures in a more interesting manner than Sir Alfred E. Bateman, who is the statistician of John Bull, shopkeeper, and has an office at the Board of Trade. He can make a blue book -- or, to be more accurate "white book" -- of figures of absorbing interest, and certainly his latest effort in this direction is not his least successful.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 31. -- The weekly competition for the President's Cup at the Park Golf Club this afternoon attracted a number of golfers. First honors went to Charles B. Morse, the points thus won, giving him first place in the contest for the trophy. S. St. John McCutcheon is second, and Senator Charles A. Reed third. The scores better than 100 were:

Fraudulent voting will receive another check through the action of the Municipal Board of Elections, which has just been made public. In requesting the Department of Health to furnish them with a list of names of all men whose deaths have been reported from Oct. 10, 1901, to the present time, and to supply supplementary lists weekly of all such deaths from now until Sept. 15.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- The teamsters' strike spread to the department stores today. Eighty-nine men working for "The Fair" struck, and it was stated that 400 more men, employed by other big down-town stores, would be out by night. The effect, it is said, will be practically to shut off the delivery of goods to customers and the bringing in of new stock.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 31. -- Joseph Nelson of Chicago broke the amateur one, two, three, four, and five mile world's records on the Colosseum cycle track this afternoon. Nelson was riding against A.A. Courter of Newark, in a five-mile amateur motor-paced race, when the records were broken. Summaries:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 31. -- Yale's 'Varsity baseball nine won a game from the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn to-day by a score of 8 to 4. In the seventh inning the visitors made 3 runs, which, with one already to their credit, tied the score for a few minutes. But in the second half of this inning Yale put in 4 runs, closing the scoring for the afternoon.

"who knew Bret Harte?" "I." "And what did you know about him?" No answer. They are ready enough with their "I's," these old residents who watched the name of Frank Bret Harte, only thrice capitalized, grow to Francis Bret Harte, capitalized from end to end, within the pages of San Francisco's Directory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The discussion going on in the public prints relative to the decadence of Central Park, so ably brought out by our competent Superintendent of Parks, Mr. Parsons, suggests that this is an opportune time to bring forward to public notice an improvement in our Park, the possibilities of which, to my mind, are practically infinite.

By hitting the ball freely, Jersey City's baseball team defeated Newark at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday, by a score of 14 to 5. Every player on the home team made one or more hits, and they rolled up a total of eighteen hits.

All the local Exchanges were again closed yesterday, and outside of the banking institutions there was little or no business doing in Wall Street. As was the case on the day previous some of the up-town offices of Stock Exchange houses were kept open for the benefit of those customers desiring to do business in London.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- In the Senate to-day during his speech on the Philippine Civil Government bill Mr. Spooner (Wis.) quoted from the diary referred to to show that Aguinaldo had said that once the independence of the Philippines was declared he (Aguinaldo) and his friends would take a trip to Europe with an allowance of $1,000,000 for expenses.

There was remarkable unanimity or sentiment at the reception given to Mrs. Linda Hull Larned, President of the National Household Economic Association, by the Directors of the School of Domestic Arts and Sciences in this city last Friday.

Yesterday was MeManus day in Central Park, where over 4,000 youthful followers of the leader of the Fifteenth District gathered to do him honor and, incidentally, to have the most enjoyable kind of a time. Thomas J. McManus himself was in charge of the festivities and aided by his mother, managed to make all the children happy.

THE Brooklyn Handicap and the very first warm days of last week brought out the Summer man in all his glory. Since then he has had to take refuge in Winter clothes and overcoats. But the cold is only temporary.

HAVANA, Cuba, May 27. -- As yet we are counting the age of the Cuban Republic in weeks and days. To-day the new nation was a week old. The wild enthusiasm with which it was greeted has lessened somewhat, but while it has lessened in a great degree, the feeling of contentment over their complete independence is very apparent in the people.

PARIS, May 31. -- The chief social feature of the week was a ball given by Mrs. Bell, sister of James Gordon Bennett, at her residence, in Avenue Henri Martin. The Misses Bell, with the Marquis de Montesquiou and the Comte de Berulle, conducted the cotillion.

Such business as has come to light during a somewhat abbreviated week has included scarcely a single transaction of the first importance and has emphasized the effect of the temporary retirement of large speculative interests from the market. Dealing has been of fair volume, but with few distinguishing features, and has for the most part had to do with those classes of property which may be expected to furnish the bulk of Summer trading.

WASHINGTON May 31. -- At the opening of the evening session of the Senate tonight Mr. Carmack, (Tenn.,) who had made several speeches during the debate on the Philippine bill during the day, took the floor. In explanation of the protracted nature of the debate, he said it had been carried on by the minority in the hope that the bill would be purged of its most objectionable features.

AMONG the interesting objects that fill the charming old house in East Eighth Street, the home of Alexander W. Drake, head of the art department of The Century, is a collection of "samplers," worked by the grandmothers of the present generation of Americans, when they were little girls.

THIS garden is not German, but only Surinam Dutch, and no one in it is called Elizabeth. This garden lies hidden behind a substantial old house that fronts the main street of Paramaribo. A high, wooden fence closes it in on its remaining sides, screened and dwarfed by an inner hedge of banana trees.

Quite generally in Wall Street surprise is expressed that W.K. Vanderbilt should have returned from abroad at this season of the year, when many prominent New Yorkers are making preparations for the regular Summer exodus -- either to the country or to London to be present at the coronation ceremonies.

PEEKSKILL, May 31. -- The twenty-first season of the New York State Camp ot Military Instruction opened to-day without ostentation or ceremony, save the firing of the National salute of twenty-one guns by a detail from the First Battery under command of Sergt. H.W. Mack. The flags, National and State, were hoisted on the poles and that was all.

ONE of the queer sights of an up-town street last Sunday was a balking horse hitched to a hearse. "I have seen a good many stubborn horses in my time," said the city salesman, "and likewise a good many funerals, but Sunday's exhibition was the first combination of the two that I ever came across.

The Cincinnati Bankers' Club at a meeting at the Queen City Club listened to addresses by James J. Hooker and Charles B. Murray. Besides these speakers others of the members were called upon for remarks.

WILLEMSTAD, Island of Curacao, May 31. -- Carupano, in the State of Bermudez, was reoccupied May 28 by the Government forces without resistance, the revolutionists having abandoned the town two days before Gen. Matos, the revolutionary leader, landed on Venezuelan soil, May 25, coming from Port of Spain, Trinidad.

There is a man out in Minnesota who seems to be in league with a woman in Dublin to neutralize the good work St. Patrick did in driving the snakes out of Ireland. The Northwesterner is proprietor of the "Minnesota Snake Farm -- rattlesnakes a specialty." He recently made a shipment of reptiles to the Dublin woman, Miss Anna Lewis by name.

The King's coronation ring has been reset. The size of his Majesty's ring finger has no doubt been accurately taken. In the case of the late Queen a neglect of this precaution led to painful results. The ring had to be forced on and a refrigeratory process was needed to get it off again.

Following the custom of King Edward, Who on returning from India allowed an exhibition to be made of those presents he had received from Eastern potentates, so the Prince and Princess of Wales have consented that the gifts and addresses which were presented to them during their tour of last year should be shown at the Imperial Institute in London.

PORTLAND, Oregon, May 31. -- At the general election Monday a full set of State officers, two Congressmen, and county officers will be chosen in Oregon. In Portland City officers are also to be elected, and a vote is to be taken on the adoption of a new city charter, framed with much care by a special commission created by the Legislature.

Tourists by wholesale and tourists by retail have been arriving in the republic during the last month. Some of them are a credit to the country from which they come and -- some of them are not. Of the first class very little is seen, though it is possible that in point of numbers they exceed the second.

LONDON, May 31. -- There were considerable movements in the money market today in connection with calls for new issues of capital and the payment of u1,000,000 ($5,000,000) of India bills. Rates for money were steady. Discounts were easier. Business on the Stock Exchange was quiet and operators were confident that Monday will be a red letter day, as peace in South Africa is expected to be then announced.

AMONG the many strange facts revealed in the records of the work of the criminal courts of this city, at present in the possession of the Court of General Sessions, probably the strangest lies in the proceedings of a jury of matrons who sat in judgment of the facts of a once-noted case in March, 1789.

IT was half-past 8 o'clock and the night staff at Beaumont Hospital was preparing to go upon duty in the wards at 9. Dr. Fenwick, the bouse surgeon, had withdrawn from his duties for the next sixteen hours, and sat smoking a cigar in the library of the apartments of the faculty when Dr. Lynds, his assistant, came in to have a half hour's chat with him.

One of the most interesting tricks that those wonderful people the Japanese have contributed to the amusement of the American public is the "enchanted fountain" act. The originator of this feat is Prof. Shogiokusai Ten-Ichi of Tokio, "juggler patronized and given a gold medal by his Imperial Majesty the Mikado," to quote his visiting card.

Since Mark Twain at a recent dinner in this city went into the subject of old-time physicians and their methods, an investigation has been proceeding in England into ancient cures and their authors, with the result that some strange and little-known facts have been brought to light.

PHOENIX, Ariz., May 31. -- Frank Conger, only twenty years of age, but famous as a daring horse thief in the Southwest, was captured on Thursday after a desperate fight with a party of Arizona rangers. For two months Oscar Felton, one of the rangers, had followed close on Conger's trail, extending more than a thousand miles in the long chase over mountains and desert.

President J.L. Greatsinger of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company has filed a protest against the terms which the Rapid Transit Commission recently decided to impose upon bidders for the construction of the tunnel between this borough and Brooklyn. In a letter sent to the commission Mr. Greatsinger says that the burdens imposed upon the new contract are greater than those imposed in the case of the subway now being built by the Belmont-McDonald syndicate.

HONGKONG, May 1. -- Whether or not Hongkong may have its best record behind it as a trading port, American opportunity is as good here, and suffers from as gross neglect, as anywhere along the China coast. The port is the commercial hub of Asia, the terminus of some of the mail lines, and the meeting place of all of them, from across the Pacific in one direction and through the Suez Canal in another.
The vote in the House for the abolition of drinks in the Capitol restaurant moved James Montreville Moody of North Carolina yesterday to an anecdote:

Woman continues to break away barriers. Her latest achievement is to induce the Post Office Department at Washington to put Martha Washington's face on the new series of eight-cent postage stamps, which will make their appearance next Fall.
A new species of shad has been discovered in this country. It inhabits the Ohio River, and has been named by the authorities of the United States Fish Commission at Washington "Alosa Ohiensis."

SEVERAL years ago a high-priced Broadway store room was converted into a restaurant of the "quicklunch" variety, and the venture wrecked the man who undertook to satisfy the noonday appetites of down-town business men and clerks. He left the fittings in lieu of rent and the owner of the property had several tenants before he found one who could make enough out of the place to pay the large rent.

When the first centrifugal sugar refining machine as invented in 1866, the period of time required for refining white sugar was reduced from sixty to seventy days down to the same number of hours. Claus Spreckels, Jr., is new the inventor of a machine or a process which reduces this period to a corresponding number of minutes.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 4. -- By Vincent A. Ryan, foreclosure sale, Joseph McElroy. Jr., referee, 12 Hamilton Street, south side, 133.5 feet east of Catharine Street, 25.1 by 103,11 by 104.1 by 25, six-story brick tenement, with stores. Due on judgment, $4,330.

THE Morris Park races brought out a number of striking gowns. Mrs. Clarence Mackay went up from town one day in a motor victoria. She wore a soft rose-pink costume of some filmy material. The skirt had a wide band of white lace insertion near the bottom and bands of white lace ran down the pouching bodice.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 31. -- This, the last day of the Philadelphia horse show at Wissahickon Heights, drew another great crowd to see the championship contests, with the pick of the blue ribbon winners of the week competing in the final classes. The feature of the day was the sweep made by the Widener entry, the bay mare Flower of Lynnewood.

LONDON, May 28. -- The Duke of Deddebroke to-day rehearsed the manner in which he will manage the royal peanut privilege on coronation day. The Duke suffered somewhat from stage fright, and did not fill his sacks very well, but hopes to overcome this before the date of the performance.

Weakened by the loss of Catcher Butler, who has been signed by the Jersey City baseball team of the Eastern League, and by the absence of Third Easeman W. O'Brien, Fordham College's has ball team was defeated by New York Athletic Club yesterday in a close game at Fordham. The score:

One of the largest of our soft coal operators, who for years has been an important factor in the development of the resources of the State of Pennsylvania, has within the past few months acquired a large acreage in the Pocahontas coal district of West Virginia, which will be tributary to the Norfolk and Western Railroad.

A most interesting story was told a Banner reporter concerning the original possession of the Island of Martinique. The story concerns Mrs. S.C. Reese of this city, whose grandmother once owned a greater part of the volcanic isle.

It will afford some excellent people in this country great satisfaction to learn that United States Consul TOURGEE, at Bordeaux, has deemed it consistent with his official duty to maintain, in a report to the State Department, the contention that the exaggerated, abnormal, and engorged goose livers which enter into the composition of the toothsome pate de foie gras are not "diseased."

AMONG the Presbyterian ministers who were presented to President Roosevelt when he came to the city recently was one who bears the burden of an overweening sense of duty and is wont to "rebuke in season and out of season" -- mostly out of season.

Four Seawanhaka challenge yachts, the Massasoit, Seeress, Nutmeg, and Tecumseh, met yesterday in a seven-mile race off Oyster Bay, on Long Island Sound. It was their first meeting and race and it was arranged by the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club.
For the first time in the history of the Congregational Church the degree of Bachelor of Divinity has been conferred on a woman.

There are many cynics loose in London. The cabby and the bus driver have lost their belief in the wisdom of man over the everlasting eruptions of the Strand. The gentlemen who sell "extry-speshuls" by shouting news which the extra specials do not contain never had any. The lions in Trafalgar Square, monuments of departed greatness, look wearily and cynically upon the present littleness that harangues them on a Sunday afternoon.

STATE CAMP, Peekskill, June 1 -- Bright skies and a bracing southerly wind from Peekskill Bay made the weather very enjoyable at the State Camp during the first Sunday of the twenty-first season. They accounted for the large number of visitors and also the lively condition of th seventeen hundred Guardsmen here.

The announcement by Lord KITCHENER that "terms of surrender" had been signed on Saturday evening is the announcement of the end of the Boer war. The problem of the British Government now is the future of South Africa.

Once more we are reminded, by the annual report of the City and Suburban Homes Company, of the financial feasibility of tenement houses constructed along strictly sanitary lines. This semiphilanthropic organization, it appears, has now more than $2,000,000 invested in New York tenements, and is so well satisfied with its experiment that it is preparing to extend its operations in new and sadly demoralized districts.

As is usually the case on the Sunday following a big regatta, there was marked decrease in activity among the Harlem River oarsmen yesterday. Most of the racing crews had broken training on Friday night and even those intending to keep in condition for coming events at Philadelphia or on Long Island Sound welcomed a day or two of rest.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 1 -- There was an automobile fire at the park In the centre of the city this afternoon. The machine was badly damaged. It was owned by Henri P. Wertheim of West Fifty-seventh Street, New York, whose Summer home is at Cedar Courts, near here, owned by his brother-in-law, Arthur H. Kahn.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The officials of the British Embassy here share the jubilant feeling existing in London over the termination of the war in South Africa. Official notice of the signing of the terms of surrender came to A.S. Raikes, the British Charge, in a cablegram from the Foreign Office at London.

LONDON, June 1 -- The most interesting question to-day in connection with the Stock Exchange is whether or not the steady upward tide of the past week will spend itself in the face of the official announcement of peace. The general impression is that this tide will not stop, although prices generally, considering the trade outlook, are quite high.
PARIS, June 1 -- The new Chamber of Deputies met this afternoon for the first time. The house and the galleries were crowded.

Four lives were lost, several people burned, some perhaps fatally, and two blocks in the seaside district of Rockaway Beach, in the heart of the amusement centre of the resort, were destroyed by a fire which began at about 4 o'clock yesterday morning and burned fiercely till 8 o'clock, when it was under control of the firemen.

BOSTON, Mass., June 1 -- To foil the miners' plans the operators to-day began hiring pump miners and engineers in this city through E.H. Sheville, an agent who opened headquarters in a West End hotel and advertised for help. It is known that he has hired and sent away several men to-night.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Under the terms of the unanimous agreement reached last Wednesday, the Senate will vote at 4 o'clock Tuesday on the bill providing a form of civil government for the Philippine Islands, and the entire intervening time of the Senate's sessions will be devoted to fifteen-minute speeches on the bill.

Nine cases of smallpox which developed in the Bronx Friday and Saturday have served to create a scare in that borough. There has been more or less of the contagion in that part of town during the Winter and Spring, but for the past three or four weeks there had been but few new cases.

HAZLETON, Penn., June 1 -- The scene that occurred here last night upon the arrival of a deputation of special officers was repeated at 7:30 o'clock to-night, when about twenty officers, in charge of a coal company agent, boarded a trolley car at the Hazleton House for Freeland. The streets of the city were crowded, and when the officers came into sight about 500 men rushed at them, hissing and yelling.

Beginning with the issue of yesterday, THE SUNDAY TIMES has been much enlarged and improved. Besides all the news of Saturday, there are included in the Sunday edition a Magazine Supplement, a Weekly Financial Review and Quotation Supplement, and many columns of special articles on subjects selected to interest readers in all the walks of life.

Mrs. Delia Shaughnessy and her two-year-old child were rescued in their night-clothes from the second story of a frame building at 157 East One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street last evening. The fire had made headway on the shingled roof when John Mahoney, of 155 East One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street ran into the house.

CINCINNATI, June 1 -- On account of the differences between the engineers and others employed in the breweries of Cincinnati and Newport more than 1,200 brewery workmen were locked out last February. At a conference yesterday it was learned that all have resumed work except 375. Meantime the breweries have been running at full capacity, and with their new men have more men in their employ now than they really need.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 1 -- M.A. Vicairo, editor of the Italian Herald of New York, and his coachman were badly Injured this afternoon, as a result of their horse running away after being frightened by an automobile. They were out driving, and were met by an automobile belonging to George Arents, Jr., which it is alleged was traveling at a high rate of speed and making a great noise, it as flew past.

Whatever the temporary course of prices may be -- this undoubtedly depending in large measure on the developments in the coal strike -- the one unmistakable fact is that general conditions, market and otherwise, of more than a transitory nature, are making for higher market prices.

Two men were shot and several were more or less seriously injured yesterday in a fight that occurred on board a barge carrying a portion of a picnic party of nearly 1,800 people, members of the Patrick Walsh Association.

LONDON, June 2 -- In an editorial article regarding the conclusion of peace with the Boers The Times says there has been and could be no treaty for a substantial settlement without the recognition by the burghers of the extinction of the South African republics and the definitive incorporation of their inhabitants into the British Empire.

The invasion of mechanics into the domain of the pastoral threatens to rob the conventional Summer vacation of much of its charm for "city folks " who are lured to the fields and woods under the largely mistaken notion that discomfort and recreation are synonymous, and that one cannot be had without the other.

A typical late day of Spring was yesterday, with a clear sky, warm sunshine, and gentle breezes out of the northwest early and the south later. Under the favorable conditions nearly 10,000 persons went to Central Park, where the first concert of the season was given by the Seventy-first Regiment Band.

One of the interesting events at the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, is the distribution of prizes to the children. It was conducted yesterday morning, and the rooms of the institution were crowded with visitors throughout the day.

LONDON, June 2 -- The Peking correspondent of The Times says the conditions drawn up by the allied commanders at Tien-Tsin for the return of the native city to the Chinese have been accepted by the representatives of the six powers interested. The Chinese are eager to regain possession of the chief city of Pe-chi-Li Province, and will yield to force majeure and accede to the conditions laid down.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The following correspondence between Gen. Brugere of the French mission to participate in the Rochambeau statue exercises and the President was made public to-day:

KINGSTOWN, Island of St. Vincent, May 30. -- La Soulriere volcano is still active. Another eruption occurred at 3 o'clock this morning. It was accompanied by a thunderour noise and a shock of earthquake, while volumes of dense vapor ascended to such a height that they were visible from Kingstown.

Here is a delightful parasol. It is of white, with raised chenille dots, also in white, covering it rather closely, and with a white, enameled handle. The top of the handle is irregular, like a small root end, and in the irregularities are small brilliants and red stones.

John G. Bogart, one of the persons injured during the races of the Automobile Club of America at Staten Island on Saturday, diet at the Smith Infirmary yesterday, changing the result of the tragedy of the freakish motor vehicle to two deaths and five injured.

The Central Federated Union denounced In strong terms at its meeting yesterday the awarding of a contract for $7,000 worth of printing for The City Record to a firm of printers in Grand Rapids, Mich., when a number of printers, it is alleged, are idle in this city.

TACOMA, Washington, June 1 -- Nine steamships and sailing vessels sailed yesterday and to-day, and during the coming week they will carry three thousand persons to Nome, the majority of the argonauts being claim owners or men with business projects.

LONDON, June 2 -- Peace has been declared after nearly two years and eight months of a war which has tried the British Empire to its uttermost and which has wiped out the Boers from the list of nations. The war has come to an end with Lord Kitchener's announcement from Pretoria that he, Lord Milner, and the Boer delegates have signed "terms of surrender."

James Brown Lord, the well-known architect, died after a lingering illness in his home at 21 West Fifty-fourth Street yesterday afternoon. He had been ill since January, and his death was not unexpected. Mr. Lord was forty-three years of age and is survived by Mrs. Lord and one son, James Couper Lord, a junior at Harvard University.

FORT DE FRANCE, Island of Martinique, Saturday, May 31, 8 P.M. -- The National Geographical Society has scored a great triumph through its representative here, Prof. Angelo Heilprin, who this morning, with three guides, ascended to the top of the crater on the summit of Mont Pelee.

The second public meeting under the auspices of the Israelite Alliance of America, in furtherance of the agitation to safeguard the rights of American citizens in Russia, was held yesterday afternoon, in the large hall of the Educational Alliance, on East Broadway. The hall was crowded and the meeting was enthusiastic.

LONDON, June 2. -- A Parliamentary paper, issued this evening, gives the correspondence preceding the peace agreement. From this it appears that Gen. Schalk-Burger, Acting President of the Transvaal, informed Lord Kitchener March 12 that he was prepared to make peace proposals.

Except in the Hazleton district the order calling out the engineers, firemen, and pumpmen from the mines does not appear to have been generally obeyed. Most of the firemen went out, not so many of the engineers and pumpmen. In the Hazleton district the order was effective.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- All the business of the Metropolitan National Bank was merged this morning with that of the First National, Deposits of the latter Institution were, in round figures. $98,137,000. While it is to be expected some accounts will change, that so large a percentage should go with the Metropolitan is still a matter for congratulation by the First National officials.

LONDON, June 3. -- In its City article to-day The Times says the conclusion of a very heavy settlement in consols made the demand for money strong and only a trifling portion of the large amount due banks was repaid. Discount houses decided to raise the deposit rates onehalf of 1 per cent, and discount rates were a shade easier.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- A demurrer was filed by the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company in the United States Circuit Court to-day, in the case begun by the Inter-State Commerce Commission last March, based on the Sherman law and the Inter-State Commerce act, to prevent rate cutting and discrimination against shippers by the railroad.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 2. -- The plans for ending the anthracite strike which gave such promise of success on Tuesday and Wednesday last appear to have miscarried. I understand the reason for this was that some of the leading operators do not think the union has yet been sufficiently punished and that if any peace overtures were now authorized the United Mine Workers would want to dictate terms.

Montefiore Isaacs, who died on Sunday morning at his apartment in this city, was one of the best-known and most popular bachelors in New York society. Mr. Isaacs came of an old and distinguished family, which has been identified for years with New York. His uncle was Sir Moses Montefiore of London, the famous philanthropist.

CHICAGO, III., June 2. -- New York exchange, to-day was 20 per cent. Time and call loans. 41/2@5 per cent. Conditions in the local market were similar to those in Wall Street. The trading was desultory and on a small scale, with prices showing only fractional variations. Union Traction was a little higher on the settlement of the labor troubles on that system, and Biscuit common also showed some improvement.
WASHINGTON, June 2. -- General debate on the Philippine Government bill was announced in the Senate to-day, the arrangement being that the debate should proceed under the fifteen-minute rule.

One might imagine the Golden Age come again, to listen to the mellifluous accents of Kings and Presidents as they beat their breasts and call the world to witness what lovers of peace they are; as they send each other telegrams dripping with the honey of brotherly love, and present each other with gifts of gold, services of silver, statues of bronze.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 2. -- The New Emmanuel Church, which has been built by Mrs. Natalie Bayard Brown as a memorial to her late husband, John Nicholas Brown, will be consecrated to-morrow. The Right Rev. Thomas M. Clark, D. D., Bishop of the Diocese of Rhode Island and Senior Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church of America, now in his ninety-first year, is expected to perform the consecration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At a mass meeting In the interest of temperance, and in connection with the meeting of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of the United States, a delegate, the Rev. Isaac J. Lansing, was reported to have said: "Liquor is to be held responsible for the great coal strike.

It is not easy to see why Miss Viola Allen should bid a superheated public to the Garrick Theatre to see her play Julia, unless it be for the same reason that Mary Jane said she played the piano -- for her own amazement.

LONDON, June 2. -- Not in years has the House of Commons been so thronged with a brilliant and enthusiastic audience as when the First Lord of the Treasury and Government leader in the House, A.J. Balfour, announced this afternoon the peace terms concluded with the Boers.
HARRISBURG, Penn., June 2. -- Commissions were issued by Gov. Stone to-day to about 100 additional coal and iron policemen for duty in the anthracite strike region.
ROME, June 2. -- The Papal Secretary of State, Cardinal Rampolla, to-day received Judge Taft, Governor of the Philippine Islands.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 2. -- The local market enjoyed a slight additional medium of activity with an encouraging degree of firmness all through the list. The advance of 1 point in Maryland and Pennsylvania Railroad was in line with the prevailing opinion as to the ultimate fate of the road.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 2. -- This was a day of extreme dullness and Irregularity in the Philadelphia market. No effect was observable from either the peace or the strike news. The coal stocks and stocks akin to them yielded somewhat, taking1 their cue from the Readings. This stock was sometimes slightly higher here than in New York, and such trading as there was was for arbitrage account.

At the meeting of the Chamber of Commerce on Thursday the report of the Committee on Finance and 'Currency, of which Mr. JOHN HARSEN RHOADES is Chairman, on the policy of redeeming silver dollars in gold will be considered. The report is in entire harmony with the views of the committee as submitted at the March meeting, which were unqualifiedly in favor of gold redemption of silver dollars when presented in sums of five dollars.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- Riot and bloodshed marked the progress of the teamsters' strike to-day. There were numerous fights between the police and the strikers and their sympathizers. Street-car traffic was stopped while the fighting went on.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 2. -- The Ninth had its first practice march today. Immediately after reveille this morning the dismantling of the camp on the North Field, across the Annsville Creek, commenced. The tents were soon struck and packed, with the equipage, rations, , in fourteen army wagons.

The Greater New York Democracy has opened the campaign for the defeat of Daniel F. McMahon. Tammany leader of the Seventeenth District and one of the triumvirs of the Wigwam. How Richard Croker and Daniel F. McMahon, as he charged, divided between 51,000,000 and $1,500,000 profit as the result of contract work done for the Metropolitan Street Railway Company was told in detail by John C. Sheehan, once leader of Tammany Hall.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 2. -- In Grace Episcopal Church, Orange, this afternoon Miss Florence Louise Day, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Weldon Day of 158 Harrison Street, this city, was married to James Pinkney Henderson Adams of New York, by Archdeacon Alexander Mann, rector of the church.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The Cuban reciprocity situation clarified somewhat to-day, but not in a way very satisfactory to the friends of Cuba. Things were being done at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue. At the White House end the President, roused to action by the imminent danger of the failure of his plan, was rounding up beet sugar Senators and pleading with them to carry out the Administration's scheme of relief for Cuba.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Gen. Samuel Pearson, the Boer representative in this country, said to-night that he intended to call to-morrow at the British Embassy and ask for transportation to South Africa.

ALBANY, June 2. -- The report of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for the quarter ended March 31, just made to the State Railroad Commission, shows phenomenal results in operating the system, in that its operating cost was less than half its earnings for the quarter, and with the taxes on all its property used in operating the road and on earnings and capital stock, but 4 1/2 per cent. above half the earnings.

In yesterday's New York security market -- less than 275,000 shares being traded in -- there was slight reflection of the improved conditions which are naturally accredited to the settlement of the British-Boer war. Final quotations showed few fluctuations of consequence, only three stocks traded in to the extent of a thousand shares changing as much as a whole point.
We submit certain propositions to the candid consideration of the Automobile Club of America.

E.H. Harriman, President of the Southern Pacific Company, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad, and chief power of various other railroad systems in the West and Southwest, returned yesterday from a three months' tour through those sections. Mr. Harriman has heretofore been almost inaccessible to reporters, but yesterday he talked to a group of newspaper men.

Carey -- Jewett. The wedding of Miss Mary Seymour Jewett, daughter of the Rev. Edward Hurst Jewett, and George Carey of Baltimore took place at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, in the Church of the Transfiguration, and was followed by a small reception at the residence of the bride's cousin, Mrs. Wilmot Towsend Cox.

District Attorney Jerome returned to his desk yesterday after his trip to Cambridge. Asked what he had to say in regard to the speech of Abraham Gruber criticising him for referring to the " Ghetto " and the Irish, Mr. Jerome said:

BOSTON, June 2. -- Robert Swan, the oldest Principal of a Boston school, died at midnight at his home in Dorchester. He attended as usual to the routine duties of his school throughout last week. Shortly after 10 o'clock last evening he experienced difficulty in breathing. A physician was at once summoned, but Mr. Swan died within two hours.

LONDON, June 2. -- The peace in South Africa and Us very elastic terms were welcomed in London to-night with a mild repetition of the Mafeking celebration. Hundreds of thousands of people surged through the streets of London from Whitechapel to Buckingham Palace, but never at any time did the density of the crowds equal that of those which created the verb "to maffick."

Henry Siegel is making arrangements for the construction of a building on the site of the small piece of property at the northwest corner of Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway, which he purchased about a year ago for $375,000.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were very limited, a fairly large number of stocks being traded in but none showing overmuch activity. As in the Stock Exchange market, the course of prices was somewhat uncertain, the same stocks advancing and declining at different times during the day.

The terms of peace agreed to by the Boers and the British are honorable to both sides and secure, as far as it is possible to foresee, in the words of King EDWARD, "prosperity in his new dominions," and "cooperation on the part of his South African subjects in promoting the welfare of their common country."

The month of June is one of marrying and giving in marriage, and yesterday was the first of the numerous weddings of the month. To-day there are also a number, both in New York itself and in the suburbs. The church ceremonials, the receptions, and the wedding breakfasts make up the sum total of the assemblages of fashionables at this late season.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Acting Secretary Darling has received a report from Commander George W. Mentz of the United States steamship Sterling, dated San Juan, May 22, on the relief work done by that ship in Martinique and St. Vincent.

The Board of Governors of the Automomile Club of America will this afternoon hold a special meeting at the offices of the President, Albert R. Shattuck, 11 Broadway, to discuss the accident at Grant City, S.I., on Saturday, which resulted in the killing of two persons and injury to many by an electric racing machine built by the Baker Motor Machine Company swerving into a crowd.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 2. -- The order of the United Mine Workers of America, calling out all engineers, firemen, and pumpmen employed at collieries where the eight-hour work day with present wages was not granted, went into effect to-day, and, as has been predicted, a majority of the men obeyed the order.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day decided the case of the Inter-State Commerce Commission vs. the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company and others, involving the right of the commission to reduce the terminal rate made by the railroads in Chicago on cars containing live stock.

Charges of brutality in caring for a patient in an ambulance have been made against Dr. J. Walsh of Fordham Hospital, and are in the hands of the Board of Trustees of Bellevue and Allied, Hospitals. The complainant is Charles Newbold of 2,867 Webster Avenue, Borough of the Bronx, who was in Dr. Walsh's care in an ambulance about two weeks ago.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 2. -- James McNamara of Chicago is here, acting in behalf of mine owners near Hazleton, Penn., to secure men to take the places of striking coal miners in that vicinity. Only firemen and pumpers are wanted, as the mines already have engineers either working or ready to work when the firemen and pumpers arrive on the scene.
SEATTLE, Washington, June 2. -- Word has been received here that an eruption of Mount Blackburn, Southeastern Alaska, occurred on April 11.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 2. -- In the District Court here to-day in the cases of the State of Texas against the Southern Cotton Oil Company and the National Cotton Oil Company, both New Jersey corporations, charged with forming a combination to control the price of cotton-seed products in Texas, in violation of the Anti-Trust act of 1898, the defendant companies admitted the facts charged, and each paid to the State penalties aggregating $2,600.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- In the House to-day Mr. Grosvenor (Ohio) moved the passage, under suspension of the rules, of joint resolution extending the thanks of Congress to Secretary of State Hay for his address on the occasion of the McKinley memorial services last February.

Fleeing gamblers surprised in a big poolroom in Forty-second Street, near Lexington Avenue, by a raiding party from the office of District Attorney Jerome yesterday afternoon in pure, wanton vengeance turned and opened fire with revolvers on the officers of the law.

ALBANY, June 2. -- After being located elswhere for thirty years the State Democratic Headquarters was reopened here tonight most auspiciously. The new home of the State Democracy is at 119 North Pearl Street, corner of Orange, and diagonally opposite the historic two-steeple Dutch Reformed Church.

BOSTON, June 2. -- The money market continues dull and easy. The weekly statement of the associated local banks, issued to-day, shows a loss in the surplus reserve of $1,203,572. The New York reserve was increased $1,074,428. Loans were expanded $1,397,000 and deposits increased $689,000. The stock market was a little firmer for the Coppers, but otherwise featureless.

The Quebec Line steamship Madiana which arrived yesterday evening from Barbados and the Lesser Antilles had on board twelve newspaper correspondents, including a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES. who sailed three weeks ago on the United States steamer Dixie, the relief ship of the American Government bearing food, clothing, and other necessary supplies to the thousands who were impoverished and ruined by the volcanic eruptions on the Islands of Martinique and St. Vincent.

It was a wise thought of ex-Senator HILL to get the Democrats together at Albany. The meeting at the State headquarters is of good augury for Democratic union and harmony. Democratic leaders all over the State showed either by their presence or by words of approval and encouragement their willingness to Co-operate for the success of the party.

Whether one of District Attorney Jerome s County Detectives had a right to shoot James McCoy, a poolroom attache, during a raid on the Sherman Hotel, in East Forty-second Street, night before last -- for it is now admitted that the bullet was fired by Detective McLellan -- is a question that agitated police and political circles considerably yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Consideration was resumed in the Senate to-day under the fifteen-minute rule of the Philippine Government bill. Mr. McLaurin (Miss.) denied that the Democrats had attacked the army.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 3. -- The new Emanuel Church, the gift of Mrs. Natalie Bayard Brown, in memory of John Nicholas Brown, was dedicated to-day by the Rev. William N. McVickar, Coadjutor Bishop of the Diocese of Rhode Island assisted by Bishop Walker of Western New York, and the clergymen of the city and diocese.

FORT DE FRANCE, Island of Martinique, June 3 -- 1 P.M. -- George Kennan, accompanied by Messrs. Jaccaci and Varian, arrived here at 11 o'clock this morning after an absence of twelve days. Prof. Angelo Heilprin, President of the Philadelphia Geographical Society, who is in Martinique under the auspices of the National Geographical Society, and M. Leadbetter are expected to reach Fort de France tonight.

Capt. Michael E. Foody, who has been on trial at Police Headquarters for neglect of duty in failing to enforce the excise law from the West Thirty-seventh Street Station, has been found guilty. Commissioner Partridge having announced his decision to that effect yesterday. A public reprimand is named as the punishment.

WEST CHESTER, Penn., June 3. -- A collision occurred to-day on the Central Division of the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad between a special train en route from New York to Lincoln University, near Oxford, Penn., and an extra freight train. John Hendricks, fireman of the special, was killed.

WEST POINT, N.T., June 3. -- The entertainment for the Board of Visitors to-day was a cavalry drill on the cavalry plain. The troop was under command of Capt. Sands and Cadets Casad, Hinrichs, and Bell. The drill was followed by target practice with machine and mounted guns on the target range by the first and second classes, and rifle practice on the target range by the third class.

PEEKSKILL, (State Camp.) June 3. -- One of those old-time thunderstorms, so familiar to National Guardsmen who have spent many Summers here, descended upon this plateau this evening as the men were at supper. There was the usual preliminary, a scorching hot day, with the sun's rays beating down on the plateau and the mercury climbing way above the ninety mark.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3. -- The Philadelphia market to-day was dull and irregular. Reading common was an exception, New York taking all the stock offered here. The advance in this issue acted in some measure toward sustaining the market, but the list generally was lower. National Asphalt, which has been somnolent for a long time, advanced one-eighth on the transfer of 100 shares.

Three years ago the theatres of the country blossomed with Cyranoses: two years age there were Sapphic staircases on every hand, and now, no sooner has Mrs. Leslie Carter taken a vacation than Jeanne du Barry crops up at the American.

ALBANY, June 3. -- Very quietly, and unannounced, seven of the Bishops of the Province of New York assembled in Albany to-day for the purpose of selecting three names to be forwarded to Rome from which, possibly, the selection for the successor to the late Archbishop Corrigan of New York may be made.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 3. -- Miss Grace Leskom, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin S. Leskom, was married in the First Presbyterian Church here to-night to the Rev. George Jeffrey Russell of Montclair. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles T. Berry of Brooklyn, assisted by ' the Rev. L.S. Fulmer, pastor of the church.

The New York baseball team was again Defeated on its own grounds yesterday afternoon. This time they lost to the Chicago team, which opened the present series. Superior playing on the part of the visitors, both at the bat and in the field won the victory by a score of 12 to 4.

Weddings still form the subject of greatest interest in society, and there were several yesterday and there are a number arranged for to-day. The sailing of the ships for Europe to-day will take away about the last Americans who intend to be in London for the coronation. There are not many well-known New York names on the different lists, and the bookings have already been given.

A fairly large number of stocks were dealt in yesterday in the market for outside securities, but none showed large totals. Prices in most cases were firm, some issues making advances of importance, while few or no stocks showed more than fractional reactions. In Trenton Potteries preferred, Union Typewriter common, and one or two other stocks the highest prices yet reached were recorded.

It is the opinion of Mr. JOHN D. STANCHFIELD, as expressed in his speech at the opening of the State Democratic headquarters at Albany, that "a horizon prophetic of success" now invites the gaze of the members of his party. In his view also "the time bristles with issues."

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The same opposition that took place in the House when the Cuban problem was pending in that body is going on in the Senate. The beetsugar Republican Senators have appointed a committee to confer with a committee representing the Administration Senators, and for the time being it is left with the joint committee of conference to wrestle with the Cuban question.

LONDON, June 4. -- The Times's correspondent at Cape Town says that Premier Sir Gordon Sprigg in his speech declared that the Colony's extraordinary expenditure caused by the war and the plague was u3,000,000, ($15,000,000,) but, owing to the buoyancy of the revenue, the debt was only u1,750,000, ($8,750,000.)

The Mayor has revised his intention of reducing the number of the City Civil Service Commission to three, and Mr. OGDEN has revised his announced intention to take no salaried office under this administration. As a result, Mr. OGDEN becomes the paid President of the commission as it was originally made up.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Philippine Government bill, as passed by the Senate to-day, approves the action of the President in creating the Philippine Commission and the offices of Civil Governor and Vice Governor of the islands, and authorizes the Governor and Vice Governor to exercise the powers of government as directed by Executive order.

BOSTON, June 3. -- Frederick F. Ingalls, for forty-eight years an officer in the municipal courts here, died to-day, aged ninety years. Both in age and in length of service Mr. Ingalls was considered the oldest municipal court officer in America, and one of the oldest, if not the oldest, active member of the Independent Order of Oddfellows in New England.

PARIS, June 3. -- At a Cabinet Council, held at the Elysee Palace to-day, and at which President Loubet presided, the Premier, M. Waldeck-Rousseau, formally presented the resignation of the Cabinet, and in so doing expressed the sentiments of gratitude which his colleagues and himself retained for the constant kindness the President had shown them.

BOSTON, June 3. -- The demand for money is very limited, and rates are nominal. Clearing House rate, 4 per cent.; New York funds, 5 cents discount; call loans, 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent.; time money, 4 to 4 1/2; Clearing House exchanges, $25,958,734; balances, $1,761,614. In the stock market, American Telephone sold off to 175; otherwise there was no feature.

The flat-iron-shaped apartment house facing on Broadway, No. 934. Brooklyn, and bounded on the east and west by Myrtle and Stuyvesant Avenues, caught fire yesterday morning, and for a time gave the firemen and policemen considerable work in rescuing the occupants, mostly women and children, and extinguishing the flames, which in a short time gained much headway.

There is evidently an attempt making in a portion of the press to awaken prejudice against District Attorney JEROME in connection with the shooting of a man in the poolroom raid on Monday afternoon, and in this effort we regret to see that Magistrate CRANE shows some sympathy.

WASHINGTON, June 3. --The Statistician of the Department of Agriculture estimates the total area planted in cotton at about three-tenths of 1 per cent, less than the acreage planted last year. On the basis of the acreage figures published on May 31 of last year this would give an acreage for the years 1902-03 of about 27,450,000.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 3. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Rock Island Railroad Company will be held in this city to-morrow. R. R. Cable, Chairman of the Board of Directors, says there is little outside of routine matter to consider.

-- A Washington dispatch, as explanation of the Navy Department's failure immediately to make public the findings of the court of inquiry in the case of the officers arrested in Venice, says that, in view of the clemency extended by the King of Italy, it is not deemed politic to publish conclusions that might reflect on Italian Judges and policemen.

Senior students of the New York University held their class day exercises on Battery Hill, at University Heights, yesterday afternoon, before an audience of about 800. F. R. W. Cleverdon was the marshal of the day, and led the opening procession from the Hall of Fame to a beautiful grove of elms, where the festivities began.

TRENTON, N.J., June 3. -- Attorney General McCarter, representing State Bank and Insurance Commissioner Bettlem, made application to-day to Chancellor Magie for a ruling for the Public Savings and Loan Association of Newark, to show cause why it should not be adjudged insolvent and a receiver appointed.

The women of the Apawamis and the Harbor Hill Golf Clubs met yesterday on the links of the Apawamis Club at Rye to compete in the Class B series of team matches for the women's metropolitan championship. Miss Genevieve Hecker headed the home club forces, and she beat Miss M.L. Scrymser, the Harbor Hill champion, by three points, the Nassau system of scoring being used.

LONDON, June 3. -- The supply of money was small to-day, and the demand was strong. Discounts were firm. Business on the Stock Exchange was quieter and there were more realizations, which depressed consols. Several home rails were lower. Americans opened dull, afterward had a hardening tendency, and remained steady and inactive, closing quiet.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 3. -- It is to be regretted that so many well-informed people speak and write of the quiet which now prevails throughout the mining districts as "ominous." To expect trouble and predict it would seem the surest way of inviting it. The sincerity of the strike leaders is generally doubted.

As all the world knows, these are busy times for England's Parliament, and busier than the cisatlantic world wots. Not only have great questions of peace and war been debated. Not only has there been considered no smaller question than the abandonment of Cobdenism, or what has been alleged as such, in the form of a tax on imported food.

LONDON, June 3. -- Many Americans found their way to Epsom to-day, where King Edward and a brilliant suite watched the races, which will culminate to-morrow in what is expected to be the most brilliant Derby in years.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,00. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

No more speed contests on public highways will be held by the Automobile Club of America. That decision was reached yesterday after a prolonged meeting of the Board of Governors, held in the offices of President Albert R. Shattuck, 11 Broadway. The formal resolution embodying this decision of the club was given out after the meeting and is:

CHICAGO, June 3. -- Present Indications are that the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago and Northwestern Thursday will be an uneventful one. W. K. Vanderbilt, Chauncey M. Depew and H. McK. Twombly will arrive here in a special train over the Lake Shore in the morning to attend the meeting.

The deliveries of soft coal were very much increased in this city yesterday, especially in the down-town office buildings, where quantities of soft coal were openly unloaded all day. Complaints poured into the offices of the Board of Health from all parts of the city of violation of the ordinance.
WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows:

CHICAGO, June 3. -- Chicago's police were given a strenuous life to-day by the striking packing house teamsters. In spite of the striking teamsters and their friends thirty-three wagon loads of meat were delivered from the stockyards to down-town stations. Before the task was accomplished, however, a score of policemen and rioters had been injured, and fully fifty persons had been placed under arrest.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 3. -- President Mitcheli to-night gave out the following statement:

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- By a vote of forty-eight to thirty the Philippine bill passed the Senate to-day. Every Democrat voted against the bill and so did three Republicans -- Senators Hoar of Massachusetts, Mason of Illinois, and Wellington of Maryland. Mr. McLaurin of South Carolina, who is no longer counted as a Democrat by either side, voted for the bill.

Lack seems to have turned at last for the racing stable of William C. Whitney, for, following the victory of King Hanover in the Carleton Stakes, which some critics asserted was a "fluke," the Whitney filly Morningside yesterday at the Gravesend track captured the Brookdale Handicap, one of the important events of the meeting, in a style that left absolutely no room for doubt that she was the best horse at the weights and distance.

William S. Devery, who is contesting in the courts his removal through the operation of the single-headed Police Commission law as Chief of Police, squared off last night at his country villa at Arverne and dealt blows from the shoulder at the Tammany Hall triumvirate and many of its leaders.
