Yesterday's dealings on the Stock Exchange, totalling barely 180,000 shares, were the smallest for any one day in the year -- the smallest, indeed, since October of 1900, almost two years ago. This fact tells the story of the day and carries its own comment. There was no market worthy of the name, trading being in the main of a spasmodic style and purely professional in nature.

The annual report of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway Company for the year ended March 31 last was made public yesterday. The report shows that the passenger earnings increased from $6,400,014 to $8,030,164 for the last year. Freight earnings Increased from $17,730,397 for 1901 to $19,061,857 for 1902.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- One of the largest and most enthusiastic gatherings ever assembled in the large banquet hall of the Auditorium was present to-night at a dinner of the Illinois Manufacturers' Association.

English editors utter many criticisms upon the exuberance of American journalism. Usually they condescendingly add that American editors must know their business, and supply the sort of reading adapted to their readers' tastes. For ourselves we make no retort, but call attention to a recent incident for what it may be worth as showing that, however different from American journals English journals may be, it does not follow that they are models of editing.

BALTIMORE, June 4 -- The local market was excessively flat and featureless to-day. The strength of Lexington Railway 5s was the roost interesting point in the day's whole list of sales. Just prior to June 1 they were selling at 102 1/2. On June 1 they sold ex dividend; since that late date they have lifted from 100 to 101 3/4.

The Boer war and its results have damaged no reputation quite so seriously as that of PAUL KRUGER, lately President of the Transvaal Republic, now a refugee in Holland, where he is said to have received the news of peace with the exclamation, "My GOD, it is impossible!"

FORT DE FRANCE, Island of Martinique, June 4 -- Prof. Angelo Heilprin, President of the Philadelphia Geographical Society, who is here for the National Geographical Society, came into Fort de France last night from his explorations of the crater on the summit of Mont Pelee. Prof. Heilprin is well and in good spirits.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 4 -- The Rev. Dr. William Rodgers Richards listened to the advice of prominent members of his congregation this evening regarding the call extended by the Brick Church in New York City. Nearly 400 members of the Crescent Avenue Church considered the subject.

Dr. Harrison Taylor Cronk, who has an office at 205 West Eleventh Street, and who is connected with the Board of Health, hurried into the Charles Street Police Station yesterday morning about 3 o'clock, clad only in nightgown, trousers, slippers, and coat, and told Sergt. Byrne that he wanted to make a charge of assault against Frederick Arlington, who also lives at the Eleventh Street address.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- The danger to American National life resulting from the love of ease and luxury was pointed out by Francis L. Patton, President of Princeton University, at the meeting of the Presbyterian Social Union, in this city last night.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Venezuela and the United States of Colombia appear again to be on the verge of war. Colombian troops are massed on the Venezuelan frontier and are preparing to invade the neighboring republic.
District Attorney Jerome yesterday gave out a statement in reference to the decision in the case of Capt. Foody by Commissioner Partridge. He said, in part:

In order to understand with any clearness what the Senate did in passing the bill relating to the Philippines, one must take into view the bill proposed by the opposition, which contains actually the sole alternative suggested in all the long and stormy debate.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 4 -- With 700 men idle in a total of 1,200, the close of the first day in the strike of conductors and motormen on the United Traction and Electric Company finds three cities and a dozen or more towns within a radius of sixteen miles of Providence seriously inconvenienced, due to the lack of adequate transportation facilities.

LONDON, June 5 -- The Times's correspondent at Pretoria says that possibly some may consider that the fact that long negotiations preceded peace and that such liberal terms were granted was a mistake, and may think that the Boers win hereafter assert that they were not really defeated.

Transactions in yesterday's stock market were only a few thousand shares in excess of those of the day previous -- itself the dullest day in nearly two years. This said, the story of the day, marketwise, is practically told. The trading was altogether listless and spiritless, with few changes either on the up or on the down side, and those of an unimportant nature.

Katharine Hartridge, accused by Otto C. Kersgood, a confectioner of San Francisco, Cal., with stealing $270 from him, was arraigned before Magistrate Pool, in Jefferson Market Court, yesterday, and held in $500 bail for examination to-day. The woman was arrested by Detective Jackson of the harbor police at the Panama Steamship Company's pier on Tuesday night, upon her disembarkation after a long voyage, during which the alleged theft occurred.

TUCSON, Ariz., June 4 -- The uprising among the Yaqui Indians is becoming general. A detachment of seventy-three men from the force of Gen. Torres, who is pursuing the Yaquis in the Mazatan Mountains, east of Hermosillo, was ambushed and thirty of the number killed. Capt. Celso Gomez and Lieut. Jose Valejo of the Twentieth Battalion were among the slain.

COLUMBIA, Mo., June 4 -- The graduating exercises of the State University of Missouri took place to-day. The programme included several special attractions. The feature was the conferring of honorary degrees of LL. D. on a number of distinguished personages, including Mark Twain, the humorist; James Wilson, Secretary of Agriculture; Ethan Allen Hitchcock, Secretary of the Interior; B.T. Galloway, Chief of the Bureau of Plant Industry, and Robert S. Brookings of St. Louis.

Newark made it three straight victories from the Jersey City baseball team yesterday, the latter being unable to hit Thielman to any extent. The work of young Daly for Newark was the feature. The score:

ALBANY, N.Y., June 4 -- Justice Chester has granted an injunction restraining the beef-packing companies of the West from carrying on business in this State in violation of the provisions of the Donnelly anti-trust law. The order was served upon the representatives of the concerns in this city and Troy to-day, and will be served on others throughout the State as quickly as they can be reached.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 4 -- State Controller Miller to-day gave his decision on the long pending contest of the law passed by the Legislature of 1901, which taxes the surplus of savings banks in addition to their real estate. The Controller decides that the tax is constitutional. The matter now probably will be carried to the courts.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., June 4 -- The Manhattan College baseball team easily defeated the Lehigh University boys here to-day after an interesting contest. The fielding of both teams was superb, but the visitors easily excelled in batting. Score by innings:

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 4 -- More engineers, firemen, and pump runners obeyed the call of the miners' union and struck to-day, but in most instances the coal company officials were able to fill the places of the strikers. The Susquehanna Coal Company's Colliery No. 5, at Nanticoke, was the worst sufferer, all the firemen refusing to go to work, which compelled the company to shut down the engines.

The marriage of William Hude Neilson Voss, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Voss, and Miss Alice Marston McKim, daughter of the Rev. Haslett McKim and Mrs. McKim, was celebrated at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in Grace Church, the Rev. Dr. Huntington, rector of the church, and the bride's father officiating.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 4 -- The Democratic State Convention held here to-day was marked by harmony, the only serious differences being over the platform and the recognition to be given William J. Bryan. The following ticket was nominated:
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., June 4 -- The Supreme Court to-day announced that it had overruled the motion of the packing companies to quash the information filed against them by the Attorney General.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The report and findings of the court-martial which tried Gen. Jacob H. Smith for cruelty in the Philippines have been received by the President, and he is now going over the papers. A dispatch from Manila some time ago stated that it was the impression there that the verdict was one of acquittal.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- There was a conference here to-day between W.W. Finley, the Second Vice President of the Southern Railway Company, and representatives, legal and otherwise, of the six railroads indicted last week by the Federal Grand Jury at Memphis on a charge of conducting a pooling arrangement for controlling the Memphis cotton business.

Squadron A's polo team, which will meet the West Point cadets in polo at West Point on Saturday, June 14, was selected yesterday by the squadron's Polo Committee at Van Cortlandt Park. It will consist of Everett Colby, R.G.D. Douglas, A.R. Whitney, Jr., and H.M. Earle. The men will play in those respective positions.
Frank L Fisher Company have sold for A.R. Davison the seven-story apartment house known as the Unadilla, at 128 and 130 West Eleventh Street.

A special dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Lakewood, N.J., last night said that Mrs. Charles D. Kingdon, mother of Mrs. Edith Kingdon Gould, the wife of George J. Gould, while in New York on Tuesday and a guest at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was robbed of a number of pieces of jewelry, in all valued at $10,000.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 4 -- Hugh L. Willoughby has arrived from Philadelphia, having come by road in his new auto-car. He made the run at good speed, but made no attempt at record breaking, keeping within the prescribed limits of speed in towns and cities and making faster time on country roads.

PRETORIA, Transvaal, June 4 -- The ballot of the Boers at Vereeniging resulted in fifty-four votes in favor of surrender and six against it. Preparations are being made here, for the surrender of the Boer commands, which will take place on the racecourse. All the Boers are allowed perfect freedom.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The President is conducting an investigation with a view to locating the leak in the War Department by means of which Senator Culberson yesterday obtained the papers in the case of Lieut. Arnold of the Fourth Cavalry.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 4 -- A very pretty home wedding took place this evening at Cliff Cottage, the home of Col. Franklin Erandreth, in the northern part of this village. The bride was Miss Virginia Grahame Brandreth, daughter of Col. and Mrs. Franklin Brandreth, and the bridegroom Capt. Fox Conner of the One Hundred and Twenty-third Coast Artillery, stationed at Fort Hamilton.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The marriage of Walter A. Donaldson of New York to Mrs. Lucy Ord Mason, daughter of the late Major Gen. Ord, took place at St. Margaret's Church, this city, at 5 o'clock this afternoon. The Rev. Herbert Scott Smith, rector of the church, performed the ceremony, and the ushers were Caldwell Tyler and Charles Urquehart of New York, Walter S. Chance of Ohio, and James F. Urquehart of Washington.

LONDON, June 4 -- The demand for money was brisk to-day and supplies were increased by miscellaneous dividend payments. Discounts were easier. Owing to the attraction of the Epsom races, the attendance on the Stock Exchange was comparatively small and business, which was mostly dull, was restricted to a stream of realizations.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Two important changes in the diplomatic representation in Washington were announced to-day. The Hon. Michael H. Herbert succeeds Lord Pauncefote as British Ambassador and Senor de Ojeda succeeds the Duke de Arcos as Spanish Minister.

Nine young women, in gowns and mortar boards, marched on the platform of Carnegie Hall last evening, with three times their number of young men of the same class of the Cornell Medical College, to receive their diplomas and degrees as Doctors of Medicine. When each of the young women received her scroll the big auditorium rang with applause.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- A movement to prevent residents of this city and vicinity from engaging to act as guards, engineers, firemen, and pumpmen in the anthracite coal region took practical shape to-day. J.P. Gallagher, Secretary of District No. 7, came to this city from Hazleton, and had a conference with Edward M. Brown, Secretary of the Allied Building Trades Council.

LONDON, June 4 -- The Waterbury-Shrewsbury incident, arising from the use of spurs by Lawrence Waterbury while playing polo at Hurlingham, Saturday, against which Lord Shrewsbury protested, has been settled, out of court, by an exchange of letters from Foxhall Keene, in his capacity as Captain of the American team, and Lord Shrewsbury.

Criminals and persons in sympathy with the criminal classes or engaged in business undertakings largely dependent upon the criminal classes for their profit will naturally make the best and utmost use of the shooting of MCCOY to injure the official standing and paralyze the official arm of District Attorney JEROME.

TROY, N.Y., June 4 -- The annual meeting of the International Pulp Company was held yesterday at Gouverneur. Much of the stock is held in Troy and vicinity, and stockholders, not satisfied with the management started a movement to secure representatives in the Board of Directors. A meeting was held in Troy and the following circular, signed by William C. Geer, as Secretary, was issued:

BERLIN, June 4 -- F.W. Whitridge of New York left here to-day for England, after having arranged with the Deutscher Bank and other financial houses of Berlin to take shares in the Bolivian syndicate of New York.

The Webb-Meyer affair, which created such a sensation in Wall Street some weeks ago, was brought to the attention of the Street again yesterday, when the following statement was issued by one of those interested in the matter:

The continued dullness in the Stock Exchange market was reflected in the outside market yesterday by a further decrease in transactions in all parts of the list. Only one or two stocks showed totals worthy of more than passing attention, and a number of issues usually more or less active were not traded in at all.

BOSTON, June 4 -- Call money, while mostly quoted at 4 per cent., is, none the less, being let out by some of the banks at 3 1/2 per cent. For the first time in months there were no sales of New York funds today, although the same were offered at 10c discount. Sterling exchange is firm, with posted rates up 1/4c all around.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 4 -- There is very little change in the situation since yesterday. Perhaps there is more excitement in the settlements surrounding the collieries, but the breaker boys and women have been responsible for most of the disorder thus far reported.
LONDON, June 4 -- It was announced this afternoon that Lord Kitchener had been created a Viscount by King Edward.

LONDON, June 4 -- Jolm Gubbins's Irish bred colt Ard Patrick, at odds of 100 to 14 and ridden by J.H. Martin, the American jockey, won the one hundred and twenty-third Epsom Derby to-day, in the presence of one of the greatest crowds that ever witnessed the decision of the historic race. King Edward and a royal party being among the spectators.

CHARLES D. BUSBY of Nutley, N.J., for the last seven years connected with the Armour Packing Company, died in Kansas City yesterday as the result of a surgical operation, aged thirty-four years. In 1895 he established the Armour agency in South Africa, and since then he had traveled around the world as a representative of the firm.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Driven by men covered with dust and blood, many of them barely able from exhaustion to hold the reins in their hands, thirty-six meat wagons entered the main gate of the Union Stock Yards to-night, amid a shower of stones, bricks, bottles, and sticks.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

PARIS, June 4 -- The appointment of the Hon. Michael Henry Herbert to succeed the late Lord Pauncefote as British Ambassador to the United States has occasioned some surprise here. Mr. Herbert was, until his appointment to Washington, Secretary to the British Embassy at Paris, and his retiring, although amiable disposition, has not brought him prominently to the public view.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- There was a heavy contraction of business in the local stock market to-day, but prices were fairly well maintained. Nearly two-thirds of the aggregate trading fell to the Readings, with New York again taking nearly all the stock. The intimation that the strike order in the West Virginia bituminous field would go into effect Monday caused all the coalers to sag.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- President Roosevelt spent some time this afternoon considering the proposition of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation that he appoint a commission to investigate the strike situation in the anthracite regions, with the view of effecting an arbitration of the differences between the miners and operators.

According to Dr. Voight of Bellevue Hospital there is a chance that James F. McCoy, who was shot by County Detective McLellan during a raid on a poolroom at 156 and 158 East Forty-second Street, may recover. The man, who has a splendid constitution and is determined that he will not die, regained consciousness yesterday afternoon.

STATE CAMP, Peekskill, June 4 -- The principal event at the State Camp scheduled for to-morrow is the visit of Gov. Odell, who will arrive on the, train reaching Peekskill at 12:17 P.M. The train will stop, however, at Roa Hook, from which station the Chief Executive will be conveyed to headquarters and remain there during the afternoon.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The prevailing belief in Washington just now is that the Democrats have not the slightest ground for ever hoping that they may control the next House.
WORCESTER, Mass., June 5 -- Worcester hit Luby at will in this afternoon's baseball game with Jersey City and won easily. Jersey City played poorly in the field. The score:

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Senator Hanna this afternoon opened the debate in the Senate in favor of constructing the isthmian canal on the Panama route. He spoke for an hour and a half in support of the Spooner substitute for the Hepburn bill, and will have more to say about it to-morrow.

DETROIT, June 5 -- On board the steamer City of Mackinac, which has been chartered for the occasion, the members of the Michigan Bankers' Association, accompanied by their wives, are holding their annual meeting, and at the same time enjoying a trip to Sault Ste. Marie and return.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Quiet reigned in the turbulent stock yards district to-day as a result of the settlement of the meat teamsters' strike, but the happiness of the men was marred somewhat by a report that the packers will refuse to re-employ leaders among the striking teamsters.
LONDON, June 6 -- According to The Daily Mail, the Allen Line steamers will not join the British shipping combine, but will remain an active competitor on the outside.

Upon Miss Helen Gould was conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Letters at the commencement exercises of the class of 1902 of New York University at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening. Miss Gould, with Mrs. Catherine Bacon Smith and Mrs. Martha Buell Munn, who also received the degree, sat in the front row of seats on the stage.

Arthur J. Kahn, doing business as Arthur J. Kahn Co., wholesale dealer in watches and diamonds at 37 and 30 Maiden Lane, is in temporary financial difficulties, and his affairs have been placed before his creditors with a view of getting an extension of time to work out of his embarrassment.

MARIENBURG, West Prussia, June 5 -- A unique and picturesque spectacle was witnessed here to-day, when, in the presence of Emperor William and the Empress, many diplomats, members of royalty, and German notabilities, the work of restoring the ancient Castle of Marienburg was officially completed.

Washington Seligman, the broker, was mulcted in $2,000 in the City Court before Judge Seabury yesterday in a suit brought against him for alleged assault and battery by Mrs. Annette M. Osborne, who declared that he had attacked her without reason at the Sea View Hotel, Bath Beach, on July 9 last.

BOSTON, June 5.--The money market is still in a state of extreme apathy, with demand lighter than ever, with rates easy and with an abundant supply of available funds at hand. Sterling exchange is a trifle weaker in tone. Clearing House rate, 4 per cent; New York funds mostly at 5 cents discount.

Mr. JAMES J. HILL, President of the Great Northern Railway Company, made two very radical statements of opinion in his speech to the Illinois Manufacturers' Association of Chicago on Wednesday evening.

Yesterday's stock market differed from others recently preceding only in a display of weakness. Many stocks declined a point or more. One conspicuous railway issue -- Canadian Pacific -- fell 4 points. In the industrial list International Power cut its not unusual sensational feature by dropping 10 points.
Mayer S. Auerbach has bought from a Mrs. Leavitt the four-story dwelling, 16 East Twenty-eighth Street, 25 by 98.9.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Truman G. Palmer of Chicago was a witness to-day before the Senate Committee on Cuban Relations. He gave a list of seventeen American corporations which, he said, have 588,727 acres in sugar producing lands in Cuba, with an annual capacity of 255,425 tons.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 5 -- A reign of violence in connection with the street railway strike made the evening the most exciting period in the history of this community. Crowds of men, who blocked the streets, hooted and jeered at the officers and passengers of passing cars, hurled missiles of every description through windows, cut trolley ropes, and defaced with knives the interior fittings of cars.

The policy as to the excise law which has now been officially announced by Commisisoner PARTRIDGE is criticised in some quarters as not sufficiently distinct and intelligible. We think that it is clear enough. We think also that it is severe, more so than the previous utterances of Mr Low had led the public to expect.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was again very quiet and practically the only events of interest were the substantial gains recorded in a few of the less active issues. For the most part the stocks which have been somewhat active for the past few days were traded in at prices below those of the previous day.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5 -- Louis Windmuller, who brought suit in the Federal Court some time ago to prevent the dissolving of the Spirits Distributing Company, but was beaten, has filed a bill at Trenton asking for the appointment of a receiver to wind up the company's affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Before an assemblage that crowded the National Theatre President Roosevelt to-day opened the eleventh annual convention of the Association of Military Surgeons of the United States.

"America first; there is no second." In this hollow fashion the blue ribbon for pleasure sailing craft passed to the United States in the middle of the nineteenth century. We are only at the beginning of the twentieth century, but Great Britain has already seen the blue ribbon of land transit pass from her also.

The assurance given by Secretary HAY, in reply to the usual form of inquiry, that the Hon. MICHAEL HERBERT would be cordially welcomed by this Government as the successor of the late Lord PAUNCEFOTE, will naturally be received with satisfaction in the British Foreign Office and British Government circles.

Reports were current yesterday that the Trustees of the City Club had prepared, or were preparing, a report demanding of Mayor Low the enforcement of the jaws; condemning Col. Partridge's administration of the Police Department, and practically calling on the Mayor to remove him. It was stated that this alleged report declared that gambling is widespread; that poolrooms are in full blast, and that the excise law is not enforced.

PARIS, June 5 -- M. Henri Brisson (the Premier who is a Radical Republican in politics) went to the Elysee Palace to-day, as a result of President Loubet's summons, and was asked to form a new Cabinet, M. Brisson declined.

LONDON, June 5 -- In accordance with King Edward's message to the House of Commons yesterday the Government leader, A.J. Balfour, in the House this afternoon asked for a vote of L30,000 ($250,000) to Lord Kitchener. As a remarkable coincidence. Parliament June 5, three years ago, voted its thanks and u30,000 ($150,000) to the same General for services in Egypt.

Eighty-two golfers finished the qualifying round yesterday at the Montclair Golf Club for the amateur championship of the State of New Jersey. It was one of the largest fields that ever started in a big tournament in the Metropolitan district, and as the first match play round for the two cups was finished in the afternoon, it was well after twilight before all the results were in.

The discontinuance of Camera Notes, the brisk little quarterly published by the Camera Club, was not occasioned by the ordinary evil that pursues club organs, a lack of funds, but by the cause which acts as a disintegrating force in many other organizations. The majority found that its own photographs met with little favor in the eyes of the men who practically ran the club and controlled the publication.

STATE CAMP, Peekskill, June 5. -- Gov. Odell left Albany at 9 o'clock this morning, accompanied by his military secretary. Major H.K. Bird. At Fishkill he was joined by his son, Master Herbert Odell, and his brother, ex-Postmaster Hiram B. Odell, who had come over from Newburg. At Roa Hook at 12:13 the party was met by Gen. Roe and Gen. Smith and driven to the camp.

SCRANTON, Penn., June 5 -- The first serious outbreak of disorder in connection with the strike in the Lackawanna region occurred to-night at Forest City. David Owens, a pump runner at the Clifford Colliery of the Hillside Company, was attacked by a mob of 300 strikers while on his way to work and beaten into insensibility.

Various interests, including officials of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, delegates from political organizations, and labor union men participated in yesterday's public hearing on the Brooklyn tunnel before the Rapid Transit Commission. Mayor Low and the other members of the commission asked questions and gave their views.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 5 -- The market experienced one of the deadest days today in the history of the Exchange. There was nothing of interest except two rumors. The first affected the Cotton Duck issues. It was discovered that some interests close to insiders were bidding $22.50 for the interest coupons due July 1.
ATLANTA, Ga., June 5 -- Incomplete returns received to-night from the Democratic primaries held throughout this State to-day show that the following State ticket has been nominated.
PARIS, June 5 -- During a dispute in the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. De Largentaye, a reactionary Deputy from the Cotes-du-Nord, exclaimed:

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- In his speech in the Senate to-day on an interoceanic canal, Mr. Hanna (Ohio) said the American people having become accustomed to the rapid transit of the railroads, now demanded quicker transportation on the seas.

WILKESBARRE, Jenn., June 5 -- The work of fining the places of the engineers, firemen, and pumpmen with non-union labor is making good progress. Not all of the 5,000 men needed for this purpose have yet been secured, but accessories to the working force are being received daily.

County Detective Robert S. McLellan was held yesterday in $3,000 bail for examination on June 12 by Magistrate Crane in the Tombs Police Court, the charge against him being felonious assault for shooting James F. McCoy in the raid on the Sherman House. The injured man continues to improve, and was able to see members of his family yesterday at Bellevue Hospital.

BOSTON, June 5 -- The Weetamoe, a bronze sixty-foot yacht, belonging to Henry F. Lippitt of Providence, was launched today at Lawley's shipyard at South Boston. Mr. Lippitt's little daughter christened the boat as she left the ways. The Weetamoe will race in Long Island Sound. She measures 87 feet over all, being 51 feet long on her water line.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The House today proceeded with the consideration of the Anti-Anarchy bill. Mr. Sibley (Penn.) favored the passage of the bill.

-- With one enthusiastic accord, the editors and correspondents of the electrical papers are supporting Prof. PUPIN'S charge that telegraphy in this country, owing to the unprogressiveness of those who are exploiting it commercially, is not what it ought to be, either as regards speed or cheapness, and almost unanimously they declare that the recent defense of the Western Union by Mr. J.C. BARCLAY will not stand expert examination.

The choir of St. Michael's Church, Jersey City, yesterday, was singing the requtem mass over the body of Mrs. John Hare, After the procession left the church the sexton noticed that the electric lights in the choir were still burning. He climbed to the organ loft and found the organist, Leopold de Grandval, an old man of more than eighty years, lying upon the steps of the platform upon which the organ stood.

A Republican State breakfast is to be held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel this morning, and Senator Thomas C. Platt, Gov. Odell, and Chairman George W. Dunn are to be the convives. The propositions to be discussed are many. Senator Platt in an interview yesterday gave in part a forecast of what is likely to happen in Republican circles during the next few months.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad Company, Charles W. Hillard, Richard M. Hoe, Joseph G. English, and Frederick D. Flower were elected Directors.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 5 -- The Congregational Home Missionary Society in national convention to-day held a business meeting for reports and election of officers.
New York's baseball nine won another game yesterday by defeating Chicago in the third contest of the series. The score was the same as that of Wednesday, 4 to 3.

NEW ORLEANS, June 5 -- The first action taken by the United States Grand Jury since it began last Saturday to inquire into the methods of the dressed-beef agencies in New Orleans, was the presenting of a report to Judge Parlange to-day relative to the refusal of some of the witnesses to answer questions and to produce documents.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 5. -- The spirit of unrest that has been manifesting itself more or less in this city and vicinity during the last few days broke out in earnest at two places in this city to-night, and as a result a boy was dangerously, if not fatally, shot by a guard at the Stanton Colliery and a considerable portion of the fence around the Murray Colliery was destroyed by fire.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 5 -- The Philadelphia market was dull to-day, but showed no special weakness, except in the Readings and Electric Storage Battery common. The latter, which has been stubbornly held for a week or more at 89, sold down to 85. Much of the stock is held in New York, and it is very susceptible to weakness in the New York list.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The wholesale condemnation meted to the balloon as an accessory in aerial navigation in the closing paragraph of your comment in Friday's issue of "Topics of the Times," seems partial in view of the fact that our knowledge of the conditions existing immediately above us, and to which we have nothing analogous on the surface, is extremely limited.

The Chevalier Alberto de Bassini, a Court singer to the late King Louis of Portugal, tenor of La Scola in Milan, and leading singer with Mme. Patti and Mme. Albani, appeared in the Seventh Municipal District Court in the Yorkville Police Court building at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in answer to a summons procured for him by an Inspector of the Board of Health.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 5 -- Mrs. John Clinton Gray arrived at her cottage on Kay Street this evening.

LONDON, June 5 -- Alexander Herd won the open championship of Great Britain today on the Hoylake golf links near Liverpool, with a total of 307 strokes for the 72 holes. James Braid, last year's champion, and Harry Vardon finished next, with 308 strokes each. J.H. Taylor, also an exchampion, and H.H. Hilton, the ex-amateur champion, tied at 314 strokes.

Capt. Titus, his staff of detectives, the Pinkerton men, and the detectives of the Waldorf-Astoria, as far as could be learned yesterday, made little progress in running down the thief or thieves who stole Mrs. Charles G. Kingdon's jewels from her apartments in the hotel on Monday night.

ROME, June 5 -- The Pope to-day received Judge Taft, Governor of the Philippine Islands; Bishop Thomas O'Gorman of Sioux Falls, S.D.; Judge Smith, and Major Porter of the Judge Advocate General's Department at Washington.
LINCOLN, Neb., June 5 -- W.J. Bryan will to-morrow publish an open letter in his Commoner addressed to President in which he says:

There was a meeting last night of the New York Academy of Medicine in West Forty-third Street, where papers were read and a discussion followed in regard to the prevalent, almost epidemic and very contagious ophthalmia. Incidentally Dr. Lederle of the Health Department, because of the investigation he is making of the many cases of contagious eye diseases in the city schools and institutions, was commended.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 5 -- Lieut. Gen. Miles passed through Kansas City to-night on his way from Fort Riley to Washington, called there, it is declared, by President Roosevelt, and threatened with an immediate court-martial on a charge of having betrayed official secrets. Gen. Miles went through here yesterday attended by several other members of a board convened to observe field gun tests at Fort Riley, to be so engaged for several days.

THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS recently deplored the lack of a good modern edition of the works of Dryden. We are glad to hear that Houghton, Mifflin Co. have in preparation an edition of Dryden, edited by George R. Noyes, to be included in the well-known series of Cambridge Poets.
SUBJECT -- Paul crosses to Europe. Acts, xvf., 6-15.

NEW ORLEANS, La., June 6. -- The New Orleans Custom House authorities had today to deal with a case absolutely without precedent. Wednesday the Norwegian steamship, John Wilson, Capt. W. Hansen, arrived here from Bluefields, Nicaragua, with fruit consigned to the Bluefields Steamship Company.

As was stated in a preliminary announcement which appeared in these columns May 24, the twenty-fourth annual meeting of the American Library Association will be held in Boston and Magnolia, Mass., in the week beginning Monday, June 16. Here are a few additional particulars both in regard to the objects of the association and its principal features of work.

The recent publication of "The Journals of Hugh Gaine," edited by the late Paul Leicester Ford, was interesting in many ways, but chiefly because the list of books printed by Gaine there given to the public marked the first serious step taken toward the completion of the long-desired bibliography of early New York imprints.

Sir Robert Ball long ago became well known to readers everywhere as a popular expositor of the science of astronomy, and that he enjoys this part of his work as well as his more serious duties as Lowndean Professor of Astronomy and Geometry in the University of Cambridge is evident from many circumstances.

Nowhere is the fact of the enormous advancement that has recently been made in the art of bookmaking better illustrated than in the reference books which have recently come to hand. It seems as though the publishers of these books not only desired to make their readers acquainted with all information possible on given subjects, but at the same time were eager to present such information in as pleasing a manner as possible.
LONDON, June 6. -- The statements which have recently appeared in the English press forecasting the formation of an all-British shipping combination seem to be open to grave doubts.

With much regret THE TIMES announces the retirement of Mr. Francis W. Halsey from the editorship of THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS. Mr. Halsey enters the service of D. Appleton Company as chief of their literary department, a place made necessary by the enlarged activities of the house in all branches of its business.

The formalities at the old castle of Marienburg on the Nogat in West Prussia must have pleased old-fashioned sentimental Germans hugely, but will strike the modern who looks at things from the scientist's ground as a piece of mediaevalism no longer in harmony with the present day.

LONDON, June 6. -- A.J. Balfour, the Government leader in the House of Commons, in a speech at a Conservative banquet in London to-night, referred to the South African war. He said the load was only thoroughly realized now that it had been removed, and that peace had not been brought by unnecessary concessions.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A story sent from Kansas City and widely published to the effect that Gen. Miles had been ordered to Washington to meet charges and explain his connection with the Lieut. Arnold case is emphatically denied at the War Department.

The ninth annual convention of the Walt Whitman Fellowship was held at the Hotel St. Denis on Saturday of last week. Besides the afternoon programme, when papers were read and poems by Whitman were recited, there was a dinner in the evening. Among those who spoke in the afternoon were Isaac Hull Platt, the President of the Fellowship; Edwin Markham, Thomas B. Harned, and George J. Smith.
WORCESTER, Mass., June 6. -- Worcester won to-day's baseball game with Jersey City in the eighth inning, when three singles, a sacrifice, and a double scored three runs. The score:

"Young Howson's Wife," by Mr. A.E. Watrous, whose tragic death occurred recently, is a book of short stories hard to classify. In spite of the attempt to give a certain virility to the book by arranging the tales under two headings, the married women and the unmarried, there is no virility either in motive, in manner of telling, or in the excellence of the stories themselves.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Senator Hanna is the head and front of the opposition to the Hepburn bill, which locates the Isthmian Canal on the Nicaragua route. If the Senate shall decide to overrule the Committee on Interoceanic Canals and pass the Spooner bill, which practically locates the canal on the Panama route, that action will be due to Mr. Hanna, it is believed.

At the class day exercises held yesterday in the Barnard Theatre in Brinckerhoff, Barnard College seniors bade farewell to their undergraduate career. The hall was crowded with friends of the graduates, who occupied the stage, attired in white duck dresses and the academic cap and gown.

The contraction of the market, which has been in progress for some days, continued in the outside market yesterday, and still fewer issues were traded in than appeared in Thursday's list of transactions. Prices were again irregular, the majority of issues being heavy, while here and there in the list appeared further substantial gains.

You suspect John Manning at the very outset. "His lower lip was perhaps too full, and the upper lip thin and shapely cut." As the husband of a child of nature Marion idolized him with all the fond devotion of a woman. It took a long time before Marion discovered that John was untruthful and indifferent to his marital vows, for he had been carrying for years an intrigue with another woman.

Capt. Frank W. Coe, Artillery Corps, will be relieved from duty at the Military Academy July 1. He is assigned to the One Hundred and Tenth Company. Coast Artillery, and will join that company July 1.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 6. -- The strike of the coal miners in the Virginias for higher wages, which is to be inaugurated to-morrow, will be directed by President Mitchell from Wilkesbarre. He said to-day there are 29,000 men in that field; that 18,000 will stop work to-morrow, and that he expects the others will all be out in the course of a few days.

A Recent Word from d'Annunzio. In spite of the failure of "Francesca da Rimini" in Rome, and of his other works in his native country, Gabriel d'Annunzio is apparently not discouraged in his belief in himself.

The arrival of Gov. Odell in the city yesterday made the Fifth Avenue Hotel the Mecca of Republican politicians of all degrees. After the numerous conferences the wise men agreed that Gov. Odell would certainly be renominated by the State Convention. Nothing that Gov. Odell said indicated otherwise.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In Mrs. Atherton's late book, "The Conqueror." where she speaks of Hamilton's eagerness for knowledge when a mere lad of fourteen, the following statement is made, (Page 88):

While it was admitted yesterday by those who knew what passed at the City Hall on Thursday, when Mayor Low met in private four members of the City Club, that the condition of the Police Department was seriously considered, none of the five who were at the conference would give any details regarding it or admit that it was other than a quiet talk over municipal affairs.

If the coal strike lasts much longer there is a likelihood that New York will lose its reputation for a clear, clean atmosphere. Despite its ordinance against the nuisance of black soot and smoke, a murky pall settled over the city yesterday. The widespread use of the soot-producing soft coal was evidenced by an announcement from the Weather Bureau.

The State Convention of the Liberal Democratic Party of New York is to be called to order in Cooper Union at 3 o'clock today. It is the purpose of the leaders of the organization to name an entire State ticket and to continue the fight through the campaign. The delegations that will gather to-day have not been chosen at primaries, but by the organizations of Senate Districts.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 6. -- Reginald C. Vanderbilt is to have a country place near Newport, having purchased the Sandy Point farm in Portsmouth, on the shore of the East River, about six miles and a half from Newport.

"Deep-Sea Plunderings" has the fresh, bracing atmosphere that carried the reader forward without a pause in "The Cruise of the Cachalot," and if it has not the engrossing interest of that most delightful book, is, nevertheless, full of novel incident graphically told and men vividly portrayed.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- After a conference with the members of his Cabinet to-day, President Roosevelt decided that there was no legal ground for interference by him in the settlement of the dispute between the coal operators and striking miners.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- During the debate on the Ani-Anarchy bill in the House to-day Mr. Richardson, (Ala.,) during the course of some remarks upon the bill, criticised President Roosevelt's Memorial Day oration at Arlington.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Recent letters in THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS from Noah Brooks anent Bret Harte and Joaquin Miller have recalled to the mind of the writer some reminiscences that may be of interest in this connection.

The Board of Estimate transacted more public business and held the longest session since the advent of the administration of Mayor Low yesterday. One hundred and twenty-one matters were considered and disposed of.

The relations of the Christian Church to the modern art of music are even closer than its relations to architecture. The music of to-day began with the efforts of the early medieval monks to find melodic settings for those parts of the liturgy which have since become fixtures of the musical service.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under 53,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3.000.

This is the time of year when all sorts of motherly advice is presented with a yard of white ribbon to the sweet girl graduate. She accepts the advice and the ribbon on her diploma with equal gratitude, and then continues to seek the man. As a rule she knows her business.

The peculiar combination of raw slang and highfalutin which used to be called newspaper English is happily obsolescent, but the movement that is extinguishing it has developed a new danger. There are few book reviewers who do not at times undertake to chastise an author for impropriety of language, and it happens astonishingly often that in attempting to scotch an error the critic convicts himself of a greater one.

LONDON, June 6. -- That clever young writer, W. Pett Ridge, is said to have excelled himself in his latest long story, which is called "Erb," the title being the Cockney abbreviation of Herbert. Mr. Ridge may be said to be to modern London what Sir Walter Besant was to ancient.

Excellent scoring and a number of closely contested games marked the progress of the second day's play yesterday at Montclair in the New Jersey State championship tournament. All of the cup rounds were brought down to the finals, and these will be completed to-day, being thirty-six holes in each case.

The Sugar Trust, technically known as the American Sugar Refining Company, but which also embraces several other socalled independent companies, has succeeded in securing a share in the beet sugar industry which, according to one sugar operator, gives to it a greater interest in that industry than all the other interests combined.

FIVE years ago, Houghton, Mifflin Co. published a little book entitled "Hawthorne's First Diary, with an Account of Its Discovery and Loss." At that time I believed the alleged "Diary" was genuine, and had been in that faith with little wavering for more than a quarter of a century.

In the streets and parks of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon there marched a great army, under banners of white, of purple, and of gold, an army of bright-faced children, the Sunday school legions of the Borough of Churches. It was the anniversary day parade of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union, and the paraders, who marched in divisions, each in its own district, numbered about 90,000, the largest number in the history of this annual event.

Senator HANNA is pre-eminently a man of practical ideas. There is no man in the Senate less inclined to exhibition of pure sentiment, nor who has less taste for purposeless academic discussion. In business, as in politics, Mr. HANNA is known as a man who gets things done.

Fifteenth century justice commonly lay in the point of the longest and heaviest sword, and the group of stories in which, under the title of "The Seigneur de Beaufoy," Mr. Hamilton Drummond describes its administration is a record of wild deeds and stern speech unchecked by any great tenderness for woman, or any deep reverence for the Church.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Secretary Root to-day sent to the Philippine Commissions of the Senate and House textual copies of the instructions given by him to Gov. Taft for his guidance in dealing with the Vatican respecting the acquisition by the United States of the friars' lands in the Philippines.

Holdridge Ward and L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for the Hoffman estate to Boehm Coon the southwest corner of Broadway and Seventy-sixth Street, a plot 17.4 by 114, now occupied by a five-story apartment house, with four four-story dwellings on the street.

Mr. Hulbert has here brought together, in handsome dress, the essays on the beaver, trout, lynx, porcupine, loon, and deer, which he has contributed from time to time to McClure's Magazine. The most valuable feature of the book is the pictures, which are life-studies of the animals mentioned, most admirably rendered by Joseph Gleeson and Walter M. Hardy.

LONDON, May 27. -- The saturday Review has lately given place to a number of correspondents, who have discussed the question of girls' books. It appears that a large proportion of girls do not care to read books written purposely for girls, but prefer to read boys' books.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- At the opening of the session of the House to-day Mr. Hull, (Iowa,) Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs, reported back the resolution requesting information as to salary or other compensation paid to Gen. Leonard Wood during the occupation of Cuba.

THE public has long waited for a reprint of Morgan's splendid treatise. Originally published in Rochester fifty-one years ago, it has for many years been scarce. The few copies which have come to light have found ready purchasers at several times the original price, Morgan's book has been recognized by the best minds as a classic.

Third Avenue Elevated electric train 91, north-bound, and crowded so that the guards struggled for minutes before they could open and close the gates, was approaching the Eighty-ninth Street Station at 6:31 o'clock last evening, when a fuse blew out under the fourth car, wrapping it in a sheet of white flame for about half its length.

Does Commissioner PARTRIDGE really think that the appearance of three officers under him in a drunken condition when summoned for trial before his Deputy Commissioner is a trivial matter? As an old soldier, as a veteran Police Commissioner, recalling the standard of discipline he formerly both enforced and cheerfully conformed to, can he contemplate such an occurrence without indignation and dismay?

Two New Volumes of Chateaubriand. Volumes III. and IV. of Chateaubriands "Memoires d'Outre-Tombe," of which the first two were reviewed in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of May 3, have come from G.P. Putnam's Sons.

-- In explaining -- and explaining away -- the generosity of the terms accorded to the Boers, the Pretoria correspondent of The London Times says that the language concession amounts only to the granting of such reasonable facilities as would have been granted anyhow, and does not interfere with the status of English as the sole official language.

ASBURY PARK, June 6. -- Education was the subject discussed to-day by the delegates to the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America, and the reports submitted by the officials of the various educational institutions supported by the church showed that they were self-sustaining last year.

At the time when Lord Roberts went home from South Africa and told his rejoicing countrymen that the war of the Boers was practically over, books recounting the features of the struggle for the freedom of the Transvaal poured from the press. Makers of historical works vied with one another in getting their wares upon the market, and they told what to them seemed a completed story.

At a meeting of the Trustees of Stevens Institute, Hoboken, held at the office of Alexander C. Humphreys, 31 Nassau Street, New York, on Thursday, Mr. Humphreys was elected President of the institute to succeed the late Henry Morton.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Secretary Root has received a letter from Felipe Buencamino the Filipino, who has just completed his testimony before the House Committee on Insular Affairs.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- The advance and activity of Reading brightened and strengthened the local market to-day. Over half the trading was in Reading, which was bought for New York account, the difference in prices frequently favoring purchases in the Philadelphia market. Electric Storage Battery rallied 2 points upon the receipt of news that a decision had been handed down in Buffalo giving the company practically a monopoly.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The War Department has issued an order prescribing the duties and status of the Army Nurse Corps, in accordance with the Army bill passed Feb. 2, 1901. It is ordered that army nurses shall be assigned to duty at military hospitals and at hospitals where more than one nurse is serving one will be assigned to duty as chief.

How India was won at Plassey, saved at Assaye, and regained at Lucknow has often enough been told. And in between that military pole of contemplation, at one end, and some sporting pole at the other, say, Mr. Stone's "Hunting in the Himalayas," there are all shades and levels of books on the Far East.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In last Saturday's REVIEW OF BOOKS your critic says that the description of the Assyrian campaign in "The Gate of the Kiss" will not bear comparison with the Biblical accounts of it, and says the story "should not be condemned because it is less startling than the actual truth as to Sennacherib's ineffective expedition against Jerusalem."

Many of the fraternal organizations that provide for small payments of life insurance to the beneficiaries of members are embarrassed by the outcome of the workings of the assessment plan, according to facts that have been abstracted by the Insurance Press from the official reports of examinations made by the Insurance Department of Connecticut.

Mr. Brooks gives an optimistic interpretation of the facts of evolution. His volume is addressed, not to the specialist either in science or metaphysics, but to the general reader. He is not overawed or dismayed by the discord prevalent among those who may be regarded as the authoritative and official interpreters of evolution, asserting on the contrary that the specialist is seldom the best interpreter of the results of his labor.

There was much heated argument yesterday on the floor of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York over the scheme of the association to buy the Popham Building at 80 Broad Street for a new home.

The baseball teams of New York and Pittsburg played eleven innings to a tie yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Each side made 4 runs, although New York played better, both at the bat and in the field. A triple play in the ninth inning by Ritchey and Wagner of Pittsburg, which retired Doyle, Smith, and Bean, was given a hearty round of applause.

FORT DE FRANCE, Island of Martinique, June 6. -- A volcanic outburst from Mont Pelee to-day resulted in the formation of a heavy cloud, similar to that of May 20 last, though it was not so dense. No stones fell, and when the cloud had spread over Fort de France half an hour later there was no panic here.
It is reported that Dr. CLEMENS, after the variegated and admirable speech recently made by him on receiving his latest degree, announced that it was his last appearance as a speaker in public.

You are not to consider Margaret Crothers in the romance of "Love Never Faileth" as a young person with eccentric traits because she goes for a morning's walk with a volume of Badminton on racing in one hand and Browning's "Paracelsus" in the other. She comes from a family devoted to sport, inasmuch as her father has ruined himself with horses.
