She comes from a family devoted to sport, inasmuch as her father has ruined himself with horses.

SCRANTON, Penn., June 6. -- Shutting down of the small screens and culm washeries erected at some of the refuse piles of long-abandoned drifts and tunnels is now engaging attention from the coal strikers of the Lackawanna Valley. There are perhaps a score of these, working with six to ten men each, and their trade is chiefly to farmers and some small industries.

Three Central Office detectives, under the direction of Capt. Titus, yesterday corraled four prisoners who they declare are swindling gamblers, who have fleeced many victims in different cities along the route from Hot Springs, Ark., to New York. The gang, the police say, followed a man from Chicago to Buffalo, where by dealing out marked cards at faro they managed to get $17,000 from him.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Mr. Hanna (Ohio) resumed in the Senate to-day his speech on the Isthmian Canal bill. He referred to some comments made yesterday by Mr. Mitchell, (Oregon,) in which the Oregon Senator had spoken of the advantages of the Nicaragua route, while the "Hanna commission" had reported once in favor of the Nicaragua route.
WORMS, they say, will turn. In that particular, the author is unlike the worm. As a general thing he, or she, grins -- or weeps -- and bears it.

ANNE UPTON NETTLETON has here edited a delightful series of letters written by Mary Cowden Clarke to Robert Balmanno of New York between 1850 and 1861. Neither the writer of the letters nor their recipient, a well-known collector of autographs, should need special introduction to the reading public, but Mrs. Nettleton has added a long introduction, which embodies much interesting matter as to both.

BALTIMORE, June 6. -- The local market showed a little more life to-day, with several points of strength cropping up throughout the list. United Railways incomes were more active and higher, due to successful promotion of the company's profits under the present management, and also to benefits expected to accrue to the railways in the event it sells its holdings of Electric Light and Power common.

Friday is dies non, as far as any entertainments in town are concerned, especially at this time of the year, when the only large gatherings are at wedding ceremonies and receptions. This afternoon Miss Francis Jane Converse, the granddaughter of Mrs. Elisha Swan, is to be married to Ord Preston at St. Paul's Church, Englewood, N.J.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- The Geographical Society of this city is just now playing a prominent part in the news of the day because of the successful ascent of Mont Pelee made by Prof. Angelo Heilprin of the University of Pennsylvania, who had been sent to the scene of the disaster in the West Indies by The Philadelphia Press.

LONDON, June 6. -- There was less demand for money to-day, owing to the favorable bank return and the forthcoming arrivals of gold from India and elsewhere. Business on the Stock Exchange opened dull, the approach of the settlement checking dealings. The demand for consols overtaking the supply, stimulated a recovery.

In his preface Mr. Forsyth explains that these lectures were written for a miscellaneous audience and were lay sermons by intention. He disclaims any attempt at offering food for the expert or student in art and declares his purpose to be the familiarizing of inartistic people with the spiritual message of certain artists.

LONDON, June 7 -- Most wealthy Americans in London are taking lively interest in a concert announced by Kitty Cheatham Thompson, under the patronage of Princess Beatrice, at the town house of the Duke of Somerset, in Grosvenor Square. To many the chance to enter the house of a Duke and Duchess is one not to be missed, and the high-priced tickets are selling rapidly.

KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, May 23 -- Had it not been for the instant destruction or all the people of a city like St. Pierre, with its 30,000 inhabitants, it is more than likely that the Island of St. Vincent, rather than Martinique, would claim the attention of the world to-day.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Truman G. Palmer, of Chicago, to-day continued his statement on the subject of American holdings of sugar lands in Cuba before the Senate Committee on Cuban Relations. Summarizing the entire presentation he placed the number of Cuban estates held by Americans individual and corporate at 172, with a total acreage of ownership amounting to 1,482,801, of which 330,846 acres are cane-producing.

MOUNT POCONO, Penn., June 7 -- Mount Pocono has been fortunate enough in past years to have excellent seasons, but this season, which has opened in full swing, promises to be a record breaker. Hotel men have been profuse in their expenditures for the comfort and convenience of their guests.

In one sense of the word at least the coal strike has been a positive benefit in that, by curtailing stock market activity, it has relieved the money market at a time when relief, though perhaps not absolutely necessary, is nevertheless not unwelcome. This, indeed, may be said to be the most important development of the week in the local money situation.

PAUL SMITH'S, N.Y., June 7 -- The H. McK. Twombly camp on Upper St. Regis Lake, which Fred W. Vanderbilt purchased recently, is being made ready for the coming of Mr. Vanderbilt. A great many features are necessary to complete the camp and grounds. A large boathouse is now in course of construction, and attention is being given to the terrace.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 7 -- The exer- cises of the one hundred and fifty-fifth commencement of Princeton University began to-day with the junior oratorical con- test in Alexander Hall. The following men delivered orations:
"It's the worst job I've tackled yet," moaned the poet laureate, feverishly turning the leaves of his rhyming dictionary.

WILLIAMSBURG dozed peacefully in the warm sunshine of the lazy Summer afternoon; dozed and dreamed complacently of glories of former days, of routs, and assemblies which were more than fair reflections of the fashionable functions of that London whence the Carters and the Byrds and the other notables of the then Virginian capital had imported their manners as well as their costumes.

For the first time in eighteen years holders of Chicago and Northwestern preferred stock are to received dividends at the rate of 8 per cent., and holders of the common stock are to receive 7 per cent., the Directors at their meeting held on Thursday having declared, besides the usual rates, an "extra" of 1 per cent, in each case.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 7 -- Mrs. Daisy Morgan, formerly a resident of this place and a favorite niece of Richard Croker, figured as defendant yesterday in a suit for absolute divorce brought by her husband, Terry G. Morgan of Port Washington.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 7 -- This cosmopolitan resort has afforded a most agreeable transformation scene during the past week, as the season has opened with a rush, and visitors and delegates to several conventions are flocking here in large numbers. They are the advance guard of the thousands who will be gathered here the coming week.

One of the picturesque regions of New York State is Sullivan County -- high, beautiful, healthful. Here the city man may find good hotels and attractive farmhouses. There are abundant opportunities for fishing and boating. The air is neither too warm nor too cool to permit of staying outdoors comfortably the greater part of the time.

Anybody wishing to occupy some of these Summer days in journeying away from the city's whirl for a few miles or half way around the globe will find that the railroads and steamship lines radiating from New York offer a perfectly bewildering series of delightful opportunities. To the mountains, to the lakes, to the North, to the South, to the West, to any whither, chances, many of them new, abound to take splendid trips.

Hardly a Summer arrives without the report from some part of the country that the "seventeen-year locust" has made its appearance, and with the same regularity we hear of the concern felt by the farmers at the coming of this destroyer. Are there still farmers who can be frightened by an insect which in its winged state does nothing more than prune the outer twigs of shade trees?

WITH the productions of "A Chinese Honeymoon" and "The Chaperons," the Summer season of entertainment may be said to have been fairly launched along those lines of light a airy effort that are generally supposed to appeal to amusement seekers in the heated term.

In Germany the slow liquidation goes on. There is some improvement reported in the iron trade, possibly because the foreign demand has been fairly good. But in other directions there is little to note. And in electricais there is undoubted depression. As a matter of course the liquidation will have to go on for some time yet.

We run some risk of diminishing the public stock of harmless amusement when we point out the grave danger that the Nicaraguan volcano factories will be overworked. Readers of canal literature have been simply dumfounded by the number and the unprincipled behavior of the volcanoes discovered and set at work during the last month along the line of the Nicaragua Canal survey.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- To-day's statement of the Treasury balances in the general fund, exclusive of the $150,000,000 gold reserve in the Division of Redemption, shows:
The State Convention of the Liberal Democratic Party in the small hall at Cooper Union last night resolved itself into a session for the denunciation of ex-Senator David B. Hill.

There is considerable excitement in Constantinople owing to a series of faith cures effected by the Greek Church of the Virgin Gorgoepikoos. Even Mahommedans were interested and joined the pilgrimage to the shrine until the Sultan issued a decree forbidding the faithful to attend. The decree, among other things, set forth that Abdul Hamid did not believe in "modern religious phenomena."
THE era of the table d'hote at clubs has at last dawned. Many times the table d'hote was tried at the larger clubs, but it was given up.
Another specimen of the so-called 1804 American silver dollar has turned up. The history of this remarkable coin is as follows:

Over 300 pleasure drivers took part in the third annual parade of the Hudson County Road Drivers' Association on the Hudson County Boulevard yesterday afternoon. The Road Drivers' Association of New York and Brooklyn were represented, while the Staten Island Road Drivers' Association sent a delegation of a dozen members, who formed a division of the parade.

An analysis of some Government statistics accounts for the attractiveness of Washington more convincingly than those reports that suggest an explanation either in the beauty of the National capital, the fascination of intimate neighborhood to the powerful, the opportunities for swift, easy, and inexpensive social success afforded by customs peculiar to Washington, or the remote possibility of promotion from the lowest clerical position to the highest subordinate office.

SHADRACH was a bull of mighty renown. His pedigree was something to be proud of. It was registered back through a line of ancestors only a little less distinguished than himself, and he was exhibited and admired at innumerable shows.

Dealing with the question of Gibraltar and the works to be carried out there, Le Temps of Paris, after recapitulating the history of the various schemes proposed, says: "The public is anxiously awaiting the result, and up to the present has said nothing. It has not complained any more than on the occasion of the errors and mistakes which marked the beginning of the Transvaal war.

"NO," said the red-haired woman at the real estate sale, with an air of injured dignity, "I would not take one of your old lots now if you would give it to me. All the other ladies have been driven around while I had to walk."

The International Convention, of Arbitration, which met at Lake Mohonk last week, was, to my mind, one of the most important gatherings held in many years. The able arguments made by the Hon. John W. Foster on international arbitration should be scattered broadcast throughout the United States.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 7 -- The past week saw the opening of the Summer vacation season in the old County of Dutchess, and by the middle of the week the rush of people to the county's favorite Summer resorts will be in full sway. Probably no county along the Hudson, outside of the mountainous districts, can extend such a happy hand and such a tempting invitation to the city-worn inhabitants as old Dutchess.

PRINCETON, July 7 -- In the annual parade of the graduates on the baseball field, just preceding the game with Yale to-day, there were a number of very unique and pretty features, as well as the undignified cavortings and picturesque cakewalks of stately Masters of Art, Doctors of Philosophy, and Bachelors of Science.

AMONG the guests whom Minturn Post Collins took out to Ardsley on the coach Pioneer was Miss Cora Van Norden, whose hat was novel in its trimmings. The hat itself was large and round, with a wide -- almost flat -- crown and a wide brim with an edge an inch high.

In his interesting book on some "Strange Corners of Our Country -- The Wonderland of the Southwest." Mr. Charles F. Lummis has a chapter on the volcanic regions in the Zuni Mountains of Western New Mexico and the rivers of stone which in former ages flowed from many volcanoes that are now "extinct."

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- In the Senate to-day consideration of the isthmian canal project was resumed. Mr. Mitchell (Ore.) addressed the Senate in continuation of his speech begun Thursday in support of the Nicaragua route.

Mark Twain has been revisiting the scenes of his early life. He arrived at St. Louis a few days ago, and was met at the train by Capt. Horace Bixby, who is described in "Life on the Mississippi," and is prominent among the "river men" of St. Louis, and who, away back in the fifties, endeavored to teach the pilot business to Mark Twain.
LONDON, June 7 -- Peace with honor it was assuredly, but peace also with an intolerable deal of ugly noise, in which the note of positive savagery was sharply sounded.

LATEST among dinner favors is the miniature ping-pong table. It is four inches long by two wide and stands an inch and a halt high. The table and legs appear to be of light brown wood with a fine grain, and the top is covered to within a quarter of an inch of its edge with light green cloth.

The old adage that it's an ill wind that blows nobody good is illustrated in the progress of the coal strike. While the anthracite properties are necessarily suffering, because of their inability to turn out their product, this is proving as meat and drink to the bituminous prop- erties, who find the demand for soft coal so abnormally large as to be altogether without precedent.

LONDON, June 7 -- Mme. Rejane's acting in "La Robe Rouge" by its intensity and naturalness made a great effect at the Imperial Theatre this week, but it is difficult to see what Arthur Bourchier, who holds the English-American rights of this argumentative play, will be able to make of it in adaptation.

PARIS, June 7 -- M. Rouvier this morning accepted the Portfolio of Finance in the new Combes Ministry, and the Cabinet was completed. Later in the day it was announced that M. Pelletan takes the Marine Portfolio, and M. Maruejouls the Portfolio of Public Works, exchanging places.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Depew made a speech in advocacy of the bill appropriating $10,000,000 for the purchase of 2,000,000 acres of land for a National forest in Virginia. North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, and Tennessee. Mr. Depew spoke of the reckless devastation of the forests that had been going on in this country, especially in the last fifty years.
HUNTINGTON, West Va., June 7 -- A skirmish between mine officials and strikers is reported at Keystone.

LONDON, June 7 -- As was predicted in these dispatches last week, the announcement of peace has had in effect, the reverse of enlivening the stock market, and folks who predicted that June would be a holiday month and unloaded their Kafirs and other speculative stocks early are having the best of it.

LENOX, Mass., June 7 -- Indications are that more visitors from New York will be in the Berkshires this season than any time before in the history of this Summer resort region. The hotel accommodations have been so greatly improved that the Summer colony is increasing year by years.

The "suspension" is dragging along, and the consumer is paying the bill. The miners do not care, for that was their demand, "Pay us more and get it out of the consumer." Many of the former miners in the anthracite fields have gone off to soft coal regions and are making high wages; the districts supplying the seaboard are having the best times in many years.

One bald fact rises prominently out of the multitude of volcano details brought back from Martinique a few days ago by those who had gone there on the Dixie, among whom was the special representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and who returned to New York after a careful and painstaking examination of the ruins of St. Pierre.

At a time when artists have overcome the fear of introducing too much color in their compositions, when stained glass has revived with unexpected sumptuousness, and even the architect is asked to introduce color in buildings, it is only natural that the treasures of color hidden in the earth should be considered.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 7 -- The Summer season, which is now gradually opening, promises to be one of the best in years. The cottage colony is larger than that of any past season at so early a date in June. The municipal authorities have put the streets, avenues, and boulevard along the ocean front in fine condition and the automobiles, handsome turnouts, and bicycles travel along the latter with ease and speed.

A former associate of tramps turned up in a cheap Chicago lodging house the other day and began looking for work. The man has since been identified as the former President of a college, who was at one time Chief of the United States Weather Bureau, and, besides having been Professor of Astronomy in the University of Michigan, had been a special envoy of the United States to a European gathering of scientists.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 7 -- The Holy Cross baseball team won an interesting game from Brown here to-day as the result of a little loose playing on the part of the local team in the sixth inning. A feature was the pitching of Coakley and Hatch, in which the honors were about even. Holy Cross infield went to pieces in the third and fourth innings, when Brown scored her runs.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 7 -- The early part of the week at Tuxedo was rather dull, but Friday and Saturday, when those who went to town returned, and today especially, were very lively among the cottagers and at the clubhouse. Many large dinners were given to-day. Richard Mortimer had many guests invited to meet Mr. and Mrs. James L. Putnam of Boston.

They are eating horses in Chicago. A great many butcher shops in that city sell large quantities of horse meat every week, and the people who buy it keep on returning for more, showing that they like it.

The promise of the racing programme at the Gravesend race track yesterday, moderate as it was, proved superior to the threats of the weather, and in spite of overcast skies, occasional drops of rain, and a soft and rather slow track, the attendance was of proportions to rival the best of the Gravesend meeting.

After thirty-seven years of mystery, the strange disappearance of Abner Lee, the celebrated old prospector who discovered the famous Lee Silver Mine, seventy miles northeast of San Bernardino, Cal., has at last been solved.

LONDON, June 7 -- Americans are beginning to arrive in larger numbers, but neither the Oceanic nor the Philadelphia brought a full complement of saloon passengers, and people in a position to judge declare that there is a smaller number of visitors from the United States here now than is usual at this time of the year.

Historic West Point, the site of the United States Military Academy, is preparing for topographical and structural changes that will make the reservation look like a new place. Those in charge of the academy have asked Congress for $6,000,000 to improve most of the old buildings, tear down some of them, and construct many new ones.
"Bat" William B. Masterson, in his own parlance, is "sore." His forty-five calibre pistol which he has carried since the strenuous days of his young manhood has been confiscated.
LONDON, June 7 -- As the date of the coronation approaches, London is assuming a beflagged aspect, the early extent of which is to no little degree due to the peace rejoicings.

Allan Kennaday of the Montclair Golf Club won the amateur golf championship of the State of New Jersey yesterday for the second consecutive time. In the final thirty-six hole round at the Montclair Golf Cluh he met and defeated Marc M. Michael of the Yountakah Country Club by the high score of 11 up and 10 to play.

AMONG the points which the Duke of Norfolk, as Earl Marshal, might have had to decide in view of King Edward's coronation, one of the most curious is as to the right of three Earls of England to wear catskin instead of ermine on their robes. As nobody but the furriers is at all likely to have disputed this right, the claim has probably not come to trial.

Richard Conrad Schiedt, A.M., Ph. D., Professor of Natural Science and Chemistry at Franklin and Marshall College, announces a new and startling theory of terrestrial construction and evolution. His theories are diametrically opposed to those espoused by geologists and scientists of the past and generally accepted to-day, and moreover are given additional interest and plausibility by the recent volcanic eruption and the accompanying disturbance of the sea bottom in the neighborhood.

ONE mighty important factor in stirring up the American home is the turkey. To be sure, there is one season of the year when he does his level best to make a mess of things, but, that riotous season being ended, he strives to make reparation by assisting at a general cleaning up.

BERLIN, June 7 -- In the Deutsche Monatschrift for June an anonymous writer, apparently a naval officer of high rank, discusses the possible success of the United States in a war with a first-class European power. He says:
H.W. Chapman has been appointed special agent of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company with headquarters at Pittsburg.

NYACK, N.Y., June 7 -- The trial of Edward Copeland Wallace of New York, who, while speeding through Rockland County with his automobile last week, frightened the horse of Edward G. Lovatt, a lawyer of Spring Valley, and caused serious injury to Mr. Lovatt and his wife, was begun before Justice Charles H. Fisher in Nyack to-day.

IN ONE section of North America the redman is now on the warpath just as viciously as he was throughout the entire Western part of the country a century and more ago. The Yaqui Indians of the State of Sonora, in the northwestern part of Mexico, are seeking the blood of the ruling race as actively, though perhaps not as effectively, as the Sioux of the Dakotas sought it not so very many years ago.

The news of the sale of the great collection of sculptures, paintings, and works of industrial art, ancient and mediaeval, made by Mgr. Marcello Massaranti, was known in America before it was in Rome, but from an interview with the buyer, Mr. Henry Walters of Baltimore. The Sun of that city gathered that the negotiations were not complete.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 7 -- There was absolutely no change in the anthracite coal miners' strike to-day which has now rounded out its fourth week. Miners and mine operators had nothing to say, and altogether it was a dull day throughout this valley. Here and there, however, men who were on their way to and from work were assaulted, but none of them was seriously hurt.
The Lutheran Ministerlum, at its recent session in Easton, Penn., declared itself as unalterably opposed to individual communion cups.

This is the season of the year when the thoughts of young men and old lightly turn to the country. The Summer season usually has its beginning in the early part of June, and then each warm day following sends a larger number to the seashore, the mountains, or the lakes until by the first of July all is in full swing.

WITH the warm season full upon us and the dog days soon at hand, it is now the time for men to make a complete change in dress. It never is wise to take off the Winter underwear, in this climate, before June. There are very sultry days in April and in May, but experience teaches us each year that this climate is fickle and there have been Summers when overcoats were grateful in June.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 7 -- The Boer officers who have been living in the prison camps near here have been driving about the island for the past two days. They are enjoying themselves immensely. Most of them are men of fine physique, and they appear to be well fed and in good condition.

It is difficult to recall any transaction affecting property on Long Acre Square, or anywhere in that immediate neighborhood, which affords such a striking illustration of the remarkable enharcement of values in that section as was furnished by the sale of 1,555 Broadway by the estate of the late William M. Ryan.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 7 -- On Tuesday and Wednesday of last week the beach presented an animated appearance, numbers of bathers enjoying a dip in the ocean. They say the water is too cold to remain in long yet, but the sun bath afterward made up for any previous discomfort.
Many a tale has been told of the development of things in the railroad and mineral line in the South, and some of them read like fairy stories.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 7 -- The interscholastic discus records was broken at the seventh annual championship games of the New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association meet, held at Pingry Oval, here to-day. W.R.A. McDonough of the Montclair High School threw 111 feet 8 inches, which beats the record of 105 feet 7 inches, made at the Cleveland High School games last year.
Bar sliver was quoted in London at 23 15-16d per ounce and in New York at 51 3/4 c per ounce. Mexican dollars at 42@ 43 1/2 c.

DULUTH, Minn., June 7 -- The whaleback steamer Thomas Wilson, Capt. Cameron master, was cut almost in two by the steamer George G. Hadley, Capt. Fitzgerald master, a half-mile south of the Duluth Canal to-day, and nine men were drowned. They were mostly men of the night crew, who had not time to get out of their bunks before the vessel sank.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The retirement of Lewis Nixon from the leadership of Tammany Hall takes away from that organization the last vestige of decency and honesty which it possessed. After the titular "Boss" had retired, the powers behind the throne, profiting by their knowledge of ancient history, elected a triumvirate, which shows that a classical education is not always thrown away.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., June 5 -- Indications point to a highly successful season for this Summer resort. Interviews find that the prospects are better than for ten years past. "We should not be surprised to find the season a record-breaker," say many.

To the Editor of The New York Times: How awkward the predicament into which our Government and we, the American people, have been placed by the promised gift of our great and good friend the German Kaiser! There is apparently but one way to retaliate. A statue of George Washington, presented by the United States and erected in imperial Berlin, will alone offset the proposed statue of Frederick the Great for republican Washington.

The subject of a National flower continues to agitate many aesthetic souls, and now it is suggested that the proper floral emblem for this country would be the product of the tobacco plant. The Tobacco World has received the following from a subscriber in Cincinnati:

The large naphtha launch Wageland, belonging to Magistrate Lorenz Zeller, had a hole ripped in her bottom by a submerged pile in Pelham Bay last evening and sank immediately. At the time the launch, in charge of John Grindle and Edward Muller, employes of Mr. Zeller, was going from the Harlem River to the Harlem Yacht Club at City Island.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 7 -- The Worcester baseball team won its third straight game from Jersey City to-day by superb pitching by Falkenberg, just secured by Worcester from the University of Illinois, and by the most brilliant kind of fielding. Running catches by Sebring, Frisbie, and Delehanty were features.

A SHORT time ago, in the month of May, I was visiting at a house in the South. There were fully two acres of lovely grounds all around, and these were covered with a rich grass carpet, soft as velvet. Here and there were splashes of red, yellow, pink, and white roses, looking for all the world as if nature had embroidered them out of floss spun from dew and sky and sunset clouds.

LONDON, June 7 -- The report of the Committee on Military Education and Training, issued to-day, furnishes the strongest official corrobaration of the inefficiency of the officers of the British Army. The committee's report, which is based on the evidence of the officers themselves, from the Commander in Chief downwards, fills forty-eight printed pages with caustic criticism of the existing system.

SAID the woman from Peoria: "I attended a meeting last night where the English language with at least twenty-six different brands of accent was spoken, and I found that in all that polyglot crowd only the person whose tongue was furred with thick Western corrugations seemed ashamed of his native heath and the language spoken thereon.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 7 -- The most interesting golf event to-day on the links of the Hillside Golf and Tennis Club was a team match between the Class B players of the home club and Baltusrol. The feature of the game was the grand playing of the Rev. Dr. William R. Richards, who has just been called to the pastorate of the Brick Presbyterian Church, New York, lately occupied by Dr. Babcock.

Columbia's annual commencement regatta was held on the Hudson River yesterday from the Columbia boathouse at One Hundred and Fifteenth Street and Riverside Drive. A number of spectators, including some graduates, gathered on the veranda of the boathouse to witness the races among eights, fours, doubles, and singles, in which all of the oarsmen in the various classes competed.
'I am perfectly satisfied with the adminstration of Col. Partridge as head of the Police Department. I would not accept his resignation, and I certainly have no idea of removing him."

READING, Penn., June -- Superintendent Luther of the Reading Company's collieries and a number of other coal region officials were summoned here to-day in consultation with President George F. Baer of the Reading and Jersey Central. The entire situation in the Reading Company's anthracite region was gone over.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The House today resumed consideration of the Anti-Anarchy bill. Mr. Patterson (Tenn.) offered an amendment to include the Judges of the Supreme Court in the list of those whose murder while engaged in the performance of their official duties should be made punishable by death. It was lost.

The Livingston Field Club played its first League championship cricket match yesterday at Prospect Park, and gained an easy victory over the Kings County eleven, which had to submit to defeat after their opponents had lost but two wickets. W. J.H. Clark bowled in good style for the winners and captured five wickets for 23 runs, while M.R. Cobb obtained four for 25.

On a field wet and slippery with the rain the Dufferin lacrosse team, champions of the Canadian Lacrosse Association of Western Canada, yesterday defeated the team of the Crescent Athletic Club by the score of 8 goals to 5. The competition was played on the field of the defeated organiation at Bay Ridge.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The two wings of the Republican Party made a well-meant but vain effort to get together on the Cuban Reciprocity question to-day. The Senators of the party had a conference designed to reach a conclusion, but it was a more hopeless failure than the first of the conferences held in the House, when the question was before that body.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The commanding position of the United States in the production and manufacture of iron and steel is illustrated by some figures published in The London Commercial Intelligence, a copy of which has just reached the Treasury Bureau of Statistics.

After winning two games from Chicago, and tieing with Pittsburg on Friday, great things were expected from the New York baseball team yesterday when they met the champions for the second time at the Polo Grounds. Over 9,000 persons sat in the stands and bleachers expecting the home team to make a good showing, but they were disappointed.

RICHMOND, Ind., June 7 -- With a hearty handshake or a smile and nod for his old acquaintances, D.G. Reid, President of the Board of Control of the United States Steel Company, visited to-day the scene of his early triumphs in the tin plate business in Elwood.

ORANGE, N.J., June 7 -- Beginning Monday, June 30, a handicap match tournament for women will be held on the links of the East Orange Golf Club. Austin Colgate has offered two cups to be played for, and a large number of entries are anticipated.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 7 -- The wedding this afternoon of Miss Frances Converse of New York to Ord Preston of Englewood at St. Paul's Church was the third brilliant wedding of the week here. The Rev. George F. Flitchner, rector of the church, performed the ceremony. The bride, the daughter of the late Amasa Converse, wore white chiffon over white silk, with flounces of point lace, and a tulle veil.

ORANGE, N.J., June 7 -- The opening of the women's new club house and a doubles match marked the formal beginning of the twenty-third season of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club to-day. While the threatening weather undoubtedly kept many away from the grounds, Orange society was well represented, and the new club house, a one-story frame structure, came in for considerable praise.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 7 -- The answer of the packers to the quo warranto, or antitrust proceedings of Attorney General Crow, to debar them from doing business in Missouri was completed to-day and sent to Jefferson City to be filed in the Supreme Court.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the most curious objects of traditional past and future relationship to the world's regal solemnities is the stone which forms the seat of the coronation chair of the Kings of Great Britain and Ireland, respecting which is the ancient distich:

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 7 -- A band of fifty men broke in the door of Henry Demming's home, six miles from here, early to-day, took Demming and his wife out in their night clothes, and whipped them with buggy whips. The whitecaps accused Demming of brutally whipping his son and told him he must leave the county if he did it again.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Interesting information with regard to the increase of the trade of the United States with Germany is given in the volume of Commercial Relations, which the Bureau of Foreign Commerce of the State Department now has in press. According to the report of Consular officers of the United States in Germany, the imports of American goods are advancing despite the existing trade depression.

Few places in America have as much to offer the Summer visitor as the Adirondack Mountains. Occupying an area of 6,000 square miles in the northeastern part of this State, the region offers scenery, opportunities for sport, and chance to live comfortably surpassed by few other summering places in the world.
SILAS LARRABEE had a high ball to-day in the House restaurant. One of his Congressional friends paid for it.
Gov. Odell will be renominated, and the Lieutenant Governorship will go to some one at this end of the State. Erie County can name one candidate on the State ticket other than Governor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a constant reader of THE TIMES, my attention has been called for some time past to the evident spirit of unfairness expressed toward automobiles and those who run them.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 7 -- Early Adirondack visitors have been experiencing a great variety of weather in the succession of rain, snow, and sunshine, but throughout the varying conditions the preparations for the general opening of camps and hotels has been going on.

Fred Rice, Charles Spencer, and Mando Mandini were arrested yesterday morning by Detective Sergeants McIver and Pollock of the Madison Street Station, charged with the larceny of 124 pairs of trousers and some carpets and rugs valued at about $100. Rice has no home, while the other two men, who have no occupation, live at 4 Macdougal Street and 104 Greenwich Avenue respectively.

The Directorate of the Hamburg-American Line sent to the shareholders of the company on May 26 a circular setting forth the following facts about the formation of the Ship Trust and its arrangement with the German lines:

LONDON, June 7 -- The supply of money was large, and rates were easier to-day. Business on the Stock Exchange was more cheerful. There were many indications of the liquidations ending. The firmness of prices noticeable late yesterday was maintained. The eve of the settlement restricted business.

On the complaint of Mrs. Ora Jacobs, who refused to give an address except to say that she was in the ladies' tailoring business as Mme. Bell at 28 West Thirtieth Street, a policeman last evening arrested John Loper, twenty-six years old, of 297 Glenmore Avenue, Brooklyn. The man was locked up on a charge of being a suspicious person.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 7 -- The annual meeting of the St. Paul and Sioux City Railroad Company was held here to-day, and the officers and Directors were reelected.
THE Summer tourist in New England with a fancy for collecting old furniture or old dishes can complain of no lack of opportunity nowadays.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been with some amazement and regret that I have noticed, not only the letters that have appeared in THE TIMES denouncing automobilists and automobiles, but your editorial attitude as well.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 -- Engagements announced this week are: Mrs. Sarah E. Briggs of 212 South Forty-second Street, this city, to Dr. Thomas Dyer Henderson of New York; Miss Dorothy Levy of Hayerstraw, N.Y., to Mr. Milton Herold of Philadelphia, and Miss Annie Elizabeth Hill of 1,808 Spruce Street to Rev. Albert J. Lyman, pastor of the South Congregational Church of Brooklyn.

"TOMMY" SAFFORD, organist of a Madison Avenue church, has been called the "boy prodigy." He is not a boy, but is very youthful in appearance, and has for some years been playing the organ in city churches. He was asked to try an organ at a small suburban city, new in its churches, paved streets, houses, and buildings of all kinds.

FAIRLY to appreciate the influence of gas on the customs, manners, arts, and science of a people one must go to the Orient. In a country where the inhabitants have for centuries gone to bed by paper night lamps, such as we saw in "Madame Butterfly," they have inevitably indulged largely in evening entertainments.

The more the ruins of St. Pierre are examined the stronger appears the probability that while the death of its 30,000 inhabitants was accomplished in an exceedingly brief period, it must have taken some time. The "instantaneous death" theory must be given up in view of what the wreck reveals.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 7 -- Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs arrived this evening at her villa, Rosecliff, for the Summer.

Portraits of notable men are accumulating so fast in New York that some way will have to be devised to bring them together into a city portrait gallery. The old City Hall is pretty well filled, and when the Hall of Records is finished there may be walls on which portraits can find place; but there is already need of some provision for further likenesses ordered and to come.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., June 7 -- So that everything shall be in readiness for an early opening of the season, the resorts about this quiet town are hard at work rushing their improvements, renovatings, and additions to completion. That the Summer of 1902 is going to be a good one is certain, for every one has received more applications for accommodations than ever before at this time.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 -- The Philadelphia market held firm to-day, but it was the dullest day of the year. The only activity was supplied by a little speculation in Union Traction rights and United Gas Improvement. The coal stocks were generally a shade lower, due, it is believed, only to inactivity.

READING, Mass., June 7 -- An accident by which two brothers, Charles and Clarence Haag, seven and five years old, respectively, lost their lives, and E.F. Brooks, an undertaker, was dangerously injured, occurred at the Main Street Railroad crossing here to-day. The horse which Mr. Brooks was driving became frightened at three automobiles, and the horns which their occupants were blowing.

No life at all was Shown by the trading in the outside market yesterday. The same conditions which resulted in the smallest total of the year in the Stock Exchange market were reflected by a practical cessation of business in the outside market. Trading was within such narrow limits that practically nothing of special interest developed in the day's transactions.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., June 7 -- Search is being made for John Walker, who was station agent of the Long Island Railroad Company at Hyde Park. Walker left the station on Tuesday night and boarded a train for Long Island City. He left the doors of the station and the express office wide open, and the place was found unprotected by persons who went there Wednesday morning to take trains.

The remarkably cool weather of the past week served to keep the theatres filled to a large extent and sustain interest in the numerous first nights. But the little furor of the putting on of new shows and of the revivals has nothing to keep it alive this week. There are scarcely any openings, and the theatregoer will have to turn to the plays which are running on indefinitely.

HUDSON, N.Y., June 7 -- A team match was played to-day in the Hudson River Golf League series on the links of the Glenwood Golf Club here between the home forces and the Highland Golf Club of Garrisons. The Glenwood team won by 28 holes to 1. The players and results are:

Way up in the Catskill Mountains, right under the shadow of ancient Mount Utsayantha, historic and beautiful, stands the town of Stamford. It is seventy-two miles from the Hudson River, and reached by the Ulster and Delaware Railroad winding here and there through that wonderful district.

In the annual regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club yesterday, S.H. Mason's schooner Miladi won the second leg for the Alcedo Cup, and thereby becomes the permanent owner of that trophy. Miladi practically had a sailover. By some misunderstanding on the part of those in charge of James N. Norris's Leslie, which was entered against the Miladi, that boat did not start until ten minutes or more after her rival had crossed the line.

The season seems to linger a bit. Although there are no entertainments, many of the fashionables are loath to go to the country. Each ship from abroad brings new arrivals, and there is a great deal of shopping, and some little dinners have been on the tapis during the week. The restaurants have been well patronized, and the avenue and park have been filled with gay equipages.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As suggestians from any source may aid in shaping final opinion on the question of banknote issues now gaining the attention of the public mind, I beg to offer the following:

SEATED around me fire at a backwoods hotel in New Jersey a party of sportsmen were comparing notes on the day's sport and "swapping" stories in general. Running the gamut of sports afield, the conversation gradually drifted to the subject nearest the sportsman's heart -- the bird dog.

An attempt on the part of the Canadian Government to deal kindly by the evicted settlers of the Island of Anticosti has proved a failure, and the last chapter in this new story of a modern Arcadia will come to a close when James Osborne and his family are released from the Winnipeg (Manitoba) Isolation Hospital.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 7 -- The study of a great strike, like that now in progress in the anthracite basin, to be of value, must go outside of and beyond the issues immediately in dispute. In themselves these are of very little consequence. Whether the miners gain what they have struck for, or, if defeated, they return to work on the terms and conditions they refuse now, is relatively unimportant.
MEN are coming to be quite regular patrons of the shopping bureaus.

WHETHER Stonehenge be Druidical has nothing to do with the contention now rife in England in regard to it. It does seem incongruous that in close juxtaposition with the old, solemn, weather-beaten stone of a remote past there should be strung encircling them a particularly ugly object of our utilitarian present, a barbed-wire fence.

SERVING as an enlisted man through the Philippine war I came across many odd trenches, barricades, and blockades erected by the ingenious Filipinos, who always calculate these fortifications with a view of retreating from them in the event of being pushed by the American troops.

Faultless accuracy combined with forceful back-court methods gained the lawn tennis championship honors yesterday for Frederick G. Anderson in the final competition of the singles in the Kings County Tennis Club's open tournament on the courts at Bergen Street and Kingston Avenue, Brooklyn.

FORT DE FRANCE, May 21 How in the early morning of Ascension Day, May 8, out of the cavernous jaws of Pelee death descended with a sword of flame and reaped the richest harvest in all history, is a story which the whole world knows almost by heart already.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 7 -- At the annual field day meet on the Elmira College campus to-day, Miss Bertha Burgett, 1902, broke the American record for college girls in baseball throwing by throwing the ball 181 feet. The best previous record was 163 feet. The summary of the events follows:

Although the Carlists were silent during the recent enthronement ceremonies in Madrid, their pens were not idle. On the eve of the coming of ago of Alfonso XIII. the Correo Espanol, the official organ of the Carlist Party in Spain, published a protest by Don Carlos, who is at present in Venice.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The children of Henry Street need a helping hand from the children of Madison Avenue and up town, and their parents. The city has given, for the use of the little ones in the "Jacob A. Riis House," Twin Island, in Pelham Bay Park, with the beautiful big house upon it, rent free.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 7 -- In the second baseball game of the Yale championship series played here to-day Princeton turned the tables on Yale in a slowly played but very interesting game by the score of 8 to 5. Steinwender's one-handed catch of a hot line drive in the last inning was the finest ever made here, and the sturdy Tiger Captain was cheered to the echo.

LONDON, June 7 -- The appointment of the Hon. Michael Herbert to the Washington Embassy is accepted dispassionately, even politely, by the very men who were urging an appointment of quite different character, and who firmly believed the Foreign Office would not act quickly in the matter.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 -- The wildness of Wicker, pitcher of the St. Louis basetall team, in the first inning of the first game with Philadelphia to-day, followed by a few timely hits, enabled the home team to win in rather handy fashion.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., June 7 -- A mob of strikers late last night surrounded the homes of Sub-bosses Homer, Murphy, Shreffler and two Polish men, and built bonfires, on which effigies representing the bosses were burned. The demonstration against the homes of Murphy and the Polish men grew so vigorous that the non-union men promised not to go to work today.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 7 -- The American Academy of Medicine opened its twenty-seventh annual meeting here to-day. An address was delivered by Dr. V.C. Vaughan of Ann Arbor, Mich., President of the Academy, and reports of special committees were presented by Dr. A.L. Benedict of Buffalo and Dr. S. Duncan Bulkley of New York.

F.X. Hussey scored nine points at the monthly club games of the Star Athletic Club, held on the club grounds on Vernon Avenue, Long Island City, yesterday afternoon, obtaining first place in the halfmile run, second in the 220-yard run, and third in the 100-yard run. This gives him the lead in the point competition of the club.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 8. -- The annual Feast of Roses was celebrated at Manhelm to-day, when the Zion Evangelical Lutheran Congregation of that place paid to the heirs of Baron Henry Stiegel their yearly rental -- one red rose. A crowd of nearly 10,000 persons poured into the little town to witness the quaint and beautiful ceremony.

The French Cabinet which has just been brought together under Dr. COMBES offers several points of contrast with that which, a little over three years ago, was drawn from every faction of the Republican Party at large by the patriotic persuasion of M. WALDECK-ROUSSEAU.

LONDON, June 8. -- Whitelaw Reid, the special Envoy of the United States to the coronation of King Edward, who arrived at Queenstown yesterday on the Cunard Line steamer Umbria, is now comfortably settled in the capacious Brook House here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your report of the meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation in THE TIMES of Thursday, June 5, reads that the resolutions offered by Mr. Darwin R. James, asking the President to take such action as is provided for in an act passed in 1888, either by commission or arbitration, as he may deem best, to settle the coal strike, was opposed by L.J. Callanan.
LONDON, June 8. -- The War Office has received the following message from Lord Kitchener, under to-day's date:

MERIDIAN, Miss., June 8. -- A threatened uprising of the negroes, which so alarmed the people north of Meridian, has been frustrated by the determined stand of the whites, who armed themselves and placed the leaders of the gang. Green Johnson and Nate Moore, under arrest.
Walter E. Hutchinson of 247 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, died at Roosevelt Hospital at 6:15 o'clock last night of injuries received a week ago.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 8. -- Although President Mitchell is lending a great struggle for a shorter workday, he is not limiting himself to any prescribed hours of labor. He works late every night, and he was busy all of to-day in his office. Most of his time to-day was given up to receiving reports by messenger or by wire from his men in the field.

ALPENA, Mich., June 8.--An excursion train on the Detroit and Mackinaw Railroad, which left here at 7:15 to-day for Saginaw, and consisted of an engine and twelve coaches, carrying more than 500 people, was wrecked at Black River while running forty miles an hour. One man was instantly killed, three were probably fatally injured, and nearly fifty others received injuries of various degrees of severity, ranging from bruises and cuts to broken limbs.

PRETORIA, June 8. -- The service of thanksgiving for the return of peace to-day was held in the principal square of Pretoria. The sun shone brilliantly and the sight was impressive. Out side of the roped inclosure of troops were gathered many thousands of the townspeople and a goodly sprinkling of Boers, whose demeanor was most respectful.

HAZLETON, Penn., June 8. -- At their meeting at Freeland this afternoon the employes of the Delaware, Susquehanna and Schuylkill Railroad refused to handle any trains carrying special officers, deputies, or non-unionists. The following resolution, addressed to Luther C. Smith, Superintendent of the road, was adopted:

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 8. -- The Rev. Dr. William Rogers Richards, pastor of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, announced to his congregation this evening that if the call extended by the Brick Presbyterian Church, New York, is properly presented through, the Presbytery he feels it his duty to accept It.

BERLIN, June 8. -- The thanksgiving service for the conclusion of peace in South Africa held in the English Church here to-day was attended by the members of the British Embassy at Berlin, Andrew D. White, the United States Ambassador, and John B. Jackson, Secretary to the embassy.

BERLIN, June 8. -- Last week on the Boerse began with uncommon strength in all departments on the expectation of a great boom in Kafirs in London, but the failure of this boom to materialize brought a sharp disappointment and caused a dull and declining market until yesterday, when the improvement of Friday in New York and London reacted strongly here.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 8. -- Dillingham Rover, twenty-two years of age, who was employed in the cashier's department of the Century Magazine, was drowned in the Hackensack River this afternoon. He had aided in holding up one of his girl companions, and had just released her to a rescuer in a boat when he sank out of sight.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 8. -- Capt. Richmond P. Hobson of the United States, Navy addressed the members at the Sunday school of the Second Reformed Church here this afternoon, the occasion being the celebration of the school's annual Children's Day.

John Sullivan, a workman engaged on what is known as "Bridge No. 3," died yesterday morning at the Brooklyn Hospital of caisson disease. Although there have been numerous cases of the disease reported, this is the first death known to result from it.
Columbia University gymnasium was crowded yesterday afternoon when the Right Rev. Frederick Burgess, Bishop of Long Island, delivered the baccalaureate sermon to the graduating classes.

A stock of passionate prejudices, springing from inaccurate impressions of ancient facts, kept active by senseless hatred, and liable to eruption at any moment, is not a good equipment for historical criticism or comment on passing affairs. Witness the muddle in which The London Saturday Review involves itself in trying to cast contempt on the reception of the Rochambeau Monument by President ROOSEVELT.

At the morning service of the Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church, McDonough Street and Tompkins Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday the resignation of the Rev. Dr. Robert R. Meredith as pastor of the church, on account of ill-health, was read. Dr. Meredith's note was dated at Clifton Springs, N.Y., where he went recently in the hope that his health, which has been failing for several months, would be improved.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 8. -- The operators in the anthracite region authorized the following statement to-day:

More soft coal than ever will be burned in New York this week, according to experts who were seen yesterday. They declare that in spite of the letters alleged to have been received by President Lederle of the Board of Health there is no coal suited for steam purposes in New York, and that the population must grin and bear it.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 8. -- The baccalaureate sermon was preached at Vassar College to-day by President Taylor. His subject was the deadening effect of pleasure seeking on all the higher activities of life. He said that the teaching of Jesus did not inculcate asceticism among His disciples, but demanded, rather, steadfastness of purpose, a stern sense of duty, and the best use of their energies in the relations of life.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 8. -- The baccalaureate sermon was preached to-day by President Patton of the university in Alexander Hall. The procession of Trustees, Faculty, and members of the senior class formed in front of Nassau Hall and led by President Patton and ex-President Grover Cleveland, marched to the hall, which was filled to its utmost seating capacity when the exercises began.

The high wind which prevailed yesterday, and which at 3:30 P.M. attained a velocity of seventy miles an hour, made things lively during the greater part of the day. No serious accidents were reported, but the damage done by the gale to trees and boat schedules, to say nothing of coiffures and straw hats, was considerable.
One of the declarations of the platform adopted by the Indiana Democratic Convention was this:

NEW HAVEN, June 8. -- The Yale-Harvard regatta, which will be held on the Thames River June 26, will be rowed, because of the tides, under entirely different conditions from last year. The ebb this year comes in the morning, and the flood at noon, so that the races will have to be split.

NEWARK, N.J., June 8. -- Pittsburg (National League) defeated Newark (Eastern League) here to-day in a loosely played baseball contest before the largest crowd of the season, over 6,000 persons being present. Stricklett pitched a clever game for Newark, striking out eight men, but received poor support.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A friend has sent me a clipping from THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 18, containing an interesting article on "Mosquito Engineering," in which occurs this passage:

Off Hunt's Point yesterday afternoon three men were drowned, as a result of the capsizing of a boat that was caught by a hawser connecting two of three barges that were in tow of the tug Packer of the Long Island Sand Company. A fourth man who was in the boat was saved by the merest chance.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The conference between Senators Spooner and Burrows, which was to have resulted in the offering of a compromise proposition on Cuban reciprocity, did not come off. Mr. Spooner waited for Mr. Burrows to call on him, and Mr. Burrows waited for Mr. Spooner. Neither called.

Southern men have usually insisted, and quite rightly, that the "negro problem" was theirs and that their fellow-citizens from the North could do little toward understanding it and still less toward solving it.

-- Major RONALD Ross, whose original researches in India and later work in Africa and elsewhere have given his name first place among those of the men who have established the relation between mosquitos and malaria, has sent to one of the London papers a queer report received by him from Major BUCHANAN, a civil surgeon in Nagpur, India.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 8. -- Three men were drowned this morning in Long Island Sound off this city. They were Ernest Leifflen, twenty-six years of age, of 748 Ninth Avenue, New York; David Kerr, forty-five years of age, of 118 South First Avenue, Mount Vernon, and Hugh McKeand, thirty-seven years old, of 333 North Terrace, Mount Vernon.

HARRISBURG, Penn., June 8. -- "The nomination of Judge Pennypacker is as certain as it is that there will be a roll call Wednesday," said Insurance Commissioner Durham to-night in speaking of the contest for the Republican nomination for Governor of Pennsylvania.

Wall Street refuses to be disturbed Over the coal strike situation. Even when sensational and exaggerated bulletins have been put out on the Street they have been received calmly and without perturbation -- this because of the recognition of the fact that, whatever the temporary course of affairs, the matter must sooner or later be adjusted.

"We have accomplished something. To-day the Police Department is better than it was, and from this time on the improvement will begin to show. The department has been gotten into such case that from now on improvements will be more noticeable."

The Central Federated Union was thrown into a state of white-hot indignation yesterday over charges that some of the delegates had been using the name of the central body last week for political purposes. The charges were made by Morris Brown, delegates of Cigarmakers Union No. 144, who particularly specified President McVey and Delegate Campbell of Typographical Union No. 6, as being among the delegates referred to.

PEEKSKILL, State Camp, June 8. -- All this afternoon the grounds have been thronged with a good-natured crowd of men, women, and children. Over 2,000 persons witnessed the two evening parades tonight. Half of these people came from New York and Brooklyn, and landed at the Roa Hook dock after midday from the steamer Grand Republic.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The greater part of the time of the Senate the present week will be given to the Interoceanic Canal bill. An effort probably will be made by the supporters of the Nicaragua route to secure an agreement to vote on the bill next Saturday, but the probabilities are all against success.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday announced that he had discovered the name of the man who shot at County Detective McLellan just before he dangerously wounded James F. McCoy in a raid last week on an alleged poolroom at 154 and 156 East Forty-second Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that electric trains are a fact on some of the elevated roads of the city, I would like to say a few words concerning them. I have never been suspected of being a prophet, and my predictions, after all, may amount to nothing, but I cannot help seeing in the future a chapter of accidents that will, to borrow from Oom Paul, "stagger humanity."

HAVANA, June 3. -- Little by little we are becoming accustomed to the changed condition of things here. We are growing used to passing up Obispo or O'Reilly Street or the Prado and seeing only strangers -- no familiar faces, no familiar uniforms. We go to Central Park on the evenings of the band concerts -- unfamiliar faces surround us.

Transfers in the Fourth Cavalry: Capt. James B. Hughes, from Troop H to Troop M. Capt. Robert A. Brown, from Troop M to Troop H. First Lieut. Frank D. Wykham, Eighteenth Infantry, is transferred to the Twelfth Infantry, Company I.

Within the next week or ten days the anthracite strike will probably enter upon its final and decisive phase. In at least two districts, and perhaps more, the mine owners are arranging to assume the aggressive on so large a scale that the strike managers will not know how to meet the movement by peaceful means and may find it impossible to restrain disorder even if they should wish to.

PEEKSKILL, June 9. -- After the "largest day" in camp of the season yesterday, the plateau presented a very deserted and peaceful aspect this afternoon. In order to accommodate the large number of visitors last night a special train was run by the New York Central, leaving here at 8 o'clock. It was promptly filled.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 9. -- The Arcade, the Citizens' National Bank block, the Theatre Saratoga, and the Shakleford Building, located on Broadway and Phila Street, were burned this morning. WEST POINT, N.Y., June 9. -- The centennial anniversary exercises of the establishment of the United States Military Academy began to-day, and will continue until Thursday, when the present first class of cadets, containing fifty-four members, will be graduated. The committee of officers to receive the visiting graduates and distinguished guests is kept busy.

HARRISBURG, June 9. -- With the chances apparently about even between Judge Samuel W. Pennypacker of Philadelphia and Attorney General John P. Elkin of Indiana, and the managers of ex-Lieut. Gov. Louis A. Watres of Scranton claiming: he holds the balance of power, the result of the contest for the Republican nomination for Governor remains to-night very uncertain.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Father Pitowal, now of the Colorado Diocese of the Catholic Church, has been appointed auxiliary Bishop to the Archbishop of Santa Fe. The Rev. Father Specht, now Vicar General of the Columbus Diocese, has been made a domestic prelate of the Church with the title of Monsignor.
The following petition has been sent to officials of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad by commuters living at Sound Beach:

CHICAGO, June 9. -- Nine men and one woman were killed and about thirty persons were injured in a fire which this afternoon destroyed the sanitarium conducted by the St. Luke's Society at the corner of Wabash Avenue and Twenty-first Street. The society occupied the building which was long known as the Hotel Woodruff, and for a brief period, as the Hotel Lancaster.

Transfers in the Fourth Cavalry: Capt. James B. Hughes, from Troop H to Troop M. Capt. Robert A. Brown, from Troop M to Troop H. First Lieut. Frank D. Wykham, Eighteenth Infantry, is transferred to the Twelfth Infantry, Company I.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday announced that he had discovered the name of the man who shot at County Detective McLellan just before he dangerously wounded James F. McCoy in a raid last week on an alleged poolroom at 154 and 156 East Forty-second Street.

The series of three games between the New York and Pittsburg baseball teams was concluded yesterday at the Polo Grounds with honors even, New York winning the last contest by a score of 5 to 3. On Friday the teams tied in an eleven inning game, and on Saturday Pittsburg won.

SALEM, Oregon, June 9. -- Two desperate prisoners, Harry Tracy, sentenced to twenty years, and David Merrill, a thirteen-year man, serving sentences for assault and robbery committed in Multnomah County, escaped from the penitentiary this morning after killing three guards -- Frank Ferrell, shop guard, and S.R. Jones and Ben Tiffany, fencemen.

LONDON, June 9. -- The new Atlantic Transport liner Minnetonka, Capt. Layland, from New York for London, passed Dover to-day and signaled that a hole had been knocked into her port bow and her port anchor lost in collision with a Runciman Line steamer off the Royal Sovereign Lightship on the coast of Sussex.

Beck, Yale's champion shot putter and winner of the intercollegiate shot put, has notified the Games Committee of the Knights of Columbus that he will enter the field against Flanagan and De Witt in the hammer-throwing contest at Celtic Park on June 21. Besides Beck's entry, "Mike" Murphy, Yale's athletic trainer, has promised to send on the entire Yale team to take part in these games.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 9. -- Mrs. H.W. Berryman is visiting her daughter. Mrs. H. Casimer de Rham, at the Willing cottage.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- "It is the President and not the beet-sugar Senators who are delaying the settlement of the Cuban relief problem," a beet-sugar Senator said to-day.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9. -- The Nassau Herald, the commencement publication edited by members of the graduating class, was issued to-day. The book contains the class history, prophecy, and the class day addresses, besides the summary of the class elections and statistics founded upon a poll made during the Spring.

LONDON, England, June 9. -- The second game of polo for the international cup was played to-day at the Hurlingham Club, and the English team won by six goals to one. The Americans have the satisfaction of knowing that the game was one of the most brilliant ever played at Hurlingham.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9. -- The most noteworthy event of the commencement exercises at Princeton University this year, and the greatest surprise of many years, was announced this afternoon at the annual meeting of the Board of Trustees, when President Francis Landey Patton resigned and Woodrow Wilson, Professor of Politics and Jurisprudence, was elected to fill the vacancy.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9. -- The most noteworthy event of the commencement exercises at Princeton University this year, and the greatest surprise of many years, was announced this afternoon at the annual meeting of the Board of Trustees, when President Francis Landey Patton resigned and Woodrow Wilson, Professor of Politics and Jurisprudence, was elected to fill the vacancy.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Mr. Harris, (Kansas,) a member of the Committee on Interoceanic Canals, addressed the Senate to-day in favor of the Nicaragua route. Mr. Harris is an engineer and served for a long time as Chief Engineer of the Union Pacific Railway, Kansas Division.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- There were received early to-day from the vaults of the New Era Safety Deposit Company 192,000 francs, or $38,400, nearly the entire proceeds of a swindle which in the ingenuity of its conception and cleverness of execution is a rival of the famous Humbert swindle.

Fully 4,000 persons gathered on the Columbia campus yesterday afternoon to witness the adieus of the college seniors to their undergraduate careers. MIDDLESBOROUGH, Ky., June 9. -- About 5,000 miners and coke workers in Buchanan County, West Va., and in Wise and Scott Counties, Va., refused to obey strike orders and are at work. The Virginia Iron, Coal and Coke Company works most of these men. High officials of the company state that they have no fear of their men going out at any time.

Pretty barette pins to be seen in the best jewelers' are in shell, with a design in gold wire upon them set with pearls. Shell is one of the most satisfactory ornaments for the hair.

Suppe's "Boccaccio" was performed at Terrace Garden last night. It would not be altogether unsatisfactory to let the record end with the statement of that important fact, but there are cerain duties which cannot be neglected, and to give some account of the nature of this unique performance is one of them.

It was a striking coincidence that Lord KITCHENER'S reward for his African campaign should be moved upon the third anniversary of the grant to him upon account of his Egyptian services. Two such services and two such rewards are a rare experience. Yet England felt called upon to make excuse or explanation of why Lord KITCHENER gets only a quarter of a million of dollars and promotion, both in the army and in the peerage.

A spectacular fire last night at 336 and 340 East Thirty-eighth Street attracted a great crowd and gutted the cigar factory of Morris Jacoby. Policeman Hickey, who turned in the first alarm, called for police reserves. Capt. Delaney, with the reserves, including those from the East Twenty-second, the East Thirty-fifth, and the Fifty-first Street Stations, ordered all persons out of the buildings close to the fire.

Carroll D. Wright, the United States Commissioner of Labor, who arrived here on Sunday to obtain information regarding the coal strike for President Roosevelt, had an interview last night with Mr. Mitchell of the United Mine Workers. Mr. Wright will undertake to see some of the coal operators to-day.

It was hardly worth while for King EDWARD and his Ministers to strain their generosity as severely as they did in according terms to the Boers, and then to permit the publication of Sir LEWIS MORRIS'S verses on the dove that flew into St. Paul's while the thanksgiving services were in progress.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- "It is the President and not the beet-sugar Senators who are delaying the settlement of the Cuban relief problem," a beet-sugar Senator said to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that electric trains are a fact on some of the elevated roads of the city, I would like to say a few words concerning them. I have never been suspected of being a prophet, and my predictions, after all, may amount to nothing, but I cannot help seeing in the future a chapter of accidents that will, to borrow from Oom Paul, "stagger humanity."

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The House today proceeded with the consideration of the bill "to transfer certain forest reserves to the control of the Department of Agriculture and to authorize game and fish preserves in forest preserves."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9. -- The Nassau Herald, the commencement publication edited by members of the graduating class, was issued to-day. The book contains the class history, prophecy, and the class day addresses, besides the summary of the class elections and statistics founded upon a poll made during the Spring.

SCRANTON, Penn., June 9. -- The coal companies in this city and its vicinity continue their preparations for a long siege. The Erie is building high board fences about its collieries, and the I ackawanna Railroad is installing bunks in its buildings about the collieries. Electric are lights are also being placed about the workings.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- Chicago and Cook County have won an important victory over the public utility corporations in their injunction proceedings to avoid payment of the additional taxes assessed against them for the year 1900, according to County Attorney Sims's reading of a report of United States Masters in Chancery Bishop and Allen.

Two judicial decisions relating to the proposed exchange of stock for bonds of the United States Steel Corporation were made yesterday, the Judges taking exactly opposite views. While Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, denied the application for an injunction to restrain the corporation from issuing $200,000,000 of bonds in exchange for preferred stock, Vice Chancellor Emery, in New Jersey, granted a temporary injunction restraining the corporation from issuing these bonds.

LONDON, England, June 9. -- The second game of polo for the international cup was played to-day at the Hurlingham Club, and the English team won by six goals to one. The Americans have the satisfaction of knowing that the game was one of the most brilliant ever played at Hurlingham.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 9. -- Gov. Odell today announced the following appointments:

It was a striking coincidence that Lord KITCHENER'S reward for his African campaign should be moved upon the third anniversary of the grant to him upon account of his Egyptian services. Two such services and two such rewards are a rare experience. Yet England felt called upon to make excuse or explanation of why Lord KITCHENER gets only a quarter of a million of dollars and promotion, both in the army and in the peerage.

A spectacular fire last night at 336 and 340 East Thirty-eighth Street attracted a great crowd and gutted the cigar factory of Morris Jacoby. Policeman Hickey, who turned in the first alarm, called for police reserves. Capt. Delaney, with the reserves, including those from the East Twenty-second, the East Thirty-fifth, and the Fifty-first Street Stations, ordered all persons out of the buildings close to the fire.

Two judicial decisions relating to the proposed exchange of stock for bonds of the United States Steel Corporation were made yesterday, the Judges taking exactly opposite views. While Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, denied the application for an injunction to restrain the corporation from issuing $200,000,000 of bonds in exchange for preferred stock, Vice Chancellor Emery, in New Jersey, granted a temporary injunction restraining the corporation from issuing these bonds.

PARIS, June 10 -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day, after a speech by M. Bourgeois, on assuming the Presidency, the Premier, M. Combes, made the Ministerial declaration. It was received in silence by the Moderates and Right, while by the Radicals and Radical-Socialists it was warmly applauded.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The InterState Commerce Commission to-day issued Accident Bulletin No. 2 showing collisions and derailments of trains and casualties to persons for the three months ending Dec. 31, 1901.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June, 10 -- The annual luncheon of the Alumnae Association of Vassar College, which was held at the college to-day, was presided, over by Mrs. MacCoy of Bryn Mawr, President of the association.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- To-day's investigation of the causes and responsibility for the catastrophe at the Sanitarium of the St. Luke's Society reveals, it is declared, a tale of negligence on the part of officials of the sanitarium and the city.

At Johns Hopkins yesterday Dr. GOULD, the City Chamberlain, took up the subject that was treated recently by Mr. JEROME at Cambridge -- the present reform administration, of which each is a part. His treatment, not unnaturally, was less picturesque and rather more fair than that of the District Attorney.

HARRISBURG, Penn., June 10 -- Bitterness between the leaders of the Pennypacker and Elkin factions cropped out several times during a meeting of the Republican State Committee this afternoon to prepare the roll of delegates and select the temporary officers of to-morrow's State Convention.

The opening matinee race meet of the Mohawk and Hudson Valley Circuit was held yesterday afternoon at the track of the Parkway Driving Club, Ocean Boulevard and Kings Highway, Brooklyn. Three races -- a 2:40 trot, a 2:13 pace, and a 2:32 pace -- comprised the first day's programme, and were witnessed by a good-sized crowd of spectators.

BALTIMORE, June 10 -- The local market, while developing nothing especially new in the way of a general change of conditions, has managed to stimulate a little additional interest in some issues which have been lying dormant. Cotton Duck bonds have been attracting more attention, owing to the improving status of the company.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- The Philadelphia market was more active and strong to-day, following up the improvement of yesterday, but it is still very dull, and such price changes as occur cannot be called significant. Brokers state that they expect a dull market for local issues throughout the Summer.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Island of Trinidad, Wednesday, June 4. -- President Castro of Venezuela has been forced to recognize that the Matos revolution is not a myth, for his best troops are beaten daily by the revolutionary forces and at the present hour the country is rising as one man against Castro.

-- Defeated by the somewhat terrible score of six to one, the Captain of the American polo players in England says "The only thing we have to complain of is that they beat us." The ponies and the players were all right, and, having done their best, the "next time" becomes the only thing worth thinking about.

Miss Helen Vanderbilt Wackerman, the American artists' model who became insane in London last November, her friends say in consequence of having been ordered to leave the house of the artist. Prof. Hubert Herkomer, R.A., for reasons which he has refused to divulge, arrived here yesterday on the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, accompanied by her mother, Mrs. John Vanderbilt Wackerman, her uncle, Dr. Lewis G. Smith, both of Buffalo, and two nurses.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The general expectation in the Senate is that the Spooner amendment to the Hepburn Canal bill will be adopted. Mr. Hanna said to-day he was sure of forty-five votes for the amendment, and expected to get more.

LONDON, June 10 -- Large crowds visited Ranelagh this afternoon to see King Edward, Queen Alexandra, and the American polo players. It was an exhibition game. America was represented by the same team as yesterday at Hurlingham, with the exception of J.M. Waterbury, Jr., who played instead of R.L. Agassiz.

Henry Hellman and George Milne have Bold for Jacob Baumann to E. Mann Vynne, for about $175,000, the six six-story flats 219 to 229 West Fortieth Street, 150 by 100. A new structure will be erected on the property, although nothing could be learned yesterday as to the nature of the projected improvement.
