WASHINGTON, June 10 -- As a result of last night's conference at the White House the Cuban reciprocity fight to-day entered upon a new phase. To-day and probably for the rest of the week the question is one of the backbone of the beet sugar Senators. The Administration men, who have hitherto been conciliatory, have now begun the process known as "putting the screws on."

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 10 -- Out-door games all day and the annual hop in the evening have kept going since early this morning the Military Academy's sturdy cadets and the hundreds of guests at the hundredth anniversary celebration. This was the centennial's second day. The visitors continue to come by the score and every available accommodation is already crowded to the utmost.

We presume it is a source of great satisfaction to the Directors of the New York Central Railroad that the storm of public indignation caused by the main- tenance of the Park Avenue tunnel nui- sance has subsided and that they are no longer under the stress of denunciatory criticism for maintaining an unbreathable atmosphere in the subterranean approach to their New York terminal.

Miss Alice Levis, twenty-three years old, daughter of a St. Louis millionaire, killed herself in the Plaza Hotel on Sunday. She had been suffering from melancholia, following an attack of nervous prostration, and was soon to have sailed to join her father in England. She hanged herself to the post of her bed with a bath towel.
New York's baseball team by its defeat yesterday at the hands of St. Louis on the Polo Grounds dropped to fifth place in the championship race.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 10 -- Yale's baseball team defeated the cadets' nine this afternoon by a score of 15 to 4. The crowd of spectators was the largest and most distinguished that has gathered here in many years, and the players celebrated the occasion by making the worst show of the season.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 10 -- The feature of the Democratic State Convention, which opened at noon to-day, was the ovation to ex-Gov. James P. Clarke, who was Declared by a resolution of the convention to be the Democratic nominee for United States Senator to succeed James K. Jones.

In the gray dawn of yesterday morning, with a dense haze hanging over the Harlem River, two policemen attached to the sub-station, of the Harbor Police, at One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, caught four "river pirates."

MANILA, Monday, June 9 -- The members of the court-martial which tried Major Edwin F. Glenn of the Fifty Infantry, who was charged with administering the water cure to Filipinos, have returned to Manila from Catbalogan, Island of Samar.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The House today resumed consideration of the bill to transfer certain forest reserves to the Agricultural Department and to authorize the President to create game and fish preserves in such reserves.

United States Labor Commissioner Carroll D. Wright had a conference by appointment yesterday afternoon with the representatives of the coal carrying companies, at which the companies' side of the differences between the striking anthracite miners and operators were submitted to him at his request.

LONDON, June 11 -- The revival of "The Merry Wives of Windsor" in Her Majesty's Theatre last night was received with a great volume of applause, directed toward the excellent general performance, as well as to the joint appearance of Mrs. Kendal and Miss Ellen Terry.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 10 -- A.G. Vanderbilt arrived at Oakland Farm this morning, having come by road from Providence in his new red automobile. Mrs. Vanderbilt, who had come by train last night, was at the farm to meet him. She is visiting at "The Breakers," but expects to occupy the new quarters at the farm in a short time.

LONDON, June 10 -- There was a good demand for money to-day owing to the Stock Exchange settlement, but the supply was not short, and rates were easy. Discounts were steady. Business on the Stock Exchange was stagnant, and there were no symptoms of activity in the near future.

After some appearance of hesitancy and irregularity in the early trading, the stock market yesterday became decidedly strong, and continued so until the close of business on a volume of transactions somewhat larger than in recent days. All told, something like 276,000 shares were traded in -- not a significant total, but nevertheless more than 100,000 shares greater than on the day previous.

There have been several suburban and town weddings during the week which are of interest. The town itself, as far as fashionable people are concerned, is thinning out. The commencement week of interest to parents and young people at Columbia, and the reception on board of the Italian ship Umbria were the only affairs of general interest yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Mr. Dalzell (Penn.) in the House to-day presented the special order for the consideration of the Corliss Pacific Cable bill. By its terms four hours were to be allowed for general debate, and any Pacific cable proposition was made germane to it. Mr. Dalzell called attention to the fact that by the terms of the rule the whole question of the Pacific cable would be before the House.

Arthur J. Kahn, doing business as Arthur J. Kahn Co., wholesale dealer in watches, diamonds, , at 37 and 39 Maiden Lane, whose financial embarrassment was reported last week, has been unable to effect a settlement with his creditors, and yesterday he filed a petition in bankruptcy with liabilities, $392,624, and nominal assets, $222,086.

NEWARK, N.J., June 10 -- Capt. "Dynamite Johnny" O'Brien, who arrived here from Cuba last night, had an altercation on the way home with a big Swede on an Arlington car. It is said the Swede, who weighs about 200 pounds, attempted to take a seat that the gallant Captain had vacated and offered to a woman.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Preliminary reports of the Spring wheat acreage indicate a reduction of about 2,511,000 acres, or 12.8 per cent. Of the nineteen States reporting Spring wheat, thirteen report a reduced acreage, Washington being the only State having 100,000 acres or upward in this product that reported an increase.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 10 -- The seventh annual convention of the National Credit Men's Association, representing a membership of 4,000 in all parts of the country, met this morning in this city. About 300 delegates were present.

BOSTON, June 10 -- Money rates continue fairly steady. Clearing Mouse rate 4 and 3 1/2 per cent. New York funds par and 5 cents discount. Call loans, 3 1/2 to 4. Time money, 4 to 5. Clearing House exchanges, $21,688,879; balances, ,$1,654,625. The stock market closed firm and rather active. Complete transactions were as follows:

CAMBRIDGE, England, June 10 -- The degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred this afternoon on Whitelaw Reid, the Special Ambassador of the United States to the coronation of King Edward, by Cambridge University. The Public Orator, John Edwin Sandys, referred to Mr. Reid's previous official visit to England and his return on the equally auspicious occasion of the coronation.

BALTIMORE, June 10 -- An immense number of friends of Johns Hopkins University were present to-day at the annual commencement in the Academy of Music. Every seat in the auditorium was occupied before the hour for the opening of the exercises began. The academic procession, headed by Dr. George B. Shattuck, filed slowly down the main aisle and ascended to the stage to the strains of the march from "Queen of Sheba."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 -- An immense crowd of alumni came into town to-day for the commencement exercises. At 10 o'clock this morning the the annual meeting of the Phi Beta Kappa took place, and at the same hour a tablet was unveiled in Marquand Chapel to the memory of George Yardley Taylor, 1902, Maryland, and Cortland Van Rensselaer Hodge, 1893, Mississippi, who lost their lives at Paoting-Fu, China, on June 30, 1900.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- Five hundred degrees in arts, music, science, philosophy, medicine, laws, and veterinary medicine will be conferred during commencement week at the University of Pennsylvania, which begins next Thursday afternoon and closes on the morning of the following Wednesday.

Thirty-three prominent women golfers from twelve clubs in the metropolitan locality started their annual tournament for the championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday on the Essex County Country Club's links near Orange. The round of the day was 18 holes, the first 16 to qualify for the chief honor and the second set to play for a consolation cup.

ALBANY, June 10 -- The Court of Appeals to-day unanimously affirmed the judgment of conviction of John Most, who was convicted of publishing an improper article in a paper owned by him in New York, and who was sentenced to one year's imprisonment in the New York penitentiary. Judge Vann, who wrote the opinion of the court, says:

BERLIN, June 10 -- Heinrich Couried, manager of the Irving Place Theatre, New York, has engaged the entire opera company of the Central Theatre here, including the chorus, to appear at the Irving Place Theatre in the months of April and May, 1903. The repertoire of the company which goes to New York will include a number of standard operettas.

Soft coal and a wind from the south-west made yesterday in New York a day in many respects unprecedented. This city got the benefit of all the bituminous fuel that was being consumed from Bayonne to Weehawken -- and there was a vast deal of it. The smoke hung over the city in a thick cloud, reminding one very strikingly of Pittsburg or St. Louis.
First Lieut. Rhinelander Waldo, Seventeenth Infantry, is relieved from recruiting duty in New York City and will proceed to join his company.

Inspector Walter Thompson's first experience with his new scene of duty. Queens Borough, was not pleasing to him. He got lost while trying to locate the headquarters. He was misdirected by a newsboy. The Inspector and one of his staff reached Long Island City in ample time to be at Headquarters ahead of time, but at the ferry they asked a boy where the Headquarters were.

Details of the proposed consolidation of ship building interests, made public yesterday, show that the concern will be incorporated under the laws of New Jersey with a capital stock of $20,000,000, equally divided in common and preferred shares, and that the name will probably be the United States Shipbuilding Company.

In some parts of the list yesterday the outside market showed more activity than at any time within the past ten days. The bulk of the transactions, however, was supplied by three or four stocks, and the rest of the market dragged along in the same dull fashion as it had for the preceding fewdays.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 12. -- This city will be under martial law to-day owing to troubles which have arisen over the strike of the conductors and motormen and violence offered. Two troops of cavalry and six infantry companies will go on duty during the morning.
Frank P. Tenney of the Williston Knight Company, of 540 Broadway, gave out the following statement yesterday afternoon:

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11. -- The commencement exercises of Princeton University were conducted before a large audience in Alexander Hall this morning. Two hundred and fifty-eight young men received diplomas, and twelve honorary degrees were conferred upon conspicuous men.

HARRISBURG, Penn., June 11. -- Judge Samuel W. Pennypacker of Philadelphia was nominated for Governor over Attorney General John P. Elkin of Indiana, by today's Republican State Convention by a vote of 206 to 152. Ex-State Senator William M. Brown of New Castle, and Major Isaac B. Brown of Erie were nominated by acclamation for Lieutenant Governor and Secretary of Internal Affairs respectively.

Chauncey M. Depew sailed yesterday on the steamship St. Louis, accompanied by Mrs. Depew and Chauncey M. Depew, Jr. The party will spend the greater part of the time in France, where Mrs. Depew's mother lives, but will take time to view the coronation ceremonies. "Of course," said the Senator, "I wouldn't miss that for the world."
WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Consideration of the Isthmian Canal project was resumed by the Senate to-day, Mr. Fairbanks (Ind.) speaking in favor of the Panama Canal route.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 11. -- Grinnell reports that the town of Laurel, in Marshall County, was destroyed by a tornado last night. Owing to the wires being down it is impossible to secure definite knowledge as to the facts. Laurel is in Jefferson Township, and has a poulation of not to exceed 100 people.

The Toledo Railways and Light Company, with a capital stock of $12,000,000, has passed into the control of interests represented by Kean, Van Cortlandt Co. of 26 Nassau Street. With the transfer of the control of this company the famous Everett-Moore syndicate, which controlled the principal street railway systems in Northern Ohio and Southern Michigan, and has been in liquidation for several months, loses one of the most important systems in its combination.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- In the Senate several days ago Mr. Berry (Ark.) asked for consideration of the motion of Mr. Wellington (Md.) to discharge the Committee on Privileges and Elections from further consideration of the resolution providing for an amendment to the Constitution that Senators should be elected by the people.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11. -- At the commencement exercises of Vassar College to-day, President Taylor announced the following new appointments:

The news at present is simply one of arrivals and departures. Those who have come back from abroad stop a very short while in town and go at once to the country. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wilson left yesterday for Newport. Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt will remain until next week at Millbrook and then go also to Newport for the season.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 11. -- The 2,000 and more members of the American Medical Association, many of whom are accompanied by their wives and daughters, are having a royal time during their Saratoga convention outing. Between business and pleasure every part of the day and evening is utilized.

Thirgs were lively in the Police Department yesterday. Before Commissioner Partridge left for Ossining in the afternoon he was closeted With Inspector Cross, who afterward conferred witn his staff, some of whom obtained evidence against Sergeant Churchill. Inspector Murphy called to his office the Captains in command in the Third District and told them that they must enforce the law to the letter.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., June 11. -- Stretching across a pathway 100 miles in width and devastating a territory fully 200 miles long, extending from Livingston County on the north to McCoupon County on the south, and leaving its mark clear across the face of Central Illinois, a cyclone last night inflicted a property loss which will aggregate millions of dollars and cost a dozen lives.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- The Philadelphia market at the opening to-day was more lively than at any previous time this month, and, though the animation was confined to the first hour, the gains recorded held all day. The Readings were quick to respond to optimistic stock news, but most of the speculation was in the purely local issues.

Miss Mildred Holland sailed yesterday, accompanied by her manager, E.C. White, for London, where she will attend the coronation ceremonies. After a six weeks' stay in Europe she will return home and appear next season on Broadway in "The Lily and the Prince."
WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The House today went into Committee of the Whole and resumed the debate upon the Corliss Pacific cable bill.

The Rhode Island Jockey Club has secured dates for a meeting to be held at Narragansett Park, Providence, R.I., from June 30 to July 5 inclusive, and has issued a programme of races, including a hurdle race or steeplechase each day, which is sure to prove satisfactory to owners and trainers.
WASHINGTON, June 11. -- To-day's statement of the Treasury balances in the general fund, exclusive of the $150,000,000 gold reserve in the Division of Redemption, shows:

SPRINGFIELD, O., June 11. -- A magnificent monument, consisting of a handsome stone arch surmounted by a bronze statue of a Confederate soldier, will be unveiled on Saturday at Camp Chase Cemetery, Columbus, O. This memorial to the heroes of "The Lost Cause" is the grift of Col. William H. Knouss, an ex-Federal office holder, who for thirty years has decorated the graves on Decoration Day of the Confederates who are buried in Columbus.

BALTIMORE, June 11. -- The market continues to hold its own with encouraging steadiness. The approach of July is having a strengthening influence. Money is sufficiently plentiful to encourage speculation, though comparatively little buying of that character is in vogue. Still, the knowledge that funds are easily procurable, if the occasion warrants greater activity, helps to keep the tone in a better state.

At the conclusion of the commencement exercises the graduates of the day, the alumni, and the holders of honorary degrees marched to Alumni Memorial Hall, where luncheon was served. The large banqueting hall was filled with rows of tables, each one assigned to a different class, and at the head of the room were located the guests of the university and the speakers of the day.

Dealings on the Stock Exchange, which on Tuesday had approximated 100,000 shares more than on Monday, rose yesterday another 100,000 shares to a total of 380,000 shares. With this increased activity came a continuation of the strength which has been apparent in the market now for some time -- this under the stimulus of purchases by the larger financial interests who now freely declare themselves in most optimistic terms.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 11. -- Centennial Day, the third of the week's hundredth anniversary celebration at the Military Academy, was distinguished by a visit of President Roosevelt, who made a speech in Memorial Hall. When he arrived in the morning he was received with full military honors, and then reveiwed the cadets on the parade plain.

The statements of Presidents BAER, TRUESDALE, THOMAS, OLYPHANT, and Others, defining the position of the operators in the present conflict with the diners, are very far from satisfactory to any one with even a partial knowledge of the facts. This is less because of what is said touching the issues of the strike, which is correct enough, than because of what is left unsaid.

LONDON, June 11. -- Col. Arthur Lynch, who fought with the Boers in South Africa and who in November last was elected to represent Galway in the House of Commons, was arrested this morning on his arrival at Newhaven from Dieppe, France. Col. Lynch, who was accompanied by his wife, was brought to London, and was afterward taken to the Bow Street Police Station.
The Tammany triumvirs issued the following statement last evening:

Senator BURROWS of Michigan is perfectly right when he says that the 20 per cent. tariff reduction scheme (for the relief of Cuba) is "a blow at the tariff." In effect, that is just what it is, and in effect that is what any scheme for the promotion of profitable foreign trade with Cuba or with any other country must be.

The close of the war in South Africa leaves Britain in a better position to deal with the situation in Persia than ever before, since, however disappointing have been her Generals and armies in conflict with the Boers, the terrible exertions she has put forth have done much to improve her military strength.

George N. Robinson has sold the five-story building 9 Dey Street, 25.6 by 91.2, to Warren Leslie. The sale is made subject to a lease of the property to James Beggs Co., expiring in 1905. The present seller paid $74,000 for the parcel in 1898.

LONDON, June 11. -- Money was in good demand to-day, and there was a fair supply. Discounts were weak. Business on the Stock Exchange was rather dispirited. The settlement progressed satisfactorily. Consols were fairly steady. Home rails were irregular. Americans were cheerful, but there was little movement from parity.

-- Wide vistas of irresponsible hilarity open before the topers of Massachusetts. A Police Judge of Boston -- or, of Chelsea, which is the same thing, only more so -- has decided that before a man can be punished for drunkenness it must be proved that he entered into this condition of his own free will and under no compulsion whatever.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11. -- Princeton easily defeated Harvard in the only baseball game for the championship here to-day in seven innings, by a score of 7 to 0. At the end of the seventh innings, with two "Tigers" out and two more on bases, the rain, which had been slowly falling for several innings, forced the calling of the game.

There was a distinguished gathering at Columbia yesterday to witness the one hundred and forty-eighth commencement of the university, and the first under the administration of President Nicholas Murray Butler. Five honorar degrees and 852 degrees in course were granted, making a total that exceeds that of any previous year by at least 20 per cent.

Developments in the outside market yesterday presented a continuation of the conditions which have prevailed in the market for some time past. The total transactions were considerably larger than on any recent day, but that was due principally to the heavy trading in Tennessee Copper, which was manipulated actively again.

BERLIN, June 11. -- Emperor William and the Crown Prince have telegraphed their congratulations to Herr Wiegand, the General Director of the North German Lloyd Line, on the new record made by the Kronprinz Wilhelm between New York and Eddystone Light. The Kronprinz Wilhelm left New York June 3 and made the passage at an average speed of 23.53 knots per hour, which is the best eastward record for speed across the Atlantic.

In spite of the fact that yesterday's winds were from the east, thereby giving to Jersey City and Hoboken the benefit of the bituminous smoke poured forth from hundreds of funnels in Brooklyn and Manhattan, this city had another day's disagreeable experience. Soft coal smoke appeared from many stacks whose furnaces had formerly adhered to anthracite, and the conditions in the coal market became very much worse.

Miss Genevieve Hecker, the metropolitan champion, narrowly escaped defeat yesterday in the first match play round at the Essex County Club, Orange, N.J., of the women's metropolitan golf tournament. Her imperturbable, steady play finally carried her to victory by the satisfactory score of 4 up and 2 to play.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 11. -- "Well, gentlemen, the anthracite strike is complete and we are going to win."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Was it out of his ignorance of human nature in general or the American nature in particular that the "Englishman" wrote his letter published in to-day's issue? The world's knowledge of just how happy those aliens now living under the British rule are makes us doubt that the "Boers will soon discover that prosperity in every way will multiply tenfold under the British flag."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 11. -- The Providence baseball team was outbatted by Jersey City to-day, but the home team's smaller number of hits came with men on bases, and with passes and misplays they produced more runs by a good margin. The score:

LONDON, June 11.--Whitelaw Reid, the Special Ambassador of the United States to the coronation of King Edward, was received in audience by his Majesty at Buckingham Palace this afternoon. A royal carriage, with outriders in red liveries, was sent to take Mr. Reid to the palace, where he met Lord Lansdowne, the Foreign Secretary; Col. the Hon. Sir William James Colville, the Master of the Ceremonies, and Col. Collins, Mr. Reid's equerry.

Capt. Spencer Cosby will take temporary station at Philadelphia and relieve Col. Jared A. Smith of the improvement of the Delaware River from Trenton to its mouth and certain other work in Col. Smith's charge.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 11. -- The University of Pennsylvania oarsmen arrived at Highland this afternoon and established training quarters at Bellevue Villa, on the west bank of the river. They are the first of the crews who are to participate in the intercollegiate regatta on Saturday, June 21, to reach here.

PEORIA, Ill., June 11. -- The double storm that struck Peoria at 10 o'clock last night and again at 2 o'clock this morning was the worst Central Illinois has experienced since 1843. Rain fell in torrents, and the damage caused by the high winds cannot be estimated at this time. Probably the worst damage in proportion to the size of the town was at Kingston Mines, a small mining town twenty miles below Peoria.

The full text of the decision of the Court of Appeals, in the suit of Benjamin L. Bates, proprietor of the Everett House, on Union Square, to compel P.H. Holbrook and others of the Holbrook, Cabot Daly Contracting Company, now Holbrook, Cabot Rollins, to remove the compressed air plant and other buildings and materials from the Union Square Plaza, had not yesterday been recorded by any of the interested parties here.

The investigation of United States Labor Commissioner Carroll D. Wright into the causes of the strike were completed yesterday, and he will make a report to President Roosevelt when he arrives in Washington. Mr. Wright had a conference lasting two hours yesterday with President Truesdale of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, President Fowler of the Ontario and Western Railroad, and John Markle, representing the interests of the independent operators.

Mr. W.J. BRYAN spurns the nomination as candidate for Governor of Nebraska. He feels that he is consecrated to the uses of the Nation. How can he listen to a twittering little State when the whole broad Union bawls in his ear?

The investigation of United States Labor Commissioner Carroll D. Wright into the causes of the strike were completed yesterday, and he will make a report to President Roosevelt when he arrives in Washington. Mr. Wright had a conference lasting two hours yesterday with President Truesdale of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, President Fowler of the Ontario and Western Railroad, and John Markle, representing the interests of the independent operators.

Mr. W.J. BRYAN spurns the nomination as candidate for Governor of Nebraska. He feels that he is consecrated to the uses of the Nation. How can he listen to a twittering little State when the whole broad Union bawls in his ear?

PORTLAND, Me., June 11. -- The Republican State Convention which met here today renominated Gov. John F. Hill and adopted a platform, "demanding" faithful and impartial enforcement of the prohibitory law, and recommending the enactment of a direct primary law by the next Legislature.

Newtown and New Utrecht, Gravesend and Bushwick, Flatlands and Flushing, and eke that Ultima Thule whose map bears no names, are hotly debating the question of the railway connection with the City Hall in Manhattan Borough. It may be necessary to explain to residents of what used to be New York City that the regions above named contain a considerable population whose annexation to New York has preceded Chicago's by some decades.

There was no National League baseball in either New York or Brooklyn yesterday, the games scheduled being postponed on account of rain. In Philadelphia the home team defeated the Cincinnatis by a three-to-two score, while the same score decided the Boston-Chicago game at the former city, the local nine winning out in the ninth inning after an interesting contest.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- A remarkable revelation made to-day at a hearing before the sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Relations with Cuba has put a new face on the entire Cuban reciprocity situation. The author of the revelation is Senator Teller, who has had it up his sleeve for about two weeks.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Consideration of the Isthmian Canal project was resumed by the Senate to-day. Mr. Hoar formally offered his amendment, of which notice was given, in the form of a substitute.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 12 -- For the first time in the history of the city, bayonets in the hands of soldiers ordered out by the Governor of the State to suppress riotous disturbances, glistened in the streets of Pawtucket to-day.

Clearly Secretary ROOT and Gen. WOOD made a sad blunder in paying money out of the Cuban Treasury to F.B. THURBER for use among "the leaders of thought in the United States," in advocacy of reciprocity with Cuba.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 12 -- It was learned at the office of the Lehigh Valley Coal Company to-day that an attempt was made last night on the life of Superintendent Thomas Thomas of the William A. colliery of the Lehigh Valley Company at Old Forge, north of this city.

EAST LONDON, Capt. Colony, June 12 -- The Norwegian bark Atbara, (Capt. Pedersen, from Hamburg, March 13, for East London,) the Swedish bark Aurora, (Capt. Nillson, from Gefle, Oct. 15, via Dover, Feb. 25, for East London,) and the German bark Elise Linck, (Capt. Straatmann, from Bremerhaven, about Feb. 1, for East London,) were wrecked during a heavy southeast gale.

GALES FERRY, Conn., June 12 -- The Harvard 'Varsity eight covered the four-mile course on the Thames this evening for the first time since their arrival. The time was slow, 23:08, and the general work unsatisfactory. The time is about three minutes slower than the record.

SCRANTON, Penn., June 12. -- The first trouble in Scranton since the miners' strike began occurred this morning John Flannigan, a fireman at the Erie No. 1 Colliery, Dunmore, worked on the night shift and was on his way to his boarding house in this city. He was walking down the Lackawanna tracks, when he came upon a crowd of about fifty men, who were waiting for him.
LONDON, June 13 -- The final Court of the season will be held at Buckingham Palace to-night. Their Majesties will then go to Windsor and will not return to London until Coronation Week.

Moonshine whisky was the principal element in a true tale of love and revenge which came to light in Commissioner Shields's courtroom in the Federal Building yesterday, when M. Jarnower, said to be one of the partners in the American Eagle Tea and Coffee Company, at 222 and 224 Lynch Street, Brooklyn, was held charged with conducting one of the biggest illicit distilleries ever found in the Borough of the Bronx.

After a disastrous trip to New England, the Jersey City baseball team of the Eastern League returned home yesterday and were defeated by the Worcester team by a score of 6 to 12. McCann was very effective until the seventh inning, when the Worcester players bunched their hits and scored three runs.

Those who have followed so much of the literature of the present tie-up of the anthracite mines as has emanated from the headquarters of President MITCHELL, have perhaps noticed that the word "strike" has been carefully avoided and the word "suspension" used in its stead.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The House today adopted a special rule for the consideration of the Irrigation bill, which passed the Senate. The House resolved itself into a Committee of the Whole, and entered upon consideration of the measure. It was arranged that Mr. Mondell (Wyoming) should control the time for the measure, and Mr. Ray (N.Y.) against it.

It is not unlikely that the decision of the Court of Appeals in favor of the proprietor of the Everett House will bring on a flood of damage suits against the subway contractors for the street obstruction, annoyance, and loss resulting from their work of excavation and construction.

Justice Greenbaum, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, rendered a decision to the effect that henceforth a fireman cannot be discharged by the Fire Commissioner for "unexplained absence for five days without leave," but must be tried on the charges, which must be in writing.

Tammany Hall was crowded last evening. More than 2,000 followers of the Wigwam watched the proceedings with bated interest to see the moves which were scheduled to be made on the political chessboard between the leaders of the factions of Tammany Hall to cause trouble. Instead of discord, there were cheers and shouts of approval for every name mentioned from that of Triumvir Charles F. Murphy to Thomas Foley.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Mark H. Evans of Des Moines, Iowa, formerly a Sergeant of Company F. Thirty-second Volunteer Infantry, to-day testified before the Senate Committee on the Philippines concerning the administration of the "water cure" to Fllipinos on four different occasions during his service in the islands.

The Panama Railroad Company and the Pacific Mail Steamship Company have signed a new traffic agreement, thus bringing to an end the condition of warfare, which had existed between the two companies since December, 1900. The negotiations resulting in this agreement have been going on for six months, and during that period there were frequent rumors that all dealings had been broken off.

Abraham Goldsmith has sold, for about $175,000, the northeast corner of Sixth Avenue and Sixteenth Street, 29.10 by 65. At the expiration of the existing lease on May 1, 1903, the new owner of the property will erect thereon a new five-story business building.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 12 -- Rounding a wide curve as it sped into Irvington today on its way to Albany the Empire State Express, the fastest train on the New York Central road, crashed into a locomotive that was standing on the north-bound tracks. A disastrous collision would have resulted had not the engineer of the lone locomotive, seeing the express approaching, started his engine ahead.

BOSTON, June 12 -- There is no change in money. Clearing House rate, 4 and 3 1/2 per cent.; New York funds par. 5 cents and 10 cents premium; call loans, 3 1/2 to 4 1/2; time money, 4 to 5; Clearing House exchanges, $23,208,850; balances, $1,642,077. Intense dullness characterized the stock market. Complete transactions to-day were as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- It is reported this evening that the beet sugar Senators at a conference this afternoon signed an agreement to govern their action in case the Committee on Relations with Cuba reports a reciprocity bill and a Republican conference undertakes to push it through according to the report.

Women lawn tennis experts began play yesterday in the annual open tournament on the courts of the Staten Island Ladies' Club at Livingston. The two events contested were the women's doubles and the mixed doubles. In the latter Miss Bessie Moore, the National champion in the singles, was paired with Robert Le Roy, the Columbia University expert.

Mr. QUAY has again won a signal victory. That is not in itself a source of wonder to a people that has become accustomed to the marvel that Mr. QUAY is still at large and that any but involuntary labor should be open to him.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 12 -- The tendency in the local markent to-day was again in the direction of improvement, which manifested itself, however, more in sentiment than in actual activity. Nevertheless, the buying is better both in volume and character. There is a demand apparent which never develops locally unless the market bears all the evidences of going higher.

LONDON, June 12 -- Money to-day was much wanted for pay day. Discounts were firm. Business on the Stock Exchange was dull and prices drooped, owing to lack of support. There was some anxiety regarding the position of a few small operators, though serious trouble was not expected. Consols continued to slacken at first, but hardened later.

BOSTON, June 12 -- A man said to be "Nick" Moran was arrested here this afternoon. The specific charge upon which he was arrested is not given out, but it is said to be at the instance of the New York police, and in connection with the recent robbery of jewels from Mrs. Kingdon, mother of Mrs. George J. Gould, in that city.

Hyacinthe Ringrose, the attorney, of 271 Broadway, who on April 10 last, preferred charges against District Attorney Jerome, in behalf of Frederick Randolph, a lawyer in The Evening Post Building, received from Gov. Odell yesterday a letter in which the Governor said that he did not consider the charges of sufficient weight to grant a hearing.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was carried on in more or less languid fashion and very few stocks showed sufficient activity to attract much, attention. As has been the case during the dullness which has prevailed for some time past, prices were firm and showed more advances than declines.

NEWARK, N.J., June 12 -- R.V. Lindsbury, counsel for the United States Steel Corporation, filed an answer this morning to the suit brought by Adrian Berger of Sullivan County, N.Y., to restrain the company from retiring $20O,000,000 of preferred stock and issuing bonds instead. The constitutional points raised in the hill will be argued to-morrow morning, and meanwhile the rule to show cause granted by Vice Chancellor Emery last Monday acts as a stay.

MONTREAL, Quebec, June 12 -- The agreement by which the Dominion Steel Company leases the mines and plant of the Dominion Coal Company at Sydney was ratified to-day. A special meeting of the Dominion Steel Company's shareholders was held at noon, when the agreement was explained and ratified by a stock vote, only 150 shares being cast against the proposal.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 12 -- A constitutional amendment granting all the privileges in the matter of constructing an isthmian canal, which were requested by the United States, is being favorably discussed in the Costa Rican Congress.

WATERBURY, Conn., June 12 -- Judge Silas A. Robinson of the Superior Court has handed down a decision dissolving the injunction which restrained the executors of the Plant will from removing the $17,000,000 trust fund from Connecticut into New York, except that $15,000, the amount of a legacy to which Charles E. Hoadley of this city is entitled, as representing his children, must remain in this State according to the decision.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 12 -- The Yonkers police this evening are in possession of a coining plant which, although apparently fitted only for making five-cent pieces, may have been used for making more valuable coins.

The contract for the construction of the rapid transit tunnel to Brooklyn received its final reading by the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday afternoon, and was passed on to the Corporation Counsel. After that official approves the document it will be published for three weeks before bids will be received.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Of those who merely profess Christianity without a word of reference whatever to those who practice it, a great majority assuredly must have been amazed at the speech made by the Rev. R.S. MacArthur in Calvary Baptist Church, Sunday, and which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES the next day.
The Colonial Fire Insurance Company of Washington has been licensed to transact business in this State by Superintendent Hendricks of the State Insurance Department.

The departures continue to increase in number each day. After the Suburban shall have been run there will be few if any fashionable people in town. Many are going direct to Newport and opening their houses there. Southampton has already quite a colony, and a few have gone to Bar Harbor.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 12.--In the presence of the same distinguished audience that had attended the previous celebrations of the Military Academy's centennial week, and protected from the blazing sun only by an awning reared on the parade ground. President Roosevelt delivered their diplomas to the successful graduates this morning.
New York defeated St. Louis in the second tussle of the series on the Polo Grounds yesterday. It was the first game since the new manager, George Smith, took charge of the team.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Secretary Root, when his attention was drawn this evening to the testimony of F.B. Thurber before the Senate Sub-Committee on Relations with Cuba yesterday, said there is no occasion for him to do more than state that the payments alleged to have been made to Mr. Thurber had been made by the Cuban Government, with the full approval of the War Department.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 12 -- The local market was fairly active to-day, but there were no striking fluctuations save in Electric Storage Battery common, which, after dragging all the morning, took on strength at 2 o'clock and advanced 2 3/4 per cent. It is rumored that it will figure prominently in an amalgamation of leading electric companies.

Commissioner Partridge, at a conference yesterday afternoon at Headquarters, with his deputies and Inspectors, complimented the latter on the improvement in the morale and efficiency of the department under the present administration. Nothing was said about the enforcement of the excise law.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 12 -- After a search of almost twenty-two years for her two sisters, Miss Anna Hoch of Ocean Grove has at last discovered their whereabouts and a happy reunion has just terminated at their Philadelphia home.

At the commencement exercises of the New York Law School in Carnegie Hall last evening, one hundred and forty graduates received the degree of LL.B. The degree of LL.M. was conferred on thirteen lawyers. The centre of the hall was occupied by the members of the graduating class.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Hepresentative McCall of Massachusetts to-day presented to the House a memorial signed by Charles Francis Adams, Andrew Carnegie, Carl Schurz, Edwin Burritt Smith, and Herbert Welsh asking that a Congressional committee of investigation be appointed to go to the Philippines to inquire into and report upon conditions existing there.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 12 -- Dr. J.B. Pioda, the Swedish Minister at Washington, arrived to-night, and is the guest of Col. Addison Thomas, at his cottage on Rhode Island Avenue.

PARIS, June 12 -- The Chamber of Deputies and its galleries were filled to the utmost this afternoon, when the first debate under the new Ministry, and one which was to indicate precisely its strength in the House, opened.

The Count and Countess de Rochambeau, who arrived here on May 17 to attend the ceremony of unveiling the statue of the first Count de Rochambeau at Washington, sailed in the French liner La Lorraine yesterday. On the promenade deck the Count told of what had impressed him most during the visit, and the Countess gave her views on American men and women.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 12 -- Gen. Leonard Wood, ex-Military Governor of Cuba, was asked to-day for an explanation of the disclosures made by F.B. Thurber of New York in regard to the use of public moneys for the propogation of literature bearing on the question of Cuban reciprocity.

-- It is a most serious thing for one who thinks himself in a very fair state of health suddenly to be informed that he is suffering from a grave cardiac affection. Such news, when it comes from an authoritative source, fills the mind with apprehension and makes the future look even darker than the New York sky has been since the coal strike clouded it.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, June 12 -- A tornado to-day overturned and sank the steamer Ravenna at Naquoketa Chute, four miles up the river.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 13 -- The annual class day exercises at Brown University to-day in Sayles Hall were opened by the President of the class, Charles Abbott Phillips of Danielson, Conn., with an address of welcome.

Two of the fastest regular trains that ever ran from here to Chicago will start on their first trips Sunday afternoon. One of them goes on the New York Central tracks, stopping at All-any, Utica, Syracuse, and Rochester, and taking on no passengers except those whose destinations are as far west as Chicago.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 13. -- The operators to-night, in an authorized statement, clearly defined their position as to what is to be done in the cut-down of the working force to one-third, compelling the men to work regularly and improving conditions in a business may. The operators say: "When the strike is over...

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Upon reading Mr. Charles H. Ward's article in your issue of May 31, in which he shows the similarity between the familiar story of "The House That Jack Built" and a passage from the Hebrew Passover Service Book, I thought that the latter suggested even more naturally that other old story, also dear to the heart of childhood, viz., "The Old Woman and Her Pig."

Between the Utopian novel, like Anthony Hope's, and the novel of the real world stands the novel in domino, the novel in which real persons and countries wear a disguise beneath which now and again lurks a substitute altogether unknown, and such a book is Sidney C. Grier's "The Prince of the Captivity."

BOSTON, June 13. -- During his visit to this city to-day Gen. Leonard Wood, ex-Governor General of Cuba, commenting on President Roosevelt's special message to Congress on reciprocity with Cuba, spoke of it in the highest of terms.

LONDON, June 1. -- New novels in considerable numbers have been published during the last week, but not one of them merits any special notice. We shall have very few noteworthy books until the coronation is past.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- Fire to-day destroyed the novelty manufactory of H. M. Rosenblatt Co., a four-story brick structure, at Second and Oxford Streets, and resulted in severe injuries to a dozen persons. The John Moffett Public School, opposite the leather works, was damaged, three dwelling houses adjoining the factory were destroyed, and nine others were slightly damaged.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- The stock market to-day was quiet and steady, fractional advances being the rule. Union Traction, United Gas Improvement, and Philadelphia Electric were the principal local features. There was good buying of Reading at a slight advance. Electric Storage made a further advance on the belief that it will be taken over by the much talked-of electric combination of the Whitney-Widener-Elkins-Dolan syndicate.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 13 -- The Summer residents found an agreeable diversion in the "Wild West Show " which exhibited here to-day. They were in large numbers and when the act with the Deadwood coach was introduced Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Fish Webster and Mrs. J. de Forest Daniel-son were the passengers, they entering into the spirit of the occasion and giving the performance an unexpected interest to their friends in the audience.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The situation regarding the epidemic of cholera in the Philippines is set out in a report received by Surgeon General Forwood from Lieut. Col. Heizeman, at present in charge of the medical department of the army in the islands.
ST. LOUIS, June 13. -- Jockey Donegan was killed- in the first race at the Pair Grounds to-day, his skull being crushed in a collision between the horses Pettijohn and Balza.

THE only thing which could possibly justify any writer in presenting at this date a new version of the wonderful drama acted by Greeks and Persians on land and sea in the years 480-479 B. C. would be the possession either of new evidence on the history of this period or a different view of that which constitutes the proper historical treatment of pre-existing evidence.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was more diversified than it had been for some days, and interest was not so exclusively centred in Tennessee Copper, although trading in this stock still continued on a large scale. Prices were generally firm, and some substantial gains were recorded.

LONDON, June 13 -- There was a strong demand for money during the early part of the day, but it slackened later and became easier, owing to the belief that the Government will soon disburse largely. Business on the Stock Exchange opened with, the firmness which developed late yesterday, the satisfactory outcome of the settlement being a good factor.
WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The President to-day sent the following message to Congress:

LSEWHERE in this issue will be found the lists of books for Summer reading which have constituted the occasion for printing this special number of THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS. As will be seen, they are lists restricted to 100 books, chosen from those published during the past year and a half.

AN ideal road, long sought, has been discovered It winds with many a turn, under the June sun, or the June shade, over bridges, past inviting glens, with the mountains beside and above one, a present joy and an incentive.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I am much obliged for a review of a book of mine in THE TIMES of Saturday last, although the reviewer takes some things rather too seriously and in several instances misapprehends my meaning, notably in regard to Thackeray, because, no doubt, I was careless in my expression.

The third part of the collection of John E. Burton, recently sold by Bangs Co., consisted of many valuable autograph letters, manuscripts, and documents. Among them was the original manuscript of a survey made by George Washington in 1750.

Bookbinding in the United Staies. Mr. William Loring Andrews has in preparation for issue in the Fall a new volume in which he has treated bibliopegy in the United States: a branch of the subject which is commonly almost, if not entirely, ignored by the best authorities on bookbinding.

LONDON, June 14. -- The Times's correspondent at Pretoria says that as another 4,000 or 5,000 Boer surrenders are expected before June 17, it is evident that the total surrenders will be near the estimate of 17,000 made by Botha during the negotiations. But the totals include a good many boys and old men scarcely reckoned for fighting purposes.

Two Lists of Fifty Each. Below win be found a List of books suitable for reading in Summer. The selections have been made from comparatively recent books -- current literature in which interest still survives.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 13 -- Action which the authorities hope means the beginning of the end of the reign of lawlessnes incident to the street railway strike was taken to-day by High Sheriff Hunter C. White removing his Deputy Sheriffs from the street cars. He did this on representations made to him that the deputies accomplished no good purpose, but incited the crowds to acts of violence.
Wanted to Rent -- A small country place, furnished, with running water and old shade trees, not far from the city. Address X.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- The presentation to the Fairmount Part Commission of the large bronze, statue of Tedyuscung, the Indian Chief, now in position on the summit of Indian Rock, on the Wissahickon, will be formally made to-morrow. The statue was designed by J. Massey Rhind, of New York, and Is the gift of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Henry.

Seeking an answer to the question why the literary achievement of American classical scholars has been insignificant, Mr. William Roscoe Thayer, in a review of recent Dante literature, suggests that it is " because, let the classicists strive as hard as they will, they can never so purge themselves of the anti-pagan legracy bequeathed by Puritanism as to become really classical in spirit."

A young gentleman of a serious turn of mind, having read our recent article addressed to " The Fair Boy Graduate," desires that we shall offer some additional advice to youths like himself possessed of a passion for wisdom and a desire to write. "We comply with this request with real pleasure.

Miss Genevieve Hecker met a decided defeat yesterday in the semi-final round for the Metropolitan championship at the Essex County Country Club of Orange, N. J. She was put out of the race by her old foe, Mrs. E.A. Manice of Baltusrol. by the good score of 4 up and 3 to play. Mrs. Manice earned her victory fully.

Police Captain Michael E. Foody of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station was indicted by the Grand Jury yesterday on a charge of neglect of duty in falling to close saloons in his precinct on the last three Sundays in March. It was in that month that many of the policemen of the precinct "revolted," banded together, and arrested every saloon keeper they thought they had evidence against for several succeeding Sundays.

AT SOME date which I cannot now recall, probably between 1875 and 1880 Mr. Charles A. Dana, one of the original editors of Appleton's Encyclopedia, requested me to write for him, for a new edition of that work then preparing, biographical articles of Manton Marble and, William Henry Hurlbert.

ALBANY, N. Y., June 13. -- The appeal of Charles Guden from the decision of the Appellate Division, Second Department, dismissing an order of Justice Gaynor, declaring illegal Guden's removal from the office of Sheriff of Kings County By Gov. Odell and the appointment of Norman S. Dike as his successor, was argued before the Court of Appeals to-day.

LONDON, June 13 -- It is reported that a nephew of the late James Anthony Froude is hesitating about publishing the announced new volumes of Carlylc's letters, in view of the bitter discussion excited by the previous volumes.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- Major L.W. T. Waller, United States Marine Corps, reached here on the transport Warren, which brought the remnant of the fighting Ninth Infantry into port from the Philippines.

Soon the schools will have closed, soon the hostelries by shore and mountain will be thronged each with its miscellany of humanity, soon the weary heads of families will start regularly for the Saturday-to-Monday reunions. On journeys out of town books will now become important items in each person's luggage, while on piazzas and in quiet rooms they will gain distinction as constant companions.

PARIS, June 13 -- The Temps to-day printed an interview with Victorien Sardou, the veteran dramatist, on the Gross-Rostand dispute regarding the originality of "Cyrano de Bergerac." The paper says: "M. Sardou laughed heartily at the Chicago judgment, and said:

One of our leading publishing houses lately announced its new books under the finely antithetical titles of " works of fiction " and " works of permanent value." The "works of fiction came first, and were of the kind that, requiring little expense or literary skill in the writing, are lavishly advertised and often sell hundreds of thousands of copies.

THE title of this thoroughly interesting story, which is in fact that of the genesis of the world and the modifications which have produced its characteristics, wants transposing. It should read " The causes of the scenery of the world and their exemplification in England." So, too, the author's name wants a subtitle; it should read: "By Lord Avebury, aforetime Sir John Lubbock."

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Unless the new Arbitration Board, composed of teamsters and team owners, succeeds in settling difficulties now existing between the packers and their teamsters, another strike will be called, which officials of the Packing Teamsters' Union say will be conducted more vigorously than the struggle that has just ended.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 13 -- The work of the strikers in attempting to bring out those who are still in the employ of the coal companies goes steadily on. Their campaign against the engineers, firemen, and pumpmen is nearly over, most of these men being out. and the union is now paying more attention to the fire bosses, clerks, and others who have taken the places of those who quit.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Senate today considered the nomination of Capt. William Crozier to be Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- New York discount to-day was quoted at 20@30c. premium. Time and call loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent. Like most of the new things listed on the local exchange, Shipbuilding common, about which but few people on the exchange could have given good information, was the actual leader, 1,000 shares being sold with the price advancing from 43 to 44, with one sale at 44 1/2.

The world in which St. Paul lived was very much the same world as that in which we live. To be sure, at that time there was no mariner's compass, no great ocean steamer, no fast printing press, no railroad, with palace cars; no electric light, no telegraph, no telephone, and none of many other things which minister daily to our comfort.

PERHAPS the last quarter of the nineteenth century, so rich in scientific achievement, saw no greater advance in any other department of human effort than that made by history. The stupendous change which the acceptance of the general law of evolution wrought in all the sciences was no less sweeping in the domain of history, which beyond doubt is the one most beset with obstacles and wherein conquest is most difficult.

Charles S. Shivler, for the past twenty-two years connected with the American District Telegraph Company, and for the greater part of that time its Secretary and Treasurer, was yesterday arrested charged with the embezzlement of $17,000. He was taken before the Grand Jury almost immediately and indicted upon three charges of larceny in the second degree.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- George W. Perkins, one of the active members of the firm of J. Pierpont Morgan Co., was among the callers at the White House to-night, and immediately after his visit took the train for New York. He was at the White House about an hour.

In the fisher village of Rodillero, Valdes observes, the men are grave, taciturn, longsuffering, of limited understanding, and noble heart, while the women, simple and beautiful in youth, are apt in age to be astute, enterprising, greedy, and quarrelsome.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 13 -- The strength of the local market was undiminished to-day, despite the absence of additional activity. The current of hopeful feeling underlying the market is very marked, and that partially explains the upward tendency in the face of dull trading. Interest still clings to the cotton group.

Lightning struck at least two places in the upper part of the city last night. Shortly before 10 o'clock the fifty-foot flagpole of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Police Station was hit by a bolt and shivered to matchwood, the splinters fairly carpeting the asphalt pavement as far as Third Avenue, half a block away.

LONDON, June 14. -- The Times's Paris correspondent reports that he has had an interview with the most eminent authority on French steamship navigation as assisted by Government bounties. This authority declared it as his opinion that the Morgan ocean trust was aimed at France and other companies not participating in the combination.
Richard V. Harnett Co. have sold for the estate of Eliza M. Sloane to Boehm Boehm the eight three-story dwellings 415 to 429 West Fifty-first Street on plot 147 by 100.5.

LONDON, June 13 -- King Edward and Queen Alexandra held the fifth and final court of the season at Buckingham Palace this evening. It was raining hard, and a cold wind was blowing, and the weather was worse, if possible, than that which marked the four inclement nights of the previous Courts.

Miss Josephine Hausler of 229 East One Hundred and Sixth Street last night caused the arrest of a peddler, John Kurzman, twenty-six years old, of 223 West Sixty-sixth Street, whom she charged with cruelty to animals.
Will the President's appeal for justice to Cuba fall on deaf ears?

-- That visit which a considerable detachment of Salvation Army soldiers paid -- or tried to pay -- to the new commander of the Oak Street Police Station on Thursday, was, so far as we remember, an event without a precedent, and its significance as a compliment to Capt. O'REILLY could hardly be exaggerated.

In " The Rebuilding of Old Commonwealths" "Walter H. Page, editor of The World's Work, has given us three timely and thoughtful essays. A Southerner by birth and for a long time deeply interested in matters educational, Mr. Page is entitled to a serious hearing. Those who are at all acquainted with his work know, too, that he approaches a subject fearlessly and with the clear vision of a thinker.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- The gunboat Manila arrived from Manila last night in distress. She was picked up off Point Bonita and towed into port by the United States tug Slocum.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The President to-day publicly declared his position on the Cuban question. In a message to Congress he called upon his party's representalives in the two houses to pass a billgranting reciprocity to Cuba; a rebate bill he said, he did not want.

The commencement exercises at Columbia University Thursday had for their notable feature the first address to the graduates by President Nicholas Murray Butler. It was an interesting and characteristic expression of Dr. Butler's attitude toward the important work which he has undertaken.

THE long-expectecl novel from the pen of the author of "Mona Jlaclean," Dr, Murgaret Todd, who writes under the pseudonym of Graham Travers, will be published to-day by D. Appleton The book is entitled "The Way of Escape."

The most important private collection of books relating to the Quakers that was ever formed in this country came upon the market in Philadelphia, May 29, when Stan. V. Henkels sold the library of the late Charles Caleb Cresson of Germantown, Penn. In all 583 lots were offered, among them being many of the rarest publications for and against Quakerism that have been printed since the first establishment of the society.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

The memorial presented to Congress asking for an investigation of the Philippine conditions to be made in the islands by a joint committee of the two houses, aided by a body of experts, is a reasonable one in tone and substance. The committee presenting it is composed of CHARLES FRANCIS ADAMS, ANDREW CARNEGIE, CARL SCHURZ, ELIHU BURRITT SMITH, and HERBERT SMITH.

Taking advantage of Friday and the thirteenth day of the month, the Thirteen Club, J.A. Abarbanell presiding, gave a dinner last evening at the Eyrie, in the Tract Society Building, in honor of the Vegetarian Society of New York. It was a dinner for vegetarians to enjoy, and there was nothing to drink stronger than tea or coffee.

PARIS, June 13. -- The request made by M. Etienne, Vice President of the Chamber of Deputies, for permission to interpellate M. Trouillot, the Minister of Commerce, on the grave consequences which may threaten French shipping as a result of the formation of the American shipping combination, and to which interpellation M. Trouillot has promised to reply in two weeks, after he has investigated the situation, has aroused considerable interest here.

There is no public evidence that the transcontinental railroads are seeking to influence the course of Isthmian canal legislation at Washington. There have been no anti-canal processions, with banners and brass bands, marching up Pennsylvania Avenue. No proof has been offered that the Nicaragua volcanoes which are now breaking out every day in the columns of the minor newspapers of Central America have been hired with railroad money to go into active eruption.

Strange as it may seem, it was the efforts of a sister that enabled Booth Tarkington, the author, to get a publisher. She is herself an author of no mean ability -- Mrs. Haute Tarkington Jameson. Tarkington was no exception to the rule of the author with rejected manuscripts. Rejected manuscripts had become a nightmare to him.

"Vagrant -- no home -- supposed to have come from Nantes -- consort of thieves -- gobetween of robbers of the woods of Vincennes and receiver of stolen goods -- fugitive from State institution, where sent by lawful authority "-- such is the brief summary of the life of Mile. Fouchette up to the time of her coming to Paris from Le Bon Pasteur.

The public markets of the Borough of Manhattan are unsanitary and a menace to the health of residents of the city and visitors, according to an elaborate report made to Health Commissioner Lederle yesterday by Dr. F.H. Dillingham, Assistant Sanitary Superintendent of the Board of Health.

TOKIO, May 26, via San Francisco, June 14 -- It is announced here that Sir Claude MacDonald, British Minister, and Count von Arco-Valley, the German Minister, have notified the Japanese Government that their respective Governments have accepted Japan's offer of arbitration of the House tax portion of the treaty, while urging submission thereto of all the remaining points in the revised treaties which are in doubt.
Senator Quay promises that the Republican campaign in Pennsylvania preliminary to the State election in November next shall occupy not much if any time over one month.

IN consequence of the coming ceremonies attending the crowning of Edward VII. it might be well to observe that, contrary to widespread opinion, the prerogatives of the King of England, though considerably curtailed by a long series of enactments, are still of great extent and of vast importance.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 14 -- The season at Block Island opens earlier than it did a few years ago. The Manisses, which has always been a favorite house with people from New York and the West, is managed by the proprietors of the Park View Hotel in New York. They have a large number of guests booked in advance and will open next week.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., June 14 -- Narragansett has at last awakened from its season of Quietude. The smaller hotels have already thrown open their doors for the summertide, and among those to fly a pennant from their housetops are the Massasoit, the Revere, the Metatoxet, and Greene's Inn, which has been keeping open, house all the Winter.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 14 -- Gov. Kimball will ask the opinion of the Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the law regulating the hours of employment for stret railway employes. This action is in response to a petition from the Pawtucket Merchants' Association, received at the State House to-day.

DECIDEDLY the feature of Alumni Day, Monday, June 9, at West Point, was the speech of Gen. E. Porter Alexander of Virginia. It was the first occasion on which the Confederate Army had been officially recognized in any proceedings at the Military Academy. Indeed, it cannot be said to have been officially recognized on this occasion, since these proceedings were taken under the direction of the associated graduates.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 14 -- Opinion of the merits of the various crews which are to compete in the intercollegiate regatta on Saturday in past years has always been formed on the basis of what local rowing men have been able to gather from inspection of the oarsmen during their preliminary practice at this Hudson River town.

In a divorce suit tried the other day in this city, it appeared from the testimony that the only serious grievance of the wife who applied for a decree was that her husband would not go out nights, did not belong to a club, and refused to become a member of a pinochle syndicate.
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., June 14 -- The Champlain Valley is this year preparing to welcome the large and steadily increasing number of health and pleasure seekers that annually come here.

Since the year 1733, when New York's first playhouse existed somewhere down town, there have been built here no less than 109 first-class places of amusement that might properly be classified under the comprehensive name of theatre. Some of these were old places rebuilt, but at least 95 separate and distinct theatres have been constructed, without taking into account such old ones as were set up anew.

WITH stories of moonshining one naturally associates dark forests and ingeniously concealed caves, rough dressed and gruff speaking mountaineers who would fight to the death in defense of their highly-prized "stills," and an occasional lovely daughter, who acts the role of spy, warning her parent of the approach of strangers who might interfere with his illicit business.

MY FRIEND Silas Larrabee is about to make another voyage on the schooner Sewsan E. Nash. Her owner and master, Capt. Rufus Hatch, has drafted him into the service again and persuaded him to navigate the old craft from Baltimore to Ogunquit, Me., his home port, by the way of Boston.

HAZLETON, Penn., June 14 -- The home of James Applegate, at West Hazleton, was badly shattered early to-day by an explosion of dynamite which had been placed near the side of the building by unknown parties. The family escaped injury. Applegate has been employed as a special officer at the Cranberry Colliery since the strike went into effect.

NEWPORT, June 14 -- Not only have the cottage residents come to their Summer homes, earlier than usual, but there is evidence on every hand that the gay season will begin much earlier than usual. Those who made the season of 1901 particularly successful by notable entertainments are again occupying houses and are expected to repeat the elaborate functions of a year ago.

The Rev. Dr. Herman P. Faust, once a rabbi, a convert from Judaism to Christianity, who for a long time conducted a local Presbyterian mission to the Jews, died in the Presbyterian Hospital Friday night after an illness of three months, the direct cause being his inability to rally from an operation for appendicitis.

THE moving of the Pennsylvania Railroad bridge and draw over the Raritan River for a distance of fourteen feet in less than three minutes recently was a striking example of how quickly great tasks are accomplished nowadays, when the preliminaries are adequately arranged in advance.

LONDON, June 14 -- In spite of the turmoil all around Westminster, Parliament goes on making laws, although slowly. Now that the "corn tax" has been incorporated into the laws of the realm, talk of a Zollverein increases, but much is merry talk, in which even the august name of the prime mover is turned into ridicule.

LONDON, June 14 -- Money was in increased demand to-day for the payment of u1,000,000 ($5,000,000) in London County bills. The supply was fairly large, Business on the Stock Exchange was dull and prices were depressed in harmony with the bad weather. Operators are now resigned to practical idleness until after the coronation festivities.

The smoke nuisance caused by the pretty general use of soft coal in this city has reached such a stage that the officials of the Law and Health Departments have decided on heroic measures in the hope of securing its abatement.

The United States Shipbuilding Company yesterday announced that it had purchased the Bethlehem Steel Company, which is one of the foremost armor plate manufacturing concerns in the United States, and by the acquisition of this company the new shipbuilding combination is enabled to build a battleship complete with all armor and equipment.

BOSTON, June 14 -- The race meeting of the Brookline Country Club began at Clyde Park to-day with glorious weather and a track, in prime condition. The chief events were the Dukes Cup Steeplechase and a similar race for the National Hunt Cup, in both of which the field of starters was large.

The offices of Wright Garfield, brokers, on the fourth floor of 44 Broadway, were closed yesterday without any explanation. Reno R. Billington, a lawyer, whose offices adjoin those of Wright Garfield, says that the people were in their offices when he left the building at 5 o'clock Friday afternon, and yesterday morning neither clerks nor principals appeared.

ASBURY PARK, June 14 -- There has been an unprecedented early June rush of visitors to Asbury Park this week, despite the unstable weather. The arrivals to-day were far more numerous than for the corresponding day last year, and for the first time this Summer several of the trains from the cities were run in two sections.

Over three thousand persons journeyed to the Empire City track at Mount Vernon, yesterday and became the guests of the New York Driving Club at its inaugural niatinee race meeting. All the prominent local drivers of fast horses were present, and a number of well-known horsemen from a distance as well, among them being Harry Darlington, Pittsburg, Penn.; Murray Howe and F.G. Jones, Memphis, Tenn.; Charles Tanner, Cleveland, Ohio; Edward Lockwood, Poughkeepsie.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Yesterday saw the last of the flowers set into the beds in the new Coney Island park -- Sea View Park -- and work will be begun on the roads this week, putting them in shape and laying the sidewalks. Every promise is given that the park will be ready for the formal opening, which has been set for the 1st of July.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 14 -- J. Borden Harriman of New York has rented the Yardley cottage on Rhode Island Avenue for the Summer.

THREE times a year a stranger happening into old Trinity Church, in lower Broadway, in the early morning would be surprised to see a German congregation and hear a service conducted entirely in German. German Episcopalians are not numerous in New York, there is no church building devoted to their use, and only a few missions.

The observant wayfarer has probably noticed that a very much larger proportion of the people of New York are now carrying umbrellas than ever before. This is a differentiation of habit due to a modification of environment which should not escape the attention of the professional evolutionists, who are not content with the law as formulated by DARWIN, but are forever seeking for evidences of its current operation in nature.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That the City of New York, Borough of Manhattan, is sadly lacking in light, open spaces and air, particularly in its residential portion, is evident to the most casual observer. This one and that one may be blamed for existing conditions -- the original rulers of the city, or those succeeding them when the town began to assume metropolitan proportions.

The Jersey City baseball players could do nothing with the pitching of Pappalau, and the Worcester team made it three straight by winning yesterday's game, the score being 3 to 1. Pfanmiller, who was in the box for the home team, was also effective, but Worcester won the game by a bunching of hits.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The criticism by J.M. Wall in this morning's TIMES on Dr. MacArthur's sermon of last Sunday evening is conspicuously unfair. It seems quite certain that the critic did not hear the discourse; no man who heard it could possibly characterize it as does this critic, except, indeed, he wished to be unjust.
WEST END, N.J., June 14 -- Dewitt Seligman and family of New York are among the past week's cottage arrivals, and are summering in cottage No. 2, on Green Avenue, Hollywood.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 14 -- Today ends the fifth week of the anthracite coal miners' strike. Neither side has weakened an inch, and each side stands just as firmly as it did thirty-five days ago. As the days go by it becomes more apparent that it is a case of the "survival of the fittest."

ALBANY, June 14 -- Attorney General Davies has decided that the Cornell School of Forestry has not violated any provisions of law on the land held by it in the Adirondack Preserve, and he has made public an opinion in which he holds that there exists no cause for the commencement of an action to dispossess from lands which the college holds for forestry purposes.

Denver interests have formed the Centennial State Mutual Fire Insurance Company, as a consequence of an ineffectual protest against the present level of rates demanded by the various joint stock fire insurance corporations doing business in that section of the country.
PAUL SMITH'S, N.Y., June 14 -- Nearly all the camps on the St. Regis chain of lakes will be occupied this Summer. On the Lower St. Regis the reservations are as follows:
Money on call, 3 per cent. Time money, 4 1/2 @5 per cent, for sixty days to six months, rates varying according to the collateral offered.
Antonio Zucca, who was a Coroner under the Van Wyck administration, arrived borne yesterday on the Philadelphia after an extended visit abroad, during which he Visited Richard Croker at Wantage.

Word has just been received at the offices of the International Banking Corporation, 1 Wall Street, that its branch in the City of Manila had opened its doors on last Monday. This is the first American bank to establish a branch in the Philippines, and financial men will observe the experiment with great interest.

A "ROOF GARDEN" for the treatment of heat prostration cases is the latest addition to the equipment of the Boston City Hospital Relief Station. Nearly the entire roof has been covered by a raised platform, inclosed by a woven-iron fence about seven feet high, and from iron stanchions erected at convenient points awnings have been stretched.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have carefully read the letters of Robert Talehero and R.W.B. in your issue of yesterday in re your editorial of the 5th inst. on Paul Kruger.

A special train, which rolled into the Erie Railway Station in Jersey City shortly belore 8 o'clock last evening, carried about twoscore of persons who were just completing an excursion a little out of the common. The journey began 72 hours before, and included over 1,300 miles of travel by steam railroad, trolley cars, steamboat, tally-hos, barouches, and other conveyances.

AFTER nearly seven years spent mainly in the wild regions of Borneo and Sumatra, John D. Gillinan, a mining engineer, arrived here last Sunday on the Etruria. He was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last week, and hoped to remain for some time, but he sailed for Holland yesterday in response to a cablegram, and will soon be on his way to the netherlands of India.

CHICAGO'S suburbanites who are now obliged to rise from their beds in the gray dawn in order that they may breakfast between two minutes before leaping aboard the humming trolley car that sprinkles them punctually among their offices or stores, hall with joy the possibility of saving time by being able to eat the matutinal meal while in transit.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 14 -- Already more than a hundred cottages in the aristocratic section of Chelsea and the northern part of the city are being renovated prior to occupancy.

BERLIN, June 14 -- The Brazilian Minister, Baron Rio Branco, has issued a warning to German investors against putting money in the Bolivian Syndicate, because, he points out, the boundaries of the Prov- ince of Acre are uncertain. Brazil and Peru are claiming, and are still negotiating with Bolivia regarding the same.

SCATTERED over the desks, tables, and chairs of a room on the second floor of the Geological Survey Building at Washington is a heterogeneous collection of hardware, gray dust, broken china, and small stones. Each item in this assortment rests on a crumpled piece of yellow paper, with a few puzzles written on its face.
