PEKING, June 14 -- In continuation of its policy of leniency toward China, the United States is taking the position that an equitable construction of the peace protocol would be that China should pay 450,000,000 taels, equivalent to a gold debt, at the rates set forth in the protocol, regardless of the fluctuations of silver.

ALTHOUGH it was on the Bowery, the interior of the theatre into which I sauntered suggested grime rather than crime, and the rows of excited young faces of children in the boxes made one feel that the hero of "The Bravo of Venice; or, the Dread-Inspiring Council of Ten" must after all turn out a family man of the stanchest mo- rality when the curtain rose.

TABLOIDS of fresh air may soon be in the market, put up in a convenient form to carry in the vest pocket. Since the soft coal nuisance broke out this will be good news to New Yorkers, who have no desire to see their beloved city descend to the condition in which London finds itself.
DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., June 14 -- Mr. R. Thompson and Miss A.R. Thompson, W.A. Ordell, and W.P. Cotton of New York City are at the Delaware House.

Mr. F.B. THURBER, thinks that if THE TIMES "had fully understood the situation" it would "have taken a different view" of the payment of money to him out of the Cuban Treasury for the advocacy of reciprocity.

After the college boys left the diamond, the professional New York and Cincinnati teams met on the Polo Grounds, and the Westerners again defeated the home team. The New Yorks certainly could not blame the umpire this time, for Cincinnati played by far the better game. There was a changre of umpires, too, Emslie officiating.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- The local stock market was quiet and dull to-day. The liveliest trading was in Welsbach bonds, nearly $150,000 being dealt in. These bonds and Asphalt 5s made the best improvements of the day, the Welsbach 5s going up to 73 3/4 and the Asphalts up to 30 1/2.

BOSTON, June 14 -- One of the officials of the Mexican Railroad admitted to-day that the management is planning some very important moves for the company -- moves that will practically give it the controlling position in the Mexican Railroad field. This emphasizes the growing conviction that the company's reorganization when the same is worked out will prove to be of much broader scope than is now generally anticipated.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 14 -- The Montreal Express, on the Hudson River Division of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad, which left New York at ten minutes after midnight last night, was struck by a fast freight here at 1:47 this morning.

BOSTON, Mass., June 14 -- Over 400 men and women, all intimately associated with library work, gathered in the lecture hall of the Boston Public Library to-day at a preliminary meeting which marks the beginning of the twenty-fourth annual conference of the American Library Association.

M. DE RIVIERE, a sartorial artist, who once was known to Americans in Paris and whose establishment was on the third floor of the building at the corner of the Rue de la Paix and the Boulevard des Capucines, lately acquired by the Equitable Life, was well known for his eccentric manners and his penchant for practical joking.
HE who has come as a freshman to college directly from a life of close supervision in home or boarding school is first of all impressed by the self-reliance of the upper classmen.

GOOD GROUND, N.Y., June 14 -- One of the results of the severe storm of last night was to wash up on the shore of Tiana Bay the bodies of Clarence Foster of this place and Miss Sarah Lawrence of NewYork, a grandniece of ex-Justice Abraham R. Lawrence, who disappeared together on Monday night, and for whom all the waters hereabout have been almost constantly but vainly dredged since Tuesday morning.

Sales of a Sixth Avenue corner, of parcels in the lower and upper Fifth Avenue sections, not to mention those down town deals involving 9 Dey Street and the purchase of 22 Pine Street by the Fourth National Bank, have contributed not a little to the market's interest in what is usually expected to be a period of declining business.

THE passing of the years and the progress at natural philosophy destroy almost completely this celebrated simile of Shakespeare. The homely little hunchback, with the rough, warty skin, is not venomous, nor does he carry a jewel in his head. In Shakespeare's time it was the current opinion that in the head of an old toad was to be found a stone or pearl to which great virtues were ascribed.

The France Militaire, according to The London Times, devotes a series of three articles to the work of the new French, gun in China. The Colonial Brigade, late marines, under Gen. Prey, was furnished with four mountain and two field batteries of 80mm. The artillerymen numbered 800, and the mules 720.

There was a further rise in prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with practically every important stock on the list showing an advance at the close of the day. Total dealings for the two hours run up to 146,000 shares, and were well diversified.

DRYDOCKED at the foot of Twenty-sixth Street, South Brooklyn, where she is receiving a final coat of paint preparatory to re-entering the merchant marine, is the former British steamship Roma, which in September, 1900, was so unfortunate as to be moored in the harbor of Galveston on the night of the memorable hurricane that devastated that city.

AFTER remaining unmarked for nearly 150 years, the scene of Gen. Braddock's defeat is to have a monument. It will be placed in Kennywood Park on a site commanding an extensive view of the environs of the battle ground, where, on July 9, 1755, the petulant Braddock was mortally wounded and his little army almost annihilated in an ambuscade of French and Indians.
BOSTON, June 14 -- The money market shows no change of consequence. Its condition is still very comfortable and demand continues abnormally light. Sterling exchange remains quiet and steady.

Mrs. Edward A. Manice of the Baltusrol Golf Club did what was expected of her yesterday in the final round for the women's metropolitan golf championship at the Essex County Country Club at Orange, N.J. She defeated Miss Helene Hernandez by 7 up and 6 to play, and will therefore hold the championship for the coming year.

The schedule of offerings in the New York Real Estate Salesroom, 111 Broadway, for June 18 contains a somewhat unusual feature in the shape of the sale of the country seat and stock farm of the late O.F. Bresee, near Rapidan, Orange County, Va., known as "Rose Hill." Mr. Bresee was for many years the General Southern Agent of the Mutual Life Insurance Company.

BALTIMORE, June 14 -- The local market presented a dull record to-day, but it lost nothing in tone. The tone continued steady to firm. That is due to the sanguine feeling predominant here. The signs are certainly favorable just at this time. That is one reason why holders are offering nothing except at an advance.

APPLIED in the same sense as used by Dr. Johnson when discussing a commonplace brewery, it is the "potentiality of the coal on the Pacific Coast which will have so much to do in shaping the world of the future. Once it was held that the accident of position was the one and important factor.

OULDN'T the cooking teachers tell tales if they would? All the world has taken to learning to cook within the last few years or so, and there is one thing certain, if "all the world" has not learned the great art it has been the means of developing some clever teachers.

Dullness continues -- but there really do appear some glimmers of market improvement. Net changes for the week are chiefly advances, some being substantial. Sentiment shows indisputable betterment. Of the week's business news almost all has been encouraging. There is disappearance of anything like apprehension that the anthracite strike can involve grave consequences beyond the confines of the one trade directly affected.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 14 -- Although order had been restored in the business section of the city where the demonstrations of the street car strike have been most frequent, the military authorities today delayed until after 10 o'clock to give notice to the traction company to operate its cars.

In a lacrosse match remarkable for the hard fast running of the competing players the Crescent Athletic Club team yesterday defeated the Crecents of Perth, Ontario, by the score of 13 goals to 5. The vanquished team hold the championship of Eastern Canada, and throughout the contest they forced the game, by the speediest footwork seen on the lacrosse field at Bay Ridge this season.

BERLIN, June 14 -- According to an official dispatch from Peking, the representatives of the foreign Powers there have unanimously accepted the plan for the final allotment of indemnity on account of the Boxer uprising, which has been urged for months past by Dr. Mumm von Schwarzenstein, the German Minister to China.

LONDON, June 14 -- The financial market has been easier and in a more wholesome condition since the rigorous measures adopted at the settlement to clear out the weaklings who had been unwisely speculating in South Africans. Per- sons having large accounts open and unable to meet payments have been closed out and their stock, to use the language of the Paris Bourse, has been "executed."

LONDON, June 14 -- The relations between King Edward and the Premier, Lord Salisbury, do not seem to improve. According to general belief among members of the House of Commons, the King wants Lord Salisbury to dissolve Parliament after the coronation and "go to the country," in other words, have a general election, and the Premier has refused point blank.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The order of Brig. Gen. Jacob H. Smith, on relinquishing command of the Sixth Separate Brigade in the Philippines preliminary to his return to the United States, is of more than ordinary interest on account of the criticisms made of that officer's conduct of the campaigns in Samar and Leyte.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 14 -- A. Meyer and family of New York are summering at the Kelly cottage, on Garfield Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Roosevelt will visit the Illinois State Fair on Thursday, Oct. 2. He so promised today the members of the State Board of Agriculture, who were presented at the While House by Senator Cullom. In accepting the invitation the President said: "I want to come to Illinois, and I cannot express to you my thanks for giving me the opportunity to visit the State on other than a partisan occasion.
WHEN Hamlet saw his father's ghost was there any kind of objective reality in the vision, or was it altogether a figment of the mind?

By the arrest of a man who was trying pawn a bagful of property yesterday the detectives of the Central Office came into possession of a large quantity of silver-plated ware and other property for which they are trying to find an owner of owners. Capt. Titus of the Central Office is of the opinion that the stuff is the product of two or three robberies.
MOUNT POCONO, Penn., June 14 -- The private cottages are being opened. The mountain brooks are being invaded by scores of fishermen.

A ROCHESTER nurseryman, who is evidently unfamiliar with the make-up of the National House of Representatives, last Fall wrote to a Norwich (N.Y.) business man, asking for the name of some energetic, trustworthy man who would represent the nursery in Chenango County.

THAT chartered liberty which a member of Congress has to attack a body of men not privileged to defend themselves either by word or ballot should make him regulate somewhat his speech. The laws of war prescribe the treatment of unarmed prisoners. The army is practically unarmed before Congress and it is protected not even by the laws of war.

With the coming in of the full tide of Summer, one by one of the seaside and mountain resorts take up their seasons and begin their yearly activities. The suburbs, that since the middle of May have been the scene of the greater part of the gayety, will give place to Newport, Bar Harbor, Southampton, Lenox, Saratoga, and other centres to which fashion goes as the tropical heat presages the approach of mid-summer.
PARIS, June 14 -- This is race week, and Paris is full of prominent Americans. Prescott Lawrence arrived to-day from London for the Grand Prix.

THERE is an American Trilby in New York, and she probably has the most-photographed foot in the country. She is only a model as far as her foot is concerned, and, truth to tell, the accompanying sketch is probably the only one ever taken without a smart shoe and stocking for a covering, for this Trilby is a shoe model.

WITH the coming of hot weather the local Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is preparing to protect the horses of New York from the heat. According to Superintendent Hankinson at the general offices, at Madison Square and Twenty-fifth Street, the society will accomplish this by preparing free shower baths and by giving away several thousand straw hats arranged to fit horses.

GALES FERRY, Conn., June 14 -- The Harvard 'Varsity eight took its second time row on the Thames this afternoon, and although the weather conditions were poor, the time was very unsatisfactory to the coaches. The time is believed to be about 25 minutes.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad has placed an order for 1,000 steelframe boxcars -- 80,000 pounds' capacity each -- to meet demands of record freight traffic. At no previous time has the business of this road reached its present volume -- Boston Dispatch.

OTHER, parts of the country may be amused by the wranglings and heartburnings incident to the coronation of King Edward, but Washington follows them with serious and sympathetic interest. Only a very few Americans have any idea of the rigid system of etiquette which has grown up at the National Capital.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 14 -- The early part of the week the colonists of Tuxedo passed in town or at West Point at the centennial, but the week's end, Friday and Saturday, was very lively, especially Saturday, when many large dinners were given by the cottagers. Among the largest were those given by the Fichard Mortimers, the G. Rutledge Gibsons, and the J.B. Haggins at the clubhouse.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorials always interest me, and I want to call attention, from a knowledge of the facts, to a gross injustice that is perpetrated upon our naval commanders by this republic which is without one iota of excuse.

The money market during the week just past has been without special feature. Call money has been distinctly easy -- so easy, indeed, that the ever-present cynic has come forward with the suggestion that it has been an artificial ease and could not be maintained. This point it is scarcely worth discussing.

Thomas A. Disbrow, father of Louis A. Disbrow, was seen at his home. Church Street, near Division Avenue, Richmond Hill, L.I., yesterday afternoon. He said to a reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES that he had no idea where his son might be. He said that he was not at home, and that even if he were he would not say so, but added:

TWO determined efforts have been made by public-spirited citizens to break up what is known in law as the "lottery policy" game. Thus far the only result of labor by officials of anti-gambling societies has been to force the "backers " of the policy games to greater concealment in carrying on their gambling operations.

IF there is one place in the world more than another where men are pessimists it is in Wall Street. If one thing is not the matter, something else is. About two months ago the financial columns of the papers were full of wails about the dreadful lack of rain that was going to destroy the Western crops beyond all hope of redemption.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The opponents of the Cuban Reciprocity bill to-day assumed the offensive. They are greatly encouraged by the failure of the President's message to produce any great effect, and are now determined to fight on the aggressive.
ING PONG, that ancient and historic game, seems to be again in vogue as evidenced by the scarcity of celluloid in the raw state.

We take pleasure in reprinting on another page the speech of Gen. E. PORTER ALEXANDER at the reunion of the alumni of West Point on the occasion of the centennial celebration. There will be, we should suppose, very few of its readers who will withhold from it the enthusiastic admiration which it elicited from all its hearers.

BELMAR, N.J., June 14 -- The Hotel Columbia is the centre for the Summer gatherings here. Music is rendered by the same orchestra that so pleased its patrons last year. There is a morning concert, music during dinner hours, and dancing every evening, while a cotillion is held once a week and there is a full dress ball every Saturday night.

A departure from the established order of the College of the City of New York was made yesterday when the members of the graduating class went to a Roman Catholic house of worship to listen to a baccalaureate address by a priest of the Roman Catholic Church. St. Patrick's Cathedral was the church where the serman was delivered, and the Rev. Alexander P. Doyle of the Paulist Fathers was the preacher.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Saturday last I paid a visit to Bronx Park, and was particularly delighted to observe the improved condition of the plants in the large conservatories over that existing about one year ago, at which time some adverse comments concerning the state of health of the plants appeared in your columns.

IRONTON, Ohio, June 14 -- As a result of the miners' strike in West Virginia the plants of the Union Iron and Steel Company, the Sarah Furnace, and the Hanging Rock Iron Company suspended work today. They can get no coke. If the strike continues the Belfont Furnace will bank its fires on Tuesday and the Marting Iron and Steel Company in a week.

STATE CAMP, Peekskill, June 14 -- The Forty-seventh Regiment has kept up its reputation as a rainmaker. It marched into camp one week ago to-day in a downpour, and its last night under canvas here was one of thunder showers gradually passing into a steady rain. The sun rose in a cloudless sky, however, and the beat has been tempered by a smart breeze from the bay all day.

The New York bank members of the Clearing House received a circular yesterday from the Clearing House Committee regarding the circular of Feb. 3 relating to rules for the collection of out-of-town checks. The circular of Feb. 3 ruled that checks stamped payable at bank, N.Y., could not be treated as New York exchange.

LONDON, June 14 -- Undoubtedly King Edward is now one of the hardestworked men in his realm, with every hour of every day until the end of the season filled by some function which must cost him some pain or inconvenience to attend. Whatever may have been his official deficiencies in earlier years, he is now toeing the mark with a vengeance.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14 -- Commencement week at Harvard starts to-morrow with the baccalaureate sermon by the Rev. George Gordon of Boston in Appleton Chapel in the afternoon. This is the introduction to a busy week for the Harvard seniors. There will follow the senior spread, class day, and commencement exercises, besides the annual baseball game and the boat race with Yale, which are looked upon as important functions of the commencement programme.

THE changes which are being wrought these days in the aspect and character of the once rigidly exclusive Heights section of Brooklyn are being viewed with interest by old residents of the Borough of Homes, to many of whom the transformation which is taking place there is anything but pleasing.

WEST POINT, June 14 -- Better ponies and steadier and more accurate goal hitting won for Squadron A the polo match with West Point to-day by a score of 8 1/2 goals to 2 1/2. Safety play on two occasions, in each case an accident, brought the West Point score down from three goals, while the half goal lost by the visiting team was the result of a foul.

THESE are the stories of his Lordship the Snake as related in my presence by four reputable citizens whose words are as good as their bonds These tales of adventure comprise the output of a single Summer.

Commenting upon the Rochambeau fetes, Le Gaulois, of Paris, says concerning the American colony in Paris: "Its official centre is at that hospitable Embassy where Mrs. Portec is a kind and graceful hostess." After enumerating the many Americans in Paris, whether belonging to diplomacy, art, society, opera or trade, the Gaulois adds: "As will be seen, the American colony, is a particularly brilliant one.

THE bathing suits for the Summer have made their appearance, and although the weather has been very backward -- the air chill and the waters icy cold -- yet it will not be long before a dip into the salt ocean will be refreshing.

LONDON, June 14 -- Mme. Bernhardt is still supreme in grace and power, but the older plays in her repertory serve her better than such a sombre, sordid piece as Marion Crawford's historical, unpoetical "Francesca da Rimini."

Edward Evanescent Rice -- he of extravaganza fame -- is a man of many friends. And that in the theatrical profession is tantamount to saying that he is largely in demand at the front door of Wallack's Theatre, now that "The Show Girl" has taken up her Summer residence there.

A BIT of paper that was prisoner in a bottle that drifted about the Atlantic Ocean for fifty-one days, traveling about 195 miles, was brought to Baltimore by the schooner Kate Darlington a day or two ago.

Bound hand and foot, an Italian who says he is no less a person than the Marquis Carlo Capappene di Cordova of Italy was discovered early yesterday morning lying near the tracks of the New York Central Railroad at the foot of One Hundred and Fifteenth Street and the North River. William Staff, the caretaker of the Columbia University boathouse at that point, found the Marquis.

We cannot discuss the entire subject of fishbait. There are slimy horrors which bite at carrion, just as there are some fishermen who permit it to be put on their barbs. We know no reason why worms should not exist, but as to the use which might or should be made of them we boast our ignorance, and intend to remain in it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that a full discussion is in progress in the Senate concerning an Isthmian canal, perhaps it may not be inappropriate to call attention to a means of transportation which, although not new, may be entitled to consideration.

Four of the Seawanhaka cup challenge trial boats met again in the midsummer regatta of the New Rochelle Yacht Club on Long Island Sound yesterday. Two of them came to grief. The Bridgeport challenge syndicate Tecumseh twisted her centreboard before she had covered half the course and was obliged to withdraw.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., June 14 -- R. Erbs Loeb and family of New York have rented Hall's cottage at North Beach and have already taken possession of it.

Advices from St. Petersburg contain the details of the report for 1901 issued by the Russian Customs Department The total volume of Russia's foreign trade amounted to 1,252,000,000 rubles, which is a decrease of 8,000,000, as compared with the returns for 1900. The exports amounted to 729,000,000 rubles, and the imports to 523,000,000, so that there appears to be a balance of 206,000,000 rubles in favor of the exports.

OFF Alexandria the steam yacht Hiawatha lay at anchor. Mr. Beverly and Ms party had concocted some runaway scheme of eating their Christmas dinner in picnic fashion at the pyramid of Cheops, and the cabin was therefore deserted. It was perfectly plain, however, that some kind of an unusual and solemn function was going to take place forward under the snowy white awning that covered the forecastle deck.

LONDON, June 14 -- Bow Street Police Court was crowded this morning when the investigation commenced into the charge of high treason brought against Col. Arthur Lynch, formerly of the Boer Army, who was elected member of Parliament for Galway in November last and who was arrest- ed at Newhaven Wednesday on landing there from France.

MISS CONSTANCE MARIE GUNther, who recently became Mrs. Carl A. Clemons, was married in a gown of lace over a fouration of white satin. The round train was plain satin, but it was partially swealed by the long tulle veil, the latter being bordered with point lace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of June 10 there is a letter headed "Elevated Electric Trains," signed by one J.D. Bowne, in which he intimates that he does not appreciate either the old locomotive drawn trains or the new trains which are now being run on the "L" by electricity.

THE tact that William K. Vanderbllt, Jr., is negotiating through agents to purchase many acres of land around Success Lake, in Lakeville, and about three miles inland from Great Neck, L.I., for the purpose of establishing a country seat on a princely scale, calls attention to a wealth of legends connected with that picturesque little body of water.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- While the rush to the shore can hardly be said to have begun, the exodus to Newport, to Europe, and to seashore and mountain resorts has been very large this week, and by the end of next week it is probable that the town will be practically cleared out of fashionable people.

LONDON, June 14 -- A curious story is being circulated in regard to the Duke of Somerset and the King at the last Court. When his Majesty made the rounds of the select circle he passed close to the Duke of Somerset, who made a careful obeisance. Either the King did not see him or he was preoccupied.

BERLIN, June 14 -- The yacht races at Kiel begin June 26, the day of King Edward's coronation, hence many Americans, who otherwise would have been present at the opening of the regatta, will be absent It is expected though that a good many steam yachts will arrive at Kiel after the British naval review in the Solent.

LONDON, June 14 -- Another week of wet and gloom with January temperature has checked the usual June gayety greatly and made the customary garden parties and outdoor fetes, common in London at this time of year, out of the question.

IT HAS now been discovered by the people of Banger, Me., that that town possesses an interesting historical relic of a personal character whose existence there had not previously been suspected. This is the only existing drawing of the ship in which Andrew Carnegie first came to this country. It is etched on a whale's tooth.

In glancing over the playbills of the past week, little that is new appeared. With the exception of the opening of Cherry Blossom Grove, the roof garden at the New York Theatre, there is little new for the coming week. Nevertheless, the bills present a good showing along Broadway, where several musical productions are running and are enjoyed, whether new or old.

"IF Santos-Dumont steers a dirigible balloon over Greater New York I should think that the aeronaut would come back to the earth and tell us that our city looked very much like a modern Venice from the height of a few thousand feet in the air. Islands he would see all over the landscape," said Chief Engineer Nelson P. Lewis of the Board of Estimate yesterday.

William Jennings Bryan, who recently visited Cuba as the special correspondent of Collier's Weekly, in his published articles predicted that dissensions which he found among the political parties in Cuba would result in civil war. The paper reached the attention of President Palma, and he sent a lengthy cable message to the editor of the paper, which reached this city last night.

An International Exhibition of Women's Arts and Crafts has just been opened in Paris in the gigantic glass buildings on the banks of the Seine in which were held the horticultural shows during the World's Fair of 1900.

Chess by wireless telegraphy is the latest transatlantic game. This novelty was reated on the westward voyages of the American liner Philadelphia and the Cularder Campania, both of which, arrived lere yesterday. The ships got into wireless commununication shortly after 2 o'clock on Tuesday afternoon, and after formal greetings had been exchanged the game was begun.

LONDON, June 14 -- The speech of Sir Frederick Pollock, Corpus Professor or Jurisprudence, University of Oxford, before the London Chamber of Commerce, Wednesday, commending the Monroe Doctrine, has caused interesting and diverse expressions of opinion from The Spectator and The Saturday Review.

Betting on the Suburban Handicap was in progress from the time the crowd began to gather early in the afternoon, with few changes in the market quotations. The odds laid against the Suburban horses from the first betting to the start of the race were as follows:

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 14 -- The cottage season here has opened with a larger colony than has been here for several Summers past. The members of this part of Cape May's visitors come from all sections of the country, and not a few of them come from New York. The hotel guests are also coming in in large numbers, and every house is now open for the reception of guests excepting two.

THE election of Charles Carroll to the Cercle de la Rue Hoyale has been chronicled with some sense of pride by the English and American press in Paris. It is a slight triumph, but not the greatest which could happen to an American in Paris. There is more difficulty for any one of them to get into a Paris club than into one in London.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a "true inwardness" in connection with the spur incident of the polo contest, which Americans cannot be expected to understand, and, as the name Shrewsbury awakens recollections from a way back, I will try to recall them in order to clear away a misapprehension.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 14 -- The hotel men of Lake Placid are preparing for the busiest Summer in the history of the resort. At the Ruisseaumont, on the eastern shore of Lake Placid, Mr. Krumbholz finds that the people are coming earlier than usual, and the inquiries received indicate that interest in the Adirondacks for the months of September and October is increasing.

Notwithstanding the fact that the coal strike is still on, the stock market last week, though not as active as in recent days, was very strong, with many gains, some of them substantial, appearing at the end of the week. This was due to the persistent buying by the larger banking interests who, new that good crops are reasonably assured, believe that even better times are ahead.

IN the office of J.S. Bache Co. a little knot of men was gathered the other afternoon, discussing the Morgan companies, the Steel Trust and the new shipping combine. Some were friendly, but two in particular -- one a railroad expert and the other a newspaper man -- were inclined to be critical and satirical.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 14 -- Hillandale defeated Innis Arden on the Hillandale links this afternoon in an interesting team match. The scores:

BERLIN, May 27 -- Kaiser William's en- ergetic protestations of affection for the United States, emphasized by gifts and a one-sided echange de compliments, may be most aptly dismissed with Shakespeare's "Thou dost protest too much." Many of the rumors of war between the United States and Germany have been dispelled by the Kaiser's aggressive friendship.

FEW families of the English nobility have been more constantly in the public eye than that to which the new Ambassador to this country, the Hon. Michael Herbert, belongs. Nor has this been due alone to the fortuitous possession by the eldest son of the title of Earl of Pembroke and Montgomery.

The new President of Columbia University has expressed himself warmly in favor of a closer attention to the fine arts on the part of the undergraduates. He has taken the occasion of a report to be made by the Committee on Education to the Trustees to submit suggestions for more thorough art instruction.

BERLIN, June 14 -- Emperor William's gift to the Germanic Museum at Nuremberg, the centennial of which he will attend next Monday, consists of a collection of imperial seals from the time of Pepin le Bref, King of the Franks, to Francis II. of Germany.

The strike among the coal miners is indirectly responsible for the spoiling of much of the enjoyment of a ride across the Brooklyn Bridge in an open trolley car these bright June days. There are hundreds of people, many of them, folks from out of town, visiting the metropolis, who go trolleying across the big span on clear days to enjoy the splendid view of the city and harbor from there.

The attention of the lawn tennis experts will centre this week upon the courts of the New York Lawn Tennis Club, One Hundred and Twenty-second Street and Manhattan Avenues. The annual open tournament of this club always attracts an entry list of large proportions and prominence, as it is held under the auspices of the Tournament Committee of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association, the governing body of the sport.

MILAN, May 25 -- A tragedy in high Italian life has occurred at Voghera. The Marchesa Ricci, who comes of a wealthy family of Parma, has attempted to kill the widow of her husband's secretary. Public sympathy is with the Marchesa, who, it is said, has for years suffered many indignities at the hands of the Marchese, and it is believed that when brought to trial he will be acquitted.
It was a blue day for Princeton at the Polo Grounds when Yale defeated the sons of Old Nassau in the third and deciding baseball game of the series between these two colieges yesterday.

PARIS, June 15. -- The Grand Prix de Paris, most famous and valuable of the open races run for in France, was decided to-day at the Longchamps course, and in a sensational finish was won by M.E. de St. Alary's filly Kazil-Kourgan, a head before two colts, Retz and Maximum, who ran a dead heat for second place.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 15. -- The New York State Camp of Military Instruction was like a picnic ground this afternoon. A special excursion and the railroad trains brought 3,000 out-of-town visitors and Peekskill and the surrounding hamlets added another thousand to the throngs.

LONDON, June 16. -- The Times's correspondent in Pretoria says a large dinner was given to the principal officers of the National Scouts and Orange Colony volunteers to celebrate their services in helping to conclude the war. Speeches were made by Gens. Ian Hamilton, Andries, Cronje, Piet De Wet, Vilonel, Celliers, and others, some English, some Dutch.

BERLIN, June 15. -- The Boerse is still under the influence of the disappointment with which the failure of the Kafir market to rise was received, and this disappointment has caused the market to lapse into its previous stagnation. All departments were inactive last week, and there were few transactions.

NEWARK, N.J., June 15. -- There is a scene of rejoicing to-night in the Polish settlement here. Little Abe Blowenstein is home after a three week's absence. Bonfires are burning and 5,000 persons cheered the boy as his father led him through Prince Street to-night on the way home. Since his arrival the Poles have been pouring through the apartment congratulating Abe, his father, mother, and brothers.

WABASH, Ind., June 16. -- Northern Indiana farmers are obliged to pay considerably higher prices for thrashing their grain this year, owing to an agreement in the nature of a trust made by the thrashermen. Farmers are protesting against this advance, and in many instances will, if it is enforced, co-operate in the purchase of their own machines.

GOOD GROUND, L.I., June 15. -- Testimony which has been adduced to-day renders still more strange and mysterious the death of Sarah Ray, the seventeen-year-old daughter of John S. Lawrence of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, and Clarence Foster of this place, and the almost simultaneous disappearance from here of Louis Disbrow of Jamaica.

LONDON, June 16. -- Dispatches received here from South Africa show that the surrenders of Boers are proceeding with the greatest good-will. The total of the number who have already surrendered is 16,500, and the British are extending every possible kindness to the men who come in.

Yesterday's edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES, which appeared in its recently enlarged Sunday form, had an unusual number of special stories, intersting cable dispatches from correspondents in the European capitals, spicy anecdotes about wellknown persons, and news items of current interest.

The Rev. John L. Scudder, pastor of the First Congregational Church, Jersey City, who is an all-round athlete, and who won the first prize, a live duck, In a swimming match, given at the church excursion on Saturday, last night delivered a sermon advocating coeducation with athletic instructlon for girls.
AURORA, N.Y., June 15. -- The commencement exercises of Wells College began on Sunday evening, June 8, with the baccalaureate sermon, preached by the Rev. Albert W. Hitchcock of Worcester, Mass.

MANILA, June 15. -- Friendly natives in Manila say a report is current among their countrymen that the five soldiers of the Fifth Cavalry, who were captured by the insurgents May 30, have been boloed to death near Teresa, in Morong Province. Luzon. This report has not been confirmed by the American authorities of that district.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is one detail of police administration which seems to me to deserve not only the very careful consideration of the Police Commissioner, tout also the thoughtful study of parents and of the public generally. This is the problem of the regulation of the small boy on the street, and of the enforcement of the various laws and ordinances of which he is the most frequent violator.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 15. -- Patrick Gilday, President of the Central Pennsylvania bituminous district of the United Mine Workers of America, who came here to consult President Mitchell on a matter local to his district, in a talk to-day gave an insight as to what the soft coal miners in his territory are doing to held their brother workmen in the anthracite field.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 15. -- The presence of 700 armed men sent by Gov. Kimball to restore order had little influence except in the central parts of this city today, where the soldiers formed an invincible guard, and this afternoon rioting broke out anew in the suburbs and spread to the neighboring city of Central Falls.

A young man describing himself as George Austin, a clerk, living at 200% West Twenty-fourth Street and claiming at one time to be an agent of the Parkhurst society and at another a representative of "one of the city vigilance leagues," was arrested by the police of the East Eighty-eighth Street Station last night.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 15. -- The chapel of ' Cornell University was packed to overflowing this afternoon, the occasion being the baccalaureate sermon to the senior class, delivered by the Rev. Henry Van Dyke, LL. D., of Princeton. The ceremony was an imposing one, President Schurman and several of the Faculty appearing for the first time on such an occasion In their honorary robes.

On her last trip to Rockaway yesterday afternoon the side-wheel excursion steamer General Slocum of the Knickerbocker Steamboat Company's line ran on a bar off Rockaway Park about a mile and a half from her dock landing at Seaside Station.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Senate will meet at 11 o'clock each day during the present week up to and including Thursday in order to permit ample opportunity for discussion of the Isthmian Canal bill prior to voting on the bill and amendments on Thursday.

The following resolution, adopted by the Executive Committee of the Civil Service Reform Association in regard to the exemptions from competitive examination which have been made under the present municipal administration, has been transmitted to the Mayor and to the President of the Municipal Civil Service Commission:

A glance at the motor vehicles in the various depots where such machines are kept when not in use reveals the surprising, and not wholly disquieting, fact that very few of these costly constructions are free from evidences of rough usage quite independent of the normal wear and tear of road service.
At the meeting of the Central Federated Union yesterday, on the motion, of Delegate Quinlan of the Pipe Calkers and Tappers' Union, the following preamble and resolution were passed:
LONDON, June 15. -- King Edward is suffering from lumbago, which prevented his Majesty from attending to-day's church parade of the Aldershot garrison.

Carlo Cappapene, described as the Marquis di Cordova, was discharged from custody in the Harlem Police Court yesterday by Magistrate Flammer. He was taken to court from the J. Hood Wright Hospital by Detective Lawson and Policeman Sullivan of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station, who asked that he be held for an examination into his mental condition.
Jersy City's baseball team was again defeated by Worcester at Weehawken yesterday. This makes four straight games that Worcester has won from Jersey City in the Eastern League schedule.

NEWARK, N.J., June 15. -- Capt. Joshua Carman of the barge Paddle was committed to the Hudson County Jail to-day to await the action of the Grand Jury on a charge of murder preferred against him by Chief Rogers of Harrison. Carman is accused of having wilfully drowned Capt. John Plumb of the barge R. Penn Smith on Saturday morning.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 15. -- The seventyfooter Mineola, the racing sloop of August Belmont, went away from Bristol a few days ago with a finely fitting mainsail, made at the Herreshoff lofts, and bent last Tuesday. It is a racing mainsail, and will be used in the Mineola's first race this season in the regatta of the Atlantic Yacht Club.

DUBLIN, June 15. -- Patrick McHugrh, M. P., has been arrested on a warrant on the charge of conspiracy and intimidation in connection with the complaint of a tenant of a farm from which a member of the United Irish League had been evicted. The warrant was issued by a special court which assembled at Sligo, Ireland, June 6, under the Crimes act.

The country is to be congratulated that the Senate Irrigation bill goes to the President substantially unchanged. It is to be credited largely to the vigorous support given by the President, who has been more closely interested in this measure than in almost any relating to internal policy.

The Cygnus, one of the Iron Steamboat Company's Coney Island boats, was about to make a landing at Pier A, North River, last evening at 6:30 o'clock when she collided with the H.F. Dimock, one of the Metropolitan Line freighters plying between here and Boston, and headed at the time for Pier 11, North River.

Capt. Miles O'Reilly, the new commander of the Oak Street Station, spent his first Sunday as a Captain in Manhattan yesterday. He began his duties early yesterday morning and at midnight he was still looking after law violators. He had very little to do, as he seemed to be expected in all parts of the precinct.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- There was no progress to-day in the settlement of the Cuban question. The beet sugar Senators showed no signs of yielding to the Administration or any lack of confidence in their expectation of preventing the passage of the Administration Reciprocity bill. There was no indication anywhere that the President's message had begun to operate along the lines on which the President expected it to work.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15. -- The Rev. Elwood C. Worcester, D.D., of this city, author of "What We Know About Genesis in the Light of Modern Science," preached the annual baccalaureate sermon to the graduating classes of the University of Pennsylvania this evening. The services were held in St. Stephen's Church.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 15. -- The Rev. D.J. Yerkes, who has been dean of the Ministers of this city, resigned to-day. He has been pastor of the First Baptist Church for thirty-nine years. At the morning service he announced his retirement from the pastorate and from the ministry because his health will not permit longer activity.

MANILA, June 15. -- The Chamber of Commerce has presented to Gen. Chaffee a set of resolutions which express the regard with which Gen. Chaffee and the army in the Philippines are held by the business men of Manila.

The most significant development of the present stock market dealings is the apparent re-entrance into the market, as purchasers, of what are designated in the Street as the Standard Oil interests. Indeed, it may be said that there is unmistakable evidence of buying by these interests, and that in speaking of their reappearance the qualifying word apparent is not necessary.

The attendance and brushing on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning would have done credit to a big trotting event. With few exceptions every contest was fought out to the very last stride, and many of the finishes were so close that only those who were fortunate enough to secure positions at the finishing post were able to decide as to the winner.

At Doherty's Handball Court, Harrison, N.J., yesterday, Edward Bruder of Harrison defeated Edward Hopkins of the NewJersey Handball Club of Jersey City in the first series of games for the championship of New Jersey and a purse of $30, winning three of the five games played. Oliver Drew, the champion handball player of Great Britain, refereed the match.

LONDON, June 16. -- The Times's Valparaiso correspondent says, apropos of the recent arrangement with Argentina, it is reported that instructions have already been issued for laying up certain Chilean warships.

If the opponents of the Cuban Reciprocity bill adhere to their plan of pressing the House bill, amended so as not to abolish the countervailing duty, the best thing for the true friends of justice to Cuba to do is to accept that plan.

There is some talk in the Sixth Maryland District of the nomination of Senator GEORGE L. WELLINGTON for Representative in the Fifty-eighth Congress. Of course this talk does not come from Republicans, for that party already has named Representative GEORGE A. PEARRE, who has represented the district since Mr. WELLINGTON was honored, five years ago or more, by promotion to the Senate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: More playgrounds should be opened this Summer, more than ever before enjoyed by the boys and girls released from school, especially as a majority live in the crowded conditions of tenement houses. No boy or girl living in one of the crowded city quarters has a fair chance for healthful and physical or spiritual growth.

-- It is distinctly amusing to learn that not only have the Boers -- the real Boers who staid at home and used their guns -- manifested an almost unanimous determination to be friends with their conquerors, but that the two nations against which they now cherish a bitter animosity are precisely the two that have given most "sympathy" to the little republics -- the two being Germany and France.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 15. -- The New York Central's twentieth century limited train reached Rochester at 10:30 o'clock tonight, just two minutes ahead of the scheduled time, having made the run to this city, a distance of 446 miles, in 371 minutes. Along the line there were large crowds of people present to watch the new flier.

MEADVILLE, Penn., June 15. -- The formal exercises of commencement week at Allegheny College, Meadville, Penn., began this morning, when the baccalaureate sermon was preached by President William H. Crawford, LL. D. The subject was "Christian Discipleship." In addressing the class President Crawford said: "You go out from us at a time of great opportunity.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 15. -- The New York and Chicago specials, the new twenty-hour trains on the Pennsylvania Railroad, passed each other on the western outskirts of Allegheny City. The westbound, No. 29, was on time to the second. The east-bound, No. 30, was two minutes late.

The defense in the trial of Sergt. James Churchill, charged with neglect of duty, was begun yesterday at Police Headquarters. Churchill on the stand tried to indicate to the Commissioner how he had tried to enforce the law under limited conditions and how Inspector Cross, as he said, had hampered him.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- There is a conflict of testimony between Gen. Leonard Wood and Secretary Root regarding the report that considerable sums of money were paid out of the Cuban Treasury by Gen. Wood for Gen. Gomez's withdrawal from the Presidential contest in favor of Tomas Estrada Palma.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 16 -- The Constitution proposed for the State of Connecticut by the convention which was in session four and a half months, beginning Jan. 1, was defeated at the polls to-day by a decisive vote.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 16 -- The sixth week of the anthracite coal miners' strike began to-day without a ripple to disturb the calmness of the situation. Plain fell nearly all day, which helped to keep the more than 150,000 idle men and boys in doors.

Capt. O'REILLY, in the Oak Street Precinct, has gently tapped the end of the bothersome and elusive excise egg, stood it up firmly, and solved the problem with which the entire new police administration has been rather futilely struggling for the past five months. It looks easy, now that it has been done.

Yesterday's Stock Exchange market was not active, but it was unqualifiedly strong. Practically every change of consequence was an advance. Stocks most conspicuous were stocks of high class. Investment purchases rather than speculative operations seemed to be the controlling influence.

-- It is a little bit unfortunate that President ROOSEVELT, near the end of his earnest plea to Congress in behalf of our Cuban wards, should have praised our administration of the island at the expense of other nations, some of which have been doing some pretty good administering themselves in recent years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Cosby's threats about what would be done to the Manhattan Railroad Company and others for burning soft coal are a fine sample of the "hot air" that the reform officials have been indulging in for some time and have about the same effect. There is absolutely no excuse for the present abominable smoke nuisance.
LONDON, June 16 -- Money was plentiful to-day and in moderate demand. Rates were easy.

Three independent theatrical managers have entered into an agreement for establishing an agency not connected with the Theatrical Trust. The organizers of the new movement are Harrison Grey Fiske, husband of Mrs. Minnie Maddern Fiske; James K. Hackett, husband of Mary Mannering, and Maurice Campbell, Henrietta Crosman's husband and manager.

NEWARK, N.J., June 16 -- Vice Chancellor Emery to-day announced his decision to continue the preliminary injunction in the United States Steel Corporation suit, thus restraining the retirement of $200,000,000 of its preferred stock and the issuing of bonds to the same amounts in payment of the stock.

President Thomas Hunter of the Normal College gave out yesterday the names of the graduates of the various public, parochial, and private schools in this city who had passed successfully the examinations for entrance into the college. Of the 1,080 girls who stood, the names of the successful applicants appear below.
The city authorities yesterday instituted criminal proceedings against the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company charged with violating the health ordinances governing the use of soft coal.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Vanderbilt arrived this evening and will be guests for several days of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lawrence Van Alen, at the latter's residence, on Bellevue Avenue, which was a gift of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderbilt to Mrs. Van Alen.

Solomon Stein, founder and senior partner of the wholesale woolen firm of S. Stein Co., at Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, and one of the well-known merchants of the United States, who died on Friday at Bay Shore, L.I., was born in Bavaria sixty-seven years ago. He came to this country when six years old.

Alexander E. Orr, Charles Stuart Smith, and Controller Grout, the Rapid Transit Commission's sub-committee appointed to determine the terms of the franchise to be granted to the Pennsylvania Railroad for its tunnel from Jersey City to Long Island, made their report to the commission yesterday.

The only element of surprise which resides in the report of the Parliamentary Committee on Military Education and Training will be found in the fact that its members found the courage to express their convictions so forcibly. The facts to which they call attention have been known for generations to every one who has had knowledge of the organization of the British Army.

BARRE, Vt., June 16 -- Great property damage was caused by a cloudburst over this section late last night, and five railroad men lost their lives, a freight train on the Central Vermont Railroad having run into a wash-out at Middlesex.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- According to the present plans of the Administration leaders, the Cuban question is to be settled in a Republican Senatorial conference which will be held either Wednesday night or Thursday night. It is intended that the Republican members of the Committee on Relations with Cuba shall agree upon a bill to-morrow and submit it to the conference.

The quarterly report of Commissioner or Street Cleaning John McGaw Woodbury to Mayor Low was made public yesterday. It possesses special interest as affording a comparison of the work done in cleaning the streets during the Tammany administration and the first four months of Mayor Low's administration.

Monotony in the outside market was somewhat relieved yesterday by the sharp advance in Northern Securities and movements of more or less importance in several other issues. The market, generally speaking, showed no great increase in activity as compared with last week's transactions, and the general course of prices was, as it had been for some days, irregular, but always confined within a narrow range.

An exigent public duty is presented to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in connection with the extension of the Rapid Transit Subway from Ann Street and Broadway to Bowling Green, where it divides, one branch going to South Ferry and the other to Brooklyn. This is the provision of pipe galleries as a part of the original construction.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 16 -- French Lick and West Baden and the valley in which the two famous Indiana health resorts are located bid fair to furnish the next scene of Indiana lawlessness. Both places and the entire length of the valley are threatened with a race war more vicious and more bitter than any that has occurred in the State within the last ten or fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Senator Kittredge of South Dakota delivered his first Speech in the Senate to-day and won high commendation for it from his fellow Senators, He spoke on the Canal bill, and made what was regarded by everybody as the clearest, sharpest, and closest argument in favor of the Panama route that has been presented to the Senate.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Directors of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company will meet in New York to-morrow and exercise an option which the company holds on a British plant. The purchase of this plant will give the Pneumatic Tool Company a monopoly of its line of business in this country, Great Britain, and Europe.

Leopold Weil has sold for the New York Realty Corporation to a prominent builder for about $250,000 the Evangelical Lutheran Church, on the north side of Twenty-first Street, about 160 feet east of Sixth Avenue, the property consisting of about four and a half lots.

An elevator, carrying a load of fifteen men and women, fell from the sixth floor of the building at 418 Broome Street at noon yesterday. Two persons were seriously hurt and all were more or less injured.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Secretary Root has assumed full responsibility for the payment of money to Gen. Gomez by Gen. Wood during the American occupation of Cuba, and if Congress asks for an explanation of the matter he stands prepared to furnish what he regards as the most convincing proofs that the payments were dictated by the wisest statesmanship.

The highest price paid for yearling thoroughbred horses this season was reached yesterday at the sale of J.B. Haggin's California-bred stock from the Rancho del Paso, when Sydney Paget, acting for William C. Whitney, bought the bay colt by Watercress-Pensa by Sir Modred, for $21,000.

LONDON, June 17 -- King Edward bore yesterday's journey to Windsor well, but it has been decided that he will not go to Ascot to-day. Queen Alexandra, however, accompanied by the Prince and Princess of Wales and other members of the royal family, will attend the races in state.

By comparison with the crowd of Suburban Handicap day, the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday seemed almost deserted, in spite of the fact that the turnstiles showed an attendance of close upon 10,000 visitors. Two good stakes figured as the attractions and produced fair contests, with results all in favor of the betting public, for both went to favorites of the "sure-thing" variety.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 16 -- Whether or not the Kansas City platform is to be reaffirmed, and who will be the Chairman of the next State Central Committee are the only causes of possible friction in the Democratic State Convention which will meet here to-morrow, and it is not considered likely that either will bring about much of a fight.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- The local market was quiet and steady to-day, and the Readings formed the leading feature. The demand for Reading common was the liveliest since the strike began. New York placed large orders for the stock here and at one time the price in this market was 1/8 above that in New York, touching 33 1-16, but this high level was not maintained.

PLEADING DISCHARGE IN BANKRUPTCY TO OFFSET CONTRACT -- After Frank H. McKinnon and Walter H. Burrows had defaulted in 1894 in an action on a promissory note brought against them by Oliver C. Latimer, their attorney, James R. Baumes, in consideration that the default be opened, agreed to pay any final judgment rendered against the defendants, or so much as remained unpaid after the return of an execution.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- A telegram was received to-day saying that President John Swain of Indiana University has signified his acceptance of the Presidency of Swarthmore College, to take effect next September.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Hugh Hastings, State Historian, in his story in to-day's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES of the relations that existed between Frederick the Great and the United States, has omitted an important prophecy which that friend of the Thirteen Colonies and "venerable seer" made in regard to the future of the American Republic.
The Jersey City baseball team continued its losing streak on the home grounds yesterday, being defeated by Providence in the first game of the series by a score of 9 to 4.

The Board of Health, in association with Assistant Corporation Counsel COSBY, will make a test case in the smoke nuisance prosecutions by the arrest under a warrant of the Secretary and Treasurer of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad. The course of President LEDERLE in this matter is entirely proper.
WASHINGTON, June 16.--The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

BALTIMORE, June 16 -- The strength of International Trust was the feature of today's market. It reached the highest price of this year. Consolidated Gas was also stronger. This rise is attributed by some to rumors of an impending deal, but others ascribe it to the immense increase in the consumption of gas, occasioned by the high prices of coal.

GOOD GROUND, L.I., June 16 -- After a week of unexplainable lethargy, the police at last awakened to-day to the fact that in the death of Sarah Lawrence and Clarence Foster coincident with the sudden disappearance of Louis A. Disbrow there was a strange and complicated mystery and one worthy of the most searching inquiry.
There is just one difference between the Cuban bill proposed by the Democrats and the beet-sugar men and the bill insisted on by the Republican leaders in the Senate.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 16 -- The college crews assembled here for the boat races of Saturday were favored with good water for this evening's practice. There was a strong flood tide, and the river was as smooth as glass. All the crews were out, and there was seen the unprecedented sight of sixteen college crews representing the six competing colleges, rowing on the river at the same time.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 16 -- With no more ado than if it were an "accommodation" from a few miles down the road, the Pennsylvania twenty-hour train from New York pulled into Union Station this morning at 8:52 o'clock, three minutes ahead of its schedule time.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 16 -- Yellow poplar's price was advanced to-day $1 per hundred feet as a result of the recent action of the Kentucky district of the National Hardwood Lumbermen's Association. The price, which several months ago was $2.50 a hundred, is now $5.50 for Kentucky yellow poplar.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 17. -- The Democratic State Convention adjourned to-night after nominating the following ticket:

PHILADELPHIA, June 17. -- The air was let out of a financial bubble to-day by the recording of the assignment of the United States Trust Company to ex-Senator Charles L. Brown for the benefit of the creditors. The concern had its office in Room No. 1,110 Witherspoon Building, and had no deposits.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 17. -- Mrs. Austin L. Sands arrived this evening as guest of her son, Fred P. Sands, at his cottage in Catherine Street.

There was a further advance in quotations on the Stock Exchange yesterday. With the conspicuous exception of General Electric, which broke sharply on the new competition developing, practically every important change represented a gain. Reading, Missouri Pacific, and Great Northern preferred were especially strong, while in other parts of the list the leaders were Atchison, St. Louis and San Francisco, Norfolk and Western, Baltimore and Ohio, the Wabashes, and Big Four.

LONDON, June 18. -- A story is current in London of the discovery of a plot to assassinate King Edward. This story has created considerable discussion in newspaper and other circles, but it is lacking in anything like official confirmation.

LONDON, June 17. -- The race meeting at "Royal Ascot" opened to-day, and though King Edward, who still is ill, was unable to attend, the first day of racing on the course most patronized by the aristocracy was the occasion of the first full State parade of the character since the death of the Prince Consort.

FAIRMONT, West Va., June 17. -- Justice Fleming decided to-day that the miners' strike leaders were guilty of violating Judge Mason's injunction, and held them in $200 bond to answer an indictment at the next term of court.

Good matter of controversy was provided in abundance yesterday in CHARLES FRANCIS ADAMS'S oration before the Phi Beta Kappa Society of the University of Chicago. "Shall CROMWELL Have a Statue?" is the title chosen by Mr. ADAMS for his address; shall ROBERT E. LEE have a statue? is the question he discusses.

GOOD GROUND, N.Y., June 17. -- As a result of the disclosures which have been made in connection with the disappearance of Louis A. Disbrow and the peculiar death of Clarence Foster and Sarah Lawrence, the seventeen-year-old daughter of John S. Lawrence of New York, Coroner John Nugent said to-night that if Disbrow was not produced to-morrow morning ho would issue a warrant for his arrest upon a charge of murder.

Notwithstanding that the best horses have won so often at the present meeting on the Sheepshead Bay racetrack, yesterday's crowd was surprised at the continued success of the popular choices, even in the face of the victory of the one unbacked outsider of the afternoon. More surprising than the average of the results, however, was the victory of one of the strongest choices of the day, Hatasoo, under the conditions that she won.

Gen. Horace Porter, Ambassador to France, was the guest of honor at a dinner given by the Lotos Club last night. Among those who assembled to do him honor were Frank R. Lawrence, President of the club and toastmaster; Major Gen. John R. Brooke, Mark Twain, George H. Daniels, Charles A. Moore, Rear Admiral Barker, and many other prominent citizens.

LONDON, June 17. -- The coronation, as a public spectacle, threatens to be a fiasco. So serious and imminent has this possibility become that The Times and other papers are printing alarmist letters, urging the authorities to take steps to prevent the failure of the coronation before it is too late.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 17. -- Because the General Manager would not discharge five girls whose relatives are still at work in the mines, the Wilkesbarre Lace Manufacturing Company, the largest in the United States, was compelled to shut down to-day.
First Lieut. Leon L. Roach, Eighth Infantry, is transferred to the Sixteenth Infantry.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday, and the routine business of the meeting was interrupted by laughter and applause caused by speeches made by Alderman James J. Bridges of Brooklyn. President Cassidy succeeded in having passed an authorization for a special issue of revenue bonds amounting to $45,000 to be used in improving the fire alarm system in Queens Borough outside of Long Island City.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 17. -- There was an exciting chase after two burglars in Rye last night, and the pursuit was kept up on the waters of Long Island Sound. One of the burglars was finally captured after they and their pursuers had returned to land.

Police Captain Miles O'Reilly and Peter De Lacy, the alleged poolroom operator, had a heart-to-heart talk in the latter's "offices," on the second floor of the building at 33 Park Row, yesterday. It had been reported that De Lacy had "opened up" again, and that he bade defiance to the aggressive Police Captain.

BOSTON, June 17. -- Filon d'Or, son of the great running mare Fides, and carrying the blue and gold of Thomas W. Lawson's stable, won the Country Club Grand Annual Steeplechase at Clyde Park this afternoon. The victory was unexpected, for, with only one hurdle and a short stretch of flat ahead, George W. Jenkins, the favorite and leader, threw his rider, Ray, at the hurdle.

An offer has been made by representatives of Western banking interests for the control of the stock of the National Shoe and Leather Bank of 271 Broadway. It is reported that the Corn Exchange National Bank of Chicago is the intending purchaser, but this report could not be confirmed authoritatively.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 17. -- All the brickyards on the Hudson River in this vicinity are shorthanded, and the manufacturers are experiencing great difficulty in procuring help to keep the yards going. This week about forty strikers from the Pennsylvania mines went to work at the yards in Stony Point, and it is expected that the end of the week will witness at least 200 miners working on the yards along the Hudson.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Estimates of the strength of the sentiment in the Senate in favor of the Panama route for an isthmian canal varied somewhat to-day, but there were few polls of the Senate which did not show a decided majority for the Spooner amendment to the Hepburn bill.

Mayor Low climbed to the top of the tower of the East River Bridge yesterday and from the Manhattan end he enjoyed a view of the Greater New York. The trip was one of inspection, and when he returned to the City Hall the announcement was made that the new East River Bridge would probably be opened to the public in October, 1903.

LONDON, June 18. -- The Peking correspondent of The Times says the six Ministers represented on the Tien-Tsin foreign Government have not submitted to their colleagues or to the Chinese the conditions on which they will restore the native city of Tien-Tsin to the Chinese.

First Baseman Carr has been appointed Manager-Captain of the Jersey City baseball team, and under his guidance the players won the second game of the series from the leaders in the Eastern League pennant race yesterday. The score was 12 to 4. Conn started to pitch for the Providence team and he lasted four and one-half innings, giving way to Friend.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17. -- Owing primarily to the cheerful feeling engendered by the vigorous advance in Reading common, the market in Philadelphia took on a broader aspect and a stronger appearance than at any time in the last six months. An important feature was the participation of the Steel stocks, after months of drowsiness, but it was in Reading that interest centred.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday concluded that the case brought against the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company by him in Magistrate Zeller's court on complaint of Health Commissioner Lederle must be expedited. The summons being against a corporation, and under the law a corporation having ten days within which to make answer, was not returnable until June 26.

In the outside market yesterday Northern Securities was again by far the most prominent stock in the list. At the same time a further substantial advance occurred in the price of this issue. Elsewhere in the list also there was considerable show of strength and most of the changes from Monday's prices appeared on the side of gains.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- The corn pit was the scene of a very active scramble at the opening to-day. Shorts in July options were much frightened over the strength displayed in that delivery yesterday, and stop loss orders were executed in considerable quantity. The result was a jump of 1 1/8 cents in the first few minutes of business.

August Belmont's sloop Mineola defeated J.R. Maxwell's Yankee by 2 minutes 31 seconds over a twenty-six-mile course in the annual regatta of the Atlantic Yacht Club in the lower bay yesterday. Frederick K. Brewster's schooner Elmina, over the same course, defeated Charles M. Smither's Muriel by 2 minutes 26 seconds.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 17. -- With the intercollegiate boat races only four days distant, the crews are rapidly approaching that stage of tension which is such a critical period in the training for an athletic contest of this character. This was exemplified to-day in the action of Coach Hanlan in forcing the resignation of Capt. Scott of the freshman eight for disobedience of orders.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- At the meeting of the Phi. Beta Kappa Society of the University of Chicago held here to-night Charles Francis Adams delivered an oration on the subject, "Shall Cromwell Have a Statue?" Mr. Adams's address was in part as follows:

PARIS, June 17. -- There is considerable anxiety regarding the state of the crops and vineyards, in consequence of the uninterrupted cold and rainy weather in France during the past two months. M. Flammarion, the astronomer, says there has been no such disastrous Springtime since 1852, and the meterological predictions promise but a little better Summer.

BOSTON, June 17. -- Financial circles took their customary holiday Bunker Hill Day. The Stock Exchange was closed, and the banks, under a mutual agreement, also gave their employes a holiday. Brokers' offices, as a rule, had only one or two clerks on hand, but the fact that business was going on as usual in New York drew out a few people to watch the current Wall Street quotations.

Everything points to the fact that the strike of the bituminous miners in West Virginia is a substantial failure. This was the only important field in which MITCHELL could make a showing of sympathetic co-operation with the anthracite miners without destroying the United Mine Workers by closing the door to any further conference with them by the operators.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17. -- For the first time in the United States the honorary degree of Doctor of Jurisprudence was conferred to-day at the Augustinian College of St. Thomas at Villanova. The recipient was ex-President Cleveland, who already had the degree of LL.D. conferred by the Princeton University.

PEEKSKILL, (State Camp,) June 17. -- At Camp Roe the Twenty-third Regiment varied their drill this morning by battle formation with blank ammunition and company drills, one company at a time. Col. William H. Chapin of Gen. Roe's staff rode over to camp and delivered a lecture to the regimental officers and First Sergeants on "Camp Sanitation and Hygiene and the Adjustment of Blanket Rolls While on Practice Marches."

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The Cabinet to-day discussed the situation in Venezuela, and it was decided that one or two warships should be sent at once to La Guayra. This action was taken not upon definite advices, but in pursuance of the general policy of looking after American interests in case of disturbance.
BERLIN, June 17. -- Gen. von Bock und Pollach, commanding a division of the army, has been seriously wounded by the lances of his own dragoons.

TACOMA, Wash., June 17. -- Cablegrams received by transportation companies state that the tea markets have opened in China and Japan at unusually high prices. The new crop is of good quality and at least average yield. The prices indicate that Oriental dealers and growers are discounting the decreased values given tea in the United States by a reduction of a 10 per cent, duty effective next January.

The thirty-third annual Commencement of the Normal College of the City of New York took place in Carnegie Hall last evening. Parents and friends of the 320 young women who were graduated were present in great numbers, the big hall being crowded.

The Provident Realty Company took title yesterday to 234, 256, and 258 West Forty-second Street, south side, vacant houses abutting on the American Theatre, whose ground area is 66.8 by 98. On the site will be constructed a modern hotel twelve and a half stories high, to cost more than $300,000.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The passage by the Senate of a bill to establish commercial reciprocity with Cuba seems to be quite out of the question. The Cuban problem, so far as this session of Congress is concerned, apparently is a moribund issue; one more day, and it will be a dead issue, unless all signs fail.

BOSTON, June 17. -- New York was beaten twice to-day by the Boston baseball team. Three hits, a base on balls, and three errors added to Cooley's being hit by a pitched ball, gave Boston four runs in the eighth inning in the morning and clinched the game. Washburn had his nose broken by a pitched ball in the seventh inning, and Dunn took his place.

The temperature will fall somewhat in the middle Rocky Mountain region and over the east slope, and rise from the Middle Mississippi Valley eastward to the Atlantic. The winds along the Atlantic Coast will be light and variable. On the great lakes fresh southeast winds will prevail; along the West Gulf Coast fresh to brisk southeast winds will continue; on the East Gulf Coast the winds will be mostly fresh south.

BALTIMORE, June 17. -- The chief interest in to-day's trading hovered around Cotton Duck stock and United Railways issues. Both groups were firm and both moved upward. The whole series of Cotton Duck issues are improving. United Railways continue to get stronger by reason of the operation of the margin of safety rule.

LONDON, June 17. -- Money was plentiful and rates were easy to-day, owing to Government disbursements. Discounts were weak, on account of the impression that rates for short loans will be easir in the near future, though the indebtedness to the Bank of England is large.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The following is the Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions:

There is something a little -- to be quite frank, much more than a little -- unpleasant in the spectacle of a Justice of the Supreme Court as the head of a faction in municipal politics. It is almost equally unpleasant whether Judge O'GORMAN is to be regarded as the real head, or only a figurehead and locum tenens for the heir to the boss-ship of Tammany Hall.

There were several suburban weddings yesterday which were of much interest. That of Miss Miller to the Rev. Mr. Brinley at Morristown, N.J., was one of the most notable. The departure of ships yesterday and to-day carrying passengers for the jubilee and others for the Continent was also a topic of interest.

Mayor Low has taken a kindly interest in the suggestion of Mrs. HAWLEY, a School Inspector, that during the Summer vacation season the public school buildings be kept open so that the children of the neighborhoods in which they are placed may use them for purposes of playgrounds.

The decision of President MITCHELL to call a National convention at Indianapolis "at the earliest possible moment," to consider the advisability of calling out all the bituminous miners in the United States, is certainly a dangerous, and may be a fatal expedient. It looks as if he were playing the highest trump for the reason that he has but one and cannot longer hold it in reserve.

A parasol in the violet shades has the body of figured silk, white, with a pattern of flowers in violet. Tied around the top is a violet velvet ribbon an inch or more in width, with a cluster of artificial violets, while another piece of the velvet is tied around the handle.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The isthmian canal question was laid before the Senate to-day. Mr. Jones, (Arkansas,) believed it to be the duty of every Senator to vote for the canal at the best location. Personally, he said, he would not vote for the proposition that would impede the progress of the canal construction.

MANILA, June 18 -- Major Cornelius Gardener called the ex-insurgent leader Malvar, who surrendered in Batangas Province last April, to testify to-day before the board which is investigating the charges brought by Major Gardener concerning conditions in Tayabas Province, Luzon. This board held its first meetings at Lucena, Tabayas Province, but adjourned to meet in Manila.

Members of leading law firms in this city who have enjoyed a large and lucrative practice for corporations in New Jersey seem agreed that the new rule of the Supreme Court of that State, announced by Chief Justice Gummere on Tuesday, barring New York lawyers from practicing in that State, was due to the efforts of Jersey attorneys who were envious of the large fees paid to members of the New York bar.

The first positive evidence in rebuttal of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company's contention that it had found it impossible to obtain hard coal available for use in its engines was secured yesterday from Nicholas N. Stokes. He is a coal dealer at Eighty-ninth Street and Riverside Avenue. Mr. Stokes says he offered the Manhattan Company's agent 550 tons of hard coal and they haggled about the price and refused to take it.

A.L. Mordecal Son have sold for steinhardt Goldman to the West Side Construction Company the vacant plot on the south side of Seventy-seventh Street, 50 feet east of Columbus Avenue, 100 by 102.2, on which the purchasing corporation will build a modern and sumptuously equipped twelve-story apartment hotel.
