Humbert, (who have mysteriously left Paris as a result of disclosures said to connect them with an extensive swindling scheme,) in all 150, were sold at auction this afternoon. The total realized by the two days' sale is 1,187,950., ($237,590.)

MR. ALOFTUS HEFTY of Boston is a student of the occult. He does not hesitate to confess, many times a day, that he takes frequent and deep plunges into those mysterious depths -- knows all about rupa, prana, manas, atma, carma, the planetary chain, devachan, and avitchi; has the theory of the seven principles of life at his tongue's end and is not devoid of a pretty fair insight into the eighth.

The Illinois Central Railroad Company has during the past week come once more into prominence through the recommendation of the Board of Directors that the capital stock of the company be further increased from $79,200,000 to $95,040,000 by the issue of 138,400 new shares, stockholders to have the right to subscribe thereto for a ratable proportion of new stock at par.

Little interest was taken in the trading in the outside market yesterday. In no part of the list were the transactions large even for a Saturday, and in the absence of developments of more importance traders turned to the few stocks which showed an upward tendency and with their help several more or less substantial advances were recorded.

Under the original charter of Greater New York it was one of the duties of the Fire Department to look after the fire escapes of the city and see to it that they were kept clear. On Jan. 1 that function was transferred to the Tenement House Department. That department is only now beginning to get its Inspectors appointed.

The silk mills in West Hoboken were all closed again yesterday. There were no crowds about the plants, and no trouble of any kind. The police were on the alert, and preparations were continued promptly to suppress any outbreak that might occur.
NEW HAVEN, June 21 -- Yale's commencement begins to-morrow morning with the annual baccalaureate address of President Arthur T. Hadley in Battell Chapel.
AT the Tilden Club Thursday night Frank H. Brooks was among those who walked up to shake hands with ex-President Grover Cleveland.

SOME one has said that the race of prophets is extinct; that the last one died without remembering to leave the recipe behind him. The man who said that had never happened to wander around when the market was in full swing in Wall Street, or he would certainly have revised his dictum very radically.

CRTAINLY Cassatet is a man of many parts, though somewhat eccentric. Years ago he had written an essay. "The Placating of the Immaterial," and had printed it at his own risk. Needless to say that it was ignored. Of course, Cassatet suffered from disappointment.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

To the Editor of The New York Times: To the publication of no more well grounded and urgent complaint than that appearing in to-day's paper, headed "Unruly Boys in the Streets," and signed "Civis," could THE TIMES lend itself. The goings on in Morningside Park and vicinity on the part of small boys are dangerous often and inexcusable ever.

SCARRED and burned, the steamer Roddam, the only vessel that escaped from St. Pierre at the time of the volcanic explosion, arrived at New Orleans a few days ago with a new crew, except for five men who were upon her when she made her remarkable flight with dead and dying upon her decks.

TACOMA, Washington, June 21 -- One of the worst forest fires ever known in this district has been raging since yesterday morning, sweeping its way through huge forests and leaving nothing but charred stumps. Waves of fire are now surging through mountain valleys turning them into seas of red hot flames.
" Me wear a white collar and black my shoes? " he cried disdainfully. " What you take me for, a Sunday school? "

From the Wilkesbarre headquarters of the United Mine Workers there has been sent to labor organizations all over the country a letter, circular, or note warning union workingmen not to array themselves against their brothers by hiring out to any anthracite coal company. We reprint one paragraph from this circular:

For many years the question of the possibility of holding a rowing regatta in this country on the plan of the famous English Henley has been discussed, and within the last few years evidence has accumulated to show that the interest in rowing among college men and college graduates is increasing, and that the time has come when a forward step might be taken in American rowing.

SUPPOSING Col. Mills, the Command- ant of the United States Military Academy at West Point, bad handed in his resignation with the undisguised, if not openly declared, purpose of devoting himself unreservedly to mediumistic experiments, not only would military circles be astonished, but the fact itself would be justly regarded as an indication of the prevailing currents in American thought.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 21 -- The boardwalk presents a midsummer appearance now as throngs of visitors are here. The first of a series of excursions from Pittsburg and the West arrived on Thursday, bringing nearly 2,000 excursionists for a ten-day's stay.

LONDON, June 21 -- Presumably the Americans who will see the coronation are now all here. Of wealthy Americans there are as many as usual at this time of year. The managers of the Savoy, Claridge's, the Carlton, and Berkeley Hotels say no more.

EVIL as is the smoke situation in New York, London and the larger English cities suffer to an even greater extent, for there the atmospheric moisture is greater. It has been conclusively demonstrated by distinguished British scientific authorities that the smoke nuisance is responsible for the density and ghastly foulness of the nauseating fog known as the "London particular," which enfolds the British metropolis in an impenetrable shroud.

FISHERMEN of the Hawaiian Islands have many ancient legends which have been transmitted from father to son for generations. While a few of these legends have been reduced to writing, many are still unwritten and waiting for the student of folk-lore who is able to converse with the native in his own language.

Pittsburg further increased its lead in the National Baseball League competition by defeating St. Louis twice yesterday. As Cincinnati was also beaten by Chicago, the New Yorks were able to advance from last to sixth place, even though they did not play.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Col. Hepburn and Senator Morgan had several conferences to-day with regard to the Isthmian Canal bill, but there was no meeting of the full Conference Committee. Its first meeting has been set for Monday at 2 o'clock P.M., when the canal battle will enter on its final stage for this session.

THE broad dark line, with the names of the thoroughfares in white lettering, gives the route of the procession on Friday, June 27, from Buckingham Palace to the city on the north side, returning on the south bank of the Thames. This route, which is thirteen miles in length, and will take about three and a half hours to traverse, includes the whole of the shorter coronation route of June 26.
Nos. 343 and 345 West Thirty-sixth Street, for a six-story brick stable, 36 by 98.9; P.A. Geoghegan of 464 Eighth Avenue, owner; J.W. Cole of 403 West Fifty-first Street, architect; cost, $15,000.

Plans for the new bronze doors and portals for St. Bartholomew's Church, which have been given by Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt in memory of her husband, have been prepared by the architects, McKim, Mead White. The structural work on the front of the church is to be continued during the Summer, while the doors are being cast, without interruption to the regular services.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter in to-day's TIMES signed "Civis" reminds me of a letter signed S.S. Began in your journal of April 6th. S.S.B. seems to me to put the matter of education in New York very practically in a few paragraphs. He says: "Children are started in the kindergarten at three or four years of age.

The long standing, complicated litigation between Mrs. Agnes K. Murphy Mulligan and her husband, William G. Mulligan, of Tremont, and Miss Mary Seiford over property dealt in by them in the Bronx, was settled yesterday when Justice O'Gorman dismissed a suit brought by Miss Seiford to have an assignment of an interest claimed by her in the Downing estate syndicate, and for an accounting of the profits which she alleges she is entitled to receive.

HISTORICAL reminiscences of Revo- lutionary days which have been so vividly recalled recently by the unveiling of the statue to Count de Rochambeau and the centennial of West Point, will be still further revived on July 16, when important exercises will be held at Stony Point, commemorative alike of the battle and of the permanent preser- vation of the site as a State Park.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 21 -- This city is unable to accept a gift of $50,000 from Andrew Carnegie for a public library building because the members of the Board of Trustees of the city libraries cannot agree upon a site, which, Mr. Carnegie says, must be furnished before the money will be forthcoming.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 20 -- It is generally conceded by officials in Washington who have to do with the government of the Philippines that one of the most difficult problems confronting the United States in connection with those islands is the settlement of the socalled friar question.

AT MY lodging house is the most wonderful woman in New York City. She is a native of Ireland -- little, and wizened, and brown -- her talk racy of the soil and her heart pure gold. She rules us all with a rod of iron -- in a velvet sheath of blarney -- and her greatest pleasure is to take unnecessary trouble for other people's comfort.

The annual show of the National Horticultural Society of France was recently opened in the greenhouses on the Cours le Reine, Paris, which were erected during the Exhibition of 1900, and which are particularly well suited for shows of this description. The two large houses have been connected by marquees, filled with exhibits in the rose classes, and in the middle of the space thus formed stands a bronze statue of a horseman on horseback.

Mayor HINCHLIFFE of Paterson seems to be a very energetic man in emergencies, and when convinced that the time for action has come is obviously capable of doing things in a forceful way. He showed great executive capacity during the devastations of the city by fire and flood, doing the right thing, and doing it with commendable promptness.

ACCORDING to a cable dispatch dated Lucca, May 11, the Italian brigand Giuseppe Musolino has been sentenced to imprisonment for life, while incarceration begins with eight years of solitary confinement. The story of his campaign against the authorities, in which he is said to have killed twelve out of the fif- teen witnesses against him when he was sentenced in 1898 for attempted murder, has already been given.

HERE is a beauty recipe of Lillian Russell's which has been going the rounds of the papers recently and we make haste to reproduce it before the strawberry season is over and the Lillian Russell complexion is lost to the world of less beautiful women for another season.

Superior work with the stick, fast running tricky dodging, and heavier weight on the part of the Shamrocks, the champion Blue Ribbon lacrosse team of Canada, yesterday worked the downfall of the Crescent Athletic Club team on the field at Bay Ridge. The final score was 15 goals to 7.

What most persons do not know is that the greater number of those who are going abroad now, and this is the time when everybody who intends to go, goes, engaged passage in the steerage, or, as the steamship companies describe it, the third cabin. On the White Star Liner Celtic, which sailed recently, were nearly twelve hundred third-cabin passengers.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 21 -- In spite of the opening of the hotels early in June and the putting of the large steamer New Shoreham in commission for daily service June 1, the people do not, as a rule, plan to get here much before the last week in June or the first week in July, although quite a number of those owning Summer residences have arrived.

LONDON, June 22.-- The report circulated last evening on the authority of a woman of fashion well known in Court circles that King Edward had a stroke of paralysis is now vigorously denied by persons of authority and is generally disbelieved, as it is most unlikely, because acceptance implies that a veritable string of lies was spoken and acted by a hundred people at Windsor this week.
ALBANY, June 21 -- The current bulletin of the New York State Library gives a register of the State Library School and some statistics regarding its career.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 21 -- To-day all the hotels and boarding houses here, with some few exceptions, have their doors open for the season of 1902.
Varied versions of the toasts given by President Loubet and the Czar at a luncheon on board the French cruiser Montcalm given by the President to Nicholas II., have been sent out by correspondents.

The boss and journeymen barbers, said to exceed 80,000 in this State, including more than 5,000 bosses in this city, want to organize" The Barbers' Society of the State of New York." Determined efforts will be made to secure a charter from the next Legislature. The attempt failed by two votes in 1901, after passing one house.

The general opinion yesterday of brokers who have the lion's share of private real estate dealings is that considering that the week was the third in June its transactions in private sales were important and of notable volume.

FOR years the lack of symmetry and historical significance in the arrangement of the stars on the blue field of our National flag has been a subject of comment among observing patriots. Fourteen years ago J.R. Stahlnecker of Silverton, Col., commenced working out the idea, but never arrived at a satisfactory solution until recently, when a design was evolved, and the question of its adoption will be brought before Congress.

George Angemeier, manager of the Althol Chemical Company, who lived at 246 Third Street, Jersey City, died in the City Hospital there on Friday under circumstances peculiar in themselves, but rendered more so in view of the information that he figured prominently in one of the great murder mysteries which have baffled the police of this city in the last quarter of a century.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The communication of "Civis" in this morning's issue of THE TIMES prompts an indorsement of the general idea therein expressed regarding the nuisances and dangers encountered in our city streets on account of the small boys and their games of ball, tip cat,

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Despite the lateness of the season and absence of the majority of fashionable folk, there have been quite a number of card parties and luncheons and a few dances this week. The university commencement is over, and its social features were probably more brilliant than ever before.

NOME, June 7 (via Seattle.) -- The steamer Portland, Capt. Lindquist, the pioneer of the Northern Commercial Company's fleet, was on June 4 caught in the ice pack, and is being carried up Bering Straits to the Arctic Ocean at the rate of from two to three miles an hour.

The poor of New York City will be benefited by the generosity of Mrs. A.A. Anderson, who has purchased the property at 825 and 327 East Thirty-eighth Street, where she will erect large bathhouses after the razing of the old buildings there now. The baths are to be thrown open to the needy, particularly of the east side.

OLD FORGE, N.Y., June 21 -- The improvement of hotels and cottages along the Fulton Chain of Lakes this Spring has been conspicuous. Incidental to changes at some of the hotels are the inaugurations of new managers. The Arrow Head, which was opened on June 16, is now under the management of Frederick V. Wishart of the Lorraine, New York, and F.M. Warner, also of the Lorraine, New York.

UTICA, N.Y., July 21 -- Business in the United States District Court for the Northern District is practically tied up because of the promotion of Judge A.C. Coxe to the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judge Coxe qualified as an Appeals Judge about one week ago.

When Prince GEORGE, the second son of King JOHN of Saxony, entered Dresden with his bride from Portugal, more than forty years ago, amid the plaudits of the Saxons, he little thought that one day he would be King in his father's place, as little as Prince WILLIAM of Prussia imagined that he would follow his father so soon on the throne as German Emperor.

The plan to revive the importance of London as a port by large expenditures for wharf facilities and for deepening the channels of approach, is likely to lead to some disappointment. Commerce is a fickle jade, with a will of her own, and not easily caught in traps which may be spread for her extremely wary feet.
TUESDAY, JUNE 24 -- By Vincent A. Ryan, public auction sale, 103 West Forty-second Street, north side, 40 feet west of Sixth Avenue, four-story and basement brick and brownstone dwelling, 20 by 75.4.

The Ladies' Anti-Beef Trust Association is divided against itself. With the idea of reporting on the progress made, the members of the Committee of Fifteen appointed recently to decide upon a definite plan of action met at 83 and 85 Forsyth Street last evening. The meeting was stormy and was adjourned without much having been accomplished.

MRS. GEORGE B. WILSON of 4,228 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, has the finest collection of orchids in America. The years she has been interested in orchid farming do not exceed ten, yet to-day her collection is valued at $300,000, and botanists from all over the world go to see it.

THE destruction of St. Pierre has solved a mystery for the cowboys of the Rio San Francisco Valley, in New Mexico. Ever since the capture of Geronimo permitted the cattlemen to occupy the extreme western part of this Territory, the cowboys have been digging for pottery in the homes of an extinct race of Indians that once lived along the Rio San Francisco.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 21 -- Serious to this place as was the Arcade fire of June 9, involving a loss of $300,000 and the death of five persons, who were suffocated, yet at the same time it was comparatively small compared with some of the sensational reports published in many newspapers outside of this town.

LONDON, June 21 -- A brisk business was done this week at Lloyd's in the coronation gamble. The odds given were 300 to 1 against the event occurring, or, to use the technical expression, the rates on the risk of the King living until June 26 ruled at 8 per cent, premium. Many thousands of pounds sterling were underwritten on this basis.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- United States Consul R.E. Mansfield, writing to the State Department from Valparaiso. Chile, speaks of the proposed law in that country affecting foreign insurance companies as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Nearly all the life displayed by the market in Philadelphia to-day was supplied by United States Steel and Consolidated Lake Superior preferred, both of which showed de- cided improvement, but failed to arouse other branches of the market. All the animation was in the first hour.

The Edgewater Creche is in need of donations for its Summer work, and it trusts that all who have sympathy for the chil- dren confined to the city during the heated term will contribute to its work. Tickets for the creche can be had by applying to the Charity Organization Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

A member of the City Council of Seattle, Washington, urges that licenses be required for ping-pong tables. Members of the social clubs of the city do not share his enthusiasm over this plan to increase the municipal revenues.

IN the Aquarium, but kept where they cannot be seen by the general public, are two species of the fish family that, if placed on view in the Aquarium proper, would no doubt be among the most interesting sights to be seen in New York's piscatorial home. The two species referred to are both of foreign origin, one kind being a native of Japan and the other of the East Indies.

A PARTY of legal lights who are addicted to the sport rendered famous by the gentle Isaak Walton were lunching recently at the Lawyers' Club and the post-prandial conversation glided from fish yarns to the sea serpent, and thence by easy stages to the subject of snakes in general.
Wall Street revels in an enigma. Why has James R. Keene gone to Europe?

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., June 21 -- Manager B.L. Brown of Hotel Champlain, Bluff Point, has arrived at the hotel, and preparations are being made for the formal opening of the hotel on July 1. All of the six cottages on the hotel grounds have been rented, H.G. Runkie of Plainfield, N.J., being one of the cottagers as usual.

"There is a pathetic side to the industrial history of South and Central American countries," said a gentleman who has spent some time down in that section of the world, "and it relates to a very interesting element of the population, an element which has crossed over the border for errors committed on this side, an element made up of fugitives from American justice.

LONDON, June 21 -- It is whispered that Wertheimer's check to John Sargent for recent portraits of certain members of his family amounted to $50,000, in addition to which the artist's fame has been greatly advanced by the wonderful quality of the work.

Henry B. McDowell, President of the United States Trust Company of Philadelphia, who is wanted by the Philadelphia authorities on a charge of embezzling funds of the Trust Company to the extent of $50,000, did not show up at his offices, 55 Liberty Street, in this city yesterday.

The sculptor Thomas Ball, whose colossal statue of Daniel Webster stands in Central Park, has passed his eighty-third birthday. On his return from Florence he settled at Montclair, N.J. Mr. Ball is writing a sequel to his autobiography. "My Three Score Years and Ten," which appeared more than a decade ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to a paragraph appearing on the editorial page of your issue of the 17th inst., in which you ask for evidence in proof of the veracity of the statements recently made by the Catholic societies of New Jersey concerning the management by Protestant clergymen of our new public school system in the Philippines.

OMAHA, Neb., June 21 -- The Union Pacific Railway is threatened with a general strike in the mechanical department of the road. To-day, as the 800 men employed in the shops at Omaha filed into the paymaster's office, they were met with a long list, containing 225 names, more than 25 per cent, of their total number, who were discharged.

IN the course of excavation for the new sewer along the line of Fort Washington Avenue the workmen opened out this week a large number of human bones as they approached the line of One Hundred and Eighty-first Street. This part of the avenue is partly filled-in ground, and after going down through about six or eight feet of loose material the original soil was reached, under which the bones were found.

Ong Sing Lee invaded the territory of the Greek and Italian pushcart men yesterday afternoon, and did a lively business. The coming of the celestial created the greatest consternation and surprise. Greek asked Greek if it were possible that their supremacy in the pushcart business was to be wrested by Chinamen from them.

LONDON, June 21 -- "The King's London," the metropolis is now assuredly, With trade, locomotion, and legislation blocked by preparations for the great pageantry for the glorification of EdWard VII., and, despite the feeling of exhilaration which possesses the multitude and the signs of holiday making on every hand, one may safely assert that the present generation will never have another coronation like unto this.

Golf activity went on merrily yesterday at the links of the Englewood Golf Club despite the rain. No less than four competitions were decided, and in the regular club handicap for the Mackay Cups there were twenty-seven members who returned full cards. The scores were very good, considering the soggy nature of the greens and the heavy rain through, which the early afternoon competitors had to play.

LENOX, Mass., June 21 -- The greatest social event to take place in Lenox this season will be the Field-Sloane wedding. Mr. and Mrs. Sloane made so much of an event of the marriage of their eldest daughter, Adele, to Abercrombie Burden, Jr., that the cottagers and the society people of New York are anticipating with much interest the marriage of the youngest daughter, Miss Lila Vanderbilt Sloane, to William Osgood Field.

RAILROAD NOT NEGLIGENT IN FRIGHTENING A HORSE NINETY-FIVE FEET AWAY -- While Walter L. Lampman was sitting in his wagon ninety-five feet from a New York Central Railroad crossing waiting for a friend, an approaching train frightened his horse so that it ran towards the crossing and was struck by the train.

An Irish foreman of the Italian laborers working on the subway circle in City Hall Park named a big, tiger-colored cat, which appeared in the park with the coming of the birds in the early Spring, General De Wet. He said that he christened him for the Boer leader as the cat had a great greed for English sparrows, and it was marvelous the great numbers which he managed to capture and devour.

As the result of a complaint made by Joseph Hurmans, 419 Brook Avenue, who said he had lost 530 in the place, Acting Captain Dillon and Detectives Black, Flynn, and Underbill of the West Thirtieth Street Station visited the alleged gambling house at 17 West Twenty-fourth Street last night, arrested four men, and captured considerable gambling paraphernalia.

One of the singular results of the reform administration in New York has been the stimulation beyond all records of the industry of manufacturing gambling tools because the new conditions have demanded udden changes in the furniture of gambling houses. The demand for gaming paraphernalia now requires that tools be light and portable, with a marked preference for appliances that are constructed on the main feature of the folding bed.

LONDON, June 21 -- Money was in active demand to-day for the settlement. Discounts strengthened on the treasury bills allotment and the weakness of Paris exchange. Business on the Stock Exchange was practically at a standstill, apart from the arrangements for the carry-over. Giltedged securities were fairly steady.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 22. -- That Knox County abounds in oil in paying quantities is now a certainty. Stinking Creek, the seat of extensive oil operations at present, was the first section of the Knox County oil fields to be developed.

It is the understanding that ex-President Cleveland's principal purpose in attending the opening of the Tilden Club in this city last Thursday was to advance the Gubernatorial prospects of ex-Secretary of War Daniel S. Lamont, who is now in Labrador.

Fred Gebhard of this city won the fiftymile championship handicap cycle road race of the New York State Division of the Century Road Club of America, held over the Merrick Road, between Springfield and Bellmoro. yesterday afternoon, by less than two lengths, from Charles Lundberg, who was second.

The cable made him an Austrian, but it seems that it was in fact "a well-known American jurisconsult who is now traveling on the Continent" that recently gave to the Vienna correspondent of The London Times his enlightened views of the American trusts. He tried to give comfort to the scared Europeans by showing that we were worse scared:

Louis H. Ayme, United States Consul at Guadeloupe, who represented this country at Fort de France, Martinique, during the period following the destruction of St. Pierre, arrived yesterday from San Juan on the Red D Line steamship Caracas. He was accompanied by Capt. Yates Stirling, Commandant of the naval station at San Juan.

CLEVELAND, June 22. -- The Rev. Father Camillus, C.F.M., celebrated his fiftieth anniversary as a priest here to-day in St. Joseph's Church. He celebrated mass, assisted by Father Benedict of St. Louis and Father Andrew of Quincy, Ill. Father Hugolinus Storff, Provincial of the Franciscans of St. Louis, preached the sermon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 22. -- "The devastations of war have cost many lives and the loss among the natives has no doubt been large, but when one takes into consideration the hundreds of thousands of lives that have been saved by reason of the sanitary precautions of the American Army and Civil Commission, that loss by war seems infinitesimal."

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The sessions of the Senate during the present week will be devoted to odds and ends of legislation. It was the purpose of the Republican steering committee to make the Cuban Reciprocity bill the order of business after the disposition of the Interoceanic Canal bill, but the two Republican conferences have rendered it evident that there could be no reciprocity legislation this session, so the steering committee has abandoned its purpose.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 22. -- Deputy Postmaster Henry H. Reynolds is missing from the village. He apparently left the village on Friday morning without saying where he was going, and no word has been received from him by either Postmaster John McNally or Mrs. Reynolds. He had been connected with the Post Office for eight years.

The explosion of a firecracker, thrown by a careless boy in Twelfth Street, near Fifth Avenue, yesterday morning, caused a runaway accident in which two men were injured. The firecracker exploded under a milk wagon while Benjamin F. Stage of 415 East Fifty-first Street was delivering milk at 17 West Twelfth Street at about 8 o'clock.

The Senate now has before it a bill already passed by the House for the admission into the Union "on an equal footing with the original States" of the Territories of New Mexico, Arizona, and Oklahoma. In the House a vain attempt was made to annex the Indian Territory to Oklahoma and admit them both as one State.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Usually President Roosevelt can ride from one end of Pennsylvania Avenue to the other without awakening the least curiosity from the passing public since they are so accustomed to seeing him mounted for riding. However, he unconsciously attracted a great deal of attention as, he headed a curious cavalcade coming down Pennsylvania Avenue the other day.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 22. -- The baccalaureate address at Yale was delivered this morning in Battell Chapel by President Hadley. Many graduates were present, as well as the usual commencement throng of visitors and friends of the senior classes. The Rev. Dr. Timothy Dwight, ex-President of the university, pronounced the benediction.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 22. -- Bright skies and a breeze from the bay made this day one of the most enjoyable of the season at the camp. It was the last Sunday of the encampment, and about 1,200 visitors came in during the afternoon. At evening parade the bluff was lined with vehicles.

Tribute was paid to the memory of Amos J. Cummings by a large gathering at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The meeting was held under the auspices of Typographical Union No. 6, of which Mr. Cummings was a member. The great hall was nearly filled. On the platform were seated the speakers and representatives of the typographical union and other labor organizations.

-- That book reviewing, as done for the dally papers -- we will not speak of, and cannot speak for, the weekly and monthly press -- has certain faults of method and certain weaknesses of result will be questioned by none, and least of all, perhaps, by the men and women who do the reviewing, since they know best the conditions under which the work has to be performed.
LONDON, June 23. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Shanghai says that the Chinese cruiser Kai-Chih was sunk yesterday by a terrific explosion while lying in the Yang-tse River.

LONDON, June 23. -- The reappearance yesterday of brilliant sunshine after weeks of rain and murky weather, gave to the first day of coronation week an air of unusual gayety, and gladdened the hearts of the thousands of British subjects from all parts of the empire and the thousands of foreigners who are pouring into London eager to witness as much of this week's events as possible.

There was no lack of good sport on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning, although the amateur reinsmen were somewhat late in putting in an appearance with their fast steppers, and the best and most exciting brushes of the day took place about the time drivers and spectators usually start for home.
What is known as a "common" jury was empaneled recently in Mr. Justice Bigham's Court. It was really a most uncommon one.

There is nothing American about which foreigners are fonder of making merry than our weakness for "Old Glory." Readers of foreign prints know that tourists from this side the Atlantic are chaffed or mobbed on the other side for wearing it in miniature in their buttonholes.

MOXLEY, Ky., June 22. -- Joplin mining experts are of the opinion that the lead mining development in Kentucky, at present not the largest, is by far the most important new field in sight, and as a result the State will be thoroughly tested as to its lead producing qualities. In none of the many lead fields is the mineral found in as rich a percentage as in the Kentucky field near Gratz and Moxley.

Among the features of THE SUNDAY TIMES yesterday were cablegrams telling about the coming coronation of the British King. Edward A. Dithmar, THE TIMES'S special correspondent, described the condition of London on the eve of the great event, and told about the American society representation in that city, its personnel, and plans.

PORTLAND, Oregon, June 22. -- A fire that started shortly before midnight last night in the Phoenix Iron Works, formerly the Wolff Zwicker plant, burned for four hours and destroyed six blocks of buildings, valued at $600,000. The insurance amounted to about $200,000. It was long after daylight before the fire burned itself out.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 22. -- Prof. William H. McDonald, sixty-five years of age, was killed instantly this morning by a train on the Lehigh Valley Railroad, between Lyons Farms and Roselle. He was an authority on botany, and he had been out in the woods gathering specimens of flowers and plants.

PATERSON, N.J., June 22. -- This has been an excedingly quiet day. The fine weather caused a large portion of the citizens to take trips to resorts, and, although there were many visitors from out of town attracted to see the soldiers on duty, there was nothing like a crowd gathered at any point during the day.

BERLIN, June 22. -- Transactions on the Boerse have grown so light that operators are agitating for shorter hours. Some demand that the Boerse close at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, while others ask that it be closed two or three days a week through the months of July and August.

The wonders of press-agent performances are without limit. A new agent has been engaged at the Casino, and his first story came out yesterday. According to him, fire drills, in which chorus girls will take part, are to be a Sunday feature at the Casino until such time as they learn to work well and are in a condition to protect the theatre.

The second and final series of a match of eleven games between Daniel Bruder of Harrison, N.J., and Edward Hopkins of Jersey City for the championship of New Jersey and a stake of $50, was played at Tarrant's Court in Jersey City yesterday and resulted in a tie, each winning three of the six games played.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 22. -- The first attempt made by the Toronto Street Railway Company to run its cars with men hired to take the places of the striking motormen and conductors was met with violence. Only one effort was made to reopen the traffic, and the temper shown by the strikers and their sympathizers convinced the officials that it would be impossible to run cars without strong protection.

Police Captain Creeden of the East Eighty-eighth Street Station soon after midnight Saturday, accompanied by Detectives Huntress, Wilbur, McCauley, and Gargens of his staff, made a tour of his precinct for the purpose of arresting any violators of the excise law. At the corner of Eighty-fourth Street and Second Avenue, a saloon owned by Sylvester Bernhauser, they found the front door closed, but heard talking and laughter on the inside.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- The Pittsburgs and the local baseball team to-day played a record-breaking game for extra innings this season. The game was full of pretty plays, remarkable catches and throws, and, considering its length, the errors were not many Pittsburg batted Taylor hard in the second and third innings, but could do nothing more with him.

A little before midnight last night Thomas McCue, conductor on a Fifth Avenue (Brooklyn) trolley car, discovered lying on the track about a quarter of a mile from the Sea Beach Palace station, Coney Island, a man bleeding and unconscious. A hasty examination showed that the man's arm was severed from the body, his face badly cut, besides other injuries, including probably broken bones.

Stowaways often find odd hiding places, but Bozo Gicano, a well-built, bright-looking young Dalmatian who came over on the Cunarder Umbria, which arrived in port yesterday, discovered the queerest of them all.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 22. -- The victorious Cornell crews and the others that were not victorious left on the West Shore Railroad for their homes to-day.

ALBANY, June 23. -- Gov. Odell to-day, at the request of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Department, ordered an extraordinary trial term of the Supreme Court to be held in Richmond County, beginning Monday, July 21, and has designated Justice William J. Gaynor of Brooklyn to hold the extra trial term.

Two polo teams from Squadron A met yesterday on the big field at Van Cortlandt Park, and one of the largest crowds other than is seen on Saturday watched the sport. The competing teams were the regular Squadron A quartet and the Freebooters. The former had its full strength out, with the exception of H.M. Earle as back, R.C. Lawrence taking his place.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 23. -- At the meeting of the Trustees of Williams College to-day the announcement was made that Francis Lynde Stetson, '57, of New York City had given $50,000 in United States Steel Corporation preferred stock, the income to go toward increasing the salaries of professors.

The buyer of the seven-story apartment house the Melrose, at the northwest corner of Central Park West and One Hundred and Eighth Street, 100 by 100, was Alonzo B. Kight. The deal was part of the trade in the Barnard apartment house, at the southwest corner of Central Park West and Seventy-first Street.

LONDON, June 24. -- From yesterday the Special Ambassadors, Envoys, and Princes invited to join in the coronation festivities became the guests of King Edward. Numbers of royal personages arrived from the Continent. All of them were met at the Tailroad stations by royal carriages and guards of honor, and were escorted to the official residences assigned to them.

The statement of President MITCHELL presenting the cause of the striking anthracite miners for public judgment is interesting in many ways. It shows that the issues of the strike are narrowed down to the one question of a just accounting to the miners for the coal they win, and warrants the statement that if this grievance was corrected the obstacles to resumption could be overcome without friction and in a very short time.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- It is not impossible nor even improvable that the differences between the two houses of Congress with relation to the Isthmian canal may be speedily adjusted. The conferrees of the House and Senate come together to-morrow at 11 o'clock for the first time, and it would not be an astonishing thing if before they separated they should practically reach an agreement.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- A speech which, in the opinion of many of the beet sugar Republicans of the House, was deliberately designed to aid in the defeat of a Republican Congressman in the State of Washington and his replacement by a Democrat, was to-day delivered in the House of Representatives by one of the Republican leaders, Gen. Grosvenor of Ohio.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. June 23. -- John Koellmer, ex-Receiver of Taxes in New Rochelle, who was indicted in February last by the Westchester County Grand Jury for the alleged misappropriation of $7,000 of the funds of the City of New Rochelle, was placed on trial before County Judge Platt to-day.

Detectives from the Tenderloin Police Station raided a poolroom at 516 Sixth Avenue about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, where they found a crowd of elderly women, some of whom are said to be the wives of Sixth Avenue shopkeepers. Six who had been seen to place bets were arrested.

It was very plausibly reported, when the Russian occupation of Manchuria was a "burning question," that one of the considerations Russia grave to China for continuing the occupation was an assurance that Russia would resist the efforts of other Powers to impair the integrity of China in other quarters.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23. -- Francis M. Carpenter, County Treasurer of Westchester County, to-day filed his report on the estate of Julia A. Shaw of Mamaroneck, late owner of the Grand Union Hotel, for the purpose of assessing and fixing the State transfer tax. As the personal estate of Mrs. Shaw only is taxable, the report does not give the value of the real estate.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 23. -- The absence of W.J. Bryan from the Democratic harmony dinner at New York is pretty well explained by a statement given out by Mr. Bryan this evening, commenting on the dinner.
LONDON, June 24. -- King Edward and Queen Alexandra arrived in London from Windsor yesterday. His Majesty appeared to walk somewhat heavily, but showed few traces of his recent illness.

"When quality meets, compliments fly." It was altogether natural and proper that, when Count VON WALDERSEE, at Lord ROBERTS'S hospitable board, referred so handsomely to Lord ROBERTS'S own achievements and to those of the British Army in South Africa, the host should have sought an occasion of reciprocal compliment.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 23. --- It was reported here to-night that the Delaware Lackawanna and Western, the Delaware and Hudson, and the Scranton Coal Companies are jointly making up a roll of names of men who have applied for work for the purpose of operating one or two collieries within the near future.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Consideration of the Philippine Civil Government bill was resumed by the House to-day, and Mr. De Armond (Mo.) made a general speech in opposition to the policy of retaining the islands. He repudiated utterly the charge that the opposition to the present Philippine policy, in criticising some of the acts of army officers in the Philippines, was slandering and assailing the army.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. S.B. French and Mrs. French's mother, Mrs. Walker Fearn, arrived to-day at the Lorillard-Spencer cottage, Halidon Hill, for the Summer.
New York's baseball team made a poor showing at Washington Park yesterday, and the Brooklyns had little trouble in winning. The score was 8 to 1.
LONDON, June 24. -- The enormous and growing crowds and the babel of foreign tongues in London may perhaps be considered so far to be the most striking features of the coronation festivities.

GOOD GROUND, L.I., June 23. -- Coroner John Nugent, who came here from his home in Southampton this morning to attend Miss Gracie Poster, the sixteen-year-old sister of Clarence Foster, who was drowned in Tlana Bay on June 9, and who is dangerously ill at her home suffering from pneumonia, said that his patient's condition was not as good as yesterday.

Fifth Avenue, from One Hundred and Eighteenth Street north to One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, was the scene of an exciting automobile chase shortly before 9 o'clock last night, in which Bicycle Policeman Hanley finally ran down and captured a large black machine, owned by Mrs. Arabella D. Huntington, widow of Collis P. Huntington, the railroad magnate, who occupies the Huntington mansion, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.

SEA GIRT, N.J., June 23. -- The partially completed rifle range caved in at 6 o'clock this evening, catching three men, who were trying to escape, between the toppling front walls and the rear wall of a butt, and crushing them to death instantaneously.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Out of 129 candidates for appointment as Assistant Surgeons in the army, only eighteen have passed the examinations recently held. The Surgeon General of the army is greatly disappointed at the showing of the doctors, and almost despairs of filling the vacancies now existing by the Autumn, when the services of a number of young surgeons should be available to relieve those whose terms of duty have expired in the Philippines.

Francis J. Scully, who has been identified for the past thirty-three years with the foreign money exchange bureau, now at Ellis Island and formerly at Castle Garden, and held the money privilege in his own name for the past six years, was dismissed from the bureau yesterday afternoon by Secretary Shaw of the Treasury Department, acting on the recommendation of Commissioner Williams of the Bu- reau of Immigration.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- With the exception of the Readings, stocks in the Philadelphia market were neglected. Diamond State Steel and Tidewater Steel made slight gains. Philadelphia Rapid Transit was entirely ignored, as were other stocks which as a rule are more or less active. Most of the buying of Reading was said to be for New York account.

If the members of the present graduating class of Yale University pay heed to the injunctions of President HADLEY'S baccalaureate address they will never set the world on fire or hitch their wagons to the stars of heaven. If we at all catch the meaning of the address President HADLEY thinks the highest duty of man is to be commonplace and uninteresting.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 23. -- The first session of the Summer conference of the Presbytery of New Brunswick at Lawrenceville this week was opened to-day. The chief feature of the meeting this afternoon was an, address by the Rev. Dr. L. W. Mudge of Princeton on "The Solution of the Vacancy and Supply Problem."

Evidence in behalf of Sergt. James Churchill was elicited yesterday from Guido Bock and William Reich, who were his Wardmen in the Fifth Street Station, at his trial before Commissioner Partridge for alleged neglect of duty.

LONDON, June 24. -- Whitelaw Reid, the Special Ambassador of the United States at King Edward's coronation, began a busy Week yesterday. During the afternoon he made a round of official calls at the Embassies in a royal carriage, accompanied by Lieut. Col. Sir Fleetwood Isham Edwards, extra Equerry to his Majesty, who is in special attendance on Mr. Reid.
The plan for converting the securities of the Distilling Company of America has just been issued.

LONDON, June 23. -- There was a good inquiry for money to-day. Discounts were firm. There is some doubt, owing to the condition of the Continental exchange rates, as to whether all the gold arriving will reach the Bank of England.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23. -- The jury in the suit brought by Horace Crosby against the New York Central Railroad for $100,000 damages for the death of his son, Franklin Crosby, one of the victims of the Park Avenue Tunnel accident last Winter, rendered a sealed verdict this morning before Supreme Cuort Justice Wilmot M. Smith.

Officials of the coal-carrying companies who were seen here yesterday said that the reply of President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers to their recently published statement giving their side of the cause leading up to the strike was altogether misleading. The statement that they had raised the price of coal $1 per ton since the strike was denied.
For the classification of salaries of clerks employed in Post Offices for the first and second classes.

Less than 500,000 shares made up the total of yesterday's Stock Exchange business. Commission house transactions were relatively small. The room trading contingent, supplementing the work of half a dozen manipulative pools, were responsible for pretty much the entire day's record.

Except in a few of the copper stocks trading in the outside market yesterday was very limited. There were, however, several events of interest, the most notable being the sharp advance in the price of the bonds of the United Railways Company of San Francisco. Prices for the most part were firm, nearly all of the changes of importance being on the side of advances.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Negotiations have been finally concluded whereby the Postal Telegraph Company will secure the 3,500 offices and all the lines owned by the Pennsylvania Railroad now operated by the Western Union. The Postal will take possession of the offices on Jan. 1, when the Western Union will be compelled to give up all of the trunk lines on the property of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

BOSTON, June 23. -- Money rates generally are still easy and there appears to be an ample supply of money to meet the present meagre requirements. Sterling exchange is quiet and steady. Clearing House rate 3 1/2 per cent. New York funds par and 5 cents premium. Call loans 3 to 4. Time money 4 to 5.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

PITTSBURG, June 23. -- An important decision was handed down by Judge Buffington in the United States Circuit Court in the case of the Pressed Steel Car Company vs. John M. Hanson. The company had asked for an injunction restraining Mr. Hanson from disposing of six patents and applications for patents.

BALTIMORE, June 23. -- Money on call was at 4 1/2 and 5 per cent. The market was very active and higher. United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company's stock made a grain of 5 1/2 points over Saturday's price. The stockholders of the Lawyers' Surety Company, who took the stock of the United States Fidelity and Guaranty at 169, are supposed to be buying in this market at the lower figure.

The recent speech of Lord GOSCHEN on the subject of British credit is attracting general and respectful attention on the Continent. The position of the speaker is one of much authority. He was one of the greatest of Finance Ministers, disputing the first rank with GLADSTONE. He is a successful banker, and he is widely known as a student of political finance, the difficult and complex finance of great nations.

The final heat in the trotting race between E.E. Smathers's green mare Queen Wilkes and Nathan Straus's bay gelding Alves (2:09 1/2) came off yesterday afternoon on the Harlem River Speedway, in the presence of a large gathering of horsemen and spectators.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- New York exchange was 25c. premium; time and call loans 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Local stocks were quiet, and for the most part altogether uninteresting. Pneumatic Tool opened off another point, at 103, a decline of 4 1/2 points from the price shown a few days ago, and later in the day dropped to 101 on a 50 above sale.

District Attorney Jerome starts this morning on a three weeks' vacation. He goes first to Amherst, where he will deliver an address to the students of his Alma Mater. He then goes to Denver, and from there to Colorado Springs, where he will deliver an address to the Bar Association of Colorado on July 3. From there he will go to Chicago, where he expects to visit the stockyards.

LONDON, June 24. -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times says Robert S. McCormick, the United States Ambassador to Austria-Hungary, will probably present his credentials to the Emperor Soon after his Majesty's return from Dresden.
Well Mayer have sold for about $57,000 the newly completed seven-story apartment house 206 East Twenty-first Street, 30 by 92.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 24. -- Four hits, a base on balls, and two errors gave the Jersey City baseball team five runs in the fourth inning to-day. Laroy relieved Amote and pitched good ball during the remainder of the game. Barnett held Buffalo down to seven scattered hits. Score:

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The Secretary of State, Mrs. Hay, and Miss Hay left Washington this morning for their Summer home in New Hampshire. They have a charming place on Lake Sunapee, and Miss Hay will entertain several house parties, composed of the girls of her set in Washington from time to time during the season.

It would be difficult to find in history anything like a parallel for the cruel disappointment of the British people. They were preparing to celebrate at the same time the accession of a new monarch and the return of peace to an empire which counts among its subjects and dependents almost a fourth part of the population of the globe.

A review of the literature of the coal strike, beginning with President MITCHELL'S announcement before the Hazleton convention and coming down to the comments of the operators on his belated and not quite ingenuous statement of the 22d inst., shows the utter futility of further discussion.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 24. -- A transfer involving probably $20,000,000 was completed here to-day, the Union Traction Company of this city, the Pawtucket Street Railway Company, and the Rhode Island Suburban Railway Company having become the property of the Rhode Island Company.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 24. -- Business meetings of various classes and the great annual gathering of the alumni occupied the early part of the second day of Yale's commencement season. The alumni meeting was held in Alumni Hall, Henry Holt of New York presiding, while representatives of each class made informal speeches.

LONDON, June 25. -- Lord Halsbury, the Lord Chancellor, telegraphed at a late hour yesterday to his fellow bencher, Sir Henry Lawrence, the Sub-Treasurer of the Inner Temple, that King Edward was gradually sinking.

The two big yawls Vigilant and Ailsa met for the second time this season in the race of the New York Yacht Club for the Glen Cove Cups yesterday on the Sound. For the first time they sailed a completed race, and Percy Chubb's Vigilant defeated Henry S. Redmond's Ailsa, crossing the finish line 36 minutes 17 seconds ahead of her rival.

According to Sir Frederick Treves, who performed the operation on King Edward, and himself one of the greatest living surgeons and specialists upon abdominal troubles, the chances of death in cases of perityphlitis where abscesses form, as in that of King Edward, are about one in three. The official bulletins say that the abscess in this instance was successfully evacuated.
NEWPORT, June 24. -- Goold H. Redmond has arrived at the Gables, Rhode Island Avenue, for the Summer.

PATERSON, June 24. -- A covered wagon drove up yesterday afternoon in front of a well known resort for Anarchists on Straight Street, near Essex Street, and a moment later half a dozen foreigners were busy carrying out heavy packages from a building in the rear of a Chinese laundry adjoining the Anarchists' rendezvous.

LONDON, June 25. -- All the royal Princes who came here for the coronation called personally on the Prince of Wales yesterday and bade him good-bye. The majority of them will leave London this morning for their respective countries.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Nearly $3,000,000 in personal property valuations will be realized through the increased assessments made against the various life, fire, accident, and casualty insurance companies doing business in Chicago if the figures decided upon by the Board of Assessors to-day stand the scrutiny of the Board of Review.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Not much notice was taken to-day of Mr. Bryan's attack on ex-President Cleveland. Members of Congress said the matter was not worth considering on the basis of what Mr. Bryan thought about the ex-President's plea for party harmony. It was of account simply because possibly it contained an intimation that Bryan was "doing business at the old stand," still claiming to be the party leader and dictator.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., June 24. -- W.T. Van Tuyl has left this village for good, according to a letter received by Floyd A. Overton, Cashier of the Patchogue Bank. The letter was dated at New York and asked Mr. Overton to take charge of his affairs. Mr. Van Tuyl had been a prominent resident of this place for twelve years.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 24. -- A notable wedding took place this afternoon at the residence of Mrs. Robert Stockton Green. The bride was Miss Caroline Seward Green, youngest daughter of the late Robert Stockton Green, formerly Governor of New Jersey, and the bridegroom Arthur Johns of New York, a grandson of the late Bishop John Johns of Virginia.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 24. -- Harvard defeated Yale this afternoon in the annual commencement baseball game. The defeat greatly dampened the enthusiasm which before the game began was as picturesque in expression as ever. Many of the classes that returned for reunions marched around the diamond fantastically headed by brass bands.

The fastest mile of the season was run at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday, by Clarence H. Mackay's stout-heart- ed mare Kamara, one of the best and truest mares on the turf last year and the year before.

Nobody that we know of has made an estimate of the amount of money which the coronation was expected to bring into London. But it must be something enormous. Although it has been reported that the expected expensiveness of London during coronation week has frightened away the ordinary and frugal American tourist, probably more American money has been already spent in London than in any previous season up to this time.

A start was made yesterday afternoon on the hearings in the case of the United States Government against Abraham S. Rosenthal and Martin L. Cohn. who are accused of fraud in the importation of Japanese silks during Wilbur F. Wakeman's incumbency as Appraiser of the Port.

LONDON, June 25. -- A brief notice has been published in The Gazette, as a result of which the entire state, social, and business arrangements throughout the country are paralyzed. The order is dated from the Earl Marshal's office, and reads as follows:

We have alluded to the awakening of the more intelligent minds on the Continent to the remarkable manner in which Great Britain has been able to stand the financial strain of the recent war. It is probable that a similar change will take place in public opinion as to the bearing of the war on the military power and efficiency of the British nation.

It is now a commonplace of political history that Great Britain is a "veiled republic" and that the function of the monarch in this ancient and powerful realm is one of great splendor and small practical effect. This is the accepted view that will occur to every one at this moment when the sovereign who has not yet been crowned is passing through a period of serious peril.

Taking of testimony for the defense continued yesterday in the case of Sergt. James Churchill, on trial before Commissioner Partridge on charges of neglect of duty, when Edward C. Beecherer told of his methods of fighting disorderly houses. Beecherer is a Sanitary Inspector in the Tenement House Department, and was an investigator for the Committee of Fifteen.

All Democrats should rejoice, most of them will, over W.J. BRYAN'S attack upon ex-President CLEVELAND. It is, we think, the most encouraging of the many hopeful signs of Democratic regeneration. It is a violent attack, and Mr. BRYAN has rarely if ever employed the language of violence and abuse against his enemies.

The San Francisco Street Railway bond episode continued to be the centre of interest on the curb yesterday. The price went up from 98 to 101 1/4, with hardly any transactions to speak of. Toward the close of the market $1,000,000 of these bonds were sold at 101 1/4, but the transaction was due to an effort on the part of Zimmermann Forshay to close out their contracts with various firms.

The stock market yesterday received a setback when at the opening it was confronted with the unexpected and unwelcome news of King Edward's illness. At the same time London sent over lower prices in this market, following them with some selling orders here to the total of about 25,000 shares.
LONDON, June 25. -- With dramatic suddenness the King has teen stricken down upon the eve of his coronation, and he is now lying in a critical state at Buckingham Palace.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- A cablegram from Ambassador Cboate, at London, to the State Department, received this morning, said that the coronation had been postponed indefinitely on account of the illness of the King. The message was taken to the President by Acting Secretary of State Hill, and the President laid it before the Cabinet, which was then in session.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The conferrees on the Canal bill did not reach an agreement to-day nor try to. They met and pleasantly talked over the situation, holding what might be called a preliminary meeting. One of the House conferrees said after the meeting was over that he believed the committee would come to an agreement tomorrow, and thus practically dispose of the canal question.

PEEKSKILL, State Camp, June 24. -- Had a house been situated up in the valley where a big white target looked like a speck against the hillside this afternoon, it would not have been very comfortable quarters. The First Battery fired eleven shots at that target; six took effect, and the other five did not go far wild.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- Reading was the only feature of the local market and practically all the trading in that issue was for New York account. During part of the time to-day Reading common could be bought here 1/8 cheaper than in Wall Street. United Gas opened 1/4 below yesterday and closed at 106 1/2, as against 107 yesterday.

Capt. Chapman, with twenty-five patrolmen in plain clothes from the Mercer Street, Leonard Street, and Elizabeth Street Stations, made a raid on the alleged poolroom of "The" Allen, at 80 Sixth Avenue, at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and captured twelve men, including Allen, six of whom were held under arrest at the station house charged with violating the law regarding poolrooms.

LONDON, June 25.--A medical writer in The Times calls attention to the lack of information which has been given to the public, as to whether the surgeons who operated on King Edward were able to do more than open the abscess and remove the accumulation of pus. It has not been stated, he remarks, whether the appendix and other structures which might contain germs from which future complications could arise were removed.

BOSTON, June 24. -- The money market continues dull. Clearing House rate, 3 1/4 per cent.; New York funds, par; call loans, 3 to 4; time money, 4 to 5; Clearing House exchanges, $20,685,531; balances, $1,592,582. The Copper stocks closed a fraction above the lowest prices of the day. Gas Securities were, however, leaders in activity and strength.

Capt. Charles G. Woodward, Artillery Corps, is relieved from duty as assistant to the recruiting officer at Milwaukee and will proceed to Columbus, Ohio, and assume charge of the recruiting station there to relieve First Lieut. Ezekiel J. Williams, Fifth Infantry.
GALE'S FERRY, Conn., June 24. -- The Yale 'Varsity oarsmen came down to Red Top early this afternoon on the launch Elihu Yale and paid their customary visit to the Harvard oarsmen.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Just as the obstacles in the path of an easy adjournment of Congress had been apparently smoothed away, a new trouble has arisen to confront the Republican leaders. It was predicted on all sides that their defeat at the hands of the beet-sugar men would encourage other Senators with grievances to flout them, and the prediction is already fulfilled.

GRAND ISLAND, Neb., June 24. -- Two State political conventions are in session here to-night, with no prospect of an adjournment at a late hour -- the Democratic and the Populist. At a conference of committees representing each it was agreed that each convention should ballot until the same candidate for Governor received a majority of the votes of both.

Justice Steckler, in Special Term. Part V., of the Supreme Court, handed down yesterday a decision of interest to owners of property along the lines of the Manhattan Elevated Railway and to real estate men generally.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 24. -- Intense sadness and disappointment have been caused here by the news of the illness of King Edward and the postponement of the coronation. All the preparations for the celebration at Kingston were completed, and a big loss is expected.
LONDON, June 24. -- There was considerable pressure on the money market to-day, notwithstanding further borrowings from the Bank of England and the renewal of all previous loans.

NEWPORT, June 24. -- The annual Rose and Strawberry Show of the Newport Hortiticultural Society, which opened here today, is of special interest to the Summer residents, because the exhibits are principally from the greenhouses of the Newport estates, and because of the rivalry between the gardeners to win for their employers the special prizes which are offered.

BOSTON, June 24. -- Suspected of the death of eleven persons, but indicted for murdering only three, Miss Jane Toppan, who was yesterday declared insane, has confessed that she has killed during her career as a professional nurse no less than thirty-one human beings.

LONDON, June 25. -- The work of demolishing the stands and all the paraphernalia prepared for the coronation pageant was in full swing late yesterday afternoon. Hundreds of workmen who in the morning were engaged in putting finishing touches on the various jobs were busily tearing down all that had taken weeks to accomplish.

LONDON, June 25. -- "Gus" Ruhlin of Akron, Ohio, defeated "Tom" Sharkey of New York in the eleventh round of their fight before the National Sporting Club to-night. The fight was held in connection with the coronation sporting tournament.
BRUNSWICK, Me., June 25. -- Thomas B. Reed of New York delivered the oration at the one hundredth anniversary celebration of the opening of Bowdoin College, which took place to-day.

PARIS, June 26. -- The great international automobile race from Paris to Vienna will start this morning at 3:30 o'clock from the village of Champigny, twelve miles east of Paris. The contestants in the Paris-Berlin automobile race last year were started from this same village.

LONDON, June 26. -- The exodus of the coronation embassies has already begun. The next two or three days will doubtless see the departure of all but one or two, and these will close np their official establishments and remain in London merely as private persons.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 25. -- The entire north central portion of Indiana was visited to-day by one of the most disastrous storms that ever swept over the State.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The last step but one in the Panama Canal's progress toward victory was taken to-day when the Conference Committee reported its agreement on the Senate bill, without amendment. It is expected to come up in the House as soon as the Philippine bill is out of the way, and when it does it will pass.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 25. -- Commodore E.C. Benedict saved a party of five young people from drowning near Oyster Bay yesterday afternoon during a squall which broke the mast of their catboat and half filled the boat with water. The men were pumping away steadily for two hours before they were rescued by the Commodore.

HAVANA, Cuba, June 10. -- The army of Cuba as a Republic is a very different one from that of Cuba as a Spanish colony. The neat-looking soldier of the Rural Guards, (the cavalry,) and the smart-looking member of the Cuerpo de Artilleria, (artillery corps.) remind one but little of the Cuban soldiers that I saw in the Winter of 1898-99.

Yesterday's Stock Exchange market was very narrow, total transactions falling much below 300,000 shares. Fluctuations for the most part were insignificant, only a few stocks showing net changes of as much as a whole point.

The will of the Rev. Eugene Augustus Hoffman, Dean of the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church, who died Tuesday, June 17, aboard a Delaware and Hudson train while en route to this city from Canada, where he had been on a vacation, was filled for probate in the Surrogates' office shortly before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

There have been sounds of hammering in the stillness of the night in the Criminal Courts Building that have caused many to wonder, according to Gus, the elevator man, "whether the spirits of those who have died while serving terms in Sing Sing do not sometimes come at night to knock on the marble heads of the caryatids in the corridors.
LONDON, June 26. -- Telegrams from all quarters of the empire tell of the canceling of proposed coronation celebrations, and the substitution of religious services for the festivities.

TRENTON, N.J., June 25. -- The United States Steel Corporation made its appeal to-day from the Vice Chancellor's decision forbidding it to convert its 7 per cent, preferred stock issue into 5 per cent, bonds before the Court of Errors and Appeals. R.V. Lindabury of Newark, counsel for the Steel Trust, sought to have the adverse decision in the chancery proceedings set aside.

ERIE, Penn., June 25. -- For the third time in twenty years ex-Gov. Robert E. Pattison of Philadelphia was nominated for Governor of Pennsylvania to-day by the Democratic State Convention. George W. Guthrie of Pittsburg was the unanimous choice of the convention for Lieutenant Governor, and James Nolan of Reading was nominated by acclamation for Secretary of Internal Affairs.

As the Iron steamboat Cepheus, returning with 1,300 members and friends of the Twelfth Assembly District Republican Club from Witzel's College Point Grove, where they had been on an outing, reached a point opposite Grand Street late last evening, she was run into by a large steam yacht, the bowsprit of which tore a hole in the side of her cabin, penetrating even to the saloon deck, which, however, it did not pierce.

BOSTON, June 25. -- Donovan was very erratic in to-day's baseball game, a wild pitch and a pass accounting for three of Boston's runs, while Long's throw into the bleachers was responsible for two Brooklyn tallies. Irwin's home run was a feature. Score:

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The Democrats of the House will meet in caucus Friday night to talk over the coming Congressional campaign. The particular matter to come under discussion is the outlining of a fight to be made against the tariff and the trusts.

PATERSON, N.J., June 25. -- In a quiet, orderly, and regular manner, in strong contrast with the violence of a week ago, the striking dyers' helpers this morning declared they wished a general strike of the silk workers of this city, and to-morrow night the matter will probably be finally decided by the General Committee of Twenty-four, representing all branches of the silk-working trade.

TRENTON, N.J., June 25. -- While the argument on the Steel Trust case was under way at the State House to-day a man clad in jeans invaded the courtroom and ascended to the bench where the august Justices were sitting and held up the Chief Justice for half a dollar.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Senator Quay has won his fight against the Senate leaders, and has secured from them an agreement with reference to the Statehood bill that is perfectly satisfactory to him. The capitulation was made in open Senate today, and it presented a most interesting spectacle.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- Judge Dallas, in the United States Circuit Court, to-day refused the application of the Brooklyn National League Baseball Club for an order restraining Catcher James McGuire of the Detroit American League team from playing with any organization other than the Brooklyn Club.

-- Only one safe deduction, apparently, can be drawn from the fact that the academic Faculty at Yale has refused to recommend twelve seniors for degrees, and that deduction is that at Yale there is complete, and, in cases of necessity, stern impartiality in the allotment of honors, and that they are given only to those who earn them.

The obligation devolving upon the anthracite operators to bring the present situation to an end by mining coal or arbitrating their differences with the miners is emphasized by the action of the latter in posting lists of men declared to be "unfair," as a means of subjecting them to the damage and discomfort of the boycott.

LONDON, June 26. -- King Edward's condition is even more satisfactory than has been indicated by the bulletins. He has made a, decided improvement, and the feeling at Buckingham Palace is very hopeful. His Majesty is able to take nourishment; he ate scrambled eggs and drank a little hock and soda last evening, and with his own hands he opened several telegram.
Kuhn, Loeb Co. announce that the $11,000,000 of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company's 4 per cent, refunding 100-year gold mortgage bonds, offered by them have been largely oversubscribed.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 25. -- Commencement at Harvard University, always an event which brings together a distinguished gathering, was of unusual interest to-day because of the presence of the President of the United States, Theodore Roosevelt, a graduate of Harvard, class of 1880, who was to receive the honorary degree of LL. D. from the university.
Six members of the Rapid Transit Commission, including the Mayor and Controller, met yesterday afternoon and transacted so much business that they did not adjourn until after 5 o'clock.

LONDON, June 26. -- King Edward is lying in his bedchamber in the palace in which he was born. His windows look out on the gardens, now in their fullest Summer bloom, and if any hint of the busy life of the world's metropolis reaches him it is only as a vague murmuring.

The unusual interest aroused within the last few days by the 10-point advance in the bonds of the United Railways Company of San Francisco subsided somewhat yes- terday, and in the rest of the list the day's developments were too commonplace to attract more than passing attention. Fewer stocks were dealt in than on Tuesday, and in many instances transactions in individual stocks showed a falling off from the previous day's figures.
LONDON, June 26. -- The British Medical Journal says:

The House conferrees have very wisely accepted the Senate Canal bill authorizing the purchase of the New Panama Canal Company's rights and the construction of a canal along that route. While Mr. HEPBURN was naturally disinclined to abandon his advocacy of the Nicaragua project, there was no reason why he should not submit as gracefully as Senator MORGAN has done.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- Rockaway won the first polo match to-day in the series for the Pembroke Cup, defeating the Philadelphia Country Club players at Bryn Mawr by the score of 6 3/4 goals to 3 1/2. G. G. McMurtry, Jr., was substituted for D. F. Savage, who was injured on Saturday last, and, being a two-goal man, the play started even, each team carrying an impost of 15 goals.

Before Magistrate Zeller there was a private hearing yesterday afternoon of County Detective Robert F. McLellan, charged with shooting James F. McCoy on June 2, when he and others raided the alleged poolroom at 152 and 154 East Forty-second Street. McLellan was represented by Louis L. Delafield and J. Jordan Rollins, Assistant District Attorneys Chadwick, Kresel, and Miner were present.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- At their regular meeting in the general offices of the company to-day the Directors of the Pennsylvania. Railroad approved of the agreement whereby the Postal Telegraph Cable Company will supplant the Western Union on the entire Pennsylvania system east of Pittsburg and Erie on Dec. 1, with the exception of a portion of the Buffalo and Allegheny Valley Division.
LONDON, June 26. -- Last night's issue of The Official Gazette contains a full list of the coronation honors. Among the names of the new baronets is that of Sir Thomas Lipton.

Lovejoy Noyes have sold for Mrs. S. Seabury Jones, for about $55,000, the fourstory and basement brownstone dwelling 712 Madison Avenue, 20 by 70. This property is on the westerly side of the avenue, 20 feet north of Sixty-third Street. There has been activity in this section recently, and it is meeting with the favor of many home seekers.

PITTSBURG, June 25. -- The United States Steel Corporation to-day began storing coal, A four-acre tract of land was cleared at Duquesne, and 200 cars of coal were dumped on it. Several hundred thousand tons will be deposited on the tract to be held in reserve should the bituminous coal miners answer the call of President Mitchell to come out in sympathy strike with the anthracite miners.

Mr. OXNARD denies that he had a bad quarter of an hour with the President Tuesday morning. The story ran that President ROOSEVELT told OXNARD with much plainness of speech that he intended to negotiate a commercial treaty with Cuba, and that the treaty would certainly be ratified at the next session of Congress, with the aid of Democratic votes, if need be.

PITTSBURG, June 25. -- The coal miners in the Central Pennsylvania district to-day failed to obey the order of President Gilday to stop work. The coal shipped from this district goes to the Atlantic Coast, with the exception of small quantities that go to Buffalo and Northern New York. The men have been working six days each week.
MONTREAL, Quebec, June 25. -- Sir Thomas Shaughnessy, President of the Canadian Pacific Railway, returned to-day from his trip of inspection, having covered over 7,500 miles.

BOSTON, June 25. -- On President Roosevelt's return to the Somerset this evening he was escorted to the Algonquin Club house, where a banquet was given in his honor by the Commandery of Massachusetts Naval and Military Order of the Spanish-American War. The guests besides the President were:

GRAND ISLAND, Neb., June 25. -- After twenty-four hours of almost continuous session the Democratic and Populist State Conventions completed a fusion ticKet this afternoon, with a Democrat at its head. Five places on the ticket were allotted to the Populists and three to the Democrats. They are as follows:

GALES FERRY, Conn., June 25. -- With the surface of the Thames none too favorable and the sky overcast, the crews of old Yale and fair Harvard had their final practice this evening, and the oarsmen are ready for the regatta of to-morrow. The atmosphere at both quarters indicates confidence with the feeling of hopefulness a trifle stronger at Broadview, where the Yale oarsmen are located.
