STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 25. -- The Seventy-first Regiment, was in the battle of Las Guasimas, Cuba, four years ago this next month. It celebrated the event last night as a farewell function of Camp Roe. The guardsmen met in front of Col. Bates's headquarters and had a good time.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 25. -- All danger of the great mass of sand known as Cooper's Bluff being dug away and shipped to New York has passed. Thirty-two acres of it to-day passed into the control of a syndicate supposed to be composed of the men who formed the North Shore Improvement Company a year ago and saved the rest of the bluff from being carted away.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 25. -- The Jersey City baseball team had a lead of one run in their half of the eighth inning to-day and had retired two of their opponents when a three-base hit by Connaughton, followed by two singles, brought in the winning run for Buffalo. Score:

LONDON, June 26. -- All day yesterday the vicinity of Buckingham Palace was invaded by anxious seekers after information. A curiously cosmopolitan crowd gathered about the railings awaiting the morning bulletin, and directly after it was posted there was a great scramble to read its contents.
LONDON, June 26 .-- Of the feeling in Parliament regarding the King's illness T. P. O'Connor, M. P., has written the following for The Associated Press:

KIEL, Germany, June 25. -- Ninety-five racing and fifty-two pleasure yachts are now lying in the roadstead here and awaiting the beginning of the regatta tar-morrow. There are also twenty-six men-of-war present, and the latter include eight German battleships. Emperor William is determined that the visitors to Kiel shall see the finest vessels of the new navy.

Plans were filed yesterday at the Bureau of Buildings for a new clubhouse at One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue for the Columbia Club, which is to cost $80,000. The architect is Oscar Lowinson. The building will be four stories high, and the base area of the property is 49,11 by 110.

BALTIMORE, June 25. -- Joshua Horner, trading as Joshua Horner, Jr., Co., dealers in fertilizers, made an assignment today for the benefit of his creditors to trustees, who gave bond in $150,000, Indicating estimated assets of about $75,000. The extent of the liabilities is yet to be ascertained.

Necessarily the circumstances of the time make the character and disposition of the new Prince of WALES matters of much keener public curiosity than they ever were before. The question what kind of man he is appeals with great force to all the British people, and with only less to the well wishers of the British people.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- The local market continues dull, but the small group of stocks that were traded in to-day regained their losses of yesterday, and the tone throughout was firm. The belief that the strike is losing ground exercised the same good effect on Reading that was seen in New York.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- Inexcusable errors gave the Philadelphia baseball team an easy victory over New York to-day -- errors that would shame even an amateur nine. Added to this, when the visitors started a batting rally in the eighth inning, Brodie took the heart out of the team by getting caught on the ancient trick of a player hiding the ball.

BAR HARBOR, Me., June 25. -- The North Atlantic Squadron will visit Bar Harbor some time during August. This announcement was made to-night at the meeting of the Bgard of Trade, as coming from Secretary Moody, who expects to accompany the fleet. Should Vice Admiral Bedford of the British squadron of the West Indian Station decide to accept the town's invitation to visit here this Summer the two squadrons will rendezvous together.

The scaling down of the appropriation asked by the Health Department for better provisions for dealing with contagious diseases in New York from $1,025,000 to $500,000 is undoubtedly a great disappointment to President LEDERLE and to the medical advisers of his department.
LONDON, June 25. -- There was a large demand for money to-day and discounts were steady.

The Bowery Savings Bank anu the Bank for Savings announced yesterday that on July 1 next each will distribute only 3 1/2 per cent in interest to depositors from the earnings of the last six months. Formerly each of these institutions paid 4 per cent., and there remain only three savings banks in this borough which still pay 4 per cent.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 23. -- Peter Brickelmaier of 333 East Eighty-fourth Street, New York, while attempting to board a fast freight train on the New York Central Railroad at Clyde slipped and fell under the trucks this morning. His left leg was severed at the knee and his right at the thigh.
LONDON, June 27. -- Only now is London beginning to realize the practical effects of the coronation postponement.

PATERSON, N.J., June 26. -- It was voted at the meeting to-night of the General Committee of Twenty-four, representing all branches of the silk-working trade, not to declare a general strike in sympathy with the striking dyers' helpers.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Several rulings have been published by the Treasury Department with reference to that part of the act of July 24, 1897, which provides for the free entry of works of art, the production of American artists residing abroad. Some of the rulings are as follows:
NEWPORT, June 26. -- Mrs. Hugh K. Norman will sail July 3 on the Hohenzollern to join Mrs. George H. Norman in Naples.

We called the other day for evidence to justify the charge, made at a convention of Roman Catholic societies held in Newark, that the new public schools in the Philippines are controlled by Protestant clergymen, and that these clergymen are using the schools as a means of changing the religious faith of the natives.

BERLIN, June 26. -- Dr. Sonnenberg, of the Berlin Charity Hospital, and Prof. Ernst von Bergmann of the medical faculty of Berlin University, have been interviewed concerning the condition of King Edward. Both agree that it is impossible to form any opinion of the King's condition from the bulletins because of their fragmentary character and the omission of the patient's temperature and pulse.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 26. -- Officials of the several large companies in this region are authority for the statement that men are applying to them daily for employment of any kind. Among the applicants are nearly all classes of workers, including miners, and it is said that nearly all the companies have more men to draw on than they can possibly need during the progress of the strike.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Admiral Dewey made a statement before the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day concerning the early operations at Manila, when he was in command of the American naval forces in Philippine waters. The Admiral's statement contributed an important addition to the history of the surrender of the City of Manila.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 26. -- The best sport thus far in the Newburg meet was in this, the third day's racing in the Hudson and Mohawk Valley circuit. There was an accident in the fifth heat of the second race. Aryean, Daltzell, Sergeant Burns, and Picolo went down in a heap and Driver Nichols was hurt.

The racing at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday fell into line with public form and was productive of about as many surprises as could be crowded into the compass of six races. Not the least of the surprises was the fact that one-half of the programme went to the popular favorites, for favorites have fared so ill in the past few days that a strong proportion of the regulars had lost confidence completely.

The Directors of the American Ice Company -- commonly known as the Ice Trustmet yesterday afternoon at the principal offices of the company, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street, and after a two-hour session made this announcement:

Mary Mulholland, daughter of Mrs. Mulholland, a widow living at Marion and Brookline Streets, Fordham, and Thomas Dunn, a young contractor of Webster Avenue and Cole Street in the same district, were married yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mercy in Webster Avenue.

ALBANY, June 26. -- The certificate of the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners, granting permission to the Pennsylvania, New York and Long Island Railroad Company to construct a tunnel railroad under the City of New York and under the East and North Rivers and to maintain a terminal station on Thirty-second Street, Manhattan Borough, was filed to-day with the Secretary of State.

PITTSBURG, June 26. -- Fifteen thousand employes of the United States Steel Company to-day received an increase in wages to the amount of 10 per cent. The increase was a complete surprise, as no prior announcement had been made. These men are employed in the mills at Braddock, Rankin, Duquesne, Carnegie, and in Pittsburg.

William R. Corwine, secretary of the Sub-Executive Committee of Five of the Executive Committee of the Associated Committees for the Relief of the West Indian Sufferers, yesterday submitted to Gustav H. Schwab, Chairman of the Executive Committee, a detailed report of his operations at Martinique, where he was sent for the distribution of supplies.

Assistant District Attorney Garvan received a telegram late yesterday afternoon from Columbus, Ohio, stating that Gov. Nash of that State had signed extradition papers, at the request of Gov. Odell, for the apprehension of William H. Hahn, who was Vice President of the insolvent Manhattan Fire Insurance Company, and who has been indicted in this county for grand larceny in the first degree.
LONDON, June 27. -- In most of the churches throughout the land yesterday the services which were to commemorate the coronation of King Edward took place in the changed form of intercessory services.

TRENTON, N.J., June 26. -- Gov. Murphy has signed the requisition for William McQueen, the English Anarchist, wanted in Paterson and now in the Tombs in New York. The papers have been sent to Gov. Odell for his signature.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The canal question is settled so far as Congress is concerned, the House to-day having adopted the Spooner amendment to the Hepburn bill. When the President shall have signed this bill it will be his duty to construct a canal as soon as the preliminary steps shall have been taken.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- At 8 o'clock to-night, at the end of a nine-hour session and of a debate lasting night and day for a week, the House passed the Philippine Civil Government bill practically as it came from the committee. It was a party vote, 141 -- 97, with the exception of Mr. McCall of Massachusetts, who voted with the Democrats.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- New York exchange to-day was quoted at 25 cents premium; time and call loans 4 1/2@5 per cent. Trading in local stocks was dull and quotations showed little change. Shortly after the opening there was a sale of Swift Co. stock at 124, which was about 4 points off from yesterday, t but there was some demand for the shares on the curb at this price.
LONDON, June 27. -- The exodus of foreign representatives who came here for the coronation proceeds apace.

PITTSBURG, June 26. -- The New York Central and Hudson River Railroad is seeking another entrance into this city, which will give it a more direct outlet to the East than it now has over the Pittsburg and Lake Erie by way of Youngstown, Ashtabula, Buffalo, and Rochester.

Dr. JOHN B. MURPHY, Dean of Rush Medical College, uses strong language in characterizing the 752 deaths from appendicitis in Chicago within the past three years as a "colossal crime." This characterization is based upon the somewhat startling assumption that if these 752 cases had been operated on in time they would all have been followed by gratifying recovery.

DOVER, N.J., June 26. -- Two accidents in No. 2 shaft of the Richard Mine, at Richard Mine, a mining settlement about two miles north of Dover, late this afternoon, resulted in the death of five men and the probable fatal injury of a sixth. The dead are:

The hearing of the charges against Abraham S. Rosenthal and Martin L. Cohn, comprising the firm of A. S. Rosenthal Co., that, as alleged, defrauded the Government out of large sums of money, was continued before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday. Special Assistant Attorney General W. Wickham Smith and Assistant United States District Attorney Houghton represented the Government, and ex-Judge Dittenhoefer represented the defendants.

PARIS, June 26. -- Girardot, Fournier, Edge, and Kniff were the first four starters in the international automobile race from Paris to Vienna, which was started at 3:30 o'clock this morning from the village of Champigny, twelve miles east of this city.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 26. -- Presi- dent Roosevelt arrived in New London from Boston at 3 o'clock this morning. His train was side tracked and he slept in the parlor car "Yale" until called at 7:30 o'clock for breakfast. As soon as was convenient he went out to the Dolphin, where he was welcomed by Mrs. Roosevelt and their children.

LONDON, June 26. -- From the most trustworthy sources it is learned that the operation on his Majesty King Edward VII. has been successful in all respects, and that no complications have declared themselves. The general medical opinion now is to the effect that ultimate recovery will be assured unless there be some unforeseen turn in present symptoms.

Justice Giegerich, in Part I. of the Supreme Court, yesterday listened to arguments for and against the granting of an injunction restraining the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners from proceeding further with the construction of the easterly tunnel of the Park Avenue section of the subway.

LONDON, June 27. -- Those around King Edward continue to be astonished at his rapid improvement. The slightly annoying symptoms mentioned in the bulletin issued at 11 o'clock last night are quite inconsequential compared to the fact, which The Associated Press has learned, that his Majesty again took food last night and was afterward allowed to smoke a cigar.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Senator Hanna said this evening that his expectation was that work would begin upon the Panama Canal at the earliest day possible. There would be no unnecessary delay, he was quite sure. As soon as the preliminary work was done active operations undoubtedly would begin at once, and as to the preliminaries it might safely be assumed that the President would proceed with promptness and energy.

After a lapse in all but competitions for the members since 1898, when the course was the venue of the United States Golf Association for the amateur championship, the Morris County Golf Club inaugurated yesterday a three-day invitation tournament. The morning was devoted to an eighteen-hole medal play round, with a gold medal for the lowest score.

Controller Grout stated yesterday that the city had decided to act as its own insurance company. For years the heads of some of the departments have insured much of the property under their charge. This was done in the Department of Docks and Ferries as long ago as 1851, and since then has paid many thousands of dollars in premiums.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- The local stock market remains firm and dull. There is so little business that it is impossible to judge of what is its trend. Philadelphia Rapid Transit to-day fell to 8 1/2 for the first time, and Philadelphia Company on small selling orders fell 1/4. Electric Storage Battery declined slightly, but United Gas Improvement was notably strong.

Miss Kathleen Neilson has been in town, and Mrs. James W. Gerard, Jr., is still here. Mrs. J.W. Gerard, Sr., has gone to Bar Harbor and opened her cottage there. Mrs. Frederic Edey has been running in often from Southampton, and at the luncheon hour and again at the dinner hour numbers of well-known faces are seen in the various fashionable restaurants.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- The statement of the coal and coke shipped on the Pennsylvania Railroad lines east of Pittsburg and Erie for the week ending June 21 shows that there were carried only 5,000 tons of anthracite coal, as compared with 92,812 tons for the corresponding period of 1901.

The President is almost invariably happy and striking in his panegyric, much more so, indeed, than in the invective which is more congenial to him. This preference he naively acknowledged at the military dinner in Boston, when he characteristically said in effect that he was rather sorry to have to vindicate the army before an audience which was prepared to agree with him.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Senor Quesada, the Cuban Minister, and Acting Secretary Hill were engaged to-day in going over the bases of a reciprocity treaty between the United States and Cuba. The matter has progressed to the point where it has been possible to draft the convention, and it would be easy to complete it and reduce it to the final form in which it would go to the Senate in a very short time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been solicited by a number of prominent Democrats in this section to express, through THE TIMES, my opinion of ex-President Cleveland's speech in New York on the evening of the 19th inst. and its probable effect on the party in this State.

The second matinee races of the New York Driving Club were held on the club's track at Empire City Park, near Mount Vernon, yesterday afternoon, and were attended by an even larger crowd than was attracted by the opening day races two weeks ago, fully 4,000 persons being present. All were the guests of the club, as there was no charge for entrance, grand stand seats, or even for programmes.
ROBERT HOLT SEVILLE, for eleven years editor and proprietor of The Oakfield (N.Y.) Reporter, died there yesterday, aged forty-five years.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 26. -- The day began with a heavy rain, which lasted until nearly 8 o'clock, necessitating the postponement of company drill until afternoon, when the different companies occupied the two parade grounds for over an hour. The usual morning battalion drill took place, the storm having entirely cleared away by 9 o'clock.

Bronson Howard, the playwright, who for the past two years has been abroad, returned on the Graf Waldersee Wednesday night, accompanied by his wife, and is stopping at 567 West One Hundred and Thirteenth Street. Asked yesterday about the reports of his serious illness, Mr. Howard replied that he was not only better, but even felt so well that entire recovery was not impossible.
LONDON, June 27. -- Previous to making up the list of coronation honors King Edward sent a letter to Sir William Vernon Harcourt, M.P., (Liberal,) offering him a peerage.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The substitute for the Senate Philippine Civil Government bill differs from the bill as it passed the Senate in many minor particulars, but principally in the following:

TRENTON, N.J., June 26. -- Robert H. McCarter, counsel for Miriam Berger, today made argument before the Court of Errors and Appeals to uphold the injunction granted by the Court of Chancery restraining the United States Steel Corporation from substituting $200,000,000 of bonds for preferred stock of a like amount.

BAR HARBOR, June 26. -- Society here is much concerned over King Edward's illness. The telegraph offices are crowded with the curious, seeking information. Many of Bar Harbor's "Summer set" are in London, and word has been received here that the unfortunate postponement of the coronation ceremonies will send a large number home for August.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 26. -- Deputy Sheriffs are watching every train leaving Minneapolis and St. Paul to-night to see that no members of the police force take sudden leave of Minneapolis. Christopher C. Norbeck, ex-detective and self-confessed briber, deliberately entered the Grand Jury room to-day and made one of the most re- markable and sensational confessions ever heard by such a body.

ALBANY, June 26. -- Superintendent Frederick Kilburn of the State Banking Department to-day issued a statement showing the condition of the banks of deposit and discount of the State at the close of business on June 10 last. The next previous statement showed their condition on March 12, and as compared with that statement the condition of the banks shows a great falling off in resources, funds due depositors, and surplus.
DETROIT, June 26. -- No surprise developed in to-day's State Republican Convention, and, as was expected, Gov. Aaron T. Bliss of Saginaw was renominated for a second term on the first ballot.

On the merits of their candidate and with the great strength of their platform the Democrats of Pennsylvania ought to carry that State this Fall. They will carry it if the independent voters who have already exhibited the strength of their convictions and made known their numbers by twice electing Mr. PATTISON Governor are not deluded from their duty by giving undue consideration to issues not pertinent to this contest.

Two horses attached to a carriage in which were Mrs. Robert E. Jennings, wife of the President of the Crucible Steel Company, whose offices are at 71 Broadway, and her two nieces, the Misses Gertrude and Marie Jennings, seventeen and nineteen years old, respectively, became frightened at an electric car while being driven on West Twenty-third Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, yesterday afternoon, and became unmanageable, and dashed toward the car.

The scratch singles of the Metropolitan tennis championship was advanced to the final round on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club, One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday. Semp Russ of San Antonio beat C.C. Kelley in the first semi-final round, though the latter displayed a rather poor article of tennis.

NEWPORT, June 26. -- The death of Anthony S. Sherman, cashier of the Merchants' Bank, as the result of a self-inflicted pistol shot wound, occurred this morning. The condition of the bank which is being investigated by the State Auditor, is believed to be much worse than imagined.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 26. -- The Governor, Sir Augustus Hemming; the leading officials, and representative citizens attended the service of intercession for King Edward at the Parish Church here this morning. The Archbishop, of the West Indies, the Most Rev. Enos Nuttall, officiated.

LONDON, June 26. -- The suspicious fires which have recently occurred in the quarters of the cadets at the Military College at Sandhurst were followed to-day by another mysterious outbreak in the room of one of the cadets. The flames were extinguished, however, with the loss of only some clothing.

It is amiably characteristic of King EDWARD that he has not been willing that his illness should affect the accompaniments of the coronation more than it must. He has not only insisted that the huge feed shall be given to all comers which was promised. He has insisted also that the receivers of "coronation honors" shall derive from them whatever pleasure such honors can give.

LONDON, June 27. -- The streets of London yesterday contained a curious mixture of Sunday and holiday crowds. All the banks and big business houses in the heart of the City were shut up. Most of the retail stores were open and the saloons and restaurants of the cheaper sort did a fairly rushing business.

Controller Grout yesterday afternoon allotted bids on proposals for $4,667,000 of 3 1/2 per cent corporate stock of the City of New York, payable in gold. Of these $3,000,000 are Rapid Transit Railroad bonds due Nov. 1, 1931; $1,000,000 for repaving streets, due Nov. 1, 1942; $167,000 of sewer bonds, due Nov. 1, 1942; and $3000,000 of new aqueduct bonds, due April 1, 1922.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Secretary of Agriculture Wilson has decided that the status of the New York Weather Bureau Station be raised to the rank of a National forecast station instead of a local forecast station. This action was taken because the number of people served by the local forecasts at New York is as large as that contained in some of the present forecast districts embracing large areas.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- Up to the ninth inning to-day Philadelphia had the New York baseball team shut out, then a single, a base on balls, and a wild pitch gave the visitors their only tally. The New Yorks fielded miserably and the Phillies won easily. Score:
POTSDAM, N.Y., June 26. -- Gov. Odell attended the Farmers' Picnic and Grange Day meeting here to-day. He delivered an address in which he said, in part:

BOSTON, June 26. -- There is no change to record in the money market. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 5c premium; call loans, 3 to 4; time money, 4 to 5; Clearing House exchanges, $17,556,091; balances, $1,486,324. The copper stocks were distinctly stronger to-day under the lead of Amalgamated, and the market in general was better in tone.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidid, B.W.I., June 26. -- Information has been received here from Venezuela that the French cruiser Suchet has effected the release of seven French citizens who had been arrested by the Government authorities at Carupano, Bermudez.

Yesterday was almost devoid of social incident. The hall holiday on Saturday gives an opportunity for men who are going on house parties to get out of town early. There are many house parties over the week end, and Tuxedo, Southampton, and other places will be crowded. Not a few will stay over the Fourth, and, in fact, until Monday week.

"Between Ourselves," the English title of Max O'Rell's new book, gives place in the United States to "Tween You and I." in which, according to him, "there is something" picturesque and cozy "which does not exist either in 'Between you and me' or the [sic] more poetical 'Twixt you and me.'"

After writing a note denouncing himself as a defaulter and a thief, James E. Pearson, a lawyer, committed suicide some time during Thursday night in his office, at 213 Montague Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Pearson was fifty-two years old and a well-known resident of Hempstead, L.I., where he was prominent in church circles.
L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for occupancy to Mrs Nattie Sniffen the three-story dwelling 125 West Eighty-seventh Street, 18 by 160.

SARATOGA, June 27. -- The civil war veterans, as represented in several organizations, concluded their Saratoga bivouac this afternoon. Within the jurisdiction of the Department of the State of New York of the Grand Army of the Republic there were included the State Encampment, the Women's Relief Corps, and the Ladies of the Grand Army of the Republic.

Following is a statement of books which have sold best in regular book and department stores in New York, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, Chicago, Baltimore, Boston, and San Francisco between May 27 and June 27 of this year. The statement is based on reports received from the regular correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in those cities, personal inquiries having been made for the information sent to us.

H.H. Hackett won the final round of the scratch singles in the metropolitan tennis championship tournament on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club, at One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday afternoon from Semp Russ, the Texas expert, in straight sets, best three in five being necessary because of the championship aspect of the match.

CINCINNATI, June 27. -- The mystery which surrounded the taking of the life of Larz Anderson, the prominent and wealthy Cincinnatian, yesterday has been lifted today by a telegram from Coroner Doten of Bridgeport, Conn., who viewed the body a few hours after death. He states that it was a case of suicide due to melancholia.

Now that the United States of America are bounding into the foremost place of the world, the State, the great unit made up of the aggregate millions of citizens, must needs be of increasing interest. The American Federal State is not a constitutional history, but a treatise on civics, which deals not only with the vast and imposing machinery of the Nation, but also with the more restricted mechanism of the individual State and municipality.

The wags of the stage, whose doings Mr. Whitton chronicles, include Forrest, the elder Booth, the elder Sothern, the elder John Drew, and their contemporaries, most of whom the author, who was connected with the business end of the theatre in the fifties and later, seems to have known personally.

MANILA, June 27. -- Capt. Matthew F. Steele, Sixth Cavalry, testified to-day before the board which is inquiring into the charges of cruelty brought by Major Cornelius Gardener Governor of Tayabas Province, against American officers and soldiers.

BOSTON, Mass., June 27. -- With the exception of a slightly increased demand for time money, the money market is unchanged. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 5 and 10 cents premium; call loans. 3 to 4; time money, 4 to 5; Clearing House exchanges, $21,052,887; balances, $2,278,476.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- The Philadelphia market was saved from stagnation to-day by lively trading in Street Railway shares. Union Traction and Philadelphia Company were in steady demand and improved slightly. In the late trading Philadelphia Rapid Transit came in for a share of the activity, and again rose above 9.

As surely as the boating season comes round, so surely does the amateur purist in language pour forth the vials of his wrath on those who talk of the 'Varsity crews. In England, in times past, the word was reprobated as the spurious coinage of cockney watermen, adopted by undergraduates who should have known better.

The print department of the New York Public Library celebrates the Hugo centenary in its own way by preparing an exhibition which consists of portraits and caricatures of the poet and of reproductions of his drawings, together with printed matter relating to his work as an artist, the material being drawn from the Avery collection.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: As this question seems to be of some mo- ment to many, permit me to offer my conviction upon the subject. Only recently I read the first installment of the story in the April Century, and directly after a short story in the May Atlantic, "In My Lady's Garden."
PATERSON, N.J., June 27. -- The result of last night's meeting, the determination not to declare a general strike in the silk trade, has caused a general feeling of relief.

IN many respects "The Rise of Religious Liberty in America" is a really great book. It is unique in that it is the first time the subject has been treated in a single volume. It conserves a genuine utility and affords a wholesome entertainment to the reader.

LONDON, June 28. -- Whitelaw Reid, the United States Special Ambassador, and Mrs. Reid called by appointment on the Prince and Princess of Wales yesterday afternoon to take official leave of their Royal Highnesses.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Admiral Dewey continued his testimony before the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day. Replying to questions put by Senator Patterson, he said that he had begun negotiations with the Governor General of the Philippines, Gen. Jaudenes, for the surrender of the city and the negotiations were conducted through the Belgian Consul, who, after the death of the British Consul, had been very courteous in acting as a go-between.

BOSTON, June 27. -- The startling news of Tuesday interrupted a revival of the dispute as to the authorship of "Truth Dexter," but the only names brought forward were those of Mrs. Michaelis and Mrs. Fenellosa, both of which were suggested long ago. At present only one novel remains on the announcement list of Messrs.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 27. -- A warrant for the arrest of Louis Disbrow, in connection with the deaths of Clarence Foster and Sarah Lawrence, was issued late this afternoon by Justice Edward H. Foster of this place, who went to Good Ground on a summons from District Attorney Smith. The Justice to-night made the following statement:

"Is the gentleman a great anonymous?" Is a familiar quotation. In this instance he is not, and why he poses as such is something of a mystery. A desire for anonymity should always be respected -- within reasonable limits. People should not seek to pry into the private concerns of others, and if an author desires to withhold his name, that surely is his private concern.

KANSAS CITY, June 27. -- R.G. Rombauer, a coal operator of Kirksville, Mo., is authority for the statement that all of the big coal mines of Missouri are to be absorbed by a syndicate controlled by J. Pierpont Morgan. In discussing the subject to-day Mr. Rombauer said:

Mrs. Anna M. Thorman, wife of Henry N.E. Thorman, is confined to her home, Fifty-fourth Street, near Ninth Avenae, Brooklyn, suffering from shock and wounds received at the hands of three thieves yesterday morning.

In connection with the sixth annual exhibit of the Art Association of Richmond, Ind., which opened on Tuesday, June 10, and which embraces paintings, "arts and crafts," , there have been brought together examples of the work of some of the best-known bookbinders of this country.
In considering the position of the anthracite operators we are forced to accept one of two conclusions -- either they are deliberately trifling with the public interest or they are moral cowards.

The initial meeting or a new Jewish forward movement is to be held next Wednesday evening, July 2, in the auditorium of the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street. This forward movement is part of the work of the B'nal B'rith, and has the ambition to be a Jewish renaissance.

On June 9 and 10 Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge sold in London the remaining portion of the valuable collection of Americans by Marshall C. Lefferts of New York City, 337 lots realizing a total of u3,802 5s. 6d. These books, together with a number of others of extreme rarity, were a part of the fine collection which Mr. Lefferts sold privately last Fall to Mr. G.H. Richmond.

NEWBURG, N. Y., June 27. -- John J. Scannell, the Tammany politician who recently bought a stock farm here, pays occasional visits to inspect the many improvements he is making on the property. He made one of those visits yesterday, and paid a hurried call to his newly acquired farm, which includes a well-laid half-mile track.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27. -- The application of some of the minority stockholders for the appointment of a receiver to wind up the recently dissolved Spirits Distributing Company, came before Vice Chancellor Emery for argument to-day. Counsel for the defendant interests sprang a surprise in the shape of an offer to buy the entire assets of the dissolved corporation.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 27. -- Another sensational lead has been discovered by the Grand Jury in its probing of the police scandal, and as a result Fred Maione, one of the police detectives, was arraigned this morning with being an accessory to a felony after the fact. An indictment was also found against Detective Charles Brackett, but he is out of the city, and the Superintendent of Police does not know where he is.
Seven more games remain to be decided to-day for the last of the whist players' tournament at Manhattan Beach. The disposition of three of the trophies depends on these matches.

Horgan Slattery, by a vote of the members of the Board of Estimate, were yesterday discharged from further work on the plans of the extension to the Court House. This action was based on an opinion of Corporation Counsel Rives, and the only officials who voted against the resolution were President Haffen of the Bronx and President Cassidy of Queens.

Gov. Odell, on his way from the St. Lawrence County Fair to the State Camp at Peekskill, yesterday rested for a brief interval in the "Amen Corner" of the Fifth Avenue Hotel, which knows him so well, and there was then asked a few questions about city politics.

The Springfield Union has done THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS the honor to print about twelve sticks (solid) in reference to our editorial remarks advising newly fledged college graduates contemplating literary lives to shun newspaper offices. Among other comments, none of which can be regarded as complimentary to this modest publication.

It is not an uncommon thing for Americans to detect in the speech of their British brothers or sisters traces of what in our own land is somewhat rudely called illiteracy. It was reserved for Mr. Henry Austin Clapp of Boston to make a protest on this matter to The Spectator of London, a paper singularly free from such offense and very hospitable to polite correction.

Actual and prospective trade with South Africa has assumed such proportions since the termination of the Anglo-Boer war that two steamship companies have inaugurated service between this city and South African points. These are the Prince Line and the Houston Line both of which are represented by the John C. Seager Company, and it is the intention of the agents to maintain a bi-weekly service.

SAYVILLE, L.I., June 27. -- Misses Marion and Lena Seely, daughters of Bessie Bonehill, received a cablegram that announced their mother's serious illness and requested them to sail immediately for Europe, as she wants them near her when she dies. The daughters left Sayville for New York to-day. They will sail in the Umbria for Europe to-morrow.

READERS will find printed below lists at the contents of the principal American magazines for July. The lists are restricted to periodicals which appear once a month; and while the contents are not absolutely complete, the omissions relate mainly to regular and familiar departments and some of the minor contributions.
BALTIMORE, June, 27. -- Baltimore City's holdings in the Western Maryland Railroad Company were formally transferred to the Fuller Syndicate, representing the Wabash Hallway System, to-day.
LONDON, June 27. -- The following bulletin was posted at Buckingham Palace at 6:15 P.M.:

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- At the meeting of the Cabinet to-day the terms of an amnesty proclamation to the Filipinos, which it is contemplated to issue on the Fourth of July, were agreed upon. The War Department for some time past has had under consideration the draft of a proclamation, and has found it necessary to make a number of changes in its text.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 27 -- The strength of International Trust stock and Atlantic Coast Line issues were the features of to-day's trading. The former advanced on the improved condition of the company, aided by the reported offer of 130 for 1,000 shares. The stock, is still about 18 points below the highest figure reached last year.

Accused of dosing a man with a part of a job lot of drugs and killing him, Max Blumfeld, thirty-eight years of age, a money lender, of 188 Orchard Street, was arrested yesterday and held in $5,000 bail for examination in the Essex Market Court of a technical charge of homicide. The dead man was Morris Honig, thirty-four years of age, an Austrian, employed as a cloak salesman, who lived at 613 Sixth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- What promises to prove an event in American bibliography of far more than the usual importance is now occupying the time of the executors of Walt Whitman, two of whom are residents of this city, who are preparing a final and definite issue of all the writings of the "good gray poet."

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 27. -- James E. Pearson, who was found dead in his office in Brooklyn this morning, had a country place here. Being considered a far-sighted and shrewd business man, Mr. Pearson gradually was given charge of different estate here and in Brooklyn, until his business in this direction was very extensive.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- The Directors of the Philadelphia and Erie Railroad Company at a meeting here to-day declared a dividend of 2 per-pent:, payable July 10. Although the company announced that it was not a semi-annual dividend a similar dividend was declared six months ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial, "A New Surgical 'Crime,' " in to-day's TIMES, hits the nail upon the head. How a man like Dr. Murphy can upon the scanty newspaper reports criticise world-renowned surgeons like Lister, Treves, Smith, , goes beyond my understanding.

The course for the Yale-Harvard races at New London may be termed one of the most beautiful on earth; for the landscape seems made for the painter, and the River Thames, from a half to three-eighths of a mile broad, with fairly high banks, is a sheet of water that sets off the hills and wooded half islands in a marvelous way.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- There was an animated discussion on sugar in the Senate this afternoon between Mr. Teller of Colorado and Mr. Platt of Connecticut. Mr. Teller practically served notice on the Senate and the President that there would be no Cuban reciprocity legislation next Winter if he could help it, and apparently he spoke for the entire body of Democratic Senators.

Speak gently -- tread softly -- breathe slowly. It is not meet that one enter the hallowed temple of art with, boisterous air. He who would turn the pages of "John Henry," seeking refreshment of spirit, should take off his hat, make a low obeisance, and conduct himself with that decorum fitting in the presence of the masters.
LONDON, June 28. -- The expectation of the King's rapid recovery has led to a revival of the projects for festivities.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 27. -- Toronto won from the Jersey City baseball team to-day. Three errors, a base on balls, and a sacrifice gave the local players three runs in the fifth. Carr's errors at first base being directly responsible. Pfanmiller was always a puzzle, while Briggs was hit harder, but kept them scattered.

In nothing has the Mayor shown to better advantage since he took office than in his steady and unrelenting opposition to the employment, and the claims for employment, of HORGAN SLATTERY. The original employment of these men by Tammany, considering their want of professional standing, would have been an insult to the city, even if it had not been complicated with attempts to turn out of professional employment men who had fairly earned it.

There are few pages in this book that are more attractive than 340, 341, and 342, which represent three of the brothers Dalziel -- George, Edward, and Thomas -- in habit as they were in 1901, gray-haired, with long gray beards, and faces furrowed with the experiences and vicissitudes of their long and honorable lives.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 27. -- Articles of incorporation were filed to-day by the Association of Manufacturers and Distributers of Food Products, no capital stated. The capital of the firms in the corporation is $30,000,000.

The convention in Philadelphia during the past week of the representatives of the various telephone interests independent of the Bell combination has focalized public attention upon the rapid growth and present magnitude of the movement to cheapen and improve the telephone service and change for the better the conditions which are the outgrowth of monopoly.

Mr. Crosland and "The Unspeakable Seot." T.W.H. Crosland's book on "The Unspeakable Scot" will be published in July by G.P. Putnam's Sons. The author in a communication says that "the book has not only reached the prospectus stage, but is already completed and in type.

WILKESBARRE, Pehn., June 27. -- Tomorrow will end the seventh week of the great anthracite coal mine workers' strike. The lines remain tightly drawn, and neither side shows the slightest disposition to weaken. Excepting President Mitchell's offer to arbitrate, there has been no proposition advanced by either of the parties to the controversy since the strike began, and the prediction that the struggle will be one to a finish still holds good.
BAR HARBOR, Me., June 27. -- Delightful weather prevailed here to-day, and society appeared in large numbers upon the drives. The town has an unusually animated appearance for so early in the season.

At Sotheby's, June 5, u240 was given for a unique copy of the earliest issue of Charles Lamb's first book for children, "The King and Queen of Hearts, with the Rogueries of the Knave who Stole Away the Queen's Pies," 1806. This highly important book, we learn, was secured by Dodd, Mead Co., and is now to New York City.

"It is not where cannon booms or the thrills of battle stir the blood that the greatest heroes are to be found, but where men and women die in silence with only God to witness their heroism;" and so Nathan Hale "being a man whose soul was fixed upon God," cared not for the failure of the present.

After an uninterrupted run of victories in tournaments whenever he has started since May, 1901, when C.H. Seeley beat him in the semi-final of the Metropolitan Golf Association championship, the list including two National championships, Walter J. Travis was beaten in the second round for the President's Cup yesterday at the Morris County Golf Club by Frank Ormond Reinhart, a Princeton freshman.

When an author gets so far upon the pathway of literary recognition as to sign a contract with a publishing house for the issuance of his book, one of the things that strikes him as most surprising, outside of the fact that he has progressed to the contract point, is the provision which states that the editor will give him for free distribution six, or it may be eight, copies of his own book!

Mr. HOWELLS has remarked the fact that the immorality of the French novel is as conventional as the morality of the English. The implication was that this fact detracted from the essential evil of French fiction in a way which the casual English reader finds it hard to comprehend.

Although the little volume before us deals with the historical development of the State of Alabama in general from Tuskaloosa, its major portion is confined to the annals of the State as an active and component part of the Southern Confederacy.

PITTSBURG, June 27. -- The largest voluntary increase ever known in the wages of 100,000 men has been decided upon by the United States Steel Corporation. They will receive an advance of 10 per cent., which will increase the annual pay roll of the Steel Corporation by $4,000,000. The advance applies to union as well as nonunion men.

The death of Dean Sage of Albany, which occurred this week at his hunting lodge in Canada, removes from the field of American book collecting one of its most prominent members. A member of the wellknown lumber firm of H.W. Sage Co. of Albany, Mr. Sage was equally well known as a bibliophile and an angler.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- The House Democrats to-night, at a harmonious and enthusiastic caucus, attended by seventy-six members, drafted their ideas of what the main planks for the Fall congressional campaign should be. There are three planks -- one on Cuban reciprocity, one on the trusts, and one on the tariff.

IF we have, as it seems apparent, poetry of artifice in abundance in these later days, it is because the rules of verse manufacture were never better or more universally understood than they are in our time.

FATHER MARQUETTE'S principal life work was performed within the present boundaries of the United States, and therefore he may be properly claimed as an American hero, as he is, in the new biography by Reuben Gold Thwaites, issued as one of their Life History Series by the house of Appleton.

KIEL, June 27. -- Emperor William's American-built schooner yacht Meteor, with the Emperor himself on board and steering most of the time, finished seven minutes and twenty-two seconds ahead of the Cicely in the large schooner race held here to-day in connection with the regatta. The Cicely is owned by Cecil Quentin of England, and was designed by Fife.

The withholding of their degrees from a certain number of seniors at Yale by reason of their want of proficiency in the course of law has excited more attention than very likely it deserves by reason of the fact that one of the young men thus turned back or down is heir to a spectacularly large fortune.

PREPARATIONS are being made by D. Appleton Co. to form a series of biographies of explorers and pioneers of America, which shall particularly show how the frontier of the original thirteen Colonies was maintained and extended West, North, and South.
WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Senator Morgan is anxious to start another campaign against the Panama route.

August Belmont's seventy-foot sloop Mineola, with Capt. Charlie Barr at the wheel, had another sailover in the second day's racing of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club regatta at Oyster Bay yesterday. J. Rogers Maxwell postponed his coming out with the Yankee until to-day, and so the Mineola had it all to herself.

LONDON, June 28. -- The more straight, forward bulletins issued by King Edward's physicians yesterday served to allay the fears of the public in regard to his Majesty's condition. The doctors were doubtless stirred up to this course by the complaints that for some time they have been misleading the publicabout the King's health.

Admiral DEWEY is positively cruel to the anti-imperialists. Their assumption that there was an "alliance" between the United States forces and the forces of AGUINALDO was the cornerstone of the fantastic structure they have reared. Two years ago they were loud, emphatic, and truculent in their insistence upon the fact of the alliance.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 27. -- This has been the last complete day in the State camp for the season of 1902, and it has been a busy day. Gov. Odell arrived in the afternoon, and was escorted to Gen. Roe's headquarters. Immediately after luncheon there was a review of the Seventy-first Regiment.

There was a chorus of bleating protest yesterday morning at the sheepfold in Central Park, where an auctioneer was holding the annual sale of superfluous stock and calling out the bids of a little group of would-be buyers.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- There was talk at the Capitol to-day of the possibility of a failure to complete at this session of Congress the legislation providing for the Civil Government of the Philippines. The conferrees, however, said this evening that they did not think their conference would be so extended as to prolong the session beyond the 2d or 3d of July.

The stock market yesterday gave another of its many exhibitions of surprising strength. Forced to face no fewer than three dividend disappointments during the day -- the passing of the Ice Trust and Colorado Fuel dividends and the decrease in the Rutland preferred rate -- it nevertheless showed no signs of weakness save in the three stocks immediately affected.

LONDON, June 17. -- Sad is the case of the British Publisher. While he was vainly striving against the depression in his trade caused toy the coronation, peace suddenly arrived, as it exprfessly to complete his discomfiture

LONDON, June 27. -- Already the coronation had hurt the book trade and its postponement hurts it still more. It is feared that the sales of all the special books of the occasion, including the Coronation Bibles, will be ruined.

LONDON, June 28. -- "It's the best yet," was the popular comment with which the bulletin posted at Buckingham Palace at 1 o'clock was greeted. A small crowd waited before the palace until the bulletin was brought out, and when the good news became known there were cries of "Hear Hear!" and cheers.

The sale at Sotheby's June 3 to 7, when 1,334 lots realized the large total of u11,828 13s. 6d., was in some ways the most remarkable auction of the present season. Many of the items possessing the most interest were purchased for American collectors. The highest price realized was the u520 given by Quaritch for a copy on vellum of the Kelmscott Press edition of Chaucer.

ASBURY PARK, June 28 -- Thus far not a single striped bass has been hooked, notwithstanding the fact that scores of skilled anglers have haunted the fishing pier day and night for the past month. Last Summer at this time, but with warmer water running, hundreds of bass weighing over fifteen pounds had been captured.

KING EDWARD'S sudden illness last week just on the eve of his coronation day, gave currency to numerous predictions which had been made by fortune tellers and palmists concerning Queen Victoria's heir apparent. It was said that in the fatigue and worry incidental to the preparation for the crowning festivities the King had been haunted by these predictions.

DURING the past week there has been a good deal of quiet discussion among naval men concerning the explosion of the Maine, excited by the news which arrived from China on Monday morning that the warship Kai Chin exploded and sank within thirty seconds while lying in the Yang-tse-Kiang River, killing 150 officers and men.

KIEL, Germany, June 28 -- The Uncle Sam, owned by F.B. Riggs of New York, to-day won her second race at the regatta here, and the Kaiser's Gold Cup, beating the Mimosa of the Hamburg Club by 11 seconds, and the Hansa of Lubeck by 3 minutes and 35 seconds. There were 17 starters, and the course was the same as that over which the Uncle Sam sailed a winning race last Thursday.

THE duration of Old Sol's stay above the horizon reached its maximum June 22, and henceforth and until June next we shall see less of him than has been our pleasure the last few weeks. The difference in the length of the daylight period, however, can not yet be discerned by the average person.

AROUND the corner from the free-lunch emporium there had been an alarm of fire and some excitable tenant had flung a costly lamp from the second-story window and then run down stairs with a dustpan and brush and deposited them carefully on the strip of sod beside the front entrance.

IT WAS just a same of "Kiss in the ring" which was being played at the last of the May parties -- but nevertheless it contained more elements of the human comedy (and tragedy) than was to be found in most of the plays on Broadway this Winter.

A SUGGESTION TO MR. CARNEGIE. "I SEE," said the Idiot, picking up the morning paper and perusing it diligently for some moments, "I see that a Western city has drawn on Mr. Carnegie for a public library at sight."

PARIS, June 28 -- Polo has greatly attracted American society this week, and all the pretty American women who have got back from the coronation flasco or wisely staid at home were at Bagatelle to witness two matches between American and French teams, in which the Americans lost the first and won the second.

LONDON, June 13 -- All the younger generation will like the resplendent revival of "The Merry Wives of Windsor" at Her Majesty's Theatre, and that is a great point gained by Beerbohm Tree, the greatest possible point he could gain in putting forward on the stage of a theatre run primarily, in spite of the manager's strongly artistic inclinations, for commercial gain, an Elizabethan comedy so coarse-fibred as this.

PEEKSKILL, State Camp, June 28 -- The departure of the Seventy-first Regiment this morning signalized the closing of the State camp for this season. As soon as breakfast had been eaten this morning accoutrements and equipments were arranged, personal belongings of officers and others packed up, and before 9 o'clock the regiment was under marching orders.

BANGOR, June 28 -- Among the thousands who will welcome President Roosevelt when he comes to Bangor in August will be his old friend and guide, Bill Sewall of Island Falls, who changed, it might be said, a sickly youth to a vigorous and athletic man, now the President. Sewall is one of the best woodsmen and hunters in the State.

An explosion of benzine in a tailor shop at 3 Manhattan Street yesterday afternoon caused a fire which gutted the establishment and severely burned three men, one of them a policeman who had run to the rescue of the others. All three, who are John Kluck, proprietor of the shop; Pagneil Gakad, 1,389 Avenue A, and Policeman Peter Donnelly of the Second Court District, are in the J. Hood Wright Hospital.

A large holder of the securities of the Distilling Company of America, who is in close touch with its affairs, and who was instrumental in the formulation of its proposed financial readjustment plan, says that it is the result not only of careful investigation of the business of the company since its formation, but close study of its future prospects.

"IT WILL be rather disappointing for the Alabama women in charge of the Jefferson Davis relics at Montgomery to learn they have made an error," said a visitor at Birmingham to an Age-Herald reporter yesterday.

OMAHA, Neb., June 28 -- A fight is on between the machinists of the Union Pacific system and the company, and the Executive Committee of the machinists has called a strike of the union all over the system.

GEORGETOWN, St. Vincent, B.W.I., June 6, 1902 -- Leaving to the regular correspondents the task of gathering the "news" features of the eruption and the relief measures, the geologists upon arriving here addressed themselves at once to learning at first hand, as far as possible, everything pertaining to the outbursts of the mountain.
SOMEBODY in the party got off that old threadbare aphorism about a man being known by the company he keeps, when the reserved man with the gray hair about his temples spoke up:
AS already intimated, the dark-green tie has come to stay. In coronation week it would have seemed as if it were the green above the red. The red coronation ties did not gain any favor here at all.

STAMFORD, N.Y., June 28 -- The real season at Stamford commenced with the opening of the Rexmere on the 20th. In spite of the severe weather this year's applications for cottages and board have been more numerous than ever before.
OLD CAESAR, a white-headed darky of the olden time, gives the following receipt for cooking and eating a 'possum:

AS the 7:40 train began to pull away from the Alexandria station an old, white-haired negro hurried across the platform and swung himself on the rear car. He was very black and very dusty, and the single occupants of seats looked a little apprehensive as he shuffled diffidently through the car, but he did not offer to sit down.
BAR HARBOR, Me., June 28 -- Mr. and Mrs. M.L. Monroe of New York arrived to-day. The Monroes have rented Bogue Chitto, the Summer home of Dave Hennen Morris.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, June 28 -- The Master Car Builders and the Railway Master Mechanics, who began their annual conventions here on June 18 and ended them on June 25, enjoyed the novelty on Tuesday afternoon of being banqueted in a Schenectady boiler shed. As guests of the American Locomotive Company, they visited Schenectady and inspected the big locomotive plant there.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- In the House to-day Mr. Foss, Chairman of the Committee on Naval Affairs, called up the conference report on the Naval Appropriation bill. The conferrees, Mr. Foss explained, had agreed to all items except those for the increase of the navy and the place where the new ships are to be built.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- E.G. Rathbone, ex-Director General of Posts of Cuba, convicted in Cuba on charges involving maladministration of his office, to-day petitioned Congress to order a Congressional investigation of all his acts in Cuba. The petition was presented by Senator Teller. Its text is as follows:

Albert Champion, the French cyclist, who has been racing very successfully in New England this season, made his first appearance of this year in the metropolis yesterday at the opening races of the season on the Manhattan Beach cycle track and defeated three other well-known racing men by large margins in a twenty-mile motor-paced race.

SARANAC LAKE, June 28 -- At Riverside Inn in Saranac Lake great strides have been made toward caring for the Summer and Winter resorters. The capacity of the hotel has been nearly doubled during the last few months.

PATERSON, N.J., June 28 -- The order issued by the United Silk Workers' Association declaring off the suspension of work that was ordered a week ago, means the end of the tie-up in the local silk mills. The ribbon weavers are already back at work in many instances, and have received instructions in every case to refrain no longer from work.

It is reported from Washington that the Agricultural Department is about to undertake a line of experiments to establish the thesis that the hog is by nature a cleanly, and even dainty, animal -- temperamentally something of a "dude," in fact -- and that, given an environment which does not destroy his self-respect, his natural tastes will develop along the lines of his original preference for sweetness and light.

Alderman BRIDGES seems to be the chief butt of the body of which he has the honor to be a member and to deserve that bad eminence, which is saying a good deal. But we are bound to say, judging by the reports of his appearance on Friday before the Board of Estimate, that he seems to entertain much sounder notions on some branches of civics than most of his colleagues.

KAUKAUNA, Wis., June 28 -- One of the greatest schemes for the development of Canada's resources yet undertaken is that proposed by Col. H.A. Frambach, who, with Chicago and Detroit capitalists, is building a million-dollar paper mill in Northern Michigan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After reading some of the so-called anti-imperialist papers, were not one acquainted with the sterling qualities of the average American soldier and the antithetical qualities of the average Boston editor, we might be led to believe that our army to-day was composed of the veriest offscouring of the country.

The plans for the eighteen-story hotel to be built at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street for the Fifty-fifth Street Company, by the General Building and Construction Company, on the plot 125 by 100.5, were filed yesterday. Hiss Weekes are the architects. The structure will cost about $2,250,000, or, with the ground, $3,250,000.

OTTAWA, June 28 -- John Charlton, M.P., a member of the Joint High Commission, who has had a seat in the Dominion Parliament since 1872, is recognized as one of the best-informed men on this continent on the subject of Canada's trade relations with other countries. For years he has worked with energy and zeal to increase the prosperity of Canada by obtaining more liberal trade relations with the United States.

The August Belmont is a craft certain to attract a good deal of attention, not only because she is a new departure in colliers, but also because in appearance she is, barring possibly the United States ram Katahdin, one of the most peculiar looking things in the shape of a vessel ever constructed for ocean navigation.

A PARTICULARLY broad forehead, surmounted by a dome, made it understandable, and at once, that the newcomer with such a cerebral construction must be endowed with talent of a superior order. It would have been a remarkable, a startling, figurehead if not for the ears; they stood at right angles, were huge, foliated, but, possibly like the animal in the child's story, they were all the better adapted to hearing.

SINCE the New York subway was begun its builders have been confronted with many new engineering problems. The work has been so productive of mechanical novelties that not a technical periodical in the country has failed to show an interest in the undertaking, and one part of the tunneling is regarded as so extraordinary that The London Engineering News has sent a special representative across the Atlantic to write about it.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., June 28 -- The Supreme Court, en banc, to-day sustained the motion of the Attorney General to strike out the returns of the packers in the ouster proceedings as to all the contentions, except the sixth, which raises the question as to whether the packers are in a combine to fix and maintain prices.

Th end of the past week found the realty market fairly active as to private sales and the sum of the week's business more satisfactory than the season would warrant. There were several deals of importance yesterday, including the sale of 27 East Twenty-first Street, where a ten-story office building is likely to be built, and the transactions of the six days compared favorably with those of several weeks in the past quarter.

THE House Committee on Public Lands has reported favorably on the bill of Congressman Martin providing for the establishment of a National park to cover the country about the Wind Cave, in the vicinity of the Black Hills, in South Dakota. Should this bill pass, the Wind Cave will soon stand with Niagara, Yellowstone Park, and the Mammoth Cave of Kentucky as one of America's most wonderful freaks.

Among the many benefits which the actual Emperor of Germany has conferred upon his kind, candid onlookers expected that not the least would be the reversion, through his example, to a more rational type of racing yacht. When the august potentate in question read the report, no doubt cabled to him expressly and in full, of Senator DEPEW'S remarks about the Meteor in the United States Senate his heart must have been heavy within him.

Conditions have so changed that, with Rockefeller interests reputed to have become powerful in Missouri Pacific -- a Gould property -- the Missouri, Kansas and Texas -- their own property -- may some day come under the wing of the larger system again.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The work of this session of Congress is practically done, and if it passes into history at all it will be as an extremely barren session. Just before the opening of Congress it was freely predicted that it would be history-making; that more important legislation would be passed than at any recent session.
[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, June 28 -- Theatrically this week has been barren, and the season of prophesying is over, for all engagements for next Fall are being made.

The news that Harvard had defeated Yale in the final game of the baseball series yesterday early reached the Tenderloin, where men who never saw a campus were quick to designate themselves as Harvard men. Women were eager to wear the victorious colors, but the genuine college student was a scarce quantity in that region.

HAVANA, Cuba, June 17 -- The water famine is over for the present at least, and few that passed through it care to have another such experience. For a time things looked very dark for the city, and there were many prophecies of the dire happenings that would occur if the water did not return shortly: sickness, even pestilence, was predicted, and not without some show of reason.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- The local market to-day was dull and unsettled. Reading was quite freely sold for New York account. Lehigh Valley was steady. Union Traction and United Gas Improvement were firm. Philadelphia Rapid Transit again sold above 9. Trading was in narrow volume and at the close there was a tendency toward weakness.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, June 28 -- Reports circulated even a week ago about the hopelessness of the coronation honor list were proved quite unfounded, for either Lord Salisbury exerted his influence strongly or the King never intended to scatter peerages broadcast.

A crowd of twenty thousand or more yesterday saw the most spectacular race of the season at the Sheepshead Bay track, when in one of the best races ever run by a two-year-old the $20,000 Great Trial Stakes was won on the post by Irish Lad, with the green and white colors of Harry Payni Whether and H.B. Duryea up.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 28 -- Judge Martin J. Keogh in the Supreme Court to-day denied the motion for a new trial in the case of Peter F. McLaurin of Mount Vernon, who obtained a verdict of $50,000 against the Cuba Company on March 24 last.

WHEN President Roosevelt affixes his signature to the bill passed by Congress providing for the construction of a canal across the Isthmus of Panama "the dream of the navigator," as the building of a canal to connect the Atlantic with the Pacific Ocean has been called, will have gained such substance that a comparatively few years will suffice to bring it to a reality.

MARLBOROUGH, Mass., June 28 -- In a head-on collision between two heavily loaded cars on the Hudson Division of the Marlborough Street Railway early this evening, Motorman John H. Harris received injuries which caused his death, and about thirty-five passengers and employes were injured, several of them to such an extent that they were removed to hospitals for treatment.

That the outward-bound steamship passenger who finds half a ton of flowers in his stateroom at the moment of sailing should take an appreciative sniff or two at the garlands and write a nice letter of acknowledgment from his London or Paris hotel is required by polite custom.

There could not be any human testimony luckier at this particular juncture than that of Admiral DEWEY before the Senate Committee on the Philippines. The most gratifying fact about the testimony to the Admiral's grateful and admiring countrymen is the evidence it affords that he has completely recovered from that unfortunate indisposition which detained him in Florida throughout the whole period of the sojourn of Prince HENRY OF PRUSSIA on these shores.

THE treacherous, merciless sands of Death Valley have yielded up the story of another gruesome, ghastly tragedy fifty years after it was enacted. Yearly, as the white men traverse that trapdoor of hell, they play their lives against the tales of yellow lure that lie under it, and some lose.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company will make an offer to purchase from the Western Union Telegraph Company the 1,500 miles of poles and 25,000 miles of wires which, otherwise, the Western Union will have to remove at the expiration of its contract, five months from now.

GOOD GROUND, L.I., June 28 -- Louis A. Disbrow, for whom a warrant has been issued in connection with the deaths of Sarah Lawrence and Clarence Foster, whose bodies were found in Tiana Bay on June 14, will arrive at Southampton on Tuesday morning with his counsel. Rowland Miles of Northport, and surrender himself to the authorities.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Mr. Deboe (Ky.) delivered a speech in the Senate to-day on his amendment to the resolution for the election of Senators by the people, providing that the qualifications of citizens entitled to vote for United States Senators and Representatives shall be uniform in all the States, and that Congress shall have power to provide for the registration of voters, the conduct of elections, and the certifying of the result.

The primates' house in the Zoological Park received last Friday night a very valuable consignment of apes, baboons, and monkeys. The lot came over from Hamburg in the Graf Waldersee from Carl Hagenbeck. It consisted of three orang-outangs, one chimpanzee, two drill baboons, three lemurs, and one very rare African monkey.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial comment on the teachings of President Hadley's address to the graduating class at Yale contained the following paragraph, under the title "The Man and the Achievement":

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 28 -- While the doors of the Empire State Savings Bank were opened as usual this morning, no money will be paid out, the Trustees having decided at a meeting held yesterday, following a quiet run on the bank, to require thirty days' notice, under a rule of the bank.

Acting District Attorney William Rand, Jr., yesterday addressed a letter to W. Bourke Coekran, in answer to one which he received from Mr. Coekran making a complaint against the Directors of the Consolidated Tobacco Company. Mr. Cockran argued that if admissions made by De Lancey Nicoll, attorney for Thomas F. Ryan, James B. Duke, and others, were true, there was evidence of criminal conspiracy.

PARIS, June 28 -- One of the most interesting receptions of the week was that given by Comte Robert de Montesquiou, the well-known poet and society leader, at his famous Pavilion des Muses, at Versailles. All literary and artistic Paris were there, among the Americans being Mr. and Mrs. Standish and Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Curtis.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 28 -- Visitors to Lake Placid have three courses over which they may play. The Whiteface course of nine holes, situated at the junction of the Saranac Lake road and the road to Whiteface Inn, is owned by John Kisterboch of Philadelphia, who has a cottage, Ne-an-doc, near Whiteface Inn.

THE opening of the museum in Lucerne founded by the late Russian financier and economist, author of "The Future of War," M. de Bloch, has already been announced by cable. The exercises were attended by personal friends of the donator, Baron D'Estournelles, Baroness von Suttner, M. Passy, Baron Koscielski, Mr. W.T. Stead, and M. Elie Ducomman, the Director of the Berne Central Peace Bureau.

BERLIN, June 28 -- The treaty providing for the prolongation of the alliance between Germany, Austria-Hungary, and Italy, (the Dreibund) was signed in Berlin this morning by the Imperial Chancellor, Count von Bulow: the Austrian Ambassador, L. von Szogyeny-Marich, and the Italian Ambassador, Count Lanza di Busca.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

[Copyright. 1902.] LONDON, June 28 -- There has been so much talk this week about the irony of fate in the terrible paralysis of the nation, owing to the King's sudden collapse, that it is perhaps just as well to look momentarily, and not disrespectfully, at the other side of the picture.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 28 -- All the cottages here are occupied, with some few exceptions, and many new faces are seen.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 28 -- In the County Clerk's office this morning a deed was filed by which Annie L.C. Elliman of Ridgewood, N.J., conveys to William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., thirty-nine acres of land in and about Lake Success, a few miles north of Hyde Park, in the town of North Hempstead.

PASSENGERS on a certain Eastern-bound sleeper a few days ago were treated to a quaint and amusing comedy. The train which left Cincinnati stopped at one of the little towns along its outskirts when the indifferent passengers were aroused to a sense of something important going on on the platform.

TACOMA, Washington, June 28 -- Negotiations for the right of way through Siberia will report completion shortly, and the principal obstacle in the way of building the great Siberian-American Railway will then be removed. Loicq de Lobel, an eminent French engineer, who is at the head of the enterprise, is now in St. Petersburg, securing the right of way and a land grant of ten miles for 6,000 miles through Northern Siberia.

England's tragedy, overshadowing all else of current public interest, has deadened the whole world's security markets. Here there was already a summer-time languor. The week's New York Stock Exchange record is of dullness, broken by hardly a notable movement anywhere.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, June 28 -- Richfield Spring's is having its last nap before waking up to the season's activity. In fact, many guests and cottagers have already arrived and the homes of wealthy families who have lived for years upon the surrounding hills are being rapidly put in order.

ONE of the things that struck me as being very peculiar when I first began to get acquainted with Oriental languages was the baby talk mothers used to their children," said a man who has lived for many years in the Far East.

QUITE the most remarkable feature at the recent meeting and exhibition of the Surfmen's Mutual Benefit Association, held in Elizabeth City, N.C., was the appearance of Lewis Lewark, the "strong boy" from Currituck County. Six feet two inches tall, weighing 649 pounds, and strong in proportion, Lewis attracted universal attention, and vied with the life-saving drills as an attraction.

Practically every stock on the list yeserday advanced -- some issues substantially. Leadership was assumed toy Illinois Central, Chicago and Eastern Illinois, and Missouri Pacific, with greatest strength in the first two, Illinois Central advancing over 2 points and Chicago and Eastern Illinois nearly 5.

THE sloop yacht Sibyl lay tugging at her anchor rope in the middle of the Fishkill Channel, in Jamaica Bay. June had lain her smiling benediction over all the land and sea. Oases of grass in the black water waved in the pulsing of the ebbing tide. A strong breeze from the ocean had kicked up a fretful sea.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, June 28 -- Some papers comment on the number of Americans in the patient crowd at the gates of Buckingham Palace this week, but there must have been very few in comparison with the immense numbers of English country folk, who seemed to dominate.

MRS. MARKHAM went to her country home a few days ago, where the old-fashioned flowers, even the red "cock's-comb," flourish in her garden. She left the city before the schools were closed, separating herself from the loved grandchildren, for there was another grandchild come into the family, and she wanted to see the third of those whose children would look upon her as an ancestor.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 28 -- As the climax of a personal controversy in the editorial columns of their respective papers. Desha Breckinridge, manager of The Morning Herald, and W.P. Walton, editor of The Morning Democrat, met on the street here to-day and engaged in a fist fight until bystanders separated them.
CONEY ISLAND'S new park, the most quiet and peaceful spot in the Sixty-ninth Precinct, is giving the police there a whole lot of trouble.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, June 28 -- There have been no fresh arrivals or departures at Claridge's all the week; it is a particularly homelike place in these days, and the people settled there like to stay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The three letters published in the last two Sunday editions of THE NEW YORK TIMES on the subject of old New York theatres made intensely interesting reading, particularly to an old New Yorker, but neither of them made mention of the old Richmond Hill Theatre, afterward called the Greenwich Theatre, named after Greenwich Village, which reached up to that point in the years gone by.

The innovation of racing launches and equalizing them by making allowances for difference in construction, power of engines, and other features was tried yesterday by the Columbia Yacht Club over a course northward from the organization's boathouse, at Eighty-sixth Street. The course vas sailed twice around from the boathouse to One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, a distance of twelve miles.

Every one in attendance at the Whist Congress at Manhattan Beach gave up all thought of the game yesterday morning and went to the big ballroom of the Oriental Hotel to pay their respects to the memory of Eugene S. Elliott of Milwaukee, who founded the league in 1891. After the delegates assembled, with President John T. Mitchell of Chicago in the chair, the orchestra of the Oriental played Chopin's funeral march.

LONDON, June 28 -- The closing of the Stock Exchange all the last half of the week was the very best thing that could have happened to the City, although confirmed bears opposed the action. No benefit to anybody would have been likely to result from reopening for a half day on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- It is announced at the War Department that the case of Gen. J.H. Smith will not be acted upon finally before the end of next week at the earliest.
