Judge Advocate General Davis has completed his review of the proceedings of the court-martial, and the papers are now in the hands of Secretary Root, who has not yet had time to give the case the attention it deserves.

Long-continued grief caused the death yesterday morning of Mrs. Veronica Stelz, a widow, sixty-five years old, whose husband, George Stelz, was murdered on the night of Aug. 29, 1897, in the belfry of the Church of the Most Holy Trinity, in Montrose Avenue, Williamsburg. Mrs. Stelz's death occurred at her home, 64 Montrose Avenue.

CLAYTON-ON-THE-ST. LAWRENCE, June 28 -- The day of excursions has come. One of the events of the week was an excursion from New York, in which seventy-five Germans participated. The members of this party are at the Thousand Island House, and will remain three days. A Raymond Whitcomb excursion will bring about 200 persons from Boston to the same hotel on Wednesday, July 2.

That boys are hard to be depended on in golf was again made plain yesterday at the tournament of the Morris County Country Club, for in the final for the President's Cup Reinhart was beaten by Conklin. Only on Friday both Travis, the great exponent, and Bayard had fallen down before Reinhart, yet yesterday he was beaten by a player whom he beat in the Princeton championship by 3 up and 2 to play.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The manifesto issued by the Democratic House caucus last night with reference to the alleged subserviency of the Republican Party to the trusts has been ridiculed a good deal to-day by Republican members of Congress. The Republicans profess to be vastly amused by the assumption on the part of the Democratic Representatives of deep interest in the matter of reciprocity for Cuba.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The third day's testimony given before the Senate Committee on the Philippines began with a reference to the statement made by the Admiral at the first day's proceeding concerning the proffer made by the Spanish Governor General to surrender to him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Unusual prosperity has attended the work of Atlanta University the past year. The enrollment of college students has increased nearly 25 per cent. More than double the usual number of students have entered with advanced standing from secondary schools elsewhere.
Senator Thomas C. Platt returned to the city yesterday, and unless something of importance occurs to require his attendance will not visit Washington again during this session of Congress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many of your readers who enjoyed the very excellent account of President Hadley's address to the senior class must have been astonished at the editorial which appeared in your issue of Tuesday -- "The Man and the Achievement." The writer of that editorial gives almost perfect expression to the temptation against which President Hadley was warning his students.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., June 28 -- The new residence of ex-Mayor James J. Reed at this place is nearly completed. It will cost about $10,000.

MRS. CHARLES GIBSON tells a funny experience. She is extremely particular about her stationery. While it is her pet luxury it is also her pet economy, and, knowing this, no one dares invade the sanctum of her writing desk. One day, however, she found a strange letter there -- and, oh, horrors, written on her best note paper!

THE efforts of officials of a Western town, as reported a day or two ago to "cleanse a circus of its fakirs " before it was allowed to exhibit there, excited the contempt of an old circus man in this city.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- At the prices asked for hard coal the efforts of city officials to lay in the usual Winter supply have proved futile. Ten dollars a ton was the price asked by dealers in response to Board of Education bids.

THE recent organization, with the full approval of the Secretary of War and the Commanding General of the Department of the East, of a baseball league composed of clubs representing the different military posts hereabouts is one of many things that go to show that athletics are progressing in the army.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 28 -- Gardner's pitching proved too much for Jersey City's baseball team to-day and Toronto won a game full of sensational plays. The visitors errors were costly. One-handed catches by Miller and Woods were features. Score:

MR. GREY is five years old, worth $1,000, was educated at Harvard, and does not swear. That last statement is not a reflection upon Harvard, but one justified by the well-known proclivities of Mr. Grey's race in that direction.

PAUL SMITH'S, N. Y., June 28 -- There was a mild sensation here this afternoon when the yacht Magdalene, owned by Alvie Bennett and sailed by John Quinn and Frank Kane, both of New York, capsized in the Lower St. Regis Lake. The wind was blowing a gale and the water was very cold.

HOLLYWOOD, N.J., June 28 -- A number of the New York young men who are summering at Hollywood have organized a baseball club, and are hard at work practicing daily on the lawn in front of Robert Nathan's residence on Ocean Avenue.

PITTSBURG, June 28 -- A fourteen-million-dollar coal corporation has been organized by Frank M. Osborne of Cleveland, until recently President of the Pittsburg Coal Company. A railroad has been built through 15,000 acres of the best gas coal land in the State, and ten openings are being made.

The crimson triumbhed over the blue on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon in the deciding baseball game in the series of three between Harvard and Yale. Old Elf had captured the first game at Cambridge and Harvard won the second at New Haven, each team losing on its own grounds.

BOSTON, June 28 -- The mining market is dull and unchanged. The Clearing House rate was 3 1/2 per cent. New York Funds were par and 5c premium. Call loans were 3 to 4. Time money was 4 to 5. The Clearing House exchanges were $19,242,029; balances, $1,196,010. The stock market to-day was extremely dull and devoid of feature.

BOSTON, June 28 -- Honors were even in in the two baseball games between Boston and Brooklyn to-day. Both games were notable for fast fielding and clean hitting, but errors determined Both results. The first game was Boston's until the ninth inning, when an error by Demont, filling the bases, was followed by a two-bagger and a single giving the visitors three runs and victory.

In the past week there was a revival of the rumor fever concerning new theatres. With several new theatres building for next season, the week brought the announcements of a new one on the Berkeley Lyceum site, of a possible one at 107-113 West Thirty-ninth Street for the Shubert Brothers, and of another in West Thirty-fourth Street for the Rice Amusement Company.
HERE is a great secret, but it must never be whispered, except sub rosa. There is a pretty woman in washington, the Nation's capital, who is blessed with a very beautiful pair of shoulders.

That interesting organization which has designated itself the National Association of Elocutionists at its recent convention in Chicago set in motion a movement looking to the legislative regulation of the practice of elocution as a profession from which great good may be expected if it does not stop short of what should be the ultimate aim of effort in that direction.

NEW JERSEY is to be the first State above Mason and Dixon's line to apply under State patronage the plan of the Tuskegee Institute for the benefit of its colored population. Many Northern States have applauded the practical and thorough beneficence of Booker T. Washington, but New Jersey is going to use some of its large surplus by appropriating his scheme of negro education.
"'THERE isn't one of them boats that I'd row in,' I told Mary Ann. Mary Ann's my wife, and she never seen a race before.

IN A recent issue of L'Echo de Paris an important contribution to the current history of the Humbert-Crawford affair appeared. A representative of that Journal, M. Hutin, has seen the new Minister of Justice, M. Valle, who was counsel for one of the creditors of the Humberts, and who has an extensive knowledge of the case.

T"HE richer a city becomes, the poorer it becomes," said President James L. Wells of the Department of Taxes and Assessments yesterday. " Now, this may seem to many people like a joke, but it is not. It is a fact. On July 1 the books of this department will be closed, and then our experts will be able to figure on the tax rate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been amused to notice, in a portion of the New York press, that I have, with such a distinguished associate as Prof. Meade of Pennsylvania, been promoted to the exalted position of a "bear leader," and that, further, I am credited with having received a very handsome fee from a group of Pittsburg capitalists for writing my recent open letter to the Directors.

FRANK CHAMBERLAIN, the "champion lassoer of America," has arrived at Chicago from the plains. He has given an exhibition of his skill with the lariat and described the art of throwing it in The Chicago Inter Ocean.

While Stock Exchange houses in and out of the financial district have been deploring the lack of business and the absence of customers, leading financiers in the Street have been rejoicing because of the continuance of this very condition of things. Reasons for this readily suggest themselves. Brokers have been losing commissions -- have barely been "earning their salt," as a member of a leading Stock Exchange house puts it.

THERE have lately been important developments in the "moving picture" business. Practically every theatre in the country where vaudeville is either incidental or a feature has its own machine, which at each performance projects on canvas a dozen or more active views, the exhibition being given equal prominence on the programme with the comedietta preceding or the "musical act" following.

A SCENE was enacted in a Brooklyn theatre last Saturday night that goes a long way toward proving that though Brooklyn is now a part of Manhattan, the borough across the bridge is still a long way from having adopted the blase and matter-of-fact attitude toward actors that prevails so largely in New York.

Commissioner J. Hampden Dougherty of the Department of Water, Gas, and Electricity, has made his quarterly report to Mayor Low for the three months which terminated March 31, 1902. The Commissioner in commenting upon the failure of the Board of Estimate to grant bond issues for extensions to the water supply system of the city, said:

With the growth of great corporations with large resources of capital and credit and high-grade executive managements which are prepared to undertake both the financing and construction of anything in the building line, from a doghouse or chicken coop to a reproduction of the Tower of Babel, the much-debated question of the relative status of architect and engineer is gradually changing and assuming new phases.

FEW, if any, of even the best informed of New York's citizens know that the Tombs, the old Tombs, a structure of seeming pyramidal solidity, was practically built upon a raft, and that this raft has been subjected to the rising and falling of the tide twice each day for many years.

Fully 4,000 spectators crowded around the boards at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday afternoon to witness the polo match between the Lakewood team and the representatives of Squadron A. They were rewarded by being able to witness an exhibition of the game which, although it was not quite up to championship form, was generally bright and sometimes exciting.

IT was 10 o'clock, and Simon Farley was looking for a breakfast. There seemed but little chance, however, of his quest proving successful, the business of the city was now well under way, and no one had time to stop for a starving man. Mr. Farley had eaten nothing for two days.

IT WAS Tuesday morning. The head copy reader came hustling into the office and glared about him savagely. Half a dozen office boys, unused to anything but mildness itself from Street, beat a hasty exit.

THERE is one type of American citizen which it is certain no foreign critic will ever be able to understand. It does not make much difference who the critic may be, when he confronts the type of silent and suffering baseball crank he will be at sea.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice in your issue of the 9th an announcement that the order that had been made by the Central Railroad of New Jersey prohibiting card playing upon its trains had been, rescinded, and that the long-suffering commuter was thereby greatly rejoiced and preparing again to resume his favorite occupation.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 28 -- All the hotels are open now. At the Stockton Hotel everything is particularly gay because of the presence there of the journalistic party from Washington, who are the guests of the Pennsylvania Railroad. They will remain until Monday. To-night a big ball was given in their honor, and was the first big event of the Summer.

LITERATURE, poetry, drama, and journalism, so conspicuously neglected in the honors lists of the Victorian era, were fondly expected to have found a "recognizing" friend in Edward VII., who, while Prince of Wales, gave many evidences of his interest in things literary, some of his most respected friends being men prominent in the realm of literature, such as the late Dean Stanley, Lord Playfair, and others.

LONDON, June 28 -- Had the coronation taken place American women would have constituted one of the most brilliant features. The Duchess of Marlborough had a new coronet even more magnificent than the big, pearl-tipped tiara she has hitherto worn at Court. Her unworn acquisition rivaled that of the Duchess of Portland, in which the great Portland diamond, itself worth u12,000, ($60,000), had been reset.

There was a delightful lawn fete at Lyndhurst, the home of Miss Helen M. Gould, at Irvington-on-Hudson, yesterday afternoon, and as a result $2,000 was secured toward an endowment fund for the Naval Department of the Young Men's Christian Association. This work, for the Brooklyn branch of which Miss Gould built a beautiful building costing $400,000, at 167 Sands Street, interests her greatly.

An eminent member of the Maryland bar has been commemorated in the new Court House at Baltimore by the erection of a wall-monument to Severn Teackle Wallis. The bust of Wallis stands on a shaft copied from that of the monument to Henri Regnault the painter at the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris.
More marriage licenses were issued in the Orphans' Court at Philadelphia last Wednesday than on any other day since the license system was adopted in the city. The number was 174.

COOLING drinks are among the necessities of every club at this time of the year. Nearly all the clubs in New York have some one drink which has been specially concocted by a member and the recipe of which is sometimes jealously guarded until at last it does become public property.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Some talk by Senator Morgan about a Panama lobby drew from Senator Hanna a spirited protest against the insinuation by the Alabama Senator that the action of the Senate on the canal question had been influenced by corrupt considerations.

An item of much interest is contained in the following news: "The Citizens' Party members of Pittsburg Councils favor the passage of an ordinance giving the Pittsburgh Carnegie and Western Railroad, otherwise the Wabash, an entrance into the city. If introduced in Common Council it will pass that branch at once.

Emanuel W. Bloomingdale, foreman of the June Grand Jury, and other members of the august body, patiently waited last week for the appearance of an elevator to take them to the room of their deliberations. As it happened, the six elevators were lost somewhere on the top floor, and the Grand Jury had to be content with ringing the electric bells in the hope that the elevators had not gone up through the roof.

NETHERWOOD, N.J., June 28 -- The lawn party and fair to have been held last Saturday on the lawn of Mrs. A.R. Dyett and her daughter, Mrs. J.R. Hill, was postponed until Monday on account of inclement weather. The cottage contingent turned out in full force, and the hotel guests were well represented.

THE woman was dressed in black, with the exception of her shirt-waist, which was white. But even that patch of brightness had its touch of gloom, for round the left sleeve was tied a narrow ribbon of crepe, the badge of mourning. The man in the doorway looked after the passer-by disapprovingly.

ELIZABETHTOWN, N.Y., June 28 -- This Summer deer are very plentiful and very tame. John Anderson, Jr., of Newcomb was with a number of friends recently at the hotel of Powell Smith, at the head of the Boreas River, and while eating supper they saw a buck walk leisurely upon the hillside in full view.
THERE is a building now being constructed in Manchester, England, for the British Westinghouse Company which marks the invasion of American builders into England.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in yesterday's issue, "Cleveland Denounced by Bryan," contains at least two statements which are far from being true. You refer to gatherings like the recent Tilden Club dinner as "councils in which all factions of the party unite," and bespeak for Mr. Cleveland's utterances "the marked approval of the party throughout the nation."

CLEVELAND, June 28 -- In a lonely locality a few miles east of this city to-day a test was made of a new explosive known as hathamite, the invention of Prof. H.M. Eathaway of Wellsborough, Penn. The safety features were demonstrated by pounding the explosive upon an anvil until the sparks flew, throwing it upon a fire, and placing it in a tin box and firing rifle bullets through it.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Attorney General and Mrs. Knox expect to go to Atlantic City Tuesday, where they will remain through the month of July, if not longer. Miss Knox will be with them, and their sons will join them from time to time, if they do not remain all of the month.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Gen. Horace Porter, United States Ambassador to France, who was on the staff of Gen. Grant during the civil war, has just been awarded a Congressional medal of honor for distinguished gallantry in action at the battle of Chickamauga.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 28 -- J. Arden Harriman has arrived at "Clover Patch," which he will occupy with F. J. Otis during the Summer, keeping bachelor hall.

BAR HARBOR, Maine, June 28 -- The inrush of cottagers this past week has given the resort an almost midsummer appearance. Bar Harbor never looked forward to a more promising Summer. One of the principal reasons for this is that there is included in the list of visitors who are to remain here until the Fall the names of several persons of wealth and social prominence whose presence is noted here for the first time.

ALL mankind is running to monograms this year. Mankind in this connection includes womankind as well, for both men and women are being marked for identification upon the sleeves of their shirts and shirtwaists.

ELBERON, N.J., June 28 -- Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Gawtry of New York, who have spent many Summers at this place, have closed their New York home, on Fortieth Street, and are now occupying the Loftus cottage for the Summer.

For some time we have known that the deep crimson of Harvard local color was fading to -- let us say a crushed strawberry; but we were not prepared to find it such a very crushed strawberry. First, the merry rout at class day gave up dancing on the green in front of Holworthy.

The development of the lawn tennis competitions last week brought Beals C. Wright, the Harvard expert, to the front, and he will again be called upon to show his ability to the Middle States championship tournament, which begins to-morrow on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at Mountain Station, N.J.

PASSAIC, N. J., June 28 -- An illicit distillery in a large house in the heart of the residence section of this place was raided here to-night by Internal Revenue Inspector James M. Fortune, and two women and one man were arrested and a copper still with a capacity of 150 gallons was destroyed.

IN his newest book, just now receiving its finishing touches, Gen. Lew Wallace, author of "Ben-Hur," devotes a good deal of attention to "Billy the Kid." This celebrated outlaw, who has never before had a biographer of distinction, occupies several chapters.

OMAHA, Neb., June 29 -- Both sides of the Union Pacific shopmen's labor controversy are anxiously awaiting to-morrow, to see just how effective the walk-out order to all machinists on the system will be obeyed. The Executive Committee is confident the order will be obeyed to a man and that not a single machinist will be working to-morrow, where two weeks ago there were more than 5,000.

Patrolman Harry McCutcheon of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station, better known to his colleagues on the force and to all others who know him as "Handsome Harry," has become heir to $75,000. The good fortune came to the patrolman, who is twenty-seven years old, through his uncle, William McCutcheon of Nashua, N. H.

Neither the unexpected announcement of King Edward's illness, followed by selling in this market for London account, nor the dividend disappointments in respect to Colorado Fuel, Ice Trust, and Rutland Railroad forced any liquidation in the stock market last week. The stocks directly affected were heavy, but this heaviness in nowise attached to the remainder of the list.

It is much to be hoped that the announcement is authentic and authorized which conies from Washington in an unusually plausible and responsible form that the Government will take the occasion of the Fourth of July to issue a general proclamation of amnesty in the Philippine Islands.
ALBANY, June 29 -- State Commissioner of Labor John McMackin has issued the following review of the condition of labor in thios State during the first quarter of 1902:

VIENNA, June 29 -- The Paris-Vienna automobile race was finished here to-day. Marcel Renault arrived first, but was dis-disqualified. He covered the distance from Paris to Vienna in 15 hours and 22 minutes, at an average speed of 82 kilometres (about 51 miles) an hour. Zborowski was second, Maurice Farman third, Baras fourth, Edmond fifth, and Hemery sixth.

ST. LOUIS, June 29 -- This city and vicinity is the centre of a rainstorm of unprecedented severity that has prevailed almost incessantly since Saturday morning. According to the local Weather Bureau reports, 5.45 inches of rain have fallen since early Saturday morning. At times the storm equaled a cloudburst in severity.

The prizefight which is alleged to have taken place last Monday at Witzel's Grove, College Point, as well as the allegations that on the same day there were numerous gambling games in full operation at the same place, are to form the basis of an inquiry by the Queens County Grand Jury, which will assemble this morning, although it had reported its work finished and asked for its discharge.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers of America arrived at Chicago to-day and will be here several days. When asked the object of his visit to Chicago, Mr. Mitchell said he came to settle several questions in dispute in the Illinois coal fields, which had been referred to Commissioner Herman Justi of the Illinois Operators' Association and himself.

DENVER, Col., June 29 -- Toronto having been selected as the meeting place of the next triennial convention of the International Sunday School Association in 1905, the world convention in 1904 will be held at Jerusalem. At the last world convention in London in 1894, the Executive Committee was empowered to select the next meeting place, a preference being expressed for either Toronto or Geneva.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 29 -- Harry B. Paul of Camden died at his cottage here last night of congestion of the brain. He was born in Philadelphia, June 11, 1855. He was educated in the schools of Philadelphia, and then entered the office of Gen. Louis Wagner in that city. In 1869 he was apprenticed in the shops of the Caffrey Carriage Company, Camden, and rose to the Secretaryship of the organization.

Major Ira A. Shaler, the sub-contractor in charge of Section 4 of the subway, who was so terribly injured on June 17 by being crushed down by a half-ton rock that fell on him in the tunnel at Thirty-ninth Street and Park Avenue, died at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the Presbyterian Hospital, as a result of that accident.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A small tablet of white marble, bearing in letters of gold a brief statement of the life and deeds of William McKinley, the tribute of his friend Judge Thomas H. Anderson, formerly of Ohio, but now a member of the District bench, was unveiled in the Metropolitan Methodist Episcopal Church here to-day.

The House of Representatives recently amended a Senate bill increasing pensions to those disabled by loss of limb or limbs. The increases had been approved by the Bureau of Pensions, we believe, before Commissioner EVANS was "promoted" out of the office he had filled so faithfully.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The exact time when the present session of Congress shall come to a close cannot be foretold until there is definite information as to when an agreement will be reached on the Philippine Civil Government bill. However, the general consensus of opinion places the adjournment on Tuesday, or at the latest, Wednesday.

KIEL, June 30 -- Emperor William's American-built yacht Meteor, the Cicely, owned by Cecil Quentin of England, and the other yachts which started in the schooner race yesterday, are at this hour, 12:30 A.M., drifting toward home. The Meteor is in the lead, and the Cicely is second.

MADISON, Wis., June 20 -- Miss Harriet B. Merrill, a former student in the University of Wisconsin, will sail on July 5 for Rio Janeiro. She expects to spend three months in South America, where she goes for the purpose of making a collection of fresh water Crustacea for the University of Wisconsin.

KANSAS CITY, June 29 -- One of the largest cotton mills in the world is to be built within twenty miles of Kansas City. Ten million dollars is to be invested, $3,100,000 of which has already been subscribed by Eastern and Western men. W.B. Smith Whaley, President of the Olympia and Granby Cotton Mills of Columbia, S.C., is to be President and General Manager of the enterprise.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The House of Representatives held a session to-day to pay tribute to the memories of Representative Amos J. Cummings of New York and Representative Peter J. Otey of Virginia. The widows and families of the deceased occupied the Speaker's pew in the galleries and delegations from Typographical Union No. 6 of New York, the Letter Carriers' Association, and the New York Pilots' Association came here to honor Mr. Cummings's memory.

LONDON, June 30 -- King Edward's physicians announced at 9:40 o'clock last night that the royal patient's progress was entirely satisfactory. They added that no further bulletin would be issued until to-day.

The latest addition to the micro-organisms which lie in wait for the unwary human being to implant within him the colonies of disease germs, to eradicate which is as troublesome as to eradicate the Boers from the Transvaal, is the microbe which reaches ones breakfast table through the agency of his morning mail.

Raymond Hitchcock quits this week for the vacation which it has been the good fortune of other actors to begin long ago. And it is none too soon, he intimated, for another week's work would have sent him to the hospital instead of the yachting trip along the Maine coast. He has been working almost continuously in "Dodo" since last July, and his nerves have been racked.

CAPE HAITIEN, Haiti, June 29 -- There has been much fighting here to-day, and great excitement prevails. Admiral Killick, commander of the Haitien fleet, disembarked an additional detachment of troops and a large quantity of ammunition at 4 o'clock this morning for the further protection of Gen. Firmin, one of the candidates for the Presidency.

The race for the cricket championship of New York still preserves its interesting state. Three clubs are tied in the lead, and among these the question of supremacy is one which is difficult of solution. The Knickerbocker Athletic Club and the Livingston, two of the leaders, will meet on the Fourth, and then there should be a change in the positions.
LONDON, June 29 -- Yesterday was another day of intercessional services throughout the kingdom for the recovery of King Edward.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., June 29 -- The largest student conference ever held at Northfield was started last week. Crowds of students from all the colleges have flocked to the little town, filling up the Northfield Seminary buildings and Camp Northfield and occupying the Northfiel Hotel.

The auditorium of the building of the Educational Alliance, at Jefferson Street and East Broadway, was filled last evening by a gathering of the enthusiastic friends of the young men and women who received their certificates of graduation from the Alliance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was much pleased with a communication signed "A Friend of Dogs" which appeared in your journal a short time ago. It is not often the case that a person who is so exceedingly fond of the canine race manifests so much consideration for the feelings of those who do not share his peculiar affection.

The mile run at the Knights of Columbus games at Celtic Park on Saturday will be a hard-fought battle. In this event are entered A.C. Bowen of the University of Pennsylvania and J.H. Wright of the New West Sides. Bowen will be remembered as the man who defeated Franchot of Yale in a sensational finish in the two-mile run at the intercollegiate championships on May 31 last, thus acquiring the title of intercollegiate champion.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 29 -- The operators are confident that the strike is breaking up, and will be ended soon by the great majority of the men returning to work. To-night they authorized the following statement:

TACOMA, Washington, June 29 -- Ex-Countess Overaden of Berlin, who fourteen years ago became widely known in both Europe and America, met with a tragic death at Whatcom this week. She being ill, her husband, F.G. Martesch, got up at night to get her some medicine. While he was out of the bedroom a lamp exploded.

PARIS, June 29 -- The French press views the renewal of the Triple Alliance, which was effected yesterday in Berlin by the signing of a treaty by the German Imperial Chancellor, Count von Bulow, and the Austrian and Italian Ambassadors to Germany, with considerable equanimity, and expresses the belief that the strength of the alliance has been much enfeebled by dissensions with regard to tariff questions and by the better understanding between Italy and France.

Important and popular turf events will crowd each other close at the conclusion of the present week, when the Sheepshead Bay meeting will end with the running of the greatest stake of the American turf for three-year-olds, the Lawrence Realization, and the Brighton Beach meeting will open with the running of the last of the great handicaps of the early season, the Brighton Handicap.

MANILA, June 29 -- The board which is inquiring into the charges of cruelty, , brought by Major Cornelius Gardener, Governor of the Province of Tayabas, against American officers and soldiers, being desirous of completing its sittings, held a session to-day.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 29 -- Capt. "Sam" Bryant, one of the beat-known turfmin in the country, died of dropsy at his home in this city last night after a long illness. His end was hastened by the fact that he insisted on going to Chicago to see the American Derby run a week ago, though he had to be carried to the train on a stretcher and then was advised that he was near death.

LONDON, June 30 -- A further instance of the offensively monitorial tone of the German press toward Austria-Hungary, says the Vienna correspondent of The Times, is furnished by the Berlin Post, which contends that in the projected erection of the new university the Hungarian authorities are not guided solely by educational requirements, but are promoting national aims.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- A gathering of representatives of the many religions and creeds of the world, which will rival the Congress of Religions of the World's Fair, is planned in connection with the Olympian games in 1904 by Bishop Fallows. Chairman of the Committee on Ethical and Religious Organizations.

LONDON, June 30 -- The Peking correspondent of The Times says the meeting held on Saturday by the foreign Ministers to discuss the conditions, under which Tien-Tsin shall be restored to the Chinese was without result. Dr. Mumm von Schwarzenstein, the German Minister, supported by Sir Ernest M. Satow, the British Minister, insisted that the conditions be unmodified, while the Japanese Minister favored modification.

Apparently the chief reason why the Republicans at Washington think that the address of the Democratic Congressional Committee will fall flat is the belief that the people of the United States care nothing about justice or injustice to Cuba. That is a belief that experience may rudely dispel.

Strikes are little likely to present humorous features anywhere, and least of all, perhaps, in England, where the national solemnity tends to take among the working classes the semblance of surliness, but certain London engine cleaners have managed to invent a form of industrial revolt which for a while was decidedly funny.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., June 29 -- Prayer for the speedy restoration to health of England's King was offered this morning in the Ocean Grove Auditorium by Bishop John W. Walden of Cineinnati. The venerable Bishop also asked the Almighty to bless the great nation of which the stricken King is the head -- a nation which has done much, he said, in shaping important events in the world's history.

PATERSON, N.J., June 29 -- Criminal prosecution and civil suits for damages are threatened as a result of the crusade of the Bakers' Union at Paterson for the organization of the non-union bakeshops of the city.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday, as in the enlarged issues of previous Sundays, there was variety enough to satisfy the most critical newspaper reader. The news section, that had special dispatches and correspondence from all the centres of to-day's great events, embraced whatever was of importance in the line of current happenings.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 29 -- The cruiser Brooklyn, which is to convey the remains of Lord Pauncefote to England, arrived here to-day. She anchored in the roadstead three miles off the Naval Academy. The tug Standish will transfer the casket from the Academy wharf to the Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been proposed to mark historic sites at "West Point. It has also been proposed to tear down the historic West Point Chapel. We rejoice that Congress has recently appropriated $6,000,000 for the expansion of West Point, and we can only hope that its traditions may be kept in their integrity.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 29 -- A man whose identity has not yet been established was struck and received probably fatal injuries at the station here this evening. He is supposed to have been trying to cross the tracks ahead of the second section of the Pennsylvania train No. 900. He crossed from the fireman's side and was hit by the pilot on the engineer's side.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a modest employe of a large corporation in this city and a constant reader of your valuable paper, will you kindly allow me sufficient space in reply to an article in your issue of Sunday last, signed by Mr. W.N. Wilmer, as well as several editorials recently published by you on the coal strike.

BERLIN, June 30. -- Business on the Boerse to-day had a hesitating tone, but the undercurrent was firm. Canadian Pacifics and Transvaals were somewhat harder. Mines opened higher, but the improvement was not maintained to the close.

PITTSBURG, June 30. -- Hundreds of delegates to the convention of the American Association for the Advancement of Science have arrived in Pittsburg. The first session of the National organization was held at Carnegie Music Hall this morning, and was devoted to addresses of welcome and responses.

LONDON, July 1. -- The general feeling of belief as a result of the favorable reports regarding the condition of King Edward rented itself last night by the lighting of the 3,000 bonfires throughout the United Kingdom which were originally prepared in celebrate coronation night.

-- That Mormonism, on its spiritual side, is a gross and squalid cult cannot be questioned, and this fact renders it all the more strange that now as in the past the Mormons achieve a degree of material success, even in the face of great natural disadvantages, rarely attained by their "Gentile" neighbors.

BOSTON, June 30. -- Tied up at the National Dock at East Boston is the handsome yacht Yacona, hailing from New York, but just arrived from a run from Southampton, which place was left July 17. Capt. Harding reports that the voyage was uneventful, save for the heavy weather which the vessel experienced, but which was not too much for her, being a stanch and well-built boat.

The Government to-day will relinquish $73,000,000 a year income in the repeal of the war revenue taxes. The change will mean about $30,000 a day alone to Wall Street. Although under the new schedule the taxes which remain will be raised from $175,000,000 to $200,000,000 annually, the reduction is still the most gigantic ever made.
LONDON, July 1. -- The German Catholic press, says the Berlin correspondent of The Times, is still discussing Emperor William's speech at Aix-la-Chapelle.

Racing at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday became a delight and joy for the followers of public form, and when Fatalist romped home first by a half dozen lenghts in the concluding event the enthuasiasm of backers bubbled over. The ring in general had a bad day of it, but a saving factor for the layers of odds was that the speculation was uncommonly light, in spite of a large attendance.
LONDON, July 1. -- The following bulletin was issued at Buckingham Palace at 7 P. M. yesterday:

Theophile Gautier went so far as to say that Victor Hugo would have made a great name for himself as an artist if literature had not monopolized his attention. Whatever worth there may be in such suppositions, there can be no doubt that the sketches in sepia, water colors, and pen and ink by Victor Hugo have always a pleasing vigor, and often great dramatic feeling.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The conferrees of the two houses of Congress on the Philppine Civil Government bill reached an agreement, and the conference report was presented to-day in both the House and the Senate. In the former it was adopted amid cheers on the Republican side by a vote of 149 to 92.

The Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company had an opportunity yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn office of the Department of Health, 38 Clinton Street, to show cause why it should not be proceeded against for creating a nuisance by burning soft coal. Dr. Raymond, Assistant Sanitary Superintendent, presided at the hearing.

The decision of the Trustees of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to establish a course in what, for want of a better name, has been designated insurance engineering, is commendable and should meet with hearty encouragement from the fire underwriters. Its object will be to instruct those who take the course in the selection and constructive use of materials with a view to minimizing the risk of destruction by fire.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is not a business man judged as much by what he omits to do as by what he does? Our esteemed Controller, whom we all know as an able business man, has been guilty of a questionable legal trick in stating only one side of a proposition -- and need I say the side which he favors? -- while omitting the strongest point of the opposition.

LONDON, June 30. -- John Barkley, who pleaded guilty on June 4 to the charge of attempting to break into the house of J. Pierpont Morgan, Jr., was sentenced today at the Old Bailey to five years' imprisonment.
To prohibit the killing or taking of seals, porpoises, whales, or marine animals or fish of any kind in the waters of the United States by means of explosive materials.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The New York delegation in Congress, ordinarily a pacific organization which is never heard from at all, to-day achieved a victory by over-throwing "Uncle Joe" Cannon, the watch-dog of the Treasury and war horse of the Committee on Appropriations, when the General Deficiency bill came to a vote.

LONDON, July 1. -- Coquelin's acting in "Cyrano de Bergerac" at the Garrick Theatre yesterday was as full of personal charm and variety as ever, but the somewhat inferior scenic dress of Rostand's play and the subordination of all the other personages to the star had their effect on the audience, which was appreciative but not overdemonstrative.

DUBLIN, June 30. -- All the principal streets of Dublin were splendidly illluminated to-night in honor of the King's satisfactory progress, and they were so crowded with people that it was necessary to stop vehicular traffic.

Mr. CHAMBERLAIN was in conference with the Colonial Premiers yesterday, and will probably continue to confer with them for some days. It is reported that he confined himself yesterday to explaining his own views. When he comes to getting those of the Colonials there will be a good deal to talk of.
LONDON, June 30. -- The half year end requirements increased the demand for money to-day. Discounts were Steady on the prospect of easier conditions after the release of the July dividends.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The Secretary of War has prepared, in accordance with the resolution of the House of Representatives, a list of officers of the army promoted since April 1, 1898, "who have been retired within one year of their last promotion with a higher grade than that held at the time of their promotion."

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Another important change in the packing field was made public to-day when it was announced formally that Armour Co. had secured the Omaha Packing Company after a sharp tilt with the Swifts, who were bidding for the same interest. It was further informally announced that Armour had practically secured the international Packing Company's Chicago plants at the Union Stock Yards.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The watchfulness of Mr. Relyes, Chief of the Redemption Division of the Treasury Department, spoiled a clever scheme concocted in Philadelphia for getting money from the Government by fraud. Early in May there came to Mr. Relyes's division the upper halves of several Treasury notes, the aggregate face value of which was $56.

NEWPORT, June 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Widener of Philadelphia arrived for the season to-day at the Pinard cottage. All the cottages are now occupied except that rented by Mrs. William B. Ogden. The occupants are Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt, Mr. and Mrs. W.M. Kingsland, Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Wickes, and Mr. and Mrs. Widener.

ALBANY, June 30. -- The fortieth University Convocation of the State of New York was opened in the Senate Chamber tonight. Regent St. Clair McKelway presided. Gov. B.B. Odell, Jr., delivered the address of welcome. In the course of his address he said:

LONDON, July 1. -- The Colonial Conference was opened yesterday morning in the room of the Secretary of State at the Colonial Office. The Premiers of the self-governing colonies were present, and the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain presided at the sitting, which was of a purely preliminary character.

The McVickar Realty Trust Company has sold for Mrs. Anna Schiele the plot at the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-fifth Street. 75.5 by 60, now occupied by three four-story dwellings. The buyer is Thomas B. Hidden, who is the owner of a plot of 17,000 square feet, surrounding the Schiele parcel and including 1,540 and 1,542 Broadway, 163 to 171 West Forty-fifth Street, and 162 and 164 West Forty-sixth Street.

Commissioner Lindenthal announced yesterday that Bridge No. 4 over the East River, known as the Blackwell's Island Bridge, will be 80 feet in width instead of 120 feet, as originally planned. Commissioner Lindenthal would not personally discuss the changes in the plans, but allowed subordinates to talk about the matter.

Christopher R. Forbes. Christopher Robert Forbes, a descendant of John Van Arsdale, who pulled down their flag when the British evacuated New York, is dead. He raised the flag on Evacuation Day at the Battery for many years. In 1896 Asa Bird Gardiner got a permit from the city allowing the Society of the War of 1812 to assume the honor.

Some fast runs were made on the Lackawanna Railroad by a special train, consisting of two Pullman cars, a private car, and a combination baggage and smoking car, which went up to the Pocono Mounttains with a party of newspaper men on Saturday and Sunday last.

New York's baseball team played with its usual weakness at the bat, and in consequence was easily defeated by the Bostons at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. The fact that it was shut out by the one-sided score of 8 to 0 shows how clearly the Bostons were its masters at the game.

KIEL, June 30. -- Emperor William steered his American-built schooner yacht Meteor across the finish line at 1:30 o'clock this morning, two hours behind the Iduna, the Empress's yacht, which, in the lightest of airs, between flat calms, passed from the tail end to heard of the fleet. The Lasca came in second.
NEWARK, N.J., June 30. -- The death of Mrs. Elizabeth Wild, an aged resident of Belleville, a few days ago, has revealed the fact that the deceased was for years a victim of Christian Science.

LONDON, June 30. -- Ian Z. Malcolm, member of Parliament for the Stowmarket Division of Suffolk and ex-assistant private secretary to Lord Salisbury, was married this afternoon to Miss Jeanne Langtry, daughter of Mrs. Langtry, the actress, at St. Margaret's Church, Westminster.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 30. -- Massasoit, the Crowninshield boat built for Commodore MacDonald and others of the Bridgeport Yacht Club had considerably the best of it at the end of the first day's racing to select a challenger for the Seawanhaka Cup.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The Senate listened this afternoon to another discussion on Cuba which followed a speech of Mr. Elkins, made in support of his Cuban annexation resolution. Mr. Elkins said that his resolution had been misunderstood. It had no bearing upon Cuban reciprocity, and was not intended to have any.

An electric elevated train of two cars had a narrow escape from being pitched over into the street opposite the Grand Central Station yesterday afternoon. It struck a bunker at the platform with such a jolt that the fifty passengers were thrown forward violently, and one of them, Andrew Jackson of the Jackson Express Company, was injured severely on the chest.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 30. -- Louis Disbrow, accused of causing the death of Clarence Foster and also that, of Sarah Lawrence, is now in the custody of Sheriff Wells. In company with his counsel, Rowland Miles of Northport, Disbrow arrived here on the fast express from Long Island City at 5:18. He looked wan and pale, but seemingly in better physical condition than he was while at Good Ground.

LONDON, June 30. -- A large company assembled at the National Sporting Club tonight to witness the boxing contests held in connection with the coronation sporting tournament, between American college students and English amateurs. All the professional fighters who took part in the contests held last week were present to-night, and in some cases they acted as attendants for the American students.

In spiteof the fact that the Paris press has assured us of the trust worthiness of the reports in the Italian popular papers, that Italy would not pledge herself to the Dreibund for another six years, cable dispatches from Berlin announce the prolongation of the alliance between Germany, Austria-Hungary, and Italy.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30. -- The local stock market to-day displayed pronounced firmness, with a good demand for Union Traction, Reading, and Cambria Steel, but the trading signified nothing, the same interests operating at times on both sides. The fact that Union Traction goes on a dividend basis to-morrow attracted inquiry for that stock, and Philadelphia Rapid Transit was benefited fractionally.
WASHINGTON, June 30. -- "Do you retract?"

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Unless the general managers of the railroads reverse their announced decision in regard to a new scale of wages. 10,000 freight handlers will in all probability quit work to-morrow morning in all the railroad warehouses and freight sheds in Chicago.

Senator PLATT hears in Washington that The New York Democrats will nominate Col. LAMONT for Governor. That report has been current here. We do not know that any one has authority to say that Col. LAMONT would accept a nomination. He is actively engaged in business, in which, it is understood, he has been very successful.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is recuired for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

The identity of the mysterious Mr. Cutler, the man who rakes in $1,000,000 a year in dividends from the United States Steel Corporation, has at last been established. He is not Andrew Carnegie, but John D. Rockefeller.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINES SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption it "The Man in the Street."

Yesterday's Stock Exchange market duplicated pretty generally the features that have been distinguishing Wall Street business for some time past. There was dullness with firmness, good business reports, scanty showing of public interest, and trifling fluctuations.

ST. LOUIS, June 30. -- As a result of the severe storm on Saturday night over two hundred persons camped cut on electric cars between Belleville and East St. Louis all night, and were exposed to danger from the wind and from electric wires.

A northward-bound Lexington Avenue car was in collision with an electric hansom at Thirtieth Street and Lexington Avenue late last evening. Although five persons were hurt and six women fainted, the police did not send in an ambulance call, nor did they make many efforts to take the names of those injured.

Michael Manion, a bellman employed to signal beside the shaft of the largest of two elevators used for hauling materials up and down in the new Hanover Bank Building, at Nassau and Pine Streets, fell six stories down one of the elevator shafts yesterday, and was taken to the Hudson Street Hospital without having sustained any injury except a cut on his head and a bad shaking up.
DENVER, Col., June 30. -- Proceedings on behalf of the State of Colorado to dissolve the Smelter Trust were started in the State Supreme Court this afternoon.

BALTIMORE, June 30. -- The local market showed a slight improvement in tone, though there was very little to back it in the way of additional activity. Cotton Duck incomes were better. The extra firmness was occasioned by the tendency toward recovery, due to the corrected understanding as to the bond prospects.

It is not intemperate to characterize any further delay in fixing the date for a general resumption of work in the anthracite mines as a crime against the public interest. The plea of the operators that it was necessary for the safeguarding of their interests that the present union should be defeated no longer has force.

There were some important changes in the elevated department of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company yesterday. P.W Folger, General Superintendent of that department, resigned his position for some reason, but whether his withdrawal was the result of a general difference of opinion, as was reported, could not be learned positively last night.

BAR HARBOR, June 30. -- William E. Dodge of New York has rented Stanwood, the famous old Blaine mansion. Mr. Dodge came Sunday. Abram S. Hewitt, ex-Mayor of New York, has taxen Reverie Cove, the Summer home of Mrs. J.D. Jones of Cincinnati.

ALBANY, June 30. -- State Superintendent of Public Instruction Charles R. Skinner to-day announced appointments to State scholarships in Cornell University. These scholarships entitle their holders to a four years' course of instruction in Cornell University free of tuition. The names of the successful ones in New York and Kings Counties follow:

CLIFF HAVEN, N.Y., June 30. -- Here in this garden spot of the Adirondack region are assembled ninety clergymen of the Burlington (Vt.) and Ogdensburg (N.Y.) Dioceses, with their respective Bishops, the Right Revs. Michand and Gabriels. They are on their annual retreat. The clergyman who is giving the retreat is the Rev. Father Charles Lang of the Passionist Fathers.

Major Isaac W. Littell, Quartermaster, is relieved from further duty in the Division of the Philippines and will proceed at once to New York City and report to the depot Quartermaster for duty in his office, to relieve Major Samuel R. Jones, Quartermaster, of his temporary assignment.

VIENNA, July 1 -- The committee having control of the recent international motor race from Paris to Vienna has decided not to disqualify Marcel Renault, who was the first contestant to arrive here, because he failed to stop at the control station, at Florisdorf, where the final racing time was to be taken.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The State Department has not yet been notified of the Chinese refusal to pay the July indemnity installment except at the rate of exchange prevailing on April 1, 1901. The department regrets being placed in the position of taking issue with other powers on this question, which is so important that grave doubt is entertained as to the probable effect of an insistence on the European contention, as affecting China's integrity.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 1 -- With a plea of not guilty entered for him, Louis Disbrow this afternoon went back to spend his second night in the county jail at Riverhead. The actual proceedings to-day did not take fifteen minutes. Disbrow uttered not one word, all the talking on his behalf being done by his counsel, Rowland Miles.

BALTIMORE, July 1 -- The strength of Light and Power issues were the feature of to-day's market. The preferred and the 4 1/2 per cent, bonds were both higher. The bonds have advanced 2 3/4 points in two days and the stock advanced proportionately. The strength of the issues is ascribed to the favorable position they are expected to hold in the deal with the Susquehanna Company.

As Saturday will be practically a holiday as well as Friday, to-morrow will see an outpouring of clubmen who are going to the reserts for house parties. Quite a number of well-known people left yesterday to attend the wedding of Miss Julia Pierrepont Edwards and Reginald Mansfield Johnson, which takes place to-day at Bar Harbor.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 1 -- The first loss of life during the anthracite strike occurred to-day at the William A. Colliery at Duryea. Antonio Giusuepe, an Italian, was shot dead by one of the Coal and Iron policeman from behind the stockade of the colliery.
Philadelphia dispatches stating that the Mallory Line has just contracted for a new $1,000,000 steamer.

An approximated statement of the earnings of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad, generally known as the Big Four, for the year ended June 30, which was published yesterday, shows a decrease of $151,003 in net earnings, due to a heavy increase in operating expenses.

Wall Street has been wondering for a month who was really behind the suit brought in New Jersey in the name of Mrs. Miriam Berger to prevent the United State Steel Corporation from retiring its 7 per cent. preferred stock and issuing therefor 5 per cent. bonds to the amount of $200,000,000. The man back of the suit is Francis D. Carley, whose meteoric financial career is a matter of familiar history it the Street.
ST. PAUL, July 1 -- The Minnesota Republicans, in convention to-day, nominated the following ticket:

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Acting Secretary of War Sanger to-day sent a communication to the House of Representatives in answer to the resolution directing the Secretary of War to furnish information as to what amounts have been paid out of the Cuban Treasury or funds of the Cuban people to F.B. Thurber, or any other person, corporation, or association for advocating reciprocity with the United States.

LONDON, July 2 -- The Peking correspondent of The Times says that a British-French syndicate, registered in London and represented in China by the ex-French Consul General, Emile Rochere, has secured a valuable mining concession in Tun-Nan Province. It was sanctioned by an imperial decree of June 15, and the contract has been officially recognized and signed by the British and French Ministers at Peking.
BERLIN, July 1 -- Mme. Teressa Carreno, the distinguished Pianiste, was married here yesterday to her fourth husband, Arturo Tagliapietra of New York, who is a brother of her Second husband.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- New York exchange to-day was 20 cents discount; time and call loans are still at 4 1/2@5 per cent., but firm. Local stocks showed little change to-day. There was no gossip to affect speculation In anything, and commission house orders on both sides of the market were scarce. Complete transactions were as follows:

NEWPORT, July 1 -- Senor Don Juan Riano, First Secretary and Charge d'Affaires of the Spanish Legation at Washington; J.H. Van Roijen of the Netherlands Legation, and Marion Randolph Wright of Boston are at the Berkeley for the Summer.

"What is that strange-looking beast in there?" said a man yesterday morning, who had followed the crowd into the Aquarium, and joined the bigger crowd that stood around the tank in which a scaleless, finless, flatheaded, six-toot-long, snakelike fish was to be seen.

Something unique in the line of city embellishment had been accomplished when late yesterday afternoon Old Glory was raised on a stretch of land licked by the ocean at Coney Island, and the crowd of several thousand men, women, and children yelled "Hurrah for Seaside Park!" A moment later the crowd remembered also to be grateful, and added: "Hurrah for Park Commissioner Young!"

A heavy track and plentiful scratching made extra guessing for the handicappers and form followers at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday, but the results were all in favor of backers, for four post favorites got to the judges first, and in the six races only one real outsider was returned winner.

BERLIN, July 1 -- Prices on the Boerse to-day were firm and business was quiet. There were some speculative purchases of Mines, the prospects of which were considered to be more encouraging. Canadian Pacifics were harder on New York advices.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Senate indulged in a final debate on the Philippine bill to-day, when Mr. Lodge moved the adoption of the conference report.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 1 -- There was no racing to-day for the trial yachts which are striving for the honor to challenge for the Sea wanhaka Cup. The day broke with a cloudy sky and with little wind. During the forenoon, however, the breeze came in strong from the northwest, and increased to half a gale before 12 o'clock.

ORANGE, N.J., July 1 -- Joseph B. McCallam, employed at the Orange office of the Essex and Hudson Gas Company, lies in the Orange Memorial Hospital suffering from a pistol wound that may prove fatal, inflicted this morning by Miss Anna Hildebrandt, a nurse and graduate of the Margaret Fahnestock Training School of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital, in the class of 1895.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- July corn sold at 78 cents to-day. Up almost 6 cents, down to starting point, and closing 1 1/2 cents higher -- that was its record. The following table tells the story of the day's cereal prices: ...

The savings banks of this city are wise in contesting the rule of the State Controller in regard to taxing "dividends." It is their plain duty to ascertain by appeal to the highest tribunal whether the demand of the Controller is in accordance with law. Of course, if it is, the banks will comply with the law until it is changed.

The burning of three cars on the Third Avenue elevated railroad by fire communicated from the high-tension power current of the third rail gives more significance than was understood or appreciated at the time to the recent letter of Mr. GEORGE WESTINGHOUSE to THE NEW YORK TIMES, pointing out the dangers attendant upon an electrical installation when the work is not done as well as is possible in the present state of the art.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The comparative annual statement of the receipts and expenditures of the United States, issued by the Secretary of the Treasury to-day, shows that for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1902, the total receipts amounted to $563,405,187, as against $537,685,337 for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1901.

It would have been entirely satisfactory to the public sense of justice if the promoters of the Charleston and Buffalo fairs had failed in the attempt to get themselves reimbursed out of the Public Treasury for their losses in those undertaking's. It is by no means satisfactory to know that they have succeeded.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R.S." for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

A bold and original plan to give relief from the evils and dangers of overcrowding at the entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge has at length been devised, and characteristically enough it proceeds from the office of the Rapid Transit Commission. The solving of the most serious transportation problems that confront us seems somehow, sooner or later, to depend upon this competent and extraordinarily useful board.

LONDON, July 2 -- The reappearance yesterday of Queen Alexandra as a participant in a public ceremony practically marked the end of the period of anxiety caused by King Edward's condition. The Queen's presence at the review of the colonial troops by the Prince of Wales greatly increased public enthusiasm over what in itself was a picturesque and interesting event.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 1 -- Lady Curzon, the wife of the Viceroy of India, will arrive in Bar Harbor about the middle of August. She will remain several weeks with her mother, Mrs. Letter, at Mossley Hall. This is Lady Curzon's first visit to America since her marriage. The trying Indian climate has weakened her greatly, and she is coming home in search of health.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Tariffs were put in effect to-day by all the roads, making the same rates on live stock as on dressed beef and packing house products. This was in conformity with the promise made by the Western roads to the Inter-State Commerce Commission at the time the complaints of the Chicago Live Stock Exchange were up for a hearing.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was along very quiet lines, and except in a few stocks transactions were not of sufficient importance to attract any attention. The demand that has resulted in substantial advances in some of the preferred industrials was still in evidence. Borden's Condensed Milk preferred sold at the record price, 108 1/8, and in one or two other cases quotations were advanced without sales.

The New York baseball team employed a young man named Wagner in short field yesterday. Wagner is from the semi-professional Murray Hill team, but this did not save the nine from defeat at the hands of the Boston team, although they played better than they did on Monday.

The painful impression made by the misbehavior of Senator BAILET is even deeper than that made not long ago by the misbehavior of Senator TILLMAN. There is no occasion for the Senate to take notice of the later outrage, for it did not occur during the session of the body.

A meeting took place late yesterday afternoon in the offices of the American Tin Plate Company, 21 State Street, between the officials of the company and the Conference Committee of the tin plate workers. President Shaffer of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers is ex-officio a member of the Conference Committee.

There was a glimpse into the future of the Greater New York yesterday afternoon, when at the special meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission at 320 Broadway the report and plans of Chief Engineer William Barclay Parsons were read. President A.E. Orr presided, and the others present were Mayor Low, Commissioners John H. Starin, Charles Stewart Smith, Chief Engineer Parsons, Controller Grout, and Edward M. Shepard. and Albert B. Boardman, counsel for the Commissioners.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Just before the Senate adjourned finally to-day, Senator Allison. Chairman of the Committee on Appropriations, presented a statement showing the total appropriations for the session by bills, as follows:

The highly sensational and exaggerated reports of crop damage sent out overnight from the West -- undoubtedly inspired with the object of influencing prices in the grain market, where an active campaign for higher figures is in progress -- were responsible for the lower range of values recorded on the Stock Exchange yesterday shortly after the opening.

David Barrie, for the past half dozen years the representative in New York of Sir Thomas Lipton, filed a precipe for a subpoena against Sir Thomas in the United States Circuit Court yesterday. The institution of the suit came as a great surprise to the friends of both men, for it was supposed that they were still the best of friends.
Second Lieut. Henry M. Fales, Twenty-first Infantry, is relieved from further duty at the Presidio of San Francisco, and will proceed to join his regiment.

PLATTSBURG, July 1 -- The convention held here to-day to nominate a candidate for member of Congress from the Twenty-sixth District broke up in a disagreement. The three counties, Franklin, Clinton, and Essex clung together, and nominated William H. Flack of Franklin, giving him 20 votes to Senator George R. Malby's 17.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your amusing editorial in Sunday's issue regarding elocutionary study does not exactly harmonize with that in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of April 12, in which the writer, referring to the value of declaiming extracts from the best literature, says "What work of public education in polite letters could be more needful or more beneficent?"

Shortly after 8 o'clock last night a handsome and stylishly dressed young woman was handed into a closed carriage in front of the Hotel Bingham. Ninety-fourth Street and Broadway, by a tall man with a light mustache. A young woman apparently a nurse was standing by holding a little girl by the hand.

Arthur S. Cox Co. and L.J. Du Mahaut have sold for Martha H. Andrew, 198 Broadway, a six-story building, between John and Fuiton Streets, which was formerly occupied by the Dennison Manufacturing Company, and which was gutted by fire about six months ago. The price paid for the property is $325,000. The buyer is a builder, who will erect on the site a twelve-story office building costing $250,000, from plans by Walter H. Wickes.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- The buying of Cambria Steel was one of the chief points of interest in the local market to-day. The price rose under persistent demand from 24 1/4 to 23 1/3 This is the highest price ever reached by the new stock. Besides Cambria, other steel stocks enjoyed a moderate demand.
LONDON, July 2 -- The following bulletin was posted at Buckingham Palace at 7 o'clock last evening:
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The following is the Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions:

ALBANY, July 1 -- The feature of the morning session of the University Convocation was an address on the subject of "The Elective System" by President J.G. Schurman of Cornell University. President Schurman said in part:

BALTIMORE, July 1 -- The entire system of electric railways in this city and its suburbs is to be operated by power furnished by immense hydraulic and electric works on the Susquehanna River, run on the Niagara plan.
LONDON, July 1 -- Money was more abundant to-day, and rates were easier with the torn of the half year and heavy coupon and dividend payments.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., July 1 -- Several hundred strikers assembled on the streets of St. Clair to-day and, headed by a drum corps, paraded around town. They then separated and marched to the various highways and paths leading to the washery of the St. Clair Coal Company, which commenced operations yesterday.
ATLANTA, July 2. -- Georgia Democrats in State Convention here to-day nominated the following ticket:

PRINCETON, N.J., July 2. -- The biggest surprise in Princeton's entrance examination that has sprung up during the past ten years came to-day when it was announced at the Registrar's office that twenty-two students from the Phillips Academy at Andover, Mass., were debarred from admission to the entering class on the charge of cribbing.

The failure of the jury to find Capt. HERLIHY guilty of neglect of duty in the face of perfectly clear, unmistakable, and undisputed evidence is discouraging. Comment on a case that is res adjudicata would seem to be useless and unprofitable. HERLIHY is in a position to continue to neglect his duty, and that he will fail to avail himself of this privilege is beyond the range of probability.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Buencamino, the Filipino leader, has secured possession of the pen with which the President signed the Philippine Government bill, and purposes to take it to Manila for presentation to the public library of that city. When he asked the President for the pen, he was told that it had been given to Senator Lodge.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 2. -- Honors are pretty nearly even between the yachts Massasoit and Tecumseh at the end of the second day's racing for the purpose of selecting a challenger for the Seawanhaka Cup in the Bridgeport Tacht Club regatta. Tecumseh won two races to-day and Massasoit one.

HARRISBURG, Penn., July 2. -- The examination into the charges of conduct unbecoming a Bishop, preferred against Bishop Talbot of the Central Pennsylvania Diocese, Protestant Episcopal Church, by the Rev. Dr. Ingram N.W. Irvine of Philadelphia, was conducted in executive session today by the Board of Inquiry recently appointed by Bishop Dudley of Kentucky.

BALTIMORE, July 2. -- The Baltimore baseball team and the American League may lose John McGraw and Joe Kelley before the close of the season. While McGraw would neither confirm nor deny a report from New York to-day that he had opened negotiations with the New York Club, he said: "I have received offers from various clubs. No, I don't care to state if I have or have not negotiated with the New York Club."

GREENWICH, Conn., July 2. -- A runaway pony dragged Richard Wainwright, Jr., aged seven years, nearly a half mile today on the old White plains Road, resulting in almost instantaneous death. The boy's father is engaged in the shipping business in New York City, and resides at Milton Point, Rye.

BALTIMORE, July 2. -- President L.J. Loree of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad returned to-day from an inspection trip, during which $8,000,000 of new work was reviewed. This embraced 21,000 miles of railway or less than half the system. The inspection included the trackage and stations, coal and timber resources along the West Virginia and Pittsburg Railroad and the Pittsburg and Western and new improvements now under way or projected.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The Bailey-Beveridge affair is not ended yet. Solicitor Penfield of the State Department, the official in whose cause the two Senators came to blows, has issued a statement regarding Senator Bailey. The language used in this statement far surpasses anything Mr. Beveridge said about the Texan.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Gen. Miles issued to-day a general order announcing that the Secretary of War had detailed the following officers as members of the War College Board:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 2. -- Probably the most interesting polo game ever played on the Rumeon grounds was contested there this afternoon between George J. Gould's Lock-wood team and the Rockaway four of Long Island. Fifteen hundred people witnessed the sport, the field being lined with handsome equipages coming from all the resorts of the North Jersey coast.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Mr. Ridgely, Controller of the Currency, has issued a statement showing that there were added to the National bank system in the last fiscal year 437 National banking associations, with aggregate authorized capital stock of $30,407,000, and with bond deposits of $6,012,750 as security for circulation.

There was a tragic climax yesterday morning to the recent long series of burglaries in the Bedford District of Brooklyn, when Albert C. Latimer was shot and probably fatally wounded by a thief whom he had cornered in a closet in his home, at 318 Hancock Street. The burglar escaped after the shooting, and the police hunt for him was fruitless.

OMAHA, Neb., July 2. -- The strike of the machinists and boilermakers of the Union Pacific seems to have settled down to a stubborn, quiet fight for supremacy. The strikers felt more encouraged to-day from the walk-out of their craftsmen on the Northwestern and Montana Central Railroads, which they say will greatly assist them.

In consenting to discuss the problems and peculiarities of the open car with an assemblage of women especially well provided with words and the inclination to use them, Mr. OREN ROOT, Jr., invited the trying experience he underwent and vindicated his courage at the expense of his discretion.

BOSTON, Mass., July 2. -- Acting Princi- pal Graves of the Phillips Andover Academy, asked to-night if he knew anything in regard to the circumstances of the cribbing said to have been discovered in the Princeton examination papers turned in by the Andover boys, said: "I did not hear anything about it until to-night.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- A Washington paper publishes the following with reference to the verdict of the court-martial that tried Gen. Jacob H. Smith:
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- There is nothing approaching a consensus in the explanations given by Senators, Representatives, and others for the failure of Congress to pass a Cuban relief bill.

ECKENFOERDE, Prussia, July 2. -- Emperor William's schooner yacht Meteor, which was built in the United States, was beaten for the fourth time by the British schooner Cicely yesterday in the long run from Kiel. The Clara was second and the Meteor was third. The Imperial Chancellor Count von Billow, was a guest of the Emperor on the Meteor.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 2. -- A runaway pony dragged Richard Wainwright, Jr., aged seven years, nearly a half mile today on the old White plains Road, resulting in almost instantaneous death. The boy's father is engaged in the shipping business in New York City, and resides at Milton Point, Rye.

The Treasury of the United States closed its business on the last day of the fiscal year with an "available cash balance" of $208,630,022. During the year the receipts and expenditures had been as follows:

Application was made yesterday in the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of New York for the appointment of a receiver for the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association and the Mutual Reserve Life Insurance Company of Broadway and Duane Street, which it is charged is hopelessly insolvent.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The Congressional committees are busy getting ready for an active campaign in the Fall.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- There is nothing approaching a consensus in the explanations given by Senators, Representatives, and others for the failure of Congress to pass a Cuban relief bill.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Gen. Miles issued to-day a general order announcing that the Secretary of War had detailed the following officers as members of the War College Board:

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- A story that rivals fiction is back of the arrest and imprisonment of Mrs. Ailene O'Malley, aged twenty-four years, wife of Prof. Austin O'Malley, and William Hearin, twenty years old, of 14 Morningside Heights, New York, with whom, it is alleged, the woman tried to elope.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Buencamino, the Filipino leader, has secured possession of the pen with which the President signed the Philippine Government bill, and purposes to take it to Manila for presentation to the public library of that city. When he asked the President for the pen, he was told that it had been given to Senator Lodge.

GOOD GROUND, L.I., July 2. -- Louis A. Disbrow, accused of the murder of Clarence Foster and Sarah Lawrence, to-day for the second time faced Justice Foster, who issued the warrant for his arrest, and the formal proceedings which may end in his being committed to the county jail to await the action of the Grand Jury were begun.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, July 2. -- Louis L. Richman and his wife, Rachael, of New York were arraigned before Justice of the Peace Willard Davis to-night, charged with stealing a pearl necklace worth $25,000 and $400 in money from Dr. and Mrs. Walter E. Delabarre of New York at the Crossmon House last night.

NEWARK, N.J., July 2. -- Judge Andrew Kirkpatrick in the United States Circuit Court has appointed ex-State Senator Michael T. Barrett of this city and J.W. Newbery of New York receivers of the Monmouth Savings and Loan Association, which holds property in various parts of the State, with a principal office at 243 Washington Street, Jersey City.

B'nal B'rith, a Jewish secret organization with a membership of more than 30,000, had an open meeting last evening in the hall of the Educational Alliance, at East Broadway and Jefferson Street. Simon Roeder, President of Justice Lodge, presided. The occasion was enlivened by the band of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society, which rendered patriotic and popular music.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 2. -- Jersey City took the last game of the present series with Rochester to-day. The game was fast and scientific until the eighth inning, when everybody batted, and the finish was of a heart-breaking variety. Rochester attempteel a whirlwind finish, but could not quite reach it.

The game was fast and scientific until the eighth inning, when everybody batted, and the finish was of a heart-breaking variety. Rochester attempteel a whirlwind finish, but could not quite reach it.
