BOSTON, July 2. -- The United States National Lawn Tennis Association announced to-night the programme for the championship of which the doubles are to be played in two sections, first at Chicago, July 19, and the second at Longwood, July 28. The singles championships will be held at Newport, beginning August 19.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- A Washington paper publishes the following with reference to the verdict of the court-martial that tried Gen. Jacob H. Smith:

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- During the twelve months just ended there were executed in the Government mints 191,419,506 coins of all denominations, with an aggregate value of $94,526,678.12, as compared with a coinage of 176,999,132, total valued at $136,340,781.58, in 1901. The increase in the number of pieces was 14,420,374; the decrease in value, $41,814,103.46.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 2. -- Americans who have investments in Mexico are much interested in the case of the American creditors of the Monterey and Mexican Gulf Railroad, which was recently acquired by the Mexican Central. The claims of these creditors aggregate about $1,500,000. Judgment was obtained in the lower courts and affirmed by the Supreme Court.

OMAHA, Neb., July 2. -- The strike of the machinists and boilermakers of the Union Pacific seems to have settled down to a stubborn, quiet fight for supremacy. The strikers felt more encouraged to-day from the walk-out of their craftsmen on the Northwestern and Montana Central Railroads, which they say will greatly assist them.

BALTIMORE, July 2. -- The Baltimore baseball team and the American League may lose John McGraw and Joe Kelley before the close of the season. While McGraw would neither confirm nor deny a report from New York to-day that he had opened negotiations with the New York Club, he said: "I have received offers from various clubs. No, I don't care to state if I have or have not negotiated with the New York Club."

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 2. -- Miss Julia Pierrepont Edwards and Reginald Mansfield Johnson were married here at noon to-day in the presence of a large gathering of society people that crowded to the doors the Transcept Street Saviour's Episcopal Church. The bride is the eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Pierrepont Edwards of New York.

The failure of the jury to find Capt. HERLIHY guilty of neglect of duty in the face of perfectly clear, unmistakable, and undisputed evidence is discouraging. Comment on a case that is res adjudicata would seem to be useless and unprofitable. HERLIHY is in a position to continue to neglect his duty, and that he will fail to avail himself of this privilege is beyond the range of probability.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 2. -- Probably the most interesting polo game ever played on the Rumeon grounds was contested there this afternoon between George J. Gould's Lock-wood team and the Rockaway four of Long Island. Fifteen hundred people witnessed the sport, the field being lined with handsome equipages coming from all the resorts of the North Jersey coast.

BOSTON, July 2. -- The United States National Lawn Tennis Association announced to-night the programme for the championship of which the doubles are to be played in two sections, first at Chicago, July 19, and the second at Longwood, July 28. The singles championships will be held at Newport, beginning August 19.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 2. -- The running races of the Rhode Island Jockey Club at Narragansett Park to-day were marred by an accident in the steeplechase. Foolhardy fell at the water jump, throwing his jockey, Alfred Hewitt, who sustained cranial injuries, possible a fracture. His wrist was also broken.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, July 2. -- Louis L. Richman and his wife, Rachael, of New York were arraigned before Justice of the Peace Willard Davis to-night, charged with stealing a pearl necklace worth $25,000 and $400 in money from Dr. and Mrs. Walter E. Delabarre of New York at the Crossmon House last night.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The Bailey-Beveridge affair is not ended yet. Solicitor Penfield of the State Department, the official in whose cause the two Senators came to blows, has issued a statement regarding Senator Bailey. The language used in this statement far surpasses anything Mr. Beveridge said about the Texan.
As a matter of public duty would it not be a good idea for some one -- Mr. POULTNEY BIGELOW or another personal friend -- to send to the Emperor of Russia a letter to the following effect:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 2. -- The running races of the Rhode Island Jockey Club at Narragansett Park to-day were marred by an accident in the steeplechase. Foolhardy fell at the water jump, throwing his jockey, Alfred Hewitt, who sustained cranial injuries, possible a fracture. His wrist was also broken.

BALTIMORE, July 2. -- President L.J. Loree of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad returned to-day from an inspection trip, during which $8,000,000 of new work was reviewed. This embraced 21,000 miles of railway or less than half the system. The inspection included the trackage and stations, coal and timber resources along the West Virginia and Pittsburg Railroad and the Pittsburg and Western and new improvements now under way or projected.

NEWARK, N.J., July 2. -- Judge Andrew Kirkpatrick in the United States Circuit Court has appointed ex-State Senator Michael T. Barrett of this city and J.W. Newbery of New York receivers of the Monmouth Savings and Loan Association, which holds property in various parts of the State, with a principal office at 243 Washington Street, Jersey City.

ECKENFOERDE, Prussia, July 2. -- Emperor William's schooner yacht Meteor, which was built in the United States, was beaten for the fourth time by the British schooner Cicely yesterday in the long run from Kiel. The Clara was second and the Meteor was third. The Imperial Chancellor Count von Billow, was a guest of the Emperor on the Meteor.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- A story that rivals fiction is back of the arrest and imprisonment of Mrs. Ailene O'Malley, aged twenty-four years, wife of Prof. Austin O'Malley, and William Hearin, twenty years old, of 14 Morningside Heights, New York, with whom, it is alleged, the woman tried to elope.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The Congressional committees are busy getting ready for an active campaign in the Fall.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- During the twelve months just ended there were executed in the Government mints 191,419,506 coins of all denominations, with an aggregate value of $94,526,678.12, as compared with a coinage of 176,999,132, total valued at $136,340,781.58, in 1901. The increase in the number of pieces was 14,420,374; the decrease in value, $41,814,103.46.

W.A. Baker, Vice President of the Postal Telegraph Company, denied yesterday that a hitch had been arrived at in the negotiations between his company and the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. He said that the contract had been approved by the Directors of both companies, and that preparations are under way to carry it out.

Application was made yesterday in the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of New York for the appointment of a receiver for the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association and the Mutual Reserve Life Insurance Company of Broadway and Duane Street, which it is charged is hopelessly insolvent.

The Protectionist, a journal needing no other introduction than its name, which is accurately and luminously descriptive, commits what would look like a "blazing indiscretion" in printing the following in its May issue:

GOOD GROUND, L.I., July 2. -- Louis A. Disbrow, accused of the murder of Clarence Foster and Sarah Lawrence, to-day for the second time faced Justice Foster, who issued the warrant for his arrest, and the formal proceedings which may end in his being committed to the county jail to await the action of the Grand Jury were begun.

BOSTON, Mass., July 2. -- Acting Princi- pal Graves of the Phillips Andover Academy, asked to-night if he knew anything in regard to the circumstances of the cribbing said to have been discovered in the Princeton examination papers turned in by the Andover boys, said: "I did not hear anything about it until to-night.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Mr. Ridgely, Controller of the Currency, has issued a statement showing that there were added to the National bank system in the last fiscal year 437 National banking associations, with aggregate authorized capital stock of $30,407,000, and with bond deposits of $6,012,750 as security for circulation.

PITTSBURG, July 3 -- Nearly a million people, it is expected, will take part tomorrow in the biggest programme for the biggest day Pittsburg ever saw. Patriotism was never more manifest, and only bad weather will be able to cause any breaks in the schedule for the day.

LONDON, July 3 -- Money was plentiful to-day and rates were easy, being benefited by the Exchequer disbursements and the release of dividends. Discounts were thereby affected, though the weakness of the Paris Cheque had a steadying influence, suggesting the possible, withdrawals of gold for Paris.
The annual report of the International Steam Pump Company for the year ended March 31, was made public yesterday. The income account shows as follows:

BALTIMORE, Md., July 3 -- Several lives were lost, a dozen or more people injured, houses unroofed, large steamships and other vessels driven adrift, yachts capsized, and other damage done by a cyclonic storm that, for ten minutes, swept over Baltimore City, Baltimore County, Anne Arundel County, and the harbor and Patapsco River at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

GOOD GROUND, L.I., July 3 -- The testimony to-day against Louis Disbrow was mainly intended to discredit the statement of Coroner Nugent that there was no wound on Foster's body and that there was one on the face of Sarah Lawrence. This testimony was the direct opposite of what had been understood and what Coroner Nugent in a dozen interviews has told from the very outset of the case.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Officials of the Illinois Steel Company applied to the Secretary of State yesterday for articles of incorporation for a new savings bank at South Chicago. Its officers will be representatives of the Steel Company. The capital stock will be $200,000. Twice a month the Steel Company pays out from $350,000 to $400,000 to its employes.

The mischievous instinct which led Johnny Madigan, six years old, of 3 Madison Street, Hoboken, to climb the steel trestle of the railroad building on Ferry Street, nearly resulted in his death yesterday. After he had started his perilous climb it was found necessary to rig up a number of ropes in order to get him safely to the ground.

A few years ago a very popular game was introduced to paretics and others having a taste for such things, which consisted in a board provided with barriers and certain evasive globules of mercury -- the puzzle being to group these globules in a common pocket into which they had no idea of going.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The State Department is discussing with the Cuban Minister the treaty disposition of the Isle of Pines. In a petition laid before the department by J.H. Keenan, the President of the Association of American Settlers in the island, it is stated that at present the need of action by this Government is imperative.

When James Hartford, Vice President of the Schoellkopf, Hartford Hanna Company of 100 William Street, died recently in the German Hospital after an operation, his wife. Lucinda Hartford, lived at Stanwick Mansions, London, England. He had up to the time of his going to the hospital lived at the Arbutus apartment house, 301 West Ninety-first Street, with his daughter, Florence Hartford, who is fifteen years old, and Lucy Boquet.
PARIS, July 3 -- W.K. Vanderbilt's Nettie (Macginn) ran second in the race for the Prix Tertre at the Maisons Laffite races today.

Having occasion to shoot Mr. HELMER the other day, Miss CORA WITTS of Oneida lodged the bullet in the left hip of Mr. LEOPOLD MYERS. Undoubtedly MYERS was guilty of contributory negligence. Seeing his great danger, he should have taken shelter in front of HELMER or fled to one of the adjoining counties.

The Rev. Edwin H. Hughes of Maiden, Mass., declines the call to the pastorate of St. Andrew's Methodist Church of this city, and asks that his name be not considered. The Rev. Dr. J.O. Wilson, who has announced his intention to retire from the pastorate of the church, has been offered the position of executive secretary of the Wesleyan University $1,000,000 Endowment Fund, and it is said that he is likely to accept it.

Parents must be careful to see that their children do not carry the Stars and Stripes near the driveways in Central Park to-day, the Glorious Fourth. This is in accordance with an old law of the Park Commissioners. Policemen who find children bearing the colors must force them to furl their flags.

LONDON, July 4 -- The Times laments the continuous wholesale exportation of rare early-printed books and illuminated manuscripts to the United States. It points out that the drain has been going on for more than half a century, and has recently reached huge proportions.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 3 -- The Newport Horse Show has issued its prize list for the sixth annual exhibition, to be held a the Casino Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, Sept. 1, 2, and 3. There will be forty-four classes, for which cash prizes will be offered in all classes, except for sweepstakes and tlie best exhibits in four different classes.
LONDON, July 4 -- When the vote for the Foreign Office came up In the House of Commons yesterday afternoon the Government's foreign policy received considerable criticism.

Actual buoyancy ruled on the Stock Exchange yesterday under the leadership of the standard railway shares. Quotations, showing strength in the early trading, climbed higher and still higher until in the late dealings the large short interest in the market -- fearful of some unexpectedly favorable announcement over the holiday -- became alarmed and ran precipitately to cover.

ROME, July 3 -- Judge William H. Taft, Civil Governor of the Philippine Islands, to-day received a long cable message from United States Secretary of War Root, containing the War Department's final instructions concerning the note relating to the disposition of the friars' lands in the Philippines which was drawn up here on Tuesday.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 3 -- Mr. and Mrs. L.L. Richman of New York, charged with grand larceny in having stolen a twenty-five-thousand-dollar necklace of diamonds and pearls and $427, the property of Mrs. Walter E. Delabarre, also of New York, from the veranda of the Crossmon House at Alexandria Bay Tuesday night, were arraigned before a Justice in that village last night.

BALTIMORE, July 3 -- The continued upward tendency of Nashville Railway 5s certificates, and the sharp recovery of United States Fidelity and Guaranty Trust shares were the features and the principal supporting influence in to-day's market. Both were bought readily on a strong upward movement.

Manager-Captain Carr of the Jersey City Eastern League baseball team distinguished himself yesterday in the game against Newark by making two home runs and bringing in three other players ahead of him. Both sides indulged in free hitting, each making fourteen hits. By bunching their hits the Jersey City players gathered in ten runs, while the Newarks made only three.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 3 -- Harry Tracy, the escaped Oregon convict, in a battle with a Seattle posse hear Bothell, twenty-two miles from here, this evening, shot and instantly killed Charles Raymond, a Deputy Sheriff from Everett, and dangerously wounded Deputy Sheriff John Williams of this city.
LONDON, July 4 -- The following bulletin was posted at Buckingham Palace at 7 o'clock last evening:

ALBANY, N.Y., July 3 -- State Controller Nathan L. Miller to-night gave out an authorized interview relative to the department's attitude on the law taxing dividends of savings banks. He said in part:
Bradstreet's, in its weekly review of the state of trade, summarizes the various special reports to it, as follows:
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Secretary Root has received the following reply from Acting Governor Wright of the Philippines to his congratulatory cablegram sent yesterday:

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The President has formally declared the restoration of peace in the Philippine archipelago; he has placed the islands under complete civil control, and has extended general amnesty to the Filipinos who have been in rebellion. These three things, marking one of the most important chapters in Philippine history, were accomplished through the issue of three separate orders and proclamations, one by the President over his own signature, extending amnesty;

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- The local market continued dull to-day, but prices were better nearly all along the list. Cambria Steel furnished the chief point of interest. Union Traction, United Gas Improvement, Consolidated Lake Superior, and Philadelphia Electric were all higher. National Asphalt preferred was advanced to 2.

The stock traded in the outside market yesterday were more numerous than on Wednesday, and at the same time several issues showed transactions considerably in excess of the average of the last few days. One or two important stocks were under selling pressure and ended the day with net losses, but on the other hand a number of sharp advances were recorded.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 3 -- The report was current here late this afternoon that the Rev. Andrew V.V. Raymond, D.D., LL.D., President of Union College and Chancellor of Union University, had received a call to the pastorate of the Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church, in Brooklyn.

A few days ago we directed attention to what seemed to be a remarkable if not revolting, proposition by Senator ALLISON, to punish by fine or imprisonment, or both, the buying or selling of appointments or promotions under the Government of the District of Columbia. The effort, which was successful, did not strite us offensively because it manifestly was intended to make dangerous further traffic in District offices.
President ROOSEVELT'S chief error of Judgment has been his decision not to pursue the policy of President McKINLEY, announced in his speech at Buffalo:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 3 -- An event interesting socially and otherwise to take place on Saturday morning will be the laying of the cornerstone, attended by proper ceremonies, of the new dwelling near this town for E.S. Reynal. The Reynal family have always been closely connected with every enterprise in White Plains, and the old Reynal home, on the Atamaroneck Road, is known far and wide.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 3 -- The Bridgeport Yacht Club to-night decided on Jones and Labord's yacht Tecumseh as challenger to go to Canada to sail for the Seawanhaka Cup. This selection was made by the club after full trial of the yachts that competed for the honor of challenging, the last race of the trials being sailed to-day, when Tecumseh again was-winner.

A munificent foundation for the education of candidates for the priesthood of the Catholic Church has been announced. The gifts composing it are from Mrs. Ann Eliza Walsh, formerly Miss McCaddin, of Brooklyn. Mrs. Walsh's donations for educational and charitable purposes have amounted to nearly $800,000.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, B.W.I., July 3 -- News has reached here that after four days' fighting the town of Barquisimeto, in the State of Lara, Venezuela, has been captured by revolutionists under Gen. Lnciano Mendoza.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- New York exchange was 50c. discount. Union Traction opened off a fraction in the local market to-day in consequence of the disappointing showing made by the annual report. The company narrowly escaped a deficit for the last year, its balance for the twelve months being only about $53,000.

The entries for the athletic carnival and the all-around championship of the Amateur Athletic Union of America show an excellent array of talent for the events which will be contested on the grounds of the Greater New York Irish Athletic Association, at Celtic Park, Laurel Hill, L.I., to-day.
NEWPORT, July 3 -- There was another large addition to the people in the cottage colony to-day, and many guests will be at the cottages until after the Fourth.

UTICA, N.Y., July 3 -- The St. Lawrence power plant at Massena, N.Y., was sold this afternoon at Massena by Referee Lynch under foreclosure proceedings begun by the first mortgage bondholders. The plant was bid in by Mark T. Cox of New York, representing the Reorganization Committee of the first and second mortgage bondholders, for $500,000.
LONDON, July 3 -- The Committee of the House of Commons appointed to inquire into the question of subsidies, heard William J. Pirrie, Chairman of the Harland Wolff Shipbuilding Company, to-day.

-- Sir THOMAS LIPTON that was, Sir T. LIPTON, Baronet, that is, and Baron Shamrock that might have been, may be the innocent victim of a blackmailing scheme, as his representatives seem to insinuate. We have yet to learn whether or not Mr. BARRIE had a license to boom tea and Shamrock in sweet communion.

The first dead heat of the present racing season on the New York tracks made the sensation of the afternoon at the Sheeps-head Bay racecourse yesterday, when the feature of the programme, the Equality Stakes, the fourth event on the card, resulted in a tie between Dublin and Highlander, after the most trying finish of the meeting for the nerves of the betting crowd.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Mrs. Allene Ellis O'Malley and William J. Hearin, the young Cornell student with whom the woman, it is said, had planned to elope, leaving her middle-aged husband, Prof. Austin O'Malley, dangerously ill in St. Agnes's Hospital, are still in the Central Police Station awaiting the arrival of friends to secure their release on bail.
BERLIN, July 3 -- Col. Fritz von Steuben, who attended the Yorktown Centennial celebration in America, telegraphs as follows to THE NEW YORK TIMES'S correspondent:

The new steam yacht Revolution, the first craft of the kind in he fitted out with turbine engines, fell in with the speedy Monmouth of the Sandy Hook line yesterday afternoon, and in a lively twenty-minute race from Robbin's Reef to Swinburne Island won out by a good length from the blue-ribbon holder among the harbor fliers.

NEWPORT, July 3 -- The Rhode Island Society of the Cincinnati will hold its annual meeting to-morrow, the business meeting taking place in the morning. The commemorative celebration of the one hundred and twenty-sixth anniversary of American independence, which has been held by the society annually since its institution in 1784, will be celebrated at 3 o'clock in the afternoon in the Representatives' Hall at the State House.

KIEL, July 3 -- Emperor William's guests on the Meteor during the return race from Eckernfoerde to this port included P.A.B. Widener, Allison Armour, Clement A. Griscom, and C.L.F. Robinson, Rear Commodore of the New York Yacht Club; the Grand Duke of Saxony, and Admiral Prince Henry of Prussia.
After a revel of special legislation in Ohio extending over several years, and embracing about all the cities in the State, the courts have at last intervened and brought all the schemes to grief.

LONDON, July 3 -- In connection with the recent starting gate fiascoes the stewards of the Jockey Club have issued a ruling that if the gate falls to act properly when the lever is pulled, or if the webbing is broken by a horse, it shall not be considered a start, and the horses must return to the post.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Senator Bailey was in Washington to-day, and so was Solicitor Penfield of the State Department, who issued the statement yesterday severely denouncing the Senator for attacking him in his speech in the Senate last Tuesday. The two men did not meet, and there was no communication between them by mail or messenger.

The Semi-final rounds in the men's singles of the Middle States championship tennis tournament were played on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at Mountain Station yesterday, Holcombe Ward beating S.C. Millett in two straight sets, though it took three sets for Montgomery Ogden to beat George H. Miles.

The first fire of the Fourth of July was started a little after midnight by a skyrocket in the planing mills of John Crawford, at 256 and 258 West Twenty-eighth Street, and in an hour had gutted his two big five-story mills, another smaller wooden mill between them, and fired several other surrounding mills, one of which, on Eighth Avenue, he owned himself.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 4 -- Harry Tracy, the escapad Oregon convict, late yesterday killed Policeman E.E. Breese and mortally wounded Neil Rawley in the city limits, after having murdered Deputy Sheriff Charles Raymond and seriously wounded Deputy Sheriff John Williams earlier in the day. Rawley died this morning.

A holiday crowd that rivalled the largest attendance of the racing season gathered at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday for the closing of the Coney Island Jockey Club's June meeting and witnessed the victory of the black colt Major Daingerfield, unbeaten this year, in the Lawrence Realization Stakes, the chief event of the afternoon.

All Wall Street took a holiday yesterday, concerning itself in no wise with stock market or financial matters. All the Exchanges were closed, nor was the least interest taken in the movement of prices in the foreign markets. Up-town brokers offices, usually open on holidays for the benefit of customers who might desire to transact business in London, were closed and little or no inquiry developed in respect to quotations.

We have had David Harum from Central New York. Eben Holden from out West, Uncle Terry from up in Maine, and so should feel no thrill of surprise at the appearance of Abner Daniel from Georgia. In fact, he has been expected all along. And now that he has come he is really a very nice sort of old fellow-kind-hearted, gentle, unpretentious, and, of course philo- sophical.

Complete reports have just reached this country of the important Fountaine sale, held by Messrs. Sotheby June 11-14, at which a total of L10,732 3s. 6d. was realized. The highest price of the sale was the L1,550 given by Quaritch for a fourteenth century manuscript of Gower's "Confessio Amantis," written on 213 leaves in old English black letter, with 99 finely painted and illuminated miniatures.

A Roman candle entered the window of the apartments of Mrs. Margaret McKeever on the top floor of 741 Tenth Avenue and exploded on a bed, causing a fire which did damage to the amount of $6,500 and caused considerable excitement in that vicinity. The house is owned by John D. Rockefeller, and next door to it is the Armitage Chapel and the West Side Settlement, also owned by Mr. Rockefeller.
LONDON, July 5 -- The following bulletin was posted at Buckingham Palace at 7 o'clock last evening:

TREMLEY, N.J., July 4 -- Spreading rails caused an accident one mile north of here this morning. It resulted in the destruction of about 290 yards of the south-bound track, eight hours' delay to traffic, damage to the extent of $3,000 to the property of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, and injuries of a severe or slight character to about ten of the thirty persons who were on the train.

M. Frederic Humbert, who disappeared with his wife from Paris, after bamboozling French bankers and lawyers for many years with a story of a great American fortune left to Mme. Humbert, was in the habit of posing for a playwright. A friend of the Humbert family recently, threw some light on this curious pair and their habits and tastes.

Miss Marion Jones, who recently won the national singles tennis championship for women, was beaten in the final round of the ladies' singles event yesterday on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at Mountain Station by Miss Maud Banks, three sets being required to decide the match.

A comprehensive appreciation of the favored corner of the earth he has chosen to describe, an all-pervasive humor and sympathy, a broad culture, and gentle spirit, and a rare felicity of style, all these combine to make Mr. Carmichael's "DT Tuscany" a most fascinating and amusing volume.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, July 4 -- William M. Hahn, ex-Insurance Commissioner of Ohio, indicted in New York, will go to jail next Monday to remain indefinitely, to prevent arrest by Detective N.C. Brindley, the New York officer, on the Governor's requisition, and to prevent his removal to New York.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4 -- Newport society enjoyed the Fourth in a very cosmopolitan way, taking little part in the city's celebration, but participating in the general observance of the day in various ways. The Newport Clambake Club opened its season at its clubhouse at Easton's Point, the members and guests participating in a genuine Rhode Island clambake with the usual and some unusual accompaniments.

The present strike of coal miners gives special timeliness to the publication of this collection of papers on the relation of employers and employed. Unfortunately, industrial conflicts are becoming so frequent that the appearance of such a volume on almost any day in the year would now have a close relation to facts.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. Dana, in his article on the subject of "Fiction in Libraries," asks: (a) "How many novels each year should any library lend relatively to the other work it does?" and (b) "How poor may be the quality of the novels it lends?"

No author of fiction ever surpassed Daniel Defoe for what may be called "apparent veracity." Swift, Gay, and Johnson held Defoe in small estimation, oblivious to his special qualities, and even Macaulay was wanting in a proper appreciation, but for all that "Robinson Crusoe" is the great masterpiece, and must live as long as does our English language.

BAR HARBOR, July 4 -- The Hotel Rodick, famous for nearly two decades as the centre of Bar Harbor life, caught fire to-night from a fire balloon, and but for the efforts of two fire fighters the main part of the town might have been destroyed.

Never indulging in criticisms or speculations, "Veritas," in the "The German Empire of To-day," does his best to impart information relative to one of the great powers of the present moment. He gives you the facts, so far as ascertainable, and puts them on record, leaving to others, "all enigmatical inferences as to their significance."

The time is long past when we took seriously the books Englishmen write about America after a visit of six weeks; but we may still look upon them with interest, nay, amazement, for what they reveal of the nature and habits of the Englishman. In "Those Delightful Americans" Mrs. EVERARD COTES makes an American say:

SIR WALTER BESANT'S last novel, called "No Other Way," will be published in the early Autumn by Dodd, Mead Co. It deals with the debtor side of English life many years ago, a glimpse of which is given in "The Vicar of Wakefield."

No such volume of sport under excellent conditions was ever seen at the Apawamis Club links, at Rye, as the Independence Day programme brought out yesterday. It included medal-play qualifying rounds for two cups and the first match-play round for another cup. The summaries follow, giving scores of those who qualified:

LONDON, July 5 -- The Fourth of July banquet of the American Society in London was given at the Hotel Cecil last evening. There was a remarkable manifestation of sympathy for King Edward on account of his illness, and incidentally there were some open expressions of displeasure with United States Ambassador Choate.

LONDON, July 4 -- Money was abundant and in fair demand and rates were easy to-day. Discounts were steady. The knowledge that large exports of sovereigns were being made to the Cape tended to strengthen the market.

ANDOVER, Mass., July 4. -- "Snap" examinations, lax methods, low requirements for examinations -- these are some of the charges hurled back at Princeton University by the Andover faculty in answer to the allegations of "cribbing" in examinations by Andover men. Acting Principal A. E. Stearns has also demanded an explanation from the Princeton faculty.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 4 -- Both teams played poorly in the first game, but Cincinnati was luckier in bunching their hits. Frazer went up in the air in the last three innings, but previous to that both men pitched fine ball. Peitz's hitting was the feature.

"LITTLE ENGRAVINGS" will be welcomed with delight by students of art. The first number is devoted to Albrecht Altdorfer, generally accepted as having produced wood engravings second only to Durer's, and Mr. Moore, who is an ardent student of Altdorfer's work, is not willing to yield the palm without reservation to the greater master.

Tammany Hall leaders welcomed W. Bourke Cockran back to the fold yesterday. The Wigrwam was crowded when the man who was once the idol of the organization appeared on the platform to make a speech. Richard Croker sent no cable or letter. The Tammany triumvirs had made arrangements to have several Democratic orators from the West and South, but in most instances letters of regret were received.

The proclamation of amnesty to political prisoners in the Philippines and of the establishment of civil government throughout the civilized portion of the archipelago marks the attainment of a long-pursued and arduously sought end. It is the official declaration of substantial peace.

An eighteen-hole qualifying medal play handicap, the eight lowest scores to keep on at match play for the Snedeker Cup, was the feature yesterday at the links of the Marine and Field Club. The returns were:
ST. LOUIS, July 4 -- St. Louis outplayed the visitors in every department of the game in the morning contest with New York to-day. Sparks had to be relieved by Blewitt in the third inning.

In a fit of jealous rage, Charles Guther, Jr., twenty-six years old, yesterday afternoon made an unsuccessful attempt to kill his wife, who is twenty-one years old, and then shot himself dead in their room in a boarding house at 245 Lawrence Street, Brooklyn. The woman was not dangerously wounded.

The copy of Shakespeare's "Henry the Fifth," 1617, which sold for L197 in London June 5 to "A. Jackson," is reported to have been secured for Marsden J. Perry of Providence, whose Shakespearean library is now probably the finest existing in private hands in this country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with considerable interest the editorial entitled "Republican Confidence" in your issue of June 30. In that editorial you hold to account the "Republicans in Congress" and the "Republican politicians in "Washington" for the failure to pass the bill reducing the duty on sugar imported from Cuba.

BALTIMORE, July 4 -- One hundred workmen employed at the yards of the Spedden Shipbuilding Company have gone on a strike, having been ordered out by the Boilermakers and Iron Shipbuilders' Union because of an alleged grievance against the company.

The gentle reader who is also somewhat squeamish will probably find little to interest him -- or one might better say her -- in Robert W. Chambers's collection of short stories under the title of "The King in Yellow." On the contrary, indeed, there is much to repel any one who likes his literature clear, translucent, or more or less peptonized.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- In the presence of 20,000 people, G.C. Bennett's Aladdin this afternoon won the Sheridan Stake at Washington Park, defeating the American Derby winner, Wyeth, and the colt which finished second in that race, Lucien Appleby. By a singular coincidence only the three colts which ran one two-three in the Derby started in to-day's stake, which had most of the Western Derby colts as eligibles.
LONDON, July 5 -- The Prince of Wales, on behalf of King Edward, received the Indian Princes who came here to attend the coronation at the India Office last night.
The "New" Harper's Weekly. Col. George Harvey, journalist, railroad builder, publisher and editor of The North American Review, is now definitely identified with Harper's Weekly as its editor.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- With half a hundred men on their trail and the promise of a battle and probably death for their portion if they shall be overtaken, the two bandits who halted the Rock Island Railroad's limited express train at midnight Thursday, and escaped after mortally wounding one of the express messengers, are still at large.

How unjust we have been with our snapshot judgment in regard to the heathen deities. We have maligned them, declaring them to be decadent. It is so good of Mr. John Kendrick Bangs to have stood up bravely in defense of Olympus, and to have shown us in the most convincing manner that the entire mythology (regardless of the past) is to-day composed of really nice and hospitable personages.

MME. VAN MUYDEN, whose husband is a great-great-grandson of Cesar de Saussure, has recently finished translating and editing a series of letters from the latter to members of his family written during the reigns of George I. and George II.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 4 The lowering of the track record to 2:13 1/2 by Dick See was the feature of the closing day of the Central New York Trotting Circuit races here to-day. The largest crowd of the meet was present. The track was good and the "see-sawing" races kept the bettors guessing.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 4 -- The Naval Academy Academic Board, having received the papers in the final examination of the cadet class of 1900, has made up the order of standing of men as they leave the grade of past cadet and attain the rank of ensign. This examination was held in the Spring and each cadet took it at the place he was stationed.
MR. MERRIMAN'S book, as he describes it in his preface, is an attempt to present the life of Thomas Cromwell as a- statesman and to estimate his work without religious bias.

Never before in the railway history of the United States have there been so few railway receiverships and foreclosure proceedings brought in the courts as during the first six months of the present year. Since Jan. 1 only one operating railroad, the New York and Pennsylvania, a road fifty-two miles long, has been placed in the hands of a receiver.

The Fourth was celebrated at the Manhattan State Hospital, East, by a baseball game in the morning and athletic games in the afternoon. There were about 700 visitors at the institution, a very large number for a single day. The baseball game was between the West and East wings, and the former won by a score of 14 to 13.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- The People's Fourth of July egatta was held on the Na tional Course of the Schuylkill River in Fairmount Park to-day under the joint auspices of the City of Philadelphia and the Schuylkill Navy of Philadelphia. The weather beautiful, the course smooth, the crowds large, and the regatta in every way was a success.

Not only every American officer and soldier, but every American citizen, ought to feel grateful to the Secretary of War for his eloquent expression of the gratitude of the American people to the American Army for the great work it has been doing during the last four years, crowned at last, as it now is, by the pacification of the Philippines.

It is the custom of THE SATURDAY REVIEW, as our readers are aware, to discuss general questions of education as an important part of the matters included in the field of letters. The cause of education in this country is very directly concerned in the honor conferred by Yale University upon Mr. Robert C. Ogden of this city.

LONDON, June 26 -- The "Dickens Number" of Household Words is certainly an interesting one. It contains an excellent sketch of Dickens and a vartety of contributions concerning him and his works. The most remarkable thing in the number is the collection of opinions as to Dickens's novels which the editor has got together.

AN interesting and valuable volume in this first of a monograph series projected by the United States Catholic Historical Series Society. If the others of the series are of like character with this, lovers of American history will owe much to the publishers.

In his "Primitive Semitic Religion Today." Prof. Curtiss, who interprets Old Testament literature in the Chicago Theological Seminary, has given in addition to the purely scientific portion of the volume a very interesting and instructive narrative of travel ana exploration in Syria, Palestine, and the Sinaitic Peninsula.

The Punch-like profile of Hogarth's portrait of the author of "Tom Jones" smirks placidly at one from the frontispiece of this excellently made "Journal of a Voyage to Lisbon," which is the wellknown diary written by Henry Fielding during his voyage, in 1754, to Portugal, where he died after a two months' sojourn, Oct. 8, of that year.

OF the many so-called "Biblical" stories of the present season, two at least, by a curious coincident, have Babylon or Nineveh, or both for their setting, though they treat of different periods. These are "The Gate of the Kiss," by John W. Harding, and "Belshazzar." by William Stearns Davis.

The Fourth of July is dies non in town as far as society is concerned. There is only one other day which equals it in absolute dearth of social news, and that is Good Friday. The unfortunate clubman who is left without an invitation to the country, or has not made plans to go away, has his club almost to himself.

PITTSBURG, July 4 -- Only three Brooklyn players reached first base, and none got as far as the second in the first game here to-day. Tannehill's great work and his errorless support accounted for this. Errors behind Newton discouraged him. The local nine duplicated its victory in the afternoon, and again Brooklyn failed to score.

LONDON, July 5. -- The Standard, commenting upon President Roosevelt's speech at Pittsburg yesterday, says it thinks it very significant that a statesman of his position and with his future should think It wise to deliver a serious warning to powerful trusts.

Solomon is authority for the infrequency of "newness" in the world, and, in the flood of books pouring in upon us all the while, it is too much to expect originality in every case of course. But writers can't disguise old themes by giving them new names. This is what Mrs, Kirk has tried to do.

BOSTON, July 4 -- A two days' endurance race between Boston and New York for motor cycles was started from Copley Square at 8 o'clock this morning. The long run is via Worcester, Springfield, Hartford, New Haven, and Bridgeport, a distance of 254 miles.
MR. RUSSELL STURGIS recently addressed the following letter to President Butler of Columbia University concerning a proposed department of fine arts:

Note -- As we have two lessons on "The Ten Commandments" in this course, instead of considering them as setting forth "Duties Toward God." and "Duties Toward Man." I have thought it would be more helpful to devote the first to the consideration of the circumstances attending their delivery, and the second, to their characteristics. J.R.W.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The negotiations for the treaty between the United States and Colombia by which this Nation will acquire the right to build the Panama Canal will begin in about one week. Minister Concha of Colombia having conferred with Secretary Hay on the preliminaries of the negotiations.

LONDON, July 4 -- Even before the publication of Jonn Morley's "Oliver Cromwell" two years ago people had grown impatient waiting for his long-promised biography of the famous Lateral leader and statesman, and now it is formally announced that the Gladstone biography will not appear until next Spring.

This little volume, while by casual examination may seem to be merely a wellburdened storehouse of quotations, prose and verse, of what has been written on the subject of friendship, and hence convenient as a sentimental correspondent's vade mecum, is in reality a philosophical work of considerable ingenuity, in which citations are a means and not an end.

SPEAKING of the canons of criticism -- so much less definite than those of the Church -- a few years ago, (only forty or so, I think,) I copied in my "Californian," from an English magazine, an article written by C.B. Gibson, descriptive of a visit to the grava of Charles Wolfe, author of "The Burial of Sir John Moore."

Delegates of the Social Democratic Party met in convention at 64 East Fourth Street all day yesterday for the purpose of nominating a candidate for Governor in the next election. After considerable discussion Benjamin Hanford of Brooklyn was named for the State's chief officer. The other nominations made were:

HARTFORD, Conn., July 4 -- Seventeen of the thirty-two riders who left Boston for New York this morning in the endurance test of motor cycles conducted by the Metropole Cycling Club of New York, arrived in Hartford to-night inside the schedule time. The riders will leave here at 8 o'clock to-morrow morning and expect to reach New York by 6 p.m.

Saugerties, on the Hudson, was named alter the little sawyer -- de Zaagertjes -- who had a mill at the mouth or the Saw Creek at a date beyond the ken of recorded history. The earliest records allude to him, and the Indians acknowledged having granted or sold land to him, but no one has ever learned his name, or for whom he sawed lumber in the uninhabited wilderness.

There are some books that seem to lead one through darkness into the light, but what of those which bring one out into the shadow? There seems to be something so distressingly hopeless about Graham Travers's "The Way of Escape." One feels after reading it how hedged in we all are by the inevitable.

The recent report of J. Pierpont Morgan's purchase of rare books produced by the earliest typographers in England credited him with acquiring the extraordinary number of thirty-two volumes printed by William Canton, together with three with the imprint of Theodericus Rood, the first Oxford printer, several issued by John Letton and William de Machlinia.

This volume will be of considerable service to students of economics as constituting an apologia for the trust, mainly from the point of view of men who have a firsthand acquaintance with its operation. It consists of eight articles, followed by a series of quotations illustrating "representative opinion" on the subject, a reprint of Mr. C.R. Flint's testimony before the Industrial Commission, and a bibliography.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., July 4 -- Charles W. Crossman of the Crossman Hotel here received an anonymous letter on a postal card this afternoon reflecting on Louis L. Richman and his wife Rachel of New York, who will appear before the Grand Jury in October, accused of stealing a twenty-five-thousand-dollar pearl and diamond necklace and $427 in money from Dr. and Mrs. Walter E. Delabarre, also of New York.

"The Lower South in American History" is a collection of six papers, mainly of historical and sociological interest, that will appeal to the general reader no less than to the special student. Mr. Brown, who is at present lecturer in history at Harvard, has evidently known both the South and the North well, and endeavors to be impartial as well as candid in his studies of the perplexing problems, past and present, of the South.

-- Life is not all woe for the unvacating. There are, to be sure, moments when one thinks with longing of those who flash white flannels across the verdure of the golf links, who eat up cool, windy miles of Summer roads on their automobiles, who fleck the blue waters of the Sound with their scudding craft.

Language experts are rapidly driving the world toward the conclusion that "everything goes." Such arbiters of elegance as Robert Louis Stevenson are out of date, and your true Petronius of literature is the ragman or the bagman, who says "wot's wot" in the most incisive and unpolished manner imaginable.

MANILA, July 4 -- President Roosevelt's amnesty proclamation was read at noon today in English and Spanish from a flagdraped stand on the Luneta after a parade of 6,000 Americans and Filipinos. Arthur Ferguson, Secretary to Gov. Taft, read the proclamation in the presence of a small gathering, the heat having dispersed the crowd when the parade ended.

Three distinct sets of athletic games were decided at Celtic Park, Long Island City, under the auspices of the Greater New York Irish Athletic Association. The weather was delightfully fine, and the track and infield in splendid order. Over 5,000 persons watched the different contests in the long programme, and for nearly four hours the spectators cheered the athletes in their struggles for supremacy.

BOSTON, July 4 -- The trotting card at the Readville track to-day was made up of seven events. In the 2:24 pace, Heloise, after taking the second heat, had a brush in the stretch with Deacon in the third and bid fair to win out until she collided with Deacon's sulky, throwing herself and driver Kane. For some time it was feared Kane was seriously hurt, but he is not.

The partition between piracy and privateering was so very thin even as late as 1815 that it is small wonder that Jean Lafitte's deeds were regarded with no overwhelming abhorrence even before the days when he served Andrew Jackson so well and began the defeat of the British forces intended to end the war in a blaze of glory for the invader.

Three men, two of whom were railroad detectives employed by the Central Railroad of New Jersey, the third man being a plumber who accompanied them occasionally, were killed between the Communipaw and Claremont stations, Jersey City, early yesterday morning. The detectives were William J. Hanson, twentyseven years of age, of 335 Whiton street, and John Cosgrove, thirty-five years of age, of 86 Phillips street.

RED BANK, N.J., July 4 -- The Monmouth Boat Club inaugurated its two-days sporting carnival on the Shrewsbury River this afternoon. Thousands of people witnessed the contests, which were very interesting. The river was alive with craft of every description, loaded with excursionists.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 4 -- The annual convention of the Southern Educational Association, which has been in session in this city for the past four days, came to a close to-day. The following State Managers' Board was appointed by the association:

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 4 -- Half a million persons greeted President Theodore Roosevelt in Pittsburg to-day. They came not only from Pittsburg and Allegheny, but from the scores of industrial towns within 100 miles of the city. It was the distinguished guest's first visit to Pittsburg as President, and his welcome was most enthusiastic.

CAPT. SIBORNE'S book on the details of the battles of Quatre Bras, Ligne, Wavre, and Waterloo might at this time be dismissed with a brief paragraph stating that this celebrated work had at length been made accessible in its fifth edition to Americans of slender purse were it not for two facts.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- J.S. Clarkson, recently selected by President Roosevelt for Surveyor of the Port of New York, has been in Washington for about a week, conferring with Postmaster General Payne and other politicians close to the President with regard to the political situation.
NEW ORLEANS, La., July 4 -- The United Fruit Company's steamship Anselm made her recent trip to the Quarantine Station with the State Inspection party -- were they guests or were they passengers?

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 -- Convict Harry Tracy, who is now terrorizing Seattle and its suburbs, began his career of crime in Colorado in 1897 by killing Deputy Sheriff Valentine Hay. In 1898, after he had been sentenced to the Oregon Penitentiary, he attempted to escape by seizing a railroad locomotive, but the engineer outwitted him, and he was captured.

Judicial decisions touching matters of business usage are always of interest. Such a decision has just been handed down by the New York Court of Appeals, which is of consequence to bank depositors everywhere. The facts are briefly as follows: A business concern depositing with the Chemical National Bank of this city was victimized by its confidential clerk, who systematically raised checks and appropriated the excess to his own use.

PUT-IN-BAY, Ohio, July 4 -- The twentyfourth annual convention of the Music Teachers National Association closed at noon amid scenes of patriotism and much musical enthusiasm. The business of the day was incorporated in a short but interesting session of the Senate and Council closing up some unfinished business relating to delegates' attendance.

"Of arms and men I sing." That is so ancient, and yet it always is the living theme. Take your "arma" and make it tools, and you mark man's progress. A materialistic measurement it is not, for it shows at its best human advancement. In Herbert Hall Turner's "Modern Astronomy," a work of a singularly impressive character, the author gives you what is the keynote of the present astronomical situation.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 5 -- A dispatch from Gloversville says that sixteen were killed and twenty-nine injured late last night in a wreck on the Fonda, Johnstown and Gloversville Railroad, three miles from that city.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Your notice in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of Dr. Charles Waldstein's proposal for the foundation of a British Academy prompts me to write, and through the medium of your valued columns to challenge Dr. Waldstein to widen his scheme.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 4 -- Commodore Frank Tilford of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club entertained about 500 members and friends of the club to-night between 8:30 and 11 o'clock on his flagship, the Norman. The guests were carried in three launches between the clubhouse and the Norman, anchored an eighth of a mile out.

SENATOR SUMNER was a purist in his use of words, although he though he sometimes used a word of learned length and thundering sound when a simpler word would do as well. I listened to a running debate in the Senate one afternoon in which Senator Conness of California, employed the word "verbiage" in place of "wording," as was the fashion some years ago.

The third volume of Mr. Meakin's valuable series on Morocco is divided into three parts. The first discusses at length the social life of the Moors; the second, their ethical life, and the third, under the head of "Supplementary," gives a sketch of the Morocco Berbers and the Morocco Jews, with a chapter on the literal and primitive customs of the Jews as practiced by the Jews of Morocco.

The smell of fish has not usually been regarded in the progress of the world as suggestive of poetic thought. The fish as an edible has given delight to many, and one might easily drop, like Silas Wegg, into poetry over a Rhode Island fish chowder or a planked shad, with white wine in loving propinquity.

The arts and crafts movement is arousing a constantly increasing amount of attention both in England and in America, through exhibitions given by or under the auspices of societies closely connected with its aims, or through publications and essays dealing with the subject. One of the latest volumes of such essays.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4 -- Jersey City's baseball team played finely and the home team very poorly in this morning's game. Barnett for the visitors was invincible, but the Newark Club aid not seem to try very hard.

There seems at tunes a peculiar irony in the workings of fate. Often -- far too often -- men die before their worth is known, before they have been accorded that praise which is theirs through services rendered the world. Or, again, one is taken away when one is but prepared for the real work of life.

Canon Ellacombe is a passionate gardener and an almost equally passionate reader of garden boobs. Consequently whatever he writes is chiefly addressed to that enviable public at home in both the outdoor world and the world of letters.

The executors of the estate of the late Josephus Collett, capitalist, of Terre Haute, Ind., have petitioned the court for an order to turn over to the Southern Indiana Gas Company of Indianapolis bonds issued by the company of face value of $100,000. When Mr. Collett died in 1893 the bonds were found in an envelope on which Mr. Collett had written: "These bonds belong to the Southern Indiana Gas Company."

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Pa., July 5 -- The new Kittatinny opened for the season on Thursday. The booking's show that many prominent society people of New York, Philadelphia, Washington and Baltimore will spend the season here. The orchestral concerts and golf tournaments are to be features.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- The pursuit of the robbers who held up the Omaha and Denver express on the Rock Island Road Thursday, near Dupont, narrowed down this afternoon to a search for two young men, believed to be experienced criminals, who lived in an Englewood rooming house for two weeks before the robbery.

SHARON SPRINGS, N.Y., July 5 -- After many years of troubles and vicissitudes which would have driven a resort possessing less natural attractions into obscurity, Sharon is once more on the highway to prosperity. For the past three years it has been steadily growing in popularity, and this year has already furnished indisputable proofs that it is destined once more to take its place among the leading resorts of the country.

A NEW theory of literary censorship has been laid down within the past few days at Evanston, in Illinois, where the local library has made up a sort of "index expurgatorius" or "black list." It is admitted that there are a lot of books in the library which ought to be suppressed, but they are among the classics and so are well known.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 5 -- No Summer resort along the New Jersey coast is as well equipped for outdoor sports as Seabright, where there are golf links and tennis courts, in addition to the attractions of the yacht clubs. The Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club has five good courts.

More than at any time this season the outside market during the past week presented Summer conditions. The double holiday which ended the week and the preparationas for it accounted in large part for the extreme dullness which prevailed during the four days of trading. Very few stocks showed activity that exceeded a few hundred shares a day, and many of the issues traded in supplied even smaller totals.

ST. LOUIS, July 5 -- St. Louis shut out the New York baseball team this afternoon after a pitchers' battle between M. O'Nelll and aMthewson. Mathewson's wild pitch in the second inning let in St. Louis's only tally. Score:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 5 -- The exodus from the cities to the seashore set in on Thursday, and from that time up to late this evening every railroad train has rolled into the Union Station crowded to the platforms with holiday seekers. The arrivals on Thursday alone numbered 20,000, and the total for the week will aggregate 50,000, so to-night finds the Park and the Grove crowded well nigh to the limit with tourists.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., July 5 -- Great interest is being taken by the Summer residents of this place in the polo games which are being held on the grounds of the Rockaway Hunt Club, at Cedarhurst. Last Saturday the Milton bicycle polo team of Boston played a match game of bicycle polo with the Rockaway Hunt Club team.

WHEN a man reaches thirty-five he is not apt to make many remarks about his birthday, but the wife of his bosom generally insists on calling his attention to the fleeting years by presenting him with a memento more or less useful as the case may be.

When the automobile made its appearance in this country a few years ago it was received with a cordiality which was nothing short of remarkable. Whether on the city streets or the country roads, pedestrians and vehicles stopped to see it pass, and the general sentiment was obviously that of admiration.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- A special from Winnipeg says:

COURT was just on the point of convening. The gowned figure of the Judge had not yet appeared. The Clerk was rummaging through a pile of papers and several court officers were grouped together discussing the latest political gossip. A straggling crowd of lawyers, witnesses, and jurors was filing in at the door of the courtroom.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 5 -- Most of the cottages in Southampton are already occupied by their owners, and with shutters open, awnings up, chairs and cushions on the piazzas, handsome traps at the doors, and people coming and going, there is a general air of home life that is very attractive.

NO class of travelers are more inveterate jokers than are the professional baseball players. Even the commercial traveler, whose reputation as a joker is worldwide, would scarcely dare attempt some of the horseplay in which ball players

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 5 -- The Business Men's Carnival and Street Fair at this place was opened on Thursday, and will be continued during the greater portion of next week. Everything was in first-class shape when the opening day came to hand, all the business places and private residences throughout the town being decorated for the occasion.

BLUE MOUNTAIN LAKE, N.Y., July 5. -- One may now alight at supper time on the shore of Blue Mountain Lake on the evening of the day he left New York City. Remarkable strides have been made in the transportation facilities here and great changes have been wrought in this, one of the oldest and best known resorts in the Adirondacks.

THERE is soon to be opened at Sharon, a few miles out of Boston, a novel scientific undertaking, to be called the Sharon Biological Observatory, which it is expected will do work of a kind that has never yet been taken up in this country in just this same way, except perhaps -- and then only in part -- by some of the official State agricultural experiment stations.

EXPERTS are the people who know so much about a thing that they are afraid to tell it all at once, for fear of disorganizing the universe. When an expert hears anything about his pet hobby he looks wise and says nothing at all till somebody suggests that he does not know anything about it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In to-day's issue of THE TIMES I notice a letter on the coal strike. The author states that he is a modest employe of a large corporation in this city, I am pained to see a writer come to the front to defend the Coal Trust. It calls to mind the words of the poet, "Man's inhumanity to man."

Walter V. Cranford of the Cranford Company, contractors, has obtained from Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn a temporary injunction restraining Borough President Swanstrom and Commissioner of Public Works Redfield from carrying out the asphalt paving contracts recently entered into between them and the Inter-State Paving Company.
LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., July 5 -- Bathing, driving, fishing, golfing, tennis, and yachting have been the amusements of this resort during the past week.
The address of District Attorney William Travers Jerome of New York before the Colorado Bar Association at Colorado Springs on Tuesday evening, July 1, is as follows:

It must be said that the present Czar of Russia is a dreamer of great dreams. It is easy to fancy the bewilderment of a man who is conscious of nothing but good-will to his people and his kind, and yet who has lived since his birth in daily danger of assassination. It is that cruel corrective by which, according to the old and bitter saying, his absolutism is tempered.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Miss Stanton is right -- the greater part of the objection to co-education as felt by young men is the restraint placed upon the latter by the presence of the former, and the demand for more exacting and efficient work. Twenty-five years' constant expedience in the co-educational world assures me of this.
HENLEY, England, July 5 -- C.S. Titus, the American sculler, did the full course to-day against the watch in 8 minutes 50 seconds.

OTTAWA, July 5 -- Clifford Sifton, Minister of the Interior, speaking on the difficulties between Canada, and the United States over the Alaska boundary, recently said: "In 1867 the Territory of Alaska passed by purchase into the possession of the United States, so that the United States Government became possessed of all the rights formerly held by Russia.

THE showcase stood near the middle of the sidewalk. It was the repository of six hats and a baby bonnet. The baby bonnet was white, but the hats were of many colors, and it was to these that the proprietor of the shops was giving her attention.

Championship events in tennis will practically be out of the list for some tim'e, as no important fixtures are scheduled with a championship aspect, hereabouts at least. With the finish of the Middle States championship decided on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, at Mountain Station, during the last week, ended the local preliminary important tournaments preparatory to the big tournaments scheduled for the near future.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 5 -- With the coming of the warm weather this week there has been an increased arrival at the shore, and Cape May in common with other coast resorts has received its fair share of visitors, among whom are many from New York and Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. John F. Doyle's interesting experience in catching a snake and a bullhead on the artificial fly, and related in your issue of July 3, has been duplicated in my own. In the Summer of 1889 I was fishing one afternoon in the Battenkill near Greenwich, N.Y., and as I floated down stream in my cance I saw a large green snake swimming across the river.

LONDON, June 28 -- A prominent British Catholic layman, who recently returned from a lengthy visit to the Vatican, declares that Cardinal John Vaughan, Archbishop of Westminster -- who is known to be one of the Pope's favorites and a persona grata to his fellow-Cardinals -- may be regarded as one of the "strongest possibilities" for the succession to St. Peter's chair.

To cap the climax it was midsummer and the city streets were scorching under a midday sun. I could have borne with Mother Hennessey and Johnnie and the infant in arms, and even with the bag of bananas and the feeding bottle, but this combination thrust upon me under a July noonday sun made me limp, hopeless, and ill-tempered within, and dangerously crisp and smiling outside.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 5 -- The movement of empty coal cars along the railroads and the unusual activity about several of the collieries in the region indicate to the strikers that an effort is to be made in a few days to start work at some of the collieries. The operators assert that they have sufficient men under engagement, both returned strikers and imported men, to man several of the collieries.

NOW that Verestohagin is actually on his way to Cuba to study the color of the verdure on San Juan Hill, it is in order for George Ade or some other up-to-date writer of comic operas to take the next Ward liner, and make his way to the Isle of Pines. According to latest reports, he should there discover color -- local color -- in large and easily manipulated quantities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I ask you to inform the readers of your valuable paper that there are 5,400 Boer prisoners of war in the prison camps on the Bermuda Islands awaiting transportation to Africa? There is a probability of these prisoners being held three or four months, perhaps longer, before they will be sent home.

PARIS, July 5 -- Americans are beginning to come back from London, where, as one of them expressed it, apart from missing two hours' rare show, they had a brilliant time. All board and no lodging is the description of London during the past ten days which another American brings back with him.

LONDON, July 5 -- After two meetings the Colonial Premiers did not get, to quote one of them, "much forrader," nor does there seem to be a, prospect of reaching any conclusions in the immediate future. The question of imperial defense was put up first as being the least argumentative, but even here difficulties have arisen.
Senator Thomas C. Platt shows the benefit of rest and recreation. When seen at the Oriental at Manhattan Beach last evening he was in a very contented frame of mind.

CERTAIN dates and certain festivals mark the boundary lines in the seasons in which society plans for this or that series of functions. Easter brings weddings and coaching, Memorial Day country life in the suburbs and country sports, and the Fourth of July the opening of the watering places.

LONDON, July 5 -- The reply of the Colonial Secretary, Joseph Chamberlain, to the petition for the suspension of the Constitution of Cape Colony was published in a Parliamentary paper this evening. It says there is no precedent for the suspension of the Constitution of a responsibly governed colony.

FAR away in the Southern Pacific, Pitcairn Island, so long isolated from the world, has at last been brought into regular communication with civilization. Its inhabitants, with one exception, are descendants of the British mutineers who stole the good ship Bounty in 1789.

The meeting of the two "seventies," the Mineola and the Yankee, has come to be looked for as a regular feature at yacht races this season. Thus far the Mineola has been uniformly successful, but J. Rogers Maxwell has shown himself a yachtsman of undaunted spirit by coming up fresh to a new conflict after every defeat.

OLD FORGE, N.Y., July 5 -- The appearance of the Fulton chain of lakes is fast approaching that of a great Summer city, and this season the building has been particularly brisk. There are several new cottages at Old Forge, and the growth of cabins and boathouses along the chain of lakes is considerable.

"Kind Dodo" closed its merry reign at Daly's Theatre on Saturday night, it being the last of the Broadway shows held over from Spring. Many of the theatres that closed in the latter part of May might have fared well, too, for the weather of the past month has been cool. The few theatres that remained open prospered.

COUSIN WILLIE is twenty-five years old, something under a mile tall, and may weigh less than a ton! Of course, you will say that that is a very feminine, and therefore foolish, way to begin my first letter about my trip to New York; but, Fan, I do think papa might have pare one's mind for such a shock.
A trolley car containing fifteen passengers, six of whom were women, was struck by lightning during the storm yesterday afternoon at West Farms and Unionport Roads.
With Monday last -- June 30 -- came to an end the fiscal year of a majority of the railroads of the country and of the Government itself.
NEWPORT, July 5 -- United States Senator and Mrs. George Peabody Wetmore joined their daughters at Chateaux-Sur-Mer this evening, coming direct from Washington.

The patients interested him tremendously. He listened patiently and kindly to their wildest vaporings, and to each he whispered a word of encouragement and hope.
"LIZZIE!" shouted Mr. Gunbusta, as he stepped out into the hallway and looked anxiously down into the lower hall, "have you seen anything of my tennis racquet?"

A PARTY was discussing, a day or two ago, the present political situation at one of the uptown clubs. Among them was Capt. William Ledyard Ellsworth, United States Army, who, upon request, will exhibit with pride, his first commission in the army, which bears the signature of Abraham Lincoln and the countersignature of Gen. Thomas.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., July 5 -- Present indications point to an unusually successful season at this resort, as many applications for rooms have been received, and during the past week the number of the arrivals has been large.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 5 -- The continued arrival of cottagers have given Bar Harbor an appearance unusually animated for so early in the season. Already the drives are crowded in the afternoons, and entertainments in large numbers are being given.

BOSTON, July 5 -- It is reported that Agulnaldo Is coming to Boston. He may sail at any time for San Francisco and join his Lieutenant, Sixto Lopez, in this city, with whom he will tour the country, delivering a series of lectures on the true conditions existing in the islands, and making a plea for the indpendence of their countrymen.

MELBOURNE, June 2 -- Sixteen months only have elapsed since the establishment of the Australian Commonwealth, and it has taken that short period to develop a state of things which was little expected. My letter three weeks ago showed that a somewhat serious imbroglio had arisen between the Governor General and the Federal Parliament over the question of his salary and allowances.

STAMFORD, N.Y., July 5 -- The change to more seasonable weather has brought many visitors to Stamford. The hotels report encouraging prospects for the season and all the available cottages have been rented.

The man without a hobby is preparing for an old age without zest while the pursuit of some idea even remotely useful to mankind lends a savor to life. How much greater is the pleasure to be reaped when the interest of collecting works of art goes hand in hand with a purpose to further the higher education in one's own State and city!

A few days ago a number of ladies and gentlemen of some social prominence summering at Newport were invited to dinner to meet "a distinguished visitor from Siam." They expected to meet a Prince traveling incognito, or at least a prominent diplomat, but the guest of honor was a monkey -- a well-educated and generally well-behaved representative of the group of primates in the classification of the higher mammals by LINNAEUS.

THERE are several men in Brighton, Mass., who will, no doubt, take a course in ornithology before they trade with a vender of birds hereafter. They have found out by experience, which cost them severally a large sum, that there are birds and birds. A few days ago a stranger appeared with many small wooden cages, in each of which appeared to be a canary the most beautiful yellowish coloring.

UPON the bicycle and the devotion to the pastime of cycling by men and women of the Eastern States, particularly those of the country districts, seem to depend in large measure the ultimate success of the prodigious project of the proposed New York and Chicago Road.

LONDON, July 5 -- The release of Government dividends accentuated the ease of money, which was in moderate demand to-day. It is estimated that nearly u0,000,000 ($30,000,000) must be repaid to the Bank of England early next week. The purchase of gold in the open market for shipment to France steadied discounts.

Henry Von Deesten, thirty years old, of 823 East One Hundred and Seventy-elghtn Street, who was a brother of Deputy Sheriff Fred Von Deesten, was instantly killed last night while alighting from a northbound car of the Union Railway, at the junction of Third and Brook Avenues. When the car came to a stop there he raised the guard rail on the left side and stepped to the street.

At St. Bartholomew's Hospital Dr. Waldo, the City Coroner, held an inquiry respecting the death of John Charles Fairman, aged sixty-two years, a night watchman, lately living at 431 Rotherhithe New Road. Harriet Margaret Fairman, the widow, stated that the deceased used to suffer with faintness if he hurried, and on Saturday when he left home he said: "I'm bound to be late, for if I hurry I know I shall fall dead."

PANAMA, Colombia, July 5 -- Confirmation has been received from a reliable source of the report that the revolutionary Generals Ramirez, Payan, and Porros, who were recently made prisoners by the rebel Chief Herrera for insubordination, and who were tried by court-martial at David, were sentenced to death.

THERE are certain spots in the sea around which storms rage so constantly that they have come to be known as "ocean graveyards." Sometimes it is a conformation of coastline that makes the spot dangerous: again it is a mere area of water which seems to be a natural storm centre, but mariners know these spots well and always give them a wide berth.

THE announcement was made a few days ago in a London paper that a perfect blue rose had been received from America at Kew Gardens. There was nothing in the short notice, aside from the mention that the rose was considered a botanical curiosity, to indicate that the flower, a perfect blue, marks an epoch in rose culture.

The French press refers to M. COMBES'S Cabinet as the "old Ministry." The reference is not to the month which has elapsed since they assumed office, although that period is already fourfold the time for which M. DUFAURE'S colleagues tasted the joys of office, and earned immortality as the Government for a week, which is the shortest time for which a Government was ever constituted in France.
WEST END, N.J., July 5 -- Ping pong having become very popular at the West End Hotel, Proprietor Walter E. Hildreth has decided to give two cups to be played for early this month.

The recent activity and advance in price of Missouri Pacific stock brings up the questions as to whether this stock is cheap at current quotations, and whether the advance is the result of investment purchases and justifed, or simply for the purpose of disposing of stock acquired at lower figures.

HE tenderfoot sportsman who goes to the Wheelertown settlement in these days finds himself treated with kinder consideration than he has any reason to expect -- far kinder, in fact, than any real woodsman would accord him elsewhere around the southeast corner of the Adirondacks.

SAN PETE COUNTY, Utah, offers a rich market for grasshoppers. Men, women, and children are engaged, from daylight until dark in collecting the pests and shipping them to the cities. The market price is $1 per bushel, and there seems to be no limit to either the supply or demand.

Heartbroken over the death of his wife, out of work, and penniless, Harry Clark, forty-five years of age, who came to this city from Buchanan, N.Y., three days ago, decided that life was not worth living yesterday morning, and in order to end it all leaped from High Bridge. He was fished out of the Harlem River more dead than alive, and taken to the J. Hood Wright Hospital.

Great interest was aroused at Coney Island among the resident population last night by the deferred announcement of the marriage of Mrs. Elizabeth Morey, sixty-four years old, a celebrated character of the place, to Benjamin Franklin Hobby, eighty-two years old, of the firm of Hobby Boody, masons and builders, of South Brooklyn.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 -- Miss Ruth Underbill, winner of the American golf championship for women in 1899, was the star of the tournament yesterday at the Burlingame Country Club. In competition with Mrs. R. Gilman Browne and Mrs. Laurence I. Scott, the two best players in Northern California, she won the Poniatowski Cup.

THERE has just been finished at Waltham, Mass., a mammoth watch, the largest in the world. To build this gigantic timepiece cost several thousand dollars and several weeks' time. Special machinery and tools were required for its construction.

ST. JOHNS, N.F., July 5 -- A furious gale raged here last night and swept the whole seaboard, destroying much fishing property. It is feared that the storm worked great havoc with shipping. The steamship Harmony, at this port, broke from her moorings, damaged three ships, several wharves and a number of fishing vessels, and finally went ashore in Petty Harbor.
