She had posted it an hour previously, she said, and since then had learned something about Mr. Blank that incensed her; therefore she did not want to keep the appointment she had consented to in the letter.

BERLIN, July 12 -- In his Fourth of July speech at Leipsic Ambassador White announced for the first time that his retirement from the Berlin post would take place next November, on his seventieth birthday.

Col. Robert Grier Monroe, who will assume the office of Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas, and Electricity on Tuesday, said yesterday that he had not made up his mind what he would do regarding positions in his department. It was too early for him to talk about it, and he would make no statement until after he took office.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At the risk of a cry of "old clothes" being raised by your readers, as they must gradually get tired of a controversy raging in this country about the clothing of the Bermuda prisoners, I beg to return once more and finally to this subject.

LONDON, July 12 -- The announcement that the coronation of King Edward will probably occur between Aug. 8 and Aug. 12 has caused a hasty rearrangement of plans in all directions. Visits to the country and the Continent have been canceled, and the season has been automatically lengthened to the middle of August.

LAKE MASSAWEPIE, N.Y., July 12 -- One of the prettiest spots in Childwold Park is Camp Isola, on an island in the extreme end of Lake Massawepie. This camp is the Summer home of Coe Downing Tows of New York. Mrs. Tows will entertain at a number of house parties at the Tows cottage on the mainland and at Camp Isola.

Minnie Kurtz, who played an important part in the trials of Capt. Diamond and Wardman Bissert, and who was arrested oh July 2, at 27 Stuyvesant Street, on a warrant issued June 21, 1901, charging her with keeping a disorderly house, made a statement yesterday which was incorporated in an affidavit, charging Detective Maher with having accepted valuable jewelry in payment for protection.'

KINGSTOWN, Island of St. Vincent, Thursday, July 10 -- The English Scientific Commission, headed by Doctors Anderson and Flett, who after investigating the various phenomena connected with the eruption of La Soufriere volcano here, left on the Fourth for England by way of other West Indian ports, noticed that the crater was seemingly quiet.
THE wind has a good opportunity to snook into everybody's business, as people, all unsuspicious, open their windows and doors to the breeze, and even invite him to enter.

SHE was very proud of his pretty young bride, it occurred to him -- foolish man -- that there would be nothing more delightful than to spend the honeymoon in making a round of visits among his relatives.

NEWPORT, R.I. July 12 -- The fleet of the Atlantic Yacht Club arrived here from Shelter Island at intervals during last night. The boats had a slow time of it, being becalmed a good part of the day. None of the yachts that came was ready to take part in to-day's racing, as it had beer, expected they would.

Citizens of the anthracite district of Pennsylvania who are neither mine owners nor miners have at last found courage to tell the truth and dispel the illusions which the union leaders have sought to maintain as to the character of the measures resorted to by organized labor to make their strike formidable.
LONDON, July 12 -- The demand for money slackened somewhat to-day owing to the settlement being ended. Discounts were steady. The inquiry for gold continued from the Continent, especially from Paris.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 12 -- Cottagers and all-year-round residents between here and North Long Branch feel very much pleased to learn that a much-needed improvement is to be made upon Ocean Avenue Drive between these two points. They have been notified that a stone road will be built under the State Road act law.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Fragmentary reports of the litigation instituted by Mr. Louis Windmuller and myself in the matter of the Spirits Distributing Company in New Jersey have given rise to so many false impressions that I have taken the liberty of asking you to publish this simple statement of fact.

THERE is a laundry over in Brooklyn which hangs the most absurd little shirt ever seen in its front window, as the sign manual of its trade. The shirt is cut in the proper style for a man, with choker collar and expansive "bosom," although it might fit a boy of six.

CARRIER PIGEONS are about to try to cross the continental divide for the first time in history. The attempt will be made from one of the mountain towns near Denver, probably Ward or Silver Plume. Cassius M. Day will free the thoroughbred birds for their cross-country fly.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 12 -- Since the Fourth of July the number of guests at the Hotel Champlain has increased with unusual rapidity, and there are now over 200 people there enjoying the cool breezes, charming views of lake and mountain, and the other features that make life in the hot Summer months a pleasure at Bluff Point.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 12 -- So large and numerous are the accommodations of this town for the entertainment in a first-class manner of Summer visitors, that it requires the presence here of a vast multitude of pleasure and health seekers before the number of strangers can be appreciated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with considerable interest your leading article on "Mains and Electrolysis," published in your issue of the 10th inst., in which you criticise a leading article on "Electrolysis" in The Electrical Review of the 3th inst. It is very unusual for the lay press to take issue successfully with any technical paper upon subjects which it is supposed to treat as an expert.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 11 -- "Addicks of Delaware" has begun to give evidences of renewed eruption, and there is every reason to believe that he will be in a state of volcanic activity during the coming campaign. There is also reason to believe that unless the Democrats carry the State, as they believe they will, Addicks will manage to land enough members of the Legislature to elect him United States Senator.

The announcement of the engagement of the Right Rev. Henry C. Potter, D.D., Bishop of New York, to Mrs. Alfred Corning Clark of this city and Cooperstown, well known in New York for her many benevolent works, was made yesterday. The Bishop is in Paris, where he has just arrived, after a tour through the Loire country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A year or so before his death, the historian Freeman said that it was a misfortune that there was no single word expressing the whole conception of the English-speaking peoples as distinguished from all other races and peoples similar to the word "Hellenes," as applied to the ancient Greeks, whether they lived in Athens, Syracuse, Marseilles, or elsewhere.

LENOX, July 12 -- This has been an extremely busy week in Lenox, with the Field-Sloane wedding and its attendant festivities, the principal one being the large garden party given by Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane at Wyndhurst on Wednesday for Gen. Horace Porter and Mrs. Porter.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., July 12 -- Real midsummer weather has reached the Pier at last. The change from wood fires in cottage hearths and hotel corridors has been a welcome one, and now out-door entertainments and dinners which had been planned will be given.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 12 -- The following notice, prominently posted at the entrance to the Meadow Club, has caused some surprise and a little excitement:

Two races were sailed yesterday by the 21 and 18 foot one-design class of boats of the American Yacht Club over a triangular course of ten miles off Milton Point, Rye. There was a strong southwest breeze which forced many of the boats to reef. Howard Willets's Cricket won the 21-foot class and Simeon Ford's Kitty that for the 18-footers.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 12 -- It has been a charming week at this resort. The weather has been delightful, and while it has been warm at the cities during the latter part of the week, there have been cool breezes blowing here from the south most of the time.

LONDON, July 12 -- Small credence is placed among substantial City men in the various yarns concerning American railroad speculation current here this week and published in some of the financial papers.

NEWPORT, July 12 -- Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish's dinner at Crossways this evening was not only her first entertainment, but was the most important social function of the season thus far, in fact it far outshone anything that has been given this year. There were forty guests, and the decorations were entirely yellow and green, a profusion of alamandas and coreopsis, with madenhair ferns being used to make the massive centrepieces for the table.

THE United States Government, in taking up the subject of wireless telegraphy, has ordered a test of the various systems between Annapolis and the navy yard at Washington, D.C., and the Coast Survey steamer Eagre is now engaged off the Long Island coast, near Bridgehampton, in a series of tests for determining longitudes by means of wireless signals.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

THE article printed in the Magazine Section last Sunday concerning the "third degree" and describing the indignities practiced upon prisoners in this country by police officers when forcing them to make "confessions" has attracted much attention. The subject was brought up by a recent decision in a Massachusetts court, and many New York lawyers are now considering means whereby the system as practiced in this city may be done away with.

AMONG the many distinctions accorded to the deeds of Major Gen. Wayne -- "Mad Anthony," as he was so generally called, and whose memory is commemorated in the new Stony Point Park -- there is the singular one that his mortal remains occupy in part two separate graves in different parts of Pennsylvania, each of which is known by suitable inscription as "the grave of Gen. Wayne."

Outlaw TRACY'S press agent broke down Thursday morning from brain fag. The Seattle reporter who was engaged to take his place drove into Covington after midnight, but still in time to get his dispatch on the wires before the morning papers of the East went to press. There is three hours' difference of time between New York and the State of Washington.
To the Editor of The New York Times: With reference to your editorial of this morning under the heading of "Mains and Electrolysis," I beg to submit the following:
The Bituminous Coal Operators' Association, which was organized on Friday at 1 Broadway, has appointed a committee to go to firms that were not represented at the meeting and enlist recruits.

The Tribune publishes the following passage from a speech by Senator BURTON of Kansas, explaining to his party in his State his position on the Cuban question, as to which he openly fought the recommendations of the President:

Yesterday's stock market was a decidedly strong one, with advancing quotations quite general to the list under the lead of such standard shares as St. Paul, Rock Island, Atchison, and Missouri Pacific. In the early trading the market had been somewhat listless, traders and others being apparently inclined to wait upon, the bank statement.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., July 12 -- The extent of the catastrophe of the Rolling Mill Mine of the Cambria Steel Company is not capable of being grasped. Early to-night, in spite of conflicting reports as to the number of dead, a careful and complete compilation shows that 112 is the extent of the list of the bodies outside the mine.

Controller Grout appears to be practically convinced that there is a metal ceiling trust, and that the city is a sufferer from its methods. Attached to a recent voucher for city work of this kind were the bids, five in number, and all for a uniform amount, $484.

ADVICES come from Paris that Dr. Garnault of that city, who challenged the statement made by Prof. Koch last year to the effect that human beings could not contract consumption from contaminated cattle, is now submitting himself to a daring experiment. Returning to Paris, he studied bovine tuberculosis, and has a treatise on the subject ready for publication.

EACH day there now toils up Fifth Avenue and through the fashionable district an enormous coach drawn by eight horses and loaded with sightseers. The most of them are out-of-town people -- but not all, not by any means all. In the midst of the bulging eyes and gaping mouths stands a man with a megaphone.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 12 -- The Warren and Jamestown Electric Railway Company to-day filed papers of incorporation with the Clerk of Chautauqua County. The company is capitalized at $100,000, and will build an electric railroad from Warren, Penn., to Jamestown.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 12 -- A special from Johnstown to-night says: "The explosion in the Klondike section of the Rolling Mill Mine was undoubtedly caused by blasting. A shot set off the fire damp and started all the trouble."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Sunday newspaper does harm and ought to be discontinued, because: 1. It disobeys a plain and explicit com mand of God to keep the Sabbath holy. The Sunday newspaper treats the Sabbath like any other day. The Sabbath is the Lord's day; man, has no right to use it for labor or mere pleasure, as he does other days.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 12 -- Saranac Lake voted recently to raise $40,000 for an improved sewer system. This is in keeping with the tone of advancement of the village, which last year expended a large amount of money on a new water works system.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The reply in your issue of the 1st inst. to my letter of the 24th of June suggests that the purpose of the operators in the present strike is to destroy unionism. The writer, who designates himself as a "modest employe," claims to represent the spirit of the operators in favor of suppressing the union in the coal regions.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Pension Commissioner Eugene F. Ware has adopted a system of promotions for his bureau which he intends to make a permanent feature. The system is explained in the following letter of instructions to a special committee on promotions:

BALTIMORE is preparing to rid itself of the smoke nuisance forever. Plans have been laid to convert the municipality into an electric city like Niagara. The power will be generated by the waters of the Susquehanna River and transmitted overland by wire to Baltimore.
LONDON, July 12 -- Mrs. George Crocker and her family have left London for Paris and Carlsbad.

THE discovery at the Massachusetts State House of two iron treasure chests, which bear unmistakable marks of sixteenth century workmanship, has been the recent feature of especial interest in Boston. That the chests were the coffers of the State in the early years there is no doubt.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- The city to-day was full of rumors that the switchmen on the various railways entering Chicago were about to go on a strike, and these stories caused widespread alarm among shippers and others. It was especially said that the switchmen of the Northwestern Railway were so dissatisfied that they were ready to quit.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario, July 12 -- The Canadian Tennis championship tournament was concluded here to-day. The Wright brothers won the double championship and Beals Wright won the single by default from W.A. Larned, last year's champion. The men's handicap was won by Patterson, who in the finals reversed the result in the opens, where McMaster beat him.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A document has just reached the document rooms of the Senate and House from the Government Printing Office entitled the "Deadly Parallel" on Cuban tariff reduction, and was compiled by Truman G. Palmer. It was ordered printed during the closing days of Congress as a Senate document.

SO far it has been a secret. Not a word concerning it has been breathed to anybody except our relatives and friends and others to whom the latter have told it in amused surprise. But, after all, why conceal it? The world will hear of it before long, anyway; at least, such is our fond hope.

The great bard of Avon has pointed out the fact that sermons are not delivered from the pulpit alone. Stones preach -- and most eloquently on occasion. Who with any imagination can stand before the pyramids of Egypt, or the Acropolis in Greece, or the Colosseum in Rome, or even many a lesser ruin, and not be spellbound by the lofty, though mute, eloquence which pours upon his understanding?

The production of bituminous coal last year was on the greatest scale ever known, and this year is not going to show any decrease, for the tonnage records up to date have been far and away beyond those of 1901. Here is the story of that year, compared with the preceding:

ALTHOUGH mad Pelee is still visiting its deadly rage on its prostrate victims of St. Pierre and vicinity, the survivors in Martinique have put aside the story of the victims to reckon the losses sustained. M. Clarac, Martinique's most prominent business man and the richest man in the West Indies, says, according to The New Orleans Times-Democrat, that the commerce of the West Indies is ruined by the eruptions of Mont Pelee.

It is scarcely to be wondered at, perhaps, that the true merits of existing conditions in the transportation industry are not fully realized or appreciated, for, after all, this would seem to be impossible while there remains any light still to be thrown upon the situation, and while there remain comparisons to be made that can only be instituted as the records come to be written up.

The park opened a fortnight since at Coney Island has been a surprise and delight to those who have seen it, but its chief value resides in the fact that it is an object lesson which those interested in seaside improvements all along the Atlantic Coast may study with profit.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 12 -- There was an exodus of "over the Fourth" visitors early in the week, but one would not notice their departure now, as the Board Walk is thronged during the mornings and evenings. There are more visitors here now than prior to last week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In this morning's issue you stated, in giving an account of certain proceedings taken by me in reference to the issuance of transfers at Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, that the Attorney General had refused to take any action.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., July 12 -- The season at this resort began some time ago and still continues to increase week by week. Guests are enjoying the golf links, which are in excellent condition. Tennis and ping-pong are also among the numerous amusements. The orchestras at the various hotels are all good, and hops and musicales are held daily.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 -- The St. Louis baseball team defeated the Brooklyns to-day by a score of 3 to 0. The feature of the game was the fine pitching of both Kitson and Yerkes, the former allowing only six hits and the latter seven. Kitson received faultless support, while Yerkes was the only man to make an error on the home team.

ONLY one man of the "Reuben" type, and he rather a suggestion than a realization of the genuine article; an old man, with his coat climbing up behind and sagging down to his knees in front, with trousers too shy to meet his shoetops, and wrinkled like a ram's horn.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 12 -- Picturesquely situated among the hills and valleys, the Dutcher House and cottages have become well known for New York and Brooklyn patronage. The pretty grounds which surround the hotel are very similar to those of the Grand Union Hotel at Saratoga, on a smaller scale.

After losing two games of the present series at Jersey City on Thursday and Friday, the Toronto baseball team won from the Jersey City players yesterday by a score of 9 to 5. In the second inning the visitors batted Barnett out of the box, scoring seven runs. McCann relieved him, but had to retire after the third inning with a split finger.

PEOPLE in New Orleans are excited over an event without a parallel which has occurred near there. A plague of fish has suddenly afflicted the neighboring town of Harvey, from which the people have been fleeing in terror, and the health authorities have been at their wits' end to know how to cope with the problems involved.

The annual regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club yesterday was the largest one of the year, in the vicinity of New York. Fifty-three yachts started, and fifty-one were timed at the finish. The fleet at the annual regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club on the Fourth of July numbered fifty-two starters, and that of the annual regatta of the Riverside Yacht Club on the day after the Fourth counted up fifty-one.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 12. -- Secretary Root, who has been expected here for some days, arrived to-night, being the first member of the Cabinet to respond to the invitation of the President. Secretary Root arrived on the Kanawha at 7:35 this evening, and he was taken in a launch to the landing on Mr. Roosevelt's property.

The first two weeks of July have witnessed a course of events which, if continued, will make the present Summer unique in the history of similar periods of real estate dealing, for while the volume of business is hardly in excess of usual Summer standards, yet it has been marked by an unusual number of important transactions.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- There is no longer any doubt that, so far as the Democratic Congressional Committee can manege it, the tariff will be one of the chief issues of the Fall campaign, if not the main one. Chairman Griggs said to-day: "We get more applications for tariff literature than for literature on any other subject."

"WHAT do I think 'bout girls learnin' to swim?" asked Capt. Knowles as he straightened up from the barrel in which he had been salting fish. "Waal, now, I'm free to say consider'ble more'n I used to. You know my girl Cedy?"

LONDON, July 14. -- The Marquis of Saleisbury has resigned the Premiership, and the Right Hon. A.J. Balfour, the First Lord of the Treasury and Government leader in the House of Commons, has been appointed his successor.

There was a wild scene last night about 11:30 o'clock on the Old Iron Pier at Coney Island. Women wept, men swore, and three policemen had all they could do to keep the crowd in order. The trouble was that hard on 300 people from Jersey were about to be left without visible means of getting home, and that with tickets in their pockets and their boat in sight.

DANBURY, Conn., July 13.--To have appear as from the dead his wife and daughter, neither of whom he had seen in twenty years, the one supposed to be dead and the whereabouts of the latter unknown to him, was the strange experience yesterday of James Foy, a prosperous manufacturing machinist of this city.

CINCINNATI, July 13. -- The baseball game to-day was a pitchers' battle. Hahn held the Pittsburgs down to less hits, but the three of them coming bunched in the first inning was what lost the game for Cincinnati. Tannehill's finger was knocked out of joint in the sixth inning and he had to retire, Leever taking his place.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- "I read with great interest Gen. Fitzhurg Lee's interview on Cuba's present situation and future prospects," said Senator" Elklns to-day, "especially as I consider that no one who Is at liberty to speak is better qualified to do so on this subject. His prediction that anarchy and annexation were certain to follow financial distress is founded on an intimate knowledge of the Cuban people, acquired under exceptionally favorable circumstances.

SAVANNAS, Ga., July 13. -- During a terrific thunderstorm this afternoon Thomas Roe, a watchman at the Ocean Steamship Company wharves, and Lizzie Williams, a negro girl who had brought him his dinner, were instantly killed by a bolt of lightning. Another girl standing two feet from the Williams child was unscathed.

Sergt William Hunter of the Eleventh United States Field Artillery, who on Friday night stabbed Private George Slusher of the same command in a garden in the rear of a saloon at One Hundredth Street and Fourth Avenue, Fort Hamilton, will be arraigned in the Coney Island Police Court to-morrow morning to answer to a charge of felonious assault.

-- It would be hard to find a better example of how a young man should not seek employment than the following advertisement, which is clipped from The Evening Post: "Young attorney, Harvard law graduate, lacking 'pull' and having used up his money, must get to work to make a living.

NEWARK, N.J., July 13. -- The stockholders of the Merchants' Fire Insurance Company of this city are contemplating voluntary liquidation, and a decision to that effect may be arrived at in the course of a few days.

The Art Museum of Worcester, Mass., holds a Summer exhibition of paintings from June to mid-September, which is open to the public without entrance fee on Saturdays till 6 P.M., and on Sunday afternoons. Two prizes of $300 and $200 are given by a jury of artists for the best two paintings, and the Museum is likely to buy one or more pictures in the exhibition to add to the permanent collection.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Wu Ting-Fang, the Chinese Minister at Washington, was not surprised to hear of the appointment of a successor to himself, as he had been expecting an announcement of this character for some time. He had received notice that his services would be required in another capacity, and for this reason has been prepared to hear of the naming of his successor at any time.
LONDON, July 14. -- The Times announces that the Marquis of Salisbury has resigned the Premiership and that the Right Hon. A.J. Balfour has been appointed to succeed him.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13. -- The races that had been arranged to be sailed under the auspices of tne Newport Yacht Racing Association Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday have been postponed. So many of the large yachts that had been entered have been withdrawn that it was found impossible to make the racing in the larger classes sufficiently interesting.

Among the various places of interest to be found in different parts of the country, the old churchyard is certainly not the least interesting, as the tombstones occasionally contain records of those who are buried below in quaint, if not humorous, language, the reading of which affords pleasure, as well as food for thought.

The American Federationist, for the editorial conduct of which Mr. SAMUEL, GOMPERS assumes responsibility, enunciates the extraordinary doctrine that when as the result of disagreements between capital and labor production is suspended and the ordinary course of the National life is checked the public has no concern in the matter, and any attempt on its part to effect such adjustments as will permit a restoration of normal conditions is an impertinence.

They appear to do these things somewhat better in France. For example, one DONADIEU, a small holder of stock in the Panama Canal Company, not feeling that he had been reckoned with to his satisfaction in the plan of the majority in interest to cede to the United States their Colombian white elephant, appeared before the French courts as a suitor to restrain such cession by injunction, or whatever may be the French equivalent therefor.

Work has been begun preparatory to the erection of the new permanent home for the choir boys of Grace Church. The three buildings at 88-92. Fourth Avenue, just back of the church, have been removed, and on this ground will be erected, besides the structure for the choir, vestry, and music room a clergy house, with accommodations for three assistant, ministers.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The appointment of Mr. Balfour to the British premiership will not result in any change in the existing relations between Great Britain and the United States. This is the view of State Department officials, who express the opinion that Mr. Balfour will be as much disposed as was Lord Salisbury to continue the friendly relations between the two countries.

John Prisani, a ten-year-old boy, of 24 Hamilton Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon by Detectives McKenna and Cavanaugh of the Leonard Street Station on a charge of arson. If the boy's statements are to be believed he is a member of one of the most dangerous gangs of youthful firebugs that has operated for some time.

BANGOR, July 13. -- The most remarkable murder mystery that Maine has known in twenty-five years is, after a long period of Official inactivity, again engaging the attention of the courts and exciting the interest of the people. On the 17th of September, 1898, an elderly woman named Sarah Ware disappeared from her home in Bucksport, and two weeks later her body was found, badly mutilated, in a pasture near the house.

Borough president Jacob A. Cantor is gathering facts on the question of the installation of pipe galleries as an experiment in the construction work of the subway through lower Broadway. His attention has been called repeatedly to the bad condition of many of the gas pipes and the highly dangerous leakage of gas.

Peace was proclaimed at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union between the members of the Brewery Workers' Union and the firemen and engineers employed in breweries, who have been fighting one another for years. The fight arose from an attempt by the Brewery Workers' Union to force the brewery engineers and firemen to join it by ordering strikes against them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The taxpayers of this city, slow as they are to get together to protect their interests, should give to Mayor Low and Controller Grout credit for promising reform in the assessment of real estate for taxation and encourage them to begin at once the good work.

ST. PETERSBURG, July " 13. -- Emperor Nicholas, wearing the chain of the Order of the Annunziata; the Czarowitch,. the Rus- Elan Grand Dukes, Count Lamsdorff, Minister of Foreign Affairs; the other Cabinet Ministers, and a number of officers greeted King Victor Emmanuel upon his arrival at the railway station here at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- It is now practicable to determine the effect of the drought of 1901 upon the export trade of 1902. The Treasury Bureau of Statistics has just completed its preliminary figures on the exports of breadstuffs and provisions, and as they show about 97 per cent, of the total exports, a reasonably accurate measurement of the exportation of articles affected by the drought of last year can now be made.

Mr. GRIGGS, Chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee, is a man of sense. He announces that his committee proposes to conduct the campaign for Congressional candidates this Fall chiefly on the issue of the tariff. He reports an urgent demand from all parts of the Union for "literature" on that issue.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 13. -- The Standard Oil Company and the Atlantic and Pacific Oil Company of New York are preparing to build pipe lines from the rich field in Knox County to Barbourville. When the pipe lines are built all the oil from the field now stored in tanks can be marketed and more developing will be done.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., July 13. -- This has been a day of funerals. Scores of victims of the Rolling Mill Mine disaster were buried here and in Cambria City, where every church had its quota of dead who were followed to the grave by hundreds of grieving relatives and friends. The black cloud of mourning was heaviest over Cambria City, where the foreign population dwells.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 13 .-- Gen. Horace Porter was entertained at luncheon to-day by W. S. Gurnee, Jr., of New York. The other gentelmen present were Henry Cadwalader Chapman, Count Langier Villars, Johnston Livingston, and Louis Livingston. To-night Gen. Schofield gave a small dinner in Gen. Porter's honor.

It is more and more apparent that the floating supply of good stocks on the Stock Exchange has become decidedly small. The experience in recent days of the snorts in one stock and another is Perhaps best Illustration of this. These pessimists have in turn sold St. Paul, New York Central, Rock Island, Missouri Pacific, Sugar, and other stocks that will readily suggest themselves.

The above is practically the slate agreed upon for the State ticket to be nominated by the Republican State Convention at Saratoga in September. The agreement was reached at the conference of Senator Platt, Gov. Odell, and other leaders at Manhattan Beach yesterday. Another conclusion reached was that Senator F.W. Higgins of Olean is not to be considered available for nomination for Lieutenant Governor.

The Peary arctic steamship Windward arrived at Long Dock near the Erie station in Jersey City at 6 o'clock last evening, and will leave for the north to-day. The Windward had come down under her own steam from Newburg, N. Y., where for the last two months she has been receiving new equipment of boilers and machinery.
On the retirement of Lord SALISBURY, which has long been expected, it was almost inevitable that Mr. BALFOUR should be his successor.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Final overtures for the settlement of the strike of freight handlers and teamsters were made at meetings Of the two unions to-night. At the instigation of the members of the Chicago Board of Arbitration, the freight handlers agreed to send committees to all the railroads tomorrow morning.

HARRISBURG, Penn., July 13.--The report of Insurance Commissioner Durham in its complete shape has just been issued, and among its contents are figures of losses sustained by Pennsylvania joint stock, fire, and marine insurance companies and foreign companies that have American branches.
LONDON, July 14. -- T.P. O'Connor, M. P., in an interview last night, summed up the situation in connection with the resignation of Lord Salisbury and the appointment of Mr. Balfour as follows:

There was an interruption yesterday of the quiet which heretofore had pervaded the boarding house conducted by Mrs. Agnes Karetski, at 237 Freeman Street, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. As a result of the happenings which followed Mrs. Karetski and her husband were taken to St. Catharine's Hospital, while two of the boarders spent the balance of the night in cells in the Greenpoint Avenue Police Station.

While crowded with close to a hundred men, women, and children on their way to Bronx and Pelham Bay Parks, a Union Railway trolley car became unmanageable on a steep grade yesterday afternoon, and, jumping the track, crashed into a telegraph pole.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 13. -- Yesterday Town Marshal Butler discovered a cave which will in all probability supply a missing link in the ill-starred history of the "State of Franklin" or what is now called Tennessee.

Some excellent sport was furnished by a small but very select gathering of trotters and pacers on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning. Close finishes marked the majority of the events, which were held on the upper stretch, where the crowd gathered in the greatest numbers. Several new pacers were on the road, and though they did not win any of the heats, they gave a good account of themselves.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13. -- Commodore Robert E. Tod of the Atlantic Yacht Club gave out this afternoon plans that lie has matured for the encouragement of ocean yacht racing. He proposes to inaugurate a series of ocean races under the auspices of the Atlantic Club, the first of which will be the race that will be started here from the Brenton Reef Lightship at 11 o'clock to-morrow.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 13. -- Residents in the neighborhood of Dwight Place and Thomas Street were aroused by screams of women's voices and appeals for help proceeding from Mrs. E.H. Canfield's house early on Saturday morning.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 13. -- President Roosevelt and Secretary Root were so busily engaged to-day in the consideration of important subjects that they did not attend church services. One of the subjects discussed was that of Gov. Taft's negotiations with the Vatican respecting the Philippine friars.

DETROIT, July 13. -- Grosse Pointe track, where the blue ribbon meeting of the Detroit Driving Club opens the grand trotting circuit of 1902 to-morrow afternoon, will be fast if the weather predictions of tonight are fulfilled. It was in good shape to-day, and if the sun shines brightly tomorrow morning will be at its very best.

Ex-Chief of Police William S. Devery made his formal debut as an anti-Croker Tammany Hall politician last night. He also delivered an address which the habitues of the Devery Four Corners and Democrats of the Ninth District characterized as a "corker."

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Minister Bowen considers the situation in Venezuela such that, at the request of the State Department, the Navy Department has decided to send an additional ship to La Guayra, and tomorrow, upon the arrival of the Marietta at Kingston, Jamaica, for which place she sailed to-day from Cape Haytien, she will be met by orders to proceed to La Guayra.

The Tilden Club made public last evening the letter of apology sent to the club by William J. Bryan for his public announcement that he had not received an invitation to the clubhouse opening, upon which occasion Grover Cleveland and David B. Hill were the guests of honor.

A race that is certain to occasion no end of excitement was practically arranged yesterday between Charles R. Flint's steam yacht Arrow, the fastest pleasure craft in existence; A. Lewisohn's steam yacht Vamoose, another famous boat, and the Central Railroad of New Jersey's fast steamboat, Monmouth, whose record trips between New York and Atlantic Highlands are of daily occurrence, for Friday.
LONDON, July 14.--Andrew Carnegie has given 10,000 to Eastbourne, Sussex, for the establishment of a library, for which the Duke of Devonshire has given the site.

BALTIMORE, July 14. -- The sudden upspurt of International Trust was one of the leading features of to-day's market. The last sale on Saturday was at 132. Today the price shot up to 136. That was high enough to attract some offerings of stock bought below 130. The price, therefore, was reached under the weight of prompt taking, but it closed with a net gain.
"Thousands, tens of thousands of people die because their physicians have not the moral courage to say to them: 'This is tuberculosis, and now is the time to take precautions.'"

The entire twelve-story building to be erected by James A. Campbell at 108 Broadway is reported to have been leased for a term of twenty-one years to the Childs Unique Dairy Company. The contract for the erection of the new structure has been awarded to Isaac A. Hopper Son, and Will be ready for occupancy on May 1, 1903.

CINCINNATI, July 14. -- The New York baseball team put up a very amateurish exhibition to-day, and was shut out by the local team. Jones was put out of the grounds by Umpire Powers for questioning a decision, and Mathewson took his place in left field. O'Hagen was put out of the grounds for talking to Powers from the bench. Score:

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Colored Republicans in two of the Maryland districts are greatly disturbing the peace of mind of two Republican Representatives who are candidates for re-election. These troublous conditions exist in the Fifth and Sixth Districts, represented by Messrs. Mudd and Pearre.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The incoming Philippine mail brings the full printed record of proceedings in the court-martial cases of Major Lyttleton W.T. Waller and Lieut. John Horace Arthur Day of the Marine Corps, growing out of the killing of some native bearers, or cargadores, in Samar.
LONDON, July 14. -- Money was much wanted in the market to-day for repayments to the Bank of England. Discounts were fairly steady.

The recent criticism of the civil service policy of the Low administration by the Democratic member of the State Civil Service Commission may or may not be wholly well founded in fact. It is a mighty encouraging sign all the same. It is none the less so because Col. OGDEN, the Chairman of the City Civil Service Board, dismisses Mr. CRAFT'S statement with some indifference as intended to "make political capital."

Borough President Swanstrom of Brook- lyn had an amusing adventure yesterday morning with an alert and determined new "scrub lady " in the Borough Hall. There have been frequent thefts of various small articles of more or less value from the office of the Borough President of late, and the employes of the Borough Hall have been cautioned to keep a sharp lookout for the thieves.

Of course it is inconceivable that the Earl of ROSEBERY, either in his possible capacity as the leader of a reunited and reorganized Liberal Party or as a student of history, should deliberately take an American audience further into his confidence than he has his hearers in Manchester, Liverpool, London, and other British political centres.
First Lieut, Samuel E. Lambert, Assistant Surgeon, recently appointed, will report to the commanding officer, Fort Morgan, for duty.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 14. -- Senator Spooner of Wisconsin arrived at Sagamore Hill at about 10:30 o'clock last night and, after a conference with the President and Secretary Root, he left for New York at about midnight. His conversation with the President related in part to the proposed purchase of the Panama Canal Company's property.

With the six races of the Brighton Beach programme yesterday divided fairly between the favorites and non-favorites, there still was no relief for the layers of odds, for the three post choices who did win came in a straight row at the finish of the programme and he was a timid form follower indeed who failed to finish the afternoon with a profit after such a "break."
VENICE, July 14. -- The Campanile of St. Mark collapsed at 10:40 o'clock this morning, and feil with a great crash into the Piazza.

Strength showed in every part or yesterday's security market. Advances were substantial, and hardly a conspicuous share on the list failed to rise. New public interest was evidenced by commission-house activity, the day's transactions running beyond 650,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- It is expected that Minister Wu will not leave Washington for his new post in China for some weeks. His successor, Liang-Chen-Tung, is now attached to the Chinese Special Embassy to the coronation of King Edward VII., headed by Prince Chun, a son of Prince Ching, who is the head of the Chinese Board of Foreign Affairs, and the embassy is expected to attend the coronation ceremony in August.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- Prospects for low scores in the qualifying rounds for the amateur golf championship, which will be played over the Glenview course to-morrow, were materially lessened to-night by a soaking rain. The play will begin at 8 o'clock in the morning, as the entry list is a long one, and those starting before 10 o'clock will undoubtedly find the course heavy and tricky in places.

LONDON, July 15. -- The Times says that "La Veine," by the latest French dramatist, Alfred Capus, was produced at the Garrick Theatre last evening. The play deals with the relations, between a briefless barrister, played by M. Guitry, and a flower-shop keeper, played by Jeanne Granier.

SALIDA, Col., July 14. -- A report was received here shortly before noon to-day to the effect that the Denver and Rio Grande narrow gauge passenger train, which left here early last night, was "held up" and robbed at Mill Switch, two miles west of Chester.

In the suit of the Standard Distilling and Distributing Company against George L. Woolsey, the Hammond Distilling Company, and the Manhattan Trust Company, Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court yesterday signed an order restraining the defendant Woolsey from engaging in the distilling business within 1,200 miles of Chicago, and directing him to sell all his stock in the Hammond Distilling Company.

Mrs. Joanna Dwyer, forty years old, of 189 Eighth Street, Brooklyn, was arrested at 1 o'clock this morning and locked up in the Fifth Avenue Station on the charge of homicide, it being alleged that she had caused the death of her seven-year-old son Peter by beating him.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14. -- The Philadelphia market broadened considerably today, and trading at times was at a lively pace, with Electric Storage, Reading, Philadelphia Rapid Transit, and Cambria Steel dominating the list. Instead of the animation being confined to the forenoon as here to fore, it extended throughout the day, and the buying was of a more confident character than at any time last week.
LONDON, July 15. -- The Times's correspondent at Venice says that the Campanile of St. Mark fell to the ground yesterday morning. Not only the tower, but also the Sansovine Loggia was destroyed.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Gen. Chaffee has been relieved of the command in the Philippines and ordered to the command of the Department of the East by an order issued to-day by Secretary Root. The order reads as follows:
BALTIMORE, July 14. -- The twin infant daughters of Mrs. Basil B. Gordon, prominent in Baltimore society, were severely burned Saturday night in a camp at Saranac Lake, in the Adlrondacks.

MADISON, Wis., July 14. -- Politics in Wisconsin are split up. Lafollette has the nomination for Governor in his pocket. The question is, will Lafollette's big vote, which seems assured, be given to indorsement of Senator Spooner for re-election. Many counties have instructed their delegations to vote for Lafollette and for Spooner, but the situation is shown in the propositions made.

J. Pierpont Morgan has sent to the Ameri can Museum of Natural History, as a gift two of the most magnificent sapphires in the world. They are to be added to the collection donated by him to the institution. This collection, which is considered among the finest existing, was gathered by Tif fany Co. to be exhibited at the Part Exposition, after which it was bought by Mr. Morgan at great cost.

DETROIT, Mich., July 14. -- C. J. Hamlin's splendid black pacer Direct Hal, with driver Ed Geers in the sulky, made the opening of the Detroit Driving Club's blue ribbon meeting, at Grosse Pointe this afternoon, memorable by winning the first heat of the Chamber of Commerce $5,000 stake in the record time of 2:06 3/4.

BERLIN, July 14. -- The announcement of Lord Salisbury's retirement was received here simply as interesting news without great political significance, because it had long been expected. The comment is generally respectful, though not cordial. No British statesman gets cordial treatment in the German press, but Lord Salisbury was so much better liked than Mr. Chamberlain that he has always been spoken of with a certain regard.

Why Brooklyn is called the City of Homes is demonstrated by the real estate assessments on the tax books. The borough across the river shows up to advantage as compared with Manhattan, because in this borough the exigencies have made unusual methods necessary in the taxation of real estate.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OFTHE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of Its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

The investigation into the sulphurous acid gas nuisance yesterday afternoon in Commissioner Lederle's office resulted in an imperative demand by the Health Department to the Interurban Street Railway Company to stop the gas from getting into the cars of the Thirty-fourth Street crosstown line within five days.

There is a merry, active crew of amateur sailors and real old "salts" about the Larchmont Yacht Club these days. Every rope and spar aboard the yachts is being overhauled in anticipation of the club's gala event of the season, Larchmont Race Week, which will begin on Saturday and continue each day, excepting Sunday, thereafter to and including Saturday, July 26.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were fairly large. Manhattan Transit and Montreal and Boston were the most active issues. These and several other stooks made gains, and only a few declines were noted. While not very active, the market has for the last few days shown some new signs of strength, and in some stocks considerable speculative interest has been aroused.
NEWPORT, July 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. J. Wadsworth Ritchle, who have recently returned from Europe, are the guests of Mrs. Rltchle's sister, Mrs. Whitney Warren.
LONDON, July 15. -- The Eight Hon. A.J. Balfour was yesterday formally greeted as Great Britain's Premier, and the new regime began its work.

PARIS, July 15. -- The Parisians yesterday celebrated the one hundred and thirteenth anniversary of the capture of the Bastile in the customary manner. They were favored by brilliant weather, the heat being tempered by a refreshing breeze. The first noticeable event of the day was the annual demonstration of the League of Patriots before the Strasburg statue and the Joan of Arc statue, on whose pedestals they deposited wreaths.

The Armory Board met at the Mayor's office yesterday and appointed the firm of Clinton Russell of 32 Nassau Street to take charge of the work of reconstructing the armory of the Seventy-first Regiment on Park Avenue.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 14. -- The ocean race of the Atlantic Tacht Club from this port to New fork outside of Long Island, a distance of about 150 miles, was started at 11 o'clock this forenoon from Brenton Reef Lightship. While the weather was somewhat easy, a fine ten-knot southwest breeze was blowing, giving the five yachts that crossed the line a long twenty-five miles' beat round Montauk Point.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 14. -- Luther R. Marsh, the noted spiritualist and once prominent jurist, is in a critical condition of health at his home here. He is suffering from general debility, and it is feared he will not live long.

The prediction lately made by a minister in one of the Western cities -- Chicago, we believe -- to the effect that the only way in which it would soon be possible to maintain an interest in church work would be by means of "the continuous vaudeville," startled a great many conservative churchgoers, and possibly shocked some of them.
LONDON, July 15. -- Mr. Balfour's first appearance in the House of Commons as Premier yesterday afternoon was characteristic of the man and of the assembly.

LONDON, July 15. -- Unionist members of both houses of Parliament attended a party meeting at the Foreign Office yesterday. The public showed little interest in the meeting, which was summoned for noon, and the members of Parliament gathered in Downing Street almost unnoticed.

The reported intention of Mr. LITTLEFIELD of Maine to devise measures for the regulation of trusts during the recess of Congress, with the hope of passing them at the next session, does credit to that gentleman's energy in the public service. But if he expects to get his bills through Congress, or even through one house thereof, he is exposed to sorry disappointment.

BOSTON, July 14. -- The money market is still in a quiet condition, showing very little change from last week. The situation generally is as comfortable as is to be expected. The expected good bank statement of Saturday has served to create a slightly better feeling all around. Rates for the most part are showing little or no change, and demand is still extremely light.
To the Editor of The New York Times: With the opening of the public baths there comes again the old abuse of petty blackmailing and oppression of the poorer public.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 14. -- The polo quartet of Freebooters of Lakewood played a dashing game this afternoon against the team of the Rumson Polo Club, defeating the latter by 8 goals to 6. The competition was held on the Rumsoft field and attracted a representative fashionable gathering from among the Summer cottage colony, who lined about the field in four-in-hands, breaks, drags, and automobiles.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- Corn bears gave the bulls who are supporting the corner in July corn a severe drubbing about midsession on the Board of Trade to-day. The market opened without any news of particular significance, although the manner in which receiving houses were taking contract corn and sending it into this market caused much nervousness among the big bull leaders.

A ten-inning baseball game was played at West side Park, Jersey City, yesterday, in which the Jersey City team defeated the Montreal players by a score of 8 to 7. The game was replete with free hitting on both sides, fourteen hits being made by the visitor's, while the locals only made eleven. The poor fielding of Stafford, the Canadians' third baseman, was very costly, three errors being marked against him.

Minnie Kurtz, who was arrested on July 2 on a bench warrant, issued lay Justice McKean on March 14 last charging her with maintaining a disorderly house at 27 Stuyvesant Place, was arraigned in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday, found guilty, and remanded to the Tombs to await sentence this morning.

CHICAGO, July 14.--The freight handlers' strike reached the rioting stage this evening, and it was only after the police had charged on the crowd repeatedly and arrested eleven men that a semblance of order was restored.

Standard Oil financiers seem to have disposed of the Chicago corner in corn, through the instrumentality of their Glucose Trust -- not for philanthropy, but for profit. The drop of 25 cents a bushel in the July option from noon one day till noon the next testifies somewhat to the thoroughness of the transaction.
Inspector P.H. McLaughlin, the uniformed head of the Brooklyn police, said last night that the police were still without light as to the identity of the slayer of Albert C. Latimer.

A visit by Col. John N. Partridge to the City Hall yesterday revived rumors that it had to do with his retirement as Police Commissioner in favor of Dr. John McG. Woodbury, the Street Cleaning Commissioner. Mayor Low received him cordially and went with him to his sanctum.
NEWPORT, July 15 -- There was much entertaining among the "cottagers" to day. Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs gave her first large entertainment of the season, a luncheon, this afternoon.

Democrats everywhere will rejoice in the perusal of another self-revealing communication from the pen of Mr. WILLIAM J. BRYAN. In a belated acknowledgment of his invitation to be a guest at the Tilden Club reception last month Mr. BRYAN makes a fresh assault upon ex-President CLEVELAND.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- When Dr. W. H. Wiley, Chief of the Bureau of Animal Industry, gets back to this country from Europe, whither he sailed to-day, the United States Government will establish a free table for people who are willing to have their stomachs experimented with.

Thunderstorms, hall showers, and high winds brought relief yesterday from heat that during the forenoon hours threatened to make the day unbearable. The sun rose upon a temperature of 71 degrees, the lowest of the night, but soon the mercury began to start toward the record point for July 15 of 94 degrees, which it scored two years ago.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 15 -- The Mayor's private secretary is now the ruler of Minneapolis. Mayor Ames has gone to West Baden broken in health and his spirit crushed. The Chief of Police, Frederick W. Ames, is in hiding somewhere, probably at San Francisco, and an acting Chief of Police has been appointed in his place.

Prices in the outside market yesterday showed increased firmness, and transactions were on a larger scale than has been usual of late. The encouraging sign in the day's trading was the fact that most of the changes were on the side of gains, and in nearly every stock which showed more than customary activity quotations were advanced.

LONDON, July 15 -- The demand for money was active to-day in connection with dividend and interest payments. Money was not abundant, and the rates were firm. Discounts were disposed to be slightly weaker.
We venture to assert with a good deal of confidence, as a suggestion to the managers of the electric lines in this city, that "what Jack has done Jack can do."

DETROIT, July 15 -- The Detroit Driving Club's classic Merchants and Manufacturers' $10,000 stake for 2:24-class trotters at Grosse Pointe track, this afternoon, was won in hollow fashion by Rhythmic, a blind horse owned by Jesse Turney of Paris, Ky., that had never before been started in a race.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 15 -- The Denny organization of the Window Glass Workers' Association has instructed its Wage Committee to sign a scale for the operation of the factories from September until June 30 of next year. This extends the fire to one of ten months instead of eight months or less of the wage agreements of previous years.

GLENVIEW GOLF COURSE, GOLF, Ill., July 15 -- The youngsters had the better of the veterans in the opening struggle for the amateur golf championship which took place over the Glenview course to-day. Of the sixty-four who qualified in the medal play at eighteen holes a large proportion were mere boys, comparatively speaking, lads who have learned the game in the last three or four years, and whose strength is not yet upon them.

QUEBEC, July 15 -- This afternoon Messrs. Gaynor and Greene filed their answers to the motions made by counsel for the United States to quash the writs of habeas corpus issued by Judge Caron on June 20 and 21. Should the writs be set aside the extradition proceedings will be heard on their merits.
Senator Thomas C. Platt yesterday observed in a very quiet way the sixty-ninth anniversary of his birth. If his inclinations had been followed the event would have passed unnoticed.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- The famous John W. Gates corner in July corn came to an abrupt termination to-day, when it became known that shorts holding a good many million bushels had effected private settlements with Harris, Gates Co., and that the deal was at an end so far as the steel magnate was concerned.
The yachts which started in the race from Newport to Sea Gate Monday finished yesterday as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg to say that in the current number of The independent the following statement is made in an article entitled, "Typical Tenement Tragedies." by the Rev. David M. Steele:
If sad expedience has come to John W. Gates through his corn-cornering ambition he is able by a flood of geniality to disguise it.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 15 -- Figures compiled from reports made by each district of the United Mine Workers show that at the National convention to be held on Thursday at Indianapolis the delegates representing the striking miners of Pennsylvania, Michigan, West Virginia, and Virginia will largely outnumber those from the districts where the soft coal miners are at work.

Polo at Cedarhurst and yachting are the principal amusements in the vicinity of town. The number of well-known people yet in New York grows smaller each day. Craig Wadsworth, by the way, is one of these. He and Mr. and Mrs. Philip Lydig are among the few still met on Fifth Avenue and at the restaurants.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- Electric Storage Battery and Rapid Transit continued to lead the market to-day, both touching record prices in the present movement, although their activity and strength are attributable to no special cause. Consolidated Lake Superior was higher and in more active demand.

Justice Chester in the Supreme Court Brooklyn, yesterday heard argument on a motion to make permanent a temporary injunction obtained by Walter V. Cranford, head of the Cranford Company, contractors restraining the borough officials of Brooklyn and the Interstate Paving Company from carrying out asphalt paving contracts amounting to about $300,000.

Jersey City's baseball players were shut out by the Montreal nine yesterday at West Side Park, Jersey City. The Canadians batted Pfanmiller rather freely, Raub leading off with a home run in the first inning. Score:

BALTIMORE, July 15 -- The movements of the Nashville Railway securities were the day's feature. They closed yesterday with a break of 6 3/4 points. That left a good percentage of the clientele of nearly every broker in the city on the "loss" side of the market. The bond certificates were lifted as high, as 74, from Which point they again began to sag.

PRETORIA, July 15 -- The settlement of the annexed territories is not being accomplished without considerable friction. This is especially noticeable in the bitter hatred and persecution on the part of the Boers who staid in the field to the end of the war against the Boers who served as British scouts.

NEWPORT, July 15 -- The Newport Trust Company, which was organized last Autumn with a number of prominent New York financiers and Newport Summer residents on the Board of Directors, the aggregate wealth of the board being estimated at nearly $200,000,000, is having trouble erecting its new building on Thames Street here.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- The new battleship Maine, built at Cramps' shipyard, to replace the vessel destroyed in Havana Harbor, started this afternoon on the builders' trial trip off the Delaware Capes.

The Pope has expressed a willingness to take up with Gov. TAFT the question of education in the Philippines as soon as the preliminary questions are settled, particularly the question of the status of the friars.
MADISON, Wis., July 15 -- The situation on the eve of to-morrow's Republican Convention is this:

GREENWICH, Conn., July 15 -- Joseph L. Thompson, one of the retired millionaires who resides at Belle Haven Summers, asked the aid of the law to-night to protect his property from vandals. Sheriff Ritch was taken to Belle Haven to-night in Mr. Thompson's automobile, and a conference was had and a plan mapped out to trap the guilty parties.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad system is to be expanded on a large scale. All the plans have been completed to extend the road from El Paso to Los Angeles, should the controlling powers of the company deem the step advisable. Surveys have been completed, for an outlet for the system to Galveston, and contracts for part of the work have been let.
WASHINGTON, July 15.--The following is the Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions:...

Only the shortsighted and the unobservant will see cause for uneasiness in the figrures of our exports and imports for the year ended June 30. The totals, with the increase and decrease, as compared with the preceding year, are here given:

The final polo game for the Adjutant's Cups, presented by Lieut. R.C. Lawrence for novice competition among Squadron A teams, will be played to-day at Van Cortlandt Park between teams representing Troop 2 and Troop 3. The first teams of these two troops will contest in the deciding game on Saturday for the Officers' Cups.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of yesterday David Phillips, the "Looker-On," makes a most remarkable blunder. Discussing the faults of the police in the Latimer and Disbrow cases, he remarks that they seem to be affected by the "pernicious influence of Dr. Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes stories."

It is stated that the shareholders of the Merchants Insurance Company of Newark will have until Aug. 1 to assent to or dissent from an offer of 135 for their shares. The offer, which comes through the Fidelity Trust Company of Newark, is said to be conditioned upon whether the proposition is accepted for the entire outstanding capital stock.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- No action has been taken by the State Department with regard to Consul General Bragg's letter to his wife, in which he is said to have used contemptuous expressions about the Cuban people. It is not the purpose of the department to take any action unless the matter is forced upon its attention.

A smooth-tongued man posing as a doctor and robbing his victims by methods said to involve the use of hypnotism has been stealing money and valuables from women in the country places of Long Island. Miss C.M. Brooks of this city, who is spending a few weeks' vacation in Medford Station, has sent to her friends a most remarkable account of the way the man does his work.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Secretary Hay has forwarded to the Commissioners of the District of Columbia a copy of a letter sent to other States and Territories bearing on the American scholarships in Oxford University created by the will of the late Cecil Rhodes. The Secretary in his communication incloses a copy of a letter from Bourchier F. Hawkley, representing the trustees of the will, in which he says:
Details will be found in another column relative to the purchase of the northwest corner of St. Nicholas Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-first Street by the Lenox Presbyterian Church.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- With agreements reached between four railroads and their employes the great strike of the freight handlers and teamsters that has paralyzed the industries of Chicago for a week is apparently broken. A majority of the strikers are expected to return to work to-morrow.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator Burrows of Michigan was quoted in The Evening Star to-day as saying:

OYSTER BAY, July 15 -- Mrs. Roosevelt gave a tea this afternoon on board the President's yacht, the Mayflower. Her guests were the sixteen members of the St. Hilda Society of Christ's Episcopal Church, of which Mrs. Roosevelt is an enthusiastic member, it being told of her that while living at Sagamore Hill she has never missed a meeting of the society.

The rough-riding polo players of the Rockaway Hunt Club captured the famous Blizzard Cups yesterday in the final match of the tournament at Cedarhurst, L.I. Their opponents were the Country Club of Westchester four and the final score was 10 goals to 7 1/2. The trophies are only for teams whose handicap does not aggregate more than sixteen goals.

-- The report that Minister Wu TINGFANG is to write two books is as welcome as it is surprising, for so original a man must produce interesting and suggestive matter. But of the two books the one written for his countrymen, to contain notes on the countries and people he has seen during his travels, promises to be the more valuable.
LONDON, July 16. -- Money was in good demand to-day and supplies were limited. Easier conditions are anticipated soon. Discounts were fairly steady.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- The corn deal is almost a forgotten episode to John W. Gates. Yesterday he appeared in Wall Street and is again a power there. His operations have been turned from corn to Alton Railroad and Chesapeake and Ohio stocks. He has caused an advance of $6 a share in the former, and up to date $2 in the latter.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Grain trading to-day lacked the excitement of yesterday's tumultuous fluctuations. Early in the day it was expected that July corn would take another drop, but this did not occur. In the end the firmness of corn gave rise to the opinion that the July corner might not be a thing of the past after all.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A little before midday occurred one of the most deliberate acts of bravery I have ever witnessed, and which I think it my duty to have made known through your columns.

BALTIMORE, July 16. -- The local market was steady, with Nashville Railway securities as the feature. Expectations of some important developments in the way of announcements as to the company's plans kept the securities up, enabling the stock to close with a net gain. The general tone was firm, resulting in a series of small advances.

Borough President Cantor announced yesterday his determination to tear up the unused tracks of the Forty-second Street, Manhattanville, and St. Nicholas Avenue Railroad Company along Amsterdam Avenue. There are four tracks in Amsterdam Avenue, two of which are used by the Metropolitan Company.

DETROIT, July 16. -- It took seven heats to decide the 2:17 trot at Grosse Pointe track this afternoon, and the event, which was won by Alice Russell, proved to be the best race thus far seen at the blue ribbon meeting of the Detroit Driving Club. Summary:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I observe that the morning papers, your own included, contain a report of Dr. Bayles, favoring pipe galleries for gas mains in connection with the subway. In my judgment this would be a great mistake. Gas is explosive only when mixed with air.

The offices of H.A. Seymour Co., on the tenth floor of the Hudson Building, at 32 Broadway, were in the charge of Peter C. De Wolf, a lawyer, of 132 Nassau Street, yesterday. Mr. De Wolf said that he did not think that the company would resume business, as it had failed to find financial help needed to tide it over certain difficulties.

In the opinion of the best informed Democrats of the State, the name of the next Democratic nominee for Governor is in the following list, with a very strong probability that it will be found among the first three.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 16. -- Andrew Carnegie has promised to give Clark University $100,000 toward $250,000 needed to secure a bequest of $500,000 under the will of Jonas G. Clark. Mr. Carnegie's offer was made known by the following cable message from Scotland, received at the university:

MARKET MOVEMENT. Close to 900,000 shares were traded in on the Stock Exchange yesterday, and throughout the list there was not merely strength, but a strength pronounced and aggressive. The list is long of stocks that went up more than a whole point; advances of 2 per cent, and more were numerous.

PARIS, July 16. -- Liang-Chen-Tung, the newly appointed Chinese Minister at Washingrton, who is now in Paris with the Chinese mission to King Edward's coronation. of which he was Secretary, is delighted with his appointment. He said in an interview to-day:

CINCINNATI, July 16. -- For the third successive time the New York baseball team was defeated here to-day by the Cincinnati nine. The visitors played their usual listless game, and, while Evans was batted rather freely and gave five bases on balls, he was supported in none too brilliant style.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16. -- Philadelphia Rapid Transit and United Gas Improvement were the leaders in the Philadelphia market to-day. The process of advancing the price of the first-named was continued, and it reached 11 1/2, its highest. United Gas made a material grain. Considerable demand developed for Philadelphia Company, with a consequent advance to 49.
BURLINGTON, Vt., July 16. -- P.W. Clement of Rutland was unanimously nominated for Governor by the Local Option League convention this afternoon.

BAR HARBOR, July 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Gould arrived here to-day. They sailed in their yacht as far as Portland and ran down by train to make arrangements for a cottage for August. With them are Dwight C. Harris of New York and N.A. Campbell. The party will go back to-morrow.

With favorites of the "sure thing" kind first in three races and heavily backed long chances winners in two other events the lot of the bookmakers at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday was even harder than it was earlier in the meeting. The weather was pleasant, the track fast, and attendance large, and to round out perfectly satisfactory conditions for the form followers the picking of winners was very easy.
Ex-Chief of Police William S. Devery yesterday continued his unique campaign for the Democratic leadership of the Ninth Assembly District. Incidentally he threw away a lot of money.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Having practically adjusted the questions connected with the surrender to the Chinese of the control of the City of Tien-tsin, the United States Government has been asked to interest itself in the settlement of the grave difficulties growing out of the insistence of some of the powers upon the payment of their shares of the war indemnity in gold instead of silver.

Trading on the curb yesterday continued to show a broadening tendency and prices in general were firm. A few substantial gains were recorded, in Northern Securities, Standard Oil, and Trenton Potteries common, while Tennessee Copper and White Knob Copper showed the greatest declines.

The Jersey City and the Rochester Eastern League baseball team this afternoon will begin a series of five games at West Side Park, Jersey City. To-day and to-morrow there will be two games for one admission, the first contest beginning at 2:30 P. M. On Sunday the same clubs will play at West New York.

NEWPORT, July 16. -- William R. Hunter gave an elaborate "stag" dinner at Sunnyfields farm in Middletown to-night in honor of Center Hitchcock. The guests were, in addition to Mr. Hitchcock, Roland King, Harry McVickar, Edward L. Bulkeley, Frederick P. Garrettson, Judge William W. Douglas, Frederick H. Paine, Col. Reginald Norman, and Capt. Woodbury Kane.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 16. -- President Roosevelt has enjoyed his first day of real vacation, the mail being lighter than usual. Hurrying through business, he was out early on the porch and away with the children for a romp. With them about him, he stretched out on the grass under a tall tree to watch the fleeting white clouds chase one another across the sky.

MOUNT VERNON, Ill., July 16. -- The Democratic Congressional Convention for the Twenty-third District, after two sessions broke the dead-lock to-night at 11 o'clock by nominating Joseph B. Crobley of Robinson, Crawford County, on the seven hundred and twenty-ninth ballot, receiving a total of 76 ballots, while T.E. Ford of Carlisle received 28, and C.E. Jennings of Salem and A.L. Maxwell of Lawrenceville each received 10.

It often happens that a small and noisy quadruped, of the kind familiarly known as "whiffet," pursues with shrill latration a larger quadruped, of equine, bovine, or elephantine type, which his barking fails to interest or even to secure from it the cold tribute of a passing glance. The larger animal keeps on his course, unmoved.

Building contractors in this city and others who were seen by a TIMES reporter yesterday did not appear to be enthusiastic about the brick-laying machine which, is reported to have been invented in Canada, by which, it is alleged, work can be done by two men and a boy which ordinarily would require six or seven skilled men.

The London Saturday Review is the most ingenious and persistent, as well as the most interesting, advocate of protection in England. It has been in a sense the organ, or at least the champion, of Mr. CHAMBERLAIN, whom, on general principles, it detests and dreads, and it has looked forward with eagerness to the time when the influence of the colonies would, under CHAMBERLAIN'S guidance, break down the free trade policy.

LONG BRANCH, July 16. -- The invincible Freebooter polo team of Lakewood scored a victory to-day by the narrowest sort of a margin. They defeated the four of the Rumson Club by half a goal, the final score being 7 1/2 goals to 7.

HAMPTON, Va., July 16. -- The annual conference of educated negroes, which has been held here during each July for several years past, to consider means for promoting the welfare and progress of the negro race, began its three-day session here this morning. The conference is held under the auspices of the Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Col. S.M. Mansfield has made his annual report to the Chief of Engineers upon the Improvements of the rivers and harbors in and about New York City. The following are the estimates:

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- One week from to-morrow Gov. Taft will sail from Italy resuming his journey to Manila. If the Vatican has by that date concluded to accept the terms respecting the sale of the friars' lands and the withdrawal of the friars themselves from the Philippines, the papers will be signed by Gov. Taft and the arrangement will be regarded as closed.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- A sensation was created in army circles to-day by the publication of President Roosevelt's decision in the case of Gen. Jacob H. Smith, serving in the Philippines, retiring that officer from the army. This was done although the court-martial which found him guilty merely sentenced him to be "admonished by the reviewing authority."

The explanation by Dr. BUMPUS of the charges made against the management of the American Museum of Natural History, of which he is the Director, consists in showing that the charges are based on an entirely mistaken statement of facts.

STONY POINT, N.Y., July 16. -- "Stony Point," the scene of "Mad Anthony" Wayne's daring midnight charge on the night of July 15-16, 1779, which formed so important an incident of the War of the Revolution, was formally turned over to the State of New York this afternoon and dedicated as a State reservation.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 16. -- "If I should fall in the water would you rescue me, Capt. Hobson?"

There are yet a few fashionable people in town. These are, for the most part, birds of passage. The ships sailed yesterday for Europe with good lists. On the St. Paul were Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Satterlee, who held a little reception on board before sailing. Mr. and Mrs. Satterlee will meet J. Pierpont Morgan and Miss Morgan In London, and will not return to America before the late Autumn.

ROME, July 16.--At noon to-day Major Porter of the Judge Advocate's Department of the United States Army at Washington, personally delivered to Cardinal Rampolla, the Papal Secretary of State, the last note of Judge Taft, Governor of the Philippine Islands, on the subject of the withdrawal of the Friars from the islands.

BALTIMORE, July 16. -- John J. McGraw, representing Andrew Freedman of New York, and acting, it is believed, as an envoy of the National League, to-day secured a controlling interest in the Baltimore Baseball Club. At his instance 201 shares of the 400 shares of the stock of the company, representing the holdings of John J. Mahon, were transferred to Joseph C. France, an attorney of this city.
A great deal of speculation was indulged in by the three score and odd Boers, at present in this city, yesterday, as to the whereabouts of Lieuts. Seventer and Nielson.

At Jersey City yesterday the local baseball players of the Eastern League defeated the Montreal nine by the score of four runs to two. Oakes, the home club's leftfielder, made three of the runs for his side and had five put-outs to his credit. Mack, at short field, also was prominent, as he accepted all of the seven chances which came his way. Score:

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Secretary Cortelyou was at his desk in the temporary White House to-day, where he will remain until he takes his family away for a vacation, the first of any length he has had in several years. His principal business in returning to Washington is to submit to Secretary Shaw a schedule of payments to be made on account of the illness and death of President McKinley.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Crimmins, who is a gentleman of fortune and with a title conferred upon him by the Pope, visited Ireland recently, for pleasure. Wherever he journeyed he rode in first-class coaches and put up at firstclass hotels. The people he visited were men with titles or pre-eminent in the social scale or what is called the gentry.
MADISON, Wis., July 16. -- The Republican State Convention was called to order to-day by the Chairman of the State Central Committee.

Detective John J.
