BERLIN, July 19 -- Prof. Sophes Ruge, the eminent authority in the Zeitschrift der Gesellschaft fuer Erdkunde of Berlin, severely criticises Henry Vignaud's Toseanelli book. He says that the writer, evidently not knowing German, had ignored German authorities, such as Wagner.

THE trolley car, on its way down town with twice as many passengers as it was built to hold, came to a sudden stop. On the crossing, waiting to get aboard, were a large woman, a still larger man, and a small army of youngsters of ages varying between two and ten years.

WE had enough of New York, I reckon." said a Texan cowboy as he stood on the deck of a Pennsylvania ferryboat, bound for the land where he lives the life of the free on the broad plains of the Lone Star State.

STAMFORD, N.Y., July 19 -- The change to more seasonable weather has brought many visitors to Stamford, and the bookings at the hotels and boarding houses indicate a more prosperous season than ever before.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 19 -- At a progressive euchre party held at the Pavilion Hotel last night Mrs. Arthur Neal won a green and gold 5 o'clock tea set and Mrs. A. Foster a burnt leather photograph holder.

SINCE the advent of the truly neated season a few days since, muslins, lawns, and other semi-transparent materials have been shown in the simply made frocks worn by modish women -- and oth- ers not so modish, but possessing much of this world's goods -- at the restaurants and roof gardens.

The most striking feature of the recent events in lawn tennis circles is the manner in which Harvard University has again taken the leading position in this sport. All of the men named to play in defense of the Dwight F. Davis International Challenge Cup, with a single exception, are Harvard graduates.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, July 19 -- With but a few exceptions the boarding houses here are reaching their limits of accommodation. The proprietors anticipated a more successful season than usual, and the recent warm weather has changed anticipation into realization.

BEING an only child she is a very old little lady for her four years. She started recently with papa and mamma for Mexico, going by boat and sailing from New York. It chanced that it was one of the least attractive boats on the line going out at this time and the little girl heard her father and mother discussing the subject with some regret.

LONDON, July 19 -- At the opening of a new Conservative Club at Fulham this afternoon, the Premier, A.J. Balfour, made his first extra-Parliamentary speech as Premier. He said he believed that with the cessation of the war in South Africa a new era of friendly relations between Great Britain and the Continental powers had set in and would continue.

The Woman's Arts and Crafts Exhibition about to open in Paris and the Woman's Exhibition which will be held here in October at the Madison Square Garden are signs of the position the fair sex is taking in matters relating to the adornment of the home. Berea College, Kentucky, is an institution at work in a peculiar field, that of encouraging the handiwork of the women among the Kentucky mountaineers.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 19 -- Charles Barton, proprietor of the Barton House, at Hancock, since 1840, died to-day, aged eighty-five years. He enjoyed the distinction of having entertained Henry Clay when the famous statesman passed through Hancock in the old staging days, and after that he was a great friend and favorite of the Kentucky statesman.

ROCKY POINT, N.Y., July 19 -- Viewed from this end, the Fulton Chain of lakes presents perhaps its most interesting features. The great growth of cottages and hotels along Fourth Lake in the last few years has only been in keeping with the demands of the Summer visitors who come each year in increasing numbers.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 19 -- At 1 o'clock this afternoon the convention of United Mine Workers adjourned after declaring against a general strike, providing for the raising of a fund with which to aid the striking anthracite miners and issuing an appeal to the American people for support.

THE announcement cabled from Europe a few days ago that Prof. Marckwald of the University of Berlin had discovered a new element is another link in a chain of discoveries which has been made chiefly by French and German scientists. Prof. Marckwald is said to have separated a morsel of metal from uranium ore which emits radiation of a very active nature.

UNITED STATES Marshals throughout the country were notified a few days ago that jurors in the Federal courts are to receive $3 a day each for services, instead of $2. This order was in accordance with an act passed at the recent session of Congress, and it applies to grand and petit juries.

"Sailing vessels are of no value whatever to this nation." These are the words of Mr. PIRRIE of the firm of HARLAND WOLFF, an authority inferior to no other upon British marine interests. He was speaking after great preparation and with much seriousness before the Parliamentary committee upon subsidies.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 19 -- The event of interest here this week was the Horse Show, which opened on Tuesday and closed to-day. It was the most successful event of the kind ever given here. As usual, New Yorkers succeeded in winning several of the cups and rosettes. The stables of Mrs. W.E. Kotman, Mrs. Ethel De Cernea, Dr. John L. Wentz, Albert De Cernea, Jerome Siegel, and others were represented.
Army. Capt. Daniel E. McCarthy, Quartermaster, will report to Col. James Miller, Twenty-second Infantry, President or the examining board convened at Omaha for examination for promotion.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 19 -- This past week at Hotel Champlain was made pleasant by the annual visit of the Troy Vocal Society. Concerts were given at the hotel on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, the soloists being George W. Franklin and Ben Franklin, tenors; Alien Lindsey, basso, and Harry D. Thomas, violinist.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The policy which the President seems to be following with reference to the lands of the friars in the Philippines, and in the furtherance of which two excellent lawyers, Messrs. Root and Taft, are engaged, is one which may in the end have farreaching results at home as well as abroad.

Wall Street is introduced to a new form of investment -- coupon gold bonds redeemable in annually maturing series, the basis of the security being timber sold under long-time contract This new departure marks significantly the broadening scope of American financiering. It forecasts plans of operation which can work vast advantage to commercial interests.

OYSTER BAY, July 19 -- Rivaling the interest in the home of the President is the old homestead of the Townsends, where exAssemblyman Solomon Townsend lives with his sister and brothers. The house is filled with relics of the strenuous days of the War for Independence, the most interesting being three window panes scratched by the diamond rings of British officers who were quartered there.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of this morning occurs a slight misstatement which tends to produce an erroneous impression of an important matter. In discussing the slate winch certain Republican politicians have prepared for the Fall campaign, you state that William E. Werner, who is named therein as a candidate for the Court of Appeals, has been, since 1900, "upon the Court of Appeals bench."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 19 -- The St. Louis division of the Southern Railway, beginning with to-day, will take a hand in the local drayase rebate war which is now in progress between the Louisville and Nashville, the Illinois Central, and the main line of the Southern. This step was ordered several days ago by General Manager H. B. Spencer of the St. Louis Division of the Southern.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One warm evening during the latter part of June I strolled over to Mount Morris Park to cool off. At the North Fifth Avenue entrance stood two policemen in very lively conversation with two young ladies. I continued up the walk to where the path ascends the hill, where it is quite broad, and took a seat on one of the benches.

FRONTENAC, N.Y., July 19 -- The beautiful Thousand Island region is now at its best and is delighting thousands of visitors every week who come from many parts of the world to enjoy the scenery, the river breezes, and the sunsets for which the region is famous.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 19 -- The Mayor of New York to-day delayed a large lunch eon party given by the President of the United States. The Mayor was invited with others to lunch with Mr. and Mrs. Roosevelt at 1:30 o'clock. Mr Low, somewhat out of breath, arrived shortly before 2. The President had been entertaining his guests with s lories of the West.

Trading on the curb yesterday, though only fairly active, was strong. A number of gains were recorded, but they were for the most part fractional. The increased interest shown during this week was still apparent in the demand for bonds and the better class of securities. In some parts of the list trading was suggestive of midwinter conditions rather than those which usually prevail in midsummer.

LONDON, July 19 -- Russia's project for an international anti-trust conference continues to repose in the Commercial Department of the Foreign Office. The proposition has excited no great interest here because it is generally held to be rather incredible that the varying interests of European countries could permit of their getting together with the object of controlling production.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Pardon the intrusion upon your valuable space -- with many others of my way of thinking. I am getting tired of hearing that shallow-brained mountebank, William J. Bryan, lecture Democrats. Particularly offensive are his nauseating hectorings when directed against that great Democrat and statesman.

HAVANA, Cuba, July 7 -- The most-talked-of event in Havana to-day among those that have heard of it is the proposed meeting of the planters and other moneyed men of Cuba for the purpose of discussing the future of the island, chiefly the advisability of urging its annexation to the power under whose protection it has been for the past three years and a half.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In this present time of improved mechanisms for accomplishing different purposes, is it not somewhat surprising to note that the electric bell has not been instituted in the home and in the hotel or boarding house instead of the old-time hand gong or bell?

The most important move made thus far in the scramble for South African trade by rival steamship companies was announced yesterday afternoon in a cable dispatch from R.P. Houston Co. of London, the owners of the Houston Line, to Daniel Ripley, the agent of that line in this city. The dispatch was as follows:

THE "boys in blue" will soon be but a memory. The United States Army, from General to the lowest grade of enlisted man, must be newly uniformed by Jan. 1, 1903, in accordance with regulations prescribed by a general board, which makes important changes in the color and cut of the clothes worn by the service.

ORANGE OVAL, July 19 -- The Orange semi-professional baseball team had no difficulty in beating the Englewood Field Club this afternoon on accout of the amateurs' inability to hit the ball safely. After the first inning it was a pitchers' battle, the three runs which Englewood made being gifts from the Orange infielders.

Higher quotations were again the order in yesterday's stock market. After some early hesitancy, or rather listlessness -- probably due to the absence from the city of the now recognized present bull leader -- the market strengthened appreciably, becoming at the same time broader, under the lead of Pennsylvania, which rose over 3 points and closed at practically the top price for the day.

Bryn Mawr defeated Rookaway by 12 goals to 3 3/4 yesterday in the opening polo match of the tournament at the Rockaway Hunting Club, Cedarhurst. The match was in the annual competition for the Ladles' Challenge Cup, for teams of four, without handicap. It has been played for each year since 1899, the Meadow Brook, Country Club of Westchester, and Bryn Mawr teams having each won a series for it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The conduct of one Marion Erwin, an attache of the office of the Attorney General of the United States, in regard to the attempted extradition of Benjamin D. Greene and John F. Gaynor from the Dominion of Canada, deserves the severest reprimand and censure.

LONDON, July 19 -- Forecasting the composition of the Cabinet after the inevitable changes are made is the favorite occupation of London journalism at the present hour, when other important political topics are scarce. But it is an extremely unprofitable one in a country in which the members of the Cabinet themselves did not know of the Premier's retirement until two days after his resignation had been accepted.

LONDON, July 19 -- Stratford Mill, on the River Stour, in Suffolk, which was owned by the painter Constable's father and figures in some of his most famous works, was put up at auction this week, but there were no bidders.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- In a recent report Henry B. Miller, United States Consul at Niu-Chwang, China, gives some information for the benefit of persons, who find it necessary to travel over the Siberian Railroad. Mr. Miller says that he is in daily receipt of requests for information in regard to the Siberian Railroad.

WHETHER suburban passenger traffic pays or not is a question which has recently been much discussed in technical journals on railroading, and it has received various answers -- according to the varying degrees of success with which the handling of such a traffic has been accompanied.

Five hundred million dollars seems to have been an altogether too insignificant figure at which to put down New York's borrowings in London -- well, say Europe -- lately. That would only be a little more than one-half the interest-bearing debt of the United States. It would be hardly as much as the net earnings of the 200,000 miles of our railroad system.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Each year's tax rate statement is a fresh proof of the folly of the attempt to tax personal property." That is from an article in to-day's issue. Not only may it be a folly, but is it exactly just to tax personal property?
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 19 -- A special from Brimfield, Mass., says:
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 19 -- Surrogate Petty to-day admitted to probate the will of George Carll of Huntington. The estate involved was $30,000.

BUTLER, Penn., July 10 -- An insufficient quarantine guard caused trouble here, a number of the quarantined steel workers escaping from the house of John B. Fleming, where they were confined, they having been exposed to the smallpox. They over-powered the guard and fled.

ALBANY, July 19 -- This promises to be the billion -- dollar year for New York trust companies. Seventy trust companies authorized to do business in this State under the laws of New York have made reports to the State Banking Department. The examination of these reports is now under way, and the indications are that their aggregate resources will reach $1,000,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent of last Sunday, Mr. Samuel W. Boardman, who, by the way, is a professor emeritus, writes on the Sunday newspaper question either from the point of dense ignorance or from that of obstinate fanaticism. Among his thirteen reasons (?) why the Sunday newspaper does harm and ought to be discontinued there is not one founded on facts or reason.

The coming week offers the midsummer variety of performances in theatres and halls and on roofs, with the temporary addition of a minstrel show at Manhattan Beach and "Fra Diavolo" at Terrace Garden. During the past week Dame Rumor was busy with a story of internal trouble in the Theatrical Trust and with the plans of certain companies, especially those of Weber Fields.

The temporary relief of dyspepsia, or the symptoms of dyspepsia, such as indigestion, flatulency, gastritis, nervousness, sour stomach, etc., is all that can be accomplished with drugs and digestive ferments.

The Governors of the Automobile Club of America have issued a letter to all the members of the club calling their attention to the injury being done to the sport and industry of automobiling by reckless or unskillful drivers, and urging that the members of the club use their influent to prevent both the inconsiderate driving of automobiles and their use by persons who do not understand how to hand them.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 19 -- The American Line steamship Belgenland, from Philadelphia for Queenstown and Liverpool, three days overdue on the other side, was towed into this harbor disabled to-day by the British steamer Scholar. On July 9, in latitude 40 degrees 57 minutes north and longitude 51 degrees 7 minutes west, the Belgenland broke her shaft.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 19. -- Plymouth Rock chickens are the especial hobby of William T. Simpson. Vice President of the American Rolling Mill Company of this city, who is taking steps to erect the largest hennery in the United States at his Summer home, four miles from Dupont, Ind.

DENIS KEARNEY of sand-lot fame in San Francisco made his first appearance as a street orator in nineteen years recently in San Jose, Cal. The former leader of the agitation against the Chinese looked well and remarkably vigorous for a man of sixty years. His voice is not as powerful as in the more strenuous period of his life, but he has lost none of that peculiar directness of speech that formerly characterized his utterances.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Don't you think your criticism of the Harvard attorney's advertisement a bit hasty and uncharitable? Your opinion of a college graduate has evidently been formed by association with the college "fop" or "chappie."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many of THE NEW YORK TIMES'S readers were doubtless amazed when in the issue of July 14, on "Rousing Teuton Against Slav," they were confronted with the words: "Whatever may be thought of the boasts of the Germans as to their superior civilization and culture [to the Poles.]"

Two men were drowned while boating on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, and a third member of the party, who escaped with his life, accused the Captain and crew of the tugboat Mattie D. of the Dailey Towing Company of falling to go to the rescue of the drowning men.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with great interest your editorial on Mayor Low's proposition relative to increasing New York City's debt limit, and I fully agree with you that the public are not yet educated to the point where they can contemplate with indifference any interference with New York City's assessed values.

At noon to-day Major Gen. John R. Brooke will be retired from active service. Simultaneously with Gen. Brooke's retirement. Major Gen. Arthur MacArthur, exCommander in Chief of the American forces in the Philippines, will assume command of the Department of the East.
Louis Bloch a cooper, twenty-four years old, of 81 North Fourth Street, Williamsburg, was removed to the Eastern District Hospital yesterday badly scalded as the result of a quarrel with his wife.

Oscar Hammerstein bought a dog recently, and now wants somebody to tell him what to do with it. He was sitting on the steps of the Victoria Theatre watching the passers-by, when an individual led a greyhound up to the steps and announced that it was for sale cheap.

Iver Lawson of the Columbia cycling team, who returned from Europe last week, had some interesting things to tell of cycle racing across the water. Lawson offers no excuses for his defeats early in the season, and is well satisfied with his trip. That the foreign promoters look upon him with favor is proved by the fact that he has signed to race in Paris in the Fall.

The east side was excited yesterday by another strike of garment workers. The strike is the largest that has been started on the east side for the last five years. About 25,000 workers are out, and there may be 15,000 more out in a week or so.

PITTSBURG, July 20 -- The Pittsburg Terminal Railroad and Coal Company, with a capitalization of $14,000,000, is preparing to build the greatest railroad yards in the United States. It is the purpose to make of the West Side Belt Railway a mammoth railroad clearing house, where all of the thousands of cars can be collected and rapidly arranged and sent to their destinations in the shortest possible time, and with the greatest economy.

Brushes were few and far between on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning, owing to the heavy footing and the threatening weather, which kept the majority or the road drivers and their fast horses within doors. A few "mud larks" braved the conditions and furnished some good sport to several hundred spectators who gathered about the finish post on the upper stretch.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 -- The plan of reorganization of the Asphalt Company of America and the National Asphalt Company, which companies are in the hands of receivers, was made public to-night by two committees that have been examining the condition of the companies. The plan provides that the property of the two companies shall be acquired by a new corporation, which is to have a capital of $31,000,000.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 20 -- Considerable speculation is being indulged in in Roman Catholic circles as to what action will be taken on the suggestion made by Archbishop Ryan of Philadelphia that the marble statue of the late Archbishop Feehan, which marked the Archdiocesan school exhibit at the World's Fair, be given some prominent public position in this city as a memorial to the dead prelate.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 20 -- Pickpockets worked along the lines of the Union Railway Company here, at New Rochelle and Larchmount, this afternoon. They appear to have met with considerable success. Several minor robberies were reported to the police of the various places, but three good-sized hauls were recorded.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A dispatch from Oyster Bay to a Washington paper says that Mr. Roosevelt is absolutely confident he will be nominated to succeed himself, but the intimation is added that some of the President's friends are just a bit apprehensive that he may be defeated at the polls.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 20 -- The heavy rains which have prevailed in this section for the past few days reached a climax last night, when three separate cloudbursts occurred within the limits of Broome County alone and several in surrounding territory to the northward, breaking mill dams, washing out railroad tracks and highway bridges, and doing much minor damage, as well as delaying trains.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 20 -- President Roosevelt left official business alone today and went to church. He had a swim and a long walk, and then he gave the rest of his time to his interesting family. The President drove to church in the morning with Archie and Miss Helen Tyler, his cousin.

A twelve-inning baseball game, the last of a series of six between the Rochester and Jersey City teams, was played yesterday at West New York Field, Weehawken, and the Jersey players won by the score of 0 to 5. Of the six games Rochester only won one. Up to the tenth inning in the final contest the Rochester men played without an error.

HARBOURSVILLE, Ky., July 20 -- Oil well No. 6 on the Jones farm was capped yesterday, and began to flow over the top of the casing. The well is owned by the Atlantic and Pacific Company of New York. The No. 4, which has been completed since the No. 6 was shot, was uncapped last evening, and it, too, overflowed, even with greater rapidity than did the No. 6.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 20.--Mrs. Ogden Mills gave her first large social function of the season this evening, a dinner for thirty guests, at her villa on the Cliffs.

KEOKUK, Iowa, July 20.--Exploration of the flooded districts of the Mississippi River from Keokuk south shows conditions beyond the knowledge of any but those of long experience with the Father of Waters in its most destructive mood.

In the obscure little house of the Jerry McAuley Mission, at 316 Water Street, down under the Brooklyn Bridge, yesterday afternoon simple funeral services were held over the body of Henry C. Miller, who was referred to by the minister and members of the mission who also spoke at the meeting as "Brother Slippery Dick."

-- Displaying an audacity which might cause unpleasant consequences if shown at home, the London correspondent of The New York Medical News states as a fact bearing directly on King EDWARD'S illness and the progress of his recovery, that "he requires an abnormal amount of nourishment."

For the first time this season M.L. Hurley, the amateur cycling champion, failed to obtain a prize at the weekly cycling race meet yesterday at the Vailsburg track, Newark. He was a starter in the first heat of the one-mile handicap, but could not overtake the long-mark men and so failed to Qualify for the final.

BALTIMORE, July 20 -- A fierce tornado, attended, by thunder, vivid lightning, and a heavy rain, suddenly burst upon Baltimore at 1:30 P.M. to-day, coming from the southwest. The result was that eleven persons lost their lives, hundreds of houses were unroofed, trees in the public parks and streets were torn up by the roots, and several people injured.

Congressman LITTLEFIELD of Maine has confided to friends in Washington an outline of his plan of campaign against the trusts, and though he is sternly opposed to communicating with the public on the subject, "he is willing," according to the correspondent of The Boston Herald, "for his friends to explain his position as to the Administration."

BRISTOL, R.I., July 20 -- Following the plan of two years ago, when an order was expected for a boat to be used as a candidate for the defense of the America's Cup, the Herreshoffs are having many improvements and repairs made on the boat shops in order to be ready for business should an order be placed for a 90-foot sloop.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 20 -- A fatal head-on collision occurred between two passenger trains on the Lehigh Valley Railroad near Hope Hospital, this city, this evening, in which Peter W. Putnam, a fireman, was almost instantly killed, and nineteen others more or less seriously injured.

The cricket team of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club strengthened its position as leader of the race for the cricket championship of New York by its victor over Brooklyn on Saturday. The Livingston Field Club, however, maintains its position strongly in second place, and it is possible that the drawn game which the Knickerbockers played will be an important factor in the result when the final percentages are worked out.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., July 20 -- The riot started late last night by several hundred soldiers from Fort Leavenworth, who demolished the house of a negro in the law quarter here following the stabbing of Eli Loucke, a cavalryman, by an inmate of the place ended soon after midnight, and to-day all was quiet.

The Merchants' Association, through G. L. Duval, the Chairman of the Committee on Revision of City Records, Accounts and Water Supply, sent a communication last week to Mayor Low concerning the changes of plan on the new Croton Dam and Jerome Park Reservoir.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 20 -- Dr. Charles C. Hendricks, in whose sanitarium here Miss Laura Biggar has been for several weeks, said to-day that, as Miss Biggar's attorney and physician, he repudiated the alleged agreement with the other heirs of Henry M. Bennett of Pittsburg, Penn., for the admission of a will to probate.

BOSTON, Mass., July 20 -- Announcement that Levi W. Hastings, an elderly resident of Brookline, had brought proceedings to prevent his wife from leasing the Hastings estate to Henry C.A. Morand has caused considerable discussion in that suburb. Mr. Hastings alleges that the family difficulty was brought about by the influence which was exerted upon Mrs. Hastings and her daughter by certain fortune tellers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In discussing strikes the other day Judge Tuley said: "It would be a long time before a first-class power or nation would agree to arbitrate with a fifth or tenth-class power, and there must first be a great change in their conception of moral principles on the part of the strong in dealing with the weak."

At first glance there is a wealth of calm assurance in Russia's invitation to the world to agree with Russia upon a subject regarding which Russia disagrees with the world. Our customs officers imposed a countervailing bounty upon Russian sugar because they regarded it as bounty fed.

Rear Admiral John C. Watson, who went to England to represent the United States Navy at the coronation, returned yesterday on the American liner St. Louis. Admiral Watson's two aides. Commander W.S. Cowles and Lieut. E.H. Watson, the Admiral's son, who accompanied him abroad, returned on the same steamship.

Whatever may be the result of the litigation in which the United States Steel Corporation is now engaged to justify before the courts the exchange of 40 per cent. of its preferred stock for bonds, its managers seem to have welcomed the opportunity to lay before the public in the course of the proceedings a full statement of the operations of the corporation and of their expectations.

Since the Black Death it has been the polite thing to say God bless you when a person sneezes. History repeats itself. To sneeze is a dangerous thing just now in the German Army, particularly if the sneezer is a Pole. Should the sudden inclination seize a Polish-speaking soldier at roll call, it is close on a capital offense -- it is political disorderliness; it is insubordination verging on riot.

A conference having for its ultimate pu pose, if certain exigencies arise, the form tion of a new National anti-Cleveland antiHill Democratic Party was held at the Oriental Hotel, Manhattan Beach, yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Walter H. Wilson of Chicago has made a gift to the University of Chicago of a rare and complete athletic library, comprising 1,400 volumes. The gift is exceptional in that very few libraries on athletics have ever been collected.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES has shown itself a most cordial supporter of the Administration in the negotiations which have been conducted with the Vatican regarding the question of the Spanish friars in the Philippines. I heartily commend it for its support, but I cannot but think that at times it advocates the adoption of methods of a somewhat too brusque and strenuous nature.

OCEAN GROVE, July 20 -- The several meetings held to-day on the camp grounds were in the interest of hospitals, and thousands of Methodists participated. Evangelist Charles H. Yatman led the Young People's meeting. The subject of his address was "Heaven." Bishop James N. FitzGerald and Vice President A.E. Ballard had charge of the holiness meeting in the Tabernacle.

HAVANA, Cuba, July 15 -- This period of transition from a dependent country guided by an experienced power, to an independent country is marked by trials of a hundred kinds. In a way the situation resembles that of the American schoolboy with a new, unknown teacher; he tries her in the many ways which his young mind devises.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 21. -- William F. Vilas, who was Secretary of the Interior in President Cleveland's Cabinet, was recently asked by A.F. Warden, Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, to give his opinion respecting political conditions, the possibilities of Democratic harmony, "and the assurances of the party's restoration to power and the relief of the people from Republican maladministration."

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 21. -- When President, Mrs., and Miss Roosevelt visit the camp here on Thursday they will be met at Atlantic Highlands at about 11 o'clock by Gov. Murphy, Senators Kean and Dryden, ex-Gov. Voorhees, Major Gen. Wanser, Brigadier Gens. Campbell and Gillmore, the members of the department staff, and the Governor's personal aides.

Town continues to be full, and there are fewer fashionable people about this week than so far before this season. Saratoga is slowly filling up, but there is no doubt that the death of John W. Mackay and the retirement of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Mackay, from whom much was expected, will have its influence upon the gayety of the season.

George C. Edgar's Sons Co., according to a report current yesterday, have sold the new five-story American basement dwelling 5 East Eighty-eighth Street, 27.6 by 100.8. The sellers would neither confirm nor deny the report. The buyer of the house is said to be at present a resident of Chicago.

HELENA, Mon., July 21. -- The Supreme Court to-day assumed the injunction asked for last May by Miles Finlen, or his successor in interest, the Amalgamated Copper Company, restraining F. Augustus Heinze, the Montana Ore Purchasing Company, and the Johnstown Mining Company from mining in the Minnie Healy Mine pending the determination of the appeal from Judge Harney's decree in the celebrated case.

DETROIT, July 21. -- C.D. Wellington of this city to-night received a dispatch from Manager Frank Dwyer of the Detroit American League caseball team stating that Pitcher Roscoe Miller has accepted a flattering offer from Manager John McGraw and has jumped to the New York team. The telegram was dated at Baltimore.

In the United States Circuit Court yesterday an action was instituted by S. Livingston Samuels in behalf of Mary A.A. Frey. known formerly as Mary Alice Almont Fleming, against John C. Shaw, an attorney of this city, to recover $40,399.38, which, as alleged, was converted wrongfully by the defendant.

It would be difficult to overestimate the popular interest or the educational value of the letters to the editor for which THE NEW YORK TIMES finds space from day to day, and especially in its Sunday edition. It detracts nothing from the qualities attributed to these voluntary contributions that very often those who write them are mistaken and express views which will not bear critical scrutiny.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 21. -- Senator McLaurin is one of the few who have refused to accept appointments under President Roosevelt. The Senator, recently a visitor to the President at Sagamore House, has notified him that because of a newspaper clipping mailed to him by a considerate friend, he must decline the honor of filling the vacancy in the Court of Claims.

LONDON, July 22. -- A telegram from Achin quoted by The Times's Brussels correspondent states that during a bivouac a column under Col. Mathes was surprised by the enemy, who made a front and rear attack with drawn swords.

In the second yacht race of the series of Larchmont race week yesterday the Yankee gave Mineola, her sister boat in the "seventies " class, a thorough beating. Capt. Barr sailed the Mineola, while the two sons of the owner of the Yankee, J.R, Maxwell, Jr., and Harry L. Maxwell, directed the fortunes of the winning boat.
SALT LAKE, Utah, July 21. -- P.H. Lannan of this city has treasured the friendship of J.W. Mackay for nearly a lifetime. He said to-day:

CHICAGO, Ill., July 21. -- New York exchange was 25c premium asked. Time and call loans firm at 4 1/2@5 per cent. Trading in local stocks to-day was quiet and featureless. Pneumatic Tool, City Railway, and Diamond Match were somewhat firmer, but the majority of stocks traded in were practically unchanged.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Representative David A. De Armond of Missouri, who probably will be a prominent candidate for Speaker in case the next House is Democratic, called to-day at the headquarters of the Democratic Congressional Committee. He was asked what he thought of the President's recent speech at Pittsburg, in which Mr. Roosevelt predicted that reciprocity with Cuba was coming "as sure as fate."

BERLIN, July 21. -- Cabinet orders conferring decorations on about 300 Americans who were connected with the trip of Prince Henry of Prussia to the United States are in Emperor William's hands for signature. The Foreign Office sent the papers to his Majesty a fortnight ago, and their return and the announcement of the decorations are expected any day.
LONDON, July 21. -- The supplies of money to met the demand arising from the indebtedness to the Bank of England were smaller to-day. Discounts were quiet and disposed to be easier.

BALTIMORE, July 21. -- There were not enough tin and sheetiron workers in Baltimore to-day even to cover temporarily from the weather the 400 houses that were unroofed and flooded by yesterday's terrible storm, and another heavy fall of rain this evening increased the damage to the interiors of many of these unprotected dwellings.

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 21. -- Miss Rebecca J. Taylor, who was summarily dismissed from the War Department on June 7 by Secretary Root for criticising the Administration's policy in the Philippines, has brought suit against Mr. Root for reinstatement. Justice Hagner to-day issued a rule ordering the defendant, Mr. Root, to show cause why a peremptory writ of mandamus should not be issued requiring him to restore Miss Taylor to her position.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21. -- The Philadelphia Public Ledger was to-day purchased by Adolph S. Ochs from George W. Childs Drexel and the Drexel estate, and possession was at once given Mr. Ochs. The purchase includes all The Public Ledger estate, comprising about half a block of improved property on Chestnut and Sixth Streets, facing Independence Hall.

Several stocks traded in on the curb yesterday gained two and three points, a few one point, and a fairly large part of the transactions occurred at fractional advances. New Orleans Railways issues and American Writing Paper stocks were the features of the market. Manhattan Transit ranged within three-eighths of a point, and closed with a gain of one-quarter of a point on tradings in 5,000 shares.

LONDON, July 22. -- In its City article to-day The Times says that on the Stock Exchange yesterday the tendency was generally weak because of realization in Consols and South Africans and a general absence of business. Even American rails were depressed in the afternoon, and, though the closing quotations were slightly above the lowest, the tone was rather dull at the end.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 21. -- The Greenwich Tramway Company suffered the Joss of $715 and valuable documents early this morning, when five burglars, two of whom were doubtless adepts with the use of nitroglycerine, blew open one of the safes in the company's office, one mile from Port Chester. They made a mistake by not blowing open the conductors' safe in the car barn, for they could have gotten over $2,000 there.

As a result of what appears to be a foolish prank, two fashionably dressed young men, who wore diamond rings, elegant watches, and diamond and emerald pins, were arrested in Central Park last night on a charge of stealing $5 worth of cigarettes from Park Tilford's branch grocery store, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 21. -- Dinners were given to-night by Mrs. Elisha Dyer, Jr., at Wayside, by Mrs. Burke at The Elms, by Mrs. Charles Daniels at the Osgood villa, by Mrs. T.A. Havemeyer, Jr., at the Stockton cottage, and by Mrs. William T. Carter at her cottage, on Narragansett Avenue.
LONDON, July 21. -- The Doyer-Ostend yacht race to-day was won by the Cicely, owned by Cecil Quentin of England. The Clara, owned by M. Guilleaume, was second, subject to protest.

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 21. -- Secretary Root has called upon Col. S.W. Groesbeck to state whether or not toe gave out the statements published as having come from him with regard to the Smith and Waller court-martials. Col. Groesbeck has been Judge Advocate General of the Department of the Philippines.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 21. -- Despite the most depressing weather society went in force to the reception given this afternoon by Mrs. William L. Graves of New York at Beccokend. This is Mrs. Graves's first season at Bar Harbor, but her popularity as a hostess at Newport and New York has already extended here.
ROME, July 21. -- The Pope received Gov. Taft and the members of his party in farewell audience at noon to-day.

Russell Sage, the aged financier, narrowly escaped serious injury while attempting to board a moving car at Broadway and Cedar Street yesterday afternoon. As it was, he fell, but, though his clothing was badly soiled, he was unhurt.

Oarsmen generally are now looking forward to the coming championship meeting of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, which will be held on Lake Quinsigamond, near Worcester, Mass., on Friday and Saturday, Aug. 8 and 9, when the National rowing championships will be decided in the following twelve classes:

Before Justice Hall in the Supreme Court to-day arguments will be heard on the application for a receiver made in the litigation pending between Clarence T. Coley and his sister, Mrs. H. Courtney Brown, against Cornelius H. Thaliman, their guardian and executor of the estate of their grandfather, Jacob B. Thallman, to determine the ownership of the Soncy apartment house, 49 to 53 West Fifty-seventh Street.

GLASSBOROUGH, N.J., July 21. -- Pretty Mrs. Anna Shaw, an eighteen-year-old bride, was found nearly dead by neighbors to-day as the result of a thrilling encounter with robbers. A stocking was twisted and tied about the young woman's throat, and the slow suffocation thus caused, was being hastened by a flour sack that had been jammed into her mouth as a gag.

HAMBURG, July 21. -- The steamship Primus of Hamburg, with 185 passengers on board, was cut in two and sunk by the tug Hansa in the Elbe at 12:30 o'clock this morning. So far as is ascertainable between fifty and sixty persons were drowned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I regret to note the ill-natured attempt at cheap sarcasm on the part of some dyspeptic old bachelor at the expense of what ha is pleased to term the "table boardery," which you printed in Sunday's TIMES. Your correspondent, "K.J.J.," compares the fare obtained at a boarding house with that furnished by the hotels and better class of restaurants, somewhat to the disadvantage of the boarding house.

TRENTON, N.J., July 21. -- The Court of Errors surprised every one interested in Steel Trust suits to-day by failing to hold the conference that was said to have been scheduled. Quite a crowd of financiers and representatives of houses in Wall Street were in the State House when the court rooms were opened.

Philadelphia's National League baseball players, who on Saturday defeated McGraw's reconstructed New York team at the Polo Grounds, were badly beaten at Washington Park yesterday by the Brooklyn team, the score being 10 to 1 in favor of the local club. Only once during the game did the visitors show to any account, and that was in the first inning.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- The alleged robbery of the Chicago bookmakers started a run on the Masonic Temple vaults this morning by depositors, who wanted to make sure their property was still intact. The company does the largest deposit business in the world, and rich and poor were in the jam.

The "entry" of Lord KITCHENER into the capital of the British Empire has led in the English press to much discussion of the man, his personality, and his work. Naturally the military side attracts the most attention, and he receives all pos- sible credit for the scope of his plans in South Africa and for the firmness, patience, vigilance, and energy with which he carried them out.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Mrs. Maggie Mitchell Hembold, the eldest daughter of United States Senator Mitchell of Oregon, was married to-day to Francis Hoyt Griffin, a lawyer of New York City. The ceremony was performed at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, the Rev. Dr. Harding officiating.

The Paris Temps draws a rather curious moral from the recent negotiations of the Government of the Philippines with the Vatican in saying that the American offers "amounted to nothing less than the conclusion of an indirect concordat with the United States."

Argument was had before Justice Hall, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, on the application of Arthur J. Singer, representing Harris, Gates Co., for a peremptory writ of mandamus to compel the Knickerbocker Trust Company, the Atlantic Trust Company, and Charles E. Phelps, as Assistant Secretary and Assistant Treasurer of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company, to permit him to see the stock books and list of stockholders of the Colorado corporation.

NEWARK, N.J., July 22 -- The "De Roy and Wagner, Incorporated," filed articles of incorporation here to-day. The concern will manufacture jewelry, with a capital of $25,000. The incorporators are Emanuel De Roy, William H. and Edward W. Wagner.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Col. Thomas Ward, Chief of Staff to Gen. Miles, to-day was appointed a Brigadier General in the regular army, vice Jacob Smith, retired. Gen. Ward himself will retire in the course of a day or two, when Col. Joseph P. Sanger of the Inspector General's department, now in the Philippines, will become Brigadier General.

Roy Evans, the baseball pitcher who was released a few days ago by Manager-Captain McGraw of the New York Club, signed and played with Brooklyn yesterday, and established an enviable reputation among the supporters of the game in that borough. He not only played his position well, but shut out the Philadelphians, holding them to six hits, and also scored a run besides making two hits, one of them for two bases.

BOSTON, July 25 -- The announcement of the engagement of a relatively small amount of gold for export, and the suggestion that still more may be shipped in the near future, are having little influence on the money market. The situation is still very comfortable, and, indeed, is showing increased ease.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- Nearly everything was better in the local market today, the local steel stocks leading. Pennsylvania Steel preferred touched par for the first time in fifteen months, and the common made an even greater advance, rising in the extreme 5 1/4 points. Cambria Steel advanced 1/4.

That an arrest would be made to-day in the Latimer murder case appeared very probable last night. Following a sudden and unexpected adjournment of the Coroner's inquest in the matter, there was a long consultation between District Attorney Clarke and Capt. John Buchanan and Sergt. Edward Harrington of the Gates Avenue Police Precinct.

One day in Larchmont race week is always given over to the "rocking chair fleet" and to the ladies. The yachtsmen have it all their own way on six days, but on this one occasion they slip somewhat into the background and become spectators rather than active participants in the programme.

LONDON, July 22 -- The Metropolitan Fire Brigade is receiving some hard knocks at the hands of lawyers engaged in the inquest upon the victims of the recent fire in Queen Victoria Street, when nine young girls were incinerated because the ladders were too short to reach the fourth story of the burning building.
J.P. Morgan Co. have not abandoned the idea of forming a Southern securities company, according to a dispatch sent out from Louisville yesterday, and which caused considerable comment in Wall Street.
C.J. Swift Co. have been appointed sole Cleveland agents of the Allemannia Insurance Company of Pittsburg.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court has-affirmed a Judgment dismissing the complaint in a suit brought by Benjamin M. Thompson, as assignee for creditors of the Metropolitan Messenger Company, against Philip M. Knight to recover $2,800, the difference between the par value of certain shares of the messenger company and the amount paid by Knight for such shares.

The course of Senator McLAURIN of South Carolina in declining the nomination to the Court of Claims will meet with general approval. There is no doubt among those who know him of the sincerity and the disinterestedness with, which he has shaped his action in the Senate and in his own State.

The hearing of the charges against Ernest L. Fleming, charged by the customs officials with having entered false and fraudulent invoices at the Custom House in the importation of so-called "washing crystals," was resumed yesterday before United States Commissioner Alexander.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 22 -- Society has awakened from its lethargy. Despite inclement weather, to-day was the gayest of the season. There were several large luncheons and numerous dinner parties tonight and the remainder of the week promises to be equally lively. Mrs. James W. Girard of New York gave a large luncheon at the Malvern.

ST. PAUL, July 22 -- Archbishop John Ireland, in an interview with a representative of the Associated Press, to-day reviewed at some length the progress of the negotiations conducted between Judge Taft and the Vatican, and took to task certain Catholic organizations that had assumed to question the fairness of the Administration toward their co-religionists.

NEW ORLEANS, July 22 -- For five months or possibly, longer the paymaster of the New Orleans Division of the Illinois Central Railroad has been paying bogus pay rolls devised and given an appearance of legitimacy with consummate skill by a dishonest employe of the roadmaster's office here.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Secretary Root before leaving Washington to-day issued the following:

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 22 -- The President had as his only guest at luncheon to-day Frederick S. Gibbs, National Committeeman of New York, who eighteen years ago was a Senator at Albany at the time Mr. Roosevelt was an Assemblyman. The two men became fast friends, and their friendship has continued through Mr. Roosevelt's meteoric career to the Presidency.

It is the report of a very sober and impartial observer that we publish in another column in an interview with Mr. CHARLES A. CONANT, Treasurer of the Morton Trust Compans, who has just returned from a month's sojourn in Paris.

MENOMINEE, Mich., July 22 -- Beginning in a war over switching charges between this city and Marinette, Wis., just across the Menominee River, a contest has developed between the Chicago and Northwestern and the Ann Arbor, a part of the Wabash system, which threatens to involve the two big railroads in a war for the entire ore business of the upper peninsula of Michigan.
LONDON, July 22 -- There was a good demand for money to-day, and the supplies were increased. Rates were fairly easy, and the indebtedness to the Bank of England was small.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 22 -- Judging from outward appearances, the decorations for the Martin-Oelrichs wedding on Thursday are to be on a most elaborate scale. Today there was extra activity at the house and at the church by decorators under the direction of J.M. Hodgson, the florist. Several very handsome bay trees and Southern palmettos have been placed on the porch of St. Joseph's Church, and show up splendidly against the dull background.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 22 -- J. Brownrigg, who is at present in Nicaragua, has written to his son, Leo W. Brownrigg of this city, giving an interesting description of one of the battles in the "revolution" which is now taking place in Central America. The letter is dated at Nicaragua, July 9, and Mr. Brownrigg says that at that time the "revolution" was on at full blast.

The suggestion made last week by the Prime Minister of Australia at the dinner of the Canada Club in London, that Newfoundland should join the Dominion of Canada, is a very natural one on the part of those who are anxious to strengthen the imperial side of Great Britain's connection with her colonies.
ROME, July 22 -- Cardinal Ledochowski, Prefect of the Congregation of the Propaganda, died this morning.

The racing at the Brighton Beach track yesterday reached the pass where but one favorite in six got to the winning post first, and, as if to aggravate the distress of the form followers, this single favorite, at odds on, won in the selling steeplechase, the most hazardous form of contest that could be devised for backers.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows:

BALTIMORE, Md., July 22 -- The local market's interest centred around Seaboard issues and Nashville Railway securities principally. Seaboards continued firm by reason of the additional impulse coming from the New York curb, assisted by the fruitage from the general bull talk which has been in diligent circulation for several weeks.
NEWPORT, July 22 -- It was altogether a busy day in society. Bellevue Avenue has not shown so much life this Summer as it did this afternoon, during the driving hour.
LONDON, July 23 -- Money was rather more abundant yesterday, says The Times in its City article to-day, and it remained easy until the close.

The Beard of Aldermen by a vote of 56 to 10 yesterday rejected the contract made by the Rapid Transit Commissioners with the Pennsylvania, New York and Long Island Railroad Company for the construction of tunnels connecting New Jersey with Manhattan and Long Islands.

It is perfectly obvious that the mine owners of the anthracite region have no idea of resuming mining operations. The fact that they are in any sense impressed with a public duty in the matter of maintaining the supply of anthracite and keeping the price on a parity with other fuels does not seem to commend itself to their comprehension at all.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 22 -- Newport society found a new object of interest to-day in the exhibition of the Newport Hortipultural Society at the Casino Theatre, which opened this afternoon. The exhibition was made the occasion of a social levee, Mullally's orchestra played its concert on the theatre piazza instead of on the horseshoe, and many groups of the most prominent Summer residents were seated on the piazza.

The result of the competition between the Belmont-McDonald syndicate and Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company to build and control the extensions of the subway which will connect the Boroughs of Manhattan and Brooklyn promises a very substantial public benefit. New York is offered about $13,500,000 in value for a little more than $4,000,000 expenditure.

When the Rapid Transit Commission meets to-morrow to award the contract for building a tunnel from this borough to Brooklyn, the Belmont-McDonald interests will not urge as their best argument the fact that they have underbid the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company by $5,000,000. Mr. Belmont will claim before the commission that he ought to get the contract anyway, even though he had bid as high a figure as his rival.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- "What President Roosevelt needs is a Democratic House Of Representatives to carry out his trust ideas," said Representative Livingston of Georgia to-day. Mr. Livingston was at Democratic headquarters arranging a speaking tour which will begin in Maine the last week in August and end in Indiana the first of November.

We note with pleasure evidences warranting the belief that the people of Great Britain are beginning to recover from the protracted attack of nervous depression from which they have suffered for so long that the condition seemed to have become chronic. They are beginning to take notice of something besides the menace of ruin to come to them through American competition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is in the note of Secretary Root to Gov. Taft, published in your issue of the 18th inst., a proposition made that strikes me as extraordinary and unconstitutional, as well as detrimental to the liberty and well-being of the Filipinos, who are to be subjected to the conditions proposed therein.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 22 -- At the annual meeting of the Trustees of the University of Tennessee to-day a Department of Education was established, the first in any Southern University. Sufficient funds have been provided to support the Chair of Pedagogy, and Prof. P.H. Claxton, Superintendent of the Summer School of the South and Chief of the Bureau of the Southern Education Board, was elected to this position.

If yesterday's developments in the Strong-Yohe affair indicate anything, both Futnam Bradlee Strong, one-time officer of the United States Army, and May Yohe, the erstwhile wife of Lord Francis Hope, are on their way to Japan. Whether they have gone thither to meet each other is a question.

BOSTON, July 22. -- To get a physician to the bedside of a patient the Boston and Maine Railroad made a record-breaking run between White River Junction and Boston over the Concord and Southern Divisions to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 22 -- This afternoon, at Jamestown, Miss Marion L. Cutter, daughter of E.C. Cutter of Washington, was married to Lieut. Arthur T. Chester, United States Navy, son of Capt. Colby M. Chester, who is now stationed at the Naval War College. The ceremony took place in St. Matthew's Church, and was performed by the rector, the Rev. C.D. Burrows, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Harding of St. Paul's Church of Washington.

American enterprise in France is attaining considerable proportions, according to the statements made yesterday by Charles A. Conant, Treasurer of the Morton Trust Company, who has returned from a month's stay in Paris.
The five-story American basement dwelling 313 West Seventy-fifth Street, 20 by 90 by 100, has been sold through L.J. Phillips Co.

The Bryn Mawr polo team won its second "leg" on the Ladles' Challenge Cup yesterday at the Rockaway Hunting Club, beating the Lakewood team in the final match of the series by 8 to 43/4 goals. The winning team gave a fine display of the very best sort of polo, each man playing his position solely for the glory of the team.

CALDWELL, N.J., July 23 -- The First National Bank of Caldwell, the first in- stitution of that kind ever established here, has been organized. The incorporators are Walter P. Lindsley and John J. Van Order of Caldwell, W.J. Davis of Harrison, Adam Groel of Newark, and William H. Loftus of Glenridge.

LONDON, July 23 -- Money was plentiful to-day and rates were easy. Discounts were stagnant, operators being cautious owing to the uncertainties as to the outlook. Business on the Stock Exchange was mostly listless. Professionals were indisposed to commitments pending the settlement. Consols were more cheerful with the cessation of French selling.

What are the public reasons that have prompted the Board of Aldermen to reject and destroy the Pennsylvania Railroad tunnel contract? Several members of the board and Borough President CANTOR have made attempts to state the objections to the contract, but with one exception their statements were obscure or heir objections frivolous.

Whenever there is a sudden rise or drop in any security on the Stock Exchange or elsewhere John W. Gates is pretty sure to be blamed or praised for it nowadays. The latest escapade in which he is reported by Dame Rumor to have been caught is a little rise in the common stock of the Fuller Construction Company of some 3 1/4 points, which took place oh the Exchange yesterday.

Cupid is very busy at this week end. There are a number of weddings and there are announcements and rumors of engagements. The marriage of Miss Estelle Kinney, the daughter of Mrs. Thomas T. Kinney, and Frederick Freylinghuysen took place yesterday at Woodside Hall, Elberon, N.J.

Policeman George Holder of the East Fifty-third Street Station late yesterday dived into the East River, at the foot of Fifty-second Street, and rescued two children, who were being carried into midstream on the swift running tide. After getting hold of the drowning children, he had a hard fight for his life, for they struggled so furiously that it seemed as if he would be compelled to fight clear of them to save himself.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- George H. Shibley, one of the mysterious triumvirate which was said to have held a conference in New York with a view to starting a third party, arrived in Washington to-day. He shed no light on the identity of his friend Droppers, but he did take occasion to emphatically deny that any scheme to launch a new party had been under consideration by himself, Droppers, and ex-Senator Pettigrew.

BOSTON, July 23 -- The second day's events at Old Saugus track to-day comprised nineteen heats, which were hotly contested. It took but four hours and twenty-five minutes to finish them, which the judges declare beat all former records by an hour. Summary:

Congress failed at the last session to adopt a monetary standard for the Philippines, but a trifling sop was thrown the business men of Manila by making provision for subsidiary and minor coinage. It will require some time to put in operation the machinery for producing this coinage, but Secretary ROOT has already taken the subject up with the Philippine Commission and with experts in this country.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Standard July oats again touched the highest point in thirty years on 'Change to-day, and closed at 67 cents, exactly on a par with the July corn price. This is a distinctly novel situation, the difference in price usually, being about 10 to 15 cents in favor of the yellow cereal.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23 -- Arrangements for the Martin-Oelrichs wedding tomorrow are completed. A rehearsal for the ceremony took place this afternoon at St. Joseph's Church, when the bride and bride-groom-elect with all their attendants and the officiating priests were present and went through the forms, including the entrance of the bridal couple, the meeting of the bridegroom at the altar, the religious ceremony, and the departure from the church.

Edward Atkinson, director of the Insurance Engineering Experiment Station at Boston, has filed a report upon the possibility or impossibility of chemically treating wood, the object being to provide an incombustible building material. The report follows:

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- It was officially announced at the office of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to-day that as the New York Board of Aldermen had rejected the tunnel franchise a new measure will be presented. It could not be learned, however, whether the company had decided upon the provisions of the new document, though it is stated the action of the Board of Aldermen yesterday was anticipated.

The frank and manly statement of Archbishop IRELAND in regard to the policy of our Government and its relations to the Catholic Church in the Philippines is a striking proof of the soundness and efficacy of the American principle of absolute independence of Church and State. It is the unqualified tribute of a devout churchman and eminent prelate to the justice and the wisdom of the policy based on and built up from that principle.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 23 -- A portfolio of water colors, depicting Indian life, by the late Col. Julian Scott, has been sold to the American Museum of Natural History of New York City, according to a statement made by H.P. Scott, the executor of the artist's-estate. The pictures were painted from life while Col. Scott was in Arizona in 1890, gathering material for the eleventh census.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- Cambria Steel and Philadelphia Rapid Transit were the features of the Philadelphia market to-day. Cambria crossed 26 and Rapid Transit went above 12. The railroad stocks were active and moved along the same lines as in Wall Street. Electric stocks were somewhat irregular.

The curb market yesterday, taken as a whole, was more quiet than either of the two preceding days. Northern Securities was the feature of the market, at one time gaining nearly 4 points. Only a few gains were recorded, which helped to offset the fractional declines.

Major GEORGE M. BARBOUR, late Sanitary Commissioner at Santiago, comes from Cuba with a story which should not be pleasant reading for those who have been chiefly instrumental in denying the people of that island the advantage in trade with this country which they should have had and we should have given them.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 23 -- Secretary Wilson of the United Mine Workers to-day received a check for $50,000 for the strike fund from the Illinois Miners' organization. This is said to be the largest single donation ever given to a strike. The check was forwarded immediately to the anthracite field.

The Jersey City baseball team played its last game prior to a two weeks' tour, at New West Side Park yesterday. Buffalo won by a score of 4 to 2. It was a pitcher's battle in which the visiting team came out ahead by bunching hits in the seventh inning. Score:

A bronze fountain that was presented to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals by John M. Gitterman in memory of his father-in-law, the late Simon Sterne, was unveiled yesterday afternoon at the intersection of Liberty Street and Maiden Lane. Mrs. Gitterman was the first to drink from one of the tin cups that have been provided for thirsty passers-by.

BERLIN, July 23 -- Court Chamberlain von Morawski, a Polish landed magnate, has appealed to Emperor William not to visit Posen during the army manoeuvres to be held in September, as his Majesty had planned to do. Racial feeling is described as at fever heat, and several Berlin journals agree with the Chamberlain's view that it would be unwise for the Emperor to expose himself unnecessarily.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 23 -- The proposed attempt by the battleships Alabama and Kearsarge, reinforced by marines, to capture the northwest portion of this island, near the entrance to New Harbor, was abandoned to-day, presumably because of the unfavorable weather conditions; and this portion of the Summer manoeuvres will probably be carried out later.

After the examination of a witness named Harry J. Parker, who admitted that he had practiced the business of a divorce detective without the license required by law, the inquest into the death of Albert C. Latimer of Brooklyn came to an end yesterday. The jury deliberated for two hours and announced that the murderer of Latimer on the night of July 9 was an unknown person.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 23 -- The first Malvern hop of the Summer occurred tonight. It properly opens the dancing season. The red room at the Inn was profusely decorated with palms and potted plants and the wide verandas were banked in with boxwood. The popularity of these functions has always been constant, and society to-night came in large numbers to attend the opening.
The biggest strawberries that have been seen this season are in the milliners' shops. The berries are as big as plums.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 23 -- The owners of the thirty-foot yachts sailed their usual race to-day, notwithstanding the round of social functions and other attractions.
Lewis G. Tewksbury, the young broker who left the city two years ago, has been sued for an absolute divorce in the Supreme Court by his wife, Mary Mills Tewksbury.
Army. First Lieut. George L. Collins, Assistant Surgeon, will proceed to Fort Warren and report to the commanding officer for duty, and to the commanding General of the Department of the East.

The upward movement in prices was continued on the Stock Exchange yesterday with many important advances showing at the close of the day. The trading was on a somewhat larger scale than on the day previous, and, more to the point, was much better distributed. No one issue or group of issues monopolized the major share of attention; instead, there was activity throughout the list.

It is not to be wondered at that the constitutionality of the Oleomargarine act passed by the last Congress is to be tested. In the early part of August, when the ruling of the Internal Revenue Commissioner will fix the interpretation of the provisions of the law, the companies engaged in the manufacture of butterine, oleomargarine, and like products will move.

Lovejoy Noyes have sold for a client the property 280 and 282 Front Street. The buyer is James F. Cosgrove, who has also purchased, through the same brokers, 350 and 352 Front Street. This firm also sold recently 167 Front Street, between Burling Slip and Fletcher Street, for George W. Spitzner.

The American people have learned the benefits of that legislation [the Dingley tariff] and are enjoying the prosperity resulting from it. They are not likely to invite a repetition of the financial disasters and industrial paralysis that followed the revision of the tariff by the followers of CLEVELAND and VILAS -- Senator FAIRBANKS of Indiana.

May Yohe, who it was reported on seemingly good authority Tuesday night had started to cross the continent to catch the first steamship for Japan, had not started on her long journey last night. Early in the morning she came to the city, accompanied by her mother, Yodi, the Japanese maid, and a woman whose identity was not obtainable during the day.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- The first attack against the present plan for the reorganization of the National Asphalt Company and the Asphalt Company of America, which concerns are in the hands of receivers, was made to-day, when Hannah V. Gallagher, a security holder in the American Company, began suit to have the proposed issue of new stock declared illegal by the court.

In light airs that rarely reached more than a strength of five or six miles an hour, and that toward the finish fell off into a dead calm, the Mineola yesterday defeated her sister boats in the "seventies" class on the third day of yacht racing in the Larchmont race week series. It was a close race from start to finish.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 23 -- The market showed nothing special aside from the point and a half rise in Alabama Coal and Iron common. The rise is interesting, not only because of itself, but also because of its bearing on International Trust, which latter holds a large line of both the preferred and common stocks of the iron company.

CLEVELAND, July 23 -- The 2:04 pace and the 2:07 trot furnished sensations for the record-breaking crowd that attended the Grand Circuit races here to-day. The unbeaten Dan Patch was always a 1 to 5 favorite for the pace and he won, but had to cut his record to 2:03 3/4 when chased out in the opening heat by Riley B.

William S. Devery met his election district captains in the headquarters over the "pump" on Eighth Avenue last night. There was a crowd of 1,000 persons or so around Devery's Four Corners, and when the ex-Chief appealed he was cheered, while hundreds tried to shake hands with him.

The Freebooters' polo team of Squadron A and the squadron's representative quartet played a practice game of polo yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, which was won by the latter by a score of 6 to 3. Plenty of spirit was infused into the contest, the superior team play of the squadron four proving the deciding factor.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 23 -- The Grand Jury, which was called for to-day by Justice Franklin Fort, met in the Court House in this place for the purpose of considering the charges against those who were arrested in the raid at Long Branch last night. After being in session for several hours, the jury returned with nine indictments and adjourned to meet Aug. 7.

Inter-borough baseball rivalry attracted a gathering of nearly 7,000 persons to Washington Park, Brooklyn, yesterday, to see the first of a series of five games between the New York and Brooklyn players. The home team was defeated by McGraw's men, who scored four runs, while Hanlon's aggregation only succeeded in making a single tally.

HASTINGS, N.Y., July 23 -- Considerable mystery now surrounds May Yohe as to whether she intends leaving here for any limited time. It is known, however, that she left her home this morning by way of Yonkers and up to midnignt had not returned.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 -- Everything now is in readiness for the Jeffries-Fitzsimmons contest on Friday night and the attendance promises to tax the capacity of the arena. Jeffries declares that he feels stronger and better than he ever did before going into any fight, and those who have been watching him during his training insist that he is faster than ever.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Major James Parker of the Adjutant General's office has compiled some interesting statistics regarding the insurrection in the Philippines. There were 2,561 engagements with the enemy, more or less serious, between Feb. 4, 1899, the date of the battle of Manila, and April 30, 1902, fixed as the virtual downfall of the insurrection.

LONDON, July 24 -- A scheme is afoot, says the Johannesburg correspondent of The Times, to attract unskilled white labor to the Rand in view of the scarcity of native labor and the consequent depression of the mining industry. The mine owners believe the employment of white labor to be practical, for wherever it has been tried lately on a limited scale it has worked well.

Augustus C. Ward, who for the past seventeen months has been an inmate of the State Insane Asylum on Ward's Island, escaped from the institution yesterday by jumping into the East River. He took with him a ten-foot plank, and when he was tired swimming he rested himself on the plank.

Mayor Low and some city officials spent yesterday trying to straighten out the tangle over the Pennsylvania Railroad plan to have a terminal in the Borough of Manhattan, which was caused by the rejection of the franchise by the Board of Aldermen.

Augustus C. Ward, who for the past seventeen months has been an inmate of the State Insane Asylum on Ward's Island, escaped from the institution yesterday by jumping into the East River. He took with him a ten-foot plank, and when he was tired swimming he rested himself on the plank.

With the death of JOHN WILSON MACKAY passed away the last of a remarkable syndicate of great, successful, and eminently useful adventurers whose names will long be remembered by reason of their identification with great developments and important enterprises. JAMES C. FLOOD, WILLIAM S. O'BRIEN, JAMES G. FAIR, and JOHN W. MACKAY, known in their day as the "Bonanza Kings," were all extraordinary men.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23 -- Interest in the Martin-Oelrichs wedding has been superseded in Newport society by the announcement of the early marriage of Miss Sara Van Alen and Robert J. Collier. The story that came from New York on Tuesday that the Collier-Van Alen wedding was to take place this week set everybody to wondering if it could be true.

PARIS, July 23 -- The agitation provoked by the order of Prime Minister Combes to close the congresationalist schools recalls to some extent the scenes enacted when M. Ferry, then Premier, expelled the Jesuits in 1880. Demonstrations in favor of the nuns and teaching friars are taking place in Paris and in many places of the provinces, where the Prefects presented themselves at the schools and ordered that the institutions be closed.

MANCHESTER-BY-THE-SEA, Mass., July 23 -- B.B. Crowninshield, the well-known naval architect and yacht designer, has been summoned by Chief of Police Burquart to appear in the Salem District Court to answer a charge of assault and battery. The complainant will be Adolphus McVey, a well-known Boston newspaper man and yachting expert.

Mayor Low and some city officials spent yesterday trying to straighten out the tangle over the Pennsylvania Railroad plan to have a terminal in the Borough of Manhattan, which was caused by the rejection of the franchise by the Board of Aldermen.

It leaked out last night that the home of Louis B. Fleischmann, 41 West Seventy-fourth Street, was robbed on last Saturday. The room of Charles Fleischmann, on the third floor, was forced and jewelry to the value of $500 stolen. The police were at once notified, and since then have been at work on the case, but without success.

BOSTON, July 23 -- The money market is still in a comfortable condition, and thus far the relative small amount of gold engaged for shipment has apparently had no effect whatever on the situation. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, par @5c premium; call loans. 3 1/2 @ 4 1/2 per cent.; Time money, 4 1/2 @5 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $22,629,584; balances, $1,741,000.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 23 -- A strong movement has been set on foot for the calling of an extra session of the Legislature for the purpose of considering legislation by which a merger of the Illinois Central, the Louisville and Nashville, and the Southern Railways, so far as Tennessee is concerned, will be impossible.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 24 -- President Roosevelt this afternoon looked as happy as a man can look, who is really happy, as he paused now and then to wait for the National Guardsmen of New Jersey to cease their cheering during his address to them dealing with the duties of the soldier and the citizen.

CLEVELAND, July 24 -- Three favorites and an outsider won at the Grand Circuit meeting to-day, the races being characterized either by close finishes or sensational time. Darwin was the selection for the opening race, and Lord Marsh was the second choice. The showing made by the Geers entry in the first two heats caused a break of the money toward him.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 24 -- At noon to-day a daring robbery was attempted in the little town of Fortville, a few miles east of Indianapolis. About 12 o'clock, while Assistant Cashier Prittipo of the Fortville bank was in charge, a well-dressed stranger entered the bank and asked Prittipo if he could change a 25 cent piece.
LONDON, July 24 -- Putnam Bradlee Strong, of New York, arrived in London this afternoon with the St. Paul's passengers and went to a private West End hotel.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 24 -- E. Rollins Morse has increased his already large holding of real estate in Newport by the purchase of the property for many years owned by the late Major J. Smith Brice, on Eellevue Avenue, corner of Narragansett Avenue. The Brice property contains about 87,000 square feet of land and a large and well equipped house.
The volume of trading in the outside market yesterday surpassed considerably that of the day previous. Transactions in bonds were well distributed and showed strong.

Mayor Low handed out yesterday in typewritten form for publication another of the so-called weekly "talks" on matters of public interest. The questions involved in public and local improvements were discussed at length, and Mayor Low advocated the passage of laws which would make unpaid assessments for improvements a mortgage on the land.

Transfers in the artillery: Capt. Frederick Marsh from the One Hundred and Twelfth to the Forty-sixth Company. Coast Artillery; Capt. Elisha S. Benton from the Forty-sixth to the One Hundred and Twelfth Company, Coast Artillery. The officers named will join the companies to which they are transferred.
LONDON, July 24 -- Asked to-day about the situation of the Atlantic shipping combine and some published statements that its consummation was considered doubtful, J. Pierpont Morgan, Jr., said:

The Chicago, Rook Island and Pacific Railroad Company is about to undergo a thorough financial reorganization, so it was learned yesterday. The exact details of this plan were not forthcoming yesterday, but enough has leaked out to warrant, the statement that the scheme will include the consolidation into one system of all the various lines which are now controlled by the company.

President MITCHELL of the United Mine Workers is of the opinion that if the anthracite miners can hold out for ten weeks longer their strike may succeed. Very likely.
